div1.head: r

div2.entryFree:
alphabetical letter r *
The tenth letter of the alphabet: called raA='N and raA: pl. [of the former] raAA=tN and [of the latter] A^arowaA='N. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~nh.) It is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, not with the breath only]; and of the letters termed *uloq, which are, and l and n, [also termed *awolaqiy~ap, or pronounced with the extremity of the tongue, and b and f and m which are also termed $afahiy~ap, or pronounced with the lips:] these letters which are pronounced with the tip of the tongue and with the lips abound in the composition of Arabic words: (L:) and hence r is termed, in a vulgar prov., HimaAru Al$uEaraA='i [“ the ass of the poets ”]. (TA in bAb AlAlf All~ynp.) r is substituted for l, in navorapN for navolapN, and in raEal~a for laEal~a, and in wajirN and A^awojaru for wajilN and A^awojalu; and this substitution is a peculiarity of the dial. of Keys; wherefore some assert that the r in these cases is an original radical letter. (MF.) -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Two hundred..]
ra * is an imperative of raA^aY [q. v.]. (AZ, T and S and M in art. rA^Y.)
raA * and raA='N: see the preceding paragraph, and arts. rwA^ and rY. -A2- raA is also said by some for raA^aY [q. v.]. (M in art. rA^Y.)

R. Q. 1 raA^oraA^a Als~araAbu * , (Sgh, and so in a copy of the S,) or Als~aHaAbu, (M, and so in a copy of the S,) or both, (K,) The mirage, or the clouds, or both, shone, or glistened. (S, M, Sgh, K.) ― -b2- [Hence, probably,] raA^oraA^ato EayonaAhu [app. meaning His eyes glanced] is said when one turns his eyes: (AZ, S:) or raA^oraA^oti AlEayonu means the eye was restless, turning [in various directions]: or was in a state of motion, or commotion, by reason of its weakness. (El-Ghooree, Har p. 85.) And raA^oraA^a (K,) inf. n. raA^oraA^apN, (M,) said of a man, (TA,) He moved about the black of his eye: (M, K, TA:) or he turned it about (K, TA) much: (TA:) and he looked sharply, or intently. (M, K, TA.) You say also, huwa yuraA^oriy^u biEayonayohi [He moves about the blacks of his eyes: &c.]. (TA. [See also A^aroA^aY, in art. rA^Y.]) And raA^oraA^oto, said of a woman, She glistened with her eyes, by reason of looking hard, or intently: (K:) or, said of a fornicatress, or an adulteress, she moved about the blacks of her eyes [as a sign] to the man seeking her: (T:) or rA^rA^t biEayonihaA, said of a woman, (S, M,) she glistened with her eye, by reason of looking hard, or intently: (S:) or she opened her eye wide, and looked sharply, or intently. (M.) Also, said of a woman, She looked at her face in a mirror. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- raA^oraA^oti AlZ~ibaA='u The gazelles wagged their tails: (K:) or so rA^rA^to biA^a*onaAbihaA; like laA^olaA^ato. (T.) -A2- raA^oraA^a, (K,) or raA^oraA^a biAlganami, (T, M,) inf. n. raA^oraA^apN, (T,) He called the sheep, or goats, to water: (T:) or he called the sheep, or goats, (M, K,) by the cry A_ir~oA_ir~o or [rather, as in the present day,] A_ir~a [i. e. A_ir~a A_ir~a,] (M,) or by the cry A^aroA^aro: (K:) accord. to analogy, the verb [derived from the cry] should be A^aroA^aro: (M:) TaroTaba bihaA, inf. n. TaroTabapN, signifies “ he called them [to be milked by making a sound] with his lips. ” (T.)

rajulN raA^oraA^N * and ↓ raA^oraA='N, (T,) or raA^oraA^uAlEayoni (S, M) and ↓ raA^oraAw^uhaA, (Kr, M,) A man who turns about the black of the eye much. (T, S, * M.) And ↓ AimoraA^apN raA^oraA='N, (T, M, K,) with medd. and without p, (T,) and raA^oraA^N and raA^oraA^apN, (M, K,) A woman who opens her eye wide, (M,) or who glistens with her eyes, (K,) looking sharply, or intently. (M, K.)
raA^oraA='N * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

1 raA^aba * , (T, S, M, A, K,) aor.
raAa^a , (M, A, K,) inf. n. raA^obN. (M, TA,) He repaired, or mended, (T, S, M, A, K,) a [cracked, or broken,] vessel, (S,) or a crack, or fissure; (M, A, K;) as also ↓ rA^~b, (M, TA,) in some copies of the K ↓ ArtA^b, [agreeably with an explanation of murotaA^abN, its pass. part. n., which see below,] and in others [and in a copy of the A] ↓ A^aroA^aba, but the right reading is rA^~b. (TA.) It is related of AHát, that he heard rabN said, [as the imperative, for AiroA^abo,] and that it is a good dial. var., like salo for AisoA^alo. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He rectified, repaired, mended, or amended, anything. (M.) You say, raA^aba bayona Alqawomi, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) (assumed tropical:) He effected a reconciliation, or made peace, between the people, or company of men. (M, K.) And Aall~`hum~a A@roA^abo bayonahumo (S, A) (assumed tropical:) O God, effect a reconciliation, or make peace, between them: (S:) or (tropical:) rectify the matter, or affair, between them. (A.) And Aall~`hum~a A@roA^abo HaAlanaA (tropical:) [O God, rectify, or amend, our state, or condition]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He collected a thing together, and bound it gently. (TA.) ― -b4- And raA^abati AlA^aroDu (assumed tropical:) The land produced its [trefoil called] raTobap, or ruTobap, [so accord. to different copies of the K,] after the cutting [of a crop thereof]. (K.)
2 raA~a^a and 4 and 8: see above, first sentence.

raA^obN * an inf. n. used in the sense of [the act. part. n.] ↓ raAy^ibN: so in the saying, kafaY bifulaAnK raA^obFA liA^amorika (tropical:) [Such a one is sufficient as a rectifier, or an amender, of thine affair, or thy case]. (A.) You say also, fulaAnN raA^obu A^amori, and ↓ raw^uwbu A^umuwrK, (tropical:) Such a one is a rectifier, or an amender, of an affair, and [a skilful rectifier or amender] of affairs. (A.) [See also ruw^obapN: and miroA^abN.] ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A chief who rectifies, or amends, the affair, or case, of a people, or party. (A.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A big, bulky, portly, or corpulent, chief. (K, TA.) -A2- A herd of seventy camels. (K.)

ruw^obapN *
A piece, (S, Msb, K,) or piece of wood, with which a large wooden bowl, (T, TA,) or with which a vessel, (S, Msb, K,) is repaired, or mended: (T, S, Msb, K:) or a thing, (T,) or piece of wood, (TA,) with which a breach, or broken place, (T, TA,) in a vessel, (T,) or in a bowl, (TA,) is stopped up: (T, TA:) a piece that is inserted in a vessel, to repair, or mend, it: (M:) and a piece of stone with which a buromap [or cooking-pot of stone or other material] is repaired, or mended: (T, TA:) and a patch, or piece, with which a camel's saddle (raHol) is patched, or pieced, when it is broken: (M, TA:) some of its meanings are mentioned also in art. rwb: (TA:) pl. ruw^abN (T) and riy^aAbN. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, huwa ruw^obapu SadoEi AlS~afaA='i (tropical:) [He is the means of repairing the breach of sincere affection]. (A.) And huwa riy^aAbu baniY fulaAnK (tropical:) [app. a mistranscription for humo: i. e. They are the means of rectifying, or amending, the affair, or case, of the sons of such a one]. (A.) [See also raA^obN and miroA^abN.]
raw^uwbN * : see raA^obN.
rA^~=b * : see miroA^abN.
raAy^ibN * : see raA^obN.
A^aroA=bN * , for A=raAbN, pl. of A_irobN, q. v.

miroA^abN *
An instrument with which cracks, or fissures, in a vessel, are repaired, or mended; syn. mi$oEabN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] the same word, and ↓ raA^~=bN, (T, A, K,) A man who repairs, or mends, cracks, or fissures, (T, K,) of bowls [&c.]: (T:) or who repairs, or mends, things well. (A.) And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) A man who effects reconciliation, or makes peace, between people. (T.) Pl. [of the former] maraAy^iybu [as though the sing. were miroA=bN also]. (T, A, TA.)

murotaA^abN * i. q. mugotafarN [Forgiven: or, accord. to the TK, (assumed tropical:) rectified, or repaired, in a suitable manner]: (K, TA:) [in one copy of the K, muEotafarN: and] in one copy, mEtfn. (TA.)

Q. 1 raA^obala * . inf. n. raA^obalapN, He was, or became, wicked, crafty, or cunning; as also ↓ taraA^obala. (T in art. rbl.) -A2- raA^obalapN (M, K) inf. n. of raA^obala, said of a man; (T, K;) [also signifies] The walking (M, K) of a man (M) inclining (M, K) to either side, (M,) or to one side, (K,) as though having the feet attenuated, and chafed, or abraded. (M, K. [yatawax~aY in the CK is a mistake for yatawaj~aY, which is expressly said in the TA to be with jym.])

Q. 2 taraA^obala * : see above. ― -b2- Also He made a raid, or a sudden attack, upon people, and acted like the lion: (S and TA in art. rbl:) and so, accord. to Fr, tarayobala. (TA in that art.) And taraA^obaluwA They practised theft, (M, K, TA,) and made raids, or sudden attacks, upon people, and acted like the lion. (TA.) And (so in the M, but in the K “ or, ”) They went on a hostile, or hostile and plundering, expedition, upon their feet, and alone, without any commander over them. (M, K. [See rabiylN and riybaAlN, in art. rbl.]) ― -b3- [trA^bl, said of a lion, occurs in the “ Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen, ” accord. to Freytag, as meaning He had perfect teeth.]

raA^obalapN *
Wickedness, craftiness, or cunning, (M, * K, TA,) and boldness, and insidiousness for the purpose of doing evil, or mischief. (TA.) So in the saying, faEala *`lika mino raA^obalatihi He did that by reason of his wickedness, &c. (M, K, TA.) It is the inf. n. of Q. 1 [q. v.]. (T, TK.)

riy^obaAlN * , a quadriliteral word [as to its root], (M, K,) of the measure fiEolaAlN, as is shown by their saying taraA^obaluwA; (M;) and also without ', (M, K,) sometimes, (K,) the ' being suppressed, and Y substituted for it; (M;) The lion: (S in art. rbl, and M and K:) and the wolf: (M, K:) or a malignant, guileful, or crafty, wolf: and accord. to Skr, a fleshy and young beast of prey: (TA:) and applied as an epithet to a thief, because of his boldness: (M:) and also, (K,) as some say, (M,) one who is the only offspring of his mother: (M, K:) pl. raA=biylu (S in art. rbl, and K) and raA=bilu, (K,) [the latter, probably, contracted by poetic license,] and raA=bilapN (TA.) [See also riyobaAlN, in art. rbl.]
1 raw^uda * : ― -b2- and raA^ada: see the next paragraph.

5 trA^~d *
It (a branch, or twig,) was, or became, in its most fresh, or supple, and. soft, or tender, state, [in the first year of its growth; see ruw^odN;] as also ↓ raw^uda: (M, L:) or it bent, in a languid manner; syn. tafay~aA^a; (T, M, L, K;) and inclined limberly from side to side; syn. ta*ab~ala, (K,) or ta*ay~ala: (M and L:) or it bent: (T:) or it inclined this way and that: (A:) and ↓ taraA='ada it waved, or inclined to the right and left. (M, L.) It, or (tropical:) he, (a man, TA,) shook by reason of softness, or tenderness, (S, K, TA,) and bent from side to side; (TA;) as also ↓ ArtA^d: (S, K, TA:) and in like manner one says of a girl, (TA,) trA^~dt, meaning she affected a bending of her body from side to side by reason of softness, or tenderness. (T.) (assumed tropical:) It (the neck) twisted, or bent- (K.) (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) moved to and fro: (TA:) or it twisted, or bent, and moved to and fro. (M.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He (an old man) was, or became, affected with a trembling, and inclined this way and that, in his rising: (A:) or he (a man) rose, and was, or became, affected with a trembling, (T, M, L, K,) in his bones, (M,) in rising, until he stood up. (T, L.) ― -b3- trA^~dt AlHay~apu (tropical:) The serpent shook, in going, or passing, quickly along. (M, A. *) ― -b4- trA^~dt Alr~iyHu (assumed tropical:) The wind was, or became, in state of commotion, (K, TA,) and inclined to the right and left. (TA.) ― -b5- trA^~d AlD~uHaY; (T, M, A, L;) and ↓ trA='d; (M, L;) and ↓ raA^ada, [in Golius's Lex. ray^ida,] inf. n. raA^odN; (A, L;) (tropical:) The DuHaY [or period after sunrise] reached the stage that is termed the $abaAb of the- day; (A;) i. e., when the sun had risen high, (T, A, TA,) one fifth of the day having passed: (A, TA:) or became bright: or advanced beyond the spreading of the sunshine and the time when the sun had become high. (M.)
6 taraA~a^a see 5, in two places.
8 A_irotaAa^a see 5.

raA^odN * : see ruw^odN. ― -b2- [Hence,] raA^odu AlD~uHaY (T, S, M, A, L, K) and ↓ raAy^iduhu (K) (tropical:) The stage of the DuHaY [or period after sunrise] that is termed the $abaAb of the day; (A;) i. e., when the sun has risen high, (T, S, A, K, TA,) one fifth of the day having passed: (A, TA:) or the brightness thereof: or the period after the spreading of the sunshine and the time when the sun has become high. (M.) -A2- Also Alr~aA^odu (S, M, A, and so accord. to some copies of the K) and ↓ Alr~uw^odu, (S, M, and so accord. to some copies of the K,) or raA^odu All~aHoYi, (T,) and ↓ Alr~aA^odapu and ↓ Alr~uw^odapu likewise, (accord. to some copies of the K, [but these I do not find in this sense in any other lexicon,]) or Alruw^odapu only of all these, (accord. to other copies of the K, in some of which it is written without ',) The root of the jaw-bone (A^aSolu All~aHoYi), (T, S, M, A, K,) that projects beneath the ear: (T:) or the part of the jaw-bone whence the molar teeth (AlA^aDoraAs) grow: or the raA^odaAni are the two thin extremities of the laHoyaAni [meaning the two sides of the lower jaw-bone], which are in their upper part, sharp, and curved, and suspended in two holes beneath the two ears: (M:) pl. A^aroA=dN. (S.) -A3- Also raA^odN A vacant tract (xalaA=') of land. (K.)

ruw^odN * (T, L, TA; in a copy of the M ↓ ruw^uwdN [perhaps a mistranscription for raw^uwdN if not for ruw^odN; but more probably for the former, which see in art. rwd]; in the L, in one place, ↓ raw^udN; and in a copy of the A ↓ raAy^idN [which is probably correct, as is also ruw^odN];) A branch, or twig, in the most fresh, or supple, and soft, or tender, state, (T, M, A, L,) in the first year of its growth: (T, A, L:) [being also used as a coll. gen. n.,] it has for its n. un. ↓ ruw^odapN: (T, L:) some say that ruw^odN signifies the extremity of any branch or twig: the pl. is A^aroA=dN and A^araAy^idu; the latter of which is extr.; and is not a pl. pl.; for, were it so, it would be A^araAy^iydu (M, L.) ― -b2- Also, (T, S ,M, A, K,) from the same word applied to a branch, or twig, (T,) and ↓ raA^odN, (S, K,) each with ', (AZ, S,) and ↓ ruw^dapN (S, M, K) and ↓ raA^odapN (T, S, M, A, K) and raAdapN, (A, K,) without ', (A,) [in the CK repeated with ',] and ↓ raw^uwdapN (M, K, in the CK raw^udapN) and ↓ raAy^idapN (A) and in some copies of the K ruwdapN without ', [which is in some copies written with ', and] to which the signification there next given (A^aSolu All~aHoYi) is in other copies made to belong, (TA,) and some add raAdN, without ', (MF,) (tropical:) A youthful girl: (T:) or a soft, or tender, girl or woman: (A:) and (T) a woman goodly, or beautiful, (T, S, K,) and youthful: (T, K:) or one who soon attains to youthfulness with good food: (M:) pl. of the first A^aroA=dN. (T, M.) You say gayoru raAdapi ↓ AimoraA^apN raA^odapN, in which the former rAdp may be without ', and the latter must be so, meaning (tropical:) A soft, or tender, woman; not one that roves about. (A, TA.) -A2- Also ruw^odN i. q. tuw^adapN [Moderation; gentleness; a leisurely manner of proceeding; &c.] (M, K. [In the latter, the form of the word having this signification is not plainly indicated.]) A poet says,
kaA^an~ahu vamilN yamo$iY EalaYruwdi
[As though he were one intoxicated, walking in a gentle, or leisurely, manner]; for ElYruw^di; suppressing the ' for the sake of the rhyme: but he who regards the word as that of which ruwayodN is the dim. does not regard it as originally with '. (M, TA.) -A3- See also raA^odN.
raw^udN * : see the first sentence in the next preceding paragraph.

riy^odN *
A sucker, an offset, or a shoot from the root, of a tree: (M, K:) or a soft, or tender, branch, or twig, thereof: pl. riy^odaAnN. (M.) ― -b2- Also i. q. tirobN, (T, S, M, K,) i. e. (TA) (tropical:) An
equal in age, (A, TA,) of a female, (T,) and of a man, but mostly used in relation to females: (M:) sometimes, [in poetry,] riydN, with the ' suppressed, (T, S, M,) for the sake of the rhyme; (M;) as in in a verse of Kutheiyir cited voce A^uSodapN: (T, S:) pl. A^aroA=dN. (M.) -A2- Also Straitness: (K, TA: [in the CK, AlD~y~iqu is erroneously put for AlD~iyqu:]) you say, waqaEa fiYAlr~iy^odi He fell into straitness. (TK.) But [SM says,] I have not found this in any of the lexicons that I have. (TA.)
raA^odapN * : see ruw^odN, each in two places: -A2- and raA^odN.
ruw^odapN * : see rw^odN, each in two places: -A2- and raA^odN.
raw^uwdN * : see raAdN, in art. rwd.
ruw^uwdN * [or raw^uwdN?]: see ruw^odN.
raw^uwdapN * : see ruw^odN.
raAy^idN * : see ruw^odN. ― -b2- raAy^idu AlD~uHaY: see raA^odN. -A2- [See also art. rwd.]
raAy^idapN * : see ruw^odN.

1 raA^asahu * , (S, M, K,) aor.
raAa^a , (K, TA, [in a copy of the M
raAu^a ,]) inf. n. raA^osN, (M, TA,) He (a man, S) hit, or hurt, his head. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- raA^asotuhu biAlEaSaY I struck his head with the staff, or stick. (A.) ― -b3- raA^asahu AlbirosaAmu The disease called brsAm affected, or overcame, (A^axa*a,) his head. (A.) [And hence,] ruy^isa, (M, A,) inf. n. raA^osN, (M,) His (a man's) head was, or became, affected, or overcome, by the disease called brsAm, or otherwise: (A:) or he had a complaint of his head. (M, TA.) -A2- raA^asa Alqawoma, (S, M, A,) and raA^asa Ealayohimo, (M,) aor.
raAa^a , (S, M,) inf. n. riy^aAsapN, (S, M, A,) (tropical:) He was, or became, head, chief, commander, governor, ruler, lord, master, prince, or king, of, or over, the people; he headed them; (M, A; *) he was, or became, their superior, (M.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- Also raA^asa, alone, aor.
raAa^a , inf. n. riy^aAsapN, (tropical:) He was, or became, high in rank or condition. (Msb.) ― -b3- And, with the same aor. and inf. n., (tropical:) He strove for riy^aAsap [or headship, or command,] (zaAHama EalayohaA,) and desired it. (IAar, TA.)

2 rA^~s AlD~ab~u AlA^afoEaY *
The [lizard called] Db~ turned his head towards the viper, or met the viper head-foremast, in coming forth from his hole: for the viper comes to the hole of the Db~, and hunts after it, and sometimes the latter comes forth with its head towards the former, and is said to be maray^~is: and sometimes a man hunts after the Db~, and puts a stick into the mouth of its hole, and it imagines it to be a viper, and comes forth head-foremost or tail-foremost, i. e., muray^~isFA A^awo mu*an~ibFA. (TA.) -A2- [The verb is also used intransitively, as meaning It (a Dab~) put its head foremost in coming forth from its hole: contr. of *an~aba.] -A3- raA^~asotuhu, inf. n. taroy^iysN, (tropical:) I made, or appointed, him ray^iys [i. e. head, chief, commander, governor, ruler, lord, master, prince, or king], (S, K,) EalaY Alqawomi over the people. (S, TA.) And raA^~asuwhu EalaYA^anofusihimo, (M, A,) seen by Az, in the book of Lth, written raw~asuwhu, but the former is the regular form, (TA,) (tropical:) They made him head, chief, commander, &c., over themselves. (M, A.)

5 trA^~s EalaYAlqawomi * (tropical:) He became made, or appointed, head, chief, commander, governor, ruler, lord, master, prince, or king, over the people; (S, M, A;) as also Ealayohimo ↓ ArtA^s: (S:) or both signify [like raA^asa ElY Alqwm,] he was, or became, ray^iys [i. e. head, chief, &c.] (K, TA) over the people. (TA.)

8 ArtA^s Al$~aYo'a *
He, or it, became mounted, or fixed, upon the head of the thing. (M, TA. *) In the saying, yarotaAsu Als~inaAna fayuqotalu [He becomes fixed upon the point of the spear-head, and is slain], in a verse cited by Th, yarotaAsu is for yarotay^isu. (M.) -A2- See also 5. -A3- ArtA^s zayodFA He took Zeyd by the neck, and lowered it to, or towards, the ground. (K, from the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb. ”) ― -b2- Hence, (assumed tropical:) He occupied Zeyd so as to divert his attention: (K, from the same:) and AikotaAsahu and Airotakasahu and AiEotakasahu also signify the same [app. in the former sense, or perhaps in both senses.] (TA, from the same.)

raA^osN * , (S, M, A, Msb, K,) generally with ', except in the dial. of Benoo-Temeem, who constantly suppress the ', (Msb,) [The head of a man and of any animal;] a certain part of an animal, (Msb,) well known: (Msb, K:) masc., (Msb, TA,) by common consent: (TA:) and (K) the highest or uppermost part, or top, or summit, (M, A, K,) of a thing, (M,) or of anything; (A, K;) as, for instance, of a mountain, &c.; (the Lexicons, passim;) and the upper, or uppermost, part of a valley: (TA: see raAy^isN:) pl. (of pauc., S, TA) A^arow^usN, (S, M, Msb, K,) and, by transposition, A=rusN, (M, TA, * [originally A^aA^orusN, in the L, erroneously, A^=ArAs,]) and (of mult., S, TA) ruw^uwsu, (S, M, Msb, K, [by some carelessly written ruw^usN, and by some, allowably, ruw^u=sN,]) which is not transposed, and ruwosN, which is elliptical. (M, TA.) A poet uses the pl. for the dual, saying,
ruw^uwsu kabiyrayohin~a yanotaTiHaAni
[The heads of the two great ones, or old ones, of them, smite each other with their horns]. (M.) ― -b2- A^um~u Alr~aA^osi: see A^um~N. ― -b3- yawomu Alr~uw^uwsi [The day of the heads] is applied by the people of Mekkeh to the day called yawomu Alqar~i, because then they eat the heads of the animals sacrificed. (A, TA.) ― -b4- A^aSaAba raA^osahu (tropical:) He kissed his head: a metonymical phrase. (TA.) ― -b5- rumiYa fulaAnN minohu fiY Alr~aA^osi [lit., Such a one was shot by him in the head; meaning,] (assumed tropical:) he turned away from him, and did not look towards him nor pay any regard or attention to him, and deemed him troublesome. (S, TA.) You say also, rumiytu minoka fiY Alr~aA^osi, meaning, (assumed tropical:) Thou hast an evil opinion of me (S, K) so that thou canst not look towards me. (S.) ― -b6- rakiba raA^osahu: see art. rkb. ― -b7- waladato waladahaA EalaY raA^osK waAHidK (assumed tropical:) She brought forth her children one after, or near after, another. (IAar, M.) In like manner you say, wulida lahu valaAvapu A^awolaAdK raA^osFA EalaY A_ivori raA^osK, (M,) or raA^osFA EalaY raA^osK, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He had three children born to him one after, or near after, another. (M, TA.) And AijoEalo h`*aA Al$~aYo'a raA^osFA waAHidFA (assumed tropical:) Make thou this thing to be [uniform, or] of one way, or mode, or manner. (ISK, TA in art. bA^j.) ― -b8- EinodiY raA^osu mina Alganami (tropical:) [I have one head of sheep or goats]: and Eid~apN mino A^arow^usK (tropical:) [a number of head thereof]. (A, TA.) It is said in a trad. of' Omar, waA@joEaluwA Alr~aA^osa raA^osayoni (tropical:) And make ye the one head two head, by buying two animals with the price of one, that, when one dies, the second may remain. (Mgh in art. frq.) And you say, fulaAnN yarotabiTu ka*aA raA^osFA mina Ald~awaAb~i [Such a one ties so many head of beasts]. (S in art. rbT.) ― -b9- A^aEoTiniY raA^osFA mino vuwmK wa sin~FA minohu (tropical:) [Give thou to me a head of garlic, and a clove thereof]: and kamo fiY raA^osika mino sin~i (tropical:) [How many cloves are there in thy head of garlic?]. (A, TA.) ― -b10- raA^osN also signifies The extremity of a thing: or, as some say, the end, or last, thereof. (MF. TA.) ― -b11- [A head, head-land, cape, or promontory.] ― -b12- The hilt of a sword; (A;) and so ↓ riy^aAsN; (S, M, K; [in a copy of the A riyaAsapN;]) or this signifies its pommel, (Sgh, K,) more correctly; (Sgh;) and is also written riyaAsN, but whether for riy^aAsN or originally with Y is doubtful. (M.) [From the first of the above-mentioned significations arise several others, which are tropical. ― -b13- Hence, Alr~aA^osu waAl*~anabu (assumed tropical:) The two nodes of a planet: see tin~iynN. ― -b14- Hence likewise,] raA^osN is also (tropical:) syn. with ray^iysN, q. v. infrà. (M, K.) You say, maA A^uriyduhu raA^osFA (tropical:) [I do not desire him as a ry^ys, i. e. head, chief, &c.]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., raA^osu Alkufori mino qibali Alma$oriqi (tropical:) [The head, or leader, of infidelity is from the direction of the place of sunrise]: indicating that Ed-Dejjál or some other of the heads of error will come forth in the east. (TA.) ― -b15- raA^osu AlmaAli (tropical:) The capital, or principal, of property. (Msb, K.) [Hence the saying,] A^aqoraDatoniY Ea$arapF biraw^uwsihaA (tropical:) She lent me ten [pieces of money] as a loan whereof the principal was to be repaid without interest. (Mgh, TA. *) ― -b16- AlqaAfiyapu AlrA^osu Albayoti (assumed tropical:) [The rhyme is the principal, or most essential, part of the verse]: said by one of the tribe of' Okeyl, to IJ. (M.) ― -b17- raA^osu Ald~iyni Alxa$oyapu (tropical:) [The principal part, or the beginning, of religion is fear of God]. (A, TA.) ― -b18- raA^osu Al$~ahori (assumed tropical:) The beginning of the month. (Msb.) [And in like manner, raA^osu Als~anapi (assumed tropical:) The beginning, or first day, of the year.] ― -b19- raA^osu AlA^amori, (K, TA,) or ↓ riy^aAs, (so in the CK,) [both correct, as will be seen from what follows,] (tropical:) The beginning of the affair; the first thereof. (K, TA.) ― -b20- A^aEido EalaY~a kalaAmaka mino raA^osK, (S, M,) and mina Alr~aA^osi, but this is less common, (M,) or is a vulgar phrase, not allowable, (S,) (tropical:) [Repeat thou to me thy speech
from the beginning:] said by a person to one talking to him. (TA.) One also says to a person talking to him, xu*ohu mino raA^osK (tropical:) [Take thou it from the beginning]. (A.) ― -b21- A^anota EalaYraA^osi A^amorika, and ↓ ElY riy^aAsihi (assumed tropical:) Thou art on the point of accomplishing thine affair: (M, TA:) or A^anota EalaY A^amorika ↓ riy^aAsi signifies (assumed tropical:) thou art at the beginning of thine affair; and the vulgar say, EalaY raA^osi A^amorika (S, TA.) ― -b22- A^aDoraEato EalaY raA^osi Alwaladi: see art. DrE. ― -b23- kaAna *`lika EalaY raA^osi fulaAnK (tropical:) That was in the time of such a one; in his life-time: like the phrase EalaY rijoli fulaAnK. (TA in art. rjl.) ― -b24- raA^osN also signifies (tropical:) A numerous and strong company of people. (As, S, M, K.) You say, humo raA^osN (tropical:) They are a numerous and strong company of people. (S.) And humo raA^osN EaZiymN (tropical:) They are an army by themselves, not needing any aid. (A, TA.) 'Amr Ibn-Kulthoom says, (S,)
biraA^osK mino baniY ju$ami boni bikorK
naduq~u bihi Als~uhuwlapa waAlHuzuwnaA
[as though meaning, With a numerous and strong company of Benoo-Jusham-Ibn-Bekr, with which we beat the plains and the rugged tracts]: (S, M:) but [J says,] I think that he means ray^iys, [i. e. head, chief, &c.,] because he says ndq~ bihi, not bihimo (S.)
ruw^aAsN * : see A^aroA^asu.
riy^aAsN * : see raA^osN, in the middle of the paragraph: and again, in three places, in the latter part thereof.

raw^uwsN * : see raAy^isN. ― -b2- Also A camel having no fatness (Tiroq) remaining except in the head; (S, K;) and so ↓ muraAy^isN, (S, TA,) incorrectly said in the K to be ↓ muraA^~asN, like muEaZ~amN; (TA;) mentioned by A' Obeyd, from Fr.; (S;) so too ↓ miroA=sN. (K.)

ray^iysN *
Hit, or hurt, in the head; as also ↓ marow^uwsN. (S.) Hence, $aApN ray^iysN A sheep or goat, or a ewe or she-goat, hit, or hurt, in her head: pl. raA=saY: (S, M, K:) you say ganamN raA=saY. (S, K.) ― -b2- Having his head broken, its skin being cleft. (TA.) ― -b3- Having his head affected, or overcome, by the disease called birosaAm; as also ↓ marow^uwsN: (A:) or ↓ the latter, a man afflicted with that disease: (M, TA:*) and ↓ the same, also, a man having a complaint of his head. (TA.) -A2- (tropical:) The head, or headman, chief, commander, governor, ruler, lord, master, prince, or king, of a people; a person of authority; (S, M, A, * K;) as also ↓ ray~isN (S, K) and ↓ raA^osN [q. v.]; (M, A, K;) and [in like manner] ↓ raAy^isN, syn. of this last, waAlK: (K:) or ray^iysN signifies, [or rather signifies also,] a person high in rank or condition: (Msb:) its pl. is ruw^asaA=hu, (M, Msb,) pronounced by the vulgar ruwasaA=': (TA:) in El-Yemen, ↓ray~isN is applied to one who shaves the head. (TA in art. rys.) ― -b2- ray^iysu AlkilaAbi (S, M, A,) and ↓ raAy^isuhaA, (M, TA,) (tropical:) [The chief, or leader, of the dogs;] the dog that is' among the other dogs, as the ray^iys among a people: (S:) the chief of the dogs, that is not preceded by them in the chase. (M, TA.) ― -b3- AlA^aEoDaA='u Alr~ay^iysapu (tropical:) [The capital parts of an animal] are, with physicians, four; (Mgh, TA;) namely, the heart, the brain, the liver, and the testicles: (Mgh, K, TA:) the first three, because without every one of them the person cannot exist; and the last, because privation thereof is a privation of nawoE [properly species]: the assertion that they are the nose, and the tongue, and the penis, is erroneous. (Mgh, TA.)
ruw^aAsiY~N * : see A^aroA^asu.
ruw^uwsN ruw~asN * : see miroA^asN.

raA^~=sN *
A seller of heads: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) raw~aAsN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or raw~aAsiY~N, (K, TA,) with w and with the relative Y, (TA,) is vulgar, (S,) or incorrect, (Mgh, K,) or post-classical. (Msb.)
riy^~iysN * One who is often made or appointed, or who often becomes, ray^iys [i. e. head, chief, &c.]. (K, TA.)

raAy^isN * [act. part. n. of 1.] ― -b2- kalobapN raAy^isN, (M,) or raAy^isapN, (TA,) A bitch that takes the object of the chase by the head. (M, TA.) And [in like manner] ↓ kalobapN raw^uwsN A bitch that springs upon the head of the object of the chase. (TA.) -A2- raAy^isN also signifies Anything elevated, or rising above the part or parts adjacent to it. (M, TA.) The head (↓ raA^os) of a valley: (M, TA:) pl. rawaAy^isu, (TA,) which signifies the upper, or uppermost, parts of valleys. (K, TA.) -A3- saHaAbapN raAy^isN, (M,) or raAy^isapN, (TA,) and ↓ muraAy^isN, (M,) (assumed tropical:) A cloud preceding the other clouds: (M: [but perhaps saHaAbapN in the copy of the M from which this is taken is a mistake for saHaAbN, i. e. clouds:]) pl. rawaAy^isu. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- See also ray^iysN, in two places.
ray~isN * : see ray^iysN, in two places.

A^aroA^asN *
Having a large head; (S, M, A, Mgh, K; *) applied to a man, (S, A, Mgh,) and to a sheep or goat, (S, TA,) and to a stallion; (TA; [but fHl, there, is perhaps a mistake for rajulN;]) as also ↓ ruw^aAsiY~N; (S, M, A, K;) which is likewise applied to a man, (S, A,) and to a stallion, (TA,) but not to a sheep or goat; (ISk, S;) and raw~aAsiY~N; (TA in art. rws;) and ↓ ruw^aAsN; (M, TA;) applied to a stallion; (TA;) and ↓ marow^uwsN: (K, * TA:) fem. of the first, raA^osaA='u. (M.) ― -b2- Also raA^osaA='u A ewe, (S, M, K,) or she-goat, (M,) having a black head (A'Obeyd, S, M, K) and face, (S, M, K,) the rest of her being white. (S.)

raA^osN miroA^asN * , incorrectly written in the K maroA^asN, like maqoEadN, (TA,) i. q. miSak~N lilr~uw^uwsi [app. meaning A head strong to butt, or knock, against other heads]: pl. ruw^uwsN maraAy^iysu, (K, TA,) or maraAy^isu; (CK;) and ↓ ruw^uwsN ruw^~asN [signifies the same]. (K, * TA.)
muraA^~asN * : see raw^uwsN.
muray^~isN * A [lizard of the kind called] Db~ coming forth from his hole having his head foremost: opposed to mu*an~ibN. (TA.) ― -b2- Almuray^~isu The lion. (K.)

miroA=sN * A horse that bites the heads of other horses when running with them in a race: (M, K: *) or [so in some copies of the K, but in others “ and, ”] that takes precedence of the other horses in a race. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- See also raw^uwsN.
marow^uwsN * : see ray^iysN, in four places: ― -b2- and see A^aroA^asu. ― -b3- Also One whose desire ($ahowap) is in his head only. (Fr, Sgh, K.) -A2- (tropical:) Subjects [of a ray^iys]. (K.)
muraAy^isN * : see raAy^isN: ― -b2- and raw^uwsN. -A2- Also One holding back (Sgh, K) from the party [to which he belongs] (Sgh, TA) in fight, or battle. (Sgh, K.)

1 raw^ufa bihi * , (AZ, T, S, M, O, K,) aor.
raAu^a ; (AZ, T, S, O;) and raA^afa, (AZ, T, S, M, K,) aor.
raAa^a ; (AZ, T, S;) and ray^ifa; (AZ, S, M, O, K;) inf. n. raA^ofapN and raA=fapN (AZ, T, S, M, O, K) and raA^afN (AZ, S, K) and raA^ofN, (O,) the first and second being inf. ns. of raw^ufa, [or the first is of raA^afa,] and the third being inf. n. of ray^ifa, (AZ, S, O,) and the fourth being of raA^afa; (O;) said of God, (K,) and of a man; (AZ, T, S;) [He pitied, or compassionated, him: or he pitied him, or compassionated him, tenderly; or in the utmost degree; or most tenderly: for] raA^afopN is syn. with raHomapN: (Fr, T, M, K: *) or it denotes a more special and more tender affection than raHomapN; (T;) or the utmost degree thereof; (S, K;) or the most tender thereof: (K:) and raAfa [in the CK raA^afa, as before, and in Freytag's Lex. raA'afa,] and raAwafa signify the same: (K:) [the right reading here appears to be raAfa; (for it is said in the K in art. rwf that raAfa, aor. yaraAfu, is a dial. var. of raA^afa, aor. yaroA^afu;) and raAwafa is-doubtful; (for it is not there mentioned;)] or raAfa, inf. n. rawofN, signifies sakana [he, or it, was, or became, still, &c.]; and raA^afa is a dial. var. thereof [signifying thus]; and is not from raw^uwfN syn. with raHiymN. (M in art. rwf.)

raA^ofN * (M, O, K) and ↓ raAy^ifN and ↓ ray^ifN (K) and ↓ raw^uwfN [which is the most common of all] and ↓ raw^ufN (T, S, M, O, K) are epithets from the verbs above: (T, S, M, K:) [the first from raw^ufa, like DaxomN from DaxumN; the second from raA^afa; and the third from ray^ifa; signifying Exercising, or having, the affection termed raA^ofap, i. e. pity, or compassion; &c.; pitying, or compassionating; &c.; or pitiful, or compassionate; &c.: the fourth and fifth having an intensive signification; very pitiful or compassionate, &c.: or] the first and fourth and fifth all signify the same, i. q. raHymN: (K:) [and ↓ A^aroA^afiY~N has a similar (most probably
an intensive) signification; as appears from what here follows:] in the saying [of a poet],
wa kaAna *uw AlEaro$i binaA A^araAfiY
[app. meaning And the Lord of the empyrean was, or is, to us, very merciful], by the last word is meant A^aroA^afiy~FA, [A^aroA^afiY~N being] like A^aHomariY~N [and A^aroyaHiY~N, q. v.]. (M.) -A2- raA^ofN also signifies Wine; (O, K;) and raAfN is a dial. var. thereof. (TA in art. rwf.)
raw^ufN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
ray^ifN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
raw^uwfN * : see raA^ofN. ― -b2- Alr~aw^uwfN is one of the epithets applied to God; meaning Alr~aHiymN [The Merciful: or rather it has an intensive signification, i. e. The Very Merciful]. (T.)
raAy^ifN * : see raA^ofN.
A^aroA^afiY~N * : see raA^ofN. [This art. is wanting in the copies of the Land TA to which I have had access.]

10 AstrA^lt Alr~iy^olaAnu *
The young ostriches became big, or advanced in age; syn. kabirat, (O,) or kaburat, (so in one of my copies of the S, in the other kavurat [which is a mistranscription],) or kaburato A^asonaAnuhaA. (K: so in my MS. copy and in the CK.) ― -b2- And [hence,] AstrA^l Aln~abaAtu (assumed tropical:) The plant, or herb, became tall; likened to the neck of the young ostrich. (S, O, K.)

raA^olN * The young one of the ostrich: (T, S, M, K:) or a young ostrich in its first year, or a year old: (M, K:) it occurs in a verse of Imra-el-Keys written rAl, without ': (M:) fem. with p: (S, M, K:) pl. (of pauc., TA) A^arowulN (K, TA, [in the TT, as from the M, written AroA^al, probably for A^aroA^ulN,]) and (of mult., TA) riy^olaAnN and riy^aAlN (S, M, K) and riy^aAlapN. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Alr~iy^aAlu [which seems to be the most common of the plso] (assumed tropical:) Certain stars: (S, Sgh, K:) [probably certain small stars in the neighbourhood of those called Aln~aEaAy^imu, or of those called Aln~aEaAmaAtu (in Cetus), and regarded as the young ones of these.] ― -b3- [Hence also,] zaf~a raA^oluhu (tropical:) He was, or became, light of intellect, lightwitted, or irresolute. (S and Z and TA in art. zf.) And zaf~a raA^oliY (assumed tropical:) I was, or became, affected with sadness, or disquietude of mind, like the young ostrich by reason of fear, or fright; a phrase like $aAlato naEaAmatuhumo meaning “ They were frightened, and fled. ” (M.) And zaf~a raA^oluhumo (assumed tropical:) They perished, or died. (TA.) And xaw~ada raA^oluhu (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, frightened. (Ham p. 179.)

ruw^aAlN * and ↓ raAw^uwlN, (As, T, M, K, [the latter in the CK raAw^ul,]) with ' accord to ISk, and without ' accord. to A'Obeyd, (M,TA,) The slaver of a horse (As, ISk, T, M, K, TA) or similar beast, (ISk, T,) that drops from him: (TA:) or his froth, or foam: (K:) accord. to Lth, ruwaAlN [q. v. in art. rwl, thus without ',] signifies the spittle of a horse or similar beast. (T.) -A2- Also the former, (M,) or ↓ the latter, (K,) A redundance in [the number of] the teeth of a horse or similar beast: (M, K:) but As denies that these two words have this meaning. (T. [See what next follows.])

raAy^ilN * and ↓ raAy^ilapN, accord. to Lth, signify A tooth that grows to a horse or similar beast, preventing him from drinking [with ease] and from [eating in the manner termed] qaDom: and accord. to En-Nadr, [the pl.] rawaAy^ilu signifies small teeth that grow at the roots of the large teeth, and excavate the roots of the latter so that these fall out: (T:) but As disallows this. (TA. [See also art. rwl: and see the latter sentence of the next preceding paragraph.])
raAy^ilapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
raAw^uwlN * : see ruw^aAlN, in two places.

naEaAmapN muroy^ilapN *
An ostrich having riy^aAl [or young ones]. (M, K.)

mar~a muraAy^ilFA *
He (a man, S) passed along quickly. (S, K.)

1 ray^imato waladahaA * , (T, S, M, K,) aor.
raAa^a , (T,) inf. n. riy^omaAnN, (T, S, M, K *) and raA^omN (M, K *) and raA^amaAnN, (TA,) She (a camel) loved, (T, S,) or affected, or inclined to, and kept to, or clave to, (M, K,) her young one. (T, S, M, K.) And taroA^amu biA^anofihaA is also said of a she-camel [as meaning She makes a show of affection with her nose, by smelling her young one; not having true love]. (S, M, K, all in art. *A^r; &c. [See mu*aAy^irN, and see also muEaAriDN.]) A poet says,
A^amo kayofa yanofaEu maA tuEoTiY AlEaluwqu bihi
riy^omaAnN A^anofK A_i*aA maA Dun~a biAll~abani
or ry^mAnu, or ry^mAni, accord. to different relaters: [i. e. Or how profits what she that smells a young one but refuses to yield her milk to it gives, (the b in bihi being redundant,) showing affection with the nose, (accord. to the first reading,) or a showing of affection with the nose, (accord. to the second and third readings,) when there is niggardliness with the milk?] he who says ry^mAna uses this word as an inf. n.: he who says ry^mAnu makes it a substitute for mA: and he who says ry^mAni makes it a substitute for the h [in bihi]. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ray^ima Al$~aYo'a (tropical:) He loved the thing, (S, K, TA,) and (S, K, TA) kept, or clave, to it. (S, M, K, TA.) One says, ray^imati AlA^avaAfiY Alr~amaAda (tropical:) [The three stones whereon the cooking-pot was placed clave to the ashes]: as though the ashes were their young. (T, K, TA.) ― -b3- And ray^ima AljuroHu, inf. n. riy^omaAnN (AZ, T, S, M) and raA^omN, (M, K,) (tropical:) The wound coalesced, or closed; (AZ, T, S, TA;) the mouth of the wound drew together, or closed, preparatively to healing. (M, K, * TA.) -A2- raA^ama, (T, S, M, K,) aor.
raAa^a , (T, K,) inf. n. raA^omN, (T, M,) He repaired (T, S, M, K) a crack, or fissure, (M,) or a bowl, (T, K,) or a crack, or fissure, of a bowl: (S:) like raA^aba: (T, M:) so says Esh-Sheybánee: and [↓ raA='amahu signifies the same; for] he cites the following verse:
waqatolaY biHiqofK mino A^uwaArapa jud~iEato
SadaEona quluwbFA lamo turaA='amo $uEuwbuhaA
[And slain men in a winding tract of sand of Uwáreh, (a certain water, or mountain, of Temeem,) that had been mutilated, broke hearts of which the rifts have not been repaired]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And He twisted a rope hard, or strongly; as also ↓ ArA^m. (M, K.)
3 raA~a^a see the last sentence but one above.

4 ArA^m Aln~aAqapa *
He made the she-camel to affect, or incline to, (ISk, T, S, K,) her raA^om [q. v.], (ISk, T,) or the raA^om, (S,) or one that was not her young one: (K:) or ArA^mhA EalaY waladihaA he made her to affect, or incline to, her young one. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ArA^mhu EalaY AlA^amori, (ISk, T,) or ElY Al$~aYo'i, (M, K,) (assumed tropical:) He compelled him against his will to do the thing: (ISk, T, M, K:) and so AzA^mhu Ealayohi. (TA.) And ArA^mhu A_ilaYka*aA (assumed tropical:) He, or it, caused him to want such a thing. (AA, TA in art. *mg.) ― -b3- ArA^m AljuroHa, (inf. n. A_irA=mN, T,) (assumed tropical:) He dressed, or treated curatively, the wound, (T, S, M, K,) in order that it might heal, or close, (S,) or so that it closed. (M, K.) ― -b4- See also 1, last sentence.

5 trA^~mt EalaY waladihaA * , said of a she-camel, i. q. taEaT~afato Ealayohi [app. meaning, as quasi-pass. of EaT~afahaA Ealayohi, She was made to affect, or incline to, her young one]. (TT, from the M. [There written trA=mt, which is, in my opinion, a mistranscription.]) ― -b2- taraA^~amotuhu i. q. taraH~amotu Ealayohi (tropical:) [I pitied, or compassionated, him; or did so much; or affected, or expressed, pity, or compassion, or much pity or compassion, for him; or expressed a wish that God would have mercy on him]. (K, TA.)

8 ArtA^m * , said by Golius to signify It (a wound) closed, or became consolidated, as on the authority of the S and K, I do not find in any copy of either of those lexicons, nor in any other lexicon.]

raA^omN *
A she-camel's young one; (T, S;) accord. to IAar: (T:) or a she-camel's young one which she affects, or to which she inclines: (M:) and, (S, M,) accord. to Lth, (T,) i. q. baw~N [which has the former of the meanings above, but more commonly signifies a skin of a young unweaned camel stuffed with straw or with panic grass or with dry herbage, to which a she-camel is made to incline when her young one has died; it being brought near to the mother of a young camel that has died, in order that she may incline to it and yield her milk]: (T, S, M, K:) or a young one to which she that is not its mother is made to incline. (T.)

fulaAnN ruw^omN lilD~ayomi * [evidently, I think, a mistranscription, for ↓ raw^uwmN, which is also written raw^u=mN,]
(tropical:) Such a one is abject, or ignominious; content to endure injury.. (TA.)

rivomN * [The antilope leucoryx, or white antelope;] an antelope (ZaboYN) that is purely white; (T, [in which only the pl. is mentioned,] S, M, K;) so accord. to As; (T, S;) and AZ says the like; (T;) inhabiting the sands: (As, T, S:) or, as some say, the young one of the ZaboY [here app. meaning gazelle]: the female is called riy^omapN: (M:) pl. A^aroA=mN (T, S, M, K) and A=raAmN; (M, K;) the latter pl. formed by transposition. (M.) [Whether the Hebrew XXX or or mean the same animal as the Arabic riy^om is doubtful.] ― -b2- [Hence,] mar~ato binaAAlA=raAmu (tropical:) The beautiful, or pretty, women passed, or went, by us: so called by way of comparison. (TA.)

ruy^imN * , (K, TA,) or Alr~uy^imu, thus accord. to Kr, with Al, (M,) i. q. AlAisotu [The podex, or the anus]: (Kr, M, K:) [said to be] the only word of its measure except Ald~uy^ilu, which means “ a certain small beast. ” (M. [But see this last word.])

Alr~aA^omapN *
The xazarp [i. e. bead, or the like, that is worn as an amulet, and] that is [held to be] a cause of love, or affection. (K.)

ruw^omapN *
Glue, with which a thing is stuck: (S:) accord. to the K, [following A'Obeyd, (see art. rwm,)] it is ruwmapN only, without ': but Th mentions it with ' also; and both are correct. (MF, TA.)

ruw^aAmN *
Slaver: (T, K:) like ruwaAlN. (T.) [See also ruwaAmN, in art. rwm.]

rawuwmN * : see raAy^imN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A ewe, or she-goat, (El-Umawee, T, S, K,) that is very familiar, (K,) that licks the clothes of him who passes by her. (El-Umawee, T, S, K.) ― -b3- See also ruw^omN.

raAy^imN * , (T, M,) or raAy^imapN, (S,) or both, (K,) and ↓ raw^uwmN, (T, S, M, K,) [but the last has probably an intensive signification,] A she-camel that loves, (T, S,) or affects, or inclines to, and keeps to, or cleaves to, (M, K,) her young one, (T, S, M, K,) or the young one of another: if she do not so, but smells it, and does not yield her milk to it, she is termed EaluwqN: so says A'Obeyd, on the authority of As: (T: [see the former of the two verses cited in the first paragraph of this art.:]) the pl. of raAy^imapN is rawaAy^imu. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, Alr~awaAy^imu signifies (tropical:) The three stones whereon the cooking-pot is placed; what are called AlA^avaAfiY; (T, M, K, TA;) that have remained cleaving to the ashes: (T, K:) because of their cleaving to the ashes: (M:) the ashes being as though they were their young. (T, K.)
4 A^aroA^aY * , in one of its senses belonging to this art.: see 4 in the art. next following.
raA^owapN * : see the next art., in which it is mentioned in the S.

raA^aY * , (S, M, &c.,) for which some say raA [suppressing the ' and the Y,] (M,) and some say raA='a, (T in art. bwA^, and M and K in art. ryA^,) like xaAfa, (TA in the latter art.,) formed by transposition, (T in art. bwA^,) first pers. raA^ayotu, (M, Msb, K, &c.,) for which some say rayotu, without ', (T, S, M,) but the former is that which is general and preferred, (T, M,) aor. yaraY (T, S, M,) for which yaroA^aY, agreeably with the root, is said by none except [the tribe of] Teym-erRibáb, (T, M,) or by such as require this form in poetry, (S,) sec. pers. fem. sing. and pl., alike, tarayona, so that you say tarayonaniY [with an affixed pronoun], and if you will you may say tarayon~iY, incorporating one n into the other by teshdeed, (S,) imperative ra and A_iro'a (AZ, T, S, M,) the people of El-Hijáz saying ra dual rayaA, pl. masc. rawoA and fem. rayona, and Teym saying Airo'a &c., (T, M,) inf. n. ruw^oyapN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and riy~apN, (T, M, K,) the former being altered to ruwoyapN and then to ruy~apN and then to riy~apN, (T, M,) and raA^oYN (T, S, K) and raA='apN, (S, M, K, [in the CK raA^ap,]) like raAEapN [in measure], (S,) in which the p is not necessarily a restrictive to unity, (M,) and raAyapN (K [but this I do not find elsewhere]) and riy^oyaAnN, (Lh, M, TA,) for which last we find in the copies of the K ruw^oyaAn, (TA,) He saw [a person or thing] with the eye: (S:) in this sense the verb has [only] one objective complement: (S, Msb:) you say, raA^ayotuhu (T, M, Msb, K) and ↓ AistaroA^ayotuhu, (T, M, K,) for which some say Aisotarayotuhu, (T, M,) and ↓ AirotaA^ayotuhu, (T, M, K,) for which some say Airotayotuhu, (T, M,) all signifying the same, (T, M, K,) I saw him, or it, (a person and a thing, Msb) with the eye; (T, M, Msb, K, TA;) [or so,] and also, with the mind. (M and K in relation to the first, and K in relation to all.) ruw^oyapN is of several sorts: (TA:) first, it signifies The seeing with the eye: (M, K, TA:) and with what serves for the same purpose as the organ of sight; as in the saying in the Kur [ix. 106], waquli A@EomaluwA fasayaraYA@ll~`hu Eamalakumo [And Say thou, Work ye, for God will see your work]; because the sense of sight cannot be attributed to God: (TA:) [and similar to this is the phrase, raA^aY fiyhi ka*aA He saw in him such a thing: and raA^aY minohu ka*aA He experienced from him such a thing.] Secondly, The seeing by supposition, or fancy; as in the saying, A^araY A^an~a zayodFA munoTaliqN [I suppose, or fancy, that Zeyd is going away]. (TA.) Thirdly, The seeing by reflection, or consideration; as in the saying [in the Kur viii. 50], A_in~iY A^araY maA laA tarawona [Verily I see by reflection, or consideration, what ye see not]. (TA.) Fourthly, The seeing with the mind, or mentally; [the opining, or judging, a thing; a sense in which the inf. n. raA^oYN is more commonly used;] (M, * K, * TA;) as in the saying in the Kur [liii. 11], maA ka*aba Alfuw^aAdu maA raA^aY [The heart did not belie what he mentally saw]. (TA.) [Of these meanings, other exs. here follow; with exs. of similar meanings.] ― -b2- An ex. of raA for raA^aY occurs in the saying of a poet,
mano raA mivola maEodaAna boni aHoyaY
[Who has seen the like of Maadán the son of Yahyà? the measure being waAfir, with the first foot reduced to mufoEalotuno]. (M.) AlHamodulil~`hi EalaY riy~atiki, for ruw^oyatika, altered in the manner explained above, [meaning Praise be to God for the seeing of thee,] (M, K, *) is a saying mentioned by IAar. (M.) SuwmuwA liruw^oyatihi means [Fast ye] at the time of seeing it; [referring to the new moon of Ramadán;] i. e., when ye see it. (Mgh.) In the phrase raA^ayotuhu qaAy^imFA [I saw him standing], qAy^mA is in the accus. case as a denotative of state. (Msb.) raA^oYu EayoniY zayodFA faEala *aAka [My eye saw (lit. my eye's seeing) Zeyd do that] is held by Sb to be an instance of an anomalous use of an inf. n., and is [said to be] the only instance of the kind, among inf. ns. of trans. verbs except samoEu A^u*uniY. (M, TA: but in a copy of the former written raA^oYa EynY and samoEaA*nY.) raA^ayotuhu raA^oYa AlEayoni means [I saw him, or it,] where the eye, or sight, fell upon him, or it. (TA.) biEayonK m~aA A^arayan~aka [lit. With some eye I will assuredly see thee] is a saying mentioned by AZ as meaning hasten thou, (AiEojalo thus in copies of the S and in the TA, or Eaj~ilo as in one copy of the S,) or work thou, (AiEomalo, thus in two copies of the S,) and be as though I were looking at thee: (S, TA:) it is said to one whom you send, and require to be quick; and means pause not for anything, for it is as though I were looking at thee. (TA in art. Eyn.) raA^aY AlmakaAnu AlmakaAna (tropical:) The place faced [or (as we say) looked upon] the place, as though seeing it, (M, TA,) is tropical: (TA:) [and in like manner you say,] daAriY taraY daArahu (tropical:) My house faces [or looks upon] his house. (T, IAth, TA.) ― -b3- raA^aYfiY manaAmihi ruw^oyaA [He saw, i. e. fancied that he saw, in his sleep, a vision, or dream]. (S, Msb, K. *) ― -b4- A^alamo tara A_ilaY ka*aA [Has thou not considered such a thing, so as to be admonished thereby?] is a phrase used on an occasion of wonder (IAth, K, TA) at a thing, and in rousing the attention of the person to whom it is addressed; as in the saying in the Kur [ii. 244], A^alamo tara A_ilaY A@l~a*iyna xarajuwA mino diyaArihimo [Hast thou not considered those who went forth from their houses, so as to be admonished by their case?]; meaning, hast thou not wondered at their act, and has not their case come to thy knowledge? and so in other instances in the same: (IAth, TA:) Er-Rághib says that, when raA^ayot is made trans. by means of A_ilaY, it denotes consideration that leads to the becoming admonished. (TA.) In like manner also, (IAth, K,) A^araA^ayotaka and A^araA^ayotakumaA and A^araA^ayotakumo, (T, IAth, K,) and to a woman A^araA^ayotaki, and to a pl. number of women A^araA^ayotakun~a, (T,) [which may be lit. rendered Hast thou, and have ye two, &c., considered?] are expressions used to arouse attention, (IAth, TA,) meaning tell thou me and tell ye two me &c.; (T, IAth, K;) as in the saying in the Kur [xvii. 64], qaAla A^araA^ayotaka h`*aA A@l~a*iY kar~amotu EalaY~a [He
said, Hast thou considered? meaning tell me, respecting this whom Thou hast honoured above me]; and in the same [vi. 40 and 47], qalo A^araA^ayotakumo A_ino A^ataAkumo Ea*aAbu A@ll~`hi [Say thou, Have ye considered? meaning tell me, if the punishment of God come upon you]; and occurring without the k in other places thereof: (IAth, TA:) you say also, A^araA^ayota zayodFA and A^araA^ayotaka zayodFA, meaning Tell thou me [respecting Zeyd]: (Mgh:) and for A^araA^ayota and A^araA^ayotaka [&c.] some say A^arayota and A^arayotaka: (S:) the pronunciation without ' is the more common: the t in A^araA^ayotaka &c. is always with fet-h; and accord. to the grammarians of accredited science, the k in these cases is redundant; (T;) [i. e.] it is a particle of allocution, to corroborate the pronoun [t, which it therefore immediately follows in every case, distinguishing the genders and numbers by its own variations, which are the same as those of the pronominal affix of the second person]: (Bd in vi. 40:) [IHsh says,] the correct opinion is that of Sb; that the t is an agent, and the k is a particle of allocution: (Mughnee in art. k:) but sometimes A^araA^ayotaka &c. mean halo raA^ayota nafosaka &c.; the k being in this case an objective complement [and the verb being differently rendered according as it has not, or has, a second objective complement, as is shown here by what precedes and what follows]. (T.) In A^aturaAka, also, [from ↓ A^uriYa, not from ruy^iYa,] meaning AtZn~ [i. e. A^ataZun~u, Thinkest thou?], the pronoun [as some term it, but properly the final particle,] is [a particle of allocution] like that in A^araA^ayotaka in the Kur vi. 40 and 47 [cited above; and in the same sense as this latter phrase, A^aturaAka is used, as meaning tell thou me]. (Har p. 570.) ― -b5- When raA^aY means He knew, (S, Msb,) or he thought, (Msb,) it has two objective complements: (S, Msb:) or when it has two objective complements, it necessarily means knowing [or the like]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [In this case, raA=hu may be rendered He saw, or knew, him, or it, to be: and he thought, or judged, or held, him, or it, to be; or he regarded, or held, him, or it, as.] You say, raA^ayotu zayodFA EaAlimFA, (S, Msb, *) or HaliymFA, (M,) I knew [or saw Zeyd to be learned, or forbearing]; (S, M, Msb;) as though seeing him to be so with the eye: (M:) and I thought him [&c.] to be so. (Msb.) In like manner, also, ↓ taraA='ayotuhu signifies I thought him to be. (Har p. 211.) yarawonahumo mivolayohimo raA^oYa A@lEayoni, in the Kur [iii. 11], means They [who were the unbelievers] thinking them [who were fighting in the cause of God] twice as many as they, according to the evidence of the sight of the eye. (TA.) The pass. form of raA^aY has [only] one objective complement: you say, ruy^iYa zayodN EaAqilFA, meaning Zeyd was thought [to be intelligent]: (TA:) and Aal~a*iY A^uraAhu, with the verb in the pass. form, means Al*YAZn~ [i. e. A^uZan~u, He whom I am thought to be; if from ruy^iYa: or Al*YA^aZun~u, what I think, if from ↓ A^uriYa: it is often used in the latter sense]. (Msb.) ― -b6- You say also, raA^aY fiY AlA^amori raA^oyFA [He formed, or held, an opinion, or a persuasion, or a belief, respecting the affair, or case]: (Msb:) and so fiYAlfiqohi [in the science of the law]. (S.) And Al~a*iY A^araAhu That to which I take, or which I hold, as my opinion, or persuasion, or belief. (Msb.) And fulaAnN yaraY raA^oYa Al$~uraApi Such a one holds, or believes, the tenets, or belief, of the $rAp [a certain sect of schismatics; pl. of $aArK]. (M.) When raA^aY is [thus] used as meaning He held, or believed, it has [only] one objective complement. (Msb.) ― -b7- laA tara maA (T, K, TA, [mentioned also in the K in art. trm, in which art. in the CK CK it is written lA taromA,]) and laA taraY maA, and lawo tara maA, and lawo taraYmaA, (T, TA, [in copies of the K A^awotara maA, which I think a mistranscription, and for which is put in the TA, as on the authority of IAar, A* tr mA, app. a mistranscription of a mistranscription, i. e. of AwtrmA,]) and lamo tara maA, (T, K, TA,) in this last case with tara [only, agreeably with a general rule], are forms of expression meaning laA siy~amaA [i. e., virtually, Above all, or especially]: (T, K, TA:) you say, A_in~ahu laxabiyvN walaA tara maA fulaAnN and wa laA taraY maA fulaAnN and wa lawo tara maA fulaAnN and walawo taraY maA fulaAnN and .alamo tara maA fulaAnN [i. e. Verily he is bad, or base, or wicked; and above all, or especially, such a one: walaA tara maA fulaAnN, or walaA taraYmaA fulaAnN, properly meaning walaA taraYmivola Al~a*iY huwa fulaAnN and thou will not see the like of him who is such a one; mivola and huwa being understood: and in like manner are to be explained the other forms of expression here mentioned]: in all of these forms, flAn is in the nom. case: all are mentioned by Lh, on the authority of Ks. (T, TA.) ― -b8- raA^ato is also said of a woman, as meaning She saw what is termed Alt~aroy^iyap and Alt~ariy~ap, i. e., a little yellowness or whiteness or blood on the occasion of menstruation. (M.) -A2- raA^ayotuhu [form Alr~iy^apu] I hit, or hurt, (S, M, Msb, K, *) or struck, or smote, (Er-Rághib, TA,) his riy^ap [or lungs]: (S, M, Msb, K, Er-Rághib:) and so warayotuhu. (Msb.) ― -b2- And ruy^iYa He had a complaint of his riy^ap [or lungs]; (M;) as also ↓ A^aroA^aY. (T, K.) -A3- raA^ayotu raAyapF I stuck, or fixed, a banner, or standard, (T in art. rY, and K in the present art.,) into the ground; (TA;) as also ↓ A^araA^ayotuhaA, (T, K,) as some say: (T:) the latter is mentioned by Lh; but [ISd says,] I hold that it is anomalous, and is properly only A^arayayotuhaA. (M in art. rY, and TA.) -A4- raA^aYAlz~anodu [like waraY and wariYa] The znd [or piece of wood for producing fire] became kindled. (Kr, M, K.) ― -b2- And raA^ayotu Alz~anoda I kindled the znd. (M, K.)

2 raA^~ayotuhu * , inf. n. taroy^iyapN, I held for him, or to him, (AZ, T, S,) or I showed, or presented, to him, (M, K,) or I withheld, or retained, or restricted, for him, [i. e. for his use,] (AZ, * T, * S, * M, K,) the mirror, in order that he might look in it, (AZ, T, S, K,) or in order that he might see himself in it; (M;) as also AlmiroA=pa ↓ A^arayotuhu. (M.) ― -b2- See also 3.

3 raA='ayotuhu * , (M, K,) inf. n. muraAA=pN and riy^aA='N, (M,) I faced, so that I saw, him, or it; (M, K;) as also ↓ taraA='ayotuhu. (M.) ― -b2- Also, inf. ns. as above, [I acted hypocritically, or with simulation, towards him;] I pretended to him that I was otherwise than I really was; (M, K; *) as also ↓ raA^~ayotuhu, inf. n. taroy^iyapN: (K:) both are mentioned by Fr: (T:) [accord. to J,] raA='aY fulaAnN Aln~aAsa, aor. yuraAy^iyhimo, inf. n. muraAA=pN, and raAyaAhumo, inf. n. muraAyaApN, the latter formed by transposition, [which indicates, though written as above in my copies of the S, that we should read raAyaA^ahumo, inf. n. muraAyaA^apN,] signify the same: (S:) [but it is said in the Mgh that raAyaA (perhaps thus written for raAyaA^a) in the sense of raA='aY is a mistake: and] raA='aY signifies [he acted ostentatiously; i. e.] he did a deed in order that men might see it: (Mgh:) or riy^aA='N signifies the making a show of what one does to men, in order that they may see it and think well of it: and the acting otherwise than for the sake of God: (Msb, TA:) and it is said in the S to be a subst. [as distinguished from an inf. n.; but why so, I do not see]. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [cvii. 6], Aal~a*iyna humo yuraAw^uwna Who act hypocritically; when the believers pray, praying with them, pretending to them that they follow the same way [of religion] as they: (M, TA:) or who make a show of their works to men, in order to be praised by them. (Bd.) And mano raA='aY raA='aY A@ll~`hu bihi He who does a deed in order that men may see it, God will expose his doing so on the day of resurrection. (Mgh) And faEala *`lika riy^aA='F wasumoEapF [He did that in order to make others to see it and hear of it]. (S.) [See also 4.] ― -b3- In the saying of El-Farezdak, satirizing a people, and charging one of their women with that which is not comely,
wa baAta yuraAA=haA HaSaAnFA wa qado jarato
lanaA burataAhaA biAl~a*iY A^ana $aAkiruho
[And he passed the night thinking her chaste, when her two anklets had run to us with that for which I was thankful], by yuraAA=haA [with HaSaAnFA following it] he means yaZun~u A^an~ahaA HaSaAnN, i. e. EafiyfapN; and by jarato lanaA burataAhaA he means A^an~ahaA A^amokanatohu mino rijolayohaA Hat~aY ga$iyahaA. (T.) ― -b4- raA='ayotuhu also signifies I consulted with him; or asked his counsel, or advice: (T, K: *) and fiY Alr~aA^oYi ↓ AisotaroA^ayotuhu I consulted him, or asked his counsel, or advice, respecting the opinion. (T, K.) 'Imrán Ibn- Hittán says,
faA_ino nakuno naHonu $aAwaronaAka qulota lanaA
biAln~uSoHi minoka lanaA fiymaA nuraAy^iykaA
i. e. [And if we ask thy counsel, or advice, thou pronouncest to us, with honesty on thy part towards us, concerning that] respecting which we ask thy counsel, or advice. (T.)

4 A^arayotuhu Al$~aYo'a * , (IAar, T, S, M, K,) originally A^araA^ayotuhu, (S,) inf. n. A_iraA='apN (Sb, IAar, T, M, K) and A_iraAyapN (IAar, T) and A_iraA='N, (Sb, IAar, T, M, K,) [the last originally A_iroA^aA'N,] the p in the first inf. n. being a substitute [for the suppressed A^, and in like manner in the second], and the last inf. n. being without any substitution, (Sb, M,) [I made him to see the thing; i. e. I showed him the thing:]
you say, A^arayotuhu Al$~aYo'a faraA=hu [I showed him the thing, and he saw it[. (S.) See also 8. Aboo-'Amr read A^aronaA manaAsikanaA, [in the Kur ii. 122, for A^arinaA i. e. Show Thou to us our religious rites and caremonies of the pilgrimage, or our places where those rites and ceremonies are to be performed,] which is anomalous. (M.) ― -b2- One says also, A^araY A@ll~`hu bifulaAnK, meaning God showed men by [the example of] such a one punishment and destruction: (K:) or God showed by [the example of] such a one that which would cause his enemy to rejoice at his misfortune: a saying of the Arabs: (T in art. rY:) said only in relation to evil. (Sh, TA.) ― -b3- And A^ariniY Al$~aYo'a Give thou, or hand thou, to me the thing. (M, TA.) ― -b4- A^araY in the sense of A^aEolama [as meaning He made such a one to know a thing, or person, to be, as in the saying, A^arayotu zayodFA EamorFAmunoTaliqFA I made Zeyd to know “ Amr to be going away, which may be rendered I showed Zeyd that 'Amr was going away,] requires [as this ex. shows] three objective complements. (M, and Bd in iv. 106. [See I “ AK, p. 117.]) ― -b5- This is not the case in the saying in the Kur [iv. 106], litaHokuma bayona Aln~aAsa bimaA A^araAka A@ll~`hu; (M, Bd;) for here it has but two objective complements, namely, the k in ArAk, and the suppressed pronoun hu in A^araAkahu: it is in this instance from Alr~aA^oYu in the sense of AlA_iEotiqaAdu: (M:) the meaning is, [That thou mayest judge between men] by means of that which God hath taught thee, syn. Ear~afaka, (Ksh, Bd,) or Eal~amaka, (Jel,) and revealed to thee. (Ksh, Bd.) ― -b6- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places, in which the pass., A^uriYa, is mentioned. -A2- A^aroA^aY [as an intrans. v., preserving the original form, inf. n. A_iroA='N, as below,] He looked in the mirror; (T, K;) and so fiY AlmiroA=pi ↓ taraA^~aY and fiyhaA ↓ taraA='aY: (T, M, K:) or ↓ taraA='aY signifies he (a man) looked at his face in the mirror or in the sword: (S:) and fiY AlmaA='i ↓ tamaroA^aY he looked at his face in the water; the doing of which is forbidden in a trad; of the measure tamafoEala [from AlmiroA=pu]; mentioned by Sb; like tamasokana from Almisokiynu, and tamadoraEa from AlmidoraEapu, and tamanodala from Alminodiylu. (M.) ― -b2- He (a man) had many dreams. (T, K. *) ― -b3- He moved his eyelids, (K,) or made much motion with his eyes, (T,) in looking: (T, K:) you say, huwa yuroy^iYbiEayonayohi, (TA,) and yuraA^oriy^N biEayonayohi. (T, TA. *) ― -b4- He acted (T, K) well, or righteously, (T,) in order to make others see what he did, and hear of it. (T, K.) [See also 3.] ― -b5- He possessed, or became possessed of, intelligence (K, TA) and judgment and forecast: (TA:) inf. n. A_iroA='N. (K, TA. [The inf. n. is mentioned with this signification, in the K, app. because it is the first there explained, and therefore as applying to the verb in all its senses.]) ― -b6- And He had the appearance, or evidence, of foolishness, or stupidity, in his face: (T, K, TA: [the words by which Az explains this meaning are tabay~anato A=rAw^hu fY wajohihi whY AlHmAqpu, accord. to one copy of the T; in another copy of the same, Alrw^Ah: the TA follows the former reading: but the right reading is Alr~aA^owapN; mentioned in the T, thus correctly written, in art. rA^rA^; in the S, in the present art; and in the M, in art. rA^w, which is its proper art., and therefore the proper art. of the verb in the sense thus explained:]) thus it bears two contr. meanings. (K. [But it is added in the TA that this requires consideration.]) ― -b7- Also He had what is termed a ray^iY~, of the jinn, or genii; (T, K, TA;) i. e., a follower, of the jinn. (TA.) ― -b8- And He followed the opinion, or belief, of some one, or more, of the lawyers (K, TA) in the science of the law. (TA.) ― -b9- A^aroA^ato said of a she-camel and of a ewe or she-goat, (M,) and of any female in a state of pregnancy, except a solidhoofed animal and a beast of prey, Her udder showed her to be pregnant: (M, K:) and in like manner it is said of a woman: (M:) or, said of a ewe or she-goat, she was, or became, big in her udder: (S:) and accord. to IAar, said of a she-goat, she was, or became, swollen in her vulva, and her being so became apparent, or evident. (M.) And A^aroA^aY said of a man, His ewe, or she-goat, was, or became, black in her udder. (T.) -A3- See also 1, in two places, near the end of the paragraph. -A4- [It is also said in the K and TA that A^arA^aY, said of a camel, means Ainotakava xaTomuhu EalaY Haloqihi; in the CK Anotakaba; and in the TA this is said to be on the authority of En-Nadr: but in a copy of the T, I find it stated, on the authority of ISh, (i. e. En-Nadr,) that AlArA= (i. e. AlA_iroA='u) signifies AntkAvu xTm AlbaEyri ElY Haloqih: in another copy of the T, on the authority of En-Nadr, that AlrA= (a mistranscription for AlA_iroA='u) signifies AntkAv xTm AlbEyr xilqp: and it is added that the epithet applied to a camel is murA^Y (as in one copy, i. e. ↓ muroA^aY, and thus it is written in the TA, but in the other copy of the T mrAoY, an obvious mistranscription); and to camels, murA=AtN (as in one copy, for muroA^aAtN, i. e. muroA=tN, in the other copy of the T erroneously written muraA^Ap, and in the TA mrAyAt): therefore the verb is evidently A^uroy^iYa, in the pass. form, inf. n. A_iroA='N; and I think that the correct explanation is Ainotakava xaTomuhu xiloqapF, app. meaning His muzzle was thin, or lean, by nature: see art. nkv: and see also muroA^FY below.]
5 trA^~Y fiY AlmiroA=pi * : see 4, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- trA^~Y liY: see the paragraph here following.

6 taraA='awoA *
They saw one another: (M, K:) dual taraA='ayaA. (TA.) And taraA='aY AljamoEaAni, (S, TA,) in the Kur [xxvi. 61], (TA,) The two bodies of people saw each other: (S:) or approached and faced each other so that each was able to see the other. (TA.) And taraA='ayonaA We met and saw each other. (A'Obeyd, T.) See also 3, first sentence. It is said in a trad, (T,) laAtaraAA=naArAhumaA, [for tataraAA=, as it is written in some copies of the K,] (T, K,) [i. e. (tropical:) Their two fires shall not be within sight of each-other;] meaning that the Muslim may not dwell in the country of the believers in a plurality of gods, and be with them so that each of them shall see the fire of the other: (T, K *) so says A'Obeyd: or, accord. to AHeyth, it means that the Muslim may not mark himself with the mark of the believer in a plurality of gods, nor assimilate himself to him in conduct and guise, nor assume his manners, or dispositions; from the phrase maA naAru baEiyrika, meaning “ What is the brand of thy camel? ” (T:) IAth explains it similarly to A'Obeyd; and says that the verb is thus used tropically. (TA.) ― -b2- trA='Y liY He addressed, or presented, himself [to my sight, or] in order that I might see him; as also lY ↓ trA^~Y. (M, K.) And trA='Y lahu $aYo'N mina Aljin~i [Somewhat of the jinn, or genii, presented itself to his sight]. (S.) ― -b3- trA='Y Aln~axolu The palm-trees showed the colours of their unripe dates. (AHn, M, K.) ― -b4- taraA='ayonaA AlhilaAla We tasked the sight by trying whether or not we could see the new moon: or, as some say, we looked [together, at, or for, the new moon]: (Sh, * T, TA:) or we lowered our eyes towards the new moon in order that we might see it. (Msb.) [See also 6 in art. nqD.] ― -b5- See also 4, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b6- taraA='ayonaA fiYAlA^amori or trA='ynA AlA^amora: see 8. ― -b7- huwa yataraA='aY biraA^oYi fulaAnK He takes to, or holds, the opinion, or persuasion, or belief, of such a one; and inclines to it; and conforms to it. (T, TA.) ― -b8- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

8 AirotaA=hu * [is syn. with raA=hu as signifying He saw him, or it, with the eye; and also, with the mind]: see 1, first sentence: or it is [syn. with raA=hu in the latter sense only, being] from Alr~aA^oYu and Alt~adobiyru: (S, TA:) or AirotaA^aY is from raA^oYu Alqalobi, (Lth, T,) or from ruw^oyapuAlqalobi, or from Alr~aA^oYu, and means he thought, reflected, or considered, and acted deliberately, or leisurely. (IAth, TA.) You say, AirotaA^ayonaA fiY AlA^amori, and ↓ taraA='ayonaA [i. e. trA='ynA fiyhi] or taraA='ayonaAhu, (accord. to different copies of the K,) meaning naZaronaAhu [or naZaronaAhunaZaronaA fyh, i. e. We looked into, examined, or considered, the affair, or case]. (K.) And AirotaA=hu waA@Eotaqadahu [He saw it with his mind, looked into it, examined it, or considered it, and believed it]. (Mgh.)

10 AstrA=hu *
He, or it, called for, demanded, or required, the seeing of it; (M, K;) i. e., a thing. (M.) ― -b2- See also 1, first sentence. ― -b3- And see 3, last sentence but one. ― -b4- You say also, yusotaroA^aY fulaAnN [Such a one is counted, accounted, or esteemed, hypocritical, or ostentatious], from Alr~iy^aA='u [inf. n. of 3]; like as you say, yusotaHomiqu, and yusotaEoqalu. (AA, S.)
Q. Q. 2 tamaroA^aY * : see 4, in the former half of the paragraph.

raA^oYN * is an inf. n. of raA^aY [q. v.]: (T, S, K:) [and is also a subst.: used as a subst.,] it means The raA^oY of the eye; (Lth, T, Msb;) i. e. the sight thereof; like ruw^oyapN, q. v.: (Msb:) and also, of the mind; (Lth, T;) [i. e.,] it signifies also mental perception: (Msb:) [conception: idea: nation:] belief; (M, K;) as a subst., not as inf. n.: (M:)
[or judgment: or persuasion: or opinion; i. e.] a preponderating belief of one of two things that are inconsistent, each with the other: (Er-Rághib, TA:) a thing that a man has seen with his mind, looked into, examined, or considered, (maA A@rotaA=hu,) and believed: (Mgh:) [a tenet:] also intelligence: and forecast: and skill in affairs: (Msb:) [and hence it often means counsel, or advice:] pl. A^aroA='N (T, S, K &c.) and A=raA='N, (S, M, K,) the latter formed by transposition, [being for A^aA^oraA='N,] (S,) and A^aroY'K [originally A^arow^uYN, like as A^aZobK is originally A^aZobuYN,] (Lh, M, K, TA, in some copies of the K A^aroYN) and ruy^iY~N and riy^iY~N [both originally ruw^uwYN], (Lh, M, TA,) in the K ruY~N, with damm, [in the CK raY~N,] and riY~N, with kesr, (TA,) and [quasipl. n.] ↓ ray^iY~N, (S, K,) of the measure faEiylN, like Day^iynN. (S.) One says, maAA^aDal~a raA^oyahu [How erroneous is his mental perception, &c.!], and maAA^aDal~a A^aruA=hu [How erroneous are his mental perceptions, &c.!]. (Lth, T.) A^aSoHaAbu Alr~aA^oYi, [often meaning The speculatists, or theorists,] as used by those who treat of the traditions, means the followers of analogy; because they pronounce according to their raA^oY [or belief, &c.,] in relation to that concerning which they have not found any [tradition such as is termed] Hadiyv or A^avar, (IAth, K, TA,) or in relation to that which is dubious to them in a tradition. (IAth, TA.) But accord. to the usage of others, one says, fulaAnN mino A^ahuli Alr~aA^oY meaning Such a one holds the belief, or opinion, &c., of the [heretics, or schismatics, called] xawaArij, and says according to their persuasion. (TA.) [Sometimes, also, this phrase means Such a one is of the people of intelligence; or of counsel, or advice.] See also ray^iY~N. And rajulN *uw raA^oYK means A man having mental perception, and skill in affairs. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.
A^ataAhumo Hiyna jan~a ruw^oYN * and ruw^oyFA and ↓ raA^oYN and raA^oyFA (M, K *) [He came to them] when the darkness had become confused so that they did not see one another. (M, K.)

riy^oYN * , (M, TA,) in the K said to be ↓ ruy^iY~N, like SuliY~N, (TA, [but the former is the right, as will be shown by a citation from the Kur in what follows,]) and ↓ ruw^aA='N and ↓ maroA=pN Aspect, look, or outward appearance: (M, K:) [and so ↓ ruw^oyapN; used in this sense in the S and K in explanation of TaloEapN:] or the first and second (i. e. riy^oYN and ↓ ruw^aA='N, M) signify beauty of aspect or outward appearance; (M, K;) or so does this last; (T, S;) [and so ruwaA='N, with w, mentioned in the S in art. rwY, and there explained as syn. with manoZarN;] and ↓ maroA=pN signifies aspect, or outward appearance, absolutely, (M, K, *) whether beautiful or ugly: (M:) or this (mrA=p) signifies a beautiful aspect or outward appearance: and riy^oYN signifies what the eye sees, of goodly condition and clean apparel; as in the phrase in the Kur [xix. 75], humN A^aHsanu A^avaAvFA wawiy^oyFA [they being better in respect of goods, or property, and of appearance of goodly condition and outward apparel], accord. to him who reads it [thus] with '; and read without ' it may be from the same, or from rawiyato A^alowaAnuhumo wajuluwduhumo meaning “ their colours and skins became full and beautiful ” [or rather “ beautiful and full ”] : (S:) for Náfi' and Ibn-'Ámir read riy~FA, by conversion of the ' [into Y] and incorporating it [into the radical Y], or from Alr~iY~N meaning Aln~aEomapu; and Aboo-Bekr read riy^FA, by transposition; and another reading is riyFA, with the ' suppressed; and another ziy~FA, from Alz~aY~u. (Bd.) One says ↓ AimoraA^apN Hasanapu AlmaroA=pi and ↓ AlmaroA^aY [A woman beautiful of aspect]; like as you say Hasanapu AlmanoZarapi and AlmanoZari: (T, S:) and fulaAnN HasanN AlEayoni ↓ fiY maroA=pi Such a one is beautiful in aspect: and it is said in a prov., ↓ tuxobiru Eano majohuwlihi maroA=tuhu His outward appearance indicates [what would otherwise be his unknown character, meaning,] his inward state. (S.) [See also tariy^yapN]

riy^apN * (T, S, M, Msb, K,) with ', (T, S, Msb,) and riyapN without ', (T, Msb,) The saHor [or lungs, or lights]; (S;) the place of the breath and wind (M, K) of a man &c., (M,) [i. e.] of an animal: (K:) the p is a substitute for the Y (S, Msb,) which is suppressed: (Msb:) pl. riy^uwna, (S, M, Msb, K,) agreeably with a general rule relating to words of this class, (M,) and riy^aAtN: (M, Msb, K:) dim. ↓ ruw^ay~apN and ruway~apN (T.) Some say that the suppressed letter [in riyapN] is w; and that it is originally wiroyapN like as EidapN is originally wiEodapN: and warayotuhu signifies “ I hit, or hurt, his riyap ” (Msb.) [hence *aAtu Alr~iy^api Inflammation of the lungs.]

raA^owapN *
An indication of a thing. (M in art. rA^w [to which it belongs: but in the S and TA mentioned in the present art.; and in the T, in art. rA^: in one copy of the S written raA=wapN; and in one place in the TA, written rw^Awp, and said to be like vumaAmapN, app. from the author's having found it written ruA=wapN for raA^owapN].) You say, EalaY fulaAnK raA^owapu AlHumoqi [Upon such a one is the indication of foolishness, or stupidity]. (M.) And EalaY wajohihi raA^owapu AlHumoqi [Upon his face is the indication of foolishness, or stupidity], when you know foolishness, or stupidity, to be in him before you test him. (Lh, T, S.) And A_in~a fiY wajohihi laraA^owapF Verily in his face is an ugliness. (T.) [See also an explanation of A^aroA^aY, above. J seems to have regarded the w as substituted for Y.]

raA^oyapN * , originally thus, with '; (T, Msb;) but the Arabs prefer omitting it, [saying raAyapN,] and some of them say that it has not been heard with '; (Msb;) [Az says,] the Arabs did not pronounce it with ': accord. to Lth, its radical letters are rYY: (T:) A banner, or standard, (T, Msb,) of an army: (Msb:) pl. raAyaAtN (T, Msb.) [See also art. rY.]

ruw^oyapN * an inf. n. of raA^aY [q. v.] : (T, S, M, Msb, K:) [and also a subst.: used a as subst.,) it means The sight of the eye; as also ↓ raA^oYN: [and accord. to the M and K, it is with the mind also; like raA^oYN:] pl. ruwFY. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also riy^oYN ― -b3- [Also The phasis of the moon.]

ruw^oyaA * , (T, S, M, Msb, K,) with ', (T, M,) of the measure fuEolaY, (S, Msb,) without tenween, (S,) [i. e.] imperfectly decl., because the A is that which is the sign of the fem. gender, (Msb,) also pronounced ruwyaA, without ', (Fr, T, M,) and ruy~aA, [which is anomalous, like ruY~N, for riY~N,] mentioned by El-Fárisee on the authority of Abu-l- Hasan, (M,) and riy~aA, (T, M,) heard by Ks from an Arab of the desert, (T,) A dream, or vision in sleep; (T, * S, * M, K;) accord. to most of the lexicologists, syn. with HulomN; or the former is such as is good, and the latter is the contr.: (MF voce HulomN, q. v.:) accord. to Lth, it has no pl.; but accord, to others, (T,) its pl. is ruw^FY, (T, S, M, K,) with tenween. (S.) One says, raA^ayotu Eanoka ruw^FY HasanapF I dreamt, of thee, good dreams. (M.)
ru'aA='N * : see riy^oYN, in two places.

riy^aA='N * an inf. n. of 3 [q. v.]. (M. [Said in the S to be a subst.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] qawomN riy^aA='N A party, or company of men, facing one another. (S.) And in like manner, buyuwtuhumo riy^aA='N [Their tents, or houses, are facing one another]. (S.) And manaAziluhumo riy^aA='N Their places of alighting, or abode, are facing, or opposite, one to another. (T.) ― -b3- And duwru Alqawomi min~aA riy^aA=w^N The houses of the people, or party, are as far as the eye reaches, where we see them, namely, the people. (M.) ― -b4- And humo riy^aA='u A^alofK They are as many as a thousand in the sight of the eye. (K, * TA.)

ray^iY~N * and ↓ riy^iY~N (Lth, T, M, K, TA) A jinnee, or genie, that presents himself to a man, and shows him, or teaches him, divination or enchantment or the like: (Lth, T, TA:) or a jinnee whom a man sees: or, accord. to Lh, one whom a person loves, and with whom he becomes familiar: (M:) or a jinnee that is seen and loved: or the latter word means such as is loved: (K:) and the former word, some other than this: (TA:) or the former means a follower, who is of the jinn; of the measure faEiylN or faEuwlN; [if the latter, originally raw^uwY;] so called because he presents himself to the sight of him of whom he is the follower; or from the saying, fulaAnN ray^iY~u qawomihi, meaning, SaAHibu ↓ raA^oyihimo [i. e. Such a one is the counsellor, or adviser, of his people, or party]: and sometimes it is pronounced riy^iY~N (IAth, TA.) You say, lahu ray^iY~N He has a jinnee &c. (Lh, M, TA.) And maEahu riy^iY~N With him is a jinnee &c. (Lth, T, TA.) And bihi ray^iY~N mina Aljin~i, meaning mas~N [i. e. In him is a touch, or stroke, from the jinn, or genii]. (S.) ― -b2- Also, both words, A great serpent, (K, TA,) that presents itself to the sight of a man; (TA;) so called as being likened to a jinnee; (K, TA;) or because they assert that the serpent is a transformed jinnee, wherefore they call it
$ayoTaAnN and jaAn~N. (IAth, TA.) ― -b3- And A garment, or piece of cloth, that is spread out for sale. (Aboo-'Alee, M, K.) -A2- For the former word, see also raA^oYN [of which it is a quasi-pl. n.].
ruy^iY~N * : see riy^oYN [for which it is app. a mistranscription].
riy^iY~N * : see ray^iY~N.
ruw^ay~apN * dim. of riy^apN, q. v.; also prounced ruway~apN. (T.)
raA^~='N * , or raA^~a'N, A man (M) who sees much. (M, K.)
raA='K * [act. part. n. of raA^aY; Seeing: &c. -A2- ] Still, or motionless: as also raAhK. (TA.)

A^aroA^aY *
More, and most, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, competent, or worthy. (M, K, TA.) You say, A^anaA A^aroA^aY A^ano A^afoEala *`lika I am more, or most, apt, &c., to do that. (K, * TA.) And huwa A^aroA=humo liA^ano yafoEala *`lika He is the most apt, &c., of them to do that. (M.)
