taroy^iyapN * inf. n. of 2. (AZ, T, S.) ― -b2- [Also,] as a subst., not an inf. n., (M,) Beauty, or goodliness; beauty of aspect. (M, K.) [See also riy^oYN.] ― -b3- Also, (M, Mgh,) and tariy~apN (S, M, Mgh) and tiriy~apN, the former of these two words extr., (M,) A slight yellowness and dinginess (S, Mgh) which a woman sees after washing herself in consequence of menstruation: what is in the days of menstruation is termed HayoDN [app. for damu HayoDK]; not try~p: (S:) or a little yellowness or whiteness or blood which a woman sees on the occasion of menstruation: or, as some say, taray~apN signifies the piece of rag by means of which she knows her state of menstruation from her state of purity: it is from Alr~uw^oyapu. (M.) ― -b4- See also what next follows.
tiroy^iyapN * A man who practises evasions or elusions, shifts, wiles, or artifices; as also ↓ taroy^iyapN. (Ibn-Buzurj, T.)

maroA^FY * : see riy^oYN ― -b2- You say also, huwa min~iY maroA^FY wamasomaEN, and maroA^FY wamasomaEFA, (M, K,) accord. to Sb, as adv. ns. having a special, or particularized, meaning, used as though they had not such a meaning, (M,) and sometimes they said marFY, (TA in art. smE,) He is where I see him and hear him. (M, K.) And fulaAnN min~iY bimaroA^FY wamasomaEK Such a one is where I see him and hear what he says. (S.)

muroA^FY * , applied to a [camel's] head, Long in the xaTomK [or muzzle], (As, T, M, K,) in which is taSowiyb [i. e. a bending down], (M, K, [in the CK, erroneously, taSowiytN,]) or in which is the like of Alt~aSowiyb, like the form of the [vessel called] A_iboriyq: (As, T:) Nuseyr likens ruw^uws muroA^ayaAt to qawaAriyr [i. e. flasks, or bottles]: I know not [says ISd] any verb belonging to this word, [though A^uroy^iY seems to be its verb,] nor any art. to which it belongs. (M.) See 4, last sentence.

muroY'K * , applied to a she-camel, and a ewe or she-goat, (M,) and any female in a state of pregnancy, except a solid-hoofed animal and a beast of prey, Whose udder shows her to be pregnant; as also muroy^iyapN: (M, K:) and in like manner applied to a woman: (M:) or, applied to a ewe or she-goat, big in her udder. (S.)

maroA=pN * : see riy^oYN, in five places. ― -b2- You say also, huwa maroA=pN bika*aA He is apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, or competent, for such a thing; or worthy of such a thing. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, maroAapN.]) And huwa maroA=pN A^ano yafoEala ka*aA He is apt, meet, suited, &c., to do such a thing: and in like manner you say of two, and of a pl. number, and of a female. (Lh, M.)

miroA=pN *
A mirror: (T, S, M, K:) originally miroA^ayapN: (Msb:) pl. maraA='K and maraAyaA; (T, S, Msb;) the latter formed by transmutation [of the ' into Y]. (T. [It is said in the S, that the former pl. is used in speaking of three; and the latter, in speaking of many; but for this distinction I see no reason: and in the Msb it is said that, accord. to Az, the latter pl. is a mistake; but this I do not find in the T.])
muraA='K * [act. part n. of 3, q. v.:] A hypocrite: [&c.:] (T, S: *) pl. muraAw^uwna. (S.)

1 rab~ahu * , (M, K,) aor.
rabu3a , inf. n. rab~N, (M,) [He was, or became, its rab~, or lord, possessor, owner, &c.;] he possessed, or owned, it; had possession of it, and command, or authority, over it; (M, K;) namely, a thing; (K;) syn. malakahu. (M, K.) [And in like manner, He was, or became, his rab~, or lord, &c.] You say, rababotu Alqawoma, [inf. n. as above and marab~apN and ribaAbapN,] I ruled, or governed, the people; syn. susotuhumo; i. e. I was, or became, over them [as their lord, master, or chief]. (S.) And TaAlato marab~atuhumu Aln~aAsa and ribaAbatuhum Their ruling, or governing, the people continued long. (M, K. *) The saying of Safwán, (T, S,) on the day of Honeyn, (T,) laA^ano yarub~aniY rajulN mino qurayo$K A^aHab~u A_ilaY~a mino A^uno yarub~aniY rajulN mino hawaAzina means [Assuredly that a man of Kureysh] should be over me (T, S) as rab~ [or lord, &c.], and as master, or chief, having command, or authority, over me, (T,) [is more pleasing to me than that a man of Hawázin should be lord, &c., over me.] ― -b2- Also, (S, M, Mgh, K,) aor.
rabu3a , (S, M,) inf. n. rab~N, (S, Mgh, M,) He reared, fostered, brought up, fed, or nourished, him; i. q. rab~aAhu; (S, M, Mgh, K;) namely, his child, (S,) or a child, (M, K,) either his own or another's; taking good care of him, and acting as his guardian, (M,) until he attained to puberty, or to the utmost term of youth: (M, K:) and so ↓ rb~bhu, (Lh, S, M, Mgh, K,) or this has a more emphatic signification, (TA,) inf. n. tarbiybN (Lh, M, Mgh, K) and tarib~apN; (Lh, M, K;) and ↓ trb~bh; (S, M, K;) and ↓ Artb~hu: (M, K:) [in like manner, also,] ↓ raboraba signifies he reared, fostered, or brought up, an orphan: (AA, T:) and accord. to IDrd, (M,) rabibotuhu is a dial. var. [of rababo=tuhu]: (M, K:) he says also that the verb is used in like manner in relation to the young one of an animal other than man; and he used to cite this ex.:
kaAna lanaA wahowa faluw~N nirobibuho
[He belonged to us when he was a young weaned, or one-year-old, colt, we rearing him]; with the letter characteristic of the aor. meksoor, to show that the second letter of the preterite is meksoor, accord to the opinion of Sb in respect of a case of this kind; and this, he says, is peculiar to the dial. of Hudheyl in this species of verb. (M, TA.) rab~ati AlmaroA^apu Sabiy~ahaA, used tropically, means (tropical:) The woman patted her child repeatedly on its side in order that it might sleep. (A, TA.) [See 2 in art. rbt.] [It is said that] the primary signification of Alr~ab~u is Alt~arobiyapu; i. e. The bringing a thing to a state of completion by degrees. (Bd in i. l.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Hassán Ibn-Thábit, (TA,)
mino dur~apK bayoDaA='a SaAfiyapK
HaAy^iru AlbaHori ↓ mim~aA tarab~aba
[Than a white, clear, pearl, of those which the depth of the sea has brought to maturity]; meaning a pearl which the shell has reared, or brought to maturity in the bottom of the water. (S, TA.) And the phrase laka niEomapN tarub~uhaA occurs in a trad., meaning [Thou hast wealth] which thou preservest, and of which thou takest care, and which thou fosterest like as the man fosters his child. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] AlmaTaru yarub~u Aln~abaAta waAlv~araY The rain causes the plants, or herbage, and the moisture [of the earth] to increase. (M.) And Als~aHaAbu yarub~u AlmaTara The clouds collect and increase the rain. (M.) And rab~a, (T, S, M, K, TA,) aor.
rabu3a , inf. n. rab~N and ribaAbN and ribaAbapN; (Lh, M, TA;) and ↓ rb~b; (M, TA;) (tropical:) He increased, (M, K, TA,) or rightly disposed, and completed, (T, S,) a benefit, or benefaction. (T, S, M, TA.) ― -b4- rab~a AlA^amora, (M, Msb, K,) aor.
rabu3a , inf. n. rab~N (M, Msb) and ribaAbapN, (M,) (tropical:) He put the affair into a right, or proper, state; adjusted it, arranged it, ordered it, or rightly disposed it; (M, K;) and established it firmly: (M:) or he managed, conducted, or regulated, the affair: (Msb:) [perhaps from rab~a signifying “ he reared, ” &c.; but more probably, I think, from what next follows.] ― -b5- rab~a, (T, S, M, K,) aor.
rabu3a , (T, M,) inf. n. rab~u (T, M, K) and rub~N; (K) and ↓ rb~b; (M;) He seasoned a skin (T, S, K) for clarified butter (T, S) with rub~ [i. e. rob, or inspissated juice], (T, S, K,) of dates, (TA,) which imparts a good odour to it, (S, TA,) and prevents the flavour and odour of the butter from being spoiled: (TA:) or he seasoned a skin with rub~, and a jar with tar or pitch: or, as some say, rababotuhu signifies I smeared it over, and prepared it properly. (M.) ↓ rab~a and ↓ rb~b, (K,) or the latter, but the former also is allowable, (M,) (tropical:) He made oil, or ointment, good, and sweet, or fragrant, or he perfumed it, (M, K, * TA,) accord. to Lh, by infusing in it jasmine or some other sweet-smelling
plant. (M, TA.) See also murab~abN, below. ― -b6- rab~a also signifies He collected, or congregated, (K, TA,) people: (TA:) [and so, probably, ↓ rb~b: see rababN.] You say, fulaAnN yarub~u Aln~aAsa Such a one collects, or congregates, to him the people. (T, S, M.) -A2- rab~a, aor.
rabi3a : see 4 -A3- rab~ato, (Lh, M, K,) aor.
rabu3a , (so in the M,) or
rabi3a , (MF, TA,) inf. n. rab~N, (M, TA,) or ribaAbN, (S, K, [in each of which this is mentioned as the inf. n. whence the epithet rub~aY,]) said of a ewe or she-goat, She brought forth: (Lh, M, K:) or, as some say, she conceived: or, accord. to some, there is no verb to the epithet rub~aY: (M:) AZ says that it has no verb: (Msb:) [but] ↓ ribaAbN is an inf. n. used in relation to a ewe or she-goat as meaning her being in the state of such as is termed rub~aY [q. v.]: (S, M, * Msb, * K: *) and in relation to a she-camel, as in the ex. cited by Munteji' Ibn-Nebhán to As,
Haniyna A^um~i Albaw~ifiY ribaAbihaA
[The yearning cry of the mother of the young camel in the time of her having recently brought forth]: (S:) and used also in relation to a woman as meaning her having recently brought forth: or her state within two months after having brought forth: or within twenty days: whence the phrase, in a trad., HamoluhaA ribaAbN, meaning She becomes pregnant soon after having brought forth. (TA.)
2 rb~b * : see 1, in five places. ― -b2- [Also He preserved with rub~, i. e., rob, or inspissated juice: see murab~abN.]

4 Arb~ biAlmakaAni * , (T, M, A, K, *) inf. n. A_irobaAbN; (T;) and ↓ rab~a, (M, K,) aor.
rabi3a ; (MF, TA;) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place, (T, M, A, K, *) not quitting it; (T;) like A^alab~a: (T, A:) and the former, [or each,] he kept, or clave, to the place. (M.) And Arb~ti AlA_ibilu biAlmawoDiEi (T,) or bimakaAni ka*aA, (S,) The camels kept, or clave, (T, S,) to the place, (T,) or to such a place, and remained in it. (S.) And Arb~t Aln~aAqapu, (S,) or Arb~t AlnaAqp biAlfaHoli, and biwaladihaA, (M,) The she-camel kept to the stallion, (S, M,) and to her young one, (M,) and affected it. (TA.) And Arb~t Als~aHaAbapu (S, M, A) biA^aroDihimo (A) (tropical:) The cloud continued raining [in their land]. (S, * M.) And Arb~t Aljanuwbu (assumed tropical:) The south, or southerly, wind continued. (T, S.) ― -b2- AlA_irobaAbu also signifies The drawing near, or approaching, (S, M, K,) a thing, (S, M,) of any kind. (M.)

5 trb~b AlA^aroDa * , (M, A, K,) and Alr~ajula, (M, K,) He asserted himself to be the rb~ [or lord, &c.,] of the land, (M, A, K,) and of the man. (M, K.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph. -A2- trb~bwA They collected themselves together, or congregated; or they became collected or congregated. (S.)

6 trAb~wA *
They united in a confederacy, league, or covenant. (M, TA.) [App. from the fact of some confederates dipping their hands into rub~: see ribaAbN.]

8 Artb~hu * : see 1. ― -b2- tarotab~u Al$~aEara [She adjusts, or arranges, and composes, or collects together, the hair], said of a woman, is from [Alr~ab~u signifying] AlA_iSolaAHu and AljamoEu. (M.) ― -b3- Aurotub~a AlEinabu The grapes were cooked so as to become rub~ [or rob], used to give a relish to bread. (AHn, M.)
R. Q. 1 raboraba * : see 1.
rabo * : see raA^aba, of which it is an imperative.
ruba * and raba and rubu and rubo and rabo; and rubamaA and rabamaA &c.: see rub~a.
rabN * : see the next paragraph, last sentence but one.

rab~N *
A lord, a possessor, an owner, or a proprietor, syn. maAlikN, (T, IAmb, S, M, A, Msb, K,) of a thing, (T,) of anything, (S, M, A, K,) or of an irrational thing; (Msb;) a person who has a right, or just title or claim, to the possession of anything; or its SaAHib [which is syn. with maAlik]; (M, A, K;) rab~N and maAlikN and SaAHibN all signifying in Pers. xudaAwanod: (KL:) and a lord, master, or chief; (Msb, TA;) or a lord, master, or chief, to whom obedience is paid: (IAmb, TA:) and a lord, ruler, governor, regulator, or disposer; (TA;) an orderer, a rectifier, or a reformer: (IAmb, TA:) a rearer, fosterer, bringer-up, feeder, or nourisher: and a completer, or an accomplisher: (TA:) it is an epithet, like nam~N from nam~a: or an inf. n. used as an intensive epithet; like EadolN; (Ksh and Bd * in i. l;) originally signifying the “ bringing (a thing) to a state of completion by degrees;” (Bd, ibid.;) then used in the sense of maAlikN: (Ksh and Bd ibid.:) the pl. [of pauc.] is A^arobaAbN and [of mult.] rubuwbN, (M, K,) and accord. to Sh, ribaAbN also, (TA,) signifying A^aSoHaAbN, (K,) and ↓ rabuwbN is app. a quasi-pl. n.: (M:) the fem. is ↓ rab~apN; of which the pl. is rab~aAtN. (T.) Whoever possesses a thing is its rab~: you say, huwa rab~u Ald~aAb~api [He is the possessor, or owner, or master, of the beast], and Ald~aAri [of the house], (T,) and AlmaAli [of the property, or cattle]; (Msb;) and Albayoti ↓ hiYa rab~apu [She is the owner, or mistress, of the house or tent]. (T.) With the article Al, it is [properly] applied only to God: (T, S, M, A, Msb, K:) He is rab~u AlA^arobaAbi [The Lord of lords]. (T. [Thus the pl. with the article Al is applied to created beings.]) To any other being it is not [properly] applied but as a prefixed noun governing another noun as its complement in the gen. case [or in a similar manner]. (S.) The pagan Arabs, however, sometimes applied it to A king, (S,) or to a lord as meaning a master or chief: (Msb:) El- Hárith says, (S, Msb,) i. e. Ibn-Hillizeh, (S,)
wahuwa Alr~ab~u waAl$~ahiydu EalaY yuwo
mi AlHiyaArayoni waAlbalaA='u balaA='u
(S, Msb,) i. e. And he (meaning El-Mundhir Ibn-Má-es-Semà, or, as some say, 'Amr Ibn-Hind,) was the king [or lord] and witness of our fighting on the day of El-Hiyárán (the name of a place), and the trial was a hard trial. (EM, p. 285: [in which AlHayaArayoni is erroneously put for AlHiyaArayoni.]) Some forbid that a man should be called the rab~ of his slave: (Msb:) it is said in a trad. that the slave shall not say to his master, rab~Y, because it is like attributing a partner to God: (TA:) but rab~ is sometimes used in the sense of lord as meaning master or chief prefixed to a noun signifying a rational being governed by it in the gen. case: thus in the saying of the Prophet, Hat~aY talida AlA^amapu rab~ahaA [So that the female slave shall bring forth him who will become her master], or ↓ rab~atahaA [her mistress], accord. to different transmitters; (Msb;) relating to the signs of the hour of resurrection: i. e., the female slave shall bring forth to her master a child that shall be as a master [or mistress] to her because like his [or her] father in rank: meaning that captives and concubines shall be numerous. (TA.) As to the phrase in the Kur [xii. 42], Au*okuroniY Einoda rab~ika [Mention thou me in the presence of thy lord], Joseph thus addressed his fellow-prisoner agreeably with the acceptation in which he [the latter] understood the words. (TA.) A similar instance also occurs in the same chapter, in the verse immediately preceding. (Msb.) In another verse, [23 of the same ch.,] A_in~ahu rab~iY [Verily he is my lord] may refer to Joseph's master or to God. (M, TA.) The words of the Kur [lxxxix. 28 and 29], AirojiEiY A_ilaY rab~iki raADiyapF maroDiy~apF faA@doxuliY fiY EabodYi, as some read, [instead of EibaAdiY,] may mean Return to thine owner, [approving, approved,] and enter into my servant. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Without the article Al, as some say, (L, TA,) it is sometimes written and pronounced ↓ rabN, without teshdeed; (L, K;) as in the following verse, cited by El-Mufaddal,
waqado Ealima AlA^aqowaAmu A^ano layosa fawoqahu
rabN gayoru mano yaEoTiY AlHuZuwZa wayarozuqu
[And the peoples have known that there is not above him a lord beside Him who gives the portions of mankind and of others and grants the means of subsistence]. (L.) And Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà [i. e. Th] mentions the phrase laA warabiyka laA A^afoEalu, for laA warab~ika [i. e. No, by thy Lord, I will not do such a thing]; the [latter] b being changed into Y because of the reduplication. (M, K: * in the CK raboyika.)

rub~a * is a word of which there are seventy dial. vars., all mentioned by Zekereeyà El-Ansáree in his great Expos. of the “ Munferijeh, ” but only eighteen of which are mentioned in the K, including some that are formed with the affix t, some with the affix maA, and some with both these affixes together; as follows: (TA:) rub~a (T, S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K, &c.) and rab~a (T, M, Mughnee, K) and rub~u, (Mughnee,) and ↓ ruba (T, S, M, Mughnee, K) and raba (T, M, Mughnee, K) and rubu and rubo (Mughnee, K) and rabo; (Mughnee;) and ↓ rub~ata (T, S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K) and rab~ata (M, Mughnee, K) and rub~uta and rub~atu and rab~atu and rub~utu and rub~ati and rab~ati and rub~uti and rab~ut (TA)
and rub~ato and rab~ato (Mughnee) and rub~uto, (TA,) and ↓ rubata (T, Mughnee, K) and rabata (Mughnee, K) and rubuta and rubota and rabota and rubatu and rabatu and rubutu and rubotu and rabotu and rubati and rabati and rubuti and rabuti and ruboti and raboti (TA) and rubato and rabato (Mughnee) and rubuto; (TA;) and rub~amaA (T, S, M, K) and rab~amaA (M, K) and rub~umaA, (TA,) and ↓ rubamaA (T, K) and rabamaA (K) and rubumaA and rubomaA and rabomaA; (TA;) and ↓ rub~atamaA (T, S, M, K) and rab~atamaA (M, K) and rub~utamaA and rub~atumaA and rab~atumaA and rub~utumaA and rub~atomaA and rab~atomaA and rub~utomaA, (TA,) and ↓ rubatamaA and rabatamaA (M, K) and rubutamaA and rubotamaA and rabotamaA and rubatumaA and rabatumaA and rubutumaA and rubotumaA and rabotumaA and rubatomaA and rabatomaA and rubutomaA: (TA:) [of all these, the most common are rub~a and rub~amaA: and] ↓ rub~ata is the most common of the forms that have the affix t: (Mughnee and K on the letter t:) and the forms with teshdeed are more common than the [corresponding] forms without teshdeed. (M.) It is a word, (M,) or particle, (T, S, Mughnee, K,) governing the gen. case: (S, M, Mughnee, K:) or a noun, (K, TA,) [i. e. an indecl. noun,] in the opinion of the Koofees and some others; but this opinion is rejected by Ibn-Málik in the Tesheel and its Expos., and by AHei, and by IHsh in the Mughnee. (TA.) Accord. to some, (K, TA,) it is used to denote a small number, (T, M, Msb, K, TA,) always, (TA,) or mostly: (Msb, TA:) [thus it may be rendered Few if we render the noun following it as a pl.; and scarce any if we render the noun following as a sing. or a pl.:] it is the contr. of kamo when this latter is not used interrogatively: (T:) [and with maA affixed, restricting it from government, it may be rendered Few times, or seldom:] or it is used to denote a large number; (K, TA;) i. e. always: so says IDrst: (TA:) [thus used, but such is not always the case, it may be rendered Many, whether we render the noun following it as a sing. or as a pl.: and with maA affixed, Many times, many a time, oftentimes, ofttimes, often, or frequently:] or it is used to denote a small and a large number; (Mughnee, K;) often the latter, and seldom the former: (Mughnee:) or it is used in a case of boasting, or glorying, (K, TA,) exclusively of other cases, (TA,) to denote a large number: (K, TA:) or it does not denote by itself either a small number or a large number; but one or the other of these meanings is inferred from the context: (K:) [but sometimes neither of these meanings can be clearly inferred from the context: in these cases, it may be rendered Some: and with maA affixed, Sometimes:] accord. to Er-Radee, its primary meaning is to denote a small number, but it has been so much used to denote a large number as to be in this latter sense as though it were proper, and in the former sense as though it were tropical, requiring context [to explain it]. (Marginal note in my copy of the Mughnee.) [Without the affix mA,] it governs an indeterminate noun (T, * S, Msb, Mughnee, K) only, (T, S, K,) and a pronoun. (S, M, Mughnee.) You say, rub~a yawomK bak~arotu fiyhi [Few, or many, days have I gone forth early therein]: (T:) and rub~a rajulK qaAy^imN [Few, or many, men are standing]: (M:) and rub~a rajulK qaAma [Few, or many, men stood]: (Msb:) and in like manner, rajulK ↓ rub~ata; (Msb;) for the t in this case is not a denotative of the fem. gender. (Msb.) The pronoun affixed to it is of the third pers., (S, M,) and is [generally] sing. and masc., (S, Mughnee,) though it may be followed by a fem. and by a dual and by a pl.: (S:) notwithstanding its being determinate in the utmost degree, its use in this manner is allowable because it resembles an indeterminate noun in its being used without the previous mention of the noun to which it relates; and hence it requires a noun to explain it: (IJ, M:) it annuls the government of rub~a; (TA;) and the indeterminate noun that follows it is put in the accus. case as a specificative: (S, Mughnee:) thus you say, rub~ahu rajulFA qado Darabotu [Few, or many, men I have beaten]: (S, M: *) but accord. to the Koofees, you say rub~ahu rajulFA, (S,) and rub~ahaA A@moraA^apF, (M,) and rub~ahumaA rajulayon$, and rub~ahumo rijaAlFA, and rub~ahun~a nisaA='F: he who puts the pronoun in the sing. [in all cases] holds it to be allusive to something unknown; and he who does not put it in the sing. [when it is not followed by a sing. noun] holds it to be used in reply to a question, as though it were said to a man, “ Hast thou not any young women? ” and he answered, rub~ahun~a jawaArK qado malakotu [Few, or many, young women have I possessed]: Ibn-Es-Sarráj says that the grammarians are as though they were of one consent in holding rub~a to be a replicative [app. meaning in a case of this kind, with an affixed pronoun]: (S:) [but it is not always a replicative in a case of this kind; though perhaps it was originally:] AHeyth cites as an ex.
warub~ahu EaTibFA A^anoqa*otu mi AlEaTabi
[And many a perishing man have I saved from perdition]. (TA. [But the reading commonly found in grammars is mino EaTabiho from his state of perdition.]) The following is an ex. of the use of rub~a to denote a small number, [or rather to denote singleness,]
A^alaA rub~a mawoluwdK walayosa lahu A^abN
wa*iY waladK lamo yalodihi A^abawaAni
[Now surely scarce an instance is there of anyone born not having a father, and of anyone having offspring whom two parents have not procreated]; meaning [our Lord] Jesus and Adam: (Mughnee: [but I have substituted yalodihi for yalodahu, the reading in my copy of that work: lamo yalodihi is for lamo yalidohu, for the sake of the metre; like as limo A^ajodi is for lamo A^ajido:]) and among the many exs. of its use to denote a large number, is the saying, in a trad., yaA rub~a kAasiyapK fiY Ald~unoyaA EaAriyapN yawoma Alqiy`mapi [O, many a female having clothing in the present state of existence will be naked on the day of resurrection!]; and the saying of an Arab of the desert, after the ending of Ramadán, yaA rub~a SaAy^imihi lano yaESuwmahu wayaA rub~a qaAy^imihi lano yaquwmahu [O, many a keeper of its fast shall not keep its fast again! and O, many a passer of its nights in prayer, or per- former of its taraAwiyH, shall not pass its nights in prayer, or perform its trAwyH, again!]. (Mughnee.) [But in this last ex., and in others, it relates to few in comparison with others, though many abstractedly.] ― -b2- maA is affixed to rub~a &c. in order that a verb may follow it; (S, Mughnee;) and the verb that follows it is generally a preterite, (T, Mughnee,) as to the letter and the meaning: (Mughnee:) you say, rub~amaA jaA='aniY fulaAnN [Seldom, or often, such a one came to me, or has come to me]: (T:) sometimes the verb is a future; (T, Mughnee;) but only when it expresses an event of which one is certain: (T:) so in the saying in the Kur [xv. 2], rub~amaA yawad~u A@l~a*yna kafaruwA lawo kaAnuwA musolimiyna, (T, S, M, Mughnee), meaning Often [will those who have disbelieved wish that they had been Muslims]; (Mughnee, Jel;) or seldom, (Zj, T, M, Jel,) because terrors will bereave them of their reason so that they will but seldom recover reason to wish this; (Jel;) for God's threat is true, as though it had come to pass, and therefore the verb here is equivalent to a preterite [which is often used in the Kur and elsewhere in this manner]. (T.) maA is also sometimes affixed when a noun follows, (T, Mughnee,) or a nominal proposition, and generally restricts rub~a &c. from governing: thus, Aboo-Duwád says,
rub~amaA AljaAmilu Almuw^ab~alu fiyhimo
waEanaA jiyju bayonahun~a AlmihaAru
[Sometimes, or often, the numerous herd of camels is among them, and there are swift horses, among which are the colts]: another says, making rub~a, with maA affixed, to govern,
rub~amaA DarobapK bisayofK SaqiylK
qayoni buSoraY waTaEonapK najolaA='a
[Many a stroke with a polished sword of the forging of Busrà, (the Bozrah of the Bible, a city famous for its sword-blades,) and many a wide spear-wound; or, perhaps, few strokes &c.]: (Mughnee: [but I have substituted qayoni for bayona, which is the reading in my copy of the Mughnee, an evident mistranscription:]) and another, cited by IAar, says,
gaArapK ↓ maAwiY~a yaA rub~atamaA
$aEowaA='a kaA@ll~a*oEapi biA@lomiysami
[Máweeyeh, (maAwiY~a being an apocopated proper name of a woman, originally maAwiy~apu,) O, many a raid spreading widely and dispersedly, like the burn with the branding-iron]. (T. [In the TT, as from the T, I find, here, balo in the place of yA, which I find in a copy of the T, and which is the reading commonly known.])

rub~N *
Rob, or inspissated juice, (dibos,) of any fruit; i. e., (M, TA,) the first, or clear, juice of the thick residuum of any fruit after it has been pressed (M, K, TA) and cooked: (M, TA:) thick TilaA=' [or expressed juice; such as the inspissated juice of dates, with which a skin for clarified butter is seasoned; see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph]: (S:) or what flows from fresh ripe
dates, like honey, when it has been cooked [and so rendered thick]; before which it is called SaqorN: (Msb in the present art. and in art. Sqr:) what is prepared by coction from, or of, dates: (TA:) expressed juice of grapes, and of apples, &c., cooked and [so] thickened: (KL:) and dregs, (K,) or black dregs, (IDrd, M,) of clarified butter, (IDrd, M, K,) and of olive-oil: (IDrd, M:) pl. rubuwbN and ribaAbN (S) [and pl. pl. (i. e. pl. of rubuwbN) rubuwbaAtN, which means sorts, or species, of rub~] -A2- See also rub~aY.

rab~apN * : see rab~N, in three places. ― -b2- Alr~ab~apu was also the name of A Kaabeh [or square temple], (M, K,) in Nejrán, (M,) belonging to [the tribe of] Medh-hij (M, K) and Benu-l-Hárith-Ibn-Kaab, who held it in honour. (M.) In a trad. of 'Orweh (K, TA) Ibn-Mes'ood Eth-Thakafee, (TA,) it is applied to El-Lát (All~aAtu), (K, TA,) the rock which [the tribe of] Thakeef worshipped, at Et-Táïf. (TA.) And in another trad., it is said to be the name of A temple of [the tribe of] Thakeef, which, when they became Muslims, was demolished by El-Mugheereh. (TA.) ― -b3- And rab~apN, (K,) or daArN rab~apN, (M,) signifies A large house or mansion. (M, K.) -A2- See also rub~aY.

rub~apN *
A party, division, sect, or distinct body or class, of men: (M:) or a large assembly or company: (K:) or a myriad; i. e. ten thousand: (M, K:) or thereabout: (M:) and ↓ rib~pN signifies the same: (M, K:) or this signifies a company [of men]: (T:) the pl. of the former is ribaAbN: (S, M:) and that of the latter is A^arib~apN: (T, K:) by Th [and in the K], the former pl. is said to be a pl. of rib~apN; but this is a mistake. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence, the pl.] ribaAbN signifies Companions. (K.) ― -b3- And hence [also], i. e., as pl. of Alr~ubapu, (S, M,) Alr~ibaAbu is an appellation of The [confederate] tribes of Dabbeh; (M, K, TA;) or Teym and 'Adee and 'Okl; (T, TA;) or Teym and 'Adee and 'Owf and Thowr and Ashyab; (TA; [but for the orthography of the last of these names I have found no authority; it is written in the TA A$yb, without any syll. signs;]) and Dabbeh was their paternal uncle; (TA;) or five tribes which united in a confederacy, consisting of Dabbeh and Thowr and 'Okl and Teym and 'Adee: (S:) they were thus called because of their division into distinct bodies; (M;) or because they collected themselves (As, Th, S, TA) in distinct bodies: (Th, M, TA:) or because they united in a confederacy against Temeem Ibn-Murr: (AO, M, TA:) or because they dipped their hands in some rub~, and formed a confederacy over it: (As, T, M, K:) or, as some say, because they congregated, and became like the ribaAb [or bundle] of arrows [used in the game called Almayosir]: (TA:) the rel. n. is ↓ rub~iY~N, formed from the sing., (Sb, S, M,) accord. to a rule generally observed except when a [single] man has a pl. word for his name, as kilaAbN &c. (S, TA.) ― -b4- The sing. (rub~apN) also signifies Plenty, or abundance, of the means of subsistence: (K:) and constant, or inseparable, prosperity. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, TA.) -A2- See also rub~aY.

rib~apN * : see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence its pl.] A^arib~apN signifies Confederates; (S, IB, K;) [or] it is for *awuw A^arib~apK having covenants; A^arib~apN being said by AAF to be pl. of ribaAbN in the sense of EahodN. (IB, TA.) -A2- Also A species of plant, (S, M, Msb, K,) of the [season called] Sayof, (M,) remaining in the end of the Sayof: (Msb:) or the name of a number of plants which do not dry up in the Sayof, remaining green in the winter and the Syf [or summer]; among which are the Hul~ab and the ruxaAmaY and the makor and the EaloqaY or EaloqFY: [see rabolN:] or a certain soft, or tender, herb, or leguminous plant: (TA:) or any plant that is green in the hot season: or certain species of trees, or of plants, undefined: (M:) pl. ribabN. (S, Msb.) [In the dial. of Egypt, Alexandrian trefoil (birosiym, q. v.,) of the second and third crops.] ― -b2- Also A certain tree: as some say, the tree of the xar~uwb [an appellation generally applied to the carob, or locust-tree]. (M, K.)

rababN * , (S, M, K,) or maA='N rababN, (S, TA,) Much water, (S, M, K,) collected together: (M:) or sweet-water: (S, K:) accord. to Th, it means maA rab~abahu AlTiynu [app. such (water) as the clay has collected; for tarab~aba signifying tajam~aEa is probably quasi-pass. of rab~aba, so that this last seems to signify jam~aEa]. (M.)
rubata * and rabata &c.; and rubatamaA and rabatamaA &c.: see rub~a.

rabaAbN *
Clouds: (M:) or white clouds: (S, K:) or clouds that one sees beneath other clouds, (S,) or clouds suspended beneath other clouds, (M,) sometimes white and sometimes black: (S, M:) this latter is said by IB to be the signification commonly known: (TA:) or clouds consisting of an accumulation of parts: (A 'Obeyd, T:) n. un. with p. (A 'Obeyd, S, K.) Hence Alr~abaAbu as a proper name of a woman. (A 'Obeyd, T, S.) -A2- Also A certain instrument of diversion, [meaning, of music,] (K,) having strings, (TA,) with which one plays [lit. beats]. (K.) [The rbAb in common use among the Arabs in the present day is a kind of viol. A specimen of it is figured and described in my work on the Modern Egyptians. Being an instrument of remarkable simplicity, it is probably similar to the ancient rbAb.] Memdood Ibn-'Abd-Allah El-Wásitee Er-Rabábee became proverbial for his musical skill with the rbAb. (K.) -A3- See also rub~aAnN.
rubaAbN * : see rub~aY, of which it is an anomalous pl.: -A2- and see also rub~aAnN.

ribaAbN * : see ribaAbapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Tithes, or tenths; syn. Eu$uwrN: (S, M, K:) from the same word signifying “ a covenant. ” (S.) ― -b3- In the phrase yuEoTiyhaA AlA^amaAna ribaAbuhaA, ending a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, describing some asses, ribaAb is said to signify An oath, or a promise, which the owner of the asses takes of a people to permit those asses to water: or the poet means that the person giving those asses permission to water gives to their owner an arrow, of those used in the game called Almayosir, [as a token,] to show that they have received permission to water, and that no one may offer them any opposition: (TA:) some say that ribaAbuhaA here means their owners: (M:) [holding this last opinion,] Sh says that ribaAb in this verse is a pl. of rab~N. (TA.) -A2- It is also a pl. of rub~apN; (S, M;) not of rib~apN, as it is said to be by Th [and in the K]. (M.) -A3- See also 1, last sentence. -A4- And see rub~aAnN.
rabuwbN * : see rabiybN. -A2- See also rab~N, of which it is said in the M to be app. a quasi-pl. n.

rabiybN *
Reared, fostered, brought up, fed, or nourished; [and taken good care of, until the age of puberty; (see 1;)] as also ↓ marobuwbN; (S, M, K;) both applied to a boy: (S, M:) and in like manner applied to a horse: (M:) or the latter epithet, applied to a horse, (tropical:) tended well, or taken good care of: (A:) the former is also applied to a gazelle; (IAar, K in art. dxl;) [as meaning (assumed tropical:) brought up in, or near, the house or tent, and there fed;] like A^aholiY~N: (TA in that art.:) and [its fem.] rabiybapN is applied to a ewe or she-goat, ($aApN, K,) meaning (assumed tropical:) brought up in the tent, or house, for the sake of her milk; (S, K; [see also rub~aY;]) pl. rabaAy^ibu; (S;) this last being applied to sheep or goats that are tied near to the tents, or houses, and there fed, and that do not go forth to pasture; (M, TA;) of which it is said that none are to be taken for the poor-rate. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, A step-son,] a man's wife's son (T, S, M, A, Msb, K) by another husband; (T, S, M, A, K;) as also ↓ rabuwbN: (T, K:) pl. A^arib~aA='u. (Msb.) And rabiybapN [A step-daughter;] a woman's husband's daughter by another wife: (S:) or a man's wife's daughter (T, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) by another husband; (T, M, A;) because he rears her: (Mgh:) pl. rabaAy^ibu (A, Mgh, Msb) and sometimes rabiybaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b3- Also, and ↓ raAb~N, (T, M, K,) both syn., like $ahiydN and $aAhidN, and xabiyrN and xaAbirN, (TA,) or the latter, (T, S,) mentioned by IAar, is the correct term, (T,) [A step-father;] the husband of a mother (T, S, M, K) who has a child by another husband. (T.) And rabiybapN and ↓ raAb~apN, (T,) or the latter [only], (S, K,) [A stepmother;] the wife of a father (T, S, K) who has a child by another wife. (T.) rabiybapN also signifies [A foster-mother;] a woman who has the charge of a child, who carries him, and takes care of him, and rears, or fosters, him; (Th, S, M, Msb, K;) like ↓ raAb~apN; the former being of the measure faEilaypN in the sense of faAEilapN. (Msb.) A^arb~aA='u Aln~abiY~ [meaning The foster-fathers of the Prophet] is an appellation given to the people [of the tribe of Saad] among whom Mohammad was suckled; as though Arb~A=' were pl. of rabiybN [as it is said to be in one of the senses mentioned above]. (TA.) ― -b4- And rabiybN signifies also A confederate; a person with whom one unites in a confederacy, league, or covenant. (M, K.) ― -b5- And A king. (M, K.)

ribaAbapN * : see rubuwbiy~apN. -A2- Also A covenant, compact, confederacy, or league; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ ribaAbN, (M, K,) of which latter, in this sense, the pl. is A^arib~apN. (AAF, IB, TA.) [See rib~apN, second sentence.]) -A3- And A thing [or case] resembling a quiver (kinaAnap), in which the arrows of the game called Almayosir are enclosed together: (S:) or a piece of skin, (T,) or a piece of thin skin, (Lh, M, TA,) in which the arrows are enclosed, (Lh, T, M, TA,) resembling a quiver (knAnp): (TA:) or a piece of rag, (M, K, TA,) or of skin, (TA,) in which the arrows are enclosed (M, K, TA) or bound: (TA:) or a piece of thin skin which is bound upon the hand of the man who takes forth the arrows (K, TA) of that game, (TA,) lest he should know the feel of an arrow for the owner of which he has an affection: (K, TA:) or a small cord with which the arrows are bound [together]: or the arrows [themselves] collectively: (M, K:) sometimes it is used in this last sense: (S:) and ↓ ribaAbN also seems to be used in like manner; as meaning the ribaAbap of the arrows of the game of Almysr. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce A^afaADa in art. fyD.]
rubuwbapN * : see rubuwbiy~apN.

rabaAbY~N *
A player on the rabaAb [q. v.]. (MA, K.)

rabuwbiY~N * , (M, K,) with fet-h [to the r], (K,) a rel. n. from Alr~ab~u, deviating from rule: so in the phrase EilomN rabuwbiY~N [Knowledge, science, or doctrine, relating to the Lord, i. e., to God]. (M, K.)

rubuwbiy~apN * [Lordship; or the state, or quality, of such as is termed rab~N i. e. a lord, a possessor, an owner, or a proprietor; &c.: and, with the article Al particularly godship, godhead, or deity:] a subst. from Alr~ab~u; (T, * S, * M, K;) as also ↓ ribaAbapN [which seems to be properly an inf. n. of 1 in the sense first explained]. (M, K.) -A2- Also, (M, K,) or ↓ rubuwbapN, (so in a copy of the K,) The state, or condition, of a mamoluwk [or slave]. (M, K.)
rub~ata * and rab~ata &c.; and rub~atamaA and rab~atamaA &c.: see rub~a, in five places.

rub~aY * , applied to a ewe or she-goat ($aApN), (S, M, &c.,) That has brought forth: (M, Msb, K:) and so if her young one has died: (M, K:) or that has recently brought forth: (Lh, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) or that has brought forth twenty days before: (M:) or that has brought forth two months before: (El-Umawee, S, M:) or that is followed, (M,) or accompanied, (As, Mgh,) by her young one: (As, M, Mgh:) or that is confined in the tent, or house, for the sake of her milk: (Msb: [see also rabiybapN, voce rabiybN:]) accord. to AZ, (S, Msb,) it is applied to a she-goat, (S, M, Msb,) and raguwvN is applied to a ewe: (M:) accord. to others, the former is applied to a she-goat and a ewe, and sometimes to a she-camel: (S, Msb:) the pl. is ↓ rubaAbN, (As, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) which is extr. [in form]: (M, K:) Lh mentions the phrase ganamN rubaAbN, or ribaAbN, which, he says, is rare. (M.) ― -b2- See also rub~aAnN, in two places. -A2- A benefit, favour, boon, or good. (AA, T, K.) [See an ex. in the first paragraph of art. j$A^.] ― -b2- A want; (AA, T, K;) as in the saying, liY Einoda fulaAnK rub~aY [I have a want for such a one to supply, or accomplish]. (AA, T.) -A3- A child's nurse; syn. daAyapN. (AA, T. In one copy of the T bAbh; and in the TA rAyp. [Perhaps the right reading is raAb~apN, meaning a foster-mother.]) -A4- A firm knot: (AA, T, K:) [and so, app., ↓ rub~aAnN, if correctly written thus, in the instance here following.] You say, A_ino kunota A_izorika ↓ biY ta$hd~u Zahoraka faA^aroxi birub~aAni, (TA,) or birub~aA A_izorika (so in the TT, as from the M, [as though for birub~aY,]) and minE rub~aY A_izorika, (T, TA,) a prov., meaning (assumed tropical:) If thou place thy reliance upon me, then let me weary myself, and enjoy thou relaxation and rest: (T, TA:) here rub~aY [properly] signifies a firm knot. (T.) [See also a similar prov. in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 24.]) -A5- Also a name of Jumádà-l-Oolà [the fifth month of the Arabian calendar]; and so ↓ rub~N: (M, K:) and likewise, (K,) or accord. to Kr, (M,) a name of Jumádà-l-Ákhireh [the sixth month]; and so ↓ rub~apu: (M, K:) and this last likewise, (K, there expressly said to be with damm,) or ↓ rab~apu, (so accord. to the M as transcribed in the TT,) a name of Dhu-l-Kaadeh [the eleventh month]: (M, K:) thus these months were called in the Time of Ignorance. (M. [See also $ahorN: and see run~aY or Alr~un~aY, in art. rn.])
rab~iY~N * : see rab~aAniY~N. ― -b2- And for its pl., rab~iy~uwna, see rib~iY~N, in two places.
rub~iY~N * rel. n. of rub~apN, q. v. (Sb, S, M.) ― -b2- See also its pl., rub~iy~uwna, in the next paragraph, in two places.

rib~iY~N * sing. of rib~iy~uwna (T, S, K,) which signifies Thousands (Fr, Th, T, S, K) of men: (S, K:) accord. to Akh, it is from Alr~ab~u; and if so, it is ↓ rab~iy~uwna, with fet-h to the r: but accord. to Fr, it is from rib~apN, meaning “ a company: ” (Th, T:) Zj says that it is rib~iy~uwna and ↓ rub~iy~uwna, with kesr to the r and also with damm to the r, and signifies a numerous company: he adds that rib~apN is said by some to signify “ ten thousand; ” and that rb~yuwn is said to signify learned, pious, patient men; and that each of these sayings is good: accord. to Aboo-Tálib, it signifies numerous companies: (T:) [in the Kur iii. 140,] El-Hasan read ↓ rub~iy~uwna; and Ibn-' Abbas, ↓ rab~iy~uwna; the former with damm, and the latter with fet-h, to the r. (L, TA.) ― -b2- See also rab~aAniY~N.
rab~aAnN * : see the next paragraph, in four places.

rub~aAnN * The first, or beginning, or commencement, or the first and fresh state, of anything; (As, A 'Obeyd, T;) [and so ↓ rab~aAnN &c., as appears from what follows.] You say, A^atayotuhu fiY rub~aAni $abaAbihi, (T,) and $bAbh ↓ rab~aAni, or $bAbh ↓ rib~aAni, (accord. to different copies of the T,) and $bAbh ↓ rubaAbi, (T,) and $bAbh ↓ rabaAbi, or $bAbh ↓ ribaAbi, (accord. to different copies of the T,) and $bAbh ↓ rub~aY, all meaning [I came to him] in the beginning, or first and fresh state, of his youth. (T.) And AifoEalo *`lika AlA^amora birub~aAnihi Do thou that thing in its first and fresh state: so accord. to ISk: and hence, he says, ↓ $aApN rub~aY [explained above]. (S.) And A^axa*otu Al$~aYo'a birub~aAnihi, (As, S, K, *) and ↓ birab~aAnihi, with damm and with fet-h, (K,) i. e. [I took the thing] in its first state: (K:) or altogether, (As, S, K,) not leaving of it aught. (As, S.) They said also, *arohu birub~aAnK [app. meaning Leave thou him early, before he acquire more power]: and Th cites the following [as an ex.]:
fa*arohumo birub~aAnK waA_il~aA ta*arohumu
yu*iyquwka maA fiyhimo waA_ino kaAna A^akovaraA
[which seems to mean Then leave thou them early, before they acquire more power; for if thou do not, or wilt not, leave them, they will make thee to taste what is in them, though it be more]. (M.) ― -b2- Also, accord. to A 'Obeyd, The chief, or main, part or portion of a constellation: or, accord. to As, the aggregate thereof: or, accord. to AO, ↓ rab~aAnN, with fet-h, has this meaning: (T:) or both signify a company or an assembly, or an aggregate or assemblage. (K, TA.) -A2- Also A captain of sailors (Sh, K) in the sea; (Sh;) and so ↓ rub~aAniY~N: (Sh, K:) one skilled in navigation: pl. [or rather coll. n. of the latter] rub~aAniy~apN. (TA voce rahonaAmajN.) -A3- See also rub~aY, in two places.
rib~aAnN * : see the next preceding paragraph, second sentence.

rab~aAniY~N * (T, S, M, A, K) and ↓ rib~iY~N (M,) or ↓ rib~iY~N, (A, KL,) One who devotes himself to religious services or exercises, or applies himself to acts of devotion; (S, A, K;) who possesses a knowledge of God: (T, S, K, KL:) or a learned man: (T:) or the first signifies, (M,) or signifies also, (K,) and so the second, (M,) i. q. HaborN [i. e. a learned man, or particularly of the Jews, &c.; or a good, or righteous, man]; (M, K;) and a lord, or master, of knowledge or science: or a worshipper of the Lord (Alr~ab~): (M:) or a learned man, a teacher of others, who nourishes people with the small matters of knowledge, or science, before the great: (IAar, T:) or a learned man firmly grounded in knowledge, or science, and religion: or a learned man who practices what he knows and instructs others: or one of high rank in knowledge, or science: or learned with respect to what is lawful and what is unlawful, and what is commanded and what is forbidden: (TA:) rab~aAniY~N is a rel. n. from rab~aAnN; or from Alr~ab~u meaning “ God: ” (TA, and some copies of the K:) the A and n being added to give intensiveness to the signification; (M;) or, as Sb says, to denote a special reference to the knowledge of the
Lord, as though the word signified one possessing a knowledge of the Lord exclusively of other branches of knowledge; (T;) so that it is like liHoyaAniY~N, (T, M, and so in some copies of the K,) meaning “ long-bearded, ” (T,) or “ largebearded, ” (M,) and raqabaAniY~N, “ thick-necked, ” and $aEoraAniY~N, “ having much hair: ” (T:) or it is a Syriac word; (TA, and some copies of the K;) or Hebrew; and was unknown to the [pagan] Arabs, and known only to the men of law and science: (TA:) the pl. is rab~aAniy~uwna, (T, S,) occurring in the Kur iii. 73 (S) [and v. 48 and 68].
rub~aAniY~N * : see rub~aAnN, last sentence but one.
rab~aAniy~apN * The quality denoted by the epithet rab~aAniY~N [q. v.]. (A.)

raborabN *
A herd (T, S, M, K) of oxen, (T,) [i. e.] of wild oxen (baqar AlwaHo$): (S, M, K:) or, as some say, of gazelles: or, accord. to Kr, a number of [wild] oxen together, less than ten: it has no sing., or n. un. (M.)
raAb~N * ; and its fem., with p: see rabiybN in three places.
A^arib~apN * said in the T and K to be pl. of rib~apN [q. v.]: and said by AAF to be pl. of ribaAbN.

marab~N *
A place of collecting (T, S, M, A) of people: (M, A:) a place of alighting: (M, K:) a place of abiding, or dwelling, and congregating. (M.) [Hence,] marab~u AlA_ibili The place where the camels keep, or remain. (T, S.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] fulaAnN marab~N (assumed tropical:) Such a one is a person who collects, or congregates, people. (T, S, M, K. *) [And hence,] fulaAnN marab~N libaniY fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) Such a one is an object of resort for his counsel and authority to the sons of such a one. (TA in art. jmE.) -A2- Also, and ↓ mirobaAbN, (M, K,) Land abounding with plants, or herbage; (K;) or with rib~ap [q. v.]: (TA:) or land in which there ceases not to be moisture; and so ↓ marab~apN: or ↓ mrobaAbN signifies land abounding with plants, or herbage, and with people. (M.)

murib~N * Anything keeping, or cleaving, to a thing. (M. [See its verb, 4]) You say naAqapN murib~N A she-camel keeping to, and affecting, her young one, and the stallion. (AZ, TA.) And A_ibilN maraAb~u [originally maraAbibu, pl. of murib~N,] Camels keeping in a place; remaining in it. (T, S.) And faqorN murib~N (assumed tropical:) Constant, inseparable, poverty: occurring in a trad.: or the epithet there is mulib~N. (IAth.)
marab~apN * : see marab~N.

murab~abN *
Made [or preserved] with rub~ [or inspissated juice]; (S, K;) like as muEas~alN signifies “ made [or preserved] with Easal [or honey]: ” (S:) you say zanojabiylN murab~abN and murab~FY [ginger so preserved]: and ↓ murab~abaAtN signifies Preserves, or confections, made with rub~; (S, K;) and in like manner murab~ayaAtN, except that this is from Alt~arobiyapu [inf. n. of rab~aY]. (S.) ― -b2- Also Oil of which the grain (Hab~ [perhaps a mistranscription for Hub~ i. e. jar]) whence it has been prepared, or taken, has been perfumed (↓ rub~iba): (T, TA:) or oil perfumed with sweet-smelling plants; as also ↓ marobuwbN and murab~FY. (A.)
murab~abaAtN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
mirobaAbN * : see marab~N, in two places.

marobuwbN * : see rabiybN. ― -b2- Also A slave; a bondman; syn. mamoluwkN [lit. possessed, and now particularly applied to a male white slave]. (M, K.) AlEibaAdu marobuwbuwna lil~`hi means [Mankind (lit. the servants of God) are] bondmen (mamoluwkuwna) [to God]. (M.) ― -b3- A skin for clarified butter &c. seasoned with rub~ [or inspissated juice]. (T, S.) [And A jar smeared with tar or pitch: see 1.] ― -b4- See also murab~abN.
murotab~N * One who confers a benefit, or benefits. (K.) ― -b2- And One on whom a benefit is conferred, or on whom benefits are conferred. (K.)

1 rabaA^a * , [aor.
rabaAa , inf. n. rabo'N,] He, or it, was, or became, high, or elevated: (K:) [or] he, or it, was, or became, high, or elevated, so as to overtop, or overlook, what was around or adjacent; as also ↓ ArtbA^. (M, K.) You say, rabaA^ati AlA^aroDu, (M, TA,) inf. n. rabo'N, (M,) The ground rose: and some read, in the Kur xxii. 5 and xli. 39, rabaA^ato instead of rabato; because, as Zj says, when a plant is about to appear, the earth rises thereat. (M, TA.) And you say also, rabaA^a EalaY jabalK and ↓ ArtbA^ and ↓ ArbA^ He took a high and commanding position upon a mountain, or ascended upon it, (A^a$orafa Ealayoh,) to look. (TA.) And maA Earafotu fulaAnFA liY ↓ Hat~aY A^arobaA^a I knew not such a one until he became within a commanding, or near, view of me; syn. A^a$orafa. (T.) And rabaA^a EalaY $arafK He ascended upon an eminence [to watch] lest an enemy should come unawares upon a party. (TA.) And rabaA^otu AlmarobaA^apa and ↓ AirotabaA^otuhaA I ascended upon the place of observation. (S.) And rabaA^a Alqawoma, (S, M, K, *) aor.
rabaAa , (M, K,) inf. n. rabo'N; (S, M;) and rabaA^alahumo; (T, M, K;) and ↓ AirotabaA^ahumo; (S;) He was, or became, [or acted as,] a scout to the party, (T, S, M, * K,) upon an eminence. (M.) And rabaA^a lanaA fulaAnN, and ↓ ArtbA^, Such a one was, or became, or acted as, a scout to us. (S.) ― -b2- rabaA^otu bika Eano ka*aA, aor. and inf. n. as above, means I exalted thee [or held thee] above such a thing: (M:) and rabaA^otu bika A^arofaEa AlA^amori I exalted thee [in the highest degree]: (IJ, M:) and rabaA^otu binafosiY Eano Eamali ka*aA [I held myself above the doing such a thing]: (Har p. 265:) and A_in~iY laA^arobaA^u bika Eano h`*aA AlA^amori Verily I exalt thee [or hold thee] above this thing, (S, Har ubi suprà, TA,) and do not approve of it for thee: (Har, TA:) as though properly signifying I betake myself with thee to an elevated place of observation, in honour of thee, and in care, or solicitude, for thee, and preserve thee and keep watch for thee as a scout and a watchman: (Har ubi suprà:) [this usage of the verb, as is shown in the TA, is what is meant by its being said that] rabaA^a is also syn. with rafaEa. (K.) ― -b3- rabaA^a AlmaAla He preserved, guarded, or took care of, (TA,) and put into a good, or right, state, (K, TA,) the property, or cattle. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 3. ― -b5- rabaA^a fiY AlA^amori He looked into the thing, or affair, and considered. (TA.) ― -b6- rabaA^otu fiyhi, accord. to Fr, means Ealimotu Eilomahu [lit. I knew his knowledge, or what he knew; app. meaning I tried, proved, or tested, him, and so knew what he knew]. (TA. [See the phrase laA^a xoburan~a xabaraka.]) ― -b7- maA rabaA^a raboA^ahu He did not know, or had no knowledge of, nor did he desire, him, or it: (M:) or he did not know, or had no knowledge of, and did not prepare himself for, him, or it: (Lh, M:) or he did not care for, mind, heed, or regard, him, or it: (T:) or maA rabaA^otu rabo'a fulaAnK means I did not know such a one, nor care for, mind, heed, or regard, him. (S, K. *) -A2- rabaw^uwA lahu They collected for him of every kind of food, (M, K, *) milk and dates &c. (M.) -A3- jaA='a yarobaA^o fiY mi$oyatihi He came bearing himself heavily, or sluggishly, in his gait. (M, K. * [Like yaronaA^u.]) -A4- See also what next follows.

2 rb~A^hu * , inf. n. tarobiy^apN, He made it to pass away; (K, TA;) namely, property: so in the Tekmileh: in the K, ↓ rabaA^a is likewise mentioned, in an earlier part of the art., as meaning A^a*ohaba; but the context in the K compared with that in the Tekmileh seems to show that this is a mistake. (TA.)

3 rAbA^ *
He watched, or observed, a thing; (M, K; *) as also ↓ rabaA^a and ↓ ArbA^ and ↓ ArtbA^: (TA:) he guarded (HaArasa, T, M, K) men, (M,) or a man, (T, K, *) being guarded by him. (T.) ― -b2- He was cautious of, or he feared, a thing, (T, * S, K, *) or a man; (M;) inf. n. muraAbaA^apN. (T, S. [In one of my copies of the S, rabaA^otu Al$~aYo'a marobaA^apF is erroneously put for raAbaA^otu Al$Y' muraAbaA^apF.])
4 A^arobaAa see 1, in two places, near the beginning: -A2- and see also 3.

8 ArtbA^ *
He stationed himself, or stood, upon a place such as is called marobaA^N. (T.) See also 1, in five places. -A2- And see 3.

raboA^apN * , (K,) written by El-Munáwee rabaA^apN, but it is not certain, (TA,) The [kind of leathern vessel for water called] A_idaAwap that is made of four skins; (K;) made of four skins because of its largeness. (MF.)
rabaA='N * [High ground]. You say A^aroDN laA rabaA='a fiyhaA walaA waTaA='a, with medd in each case, [A land in which is no high ground nor low ground.] (T.)
rabiYo'N * : see what next follows, in two places.

rabiyoy^pN * (T, S, M, O, K) and ↓ rabiYo'N (S, O) and
↓ murotabiY'N (T in art. rmY) A scout; (T, S, M, O, K;) but only (O, TA) such as is stationed upon a mountain or some elevated spot, (T, * O, TA,) whence he looks out: (O, TA:) [perhaps also signifying scouts; for the word TaliyEapN by which the first is explained in the S and M and O and K, and the second also in the S and O, means “ a scout ” and “ scouts: ”] pl. [of the first] rabaAyaA. (S, O.) The first is fem. because the TlyEp is also called EayonN, and Eyn is fem.: but Sb states that this last word in the sense of TlyEp is masc. and fem.; fem. originally, and masc. as being turned from [the signification of] a part [i. e. an eye] to [that of] the whole [person]. (M.) AA cites, as an ex. of ↓ rabiYo'N
faA^arosalonaA A^abaA EamorKw rabiyoy^FA
[And we sent Aboo-' Amr as a scout]: (TA:) from a poem of 'Abd-Esh-Shárik El-Juhanee. (Ham pp. 218 et seqq.)
raAbiY'u AlD~urabaA='i * [The superintendent, or supervisor, of the players at the game called Almayosir, whose place is behind them]. (TA in art. rqb.)

marobaA^N * and ↓ marobaA^apN (S, M, K) and ↓ murotabaA^N (S, K) and ↓ mirpbaA='N (TA as from the K [but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K]) An elevated place of observation, or upon which a person is stationed to watch; (S, K;) the place of the rabiyoy^ap [or scout]. (M.) ― -b2- And hence, the first of these words, (S,) or ↓ the second, (T, M,) The manaArap [or perch], (T,) or place, (S, M,) of the hawk, or falcon, (T, S, M,) upon which he stands, (S,) or upon which he mounts. (M.) A rájiz suppresses the ', saying,
muqay~adaA ↓ baAta EalaY marobaAtihi
[He passed the night upon his perch, shackled]. (T.)
marobaA^apN * and marobaApN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

marobaA='N * , (M, and so in copies of the K,) accord. to IAar, with medd and fet-h, (M,) or ↓ mirobaA='N, (M, and so in the K accord. to the TA,) the latter preferred by Th, (M,) A stair, or ladder. (IAar, M, K.)
mirobaA='N * : see marobaA^N; and marobaA='N.
murotabaA^N * : see marobaA^N.
murotabiY'N * : see rabiyoy^apN.

1 rabata * : see 2. -A2- rabita, aor.
rabata , (TK,) inf. n. rabatN, (K,) It (a thing, TK) was, or became, closed; syn. Aisotagolaqa. (K, TK.)

2 rb~t * , (T, S, M,) inf. n. tarobiytN, (T, S, K,) He fed, nourished, reared, or brought up, (T, S, M, K,) a child; (T, * S, M;) syn. rab~aY; (T, S, M, K;) as also ↓ rabata, (M,) aor.
rabita , (TK,) inf. n. rabotN; (K;) and ↓ trb~t. (TA, and Ham p. 633.) ― -b2- And rb~t, (TK,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He patted a child (K, TA, TK) repeatedly (TA) on the side in order that it might sleep. (K, TA, TK.) [See rab~ati AlmaroA^apu Sabiy~ahaA, in art. rb.]
5 tarab~ata see 2.
rubata * &c.: see rub~a, in art. rb.
rub~ata * &c.: see rub~a, in art. rb.

1 rabavahu * , aor.
rabuva , inf. n. rabovN, (Ks, ISk, T,) He hindered, withheld, restrained, or prevented, him, and retarded him; or diverted him, by occupying him otherwise; (Ks, T, TA;) as also ↓ rb~vhu: (A:) and he kept him, or held him, back: (Ks, T, TA:) and he deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him. (ISk, T.) You say, rabavahu Eano HaAjatihi, (Sh, T, S, A, * K, *) and A^amorihi, (T, M,) aor. as above, (T, S, M,) and so the inf. n.; (T, S, M, A, K;) and ↓ rb~vhu, (M,) inf. n. tarobiyvN; (K;) He hindered, withheld, restrained, or debarred, him; (Sh, T, S, M, A, K;) and turned, or diverted, him; (M;) from the thing that he wanted, (Sh, T, S, A, K,) and from his affair, (T, M,) by pretexts. (T.) -A2- rabava He was, or became, slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward. (Sh, TA.) [See also 5.]
2 rb~vhu * : see above, in two places. Also He made him to tarry, stay, or stop. (M.)

5 trb~v *
He tarried, stayed, or stopped, (S, K,) in his journeying. (S.)
8 A_irotabava see the next paragraph.

9 Arbv~wA *
They became separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered. (TA.) And Arbv~t Alganamu The sheep, or goats, became dispersed, or scattered. (A, TA.) And Arbv~wA fiY manaAzilihimo, and raA^oyihimo, They became separated, or disunited, in their places of alighting or abode, and their judgment or opinion. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Arbv~ A^amoruhumo, (S, TA,) or ↓ AirobaAv~ (K, TA,) or ↓ AirobaA^av~a, (CK,) which last has been heard thus pronounced with ' to avoid the conjunction of two quiescent letters, (MF,) (assumed tropical:) Their affair was, or became, weak, and slow, tardy, or dilatory, so that they became separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered: (S, K:) or the first (Arbv~ Amrhm) signifies, (T, M, A,) or signifies also, (K, * TA,) (tropical:) their affair, or state of affairs, was, or became, discomposed, dissipated, disorganized, disordered, or broken up; (T, M, A, K; *) as also ↓ Artbv. (K.)

11 AirobaAv~a * , (K, TA,) or ↓ AirobaA^av~a, (CK,) He was, or became, hindered, withheld, restrained, or debarred. (K, TA.) You say, danaA fulaAnN vum~a A@robaAv~a Such a one drew near, or approached: then became hindered, withheld, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 9.
Q. Q. 4 AirobaA^av~a * : see 11: ― -b2- and see also 9.

rabiyvN *
i. q. ↓ marobuwvN, (M, K,) Hindered, withheld, &c.: (M, * K:) the former, (T, M,) and the latter also, (M,) applied to an affair, or an event. (T, M.) One says, jaroyuhu kariyvN waA^amoruhu rabiyvN [app. meaning His running is attended with difficulty, and the accomplishment of his affair is hindered]: (T: [in a copy of the A, as cited in the TA, Hizobuhu is put in the place of jaroyuhu, which appears to be the right reading, from what here follows:]) and
jaroYN kariyvN A^amoruhu rabiyvu
[app. meaning A running attended with difficulty, the affair of which is hindered]: (M:) kariyvN is [here] syn. with makoruwvN. (T.) -A2- It is also said to signify The jir~iyv [or eel]; and so ↓ rabiyvapN: and in the " Jámi" of El-Ghooree, ↓ rib~iyvaY with kesr to the r and with teshdeed of the b, is said to mean a species of fish. (Mgh.)

rabiyvapN * , (T, S, M, K,) a subst. from rabavahu signifying as expl. in the second sentence of this art., (T,) and ↓ rib~iyvaY (T, S, M, K,) [in like manner a subst.] from rabavahu signifying as expl. in the first sentence of this art., (T,) A thing, or an event, that hinders, withholds, restrains, or prevents, one [from a thing that he wants, and from his affair; and that turns, or diverts, one therefrom; and that deceives, or deludes, one]: (S, K:) or both signify deceit, or delusion; [in which sense, accord, to the TA, the former word is expl. in the K, but it is not so in my MS. copy of the K nor in the CK;] and hindrance, restraint, or prevention: (M, TA:) pl. of the former rabaAy^ivu. (TA.) You say, faEala *`lika lahu rabiyvapF and ↓ rib~iyvaY He did that to him from a motive of deceit, or delusion, and hindrance, restraint, or prevention. (M.) And A_in~amaA qulotu *`lika rabiyvapF min~iY I said that only from a motive of deceit, or delusion, on my part. (ISk, T.) It is said in a trad., taEotarDu Al$~ayaATiynu Aln~aAsa yawoma AljumuEapi biAl~arbaAy^ivi, meaning [The devils go forth against men indiscriminately, on Friday,] with the means of hindering them, or withholding them, from prayer: (M:) or A_i*aA kaAna yawomu AljumuEapi baEava A_iboliysu junuwdahu A_ilaY Aln~aAsi faA^axa*uwA Ealayohimo baAlr~abaAy^ivi, i. e. [When Friday is come, Iblees sends forth his forces to men, and] they remind them of the wants that hinder, or withhold, them [from the prayers of that day]: (S:) or, as some relate it, ↓ yaromuwna Aln~aAsa biAlt~araAbiyvi, which is said by El-Khattábee to be of no account; but it may mean [they assail men with] hindrances; for taraAbiyvu may be pl. of ↓ tarobiyvapN, inf. n. un. of rab~avahu. (MF.) -A2- See also rabiyvN last sentence.
rib~iyvaY * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places: -A2- and see also rabiyvN last sentence.

raAbivN *
Slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward. (TA.)
tarobiyvapN * , and its pl. taraAbiyvu: see rabiyvapN last sentence but one.
marobuwvN * : see rabiyvN.

1 rabiHa fiY tijaAratihir * (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,)
aor.
rabaHa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. riboHN (Mgh, Msb, TA) and rabaHN and rabaAHN, (Msb, TA,) He gained; or made gain, or profit; in his traffic; (MA, KL, TK;) i. q. Aisota$af~a (S, K) or A^afoDala. (Az, Msb.) The Arabs say to a man when he enters upon traffic, biAlr~abaAHi waAls~amaAHi [With gaining and liberality.] (TA.) ― -b2- And rabiHato tijaAratuhu (tropical:) (A, Msb, TA) His traffic brought him gain, or profit. (Msb, TA.)
2 rb~Hhu * : see 4. -A2- Also rb~H, inf. n. tarobiyHN, He took to himself (Ait~axa*a) an ape (rub~aAH, TA) in his place of abode. (K.)

3 A^aEoTaAhu maAlFA muraAbaHapF *
He gave him property on the condition that the gain, or profit, should be [divided] between them two. (TA.) And biEotuhu AlmataAEa muraAbaHapF (S, * Msb) I sold him the commodity naming a certain gain, or profit, for every portion of the price: (Msb:) you say, biEotuhu Als~iloEapa muraAbaHapF EalaY kul~i Ea$arapi daraAhima dirohamN [I sold him the commodity on the condition of my receiving as gain, or profit, upon every ten dirhems, a dirhem]: (TA:) and Ai$otarayotuhu minohu maraAbaHapF I bought it of him in like manner: (Msb, TA:) the gain, or profit, must be named. (TA.) -A2- See also 4.

4 ArbH fiY tijaAratihi *
He found a profitable market in [or for] his traffic. (Az, Msb.) -A2- ArbHhu He gave him gain, or profit: (Mgh, Msb:) ↓ rb~Hhu we have not heard; (Mgh;) [i. e.] rab~aHotuhu as meaning I gave him gain, or profit, has not been transmitted [from the Arabs of classical times]. (Msb.) You say, A^arobaHotuhu EalaY siloEatihi, (S,) or EalayohaA ↓ raAbaHotuhu, (A, K,) or both, (TA,) I gave him a gain, or profit, upon his commodity. (S, A, K, TA.) And ArbHhu bimataAEihi [He made him to gain by his commodity]. (TA.) And ArbH A@ll~`hu bayoEatahu [God made, or may God make, his sale to be productive of gain, or profit]. (S and K in art. rjE.) -A3- Also ArbH He slaughtered for his guests young weaned camels; (K, TA;) which are called rabaH. (TA.) -A4- And ArbH Aln~aAqapa He milked the she-camel in the early morning, or between the prayer of daybreak and sunrise, and at midday. (K.)

5 trb~H *
He sought gains, or profits. (A.) -A2- He (a man, TA) was, or became, confounded or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (K.)

riboHN * and ↓ rabaHN and ↓ rabaAHN [all originally inf. ns.] Gain, or profit; (IAar, S, A, K, and Mgh in explanation of the first and last;) increase [obtained] in traffic; (TA;) excess, or surplus, [obtained,] above the capital [expended]; wherefore it is also termed $if~N. (Ksh and Bd in explanation of the first in ii. 15.) [Hence,] ↓ Albir~u xayoru tijaArapK rabaAHFA (tropical:) [Piety is the best traffic in respect of gain, or profit.] (A.)

rabaHN * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Horses and camels that are brought from one place to another for sale. (K.) ― -b3- And Fat, as a subst. (S, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Khufáf Ibn-Nudbeh, (TA,)
qarawoA A^aDoyaAfahumo rabaHFA bibuH~K
yEiy$u bifaDolihin~a AlHaY~u sumori
[as though meaning They entertained their guests with fat, on the superabundant remains of which the tribe lived, by means of tawny-coloured gaming-arrows whereby the lots that determined who should afford the entertainment were divided]: (S, * TA:) but [this is inconsistent with the affixed pronoun relating to rbHA, wherefore], in this case, as some say, (S, TA,) it means young weaned camels; (S, K, TA;) [as a quasi-pl. n.;] and its sing. is ↓ raAbiHN; (K;) like as that of HarasN is HaArisN; and that of xaAdimN xadamN: (TA:) or a young weaned camel; [like rubaHN;] and its pl. is ribaAHN: (K:) or it means here the gain, or profit, obtained by means of the game called Alamyosir. (S, TA.) ― -b4- See also the next paragraph.

rubaHN *
A young weaned camel; (S, K:) app. a dial. var. of rubaEN. (S.) [See also rabaHN and rub~aAHN.] ― -b2- A lamb, or kid: (ISd, TA in art. nSH:) or the latter: (K;) as also ↓ rub~aAHN. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- See also rub~aAHN, first sentence. ― -b4- Also A certain bird, (S, K,) resembling the raAmij [which is an owl employed for catching hawks]: or, accord. to Kr, the word is ↓ rabaHN, and signifies a certain bird resembling the zaAg[or rook]. (TA.)

rabaAHN * : see riboHN in two places. -A2- Also A certain small animal, resembling the cat. (So in many copies of the S.) F observes that J says, Alr~abaAHu duwayob~apN yujolabu minohaA AlkaAfuwru; and that baladN has been substituted as an amendment for dwyb~p in some of the copies [of the S]; but that each of these readings is erroneous: for yjlb we find [in copies of the S] in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeyà and that of Aboo-Sahl yuHolabu, with the unpointed H; and the substitution of bld for dwybap was made by IKtt: in the copies of the S, moreover, we find minohu instead of minohaA: and IB says that the passage in J's original copy, in his own handwriting, runs thus: Alr~abaAHu A^ayoDFA duwayob~apN kaAls~in~awri yujolabu minohu AlkaAfuwru. (TA.) [But I find that, in five copies of the S, between Alsn~wr and yjlb, occur the words waAlr~abaAHu A^ayoDFA baladN, or balodapN or A@somu baladK: and I think it most probable that J intended to have introduced these or similar words, and therefore wrote minohu instead of minohaA; meaning that rbAH is the appellation of a certain small animal, resembling the cat: and that AlrbAH is also the name of a country or town from which camphor is brought: this country or town is said in a marginal note in a copy of the S to be in India.]
rubaAHN * : see rub~aAHN.
rabiyHN * : see raAbiHN.

rabaAHiY~N *
A certain kind of camphor: (K:) so called in relation to a certain country, or town, agreeably with what is [said to have been] asserted by J, or to a certain king named rabaAHN, who applied his mind to this kind of camphor, and discovered it. (TA.)

rub~aAHN * (A' Obeyd, S, A, L, K) and ↓ rubaAHN, (A, TA,) the latter of the dial. of El-Yemen, (TA,) and ↓ rubaHN, (L, TA,) The male ape; (S, A, L, K;) [simia caudata, clunibus nudis: (Forskål, "Descr. Animalium" &c., p. iii.:)] or the young one of an ape: (TA:) or apes [as a coll. gen. n.]: (TA in art. nSH, in explanation of the last, which is there said to be originally rubaAHN:) pl. of the first rabaAbiyHu. (TA.) One says A^amolaHu mino rub~aAHK and rubaAHK, meaning [Prettier] than the ape. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] rub~u rub~aAHK (Lth, A, K) or rubaAHK (A) A sort of dates (Lth, A, K) of ElBasrah. (Lth.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) accord. to some, (TA,) rub~aAHN signifies A small young weaned camel, (K,) and small young camels, syn. HaA$iyapN, (TA,) slender in the bones and meagre in the body: (K:) but A Heyth asks, How can it mean small young weaned camels, seeing that a poet applies to it the epithet vaniY~, and the vnY~ is five years old? and Khidásh Ibn-Zuheyr, in a verse cited by Sh, speaks of a rb~AH breathing hard in labour, in order that her young one might come forth. (TA.) ― -b4- See also rubaHN.

matojarN raAbiHN * and ↓ rabiyHN (tropical:) Trafficking in which one makes gain, or profit; (TA;) and so tijaArapN raAbiHapN; (T, S, A, * Msb, K;) [lucrative, or profitable, traffic;] a phrase like layolN naAy^imN and saAhirN meaning "a night in which one sleeps" and "in which one is wakeful:" (Az, TA:) and bayoEN ↓ murobiHN a sale in which one makes gain, or profit. (TA.) And maAlN raAbiHN (assumed tropical:) Property having gain, or profit: rAbH in this case being like laAbinN and taAmirN: occurring in a trad.: but some read [raAy^iHN, or, more probably, raAy^ijN, from raAja,] with Y [or rather ']. (TA.) ― -b2- See also rabaHN.
murobiHN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 rabada * , (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
rabuda , (S, L,) or
rabida , (Msb,) inf. n. rubuwdN, (S, L, K,) or rabodN, (Msb,) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) bimakaAnK in a place. (S, M, L, Msb.) -A2- rabada, (IAar, S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
rabuda , (M,) inf. n. rabodN, (T, M, Msb,) He confined; kept close, or within certain limits; or shut up; (IAar, T, S, M, Msb, K;) him, or it; (IAar, S, M, Msb;) or camels [&c.]. (M.) ― -b2- He tied camels. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (TA,) or ↓ rb~d, (so accord. to the TT, as from the T,) [or rbd Alt~amora,] He stowed, or packed, dates, or the dates, in rabaAy^id, i. e. oblong pieces of matting [of woven palm-leaves]. (AA, T, TA.) [From what here follows, and from the usage of the part. n. raAbidN (q. v.), it appears that the former verb is correct; but the latter may be so too, or may have an intensive signification.]
You say also, rabadotu tamoraka rabodFA HasanFA I stowed thy dates in the mirobad in a good manner. (A.)

2 rab~ada see 1. -A2- rab~adato, said of a ewe or she-goat, She secreted milk in her udder a little before her bringing forth (A^aDoraEato), and her udder exhibited patches, or shining hues, of black (S, M, A) and white: (S:) or her udder exhibited patches, or shining hues, of faint blackness and whiteness: (T:) a dial. var. of ram~adato [q. v.]. (S.)

4 Arbd *
He (a man) marred, or wasted, or ruined, his property, and his goods. (M, TA. [See also Armd.])

5 trb~d *
It (the udder of a ewe or goat) exhibited patches, or shining hues, of black (M, A, L) and white, (L,) or of faint blackness and whiteness. (T.) He, or it, was, or became, marked, in oblong shapes, (kaAna muwal~aEFA,) with black and white; (TA;) and so ↓ Arbd~ and ↓ ArbAd~: (K, TA:) or all three signify it became of a red hue in which was blackness; (M and L and TA in explanation of the first and second, and TA in explanation of the third also;) said of a man's face, on an occasion of anger: (M, L:) or, said of a man's face, (S, TA,) trb~d signifies it became altered, (S, K, TA,) by reason of anger; (S;) and so ↓ Arbd~ and Armd~: (As, T:) or it became like the colour of ashes; as also Armd~: (TA:) or was as though parts of it became black, on an occasion of anger: (T, TA:) and ↓ Arbd~, said, in a trad., of the Prophet's face when revelations came down to him, it became altered to a dusty hue: (TA:) and trb~d said of a man's colour, it assumed various hues; appearing at one time red, and another time yellow, and another time A^axoDar [here meaning a dark, or an ashy, dustcolour], by reason of anger. (ISh, TA.) ― -b2- Also He (a man, S) looked sternly, austerely, or morosely. (S, K.) ― -b3- And trb~dt Als~imaA='u The sky became clouded. (S, M, A, K.)
9 Arbd~ * , (S, M, K,) or Arbd~ lawonuhu, (T,) He (an ostrich, S, M) was, or became, of the colour termed rubodapN; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ ArbAd~. (K.) ― -b2- See also 5, in three places.
11 A_irobaAod~a see what next precedes: ― -b2- and see also 5.
rabodN * or rabadN: see rubodapN.

rubadN * [app. pl. of rubodapN] The diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, (firinod,) of a sword: (S, M, A, K:) of the dial, of Hudheyl. (M.) You say sayofN *uw rubadK A sword [having such marks;] xa$iybapN in which one sees what resembles dust, or the tracks of ants. (S, L.) [See an ex. in a verse of Sakhr, cited voce rubodapN.]

wuroqapN *
A colour like rumodapN, inclining to blackness; as also rumodapN: (T:) or dust-colour: (M:) or a colour inclining to that of dust: (S, K:) or a colour between blackness and dust-colour: (AO, TA:) or ash-colour; like rumodapN: (A:) or blackness mixed with dinginess, or duskiness: (Msb:) or, in the ostrich, (M, L,) as also ↓ rabadN, (M,) or ↓ rabodN, (L,) a mixed black colour: or, accord. to Lh, entire blackness. (M, L.) Also Dust-colour in the lip. (M, L.) [See also A^arobadu.]
rabiydN * Dates (tamorN) laid one upon another (S, M, K) in an earthen pot, (S,) or in jars, (M,) and then sprinkled with water. (S, M, K.) [See also rabiyTN.]
rabiydapN * The [kind of repository termed] qimaTor [q. v.] of the [records termed] maHaADir, (K, TA,) i.e. sijil~aAt. (TA.) ― -b2- See also rabaAy^idu.

rubayodaAnN *
A certain plant. (M, L.)
rabaAy^idu * [a pl. of which the sing. (probably ↓ rabiydapN) is not indicated] Oblong pieces of matting [of woven palm-leaves], in which dates are stowed, or packed. (AA, T.)

raAbidN *
One who reposits, stows, lays up, keeps, preserves, or guards, property &c.; a treasurer: (IAar, T, K:) fem. with p. (IAar, T.)

A^arobadu * , and its fem. rabodaA='u, applied to an ostrich, Of the colour termed rubodapN; (S, M, A;) and so the former applied to dates (tamorN): (A:) accord. to Lh, (M,) the latter, applied to an ostrich, (T, M,) as also ramodaA='u, (T,) signifies black; (T, M;) entirely: (M:) or, (T, M,) as he says in one place, (M,) having, in its blackness, specks of white or red: (T, M:) pl. rubodN. (S.) Hence A^arobadu meaning A male ostrich. (T, L.) Also the fem., applied to a ewe (Msb, TA) or she-goat, (T, S, K,) to the latter specially, (S,) Speckled, and marked in the place of the girdle with red: (T, L:) or speckled with red and white or black: (L, TA:) or black, speckled with red (S, Msb, K) and white. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A man, and a woman, having a dusty hue in the lips. (M, L.) ― -b3- AlA^arobadu also signifies A species of serpent, (T, M, K, * TA,) of a foul, malignant, or noxious, nature, (T, K,) that bites so that the face in consequence alters to an ashy hue or the like (yatarab~adu), (M, [but this addition in the M seems to be founded upon a mistranscription in a passage in the T immediately following, but not relating to, what is said of this serpent,]) or that bites camels. (TA.) ― -b4- And The lion; as also ↓ Almutarab~idu. (K.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] daAhiyapN rabodaA='u (tropical:) An abominable calamity. (S, A, K. *) And A^umuwrN rubodN (assumed tropical:) Black calamities. (M.) ― -b6- And EaAmN A^arobadu (tropical:) A year of drought. (A.)

mirobadN * , a subst. like miTobaxN [q v.], (Sb, M,) from the trans. v. rabada, (Msb, TA,) [properly A thing with which one confines, &c.: and hence,] a place of confinement: (K:) [pl. maraAbidu. And particularly] Anything with which camels are confined; (As, T;) and also sheep or goats: (TA:) a place in which camels (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb) and other animals (S, Mgh) are confined (T, S, M, A, * Mgh) or stationed. (Msb.) In the phrase EaSaA mirobadK, used by a poet, the latter word is said to signify A piece of wood, or a staff, that is put across the breasts of camels to prevent them from going forth: (M:) or, accord. to As, by that word is meant a staff put across at the entrance [of an enclosure] to prevent the camels from going forth; wherefore it is thus called: but others disapprove of this; and say that the poet means [by the phrase] a staff put across at the entrance of the mirobad; not that the staff is a mirobad. (T.) ― -b2- Also The place of dates, (T, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) in which they are put to dry (S, A) in the sun; (A;) in the dial. of El-Medeeneh; (S;) i. q. misoTaHN (S, Msb) in the dial. of El-Yemen, (TA in art. sTH,) and jariynN (T, S, Mgh, K) in the dial. of Nejd: (S:) or mirobadu Alt~amori signifies the jariyn of dates, [i. e. the place] in which they are put, after the cutting, in order that they may dry: (M:) accord. to A 'Obeyd, mirobadN and jariynN in this sense are both of the dial. of El-Hijáz, and A^anodarN of that of Syria, and bayodarN of El-' Irák. (T.) ― -b3- Also A court, or yard, or spacious place, behind houses, of which use is made. (M.) ― -b4- And The like of a Hujorap [i. e. a chamber, or an upper chamber,] in a house. (M.)

murobad~N *
Marked, in oblong shapes, (muwal~aEN,) with black and white. (Aboo-' Adnán, K.) [See also its verb, 9.]
Almutarab~idu * : see A^arobadu.

1 rabi*a * , [aor.
raba*a ,] (M,) inf. n. raba*N, (Lth, T, M, K,) He was, or became, light, or active, (Lth, T, M, K,) in the arm, or hand, (M, K,) in working or in doing a thing, and in the leg, or foot, in walking or going, (M,) or in the legs in walking or going, and in the fingers in working or in doing a thing. (Lth, T.) And rabi*ato yaduhu biAlqidaAHi aor.
raba*a , inf. n. as above, His hand was light, or active, with the qdAH [or gaming-arrows]. (S, A, * L, K.)
raba*N * : see ribo*apN: ― -b2- and see also raba*apN.

rabi*N *
Light, or active, (Lth, T, S, M, K,) in the arm, or hand, in working or in doing a thing, and in the leg, or foot, in walking or going, (M,) or in the legs in walking or going, (Lth, T, S, K,) as also rabi*u AlqawaAy^imi; (A;) and light, or active, in the fingers in working or in doing a thing, (Lth, T,) as also rabi*u AlA^aSaAbiEi fiY Eamalihi. (A.) And A quick, or fleet, horse. (T.) And farasN lahu qawaAy^imu rabi*AtN A horse having light, or active, legs. (A.) ― -b2- jaA='a rabi*a AlEinaAni means (assumed tropical:) He came alone, put to flight. (IAar, M, K. *) But the saying of Hishám El-Mara-ee,
gadaApa tarakotahu rabi*a AlEinaAni
is explained by IAar as meaning (assumed tropical:) [In the morning] when thou leftest him exempt from satire. (M.) ― -b3- Accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, (T,) livapN rabi*N means A gum having little flesh. (T, K.)

ribo*apN * (T, S, M, A, K) and ↓ raba*apN, (S. A, K,) the former of which is said to be the more chaste, (TA,) The wisp of wool, (T, S, M, A, K,) or piece of rag, (Ks, T, M,) with which one smears with tar a camel (Ks, T, S, M, A, K) that is
scabby or mangy: (Ks, T:) of the dial. of Temeem: (M:) also called wafiyEapN [and vamalapN]. (T.) One says, kaA^an~a EiroDahu ribo*apu AlhaAniY'i [As though his honour, or reputation, were the rb*p of him who smears camels with tar]; and in like manner, ribo*apu AlHaAy^iDi [explained below]. (A.) And lam~aA A^asomaEahumu AlHaq~a naba*uwhu kamaA yanobi*u AlhaAniY'u Alr~ibo*apa [When he made them to hear, or told them, the truth, they rejected it, like as he who smears camels with tar rejects the rb*p after using it]. (A.) ― -b2- Also The piece of rag with which the goldsmith polishes ornaments. (S, L, K, and Msb in explanation of the latter word.) ― -b3- And the former word, The rag of a menstruating woman; (M, A, L, K;) the thing that the menstruating woman throws away. (Lth, T.) ― -b4- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) Anything unclean, dirty, or filthy, (M, L, K, TA,) and stinking. (TA.) ― -b5- And [hence likewise,] (assumed tropical:) A man in whom is no good or goodness, devoid of goodness, or worthless, (M, K,) and, accord. to Lh, stinking. (M.) ― -b6- Also The stopper (SimaAm) of a bottle, or flask. (IAar, T, M, K.) ― -b7- Also, (M, L, K,) and ↓ raba*apN (Fr, A 'Obeyd, S, M, L,) of which latter ↓ raba*N is pl., or rather a quasi-pl. n., (M,) [or more properly a coll. gen. n., raba*apN being its n. un.,] A single one of the raba* meaning tufts of dyed wool (Euhuwn) which are hung upon the necks of camels; (Fr, A 'Obeyd, S, L;) and which are likewise called ↓ maraAbi*u (A, TA,) an irreg. pl. like maHaAsinu [and malaAmaHu &c.]; (TA;) or which are hung upon a she-camel: (L:) or a tuft of dyed wool (EhonapN) which is hung upon the ear of a camel (M, L, K) &c., (K,) [i. e.,] upon the ear of a he-camel and she-camel, or of a sheep or goat. (M, L.) ― -b8- The pl. of ribo*apN in all the senses expl. above is rib*N and ribaA*N (M, L, K.)

raba*apN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Also The Ea*abap [app. as meaning the EilaAqap, or suspensory thong in the handle,] of a whip: (K:) [n. un. of ↓ raba*N: for you say] sawoTN *uw raba*K meaning A whip having thongs in the fore part of its jaloz [or handle]. (En-Nadr, TA.) -A2- Also Difficulty, or distress. (IAar, T, K.) So in the saying, kun~aA fiY raba*apK faA@nojalato Ean~aA [We were in difficulty, or distress, and it became removed, or cleared away, from us]. (IAar, T.)
*uw rabi*aAtK * [in one of my copies of the S raba*aAtK, and in a copy of the A rabo*aAtK,] (tropical:) One who makes many mistakes in his speech. (S, A, L, K.) [See also mirobaA*N, below.]
raba*aAniY~N * : see mirobaA*N.

rabaA*iyapN * (assumed tropical:) Evil (ISk, T, S, M, K) that occurs between, or among, people. (ISk, T, S, * M. *) You say, bayona Alqawomi rabaA*iyapN Between, or among, the people is evil. (S, M. *)
mirobaA*N * and ↓ raba*aAniY~N (assumed tropical:) One who talks much, and irrationally, or erroneously, (K, TA,) making many mistakes in his speech. (TA.)
maraAbi*u * : see ribo*apN.
