1 rabaSa bifulaAnK * , or biAl$~aYo'i: see 5. -A2- rabaSaniY (K) A thing, or an affair, or an event, put me in expectation. (TA.)

5 trb~S *
He expected; or awaited: (S:) he tarried; or tarried expecting. (IAth.) You say trb~S AlA^amora He looked for, expected, awaited, or waited for, the thing, or event. (Msb.) And trb~S bihi Al$~aYo'a, (M,) or AlA^amora, (Msb,) He looked for, expected, awaited, or waited for, the thing, or event, to befall him, or betide him. (M, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [ix. 52], halo tarab~aSuwna binaA A_il~aA A_iHodaY A@loHusonayayoni [Do ye look for, &c., aught save one of the two best things (namely victory or martyrdom) to betide us?]. (M.) And a poet says,
tarab~aSo bihaA rayoba Almanuwni laEal~ahaA
tuTal~aqu yawomFA A^awo yamuwtu HaliyluhaA
[Wait thou for the vicissitudes of fortune to befall her: perhaps she may be divorced some day, or her husband may die]. (TA.) You say also, trb~S bisiloEatihi AlgalaA='a [He looked for, &c., a time of dearness for his commodity, or article of merchandise]. (A.) And, [elliptically,) trb~S bifulaAnK, (K,) or biAl$~aYo'i; (M;) and bihi ↓ rabaSa, (M, A, K,) aor.
rabuSa , (TK,) inf. n. raboSN; (M, A, K;) He looked for, expected, awaited, or waited for, [something] good or evil to befall, or betide, (M, A, K,) such a one, (A, K,) or the thing: (M:) or trb~F biAl$~aYo'a signifies he looked for, expected, awaited, or waited for, a day for the thing. (Lth.)

ruboSapN *
An expecting; an awaiting; a waiting: (AHát, S, A, Msb, K:) a tarrying; or tarrying in expectation. (M.) You say, liY fiY mataAEiY ruboSapN [I have to endure an expecting, &c., with respect to my goods, or commodities; app. meaning, I have to wait for a favourable opportunity to sell them]. (S, A.) And liY biAlbaSorapi ruboSapN [I have to endure an expecting, or a waiting, in ElBasrah]. (AHát, A.) And liY EalaY h`*aA AlA^amori ruboSapN [I have to endure a tarrying, or a tarrying in expectation, for, or on account of, this thing, or affair]. (M.) ― -b2- Also The period that is assigned to a husband when he has been pronounced incapable of sexual intercourse with his wife; so that if he go in to her [it is well with him, and he remains her husband]; but if not, a separation is made between them: so in the saying, A^aqaAmati A@lomaroA^apu ruboSatahaA fiY bayoti zawojihaA [The woman abode during the period so assigned to her husband in the house, or tent, of her husband]. (ISk, K.) [In like manner ruboDapN (perhaps a mistranscription) is explained in the A and TA in art. rbD: and the period is there said to be a year.]
marobuwSN * , applied to a man, (K,) Put in expectation. (TK.)
mutarab~iSu * One who withholds, or collects and withholds, wheat or the like, waiting for a time of dearness; syn. muHotakrN. (S.)

1 rabaDa * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
rabiDa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. rubuwDN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and raboDN (Msb, K) and raboDapN, (K,) [the last an inf. n. of un.,] said of the sheep and goat, (S, A, Mgh, K,) and of the gazelle, (S, A,) and of the ox-kind, and the horse, (S,) or beast, (Msb,) and of the dog, (S, A,) [signifying He lay down, or laid himself down, upon his breast,] is like baraka said of a camel, (S, Msb, K,) and javama said of a bird, (S, TA,) or jalasa said of a man. (Mgh.) Said of a man, it means [(assumed tropical:) He lay down: and he sat: or] he sat upon his knees: and it may also mean he sat upon his thighs and his buttocks. (Har p. 172.) [And hence, (assumed tropical:) He remained fixed, or stationary, like an animal lying upon its breast; as is shown by what here follows: whence a signification of rab~aDa, q. v.] The saying of Mohammad to Ed- Dahhák, when he sent him to his people, A_i*aA A^atayotahumo faA@robiDo fiY daArihimo ZaboyFA, means When thou comest to them, remain in their abode in security, or without fear, like the gazelle in his covert: (IAar, ISd, K:) or trust them not, but be vigilant, like a wild animal, ready to spring up, for thou wilt be in the midst of the unbelievers; (Az, ISd, K; *) so, if anything induce in thee suspicion, thou mayest flee from them like the gazelle: (Az, ISd, TA:) accord. to each interpretation, ZbyA is in the accus. case as a denotative of state; the subst. being put in the place of the act. part. n., as though for mataZab~iyFA: the former of the two explanations is said to be the more agreeable with the circumstances of the case. (TA.) You say also, rabaDa AlA^asadu EalaY fariysatihi, and Alqironu EalaY qironihi, The lion laid himself down upon his breast (baraka) on his prey, and the adversary on his adversary. (K.) ― -b2- He (a beast) lodged, and abode, in a place. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became heavy, and slept, stretched upon the ground. (TA.) ― -b4- rabaDa Eani Alganami, (S, A, K,) inf. n. rubuwDN, (S,) (tropical:) He (a ram) abstained from tupping, or covering the ewes, and avoided it, (S, A, * K, *) or them, (TA,) being fatigued: (S:) or was unable to cover them: (K:) one does not say, of a ram, jafara. (S.) You say also of a ewe when she is pregnant, qado rubiDa EanohaA. (Ibn- 'Abbád, A.) And you say of a man, rabaDa Eano maEaAliY AlA^umuwri (assumed tropical:) He abstained, or held back, from seeking the means of acquiring eminence, or nobility. (TA.) ― -b5- rabaDa All~ayolu (A, K) (tropical:) The night cast its darkness [lit. itself (expl. by A^aloqaY bnafosihi) upon the earth]. (K.) -A2- rabaDahu, aor.
rabiDa and
rabuDa , (IAar, O, K,) but the latter aor. was afterwards rejected by IAar, (TA,) He betook himself, or repaired, to him for lodging, covert, or refuge. (IAar, O, K.) -A3- rabaDatohu, aor.
rabiDa , and IAar is related to have said
rabuDa also, but afterwards to have retracted it, (tropical:) She (a wife, or sister, or other woman,) undertook, or managed, his affairs, and gave him lodging, or refuge: (TA:) she was to him [as though she were] a rabaD, or place of abode: like A^abawotuhu “ I was to him a father, ” and A^amamotuhu “ I was to him a mother. ” (A, TA.) [The aor. occurs in the K, in the phrase tarobiDu zawojahaA: thus in the TA:
in the CK, turab~iDu: in the L, tarobuDu; and thus also the aor. is written in a copy of the A.]

2 rab~aDa see 4. ― -b2- rab~aDotuhu biAlmakaAni, inf. n. tarobiyDN, (assumed tropical:) I fixed him, or made him to remain fixed, in the place. (TA.) ― -b3- rb~D Als~iqaA='a biAlmaA='i, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) [He made the skin to cleave to the ground with water; i. e.] he put into the skin as much water as covered and concealed its bottom: (K, * TA:) mentioned by Sgh, from Ibn- 'Abbád. (TA.)

4 ArbD *
He made a sheep, or goat, [&c., (see 1,)] to lie down upon his breast; (S, K;) as also ↓ rb~D, inf. n. tarobiyDN. (TA.) ― -b2- A^arobaDahumo (tropical:) It (a vessel, S, A, K, and beverage, or wine, A, TA) satisfied their thirst so that they became heavy, and slept, stretched upon the ground: (S, * A, * K:) (tropical:) it (milk) satiated them. (TA.) ― -b3- ArbDt Al$~amosu (tropical:) The sun became vehemently hot, (S, A, K,) so as to make the gazelle and the sheep or goat, (S,) or the wild animals, (A,) to lie down upon their breasts: (S, A:) or became still, like a beast lying upon its breast, having attained its utmost height and not begun to descend. (O.) ― -b4- ArbD A^aholahu, (O, K,) and A^aSoHaAbahu, (O,) (assumed tropical:) He undertook, or managed, the expenses of his family, (O, K,) and of his companions; (O;) syn. qaAma bnafaqatihimo: (O, K:) so says Ibn- 'Abbád. (TA.)
raboDN * : see rabaDN.

ruboDN * : see rabaDN, in five places. ― -b2- Also, accord. to Ks, (S,) and As, (Sgh, TA,) The middle of a thing: (S, Sgh, K:) but this is disapproved by Sh. (T, TA.) ― -b3- And A collection of trees of the kinds called TaloH and samur: (K:) or a collection of abundant and dense trees. (TA.)
riboDN * : see rabiyDN: in three places.

rabaDN * The lodging-place of sheep or goats; (S, A, * K;) because they lie therein upon their breasts; and in like manner of wild animals: (TA:) the nightly lodging-place of sheep or goats: (Msb:) and ↓ marobiDN signifies the same: (S, * A, Mgh, Msb:) pl. of the former A^arobaADN: (S, A, * TA:) and of the latter maraAbiDu: (S, K: *) the mrAbD of sheep or goats are like the maEaATin of camels. (S.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A place of abode: a place of abode of a people by itself: (A, TA:) pl. as above. (A.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Anything to which a man betakes himself, or repairs, for lodging, covert, or refuge, (ISk, S, A, * Msb, K,) and at which, or with which, he finds rest, or ease; (K;) such as a house or tent, (S, A, K,) and the like, (S, K,) and a wife, (ISk, S, A, Msb,) or relations, (ISk, A, Msb,) or a family, and a relation, and property, (K,) and sheep or goats, and means of subsistence, and food; (TA;) and hence, (S,) milk which sustains a man, and suffices him for food: (S, K: *) pl. as above: (K:) rabaDN and ↓ raboDN and ↓ ruboDN (IAar, Sgh, K) and ↓ rubuDN (K) are applied to a wife liA^an~ahaA tarobiDu zawojahaA, (so in copies of the K and in the TA, but in the CK turab~iDu,) i. e. because she undertakes, or manages, the affairs of her husband, and gives him lodging, or refuge; (TA;) or because she fixes him, (turab~iDuhu, i. e. tuvab~ituhu,) so that he does not quit his place: (L, TA:) or to the mother; or the sister; who undertakes, or manages, the affairs of (tuEaz~ibu [so in copies of the K and in the TA, in the latter of which it is thus explained, but in the CK tuqar~ibu,]) her relation. (K.) A poet says,
jaA='a Al$~itaA='u walam~aA A^at~axi*o rabaDFA
yaA wayoHa kaf~aY~a mino Hafori AlqaraAmiySi
(S, Mgh) i. e. [The winter has come, and I have not yet made for myself] a lodging: [O, wo to my two-hands, in consequence of digging] hollows in which to sit for protection from the cold. (Mgh.) And from rabaDN applied to “ milk which sustains a man, and suffices him for food, ” originated the prov., (K, TA,) minoka rabaDuka waA_ino kaAna samaArFA, meaning (tropical:) Thy family and thy servants (S, K) and those to whom thou betakest thyself for lodging or refuge, (S,) are appertenances of thine, though they be persons falling short [of their duty]: (S, K:) or thy manager of affairs, &c., though he be not a good manager of thine affairs: (L, TA:) and rabaDN also signifies any woman who undertakes, or manages, the affairs of a house: but in the T we find ↓ ruboDuka, thus written, as by Th, on the authority of IAar, but not restricted by a measure, and explained as meaning the person who undertakes, or manages, the affairs of thy house; and so in the book of proverbs by As: and in the margin of a copy of the S, we find the above-cited prov. thus written, waA_ino kaAna samaArFA ↓ minoka rubuDuka, as from the “ Book on Goats ” by Ibn-Zeyd, and expl. as meaning the sons of thy father are appertenances of thine, though they be evil persons, in whom is no good. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The wall of a city: (K, TA:) the environs of a city, (S, A, Mgh,) and of a qaSor [or palace &c.], (A,) consisting of houses or dwellings, (A, Mgh,) or of open country: (TA:) and ↓ ruboDN signifies the same: (TA:) or this latter signifies the foundation, or basis, of a building; and of a city also: (K:) IKh writes it ↓ rubuDN: and some say that ↓ ruboDN and rabaDN signify the same: (TA:) the former of these two signifies also the part, of a thing, that touches the ground: (K, TA:) so says Sh: accord. to ISh, AlA^aroDi ↓ ruboDu signifies what touches the ground, of a thing: (TA:) and rabaDN also signifies a lateral, or an outward or adjacent, part: (K:) or lateral, or outward or adjacent, parts of a thing: (Ks, S:) also the space immediately pertaining to a mosque: and [the pl.] A^arobaADN is explained by El-Karkhee as applied to the quarters, or districts, of a town, or city. (Mgh.) ― -b5- rabaDN also signifies (tropical:) The rope of the [camel's saddle called] raHol, (A, K,) with which the rHl is bound; (A, TA;) one of the A^arobaAD, or ropes of the raHol: (S, A:) or the part that is next the ground thereof; (K;) i. e., of the rope of the rHl; (TA;) not what is above the rHl: (K:) accord. to Lth, the part [of the belly] of the camel that is next the ground when he lies down; (L, TA; *) and the belly of the she-camel; and in like manner IAar explains the pl. A^arobaADN as meaning the bellies of camels; but Az says that this is a mistake. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A girth of a raHol, like the niTaAq [q. v.], which is put upon the flanks of the she-camel, so as to have the haunches behind it, (K, TA,) on either side, having at its two ends two rings, to which are tied the [woven, or plaited, thongs called] A^anosaAE: the rHl is bound with it. (TA.) ― -b6- Also (tropical:) The maSaAriyn [or guts, or intestines,] of the belly, that have a winding, or coiled, form; (Lth, A, TA;) such as are in the belly of a sheep or goat: (Lth, TA:) or the folding intestines of beasts: (AHat, TA:) or the guts, bowels, or intestines, into which the food passes from the stomach; syn. A^amoEaA='N: (S, K:) or the contents of the belly, (K, TA,) consisting of the maSaAriyn &c., (TA,) except the heart (K, TA) and the lungs. (TA.) (assumed tropical:) The part that comprises the HawaAyaA [or winding, circling, or coiled, guts or intestines]; (IAar, TA;) as also ↓ rabiyDN and ↓ marobiDN and ↓ marobaDN: (IAar, K, TA:) some describe the rabaD as below the navel; and the ↓ marobaD, as beneath the navel and above the pubes. (TA.)

rubuDN * [(tropical:) Holding back, through indolence]. rubuDN Eani AlHaAjaAti, (A, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, EalaY AlHAjAt, (TA,) and AlA^asofaAri, (A, TA,) means (tropical:) A man who does not rise to perform needful affairs, (A, K,) and journeys: (A, TA:) or who does not go forth to undertake them. (Lh, TA.) -A2- See also rabaDN, in three places.

ruboDapN * , applied to a man, i q. ↓ mutarab~iDN; (K;) i. e. (tropical:) Remaining stationary, and impotent; (TA;) as also ↓ rubaDapN. (K.) -A2- See also riboDapN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A portion, (K,) or large portion, (IDrd,) of variyd [i. e. crumbled bread moistened with broth]. (IDrd, K.) -A3- See also ruboSapN, with the unpointed S.

riboDapN *
A mode, or manner, of lying upon the breast: (K, and Har p. 382: [see 1, first signification:]) this is the primary meaning. (Har.) ― -b2- And A place thereof. (Har ibid. [See again rabaDN, first signification.]) ― -b3- See also rabiyDN, in three places. ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) A place of slaughter (maqotal) of any party, or company of men, slain in one plot of ground: (Lth, Sgh, K:) erroneously written by Sgh in the TS rabaDap; but in the O correctly. (TA.) [And accord. to the TA, it seems to be also applied to (assumed tropical:) The party so slain.] -A2- Also The body [of an animal] when lying upon the breast; particularly, of a hare, (A, K,) and of a lamb, (A, TA,) and of a she-goat; and so ↓ ruboDapN. (TA.) Hence the saying, A^ataAnaA bivariydK kaA^an~ahu riboDapu A^aronabK [He brought us crumbled bread moistened with broth resembling in size and shape the body of a hare lying upon its breast]. (A, K. *)

daAb~apN Daxomapu Alr~abaDapi *
A beast of which the traces of the place where it has been tied [and app. where it has lain] are large, or wide. (TA.)
rubaDapN * : see ruboDapN.

rabuwDN * : see raAbiDN. ― -b2- Applied to a [skin such as is termed] qirobap, (tropical:) Great, or large; hardly, or not at all, to be lifted; so that it remains fixed; or so that it causes him who desires to lift it to remain fixed. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Then, (A,) applied to a tree ($ajarap), meaning (tropical:) Great, or large, (A 'Obeyd, S, A, * K,) and thick, (S,) and, accord. to the K, wide, but [SM says,] I have not seen that any of the leading authorities applies it in this last sense to a tree: (TA:) pl. rubaDN. (K.) ― -b4- Applied to a chain (silosilap), (tropical:) Large, or big, (S, K, TA,) and heavy, cleaving to him upon whom it is put: it is of a measure having an intensive signification, and qualifying alike a masc. and a fem. n. (TA.) ― -b5- Applied to a coat of mail (diroE), (tropical:) Large, or big: (A, TA:) or wide. (K.) ― -b6- And, applied to a town (qaroyap), (assumed tropical:) Populous, (Sgh, K, TA,) and large. (TA.)

rabiyDN *
Sheep, or goats, with their pastors, collected together in their lodging-places; (S, A, K;) as though it were a quasi-pl. n.; as also ↓ riboDapN and ↓ riboDN: (TA:) and hence, (L, TA,) ↓ the former of these two, (assumed tropical:) a company of men: (L, K:) and ↓ the latter of them, [accord. to the K,] a herd of bulls, or cows, in their lodgingplace; from the author of the book entitled kitaAbu Almuzodawiji mina All~ugaAti, only: (K, * TA:) but what this author says is, that ↓ riboDN signifies the lodging-places of bulls or cows [app. with the beasts in them]: and that the primary application of this word (riboDN) and ↓ riboDapN is to sheep or goats; and that by a subsequent usage they have been applied to bulls or cows and to men. (TA.) See also raAbiDN. ― -b2- One says also, Sab~a A@ll~`hu Ealayohi Hum~aY rabiyDFA [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) May God send (lit. pour) upon him a fever that shall cleave to him like as an animal lying upon its breast cleaves to the ground]. (TA.) -A2- See also rabaDN, last sentence.
rab~aADN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

raAbiDN *
Lying upon his breast; applied to a sheep or goat [&c.]; and so ↓ rabuwDN applied to a hare; so too ↓ rab~aADN [but app. in an intensive or a frequentative sense] applied to a lion, as is also raAbiDN, and to a man lying on his adversary: (TA:) and [hence] ↓ Alr~ab~aADu is an appellation of the lion: (K:) the pl. [of raAbiDN] is rub~aDN and rubuwDN: and the phrase Alganami ↓ karabiyDapi, occurring in a trad., means kaAlganami Alr~ub~aDi [Like the sheep, or goats, that are lying upon their breasts]. (TA.) It is said in a prov., kalobN jaw~aAlN xayorN mino A^asadK raAbiDK or rabaDa [A dog that roams about is better than a lion lying upon his breast or that has laid himself down upon his breast]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, because of his cleaving to the ground,] (tropical:) A sick man. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also the phrase,] A^aronabatuhu raAbiDapN EalaY wajohihi (tropical:) The end of his nose is flat, and spreading upon his face. (A.) ― -b4- Alr~aAbiDaAni is an appellation applied to The Turks and the Abyssinians. (K, TA.) These are meant in the trad. of Mo'áwiyeh, laA taboEavuwA Alr~aAbiDayoni, i. e. Rouse not ye against you the two [peoples] that are remaining quiet as long as they do not pursue you: it is like another trad., in which it is said, AutorukuwA Alt~uroka maA tarakuwkumo wadaEuwA AlHaba$apa maA wadaEuwkumo [Leave ye alone the Turks as long as they leave you alone, and let ye alone the Abyssinians as long as they let you alone]. (TA.)

raAbiDapN * [as a subst. from raAbiDN, made so by the affix p, An animal lying upon its breast]. One says of a man who kills when he shoots, and more commonly of him who kills when he smites with the [evil] eye, fulaAnN maA taquwmu raAbiDatuhu [Such a one is so effective in his aim that his animal lying upon its breast does not rise]: (ISk, S, TA:) and in like manner, maA taquwmu lahu raAbiDapN: it is a prov. (TA.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., faA@nobaEava lahu waAHidN mina Alr~aAbiDapi [And there rose and went to him one of the raAbDp]: (Lth, A, TA:) Alr~aAbiDapu means (tropical:) certain angels who were sent down [from Paradise] with Adam, (Lth, A, K, TA,) who direct those that err from the right way: (Lth, A, TA:) perhaps (Lth, TA) so called from their remaining upon the earth: (Lth, * A, TA: *) and [so in the K, but correctly “ or, ”] the remainder of the Bearers of Evidence (Hamalapi AlHuj~api [meaning those angels whereof every individual of mankind has two appointed to attend him constantly for the purpose of their bearing evidence of his good and evil deeds, which two are termed in the Kur l. 16 Almutalaq~iyaAni,]) whereof the earth will never be destitute. (S, K.) ― -b3- And in another trad., respecting the signs of the coming of the resurrection, the Prophet is related to have said that one of those signs will be, that the ↓ ruwayobiDap will speak respecting the affairs of the community: (T, TA:) Alr~uwayobiDapu is the dim. of Alr~aAbiDapu (T, K, TA) signifying The pastor of rabiyD [q. v.]; (T, TA;) and means (assumed tropical:) the mean, contemptible man, (S, K,) who speaks respecting the affairs of the community: thus expl. by the Prophet himself: (K: [in the CK, Aln~Aqihu is erroneously put for Alt~aAfihu:]) or he explained it as meaning (assumed tropical:) the vitious, or wicked, who speaks respecting the affairs of the community: A 'Obeyd compares this trad. with another, in which it is said that one of the signs above mentioned will be, that the pastors of sheep or goats will be the heads of the people: and Az says that AlrwybDp means the pastor of sheep or goats: some say that it means (assumed tropical:) he who abstains, or holds back, from seeking the means of acquiring eminence, or nobility; and Alr~aAbiDapu signifies [the same, or] impotent to attain eminence: in this latter, the p is added to give intensiveness to the signification: and Az thinks it most probable that each of these is applied to the mean man because of his remaining in his house, or tent, and seldom rising and going forth to occupy himself in great affairs. (TA.)
ruwayobiDapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

tirobaADN *
i. q. EuSofurN [Safflower, or bastard saffron]. (IAar, K.)
marobaDN * : see rabaDN, last sentence, in two places.
marobiDN * : see rabaDN, first sentence: ― -b2- and the same in the last sentence.
mutarab~iDo * : see ruboDapN.

1 rabaTa * , (S, Mgh, &c.,) aor.
rabiTa and
rabuTa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. raboTN, (Msb, TA,) He tied, bound, or made fast, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) a thing, (S, Msb, * K, * TA,) and a beast; (Mgh, TA;) and in like manner ↓ ArtbT he tied, or bound, a beast with a rope, in order that he might not run away. (TA.) You say, ka*aA raA^osFA mina Ald~awaAb~i ↓ fulaAnN yarotabiTu [Such a one ties so many head of beasts: or the verb may here have a different signification, explained below]. (S, TA.) And it is said in a prov., Aisotakoramota faA@robiTo, or, accord. to one relation, A^akoramota, i. e. Thou hast found a generous horse, therefore do thou preserve him; or, as some relate it, ↓ faA@rotabiTo: relating to the duty of preservation. (TA.) See also 3. ― -b2- rabaTa Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) He held back, or drew back, from him, or it; as though he confined, and bound, himself. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- rabaTa jaA^o$uhu, inf. n. ribaATapN, (assumed tropical:) His heart became strong, and firm, and resolute, (K, * TA,) so that he did not flee on the occasion of fear. (TA. [In the CK, rabaTa jaA^o$ahu, which would be more properly rendered (tropical:) He strengthened, or fortified, his heart.]) ― -b4- rabaTa li*`lika AlA^amori jaA^o$FA (tropical:) He constrained himself to be patient, and confined, or restricted, himself to that thing, or affair. (TA.) ― -b5- rabaTa A@ll~`hu EalaY qalobihi (Msb, K) biAlS~abori (Msb) (tropical:) God inspired him with patience. (Msb, K.) Thus in the Kur [xviii. 13], warabaTonaA EalaY quluwbihimo (tropical:) And we inspired them with patience: (TA:) or strengthened them with patience. (Bd.) And in like manner in [viii. 11 and] xxviii. 9. (TA.)

3 AlmuraAbaTapu * signifies, (K, TA,) in its primary acceptation, (TA,) Two [hostile] parties' tying of their horses, each at their frontier, and each in preparation for the other: (K, TA:) and ribaATu Alxayoli and muraAbaTatuhaA signify the same [as above]. (S, TA.) [You say, raAbaTa AlfariyqaAni The two parties tied their horses at their respective frontiers, each in preparation for the other.] And one says, with reference to horses, ↓ rabaTa, inf. n. raboTN and ribaATN, as well as rAbT, inf. n. muraAbaTapN and ribaATN. (Bd in viii. 62.) Hence, (Sgh, L, K,) rAbT, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. ribaATN (S, Mgh, Sgh, L, K) and muraAbaTapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He, or it, (an army, Mgh) kept post, or remained, on, or at, the frontier (S, Mgh, Sgh, L, K) of the enemy, (S, Msb, K,) or over against the enemy. (Mgh.) And hence, i. e. from this latter application, (AAF, TA,) rAbT AlA^amora, (TK,) inf. n. ribaATN (AAF, K) and muraAbaTapN, (TK,) (assumed tropical:) He kept, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to the thing, or affair. (AAF, K, TK.) It is said in the Kur [ch. iii., last verse], A@SobiruwA waSaAbiruwA waraAbiTuwA Be ye patient in endurance of what your religion requires, and vie ye in patience with your enemy, and persevere ye in fighting against your enemy, (Mgh, TA,) and in tying the horses
[at the frontier]: (TA:) or the last of these verbs means keep ye post, or remain ye, on, or at, the frontier [of the enemy]: (Az, K:) or (assumed tropical:) be ye mindful of the times of prayer: or (assumed tropical:) apply yourselves constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to prayer: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) wait ye for prayer after prayer; the doing this being termed by the Prophet ribaATN; (Az, K, TA;) which word, thus used, is an inf. n. of raAbaTotu; or, as some say, a simple subst., meaning, in this case, a thing whereby one is tied from acts of disobedience, and restrained from forbidden deeds. (TA.) [See also SaAbara.]

entryFree.key: trAbT AlmaA='u fiY makaAni ka*aA waka*aA

div2.entryFree: 6 trAbT AlmaA='u fiY makaAni ka*aA waka*aA * (tropical:) The water remained in, or did not quit, or go forth from, such and such a place. (TA.)

8 A_irotabaTa see 1, in three places. ― -b2- ArtbT farasFA He took a horse for the purpose of tying him, or keeping post, on the enemy's frontier. (K, * TA.) -A2- [He, or it, became tied, bound, or made fast.] ― -b2- ArtbT fiY AlHaboli He became caught, or entangled, in the rope. (Lh.) ― -b3- AirotibaATN is also explained by AO and Ez-Zejjájee as syn. with AEotlaAqN. (TA.) [Thus, ArtbThu signifies He, or it, attached himself, or itself, or clung, or clave, to him, or it: (see a citation from Lebeed, voce baEoDN:) and app. also (assumed tropical:) he loved him.]

ribaATN *
A thing with which one ties, binds, or makes fast, (S, Msb, K,) a skin, (S, Msb,) and a beast, (S,) &c.; (S, Msb;) a rope with which a beast is tied: (Mgh:) pl. rubuTN (S, Msb, K) and ruboTN; (S, TA;) the latter a contraction of the former: (TA:) and ↓ mirobaTN and ↓ mirobaTapN also signify a thing with which a beast is tied. (K.) It is said in a prov., A_ino *ahaba EayorN faEayorN fiY Alr~ibaATi [If an ass is gone away, an ass is tied to the cord]: relating to contentment with what is present and relinquishment of what is absent. (Mgh.) [See also 3.] ― -b2- [Hence,] used by the vulgar in the sense of A^uxo*apN, meaning (assumed tropical:) A kind of fascination by which enchantresses withhold their husbands from other women. (TA in art. Ax*.) ― -b3- A snare for catching game. (S, Mgh.) You say, qaTaEa AlZ~aboYu ribaATahu [The gazelle rent his snare]. (S.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The heart: (K:) as though the body were tied thereby. (TA.) Hence, (TA in art. qrD,) qaraDa rbaATahu (assumed tropical:) He died: (M and K in that art.:) or he was at the point of death. (K in that art.) And jaA='a fulaAnN waqado qaraDa ribaATahu (tropical:) Such a one came having turned away, or back, harassed, distressed, or fatigued, (S, TA, and AZ and Az in art. qrD,) and at the point of death: (AZ, Az:) or harassed, or distressed, by thirst, or by fatigue: (A in art. qrD:) or in a state of intense thirst and hunger. (M in that art.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) The spirit: as in the saying of El-'Ajjáj, describing a wild bull,
fabaAta wahowa vaAbitu Alr~ibaATi
[And he passed the night firm in spirit]. (TA.) -A2- See also rabiyTN, (of which it is a pl., or pl. pl.,) in three places. -A3- A single building of those which are called ribaATaAtN: (S, K:) [a public building for the accommodation of travellers and their beasts; (see bariydN;) an application well known, and mentioned in the TK:] a religious house, or house inhabited by devotees; a dwelling for Soofees; (El-Makreezee's “ Khitat ” ii. 427;) [a hospice, or an asylum for poor Muslim students and others, like zaAwiyapN;] a building for the poor: in this sense post-classical: pl., accord. to analogy, rubuTN and ribaATaAtN. (Msb.)

rabiyTN *
Tied, bound, or made fast; as also ↓ marobuwTN; (K, TA;) applied to a horse, (Mgh,) or similar beast (daAb~ap); as also ↓ marobuwTapN; (TA;) applied to the former, i. q. marobuwTN; (Mgh;) or maAyurotabaTu [which may perhaps signify the same; but more probably, taken to be tied, or for keeping post, on the enemy's frontier]; (S;) and [in like manner] rabiyTapN, applied to the latter, i. q. maAA@rotubiTa: (K:) and rabiyTN applied to a horse also signifies tied and fed in the court of a house: (TA:) pl. rubuTN (TA) and ↓ ribaATN, (Mgh,) or the latter is a pl. pl., being pl. of rubuTN. (TA.) Alxayoli ↓ mino ribaATi, in the Kur [viii. 62], means Of horses that are tied; (Bd, Mgh;) ribaATN being of the measure fiEaAlN in the sense of the measure mafoEwlN; or an inf. n. used as a subst., being an inf. n. of rabaTa in the sense of raAbaTa; (Bd;) or it is an inf. n. of raAbaTa; and therefore [when used as an epithet, like any inf. n. so used,] is applied to one as well as to a pl. number; (Ham p. 222;) or pl. of rabiyTo: (Bd, Mgh:) or it means of mares: (Fr, TA:) and ribaATN signifies horses; five thereof, and upwards: (S, K:) or horses, themselves, that are taken to be tied, or for keeping post, on the enemy's frontier. (L.) And you say, lifulaAnK mina Alxayoli ↓ ribaATN Such a one has a stud constituting the source of his horses; like as you say tlaAdN. (S.) ↓ raAbTapN, also, applied to horses, signifies Tied in a town or country or the like: occuring in a trad., in which it is said that upon every horse shall be levied a deenár; but upon the rAbTp, nothing: properly meaning, in this case, *aAtu Alr~aboTi; being like raADiyapN in the phrase Eiy$apN raADiyapN. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also raAbiTN. ― -b3- Also, and ↓ raAbiTN, (assumed tropical:) A monk: one who abstains from worldly pleasures: a sage who restrains himself from worldly things. (K, TA.) [In the L and TA, Alr~abiyTu is also explained, as on the authority of Ez-Zejjájee, as signifying Al*~aAhibu; but this I think a mistranscription, for Alr~aAhibu.] -A2- (assumed tropical:) Unripe dates soaked [in water]: (S, K:) or (assumed tropical:) fresh ripe dates soaked with water; also called manoquw$N: (Sgh, TA in art. nq$:) or (tropical:) dried dates (A 'Obeyd, IF, A, K) put into jars (jiraAr), (A 'Obeyd, A,) and having water poured upon them, (A 'Obeyd, IF, K,) or moistened with water, in order that they may become like fresh ripe dates: (A:) but perhaps this is an adventitious term: (IF:) some say that it is rabiydN, and not original. (TA.)

rab~aATN *
One who ties bow-strings. (TA.)

raAbiTN * [act. part. n. of 1]. ― -b2- xal~afa fulaAnN biAlv~agori jayo$FA raAbiTapF [Such a one left behind him on the frontier an army having their horses tied in preparation for the enemy; or keeping post]. (S.) And bibaladi ka*aA raAbiTapN mina Alxayoli [In such a town, or country, or the like, is a company of horsemen having their horses tied at the frontier in preparation for the enemy; or keeping post on the frontier: or it may perhaps mean, a number of horses tied: see rabiyTN]. (S.) ↓ muraAbiTapN also signifies A company of warriors; or of men warring against an enemy: (Mgh:) or a company of men having their horses tied at the frontier in preparation for the enemy; or keeping post on the frontier; and in like manner [its pl.] muraAbiTaAtN, a company of horsemen having their horses tied &c. (TA.) ― -b3- fulaAnN raAbiTu AljaA^o$i, and AljaA^o$i ↓ rabiyTu, (tropical:) Such a one is strong in heart: (S:) or courageous: (K:) as though he tied himself from flight, (S, TA,) and restrained himself. by his boldness and courage. (TA.) ― -b4- nafosN raAbiTN (assumed tropical:) A spirit [still attached to the body, and consequently not doomed, but] having ample power, or liberty, [and] capable of good; syn. waAsiEN A^ariyDN. (K.) An Arab is related by IAar to have said, Aall~`hum~a A@gofiroliY waAljilodu baAridN waAln~afosu raAbiTN waAlS~uHufu munota$irapN waAlt~awobapu maqobuwlapN [O God, forgive me while the skin is cool, not heated by fever, and the spirit is yet attached to my body, and is at liberty, and capable of good, and the volumes in which my actions are registered are still expanded, and repentance is accepted]: he meant thereby, while he was in health; before death. (TA.) ― -b5- See also rabiyTN, in two places.

raAbiTapN * [fem. of raAbiTN. ― -b2- Also] A tie, or connection, of any kind; syn. EuloqapN [q. v.] and wuSolapN. (TA.) [This meaning of rAbTp is well known, though omitted in the S and K &c. ― -b3- Hence, (assumed tropical:) The copula in a proposition.]

marobiTN * (S, Mgh, K) and marobaTN, (S K,) the former used by him who says A^arobuTu, and the latter by him who says A^arobuTu, (IB,) The place where a thing, (S,) or where a beast, (Mgh, K,) is tied, bound, or made fast: (S, Mgh, K:) a stable: pl. maraAbiTu. (Har p. 33.) You say, layosa lahu marobiaTu EanozK [He has not so much as, or even, a place where a she-goat is tied]. (S.) Each is a noun of place used in a definite manner; so that you may not say, huwa min~iY marobaTa Alfarasi, like manaATa Alv~uray~aA. (TA: [in which, however, the word mnAT has been inadvertently omitted.]) ― -b2- [Also A place where soldiers tie their horses at the frontier in preparation for the enemy; or where they keep post on the frontier; as also ↓ muraAbaTN. You say,] AlguzaApu fiY maraAbiTihimo and ↓ muraAbaTaAtihimo The warriors are in their places where they tie their horses at the frontier in preparation for the enemy; or where they keep post on the frontier. (TA.)
mirobaTN * : see ribaATN.

mirobaTapN * : see ribaATN. ― -b2- Also A slender plaited thong which is bound over the pad (Ha$iy~ap, for
which, in the copies of the K, we find erroneously substituted xa$abap, TA,) of the raHol [or camel's saddle]. (K, *, TA.)
marobuwTN * , and its fem., with p: see rabiyTN.
muraAbaTN * : pl. muraAbaTaAtN: see marobiTN, in two places.
muraAbiTapN * : see raAbiTN.

entryFree.key: huwa murotabiTN ka*aA waka*aA mina Alxayoli

div2.entryFree:
huwa murotabiTN ka*aA waka*aA mina Alxayoli *
He takes, or is taking, such and such [a number] of horses for the purpose of tying them, or keeping post, on the enemy's frontier. (TA.)
maA=w^N mutaraAbiTN * (tropical:) Water remaining in a place, not quitting it, or not going forth from it. (EshSheybánee, * S, * K, * TA.)

1 rabaEahumo * , aor.
rabaEa and
rabuEa and
rabiEa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) He took the fourth part of their property, or possessions. (Msb, K.) And (so in the K, but in the Msb “ or, ”) rabaEahumo, (S, Sgh, Msb, K,) aor.
rabaEa (S, Sgh, Msb) and
rabuEa and
rabiEa , (Sgh, Msb,) not, as is implied in the K,
rabiEa only, (TA,) [or rather, not
rabaEa only,] inf. n. as above, and rbAEp [most probably rbAEapN] also, (L,) He took the fourth part of their spoil: (S, Sgh, Msb, K:) i. e., of the spoil of an army: this was done in the Time of Ignorance, but El-Islám reduced it to a fifth part; (K;) as is declared in the Kur viii. 42. (TA.) It is said in a trad., A^alamo A^ajoEaloka tarobaEu watadosaEu, (S, * TA,) mentioned [and explained] in art. dsE, q. v.: the meaning [intended] is, Did I not make thee an obeyed chief? (TA.) ― -b2- And rabaEahumo, (S, Sgh, Msb,) or rabaEa Alv~alaAvapa, (K,) aor.
rabaEa (S, Sgh, Msb, K) and
rabuEa and
rabiEa , (Sgh, Msb, K,) [inf. n., app., raboEN,] He became the fourth of them; (S, Sgh, Msb;) or, the fourth of the three: (TA:) or he made the three to be four by [adding to them] himself. (K.) And rabaEahumo also signifies He made them, by adding himself to them, forty: or, four and forty. (K, * TA.) And He made them (namely thirteen) to be fourteen. (T in art. vlv.) ― -b3- rabaEahu, aor.
rabaEa , (S, K,) inf. n. rabEN, (S,) He twisted it (namely a bow-string, S, TA, and a rope, or cord, K, TA) of four twists, or strands. (S, K.) -A2- rabaEat AlA_ibilu, (S, K,) aor.
rabaEa , inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) i. q. ↓ waradati Alr~iboEa; (S, K;) i. e., The camels, having been kept from the water three days [counting two portions of days as one of those days], or four days [counting two portions of days as two days (for the difference is only verbal)], and three [whole] nights, came to the water on the fourth day [counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first]. (K.) [See riboEN, below. Another meaning of this phrase will be found later in the present paragraph.] Hence, A^arobaEa AlmariyDa: see 4. (TA.) ― -b2- rabaEato Ealayohi AlHum~aY, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
rabaEa , inf. n. raboEN; (Msb;) and Ealayohi ↓ A^arobaEato, (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ A^arobaEatohu, but not rabaEatohu; (IAar;) or the phrase used by the Arabs is Elyh AlHm~Y ↓ A^arobaEato: (Az, TA:) The fever seized him on one day and left him two days and then came again on the fourth day [counting the day of the next preceding fit as the first], (S, Msb, K,) and so on. (Msb.) And rubiEa, and ↓ A^orobiEa, (S, K,) and ↓ A^arobaEa is said to be also used in the same sense, (TA,) He had, or was seized by, a quartan fever; a fever of the kind described above. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- rabaEa said of a horse, He came fourth in the race. (T, M, L, all in art. vlv.) -A3- rubiEa, said of a man, also signifies He was hit, or hurt, in the A^arobaAE, meaning regions, of his head. (TA.) -A4- rabaEa AlmaTaru AlA^aroDa [The rain watered the earth and made it to produce herbage: see rabiyEN]. (TA.) And rubiEati AlA^aroDu The land was watered by the rain in the season called rabiyE. (S.) And rubiEuwA They were rained upon by the rain of the season called rabiyE; (K, * TA;) similar to qiyZuwA and SiyfuwA: (TA in art. qyZ:) and in like manner, rubiEati AlA_ibilu The camels were rained upon by that rain: and marobaEN may be an inf. n. thereof. (Ham p. 425.) ― -b2- Hence, i. e. from rabaEa AlmaTaruAlA^aroDa, the phrase, rabaEa Alfarasu EalaY qawaAy^imihi (assumed tropical:) The horse sweated in his legs. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence also,] rabaEahu A@ll~`hu (tropical:) God restored him from a state of poverty to wealth or competence or sufficiency; recovered him from his embarassment or difficulty, or from a state of perdition or destruction. (TA.) -A5- rabaEa Alr~abiyEu, aor.
rabaEa , inf. n. rubuwEN, The [season called] rbyE commenced. (TA.) ― -b2- rabaEa biAlmakaAni, (K, TA,) aor.
rabaEa , inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) in its primary acceptation, signifies He remained, abode, or dwelt, in the place in the [season called] rabiyE; (TA;) as also bihi ↓ ArtbE. (S, K.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) (tropical:) He remained, abode, or dwell, in the place, (K, TA,) in any circumstances, and at any time; (TA;) he took it as his home. (K.) ― -b4- Also He alighted and abode wherever he would, in the place, in abundance of herbage, and pasturage. (K, * TA.) ― -b5- rabaEati AlA_ibilu, (K,) aor.
rabaEa , inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) The camels fed by themselves in the pasturage, and ate as they pleased, and drank. (K.) [Another meaning of this phrase has been mentioned before.] ― -b6- rabaEa fiY AlmaA='a He (a man, TA) acted according to his own opinion or judgment, or did what he judged fit, with respect to the water. (K.) ― -b7- rabaEa, (K,) aor.
rabaEa , inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) said of a man, also signifies He had, or obtained, abundance of herbage (K, TA) [arising] from the [season, or rain, called] rabiyE. (TA.) ― -b8- Also, [app. from rabaEa biAlmakaAni in the second of the senses explained above, and if so, tropical, or doubly tropical,] aor. rabaEa, (assumed tropical:) He (a man, ISk, S) paused, (ISk, S, K,) and acted, or behaved, with deliberation or in a leisurely manner, (K,) and withheld himself. (ISk, S, K.) And [hence,] rabaEa Ealayohi, (K,) inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He was affectionate, or pitiful, or compassionate, towards him: (K:) or he acted gently towards him. (TA.) And rabaEa Eanohu (K,) inf. n. raboEN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He restrained himself, refrained, abstained, or desisted, from it. (K.) The phrases AirobaEo EalaY nafosika and ArbE ElY ZaloEika (S, K) and ArbE Ealayoka (K) are from rabaEa in the sense of “ he paused, ” &c., (S, K,) as explained by ISk, (S,) [or in one of the senses following that,] meaning (assumed tropical:) Deal thou gently with thyself; moderate thyself; restrain thyself: (S, TA:) or behave thou with deliberation, or in a leisurely manner: or the second of these phrases may mean continue thou notwithstanding thy slight lameness: or it may be from rabaEa AlHajara, [q. v. infrà,] meaning take thou it, or reach it, notwithstanding thy slight lameness. (TA.) The phrase AirobaEiY binafosiki, or EalaY nafosiki, in the trad. of Subey'ah El-Aslameeyeh, accord. to two different relations, admits of two interpretations: one is, (assumed tropical:) Pause thou, and wait for the completion of the Eid~ap [q. v.] of decease; and this is accord. to the persuasion of those who say that her Ed~p is the more remote of the two periods, which is the persuasion of 'Alee and I'Ab: the second is, from rabaEa Alr~julu signifying “ the man had, or obtained, abundance of herbage, ” and the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) relieve thou thyself, and release thyself from the straitness of the Ed~p, and the evil of thy condition; and this is accord. to the persuasion of those who hold that her Ed~p is the nearer of the two periods; and hence 'Omar said, “ If she bring forth when her husband is on his bier, meaning, not buried, it is allowable for her to marry. ” (TA.) It is also said, in another trad., laA yarobaEu EalaY ZaloEika mano laA yuHozinuhu A^amoruka, i. e. (assumed tropical:) He will not restrain himself, and be patient with thee, whom thy case does not grieve. (TA.) And it is said in a prov., Had~ivi A@moraA^apF Hadiyvayoni faA_ino A^abato faA@robaEo, i. e. (assumed tropical:) Speak thou to a woman twice; and if she refuse, abstain thou: or, accord. to one relation, it is ↓ faA^arobiEo: and accord. to another, faA@robaEohu, i. e., then add; for she is very weak in understanding; if she understand not, then make thou the two speeches to be four: Aboo-Sa'eed says, faA_ino lamo tafohamo baEoda AlA^arobaEapi faA@lomirobaEap, i. e., [and if she understand not after the four, then] the stick [is to be used; or, then use thou the stick]: the prov. applies to the hearing and answering in an evil manner. (TA.) You say also, rabaEato EalaY Eaqoli fulaAnK wakasara fiyhaA ribaAEahu, inf. n. ribaAEapN, (tropical:) [app. She behaved in a gentle and coaxing manner so as to get the better of the reason, or understanding, of such a one, and he sold his houses one after another to expend upon her;] i. e., he expended upon her all that he possessed, so that he sold his dwellings. (TA. [The w before ksr is not in the TA; but as it seems to have been dropped by inadvertence, I have supplied it.]) -A6- rabaEa AlfaSiylu The young camel widened his stepping, and ran; as also ↓ ArtbE. (TA.) -A7- rabaEa AlHajara, (S, K,) aor.
rabaEa , inf. n. raboEN; (TA;) and ↓ ArtbEhu; (S;) He raised, or lifted, the stone, (S, K, TA,) with the hand; (K, TA;) or carried it; (TA;) for trial of strength. (K.) It is said in a trad., mar~a biqawomK yarobaEuwna HajarFA, [He passed by a company of men raising, &c., a stone]; and ↓ yarotabiEuwna [signifies the same]; (S;) and ↓ yatarab~aEuwna. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- rabaEa AlHimola, (S, K,) aor.
rabaEa , inf. n.
raboEN (TA,) He put the [staff, or small staff, called] mirobaEap beneath the load, and took hold of one end of the former, while another took hold of the other end, and then raised it, (S, K,) with the help of his companion, (K,) upon the camel, (S,) or upon the beast. (K,) [See also 3.] -A8- rabiEa biEayo$ihi He (a man) approved his life; was satisfied, or content, with it. (TA.)

2 rb~Ehu * , inf. n. tarobiyEN, He made it four. (EshSheybánee, K voce waH~adahu.) ― -b2- He made it (a thing) murab~aE; (S, K;) i. e. he made it to have four portions [or sides or faces or angles &c.]: or he made it of the form of a thing having four legs; or of the form of a quadruped. (TA.) ― -b3- fulaAnN yuval~ivu walaA yurabab~Eu Such a one counts three Khaleefehs, [namely, Aboo-Bekr and 'Omar and 'Othmán,] and [does not count a fourth, i. e.,] rejects [' Alee,] the fourth. (TA in art. vlv.) ― -b4- rab~aEato She brought forth her fourth offspring. (TA in art. bkr.) ― -b5- rb~E liA@moraA^atihi, or EinodahaA, He remained four nights with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA voce sab~aEa.) ― -b6- tarobiyEN also signifies [The watering of seed-produce on the fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first;] the watering of seed-produce that is [next] after the tavoliyv. (TA.) [You say, rb~E Alz~aroEa He watered the seed-produce on the fourth day, &c.]

3 EaAmalahu muraAbaEapF * , (Ks, S, K,) or AisotaA^ojarahu muraAbaEapF, and ribaAEAF, (K,) [He bargained with him for work, or he hired him, or took him as a hireling, by, or for, the season called ribayE,] is from Alr~abiyE, (K,) like mu$aAharapF (Ks, S, K) from Al$~ahoru, (K,) and muSaAyafapF (Ks, S, TA) from AlS~ayofu, &c. (TA.) -A2- muraAbaEapN also signifies The taking hold of the hand of another person beneath a load, and so raising it upon the camel, without a [staff, or small staff, such as is called] mirobaEap. (S, * K, * TA.) You say, raAbaEahu He took hold of his hand &c. (IAar.) [See also 1; last signification but one.]

4 ArbE Alqawomu *
The party of men (three in number, Msb) became four: (S, Msb, K: [but in the last of these, mentioned after another signification with which it is connected by the conjunction A^awo “ or ”]) or, became forty. (TA.) -A2- A^arobaEato Ealayohi AlHum~aY, and A^arobaEatohu, and A^urobiEa, and A^arobaEa: see rabaEato Elyh AlHm~Y, [which is from rabaEati AlA^ibilu,] in three places; and rubiEa, in two places. ― -b2- A^agib~uwA fiY EiyaAdapi AlmariyDi waA^arobiEuwA, occurring in a trad., [Come ye every third day, and every fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding visit as the first, in visiting the sick; or, which is the same, leave ye him one day, and] leave ye him two days, and come to him on the third day, in visiting the sick; unless he be overcome [by his sickness]: (S, TA:) this is [in like manner] from the water-ing of camels termed riboEN. (TA.) You say also, A^arobaEa AlmariyDa He omitted visiting the sick man two days, and came to him on the third; (O, K;) or, as in the L, and in [some of] the copies of the S, on the fourth [if counting the day of the next preceding visit as the first]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] ArbE Ealayohi Als~aAy^ilu The asker, or beggar, asked, or begged, then went away, and then returned. (Ibn-' Abbád, Sgh, K. *) ― -b4- And ArbE biAlomaroA^api He returned to the mujaAmaEap of the woman without langour: (L:) or ArbE alone, said of a man, multum coïvit. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.) ― -b5- And ArbE Alwirodu, (O, K,) i. e. A^arobaEati AlA_ibilu biAlowirodi, (TA,) The camels quickly returned to watering, (O, * K, * TA,) so that they came to water without any appointed time: (TA:) mentioned by A 'Obeyd as written with the pointed g, which is a mistranscription. (L, TA.) ― -b6- And ArbE said of the water of a well, It [returned quickly so that it] became abundant, or copious. (K.) ― -b7- Said of a man, it also signifies ↓ waradato A_ibiluhu ribogFA; (S;) [meaning] He was, or became, one whose camels came in the state in which they are termed rawaAbiE [i. e. being watered on the fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first: from rabaEati AlA_ibilu: whence, likewise, what next follows]. (TA.) ― -b8- ArbE AlA_ibila He watered the camels in the manner termed riboEFA [i. e. on the fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first]. (TA.) ― -b9- This last phrase, also, (K,) or ArbE AlA_ibila EalaY AlmaA='i, (As,) signifies He sent and left the camels to go to the water whenever they pleased. (As, K. *) [Another signification of the verb thus applied will be found below.] -A3- ArbE, (inf. n. A_irobaAEN, S, Msb) He (a sheep or goat, a bull, a solid-hoofed beast, and a camel,) became what is termed rabaAEK: i. e., he shed the tooth called rabaAEiyap: (S, Msb, K:) it is when they do this that the camel and the horse begin to be strong. (TA.) -A4- ArbE Alqawomu The people, or company of men, entered the [season called] rabiyE: (S, K:) or [app. a mistake for “ and ”] it has the first of the significations mentioned in this paragraph. (K.) ― -b2- And (so in the S, but in the K “ or ”) The people, or company of men, remained in the place where they had alighted and taken up their abode in the [season called] rabiyE, abstaining from seeking after herbage; (S, K, TA;) the rain having been general, they remained where they were, because of the general fertility, not needing to remove for seeking after herbage. (TA.) [See also rabaEa biAlmakaAni.] ― -b3- And The people, or company of men, came to, or arrived at, land of seed-produce and fruitfulness, and water. (TA.) ― -b4- ArbE Algayovu The rain caused the [herbage called] rabiyE to grow: (TA:) or the rain confined the people in their ribaAE [or dwellings] by reason of its abundance. (Msb.) ― -b5- ArbEt AlA^aroDu The earth, or land, produced herbage. (Msb in art. jmd.) ― -b6- ArbE said of a man, (tropical:) He had offspring born to him in the prime of his manhood: (S, TA:) this being likened to the [season called] rabiyE (TA.) ― -b7- ArbE A_ibilahu bimakaAni ka*aA He pastured his camels in the [season called] rabiyE in such a place. (S.) ― -b8- ArbEt Aln~aAqapu The she-camel's womb was, or became, closed, (Aisotagolaqato raHimuhaA,) so that it did not admit the seminal fluid; (Lth, K;) [perhaps because this commonly takes place in the season called rabiyE, meaning either the spring or the season called rabiyEu AlkalaA^i; the usual season of the coupling of camels being winter;] as also ↓ ArtbEt. (TA.) -A5- ArbE lahaA biA lkalaAmi He made an abominable request to her; mentioned in the T in art. E*m; (TA;) meaning saA^alahaA AlwaTo'a fiY Ald~uburi. (TA in art. E*m.) -A6- See also a prov. mentioned in the latter part of the first paragraph.

5 trb~E fiY juluwsihi * (S, K) [He crossed his legs in his sitting; i. e. he sat cross-legged; because a person who does so puts himself in such a posture as to occupy nearly a square space;] contr. of javaA and A^aqoEaY. (K.) -A2- trb~E said of a camel, (S, K,) and of a horse, (TA,) He ate the [herbage called] rabiyE (S, K, TA,) and in consequence became brisk, lively, or sprightly, (TA,) and fat; (K, TA;) and ↓ ArtbE signifies the same: (S, K:) or trb~EwA and ↓ ArtbEwA signify they lighted on, or found, [herbage called] rabiyE: or they lighted on it, or found it, and remained among it: and trb~Et AlA_ibilu bimakaAni ka*aA The camels remained, or abode, in such a place. (TA.) You say also, tarab~aEonaA fiY AlHazoni waAlS~am~aAni We pastured upon the herbs, or leguminous plants, during the winter, upon the rugged ground and the hard and stony ground by the side of sand. (TA.) ― -b2- trb~Et Aln~axiylu The palm-trees had their fruit cut off; (TA, and in some copies of the K;) [because this is done in the autumn, which is called Alr~biyE.] -A3- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence,] trb~Et Aln~aAqapu sanaAmFA TawiylFA The she-camel carried a tall hump. (K.)
6 trAbEwA HajarFA * [They vied, one with another, in lifting a stone, for trial of strength: see rabaEa AlHajara]. (TA in art. j*w.)

8 ArtbE *
He (a. camel) beat [the ground] with all his legs, in going along; (S;) and went quickly. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph. -A2- He (a man) was of middling stature, neither tall nor short. (S.) -A3- See also rabaEa biAlmakaAni: ― -b2- and see 5, in two places: ― -b3- and 4, near the end of the paragraph: -A4- see also rabaEa AlHajara, in two places, near the end of 1. -A5- ArtbE A^amora Alqawomi He looked for, expected, or awaited, his being made commander, or lord, over the people, or party of men. (TA.)

10 AstrbEhu *
He had power, or ability, for it, to do it, or to bear or endure it: (IAar:) from rabaEa AlHajara. (Az.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] AstrbE said of a camel, He was, or became, strong, lils~ayori for journeying. (ISk, K.) ― -b3- It (sand) became heaped up. (AZ, K.) ― -b4- It (dust) rose; or rose high. (AZ, K.)

raboEN *
A place where people remain, abide, or dwell, in the [season called] rabiyE; (K, TA;) as also ↓ marobaEN, (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ murotabaEN: (K, TA:)
this is the primary signification: (TA:) and hence, (TA,) (tropical:) a place of alighting or abode, (Sh, S, Msb, K, TA,) of a people, or company of men; (Msb;) a settled place of abode; a place of constant residence; a dwelling; a home; whenever and wherever it be; as also ↓ marobaEN, and ↓ murotabaEN: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) a house, wherever it be: (S, Mgh, K:) [in Egypt, a range of distinct lodgings over shops or magazines, separate from the shops or magazines, but generally having one common entrance and staircase:] pl. [of mult.] ribaAEN and rubuwEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] A^arobaAEN and A^arobuEN: (S, Msb, K:) and the pl. of ↓ marobaEN is maraAbiEu. (S.) You say, maA A^awosaEa raboEa baniY fulaAnK (tropical:) How ample, or spacious, is the place of alighting, or abode, of the sons of such a one! (S, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, also, (tropical:) The people of a place of alighting or abode; (Sh, Msb, TA;) the people of a house or tent: (Aboo-Málik, TA:) a company of men or people: (K:) a large number: (IB:) pl. as above: (Msb:) rubuwEN signifies the people of places of alighting or abode: (Sh:) and also tribes. (TA.) You say, A^akavara A@ll~`hu raboEaka (tropical:) May God multiply the people of thy house or tent. (TA.) And humu Alyawoma raboEN (tropical:) They now, or to-day, [are a large number; or] have become many, and have increased. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] (assumed tropical:) A bier; or a bier with a corpse upon it; syn. naEo$N. (K, TA: [in the CK nafos.]) So in the saying, Hamalotu raboEahu (assumed tropical:) [I bore, or carried, his bier, or his bier with his corpse upon it]. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The extremity of a mountain. (TA.) [App. because travellers often stop and rest there.] -A2- Also i. q. ↓ raboEapN, (L, Msb, K,) which signifies, (S, L, &c.,) as also ↓ rabaEapN, and ↓ marobuwEN, (L, Msb, K,) or Alxaloqi ↓ marobuwEu, (S, Mgh, L,) and ↓ murotabiEN, (S, L, K,) and ↓ murotabaEN, (L, K,) and ↓ mirobaAEN, (K, but this last [says SM] I have not seen in the lexicons, except applied by the author of the “ Mo- heet ” as an epithet to a rope, TA,) applied to a man, (S, L, &c.,) Of middling stature; (Msb;) neither tall nor short; (S, L;) between tall and short: (K:) and so, applied to a woman, ↓ raboEapN (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and ↓ rabaEapN, (L, Msb,) though originally applied to a man, like xamosapN &c.: (L:) the pl. of raboEN is raboEuwna: (Fr:) and that of ↓ raboEapN is rabaEaAtN, applied to men and to women, (S, Mgh, L, K,) and raboEaAtN also; (IAar, Fr, L, K) the former of these two pls. being anomalous, because a word of the measure faEolapN has not its medial radical movent when it is an epithet, but only when it is a subst. and has not w or y for that radical; (S, O, K;) or the medial radical is movent in this instance because raboEapN is originally a fem. subst. applied to a male and a female, and used as an epithet; (L;) or because it resembles a subst. in its being applied alike to a man and a woman. (Az.)

ruboEN * (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ rubuEN, (S, Msb, K,) the former a contraction of the latter, (Msb,) [which is the more chaste, but the former is the more common,] A fourth part; (S, Msb, K;) one of four parts; (Mgh;;) as also ↓ rabiyEN, (Msb, K,) like Ea$iyrN; (TA;) and ↓ mirobaAEN, like miEo$aArN: (Ktr, and S:) or the last signifies, (Msb, K,) or signifies also, (S,) the fourth part of the spoil, which the chief used to take (S, Msb, K) in the Time of Ignorance: (K:) the pl. of ruboEN and ↓ rubuEN is A^arobaAEN [a pl. of pauc.] (Msb, TA) and rubuwEN [a pl. of mult]: (TA:) and that of ↓ rabiyEN is rubuEN (K.) ― -b2- Alr~uboEu AlhaA$imiY~u The same as the SaAE; because the qafiyz is twelve times what is termed man~: but Alr~uboEu AlHaj~aAjiY~u is the same as the mud~, which is a quarter of what is termed AlS~aAEu AlHaj~aAjiY~u. (Mgh.) [In Egypt, the ruboE is the fourth part of a wuyobap, q. v.] ― -b3- A^arobaAEu Alr~aA^osi The [four] regions of the head. (TA.)

riboEN * The Zimo' [or interval between two water-ings, or keeping from water during that interval,] which is meant in the phrase rabaEati AlA_ibilu [q. v.]; (S;) a certain Zimo' of camels, respecting which authors differ: (TA:) it is when camels are kept from the water three days [counting two portions of days as one of those days], or four days [counting two portions of days as two days (for the difference is only verbal)], and three [whole] nights, and come to the water on the fourth day [counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first]; (K;) or [in other words] their coming to the water one day, and leaving it two days, and then coming to it on the fourth day; or a period of three [whole] nights and four days [of which the first and last are incomplete]; as is indicated in the K: or, as some say, [but this at variance with common usage,] their being kept from the water four [nights (for the n. of number is here fem.)], and then coming to it on the fifth [day (for the n. of number is here masc.)]. (TA.) You say, waradati AlA_ibilu Alr~iboEa: see rabaEati AlA_ibilu. (S, K.) And waradato A_ibiluhu riboEFA: see 4. (S.) And A^aworada AlA_ibila riboEFA i. q. A^arobaEa AlA_ibila [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also, for sayoru riboEK, A journey in which the camels are watered only on the first and fourth days.] ― -b3- [In like manner,] with respect to fever, it signifies The seizing on one day and leaving two days and then coming again on the fourth day [counting the day of the next preceding fit as the first]. (S, K.) [The fever is termed] Hum~aY Alr~iboEi [The quartan fever;] the fever that occurs on one day and intermits two days and then comes again on the fourth, and so on. (Msb.) And you say, jaA='atohu AlHum~aY riboEFA, i. q. rabaEato Ealayohi AlHum~aY [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b4- Also The fourth young one, or offspring. (A in art. vlv.)

rubaEa * : see rubaAEu. -A2- rubaEN A young camel brought forth in the [season called] rabiyE [here meaning autumn], which is the beginning of the breedingtime: (S, Msb, K:) so called because he widens his stepping, and runs: [see 1, near the end of the paragraph:] (TA:) fem. with p: pl. masc. ribaAEN [a pl. of mult.] and A^arobaAEN [a pl. of pauc.]; (S, Msb, K;) both irreg.; for accord. to the rule given by Sb, the pl. should be riboEaAnN [like SrodaAnN pl. of SaradN]: (TA:) pl. fem. rubaEaAtN (S, Msb, K, TA [in the CK, erroneously, raboEAtN]) and ribaAEN. (K.) Hence the saying, maA lahu hubaEN walaA rubaEN He has not a young camel brought forth in the end of the breeding-time nor one brought forth in the beginning thereof. (S, TA.) [See another ex. voce bulaEN.] ― -b2- [Hence, also,] Alr~ubaEi (assumed tropical:) A very small star in the midst of the EawaAy^i*, which are in the head of Alt~in~iyn [or Draco]. (Kzw.)
rubuEN * : see ruboEN, in two places.

raboEapN * : see raboEN, last signification, in three places. -A2- [A small round basket, covered with leather, in which perfumes are kept by him who sells them;] the juwnap of the EaT~aAr; (S, Mgh, K;) which is a sulayolap covered with leather: (Mgh:) or a four-sided vessel, like the juwnap: said by El-Isbahánee to be so called because originally having four TaAqaAt [app. meaning compartments, one above another, for different kinds of perfume]; or because having four legs. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, app., A chest in which the volumes of a copy of the Kur-án are kept; (Sgh, K;) called raboEapu AlmuSoHafi: (Mgh:) but thus applied, it is post-classical, (Sgh, K,) belonging to the conventional language of the people of Baghdád. (Sgh.) ― -b3- Its application to A household utensil proper for women requires consideration. (Mgh.)

ribEapN * The beasts' collecting of themselves together in the [season called] rabiyE: [whence] a a country, or region, is said to be Tay~ibu Alr~iboEapi [good for the beasts' collecting of themselves together &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] tarakonaAhumo EalaY riboEatihimo We left them in their former, or first, or original, and right, or good, state, or condition. (TA.) ↓ rabaAEapN, also, and ↓ ribaAEapN, signify An affair, a business, or a concern, in which one continues occupied; or a case, a state, or a condition, in which one abides, or continues; (K, TA;) meaning a former, or first, affair, &c.; (TA;) and only relating to a good state or condition: (Yaakoob, K:) or one's way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like: (K:) or one's right, or good, state, or condition, (K, TA,) in which he has been before: (TA:) or his [tribe such as is termed] qabiylap: or [the portion thereof which is termed] his faxi*a: (K:) or ↓ humo EalaY ribaAEatihimo, (S, K,) and ↓ rabaAEatihimo, and ↓ rabaAEihimo, and ↓ rabaEaAtihimo, and ↓ rabiEaAtihimo, and ↓ ribaEatihimo, (K,) means They are in their right, or good, state, or condition: (K, TA:) or they are occupied in their affair, or business, or concern, in which they were occupied before; or they are in their case, or state, or condition, in which they were before: (S, K:) or ↓ ElY rabaEaAtihimo, (S, K,) and ↓ rabiEaAtihimo, (Fr, S, K,) signifies in their right, or good, state, or condition, and in their former, or first, case; or in their right, or good, state, or condition, and occupied in their former, or first, affair, or business, or concern: (S:) or it means in their places of abode. (Th, K.) You
say also, gayoru ↓ maAfiY baniY fulaAnK mano yaDobiTu ribaAEatahu fulaAnK i. e. [There is not among the sons of such a one he who manages thoroughly, or soundly,] his case, or affair, or business, or concern, in which he is occupied [except such a one]. (S.) And [hence,] qawomihi ↓ huwa EalaY ribaAEapi and huwa *uw ribaAEapi qawomihi He is the chief of his people. (Ham p. 313. [See also ribaAEapN below.])

rabaEapN *
A quick pace of a camel, in which he goes along beating the ground with his legs: (TA:) or the most vehement running: (K:) or the most vehement running of camels: (S and K:) or a kind of running of camels which is not vehement. (K.) -A2- See also raboEN, last signification, in two places. ― -b2- See also its pl., rabaEaAt, voce riboEapN, in two places.
rabiEapN * : see its pl., rabiEaAt, voce riboEapN, in two places.
ribaEapN * : see riboEapN.

riboEiY~N *
Of, or relating to, the rabiyE; (S, Msb, K;) i. e., the season so called; [and the rain, and the herbage, so called;] a rel. n. irregularly formed. (Msb.) ― -b2- Born in the [season called] rabiyE; applied to a young camel: born in the beginning of the breeding-time; [which means the same;] so applied. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) (tropical:) A son born in the prime [or spring-time] of his father's manhood; (S, * TA;) because the rbyE is the beginning, and the most approved part, of the breeding-time: (TA:) pl. riboEiy~uwna. (S, TA.) Saad Ibn-Málik says, (TA,)
A_in~a baniY~a SiboyapN Sayofiy~uwno
A^afolaHa mano kaAna lahu riboEiy~uwno
[Verily my sons are boys born in the summer of my age: happy is he who has sons born in the spring-time of his manhood.] (S, TA.) ― -b4- A palm-tree (siboTN, i. e. naxolapN,) of which the fruit ripens in the end of the summer, or hot season; AHn says, because then is the time of the [rain called] wasomiY~. (TA.) ― -b5- The Arabs say, SarafaAnapN riboEiy~aho tuSoramu biAlS~ayofi watuw^okalu biAl$~atiy~apo [A hard kind of date that would ripen in the season called rabiyE (meaning autumn) that is cut in the summer and eaten in the winter-season]. (TA.) ― -b6- naAqapN riboEiy~apN A she-camel that brings forth [in the season called rabiyE,] before others. (TA.) ― -b7- riboEiy~apN [used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, for miyrapN riboEiy~apN,] signifies The miyrap [or corn brought for provision, or the bringing thereof,] in the beginning of winter: (S, K:) or the miyrap of the [season called] rabiyE; which is the first myrp; next after. which is the Sayofiy~ap; and next after this, the dafay^iy~ap; and next after this, the ramaDiy~ap. (TA.) [See art. myr.] ― -b8- Also, the same, [used in like manner, for EiyrN riboEiy~apN,] Camels that bring provision of corn in the [season called] rabiyE; or, which means the same, in the beginning of the year: pl. rabaAEiY~u. (TA.) ― -b9- And [used in the same manner, for gazowapN riboEiy~apN,] A warring, or warring and plundering, expedition in the [season called] rabiyE. (TA.) ― -b10- riboEiY~N also signifies (tropical:) The first, or beginning, or former part, of anything; for instance, of youthfulness, or the prime of manhood; and of glory: and riboEiy~apN likewise, the beginning of breeding, and of summer. (TA.) ― -b11- riboEiY~u AlT~iEaAni (assumed tropical:) The sharpest kind of thrusting, or piercing. (Th, TA.)
riboEiy~apN * fem. of riboEiY~N: [and also used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: see the latter word, in several places.]

rabaAEN * : see an ex. in the phrase humo EalaY rabaAEihimo, voce riboEapN. -A2- rabaAEK, (S, Msb, K,) like vamaAnK (S, K) and yamaAnK [in the CK vamaAnN and vamaAnK] and $anaAHK and [pls. like] jawaArK, which are the only words of this form, (K,) and rabaAEN, (Kr, K,) accus. of the former rabaAEiyFA, (S, Msb, K,) and fem. rabaAEiyapN, (S, K,) Shedding its tooth called the rabaAEiyap, q. v.; applied to the sheep or goat in the fourth year, and to the bull and cow and the solid-hoofed animal in the fifth year, and to the camel in the seventh year: (S, Msb, K:) [see 4:] pl. [of pauc.] A^arobaAEN (Az, K) and [of mult.] rubuEN (Az, S, Msb, K) and ruboEN, (Th, Az, K,) but the former is the more common, (Az,) and rubaEN (IAar, K) and riboEaAnN (S, Msb, K) and ribaAEN and rabaAEiyaAtN. (K.) You say, rakibotu biro*awonFA rabaAEiyFA [I rode a hackney shedding his rabaAEiyap, or in his fifth year]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Hence, HarobN rabaAEiyapN (assumed tropical:) Vehement and youthful war. (TA.)

rubaAEu * [Four and four: four and four together: or four at a time and four at a time:] is a deviation from the original form, (S, K,) or A^arobaEapN A^arobaEapN; for which reason, [and, accord. to general opinion, because it is at the same time an epithet, (see vulaAvu,)] it is imperfectly decl.: (K:) but the dim. is ↓ rubay~iEN, perfectly decl. (S voce vulaAvu, q. v.) [See exs. voce vulaAvu.] In the Kur iv. 3, El-Aamash read ↓ warubaEa instead of warubaAEa. (IJ, K.)
rabuwEN * A she-camel that yields four A^aqodaAH [pl. of qadaHN] of milk. (IAar.) -A2- See also AlA^arobiEaA='u.

rabiyEN * : see ruboEN, in two places. -A2- It has also a twofold application; to months and to seasons: and it has a twofold application to months; denoting Two months, (S, Msb, K,) [next] after SafarN; (S, K;) and they say, (Msb,) one should only say, in speaking of them, $ahoru rabiyEK AlA^aw~alu and $ahoru rabiyEK AlA=xirN; (S, Msb, K;) [but in the margin of the copy of the S which I have here followed, I find it stated that in the handwriting of the author the former is $hr rbyEi AlAwl (with a single kesreh, and with no syll. sign to AlAwl); and in another copy of the S I find $hru rbyE AlAwli and $ahru rabyE AlA=xir;] with the addition of $hr: but it is allowable to say also $ahoru rabiyEi AlA^aw~ali and $ahoru rabiyEi AlA=xiri: the word $hr is necessarily added in order to discriminate between the months thus called and the season called rbyE: Az says, the Arabs mention all the months without the word $hr except the two months of rbyE and the month of ramaDaAn: and they say also $ahoraA rabiyEK and A^a$ohuru rabiyEK and $uhuwru rabiyEK: (Msb:) these months were thus called because, when they received this name, they occurred in the season when the earth produced herbage. (Msb in art. jmd.) It has a twofold application also to seasons; Alr~abiyEu AlA^aw~alu being The season in which the truffles and the blossoms come, (S, Msb, K,) and this is [also called] rabiyEu AlkalaA^i [the rabeea of the herbage, properly called the spring of Arabia]; (S;) and Alr~abiyEu Alv~aAniY The season in which fruits ripen; (S, Msb, K;) [also called rabiyEu Alv~imaAri;] but some people call this Alr~abiyEu AlA^aw~alu; (S, TA;) and the season which follows the winter, and in which the truffles and the blossoms come, they call Alr~abiyEu Alv~aAniY; but all of them agree that the xariyf [or autumn] is called Alr~abiyEu: AHn says, the two divisions of the winter [by which he means the half-year commencing at the autumnal equinox] are called rabiyEaAni; the former being rabiyEu AlmaA='i waAlA^amoTaAr i [the rabeea of the water and the rains, in which the rain called AlwasomiY~, which is termed the first of the rains, commences]; and the second being rabiyEu Aln~abaAti [or rabiyEu AlkalaA^i the rabeea of the herbage], because the herbage therein attains to its last stage: and he adds, that rabiyEN is applied by the Arabs to the whole winter, [meaning, again, the half-year commencing at the autumnal equinox,] because of the moisture, or rain: (TA:) or the year consists of six seasons; (so in the K; but in the S, “ and I heard Abu-l-Ghowth say, the Arabs make the year to be six seasons; ”) two months thereof are called Alr~abiyEu AlA^aw~alu; and two months, SayofN; and two months, qayoZN; (S, K;) and two months, rbyE AlvAnY, (so in a copy of the S,) or rabiyEN Alv~AnY, (so in another copy of the S, [but in the margin of this latter, I find it stated that in the handwriting of the author it is rbyEu AlvAnY, without tenween,]) or Alr~abiyEu Alv~aAniY; (K;) and two months, xariyfN; and two months, $itaA='N. (S, K.) Az relates, with respect to the seasons and divisions of the year, on the authority of Aboo-Yahyà Ibn-Kibáseh, who possessed very great knowledge thereof, that the year consists of four seasons; namely, Alr~abiyEu AlA^aw~alu, which the vulgar call Alxariyfu [The autumn]; then Al$~itaA='u [the winter]; then AlS~ayofu, which is Alr~abiyEu AlA=xiru [or Alv~aAniY, i. e. the spring]; then AlqayoZu [the summer, or hot season]: all this is what the Arabs in the desert say: the rbyE which is with the Persians the xryf, he says, commences on the third of A^ayoluwl [September O. S.]; and the $itaA=', on the third of kaAnuwn AlA^aw~al [December O. S.]; and the Syf
which is with the Persians the rbyE. on the fifth of A=*aAr [March O. S.]; and the qyZ which is with the Persians the Syf, on the fourth of HaziyraAn [June O. S.]: and Aboo-Yahyà adds, the rbyE of the people of El-' Irák agrees with the rbyE of the Persians, which is after the $tA' [or winter], and which is the season of the flowers, or roses, and is the most temperate of the seasons: the people of El-' Irák, he says, have rain in all the winter, and have abundance of herbage in the xryf, which the Arabs call AlrbyE AlAw~l: and Az says, the quarter of the xryf is called xryf because the fruits are gathered therein; and the Arabs call it rbyE because the first rain [which is called AlwasomiY~] falls therein. (TA.) The pl. of rbyE is A^arobiEapN [a pl. of pauc.] and A^arobiEaA='u [a pl. of mult.] (S, Msb, K) and ribaAEN; (AHn, K;) or the first of these is pl. of rbyE AlklA^ (Fr, Yaakoob, S, Msb, K) and of the rbyE of the months; (Fr, Msb;) but the second is pl. of rbyE in the sense of jadowalN, to be explained below. (Fr, Yaakoob, S, Msb, K.) Hence the phrase in a supplication, mentioned in a trad., Aall~`hum~a A@joEali AlquroA=na rabiyEa qalobiY [O God, make Thou the Kur-án to be the life, or ease, of my heart]; because the heart of man becomes lively, or at ease, in the season called rabiyE. (TA.) Hence also, (TA,) A^abuw Alr~abiyEi The hudohud [or hoopoe]; (K;) because it appears with the [season called] rbyE. (TA.) [See also, respecting the seasons &c., the word zamanN.] ― -b2- Also The rain in the [season called] rabyE [as meaning the half-year commencing at the autumnal equinox, (which includes what is really the spring of Arabia, called “ the rabeea of the herbage, ”) accord. to a statement of AHn cited above, and accord. to what is stated on the authority of AZ voce nawo'N]: (S, K:) or [only, accord. to some,] the rain which is after the wasomiY~, and after which is [that called] the Sayof, and then the Hamiym: or, accord. to AHn, rain whenever it comes: Az says, I have heard the Arabs call thus the first rain falling upon the earth in the days of the xariyf [or autumn]: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] is A^arobiEapN and [of mult.] ribaAEN. (AHn, TA.) [See also, respecting the rains, the word zamanN.] ― -b3- Also Herbage; green herbage which the beasts eat; (TA;) [properly] the herbage that is produced by the first rain in the quarter which is called the rabiyE, and which is commonly called the xariyf [or autumn], (Msb in art. zmn,) [continuing its growth during the winter-quarter, which is also called the rabiyE, and which includes, as stated above, what is really the spring of Arabia, called “ the rabeea of the herbage, ” wherein, as AHn says, the herbage attains to its last stage: it seems generally to mean the spring-herbage, which is earlier or later in different latitudes:] pl. A^aroibEapN. (TA.) [Hence,] a poet says,
yadaAka yadN rabiyEu Aln~aAsi fiyhaA
wafiY AlA^uxoraY Al$~uhuwru mina AlHaraAmi
meaning (assumed tropical:) [Thy two hands are such that] one hand has in it the means of the plentiful subsistence of mankind, [and in the other are the sacred months, i. e.] in the other is [that which causes] security, and safeguard, and the preservation of what is to be regarded as sacred and inviolable. (TA.) [Compare Proverbs iii. 16.] ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) A rivulet, or streamlet; (Msb, K;) i. q. jadowalN: (S, Msb, K:) or i. q. nahorN: (Mgh:) or nahorN SagiyrN: (Har p. 402:) (tropical:) a rivulet, or streamlet, that runs to palmtrees: and rabiyEu Als~aAqiY, a subst prefixed to its epithet, occurring in a trad., (assumed tropical:) the river [or rivulet] that waters seed-produce: (TA:) pl. A^arobiEaA='u (Fr, Yaakoob, S, Msb, K) and riboEaAnN. (TA.) A poet says, describing one drinking much,
fuwhu rabiyEN wakaf~uhu qadaHN
(assumed tropical:) His mouth is a river [and his hand is a bowl]. (TA.) ― -b5- Also A share, or portion, of water for [irrigating] land, (IDrd, K, TA,) whatever it be: or, as some say, a share, or portion, thereof for the quarter of a day or night; but this is not of valid authority. (TA.) You say, lifulaAnK mino h`*aA AlmaA='i rabiyEN, (K, TA,) or, as in some copies of the K, fiY, instead of mino, i. e. To such a one belongs a share, or portion, of this water [for irrigating land]. (TA.) ― -b6- The dim. of rabiyEN is ↓ rubay~iEN. (Msb.)
rubay~iEN * : see rubaAEN: -A2- and see also rabiyEN, last sentence.
rabaAEapN * : see riboEapN, in two places.

ribaAEapN * : see riboEapN, in four places. ― -b2- It also signifies A kind of HamaAlap [meaning obligation, or responsibility, that must be discharged, or performed, taken upon himself by a person for others; and here, particularly, such as is taken upon himself by the head, or chief, of a people]. (S, K.) You say, huwa EalaY ribaAEapi qawomihi, [properly He is over the affairs of his people, as indicated above, voce riboEapN, last sentence,] meaning He is the head, or chief, of his people. (TA.) Abu-l- Kásim El-Isbahánee says, ribaAEapN is metaphorically used to signify (tropical:) The being a head, or chief; or the office of head, or chief; in consideration of the taking of the mirobaAE [or fourth part of the spoil, which was the share of the chief]: and hence one says, laAyuqiymu ribaAEapa Alqawomi gayoru fulaAnK (tropical:) [None will act vigorously in the office of head, or chief, of the people, except such a one]. (TA.)

rabiyEapN *
A stone that is raised, or lifted, (S, K, TA,) for trial of strength: (K, TA:) applied only to a stone. (Az, TA.) -A2- A helmet of iron. (Lth, S, K.) -A3- A meadow; or a garden; syn. rawoDapN. (IAar, K.) -A4- A [leathern water-bag, such as is called] mazaAdap. (K.) ― -b2- A kind of receptacle for perfume and the like; syn. EatiydapN, q. v. (K.)

rubaAEiY~N * A boy four spans (A^a$obaAr) in height. (S and Msb voce xumaAsiY~N, q. v.) It is also applied to a camel, like subaAEiY~N; [app. meaning Four cubits in height:] fem. with p. (TA in art. sbE.) ― -b2- [Also A word composed of four letters, radical only, or radical and augmentative.]

rabaAEiyapN * The tooth that is between the vaniy~ap [or central incisor] and the naAb; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. each of the four teeth which are next to the vanaAyaA, (Mgh, * TA,) pertaining to man and to others: (TA:) pl. rabaAEiyaAtN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) a man has, above, [two teeth called] vaniy~ataAni, and [two called] rabaAEiyataAni, after them, and [two called] naAbaAni, and [two called] DaAHikaAni, and six A^aroHaA=', on each side [three], and [two teeth called] naAji*aAni; and the like below: (As, TA:) and the solid-hoofed animal has, after the vanaAyaA, four rabaAEiyaAt, and four qawaAriH, and four A^anoyaAb, and eight A^aDoraAs. (AZ, TA.) -A2- Also fem. of rabaAEK [q. v.]. (S, K.)
rab~aAEN * One who often buys, or sells, ribaAE, meaning houses, or places of abode. (IAar, K.)

raAbiEN * [act. part. n. of rabaEa]. ― -b2- The chief who used to take the fourth part of the spoil, in the Time of Ignorance. (Ham p. 336.) ― -b3- huwa raAbiEu A^arobaEapK He is [the fourth of four, or] one of four. (TA.) ― -b4- [raAbiEa Ea$ara and raAbiEapa Ea$orapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Fourteenth, are subject to the same rules as vaAliva Ea$ara and its fem., expl. in art. vlv, q. v.] ― -b5- A_ibilN rawaAbiEu [Camels coming to water, or being watered, on the fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first: pl. of raAbiEapN]: from rabaEati AlA_ibilu, meaning waradati Alr~iboEa. (S, K.) In like manner, also, rawaAbEu is applied, metaphorically, to birds of the kind called qaTFA, as an epithet denoting their coming to water, by El- 'Ajjáj. (TA.) -A2- rabiyEN raAbiEN A fruitful, or plentiful, rbyE [meaning the season so called]. (ISk, K.) ― -b2- One does not say yawomN raAbiEN like as one says yawomN qaAy^iZN &c., because there is no corresponding verb, like qaAZa, &c., for such a verb would have no meaning of heat nor of cold. (IB.) -A3- huwa raAbiEN EalaY HaAlihi He is abiding, or continuing, in his state, or condition. (TA.)
A^arobaEN * : see A^arobaEapN. -A2- hiYa A^arobaEuhun~a laqaAHFA She is the quickest of them in conceiving, or becoming pregnant. (Th.)

A^arobaEapN * [Four;] a masc. n. of number; fem. ↓ A^arobaEN. (S, K.) [Respecting a peculiar pronunciation of the people of El-Hijáz, and a case in which ArbEp is imperfectly decl., see valaAvapN. See also sit~apN.] ― -b2- *awaAtu AlA^arobaEi The quadrupeds. (The Lexicons passim.) ― -b3- jaA='ato EayonaAhu biA^arobaEapK (tropical:) His two eyes shed tears running from their four sides: or it means, accord. to Z, he came weeping most vehemently. (TA.) [See another ex. voce vamaAniyapN.] ― -b4- A^arobaEapa Ea$ara [indecl. in every case, meaning Fourteen,] is pronounced by some of the Arabs A^arobaEapa Eo$ara: and [the fem.] A^arobaEa Ea$orapa, thus in the dial. of El-Hijáz [and of most of the Arabs], is pronounced A^arobaEa Ea$irapa in the dial. of Nejd. (S in art. E$r.)
