AlA^arobiEaA='u * , [also written without tenween when not rendered determinate by the article or otherwise accord. to most authorities, who make it fem., but with tenween when indeterminate accord. to those who make it masc.,] and AlA^arobaEaA='u, (As, S, Msb, K,) the latter on the authority of some of the BenooAsad, (S, Msb,) and AlA^arobuEaA='u, (As, Msb, K,) which is a form of the word seldom used, (Msb,) and AlA_irobiEaA='u, and AlA_irobaEaA='u, the last two mentioned by IHsh, the first of all the most chaste, (MF,) but it is the only sing. word of its measure, (El- Kutabee, Msb,) except A^aromidaA='u, (AZ, O,) the name of A certain day; (S, Msb, K;) [namely Wednesday;] the fourth day of the week; (L;) as also ↓ Alr~abuwEu; but this is post-classical: (TA:) the dual of A^arobiEaA=' is A^arobiEaAwaAni; (L;) and the pl. is A^arobiEaAwaAtN, (S, L,) [accord. to those who make the sing. fem.;] or the dual is A^arobiEaA='aAni, and the pl. is A^arobiEaA='aAtN; (K;) thus says Aboo-Jukhádib, regarding the noun as masc.: (Fr:) Aboo-Ziyád used to say, maDaY AlA^arobiEaA='u bimaA fiyhi [Wednesday passed with what (occurred) in it], making it sing. and masc. [because he meant thereby yawomu AlA^arobiEaA='u]; but Abu-l-Jarráh used to say, maDati AlA^arobiEaA='u bimaA fiyhin~a, making it fem. and pl., and employing it like a n. of number: (Lh:) Th is related to have mentioned A^araAbiyEu as a pl. of AlA^arobiEaA='u; but ISd says, I am not sure of this. (TA.) The word has no dim. (Sb, S in art. Ams.)
A^arobaEuwna * [Forty;] a certain number, (TA,) after valaAvuwna. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Also Fortieth.]
A^arobiEaAwiY~N * One who fasts alone on the A^arobiEaA=' [or Wednesday]. (IAar.)
marobaEN * ; see raboEN in three places.

murobaEN * , applied to a camel, [That is watered on the fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first: (see 4:) and] that is brought to the water at any time. (TA.) ― -b2- See also marobuwEN.

murobiEN * : ― -b2- see marobuwEN. -A2- Applied to rain, (S, Msb, TA,) That comes in the [season called] rabiyE: [in the Ham p. 425, written marobaE:] or that induces the people to remain in their abodes and not to seek after herbage: (TA:) or that confines the people in their ribaAE [or dwellings] by reason of its abundance: (Msb:) or that causes the [herbage called] rabiyE to grow: (TA:) or that causes the growth of that in which the camels may pasture at pleasure. (S.) ― -b2- With p, applied to land (A^aroDN), Abounding with [the herbage called] rabiyE; as also ↓ mirobaAEN. (TA.) ― -b3- Without p, applied to a she-camel, (As, S, K,) That brings forth in the [season called] rabiyE: (S, K:) or that has her young one with her; (As, S, K;) the young one being called rubaEN: (As, S:) as also ↓ mirobaAEN: (As, TA:) or the latter signifies one that usually brings forth in the [season called] rabiyE: (S, K:) or that brings forth in the beginning of the breeding-time: (As, S, K:) or that is early, or before others, in becoming pregnant: (TA:) and the former, so applied, signifies also one whose womb is, or becomes, closed, [app. in the season called rabiyE, (see 4,)] so that it does not admit the seminal fluid. (TA.) ― -b4- Applied to a man, (tropical:) Having offspring born to him in the prime of his manhood. (TA.) [See 4] -A3- Also The sail of a full ship: (AA, K:) that of an empty ship is called ruwmiY~N. (AA, TA.)
mirobaEN * : see mirobaEapN.

murab~aEN * (S, K,) Having four portions [or sides or faces or angles &c.; generally meaning either square or quadrilateral]: or of the form of a thing having four legs; or of the form of a quadruped. (TA.) [See also muval~avN.] ― -b2- murab~aEu AlHaAjibayoni (assumed tropical:) A man whose eyebrows have much hair; as though he had four eyebrows. (TA.) ― -b3- murab~aEN Aljabohapi [Having a square forehead; meaning] (tropical:) a slave. (TA.)

A^aroDN marobaEapN *
A land containing, or having, yaraAbiyE [or jerboas]; (S, K;) as also ↓ A^aroDN murotabiEN. (TA.)

mirobaEapN *
A staff, (K,) or small staff, (S,) of which two men take hold of the two ends in order to raise a load (S, K) and put it upon the back of the camel, (S,) or upon the beast; (K;) as also ↓ mirobaEN: (K:) which latter is also expl. as signifying a piece of wood with which a thing is taken. (TA.) [See 1, last signification but one.]

mirobaAEN * : see ruboEN: -A2- and marobuwEN: -A3- and raboEN. -A4- Rain that comes in the beginning of the [season called] rabiyE: [an epithet used in this sense as a subst.:] pl. maraAbiyEu. (S, * K, * TA, * [in which only the pl. is mentioned,] and EM p. 140.) Hence, maraAbiyEu Aln~ujuwmi, as used in a verse of Lebeed cited in the first paragraph of art. rzq; by the nujuwm being meant the A^anowaA='; (S;) i. e. the Mansions of the Moon [which by their rising or setting at dawn were supposed to bring rain or wind or heat or cold]. (EM ubi suprà.) ― -b2- Applied to a place, That produces herbage in the beginning of the [season called] rabiyE. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Applied to land (A^aroDN): see murobiEN. ― -b4- Applied to a she-camel: see murobiEN.

marobuwEN *
Twisted of four twists, or strands; (S, TA;) applied to a rope, (TA,) as also ↓ mirobaAEN, (Ibn-' Abbád, TA,) and to a bow-string, and a bridle. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a spear, Four cubits in length: (TA:) or neither long nor short; (S, TA;) and in like manner applied to a man: see raboEN, in two places: (S, Mgh, L, &c.:) and [hence its pl.] maraAbiyEu, applied to horses, compact in make. (TA.) -A2- Also, applied to a man, Having a fever which seizes him on one day and leaves him two days and then comes again on the fourth day [counting the day of the next preceding fit as the first; i. e. having, or seized by, a quartan fever]; as also ↓ murobaEN; (S, K;) and ↓ murobiEN is said to be used in the same sense; but the Arabs say murobaEN. (Az, TA.) -A3- A^aroDN marobuwEapF, and $ajarN marobuwEN, Land, and trees, watered by the rain in the season called rabiyE. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] marobuwEN, applied to a man, also signifies (tropical:) Restored from a state of poverty to wealth or competence or sufficiency; recovered from his embarassment or difficulty, or from a state of perdition or destruction. (TA.)
maraAbiyEu * , pl. of marobuwEN [q. v.]: -A2- and pl. of mirobaAEN [q. v.].
murotabaEN * : see raboEN, in three places.
murotabiEN * , applied to a beast, That has pastured upon the [herbage called] rabiyE, and become fat, and brisk, lively, or sprightly. (TA.) -A2- See also raboEN: -A3- and see A^aroDN marobaEapN.

jalasa mutarab~iEFA *
He sat cross-legged; i. q. tarab~aEa fiY juluwsihi. (TA.)

musotarobiEN $ayoy^FA *
Having power, or ability, for, or to do, a thing; as, for instance, war, or battle; (IAar;) or to bear, or endure, a thing; (IAar, Sgh;) as when relating to an envier, meaning his envy. (Sgh.) You say also rajulN musotarobiEN biEamalihi A man who is able by himself to execute his work, having power, or strength, to do it, and very patient. (K.)

yarobuwEN * , in which the Y is augmentative, (Kr, S, Msb,) because there is not in the language of the Arabs any word of the measure faEoluwlN, (Kr, S,) except what is extr., such as SaEofuwqN, (K,) which is a foreign word [introduced into their language], (S in art. SEfq,) [The jerboa;] a certain wellknown beast; (K;) a small beast like the faA^orap [or rat], but longer in the tail and ears, and of which the hind legs are longer than the fore-legs, the reverse of what is the case in the zaraAfap [or giraffe]; called by the vulgar jarobuwE; (Msb;) a rat (faA^orap) of which the burrow has four entrances; Az says, it is a small beast larger than the jura*, [q. v.; but in the L, in art. jr*, the reverse of this is said;] and the name is applied alike to the male and the female: (TA:) [Forskål (“ Descr. Animalium, ” p. iv.,) terms it mus jaculus: see the questions appended to Niebuhr's “ Descr. de l' Arabie, ” p. 177:] pl. yaraAbiyEu. (S, Msb.) [See *uw Alr~umayoHi, voce rumoHN.] ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) AlyarobuwEu also signifies laHomapu Almatoni (tropical:) [The portion of flesh and sinew next the back-bone, on either side]; (S * K;) as being likened to the fA^arp [thus called]: (TA:) or this is with damm [AlyurobuwEu]: (K:) or the yaraAbiyEu of the maton are its portions of flesh; (T, S, K;) and the word has no sing.: (K:) Az says, I have not heard any sing. thereof. (TA.)

AljaAru AlyarobuwEiY~u *
The neighbour that is variable in his actions [like the jerboa, which is noted for having recourse to various expedients, in the formation of its burrow, &c., to avoid capture]; like AljaAru AlbaraAqi$iY~u. (IAar, TA in art. jwr.)

1 rabaqahu * , aor.
rabuqa (S, Msb, K) and
rabaqa , (S, K,) inf. n. raboqN, (JK, S, Msb,) He put his head (i. e. the head of a kid, S, K, or of a lamb, K, or of a sheep or goat, Msb) into the riboqop, (S, K,) or into the riboq: (Msb:) or, accord. to the M, he made fast, or bound or tied fast or firmly, him, or it, in the riboqap: (TA:) or he made fast, or bound or tied fast or firmly, his (a sheep's or goat's) neck with the riboq, or cord: (JK:) and ↓ rb~qhu, inf. n. tarobiyqN, he made fast, or bound or tied fast or firmly, him, or it, in the ribaAq [pl. of riboqN or of riboqapN]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rabaqahu fiY AlA^amori, (Msb, K,) aor.
rabuqa , inf. n. raboqN, (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) He made him to fall into the thing, or affair. (Msb, K.) ― -b3- raboqN also signifies The act of making fast; or binding, or tying, fast, or firmly; and so riboqN; (K;) each as an inf. n. of rabaqahu. (TK.)

2 rb~q * [He prepared the A^arobaAq, pl. of riboqN]. One says, ram~aditi AlD~aA^onu farab~qo rab~qo, i.e. [The ewes have secreted milk in their udders: therefore] prepare thou the A^arobaAq: prepare thou the ArbAq: for they will bring forth soon: (S, K:) because they [begin to] secrete milk in their udders EalaY raA^osi Alwaladi [i. e. at the time of bringing forth, or when about to produce the young]. (S.) It is not thus in the case of she-goats: therefore, (S,) in the case of these, one says ran~qo, with n, (S, K,) meaning “ wait thou: ” because they show sings of pregnancy in the state of their udders, and bring forth after some length of time: and [in the case of these] one says also ram~iqo, with m. (K. [See arts. rmq and rnq.]) ― -b2- One also says, rab~aqa A^avonaA='a AlHaboli, meaning He made loops in the middle of the rope to put upon the necks of the young lambs or kids. (T in art. vnY.) ― -b3- See also 1. ― -b4- rab~aqotu AlkalaAma I interlarded, or embel-lished, the speech, or discourse, with falsehood; as also ram~aqotuhu; syn. laf~aqotu bayonahu; (JK;) [or laf~aqotuhu; for] tarobiyqu AlkalaAmi signifies talofiyquhu; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) as also taromiyquhu. (Ibn-'Abbád.)
5 tarab~aqotu Al$~aYo'a * , (JK,) or trb~qthu mino EunuqiY, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) (tropical:) I hung the thing upon my neck. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.)

8 Artbq *
He (a kid) had his head put into the riboqap. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Artbq fiY HibaAlatiY He (a gazelle, S, K) became caught in my snare. (Lh, JK, S, K.) ― -b3- And Artbqtu fiY HibaAlatihi (tropical:) I became caught in [the snare of] his deceit. (TA.) ― -b4- And Artbq fiY AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) He fell into the thing, or affair. (Msb, K.) -A2- Airotabaqotuhu linafosiY I tied, bound, or made fast, him, or it, for myself. (TA.)

riboqN *
A cord having in it a number of loops wherewith lambs, or kids, are tied, or made fast; any one of which loops is termed ↓ riboqapN (S, Msb, K) and ↓ raboqapN: (K:) or a cord which is doubled in the form of a ring, into which is put the head of a sheep or goat, and which is then tied, or made fast: so, says Az, I have heard from the Arabs of the desert of Benoo-Temeem: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] ribaAqN (S, Msb, K) and ribaqN and [of pauc.] A^arobaAqN. (S, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) xalaEa AlA_isolaAmi mino Eunuqihi ↓ riboqapa, (S, Msb, TA,) occurring in a trad., (S,) (tropical:) He cast off the tie of El-Islám, (Msb, TA,) with which he had bound himself, (TA,) [from his neck.] (Msb, TA. [See also xalaEa.]) And lakumu AlEahodu maA lamo taA^okuluwA Alr~ibaAqa, also occurring in a trad., (S,) meaning (tropical:) [The covenant is yours] as long as ye sever not the tie with which ye are bound; this tie being likened to the riboq upon the necks of lambs or kids; and the severing thereof, to the beast's eating its riboq, and severing it; for thereby the beast becomes free from the tie. (TA.) And in a trad. of 'Omar, Huj~uwA biAl*~ur~iy~api laA taA^okuluwA A^arozaAqahaA wata*aruwA A^arobaAqahaA fiY A^aEonaAqihaA [Perform ye the pilgrimage with the women: devour not their means of subsistence, while ye leave their ties upon their necks]: he likens the obligations imposed upon them to ArbAq. (TA.) One says also, ↓ Hal~a riboqatahu, meaning (tropical:) He removed from him his anxiety: (K, TA:) and so ↓ qaTaEa riboqatahu. (TA.)
raboqapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

riboqapN * : see riboqN, in four places. ― -b2- Also A thing woven of black wool, of the width of the tik~ap [or band of the drawers or trowsers], in which is a red stripe of dyed wool: its extremities are tied together, and then it is hung upon the neck [or shoulder] of a boy, so that one of his arms comes forth from it like as when a man puts forth one of his arms from the suspensory of the sword: the Arabs of the desert hang the ribaq [pl. of riboqapN] upon the necks of their boys only as a preservative from the [evil] eye. (T, TA.)
ribiq~aAnN * and ribiq~aAnapN Evil in disposition: applied to a man; and in like manner to a woman: mentioned by As and in the K in art. Ebq [where, in some copies, it is written raboqaAnu]. (TA.)

rabiyqN * , (TA,) or rabiyqapN, (S, Msb, K,) applied to a lamb or kid (bahomap), (ISk, S, K,) or to a sheep or goat ($aAp), (Msb, TA,) Having its head put into the riboqap; (ISk, S, Msb, K, TA;) as also ↓ marobuwqapN (ISk, JK, S, Msb, K) and ↓ murab~aqapN. (JK, TA.)

A^um~u Alr~ubayoqi *
Calamity, or misfortune: (JK, S, K:) whence the prov., jaA='anaA biA^m~i Alr~ubayoqi EalaY A^urayoqi, (TA,) meaning He brought us a great calamity, or misfortune: (K in art. Arq:) As says that the Arabs assert it to have been said by a man who saw the ghool upon a dusky white camel (jamal A^aworaq); (S in that art., and TA;) A^urayoq being the dim. of A^aworaq: (K in that art.:) or Am~ Alrbyq is a name of war, or battle: or the viper: (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, TA:) this last signification is held to be correct by Z, because, he says, the viper is short, and when it folds itself it resembles the ribaq (TA.)

tirobiyqN *
A cord with which a ewe, or goat, is tied (K, TA) by the neck. (TA.)

murobiqN *
i. q. muToriqN [Silent: or lowering the eyes, looking towards the ground: &c.]. (JK, TA.)
murab~aqapN * : see rabiyqN. -A2- Also, [or xubozapN murab~aqapN,] A cake of bread, or one baked in ashes, into which fat has been put; syn. xubozapN mu$aH~amapN. (K.)
marobuwqapN * : see rabiyqN

1 rabakahu * , (S, K,) [like labakahu,] aor.
rabuka , inf. n. rabokN, (S, TA,) He mixed, or mingled, it. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (S, TA,) He made it good, or qualified it properly, namely, variyd [i. e. crumbled, or broken, bread, moistened with broth], (S, K, TA,) and mixed it with some other thing. (TA.) ― -b3- And rabaka rabiykapF, (K, TA,) [and rabaka alone,] aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He made rbykp [q. v.]. (K.) garovaAnu faA@robukuwA lahu [He is hungry, therefore make ye rbykp for him], (S, K,) or, as IDrd relates it, fiA@bokuluwA lahu [i. e., “ therefore mix ye bakaAlap (a certain food) for him ”], (TA,) is a prov.; (S, K;) the origin of which was this: (S:) a certain Arab of the desert, (S, K,) said in the O to be Ibn-Lisán-el-Hommarah, (TA,) came to his family, or wife, (S, K,) from a journey, (TA,) and was congratulated with the annunciation that a boy was born to him: whereupon he said, “ What shall I do with him? Shall I eat him or shall I drink him? ” so his wife said, garovaAnu faA@robukuwA lahu: and when he was satiated, he said, “ How are the infant and his mother? ” (S, K:) the saying means, “ he is hungry, therefore prepare ye for him food, that his hunger may be allayed, and then congratulate him with the annunciation of the birth of the child: ” and IDrd says that it is applied to the case of him whose anxiety has departed and who has become unoccupied so that he may attend to other things. (TA.) ― -b4- And rabaka fulaAnFA, (Lth, K,) inf. n. as above, (Lth, TA,) He threw such a one into mire. (Lth, K.) -A2- rabika: see 8.

8 Artbk *
It was, or became, mixed, or mingled. (S, K.) ― -b2- He (a man) stuck fast in mire. (Lth, K, * TA.) And (tropical:) He (an animal of the chase) struggled in the snare. (K, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He (a man, TA) was, or became, in the condition of one whose affair, or case, is confused to him; as also ↓ rabika, aor.
rabaka , (K, TA,) inf. n. rabakN. (TA.) And Artbk fiY AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, entangled in the affair, and could hardly, or not at all, escape from it. (S.) And Artbk fiY AlhalakaAti (tropical:) He fell into cases of perdition, and could hardly, or not at all, escape from them. (TA from a trad. of 'Alee.) ― -b4- Artbk fiY kalaAmihi (tropical:) He reiterated in his speech, by reason of an impediment, or inability to say what he would; syn. tataEotaEa. (K, TA.)

11 ArbAk~ raA^oyuhu Ealayohi * , (K, * TA,) inf. n. AirobiykaAkN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) His opinion, or judgment, was, or became, confused to him. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.) ― -b2- And ArbAk~ Eani AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) He (a man) paused, or stopped, from the affair. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

rabikN * (assumed tropical:) A man (IDrd) weak in art, artifice,
cunning, ingenuity, or skill, in the management of affairs: (IDrd, K:) a possessive epithet. (IDrd.)
rubakN * and ↓ ribak~N and ↓ rabiykN (assumed tropical:) A man in a state of confusion in respect of his affair, or case: (K:) the last is a possessive epithet. (TA.)
ribak~u * : see what next precedes.

rabuwku *
Dates kneaded with clarified butter and [the preparation of dried curd called] A^aqiT, after which it is eaten. (Sgh, TA.) [See also rabiykapu.]
rabiykN * : see the next paragraph: ― -b2- and see also rubakN.

rabiykapN * (S, K) and ↓ rabiykN (K) Dates with clarified butter and [the preparation of dried curd called] A^aqiT, (S, K,) kneaded together, and then eaten; [like rabuwkN, as explained above;] and, as ISk says, sometimes water is poured upon it, and it is drunk: or, he adds, accord. to Ghaneeyeh Umm-El-Homáris, A^aqiT and dates and clarified butter, made soft, not like what is called Hayos: (S:) or (accord. to Ed-Dubeyreeyeh, S) flour and A^aqiT (S, K) ground, and then (S) mixed with clarified butter (S, K) and rub~ [or inspissated juice]: (S:) or dates and A^aqiT (K, TA) kneaded without clarified butter: (TA:) or inspissated juice (rub~, K, TA) mixed (TA) with flour or sawiyq [i. e. meal of parched barley]: (K, TA:) or a cooked compound of dates and wheat. (K.) ― -b2- Also the former word, A portion of fresh butter from which the milk will not separate, (Sgh, K,) so that it is mixed [therewith]. (Sgh.) ― -b3- And Water mixed with mud. (Sgh, K.) ― -b4- [Hence,] ramaAhu biAlr~abiykapi i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He accused him of] a thing that stuck fast upon him. (TA.)

1 rabaluwA * , (T, S, M, K,) aor.
rabula (T, S, K) and
rabila , (K,) inf. n. rubuwlN, (T,) They multiplied; became many in number: (T, M, K:) they increased and multiplied: (S:) and their children multiplied, and their cattle, or property. (M, K.) See also 8. ― -b2- rabalato She (a woman) was, or became, fleshy; (M;) and so ↓ trb~lt. (S.) And you say also laHomuhu ↓ trb~l [app. meaning His flesh was, or became, abundant]. (M in art. rA^bl.) -A2- rabalati AlA^aroDu, (IDrd, M, K,) inf. n. rabolu; (IDrd, TA;) and ↓ Arblt; (IDrd, M, K;) The land produced rabol [q. v.]: (IDrd, K:) or abounded with rabol: (M:) or the latter signifies it ceased not to have in it rabol. (T.) And rabalati AlmaraAEiY The pasturages abounded with herbage. (T.) [See also 5.]
4 A^arobala see above. -A2- Also Arbl He was, or became, wicked, crafty, or cunning; [like raA^obala; see art. rA^bl;] and lay in wait for the purpose of doing evil, or mischief. (TA.)

5 tarab~ala see 1, in two places. -A2- trb~ilt AlA^aroDu The land had trees such as are termed rabol; i. e. breaking forth with green leaves, without rain, when the season had become cool to them, and the summer had retired: (As, A'Obeyd, T:) or the land became green after dryness, at the advent of autumn. (S.) And trb~l Al$~ajaru The trees put forth leaves such as are termed rabol. (M, K. *) ― -b2- trb~l also signifies He ate rabol; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) said of a gazelle. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) And They (a company of men) pastured their cattle upon rabol. (M, K.) And He prosecuted a search after rabol. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- Also He took, captured, caught, snared, or trapped; or sought to take &c.; game, or wild animals, or the like. (M, K.) You say, xarajuwA yatarab~aluwna They went forth to take &c., or seeking to take &c., game &c. (M.)

8 Artbl maAluhu *
His cattle, or property, multiplied; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) like ↓ rabala. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)
Q. Q. 2 tarayobala * , originally taraA^obala: see the latter, in art. rA^bl.

rabolN *
Fat, and soft, or supple: [perhaps, in this sense, a contraction, by poetic license, of rabilN:] an epithet applied to a man. (Ham p. 630.) -A2- Also A sort of trees which, when the season has become cool to them, and the summer has retired, break forth with green leaves, without rain: (As, A'Obeyd, T, S:) or certain sorts of trees that break forth [with leaves] in the end of the hot season, after the drying up, by reason of the coolness of the night, without rain: (K:) accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, a plant, or herbage, that scarcely, or never, grows but after the ground has dried up; as also ray~iHapN and xilofapN and rib~apN: (TA:) [and] leaves that break forth in the end of the hot season, after the drying up, by reason of the coolness of the night, without rain: (M:) pl. rubuwlN. (S, M, K.)

rabalN *
A certain plant, intensely green, abounding at Bulbeys [a town in the eastern province of Lower Egypt, commonly called Belbeys or Bilbeys,] (K) and its neighbourhood: (TA:) two drachms thereof are an antidote for the bite of the viper. (K.)

rabilN * , applied to a man, Fleshy: (A'Obeyd, S, TA:) or fleshy and fat. (TA. [See also rabiylN.]) And [in like manner the fem.] rabilapN, as also ↓ matarab~ilapN, Fleshy (M, K) and fat; applied to a woman. (M.) And rabilapN applied to a woman signifies also Large in the rabalaAt [pl. of rabalapN, q. v.]; (Lth, T, M, K;) as also ↓ rabolaA^'u: (M, K:) or both signify rafogaA='u; (O, K; [in the CK, erroneously, raqoEA'u;]) i. e. narrow in the A^aroqaAg [or groins, or inguinal creases, or the like], as expl. in the 'Eyn: (TA:) or you say rabolaA='u rafogaA='u, meaning [app., as seems to be implied in the context, large in the rabalaAt and] narrow in the A^arofaAg. (Lth, T.)
rabolapN * : see what next follows.

rabalapN * (AZ, T, S, M, K) and ↓ rabolapN, (S, M, K,) the former said by As to be the more chaste, (S,) The inner part of the thigh; (AZ, T, S, M, K;) i. e., of each thigh, of a man: (AZ, T:) or any large portion of flesh: (M, K:) or the parts (M, K) of the inner side of the thigh [or of each thigh] (M) that surround the udder (M, K) and the vulva: (K:) pl. rabalaAtN; (AZ, T, S, M, K;) which Th explains as meaning the roots of the thighs. (M, TA.)

rabaAlN *
Fleshiness and fatness. (IAar, T. [Thus in two copies of the T, without p. See also rabaAlapN.])

rabiylN *
Fleshy; applied to a man: (T:) or corpulent, large in body, or big-bodied; so applied: (TA:) and with p fat; applied to a woman. (TT, as from the T; but wanting in a copy of the T. [See also rabilN.]) ― -b2- [Also] A thief who goes on a hostile, or hostile and plundering, expedition, (M, K,) against a party, (M,) by himself. (M, K. [See also riybaAlN; and see Q. 2 in art. rA^bl.])

rabaAlapN *
Fleshiness, (A'Obeyd, S, M, K,) and some add and fatness. (TA. [See also rabaAlN.]) ― -b2- by^orN *aAtu rabaAlapK A well of which the water is wholesome and fattening to the drinkers. (Ham p. 367.)

rabiylapN *
Fatness; (S, M, K;) and ease, or ampleness of the circumstances, or plentifulness and pleasantness, or softness or delicateness, of life: (M, K: [in the CK, Aln~iEomapu is erroneously put for Aln~aEomapN:]) or the primary signification is softness, or suppleness, and fatness. (Ham p. 367.)
rayobalN * , applied to a woman, Soft, or tender: (O, TA:) or fleshy: (TA:) or soft, or tender, and fleshy. (K. [In the CK, Aln~Aqpu is erroneously put for Aln~aAEimapu.])
raAbilapN * The flesh of the shoulder-blade. (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA.)

riybaAlN * The lion; (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K;). as also riy^obaAlN, (S,) which is the original form, (M in art. rA^bl, q. v.,) derived from raA^obalapN signifying “ wickedness, ” &c.: (TA in that art.:) Aboo-Sa'eed says that it is allowable to omit the ' [and substitute for it Y]: (S:) [and Az says,] thus I have heard it pronounced by the Arabs, without ': (T:) or, accord. to Skr, it signifies a fleshy and young lion: (TA:) the pl. is rayaAbilapN (T, TA) and rayaAbiylu: (S, TA:) and hence rayaAbiylu AlEarabi, meaning Those, of the Arabs, who used to go on hostile, or hostile and plundering, expeditions, upon their feet [and alone]. (TA. [See also rabiylN; and see Q. 2 in art. rA^bl.]) It is also applied as an epithet to a wolf: and to a thief: (T, S:) accord. to Lth, because of their boldness: (T:) or as meaning Malignant, guileful, or crafty. (TA.) Applied to an old, or elderly, man, (M, K,) it means Advanced in age, (M,) or weak, or feeble. (K.) Also One who is the only offspring of his mother. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ― -b2- Applied to herbage, Tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and tall. (Fr, T, K.)
riybaAlapN * A cunning, or crafty, lion. (TA.)

rabolu A^arobalu * means, (M, K,) app., (M,) Good, or
excellent, rabol. (M, K. *) -A2- rabolaA='u [its fem.]: see rabilN.

A^aroDN mirobaAlN *
A land that ceases not to have in it rabol: (T:) or a land abounding therewith. (M, K.)
mutarab~ilapN * , applied to a woman: see rabilN.

1 rabaA * , aor. yarobuw, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. rabowN, (so in copies of the S, [in one of my copies of the S not mentioned,]) or rubuw~N and rabaA='N, (M, K, TA,) the latter erroneously written in [some of] the copies of the K ribaA=', (TA,) It (a thing, T, S, Msb) increased, or augmented. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) Said, in this sense, of property: (Mgh:) or, said of property, It increased by usury. (M, TA.) liyarobuwa fiY A^amowaAli A@ln~aAsi falaA yarobuw ↓ wamaA A=tayotumo Einoda A@ll~`hi, in the Kur [xxx. 38], (T, Bd,) means And what ye give of forbidden addition in commercial dealing, [i. e. of usury,] (Bd,) or what ye give of anything for the sake of receiving more in return, (Zj, T, Bd,) and this is not forbidden accord. to most of the expositions, though there is no recompense [from God] for him who exceeds what he has received, (Zj, T,) in order that it may increase the possessions of men, (T, * Bd,) it shall not increase with God, (T, Bd,) nor will He bless it: (Bd:) some (namely, the people of El-Hijáz, T, or Náfi' and Yaakoob, Bd) read ↓ liturobuwA, (T, Bd,) meaning, in order that ye may increase [the property of men], or in order that ye may have forbidden addition [or usury therein]. (Bd.) ― -b2- Also It became high. (Msb, * TA.) ― -b3- rabaA, aor. as above; and rabiYa, aor. yarobaY; said of a child, He grew up. (Msb.) You say, rabawotu fiY baniY fulaAnK, (S,) or fiY Hajorihi, inf. n. rubuw~N (M, K, TA) and rubowN, (M, TA,) with damm, (TA,) this latter on the authority of Lh, (M, TA,) accord. to the K rabowN, with fet-h, but correctly with damm; (TA;) and rabiytu, (S, M, TA,) in the copies of the K erroneously written rabayotu, (TA,) inf. n. rabaA='K and rubiY~N; (M, K, TA; [the latter, accord. to the CK, rabiY~N, which is a mistranscription;]) I grew up [among the sons of such a one, or in his care and protection]. (S, M, K.) ― -b4- rabati AlA^aroDu The ground [being rained upon] became large, and swelled. (M, TA.) In the Kur xxii. 5 and xli. 39, for warabato, some read warabaA^atN: the former means and [becomes large, and swells; or] increases: the latter means “ and rises. ” (T. [See art. rbA^.]) ― -b5- rabaA Als~awiyqu, inf. n. rubuw~N, The swyq [or meal of parched barley] had water poured upon it, and in consequence swelled: (M, TA:) in the copies of the K, rabaA Als~awiyqa, expl. as meaning he poured water on the swyq, and it consequently swelled. (TA.) ― -b6- rabaA said of a horse, (S, K,) aor. yarobuw, (TA,) inf. n. rabowN, (K,) He became swollen, or inflated, from running, or from fear, or fright (S, K.) ― -b7- He was, or became, affected with what is termed rabowN; (S, M, K;) i. e. he was, or became, out of breath; his breath became interrupted by reason of fatigue or running &c.; or he panted, or breathed shortly or uninterruptedly; syn. Ainobahara: (TA:) and so ↓ trb~Y; for you say, TalabonaA AlS~ayoda Hat~aY tarab~ayonaA, i. e. [We pursued the chase until] we became out of breath; &c.; syn. buhironaA. (M.) ― -b8- See also 4. -A2- rabawotu Alr~aAbiyapa I ascended, or mounted, upon the hill, or elevated ground. (S, K.)

2 rab~ayotuhu * , (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. tarobiyapN, (S, K,) I reared him, fostered him, or brought him up; (M, Msb;) namely, a child: (Msb:) I fed, or nourished, him, or it; (S, Mgh, K;) namely, a child, (Mgh,) or anything of what grows, or increases, such as a child, and seedproduce, and the like; (S;) as also ↓ tarab~ayotuhu: (Mgh, K:) the former is said to be originally rababotuhu. (Er-Rághib, TA. [See 1 in art. rb, in two places.]) [Thus rab~ayotu signifies I reared, or cultivated, plants or trees.] And rb~Y is said of earth, or soil, meaning It fostered plants or herbage. (L in art. r$H, &c.) And yunaw~iru walaA yurab~iY is said of a tree [as meaning It produces blossoms, but does not mature its produce]. (AHn, M and L in art. mZ.) ― -b2- rab~ayotu AlA^otoruj~a biEasalK (tropical:) [I preserved the citron with honey], and Alwaroda bisuk~arK [the roses with sugar: like rab~abotuhu]. (TA.) ― -b3- rab~ayotu Eano xinaAqihi [in the CK xunAqih, which I think a mistranscription,] (tropical:) I removed, or eased, [his cord with which he was being strangled; app. meaning, his straitness;] (K;) mentioned by Z. (TA.) [See a similar phrase in art. rxw, conj. 4.]

3 rAbAhu * , (K in art. mjr, as syn. of maAjarahu,) inf. n. muraAbaApN, (TA ibid.,) [He practised usury, or the like, with him: used in this sense in the present day.] ― -b2- And raAbayotuhu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) I treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him. (K, * TA.)

4 A^arobayotuhu * (in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, Artbyth, TA) I increased, or augmented, it. (M, K, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [ii. 277], wayurobiY AlS~adaqaAti (M, TA) And He will increase, or augment, alms-deeds; (Jel;) will multiply the recompense thereof, (Bd, Jel,) and bless them. (Bd.) See also an ex. in the first paragraph. -A2- A^arobayotu I took more than I gave. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ArbY, said of a man, signifies [particularly] He engaged in, or entered upon, Alr~ibaA [i. e. the practising, or taking, of usury or the like; he practised, or took, usury or the like; as also ↓ rabaA, aor. rabowN; for] A_irobaA='N and rabowN, as inf. ns., both signify, in Pers., ribaA xwurodano. (KL. [In the TA, rabaA, said of a man, is expl. by the words HSl fY rbwp: but I think that the right reading must be HaS~ala fiY ribFwA, or mino ribFwA; and the meaning, He acquired in the practice of usury or the like, or he acquired of usury or the like.]) See, again, an ex. in the first paragraph. ― -b3- ArbY EalaY Alxamosayna, (M, Msb,) wanaHowihaA, (M,) He exceeded [the age of fifty, and the like]. (M, Msb.) ― -b4- [A^arobaY said of the Earofaj, in a copy of the S, in art rqT is a mistranscription for A^adobaY, with dál.]

5 trb~Y * , said of a child, (Mgh, Msb,) He was, or became, fed, or nourished; (Mgh;) or reared, fostered, or brought up. (Msb.) -A2- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph. -A3- tarab~ayotuhu: see 2.

rabowN * : see rubowapN. ― -b2- Also A company (IAar, T, K, TA) of men: (IAar, T, TA:) pl. A^arobaA='u: (IAar, T, K, TA:) and ↓ ribowapN likewise signifies a company; or, as some say, ten thousand; as also rub~apN; (M, TA;) or the former of these two words, (i. e. rbwp,) accord. to the A, signifies a great company of men, such as ten thousand. (TA.) It is said in the K that ↓ ribowapN signifies Ten thousand dirhems; as also ↓ rubapN: but in this assertion are errors; for the former of these two words signifies as explained in the foregoing sentence; and the latter of them is with teshdeed, belonging to art. rb, and signifies a company [or great company] of men. (TA.) -A2- Also, (T, S, M, K, TA,) and ↓ rabowapN, (M, TA,) The state of being out of breath; interruption of the breath by reason of fatigue or running &c.: or a panting, or breathing shortly or uninterruptedly: syn. buhorN, (T, M, TA,) and AinobihaArN: (TA:) or a loud (lit. high) breathing: (S:) and a state of inflation of the jawof [or chest]. (M, TA.) [The former word is now often used as signifying Asthma.]

ribFA * , (T, M, Msb, K,) or ↓ ribFwA, (S, Mgh,) [for it is often thus written, and generally thus in the copies of the Kur-án,] with the short A accord. to the pronunciation best known, (Msb,) [which implies that it is also pronounced ↓ ribaA='N,] An excess, and an addition: (Msb:) an addition over and above the principal sum [that is lent or expended]: but in the law it signifies an addition obtained in a particular manner: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [i. e. usury, and the like; meaning both unlawful, and lawful, interest or profit; and the practice of taking such interest or profit:] it is in lending, (Zj, T,) or in buying and selling, (S,) and in giving: and is of two kinds; unlawful, and lawful: the unlawful is any loan for which one receives more than the loan, or by means of which one draws a profit; [and the gain made by such means:] and the lawful is a gift by which a man invites more than it to be given to him, or a gift that he gives in order that more than it may be given to him; [and the addition that he so obtains:] (Zj, T:) [it generally means] an addition that is obtained by selling food [&c.] for food [&c.], or ready money for ready money, to be paid at an appointed period; or by exchanging either of such things for more of the same kind: (Bd in ii. 276:) or the taking of an addition in lending and in selling: (PS:) [it is said to be] i. q. EiynapN: (M, K:) [but although ribFA and EiynapN are both applicable sometimes in the same case, neither of them can be properly said to be generally explanatory of the other, or syn. therewith: ribaA Aln~asiyoy^api is a term specially employed to signify profit obtained in the case of a delay of payment: and ribaA AlfaDoli to signify profit obtained by the superior value of a thing received over that of a
thing given:] the dual of ribFA (M, Msb, K) or ribFwA (S) is ribawaAni and ribayaAni; (S, M, Msb, K;) the former being agreeable with the original; (M, Msb;) the Y in the latter being because of the imáleh occasioned by the preceding kesreh. (M.) See an ex. near the beginning of the first paragraph of this art. ↓ ruboyapN, thus pronounced by the Arabs, but by the relaters of a trad., in which it occurs, ↓ rub~iy~apN, (Fr, T, S, Mgh,) or, as some say, ↓ rubay~apN, as though this were the dim. of ruboyapN, (Mgh,) is a dial. var. of ribFwA [or ribFA]; and by rule should be rubowapN: (Fr, T, S, Mgh:) or, accord. to Z, rub~y~apN may be of the measure fuE~uwlapN from Alr~ibaA. (TA.) [See also ramaA='N, in art. rmY.]
rubapN * : see rabowN.
rabowapN * : see the next paragraph: -A2- and see also rabowN.

rubowapN * and ↓ rabowapN and ↓ ribowapN; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) the first of which is preferred, (T,) or most common; (Msb;) and the second, of the dial. of Temeem; (T, Msb;) and ↓ rabowN (M, K) and ↓ rabaAwapN (T, S, M, K) and ↓ ribaAwapN (M, K) and ↓ rubaAwapN (IJ, K) and ↓ raAbiyapN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ rabaA='apN; (M, K;) A hill; i. e. an elevation of ground, or elevated ground: (T, S, M, K:) or an elevated place: so called because it is high: (Msb, TA:) the pl. of rubowapN is rubFY (T, Msb) and rubiY~N: (T:) and the pl. of ↓ raAbiyapN is rawaAbK; (T, Msb;) which ISh explains as meaning elevated sands, like the dakodaAkap [q. v.], but higher and softer than the latter; the latter being more compact and rugged; the rAbyp, he says, has in it depression and elevation; it produces the best and the most numerous of the herbs, or leguminous plants, that are found in the sands; and men alight upon it. (T.)
ribowapN * : see the next preceding paragraph: ― -b2- and see rabowN, in two places.
ruboyapN * and rubay~apN and rub~iy~apN: see ribFA, last sentence: -A2- and see also art. rbY.
ribFwA * : see ribFA. [The w is silent, like the A.]
rabowaA='u * : see raAbK.

ribawiY~N *
Of, or relating to, what is termed ribFA or ribFwA [i. e. usury and the like]: (Mgh, Msb:) rabawiY~N is said by Mtr to be wrong. (Msb.)

rabaA='N *
Excess, excellence, or superiority; syn. TawolN: (IDrd, S, K:) so in the saying, lifulaAnK EalaY fulaAnK rabaA='N [Such a one possesses excess, or excellence, or superiority, over such a one]. (IDrd, S.) ― -b2- And An obligation, a favour, or a benefit; syn. min~apN. (K.)
ribaA='N * : see ribFA.
rabaA='apN * : see rubowapN.
rabaAwapN * and rubaAwapN and ribaAwapN: see rubowapN.

[
raAbK *
Increasing, or augmenting: &c. ― -b2- Hence,] faA^axa*ahumo A^axo*apF raAbiyapF, in the Kur [lxix. 10], And He punished them with a punishment exceeding other punishments; (Fr, * S, * M, * K, * Jel;) a vehement punishment. (K.) -A2- AimoraA^apN raAbiyapN A woman affected with what is termed rabowN; [i. e., out of breath; &c.; (see 1, near the end of the paragraph;)] (T, TA;) as also ↓ rabowaA='u. (TA.)
raAbiyapN * [as a subst.]: see rubowapN, in two places.
A^arobaY * in the Kur xvi. 94 means More numerous, (Bd, Jel,) and more abundant in wealth. (Bd.)

A^urobiy~apN * , originally A^urobuw~apN, (S,) or of the measure fuEoliy~apN, (M,) The root of the thigh: (Ks, T, S, K:) or the part between the upper portion of the thigh and the lower portion of the baTon [or belly]: (ISh, T, K:) or the part between the upper portion of the thigh and the lower portion of the baZor [q. v.]: or, accord. to Lh, the root of the thigh, next the baZor: (M:) or, as in the A, a portion of flesh, in the root of the thigh, that becomes knotted in consequence of pain: (TA:) there are two parts, together called A^urobiy~ataAni. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A man's household, and the sons of the paternal uncle of a man; (T, M, K, TA;) not including any others: (T, M:) or the nearer members of the household of a man. (A, TA.) One says, jaA='a fulaAnN fiY A^urobiy~atihi, and fiY A^urobiy~apK mino qawomihi, (T,) or fiY A^urobiy~api qawomihi, (S,) (tropical:) Such a one came among his household, and the sons of his paternal uncle: (T, TA:) or among the people of his house consisting of the sons of his paternal uncles; not of any others. (S.)
A_irobiyaAnN * : see art. rbY.
murobK * One who practises ribFA [i. e. usury or the like]. (M, K.) ― -b2- A^ar oDN murobiyapN (assumed tropical:) Good land. (M.)
marobaApN * for marobaA^apN: see the latter, in art. rbA^.

murab~FY * [Reared, fostered, brought up, fed, or nourished: see 2. ― -b2- And] Made [or preserved] with rub~ [or inspissated juice, &c. (see 2, last sentence but one)]: you say zanojabiylN murab~FY [Ginger so preserved]; as also murab~abN: (S, K:) and ↓ murab~ayaAtN signifies Preserves, or confections, made with rub~; like murab~abaAtN. (S in art. rb.)
murab~ayaAtN * : see what next precedes.
1 rabayotu * , in the copies of the K, in art. rbw, is a mistake for rabiytu. (TA in that art., q. v.)
laA warabiyka * for laA warab~ika [as though rabK were a dial. var. of rab~N]: see rab~N (last sentence), in art. rb.
ribayaAni * a dual of ribFA, mentioned in art. rbw.

ruboyapN *
A species. of the [small animals called] Ha$araAt [q. v.]: (AHát, S and K * in art. rbw:) pl. rubFY: (AHát, S:) accord. to IAar, the rat, or mouse: pl. as above: (T:) [or] a certain small beast, or reptile, between the rat, or mouse, and [what is called] A^um~u HubayonK [q. v.]. (M.) And The cat. (K in art. rbw.) -A2- See also ribFA (last sentence), in art. rbw.
rubay~apN * : see ribFA (last sentence), in art. rbw.
rub~iy~apN * : see ribFA (last sentence), in art. rbw.
A^urobiy~apN * : see art. rbw.

A_irobiyaAnN *
A species of fish, (S and K in art. rbw, and M in the present art.,) white, (S,) resembling worms, (S, K,) found at El-Basrah. (S.) ― -b2- Accord. to Seer, A certain plant. (M.)

1 rat~a * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
rata3a , (Msb,) inf. n. ratatN; (S, * Msb;) or rut~a, inf. n. rut~apN; (so in the M;) He had, in his speech, or utterance, what is termed rut~apN, expl. below. (S, M, Msb, K.)

4 Art~hu *
He (God) caused him to have, in his speech, or utterance, what is termed rut~apN. (S, K.)

R. Q. 1 ratorata *
He reiterated, by reason of an impediment in his speech, in uttering the letter t (IAar, T, K) &c. (IAar, T.)

rat~N * The swine that assaults or attacks [men]: (T, TA:) or a thing [meaning an animal] resembling the wild swine: (M, TA:) pl. rit~apN, (T,) or ritatapN, (TA,) and rutuwtN: (S, M, TA:) or rutuwtN signifies [simply] swine: (S, K:) in some of the copies of the S, wild swine: (TA:) or boars: (M:) or boars in which is strength and boldness: (A:) it has been asserted that no one but Kh has mentioned it. (IDrd, M.) ― -b2- [Hence, (in the TA said to be bAlDm~, but this is a mistranscription for biAlfatoHi,]) (tropical:) A chief (IAar, T, S, A, K) in eminence, or nobility, and in bounty, or gifts: (IAar, T:) pl. rutuwtN (IAar, T, S, A, K) and rut~aAnN. (K.) You say, huwa mano rutuwti Aln~aAsi (tropical:) He is of the lords of mankind. (A.) And h`w^ulaA='i rutuwtu Albaladi (tropical:) These are the lords of the town, or country. (TA.)

rut~apN *
A vitiousness, or an impediment, in speech or utterance, so that one does not speak distinctly: (S, A, K:) or a hastiness therein, (M, Mgh,) and a want of distinctness: or the changing of l into Y: (M:) or an impediment in speech or utterance: (Msb:) or, accord. to Mbr, what resembles wind, impeding the commencement of speech, until, when somewhat thereof comes forth, it becomes continuous: it is an inborn habit, and is often found in persons of elevated, or noble, rank: (T, Mgh, Msb:) or, as some say, it is a reiterating of a word, preceded by the breath: or the incorporating of one letter into another (A_idogaAmN) when this should not be done: (Msb:) or a vitious and faulty kind of repetition, in the tongue. (AA, TA.)
rut~aY * A woman who changes, in pronunciation, s into v, or r into g or l, and the like; or who changes one letter into another; syn. lavogaA='u. (AA, T, K.) [See also what follows.]

A^arat~u * A man having in his speech, or utterance, what is termed rut~apN: (T, S, A, Mgh, Msb:) accord. to 'Abd-Er-Rahmán, whose word, or speech, is held back, and is preceded by his breath: (Mgh:) or having an impediment in his speech, so that his tongue will not obey his will: (TA:) fem. rat~aA='u: (Msb:) and pl. rut~N. (A, Msb.) [See also rut~aY.]

1 rataba * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
ratuba , inf. n. rutuwbN, (S, M, Msb, K, *) It (a thing, S, M, Msb) was, or became, constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, established, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and stationary, or motionless; (S, * M, A, * Msb, * K;) as also ↓ trt~b. (M, K.) Also, said of a thing, (T,) of a kaEob [i. e. cockal-bone, or die], [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (S, M, A, TA,) and of a man, (M, TA,) aor. as above, inf. n. ratobN, (M,) or ratabN, (K, * TA,) It, and he, stood erect, or upright; (T, S, M, A, TA; [but in some copies of the K, AlAinoSibaAbu is erroneously put for AlAinotiSaAbu as the explanation of Alr~atabu;]) and (TA) so ↓ Artb, (K, TA, [but this I rather think to be a mistranscription,]) said of a man: mentioned in the T as on the authority of IAar. (TA. [But in the T, I find only rataba in this sense.]) So in the saying, rataba rutuwba AlkaEobi fiY AlmaqAmi AlS~aEobi [He stood erect like as does the cockal-bone, or the die, in the difficult standingplace]: (S, * A, TA:) occurring in a trad. of Lukmán Ibn-'Ád. (TA.) And rataba fiY AlS~alaApi He stood erect in prayer. (A.) [Or] rataba said of a man, [aor.
ratuba ,] inf. n. ratobN and rutuwbN, signifies He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the town, or country: and also he stood firm. (Msb.) And you say also, rataba fiY AlA^amori [He was constant, firm, &c., in the affair]. (A.)

2 rt~b * , (S, M, A, &c.,) inf. n. tarotiybN, (S, K,) He made, or rendered, (a thing, S, M, or things, A,) constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, established, and stationary, or motionless. (S, * M, Msb, K.) You say, rt~b AlT~alaAy^iEa fiY AlmaraAtibi [He stationed the scouts upon the mrAtb]. (A. See marotabapN.) ― -b2- He set things in order, disposed them regularly, arranged them, or classified them. (MA.) You say, rt~b Alr~utaba [He set in order, regularly disposed, arranged, classified, distributed, or appointed, the stations, posts of honour, &c.]. (TA voce A^aS~ala.) ― -b3- [Hence,] tarotiybN is sometimes used as signifying The mode of construction termed laf~N wana$orN [when it is regularly disposed: see art. lf]. (Har p. 383.) ― -b4- [Also The prescribing, or observing, a particular order in any performance; as, for instance, in the ablution termed AlwuDuwo'.] ― -b5- And The drawing of omens, one after another. (KL.)

4 Artb AlkaEoba * , (T, M, A,) inf. n. A_irotaAbN, (T,) said of a boy, (T, M, A,) He made the kEb [i. e. cockal-bone, or die,] to stand erect, or upright: (T, * A:) or he made the kEb firm, or steady. (M.) -A2- Artb as an intrans. v.: see 1. -A3- Also, inf. n. as above, He became a beggar, after having been rich, or in a state of competence. (IAar, T, K. [Perhaps formed by transposition from A^atoraba.]) -A4- And He invited distinguished persons to his food, or banquet. (T.)

5 trt~b * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [Also, as quasi-pass of 2, It was, or became, set in order, regularly disposed, arranged, or classified. ― -b3- And trt~b Ealayohi It was consequent upon it; it resulted, or accrued, from it.]
ratobN * : see the next paragraph.

ratabN * The steps of stairs. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Rocks near together, some of them higher than others: (M, K:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. ↓ ratabapN; mentioned on the authority of Yaakoob as [written ↓ rutabN,] with damm to the r and fet-h to the t. (M.) ― -b3- Elevated ground, (S, K,) like a barozax [or bar, or an obstruction, between two things: app. a coll. gen. n. in this sense also; n. un. with p; for] you say ↓ ratabapN and ratabN like as you say darajapN and darajN. (S.) ― -b4- Hardness, or difficulty: (S, A, K:) coarseness, hardness, or difficulty, of life or living: (M, K: *) fatigue, weariness, embarrassment, or trouble; as also ↓ marotabapN. (M.) You say, maA fiY Eayo$ihi ratabN (T, S, M, A) There is no hardness, or difficulty, in his life or living: (S, A:) or no coarseness, hardness, or difficulty. (M.) And maA fiY h`*aA AlA^amori ratabN, and ↓ marotabapN, There is no fatigue, weariness, embarrassment, or trouble, in this affair. (M.) And maA fiY h`*aA AlA^amori ratabN walA EatabN There is not in this affair any hardness, or difficulty: (S:) or any fatigue, or trouble: (T:) i. e. it is easy, and rightly disposed. (T, A.) -A2- Also The space between the little finger and that next to it, namely, the third finger, [when they are extended apart:] and the space between the third finger and the middle finger [when they are so extended]: (M, K:) or the space between the fore finger and the middle finger [when they are so extended]: sometimes written and pronounced ↓ ratobN: (S, TA:) [or it is a coll. gen. n.; and] ↓ ratabapN [is the n. un., and] signifies the space between [any two of] the fingers. (TA in art. rtq. [See also buSomN.]) It denotes also The [space that is measured by] putting the four fingers close together. (K. [See also EatabN.])

rutobapN *
A single step of stairs or of a ladder; (MA;) [and so ↓ marotabapN, as appears from what follows:] pl. of the former rutabN (MA) [and rutabaAtN, for Az says that] rutobapN signifies one of the rutabaAt of stairs: (T:) [the pl. of marotabapN is maraAtibu.] You say, raqiYa fiY rutabi Ald~araji and ↓ maraAtibihaA [He ascended the steps of the stairs]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] also, (S, M, A, * Msb, K,) and ↓ marotabapN, (T, S, M, A, K, TA,) [or] from rataba signifying “ he stood erect, ” (TA,) (tropical:) A station, or standing; a post of honour; rank; condition; degree; dignity; or office; (T, S, M, A, Msb, K, TA;) with, or at the courts of, kings; and the like: (T, TA:) or a high station, &c.: (TA:) pl. of the former rutabN; (A, * Msb, TA;) and of the latter ↓ maraAtibu. (A, TA.) You say, huwa fiY A^aEolaY Alr~utabi (tropical:) [He is in the highest of stations, &c.]: and Einoda ↓ lahu marotabapN Als~uloTaAni (tropical:) [He has a station, &c., or high station, &c., with, or at the court of, the Sultán]: and ↓ huwa mino A^aholi AlmaraAtibi (tropical:) [He is of the people of high stations, &c.]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- [rutobapN also signifies The order of the proper relative places of things; as, for instance, of the words in a sentence.] ― -b4- See also the pl. rutabN in the next preceding paragraph.
ratabapN * n. un. of ratabN, which see in three places. (S, * M.)
ratobaA='u * A she-camel erect in her pace. (T, K.)

raAtibN * (Msb) and ↓ turotubN and ↓ turotabN (M, K) and ↓ tarotubN (M) A thing constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, established, stationary, or motionless: (M, Msb, K: [the third of these words, in this sense, is mentioned in the T in art. trb: but see the next paragraph:]) and the first, standing erect, or upright; (T, TA;) applied to a thing, (T,) to a kaEob [i. e. cockal-bone, or die], and to a man. (TA.) You say A^amorN raAtibN A thing, or an affair, continual, or uninterrupted, (daAr~N.) constant, firm, steady, &c.: and ↓ A^amorN turotabN, the latter word of the measure tufoEalN, with damm to the t and fet-h to the E, a thing, or an affair, constant, firm, steady, &c. (S.) And Eiz~N raAtibN Might, high rank or condition, or the like, constant, firm, &c. (A.) And Eayo$N raAtibN Constant, or continual, (M, TA,) fixed, settled, or established, (TA,) means of subsistence. (M, TA.) And maA zilotu EalaY h`*aA raAtibFA I ceased not to be, or to do, thus constantly; as also raAtimFA; in which, IJ says, the m is app. a substitute for b, because we have not heard ratama used like rataba; but it may be radical, from Alr~atiymapu. (M.) ― -b2- [raAtibN in the modern language, used as a subst., signifies A set pension, salary, and allowance; a ration; and any set office, or task: and so raAtibapN; pl. rawaAtibu.]

turotabN * and turotubN and tarotubN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places. ― -b2- You say also, jaAw^uwA turotabFA and turotubFA, meaning They came all together. (K.) And a poet says, (M,) namely, Ziyád Ibn-Zeyd El-'Odharee, (TA,)
wakaAna lanaA faDolN EalaY Aln~aAsi turotabaA
meaning [And we possessed excellence above the people] all together: (M, TA:) thus accord. to the reading commonly known: but, as some relate it,
wakaAna lanaA Haq~FA EalaY Aln~aAsi turotabaA
i. e. [And it was a just claim that we had upon the people,] settled, or established. (TA.) The first t in turotabN is augmentative, because there is no word like juEofarN; and the derivation also is an evidence of this, for the word is from Al$~aYo'u Alr~aAtibu. (M.) -A2- Also the second of these three words, (T in art. trb, and M, and L,) or the first of them, (K,) A bad slave: (T, K:) or a slave whom three persons inherit, one after another;
because of his continuance in slavery: [it being a common custom for a man to make a good slave free at his death:] mentioned by Th. (M.) ― -b2- Also the second, (Th, M, K,) and the first, (K,) Dust, or earth; syn. turaAbN: (Th, M, K:) because of its long endurance. (Th, M.) ― -b3- And the first, i. q. A^abadN [Time, or duration, or continuance, or existence, without end; &c.: or the right reading may perhaps be A=bidN, i. e. remaining constantly, &c.]. (K.)

A^axa*a fulaAnN turotub~apF *
Such a one took what was like a road, to tread it. (K, * TA.)

marotabapN * , and its pl. maraAtibu: see rutobapN, in six places. ― -b2- Accord. to As, it signifies A place of observation, which is the summit of a mountain, or the upper part thereof: (S:) accord. to Kh, (S,) the maraAtib in mountains and in deserts (SaHaArK) are [structures such as are termed] A^aEolaAm [pl. of EalamN, q. v.,] upon which are stationed (↓ turabu) scouts, or spies: (T, S:) or places to which scouts ascend, in, or upon, mountains. (A.) ― -b3- The pl. also signifies Narrow and rugged parts of valleys. (TA from a trad.) ― -b4- And the sing., Any difficult station or position. (M.) ― -b5- See also ratabN, in two places. ― -b6- [In post-classical works, and in the language of the present day, it is applied to A mattress, upon which to sit or recline or lie; such as is spread upon a couch-frame or upon the ground.]

1 rataja * , inf. n. ratojN: see 4. -A2- ratija, (K,) or ratija fiY manoTiqahi, (S, A, Msb,) aor.
rataja , (Msb, K,) inf. n. ratajN, (Msb, TA,) (tropical:) He was, or became, impeded in his speech, unable to speak, or tonguetied; (S, A, * Msb, K;) as also Ealayohi ↓ A^urotija, (A, K,) and Elyh ↓ Aurotutija, and Elyh ↓ Ausoturotija. (K.) You say, EalaY AlqaAriY'i ↓ A^urotija, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and ElY AlxaTiybi, (Mgh,) (tropical:) The reader, or reciter, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and the orator, or preacher, (Mgh,) was unable to read, or recite, (S, Msb,) as though he were prevented doing so, (Msb,) or as though a thing were closed against him like as a door is closed; (S;) or was, or became, impeded in his reading, or recitation, and his oration, or sermon, and unable to complete it; (Mgh;) from A^arotaja AlbaAba: (Mgh, Msb: [see 4:]) and Ealayohi ↓ Aurotutija signifies the same: (S: [in my copy of the Msb, “ Artyj, of the same measure as Aqtyl, in the pass. form: ” but this is evidently a mistranscription, for Aurotutija, of the same measure as Auqotutila:]) one should not say Aurotuj~a Elyh: (S: [but it seems that those who pronounced the verb with teshdeed said Airotaj~a: see art. rj:]) this is sometimes said; but some disallow it: (Msb:) the vulgar say it; and accord. to some, it may be correct as meaning “ he fell into confusion. ” (Mgh.) You say also, Ealayohi ↓ SaEida Alminobara faA^urotijaEalaY (tropical:) He ascended the pulpit, and was, or became, impeded in his speech, unable to speak, or tonguetied. (A.) And EalaY fulaAnK ↓ A^urotija (tropical:) Such a one was unable to finish a saying, or poetry, that he desired to utter. (TA.) And fiY kalaAmihi ratajN (tropical:) In his speech is a reiterating, by reason of an impediment, or inability to say what he would. (A, TA.) -A3- rataja, inf. n. ratajAnN, He (a child) walked a little, at his first beginning to walk; or walked with a weak gait; crept along; or walked slowly. (K, TA.)

4 Artj AlbaAba * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_irotaAjN; (Msb;) and ↓ ratajahu, (K,) inf. n. ratojN; but As allows only the former verb; (TA;) i. q. A^agolaqahu, [which means He locked the door, and also he shut, or closed, the door, but the former appears to be the signification here intended, from what follows,] (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) so as to make it fast, or firm: (A, Mgh, Msb:) so says Az, after Lth: and, by extension of the signification, he shut, or closed, the door, without locking it. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., A_in~a A^abowaAba Als~amaA='i tufotaHu Einoda zawaAli Al$~amosi falaA turotaju Hat~aY yuSal~aY AlZ~uhoru, (Mgh, * and “ Jámi' es-Sagheer ” of EsSuyootee,) i. e. [Verily the gates of Heaven are opened at the declining of the sun from the meridian,] and are not closed nor locked [until the noon-prayer has been performed]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^urotija Ealayohi AlA^amoru (assumed tropical:) The affair was as though it were closed against him, so that he knew not the way to engage in it, or execute it; syn. Aisotabohama Ealayohi. (TA in art. bhm.) ― -b3- See also 1, in four places. ― -b4- [Hence also,] A^arotajato (tropical:) She (a camel) closed her womb against the seed (S, A, K, TA) of the stallion, (TA,) having become pregnant. (A.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) She (an ass) became pregnant. (K.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) She (a hen) had her belly full of eggs. (S, A, * K.) ― -b7- Also A^arotaja (assumed tropical:) It (the sea) became raised into a state of commotion, and covered everything with the abundance of its water, (K, TA,) and the voyager upon it found no way of escape from it. (TA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) It (snow) was continual, and covered [the land]. (K.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) It (abundance of herbage) was universal over the land, (K, TA,) leaving no part thereof wanting. (TA.) And A^arotajati Als~anapu (assumed tropical:) The year of drought involved every part in sterility, (K, TA,) so that man found no way of escape. (TA.)
8 A_irotataja see 1, in two places.
10 A_isotarotaja see 1, second sentence.

sik~apN ritojN * (tropical:) [A street that is closed;] that has no place of egress. (A, K.) maAlN ritojN (tropical:) Property to which there is no access; (A, TA;) contr. of TiloqN, (K, TA,) which is likewise with kesr; (TA; [in the CK Taloq;]) as also giloqN. (K, TA.)
ratajN * : see what next follows.

ritaAjN *
A door: (TA:) or a great door; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ ratajN: (S A, K:) or a door locked, or shut or closed, (S, Mgh, K,) having a small door, or wicket: (S, K:) or it signifies also a door that is locked, or shat or closed: (Msb:) pl. rutujN and rataAy^iju, and, accord. to MF, A^arotaAjN, but this is irreg., and he has given no authority for it. (TA.) Hence ritaAju AlkaEobapi [The door of the Kaabeh]: (S, TA:) and (tropical:) the Kaabeh itself: (A, * TA:) and [hence also] Alir~taAju is (tropical:) a name of Mekkeh. (K, TA.) jaEala maAlahu fiY ritaAji AlkaEobapi, (A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) occurring in a trad., (Mgh, TA,) means, (A, Msb, TA,) or is said to mean, (Mgh,) (tropical:) He made his property, or cattle, a votive offering to be taken to the Kaabeh; (A, Mgh, Msb;) not the door itself; (Mgh;) the Kaabeh being thus called because by the door one enters it. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) The part of the womb that closes upon the fœtus; as being likened to a door. (L.) ― -b3- A^aroDN *aAtu ritaAjK occurs in a trad. [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) A land having a place of ingress that is, or may be, closed: or it may mean a land having in it rocks: see ritaAjapN, of which ritaAjN may be a coll. gen. n.]. (TA.) -A2- naAqapN ritaAju AlS~alaA (assumed tropical:) A she-camel firm or compact [in the middle of the back, or in the part on either side of the tail, &c.]. (K.)
ritaAjapN * sing. of rataAy^iju, which signifies Rocks. (K.) ― -b2- Also Any narrow $iEob [or mountainroad, &c.]; as though it were closed, by reason of its narrowness. (L.)
murotajN * A door, and a chamber, or house, locked, or shut or closed, (mugolaqN,) so as to be made fast, or firm. (A.)

murotijN * , applied to a she-camel, (tropical:) Pregnant; because the mouth of her womb becomes closed against the seed of the stallion: (T, A, * TA:) applied also to a she-ass, in the same sense: (TA:) pl. maraAtiju and maraAtiyju. (A, TA.)

mirotaAjN *
A thing with which a door is closed, or made fast; syn. migolaAqN; (S;) [app. a kind of latch:] it is affixed behind the door, in the part next to the lock. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA in art. ErbD.)

maraAtiju *
Narrow roads or paths: (S, A, K:) the sing. is not mentioned. (TA.)

1 rataEa * , aor.
rataEa , inf. n. rutuwEN (S, Msb, K) and ratoEN (Msb, K) and ritaAEN, (IAar, K,) He (a beast) pastured at pleasure; (Msb;) he (a beast, S, TA) ate (S, K) and drank (K) what he pleased, (S, K,) and came and went in the pasturage, by day, (TA,) amid abundance of herbage, and plenty: (K:) or (tropical:) he ate and drank plentifully and pleasantly, in land of seed-produce and fruitfulness, of green herbs or leguminous plants and of waters: (Lth, K, TA:) or (tropical:) he ate (IAar, K) and drank (K) with great greediness. (IAar, K.) In its primary acceptation, it is said of a beast. (TA.) ― -b2- It is metaphorically said of a man, as meaning (tropical:) He ate much; accord. to El-Isbahánee in the Mufradát, and the A and the B. (TA.) ― -b3- You say, rataEa fulaAnN fiY maAli fulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one acted as he pleased in eating and drinking the property of such a one. (TA.) ― -b4- And xarajonaA naloEabu wanarotaEu (tropical:) We went forth [playing, or sporting, and enjoying ourselves; or] enjoying ourselves; and playing,
or sporting. (S, TA. *) It is said in the Kur [xii. 12], (TA,) accord. to different readings, (K, TA,) A^arosilohu maEanaA gadFA yarotaEo wayaloEabo (tropical:) [Send thou him with us to-morrow] that he may play, or sport, and enjoy himself: or the meaning is, that he may walk [abroad at his pleasure] and become cheerful in countenance, or dilated in heart: (TA:) and wayaloEabu ↓ nurotiEo that we may put our beasts to eat and drink what they please, amid abundance of herbage, and plenty, [or to pasture at pleasure,] and he shall play: (K, TA:) and the reverse, (K,) yurotiEo wanaloEabu, (TA,) i. e. that he may put our beasts to eat and drink &c., and we will play together: (K, TA:) and with n in each case. (K.) ― -b5- And it is said in a trad., mano yarotaEo Hawola AlHimaY yuw$iko A^ano yaxaAliTahu, i. e. (assumed tropical:) He who goes round about [the prohibited place of pasturage will soon enter into it]. (TA.) ― -b6- And in another trad., A_i*aA mararotumo biriyaADi Aljan~api faA@rotaEuwA, meaning (tropical:) [When ye pass by a scene of] the commemoration of the praises of God, enter ye thereinto; the entering thereinto being thus likened to the eating and drinking what one pleases, amid abundance of herbage. (TA.)

4 ArtE *
He put his camels [to pasture at pleasure; (see 1;) or] to eat (S, K) and drink (K) what they pleased, (S, K,) amid abundance of herbage, and plenty: (K: [in which it is implied that the verb may have this signification or others agreeable with explanations in the first sentence of this art.:]) or he pastured his camels, or put them to pasture, by themselves. (TA.) See the ex. in the Kur-án cited above. ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) He ruled, or governed, his subjects well; [as though] leaving them to satiate themselves in the pasturage. (TA.) ― -b3- It (a party of men) lighted upon abundance of herbage, and pastured. (TA.) ― -b4- It (rain) produced, or gave growth to, herbage in which the camels might pasture at pleasure, or eat and drink what they pleased, amid abundance thereof and plenty. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b5- ArtEt AlA^aroDu The land became abundant in herbage. (TA.)
rataEN * [app. an inf. n., of which the verb (ratiEa) is not mentioned, and perhaps not used,] The leading a plentiful and pleasant and easy life. (TA.) [See also ratoEapN.]
ratiEN * sing. of ratiEuwna, q. v. voce murotiEN: ― -b2- and applied to herbage: see murotiEN.

ratoEapN *
Abundance of herbage; or of the goods, conveniences, and comforts, of life; fruitfulness; plenty: and a state of ampleness in respect thereof: (K:) a subst. from 1. (TA.) Hence the prov., Alqayodu waAlr~atoEapu, and ↓ Alr~ataEapu; (K;) the former on the authority of Fr, and the latter from some other, accord. to the O; but in the L, the latter is ascribed to Fr; (TA;) [Bonds and plenty; the latter word] meaning AlxaSobu: said by 'Amr Ibn-Es-Saak: he had been taken prisoner by Shákir Ibn-Rabee'ah, a tribe of Hemdán, who treated him well; and when he left his people, he was slender; then he fled from Shákir; and when he came to his people, they said, “ O 'Amr, thou wentest forth from us slender, and now thon art corpulent; ” and he replied in the words above. (K.)
rataEapN * : see what next precedes.
rat~aAEN * One who seeks, with his camels, after the places of pasturage abounding with herbage, one after another. (TA.)

raAtiEN * A camel, (S, K,) or beast, pasturing at his pleasure; (Msb;) or eating (S, K,) and drinking (K) what he pleases, (S, K,) and coming and going in the pasturage, by day, (TA,) amid abundance of herbage, and plenty; (K;) [part. n. of 1, q. v.:] pl. ritaAEN (S, Msb, K) and rut~aEN and rutuEN and rutuwEN. (K.) ― -b2- You say also qawomN raAtiEuwna. (S.) See marotiEN.

raA^ayotu A^arotaAEFA mina Aln~aAsi *
I saw a multitude of men. (Sgh, K.)

marotaEN *
A place of pasturing: (KL:) [or of unrestrained and plentiful pasturing;] a place where beasts pasture at pleasure; (Msb;) where they eat (S, K) and drink (K) what they please, (S, K,) going and coming therein, by day, (TA,) amid abundance of herbage, and plenty: (K:) [see 1:] pl. maraAtiEu. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And Pasture itself:] one says, A^akaluwA marotaEa AlA^aroDi [They consumed, or ate, the pasture of the land]. (M in art. rdm.)

murotiEN * One who leaves his travelling-camels to pasture at their pleasure, or to eat and drink what they please, coming and going in the pasturage, by day, amid abundance of herbage, and plenty. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A man having abundance of herbage, or of the goods or conveniences and comforts of life, not lacking anything that he may desire. (K, TA.) You say also qawomN murotiEuwna ↓ raAtiEuwna, meaning (assumed tropical:) A people, or company of men, who are scarcely ever without abundance of herbage, or of the goods or conveniences and comforts of life; syn. maxaASiybu; and ↓ qawomN ratiEuwna, after the manner of a rel. n., like TaEimN: and in like manner ↓ ratiEN is applied to herbage [as meaning scarcely ever other than abundant, or generally abundant]. (TA.) ― -b3- Rain that produces, or gives growth to , herbage in which the camels may pasture at pleasure, or eat and drink what they please, amid abundance thereof and plenty. (S, Msb.) ― -b4- A^aroDN murotiEapN Land in which the beasts eagerly desire to satiate themselves. (Sh.)

1 rataqa * , aor.
ratuqa (S, L, Msb) and
ratiqa , (L,) inf. n. ratoqN, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) He closed up, (M, Msb, TA,) and repaired, (M, TA,) a rent: (S, M, Msb, TA:) [he sewed up, or together: see ritaAqN:] Alr~atoqu is the contr. of Alfatoqu. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, rataqa fatoqahumo, meaning (tropical:) [He closed up the breach that was between them; he reconciled them; or] he reformed, or amended, the circumstances subsisting between them. (TA.) -A2- ratiqato, aor.
rataqa , (IKoot, Msb, TA,) inf. n. rataqN, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) in the K, erroneously, rataqapN, (TA,) She was, or became, such as is termed ratoqaA='; (IKoot, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) said of a woman, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or of a girl, and also of a camel. (IKoot, Msb.)

8 Arttq *
It was, or became, closed up, (S, Msb, K,) [and repaired; and sewed up, or together;] said of a rent: (S, Msb:) and also of the vulva of a woman. (S, * TA.)

ratoqN *
i. q. ↓ marotuwqN [and marotuwqapN, &c., being originally an inf. n.; i. e. Closed up, and repaired; applied to a rent; and so ↓ rataqN]. (TA.) kaAnataA ratoqFA fafataqonaAhumaA, in the Kur [xxi. 31, lit. They (the heavens and the earth) were closed up, and we rent them], is from Alr~atoqu as the contr. of Alfatoqu: (S:) accord. to Ibn-'Arafeh, it means they were closed up, without any interstice, and we rent them by the rain and by the plants: accord. to Az, it means they were a heaven closed up and an earth closed up, and we rent them into seven heavens and seven earths: Lth says that the heavens were closed up, no rain descending from them; and the earth was closed up, without any fissure therein; until God rent them by the rain and the plants: Zj says that ratoqFA is for *awaAtaYo ratoqK: (TA:) and he says that the heaven and the earth were united, and God rent them by the air, which He placed between them: (TA in art. ftq:) some read ↓ rataqFA, for $ayoy^FA rataqFA, meaning marotuwqFA. (Bd.)

rataqN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. -A2- It is [also] pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of ↓ rataqapN, syn., accord. to the copies of the K, with rutobapN, but correctly with ratabapN, which signifies The space between [any two of] the fingers: mentioned [in the JK, where I find the correct reading, and] by Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)
rataqapN * : see what next precedes.

ratoqaA='u * , applied to a woman, (AHeyth, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or to a girl, (Lth,) [and also to a she-camel, (see 1, last sentence,)] Impervia coëunti; (S, Msb, K;) having the meatus of the vagina closed up: (S, * Msb:) or having no aperture except the mabaAl [or meatus urinarius]: (Lth, Mgh, K:) or having the faroj so drawn together that the *akar can hardly, or not at all, pass. (AHeyth.)

ritaAqN * [A garment composed of] two pieces of cloth sewed together (yurotaqaAni) by their borders. (Lth, S, K.) Hence the saying of a rájiz,
jaAriya bayoDaA='u fiY ritaAqi
tudiyru TarofFA A^akoHala AlmaA=qiY
[A fair girl in a rtAq, turning about eyes black in the inner angles.] (Lth, S. *)

rutuwqN *
Inaccessableness, or unapproachableness; (manaEapN, [in some copies of the K, AlxnEp is erroneously put for AlmanaEapu,]) and might; and high, or elevated, rank. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.)

raAtiqN * [for saHaAbN raAtiqN] Clouds closing up, or coalescing. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- huwa AlfaAtiqu Alr~aAtiqu (assumed tropical:) He is the possessor of command or rule, so that he
opens and closes, and straitens and widens. (Har p. 208.) [See also mixolaTN.]

farojN A^arotaqu *
A vulva of which the sides stick together. (TA.)
marotuwqN * : see ratoqN.
marotatiqN * Herbage of which the blossoms have not yet come forth from their calyxes. (TA in art. SwH.) [See remarks on a verse cited voce murotafiqN.]

1 rataka * , (S, K,) aor.
ratuka , (S,) thus it appears to be accord. to the K [also], and thus in the Deewán el-Adab of El-Farábee, but accord. to Sgh it is correctly
ratika , (TA,) inf. n. ratokN and ratakaAnN (S, K) and ratakN, (K,) He (a camel) went with short steps (S, K) in his ramalaAn [or quick pacing, or going a kind of trotting pace, between a walk and a run], (S,) to which Kh adds, shaking himself: and accord. to him, and J, it is said only of a camel: but it is sometimes said of other animals, [perhaps tropically, or improperly,] as, for instance, of an ostrich: and accord. to Sgh, it is sometimes said of a human being. (TA.) [See also Hataka: and see naSaba Als~ayora, in art nSb.]

4 Artkhu *
He made him (namely, a camel,) to go in the manner expl. above: (S, K:) or made him to go a quick pace. (TA.) ― -b2- And Artk AlD~aHika (assumed tropical:) He laughed languidly: (K:) and so A^arotaA^a AlD~aHika. (TA.)
raAtikapN * A she-camel [going with short steps &c.: (see 1:) or] going as though she had shackles on her legs: or beating [the ground] with her fore legs: (As, TA:) pl. rawaAtiku. (TA.)

marotakN *
i. q. murodaAsanojN [from the Pers. murdaAsanoG, both of which signify Litharge in the present day, as in the classical dialect]: (K:) it is of two kinds; namely, *ahabiY~N [i. e. red, or of gold], and fiD~iY~N [i. e. white, or of silver]. (TA.)

1 ratila Alv~agoru * , aor.
ratala , inf. n. ratalN, The front teeth were, or became, even in their growth, (Msb,) [or separate, one from another, and even in the manner of growth, well set together, and (accord. to some) very white and lustrous: see ratalN and ratilN, below.] ― -b2- And ratila Al$~aYo'u, aor. and inf. n. as above, The thing was, or became, well arranged or disposed. (TK.)

2 tarotiylN * , in its original sense, relates to the teeth; signifying tafoliyj thereof [i. e., as inf. n. of the verb in its pass. form, Their being separate, one from another]. (Bd in xxv. 34.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rt~l AlkalaAma, (T, M, K,) inf. n. tarotiylN, (K,) He put together and arranged well the component parts of the speech, or saying, (M, K,) and made it distinct: and hence tarotiylu AlquroA=ni [explained in what follows]: (M:) or he proceeded in a leisurely manner in the speech, or saying, [making the utterance distinct,] and put together and arranged well its component parts: (T:) and rat~alotu AlquroA=na inf. n. as above, I read, or recited, the Kur-án in a leisurely manner; without haste: (Msb:) or Alt~arotiylu in reading, or reciting, [and particularly in the reading, or reciting, of the Kur-án,] is the proceeding in a leisurely manner, and uttering distinctly, without exceeding the proper bounds or limits: (S:) [and hence, conventionally, the chanting of the Kur-án in a peculiar, distinct, and leisurely, manner:] and fiY kalaAmihi ↓ trt~l, (T,) or fiY AlkalaAmi, (M, K,) signifies [in like manner] he proceeded in a leisurely manner (T, M, K) in his speech, or saying, (T,) or in the speech, or saying: (M, K:) Mujáhid explains Alt~arotiyl as signifying the proceeding in a leisurely manner [in reading, or reciting], and as being consecutive in its parts, or portions; regarding it as etymologically relating to vagorN ratilN [q. v.]: (T:) accord. to Er-Rághib, it signifies the pronouncing the word [or words] with ease and correctness: this is the proper signification: but the conventional meaning, as verified by El-Munáwee, is the being regardful of the places of utterance of the letters, and mindful of the pauses, and the lowering of the voice, and making it plaintive, in reading, or reciting: (TA:) [accord. to Mtr,] the [proper] meaning of Altrtyl in [the reciting, or chanting, of the Kur-án and of] the call to prayer &c. is the pronouncing of the letters in a leisurely manner, and distinctly, and so giving them their proper full sound; from the phrase vagorN murat~alN and ratilN signifying “ front teeth separate, one from another, and even in the manner of growth, and well set together. ” (Mgh.) [See also tarosiylN.] warat~alonaAhu tarotiylFA, in the Kur [xxv. 34], means And we have sent it down unto thee in a leisurely manner: (M, TA:) or we have recited it to thee part after part, in a deliberate and leisurely manner; in [the course of] twenty years, or three and twenty: tarotiylN in its original sense relating to the teeth, and having the signification explained in the beginning of this paragraph. (Bd.)
5 tarat~ala see the next preceding paragraph.

rtalN * inf. n. of 1: (Msb:) [Evenness in the growth of the front teeth: or their being separate, one from another, and even in the manner of growth, and well set together: (see 1 and ratilN:) or] whiteness, [or much whiteness,] and much lustre, of the teeth. (M, K.) ― -b2- And A good, (M, K, TA,) and correct, or right, (TA,) state of arrangement or disposition of a thing. (M, K, TA.) ― -b3- The quality, in a man, of having the teeth separate, one from another, (S,) [and even in the manner of growth, &c.] ― -b4- And Coldness, or coolness, of water. (Kr, M, K.) -A2- See also the next paragraph, in three places.

ratilN * (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ ratalN, (S, M, K,) [the latter an inf. n. used as an epithet,] applied to front teeth, (vagorN, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) Well set together: (T, M:) or even in growth: (S, Msb:) or separate, one from another; or having interstices between them, not overlapping one another: (M:) or separate, one from another, and even in the manner of growth, and well set together; as also ↓ murat~alN: (Mgh:) or separate, one from another, well set together, very white, and very lustrous. (K.) ― -b2- And ratilN, (S,) or ratilu AlA^asonaAni, (M,) [or Alv~agori,] A man having the teeth [or the front teeth] separate, one from another, (S, M,) &c. (M.) ― -b3- And ↓ ratalN (S, M, K) and ratilN, (M, K,) applied to speech, or language, (S, M, K,) i. q. ↓ murat~alN; i. e. uttered in a leisurely manner, and distinctly, without exceeding the proper bounds or limits: (S:) or good, (M, K,) and uttered in a leisurely manner. (M.) ― -b4- And ratilN and ↓ ratalN, applied to anything, Good, sweet, or pleasant. (M, K.) ― -b5- And the former, applied to water, Cold, or cool. (Kr, M, K.)

rutayolaY * and ↓ rutayolaA='u A certain genus of hawaAm~ [or venomous creeping things]; (S, M, K;) [the genus of insects called phalangium; applied thereto in the present day; and (perhaps incorrectly) to the tarantula:] there are several species thereof; (K;) many species; (TA;) the most commonly known thereof is [in its body, app.,] like the fly (*ubaAb) that flies around the lamp; another is black speckled with white (sawodaA='u raqoTaA='u); another is yellow and downy; and the bite of all causes swelling and pain; (K;) and sometimes is deadly. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the latter (↓ rutayolaA='u), A certain plant, the flower of which resembles that of the lily; [app. the plant called (like the insect above mentioned) phalangium, (as Golius states it to be,) and, by Arabs in the present day, zahoru AlEanokabuwti;] good as a remedy against the bite of the venomous creature above mentioned, (K,) for which reason it is thus called, (TA,) and against the sting of the scorpion. (K.)
rutayolaA='u * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

raAtilapN *
Short; (K;) applied to a man. (TA.)

A^arotalu *
i. q. A^arat~u [i. e. Having a vitiousness, or an impediment, in his speech, or utterance: see art. rt]. (O, K.)
murat~alN * : see ratilN, in two places.

1 ratama * , (T, S, M, K,) aor.
ratima , (M, K,) inf. n. ratomN, (T, S, M, K,) He broke a thing: (ISk, T, S, M, K:) and bruised it, or crushed it, (ISk, T, M, K, TA,) much: (M, and so in the CK:) or, (M, K,) accord. to Lh, (M,) specially, (M, K,) he broke (M) the nose: (M, K: [but see ratomN, below:]) and ravama [q. v.] signifies the same: you say, ratama A^anofahu and ravamahu [He broke his nose]. (T, S.) -A2- See also 4. -A3- maA ratama bikalimapK He spoke not a word. (T, S, M, K.) -A4- ratamati AlmiEozaY The goats pastured upon the plant called Alr~atam [in the CK Alr~atom]. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And ratama He became affected with swooning from eating the plant so called. (K, * TA.) -A5- ratama fiY baniY fulaAnK He grew up among the son of such a one. (K.)

4 Artm * , inf. n. A_irotaAmN, [app. He tied a ratiymap, q. v.]. (T.) ratomN, also, as an inf. n., [i. e. of ↓ ratama,] signifies The tying a thread, or string, upon one's own finger for the purpose of remembering something. (KL.) ― -b2- And Artmhu, (inf. n. as above, S,) He tied upon his (a man's, T, S, Mgh) finger a thread, or string, such as is termed ratiymap. (T, S, M, Mgh, K.) -A2- Also He (a young camel) bore fat in his hump. (K.)
5 tarat~ama see what next follows.
8 Arttm * , (Mgh, K,) or Arttm biratiymapK or biratamapK, (M, TA,) and ↓ trt~m, (M, K,) He had a thread, or string, such as is termed ratiymap or ratamap tied upon his finger. (M, Mgh, K.)

ratomN * (S, M, K) and ↓ ratiymN (M, K) and ↓ marotuwmN (S, K) signify the same; i. e. Broken: (S, M, K:) and bruised, or crushed, (M, K, TA,) much: (M, and so accord. to the CK:) the first being an inf. n. used as an epithet. (M, K.) Ows Ibn-Hajar says,
laA^aSabaHa ratomFA duqaAqa AlHaSaY
makaAna Aln~abiY~i mina AlkaAvibi
(S, in the present art.,) i. e. It (referring to a mountain called AlSaAqib) would become [broken, having the pebbles crushed,] like the sands around the mountain El-Káthib. (S in art. nbw. [But there are other explanations of AlnbY~ and AlkAvb as here used. In the T, in art. rvm, a different reading is given: lASbH ravomFA.]) -A2- See also ratiymapN. ― -b2- [Freytag, misled by the CK, has assigned to ratomN a signification that belongs to ratamN.]
