ratamN * [applied in the present day to The shrub broom; to several species thereof: spartium monospermum of Linn.: genista rætam of Forsk.: (Delile, Flor. Aegypt. Illustr., no. 657:) spartium: (Forskål, Flora Aegypt. Arab., p. lvi.:) and phalaris setacea: (Idem, p. lx.:)] a species of plant: (T:) or a species of tree; (Mgh;) or so ↓ ratamapN; of which the former is the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.]: (S:) or the latter, (Lth, T,) or the former, (AHn, M, K,) the latter being its n. un., (K,) a certain plant, of the shrub-kind; (AHn, T, M, K;) as though by reason of its slenderness, it were likened to the thread, or string, called ratami: (AHn, T, * K, * TA: [see this word voce ratiymapN: in the CK, in the present instance, erroneously written raqom:]) and so ↓ ratiymapN: (AHn, T:) its flower is like the xiyriY~ [or yellow gilliflower], and its seed is like the lentil: each of these (i. e. the flower and the seed, TA) strongly provokes vomiting: the drinking the expressed juice of its twigs, fasting, is a beneficial remedy for sciatica (Eiroqu Aln~asaA); and likewise the using as a clyster an infusion thereof in sea-water: and the swallowing twenty-one grains thereof, fasting, prevents the [pustules called] damaAmiyl. (K.) When a man was about to make a journey, he betook himself to two branches, or two trees, and tied one branch to another, and said, “ If my wife be faithful to the compact, this will remain tied as it is; otherwise, she will have broken the compact: ” so says As; and ISk says the like: (T:) or he betook himself to a tree, (S, K,) or to the species of tree called ratam, (ISk, Mgh,) and tied together two branches thereof, (ISk, S, Mgh, K,) or he tied together two trees; (M;) and if he returned and found them as he tied them, he said that his wife had not been unfaithful to him; but otherwise, that she had been so: (ISk, S, M, Mgh, K:) this [pair of branches or trees] is called Alr~atamu [in the CK, erroneously, Alr~atomu] and ↓ Alr~atiymapu: (K:) or this is what is meant by ↓ Alr~atiymapu: (M:) or this [action] is what is meant by taEoqaAdu Alr~atami in the following verse: (As, ISk, T, Mgh:) but IB says that Alr~ataAy^imu [pl. of ↓ Alr~atiymapu] does not mean peculiarly one kind of trees exclusively of others: and he cites this verse as an ex. of Alr~atamu meaning the threads, or strings, so called; (TA;) as does AZ. (Mgh.) A rájiz says,
halo yanofaEanoka Alyawoma A_ino ham~ato bihimo
kavorapu maA tuwSiY wataEoqaAdu Alr~atamo
[Will the muchness of thine enjoining, and the tying of the retem, be indeed of use to thee to-day, if she be desirous of them?]. (T, S, Mgh.) ― -b2- See also ratiymapN, in two places. -A2- Also A [leathern water-bag such as is called] mazaAdap that is filled (IAar, T, K) with water: (IAar, T:) or a [water-skin such as is called] mazaAd. (M, TT.) -A3- And A road, or way; or the middle, or main part and middle, thereof; or a beaten track; syn. maHaj~apN. (IAar, T, K.) -A4- And Suppressed, low-sounding, occult, or secret, speech or language. (IAar, T, K.) -A5- And Perfect shame or sense of shame or pudency. (IAar, T, K.)
ratomapN * : see ratiymapN.
ratamapN * : see ratamN [of which it is the n. un.]: ― -b2- and see also ratiymapN.
ratomaA='u * A she-camel that eats the plant called Alr~atam, and keeps to it, and is fond of it. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And That carries the filled mazaAdap (K, TA) called ratam. (TA.)
rutAmN * A thing broken in pieces, or into small pieces; crushed; or crumbled. (K, TA.)
ratiymN * : see ratomN: -A2- and see also ratiymapN. -A3- Also A slow pace. (K.)

ratiymapN * (T, S, M, Mgh, K) and ↓ ratamapN, (T, M, L,) the latter written thus by IB on the authority of 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh, (L, TA,) or ↓ ratomapN, (S, K, [in one copy of the S written ratamp, and in my copy of the Mgh without any syll. signs,] A thread, or string, that is tied upon the finger for the purpose of reminding one (T, S, M, Mgh, K) of some object of want: (T, S:) pl. of the first, rataAy^imu (S, M, Mgh, K) and ritaAmN; (M, K;) and [coll. gen. n.] of the second, ↓ ratamN; (M, IB;) and of the third, [if it be correct,] ↓ ratomN: (K: in the CK rutomN:) IAar says that ↓ ratiymN signifies the thread, or string, for reminding; but others say ratiympN: Lth says that ↓ ratimN signifies a thread, or string, that is tied upon the finger, or upon the signet-ring, for a sign, or token: (T:) and IB cites the verse cited above voce ratamN as an ex. of this word in the sense here assigned to it as a pl. [or coll. gen. n.]; (TA;) and so does AZ. (Mgh.) The binding of rataAy^im [upon the fingers] is forbidden in a trad.: and it is said that Almusota*okiru biAlr~ataAy^imi musotahodfN ll$~ataAy^m [He who seeks to remember by means of the threads, or strings, that are tied upon the fingers for the purpose of reminding becomes a butt for revilings]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also ratamN, in four places.
rutaAmay * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned], like sukaAray, Persons affected with swooning from eating the plant called Alr~atam. (K.)

entryFree.key: maA zaAla raAtimFA Ealay h`*aA AlA^amori

div2.entryFree: maA zaAla raAtimFA Ealay h`*aA AlA^amori * means He ceased not to be constantly occupied in this affair: (T, M, K, * TA:) Yaakoob asserts that the m of rAtmA is a substitute [for b], though ratama does not occur in the sense of rataba: (M, TA:) IJ says that this may be the case, or that the word may be from Alr~atamapu and Alr~atiymapu. (TA.) [See also raAtbN: and see turotumN, below.]

A^arotamu * [app. Having his nose broken. ― -b2- And hence,] One who does not speak clearly, nor intelligibly; as though his nose were broken: occurring in a trad.: or, as some relate it, A^arovamu [q. v.]. (TA.)

$ar~u turotumN * and turotamN Continual, or constant, evil: (K, TA:) the m is a substitute for the b of turotuab; and the former t is augmentative, because there is no word like juEofarN consisting of radical letters. (TA.) [See also raAtimFA, above.]
marotuwmN * : see ratomN.

1 rav~a * , (T, S, M, &c.,) sec. pers. [ravavota and ravivota and] ravuvota, (Msb,) aor.
ravi3a (T, S, M, K) and
rava3a (M) and
ravu3a , (Msb, TA,) the last being of rav~a of the class of qaruba, (Msb,) inf. n. ravaAvapN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and ruvuwvapN; (M, Msb, K;) and ↓ Arv~; (S, M, Msb, K;) both authorized by AZ; the latter at first disallowed by As, but afterwards allowed by him; (M;) It was, or became, old, and worn out; (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb;) and mean, or bad; (M;) namely, a garment, (T, S, M, A, Mgh,) and a rope, (S, M, A,) or other thing, (S, Msb,) i. e. anything, but mostly said of what is worn as clothing, or spread as furniture: (M:) or he, or it, was, or became, threadbare, shabby, or mean. (M, K:) said of a man, it has for its aor. yarav~u, and inf. n. ravaAvapN. (M.) ravaAvapu Alhayoy^api means An old, worn-out, state of garb or apparel; and a bad condition. (Mgh.) And you say, fiy hayoy^atihi ravaAvapN In his garb, or apparel, is threadbareness, shabbiness, or meanness. (S.) And rav~ato hayoy^apu Al$~axoSi, and ↓ Arv~t, (assumed tropical:) The aspect, or state, or condition, of the person was, or became, weak, and vile, mean, paltry, or despicable. (Msb.) [And rav~a Alr~ajulu (assumed tropical:) The man was, or became, old, and worn out; or weak,
&c.: see rav~N.] ― -b2- [And hence,] fiY h`*aA Alxabari ravaAvapN (tropical:) In this information, announcement, piece of news, or narration, is unsoundness, invalidity, or incorrectness; and so, fiyhi rakaAkapN. (A, TA.)

4 Arv~ * : see above, in two places. ― -b2- Also, said of a man, His rope was, or became, old, and worn out. (M.) -A2- Arv~hu He, (K,) or it, i. e. wear, attrition, or wear and tear, (Th, M,) rendered it old, and worn out; and mean, or bad; (Th, M;) or threadbare, shabby, or mean; (K;) namely, anything, but mostly used in relation to what is worn as clothing, or spread as furniture. (M.)

8 AirotavavonaA riv~apa Alqawomi *
We collected, (T, S, M,) or bought, (M,) the paltry, mean, or vile, chattels, or articles of furniture, of the people, or party, (T, S, M,) consisting of old and worn-out garments or pieces of cloth. (S, M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Aurotuv~a (of the pass. form, S, K) (tropical:) He (a man) was carried off from the field of battle wounded (S, A, K) so as to be rendered weak, (A,) retaining remains of life: (S, K:) from riv~apN as meaning the “ weak ” of mankind, who are likened to the paltry, mean, or vile, chattels, or articles of furniture, termed riv~apN: (A:) or he, being smitten in battle, and wounded so as to be rendered weak, was carried off, retaining remains of life, and then died: (T:) or he (a wounded man) was carried off from the field of battle retaining remains of life; because, in that case, he is weak, or is thrown down like the chattels, or articles of furniture, termed riv~apN. (Mgh.) And mar~abayonahumo faA@rotav~ahumo (tropical:) [He passed amid them, and carried them off from the field of battle wounded so as to be rendered weak, but retaining remains of life]. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] Airotav~a (assumed tropical:) He slaughtered a she-camel belonging to him, (T, K,) or a sheep or goat, or the like, (T,) by reason of [its] emaciation. (T, K.)

rav~N *
Old, and worn out; (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) and mean, or bad; (M;) and ↓ raviyvN signifies the same, (M, A, K,) as does also ↓ A^arav~u, (A, K,) and ↓ riv~apN: (M, TA: [but this last is app. a subst, as it is said to be in another place in the M and in the TA, meaning a thing that is old, and worn out; &c.:]) applied to a garment, (T, M, A, Mgh,) and a rope, (A,) or a thing (S, M, Msb) of any kind, but mostly to what is worn as clothing, or spread as furniture: (M:) the pl. of rav~N is rivaAvN. (S, M, Msb.) You say hayoy^apN rav~apN An old, worn-out, state of garb or apparel; such as is in bad condition. (Mgh.) And rajulN rav~u Alhayoy^api A man whose garb, or apparel, is old, and worn out; (T, S, * M;) threadbare, shabby, or mean. (M.) This last phrase is [also] tropical [as meaning (tropical:) A man whose aspect, or state, or condition, is weak, and vile, mean, paltry, or despicable: see 1, last sentence but two]. (A.) And one says also rajulN rav~N (assumed tropical:) [A man old, and worn out; or weak, &c.]. (T.) ― -b2- And [hence,] kalaAmN rav~N (tropical:) Meagre, unsubstantial, or flimsy, speech or language. (A.) ― -b3- See also what next follows.

riv~apN * (T, S, M, Mgh, K) and ↓ rav~N (T, M, K) The paltry, mean, or vile, chattels, or articles of furniture, (T, S, M, A, K,) of the house or tent, (S, M, A, K,) consisting of old and worn-out garments or pieces of cloth: (S, M:) or such are termed riv~apu AlmutaAEi: (Mgh:) the pl. of riv~apN is rivavN (T, S, K) and rivaAvN: (S, K:) it is a subst. from rav~a signifying “ it was, or became, old, and worn out, ” and “ mean, or bad; ” said of anything, but mostly of what is worn as clothing, or spread as furniture, and of a rope: (M:) [i. e. it means any such thing that is old, and worn out, and mean, or bad:] see also rav~N. ― -b2- Hence, (T, A, Mgh,) riv~apN signifies (tropical:) The weak of mankind; (T, S, M, A, Mgh, K;) [the old, and worn-out, thereof;] and the refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, thereof: (S, M:) as being likened to the chattels, or articles of furniture, thus termed. (A, Mgh.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A foolish, or stupid, woman; one who is unsound, or deficient, in intellect or understanding. (S, K.)
raviyvN * : see rav~N. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Wounded; and so ↓ murotav~N: (TA:) or wounded, but retaining remains of life. (S, K.) [See the latter epithet below.]
A^arav~u * : see rav~N.
muriv~N * A man whose rope is old, and worn out. (K.)

murotav~N * (tropical:) One who is carried off from the field of battle (Th, S, M) wounded [so as to be rendered weak (see 8)], (S,) retaining remains of life; (Th, S, M;) if slain, he is not thus termed: (Th, M:) or one who is thrown prostrate, and wounded so as to be rendered weak, in battle, and is carried off alive, and then dies. (M.) See also raviyvN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Falling down, and weak: from rav~N applied to a garment that is old, and worn out. (TA.)

1 ravaA^a * , (S, M, K,) aor.
ravaAa , (M, K,) inf. n. ravo'N, (S, M,) He drew milk from the udder upon sour milk, so that it thickened, (S, K,) and became what is termed raviyoy^ap: (K:) or he mixed fresh milk with sour milk: or, as some say, he made milk to become what is termed raviyoy^ap: (M:) or it has this last signification, and also signifies he mixed [in an absolute sense]. (K.) [Az says,] I heard an Arab of the desert, of Benoo-Mudarris, say to a servant of his, AirovaA^o liY lubayonapF A^a$orabuhaA [Mix thou for me a little milk so as to make raviyoy^ap, which I will drink]. (T.) And you say, ravaA^a Alqawoma (M, K) and ravaA^a lahumo (M) He made for the party raviyoy^ap. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] humo yarovaw^uwna raA^oyahumo, (S,) and ravaw^uwA raA^oyahumo, (M,) inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) They confuse, or confound, and they confused, or confounded, their judgment, or opinion. (S, M. [See also 8.]) ― -b3- And [hence also, perhaps, as rvyy^p is said to be beaten with a mijodaH in the mixing of it,] He beat (K) with a staff, or stick. (TA.) -A2- It (anger) became stilled, or appeased. (K.) -A3- He (a camel) became affected with the disease termed ravoA^ap. (K.) -A4- Also, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (M,) a dial. var. of ravaY, meaning He eulogized a man after his death [in verse or otherwise; or he wept for him, or over him, enumerating his good qualities or actions]: (M, K: *) and in like manner one says of a woman eulogizing her husband after his death; inf. n. maroviy^apN: (M:) ISk mentions an Arab woman's saying ravaA^otu zawojiY biA^aboyaAtK [I eulogized my husband after his death with verses]; pronouncing the verb with '; but it is originally without ': (S, Sgh:) Fr says that her doing this arose from her finding them to say ravaA^otu All~abana and her therefore supposing Almaroviyap to be from the same source: (TA in the present art.:) or, accord. to Fr, their chasteness of speech sometimes induced them to pronounce with ' that which is [properly] without '; and thus they said ravaA^otu Almay~ita and lab~aA^otu biAlHaj~i and Hal~aA^otu Als~awiyqa. (TA in art. rvw.)
4 A^arovaAa see the next paragraph.

8 ArtvA^ *
It (milk) thickened, or became thick: (S, K:) and so ↓ ArvA^, (M, K,) in some one or more of the dialects. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ArtvA^ Ealayohimo A^amoruhumo (assumed tropical:) Their case, or affair, became confused to them. (S, M.) And ArtvA^ fiY raA^oyihi (assumed tropical:) He made a confusion in his judgment, or opinion. (S, K.) And humo yarotaviy^uwna A^amorahumo (assumed tropical:) [app. for fiY A^amorihimo, and thus meaning They are confused, or they make a confusion, in their case, or affair: or, otherwise, they confuse their case, or affair]: from Alr~aviyoy^ap; (T, TA;) and if so, tropical. (TA.) -A2- Also He drank what is termed raviyoy^ap. (T, K.)
ravo'N * : see ravoA^apN.
ruvo'N * : see ruvoA^apN.

ravoA^apN * , (M, TA,) or ↓ ravo'N, (K, [probably a mistranscription,]) (assumed tropical:) Littleness of intelligence or sagacity: (M, K:) and (assumed tropical:) weakness of heart: (M, TA:) and (assumed tropical:) foolishness, or stupidity; (K;) and so ↓ raviyoy^apN (Th, M, K) and ↓ marovaA^N. (TA in art. wA^b.) ― -b2- Hence, perhaps, (TA,) the first of these words (ravoA^apN) signifies [also] (assumed tropical:) A certain disease in a camel's shoulder-joint, (K,) in consequence of which he limps. (TA.)
ruvoA^apN * , (M, TA,) or ↓ ruvo'N, (K, [probably a mistranscription,]) Blackness mixed with speckles of white; or the reverse: syn. ruqoTapN. (M, K.)

raviyoy^apN *
Sour milk upon which fresh milk is drawn from the udder, so that it becomes thick: (Lh, S, M, K:) or fresh milk poured upon sour, (As, T, M, Mgh,) and then stirred about with a [wooden instrument called] mijodaH until it becomes thick: (Lh, M:) or fresh milk upon which sour milk is poured, then left a while, whereupon thin yellow water [or whey] comes forth, and is poured away from it, and then the thick is drunk. (Har p. 451.) One says, Alr~aviyoy^apu tafovaA^u AlgaDaba (S, TA) What is termed rvyy^p stills, or appeases, anger: (TA:) alluding to [the effect produced
by] a small kindness: a saying which originated from a man's being incensed against some persons. and being hungry, and their giving him to drink some rvyy^p, whereupon his anger became appeased: (S in art. fvA^:) hence it became a proverb. (TA.) -A2- See also ravoA^apN.
A^arovaA^u * , fem. ravoA='u, A ram, and a ewe, black speckled with white; or the reverse: syn. A^aroqaTu, and raqoTaA='u. (M, K.)
marovaA^N * : see ravoA^apN.
marovuwo'N * (assumed tropical:) A man weak-hearted, and of little intelligence or sagacity. (M.) [See also marovuw~N, in art. rvw.]

1 ravada AlmataAEa * , (T, S, M, A, K,) aor.
ravuda , inf. n. ravodN; (S, M;) and ↓ Artvdhu, (K,) in some copies of the K ↓ Arvdhu [which I doubt not to be a mistranscription]; (TA;) He put the goods, or household goods, or utensils and furniture, one upon another, or together, in regular order, or compactly, (T, S, M, A, K,) or side by side. (S.) ― -b2- ravadato bayoDahaA She (a hen) collected together her eggs. (IAar, M.) ― -b3- ruvidati AlqaSoEapu biAlv~ariydi The bowl was heaped with the vryd [or crumbled, or broken, bread, moistened with broth,] put together and made even. (M, L.) ― -b4- ravada HaAjatahu (assumed tropical:) He deferred, delayed, postponed, or put off, his (another's) needful affairs; the sing. noun being used for the pl. (L, from a trad.) -A2- ravida, aor.
ravada , (K,) inf. n. ravadN; (TK;) and ↓ Arvd; i. q. kadira; (K;) said of a man [as meaning He was, or became, disturbed, perturbed, or troubled, in mind]; (TA;) or said of water [as meaning it was, or became, turbid, thick, or muddy.] (TK.)

4 A^arovada see 1, first sentence. -A2- ArvdwA They stayed, or abode [in a place; not journeying, or departing: see rivodapN]. (Ks, S, K.) ― -b2- And Arvd, said of one digging, He reached the moist earth. (ISk, S, K.) -A3- See also 1, last sentence.
8 A_irotavada see 1, first sentence.
rivodN * : see rivodapN.

ravadN * : see raviydN. ― -b2- Also The goods, or utensils and furniture, of a house or tent, that are of a worthless, paltry, mean, or vile, kind, or that are held in little account. (M, L.) ― -b3- And Weak, or powerless, people: (S, L, K:) differing from murotviduwna [q. v.]. (S, L.) One says, tarakonaA EalaY AlmaA='i ravadFA maA yuTiyquwna taHam~ulFA [We left at the water weak, or powerless, people, unable to take up their goods and to depart]. (S, L.)

rvodapN * , (IAar, T, S, M, L,) or ↓ rivodN, (K,) or both, (TA,) A company, (IAar, S,) or a numerous company, (T, L,) of men, (IAar, T, S, M, L,) staying, or abiding, [in a place,] (IAar, T, S, M, L, K,) not journeying, or departing, (S,) when the rest of them journey, or depart; (T;) as also livodapN. (T, L.)

mataAEN raviydN * (S, M, A, L, K) and ↓ marovuwdN (S, M, L, K) Goods, or household-goods, or utensils and furniture, put one upon another, or together, in regular order, or compactly, (S, M, A, L, K,) or side by side; (S;) as also ↓ ravadN; (A, K;) or this last, [as a subst.,] household-goods, or utensils and furniture, so put. (T, S, M, L.) And TaEaAmN raviydN and ↓ marovuwdN Food, or wheat, heaped up. (T, L.) And xubozN raviydN [Bread piled up]. (A.) And Alv~ariydu fiY AlqaSoEapi [The crumbled, or broken, bread, moistened with broth, is heaped and put together and made even in the bowl]. (A.)
marovadN * A generous man: (ISk, K:) from A^arovada signifying “ he reached the moist earth in digging. ” (ISk.) ― -b2- And Almarovadu is a name of The lion. (S, K.)
marovuwdN * : see raviydN, in two places.

tarakotuhumo murotavidiyna maA taHam~aluwA baEodu * means I left them putting their goods, or utensils and furniture, one upon another, (T, * S, M, * L, K,) without having that whereon to remove them, (S, L,) [not having yet taken them up and departed:] thus murotaviduwna differs from ravadN [q. v.]. (S, L.)

1 ravama * , (T, S, M, K,) aor.
ravima , (M, K,) inf. n. ravomN, (T, M,) He broke one's nose, (S, M, K,) or his mouth, (T, M, K,) so as to make it bleed, (S,) or so that the blood dropped from it: (M, K:) and ratama is a dial. var. thereof: (TA:) rutomN and ravamN signify also any breaking. (T, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ravamoto A^anofahaA biAlT~iybi (assumed tropical:) She (a woman) smeared her nose with perfume. (S, M, K. [See marovuwmN, below.]) ― -b3- And ruvima, said of the manosim [or foot, or sole of the foot, or extremity of the fore foot,] of a camel, (T, M,) It was wounded so that the blood flowed from it: (T:) or it bled. (M.) -A2- ravima, (M, K,) aor.
ravama , (K,) inf. n. ravamN; (M;) and ↓ Arvm~, inf. n. AirovimaAmN; (S, K;) said of a horse, He had what is termed ↓ ravamN [in a copy of the M written ravom, but expressly said in the K to be muHar~akap,] and ↓ ruvomapN [in a copy of the T written ravomp, and in a copy of the M rvamp, but said in the K to be with damm]; (S, K;) i. e. a whiteness in the upper lip: (AO, T, S:) if in the lower lip, it is termed lumoZapN: (AO, TA:) or a whiteness in the extremity of the nose: (M, K:) or any whiteness, (M, K,) little or much, (M,) upon the upper lip, reaching to the place of the halter: or a whiteness in the nose. (M, K.) The epithet applied to the horse in this case is ↓ A^arovamu (T, S, M, K) [explained in the Mgh as signifying, thus applied, Of which the upper lip is white,] and ↓ ravimN; fem. of the former ravomaA='u. (M, K.) ― -b2- [ravima is also app. said of one's nose, as meaning It was much scratched, and slit, in its extremity, so that the blood issued from it and fell in drops: see ravamN, which seems to be its inf. n. in this sense, below.]
9 A_irovam~a see above.
ravomN * : see raviymN: and see also a reading of a verse cited in art. rtm, voce ratomN.
ravamN * : see 1. ― -b2- Also, [app. as inf. n. of ravima, q. v.,] A vehement scratching, and slitting, of the extremity of the nose, so that the blood issues from it and falls in drops. (T.)
ravimN * : see 1.

ravomapN *
A weak, or scanty, rain; as also ↓ ravamapN: pl. rivaAmN (K.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] halo Einodaka ravomapN mino xabarK (assumed tropical:) Hast thou somewhat of news, or tidings. (K, * TA. [In the CK, erroneously, mn xubozK.])
ruvomapN * : see 1.
ravamapN * : see ravomapN.
raviymN * : see marovuwmN, in two places. ― -b2- HaSFY raviymN Pebbles broken in pieces; as also ↓ ravomN: (T:) or ravymu AlHaSaY means what are crushed, of the pebbles, by the feet of camels. (TA.)

ravimapN *
i. q. faA^orapN: (K; and so in the M, accord. to the TT:) [or] correctly, qaArapN, with qAf. (TA. [But no evidence of the correctness of this reading is adduced in the TA.])

A^arovamu * ; fem. ravomaA='u: see 1; and see also A^alomaZu. ― -b2- [Also, app., applied to a man, Having his nose much scratched, and slit, in its extremity, so that the blood issues from it and falls in drops. ― -b3- And hence,] One who does not speak clearly, nor correctly, [as though his nose were broken at the end and so closed, or] by reason of some evil affection of his tongue: occurring in a trad.: or, as some relate it, A^arotamu [q. v.] (TA.)
marovimN * : see what next follows.
mirovamN * The nose; (M, K;) in some one or more of the dialects; (M;) as also ↓ marovimN. (K.)

A^aroDN murav~amapN *
Land rained upon [app. with such rain as is termed ravomapN]. (K.)

marovuwmN * (T, S, M, K) and ↓ raviymN (M, K) A nose, (T, S, M, K,) or mouth, (M, K,) broken, and smeared with blood: (T:) or broken so as to be made to bleed: (S:) or broken so that the blood drops from it: (M, K:) and anything smeared with blood, or (so in the M, but in the K “ and ”) broken. (M, K.) ― -b2- And the former, as being likened to a nose in the state above described, (assumed tropical:) A woman's nose smeared with perfume. (T, S.) ― -b3- Also A camel's foot wounded by stones, so that it bleeds; like malovuwmN; (S, TA;) and in like manner ↓ raviymN applied to a manosim [see 1, third sentence]: or, accord. to Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee, A^axofaAfN marovuwmapN signifies camels' feet upon which the stones have had an effect, or made marks. (TA.)
1 ravawotu * : see 1 in art. rvY, passim.

ravowN *
Milk such as is termed raviyoy^apN. (M, K. [See the latter word, in art. rvA^.])

marovuw~N * , meaning A man weak in intellect, is from Alr~avoyapu, [mentioned in art. rvY,] and [therefore]
by rule should be maroviY~N. (M.) And marovuwo'N [signifies the same, (see this word, in art. rvA^,) and in like manner, accord. to ISd,] is from Alr~avoyapu, irreg., being with ' (M in art. rvY.)

1 ravayotu Almay~ita * , (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. A^aroviyhi, (Msb,) inf. n. maroviyapN (S, M, Msb, K) and marovaApN and rivaAyapN and rivaA='N and ravoYN; (M, K;) and ravawotuhu; (S, M in art. rvw, * and K;) I wept for, or over, [or bewailed,] the dead man, and [eulogized him, or] enumerated his good qualities or actions; (S, K;) as also ↓ rav~ayotuyhu, inf. n. taroviyapN; and ↓ tarav~ayotuhu: (K:) and also I composed verses on the dead man; (S, K;) [composed an elegy, a dirge, or an epicedium, on him;] eulogized him in verse: (TA:) or I eulogized the dead man, and wept for him or over him; as also ↓ rav~ayotuhu: (M:) or, accord. to Lth, ravaY fulaAnFA, aor. yaroviyhi, inf. n. ravoYN and maroviyapN, signifies he wept for, or over, such a one after his death; and ↓ rv~Ahu, inf. n. troviyapN, he eulogized him after his death: (T:) or ravayotu Almay~ita and lahu ↓ tarav~ayotu signify I felt, or expressed, pity, or compassion, for the dead man. (Msb. [See also ravaY lahu, in what follows.]) You say also, ravati AlmaroA^apu zawojahaA, (IAar, T,) or baEolahaA, (M,) aor. taroviyhi (IAar, T, M) and tarovuwhu, (IAar, T, and M in art. rvw,) inf. n. rivaAyapN [&c.]; (T;) and raviyatohu, aor. tarovaAhu, inf. n. rvaAyapN [&c.]; (Lh, M;) and ↓ tarav~atohu; (M;) [The woman wept for, or over, her husband, &c, he being dead:] and ISk mentions an Arab woman's saying ravaA^otu zawojiY biA^aboyaAtK; pronouncing the verb with ' (S. [See 1 (last sentence) in art. rvA^.]) And you say, ravaY lahu He was, or became, tender, pitiful, or compassionate, towards him. (S, M, K.) And maA yaroviY fulaAnN liY Such a one does not lament, complain, or express pain or grief, for me; nor does he care for me: and A_in~iY laA A^aroviY lahu [Verily I do not lament, &c., for him], inf. n. marovaApN and ravoYN. (T.) ― -b2- ravayotu Eanohu HadiyvFA, (AA, Lh, T, S, M, K,) aor. A^aroviY, inf. n. rivaAyapN, (AA, T, S, K,) I mentioned a story, or tradition, received from him: (AA, T, S, K:) and (K) I retained in my memory a story, or tradition, received from him: (Lh, M, K:) but the phrase that is well known is navayotu Eanohu xabarFA, meaning “ I bore information, or tidings, from him: ” (M:) and ravawotu Eanohu HadiyvFA also has the second of these meanings; (M and K * in art. rvw;) or the first of them: (K in that art.:) but the phrase that is well known is navawotu Eanohu xabarFA: (M in that art.:) accord. to E-'Okeylee, you say, ravawonaA bayonanaA HadiyvFA and ravayonaAhu [i. e. We mentioned among us a story, or tradition]; and tanaAvayonaAhu means the like thereof. (T.) -A2- raviYa, (IAar, M, K, [and accord. to the TA, ruviYa, but it appears from the context that this is taken from a copy of the M, and is wrong,]) inf. n. ravoYN, by rule ravFY, (IAar, M,) He was, or became, affected with what is termed ravoyapN, (IAar, M, K,) in all the senses of this word. (K.) -A3- [A meaning assigned to ravaA by Golius belongs to ravaA^a, q. v.]
2 rav~aYa see 1, in three places.
5 tarav~aYa see 1, in three places.
8 ArtvY * . The meanings assigned to this verb by Golius belong to ArtvA^, q. v.]

ravoyapN *
A pain in the knees and [other] joints: (S:) or a pain in the joints, and in the arms and legs, or hands and feet, or fore and hind legs: (M, K:) or a swelling, (M, K,) and a [malady such as is termed] ZulaAE, (M,) in the legs of a beast: (M, K:) or anything that prevents a person from rising and going away, or going quickly, occasioned by old age or pain: (M, K, * TA: AlAilotifaAt in the K is a mistake for AlAinobiEaAv: TA:) pl. ravayaAtN. (S.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ raviy~apN, Weakness. (Th, M, K. [Aw DaEofK in the CK is a mistake for waAlD~aEofu.]) ― -b3- And Foolishness, or stupidity. (Th, M, K.) And you say, fiY A^amorihi ravoyapN In his affair is a flagging, or remissness, or languor. (M.)
raviy~apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
rav~aA='apN * and ↓ rav~aAyapN, epithets applied to a woman, (T, S, K,) Who wails much (T, * K, TA) for her husband: or who weeps much for, or over, another, of those whom she holds in honour. (TA.)
rav~aAyapN * : see what next precedes.
A^arovaY * A man who does not perform an affair firmly, soundly, or thoroughly, (M, K, TA,) by reason of his weakness. (TA.)
marovaApN * (M, K) and ↓ maroviyapN (S, M, Msb, K) [see 1: used as simple substs., A lamentation for one dead; an elegy; a dirge; an epicedium: pl. miraAvK].
maroviyapN * : see what next precedes.

1 raj~ahu * , (S, A, Msb,) aor.
raju3a , (S, Msb,) inf. n. raj~N, (S, Msb, K,) He put it in motion, or in a state of commotion or agitation: (S, A, Msb, K:) he put it in a state of convulsion, or violent motion; or made it to shake, quake, or quiver: (S, A, TA:) as also ↓ rajorajahu. (A.) Hence, in the Kur [lvi-4], A_i*aA ruj~ati AlA^aroDu raj~FA When the earth shall be convulsed with violent convulsion. (TA.) And raj~a AlbaAba He shook the door violently. (TA from a trad.) -A2- See also 8.

4 A^araj~ato *
She (a mare) was near to bringing forth, and the part on either side of her tail (SalaAhaA) quivered, or quaked; (K;) as also ↓ Airotaj~ato. (TA.) The part. n. applied to the mare in this case is ↓ murij~N [without p]. (K.)

8 Artj~ * , (S, A,. Msb,) inf. n. AirotijaAjN, (K,) It was, or became, in a state of commotion or agitation; (S, A, Msb, * K;) or of convulsion, or violent motion; or it shook, quaked, or quivered; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ tarajoraja; (A, K;) and ↓ rajoraja inf. n. rajorajapN; (S, K; but they mention only the inf. n. of this verb;) and so ↓ raj~a, inf. n. raj~N: (K, * TA; but of this verb, also, only the inf. n. is mentioned:) Artj~ is quasi-pass. of raj~ahu; (T, A, Msb;) and is said of the sea, as meaning it was, or became, in a state of commotion or agitation (S, Msb) with its waves; and in like manner of other things: (S:) and ↓ tarajoraja signifies it (a thing) went to and fro; and is said of a woman's flesh; (S;) or [particularly] of her hinder part; (A;) or of both. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting the blowing of the horn [on the day of resurrection], fatarotaj~u AlA^aroDu biA^aholihaA And the earth shall be in a state of commotion or agitation, with its inhabitants. (TA.) See also 4. ― -b2- [Hence,] Artj~ AlZ~alaAmu (assumed tropical:) The darkness became confused. (Msb.) ― -b3- And Artj~ AlkalaAmu (assumed tropical:) The speech, or language, became confused; mentioned by ISd in this art: (TA:) or Airotaj~a Ealayohi AlkalaAmu (tropical:) the speech, or language, became conflicting and confused to him. (A.) [See also Aurotuj~a Ealayohi in the first paragraph of art. rtj.]

R. Q. 1 rajoraja * , inf. n. rajorajapN: see 1: -A2- and see also 8. ― -b2- rajorajapN also signifies The being fatigued, tired, weary, or jaded, (K, TA,) and weak [app. so as to shake, or totter]. (TA.)
R. Q. 2 tarajoraja * : see 8, in two places.

raj~apN * [app. A confused, or murmuring, or rumbling, sound:] the confusion of the voices [or the confused voices] of a company of men: and the sound of thunder. (TA.) sumiEato raj~apu Sadorihi [app. meaning The rumbling of his chest was heard] occurs in a trad. as describing the result of [fright occasioned by] a cry, or shout. (TA.)

ruj~apN *
A state of confusion: so in the phrase, waqaEa fiY ruj~apK [He fell into a state of confusion]. (Mgh in art. rtj.)

rajajN *
A state of commotion, agitation, convulsion, shaking, quaking, or quivering. (TA.)

rajaAjN *
Lean, or emaciated, sheep or goats, (S, K,) and camels: (TA:) and naEojapN rajaAjapN a lean, or an emaciated, ewe; (S, K;) or a weak ewe, that has no marrow in her bones. (As, TA.) And Weak men, and camels; (S, K;) and so ↓ rajoraAjN applied to the latter, and to men as meaning weak, without understanding, intellect, or intelligence. (TA.) Hence, it is said of men who have become weak by reason of travel, and whose camels upon which they are riding have also become weak,
fahumo rajaAjN waEalaY rajaAji
[And they are weak men, and upon weak beasts]. (S.)
rijaAjapN * The covert, or retreat, of a lion. (TA.)

raj~aA='u * A she-camel having a large hump: (S:) or having a large, and shaking, quaking, or quiver-
ing, hump: (K:) IDrd says, in the Jm, They assert it to mean having a shaking, quaking, or quivering, hump; but I know not what is its true meaning. (TA.)

rajorajN * an epithet applied to that which is ↓ mutarajorij [or In a state of commotion or agitation; or of convulsion, or violent motion; or shaking, quaking, or quivering, or going to and fro]; (S;) [and so ↓ rajoraAjN.]

rijorijN * : see rijorijapN. ― -b2- Also Slaver, or drivel. (TA. [See, again, rijorijapN.]) ― -b3- And i. q. maA='u qariysK [app. meaning The fluid of the gelatinous substance termed qariys, prepared from fish &c.]. (TA.) ― -b4- And Crumbled, or broken, bread, (variyd,) made soft with grease, or gravy: (TA:) and ↓ rijorijapN [as its n. un.] signifies a mess of such bread (variydapN) so made soft; (Sudot;;) and variydapN rajoraAjapN [signifies the same, or] a mess of such bread made soft and compact. (TA.) -A2- Also, [said in the K and TA to be like qiloqilN, but in the CK like fulofulN,] A certain plant. (S, K.)

rijorijapN *
Remains of water in a watering-trough, or tank, (S, K,) turbid, and mixed with mud; (S;) as also ↓ rijorijN: in a trad., in which it occurs, accord. to one relation it is ↓ rajoraAjapN; but rijorijapN is the word commonly known: accord. to As, it is syn. with radohapN: the pl. is rajaAriju. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Water mixed with slaver, or drivel. (TA.) ― -b3- And Spittle, or saliva, that has gone forth from the mouth; or flowing saliva: (K, TA:) so in the saying, A_in~a fulaAnFA kaviyru Alr~ijorijapi [Verily such a one has much spittle, &c.: and rijorijN signifies nearly, or exactly, the same]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also rijorijN. -A2- Also A large company, or troop, in war. (K.) -A3- And [an epithet signifying] Devoid of understanding, intellect, or intelligence; (K:) and devoid of good: (TA:) or the evil, bad, or corrupt, of mankind, in a pl. sense: (Nh, TA:) or the low, base, vile, or mean, of mankind, or of the young thereof; or the lowest, basest, or meanest, sort, or refuse, of mankind, that have no understanding, intellect, or intelligence; as also ↓ rajoraAjapN: (Sh, TA:) or, in a pl. sense, such as have no understanding, intellect, or intelligence, of a people, or party. (El-Kilábee, TA.)

rajoraAjN * : see rajorajN. ― -b2- [Hence,] rajoraAjapN A woman, (S,) or girl, (A,) whose flesh, (S,) or hinder part, (A,) quivers, or quakes; (S, A;) [and so ↓ mutarajorijapN, occurring in the A and TA in art. dyS.] ― -b3- And variydapN rajoraAjapN: see rijorijN. ― -b4- And katiybapN rajoraAjapN (tropical:) And army, or a troop, agitated to and fro (A, L) in its march, (L,) scarcely moving onwards, (A, L,) by reason of its multitude: (L:) or as though agitated to and fro, and not moving onwards, by reason of its multitude. (S.) ― -b5- See also rajaAjN. ― -b6- Also A certain medicine, (L, K,) well known. (K.)
rajoraAjapN * [fem. of rajoraAjN, q. v. ― -b2- Also, as a subst.,] A mess of the kind of food called faAluw* [q. v.]. (A.) -A2- See also rijorijapN, in two places.

raAj~N *
Having a confusion of voices, by reason of the multitude of the people therein. (Aboo-Moosà, TA in art. zj)
murij~N * : see 4.
mutarajorijN * ; and its fem., with p: see rajorajN, and rajoraAjN

4 ArjA^ *
He postponed, put off, deferred, or delayed, (ISk, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) an affair, (ISk, S, Mgh, K,) and a person; (TA;) as also ArjY: (ISk, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) but the former is the better: the inf. n. is A_irojaA='N. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xxxiii. 51], accord. to different readings, turojiY'u mano ta$aA='u minohun~a or turojiY, meaning Thou mayest put off whom thou wilt of them: addressed peculiarly to the Prophet, exclusively of others of his people. (Zj, TA.) [See also an ex. in the Kur vii. 108 and xxvi. 35; and the various readings mentioned by Bd in the former instance.] -A2- A^arojaA^ato She (a camel, S, K, and in like manner a pregnant female [of any kind], TA) was, or became, near to bringing forth; as also A^arojato: (S, K:) AA says the former. (S.) -A3- And ArjA^ He (a hunter or sportsman) was unsuccessful, getting no game; as also ArjY: (K, TA:) or you say, ArjA^ AlS~ayoda, (TA in art. rjw,) and ArjY AlS~ayoda. (K in that art.)

murojaA^N * [pass. part. n. of 4]. It is said in the Kur [ix. 107], (S, K,) as some read, (S,) waA=xaruwna, murojaw^uwna liA^amori A@ll~`hi, (S, K,) or, as others read, murojawona, (S,) meaning [And others are] delayed [for the execution of the decree of God,] until God shall cause to betide them what He willeth. (S, K.)

murojiY'N * [act. part. n. of A^arojaA^a], (S, K,) and murojK [act. part. n. of A^arojaY], (S, [in which, however, it is not clearly shown whether the author means that this corresponds to murojiY'N or that it is a rel. n. corresponding to murojiy^iY~N, the former being certainly the case,]) or not thus, but murojiY~N, (K,) so some say, (TA,) but this is a rel. n. like mrojiy^iY~N, (IB, TA,) A man who is one of [the sect called] ↓ Almurojiy^apu (S, K) and Almurojiyapu, without teshdeed to the Y (K,) accord. to J, Almurojiy~apu, with teshdeed, (IB,) but this is incorrect, unless as meaning those who are called in relation to the murojiyap, for otherwise it is not allowable. (IB, TA.) The sect called the ↓ murojiy^ap [and murojiyap] are [A sect of Muslim antinomians;] a sect of Muslims who assert that faith (AlA_iymaAn) consists in words without works; as though they postponed works to words; asserting that if they do not pray nor fast, their faith will save them: (TA:) a sect who assert that disobedience, with faith, does not injure; and that obedience, with disbelief, does not profit: (KT:) or a sect who do not pronounce judgment upon any one for aught in the present life, but defer judgment to the day of resurrection: (Msb:) those who decide not, against the committers of great sins, aught as to pardon or punishment; deferring the judgment respecting such sins to the day of resurrection. (Mgh in art. jhm.) ― -b2- murojiY'N is also applied to a she-camel, and a pregnant female [of any kind], as meaning Near to bringing forth; and so murojiy^apN. (TA.)
Almurojiy^apu * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
rajulN murojiy^iY~N * (S, IB) and murojiY~N (IB) A man called in relation to the murojiy^ap (S, IB) or murojiyap (IB.)

1 rajiba * , aor.
rajaba , (K,) inf. n. rajabN, (TA,) He (a man, TA) was frightened, or afraid, (K) minohu [at, or of, him or it]. (TK.) ― -b2- And also, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (TA;) and rajaba, aor.
rajuba , (K,) inf. n. rajobN; (TK;) He was ashamed, or bashful, or shy, (K,) minohu [with respect to him or it]. (TK.) -A2- rajibahu, (S, A, K,) aor.
rajaba , (K,) inf. n. rajabN, (A,) He feared him or it: (A:) or he revered him, venerated him, regarded him with awe, and honoured him, or magnified him; (S, K;) namely, a man; [and in like manner, it; see rajabN;] as also rajabahu, (K,) aor.
rajuba , (TA,) inf. n. rajobN and rujuwbN; and ↓ rj~bhu, (K,) inf. n. tarojiybN and tarojibapN; (TA;) and ↓ Arjbhu: (K:) or ↓ rj~bhu, (Msb,) inf. n. tarojiybN, (S,) signifies [simply] he honoured him, or magnified him. (S, * Msb.) You say, daxalotu faraH~aba ↓ biY waraj~abaniY [I entered, and he welcomed me with the greeting of maroHabFA, and treated me with honour]. (A.) And a poet says,
A^aHomadu rab~iY faraqFA waA^arojabuho
i. e. [I praise my Lord with fear,] and magnify Him. (TA.) -A3- rajaba said of a branch, or twig, It came forth singly. (K. [Perhaps from rajabN as the name of a month which is called “ Rejeb the separate. ”]) -A4- rajabahu biqawolK say~iY'K is like rajamahu bihi (K,) i. e. He reviled him with a foul, or an evil, saying. (Abu-l-'Omeythil, TA.)

2 raj~aba see 1, in three places. ― -b2- Hence, (S,) tarojiybN signifies also The sacrificing a victim, or victims, in the month of Rejeb: (S, K:) for the [pagan] Arabs used to slaughter animals as sacrifices in that month. (TA.) The days of the said sacrifice were called A^ay~aAmu tarojiybK: and the victim was called EatiyrapN (S, TA) and ↓ rajabiy~apN. (TA.) ― -b3- rjb~ Al$~ajarapa, (Msb,) inf. n. tarojiybN, (S,) He propped up the tree, because of the abundance of its fruit, lest its branches should break; (S, Msb;) sometimes by building a wall, for it to rest upon, because of its weakness: (S:) or tarojiybu naxolapK signifies the building, at the foot of a palm-tree, a structure of the kind called duk~aAn, which is termed rujobapN, for it to rest upon, (K, TA,) because of its leaning, and its being valuable to him, and being weak: (TA:) or the propping up a valuable palm-tree, when it is feared that it will fall,
because of its tallness and the abundance of its fruit, by means of a structure of stones: and also the putting thorns round a palm-tree, lest any one should climb it, and pluck its fruit: (T, TA:) or [in the CK “ and ”] the attaching the racemes of a palm-tree to its branches, binding them with palm-leaves, lest the wind should shake off the fruit: (K, TA:) or the putting thorns round the racemes of a palm-tree, lest anyone should be able to take and eat them: (K, * TA:) and hence the saying cited below, voce muraj~abN. (K.) You say [also], A^awoqarato naxoluhumo ↓ faA^arojabuwhaA, meaning [Their palm-trees became laden, or heavily laden, with fruit,] and they consequently propped them up. (A. [But the verb, here, may perhaps be mistranscribed; for the verb commonly known in this sense is not mentioned in the copy of the A from which this i ? taken.]) Selámeh Ibn-Jendel says, describing some horses,
kaA^an~a A^aEonaAqahaA A^anoSaAbu tarojiybi
meaning As though their necks were propped palm-trees: or, as some say, the stones on which the victims slain in Rejeb are sacrificed. (TA.) ― -b4- tarojiybu karomK The disposing evenly the shoots of a grape-vine, and putting it in its [appropriate] places, (K, TA,) by means of props. (TA.)
4 A^arojaba see 1: -A2- and see also 2.
8 Artjb * is said by Freytag, as on the authority of Meyd, to signify He filled with reverence; was reverend.]
rujobN * The part between the rib and the qaS~ [or sternum]. (K.) ― -b2- See also A^arojaAbN.
rijobN * : see A^arojaAbN.

rajabN *
One of the [Arabian] months; (Msb;) [namely, the seventh thereof;] so called because of the honour in which it was held in the Time of Ignorance, (S, A, * K, *) inasmuch as war, or fighting, during it was held unlawful: (S:) in a trad., (TA,) it is called rajabu muDara [Rejeb of Mudar], because Mudar most honoured it: (S, TA:) and it is further distinguished as being between jamaAdaY and $aEobaAn, to show that what is meant by it is not what the [pagan] Arabs called rjb according to the computation founded upon postponement; for they used to postpone it from month to month: (TA:) [it is also called rajabN Alfarodu Rejeb the separate; because it is the only sacred month that is not preceded nor followed by another sacred month; the other sacred months being AlmuHar~amu and *uw AlqaEodapi and *uw AlHaj~api:] the pl. is A^irojaAbN (S, Msb, K) and A^arojibapN and A^arojubN [all pls. of pauc.] (Msb) and rujuwbN and rijaAbN and rajabaAtN (Msb, K) and rajuwbN [or rather this last is a quasi-pl. n.] (TA) and [pl. pl.] A^araAjibu [pl. of A^arojubN] and A^araAjiybu [pl. of A^arojaAbN]. (Msb.) The dual, rajabaAni, (S, Msb,) or Alr~ajabaAni, (A,) [The two Rejebs] is applied to [the two months] rajabN and $aEobaAnu, (S, A, Msb,) by the attribution of predominance to the former. (Msb.) -A2- See also A^arojaAbN.

rujobapN *
A thing by means of which a tree is propped up, because of the abundance of its fruit, lest its branches should break: sometimes it is a wall built for it to rest upon, because of its weakness: (S:) a wall, or the like, built round a palm-tree, for it to rest upon, because of its heaviness or its weakness: (Mgh in art. Erw and ErY:) a kind of wide bench of stone or brick (duk~aAnN) built at the foot of a palm-tree, for it to rest upon, (K, TA,) because of its leaning, and being valuable to its owner, and being weak: (TA:) accord. to As, a structure of rock with which a palm-tree is supported by means of forked pieces of wood: (TA:) it is also called rujomapN: (K * and TA in art. rjm:) pl. rujabN. (S.) [See 2.] ― -b2- Also A structure by means of which (S, K) the wolf &c., (S,) or objects of the chase, (K,) are caught: (S, K:) a piece of flesh-meat is put in it, and tied with a small cord; and when the beast pulls it, the rjbp falls upon him. (S.) -A2- See also riAjibapN.

rajabiy~apN *
A victim, (Mgh, TA,) [i. e.] a sheep or goat, (Msb,) which the Arabs used to sacrifice, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) in the Time of Ignorance, to their gods (Msb) in Rejeb, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) the month thus called: (TA:) the doing of which is forbidden: (Msb:) it was abrogated by the ordinance of the A^aDoHaY. (Mgh.) See 2.

naxolapN rujabiy~apN *
A palm-tree having a rujobap to support it; (S, * Mgh in art. Erw and ErY, and K *;) as also ruj~abiy~apN; each an extr. rel. n., (K, TA,) and the latter the more so. (TA.)
raAjibN * One who honours his lord, chief, or master. (AA, TA.)

raAjibapN * sing. of rawaAjibu; (S, K;) or, accord. to Kr, the sing. of this latter is ↓ rujobapN [also mentioned as a sing. in the K]; but the correctness of this is doubted: (TA:) the rwAjb are The finger-joints that are next to the ends of the fingers: (S, K:) next to these are the baraAjim: then, the A^a$aAjiE, which are next to the kaf~: (S:) or the joints of the lowest parts (A^uSuwl) of the fingers: (K: [by which is meant the same as by the former explanation, accord. to the TA; though this seems to be more than doubtful:]) or the inner sides of those joints: or the bones of the fingers: (K:) or the finger-joints: (A, K:) or the backs of the sulaAmayaAt [generally meaning the phalanges of the fingers]: or the parts of the sulaAmayaAt between the baraAjim; (K;) which last word [commonly signifies the knuckles, and] is explained by IAar as signifying the wrinkled parts at the joints of the fingers; whereof each finger has three, except the thumb: or the rwAjb are the parts, of the inner sides, between the finger-joints: or [the knuckles next the metacarpal bones; i. e.] the parts that protuberate at the roots of the fingers when the hand is clinched. (TA.) [See also burojumapN, and A^a$ojaEu.] ― -b2- The raAjibap of a bird is The toe that is next to the daAbirap [or back toe], on the outer side of each foot. (Lth, TA.) ― -b3- rawaAjibu AlHimaAri The veins (Euruwq) of the passages of the voice of the ass. (IAar, K.)

A^arojaAbN * The A^amoEaA=' [i. e. bowels, or intestines, into which the food passes from the stomach]: (As, S, K:) it has no pl. (S, K) known to A'Obeyd: (S:) or its sing. is ↓ rajabN, (Kr, K,) or ↓ rujobN, (K,) or ↓ rijobN. (Ibn-Hamdaweyh.)

muraj~abN *
Honoured, or magnified: (S:) or revered, venerated, regarded with awe, and honoured, or magnified; (A;) as also ↓ marojuwbN (S.) ― -b2- The saying of Hobáb Ibn-El-Mundhir A^anaA Eu*ayoquhaA Almuraj~abu means I am their propped little palm-tree loaded with fruit; (S, * TA;) i. e. I have a family that will aid and defend me: so accord. to Yaakoob: or, as some say, I am their honoured little palm-tree &c. (TA. [See 2.]) [It is part of a prov., for which see ji*olu.]
marojuwbN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 rajaHa * , aor.
rajaHa and
rajuHa (Msb, TA) and
rajiHa , (TA,) inf. n. rujuwHN (Msb, TA) and rajaHaAnN and rujoHaAnN, (TA,) or this last is a simple subst., (Msb,) It (a thing) exceeded another thing in weight; outweighed; preponderated. (Msb, TA. *) And rajaHa AlmyzaAnu, aor.
rajaHa (S, A, Msb, K) and
rajuHa (S, Msb, K, but omitted in some copies of the S) and
rajiHa , (S, K,) inf. n. rujoHaAnN (S, A, K) and rujuwHN, (K,) [but see what is said of the former above,] The balance inclined; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. the scale, of the balance, in which was the thing weighed was heavier than the other; (Msb;) as also ↓ trj~H. (MA.) And rajaHato A_iHodaY Alkaf~atayoni EalaY AlA^uxuriY [One of the two scales outweighed the other]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rajaHa A^aHadu qawolayohi EalaY AlA=xari (tropical:) [One of his two sayings outweighed the other; surpassed, excelled, was preferable to, or of more force or validity than, the other]. (A.) ― -b3- And rajaHa Al$~aYo'u The thing was, or became, heavy. (TA in art. rjHn [q. v.].) ― -b4- [Hence,] rajaHa fiY majolisihi (tropical:) He was, or became, heavy, [i. e. dull, torpid, or drowsy,] not light, [i. e. not lively or sprightly,] in his sitting-place. (TA.) -A2- It is also used transitively: one says, rajaHotuhu [I outweighed him]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rajaHahu (assumed tropical:) He surpassed him in gravity, staidness, sedateness, and forbearance, or clemency; was, or became, more grave, staid, sedate, and forbearing, or clement, (A^arozan, S, K, TA, and A^aHolam, TA,) than he. (S, K, TA.) So in the saying, naAwaA^onaA qawomFA farajaHonaAhumo (assumed tropical:) [We vied with a people, or party, and surpassed them in gravity, &c.]. (TA.) And farajaHotuhu ↓ raAjaHotuhu (assumed tropical:) [I vied with him in gravity, &c., and surpassed him therein]. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- You say also, rajaHa Al$~aYo'a biyadihi He weighed the thing with his hand, trying what was its weight: (TA:) or so rajaHahu alone. (A.)

2 rj~H h`*aA EalaY *aAka *
He made this to outweigh that. (MA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rj~H Al$~aYo'a (assumed tropical:) He
held, or pronounced, [and it made,] the thing [to outweigh, as meaning] to be more, or most, excel-lent or preferable, and of more, or most, force or validity. (Msb.) ― -b3- See also 4. -A2- And see 5.
3 raAjaHotuhu farajaHotuhu * : see 1.

4 ArjH AlmiyzaAna *
He made the balance to incline, the scale in which was the thing weighed being heavier than the other. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And ArjHhu, (Msb.) or ArjH lahu, (S, A, * K,) He gave him preponderating weight; (S, A, * Msb, K;) as also lh ↓ rj~H, (S, A, * K,) inf. n. tarojiyHN. (S.) One says, A_i*aA wazanota faA^arojiHo [When thou weighest, give preponderating weight]. (A.)

5 trj~H * : see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- Also i. q. ta*abo*aba [It moved to and fro; dangled; was, or became, in a state of motion or commotion; said of a thing hanging in the air, &c.; and so ↓ ArtjH]. (K.) You say, ↓ trj~Ht AlA^urojuwHapu The seesaw inclined, [or moved up and down,] (S, K,) bihi (K,) i. e., (TA,) biAlgulaAmi [with the boy], (S, TA,) or biAlgulaAmayoni [with the two boys]. (A. [There mentioned as tropical; but why, I see not.]) And ↓ ArtjH He (a boy, TA) inclined, [or moved up and down,] upon a seesaw, (K, TA,) and [moved to and fro] upon a rope, or swing. (TA.) And rawaAdafuhaA ↓ ArtjHt Her posteriors moved to and fro: (K:) and EalayohaA ↓ rawaAdifuhaA tarotajiHu Her posteriors move to and fro upon her; said of a girl whose posteriors are heavy. (Az, TA.) And AlA_ibilu ↓ ArtjHt and trj~Ht The camels had a quivering [or vacillating] motion in going along with short steps. (K.) And falawaAtN kaA^an~ahaA tataraj~aHu bimano saArafiyhaA (assumed tropical:) [Deserts, or waterless deserts, seeming] as though they bandied him who journeyed therein to the right and left. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] trj~H bayona $ayoy^ayoni (assumed tropical:) He wavered, or vacillated, between two things; (A in art. rnH, and TA;) [and so ↓ rj~H, for] Alt~arojiyHu bayona $ayoy^ayoni is like Alt~amoyiylu bayonhumaA. (TA in art. myl.) And trj~H fiY Alqawoli i. q. tamay~ala bihi (tropical:) [app. meaning He inclined, in the saying, now this way and now that]. (A, TA.)
8 A_irotajaHa see the next preceding paragraph, in five places.
10 AstrjH Aln~iEomapa * (assumed tropical:) He held the benefit, or favour, &c., to be a thing of weight, or importance; contr. of Aisotaxaf~ahaA. (A in art. bTr.)
rujoHaAnN * an inf. n. of 1: (S, A, K, TA:) or a simple subst., signifying Excess in weight; preponderance. (Msb.)

rajaAHN * (S, A, K) and ↓ raAjaHN, (K,) applied to a woman, (S, A, K,) (tropical:) Heavy in the posteriors; (TA;) large therein: (S, K:) pl. [of the former accord. to rule, and perhaps of the latter also,] rujuHN, (S, K,) [and of the latter accord. to rule, and perhaps of the former also, ruj~aHN, and of the latter also rawaAjiHu, for] you say nisaA='N rawaAjiHu AlA^akofaAli and ruj~aHuhaA (tropical:) [women heavy, or large, in the posteriors]. (A.) ― -b2- kataAy^ibu rujuHN, (K,) or ruj~aHN, (A,) (tropical:) Armies, or troops, marching heavily by reason of numbers, or dragging along the apparatus of war, heavily laden. (K.) ― -b3- jifaAnN rujuHN, (K,) or ruj~aHN, (A,) (tropical:) [Large bowls] filled with variyd [or crumbled bread moistened with broth] and with flesh-meat: (K:) or correctly, as in the T, filled with fresh butter and flesh-meat. (TA.) ― -b4- qawomN ruj~aHN and rujoHN, [the latter, thus in the TA, perhaps a pl. of raAjiHN, like as buzolN is of baAzilN, but more probably, I think, a mistranscription for rujuHN,] (tropical:) A people, or party, forbearing, or clement; or grave, sedate, or calm; (TA;) as also ↓ maraAjiyHu (K, TA) and ↓ maraAjiHu; of which latter two pls., the sings. are ↓ mirojaAHN and ↓ mirojaHN; or, accord. to some, these pls. have no proper sings.: HilomN [“ forbearance ” &c.] is described by the term viqalN, like as its contr. [safahN] is described by the terms xif~apN and Eajalu. (TA.) You say also fiY AlHilomi ↓ qawomN maraAjiyHu (S) or maraAjiyHu AlHilomi (A) (tropical:) [A people, or party, grave in forbearance or clemency, or of much gravity, or sedateness, or calmness, so as not to be excited to lightness of deportment: see HilomN raAjaHN, below.]

rajaAHapN * (tropical:) Forbearance, or clemency; or gravity, sedateness, or calmness. (TA.) One says, fiY Eaqolihi rajaAHapN wafiY xuluqihi sajaAHapN (tropical:) [In his intellect is gravity, and in his natural disposition is gentleness]. (A.)
rujaAHapN * : see what next follows.

ruj~aAHapN * (K) and ↓ rujaAHapN, (TA, as from the K, but omitted in some copies of the latter,) the latter word without teshdeed, mentioned by IDrst., (TA,) A swing of rope; a rope suspended, (K, TA,) in, or upon, which one goes to and fro; (TA;) it is ridden by a boy: (K:) thought by MF to be what is called A^urojuwHapN; he holding this last also to mean the rope [above mentioned]; but no other says this except IDrst. (TA.)

raAjiHN *
Outweighing, or preponderating; or heavy; or of full weight; syn. waAzinN. (TA.) You say, A^aEoTaAhu rajiHFA [He gave him preponderating, or full, weight]. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also rajaAHN. ― -b3- [(assumed tropical:) Outweighing, preponderating, or preponderant, as meaning surpassing, excelling, or preferable, or of more force or validity; applied to a saying and the like: of frequent occurrence in this sense.] ― -b4- One says also, HilomN raAjiHN, meaning (assumed tropical:) Forbearance, or clemency, or gravity, sedateness, or calmness, that weighs down the person in whom it exists so that nothing renders him light [in deportment]. (TA.) And rajulN raAjaHu AlEaqoli (tropical:) [A man grave in respect of intellect]. (A.)

A^urojuwHapN * (S, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ marojuwHapN, both signify the same, (Msb, K, TA,) but the latter is disapproved by the author of the “ Bári'; ” (Msb, TA;) A seesaw; i. e. a piece of wood [or a plank] the middle of which is placed upon a heap of earth or the like, then a boy sits upon one end of it and another boy upon its other end, (Msb, TA,) and it moves up and down with them: thus explained in the 'Eyn and its Abridgment, and in the Jámi' of Kz, and thus Th says on the authority of IAar: (TA:) [accord. to the CK and some MS. copies of the K, these two words signify the same as ruj~aAHapN; but accord. to other copies of the K, and the TA, the meaning of this last word is different from that of the two preceding words: see also zuHoluwqapN:] the pl. of the first is A^araAjiyHu (Msb) [and that of the second, accord. to rule, maraAjiyHu]. See 5.

A^araAjiyHu * pl. of A^urojuwHapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) Deserts, or waterless deserts: (A, K:) as though they bandied the travellers therein to the right and left. (TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The quivering [or vacillating] motions of camels: (A, TA:) or the quivering [or vacillating] motion of camels in going along with short steps: (K, TA:) Abu-l- Hasan understands not how a pl. word can be thus explained by a sing. word: (TA: [but an inf. n., such as is here used, is often used in explanation of a sing. and of a dual and of a pl.])
mirojaHN * : see rajaAHN.

mirojaAHN * : see rajaAHN. ― -b2- Also sing. of maraAjiyHu, (TA,) which signifies (tropical:) Camels having a quivering [or vacillating] motion in going along with short steps: (K:) the sing. is applied to the female, without p, and to the male. (TA.)

[
marojuwHN *
Outweighed, or preponderated, in the proper sense: ― -b2- and also as meaning (assumed tropical:) surpassed, or excelled, and particularly in force, or validity; applied to a saying and the like: of frequent occurrence in this tropical sense.]
marojuwHapN * : see A^urojuwHapN.
maraAjiHu * : see rajaAHN.

maraAjiyHu * (tropical:) Palm-trees heavily laden with fruit: (A, K:) [because they are moved to and fro by the wind.] ― -b2- [Also pl. of marojuwHapN.] ― -b3- And pl. of mirojaAHN, expl. above. (TA.) See also rajaAHN, in two places.

Q. 4 AirojaHan~a *
It (a thing, S) inclined, bent, or declined. (S, K.) Hence the prov.,
A_i*aA A@rojaHan~a $aASiyFA faA@rofaEo yadFA
(S, Meyd,) or A@rojaEan~a, or A@joraEan~a, accord. to different readings, the last being formed by transposition from the second, (Meyd,) i. e. When he (a man, Meyd) inclines, (S, Meyd,) or falls, (Meyd,) raising his legs, then hold thou back [thine arm, or thy hand,] from him; meaning, when he becomes lowly, humble, or submissive, to thee, hold thou back from him: (S, Meyd:) or it is said to a man fighting with another, and means when thou overcomest him, and he lies on his side, and
falls, and raises his legs, then hold thou back thine arm, or thy hand, from him: (TA in art. rjEn, in explanation of the second reading:) [or when he is prostrated, and stretched upon the ground: for,] accord. to As, ArjHn~ and ArjEn~ signify he was prostrated, and stretched upon the ground. (TA in art. rjEn.) And you say, ArjHn~ Als~aHaAbu baEoda tabas~uqK The clouds became heavy, and inclined [downwards], after being high. (TA.) ― -b2- Also It (a thing, S) fell at once. (S, K.) ― -b3- And It (a thing, S) shook; quivered; or was, or became, in a state of commotion. (S, K.) ― -b4- And ArjHn~ Als~araAbu i. q. AirotafaEa [i. e. The mirage became upraised, withdrawn, or removed]. (K.)

murojaHin~N * [part. n. of the verb above]. You say, A^anaA fiY h`*aA AlA^amori murojaHin~N I am wavering, or vacillating, and inclining, in this affair. (TA.) And AimoraA^apN murojaHin~apN A fat woman, who, when she walks, bends in her gait. (TA.) And jayo$N murojaHin~u A heavy army. (S, K.) And rHFY murojaHin~apN A heavy round cloud. (S, * K, * and A in art. rjH. [In the S and K, only the latter word is explained; though the meaning of the former (i. e. saHaAbapN musotadiyrapN, as in the A,) is plainly indicated in the S by a verse there cited.]) And fulaAnN fiY dunoyaA murojaHin~apK Such a one is in an ample, abundant, state of worldly prosperity. (TA.) And layolN murojaHin~N Heavy, wide-spreading, night. (TA.) The author of the K follows ISd and J and Az in regarding the n in this case as radical: but IAth says that some hold it to be augmentative; and the derivation to be from rajaHa Al$~aYo'u, meaning “ the thing was, or became, heavy. ” (TA.)

1 rajiza * , [aor.
rajaza ,] (S,) inf. n. rajazN, (TA,) He (a camel) had the disease termed rajazN [expl. below]. (S.) -A2- rajaza, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
rajuza , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. rajozN, (TA,) He said, spoke, uttered, or recited, poetry, or verse, of the metre termed rajazN; [see this word below;] he spoke in verse of that metre; he poetized, or versified, in that metre; as also ↓ Artjz; (S, * Msb, K, * TA;) and in like manner ↓ Arjz, he composed verses of that metre. (Ibn-Buzurj, L in art. qSd.) You say also, rajazabihi He recited to him (A^ano$adahu [so in more than one MS. copy of the K, and in the TA, but in the CK A^ano$ada, without the affixed pronoun, which is probably wrong,]) a poem of that metre; as also ↓ rj~zhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. tarojiyzN. (TA.) And ↓ trj~z He urged, or excited, his camels by singing rajaz, or his rajaz: so accord. to different copies of the K. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rajazati Alr~iyHu, inf. n. rajozN, (assumed tropical:) The wind was continuous, or lasting. (TA.) And Alr~aEodu ↓ Artjz (tropical:) The thunder made uninterrupted sounds, like the recitation of the raAjiz: (A, TA:) or, as also ↓ trj~z, made a sound: (K:) or made consecutive sounds. (TA.) And baA=*iy~ihi ↓ AlbaHoru yarotajizu (tropical:) [The sea makes a continuous sound, or murmuring, with its waves]; as also ↓ yataraj~azu. (A, TA.) [And hence, perhaps,] ↓ trj~z Als~aHaAbu (tropical:) The clouds moved slowly by reason of the abundance of their water. (K, TA.) [See also 6.]
2 rj~zhu * : see 1.
3 rAjz SaAHibahu * [He recited verses, or poetry, of the metre termed rajaz with his companion: or vied with him in doing so: see 6]. (A.)
4 A^arojaza see 1.
5 taraj~aza see 1, in four places.

6 trAjzwA *
i. q. tanaAzaEuwA Alr~ajaza bayonahumo, (A, K,) and taEaATawohu, (TA,) i. e. They recited verses, or poetry, of the metre termed rajaz, one with another: (TK:) [or vied, one with another, in doing so.] ― -b2- [Hence,] trAjz Als~aHaAbu (tropical:) [The clouds combined, one with another, in uninterrupted thundering]. (A.) [See also 1.]
8 A_irotajaza see 1, in three places.
rujozN * : see the next paragraph, in four places.

rijozN * properly signifies Commotion, agitation, or convulsion; and consecutiveness of motions. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) Punishment (Aboo-Is-hák, S, Mgh, Msb, K) [like rijosN] that agitates by its vehemence, and occasions vehement consecutive commotions; (Aboo-Is-hák, Mgh, * TA;) as also ↓ rujozN: (K:) so in the Kur vii. 131; (Aboo-Is-hák;) and in ii. 56, and vii. 162, and xxix. 33. (S.) ― -b3- Conduct that leads to punishment: so, accord. to some, in the Kur lxxiv. 5; (TA;) where some read Alr~ijoza and others ↓ Alr~ujoza: (S, TA:) ↓ the latter is also expl. as signifying sin: (TA:) and both, uncleanness; or filth: (S, K:) so in that instance: like rijosN: (S:) and polytheism; or the associating of another, or others, with the true God: (K, TA:) so, accord to some, in that instance: because he who worships what is not God is in doubt respecting his case, and unsettled in his belief: (TA:) and the worship of idols: (K:) so, accord. to some, in the same instance: (TA:) or the meaning there is and idol: (Mujáhid, S:) or ↓ the latter word signifies a certain idol; being the name thereof: (Katádeh, TA:) and the devil: and his suggestions. (TA.) ― -b4- Also Plague, or pestilence; syn. TaAEuwnN. (Mgh.)

rajazN *
A certain disease which attacks camels, in the rump; (S, K;) so that when a she-camel rises, or is roused, her thighs tremble for a while, and then stretch out: (S:) or it is when there is a convulsive motion in the hind leg or the thighs of a camel, when he desires to stand up, or rises, or is roused, for a while, and then a stretching out of the same. (TA.) -A2- Hence, (S,) Alr~ajazu is the name of A certain species [or kind] of verse or poetry; (S, A, K;) a species [or kind] of the metres of verse; (Msb;) consisting of the measure musotafoEiluno [primarily] six times: (K:) a metre easy to the ear and impressive to the mind; wherefore it may be reduced to a single hemistich, and also to two feet instead of six: (TA:) so called because it commences with a motion and a quiescence, [i. e., a movent and a quiescent letter,] followed by a motion and a quiescence; and so in the other feet; resembling the rajaz in a she-camel, which consists in her quivering and then being quiet: (TA:) or because of the contractedness of its feet, and the fewness of its letters: (S, K:) or because it is [characterized by] Suduwr without A^aEojaAz [lit. breasts without rumps; for, as the two hemistichs generally rhyme with each other, the verse seems as though it had no Eajuz; i. e., as though its last foot should rather be called EaruwDN, like the last of the first hemistich, than EajuzN:] (TA:) Akh once said, rajazN, with the Arabs, is whatever consists of three feet; and it is that [kind of verse] which they sing in their work, and in driving their camels: [see bi*olapN, last sentence:] ISd says that certain of those in whom he placed confidence related this on the authority of Kh. (TA.) Some say that it is not verse, or poetry, but a kind of rhyming prose; but Kh held it to be true verse, or poetry: so in the M: but in the T it is said [as in the K] that Kh asserted it to be not poetry, but halves or thirds of verses: one of his reasons for this assertion [the only one that seems to have had much weight with the Muslims] is, that Mo- hammad once said,
A^anaA A@bonu Eabodi AlmuT~alibo
A^anaA Aln~abiY~u laA ka*ibo
[which is an instance of a species of rajaz, meaning, “ I am the Prophet: it is no lie: I am the son of 'Abd-el-Muttalib ”]: and were this verse, he would not have said it, as is shown by what is said in the Kur., xxxvi. 69: but on this point, Akh has contended against him. (TA.)

rijaAzapN *
A certain vehicle for women, (S, * TA,) a thing smaller than the hawodaj: (S, K, TA:) pl. rajaAy^izu: (TA:) or a [garment of the kind called] kisaA=', (S, K, TA,) in which is a stone, (K, TA, [in the CK a while stone,]) or in which are put stones, (S,) and which is suspended to one of the two sides of the hwdj, to balance it, when it inclines: (S, TA:) so called because of its commotion: (TA:) or a thing consisting of a pillow and skins, or hides, put in one of its two sides for that purpose, and called rijaAzapu Almayoli: (T, TA:) or hair, (K,) or red hair, (TA,) or wool, suspended to the hwrj, (K, TA,) for ornament: pl. rajaAy^izu, said to occur in a verse of EshShemmákh: but accord. to As, this is a mistake for jazaAy^izu [pl. of jaziyzapN, q. v.]. (TA.)
raj~aAzN * and raj~aAzapN: see raAjizN; the latter, in two places.

raAjizN * One who utters, or recites, poetry, or verse, of the metre termed rajazN; who speaks in verse of that metre; who poetizes, or versifies, in that metre: and in like manner, ↓ murotajizN, and ↓ raj~aAzN [which signifies one who does so much], and ↓ raj~aAzapN [one who does so very much]. (TA.) El-'Ajjáj has been placed the highest in rank as a rAjz. (Mz, 49th nwE.) [His son, Ru-beh, seems
to occupy nearly an equal place. Each of them composed a complete deewán of rajaz.] ― -b2- [Hence,] ↓ saHaAbapN raj~aAzapN (tropical:) [A cloud thundering much, or uninterruptedly]. (A, TA.) And ↓ gayovN murotajizN, and ↓ mutaraj~izN, (tropical:) Rain accompanied by thunder. (TA.)

A^arojazu * A camel having the disease termed rajazN: fem. rajozaA='u: (S, K:) the latter is explained as signifying weak in the rump, that does not move from her place unless after twice or thrice rising from the place where she lay: and that does not rise, when she desires to do so, unless after vehement trembling. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A_in~ahaA larajozaA='u, said of the wind (Alr~iyH), (assumed tropical:) Verily it is continuous, or lasting. (TA.) And rajozaA='u AlqiyaAmi (tropical:) A great, heavy cooking-pot. (TA.)

A^urojuwzapN *
A poem of the metre termed rajazN: (Msb, K:) pl. A^araAjiyzu. (A, K.)
murotajizN * : see raAjizN; the former, in two places.
mutaraj~izN * : see raAjizN; the former, in two places.

1 rajasati Als~amaA='u * , (S, A, K,) aor.
rajusa , (S,) inf. n. rajosN, (S, A,) The sky thundered vehemently, (S, A, K,) and became in a state of commotion (S, K) preparatory to rain; (TA;) as also ↓ Artjst. (S, A, K, * TA.) ― -b2- rajasa AlbaEiyru, (K,) inf. n. as above, (A, TA,) The camel brayed: (K:) or made a vehement noise in braying. (A, * TA.) ― -b3- And rajasa, inf. n. as above and rajosapN and rajasaAnN, It (a confused and great thing, such as an army, and a torrent, and thunder,) made a sound or noise; as also ↓ Artjs. (TA: [but in this sense, only the inf. ns. are mentioned, and rajosapN is probably an inf. n. of un.]) -A2- rajasa, (K,) inf. n. rajosN, (TA,) He measured [the depth of] the water of a well with the mirojaAs; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ Arjs, (K,) inf. n. A_irojaAsN. (TA.) -A3- rajasahu Eini AlA^amori, aor. u and
rajisa , (O, K,) inf. n. rajosN, (O, TA,) He hindered, withheld, or prevented, him from doing the thing. (O, K.) -A4- rajisa, aor.
rajasa , inf. n. rajasN; (Msb;) and rajusa, aor.
rajusa , inf. n. rajaAsapN; (A, Msb, TA;) It (a thing) was, or became, unclean, dirty, or filthy: (A, Msb, TA:) or stinking: or disliked, or hated, for its uncleanness, dirtiness, or filthiness. (Msb.) ― -b2- And both these verbs, (K,) inf. n. of the former, (TA,) and of the latter, (K,) as above, (K, TA,) He did a bad, an evil, an abominable, or a foul, action. (K, TA.)
4 A^arojasa see 1.
8 Artjs * : see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also It (a building) became in a state of commotion, (K, TA,) so as to make a sound, or noise. (TA.)

rijosN *
Uncleanness, dirt, or filth: or an unclean, a dirty, or a filthy, thing: syn. qa*arN: (S, A, Msb, K, TA: [in the CK, Alqadaru is put by mistake for Alqa*arN:]) or $aYo'N qa*irN: (TA:) anything that is disliked, or hated, for its uncleanness, dirtiness, or filthiness: stink, or foul odour: accord. to Az, filth that comes forth from the body of a man: En-Nakkásh says that it is syn. with nijosN; and it is said in the Bári' that sometimes they say Alr~ajaAsapu waAln~ajaAsapu, meaning that they make these two words syn.: (Msb:) it is also written ↓ rajisN and ↓ rajasN: (A, K:) you say rijosN nijosN, and rajisN najisN; and IDrd says, I think that they also said rajasN najasN: Pr says that when rjs is followed by njs, the j is with kesr; but when njs is mentioned without rjs, the j and n are with fet-h. (TA.) You say also $aYo'N rijosN [An unclean, a dirty, or a filthy, thing]. (A.) And ↓ mar~abinaA jamaAEapN rajisuwna najisuwna, meaning, A company of unbelievers passed by us. (IAar and TA.) As used in the Kur vi. 125, Mujáhid explains Alr~ijos as meaning That in which is no good. (TA.) ― -b2- Any action that is disliked, or hated, for its uncleanness, dirtiness, or filthiness: (Zj, A, K:) a sin, or crime: (Ibn-El-Kelbee, A, K:) so in the Kur v. 92, and vi. 146: (Ibn-El-Kelbee:) an action that leads to punishment: (T, A, K:) as rajosN signifies “ vehemence of sound, ” [see 1,] rijosN seems to mean an action the mention whereof is evil, and highly evil: (TA:) sometimes it signifies a thing that is unlawful, or forbidden: and unbelief: infidelity: (L:) and doubt: (Aboo-Jaafar, A, K:) so in the Kur xxxiii. 33. (Aboo-Jaafar.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Punishment; (Fr, T, S, A, K;) a sense which Z makes tropical, as being the recompense of rijos [in the sense of “ sin ”], (TA;) and anger: (Fr, S, A, K:) so in the Kur x. 100: like rijozN, which is perhaps formed from it by the change of s into z: (Fr, S:) and sometimes, malediction, or execration. (L.) -A2- A light, or slight, motion. (TA.) -A3- Suggestion of the devil. (TA.)
rajasN * : see rijosN; the latter, in two places.
rajisN * : see rijosN; the latter, in two places.
rajuwsN * : see raAjisN; the latter, in three places.
raj~aAsN * : see raAjisN; the latter, in three places.

raAjisN * and ↓ murotajisN (A, K) and ↓ raj~aAsN (S, A, K) A cloud making a loud, or vehement, sound; (S, A, K, TA;) and so thunder. (TA.) You say, [of a cloud,] h`*aA raAjisN HasanN This is a goodly thunderer. (S.) And Eafati Ald~iyaAra AlgamaAy^imu Alr~awaAjisu waAlr~iyaAHu Alr~awaAmisu [The loudthundering clouds and the dust-spreading winds effaced the traces of the dwellings]. (A.) ― -b2- [And in like manner,] ↓ raj~aAsN (S, K) and ↓ rajuwsN and ↓ mirojasN (K) A camel that brays vehemently. (S, K, * TA.) You say also AlHaniyni ↓ naAqapN rajosaA='u, [fem. of ↓ A^arojasu,] A she-camel that utters the [yearning cry termed] Haniyn consecutively, or continuously. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence,] ↓ Alraj~aAsu The sea: (K:) because of the sound of its waves; or because of its commotion. (TA.) -A2- raAjisN also signifies The thrower of the mirojaAs; (K;) and so ↓ murojisN. (TA.)
A^arojasu * ; and its fem. rajosaA='u: see raAjisN.
murojisN * : see raAjisN, last sentence.
mirojasN * : see raAjisN.

mirojaAsN *
A stone which is tied to the end of a rope, and which is then let down into a well, and stirs up its black mud, after which the water is drawn forth, and thus the well is cleansed: (S, K: *) or a stone which is thrown into a well in order that one may know, by the sound thereof, its depth; or that one may know whether there be in it water or not: (IAar, K:) or, accord. to ISd, the name by which this is known is mirodaAsN. (TA.)

A_in~ahu larijosN marojuwsN * and rjl marojuwsN [are phrases mentioned, but not explained, in the TA: but I think that rjl is a mistranscription for rijozN; and that mrjws, in each case, is a corroborative].
humo fiY marojuwsapK * , (S, A, K,) and ↓ fY marojuwsaA='a, (TA,) They are in a state of confusion (S, A, K) and perturbation, (A,) mino A^amorihimo in respect of their affair, or case. (S, TA.)
marojuwsaA='u * : see what next precedes.
murotajisN * : see raAjisN.

narojisN * (S, Msb, K) and nirojisN (AA, Sgh, Msb, K) [The narcissus;] a certain sweet-smelling flower, (Msb, * TA,) well known: (Msb, K:) the smell of which is beneficial for the cold rheum and the cold headache: (K:) the word is arabicized, (S, Msb, TA,) from [the Persian] naroGiso: (TA:) [this being the case, the n should be regarded as radical it is said, however, that] the n in narojisN is augmentative, because there is no word of the measure faEolilN, but there is of the measure nafoEilN, (S,) though only what is changed, in application, from a verb: (Msb:) but nirojisN is of the measure fiEolilu; (TA;) or it is of the measure nifoEilN, the augmentative letter being made to accord in its vowel with the radical letter in A_i*oxirN and that in A_ivomidN &c.: (Msb:) or, accord. to IDrd, narojisN is of the measure faEolilN, and the only instance of that measure. (TA in art. nrjs.) If you name a man narojis, you make it imperfectly decl., because it is like naDoribu: (S:) but if you name him nirojis, it is perfectly decl., because it is of the measure fiEolilN (TA) [or nifoEilN, neither of which is the measure of a verb]. ― -b2- narojisu AlmaAy^idapi: see zumaAwarodN.

1 rajaEa * , aor.
rajiEa , inf. n. rujuwEN (S, Msb, K, &c.) and rajoEN, (M, Msb,) but the former is that which commonly obtains and is agreeable with analogy as inf. n. of the intrans. v., and the latter as inf. n. of the trans. v., (MF, TA,) and marojaEN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) which is anomalous, because inf. ns. [of this kind] of verbs of the measure faEala having the
aor. of the measure yafoEilu are [by rule] only with fet-h [to the medial radical], (S, K,) and marojiEapN, which is in like manner anomalous, (K,) and rujoEaY, (S, Msb, K,) [not rujoEFY as in the Lexicons of Golius and Freytag,] and rujoEaAnN, (K,) He returned; he went, or came, back [to the same place, or person, or (assumed tropical:) state, or (assumed tropical:) occupation, or (assumed tropical:) action, or (assumed tropical:) saying, &c.]; he reverted; contr. of *ahaba; (ISk, Msb;) i. q. AnoSarafa: (K:) rujuwEN signifies the returning to a former place, or (assumed tropical:) quality, or (assumed tropical:) state; (Kull p. 196;) the returning to that from which was the commencement, or from which the commencement is supposed to have been, whether it be a place, or (assumed tropical:) an action, or (assumed tropical:) a saying, and whether the returning be by the [whole] person or thing, or by a part thereof, or by an action thereof. (Er-Rághib.) Hence the saying in the Kur [lxiii. 8], lay^ino rajaEonaA A_ilaY Almadiynapi [Verily if we return to the city]. (Er-Rághib.) And [in the same, xii. 63,] falam~aA rajaEuwA A_ilaY A^abiyhimo [And when they returned to their father]. (Idem.) And in the same, [vi. 164, and xxxix. 9,] vum~a A_ilaY rab~ikumo marojiEukumo [Then unto your Lord shall be your return]: (S:) the like of which occurs in the same, vi. 60: but it may be either from [the intrans. inf. n.] rujuwEN or from [the trans.] rajoEN: (Er-Rághib:) it cannot be a n. of place, because it is made trans. by means of A_ilaY, and also because it occurs in the Kur [v. 53, &c.], followed by jamiyEFA, as a denotative of state: (L:) in like manner Alr~ujoEaY also occurs in the Kur xcvi. 8. (TA.) You say also, rajaEati AlmaroA^apu A_ilaY A^aholihaA The woman returned to her family by reason of the death of her husband or by reason of divorcement. (Msb.) ― -b2- rajaEa A_ilaY AlS~iH~api (assumed tropical:) [He returned to soundness, or health], or AlmaraDi [disease, or sickness]; and A_ilaY HaAlapi Alfaqori (assumed tropical:) [to the state of poverty], or AlginaY (assumed tropical:) [wealth, or competence, or sufficiency]. (Kull p. 196.) ― -b3- rajaEa Eawodahu EalaY badoy^ihi He returned in the way by which he had come. (Kull ibid.) ― -b4- rajaEa mino safarihi He returned from his journey. (Msb.) ― -b5- rajaEa Eani AlA^imori (assumed tropical:) He returned [or reverted] from the affair. (Msb.) ― -b6- rajaEa Eani Al$~aYo'i (assumed tropical:) He left, or relinquished, the thing. (Kull p. 197.) ― -b7- rajaEa Eani Al*~anobi (assumed tropical:) [He relinquished sin; i. e.] he repented; and so rajaEa alone, agreeably with the usage in the Kur iii. 65, &c. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b8- [Several other phrases, in which this verb occurs, will be found in other arts.: as rajaEa EalaY Zahorihi in art. Zhr: rajaEotu AlqahoqaraY in art. qhqr: rajaEa darajahu, and variations thereof, in art. drj: &c.] ― -b9- rajaEa A_ilayohi [sometimes signifies the same as rajaEa Ealayohi] He returned against him; he returned to attack him. (TA.) ― -b10- Saram~niY vum~a rajaEa yakal~imuniY (tropical:) [He cut me, or ceased to speak to me; then he returned to speaking to me]. (TA.) ― -b11- xaAlafaniY vum~a rajaEa A_ilaY qawoliY (tropical:) [He opposed me, or disagreed with me; then he returned, or had regard, to my saying]. (TA.) ― -b12- maA rujiEa A_ilayohi fiY xaTobK A_il~aA kafaY (tropical:) [Re course was not had to him in an affair, or an affliction, but he sufficed.] (TA.) [rajaEa A_ilayohi often means He had recourse, or he recurred, to him, or it.] ― -b13- rajaEa bihi EalaY $ariykihi (assumed tropical:) He made a claim for restitution of it upon his co-partner. (IAth, TA in art. xlT.) And [in like manner you say,] EalaY Algariymi ↓ AirotajaEa, and Almut~ahami, (assumed tropical:) He sued, prosecuted, or made a demand upon, the debtor, and the suspected, for his right, or due. (TA: [in which it is said, immediately before this, that ArtjE is like rajaEa.]) ― -b14- rajaEa Alkalobu fiY qayoy^ihi The dog returned to his vomit, (Msb, TA,) and ate it. (Msb.) ― -b15- Hence, rajaEa fiY hibatihi (tropical:) He took back his gift; repossessed himself of it; restored it to his possession; (Msb;) as also ↓ ArtjEhA, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) and ↓ AstrjEhA.
