(Msb, TA.) And minohu Al$~aYo' ↓ AstrjE (assumed tropical:) He took back from him the thing which he had given to him. (S, K.) ― -b16- [Hence also, rajaEa fiY qawolihi, and fiY Hukomihi (assumed tropical:) He retracted, or revoked, his saying, and his judgment, or sentence.] ― -b17- huwa yarojiEu A_ilaY manoSibi SidoqK (assumed tropical:) He traces back his lineage to an excellent origin. (TA in art. nSb.) ― -b18- [yarojiEu A_ilaY maEonaY ka*aA (assumed tropical:) It (a word used in a certain sense) is referrible, or reducible, to such a meaning. And yurojiEu A_ilaY ka*aA, said of a word, also means (assumed tropical:) It relates to such a thing; i. e., to such another word, in grammatical construction.] ― -b19- rajaEa A_ilaY qadori ka*aA (assumed tropical:) It (wine when cooked) became reduced to such a quantity; syn. A=la. (S in art. Awl.) ― -b20- rajaEa AlHawoDu A_ilaY A_izaAy^ihi The water of the trough, or tank, became much in quantity [so that it returned to the height of the place whence it poured in]. (TA.) ― -b21- ↓ rijaAEN, also, is an inf. n. of this verb, (L,) and is used as signifying The returning of birds after their migrating to a hot country. (S, L, K.) You say, rajaEati AlT~ayoru AlqawaATiEu, inf. n. rijaAEN and rajoEN, The migratory birds returned. (L.) ― -b22- Also inf. n. of rajaEato said of a-she camel, and of a she-ass, signifying (assumed tropical:) She raised her tail, and compressed her two sides (quTorayohaA), and cast forth her urine in repeated discharges, so that she was imagined to be pregnant, (S, K,) and then failed of fulfilling her [apparent] promise: (S: [in some copies of which, as is said in the TA, the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is written rujuwE:]) or she conceived, and then failed of fulfilling her promise; because she who does so goes back from what is hoped of her: (TA:) or, said of a she-camel, she cast forth her fœtus in an imperfect state: (AZ, TA,) or, as some say, her embryo in a fluid state: (TA:) or in an unformed state; inf. n. rijaAEN. (Msb in art. xdj.) [See also raAjiEN, below.] -A2- , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. rajaEahu, (Mgh,) inf. n. rajoEN and marojaEN and marojiEN, (K,) He made, or caused, him, or it, to return, go back, come back, or revert; sent back, turned back, or returned, him, or it; syn. rad~ahu; (Mgh, Msb, K;) and Sarafahu; (K;) Eani Al$~aYo'i from the thing; and A_ilayohi to it; (Msb, K;) as also ↓ ArjEhu; (S, Msb, K;) but the former is the more chaste word, and is that which is used in the Kur-án, in ix. 84 [and other places]: (Msb:) the latter is of the dial. of Hudheyl; (S, Msb;) and is said by MF to be of weak authority, and bad; but [SM says,] I do not find this asserted by any of the leading authorities: (TA:) ↓ ArtjEhu, also, signifies [the same, i. e.] the same as rad~ahu in like manner followed by A_ilaY. (TA.) Thus in the Kur ix. 84, referred to above, faA_ino rajaEaka A@ll~`hu [And if God make thee to return, or restore thee]. (Msb.) ― -b2- rajaEa fulaAnN EaliY A^anofi baEiyirhi Such a one put back, or restored, the nose-rein [AlxiTaAma being understood] upon the nose of his camel; it having become displaced. (TA.) ― -b3- rajaEa A_ilaY~a AljawaAba, aor.
rajiEa , inf. n. rajoEN and rujoEaAnN, He returned to me the answer. (S, TA: [in the latter of which, this is said to be tropical; but when a written answer is meant, it is evidently not so.]) ― -b4- rajaEotu AlkalaAma (assumed tropical:) I returned the speech; or I repeated it; or I rebutted, or rejected, or repudiated, it, in reply, or replication; syn. radadotuhu. (Msb.) [In like manner,] yarojiEu baEoDuhumo A_ilaY baEoDK Alqawola, in the Kur [xxxiv. 30], means (assumed tropical:) Holding a colloquy, or a disputation, or debate, one with another: (Bd:) [or it means (assumed tropical:) rebutting one another's sayings:] or (assumed tropical:) blaming one another. (S.) ― -b5- Alr~ajoEu, (K,) or rajoEu Ald~aAb~api yadayohaA fiY Als~ayori, (S,) (tropical:) The stepping of the beast, (S, K,) or her returning her fore legs, [drawing the fore feet backwards towards the body, by lifting them high,] in going; (K;) and ↓ Alt~arojiyEu, (K,) or tarojiyEu Ald~aAb~pi yadayohaA fiY Als~ayori, (S,) signifies the same: (S, K:) or rajoEN signifies a beast's elevating, or lifting high, the fore foot and hind foot, in going. (KL.) You say, Ald~aAb~apu yadayohaA fiY ↓ raj~aEati Als~ayori (tropical:) [The beast stepped, &c.; like as you say, rajaEat]. (TA.) ― -b6- rajoEu AlwaA$mapi, and ↓ tarojayEuhaA, (assumed tropical:) The female tattooer's making marks or lines [upon the skin]: (S, K: *) [or rather, as the former phrase is explained in the EM p. 143, “ her retracing ” those marks or lines, and renewing their blackness; for] you say also, Alnaqo$a ↓ raj~aEa, and Alwa$oma, [and rajaEahu,] (assumed tropical:) He retraced the marks, or lines, of the variegated work, and of the tattooing, and renewed their blackness, one time after another. (TA.) And AlkitaAbapa ↓ raj~aEa, [and rajaEahaA,] (assumed tropical:) He retraced, or renewed, the writing. (TA.) ― -b7- rajaEa naAqapF, and ↓ ArtjEhA, and ↓ trj~EhA, He purchased a she-camel with the price of another that he sold: (S, TA:) or he purchased a she-camel with the price of a he-camel that he sold; and ↓ rijaEN, which is app. an inf. n., signifies the selling males and purchasing females: (TA:) or maAlFA ↓ ArtjE signifies he sold the aged and the younglings of his came's, and purchased such as were in a state of youthful vigour: or, as some say, he sold the males, and purchased females: (Lh:) or ↓ AirotijaAEN signifies the selling a thing, and purchasing in its place what one imagines to be more youthful, and better: (Lh in another place:) regard is bad, therein, to the meaning of a return, virtual, or understood, though not real: (Er-Rághib:) also A_ibilFA ↓ ArjE he sold old and weak camels, and purchased such as were in a state of youthful vigour: or he sold male camels, and purchased females: (TA:) and A_ibilFA ↓ ArtjE biA_ibilihi he took camels in exchange for his camels:
or, as some say, ↓ AirotijaAEN signifies the taking one in the place, and with the price, of two. (Mgh.) ― -b8- rajaEa AlEalafu fiY Ald~aAb~api (tropical:) The fodder, or food, produced an effect, or showed its effect, upon the beast. (K, * TA.) And rajaEa kalaAmiY fiyhi (tropical:) My speech produced a beneficial effect upon him. (K, * TA.)

2 rj~Ehu * , inf. n. tarojiyEN, He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to return, go back, come back, or revert, again and again, or time after time; sent back, turned back, or returned, him, or it, again and again, or time after time; made, or caused, him, or it, to go, or move, repeatedly to and fro; so to go and come; to reciprocate: he repeated it; iterated it; or rather reiterated it: he reproduced it: he renewed it: syn. rad~adahu. (Mgh.) [All these significations are well known, as pertaining to the two verbs here mentioned, and of frequent occurrence in classical and postclassical writings: and hence several phrases here following.] ― -b2- See 1, last quarter of the paragraph, in five places. ― -b3- Hence, (Mgh,) Alt~arojiyEu fiY AlA^a*aAni, (S, Mgh, K,) because the two professions of the faith [for which see the word A^a*aAnN] are uttered in the A*An [or call to prayer] in a low voice [and then repeated in a high voice]; (Mgh;) [for] this phrase means (tropical:) The repeating the two professions of the faith in a raised, or loud, voice, after uttering them in a low, or faint, voice; (Sgh, K, TA;) or the lowering of the voice in the A*An in uttering the two professions of the faith, and then raising it in uttering them: (KT:) or rj~E fiY A^a*aAnihi signifies he uttered the two professions of the faith in his A*An once to repeat them. (Msb: [but this is a strange explanation; and probably corrupted by a copyist: it seems that, instead of “ to repeat them, ” we should read “ and repeated them. ”]) ― -b4- [Hence also,] Alt~arojiyEu, (K, TA,) or tarojiyEu AlS~awoti, (S,) (assumed tropical:) [The act of quavering, or trilling; rapidly repeating many times one very short note, or each note of a piece; a general characteristic of Arabian chanting and singing and piping, and often continued throughout the whole performance;] the reiterating (tarodiyd) of the voice in the throat, or fauces, (S, K, TA,) like [as is done in] chanting, (S,) or which is practised in reading or reciting, or singing, or piping, or other performances, of such as are accompanied with quavering, or trilling: (TA:) or, as some say, the mutual approximation of the various kinds of movements in the voice: 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Mughaffal, in his trjyE, by the prolonging of the voice, in reading, or reciting, imitated the like of A=A A=A A=A. (TA.) You say also, rj~E AlHamaAmu fiY ginaAy^ihi (assumed tropical:) [The pigeons quavered in their singing, or cooing]; as also ↓ AstrjE. (TA.) And rj~E AlbaEiyru fiY $iqo$iqatihi (assumed tropical:) The camel brayed, or reiterated his voice, in his $q$qp [or bursa faucium]. (TA.) And rj~Et Aln~aAqapu fiY HaniynihaA (assumed tropical:) The she-camel interrupted her yearning cry to, or for, her young one [and then, app., quickly repeated it, and did so again and again]. (TA.) And rj~Et Alqawosu (assumed tropical:) The bow made a sound [by the vibration of its string; because the sound so made is a repeated sound]. (AHn.) ― -b5- See also 4. ― -b6- And see 10.

3 rAjE *
He (a man) returned to good or to evil. (TA.) [See also 6.] ― -b2- rAjEt Aln~aAqapu, (K,) inf. n. rijaAEN, (TA,) The she-camel returned, or reverted, from one kind of pace, which she had been going, to another pace. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- rAjEhu (assumed tropical:) It returned to him: said of pain [&c.]. (TA in art. Ed.) ― -b4- rAjE A@moraA^atahu (tropical:) [He returned to his wife, or restored her to himself, or took her back by marriage or to the marriage-state, after having divorced her; (see also 6;)]; (S;) and ↓ ArtjEhA signifies the same. (TA.) ― -b5- [See also a verse cited voce radaAdN; whence it seems that rAjE also signifies He restored, or brought back, anything.] ― -b6- rAjEhu signifies also He endeavoured to turn him [from, or to, a thing]; syn. raAwadahu, and raAd~ahu. (L in art. rwd.) ― -b7- rAjEhu AlkalaAma, (S and K in this art., and A and Mgh and Msb in art. Hwr,) and fiY AlkalaAmi, (Bd in xviii. 32,) and simply raAjEhu, (Msb in this art., and Jel. in lviii. l,) inf. n. muraAjaEapN (S, TA) and rijaAEN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He returned him answer for answer, or answers for answers; held a dialogue, or colloquy, or conference, or a disputation, or debate, with him; bandied words with him; syn. HaAwarahu, (A and Mgh and Msb in art. Hwr, and Bd in xviii. 32,) [i. e.] HaAwarahu AlkalaAma; (TA;) or EaAwadahu; (S and Msb and K in this art.;) or jaAdalahu. (Jel in lviii. 1.) And rAjEhu, or rAjEhu Alqawola, (assumed tropical:) He disputed with him, rebutting, or rejecting, or repudiating, in reply to him, what he said; he bandied words with him; syn. raAd~ahu Alqawola. (A in art. rd.) You say, rAjEhu fiY muhim~aAtihi He held a colloquy, or conference, or a disputation, or debate, with him respecting his affairs of difficulty; syn. HaAwarahu. (TA.) [And rAjEhu fiY ka*aA He addressed him repeatedly, or time after time, respecting such a thing.] And raAjaEuwA Euquwlahumo [They consulted their understandings, or minds; as though they held a colloquy, or conference, or a disputation, or debate, therewith]. (Bd in xxi. 65.) [rAjE often signifies He consulted, or referred to, a person, a book, a passage in a book, &c.]

4 ArjEt Aln~aAqapu * (assumed tropical:) [The she-camel returned to her former condition, either of leanness or fatness:] (assumed tropical:) the she-camel became lean [after having been fat]: and (assumed tropical:) became in good condition after leanness: (Ks, T, TA:) or ArjEt AlA_ibilu (assumed tropical:) the camels became lean and then became fat; (S, O, K;) so says Ks. (S.) You say also, Al$~ayoxu yamoraDu yuwomayoni falaA yurojiEu $ahorFA (assumed tropical:) i. e. [The old man is sick two days, and] does not return to a healthy state of body, and to strength, in a month. (K, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, flA yurojaEu.]) And [in like manner] AinotaqaSa Alfarasu vum~a ↓ taraAjaEa (assumed tropical:) [The horse wasted, and then gradually returned to his former condition]. (TA.) -A2- ArjEhu: see rajaEahu, first signification. ― -b2- ArjEhu naAqatahu He gave him [back] his she-camel in order that he might return upon her, he [the latter] having sold her to him. (Lh.) ― -b3- ArjE A_ibilFA: see 1, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b4- ArjE A@ll~`hu bayoEatahu (tropical:) God made his sale to be productive of gain, or profit. (S, K.) ― -b5- ArjE A@ll~`hu ham~ahu suruwrFA (assumed tropical:) God converted his grief, or disquietude of mind, into happiness or joy; and Sb mentions ↓ raj~aEahu [in this sense]. (TA.) ― -b6- ArjE also signifies He extended, or stretched out, his arm, or hand, backwards, to reach, or take hold of, a thing. (S, K.) [In this case, yadahu seems to be understood: for] you say [also], ArjE Alr~ajulu yadayohi The man put his arms, or hands, backwards in order to reach, or take hold of, a thing. (Lh.) And ArjE yadahu A_ilaY sayofihi liyasotal~ahu He extended, or stretched out, his arm, or hand, to his sword, to draw it: or A_ilaY kinaAnatihi liyaA^oxu*a sahomFA to his quiver, to take an arrow. (TA.) ― -b7- Also (tropical:) He ejected excrement, or ordure; said of a man. (S, K.) [See rajiyEN.] -A3- See also 10.
5 trj~E fiY SadoriY ka*aA * (tropical:) Such a thing became agitated to and fro in my mind, or bosom; syn. tarad~ada. (TA.) -A2- trj~E naAqapF: see 1; in the last quarter of the paragraph.

6 taraAjaEaA * (tropical:) They two (a man and his divorced wife) returned to each other by marriage; (Bd in ii. 230;) or returned together to the marriagestate. (Jel ibid.) ― -b2- trAjE Al$~aYo'u A_ilaY xalofK [The thing went backward or back, receded, retrograded, retired, retreated, or reverted, by degrees, gradually, by little and little, or part after part: and trAjE alone, He, or it, returned by degrees: the form of the verb denoting a gradual continuation, as in tasaAqaTa, and tazaAyada, and tanaAqaSa, &c.]. (S.) trAjE and taraAd~a and tarad~ada are syn. (M and L in art. rd.) You say, trAjEwA fiY masiyrK They returned, retired, or retreated, by degrees, or by little and little, in a journey, or march; syn. taraAd~uwA. (TA in art. vbjr.) And tafar~aquwA fiY A^aw~ali Aln~ahaAri vum~a taraAjaEuwA maEa All~ayoli i. e. [They separated, or dispersed themselves, in the first part of day; then] they returned, [one after an every one to his place of abode. (TA.) ― -b3- taraAjaEato A^aHowaAlu fulaAnK (tropical:) [The circumstances of such a one gradually reverted to their former condition; meaning either a better condition, agreeably with an ex. mentioned above, see 4; or, as is most commonly the case, a worse condition; i. e. retrograded; or gradually went back to a worse state; contr. of advanced, or improved]: (TA:) [whence the saying,] zaAlato dawolatuhumo waA^axa*a A^amoruhumo yataraAjaEu (assumed tropical:) [Their good fortune ceased, and their affairs began to retrograde, or gradually go back to a worse state]. (A in art. rkd.) And taraAjaEa AljuroHu A_il~Y Alburo'i (assumed tropical:) [The wound gradually recovered]. (Msb in art. dml.) -A2- taraAjaEaA bayonahumaA They two (copartners) made claims for restitution, each upon the other. (IAth, TA in art. xlT.) [See this more fully explained, and illustrated, voce xaliyTN.] ― -b2- trAjEwA AlkalaAma, (Msb and K in art. Hwr,) and fiY AlkalaAmi, (Bd in lviii. 1,) and simply trAjEwA, (Jel in lviii. 1,) (assumed tropical:) They returned one another answer for answer, or answers for answers; held a dialogue, or colloquy,
or conference, or a disputation, or debate, one with another; bandied words, one with another; syn. taHaAwaruwA. (Bd, Jel, Msb, K, in the places mentioned above.)

8 ArtjE EalaY Algariymi * , and Almut~ahami: see rajaEa, with which it is syn. (TA.) -A2- ArtjEhu i. q. rad~ahu, like rajaEahu, q. v. (TA.) So in the phrase, ArtjEt AlmaroA^apu jilobaAbahaA The woman put back her jlbAb [q. v.] upon her face, and covered herself with it. (TA.) ― -b2- ArtjE Alhibapa: see rajaEa fiY hibatihi. ― -b3- ArtjE A@moraA^atahu: see 3. ― -b4- ↓ baAga A_ibilahu faA@rotajaEa minohaA rijoEapF SaAliHapF He sold his camels, and obtained by the expenditure of their price a good return, or profit. (S, K.) ― -b5- ArtjE naAqapF, and the like: see 1, near the end of the paragraph, in five places. ― -b6- ArtjE A_ibilFA also signifies He (and Arab of the desert) purchased camels [app. in exchange for others] not of his own people's breeding nor bearing their marks. (TA.)

10 AstrjE Alhibapa * , and AstrjE minohu Al$~aYo'a: see rajaEa fiY hibatihi, and the sentence next following it. ― -b2- TaEaAmN yusotarojaEu Eanohu (assumed tropical:) Food, both of beasts and of men, from which profit, or advantage, [or a good return (rijoEap),] is obtained; which is found to be wholesome, or approved in its result; and from eating which one becomes fat. (TA.) -A2- AstrjE AlHamaAmu: see 2, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- AstrjE also signifies (tropical:) He said, on the occasion of an affliction, or a misfortune, [using the words of the Kur ii. 151,] A_in~aA lil~`hi waA_in~aA A_ilayohi raAjiEuwna, (S, K,) meaning Verily to God we belong as his property and his servants, so that He may do with us what He pleaseth, and verily unto Him we return in the ultimate state of existence, and He will recompense us; (Jel;) as also ↓ rj~E, (S, * K,) inf. n. tarojiyEN; (S; [accord. to the TA, only the former verb is mentioned in this sense by J; but I find the latter also in two copies of the S;]) and ↓ ArjE. (K.)

rajoEN * ; originally an inf. n.: [see rajaEa and rajaEahu:] ― -b2- and see rajoEapN, in two places. ― -b3- (tropical:) Rain: so in the Kur [lxxxvi. 11], waAls~amaA='i *aAti Alr~ajoEi [by the heaven that hath rain]: (S, Bd:) because God returns it time after time: or because the clouds raise the water from the seas and then return it to the earth; and if so, by AsmA' may be meant the clouds: (Bd:) or rain after rain; (K;) because it returns time after time; or because it is repeated, and returns, every year: (TA:) or the said words of the Kur mean by the heaven that returns in every revolution to the place whence it moved. (Bd.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Hail; because it gives back the water that it takes. (TA.) ― -b5- Accord. to El-Asadee, as recorded by AHeyth, (assumed tropical:) Thunder. (Az.) ― -b6- Accord. to some, in the passage of the Kur cited above, (S, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Profit, benefit, advantage, or good return. (S, K, TA.) You say, layosa liY mino fulaAnK rajoEN (assumed tropical:) There is no profit to me from such a one. (TA.) And maA huwa A_il~aA sajoEN layosa taHotahu rajoEN (assumed tropical:) [It is nothing but rhyming prose, beneath which is to be found no profit]. (TA.) [See also rijoEapN.] ― -b7- Accord. to Ks, in the ex. cited above from the Kur, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The place that retains water: (K, TA:) pl. rujoEaAnN. (TA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) A pool of water left by a torrent; (S, K;) because of the rain that is in it; or because of its fluctuating to and fro in its place; (Er-Rághib;) as also ↓ rajiyEN, and ↓ raAjiEapN: (K:) pl. as above: (S:) or (assumed tropical:) a place in which the torrent has extended itself, (Aimotad~a, accord. to Lth and the O and K,) or in which it has returned, or reverted, (Airotad~a, accord. to AHn,) and then passed through: (Lth, AHn, O, K:) pl. rujoEaAnN and rijoEaAnN and rijaAEN; (K;) or this last, accord. to some, is a sing., having the signification next preceding the last here mentioned, and is found prefixed to its syn., namely gadiyr, to show that it is used in this sense, and is qualified by a sing. epithet, namely raAy^iE; but some say that it is thus qualified becanse it has a form which is that of a sing. noun: (TA:) or rajoEN signifies (assumed tropical:) water, (AO, K,) in general; (K;) and a sword is likened to it, to denote its whiteness: (AO, S: [but accord. to the latter, in this case it signifies “ a pool of water left by a torrent ”:]) and also (assumed tropical:) a tract of ground, or land, in which the torrent has extended itself: (K:) but this, it should be observed, is a repetition of the saying of Lth mentioned above: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) the part that is above a taloEap [q. v.]; (K, TA;) the upper, or highest, part thereof, before its water collects together: (TA:) pl. rujoEaAnN. (K.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) The herbage of the [season, or rain, called] rabiyE; (K;) [because it returns year after year;] as also ↓ rajiyEN. (TA.) ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) The [membrane called] girps which is in the belly of the woman, and which comes forth upon, or over, the head of the child. (TA.) ― -b11- See also rajiyEN, in three places, in the latter part of the paragraph. ― -b12- sayofN najiyHu Alr~ajoEi, and ↓ Alr~ajiyEi, A sword which penetrates into the thing that is struck with it [so that it is quickly drawn back]. (TA.) ― -b13- rajoEu Alkatifi: see marojiEN.
rijoEu safarK * : see rajiyEu safarK.
rujaEN * : see rijoEapN.
rijaEN * : see rajaEa naAqapF: and see rijoEapN.

rajoEapN * inf. n. of un. of 1; A return; a single act of returning, of going back, coming back, or reverting: (TA:) [and] i. q. rujuwEN, i. e. the act of returning, &c. (Msb.) ― -b2- The returning to the present state of existence (S, Msb, K) after death. (S, K.) So in the phrase, fulaAnN yuw^ominu biAlr~ajoEapi [Such a one believes in the returning to the present state of existence after death]. (S, Msb, K. *) This was a tenet of some of the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance, and of a sect of Muslim innovators, and of a sect of the raAfiDap, who say that 'Alee the son of Aboo-Tálib is concealing himself in the clouds, to come forth when he shall be summoned to do so. (L.) ― -b3- The returning, or homeward course, of a military expedition; opposed to badoA^apN, q. v. (T and Mgh in art. bdA^.) ― -b4- The return of a party of warriors to war after their having come back from an expedition. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, and ↓ rijoEapN, (S, A, Nh, Mgh, Msb, K,) but the former is the more chaste, (S, Msb, TA,) though the latter is mentioned before the former in the K, (TA,) (tropical:) A man's returning to his wife, or restoring her to himself, or taking her back by marriage or to the marriage-state, after having divorced her; (IF, Msb;) the returning of the divorcer to the divorced woman: (K:) or the taking back to marriage a woman who has been divorced, but not by an absolutely-separating sentence, without a new contract. (Nh.) You say, lahu EalaY A@moraA^atihi rajoEapN and ↓ rijoEapN (tropical:) [He has a right of returning to, or taking back, his wife after having divorced her]: (S, Mgh:) and yamoliku Alr~ajoEapa EalaY zawojatihi (tropical:) [He possesses the right of returning &c.]: (Msb:) and Tal~aqa fulaAnN fulaAnapa TalaAqFA yamoliku fiyhi Alr~ajoEapa (tropical:) [Such a man divorced such a woman by a divorce in which he possessed the right of returning &c.]. (TA.) ― -b6- Also the former, (S, Msb, TA,) and ↓ rijoEapN likewise, (Msb,) and ↓ rujoEapN (K) and ↓ rujoEaY [which is originally an inf. n.] and ↓ rujoEaAnN [which is also originally an inf. n.] and ↓ marojuwEN (S, K) and ↓ marojuwEapN and ↓ rajuwEapN and ↓ rajoEN, (K,) the last of these is allowable, (TA,) [being an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n.,] (tropical:) The reply, or answer, of an epistle. (S, Msb, * K, TA.) You say, halo jaA='a rajoEapu kitaAbika (S, TA) and ↓ rujoEaAnuhu (TA) (tropical:) Hath the reply, or answer, of thine epistle come:? (S, TA:) and ↓ A^arosaltu A_ilayoka famaA jaA='aniY rujoEaY risaAlatiY (tropical:) I sent to thee, and the reply, or answer, of my epistle came not to me; i. e. ↓ marojuwEuhaA: (S, K, * TA:) and fulaAnK Ealayoka ↓ maA kaAna mino marojuwEi (tropical:) What was [the purport] of the reply, or answer, of such a one to thee? (S, TA.) And [in like manner] Alr~i$oq ↓ rajoEu signifies (assumed tropical:) What is returned against, or in opposition to, [or in reply to,] the simultaneous discharge of a number of arrows in a particular direction. (TA.) ― -b7- See also rijoEapN.
rujoEapN * : see rajoEapN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

rijoEapN * : see rajoEapN, in three places. ― -b2- A return, or profit, obtained by the expenditure of the price of camels sold: see an ex. above, voce AirotajaEa: (S, K:) or camels taken in exchange for other camels: or one that is taken in the place, and with the price, of two: (Mgh:) also the young, or younglings, of camels, which are purchased from the market with the price of others, or taken from the market in exchange for others: (K:) or, as Khálid says, the [return obtained by] bringing bad camels into the market and taking back good ones: or, as some say, the [return obtained by] bringing in males and taking back females: (TA:) [the words which I have here twice inserted in brackets are perhaps not necessary to complete the sense intended, as will be seen at the close of this sentence; but they seem to be required in the opinion of SM, for he has
immediately added the further explanation which here next follows, and which is also, but less fully, given by J, immediately after the first explanation in this paragraph:] and rijoEapN has a similar meaning in relation to the poor-rates; being applied to camels taken by the collector of the poor-rates older or younger than those which their owner is bound to give: (S, * TA:) and camels which are purchased by the Arabs of the desert, [app. in exchange-for others,] not of their own breeding nor bearing their marks; as also ↓ rajoEapN: (TA, [see 8:]) IB says that the pl. of rijoEapN is ↓ rujaEN; and that it was said to a tribe of the Arabs, “ By what means have your beasts become many? ” and they answered, A^awoSaAnaA A^abuwnaA biAln~ujaEi waAlr~ujaEi: but Th says, ↓ bAln~ijaEi wAlr~ijaEi: [both are probably correct; for it seems that the original forms are Aln~ujaE and Alr~ijaE; and that, in one case, the latter is assimilated to the former; in the other, accord. to a usage less common, the former to the latter:] accord. to Th, the meaning is, [Our father charged us with the seekings after herbage in the places thereof, and] the selling the old and weak beasts and purchasing others in a state of youthful vigour: or, accord. to another explanation, the meaning is, the selling males and purchasing females: thus explained, rijaEN seems to be an inf. n. (TA. [See rajaEa naAqapF.]) [See also rajiyEa.] ― -b3- [(assumed tropical:) Any return, profit, or gain, accruing from a thing, or obtained by the sale or exchange thereof; as also ↓ marojuwEN; and rajoEN, q. v.] You say, jaA='ato rijoEapu AlD~iyaAEi (assumed tropical:) The return, or increase, accruing to the owner of the lands came, or arrived. (Lh.) And jaA='a fulaAnN birijoEapK HasanapK (assumed tropical:) Such a one brought a good thing which he had purchased in the place of a bad thing; or in the place of a thing that was inferior to it. (TA.) And ↓ h`*aA mataAEN lahu marojuwEN (assumed tropical:) This is a commodity for which there will be a return, or profit, or gain. (S, * TA) And ↓ daAb~apN lahaA marojuwEN (assumed tropical:) A beast that may be sold after having been used. (El-Isbahánee.) And ↓ layosa lih`*aA AlbayoEi marojuwEN (tropical:) There is not, or will not be, any return, or profit, or gain, for this sale. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) An argument, or allegation, by which one rebuts in a litigation, or dispute; a proof; an evidence. (Ibn-'Abbád.)
rujoEaY * : see rajoEapN, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places.

TalaAqN rajoEiY~N * , and rijoEiY~N, (assumed tropical:) A divorce in which one reserves to himself the right of returning to his wife, or restoring her to himself, or taking her back to the marriage-state. (Mgh, * Msb.) ― -b2- rajoEiY~N applied to a beast: see rajiyEu safarK.
rajoEiy~apN * : see rajiyEapN.
rujoEaAnN * : see rajoEapN, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places.

rijaAEN * The nose-rein of a camel: (IDrd, K:) or the part thereof which falls upon the nose of the camel: pl. [of pauc.] A^arojiEapN and [of mult.] rujuEN: (K:) from rajaEa in the phrase rajaEa fulaAnN EalaY A^anofi baEiyrihi [q. v.]. (IDrd.) ― -b2- It is also an inf. n.: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph.

rajiyEN * . [Made, or caused, to return, go back, come back, or revert; sent back, turned back, or returned: repeated: rebutted, rejected, or repudiated, in reply, or replication: like ↓ marojuwEN: and used in all these senses; as will be seen from what follows: and also, like ↓ muraj~aEN,] made, or caused, to return, go back, come back, or revert, again and again, or time after time; sent back, turned back, or returned, again and again, or time after time; made, or caused, to go, or move, repeatedly to and fro; so to go and come; to reciprocate: reiterated: reproduced: renewed: syn. murad~adN: [in the CK maroduwdN:] applied to anything: (S, K:) or to anything that is said or done: (Msb, TA:) because meaning ↓ marojuwEN, i. e. maroduwdN: (S, Msb, TA:) or, applied to speech, (assumed tropical:) returned to its author; or repeated to him; or rebutted, rejected, or repudiated, in reply to him; syn. maroduwdN A_ilaY SaAHibihi: (Lth, K:) or, so applied, (tropical:) repeated: (A, TA:) or, so applied, (assumed tropical:) reiterated: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or, so applied, (assumed tropical:) disapproved, or disliked. (TA.) You say, A_iy~aAka waAlr~ajiyEa mina Alqawoli (tropical:) Avoid thou the saying that is repeated; (A, TA;) [or rebutted, &c.;] or disapproved. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a beast, (S, TA,) and [particularly] to a camel, (K,) it signifies Made to return from journey to journey: (S, TA:) and also means (assumed tropical:) fatigued, or jaded, (S, K,) by journeying: (K:) fem. with rujuEN (S, K:) or (tropical:) lean, or emaciated: (Er-Rághib, K:) in the K is here added, or which thou hast made to return from a journey, meaning from journey to journey; but this is identical with the first explanation of the word applied to a beast: (TA:) pl. rujuEN; (K;) or [app. of the fem., agreeably with analogy, and as seems to be indicated by J,] rajaAy^iEu. (S.) rajiyEu safarK and safarK ↓ rijoEu [in like manner] signify Made to return repeatedly, or several times, in journeying; applied to a she-camel: (K:) and the former signifies, applied to a beast, and [particularly] to a camel, a he-camel, (baEiyr,) which one makes to return again and again, or time after time, or to come and go repeatedly, in journeying, and drags along: (TA:) both also mean (tropical:) lean, or emaciated: and are in like manner applied to a man: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and ↓ rajoEiY~N and ↓ marojaEaAniY~N, also, but the latter is vulgar, (assumed tropical:) lean, or emaciated, by journeying; applied to a beast. (TA.) You say also saforN rajiyEN Travellers returning from a journey. (TA.) And safarN rajiyEN A journey in which are repeated returnings. (IAar.) ― -b3- Any food returned to the fire [to be heated again], having became cold: (K:) [and particularly] roasted meat heated a second time. (As.) ― -b4- A rope, or cord, undone, and then twisted a second time: (L, K:) and, as some say, anything done a second time. (L.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Writing retraced with the pen, in order that it may became more plain: (KL:) and ↓ marojuwEN [signifies the same: and also] (assumed tropical:) tattooing repeated and renewed; (EM p. 108;) tattooing of which the blackness has been restored: (TA:) pl. of the latter maraAjiyEu. (TA, and EM ubi suprà.) ― -b6- (tropical:) Dung, ordure, or excrement, of a solid-hoofed animal; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ rajoEN; (K;) and of a man; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ the latter word; (TA;) and of a beast of prey; as also ↓ the latter: (S, TA:) because it returns from its first state, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) after having been food or fodder &c.; (TA;) having the meaning of an act. part. n., (Er-Rághib, Msb,) or, it may be, of a pass. part. n. (Er-Rághib.) ― -b7- (tropical:) The cud which is ruminated by camels and the like: (S, * K:) because it returns to be eaten. (TA.) So in the saying of El-Aashà,
wafalaApK kaA^an~ahaA Zahoru turosK
layosa A_il~aA Alr~ajiyEa fiyhaA EalaAqu
i. e. [Many a desert, or waterless desert, as though it were the back of a shield,] in which there is not found by the camels anything to serve for the support of life except the cud. (S.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) Sweat: (K:) because, having been water, it returns as sweat. (TA.) ― -b9- See also rajoEN, in three places. ― -b10- Also (assumed tropical:) The [part called] faA^os of a bit: (Ibn-' Abbád, K:) [because of its returning motion.] ― -b11- And (assumed tropical:) Niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious; syn. baxiylN [in the CK and a MS. copy of the K, naxiyl]. (Ibn-' Abbád, K, TA.)
rajuwEapN * : see rajoEapN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

rajiyEapN *
A she-camel that is purchased with the price of another she-camel; as also ↓ raAjiEapN: (S:) or a female that is purchased with the price of a male. (' Alee Ibn-Hamzeh.) [See also rijoEapN: and see rajiyEN, of which it is originally the fem.] Accord. to ISk, ↓ rajoEiy~apN signifies A camel which one has purchased from men who have brought him from another place for sale; which is not of the district in which he is: [but this appears to be a mistranscription, for rajiyEapN; for he adds,] the pl. is rajaAy^iEu. (TA.)
raj~aAEN * (assumed tropical:) One who returns much, or often, unto God. (TA.)

raAjiEN * [act. part. n. of 1. Hence the saying, A_in~aA lil~`hi waA_in~aA A_ilayohi raAjiEuwna, explained above: see 10. ― -b2- Also, without p,] (assumed tropical:) A woman who returns to her family in consequence of the death of her husband (Az, S, Msb, K) or in consequence of divorcement; (Az, Msb;) as also ↓ muraAjiEN: (Az, K:) or, accord. to some, (Msb,) she who is divorced [and sent back to her family] is termed maroduwdapN. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- [In like manner without p,] applied to a she-camel, and to a she-ass, it signifies (assumed tropical:) That raises her tail, and compresses her two sides (quTorayohaA), and casts forth her urine in repeated discharges, so that she is imagined to be pregnant, (S, K,) and then fails of fulfilling her [apparent] promise: (S:) or (assumed tropical:) that conceives,
and then fails of fulfilling her promise; because she goes back from what is hoped of her: (TA:) or, applied to a she-camel, (assumed tropical:) that has appeared to have conceived, and is then found to be not pregnant: (As:) pl. rawaAjiEu. (S, TA.) [See also rajaEato.] ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A sick man whose soul [or health] has returned to him after his being debilitated by disease: and (assumed tropical:) a man whose soul [or health] has returned to him after severe and constant illness. (TA.)

raAjiEapN * [originally fem. of raAjiEN, q. v.]: see rajiyEapN: ― -b2- and see rajoEN. ― -b3- Also, [app. from the returning of its water time after time,] (assumed tropical:) A water-course of a valley. (ISh, TA.) ― -b4- rawaAjiEu [is its pl., and] signifies Varying winds; because of their coming and going. (TA.) ― -b5- Hence also, rawaAjiEu AlA^abowaAbi [The leaves of doors]. (TA.)

A^arojaEu * (tropical:) More [and most] productive of return, or profitable. (TA.) You say, h`*aA A^arojaEu fiY yadY mino h`*aA (tropical:) This is more productive of return, or profitable, in my hand than this. (TA.)

marojiEN * an inf. n. of the intrans. verb rajaEa [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence it signifies sometimes (assumed tropical:) Recourse. See manaAbN, in art. nwb.] -A2- [A place to which a person, or thing, returns after going or moving therefrom; agreeably with analogy. See an ex. voce maHoDarN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] marojiEu Alkatifi (tropical:) The lower part of the shoulderblade, (S, K, TA,) next the arm-pit, [that on the left side being] in the region where the heart beats; (TA;) as also Alkatifi ↓ rajoEu: (S, K:) and marojiEu Almirofaqi (tropical:) [the place to which the elbow returns when, after it has been removed from its usual place, it is brought back thereto; which place in a beast is next the arm-pit: see fariySN, in three places]: (TA:) pl. maraAjiEu. (TA.) ― -b3- [marojiEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The place, or thing, to which a person, or thing, is referred, as his, or its, source: see manoSibN. ― -b4- Also, (assumed tropical:) A state, or condition, to which a person, or thing, returns. ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) The place, and the state, or condition, or result, to which a person, or thing, ultimately, or eventually, comes. A goal.] -A3- It is also an inf. n. of rajaEahu. (K.)

murojiEN * , [without p,] applied to a she-camel, (assumed tropical:) Becoming in good condition after leanness. (Ks, TA.) [See 4, of which it is the act. part. n.] ― -b2- h`*aA mataAEN murojiEN (assumed tropical:) This is a commodity for which there will be a return, or profit, or gain. (S, * TA.) ― -b3- saforapN murojiEapN (tropical:) A journey having a recompense, or reward, and a good issue or result. (K, TA.)
muraj~aEN * : see rajiyEN; first sentence.
marojaEaAniY~N * : see rajiyEN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

marojuwEN * [pass. part. n. of rajaEahu]: see rajiyEN, in three places: ― -b2- and rajoEapN, in the latter half of the paragraph, in three places: ― -b3- and rijoEapN, near the end of the paragraph, in four places.
marojuwEapN * : see rajoEapN, in the latter half of the paragraph.
muraAjiEN * : see raAjiEN.

Q. 4 AirojaEan~a * a dial. var. of AirojaHan~ [q. v.] in the several senses of the latter. (K.) You say, Darabahu faA@rojaEan~a He beat him, or struck him, and he lay on his side, and threw himself down. (Lh, TA.) And ArjEn~wA They lay on their sides and were overcome. (TA.) ― -b2- Also It became spread, expanded, or extended. (TA.)

1 rajafa * , (O, Msb, K,) aor.
rajufa , (Msb,) inf. n. rajofN and rajafaAnN (O, Msb, K) and rajiyfN (Msb, K) and rujuwfN; (O, K;) [and ↓ Arjf; (see the next sentence;) and ↓ Artjf; (see nagaDa, in two places;)] It (a thing, O, Msb) was, or became, in a state of motion, commotion, (O, Msb, K,) agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance: (Msb, K: *) or in a state of violent motion, commotion, agitation, &c.; (K;) as the camel beneath the saddle, and the tree when put in motion by the wind, and the wabbling tooth, and the like. (O.) You say, rajafati AlA^aroDu, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
rajufa , inf. n. rajofN, (S,) The earth quaked; or was, or became, in a state of motion, commotion, agitation, &c., (S, O, Msb, K,) as above; (Msb;) and so ↓ A^arojafat, and ↓ A^urojifat; (K;) [for Arjf is both intrans. and trans.:] and Alr~ajafaAnu signifies the being in a state of violent commotion, agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance. (S.) And rajafato yaduhu His arm, or hand, trembled, by reason of disease, or old age. (Msb.) And rajafa Alqalobu The heart became agitated by reason of fright. (IDrd, O.) ― -b2- rajafa Alr~aEodu, (Lth, O, K,) inf. n. rajofN and rajiyfN, (Lth, O,) The thunder made a reiterated rumbling, or confused noise, in the clouds. (Lth, O, K.) ― -b3- rajafa Alqawomu The people, or party, prepared themselves for war, or battle. (Lth, O, K.) -A2- Also He put [a thing] into a state of motion, commotion, or agitation; (O, K;) [so too, app., rajafa bihi;] see 4, last sentence; [and so ↓ A^arojafa; for] A^arojafa AlA^aroDa bihimo is said of God [as meaning He made the earth to quake with them]. (TA in art. dm.) And one says also, rajafatohu AlHum~aY The fever caused him to quake, or shiver. (Msb.)

4 A^arojafa as an intrans. v.: see 1, in two places. -A2- And as a trans. v.; act. and pass.: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] Arjf bika*aA [originally He put another, or others, into a state of commotion, or agitation, by such a thing; meaning] he told of such a thing without truth, or not according to the true, or real, state of the case: [because he thereby caused commotion, or agitation; or] because the information was unsettled: from rajofapN meaning as explained below. (Ksh in xxxiii. 60.) And ArjfwA fiY Al$~aYo'i (S, Msb, K) and bihi, (Msb, K,) inf. n. A_irojaAfN, (Msb,) i. q. xaADuwA fiyhi [mean- ing They said what was false respecting the thing]: (S, O, K:) or they told many evil tales, and uttered many discordant lying sayings, respecting the thing, in order that the people might become in a state of commotion, agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance, in consequence thereof: whence, in the Kur [xxxiii. 60], fiY Almadiynapi ↓ waAlmurojifuwna [and they who tell many evil tales, &c., in the city:] (O, * Msb:) or ArjfwA fiY Albaladi bika*aA they told, in the town, or country, of such a matter, in order that they might cause commotion, or agitation, &c., to befall the people, without there being aught [thereof] true in their estimation; from Alr~ajafaAnu signifying “ violent commotion or agitation ” &c. (Har pp. 218, 219.) And ArjfwA, alone, They said what was false (xaADuwA) in [relating] tales of conflicts and factions, or seditions, or discords, or dissensions, and the like: whence, ↓ waAlmurojifuwnu fiY Almadiynapi [cited above]. (K.) ― -b3- And Arjft Aln~aAqapu The she-camel came in a state of fatigue, with her ears flaccid, shaking them (bihimaA ↓ tarojufu). (O, K.)
8 A_irotajafa see 1, first sentence.

rajoEapN *
i. q. zalozalapN (S, K) [meaning Commotion, agitation, or convulsion; or violent commotion &c.; and particularly an earthquake; or] a violent earthquake: and a vehement cry from heaven: (Jel in vii. 76:) or it signifies, in the Kur-án, any punishment that befalls a people. (Lth, O.)

[
rajuwfN * , accord. to Freytag, occurs in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen as meaning Put into a state of commotion.] ― -b2- saHaAbN rajuwfN Clouds in commotion with thunder, or with much water. (O.)

Alr~aj~aAfu *
The sea; because of its commotion, or agitation. (S, O, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Matrood Ibn-Kaab, lamenting the death of ' Abdel-Muttalib, (IB, O,) the grandfather of the Prophet, and eulogizing him, (IB,)
AalomuToEimuwna Al$~aHoma kul~a Ea$iy~apK
Hat~aY tagiyba Al$~amosu fiY Alr~aj~aAfi
[The feeders with fat every evening, until the sun disappeared in the sea]. (S, O.) ― -b2- And The day of resurrection: (Sh, O, K:) and the congregation [of the risen]. (K.) ― -b3- And raj~aAfN also signifies A certain kind of pace [app. with a jolting motion]. (O, K.)

raAjifN * [Putting into a state of motion, commotion, or agitation. ― -b2- And also, or Hum~aY raAjifN,] A fever attended with quaking, or shivering: (O, Msb, K:) deviating from rule [because Hum~aY is fem.]. (Msb.) ― -b3- [The fem., with p, app. applied to a she-camel or the like, occurs, accord. to Freytag, in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen, as meaning Moving the head in going along.]

Alr~aAjifapu * , in the Kur lxxix. 6, means The first blast [of the horn on the day of resurrection]: and Alr~aAdifapu, in the next verse, “ the second blast: ” (O, Bd, Jel, K:) or the former means the motionless bodies that shall be in a state of violent motion
at the time here spoken of, such as the earth and the mountains; because of the saying in the Kur [lxxiii. 14], yawpma tarojufu A@loA^aroDu waA@lojibaAlu: and the latter, “ the heaven, and the stars, which shall be cleft and scattered. ” (Bd.)

A_irojaAfN * inf. n. of 4 [q. v.]. (Msb.) [And hence, as a simple subst.,] sing. of [A^araAjiyfu in the phrase] A^araAjiyfu AlA^axobaAri [meaning Tales without truth, or reality: or evil tales, and discordant lies, uttered in order that people may become in a state of commotion, agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance, in consequence thereof: see 4]. (S.) You say, waqaEuwA fiY A^araAjiyfa [They fell into convulsing perplexities, arising from evil and discordant and false rumours or the like]. (AA, S and K in art. tE.)

AlmurojifaAni *
The basin and ewer (AlT~asotu waAlA_iboriyqu) [that are used for washing the hands before and after a meal]: because they produce a sound when one of them is knocked against the other: as though that sound told of the completion of the meal, and excited [the persons that had partaken thereof] to rise. (Har p. 228.) ― -b2- waAlmurojifuwna fiY Almadiynapi, in the Kur xxxiii. 60: see 4, in two places. [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 rajila * , (T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
rajala , (Msb, K,) inf. n. rajalN (T, S, M, Msb) and rujolapN, (T, TA,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) He (a man) went on foot, in a journey, by himself, [i. e.] having no beast whereon to ride; (T, TA;) he had no beast whereon to ride, (M, K, TA,) in a journey, so went on his feet: (TA:) or he remained going on foot: so says AZ; and Ks says the like: (S:) or he was, or became, strong to walk, or go on foot: (Msb:) and ↓ trj~l [in like manner] signifies he went on foot, (S, K, TA,) having alighted from his beast: (TA:) [used in the present day as meaning he alighted from his beast:] and ↓ trjulwA they alighted [upon their feet, or dismounted,] in war, or battle, to fight: and ↓ Artjl he (a man) went on his legs, or feet, for the purpose of accomplishing the object of his want. (TA.) ― -b2- rajila, (M, K,) aor.
rajala , (K,) [inf. n. rajalN, being similar to rakiba, aor.
rajala , inf. n. rakabN,] also signifies He (a man) was, or became, large in the rijol [i. e. leg, or foot]. (M, K: but omitted in some copies of the K.) ― -b3- And rujila, like EuniYa; and rajila, aor.
rajala ; inf. n. [of the former] rijolapN and [of the latter] rijolN; [so in the CK; but accord. to the rule of the K they should be rajolapN and rajolN, as neither is expressly said to be with kesr; or the latter may be correctly rijolN, as rajila is said to be like Ealima, of which the inf. n. is EilomN;] He had a complaint of his rijol [i. e. leg, or foot]: (CK; but omitted in other copies: both mentioned in the TA:) the latter verb is mentioned in this sense by El-Fárisee, and also on the authority of Kr. (TA.) ― -b4- And rajila mino rijolihi He was, or became, affected in his leg, or foot, by something that he disliked. (TA.) ― -b5- And rajila, aor.
rajala , (K, TA,) inf. n. rajalN, (TA,) He (a beast, such as a horse or the like,) had a whiteness in one of his rijolaAni [i. e. hind legs or feet], (K, TA,) without a whiteness in any other part. (TA.) -A2- rajila, aor.
rajala , (Msb, K,) inf. n. rajalN, (Msb, TA,) is also said of hair, (Msb, K,) meaning It was, or became, [wavy, or somewhat curly, i. e.] of a quality between lankness and crispness or curliness, (K,) or neither very crisp or curly, nor very lank, but between these two. (Msb, TA.) -A3- rajalahu, (CK, TA, omitted in some copies of the K,) [aor.
rajula , as in similar verbs,] inf. n. rajolN, (TA,) He, or it, hit, or hurt, his rijoli [i. e. leg, or foot]. (CK, TA.) ― -b2- rajala Al$~aApa, (S, K,) or, accord. to the O and the Mufradát, rajala Al$~aApa birijolihaA, (TA,) and ↓ ArtjlhA, (K,) He suspended the sheep, or goat, by its hind leg or foot: (S, O, K:) or the meaning is EaqalahaA birijolayohi [app. he confined its shank and arm together with his feet, by pressing his feet upon its folded fore legs while it was lying on the ground], (K,) or, as in the M, birjolihi [with his foot]. (TA.) ― -b3- rajalato waladahaA, (K,) inf. n. rajolN; in the copies of the M written ↓ raj~alato, with teshdeed; (TA;) She (a woman) brought forth her child preposterously, so that its legs came forth before its head. (K.) -A4- rajalahaA, namely, the mother of a young camel, (K,) aor.
rajula , inf. n. rajolN, (TA,) He sent the young one with her [to suck her whenever he would; as is implied by what immediately precedes]; as also ↓ A^arojalahaA: (K:) or AlfaSiyla ↓ A^arojalotu (so in two copies of the S and in the O) I left the young camel with his mother to such her whenever he pleased: (S, * O: [in one of my copies of the S rajalotu, which appears from what here follows to be a mistake:]) so says ISk: and he cites as an ex.,
Hat~aY fuTimaA ↓ musarohadN A^urojila
[Fat, and well nourished: he was left with his mother to such her when he pleased until he was weaned]. (O.) [See also rajalN, below; where it is explained as though a quasi-inf. n. of A^arojalotu in the sense here assigned to it in the S and O, or inf. n. of rajalotu in the same sense.] ― -b2- And rajala A^um~ahu, (S, K,) aor.
rajula , inf. n. rajolN, (S,) He (a young camel, S, or a lamb, or kid, or calf, K, TA) sucked his mother. (S, K.) ― -b3- rajalN also signifies The act of [the stallion's] leaping the mare: (O, K, TA:) [i. e., as inf. n. of rajala; for] one says, baAta AlHiSaAnu yurojulu Alxayola The stallion-horse passed the night leaping the mares. (TA; and so in the O, except that Alxyl is there omitted.) ― -b4- And rajala AlmaroA^apa He compressed the woman. (TA.) -A5- [Golius says that rajula signifies Vir et virili animo fuit; as on the authority of J; and that rujolapN is its inf. n.: but it seems that he found Alr~ujolapu incorrectly explained in a copy of the S as maSodaru rajula instead of maSodaru Alr~ajuli: ISd expressly says that rujolapN and its syns. (explained below) are of the number of those inf. ns. that have no verbs.]

2 raj~alato waladahaA * [app. a mistranscription]: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. -A2- tarojiylN [the inf. n.] signifies The making, or rendering, strong. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) -A3- rj~l Al$~aEara, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. tarojiylN, (S, Msb, K,) He made the hair to be [wavy, or somewhat curly, i. e.] not very crisp or curly, nor lank, (S,) or in a state between that of lankness and that of crispness or curliness: (K:) or he combed the hair; (Msb, TA;) either his own hair, [see 5,] or that of another: (Msb:) or he combed down the hair; i. e., let it down, or made it to hang down, by means of the comb: (Mgh:) Er-Rághib says, as though he made it to descend at the rijol [or foot], i. e. from its places of growth; but this requires consideration: (MF:) or he combed and anointed the hair: (TA voce EasibN:) or he washed and combed the hair. (Ham p. 356.)

4 Arjlhu *
He made him to go on foot; (S, K, TA;) to alight from his beast. (TA.) -A2- And He granted him some delay, or respite; let him alone, or left him, for a while. (S, K.) ― -b2- A^arojalotu AlHiSaAna fiY Alxayoli I sent-the stallion-horse among the mares. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in three places.

5 taraj~ala see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- trj~l fiY Albiy^ori, (S, Msb, K,) and trj~l Albiy^ora, (K,) He descended into the well (S, Msb, K) [by means of his feet, or legs, alone, i. e.,] without his being let down, or lowered, or suspended [by means of a rope]. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- trj~l Alz~anoda, and ↓ Artjlhu, [or, more probably, Artjl Alz~anodapa, and trj~lhA, (see murotajilN,)] He put the znd [or the zndp; (the former meaning the upper, and the latter the lower, of the two pieces of wood used for producing fire,)] beneath his feet: (M, K:) or ↓ Artjl signifies he (a man come from a distant country) struck fire, and held the zanod [here app. meaning (as in many other instances) the znd properly so called and the zndp] with his hands and his feet, [i. e. the znd with his hands and the zndp with his feet,] because he was alone. (TA. [See murotajilN.]) -A2- [trj~l He became a rajul, or man; he rose to manhood. (See an explanation of trj~l Aln~ahaAru, in what follows.) And] trj~lt She (a woman, TA) became like a rajul [or man] (K, TA) in some of her qualities, or states, or predicaments. (TA.) ― -b2- trj~l Aln~ahaAru i. q. AirotafaEa (tropical:) [i. e. The day became advanced, the sun being somewhat high]; (S, IAth, O, K, TA;) it being likened to the rising of a man from youth; (IAth, TA;) and so AlnhAr ↓ Artjl: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the former means the sun went down from [or below] the walls; as though it alighted (kaA^an~ahaA taraj~alato [in a proper sense of this verb: see 1, first sentence]). (TA.) -A3- And trj~l He combed his own hair: (Msb:) or he combed down his own hair; i. e., let it down, or made it to hang down, by means of the comb: (Mgh:) or he anointed [or washed] and combed his own hair. (TA. [See 2.]) Hence, nahaY
Eani Alt~araj~uli A_il~aA gib~FA (Mgh, TA) He [Mohammad] forbade the anointing and combing of one's own hair except it be less frequent than every day. (TA.)

8 Artjl * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Said of a horse, (in his running, TA,) He mixed the pace termed AlEanaq with that termed Alhamolajap, (T, TA,) or the former pace with somewhat of the latter, and thus, (S,) he went those two paces alternately, (S, K,) somewhat of the former and somewhat of the latter. (S.) -A2- He took a man by his rijol [i. e. leg, or foot]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Artjl Al$~aApa: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph. ― -b3- Artjl Alr~anoda [or Alz~anodapa], and Artjl alone in a similar sense: see 5, in two places. -A3- [He extemporized a speech or verses; spoke it or them extemporaneously, impromptu, or without premeditation;] he began an oration (a xuTobap), and poetry, without his having prepared it beforehand; (S;) he spoke a speech (Msb, K) without consideration or thought, (Msb,) or without his having prepared it; (K;) he recited it, or related it, standing, without forecast, consideration, thought, or meditation; so accord. to Er-Rághib [who seems to have held this to be the primary signification of the verb when relating to a speech or the like]; or without reiteration, and without pausing, halting, or hesitating. (TA.) And Artjl Al$~aYo'a [He did, performed, or produced, the thing without premeditation, or previous preparation]. (TA in art. xrE.) [And Artjl A@somFA He coined a name.] ― -b2- Artjl biraA^oyihi He was, or became, alone, or independent of others, with none to take part or share or participate with him, in his opinion, (Msb, K, TA,) without consulting any one respecting it, (Msb, TA,) and kept constantly, or perseveringly, to it. (Msb.) [Hence,] A^amoruka maA A@rotajalota Thine affair [to which thou shouldst keep] is that respecting which thou art alone [&c.] in thine opinion. (K.) And Airotajilo maA A@rotajalota mina AlA^amori is explained in the T as meaning Airokabo maA rakibota minohu [i. e. Undertake thou what thou hast undertaken of the affair: but it may rather signify keep thou to what thou hast undertaken of the affair; agreeably with what here follows]. (TA.) One says also, ↓ Airotajilo rajolaka Keep thou to thine affair: (IAar, M, K, TA:) in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, rajalaka. (TA.) -A4- He collected a detached number (qiToEap [or rijol]) of locusts, to roast, or fry, them. (S.) -A5- He set up a mirojal [q. v.], to cook food in it: (T, TA:) or he cooked food in a mirojal. (K.) -A6- Artjl Aln~ahaAru: see 5.

10 Astrjl *
He desired, or requested, to be, or to go, on foot. (KL.)

rajolN * : see rajulN: ― -b2- and raAjilN; the latter in two places. -A2- See also rajilN, in two places. -A3- Airotajilo rajolaka, in some of the copies of the K, erroneously, rajalaka: see 8, near the end of the paragraph.

rijolN * [The leg of a human being and of a bird, and the kind leg of a quadruped; in each of these senses opposed to yadN;] the part from the root of the thigh to the [sole of] the foot of a man [and of any animal]; (Mgh, Msb, K:) rijolu AlA_inosaAni meaning that [limb] with which the man walks: (Msb:) or the foot of a man [and of a bird, and the kind foot of a quadruped: or rather it signifies thus in many instances; but generally as before explained: and sometimes, by a synecdoche, it is used in a yet larger sense, as will be explained below]: (K:) of the fem. gender: (Zj, Msb, TA:) pl. A^arojulN: (S, Msb, K, &c.:) it has no other pl. (Msb, TA) known to Sb; (TA;) the pl. of pauc. being also used as a pl. of mult. in this instance. (IJ, TA.) [Hence,] Alr~ijolu jubaArN [The hind leg or foot, or it may here mean the leg or foot absolutely, is a thing of which no account, or for which no retaliation or mulct, is taken]: i. e., if a beast tread upon a man with its rijol, there is no retaliation or mulct, if in motion; but if the beast be standing still in the road, or way, the rider is responsible, whether it strike with a yad or a rijol. (TA.) And huwa qaAy^imN EalaY rijolK [lit. He is standing upon a single leg; meaning] (assumed tropical:) he is setting about, or betaking himself to, an affair that presses severely, or heavily, upon him, or that straitens him. (T, K, TA. [In the CK, Hazanahu is erroneously put for Hazabahu.]) And A^anaA EalaY rijolK (assumed tropical:) I am in fear, or fright, lest a thing should escape me. (TA.) ― -b2- *uw Alr~ijoli [as though meaning The onelegged;] a certain idol, of El-Hijáz. (TA.) ― -b3- rijolu Aljab~aAri (assumed tropical:) The very bright star [3, called by our astronomers “ Rigel, ” and also called by the Arabs rijolu AljawozaA='i AlyusoraY,] upon the left foot of Orion. (Kzw.) [And rijolu AljawozaA='i AlyumonaY (assumed tropical:) The star k upon the right leg of Orion.] ― -b4- rijolu AlguraAbi (assumed tropical:) A certain plant, (K,) called also rijolu Alr~aAgi, the root, or lower part, of which, when cooked, is good for chronic diarrhœa; mentioned in art. grb [q. v.]. (TA.) Also A certain mode of binding the udder of a camel, so that the young one cannot suck, therewith, nor will it undo: (S, K:) whence the phrase Sar~a rijola AlguraAbi, for Sar~a Sar~FA mivola Sar~irijoli AlguraAbi. (TA.) El-Kumeyt says,
Sar~a rijola AlguraAbi mulokuka fiY Aln~aA
si EalaY mano A^araAda fiyhi AlfujuwraA
(assumed tropical:) [Thy dominion among the people has bound with a bond not to be undone him who desires, within the scope of it, transgression]: (S, TA:) i. e. thy dominion has become firm so that it cannot be undone; like as what is termed rjl AlgrAb cannot be undone by the young camel. (TA.) And one says, Sur~a Ealayohi rijolu AlguraAbi, meaning (tropical:) The affair was, or became, difficult to him: (K and TA in art. grb:) or his life, or subsistence, was, or became, difficult to him. (TA in that art.) ― -b5- rijolu AljaraAdi (assumed tropical:) A certain plant, like Albaqolapu AlyamaAniy~apu [see art. bql: accord. to Golius, the former appellation is applied to a species of atriplex, or orache]. (IAar, K.) ― -b6- [And several other plants have similar appellations in the present day.] ― -b7- rijolu AlT~aAy^iri (assumed tropical:) A certain miysam [i. e. branding-instrument, or brand]. (S, K.) ― -b8- rijolu AlbaAbi (assumed tropical:) The foot, or heel, of the door, upon which it turns in a socket in the threshold. (MA.) ― -b9- rijolu Alqawosi (assumed tropical:) The lower curved extremity of the bow; (Kh, S, K;) the upper curved extremity being called its yad: (Kh, S:) or the part below its kabid [q. v.]: accord. to AHn, it is more complete, or perfect, than its yd: accord. to IAar, A^arojulu Alqawosi means, when the string is bound, or braced, the upper parts of the bow; and A^ayodiyhaA, its lower parts; and the former are stronger than the latter: and he cites the saying,
layota AlqisY~a kul~uhaA mino A^arojuli
[Would that the bows were all of them, or wholly, of what are termed A^arojul]: the two extremities of the bow, he says, are called its ZuforaAni; and its two notches, its furoDataAni; and its curved ends, its siy^ataAn$; and after the sy^tAn are the TaAy^ifaAni; and after the TAy^fAn, the A^aboharaAni; and the portion between the AbhrAn is its kabid; this being between the two knots of the suspensory. (TA.) ― -b10- rijolaA Als~ahomi (assumed tropical:) The two extremities of the arrow. (K, * TA. [In the former it is implied that the phrase is rijolu Als~ahomi.]) ― -b11- rijolu baHorK (tropical:) A canal (xlyj) of a bHr [or large river]. (Kr, K, TA.) ― -b12- rijolN also signifies (tropical:) A part, or portion, of a thing: (K, TA:) of the fem. gender. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, A^ahodaY lanaA A^abuw bakorK rijola $aApK ma$owiy~apK faqasamotuhaA A_il~aA katifihaA, meaning (tropical:) [Aboo-Bekr gave to us] the half of a roasted sheep, or goat, divided lengthwise [and I divided it into shares, except its shoulder-blade, or its shoulder]: she called the half thus by a synecdoche: (IAth, O, TA:) or she meant the leg (rjol) thereof, with what was next to it [for mmA yaliyhaA in the O and TA, I read bimaA yaliyhaA] of the lateral half: or she thus alluded to the whole thereof, like as one does by the term raA^os. (O, TA. [But see what here next follows.]) And in another trad., the rijol of a [wild] ass is mentioned as a gift, meaning (tropical:) One of the two lateral halves: or, as some say, the thigh: (TA:) and it is explained as meaning the whole; but this is a mistake. (Mgh.) ― -b13- Also (assumed tropical:) The half of a raAwiyap [or pair of leathern bags, such as are borne by a camel, one on each side,] of wine, and of olive-oil. (AHn, K.) ― -b14- It is also applied by some to (assumed tropical:) A pair of trousers or drawers; and rijolu saraAwiyla occurs in this sense in a trad., for rijolaA saraAwiyla; like zawoju xuf~K and zawoju naEolK, whereas each is properly zawojaAni; for the srAwyl are of the articles of clothing for the two legs: (IAth, TA:) this is what is meant by the saying in the K [and in the O likewise] that Alr~ijolu also signifies Als~araAwiylu [app. for mina Als~araAwiyli AlT~aAqu]. (TA.) ― -b15- Also (assumed tropical:) A swarm, or numerous assemblage, of locusts: (S:) or a detached number (qiToEapN) thereof: (K:) [or] one says [or says also] rijolu jaraAdK, (S, TA,) and
rijolN mino jaraAdK: it is masc. and fem.: (TA:) a pl. without a proper sing.; like EaAnapN (a herd of [wild] asses, S) and xiyTN (a flock of ostriches, S) and SuiwaArN (a herd of [wild] bulls or cows, S): (S, K:) pl. A^arojaAlN; (K:) and so in the next two senses here following. (TA.) ― -b16- And hence, as being likened thereto, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) An army: (K:) or a numerous army. (TA.) ― -b17- Also (assumed tropical:) A share in a thing. (IAar, K.) So in the saying, liY fiY maAlika rijolN (assumed tropical:) [To me belongs a share in thy property]. (TA.) ― -b18- And (tropical:) A time. (TA.) One says, kaAna *`lika EaliY rijoli fulaAnK (tropical:) That was in the time of such a one; (S, K, TA;) in his life-time: (K, TA:) like the phrase ElY raA^osi fulaAnK. (TA.) ― -b19- Also (assumed tropical:) Precedence. (Abu-l- Mekárim, K.) When the files of camels are collected together, an owner, or attendant, of camels says, liYa Alr~ijolu, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The precedence belongs to me; or] I precede: and another says, laA bali Alr~ijolu liY (assumed tropical:) [Nay, but the precedence belongs to me]: and they contend together for it, each unwilling to yield it to the other: (Abu-l-Mekárim, TA:) pl. A^arojaAlN: (K:) and so in the senses here following. (TA.) ― -b20- And (assumed tropical:) Distress; straitness of the means of subsistence or of the conveniences of life; a state of pressing want; misfortune; or calamity; and poverty. (O, K.) -A2- Also A man who sleeps much: (O, K:) fem. with p. (TA.) ― -b2- And A man such as is termed qaA*uwrapN [which means foul in language; evil in disposition: one who cares not what he does or says: very jealous: one who does not mix, or associate as a friend, with others, because of the evilness of his disposition, nor alight with them: &c.: see art. q*r]. (O, K.) -A3- Also Blank paper; (O, K, * TA;) without writing. (TA.)

rajalN * : see raAjilu, first sentence: -A2- and see also rajilN, in two places. -A3- [It is also explained as here follows, as though a quasi-inf. n. of 4 in a sense mentioned in the first paragraph on the authority of the S and O, or inf. n. of rajala in the same sense; thus:] The sending, (S, O,) or leaving, (K, TA,) a lamb or kid or calf, (S, O, TA,) or a young camel, (K, TA,) and a colt, (TA,) with its mother, to such her whenever it pleases: (S, O, K:) [but I rather think that this is a loose explanation of the meaning implied by rajalN used as an epithet; for it is added in the S and O immediately, and in the K shortly after, that] one says bahomapN rajalN (S, O, K) and ↓ rajilN (K) [meaning, as indicated in the S and O, A lamb, or hid, or calf, sent with its mother to such her whenever it pleases, or, as indicated in the K, sucking, or that sucks, its mother]: pl. A^arojaAlN. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- Also A horse [i. e. a stallion] sent upon the xayol [meaning mares, to leap them]: (K:) and in like manner one says xayolN rajalN, [using it as a pl., app. meaning horses so sent,] (K accord. to the TA,) or ↓ xayolN rajilapN. (CK, and so in my MS. copy of the K: [perhaps it should be rajalapN.])

rajulN * (S, O, Mgh, Msb, K &c.) and ↓ rajolN, (O, K,) the latter a dial. var., (O,) or, accord. to Sb and El-Fárisee, a quasi-pl. n., [but app. of raAjilN, not of rajulN,] called by Abu-l-Hasan a pl., (TA,) A man, as meaning the male of the human species; (Msb;) the opposite of AimoraA^apN: (S, O, Mgh:) applied only to one who has attained to puberty and manhood: (K, * TA:) or as soon as he is born, (K, TA,) and afterwards also: (TA:) pl. rijaAlN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) [applied in the Kur lxxii. 6 to men and to jinn (or genii), like naAsN and A^unaAsN, and likewise a pl. of raAjilN, and of its syn. rajolaAnu,] and rjaAlaAtN, (S, K,) said by some to be a pl. pl., (TA,) and ↓ rajolapN, (Sb, Msb, K, TA, in the CK rijolapN, [which is a mistake, as is shown by what follows,]) of the measure faEolapN, with fet-h to the f, (Msb,) [but this is, properly speaking, a quasi-pl. n.,] said to be the only instance of its kind except kamoA^apN, which, however, some say is a n. un. like others of the same form belonging to [coll.] gen. ns., (Msb,) used as a pl. of pauc. instead of A^arojaAlN, (Sb, Ibn-Es-Serráj, Msb, TA,) because they assigned to rajulN no pl. of pauc., (Sb, TA,) not saying A^arojaAlN (TA) [nor rijolapN], and ↓ rajilapN, mentioned by AZ as another pl., but this [also] is a quasi-pl. n., and of it Abu-l-' Abbás holds ↓ rajolapN to be a contraction, (TA,) and rijalapN (Ks, K) and A^araAjilu (Ks, S, K) and [another quasi-pl. n. is] ↓ marojalN. (IJ, K.) $ahiydayoni mino rijaAlikumo, in the Kur [ii. 282], means [Two witnesses] of the people of your religion. (TA.) [rajulN also signifies A woman's husband: and the dual] rajulaAni [sometimes] means A man and his wife; predominance being thus attributed to the former. (IAar, TA.) And ↓ rajulapN signifies A woman: (S, K:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, a woman who is, or affects to be, or makes herself, like a man in some of her qualities, or states, or predicaments. (TA.) It is said of 'Áïsheh, (S, TA,) in a trad., which confirms this latter explanation, (TA,) kaAnato Alr~aA^oYi, ↓ rajulapa, (S, TA,) meaning She was like a man in judgment. (TA. [See also marojalaAniy~apN.]) The dim. of rajulN is ↓ rujayolN and ↓ ruwayojilN: (S, K:) the former reg.: (TA:) the latter irreg., as though it were dim. of raAjilN: (S, TA:) [but it seems that ruwayojilN is properly the dim. of raAjilN, though used as that of rajulN.] One says, huwa rajulu waHodihi [He is a man unequalled, or that has no second], (IAar, L in art. wHd,) and waHodihi ↓ rujayolu [A little man (probably meaning the contrary) unequalled, &c.]. (S and L in that art.) And it is said in a trad., A_ino Sadaqa ↓ A^afolaHa Alr~uwayojilu [The little man prospers if he speak truth] (TA.) ― -b2- Also One much given to coition: (Az, O, K:) used in this sense by the Arabs of ElYemen: and some of the Arabs term such a one EuSofuwriY~N. (O, TA.) ― -b3- And i. q. raAjilN, q. v. (Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b4- And Perfect, or complete [in respect of bodily vigour or the like]: ('Eyn, O, K, TA: [in the CK, wAlr~Ajilu AlkaAmilu is erroneously put for wAlrAajl wAlkAml:]) or strong and perfect or complete: sometimes it has this meaning, as an epithet: and when thus used, Sb allows its being in the gen. case in the phrase, mararotu birajulK rajulK A^abuwhu [I passed by a man whose father is strong &c.]; though the nom. case is more common: he says, also, that when you say, huwa Alr~ajulu, you may mean that he is perfect or complete, or you may mean any man that speaks and that walks upon two legs. (M, TA.) -A2- [In the CK, $aEarN rajulN is erroneously put for $aEarN rajolN: and, in the same, rajulu Al$~aEari, as syn. with rajilu Al$~aEari, is app. a mistake for rajolu Al$~aEari; but it is mentioned in this sense by 'Iyád:] see the paragraph here following.

rajilN * ; and its fem., with p: see raAjilN. -A2- $aEarN rajilN (ISk, S, Msb, K) and ↓ rajalN (ISk, S, K) and ↓ rajolN, (Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, rajulN,]) Hair [that is wavy, or somewhat curly, i. e.] of a quality between [bayona, for which bay~inu is erroneously put in the CK,] lankness and crispness or curliness, (K,) or not very crisp or curly, nor lank, (ISk, S,) or neither very crisp or curly, nor very lank, but between these two. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And rajilu Al$~aEari and ↓ rajaluhu (ISd, Sgh, K) and ↓ rajoluhu (ISd, K, TA, but accord. to the CK as next follows,] and ↓ rajuluhu, with damm to the j, added by 'Iyád, in the Meshárik, (MF, TA,) A man having hair such as is described above: pl. A^arojaAlN and rajaAlaY; (M, K;) the former, most probably, accord. to analogy, pl. of rajolN; but both may be pls. of rajilN and rajalN: accord. to Sb, however, rajalN has no broken pl., its pl. being only rajaluwna. (M, TA.) -A3- See also rajalN, in two places.
rajolapN * : see rajulN, first sentence, in two places: ― -b2- and raAjilN. -A2- See also the next paragraph.

rujolapN * The going on foot; (T, S, * M, TA;) the act of the man who has no beast [to carry him]; (T, TA;) an inf. n. (T, S, TA) of rajila: (T, TA: [see 1, first sentence:]) or it signifies strength to walk, or go on foot; (Msb, K;) and is a simple subst.: (Msb:) and also excellence of a daAb~ap [meaning horse or ass or mule] and of a camel in endurance of long journeying; in which sense [Az says] I have not heard any verb belonging to it except [by implication] in the epithets rajiylapN, applied to a she-camel, and rajiylN, applied to an ass and to a man: (T, TA:) and (M) ↓ rijolapN, with kesr, signifies vehemence, or strength, of walking or going on foot; (M, K;) as also ↓ rajolapN. (K. [In the K is then added, “ or with damm, strength to walk, or go on foot; ” but it seems evident that we should read “ and with damm, ” &c., agreeably with the passage in the M, in which the order of the two clauses is the reverse of their order in the K.]) One says, Hamalaka A@ll~`hu Eani Alr~ujolapi and mina Alr~ujolapi, i. e. [May God give thee a beast to ride upon, and so relieve thee from going on foot, or] from the act of the man who has no beast. (T, TA.) And huwa *uw rujolapK He has strength to walk, or go on foot. (Msb.) ― -b2- And The state, or condition, of being a rajul [or man, or male human being; generally meaning manhood, or manliness, or manfulness]; (S, K;)
as also ↓ rujuwlapN (Ks, S, TA) and ↓ rujuwliy~apN (IAar, S, K) and ↓ rajuwliy~apN (Ks, T, K) and ↓ rujoliy~apN; (K) of the class of inf. ns. that have no verbs belonging to them. (ISd, TA.) -A2- And The having a complaint of the rijol [i. e. leg, or foot]. (TA.) ― -b2- And in a horse, (S,) or beast, (daAb~ap, K,) A whiteness, (K,) or the having a whiteness, (S,) in one of the rijolaAni [i. e. hind legs or feet], (S, K,) without a whiteness in any other part; (TA;) as also ↓ tarujiylN (K.) This is disliked, unless there be in him some other [similar] waDaH. (S.)

rijolapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence. -A2- [Also, accord. to the K, a pl. of raAjlN or of one of its syns.] -A3- And A herd, or detached number collected together, of wild animals. (IB, TA.) -A4- And A place in which grow [plants, or trees, of the kind called] Earofaj, (K,) accord. to Az, in which grow many thereof, (TA,) in one rawoDap [or meadow]. (K.) ― -b2- And A water-course, or channel in which water flows, (S, K,) from a [stony tract such as is called] Har~ap to a soft, or plain, tract: (K:) pl. rijalN; (S, K;) a term similar to ma*aAnibu [pl. of mi*onabN]: so says Er-Rághib: the waters (he says) pour to it, and it retains them: and on one occasion he says, the rijolap is like the qariy~; it is wide, and people alight in it: he says also, it is a water-course of a plain, or soft, tract, such as is mlbAv, or, as in one copy, minobaAt [which is app. the right reading, meaning productive of much herbage]. (TA.) -A5- Alrijolapu also signifies A species of the [kind of plants called] HayoD. (K.) ― -b2- And, accord. to [some of] the copies of the K [in this place], The Earofaj; but correctly the farofax [as in the CK here, and in the K &c. in art. frfx]; (TA;) i. q. Albaqolapu AlHamuqaA='u; (S, Msb, TA;) thus the people commonly called it; i. e. AlbqlpAlHmqA='; (TA;) [all of these three appellations being applied to Purslane, or purslain; and generally to the garden purslane:] it is [said to be] called AlHmqA=' because it grows not save in a water-course: (S: [i. e. the wild sort: but see art. Hmq:]) whence the saying, A^aHomaqu mino rijolapK [explained in art. Hmq], (S, K,) meaning this baqolap: (TA:) the vulgar say, mino rijolihi. (S, K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, mn rajolapK.])
rajulapN * : see rajulN in two places.
rajilapN * a quasi-pl. n. of rajulN q. v. (TA.) -A2- [Also fem. of the epithet rajilN.]

rjolay * fem. of rajolaAnu: see raAjilN near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- Har~apN rajolay and ↓ rajolaA='u A [stony tract such as is called] Har~ap that is rough [or rugged], in which one goes on foot: or level, but abounding with stones: (K:) or rough and difficult, in which one cannot go except on foot: (TA:) or the latter signifies level, but abounding with stones, in which it is difficult to go along: (S:) or hard and rough, which horses and camels cannot traverse, and none can but a man on foot: (AHeyth, TA:) or that impedes the feet by its difficulty. (Er-Rághib, TA.) -A2- rajolay is also a pl. of rajolaAnu: (S:) [and app. of rajiylN also.]
rajolaA='u * fem. of A^arojalu [q. v.]. ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

rajaliy~N * sing. of rajaliy~uwna, which latter is applied, with the article Al to Certain men who used to run (kaAnuwA yaEoduwna, so in the O and K, but in the T yagozuwna [which is evidently a mistranscription], TA) upon their feet; as also ↓ rujayolaA='u, in like manner with the article Al: (O, K, TA:) in the T, the sing. is written rajoliy~N; and said to be a rel. n. from Alr~ujolapu; which requires consideration: (TA:) they were Suleyk El-Makánib, (O, K, TA,) i. e. Ibn-Sulakeh, (TA,) and El-Munteshir Ibn-Wahb El-Báhilee, and Owfà Ibn-Matar ElMázinee. (O, K, TA. [All these were famous runners.])
rujoliy~apN * : see rujolapN.
rajolaAnu * ; and its fem., rajolay: see raAjilN.
rujaAlN * [a quasi-pl. n.] : see raAjilN.

rajiylN * : see raAjilN, in two places. ― -b2- Also i. q. ma$~aA='N; and so ↓ raAjilN; (K;) i. e. (TA) [That walks, or goes on foot, much; or a good goer; or] strong to walk, or go, or go on foot; (S, in explanation of the latter, and TA;) applied to a man, (S, K, TA,) and to a camel, and an ass: (TA:) or the latter, a man that walks, or goes on foot, much and well: and strong to do so,. with patient endurance: and a beast, such as a horse or an ass or a mule, and a camel, that endures long journeying with patience: fem. with p: (T, TA:) or, applied to a horse, that does not become attenuated, or chafed, abraded, or worn, in the hoofs [by journeying] : (S, O:) or, so applied, that does not sweat: and rendered submissive, or manageable; broken, or trained: (K, * TA:) the fem., with p is also applied to a woman, as meaning strong to walk, or go on foot: (TA:) pl. rajolay [most probably of rajiylN, agreeably with analogy,] and rajaAlay. (K.) ― -b3- Also A place of which the two extremities are far apart: (M, K, * TA:) in the copies of the K, AlT~ariyqayoni is here erroneously put for AlT~arafayoni: and the M adds, trodden, or rendered even, or easy to be travelled: (TA:) or rugged and hard land or ground: (O, TA:) and a hard place: and a rugged, difficult, road, in a mountain. (TA.) -A2- Also, applied to speech, i. q. ↓ murotajalN [i. e. Extemporized; spoken extemporaneously, impromptu, or without premeditation]. (O, K, TA.)
rujayolN * dim. of rajulN, which see, in two places.
rujuwlapN * : see rujolapN.
rajuwliy~apN * : see rujolapN.
rujuwliy~apN * : see rujolapN.
rujayolaA='u * : see rajaliy~N ― -b2- waladatohaA Alr~ujayolaA='a They (sheep or goats) brought them forth [i. e. their young ones] one after another. (El-Umawee, T, S, O, K.)

raj~aAlN *
i. q. raAjilN, q. v. (Az, TA.)
raj~aAlapN * : quasi-pl. ns. of raAjilN, q. v.
ruj~aAlay * : quasi-pl. ns. of raAjilN, q. v.

raAjilN * (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ rajulN, (Mgh, Msb, K,) the latter of the dial. of El-Hijáz, (MF,) in copies of the M written ↓ rajalN, (TA,) and ↓ rajilN (S, K) and ↓ rajiylN [afterwards mentioned as a quasi-pl. n.] (K) and ↓ rajolaAnu (S, K) and ↓ rajolN, (K,) but this last is said by Sb to be a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) Going, or a goer, on foot; a pedestrian; a footman; the opposite of faArisN; (S, Msb;) one having no beast whereon to ride, (K, TA,) in a journey, and therefore going on his feet: (TA:) see also rajiylN : pl. ↓ raj~aAlapN, (Ks, T, S, M, Msb, K,) [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.,] written by MF rijaAlapN, as on the authority of AHei, but the former is the right, (TA,) and ruj~aAlN (Ks, T, S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ rajolN, (S, Msb, TA,) this last mentioned before as being said by Sb to be a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) like SaHobN (S, Msb, TA) and rakobN, and occurring in the Kur xvii. 66, (TA,) all of raAjilN, (S, Msb,) and rijaAlN, (S, M, K,) of rajolaAnu (S) and of raAjilN, (TA,) [but more commonly of rajulN, q. v.,] and rajolay, (S, O, K,) of rajolaAnu, (S, O,) and rajaAlay, (S, M, K,) of rajilN, (S,) or of rajolaAnu, (TA,) and rujaAlay and rujolaAnN, (M, K,) which last is of raAjilN or of rajiylN, (TA,) and rijolapN [a pl. of pauc.], (M, K,) written by MF rajalapN, and if so, of raAjilN, like as katabapN is pl. of kaAtibN, (TA,) and ↓ rajolapN, (T, M, K,) [but this is a quasi-pl. n., mentioned before as of rajulN, q. v.,] and A^arojilapN, (M, K,) which may be pl. of rijaAlN, which is pl. of raAjilN, (IJ,) and A^araAjilu, (M, K,) which may be pl. of the pl. A^arojilapN, (IJ,) and A^araAjiylu, (M, K,) and to the foregoing pls. mentioned in the K are to be added (TA) rijalapN, (Ks, M, TA) which is of rajulN, (TA,) and ruj~alN, like suk~arN, (AHei, TA,) and [the quasi-pl. ns.] ↓ ruj~aAlay, (Ks, T, M, AHei, TA,) termed by MF an anomalous pl., (TA,) and ↓ rujaAlN, (AHei, TA,) said by MF to be extr., of the class of ruxaAlN, (TA,) and ↓ rajiylN, (AHei, TA,) said to be a quasi-pl. n. like maEiyzN and kaliybN. (TA.) Az says, I have heard some of them say ↓ raj~aAlN as meaning raAjilN; and its pl. is rajaAjiylu. (TA.) And raAjilapN and ↓ rajilapN are applied in the same sense to a woman, (Lth, TA,) and so is ↓ rajolay [fem. of rajolaAnu, like gaDobay fem. of gaDobaAnu]: (S:) and the pl. [of the first] is rawaAjilu (TA) and ([of the first or second or] of the third, S) rijaAlN (Lth, S, TA) and rajaAlay. (S.) ― -b2- Lh mentions the saying, laA tafoEalo ka*aA A^um~uka raAjilN, but does not explain it: it seems to mean [Do not thus:] may thy mother mourn, and be bereft of thee. (TA.) -A2-
naAqapN raAjilN EalaY waladihaA means A she-camel [left to give suck to her young one,] not having her udder bound with the SiraAr [q. v.]. (K.)

raAjilapN * The pastor's kabo$ [or ram] upon which he conveys, or puts to be borne, his utensils. (AA, O, K.) So in the saying of a poet,
faZal~a yaEomitu fiY qawoTK waraAjilapK
yukaf~itu Ald~ahora A_il~aA rayova yahotabidu
