(AA, TA,) meaning [And he passed the day] spinning from a portion of wool [wound in the form of a ring upon his hand], termed Eamiytah, [amid a flock of sheep, with a ram upon which he conveyed his utensils,] ever collecting [to himself], and coveting, or labouring to acquire, save when he was sitting cooking habiyd [i. e. colocynths or their seeds or pulp]. (T and TA in art. Emt: where rAjlp is likewise explained as above.)
ruwayojilN * : see rajulN, in two places.

A^arojalu * A man large in the rijol [i. e. leg, or foot]: (S, K:) like A^arokabu “ large in the knee, ” and A^aroA^asu “ large in the head. ” (TA.) ― -b2- And A horse, (S,) or beast, (daAb~ap, K,) having a whiteness in one of his rijolaAni [i. e. hind legs or feet], (S, K,) without a whiteness in any other part. (TA.) This is disliked, unless there be in him some other [similar] waDaH. (S. [See also 2 in art. xdm.]) The fem. is rajolaA='u, (S, K,) which is applied in like manner to a sheep or goat: (S:) or to a ewe as meaning whose rijolaAni [or hind legs] are white to the flanks, (M, TA,) or with the flanks, (T, TA,) the rest of her being black. (TA.) ― -b3- Har~apN rajolaA='u: see rajolaY. -A2- huwa A^arojalu Alr~ajulayoni means [He is the more manly, or manful, of the two men; or] he has rujoliy~ap that is not in the other [of the two men]: (T, TA:) or he is the stronger of the two men. (K.) ISd thinks Arjl in this case to be like A^aHonaku, as having no verb. (TA.)

A^araAjiylu * app. a pl. of A^arojilapN, which may be pl. of rijaAlN, which is pl. of raAjilN [q. v.] (TA.) ― -b2- Also Men accustomed to, or in the habit of, taking, capturing, catching, snaring, or trapping, game or wild animals or the like, or birds, or fish; hunters, fowlers, or fishermen. (Sgh, K.)
tarojiylN * : see rujolapN, last signification.

taraAjiylu *
i. q. karafosN [q. v., i. e. The herb smallage]; (K;) of the dial. of the Sawád; one of the herbs, or leguminous plants, of the gardens. (TA.).
marojalN * : see rajulN, of which it is a quasi-pl. n. : -A2- and mirojalN.
murjilN * A woman that brings forth men-children; (M, TA;) i. q. mu*okirN, (M, K, TA,) which is the epithet commonly known. (M, TA.)

mirojalN *
A copper cooking-pot: (S, Mgh, Msb:) or a large copper cooking-pot: (Ham p. 469:) or a cooking-pot of stones [or stone], and of copper: (K:) or any cooking-pot (Mgh, Msb, TA, and Ham ubi suprà) or vessel in which one cooks: (TA:) of the masc. gender: (K:) pl. maraAjilu. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b2- And A comb. (Mgh, K.) ― -b3- Also, and ↓ marojalN, (K,) the latter on the authority of IAar alone, (TA,) A sort of [garment of the kind called] burod, of the fabric of El-Yemen: (K:) pl. as above, maraAjilu; with which maraAHil, occurring in a trad., is said in the T, in art. rHl, to be syn.: [and ↓ burodN mirojaliY~N signifies the same as mirojalN:] it is said in a prov.,
HadiyvFA kaAna buroduka mirojaliy~aA
[Recently thy burod was of the sort called mirojaliY~;] i. e. thou hast only recently been clad with the maraAjil, and usedst to wear the EabaA=': [whence it appears that the mirojal may be thus called because worn only by full-grown men:] so says IAar: it is said in the M that vawobN mirojaliY~N is from Almmrjl [i. e. Almumarojalu, perhaps a mistranscription for Almarojalu]: (TA:) [but] ↓ mumarojalN signifies a sort of garments, or cloths, variegated, or figured; (S and K in art. mrjl;) similar to the maraAjil, or similar to these in their variegation or decoration, or their figured forms; as explained by Seer and others; (TA in that art.;) [wherefore] Sb holds the m of maraAjilu to be an essential part of the word; (S in that art.;) and hence Seer and the generality of authors also say that it is a radical, though Abu-l-'Alà and some others hold it to be augmentative. (MF and TA in that art.)

mirojaliY~N *
A maker of cooking-pots [such as are called maraAjila, pl. of mirojalN]. (MA.) ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph.
marojalaAniy~apN * A woman who is, or affects to be, or makes herself, like a man in guise or in speech. (TA. [See also rajulapN, voce rajulN.])

muraj~alN * A skin, (Fr, TA,) or such as is termed a ziq~, (K,) that is stripped off [by beginning] from one riajol [or hind leg]; (Fr, K, TA;) or from the part where is the rijol (M, TA.) And $aApN muraj~alapN A sheep, or goat, skinned [by beginning] from one rijol: (Ham p. 667:) and in like manner ↓ marojuwlN applied to a ram. (Lh, K voce mazoquwqN, which signifies the contr. [like muzaq~aqN].) ― -b2- Also A [skin such as is termed] ziq~ full of wine. (As, O, K.) -A2- A [garment of the kind called] burod upon which are the figures of men; (K;) or upon which are the figures of of men. (TA.) ― -b2- And A garment, or piece of cloth, (O, TA,) and a burod, (TA,) ornamented in the borders. (O, K, TA.) -A3- Combed hair. (O, TA. [See its verb, 2.]) -A4- jaraAdN muraj~alN Locusts the traces of whose wings are seen upon the ground. (ISd, K.)

marojuwlN * A gazelle whose rijol [or hind leg] has fallen [and is caught] in the snare: when his yad [or fore leg] has fallen therein, he is said to be mayodiY~N. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph.
murotajalN * : see rajiylN, last sentence.

murotajilN * A man holding the zanod with his hands and feet, (K, TA,) because he is alone: (TA:) [i. e.] one who, in producing fire with the zanod, holds the lower zanodap with his foot [or feet]. (AA, TA. [See 5.]) -A2- One who collects a detached number (qiToEap [or rijol]) of locusts, to roast, or fry, them: (S:) one who lights upon a rijol of locusts, and roasts, or fries, some of them, (K, TA,) or, as in the M, cooks. (TA.)
mumarojalN * : see mirojalN.

2 rj~m Alqabora * , inf. n. tarojiymN, He placed upon the grave rujam [meaning large stones, to make a gibbous covering to it]. (TA.) It is related in a trad. of 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Mughaffal, that he said, laA turaj~imuwA qaboriY, i. e. Place not ye upon my grave rujam; meaning thereby that they should make his grave even with the ground, not gibbous and elevated: the verb is thus correctly, with tesh-deed: but the relaters of trads. say, ↓ lA tarojumuwA qbrY: (S:) [and it is said that] Alqabora ↓ rajama, (K, TA,) aor.
rajuma , inf. n. rajomN, (TA,) signifies Eal~amahu, (K,) i. e. He put a tombstone to the grave: (TK:) or he placed upon the grave rijaAm [a pl., like rujam, of rujomap]: (K:) or, accord. to Aboo-Bekr, laA qaboriY ↓ tarojumuwA means Wail not ye at my grave; i. e. say not, at it, what is unseemly; from Alr~ajomu signifying “ the act of reviling. ” (TA.)

3 muraAjamapN * [in its primary acceptation] is The mutual throwing, or casting, of stones; or the vying, or contending for superiority, in the throwing, or casting, of stones. (Mgh. [See also 6.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) The act of mutually reviling; or the vying in reviling; or so muraAjamapN biAlkalaAmi. (TA. [See, again, 6.]) ― -b3- And raAjm fiY AlkalaAmi, and AlEadowi, and AlHarobi, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He exerted himself to the utmost in vying, or contending for superiority, in speech, and in running, and in war, or battle. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And rAjm Eanohu, (K,) or Eano qawomihi, (S,) (tropical:) He defended him, or his people; or spoke, or pleaded, or contended, in defence of him, or of them: (S, K, TA:) and so daAraY. (TA.)

6 trAjmwA baAlHijaArapi *
They threw, or cast, stones, one at another; or vied, or contended for superiority, in throwing, or casting, stones, one at another: (S, TA:) and ↓ ArtjmwA signifies the like of this. (IAar, TA. [See also 3.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] trAjmt AlA_ibilu: see 8. ― -b3- And trAjmwA biAlkalaAmi (tropical:) They reviled one another; or vied in reviling one another. (TA. [See, again, 3.])

8 A_irotajama see 6. ― -b2- [Hence,] Artjmt AlA_ibilu, and ↓ trAjmt, (assumed tropical:) The camels beat [or battered] the ground (rajamati AlA^aroDa) with their feet: or went heavily, without slowness. (TA.) [See mirojamN: and see also 1, in two places.] ― -b3- And Artjm (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) lay one part upon another; was, or became, heaped, or piled, up, or together, or accumulated, one part upon, or overlying, another; (Aboo-Sa'eed, K, TA;) as also Artjn. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.)
10 jaA='ato tasotarojimu Aln~abiY~a * , said of a woman [who had committed adultery], means She came asking the Prophet for Alr~ajom [i. e. to be stoned.] (TA.)

Q. Q. 1 tarojama kalaAmahu *
He interpreted, or explained in another language, his speech. (S.) See art. trjm.

rajomN * , an inf. n. [of 1, q. v.], used as an appellative, (Bd in lxvii. 5,) A thing that is thrown, or cast, like as is a stone: pl. rujuwmN. (Bd ib., and K.) Hence, in the Kur (ubi suprà), wajaEalonaAhaA rujuwmFA lil$~ayaATiyni And we have made them things to be cast at the devils; meaning shooting stars: [see also rujumo:] or, as some say, we have made them to be [means of] conjectures to the devils of mankind; i. e., to the astrologers. (Bd, TA. [See another explanation in the first sentence of this art.]) -A2- Also A friend; or a true, or sincere, friend; or a special, or particular, friend; syn. xaliylN: and a cup-companion, or compotator. (Th, K.) See also the last signification in the next paragraph.

rajamN *
Stones (Msb, TA) that are placed upon a grave. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (Msb, TA,) A grave; (S, Msb, K, TA;) because stones are collected together upon it; (Msb;) as also ↓ rajomapN and ↓ rujomapN: (K:) the pl. of rajamN is A^arjaAmN: you say, h`*ihi A^arojaAmu EaAdK These are the graves of [the tribe of] 'Ád: (TA:) and ↓ rujomapN, of which the pl. is rujamN and rijaAmN, signifies also, like as does ↓ rujumN, stones, (K,) or high stones, (TA,) that are set up upon a grave: (K, TA:) or both these signify a sign [that is set up upon a grave; or a tombstone: see 2] : (K:) or the former of them (rujomapN) signifies stones collected together, (Lth, Msb, TA,) as though they were the graves of [the tribe of] 'Ád; (Lth, TA;) and its pl. is rijaAmN: (Msb:) or it is sing. of rujamN and rijaAmN which signify large stones, less then [such as are termed] riDaAm, (S,) or like riDaAm, (TA,) sometimes collected together upon a grave to form a gibbous covering to it. (S.) ― -b3- Also (i. e. rajamN) A well. (K.) ― -b4- And A [kind of oven such as is called] tan~uwr [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b5- And i. q. juforapN, with jym, accord. to the K, i. e. A round space in the ground: or, as in other lexicons, HuforapN [meaning a hollow, or cavity, in the ground, made by digging, or natural]. (TA.) -A2- Also Brothers, or brethren: [a quasipl. n.:] sing., accord. to Kr, ↓ rajomN and rajamN; [so that the latter is used as a sing. and as a pl.;] but (ISd says, TA) I know not how this is. (K, TA.) [See also rajomN.]
rujumN * The [shooting] stars that are cast [at the devils; like rujuwmN, as explained by some, pl. of rajomN, q. v.]. ― -b2- See also the second sentence of the next preceding paragraph.

rajomapN * : see rajamN, second sentence. ― -b2- [It is applied in the present day to Any heap of stones thrown together or piled up.] ― -b3- Also A [kind of turret, such as is called] manaArap, like a bayot [i. e. tent, or house, &c.], around which they used to circuit: a poet says,
↓ kamaA TaAfa biAlr~ajomapi Almurotajimo
[Like as when he who beat the ground circuited around the rjmp]. (TA.) ― -b4- rjmp [thus written, but perhaps it is ↓ rujomapN,] is also sing. of rijaAm signifying [Hills, or mountains, &c., such as are called] hiDaAb [pl. of haDobapN]. (AA, TA.)

rujomapN * : see rajamN, second sentence, in two places: ― -b2- and see also rajomapN. ― -b3- Also The hole, den, or subterranean habitation, of the hyena. (S, K.) ― -b4- And A thing by means of which a palm-tree that is held in high estimation is propped; (K;) also called rujobapN; i. e. a kind of wide bench of stone or brick (duk~aAnN) against which the palm-tree leans; as is said by Kr and AHn: the m is said to be a substitute for b; or, as ISd thinks, the word is a dial. var., like rujobapN. (TA.)

rijaAmN * i. q. mirojaAsN; (S, K;) i. e. A stone which is tied to the end of a rope, and which is then let down into a well, and stirs up its black mud, after which the water is drawn forth, and thus the well is cleansed: (TA:) sometimes it is tied to the extremity of the cross piece of wood of the bucket, in order that it may descend more quickly. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also A thing that is constructed over a well, and across which is then placed the piece of wood for the bucket. (AA, K.) And [the dual] rijaAmaAni Two pieces of wood that are set up over a well, (S, K, TA,) at its head [or mouth], (S, TA,) and upon which is set the pulley, (S, K, TA,) or some similar thing by means of which one draws the water. (TA.) ― -b3- Also a pl. of rujomapN. (S, Msb, K.)
rajuwmN * : see the next paragraph.

rajiymN * and ↓ marojuwmN Thrown at, or cast at, with stones. (S.) The former is said to be applied to the devil because he is cast at (mrjwm) with [shooting] stars. (TA.) [In the MA, ↓ rajuwmN, as well as rajiymN, is explained as signifying Stoned: but it is probably a mistranscription for marojuwmN.]
― -b2- Slain [in any manner, but generally meaning put to death by being stoned]. (S.) latakuwnan~a mina Almarojuwmiyna, in the Kur [xxvi. 116], is explained as meaning Thou shalt assuredly be of those slain in the most evil manner of slaughter: (TA:) or the meaning is, of those smitten with stones: or, (assumed tropical:) reviled. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b3- Also the former, (tropical:) Cursed, or accursed; and in this sense, i. e. biAll~aEonapi ↓ marojuwmN, applied to the devil. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Reviled; [and so ↓ marojuwmN, as shown above;] and in this sense, also, said to be applied to the devil: and so in the two senses here following. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Driven away; expelled; put, or placed, at a distance, away, or far away. (TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) Cut off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse; forsaken; or abandoned. (TA.)
rajiymapN * sing. of rajaAy^imu, which signifies Mountains at which stones are cast [app. from some superstitious motive, as is done by Arabs in the present day]. (TA.)
tarojamapN rjm trjm trjmh trjmp ; pl. taraAjimu: see art. trjm.
tarojumaAnN rjm trjmAn and turojumaAnN and tarojamaAnN; pl. taraAjimu and taraAjimapN: see art. trjm.

mirojamN * (tropical:) A horse that beats [or batters] the ground (yurojumu fiY AlA^aroDi, S, or yarojumu AlA^aroDa, K) with his hoofs: (S, K:) or that is as though he did thus: (TA:) or that runs vehemently: (Ham p. 158:) applied also in the first sense to a camel; implying commendation: or, as some say, heavy, without slowness. (TA.) And (tropical:) A strong man: as though his enemy were cast at with him: (S, K:) or a defender of his jinos [i. e. hind, or kindred by the father's side]. (A, TA.) IAar says, A man pushed another man, whereupon he [the latter] said, latajidan~iY *aA manokibK mirojamK warukonK midoEamK (assumed tropical:) [Thou shalt assuredly find me to be one having a strong shoulder-joint and a stay that is a means of support]. (TA: but there written without any syll. signs.) lisaAnN mirojamN means (assumed tropical:) A tongue copious in speech; or chaste, or perspicuous, therein; or eloquent: and strong, or potent. (TA. See also 1, last sentence but one.)

mirojamapN *
i. q. qa*~aAfapN [or qu*~aAfapN, which means A sling; and mirojaAmN, q. v., app. signifies the same]: pl. maraAjimu. (TA.)

muraj~amN * A narrative, or story, of which one is not to be made to know the real state: (S, K, TA:) or, as in some of the copies of the S, of which one knows not, or will not know, whether it be true or false: (TA:) or respecting which conjectures are formed. (Ham p. 494.)

mirojaAmN * [app. A sling; like mirojamapN;] a thing with which stones are cast; (K, TA;) i. q. qa*~aAfN [q. v.]: pl. maraAjiymu. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A camel that stretches out his neck in going along: or that goes strongly, or vehemently; (K, TA;) as though beating the pebbles (kaA^an~ahu yurojumu AlHaSaY) with his feet. (TA.)
marojuwmN * : see rajiymN, in three places.
maraAjimu * pl. of mirojamapN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Foul words: (M, K: *) a pl. of which no sing. is mentioned. (TA.)
muraAjimN * One casting [stones] at thee, thou casting at him. (Har p. 567.)
murotajimN * : see rajomapN.
mutarojimN * : see art. trjm.

1 rajana biAlmakaAni * , (S, K,) aor.
rajuna , (S,) inf. n. rujuwnN, He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place; (S, K;) as also ↓ Artjn; (K, * TK;) and kept to it, or became accustomed to it; (S, accord. to one copy;) and so dajana bihi. (S, * Msb, * K, * TA: all in art. djn.) ― -b2- And rajanato, (Fr, S, K,) aor.
rajuna ; (TA;) and rajinato, (Fr, S, K,) aor.
rajana ; (TA;) and rajunato; (K;) said of camels, (Fr, S, K,) &c.; (K;) They kept, or became accustomed, to the tents, or houses: (K, * TA:) and ↓ Arjnt said of a she-camel, she remained in [or at] the house, or tent. (TA.) ― -b3- And rajanati Ald~aAb~apu, (S, K,) aor.
rajuna , (TA,) inf. n. rujuwnN, The beast was confined, kept close, or shut up, and badly fed, (S, K,) so that it became lean: (S:) or was confined to the fodder in the dwelling, or place of abode. (K.) ― -b4- And rajana fiY AlT~aEaAmi, (Lh, TA,) aor.
rajuna , inf. n. rujuwnN, (L and TA in art. rmk,) [app. He kept constantly to the food;] he loathed nothing of the food; and so ramaka: and in like manner one says of the camel, rajana fiY AlEalafi [he kept constantly to the fodder; or loathed nothing thereof]. (Lh, TA.) ― -b5- And rujuwnN and rujuwnapN [inf. ns. of which the verb is not mentioned] A camel's feeding upon date-stones, and seeds, or grain. (TA.) -A2- rajana AlA^ibila, and ↓ ArjnhA, He confined the camels to feed them with fodder, not pasturing them, or not sending or driving or conducting them forth in the morning to the pasturage. (Fr, S.) And rajana raAHilatahu rajonFA $adiydFA He confined his riding-camel strictly in the house, making her to lie down upon her breast, and not feeding her with fodder. (ISh, TA.) And rajana daAb~atahu, (S, K,) inf. n. rajonN, (S,) He confined, kept close, or shut up, his beast, and fed it badly, (S, K,) so that it became lean: (S:) or confined his beast to the fodder in the dwelling, or place of abode; as also ↓ rj~nhA: (K:) or, accord. to J, [perhaps a mistake for Az, for it is not in either of my copies of the S,] on the authority of Fr, the former signifies he confined the beast from the pasturage, without fodder: and ↓ the latter, inf. n. tarojiynN, he confined, or restricted, the beast to fodder. (TA.) -A3- rajana fulaAnFA He was ashamed for himself, or of himself, or was bashful, or shy, with respect to such a one; he was abashed at him, or shy of him; or he shrank from him. (AZ, K.)
2 raj~ana see 1, latter part, in two places.
4 A^arojana as intrans. and trans.: see 1, in two places.

8 Artjn * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also It was, or became, heaped, or piled, up, or together, or accumulated, one part upon another; syn. Airotakama, (K,) and Airotajama. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA in art. rjm.) ― -b3- And, said of fresh butter, It was cooked [for the purpose of clarifying it] without its becoming clear, and became bad, or spoiled: (S, K, TA:) or it turned in the skin containing the churned milk: (TA:) or it became bad, or spoiled, in the churning: (TA in art. xlT:) from AirotijaAnu AlA_i*owaAbapi meaning the fresh butter's coming forth from the skin mixed with the thick milk, and being in that state put upon the fire, so that, when it boils, the thick milk appears mixed with the clarified butter. (TA.) Airotajanati Alz~ubodapu, meaning The piece of fresh butter became mixed up with the milk, is a prov., alluding to a difficult affair which one cannot find the way to adjust. (L in art. zbd.) ― -b4- Hence, (TA,) Artjn EalaY Alqawomi A^amoruhumo (assumed tropical:) The affair, or case, of the people, or party, became confused to them. (S, K. *)

raAjinN *
That keeps to the tents, or houses; domesticated, familiar, or tame; (S, TA;) like daAjinN: (S:) applied in this sense to a bird: (TA:) and in like manner raAjinapN applied to camels: (S, * TA:) and to a sheep or goat ($aAp), and a she-camel, that remains in [or at] the houses, or tents. (TA.) ― -b2- And $aApN raAjinN A sheep, or goat, confined, shut up, or kept close, and badly fed, so that it becomes lean. (S.)

1 rajawotuhu * , aor. A^arojuwhu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rajowN, (S, M, K,) or rujuw~N, (Msb,) and rajaA='N, (S, K, TA, &c., [in the CK erroneously written with the short A i. e., without the meddeh and ',]) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and rajaAwapN (S, K) and rajaApN, or rajaA='apN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) or both, (CK,) and marojaApN; (K;) and ↓ raj~ayotuhu, (S,) inf. n. tarojiyapN; (K;) and ↓ taraj~ayotuhu, (S, K, *) and ↓ Airotajayotuhu; (S, Msb, K; *) I hoped for him [or it; relating only to what is possible; syn. with A^amalotuhu; see rajaA='N, below]; all signify the same: (S:) and rajayotuhu, aor. A^arojiyhi, is a dial. var. of rajawotuhu: (Msb:) and rajiyahu, aor. yarojaAhu, like raDiyahu, is a dial. var. of rajaAhu, aor. yarojuwhu, accord. to Lth: it is disapproved by Az, because heard by him on no other authority than that of Lth; but it is mentioned also by ISd. (TA.) One says, maA A^atayotuka A_il~aA rajaAwapa Alxayori [I did not, or have not, come to thee except hoping for that which is good]. (S.) No regard is to be paid to the assertion of Lth, that the saying faEalotu rajaApa ka*aA [I did a thing hoping for such a thing] is a mistake, and that the correct word is only rajaA='a; for rajaApN occurs in a trad., and in the poetry of the Arabs. (TA.) ― -b2- Sometimes rajowN, (S,) or rujuw~N, (Msb,) has the meaning of xawofN; (S, Msb;) because the hoper fears that he may not attain the thing for which he hopes; (Msb;) and so rajaA='N; (T, S;) but only when there is with it a negative particle: (Fr, T, TA:) you say, maA rajawotuka (assumed tropical:) I feared not
thee: but you do not say, rajawotuka, meaning I feared thee: (TA:) the saying in the Kur [lxxi. 12], maA lakumo laA tarojuwna lil~`hi waqaArFA means (assumed tropical:) [What aileth you] that ye will not fear the greatness, or majesty, of God? (S:) or the meaning is, that ye will not hope for God's magnifying of him who serves Him and obeys Him? or that ye will not believe in greatness, or majesty, belonging to God, so that ye may fear disobeying Him? (Bd:) another instance occurs in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, cited in art. xlf, conj. 3: (S:) and ↓ ArtjAhu, also, signifies (tropical:) he feared him, or it; [but app. only when preceded by a negative particle, as in exs. cited in the TA;] (K, TA;) in which sense it is tropical. (TA.) Accord. to Lth, rajowN is also syn. with mubaAlaApN; and maA A^arojuw means maA A^ubaAliY [I do not care, mind, or heed]: but this is disapproved by Az. (TA.) -A2- rajiYa He broke off, or ceased, [app. by reason of inability,] from speaking: (K:) or, accord. to Az, he became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: or, as Fr says, he desired to speak, and was unable to do so: (TA:) and rujiYa Ealayohi, like EuniYa, he became unable to speak. (K.)
2 raj~awa see 1, first sentence.

4 A^arojato *
She (a camel, S, or a pregnant female [of any kind], TA) was, or became, near to bringing forth; (S, K, TA;) so that her bringing forth was hoped for: accord. to Er-Rághib, the proper signification is she made her owner to have hope in himself that her bringing forth was near: (TA:) and A^arojaA^ato means the same. (S.) ― -b2- ArjY AlS~ayoda He failed of getting any game; (K;) [as though he made the game to have hope;] and ArjA^hu signifies the same: (TA:) or so ArjY [alone], and ArjA^ [alone]. (K and TA in art. rjA^.) -A2- And A^arojayotuhu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. A_irojaA='N, (K,) I postponed it, put it off, deferred it, or delayed it; (S, Msb, K; *) namely, an affair [&c.]; (S;) as also ArjA^thu. (S, Msb.) [See the latter verb: and see also an ex. in the Kur vii. 108 and xxvi. 35; and the various readings mentioned by Bd in the former instance.] -A3- ArjY Albiy^ora He made a side (rajFA) to the well. (S, K.)
5 taraj~awa see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [In the present day, trj~Y is often used as meaning He besought, entreated, petitioned, or prayed.]
8 A_irotajawa see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and again in the latter part of the paragraph.

rajFA * The side, (K,) in a general sense: (TA:) or the side of a well, (S, Msb, K,) and of the sky, (Er-Rághib, TA,) and of anything; (S, Msb; *) and ↓ rajaA='N signifies the same: (K:) the side of a well from its top to its bottom; (TA;) and the two sides thereof: which last is also [or properly] the meaning of the dual; which is rajawaAni: (S:) pl. A^arojaA='N. (S, Msb, K.) Hence, in the Kur [lxix. 17], waA@lomalaku EalaY A^arojaAy^ihaA [The angels being at the sides thereof]. (S, TA.) They said, rumiYa bihi Alr~ajawaAni, meaning (assumed tropical:) He was cast into places of destruction: (S:) or it is said of one who is held in mean estimation: (M, TA:) AisotihozaA='N in the K is a mistake for Ausotuhiyna bihi, the reading in the M: (TA:) as though the two [opposite] sides of the well were cast at with him. (K.) And one says of him who will not be deceived so as to be turned away from one course to another, laA turomaY bihi Alr~ajawaAni (assumed tropical:) [lit. The two sides of the well will not be cast at with him]; in allusion to the well's two [opposite] sides' being cast at with the bucket. (Z, TA.)

rajaA='N * [accord. to most an inf. n., (see 1, in two senses,) but accord. to the Msb a simple subst.,] Hope; syn. A^amalN; (S and M and K in art Aml;) contr. of yaA^osN; (K;) an opinion requiring the happening of an event in which will be a cause of happiness; (Er-Rághib, TA;) expectation of deriving advantage from an event of which a cause has already occurred: (El-Harállee, TA:) or, as Ibn-El-Kemál says, properly, i. q. A^amalN: and conventionally, the clinging of the heart to the happening of a future loved event: (TA:) or hope, or eager desire, for a thing that may possibly happen; differing from taman~K, which relates to what is possible and to what is impossible. (MF, TA.) -A2- See also rajFA.
rajiy~apN * [A thing hoped for]: you say, maAlaY fiY fulaAnK rajiy~apN There is nothing for me to hope for in such a one. (S.)
raAjK * [Hoping: ― -b2- and Fearing]. (Msb.)

A^urojiy~apN *
A thing postponed, put off, deferred, or delayed. (ISd, K.)

A^urojuwaAnN *
Redness: (Msb, K:) a certain red dye: (K:) or a certain dye, intensely red: (S:) accord. to A'Obeyd, (S,) what is called na$aAsotaj; (S, K;) and he says that the bahoramaAn is inferior to it (duwnahu [but this often has the contr. meaning]): it is said also that ArjwAn is an arabicized word, from the Pers. A^arogawaAn, which means a sort of trees having a red blossom, of the most beautiful kind; and that every colour resembling it is termed ArjwAn. (S.) Also Red: (K:) and red garments or clothes. (IAar, K.) And one says A^aHomaru A^urojuwaAnN, mentioned by Seer has having an intensive meaning; (M, TA;) in the K, ↓ A^aHomaru A^urojuwaAniY~N; but this is wrong; (TA;) i. e. Intensely red. (K, TA.) And qaTiyfapN HamoraA='u A^urojuwaAnN [A villous, or nappy, outer, or wrapping, garment, intensely red]: (S, M, A:) but IAth says that the most common practice is to prefix the word vawob or qaTiyfap to A^urojuwaAn so as to govern the latter in the gen. case; [saying vawobu A^urojuwaAnK or qaTiyfapu A^urojuwaAnK;] and that the word [ArjwAn] is said by some to be Arabic, the A and n being augmentative. (TA.)
A^urojuwaAniY~N * : see the next preceding paragraph.

[
murojFY *
Postponed, put off, deferred, or delayed; as also murojaA^N.] Some read [in the Kur ix. 107] waA=xaruwna murojawona liA^amori A@ll~`hi. (S: see mrjA^, in art. rjA^.)

[
murojK * and murojiyapN and] murojiY'N and muroji'apN A female near to bringing forth. (K, * TA.) -A2- murojK also signifies A man who is one of the people [or sect] called the murojiyap; (S;) or one of the murojiy^ap, mentioned in art. rjA^; as also murojiY'N; and so ↓ murojiY~N; (K;) or this is [properly speaking] a rel. n. from murojK; (S;) and murojiy^iY~N also; (K;) or rather this is another rel. n., like murojiY~N. (IB and TA in art. rjA^, q. v.)
murojiY * : see what next precedes. You say rajulN murojiY~N [A man of, or belonging to, the sect called the murojiyap]. (S.)
1 rajayotuhu * : see 1 (first sentence) in art. rjw.
1 raH~a * [sec. pers. raHiHota,] aor. yaraH~u, [inf. n., app., raHaHN,] It (a solid hoof, &c.,) had the quality termed raHaHN meaning as expl. below. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 raHoraHa *
He (a man, TA) did not exceed the usual bounds so as to reach the bottom, or utmost depth, of the object of his desire; (K, TA;) as, for instance, of a vessel: (TA:) [IbrD thinks that it signifies he sought, by his speech, the expression of a meaning which he failed to attain.] ― -b2- rHrH biAlkalaAmi He spoke, or expressed himself, obliquely, ambiguously, or equivocally; not plainly. (K, TA.) ― -b3- rHrH Eino fulaAnK i. q. sataraduwnahu [He protected such a one by intervening, or by interposing something]. (K.)

R. Q. 2 taraHoraHato *
She (a mare) straddled, in order to stale. (S, A, K.)

raH~apN * [or Hay~apN raH~apN] A serpent being, or becoming, like a Tawoq, or neck-ring, (mutaTaw~iqapN, K, [see 5 in art. Twq,]) when folding itself: (TA:) originally raHoyapN; (K;) the Y being changed into H. (TA.)

raHaHN *
Width in a solid hoof: such is approved; (S, K;) being the contr. of that which is termed muSoTar~N: but when it spreads out much, it is a fault: (S:) or a spreading therein: (A:) or a spreading thereof; and width of a human foot: (Lth, TA:) or a spreading of a solid hoof, with thinness: or width of a human foot, with thinness: and in a solid hoof, which is a fault: or excessive width in a solid hoof. (TA.)

raHoraHN * and ↓ raHoraAHN and ↓ raHoraHaAnN A thing wide and spreading, (K, TA,) not deep, like a Tsot and any similar vessel; as also rahorahN and rahorahaAnN: (TA:) [or ↓ the third of these epithets signifies very wide &c.; as will be seen from what follows: and] ↓ the second signifies a thing wide and thin. (S.) You say A_inaA='N raHoraHN A wide and low vessel; as also rahorahN. (TA.) And qadaHN raHoraHN and ↓ raHoraAHN A wide bowl. (A.) And qaSoEapN raHoraHN and ↓ raHoraHaAniy~apN A bowl spreading widely [and very widely]. (AA, TA.) And it is said in a trad., buHobuwHupu Aljan~api ↓ raHoraHaAniy~apN The middle of Paradise is [very] wide,
or ample: the A and n are added to give intensiveness to the signification. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Eayo$N raHoraHN (A) and ↓ raHoraAHN (S, A) (tropical:) An ample and easy state of life. (S, TA.)
raHoraHaAnN * : see the next preceding paragraph, throughout.
raHoraHaAniy~apN * : see the next preceding paragraph, throughout.
raHoraAHN * : see the next preceding paragraph, throughout.

A^araH~u *
Spreading, (Lth, TA,) or widely expanded; (TA;) applied to a solid hoof, (Lth, TA,) and to a foot such as is termed xuf~: (TA:) and wide; applied to anything: thus qadamN raH~aA='u a wide human foot: (Lth, TA:) and a human foot having the middle of the sole even with the fore part; (L, TA;) flat-soled; i. e. having, in the sole, no hollow part that does not touch the ground: (S:) and kirokir~pN raH~aA='u a wide callous protuberance upon the breast of a camel: (TA:) and jafonapN raH~aA='u a wide [bowl such as is termed] jifnp; like rawoHaA='u; wide and not deep: (TA:) and jifaAnN ruHuHN wide jfAn [pl. of jafonapN]. (IAar, K.) Having a spreading hoof; (S, A, K;) applied to a horse, (A,) and to a mountain-goat: (S, A, K:) also, applied to a man, having a wide foot; (A;) or having, in the sole of his foot, no hollow part that does not touch the ground, (S, K,) as is the case in the feet of the Zinj; (S;) having the sole of the foot flat, so that all of it touches the ground: fem. raH~aA='u: you say AimoraA^apN raH~aA='u Alqadamayoni: a high hollow to the sole of the foot is approved in a man and in a woman. (T, TA.) Also, applied to a camel, Having one foot cleaving to another. (TA.)

1 raHuba * , (Msb, K,) said of a place, (Msb,) or of a thing, (TA,) and raHubato, said of a land, (A^aroD, S,) or of a country, (bilaAd, A, TA,) aor.
raHuba , inf. n. ruHobN (S, A, * Msb, K) and raHaAbapN; (S, K;) and raHiba, (Msb, K,) and raHibato, (TA,) aor.
raHaba , (Msb, K,) inf. n. raHabN; (Msb, TA;) and ↓ ArHb, (Msb, K,) and ArHbt; (TA;) It was, or became, ample, spacious, wide, or roomy. (S, K, TA.) raHubati Ald~aAru and ↓ A^aroHabat both signify the same, i.e. The house, or abode, was ample, &c.; or may the house, or abode, be ample, &c. (S, TA.) And they said, Ealayoka waTul~ato ↓ A^aroHabato, meaning May it (the country, AlbilaAdu,) be spacious to thee, and be moistened by gentle rain, or by dew: so accord. to Aboo-Is-hák. (TA.) DaAqato Ealayohimu AlA^aroDu bimaA raHubato, in the Kur ix. 119, means The earth became strait to them with [i. e. notwithstanding] its spaciousness. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b2- raHuba, accord. to the original usage, is trans. by means of a particle; so that one says, raHuba bika AlmakaAnu [The place was, or may the place be, spacious with thee]: afterwards, by reason of frequency of usage, it became trans. by itself; and thus one said, raHubatoka Ald~aAru [The house, or abode, was, or may the house, or abode, be, spacious with thee, or to thee]. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence the saying,] A^araHubakumu Ald~uxuwlu fiY TaAEatihi (assumed tropical:) Was it proper, or allowable, for you [to enter among his obeyers? i. e., to become obedient to him?]: (S, K * TA:) referring to El-Kirmánee, (so in the S,) or Ibn-El-Kirmánee: (so in the TA:) mentioned by Kh, on the authority of Nasr Ibn-Seiyár; but he says, (S,) the verb thus used is anomalous; (S, K;) for a verb of the measure faEula is not trans., (K, TA,) accord. to the grammarians, (TA,) except with the tribe of Hudheyl, who, accord. to AAF, make it trans. (K, TA) when its meaning admits of its being so: (TA:) Kh mentions the phrase raHubatokumu Ald~aAru [meaning The house, or abode, was, or may the house, or abode, be, spacious with, or to, you]; but it is thought that there is an ellipsis here, and that it is for raHubato bikumu Ald~aAru: and ElJelál Es-Suyootee mentions, on the authority of AAF, the saying raHuba A@ll~`hu jawofahu, as meaning was~aEahu [i. e. May God make wide his belly]: (TA:) [J says, app. quoting Kh,] there is no sound verb of the measure faEula that is trans. except this; but as to the unsound, there is a difference of opinion: accord. to Ks, qulotuhu is originally qawulotuhu; but Sb says that this is not allowable, because it is trans.: (S:) Az says that raHubatokumo is not held to be allowable by the grammarians; and that Nasr is not an [approved] evidence. (TA.)

2 raH~aba see 4. ― -b2- rH~b bihi (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. taroHiybN (S, A, K) and taroHaAbN (Har p. 579,) He said to him maroHabFA; (S, Msb;) [he welcomed him with the greeting of maroHabFA; or simply he welcomed him;] he invited him to ampleness, spaciousness, or roominess: (A, K:) and ↓ maroHaba, also, signifies he said maroHabFA; but the expression commonly known is raH~aba bihi. (Har pp. 422-3.) You say, laqytuhu biAlt~aroHiybi [I met him with the greeting of maroHabFA; or with welcoming]. (A.) See also maroHabN

4 A^aroHaba see 1, in three places. -A2- ArHbhu He made it (a thing, S) ample, spacious, wide, or roomy; (S, K;) as also ↓ rH~bhu. (CK. [The latter is not in the TA, nor in my MS. copy of the K.]) El- Hajjáj said, when he slew Ibn-El-Kirreeyeh, A^aroHibo yaA gulaAmu juroHahu [Make wide, O young man, his wound]. (S.) And one says, in chiding a horse or mare, A^aroHibo (S, K) and A^aroHibiY (S, A, K,) meaning Make room, and withdraw. (S, A, K.)

6 taraAoHaba An instance of this verb occurs in the saying, h`*aA AlA^amoru A_ino taraAHabato mawaAriduhu faqado taDaAyaqato maSaAdiruhu (tropical:) [This affair, or case, if the ways leading to it, or the ways of commencing it, be easy, the ways of return from it, or the ways of completing it, are difficult]. (A, TA.)

Q. Q. 1
maroHaba: see 2.

raHobN * (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ raHiybN (Msb, K) and ↓ ruHaAbN (K) Ample, spacious, wide, or roomy; (S, A, K;) applied to a place, (Msb,) or a thing. (TA.) You say biladN raHobN, and A^aroDN raHobapN, An ample, or a spacious, or wide, country, and land, (S,) and ↓ ArD raHiybapN also: and manozilN raHobN and ↓ raHiybN an ample, or a spacious, or wide, place of alighting or abode: and TariyqN raHobN a wide road. (TA.) And ↓ qidorN ruHaAbN An ample cookingpot: (S:) and ruHaAbN alone is [elliptically] used as meaning a cooking-pot. (Ham p. 721.) And ↓ AimoraA^apN ruHaAbN A wide woman; (K;) meaning wide in respect of the faroj. (TK.) And rajulN Aljawofi ↓ raHiybu A man ample, or wide, in the belly: and, as mentioned by Es-Suyootee, (assumed tropical:) a great eater; voracious; (TA;) and so raHiybN alone. (S, K, TA.) And rajulN raHobu AlS~ador (TA) and AlS~adori ↓ ruHobu and AlS~adori ↓ raHiybu, (S, TA) A man ample, or dilated, in the breast, or bosom; [meaning (assumed tropical:) free-minded; free from distress of mind; without care: and free from narrowness of mind; liberal, munificent, or generous.] (S, TA.) And raHobu Al*~iraAEi (tropical:) Liberal, munificent, or generous; as also raHobu AlbaAEi; and so Al*~iraAEi ↓ raHiybu and AlbaAEi (A, TA.) And raHobu Al*~iraAEi means also (assumed tropical:) Having ample, or extensive, power, or strength, in cases of difficulty: (TA in the present art.:) or (tropical:) having ample strength, and power, and might in war or fight, courage, valour, or prowess. (TA in art. *rE) And fulaAnN raHobu Al*~iraAEi lika*aA (tropical:) Such a one has power, or ability, for that. (A.) ― -b2- See also raHabapN.

ruHobN * an inf. n. of raHuba [q.v.]. (S, Msb, K.) [Used as a simple subst.,] Ampleness, spaciousness, wideness, or roominess. (S A, Mgh, K.) You say, daEaAhu A_ilaY Alr~uHobi [He invited him to ampleness, &c.]. (A.) And hence the saying of Zeyd Ibn-Thábit to 'Omar, h`hunaA biAlr~uHobi, meaning Advance to ampleness, &c. (Mgh.) See also maroHabN, in two places. ― -b2- [It is also used as an epithet:] see the next preceding paragraph.
raHabN * : see the next following paragraph.

raHabapN * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and raHobapN, (A, Mgh, Msb,) K,) the former of which is the more chaste, (A,) or the better, (Mgh,) or the more common, (Msb,) The court, open area, or spacious vacant part or portion, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) of a mosque, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) and of a house, (A, TA,) or of a place; (K;) so called because of its ampleness: (TA:) and in like manner, between, or among, houses: (A:) a desert tract, (Fr, Mgh, TA,) or a spacious vacant tract, (A,) or a spacious piece of ground, (Msb,) between, or among, the yards of the houses of a people: (Fr, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and sometimes thus is termed an enclosure, or a [kind of wide bench of stone or brick such as is called] duk~aAn, that is made at the doors of some of the mosques in the towns and the rural districts, for prayer: hence the saying of Aboo-'Alee Ed-Dakkák, [in which it means an enclosure outside the door of a mosque,] “ It is not fit that the HaAy^iD should enter the rHbop of the mosque of a people, whether the rHbp be contiguous or separate: ” and hence, also, in a trad. of 'Alee, by the rHbp of El-Koofeh is meant a duk~aAn in the midst of the mosque of El-Koofeh, upon which he used to sit and to preach, and upon which he is related to have cast the spoils that he obtained from the people of En-Nahrawán:
(Mgh:) pl. ↓ raHabN (S, Msb, K) and ↓ raHobN (K) [or rather these are coll. gen. ns. of which raHabapN and raHobapN are the ns. un.] and [the pl. is] riHaAbN and raHabaAtN (S, Msb, K) and raHobaAtN. (K.) ― -b2- Also, both words, An ample tract of land, that produces much herbage, and in which people alight, or abide, much, or often: (AHn, K:) pl. as above, accord. to the K; but accord. to IAar, raHobapN signifies an ample tract of land; (TA;) and he says that its pl. is ruHabN, like as qurFY is pl. of qaroyapN: Az says that this occurs as an anomalous pl. of words of the defective class, and that he had not heard a word of the perfect class of the measure faEolapN having a pl. of the measure fuEalN; but that IAar is an authority worthy of reliance. (L, Msb.) And raHabapu AlwaAdiY, and raHobatuhu The part of the valley in which its water flows into it from its two sides: (K, TA:) pl. riHaAbN (TA.) [Or the pl.] riHaAbN signifies Plain, smooth, or soft, places, in which water collects and stagnates: they are the places where vegetation is most rapid, and are at the extremity of a valley, and in its middle, and sometimes in an elevated place, where water collects and stagnates, surrounded by what is more elevated: if in a plain tract of land, people alight and sojourn there: if in the interior of water-courses, people do not alight and sojourn there: if in the interior of a valley, and retaining the water, not very deep, and in breadth equal to a bow-shot, people alight and sojourn by the side thereof: rHAb are not in sands; but they are in low and in elevated tracts of land. (L.) ― -b3- The place of aggregation and growth of the plant called vumaAm [i. e. panic grass]. (K, TA.) ― -b4- The place of grapes, (K,) [where they are dried,] like the jariyn for dates. (TA.)

ruHobaY * The broadest rib (S, K) in the breast: (K:) and the ruHobayaAni, are the two ribs next to the armpits, among the upper ribs: (K:) or the place to which each elbow returns [when, after it has been removed from its usual place, it is brought back thereto; which place in a beast is next the arm pit]: (S, K:) it is there only that the camel's elbow wounds the callous protuberance upon his breast: (S:) or the rHbY is the place where the heart beats, (Az, K, TA,) in a beast and in a man: (Az, TA:) or, as some say, the part from the place where the neck is set on to the place where end the cartilages of the ribs, or the extremities of the ribs projecting over the belly: or the part between the two ribs of the base of the neck and the place to which the shoulder-blade returns [when, after it has moved from its usual position, it is brought back thereto, i. e. its lower part, next the armpit]: and the ruHobayaAni, also called the ↓ ruHobaAyaAwaAni [perhaps a mistranscription for ruHobaAwaAni as though the sing. were ruHobaA='N,] of the horse, are the upper parts of the ka$oHaAni [or two flanks.] (TA.) ― -b2- Also A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon the side of a camel. (S, K.)
ruHobaAyaAwaAni * [or perhaps ruHobaAwaAni]: see the next preceding paragraph.
ruHaAbN * : see raHobN, in three places.
raHiybN * ; and its fem., with p: see raHobN, in six places.

raHaAy^ibu Alt~uxuwmi * , (S, K,) in some copies of the K, erroneously, Aln~ujuwm, (TA,) Ampleness [of the limits, or boundaries, and therefore] of the tracts, or regions, of the land, or earth. (S, K.)

najaAy^ibu A^aroHabiy~aAtN *
Certain excellent she-camels, so called in relation to A^aroHabu, the name of a tribe of Hemdán, (S, Msb, K,) or of a certain stallion (Az, K, TA) whence they originated, (Az, TA,) or of a place (K, TA) of El-Yemen called after that tribe. (TA.)

maroHabN * [is an inf. n., like ↓ ruHobN; or a n. of place]. You say maroHabFA (T, S, Msb, TA) and maroHabFA bika (A, Msb) [and bika ↓ ruHobFA] meaning Thou hast come to, (T, S, TA,) or found, (T, A, TA,) ampleness, spaciousness, or roominess; (T, S, A, TA;) not straitness: (T, TA:) or alight thou, (Kh, Lth, TA,) or abide thou, (Kh, TA,) in ampleness, &c.; (Kh, Lth, TA;) for such we have for thee; (Lth, TA;) the word being put in the accus. case because of a verb understood: (Kh, TA:) or thou hast alighted in an ample, a spacious, or a roomy, place: (Msb:) [or welcome to ampleness, &c.; or to an ample, a spacious, or a roomy, place: or simply welcome:] and maroHabFA waA^aholFA Thou hast come to [or found, &c.,] ampleness, spaciousness, or roominess, and [such as thine own] kinsfolk; therefore be cheerful, and be not sad: (S:) and maroHabFA wasaholFA Thou hast found ampleness [and ease]: (K:) or saholFA means thou hast alighted in a plain, smooth, not rugged, district: (T, TA:) and maroHabaka A@ll~`hu wamasohalaka and maroHabFA bika A@ll~`hu wamasohalFA [May God grant ampleness to thee, and ease]: (K:) Sh says, thus I heard IAar say: and the Arabs also say, laA maroHabFA bika, meaning May it [the land or country] not be ample, or spacious, to thee: maroHabFA, he says, is one of the inf. ns. that are used in calling down blessings or curses on a man; as saqoyFA and raEoyFA and jadoEFA and EaqorFA, for saqaAka A@ll~`hu and raEaAka A@ll~`hu &c.: and Fr says that the meaning [of maroHabFA or maroHabFA bika] is A@ll~`hu bika maroHabFA ↓ raH~aba [May God invite thee to ampleness, &c.]; as though the last word were put in the place of taroHiybFA. (TA.) ― -b2- A^abuw maroHabK means (assumed tropical:) The shade: so in the saying of a poet, (S,) namely, En-Nábighah El-Jaadee, (TA,)
wakayofa tuwaASilu mano A^aSobaHato
xulaAlatuhu kaA^abiY maroHabi
[And how wilt thou hold loving communion with him whose friendship has become like the shade?]. (S, TA.) It is also a surname of 'Orkoob, the man notorious for lying promises. (TA.) ― -b3- And maroHabN is the name of An idol that was in Hadramowt. (K.)

1 raHaDa * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
raHaDa , (A, Msb, K,) or
raHuDa , (so in two copies of the S,) or both, (L, TA,) inf. n. raHoDN, (S, Msb) and taroHaADN, [but this is an intensive form,] (TA,) He washed (S, A, Msb, K) a thing, (A, K,) or garment, (S, A, Msb,) and his hand; (S;) as also ↓ ArHD (IDrd, K,) which latter is of the dial. of El- Hijáz. (IDrd.) You say also, h`*ihi sawo'apN laA Eanoka $aYo'N ↓ yuroHiDuhaA (tropical:) [This is a disgrace which nothing will wash from thee]. (A: [but the last word is not in the copy from which I quote.]) ― -b2- ruHiDa, (inf. n. as above, AZ, AAF,) (tropical:) He (a person suffering from fever) was, or became, affected with what is termed ruHaDaA=' [q. v.]: (Lth, S, A, K:) or he sweated, and his sweat became abundant upon the sides of his forehead above the temples, in his sleeping or waking, but only in consequence of disease. (AZ, AAF.)
4 A^aroHaDa see above, in two places.
8 ArtHD * (tropical:) He became disgraced, or put to shame. (AA, O, K.)
raHoDN * A garment, or piece of cloth, washed until it has become worn out. (IAar.) ― -b2- A small worn-out skin: a worn-out mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag]. (Sgh, K.)

ruHaDaA='u * (tropical:) Sweat; absolutely: (TA:) or the sweat of fever: (Lth, A, TA:) or sweat following fever: (S, K:) or fever with sweating: (TA:) or sweat that washed the skin by reason of its abundance: (K:) often used to signify the sweat of fever and of disease. (TA.)
ruHaADN * (tropical:) [The state of being affected with what is termed ruHaDaA=';] a subst. from ruHiDa, (K,) or from ruHaDaA='. (IDrd.)

raHiyDN *
Washed; (S, A, Msb, K;) applied to a garment [&c.]; (S, A;) as also ↓ maroHuwDN (S, K) and ↓ muroHaDN. (TA.)

ruHaADapN *
Washings. (Lh.)
muroHaDN * : see raHiyDN.

miroHaDapN *
A place [or tank] in which one washes his limbs, performing the ablution termed wuDuwo': (A, TA: *) or a thing in which one performs that ablution, like the kaniyf: (Lth, K:) and ↓ miroHaADapN a thing with which one performs that ablution, like the [kind of vessel called] tawor. (IAar.) ― -b2- See also miroHaADN.

miroHaADN *
A piece of wood with which a garment, or piece of cloth, is beaten (S, A, * K) when it is washed. (S, A. *) ― -b2- A vessel of the kind called A_ij~aAnap, or of the kind called Tasot, in which clothes are washed: (A:) and ↓ miroHaDapN signifies a vessel of the kind called A_ij~aAnap; because clothes are washed in it. (Lh.) ― -b3- A place of washing: (Mgh, Msb:) or a place in which one washes himself. (S, K.) ― -b4- And hence, (tropical:) A privy: (S, * A, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. maraAHiyDu (S, Mgh) and maraAHiDu. (TA.)
maroHuwDN * : see raHiyDN. ― -b2- Also part. n. of ruHiDa [q. v.]. (AZ, AAF, S.)
miroHaADapN * : see miroHaDapN.
ruHaAqN * : see what follows, in two places.

raHiyqN *
Wine: (A 'Obeyd, K:) or the choicest of wine: (S, TA:) or the sweetest of wine: or the most excellent thereof: (K:) or the oldest and most excellent thereof: (M, TA:) or unadulterated wine: (Zj, TA:) or wine that is easy to swallow: (TA:) or pure wine: or clear wine: as also ↓ ruHaAqN: (K:) in all of these senses the former word has been explained as used in the Kur lxxxiii. 25: (TA:) and ↓ the latter occurs as syn. with the former in chaste poetry. (IDrd.) ― -b2- Also A sort of perfume. (K.) ― -b3- And Honey. (O, TA.) ― -b4- [And it is used as an epithet.] You say misokN raHiyqN (tropical:) Unadulterated musk. (TA.) And HasabN raHiyqN (tropical:) Pure, or genuine, grounds of pretension to respect. (TA.)

1 raHala AlbaEiyra * , aor.
raHala , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. raHolN, (S, Msb,) [He saddled the camel;] he bound, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or put, (M, K,) the raHol upon the camel; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ ArtHlhu. (K.) And raHalahu raHolahu He bound upon him his apparatus. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He mounted the camel: (T, TA:) and AlbaEiyra ↓ AirotaHalotu I rode the camel, either with a qatab [or saddle] or upon his bare back. (Sh, TA.) ― -b3- [Both of these verbs are also used tropically.] You say, raHalotu lahu nafosiY [lit. I saddled for him myself;] meaning (assumed tropical:) I endured patiently his annoyance, or molestation. (S.) And raHala fulaAnN SaAHibahu bimaA yakorahu (assumed tropical:) [Such a one put upon, or did to, his companion that which he disliked, or hated]. (TA.) And [in like manner] ↓ trH~lhu means rakibahu bimakoruwhK (tropical:) [He did to him an evil, or abominable, or odious, deed]. (K, TA.) And raHalahu bisayofihi (tropical:) He smote him with his sword. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And raHala fulaAnN fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) Such a one mounted upon the back of such a one; as also EalaY Zahorihi ↓ ArtHlhu; [and ArtHlhu alone; for] it is said in a trad., ↓ A_in~a A@boniY A@rotaHalaniY, meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily my son mounted upon my back, making me like the raAHilap: (TA:) and if a man throws down another prostrate, and sits upon his back, you say, raA^ayotuhu murotaHilahu (assumed tropical:) [I saw him sitting upon his back]. (Sh, TA.) And [hence] ↓ ArtHl AlA^amora (assumed tropical:) He embarked in the affair. (TA.) And fulaAnN A^amorFA maA yuTiyquhu ↓ ArtHl (assumed tropical:) [Such a one embarked, or has embarked, in an affair which he is unable to accomplish]. (TA.) And AlHum~aY ↓ AirotaHalatohu (assumed tropical:) [The fever continued upon him]; a phrase similar to rakibatohu AlHm~Y and AimotaTatohu and A^agobaTatohu. (A and TA in art. gbT.) -A2- raHala (S, Mgh, Msb, K) Eani AlmakaAni, (TA,) or Eani Albaladi, (Mgh, Msb,) aor.
raHala , (K,) inf. n. raHolN, (TA,) or raHiylN, (Msb,) or this latter is a simple subst.; (S, K, TA;) and ↓ ArtHl, and ↓ triH~l, (S, Msb, K,) Eani AlmakaAni, (K,) or Eani Alqawomi; (Msb;) all signify the same; (S, Msb;) He removed, (Mgh, K, TA,) went, went away, departed, went forth, or journeyed, (Mgh, TA,) from the place, (K, TA,) or from the country or the like, (Mgh, Msb,.) or from the people. (Msb.) See an ex. of the first of these verbs in a verse cited in the next paragraph. ↓ ArtHl said of a camel, (K,) or ArtHl raHolahu, (TA,) signifies He journeyed, and went away: (K, TA:) [or he had his saddle put upon him:] and hence, ↓ ArtHl Alqawomu The people, or party, removed. (TA.) ― -b2- raHala bihi: see 2.

2 raH~alotuhu * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. taroHiylN; (K;) and ↓ A^aroHalotuhu (Mgh;) I made him to remove, to go, go away, go forth, or journey, (S, Mgh, Msb, * K, *) from his place; and sent him [away]: (S:) and [in like manner] bihi ↓ raHala he made him to remove, go away, depart, or journey: (L in art. x*rf:) and ↓ AlAirotiHaAlu [if not a mistranscription for AlA_iroHaAlu] signifies the making [one] to go, go away, depart, go forth, or journey; and the removing from one's place. (TA.) A poet says,
Al$~ayobu Eano daArK yaHul~u bihaA ↓ laA yaroHalu
Hat~aY yuraH~ala EanohaA SaAHibu Ald~aAri
[(assumed tropical:) Hoariness will not depart from a dwelling in which it alights until the owner of the dwelling be made to depart from it]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. that, at the approach of the hour [of resurrection], Aln~aAsa ↓ taxoruju naArN mino Eadana turoHilu, i.e. [A fire shall issue from 'Adan] that shall remove with the people when they remove, and alight with them when they alight: so says EshShaabee; or, Sh says, as some relate it, turaH~ilu Aln~aAsa, i.e. that shall make the people to alight at the maraAHil [or stations]: or, as some say, that shall make the people to remove, or depart. (TA.) -A2- taroHiylN also signifies The figuring, or embellishing, of garments or cloths [with the forms of riHaAl, or camels' saddles: see muraH~alN]. (TA.)
3 rAHlhu * , (S, K,) inf. n. muraAHalapN, (TA,) He aided him to undertake, or perform, his riHolap [or journey]. (S, K.)

4 ArHl *
He broke, or trained, a she-camel, so that she became such as is termed raAHilap, meaning fit to be saddled; (K;) like A^amohara meaning “ he (a breaker, or trainer,) rendered ” her “ a mahoriy~ap: ” (TA:) or he took a camel in an untractable state and rendered him such as is termed raAHilap. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- And ArHlhu He gave him a raAHilap, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) that he might ride it. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 2, in two places. -A2- He (a camel) became strong in his back, [so as to be fit for the raHol (or saddle) or for journeying,] after weakness: (IDrd, K:) or he (a camel) became fat; as though there came [what resembled] a raHol upon his back, by reason of his fatness and his [large] hump: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and ArHlt AlA_ibilu The camels became fat after leanness, so as to be able to journey. (S K.) ― -b2- And He (a man, TA) had many [camels such as are termed] rawaAHil [pl. of raAHilapN]; (ISd, K;) like A^aEoraba meaning “ he had horses such as are termed EiraAb ” (ISd, TA.)
5 taraH~ala trans. and intrans.: see 1, in two places.

6 trAHlwA A_ilaY AlHakami *
They went, or journeyed, [together] to the Hakam [or judge]. (O, TA.)
8 A_irotaHala as a trans. v.; see 1, in seven places: ― -b2- and see also 2: ― -b3- and as an intrans. v.; see 1, in the latter part of the paragraph, in three places.

10 AstrHlhu *
i. q. saA^alahu A^ano yaroHala lahu [which may be rendered He asked him to remove, or journey, to him: and also he asked him to bind, or put, the raHol (or saddle of the camel) for him: the former is the meaning accord. to the PS]. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- AstrHl Aln~aAsa nafosahu means (assumed tropical:) He abased himself to men, or to the people, so that they annoyed, or molested, him: or, as some say, he asked men, or the people, to take off from him his weight, or burden. (TA.)

raHolN *
A saddle for a camel; (S, * K;) as also ↓ raAHuwlN; (O, L, K;) for a he-camel and a she-camel; (TA;) the thing for the camel that is like the saroj for the horse or similar beast; (Mgh;) the thing that is put upon the camel for the purpose of riding thereon; (Er-Rághib, TA;) smaller than the qatab; (S, TA;) one of the vehicles of men, exclusively of women: (TA:) [this seems to be regarded as the primary signification by the authors of the Mgh and the K and by Er-Rághib: but see what follows:] or it signifies the camel's saddle together with his [girths called] rabaD and Haqab and his [cloth called] Hilos [that is put beneath the saddle], and all its other appertenances: and is applied also to the pieces of wood of the raHol, without any apparatus: (AO, Sh, TA:) or it signifies anything, or everything, that a man prepares for removing, or journeying; such as a bag, or receptacle, for goods or utensils or apparatus, and a camel's saddle, and a [cloth such as is called] Hilos [that is put beneath the saddle], and a rasan [or rope for leading his camel]: (Msb:) or it signifies as first explained above, and also the goods, or utensils, or apparatus, which a man takes with him [during a journey]: (S, K, TA:) [but accord. to the Msb, this signification is from another, mentioned below; and the same seems to be indicated in the S, which reverses the order in which I have mentioned the three significations that I quote from it:] this last signification is disapproved by El-Hareeree, in the “ Durrat el-Ghowwás: ” [but see two exs. voce Hu*aAfapN:] the pl. is A^aroHulN and riHaAlN; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) the former a pl. of pauc.; (S, TA;) the latter, of mult. (TA.) One says, HaT~a raHolahu and A^aloqaY raHolahu [He put down his camel's saddle]; meaning he stayed, or abode. (TA.) And h`*aA maHaT~u Alr~iHaAli [This is the place where the camels' saddles are put down]. (TA.) And in reviling, one says, yaA A@bona muloqaYA^aroHuli Alr~ukobaAni [O son of the place in which are thrown down the camels' saddles of the riders; as though the person thus addressed were there begotten]; (S, O, TA;) meaning
yaA A@bona AlfaAjirapi [O son of the adulteress or fornicatress]: (TA in art. lqY:) or huwa Abn mlqY ArHl AlrkbAn [He is the son &c.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Er-Rághib, after giving the explanation mentioned as on his authority above, says that it is then sometimes applied to The camel [itself]: and is sometimes used in the sense next following; i. e. ― -b3- A part, of a place of alighting or abode, upon which on sits: (TA:) or a man's dwelling, or habitation; (S, K, TA;) [in the first of which, this commences the art., app. showing that the author held this to be the primary signification;]) his house or tent; and his place of alighting or abode: (TA:) a place to which a man betakes himself, or repairs, for lodging, covert, or refuge; a man's place of resort; (Mgh, Msb;) in a region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land: and then applied to the goods, utensils, or apparatus, of a traveller; because they are, in travelling, the things to which he betakes himself: (Msb:) pl. A^aroHulN (TA) and riHaAlN [as above]. (Mgh, TA.) One says, daxalotu EalaY Alr~ajuli raHolahu, i. e. [I went in to the man in] his dwelling, or place of abode. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., A_i*aA A@botal~ati Aln~iEaAlu faSal~uwA fiY Alr~iHaAli, (TA,) or fiYlS~alaApu fiY Alr~iHaAli, (Mgh, and so in the TA in art. nEl,) i. e. [When the niEaAl are moistened by rain, then pray ye, or then prayer shall be performed,] in the houses, or habitations, or places of abode; the nEAl meaning here the HiraAr; (IAth, TA in the present art.;) or rugged and hard tracts of ground; which are here particularized because the least wet moistens them, whereas the soft tracts dry up the water: (IAth, TA in art. nEl:) Az says that the meaning is, when the hard grounds are rained upon, they become slippery to him who walks upon them; therefore pray ye in your abodes, and there shall not be anything brought against you for your not being present at the prayer in the mosques of the congregations: (TA in that art.:) or the trad. may mean, then pray ye [on the camels' saddles, i. e.] riding. (TA in the present art.) ― -b4- In another trad., it is related that 'Omar said to the Prophet, Haw~alotu raHoliYa AlbaAriHapa; by the word raHol, as signifying [properly] either the “ place of abode and resort ” or the “ saddle upon which camels are ridden, ” alluding to his wife; meaning gi$oyaAnuhaA fiY qubulihaA mino jihapi ZahorihaA (TA.) ― -b5- raHolu AlmuSoHafi means The thing [or desk] upon which the mSHf [or copy of the Kur-án] is put, in shape [somewhat] like the saddle. (TA.) [It is generally a small desk of which the front and back have the form of the letter X; commonly made of palm-sticks.] -A2- [The pl.] raHaAlN also signifies [Carpets, or cloths, or the like, such as are called] TanaAfis, of the fabric of El-Heereh. (S, K.)

ruHolapN *
Strength; [app. in a camel, such as renders fit for the saddle, or for journeying;] and fleetness, or swiftness, and excellence: (TA:) [and ↓ riHolapN has a similar meaning, as appears from what follows:] or excellence of pace of a camel. (S voce HiDaArN.) You say baEiyrN *uw ruHolapK and ↓ riHolapK, and ↓ miroHalN, like minobarN, (K,) or ↓ muroHilN, and ↓ raHiylN, so in the T, (TA,) A strong he-camel: (T, K:) and (so in the K [but properly “ or ”]) bEyr *w ruHolapK (CK) or ↓ riHolapK (K accord. to the TA) or both, and ↓ miroHalN, with kesr to the m (O,) and ↓ jamalN raHiylN, (AA, S, S, O, K, TA,) and ↓ naAqapN raHiylapN (S, O) or raHiylN, (TA,) and *aAtu ruHolapK, (S,) a he-camel, (S, O, K,) and a she-camel, (S, O,) strong to journey; (S, O, K, TA;) so says Fr: (O:) or strong to be saddled: (TA:) and ↓ naAqapN raHiylapN and raHiylN and ↓ muroHilapN, accord. to the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb, ” a she-camel that is excellent, generous, of high breed; or strong, light, and swift; (TA;) and so ↓ musotaroHilapN. (K, TA. [See also raAHilapN.]) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in seven places.

riHolapN * The act of saddling of camels: (K, * TA:) [and also, agreeably with analogy, a mode, or manner, of saddling of camels:] so in the saying, A_in~ahu laHasanu Alr~iHolapi [Verily he is good in respect of the saddling, or the mode or manner of saddling, of camels]. (K.) ― -b2- Also A removal, departure, or journey; (AZ, S, Msb, K;) and so ↓ ruHolapN, (Lh, Msb, K,) and ↓ raHiylN: (S, K: [the last said in the Msb to be and inf. n.:]) you say danato riHolatunaA (S) or qarubato riHolatunaA (Msb) [Our removal, &c., drew near, or has drawn near]: and A_in~ahu la*uw riHolapK A_ilaY Almuluwki and ↓ riHolap Verily he is one who journeys, or has journeyed, to the kings: (Lh, TA:) and in like manner ruHolapN is used in the Kur cvi. 2: (TA:) ― -b3- or ↓ riHolapN with damm, (S, Msb, K,) signifies The thing to which one removes, departs, or journeys; (AZ, Msb;) or the direction, or point, or object, to which one desires to repair, or betakes himself: (AA, S, Msb, K:) and also, (K,) or ruHolapN, (TA,) a single journey; (K, TA;) as ISd says: (TA:) you say, ↓ mak~apu ruHolatiY Mekkeh is the point, or object, to which I desire to remove, or depart, or journey: (TA:) and ↓ A^anotumo ruHolatiY Ye are they to whom I remove, or depart, or journey: (S, TA:) and ↓ A^anota ruHolatunaA Thou art the object to which we repair, or betake ourselves. (Msb.) And hence ↓ ruHolapN is applied to signify A noble, or an exalted, person, or a great man of learning, to whom one journeys for his [the latter's] need, or want, or for his [the former's] science. (TA.) ― -b4- See also the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
raHuwlN * : see raAHilapN: ― -b2- and raH~aAlN.

raHiylN * A camel having the saddle (raHol [not rHAlp as in Freytag's Lex.]) put upon him; as also ↓ maroHuwlN. (K.) ― -b2- See also ruHolapN, in four places. -A2- As a simple subst, or, accord. to the Msb, an inf. n.: see riHolapN.

riHaAlapN *
A saroj [or horse's saddle]: (K:) or a saroj of skins, (S, M, Msb, K,) in which is no wood; used for vehement running [of the horse]: (S, M, K:) ISd says also that it is one of the vehicles [or saddles] of women, like the raHol: but Az says that it is one of the vehicles [or saddles] of men, exclusively of women, i. e. not of women; as is also the raHol: and some say that it is larger than the saroj, covered with skins, and is for horses, and for excellent, or strong and light and swift, camels: (TA:) pl. raHaAy^ilu. (S.) When a man is hasty in doing evil to his companion, one says to him, Aisotaqodamato riHaAlatuka [lit. Thy saddle has got before thee, or shifted forwards]: (S in the present art.:) it is a prov., meaning that has preceded than which another was more fit to do so. (S in art. qdm.) In the following saying of Imra-el-Keys, addressing his wife,
faA_im~aA tarayoniY fiY riHaAlapi jaAbirK
EalaY HarajK kaA@loqar~itaxofiqu A^akofaAniY
[And either thou wilt see me upon the saddle of Jábir, upon a bier like the vehicle called qar~, my grave-clothes fluttering], he means, by the word rHAlp, [merely] the Haraj; there being in this case no rHAlp in reality: it is like the saying, jaA='a fulaAnN EalaY naAqapi AlHa*~aA='i, meaning [“ Such a one came upon] the sandal [or sandals]: ” Jábir is the name of a certain carpenter. (S.) -A2- Also A ewe. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) [Hence,] riHaAlaho riHaAlaho is A call to the ewe, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) on the occasion of milking. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ― -b2- And Alr~iHaAlapu is the name of A certain horse of 'Ámir Ibn-Et-Tufeyl; (K;) erroneously said by AO to be AlHmAlp. (TA.)
raHuwlapN * : see raAHilapN.

raH~aAlN *
Skilled in the saddling of camels. (K.) ― -b2- Also A man who removes, or journeys, or travels, much; and so ↓ raH~aAlapN, [or rather this signifies one who removes, or journeys, or travels, very much,] and ↓ raHuwlN: and ↓ ruH~alN [pl. of raAHilN, q. v.,] persons who remove, or journey, or travel, much. (TA.)
raH~aAlapN * : see what next precedes.

raAHilN *
Removing, (K, TA,) going, [going away, departing, going forth,] or journeying: (TA:) pl. ruH~alN. (TA.) For another meaning assigned to the pl., see raH~aAlN.

raAHilapN *
A she-camel that is fit to be saddled; (S, Msb, K;) thus some say; (Msb;) as also ↓ raHuwlN (S, K) and ↓ raHuwlapN: (K:) or [generally a saddle-camel, or] a camel that is ridden, male or female: (S, Msb:) accord. to IKt, a she-camel that is strong to journey and to bear burdens; and such as a man chooses for his riding and his saddle on account of excellence, or generousness, or high breed, or of strength and lightness and swiftness, and of perfectness of make, and beauty of aspect: but this explanation is wrong: (Az, TA:) it signifies a he-camel, and a she-camel, that is excellent, or generous, or high-bred, or strong and light and swift: (Az, Mgh, TA:) the she-camel is not more entitled to this appellation than the he-camel: (Az, TA:) the p is added to give intensiveness to the signification; as in
daAhiyapN and baAqiEapN and Eal~aAmapN, epithets applied to a man: or, as some say, the she-camel is so called because she is saddled; and it is like Eiy$apN raADiyapN meaning maroDiy~apN, and maA='N daAfiqN meaning madofuwqN: or, as others say, because she is *aAtu raHolK [one having a saddle]; and in like manner, Eiy$apN raADiyapN means *aAtu raDFY, and maA='N daAfiqN means *uw dafoqK: (TA:) the pl. is rawaAHilu. (S, Msb.) It is said in a trad., tajiduwna Aln~aAsa baEodiY kaA_ibilK miAy^apK layosa fiyhaA raAHilapN [Thou wilt find the people, or mankind, after me, like a hundred camels among which there is not a rAHlp]: (Mgh, * TA:) because the rAHlo among a herd of camels is conspicuous and known. (TA.) ― -b2- ma$ato rawaAHiliY, a phrase used by the poet Dukeyn, means (tropical:) I have become hoary and weak: or, as some say, I have forsaken my ignorant, or foolish, behaviour, and have restrained myself from foul conduct, and become obedient to my censurers; like as the rAHlp obeys her chider, and goes. (TA.)
raAHuwlN * : see raHolN, first sentence.

raAHuwlaAtN *
A camel's saddle, (raHolN, Az, K,) or camel's saddles, so in the O, (TA,) variegated, figured, or embellished. (Az, O, K, TA.) [It is really, as well as literally, a pl.: for] a poet says,
Ealayohin~a raAHuwlaAtu kul~i qaTiyfapK
[Upon them (referring evidently to she-camels) are variegated, figured, or embellished, saddles of every kind of villous, or nappy, cloth]. (TA.)

A^aroHalu * (tropical:) A horse white in the back; (S, Mgh, K;) because it is the place of the raHol [or rather of the riHaAlap]; (Mgh, TA;) the whiteness not reaching to the belly nor to the rump nor to the neck: (TA:) and a sheep or goat black in the back: accord. to Abu-l-Ghowth, the fem., raHolaA='u, applied to a mare, has the former meaning only: (S:) but $aApN raHolaA='u means a sheep or goat, or a ewe or she-goat, white in the back, and black in the other parts; and likewise black in the back, and white in the other parts: (S, K: *) so says Abu-l-Ghowth: (S:) and it is also explained as meaning black, but white in the place of the saddle, from the hinder parts of the shoulderblades: also as meaning white, but black in the back: Az adds that such as is white in one of the hind legs is termed rajolaA='u [with jym]. (TA.)

taroHiylN * (assumed tropical:) A whiteness predominating over, or interrupted by, blackness, ($uhobapN,) or a redness, upon the shoulder-blades, (K, TA,) the place upon which lies the raHol [or camel's saddle]. (TA.)

taroHiylapN *
A thing that makes thee to remove, go, go away, depart, go forth, or journey; expl. by maA yuraH~luka. (TA.)

muroHilN * One who breaks, or trains, and renders fit to be saddled, a camel or camels. (TA.) ― -b2- A man having many [camels such as are termed] rawaAHil [pl. of raAHilapN]; like muEoribN meaning “ having horses such as are termed EiraAb ” (A'Obeyd, S.) -A2- A camel strong in the back, [so as to be fit for the raHol,] after weakness. (IDrd, TA.) And A fat camel; though he be not excellent, or generous, or high-bred, or strong and light and swift: so in the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb. ” (TA.) See also ruHolapN, in two places.
miroHalN * : see ruHolapN, in two places.

maroHalapN * [A station of travellers; i. e.] a place of alighting or abode, between two such places: (TA:) [and also a day's journey, or thereabout; or] the space which the traveller journeys in about a day: (Msb:) sing. of maraAHilu; (S, Msb, K;) which is also a pl. of muraH~alN as an epithet applied to a burod. (TA.) One says, bayoniY wabayona ka*aA maroHalapN A^awomaroHalataAni [Between me and such a place, or thing, is a station or a day's journey or thereabout, or are two stations &c.]. (S, TA.)

A_ibilN muraH~alapN *
Camels having their riHaAl [or saddles] upon them: and also camels whose riHaAl have been put down from them: thus having two contr. meanings. (K.) ― -b2- And burodN muraH~alN A garment of the kind termed burod upon which are the figures of a raHol [or camels' saddle], (K,) and the like thereof; as in the T: (TA:) the explanation that J has given of it, [or rather of miroTN muraH~alN,] i. e. an A_izaAr [or a waist-wrapper] of [the cloth called] xaz~, upon which is an ornamented border, is not good: such is termed muraj~alN, with jiym: (K:) the pl. is muraH~alaAtN and maraAHilu; both occurring in traditions; (TA in the present art.;) and the latter of them said in the T to be syn. with maraAjilu, which is pl. of mirojalN [q. v.]. (TA in art. rjl.)
maroHuwlN * : see raHiylN.

murotaHalN * signifies [The act of removing or departing; i. e.] the contr. of maHal~N used in the sense of HuluwlN. (TA.) ― -b2- And sometimes it signifies The place in which one alights, or descends and stops. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The place of the raHol [which may here mean either the saddle or the saddling] of a camel. (TA.)
AlHaAl~u AlmurotaHilu * : see art. Hl.
musotaroHilapN * , applied to a she-camel: see ruHolapN.

1 raHimahu * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
raHama , (K,) inf. n. raHomapN and ruHomN [and raHamapN and ruHumN] and maroHamapN, (S, * Msb, K, *) [He had mercy, or pity, or compassion, on him; or he treated him, or regarded him, with mercy or pity or compassion; i. e.] he was, or became, tender [or tender-hearted] towards him; and inclined to favour him [and to benefit him]: (S, Msb, K: [see also raximahu and raxamahu:]) and he pardoned him, or forgave him: (K:) said of a man: (S, Msb, K:) and also of God [in the former sense, but tropically, or anthropopathically: or as meaning He favoured him, or benefited him; or pardoned, or forgave, him: see explanations of raHomapN below]: (Msb, K:) and Ealayohi ↓ trH~m signifies the same, (MA, [and the same seems to be indicated in the S,]) said of a man: (S:) [and so does ↓ trH~mhu, (occurring in the S and K in art. rEY, &c.,) accord. to Ibn-Maaroof, for he says that] taraH~umN signifies the regarding [another] with mercy or pity or compassion; or pardoning [him], or forgiving [him]: and also the being merciful or pitiful or compassionate or favourably inclined [EalaY gayorihi to another]. (KL: but respecting this latter verb, see 2.) -A2- raHumato, and raHimato, (S, K,) and ruHimato, (K,) inf. n. raHaAmapN, (S, K,) which is of the first, (S, TA,) and raHamN, (S, K,) which is of the second, (S, TA,) and raHomN, (K,) which is of the third, (TA,) She had a complaint of her womb after bringing forth, (S, K,) and died in consequence thereof: (K:) said of a camel, (S, TA,) and of a ewe or goat, and of a woman, and of any animal having a womb: (TA:) or she had a disease in her womb, in consequence of which she did not receive impregnation: or she brought forth without letting fall her secundine: (K, TA:) or, accord. to Lh, the bringing forth without letting fall her secundine, by a sheep or goat, is termed ↓ ruHaAmN. (TA.) ― -b2- raHima, aor.
raHama , inf. n. raHamN, is also said of a water-skin, meaning It was left, or neglected, by its owners, after its being seasoned with rob, [for gyth, in the phrase bEd gyth, an evident mistranscription, I read, conjecturally, tamotiynihi, as the only word at all resembling gyth, that I can call to mind, having an apposite signification,] and they did not anoint it, or grease it, so that it became spoilt, or in a bad state, and did not retain the water: the epithet applied to it in this case is ↓ raHimN. (TA.) ― -b3- And raHaAmapN is also an inf. n. [of which the verb, if it have one, is app. raHuma,] signifying The being connected by relationship. (TA.)
2 rH~m Ealayohi * , inf. n. taroHiymN; and ↓ trH~m; but the former is the more chaste; He said to him, raHimaka A@ll~`hu [May God have mercy on thee; &c.]. (K.)

5 trH~m Ealayohi * and trH~mhu : for both see 1; and for the former see also 2. [Accord. to different authorities, it appears that both may be rendered He had mercy, or pity, or compassion, on him; or he pitied, or compassionated, him: (see 1:) or he pitied him, or compassionated him, much: (see what follows:) and the former, he said to him, May God have mercy on thee; &c.; (see 2;) or he expressed a wish that God would have mercy on him; or he expressed pity, or compassion, for him: and also he affected, or constrained himself to have or to show, pity, or compassion.] Though taraH~amotu Ealayohi is mentioned by J, and not raH~am~hu, some say that the former is incorrect: and it is said that taraH~umN implies self-constraint, and therefore is not to be attributed to God: but some repudiate this assertion, because it occurs in correct traditions, and because tafaE~ulN is not restricted to the denoting peculiarly self-constraint, but has other properties, as in the instances of tawaH~udN and takab~urN, denoting intensiveness and muchness. (TA.)
6 trAHmwA * signifies raHima baEoDuhumo baEoDFA [They had mercy, or pity, or compassion, one on another; &c.]. (S, TA.)

10 AstrHmhu *
He asked, or demanded, of him Alr~aHomap [i. e. mercy, or pity, or compassion; &c.]. (TA.)
raHomN * : see its syn. raHimN, in two places.

ruHomN * : see its syn. raHomapN. ― -b2- [Hence,] A^um~u ruHomK one of the names of Mekkeh; (S, K; *) as also A^um~u Alr~uHomi; (K;) meaning the source of Alr~aHomap [or mercy, &c.]. (TA.) [See also zuHomN.]
riHomN * : see its syn. raHimN, in two places.
raHamN * The coming forth of the womb, in consequence of a disease. (IAar, TA.) [See also raHimato and raHima, of each of which it is an inf. n.]

raHimN * The womb, i. e. the place of origin, (Mgh, Msb, K,) and the receptacle, (Mgh, K,) of the young, (Mgh, Msb, K,) in the belly; (Mgh;) as also ↓ riHomN, (Msb, K,) a contraction of the former, and ↓ raHomN, which is of the dial. of Benoo-Kiláb: (Msb:) in this sense, (Msb,) which is the primary signification, (Mgh,) [i. e.] as meaning the raHim of the female, (S,) it is fem.; (S, Msb;) or, as some say, masc.; (Msb;) but IB cites a verse in which riHom is fem.: (TA:) pl. A^aroHaAmN. (MA.) ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh, Msb,) as also ↓ riHomN (S, Msb, K) and ↓ raHomN, (Msb,) (tropical:) Relationship; i. e. nearness of kin; syn. qaraAbapN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) [by some restricted to relationship by the female side; as will be shown below:] and connexion by birth: (Mgh, Msb:) or relationship connecting with a father or an ancestor: or near relationship: so in the T: (TA:) or a connexion, or tie, of relationship: (A, TA:) or the ties of relationship: (M, K, TA:) accord. to the K, Alr~aHimu signifies AlqaraAbapu or A^aSoluhaA and A^asobaAbuhaA: but in the M it is said, Alr~aHimu A^asobaAbu AlqaraAbapi waA^aSoluhaA Alr~aHimu Al~atiY hiYa manobitu Alwaladi; in which waA^aSoluhaA forms no part of the explanation of AlrHm, as the author of the K asserts it to do: (TA:) as meaning relationship, rHm is in most instances masc.: (Msb:) pl. as above. (K.) It is said in a holy tradition (Hadiyv qudosiY~ [i. e. an inspired or a revealed tradition]) that God said, when He created Alr~aHim [meaning “ relationship, ” &c.], A^anaA Al~aHom`nu waA^anota Alr~aHimu $aqaqotu A@somaka mini A@somiY famano waSalaka waSalotuhu wamano qaTaEaka qaTaEotuhu (assumed tropical:) [I am AlrHm`n and thou art AlrHm: I have derived thy name from my name: therefore whoso maketh thee close, I will make him close; and who severeth thee, I will sever him]. (TA.) [waSala raHimahu means (assumed tropical:) He made close his tie, or ties, of relationship, by kind behaviour to his kindred: and qaTaEa raHimahu, He severed his tie, or ties, of relationship, by unkind behaviour to his kindred: see art. wSl: and see also bal~a raHimahu, in the first paragraph of art. bl; and a verse there cited.] ― -b3- *uw Alr~aHimi means (assumed tropical:) [The possessor of relationship, &c.; i. e.] the contr. of AlA^ajonabiY~u: (Mgh, Msb:) the pl. *awuw AlA^aroHaAmi, [or, as in the Kur viii. last verse, and xxxiii. 6, A^uwluw AlA^aroHaAmi,] in the classical language, means any relations: and in law, any relations that have no portion [of the inheritances termed faraAy^iD] and are not [such heirs as are designated by the appellation] EaSabap [q. v.]; (KT, TA in art. *w;) [i. e.,] with respect to the faraAy^iD, it means the relations by the women's side. (IAth, TA in the present art.) *uw raHimK maHoramK and [some say] muHar~amK [and *uw raHimK maHoramN also (see art. Hrm)] mean (assumed tropical:) A relation whom it is unlawful to marry, [whether male or female, the latter being included with the former, but the female, when particularly meant, is termed *aAtu raHimK maHoramK &c.,] such as the mother and the daughter and the sister and the paternal aunt and the maternal aunt [and the male relations of such degrees]: and most of the learned, of the Companions and of the generation following these, and Aboo-Haneefeh and his companions, and Ahmad [Ibn-Hambal], hold that when one possesses a person that is termed *uw raHimK maHoramK, this person becomes emancipated, whether male or female; but Esh-Sháfi'ee and others of the Imáms and of the Companions and of the generation following these hold that the children and the fathers and the mothers become emancipated, and not any others than these. (IAth, TA.) ― -b4- [HaAs~apu raHimK means (assumed tropical:) A feeling of relationship or consanguinity, or sympathy of blood; and in like manner, elliptically, raHimN alone. You say, A^aT~ato lahu min~iY HaAs~apu raHimK; expl. in art. Hs: and A^aT~ato lahu raHimiY; and A^aT~ato bika Alr~aHimu; expl. in art. AT. ― -b5- raHimN is also often used for farojN or HayaA='N, meaning (assumed tropical:) The vulva: see, for exs., $uforN, and 1 in art. ZA=r, and 8 in art. HwS.] -A2- As an epithet, with p, applied to a she-camel: see raHuwmN. ― -b2- And as an epithet without p, applied to a water-skin: see 1, last sentence but one.
ruHumN * : see the next paragraph. -A2- It is also pl. of raHuwmN. (TA.)
