raHomapN * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ raHamapN (Sb, K) and ↓ ruHomN (S, Msb, K) and ↓ ruHumN, (S, K,) thus in a verse of Zuheyr, (S, TA,) and thus in the Kur xviii. 80 accord. to the reading of Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, (TA,) and ↓ maroHamapN, (S, Msb, K,) of which last maraAHimu is pl., (TA,) [all inf. ns.; when used as simple substs. signifying Mercy, pity, or compassion; i. e.] tenderness (S, Msb, K, and Bd on the basomalap) of heart; (Bd ibid.;) and inclination to favour, (S, Msb, K,) or inclination requiring the exercise of favour and beneficence: (Bd ubi suprà:) and pardon, or forgiveness: (K:) accord. to Er-Rághib, raHomapN signifies tenderness requiring the exercise of beneficence towards the object thereof: and it is used sometimes as meaning tenderness divested of any other attribute: and sometimes as meaning beneficence divested of tenderness; as when it is used as an attribute of the Creator: when used as an attribute of men, it means tenderness, and inclination to favour [without necessarily implying beneficence]: accord. to El-Káshánee, it is of two kinds; namely, gratuitous, and obligatory: the former is that which pours forth favours, or benefits, antecedently to works; and this is the rHmp that embraces everything: the obligatory is that which is promised to the pious and the doers of good, in the Kur vii. 155 and vii. 54: but this, he says, is included in the gratuitous, because the promise to bestow it for works is purely gratuitous: accord. to the explanation of the Imám Aboo-Is-hák Ahmad Ibn-Mohammad-Ibn-Ibráheem Eth-Thaalebee, it is God's desire to do good to the deserving thereof; so that it is an essential attribute: or the abstaining from punishing him who deserves punishment, and doing good to him who does not deserve [this]; so that it is an attribute of operation. (TA.) The saying in the Kur [xxi. 75] waA^adoxalonaAhu fiY raHomatinaA (tropical:) [And we caused him to enter into our mercy] is tropical: so says IJ. (TA.) ― -b2- waA@ll~`hu yaxotaS~u biraHomatihi mano ya$aA='u, in the Kur [ii. 99 and iii. 67], means (assumed tropical:) [And God distinguishes] with his gift of prophecy [whom He will], or his prophetic office or commission. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- raHomapN also means (assumed tropical:) Sustenance, or the means of subsistence: this is said to be its meaning as used in the Kur xli. 50. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Rain: (TA:) so in the Kur vii. 55. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Plenty; or abundance of herbage, and of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life: so in the Kur x. 22 and xxx. 35. (TA.)
raHamapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
ruHomaY * [The saying raHimaka A@ll~`hu May God have mercy on thee; &c.;] a subst. from raH~ama Ealayohi [like buqoyaA from A^aboqaY Ealayohi]. (K.)
raHomaA='u * : see raHuwmN.

Alr~aHom`nu * [thus generally written when it has the article Al prefixed to it, but in other cases raHomaAnu, imperfectly decl.,] and ↓ Alr~aHiymu are names [or epithets] applied to God: (TA:) [the former, considered as belonging to a large class of words expressive of passion or sensation, such as gaDobaAnu and EaTo$aAnu &c., but, being applied to God, as being used tropically, or anthropopathically, may be rendered The Compassionate: ↓ the latter, considered as expressive of a constant attribute with somewhat of intensiveness, agreeably with analogy, may be rendered the Merciful: but they are variously explained: it is said that] they are both names [or epithets] formed to denote intensiveness of signification, from raHima; like AlgaDobaAnu from gaDiba, and AlEaliymu from Ealima; and Alr~aHomapu, in the proper language, is “ tenderness of heart, ” and “ inclination requiring the exercise of favour and beneficence; ” but the names of God are only to be taken [or understood] with regard to the ultimate imports, which are actions, exclusively of the primary imports, which may be passions: and the former is more intensive in
signification than the latter; the former including in its objects the believer and the unbeliever, and ↓ the latter having for its peculiar object the believer: (Bd on the basomalap:) accord. to J, (TA,) they are two names [or epithets] derived from Alr~aHomapu, and are like nadomaAnu and nadiymN, and are syn.; the repetition being allowable when the [mode of] derivation is different, for the purpose of corroboration: (S, TA:) or the repetition is because the former is Hebrew, [originally 165,] and ↓ the latter is Arabic: (I'Ab, TA:) but the former is applicable to God only; though Museylimeh the Liar was called raHomaAnu AlyamaAmapi; (S, TA;) and it is said to mean the Possessor of the utmost degree of Alr~aHomap; and accord. to Zj, is a name of God mentioned in the most ancient books: (TA:) whereas ↓ the latter is syn. with ↓ Alr~aAHimu: (S, TA:) or [rather] ↓ raAHimN is the act. part. n. [signifying having mercy, &c.], and ↓ raHiymN has an intensive signification [i. e. having much mercy, &c.]: (Msb:) the latter is applied also to a man; and so is ↓ raHuwmN, in the same sense, and likewise to a woman: (TA:) the pl. of ↓ raHiymN is ruHamaA='u; (Msb, TA;) occurring in the trad., A_in~amaA yaroHamu A@ll~`hu mino EibaAdihi Alr~uHamaA='a, or Alr~uHamaA='u, as related by different persons; [i. e. God has mercy on the merciful only of his servants, or verily those on whom God has mercy, of his servants, are the merciful;] AlrHmA' being in the accus. case as the objective complement of yrHm, and in the nom. case as the enunciative of mA in the sense of Al~a*iY. (Msb.)

raHamuwtN * is from raHomapN, [with which it is syn.,] (S, TA,) but it is used only coupled with its like in form: (K, TA:) one says, rahabuwtN xayorN laka mino raHamuwtK [Fear is better for thee than pity, or compassion], meaning thy being feared is better than thy being pitied, or compassionated: (S, K: but in the former, without lk:) or, accord. to Mbr, ↓ rahabuwtaY xayorN mino raHamuwtaY. (Meyd. [See art. rhb.])
raHamuwtaY * : see what next precedes.
ruHaAmN * : see 1, last sentence but two.

raHuwmN * (Lh, S, K) and ↓ raHomaA='u, (K,) applied to a she-camel, (Lh, S, TA,) and to a ewe or she-goat, and to a woman, (TA,) [and app. to any animal having a womb, (see raHumato)] Having a complaint of her womb (Lh, S, M, K) after bringing forth, (Lh, S, K,) and dying in consequence thereof; (K;) and ↓ raHimapN, applied to a she-camel, signifies the same: the pl. of raHuwmN is ruHumN, with two dammehs. (TA.) ― -b2- For the first, see also Alr~aHom`nu, near the end of the paragraph.

raHiymu * : see Alr~aHom`nu, in seven places. ― -b2- Sometimes it is syn. with ↓ maroHuwmN [i. e. Treated, or regarded, with mercy or pity or compassion; &c.: see 1, first sentence]: 'Amelles Ibn-'Akeel says, (using it in this sense, Ham p. 628,)
faA^am~aA A_i*aA EaD~ato bika AlHarobu EaD~apF
faA_in~aka maEoTuwfN Ealayoka raHiymu
(S, and Ham,) i. e. [But at all events,] when war becomes [once] severe to thee, and thine enemy has almost overcome thee, [verily thou art regarded with favour,] treated with mercy, and defended, by us. (Ham.)
raAHimN * : see Alr~aHom`nu, in two places, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also, applied to a ewe, and to a she-goat, Having the womb swollen. (Lh, K.)
A^aroHamu * [More, and most, merciful, &c.]. God is A^aroHamu Alr~aAHimyna [The Most Merciful of those that have mercy]. (TA.)
maroHamapN * : see raHomapN.

muraH~amN * [Treated, or regarded, with much mercy or pity or compassion; &c.]: it is with teshdeed to denote intensiveness of the signification. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [See also 2, of which it is the pass. part. n.]

maroHuwmN * : see raHiymN. ― -b2- AlmaroHuwmapu is a name of El-Medeeneh. (K.) ― -b3- [And AlmaroHuwmu, which may be rendered The object of God's mercy, is commonly used in the present day as an epithet applied to the person, whoever he be, that has died in what is believed to be the true faith; as though meaning merely the deceased.]

div2.head: rHw and rHY
div2.entryFree: 1 raHati AlHay~apu * , (S, K,) aor. taroHuw (S) [and app. taroHaY also (see raHoyapN)]; and ↓ trH~t; (S, K;) The serpent turned round about, (S, K, TA,) and twisted, or wound, or coiled, itself; ISd adds, kaAlr~aH~Y [i. e. like the mill, or millstone]; for which reason it is said to be A_iHod~Y banaAti TibaqK. (TA.) -A2- raHawotu Alr~aHaA or Alr~aHaY, (S, K,) inf. n. raHowN; (TA;) and raHayotuhaA, (S, K,) inf. n. raHoYN; (TA;) I turned round the rHA or rHY [i. e. the mill, or mill-stone]: (S, K:) or I made it: (K:) in the K, the latter verb is said to be extr.; but not so in the T or S or M: in the M it is said to be the more common. (TA.) -A3- And raHaAhu He magnified him, or honoured him. (IAar, TA.)
5 ta1a2~a3a see above, first sentence.

raHFY * (S, Msb, K, &c.) and raHFA, (Msb, * K,) the former of which is the more approved, (TA,) and some say ↓ raHaA='N, (S,) A mill; syn. TaAHuwnN: (Msb:) [and] a mill-stone; i. e. the great round stone with which one grinds: (TA:) of the fem. gender: (Zj, S, Msb, K:) dual of the first raHayaAni, (S, Msb, K,) and of the second raHawaAni, (Msb, * K,) and of the third, raHaAA=ni: (S:) the pl. (of pauc., S) of raHFY (Msb) [and of raHFA] is A^aroHK and (of mult., S) A^aroHaA='N, (S, Msb, K,) which latter is the pl. that is preferred accord. to IAmb, (Msb,) and ruHiY~N and riHiY~N, (Msb, K, TA,) with damm and with kesr (Msb, TA) to the r (Msb,) [for the last of which raHiY~N is substituted in the CK,] and A^uroHiY~N, (K, TA,) with damm, and with kesr to the H and teshdeed to the Y (TA,) [in the CK A^aroHiY~N,] and A^aroHiyapN, (Msb, K,) which is extr., (K,) said by AHát to be wrong, and by IAmb to be anomalous, and by Zj to be not allowable, (Msb,) in the T said to be as though it were a pl. pl., (TA,) or it is pl. of raHaA='N [and therefore regular]: (S:) the dim. is ↓ ruHay~apN. (Zj, Msb.) raHaA Alyadi [or raHaY Alyadi] signifies The hand-mill. (MA.) ― -b2- [Hence, A molar tooth, or grinder:] i. q. DirosN; (S, Msb, K;) pl. A^aroHaA='N i. q. A^aDoraAsN: (S:) [or rather] the A^aroHaA=', also called the TawaAHin, are the twelve teeth, three on each side [above and below], next after the DawaAHik [or bicuspids]. (Zj, in his “ Khalk el-Insán. ”) ― -b3- [And app. A roller with which land is rolled to crush the clods; as being likened to a mill-stone: see 1 in art. xtm, near the end of the paragraph.] ― -b4- Stones: and a great rock, or mass of stone. (TA.) ― -b5- A round piece of ground, rising above what surrounds it, (S, K,) about as large in extent as a mile: (K:) pl. A^aroHaA='N: (K, TA:) or this latter, i. e. the pl., signifies pieces of rugged ground, less than mountains, round, and rising above what surrounds them: (M, TA:) or raHFA mina AlA^aroDi means a round and rugged place [or piece of ground] among sands: (Sh, TA:) or a large and rugged [elevation such as is termed] qaArap or A^akamap, round, rising above what surrounds it, not spreading upon the surface of the earth, nor producing herbs, or leguminous plants, nor trees. (ISh, TA.) ― -b6- A round cloud; [as being likened to a mill-stone;] (A in art. rjH:) or so raHaY saHaAbK. (S.) ― -b7- The kirokirap [or callous protuberance upon the breast] of a camel; (T, S, K;) so called because of its roundness: (TA:) pl. A^aroHaA='N: (K:) which likewise signifies the callous protuberances upon the knees of the camel. (T, TA.) ― -b8- The foot (firosin) of the camel and of the elephant: pl. A^aroHaA='N. (M, K.) ― -b9- A daAy^irap [app. meaning a circling border] around the nail. (TA.) ― -b10- The breast, or chest: pl., as in the other senses following, A^aroHaA='N. (K.) ― -b11- Spinage, or spinach; (M, K;) because of the roundness of its leaves. (TA.) ― -b12- (tropical:) A collective body of the members of a household. (ISd, K, TA.) ― -b13- (tropical:) An independent tribe: (K, TA:) A^aroHaA='N (which is its pl., K, TA) signifies (tropical:) independent tribes, that are in no need of others. (S, TA.) ― -b14- (assumed tropical:) A large number of camels, crowding, or pressing, together; (S, K, TA;) also called TaH~aAnapN: (S, TA:) or raHaA AlA_ibili means the collective herd of the camels: and in like manner, raHaA Alqawomi the collective body of the people, or party. (ISk, TA.) ― -b15- raHaY Alqawomi signifies [also] (tropical:) The chief of the people, or party. (T, S, M, K, TA.) [It is added in the TA that 'Omar Ibn-El-Khattáb was called raHaY AlHarobi, as though meaning (assumed tropical:) The chief of war; because of his warlike propensities: but it seems from what here follows, as well as from what precedes, that this may be a mistranscription, for raHaY Alqawomi or raHaY AlEarabi.] ― -b16- raHaY AlHarobi signifies (tropical:) The most vehement part [or the thickest] of the fight; syn. HawomatuhaA: (S, Msb:) in the K it is said that Alr~aHaY signifies Hawomapu AlHarobi, and muEoZamuhu; as also ↓ AlmaroHaY: but it seems that there is an omission;
for AlHrb is [generally] fem., and in the M it is said that raHaY Almawoti signifies muEoZamuhu [app. meaning the main stress, or the thickest, of death in battle]. (TA.) In a saying relating to 'Alee's having made an end of Aljamali ↓ maroHay, this expression is expl. by A 'Obeyd as meaning The place around which revolved the thickest of the fight (AlmawoDiEu Al~a*iy daArato Ealayohi raHay AlHarobi) [in the Battle of the Camel]. (TA.) And daArato Ealayohi raHay Almawoti [which may be rendered (assumed tropical:) The main stress of death beset him round about] means death befell him. (Msb, TA.)
raHoyapN * [or Hay~apN raHoyapN meaning A serpent folding, or coiling, itself, so as to resemble a neck-ring]: see raH~apN, in art. rH.
raHaA='N * : see raHFy, first sentence.
ruHay~apN * dim. of raHFy, q. v. (Zj, Msb.)

qaSoEapN raH~aA='u *
A shallow, or a wide, [bowl such as is termed] qSEp. (TA. [It is there mentioned in art. rHw, but belongs to art. rH q. v.])

maroHFy *
A place of a mill or mill-stone. (MA.) ― -b2- See also raHFy (near the end of the paragraph), in two places. ― -b3- [Accord. to Freytag, it occurs in the Deewán of the Hudhalees as meaning (assumed tropical:) A place where any one stands firmly.]

muraHK *
A maker of mills or mill-stones. (K, TA.) -A2- And Moisture in the ground to the extent of a palm. (AHn, TA.)

1 rax~a * , aor.
raxi3a , inf. n. rax~u, said of dough, It had in it much water [so that it was soft: see also 8]. (TA.) -A2- rax~ahu, (JK, T, K,) aor.
raxu3a , (JK,) inf. n. as above, (TK,) He broke it, or crushed it, (JK, T,) and so made it soft: (T:) or he trod upon it, (T, K,) and so made it soft. (T.) ― -b2- Also He mixed (JK, S, K) what is termed nabiy*, (JK,) or wine, or beverage: (S, K:) and likewise food with condiment. (JK.)

4 Arx~hu *
He put much water into it [so as to make it soft]; namely, dough. (TA.) -A2- [The inf. n.] A_iroxaAxN also signifies The exceeding the usual, or ordinary, or the just, or proper, bounds, or degree; or the acting egregiously, or immoderately; or the like; (syn. mubaAlagapN;) in a thing. (K.)

8 Artx~ * , (IAar, TA,) inf. n. AirotixaAxN, (IAar, K, TA,) for which, in some copies of the K, is put AstrxAx, but the former is the right reading, (TA,) said of dough, (IAar, TA,) It was, or became, soft, or flaccid. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) It (one's opinion) was, or became, unsound, faulty, or confused; syn. AiDoTaraba. (K, TA.)
rax~N * [Lax, or flaccid: (Golius, on the authority or Meyd:) or soft]: see its fem., rax~apN, voce raxaAxN.

rux~N *
A certain soft, flaccid, or fragile, plant; (AHn, S, K;) as also ↓ raxaAxN, with fet-h, (mentioned by ISd,) or ↓ rixaAxN. (So in the JK.) -A2- Also A certain great bird, that carries off the karokad~an [or rhinoceros]. (K. [See note 22 to ch. xx. of my translation of the “ Thousand and One Nights. ” The word is of Persian origin, arabicized; as it is said to be by Lth in the sense next following.]) ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, (TA,) One of the pieces with which the game of chess is played; [called by us the rook, castle, and tower:] pl. rixaxapN, (K,) or rixaAxN (JK, A,) or both. (TA.)

raxaAxN * [app., in its primary acceptation, Softness of a substance, such as earth &c.: and hence,] softness, delicateness, or easiness, of life. (JK, TA.) ― -b2- It is also used as an epithet. (TA.) You say A^aroDN raxaAxN Soft land, of which the soil is good; as also ↓ rax~apN: pl. raxaAy^ixu: (JK:) or wide and soft land, whether level or not level: (ISh:) or soft, or yielding, land: (S, K, TA:) and ↓ rax~aA='u, (K, TA,) with teshdeed and medd, (TA,) [in the CK raxA', without teshdeed,] signifies the like: (IAar, K:) or this last (rx~A='), wide land: (K:) or tumid land or earth, that breaks in pieces beneath the tread: and its pl. is raxaAxay~u. (JK, K.) And raxaAxu Alv~aray What is soft of soil, or of moist earth. (TA.) And Eayo$N raxaAxN A life, or state of life, that is ample, unstraitened, or easy, (S, K, TA,) and soft. (TA.) ― -b3- See also rux~N.
rixaAxN * : see rux~N.
raxiyxN * : see raxoraxN.
rax~aA='u * : see raxaAxN.
raxoraxN * and ↓ raxoraAxN, applied to mud, or clay, (JK, K,) and to dough, (JK,) Thin, and soft: (JK, K, TA:) and ↓ raxiyxN soft, or moist, mud or clay. (KL.)
raxoraAxN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
muraxoraxu Alxaloqi * , applied to a man, and to a camel, Lax, or not firm, in make, by reason of fatness. (JK.)

sakoraAnu murotax~N *
Intoxicated, full of drink; (K;) as also mulotax~N. (TA.)
mutaraxorixN * , applied to a man, and to a camel, Flaccid, or flabby, by reason of old age or of emaciation. (JK.)

1 raxuSa * , aor.
raxuSa , inf. n. ruxoSN, It (a thing, Msb, or a price, S, A) was, or became, cheap, low-priced, or low. (S, A, Msb, K, TA.) [Accord. to all of these authorities, this seems to be the primary signification: but Et-Tebreezee (Ham p. 47) thinks it to be from raxoSapN applied to a woman, as meaning “ soft, or tender. ”] Some say raxaSa also; but this is not of established authority. (MF.) ― -b2- raxuSa, aor.
raxuSa , (M, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. raxaASapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and ruxuwSapN (S, M, Msb, K) and ruxoSaAnu, (Lth, TA,) It (a thing, K, or the body, S, Msb, or flesh, A) was, or became, soft, or tender; (S, M, A, Msb, K, TA;) and soft to the feel: (Msb:) and in like manner raxuSato said of a girl: (A:) or, said of a woman, inf. n. ruxoSaAnN, she was, or became, soft, or tender, and delicate, or thin, in her external skin: and said of a woman's fingers, they were, or became, soft, or tender: but when said of a plant, inf. n. raxaASapN, it was, or became, soft, flaccid, or easily or quickly broken: (Lth:) [and said of a twig, or rod, it was, or became, fresh, or succulent, and soft, or tender: see raxoSN.]

2 ruxiSa lahu fiy ka*aA * , inf. n. taroxiySN, He had indulgence, license, or facilitation, granted, or conceded, to him in, or with respect to, such a thing. (S, A, * K *) You say, rax~aSa Al$~aroEu lanaA fiy ka*aA, inf. n. as above, The law has been indulgent to us in, or with respect to, such a thing; has facilitated it to us; as also ↓ ArxS, inf. n. A_iroxaASN. (Msb.) And rax~aSotu fulaAnAF fiy ka*aA wa ka*aA, [or, more commonly, lifulaAnK,] I gave license, or permission, to such a one to do such and such things after my forbidding him to do them. (TA.)

4 ArxShu *
He (God, S, A, Msb, or a man, JK) made it (a thing, Msb, or a price, S, A) cheap, low-priced, or low. (JK, S, A, Msb, K.) rax~aSahu, in this sense, is not known. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also He found it to be cheap, low-priced, or low. (K.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or ↓ ArtxShu, (S, A,) He bought it cheap, or at a low price. (S, A, K.) ― -b4- See also 2.

5 trx~S *
He took, or availed himself of, or allowed himself, indulgence, license, or facilitation; (A, TA;) he did not go to the utmost length; (S, Msb, K;) [he relaxed, or remitted;] in (fiy) such a thing; (S;) in affairs; (A;) or in the affair. (Msb.) You say also, trx~S fiy Haqihi He took what was easily attainable, of his right, or due, and did not go to the utmost length. (A.)
8 ArtxShu * : see 4. ― -b2- Also, (S, Sgh, K,) or ↓ AstrxShu, (A,) He reckoned it cheap, or lowpriced: (S, A, Sgh, K:) and ↓ the latter, he saw it, or judged it, to be so. (Lth, K.)
10 AstrxShu * : see 8, in two places.

raxoSN * applied to a thing, (A, K,) or to the body, (S, Msb,) and to flesh, and to a plant, (A,) Soft, or tender; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) and soft to the feel: (Msb:) and ↓ raxiySN signifies the same, (AA, M, K,) applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (AA, K,) as also the former: (TA:) fem. of each with p: (M, TA:) raxoSpN is also applied to a girl, (A,) and to a woman, (K, TA, but omitted in the CK,) and to fingers, signifying not rigid or tough: (K:) or, applied to a woman, it signifies soft, or tender, and delicate, or thin, in her external skin: and applied to a woman's fingers, soft, or tender: but raxoSN applied to a plant, soft, flaccid, or easily or quickly broken: (Lth, TA:) and applied to a twig, or rod, fresh, or succulent, and soft, or tender: (Msb:) the pl.
of raxoSN is rixaASN: (Msb:) and that of raxoSapN is raxaAy^iSu, which is irreg. [as such, but reg. as pl. of ↓ raxiySapN]; (K, TA;) occurring in poetry. (TA.) You say, huwa raxoSu Aljasadi He is soft, or tender, in body. (S.) And AimoraA^apN raxoSapu Albadani A woman soft, or tender, in body. (IDrd, TA.)

ruxoSN * [see 1, of which it is the inf. n., in the first of the senses explained above. ― -b2- Also The act of making cheap;] a subst. from A^aroxaSahu in the first of the senses here assigned thereto. (Msb.)

ruxoSapN * (S, A, Msb, K) and ruxuSapN (A, Msb, K) Indulgence, license or facilitation; (S, A, Msb, K;) in an affair: (S, A, Msb:) pl. ruxaSN (A, Msb) and ruxoSaAtN and ruxaSaAtN and ruxuSaAtN. (Msb.) You say, laka fiY h`*aA ruxoSapN [Thou hast, or shalt have, in, or with respect to, this, indulgence, license, or facilitation]. (A.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Indulgence granted, or conceded, by God to his servant, in a matter which He alleviates to him. (A, K.) ― -b3- [(assumed tropical:) An ordinance of indulgence; such as the shortening of prayer in travelling, and the like: pl. ruxaSN, of which we have an ex. in the following trad.:] Aall~`hu yuHib~u A^ano tuw^otaY ruxaSuhu kamaA yuHib~u A^ano tuw^otaY EazaAy^imuhu [(assumed tropical:) God loveth that his ordinances of indulgence be performed, like as He loveth that his obligatory ordinances be performed]. (A.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A portion, or share, of water: (A:) or a time, or turn, in drinking. (K.)

raxiySN * A cheap, or low-priced, thing; (Msb;) a low price. (S, A.) -A2- (tropical:) A quick death. (Lth, A, K.) -A3- See also raxoSN, in two places. ― -b2- (tropical:) Soft, without strength or sturdiness, and without endurance: or stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence; syn. baliydN. (TA.)

rixolN *
A ewe-lamb; (S, K;) as also ↓ rixolapN and ↓ raxilN: (K:) the male is called HamalN: (S:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aroxulN (K) and [of mult.] rixaAlN and ruxaAlN (S, K,) which last is of an extr. form, (TA,) and rixolaAnN and raxalapN and rixalapN. (K.)
raxilN * : see the preceding paragraph.
rixolapN * : see the preceding paragraph.

mutarax~ilN *
A possessor and rearer of ewe-lambs. (S.)

1 raxuma * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
raxuma , (K,) inf.n. raxaAmapN; (S, Msb;) and raxama aor.
raxuma ; (K;) It (the voice, S, TA, and speech, K, TA) was, or became, soft, or gentle, and easy: (S, * K, TA:) [or it (the voice) was, or became, soft, or gentle, plaintive, and melodious: (see raxiymN:)] it (a thing, and the speech,) was, or became, easy: (Msb:) raxaAmap in speech is a good quality in women. (TA.) One says also of a girl, raxumato, (K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) meaning She was, or became, easy [and soft or gentle] in speech: (K, TA:) and in like manner, of a [young gazelle such as is termed] xi$of [meaning in voice, or cry]: and raxamato, said of a she-gazelle, means she uttered a [soft or gentle] cry. (TA.) -A2- raxamato bayoDahaA and EalaY bayoDihaA: see 4. ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] raxamato waladahaA, aor.
raxuma and
raxama , (assumed tropical:) She (a woman) played with her child: (K:) [or,] accord. to the “ Nawá- dir el-Aaráb, ” trxm Sabiy~ahaA and trxm Ealayohi, [app. taroxumu and taroxamu in both cases,] said of a woman, mean taroHamuhu (tropical:) [She treats, or regards, her boy with mercy, pity, or compassion; &c.]: (TA:) and raxamotu Al$~aYo'a means raHimotuhu (tropical:) [I treated, or regarded, the thing with mercy, &c.]: (K, TA:) AZ says that raximahu, aor.
raxama , inf. n. raxamapN, and raHimahu, aor.
raxama , inf. n. raHomapN, are syn.: (S:) and he says that raxama [thus accord. to the TA] is of the dial. of some of the people of El-Yemen: it is tropical: Lh, also, mentions raxamahu, aor.
raxama , inf. n. rxamapN, as meaning (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, inclined to favour him, or affectionate to him. (TA.) -A3- raxima, said of a skin for water or milk, It was, or became, stinking. (TA.)

2 rx~mh * , (Msb,) inf. n. taroxiymN, (S, Msb, TA,) He made it soft, or gentle: (S, TA:) or he made it easy: namely, [the voice, (see 1,) or] speech. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb, K,*) or from Alt~aroxiymu signifying, as some say, The cutting off [a thing], or cutting [it] at its extremity, or curtailing [it], (S,) the taroxiym of the name, (S, Msb, K,) in the vocative form of speech; (S;) [accord. to general opinion,] because it facilitates the pronunciation thereof; (K;) i. e. the [abbreviating by the] eliding of the end thereof, for the alleviation of the utterance; (Msb;) the curtailing a name of its last letter, or more; (S, TA;) as when, to one whose name is HaArivN or maAlikN, you say yaA HaAri or yaAmaAli: but accord. to Z, in the A, it is from the trxym of the hen; because this is only on the occasion of the cutting short (qaToE) [of the laying] of the eggs: (TA:) [in like manner also] the taroxiym of the diminutive is the [abbreviating thereof by the] cutting off of [one or more of] the augmentative letters [and sometimes of radical letters]; as when, in forming the diminutive of A^asowadu [and that of A_iboraAhiymu], one says suwayodN [and burayohu]. (Har p. 334.) ― -b3- rx~m Ald~ajaAjapa, inf. n. as above, He made the hen to cleave to, or keep to, [or brood upon,] her eggs [for the purpose of hatching them]. (M, K.) -A2- [rx~m also signifies He constructed, or cased, a building, or a floor &c., with ruxaAm: but this is perhaps post-classical.]

4 Arxmt EalaY bayoDihaA * ; (S, K;) or Arxmt alone; (JK;) and bayoDahaA ↓ raxamato, and EalaY bayoDihaA, (K,) aor.
raxuma , (TA,) inf. n. raxomN and raxamN and raxamapN; (K;) She (a domestic hen, JK, S, K, and an ostrich, JK, TA) brooded upon her eggs, to hatch them. (JK, S, K.)
8 Artxmt faSiylahaA * (assumed tropical:) She (a camel) loved, affected, or inclined to, and kept to, or clave to, her young one. (TA.)

raxamN * (assumed tropical:) Favour, or affection; or mercy, pity, or compassion: and love: and gentleness; (K, TA;) as also ↓ raxamapN [which appears to be the more common, and which is mentioned above as an inf. n]: (S, K,* TA:) the latter is nearly the same as raHomapN. (S.) One says, ↓ waqaEato Ealayohi raxamatuhu (assumed tropical:) His love, and his gentleness, fell, or lighted, upon him. (S.) And ↓ A^aloqaY Ealayohi raxamatahu and raxamahu, (K, TA,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He made to fall, or light, upon him, or bestowed upon him,] his love, and his gentleness: this is said of God. (TA.) And A^aloqato Ealayohi raxamahaA and ↓ raxamatahaA i. e. (assumed tropical:) [She made to fall, or light, upon him, or bestowed upon him,] her favour, or affection, or her mercy, pity, or compassion. (TA.) And A^um~ihi ↓ A^uloqiyato Ealayohi raxamapu, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [upon whom] the love and familiarity of his mother [have been made to fall or light, or have been bestowed], is an explanation given by As of the pass. part. n. ↓ maroxuwmN. (S, TA.) [But accord. to Z, these significations are from raxamapN as signifying a bird of a certain species described in what follows: for] it is said in the A that A^aloqaY Ealayohi ↓ raxamapF means (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, affectionate, or pitiful, or compassionate, to him, and attached to him: because the raxamap is vehemently voracious, and fond of alighting upon carcasses: therefore love and affection lighting upon one are likened thereto. (TA.) -A2- A certain [species of] bird, well known; [the vultur percnopterus; being for the most part white, called by some the white carrion-vulture of Egypt and the neighbouring countries; and also called Pharaoh's hen; in Hebr. 165: (see Bochart, Hieroz., 297-322:)] n. un. ↓ raxamapN: (K:) the former is the pl. of the latter, (S, Msb,) denoting the genus, (S,) [i. e., its coll. gen. n.,] like as qaSabN is of qaSabapN: (Msb:) the pl. [properly so termed] of raxamapN is ruxomN [like as budonN is of badanapN, or perhaps of raxamN, like as A^usodN is of A^asadN,] (JK, TA) and also ↓ruxamN [which is anomalous]: (JK:) the ↓ raxamap is a partycoloured bird, white and black, (S, TA,) resembling the nasor (JK, S, TA) in form; and also called A^anuwqN: (S, TA:) [it is said to be] a bird that eats human dung, a foul bird, not of such as are pursued as game, wherefore no expiation is incumbent on him who kills it when he is in the state of A_iHoraAm, for it is not eaten: it is [said to be] thus called because it is too weak to take prey: (Msb:) [various fanciful uses of its gall-bladder and flesh &c. for medicinal and other purposes are described in the K: accord. to some, if not all, it is a term for the female: (see A^anuwqN:)] the male is called ↓yaroxumN and ↓yaroxuwmN (JK, K) and ↓taroxuwmN. (Kr, K.) -A3- Also Thick milk. (IAar, K.) -A4- The ↓raxamap [as written in the JK, but in the TA without any syll. signs,] of the horse is like the rabolap [app. as meaning The inner part of the thigh] of a human being: (JK, TA:) one says, farasN naAtiY'u Alrxmpi [A horse having the rxmp protuberant]. (TA.) [If correctly written in the JK, it is probably a n. un. of which raxamN is the coll. gen. n.: and hence, perhaps,] warohaA='u Alr~axami, applied by the poet ' Amr Dhu-l-Kelb to a ewe abounding with milk, as meaning Soft [in the raxam, and app. protuberant therein, and by reason
thereof, and of the largeness of her udder, waddling,] as though she were mad, or possessed. (TA.)
ruxamN * a pl. of raxamapN q. v. [n. un. of raxamN; like
ruxomN * , but anomalous]. (JK.)

ruxumN *
Lumps of biestings. (IAar, K.)

ruxomapN * , with damm, (TA, [analogously with the generality of words of similar meaning, but this fact may have occasioned some writer's adding “ with damm, ”] or ↓ raxamapN, (so in the JK, [if correct, app., as being likened to a white vulture,]) A whiteness in the head of a ewe or she-goat: (JK, TA:) and a dust-colour in her face, the rest of her being of any colour. (TA.)
raxamapN * : see raxamN, in nine places: ― -b2- and see also ruxomapN.

raxomaAnu *
i. q. raHomaAnu. (TA.)

ruxaAmN * [commonly applied to Marble: and sometimes to alabaster: the latter application is the more agreeable with the following explanation:] a certain white, soft stone: (JK, S, Mgh, K, TA:) what is of the colour of wine, or yellow, or dappled, is of the kinds of stones, (K, TA,) i. e., not [a sort] of ruxaAm: (TA:) a well-known kind of stone: (Msb:) n. un. with p [meaning a piece, or slab, &c., thereof]. (Mgh, Msb.) [See also maromarN.]

raxiymN * , applied to speech, (S, Msb, K,) &c., (Msb,) Soft, or gentle, and easy: (S,* K:) or [simply] easy: (Msb:) and, applied to the voice, soft, or gentle, plaintive, and melodious. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a girl, (K,) and so raxiymapN, (As, JK, K,) Easy [and soft or gentle] in speech: (As, K:) and in like manner, AlS~awoti ↓ muroxuwampu [a girl soft, or gentle, &c., in voice]: (JK:) and in like manner also the first and second are applied to a [young gazelle such as is termed] xi$of. (TA.) ― -b3- raxiymu AlHawaA$iY Gentle, gracious, or courteous, to his associates. (TA.)
ruxaAmapN * n. an. of ruxaAmN [q. v.]. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- Also A certain plant. (AHn, K.)

ruxaAmaY *
A certain plant, (AHn, K,) different from the xDrp [app. xaDirap, with which some probably identify it], having a blossom of a pure white, and a white root, which the [wild] asses dig up with their hoofs, and all the wild animals eat because of its sweetness and pleasantness; and its places of growth are the sands: (AHn, TA:) or, as some say, (TA,) a kind of tree like the DaAl [q. v.]. (S, TA.) [See also ray~iHapN, in art. rwH.] -A2- Also [or riyHN ruxaAmaY] A soft, or gentle, wind. (K.)
raAximN * : see muroximN. ― -b2- A_in~ahu laraAximN lahu Verily he is inclined to favour him; or is affectionate to him. (Lh, TA.)

A^aroxamu * , applied to a horse, and the fem. raxomaA='u applied to a ewe or she-goat, Whose head is white, the rest being black: (S, K:) the latter like muxam~arapN : one should not say murax~amapN: (S:) or the former, a horse whose face is white: (Mgh:) and the latter, a ewe, or she-goat, having a whiteness on her head. (JK.)

maA A^adoriY A^aY~u turoxamK huwa * (JK, S, K) and turoxama (JK, K, TA, but not in the CK) and turoxumK (S, K) and turoxuma (K, TA, but not in the CK) and, accord. to the M, taroxum, (TA,) and ↓ turoxamapa, (accord. to the JK,) or turoxamapK, and turoxumapK, (K,) I know not who of mankind he is. (JK, S, K.)
muroximN * (JK, S, K) and muroximapN (S, TA) and ↓ raAximN (K) A domestic hen, (JK, S, K,) and an ostrich, (JK,) Brooding upon eggs, for the purpose of hatching. (JK, S, K.)
yaroxumN * : see raxamN, in the latter part of the paragraph.
turoxamapu * [or turoxamapN and turoxumapN] i. q. turoxamN and turoxamu [&c.]. (JK.)
taroxuwmN * : see raxamN, in the latter part of the paragraph.
maroxuwmN * : see raxamN, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- maroxuwmapu AlS~awoti: see raxiymN.
yaroxuwmN * : see raxamN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

1 raxuwa * , aor. yaroxuw; and raxiYa, aor. yaroxaY; (S, M, Msb, K;) inf. n. raxaAwapN (M, Msb, K) and raxaA='N, (M, K, but in several copies of the latter raxFA,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and rixowapN, with kesr, (M, K,) which is extr., (M,) and some add ruxowapN, and raxowapN; (MF, TA;) It (a thing, S) was, or became, soft, yielding, flaccid, flabby, lax, slack, uncompact, crummy, fragile, frangible, brittle, friable, easily or quickly broken; i. q. SaAra rixowFA, (S, K, TA,) i. e. ha$~aA; (TA;) or laAna; (Msb;) and ↓ AstrxY signifies the same. (S,* K.) ― -b2- And raxuwa, and raxiYa, (Msb, K,) and [raxaA] like daEaA [of which the aor. is yadoEuw], and [raxaA] like raEaY [of which the aor. is yaroEaY; in the CK, erroneously, like ruEiYa]; (K, TA;) the aor. [or the first and third] being yaroxuw and [that of the second and fourth being] yaroxaY; (TA;) said of life (Eayo$), (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, ample, unstraitened, or plentiful, in its means, or circumstances: (Msb, K: *) or said of a man, inf. n. raxaA='N, (assumed tropical:) he was, or became, in an ample, an unstraitened, or a plentiful, state of life. (TK.)

2 taroxiyapu Al$~aYo'i biAl$~aYo'i *
The mixing of the thing with the thing. (TA.) [The verb is rax~aY, He mixed; like rax~a, which is mentioned in this sense in the present art. in the JK, app. for rax~aY.]

3 rAxAhu * : see 4, in three places. ― -b2- Also, inf. n. muraAxaApN, i. q. baAEadahu [He was, or became, distant, remote, &c., from him: or he made, or caused, him, or it, to be, or become, distant, remote, &c.]. (K.) -A2- And rAxt She (a woman, TA) was, or became, near to bringing forth. (K, TA.)

4 ArxAhu *
He made it, or rendered it, soft, yielding, flaccid, flabby, lax, slack, uncompact, crummy, fragile, frangible, brittle, friable, easily or quickly broken; i. q. jaEalahu rixowFA; as also ↓rAxAhu. (K.) You say, ArxY Alr~ibaATa [He relaxed, or slackened, the tie, or bond]; (M, TA;) and ↓rAxAhu, inf. n. muraAxaApN. (JK, TA.) And lahu mino xinaAqihi ↓ raAxi [lit, Relax thou, or slacken thou, his cord with which he is being strangled]; meaning (assumed tropical:) make thou his circumstances ample and easy to him; ease him; relieve him; or grant him a delay. (TA. [See a similar phrase in art. rbw, conj. 2.]) And A^aroxi lahu qayodahu Make thou his shackle, or shackles, wide, or ample, not strait, to him. (TA.) And A^aroxi lahu AlHabola [lit. Relax thou, or slacken thou, to him the rope]; meaning (tropical:) give thou to him ample scope for using his own judgment, or discretion, in the disposal, or management, of his affairs, so that he may go whither he pleases. (TA.) And ArxY Alfarasa and lilofarasi He lengthened the horse's rope. (K.) And ArxY lahu AlT~iwala [lit. He relaxed, or slackened, his tether]; meaning (tropical:) he left him to his own affair. (A, TA.) And ArxY EimaAmatahu [lit. He slackened, or loosened, his turban]; meaning (assumed tropical:) he became, or felt, in a state of security or safety, tranquil, or at ease; (K, TA;) because the turbans are not slackened, or loosened, (laA turoxaY,) in difficulty, or hardship. (TA.) And ArxY Als~itori (S, Msb, K) wagayorahu (S) He let loose, let down, or lowered, the veil, or curtain, &c. (S, K.) And ArxY viyaAbahu EalaY rijolayohi [He let, or made, his clothes hang down loosely upon his legs] in riding and in sitting [&c.]. (TA in art. rsl.) [And ArxY dumuwEFA (assumed tropical:) He shed tears.] And ArxAhu xaTobuhu (tropical:) His state, or condition, made him to enjoy an easy, ample, or unstraitened, life, or a life of ease and plenty. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Arxt, said of a she-camel, [app. for Arxt SalaAhaA, i. e. She relaxed the part on either side of her tail, virtually] means SalaAhaA ↓AisotaroxaY, (S, K, TA,) i. e. [the part on either side of her tail became relaxed; or] her SalawaAni [or parts on the right and left of her tail] gaped, [or receded from each other,] on the occasion of bringing forth. (T, TA.) ― -b3- A_iroxaA='N also signifies A sort of running: (S:) or vehement running: (K:) or running exceeding what is termed taqoriybN: (JK, K: [see 2 in art. qrb:]) or running (HuDorN) that is not ardent, or not impetuous: (A, TA:) or gentleness in running: (Ham p. 158:) accord. to Az, AlA_iroxaA='u AlA^aEolaY means The most vehement [running termed] HuSor; and AlA_iroxaA='u AlA^adonaY is less than that: and ArxY fiY Eadowihi, said of a horse, signifies A^aHoDara [app. as meaning He rose in his running]; and is from ruxaA='N as an epithet applied to wind. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, ArxY daAb~atahu, meaning He made his beast to go the pace, or in the manner, termed A_iroxaA=', explained above: (Lth, K:) [or,] accord. to A 'Obeyd, AlA_iroxaA='u signifies the leaving a horse to follow his own eager desire in running, without fatiguing him. (S.)

6 trAxY *
He (a horse) remitted, or flagged, in his running; or was, or became, remiss, or
languid, therein. (Az, TA.) And [in like manner] fiY AlA^amori ↓ AstrxY [He remitted, or flagged, in the affair; or was, or became, remiss, or languid, therein]. (K in arts. bn$ and fn$, &c.) And trAxY Eano HaAjatihi He remitted, or flagged, in the accomplishment of his want; or he was, or became, remiss, or languid, therein. (TA.) ― -b2- He drew back, held back, or hung back, (JK, K, TA,) Ean~iY from me, (TA,) or Eani Al$~aYo'a from the thing. (JK.) ― -b3- He was, or became, slow, sluggish, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward. (JK, TA.) You say also, trAxY Als~amaA='u The rain delayed; or was tardy, late, or backward. (S, K.) [And trAxY Alwaqotu The time was, or became, late: and it became protracted. And trAxY Eanohu It was, or became, after, or later than, it: see mutaraAxK, below.] And trAxY AlA^amoru The affair, or case, was, or became, protracted; the time thereof became extended. (Msb.) And fiY AlA^amori taraAxK In the affair, or case, is ample time or scope [for action &c.]; syn. fusoHapN; (Msb, TA;) and extension, or protractedness: (TA:) or remoteness; referring to the case of the resurrection, i. e. the time thereof. (Mgh in art. ntj.)

10 AstrxY * : see 1, first sentence. AstrxY SalaAhaA, said of a she-camel: see 4, in the latter half of the paragraph. AstrxY Als~itoru [The veil, or curtain, hung down; hung down loosely; was pendent, or pendulous: and in like manner the verb is said of a garment, or a portion thereof, and of hair, or a lock of hair, &c.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- AstrxY fiY AlA^amori: see 6. AstrxY fiY raA^oyihi baEoda quw~apK (assumed tropical:) [He was, or became, weak in his opinion after being strong]. (IAar, TA in art. xrE.) ― -b3- AstrxY bihi AlA^amoru, (JK, T, TA,) and Astrxt HaAluhu, (JK,) or Astrxt bihi HaAluhu, (T, TA,) (assumed tropical:) The affair, or case, and his state, or condition, became good with him after straitness; (JK;) or (tropical:) he became in a good state, or condition, (T, TA,) in ample, unstraitened, or plentiful, circumstances, (TA in explanation of the first of these phrases,) after straitness. (T, TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Tufeyl El-Ghanawee, (TA,)
faA^ab~ala waA@sotaroxaY bihi AlxaTobu baEodamaA
A^asaAfa walawolaA saEoyunaA lamo yuw^ab~ili
meaning (tropical:) [And he acquired camels, or numerous camels, and] his state, or condition, became good [after his cattle had perished; and had it not been for our labour, or exertion, he would not have acquired camels, or numerous camels]: (S, TA:) or the phrase AstrxY bh AlxTb means A^aroxaAhu xaTobuhu [explained above: see 4]. (T, TA.)

rixowN * and raxowN (Lth, S, M, Msb, K) and ruxowN; (M, Msb, K;) but accord. to As and Fr, the first is that which is approved, (TA,) or, accord. to Az, it is that used by the Arabs; (Msb;) the second, accord. to As and Fr (TA) and Az, (Msb,) being post-classical; (Msb, TA;) and the third is of the dial. of the Kilábees; (Msb;) applied to a thing (S, K) of any kind, (K,) Soft, yielding, flaccid, flabby, lax, slack, uncompact, crummy, fragile, frangible, brittle, friable, easily or quickly broken; syn. ha$~u; (S, K;) or lay~anN saholN; (Msb;) [and ↓ musotaroxK signifies the same, as is shown by the explanation of its verb in the first sentence of this art.:] the fem. is with p, i. e. rixowapN and raxowapN and ruxowapN (K) [and musotaroxiyapN]. You say HajarN rixowN or raxowN or ruxowN A stone that is soft, yielding, &c. (Msb.) ― -b2- And farasN rixowapN A mare that is easy, and gentle, moderate, deliberate, or leisurely, in pace. (S.) And farasN rixowu AlEinaAni A horse that is easy to be led, or tractable. (A, TA.) The phrase fahiYa rixowN is used in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb instead of fhY rixowapN because meaning fahiYa $aYo'N rixowN. (S.) ― -b3- AlHuruwfu Alr~ixowapu [which may be rendered The lax letters] is said in the K, by an anticipation of the pen, to be applied to the letters exclusive of those comprised in the phrase lamo yuroEuwnaA [for which some say lamo yarowi Ean~aA]: Sgh says [correctly] that they are the letters exclusive of those termed Al$~adiydapu and of those in the phrase lm yrEwnA: as is said in the M, they are thirteen; namely, v,H,x,*,z,s,$,S,D,Z,g,f, and h; [to which De Sacy adds, in his Grammar, (2nd ed. i. 29,) A without ', and w and Y, which are generally included in an intermediate class between the $dydp and the rxwp, namely, in the class consisting of the letters in the phrase lm yrEwnA or lm yrw En~A:] the letter termed rixowN is that in which the sound runs on, as it does, for instance, in the s and $ when you say Almas~ and Alr~a$~. (TA.)
ruxowapN * : see what next follows.

rixowapN * an inf. n. of 1: (M, K:) i. q. AisotiroxaA='N [i. e. Softness, yieldingness, flaccidity, &c.: see 1, first sentence]; as also ↓ ruxowapN: you say, fiyhi rixowapN and ruxowapN [In him, or it, is softness, &c.]. (K.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

raxaA='N * [said by some to be an inf. n. of 1] Ampleness, or freedom from straitness, of the means, or circumstances, of life; (JK, S, Msb, K;) [and so raxaA='u AlbaAli;] as also ↓ rixowapN. (JK.) raxaA='u Aln~afosi (assumed tropical:) [An easy, or unstraitened, state of mind]. (S in art. bwl.)

ruxaA='N * A soft, or gentle, wind: (S, K:) or a soft, or gentle, and quick, wind: (JK:) or a soft, or gentle, wind, that does not move anything. (Har p. 38.) It has the first of these meanings in the Kur xxxviii. 35: (Bd, Jel:) or it there means A wind that does not oppose, or contravene, the will of God. (Bd.)

raxiY~N * (Msb, K) and ↓ raAxK, (K,) applied to life (Eayo$, Msb, K), (assumed tropical:) Ample, unstraitened, or plentiful, in its means, or circumstances: (Msb, K:) or both applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) in an ample, an unstraitened, or a plentiful, state of life. (TK.) You say, A_in~ahu lafiY Eayo$K raxiY~K (assumed tropical:) [Verily he is in an ample, an unstraitened, or a plentiful, state of life]. (TA.) And huwa raxiY~u AlbaAli (JK, S, Msb, TA) and AlbaAli ↓ raAxiY (JK) (assumed tropical:) He is in an ample, or unstraitened, (S,) or an easy, or a pleasant, and a plentiful, state, or condition. (JK, S, * Msb, TA. * [See also other explanations in art. bwl.]) And A_in~a *`lika AlA^amoru laya*ohabu min~iY fiY baAlK raxiYK [Verily that affair passes away from me, I being in an easy state of mind,] is said when you are not disquieted, rendered anxious, or grieved, by the affair. (TA.)
raAxK * , and raAxiY: see the next preceding paragraph.

A^aroxaY * [as meaning More relaxing or slackening or loosening] is used in a verse of Hassán Ibn-Thábit for the regular expression A^a$ad~u A_iroxaA='F: it is like maA A^aHowajahu meaning maA A^a$ad~a HaAjatahu. (El- Hareeree's “ Durrat el-Ghowwás, ” in De Sacy's “ Anthol. Gramm. Ar, ” p. 52 of the Ar. text.)

A^uroxiy~apN *
A thing, or part of a thing, (as, for instance, a veil, or curtain, TK,) that one has let loose, let down, or lowered. (S, K.)

miroxaA='N * , applied to a beast, (daAb~ap, K,) or a horse or mare, (faras, S,) and a she-camel, (TA,) and a she-ass, (S,) That runs in the manner termed A_iroxaA=': (K: [see 4, in the latter part of the paragraph:]) or that runs much in that manner: (S:) pl. maraAxiY~u. (S, TA.)

mutaraAxK * [part. n. of 6, q. v.]. ― -b2- You say jaA='a zayodN mutaraAxiyFA zamaAnuhu Eano zamaAni majiYo'i EamorKw [Zeyd came, his time of coming being after, or later than, the time of the coming of 'Amr]; i. e. jaA='a baEoda EamorKw. (Msb in art. bEd.)
musotaroxK * ; fem. musotaroxayapN: see rixowN, first sentence.

1 rad~ahu * , (S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
rada3a , (S, M, L,) inf. n. rad~N (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and marad~N (S, M, L, K) and maroduwdN, (S, L, K,) this last an inf. n. like maHoluwfN and maEoquwlN, (S, L,) and rid~apN (S [there said to be an inf. n., like rad~N of rad~ahu, aor.
radu3a ,]) and rid~iydaY, (S, L, K, [but in the S and L merely said to be syn. with rad~N,]) an intensive form, (Mgh, TA,) and tarodaAdN, which is [also] an intensive or a frequentative inf. n. of rad~ahu, (Sb, M, L,) and likewise an inf. n. of rd~dhu; (Sb, S, M, L;) and ↓ Artd~hu; (M, L;) He made, or caused, him, or it, to return, go back, come back, or revert; sent, turned, or put, him, or it, back, or away; returned, rejected, repelled, or averted, him, or it; syn. rajaEahu, (S, M, L, Msb,) and Sarafahu, (S, M, L, K) and dafaEahu; (Msb in art. dfE, &c.;) Eano wajohihi [from his, or its, course]. (S, M.) Hence, in the Kur [xxx. 42 and xlii. 46], yawomN laA marad~a lahu [A day which there shall be no repelling, or averting], meaning the day of resurrection. (Th, M, L.) One says, A^amoru A@ll~`hi laA marad~a lahu The command of God, there is no repelling, or averting it. (L.) And layosa liA^amori A@ll~`hi maroduwdN i. e. rad~N [There is no repelling, or averting, the command of God.] (A.) And
rad~ahu Eani AlA^amori He made him to return or revert, or turned him back or away, with gentleness, from the thing, or affair; as also lad~ahu. (T, L.) ― -b2- Accord. to some, rad~a is made doubly trans. with A_ilaY to the second objective complement when honour is intended to be shown, and with EalaY when dishonour is intended; and they adduce as evidence of the correctness of their assertion the sayings in the Kur [xxviii. 12] faradadonaAhu A_ilaY A^um~ihi [So we returned, or restored, him to his mother] and [iii. 142] yarud~uwkumo EalaY A^aEoqaAbikumo [They will turn you back, or cause you to return, to your former condition]: but instances may be found at variance with this assertion. (MF.) [Such instances are of frequent occurrence; though in others, the distinction pointed out above is observed, as may be seen in what here follows.] You say, rad~ahu A_ilaY manozilihi He sent him back to his abode. (S, L, Msb.) And rad~a A_ilayohi jawaAbFA He returned, or rendered, to him a reply, or an answer; (S, A, * L, Msb;) he sent to him a reply, or an answer. (Msb.) And rad~a Ealayohi He replied to him, or answered him, in an absolute sense; (L;) and also, by way of refutation or objection, i. e. he replied against him; faqaAla and said, or biqawolihi by his saying. (TA &c., passim.) And rad~a Ealayohi Als~alaAma He returned to him the salutation. (The Trads. &c., passim.) And rad~a Ealayohi AlwadiyEapa He returned, rendered, restored, or sent [back], to him the deposite; (Msb;) and AlmaniyHapa [the she-camel, or sheep, or goat, lent to him for him to milk her]. (S in art. mnH.) And rad~a Ealayohi Al$~aYo'a, (S, Mgh, L, K,) inf. n. rad~N and marad~N, (Mgh,) He rejected the thing, (such as a gift, A, and bad money, L,) refusing to receive it, or accept it, from him; [as though he cast it back at him;] and so Al$~aYo'a ↓ raAd~ahu. (S, L, K. *) And in like manner, He rejected the thing in reply to him, charging him with error in respect of it. (S, L, K.) And radadotu Ealayohi qawolahu [I rebutted, rejected, or repudiated, in reply to him, his saying, charging him with error therein; I refused him my assent to it]. (A, Msb.) [And radadotu qawolahu I rebutted, rejected, or repudiated, in reply, or replication, his saying, as wrong, or erroneous; refuted it, or refelled it; refused assent to it; controverted it, or contradicted it. And rad~a AlA^amora He refused assent, or consent, to the thing, or affair. And rad~a Ealayohi AlA^amora He refused him his assent, or consent, to the thing, or affair.] And rad~a Als~aAy^ila He turned back, or away, the beggar, or asker, from the object of his want: (A:) [he rebuffed him:] or he sent away, or dismissed, the beggar, or asker, either with refusal or with a gift: occurring in trads. with both of these meanings. (L.) ― -b3- rad~a AlbaAba He shut, or closed, the door. (Mgh. [See maroduwdN.]) ― -b4- [rad~a yadahu A_ilaY sayofihi is a phrase of frequent occurrence, meaning He put back his hand to his sword; it being hung behind him: (see 4 in art. xlf:) and hence, simply, he put his hand to his sword.] farad~uwA A^ayodiyahumo fiY A^afowaAhihimo, in the Kur xiv. 10, means And they put their hands to their mouths by reason of vehement anger or wrath or rage. (Jel.) ― -b5- rad~ahu fiY A^amorK [He made him to enter again into an affair, or a state]. (ISh, TA in art. nks.) ― -b6- rad~a Al$~aYo'a He repeated the thing; did it again; syn. A^aEaAdahu. (M in art. Ewd.) You say, rad~a Ealayohimu AlA^ayomaAna He repeated to them the oaths. (L in art. jld.) [In this sense, rid~iydaY is one of the inf. ns. in use; as in the following ex.] It is said in a trad., laA rid~iydaY fiY AlS~adaqapi [There shall be no repeating in the case of the poor-rate]; (T, S, L;) meaning that the poor-rate shall not be taken twice (T, L) in one year. (L.) [See also 2, which has a similar signification.] ― -b7- h`*aA laA yarud~u Ealayoka, originally laA yarud~u Ealayoka $ayoy^FA (assumed tropical:) [This will not return anything to thee], means [this will not bring any return to thee, or] this will not profit thee: (Har p. 483:) and maA yarud~u Ealayoka h`*aA (tropical:) This does not profit thee. (A.) ― -b8- rad~a A_ilayohi AlA^amora (assumed tropical:) [He referred the affair, or case, to him for management or decision: or] he committed to him the affair, or case; syn. faw~aDahu A_ilayohi. (S and A and K in art. fwD.) ― -b9- [rad~a Al$~aYo'a A_ilaY A^aSolihi, a phrase of frequent occurrence, He reduced the thing to its original state.] And rad~a Alr~uboEa xumosFA [He reduced the fourth part to a fifth part]. (K in art. rbE.) ― -b10- rad~a A@ll~`hu nafosiY A_ilaY waqoti A@notihaA='i mud~atiY [God brought my soul to the time of the end of my duration]. (IB, TA in art. Amr.) ― -b11- rad~ahu A_ilaY AlA^amori [He reduced him to the thing, or affair]: (M and K in art. qSr, in explanation of qaSarahu EalaY AlA^amori:) or he appropriated him [or it, restrictively,] to the thing, or affair. (TK in that art.) ― -b12- rad~a A=xira Al$~aYo'i A_ilaY A^aw~alihi, (S and K in art. Eks, &c,) and rad~a A^aw~alahu EalaY A=xirihi, (Msb in the same art., &c.,) [He reversed the thing; made the last part of it to be first, and the first part of it to be last; turned it hind part before, and fore part behind.] And rad~a baEoDa AlA^amori EalaY baEoDi [He reversed the order of part, or of the parts, of the affair, or case]. (TA in art. rk.) And radadotu Ealayohi A^amorahu i. q. Eakasotuhu Ealayohi [I reversed to him his affair, or case; I made his affair, or case, to become the contrary of what it was to him]. (Msb in art. Eks.) [Hence,] vum~a radadonaA lakumu Alkar~apa Ealayohimo, in the Kur xvii. 6, means [Then we gave to you] the turn to prevail against them, or the victory over them. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b13- [Hence, also, rad~ahu sometimes signifies He, or it, rendered him, or it; or caused him, or it, to become; (like Say~arahu;) when it has a second objective complement the contrary in meaning to the first; as in the following ex.; and it may have this meaning likewise when it has a second objective complement differing in meaning from the first in a less degree.] A poet says,
ramaY AlHadavaAnu nisowapa A=li HarobK
biA^amorK qado samadona lahu sumuwdaA
farad~a $uEuwrahun~a Als~uwda biyDFA
warad~a wujuwhahun~a AlbiyDa suwdaA
[The casualties of fortune smote the women of the family of Harb with an event whereat they became confounded with great confoundedness; and it rendered their black hairs white, and rendered their white faces black]. (L in art. smd.)

2 rd~dhu * , inf. n. tarodiydN and tarodaAdN, (S, L,) [the latter of which ns. is merely said in the K to be syn. with the former, and is said in the M and L to be also an inf. n. of rad~a in an intensive or a frequentative sense,] means more than rad~ahu; [i. e. He made, or caused, him, or it, to return, go back, come back, or revert; sent, turned, or put, him, or it, back, or away; returned, rejected, repelled, or averted, him, or it; much, frequently, again and again, or time after time;] having an intensive, or a frequentative, signification. (L.) ― -b2- [Also He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to go, or move, repeatedly, to and fro; to go and come; to reciprocate: see its quasi-pass., 5. ― -b3- Hence, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, made him, or caused him, to waver, or vacillate, in an affair, or between two affairs: see, again, 5. And hence, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, confounded, or perplexed, him, so that he was unable to see his right course: see, again, 5; and see also murad~adN.] And rd~d AlA^amora (assumed tropical:) [He agitated the thing, or affair, to and fro in his mind]. (TA in art. nj, &c.) ― -b4- And He repeated it; iterated it: [or rather] he repeated it time after time; reiterated it: he reproduced it: he renewed it: syn. A^aEaAdahu, (W p. 15,) and kar~arahu, (A, and W ibid.,) and raj~aEahu. (Mgh in art. rjE. [See also 1.]) You say, rd~d Alqawola He repeated the saying time after time; reiterated it; syn. kar~arahu. (A.) [And rd~d Ealayohi AlkalaAma He repeated to him the speech, or sentence, time after time; reiterated it to him.] And rd~d Sawotahu fiY Haloqihi He reiterated his voice in his throat, or fauces; syn. raj~aEahu; (S and K in art. rjE, &c.;) [as camels and other animals do in braying; (the Lexicons passim;) and he quavered, or trilled, rapidly repeating many times one very short note, or each note of a piece;] like [as is done in] chanting, [for so the Arabs generally do in chanting, and in singing and piping, often throughout the whole performance,] (S in that art.,) or in reading or reciting, or in singing, or piping, or other performances, of such as are accompanied with quavering, or trilling. (TA in that art.)

3 rAd~hu * , (L and TA in art. rwd,) inf. n. muraAdadapN, (TA in that art.,) or muraAd~apN, (TK in the present art.,) He endeavoured to turn him [from, or to, a thing]; syn. raAjaEahu and raAwadahu. (L in art. rwd.) ― -b2- rAd~hu Al$~aYo'a: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph. [Hence,] rAd~hu Alqawola [and rAd~hu fiY Alqawoli (occurring in the TA in art. Et)] He disputed with him, rebutting, or rejecting, or repudiating, in reply to him, what he said; he bandied words with him; syn. raAjaEahu. (A.) And rAd~hu AlbayoEa He dissolved, or annulled, with him the sale; syn. qaAyalahu. (A.)

4 Ard~t *
She (a sheep or goat or other animal) secreted milk in her udder a little before her
bringing forth; syn. A^aDoraEato: (S:) [or,] said of a camel, her udder became shining, and infused with milk. (M, L.) And She (a camel) had her udder and vulva inflated, or swollen, in consequence of her lying upon moist ground: or had her vulva swollen in consequence of lust for the stallion: or had her A^arofaAg [or groins, or inguinal creases, or the like], or her udder, and her vulva, swollen in consequence of drinking much water. (M, L.) [See also murd~N.] ― -b2- And Ard~ [said of a man, app. from the verb as explained in the first sentence of this paragraph, His seminal fluid returned into his back, or he secreted much seminal fluid, in consequence of his having been long without a wife, or absent from his home: see murid~N: and see also 6. And hence, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, very libidinous: see, again, murid~N. And] (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, swollen with anger. (M. [In the L and TA, erroneously written, in this sense, ArAd~: see, again, murid~N.]) ― -b3- Also It (the sea) was, or became, tumultuous, with many waves. (M, L.)

5 trd~d * quasi-pass. of 2; (S, L;) He, or it, was made, or caused, to return, go back, come back, or revert; &c.; or he, or it, returned, went back, came back, or reverted; much, frequently, again and again, or time after time. (L.) You say, tarad~adotu A_ilaY fulaAnK I returned time after time to such a one (Msb.) And huwa yatarad~adu A_ilaY majaAlisi AlEilomi He repairs frequently to, or frequents, the assemblies of science; syn. yaxotalifu. (A.) See also 6. ― -b2- [And as the returning repeatedly involves the going repeatedly, it signifies also, like Axtlf, He, or it, went, or moved, repeatedly, to and fro; so went and came; or reciprocated. Thus,] tarad~udu Al$~aYo'i AlmuEal~aqi fiY AlhawaA='i [means The moving to and fro of a thing suspended in the air]. (K in art. *b.) You say, trd~dt Alr~uwHu The soul, or spirit, went and came. (W p. 5.) ― -b3- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He wavered, or vacillated, fiY Alr~aA^oYi [in opinion]: (MA:) and fiY AlA^amori [in the affair], (S and K in art. lv, &c.,) and bayona A^amorayoni [between two things, or affairs]. (S and K in art. *b, &c.) And trd~d fiY SadoriY ka*aA (assumed tropical:) [Such a thing became agitated to and fro in my mind, or bosom]. (TA in art. rjE.) And trd~d said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, so that he was unable to see his right course. (Bd and Jel in ix. 45.) [And (assumed tropical:) He laboured, or exerted himself, as though going to and fro, or making repeated efforts, in an affair: a meaning well known.] ― -b4- [And It was, or became, repeated time after time, or reiterated: it was, or became, reproduced: it was, or became, renewed.] You say, trd~d Sawotuhu fiY Haloqihi His voice was, or became, reiterated in his throat, or fauces. (The Lexicons passim.) And trd~dfiY AlfaA='i [He reiterated in uttering the letter f; or, as the meaning is shown to be in the K in art. fA^, he reiterated the letter f (rad~ada AlfaA='a)]. (S in art. fA^.) And trd~A_ fiY AljawaAbi wataEav~ara lisaAnuhu [He reiterated, or stam- mered, or stuttered, in uttering the reply, and his tongue halted, faltered, or hesitated]. (A.)

6 trAd~ * and ↓ trd~A_ are both syn. with taraAjaEa: (M, L:) [or nearly so; inasmuch as each implies repetition in returning:] you say, trAd~wA fiY masiyrK, meaning taraAjaEuwA [i. e. They returned, retired, or retreated, by degrees, or by little and little, in a journey, or march]. (TA in art. vbjr.) And trAd~ AlmaA='u The water reverted (↓ Airotad~ [app. by repeated refluxes]) from its channel, on account of some obstacle in its way. (A.) And trAd~ AlmaA='u fiY Zahorihi The seminal fluid returned [by degrees] into his back, in consequence of his having been long without a wife. (L. [See also 4.]) -A2- taraAd~aA Alqawola [or AlkalaAma, and fiY Alqawoli or fY AlkalaAmi, They two disputed together, each rebutting, or rejecting, or repudiating, in reply, what the other said; they bandied words, each with the other]. (A: there immediately following the phrase raAd~ahu Alqawola [q. v.].) And trAd~A AlbayoEa They two rejected, (S, Msb,) or dissolved, or annulled, (S,) [by mutual consent,] the sale. (S, Msb.)

8 Artd~ * quasi-pass. of 1 as expl. in the first sentence of this art.; (Msb;) He, or it, returned, went back, came back, or reverted; &c.; (S, L, Msb, * K;) [Eano wajohihi from his, or its, course; and] Eano saEodihi wadiynihi [from his state of prosperity and his religion]; (A;) and A_ilaY manozilihi [to his abode]: (Msb:) or he turned, or shifted; Eanohu [from it]; and Eano diynihi [from his religion]. (M.) [Hence, He apostatized; or revolted from his religion: and particularly] he returned from El-Islám to disbelief; (Msb;) or so Artd~ Eini AlA_isolaAmi. (L.) And yarotad~u AlbaSaru Eanohu mino quboHihi [The eye reverts from him by reason of his unseemliness, or ugliness]. (TA.) See also 6. ― -b2- [Hence also,] Airotad~ato nafosiY A_ilaY waqoti A@notihaA='i mud~atiY [My soul was brought, or came, to the time of the end of my duration]. (IB, TA in art. Amr. [See a verse of El-'Ajjáj cited voce A^amaArN.]) ― -b3- And Airotad~ato EalaY fulaAnK bigoyatuhu [The thing that he sought was refused, or denied, to such a one]: said of one who finds not what he seeks. (TA in art. bgY.) -A2- Artd~hu is syn. with rad~ahu as expl. in the first sentence of this art., q. v. (M, L.) ― -b2- See also 10, (with which it is likewise syn.,) in two places.

10 Astrd~ Al$~aYo'a * , and ↓ Artd~hu, He desired, or sought, or demanded, that the thing should be returned, or restored, to him; revoked, recalled, or retracted, it. (M, L.) You say, hibatahu ↓ Artd~ [and Astrd~hA He revoked, recalled, or retracted, his gift: or the former signifies] he took back his gift; repossessed himself of it; restored it to his possession; syn. AirotajaEahaA. (A.) And Astrd~hu Al$~aYo'a He asked him, (S, A, L, K,) and desired, or sought, of him, (K,) that he should return, or restore, the thing. (S, A, L, K.)

rad~N * an inf. n. of rad~ahu. (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] DayoEapN kaviyrapu Alr~ad~i, and ↓ Almarad~i, [this being also an inf. n. of the same, (tropical:) An estate] yielding much revenue. (A.) [See also raAd~apN.] ― -b3- [Hence also, app.,] fiY lisaAnihi rad~N In his tongue, or speech, is a difficulty of utterance, or a hesitation, (S, K, * TA,) [probably meaning such as occasions the repetition of certain letters.] -A2- It is also an inf. n. used as an epithet, signifying, (L, Msb,) and so ↓ maroduwdN, (M, L, Msb,) and ↓ radiydN, (M, L,) Made, or caused, to return, go back, come back, or revert; sent, turned, or put, back, or away; returned, rejected, repelled, or averted: (M, L, Msb: *) rejected as meaning not received or accepted: rejected as wrong or erroneous; [as] contrary to the precepts, or ordinances, of the Sunneh: (L:) rad~N signifies anything returned after it has been taken. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A dirhem that will not pass; that is not current; (A, Mgh, L;) that is returned to him who offers it in payment: (M, L:) pl. ruduwdN. (M, A, L, K.) ― -b3- And hence, (Mgh,) (tropical:) A thing (S, A) that is bad, corrupt, disapproved, or abominable. (S, A, K.) ― -b4- Also, (TA passim,) and ↓ maroduwdN, (S in art. rjE, and A, *) and ↓ radiydN, (A, * [where it is evidently mentioned in this sense, a sense in which it is still often used,] A reply; an answer; syn. marojuwEN, and jawaAbN. (S in art. rjE.) You say, qawolika ↓ h`*aA maroduwdu and ↓ radiyduhu [This is the reply, or answer, to thy saying]. (A: there immediately following the phrase rad~a A_ilayoha jawaAbFA.) ― -b5- And A camel used for riding or carriage: so called because brought back from the pasture to the dwelling on the day of journeying. (T.)

rid~N *
A support, or stay, of a thing: (M, K:) a refuge; an asylum. (Kr, M.) A poet says,
fakuno lahu mina AlbalaAyaA rid~aA
yArab~i A^adoEuwka A_ilaAhFA farodaA
meaning [O my Lord, I call Thee one God; then be Thou to him] a refuge from trials: and rid~aA occurs in a reading of verse 34 of ch. xxviii. of the Kur; meaning as above; or thus written and pronounced for rido'FA, on account of the pause, after suppressing the '. (M.)

rad~apN * , (T, S, A, K,) or ↓ rd~apN, (so in a copy of the M,) (tropical:) [A quality that repels the eye:] unseemliness, or ugliness, (IAar, IDrd, S, M, K,) with somewhat of comeliness, in the face: (S:) or somewhat of unseemliness or ugliness (T, A) in the face of a woman who has some comeliness, (T,) or in the face of a comely woman: (A:) or unseemliness, or ugliness, from which the eye reverts: (Aboo-Leylà:) and a fault, or defect, (IAar, IDrd, M,) in a man, (IAar,) or in the face. (IDrd, M.) ― -b2- And the former, (accord. to a copy of the M,) or ↓ the latter, (A, K,) (tropical:) A receding (taqaAEasN) in the chin, (M, A, K) when there is in the face somewhat of unseemliness, or ugliness, and somewhat of comeliness. (M.) ― -b3- And the former, (accord. to a copy of the A,) or ↓ the latter, (K,) (tropical:) The returned sound of the echo; as in the phrase, samiEotu rad~apa AlS~adaY [I heard the returned sound of the echo]: (A:) or the echo of a mountain. (K.) ― -b4- Also the former, A gift, or stipend; syn. EaTiy~apN. (L, from a trad.) ― -b5- And Affection, and desire: so in the phrase,
lahu rad~apN fiynaA [He has affection, and desire, for us], in a verse of 'Orweh Ibn-El-Ward. (Sh.)

rid~apN * a subst. from Airotad~a, (S, M, L, K,) signifying [An apostacy: and particularly] a returning from El-Islám to unbelief; (L, Msb;) or so rid~apN Eani AlA_isolaAmi. (M.) ― -b2- See also rad~apN, in three places. ― -b3- Also Camels' drinking water a second time (M, L, K) and so causing the milk to return into their udders; as also ↓ radadN. (M, L.) ― -b4- And A swelling of the teats of a she-camel: or their swelling by reason of the collecting of the milk: as also ↓ radadN, in either sense: and the former, a camel's udder's becoming shining, and infused with milk: (M, L:) or the udder's becoming filled with milk before bringing forth. (As, S, K.) ― -b5- And A remain, remainder, or anything remaining. (M, L.)
radadN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
rududN * : see raAd~N

radaAdN * and ridaAdN substs. from Astrd~ Al$~aYo'a and Artd~hu; [accord. to the K, of rad~ahu as expl. in the first sentence of this art., but this is a mistake, for the meaning evidently is Desire for the return, or restoration, of a thing;] as in the saying of El-Akhtal,
wamaA kul~u magobuwnK walawo salofa Safoquhu
yuraAjiEu maA qado faAtahu biriadaAdi
[And not every one who has been cheated in a sale, his striking of the bargain having passed, will restore, or bring back, what has escaped him, by a desire for its restoration]. (M, L. [In the M, in art. slf, this verse is differently related; with mubotaAEK, for magobuwnK, and biraAjiEi for yuraAjiEu: and it is there said that salofa is here used by poetic license for salafa.])
radiydN * : see rad~N, in three places. ― -b2- Also Clouds (saHaAbN) of which the water has been poured forth. (K.) ― -b3- And A compact limb, or member. (M, L. [See also mutarad~idN.])
rud~aY * : see maroduwdN.

rad~aAdN * , (as in the T and in some copies of the K,) or ↓ rad~aAdiY~N, (as in other copies of the K and in the TA,) A setter of broken bones: from rad~aAdN as the name of a certain well-known bone-setter. (T, K.)
rad~aAdY~N * : see what next precedes.
raAd~N * sing. of ↓ rududN, (TA,) which signifies Unseemly, or ugly; [or having a quality that repels the eye; (see rad~apN;)] applied to men. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

raAd~apN * [the act. part. n. raAd~N converted by the affix p into a subst.]. You say, h`*aA AlA^amoru laA raAd~apa lahu, (S, L,) or fiyhi, (K,) or fyh ↓ lA raAd~a, (so in a copy of the A, [but probably a mistranscription,]) and ↓ lA marad~apa, (K,) (tropical:) This affair has, or will have, or there is in it, or will be in it, no profit, (S, A, L, K,) or no return. (S, L.) [See also rad~N.] -A2- Also The piece of wood, in the fore part of the Eajalap [or cart], that is put across between the naboEaAni [or two shafts, thus called because they were commonly made of wood of the tree called naboE; which piece rests upon the neck of the bull that draws the cart]. (K.)

A^arad~u * (tropical:) More, and most, profitable [or productive of a return]. (S, L, K.) So in the saying, h`*aA AlA^amoru A^arad~u Ealayohi (tropical:) [This affair is, or will be, more, or most, profitable to him]. (S, L.)
marad~N * : see rad~N, second sentence.

murid~N * A ewe or she-goat (S, K) or other animal (S) secreting milk in her udder before bringing forth: (S, K:) or a she-camel having her udder shining, and infused with milk; (Ks, M, L;) as also muromidN: (Ks, L:) and any female near to bringing forth, and having her belly and udder large. (M, L.) And A she-camel having her udder and vulva inflated, or swollen, in consequence of her lying upon moist ground: or whose vulva is swollen in consequence of lust for the stallion: or having her A^arofaAg [or groins, or inguinal creases, or the like], or her udder, and her vulva, swollen in consequence of drinking much water: (M, L:) and a he-camel, (T, K,) and a she-camel, (T, L,) heavy from drinking much water: pl. maraAd~u. (T, L, K.) ― -b2- Also, [app. from the first of the meanings explained in this paragraph,] A man who has been long without a wife, or absent from his home, (T, * L, * K,) and whose seminal fluid has in consequence returned into his back; (T, L;) as also ↓ maroduwdN. (K.) And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) Very libidinous; (S, K;) applied to a man. (S.) And (assumed tropical:) [Swollen with anger; see 4: or] angry. (K.) One says, jaA='a fulaAnN murid~a Alwajohi Such a one came angry [in countenance]. (S.) ― -b3- Also A sea (T, S) tumultuous with waves; syn. maw~aAjN: (K:) having many waves: (S:) or having much water. (T.)
mirad~N * A man who repels much, and often wheels away and then returns to the fight; or who repels and returns much. (M, L.)
marad~apN * : see raAd~apN.
murad~adN * : see the next paragraph. ― -b2- Also, [and ↓ mutarad~idN, (see 5,)] (tropical:) A man (S, A) confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (S, A, K.)

maroduwdN * : see rad~N, in three places. ― -b2- You say also, ↓ laA xayora fiY qawolK maroduwdK wamurad~adK [There is no good in a saying rebutted and reiterated]. (A.) ― -b3- And baAbN maroduwdN A door shut, or closed; not opened. (Mgh.) ― -b4- And AimoraA^apN maroduwdapN (tropical:) A woman divorced; (T, S, * M, A, K; *) as also ↓ rud~aY: (AA, K:) because she is sent back to the house of her parents. (A.) [In the present day, also applied to A woman taken back after divorce.] ― -b5- See also murid~N. -A2- Also an inf. n. [of an unusual form] of rad~ahu. (S, L, K.)
maroduwdapN * [the part. n. maroduwdN converted by the affix p into a subst.,] (tropical:) A razor: [so called] because it is turned back into its handle. (S, A, K.)
murotad~N * , from AirotidAdN meaning “ a returning; ” (S;) [An apostate: and particularly] one who returns from El-Islám to disbelief. (L.)
mutarad~idN * : see murad~adN. ― -b2- Also A man compact and short, not lank in make: (M, L:) or extremely short. (L.) [See also radiydN.]

1 radaA^a AlHaAy^iTa * , [aor.
radaAa , inf. n. rado'N,] He supported, propped, or stayed, the wall, (ISh, T, K,) by means of a piece of timber or wood, or a buttress or the like, to prevent its falling; (ISh, T;) as also ↓ ArAdA^hu: (Yoo, T, K:) or radaA^a AlHaAy^iTa bibinaA='K [he supported the wall by a structure;] he attached a structure to the wall. (M.) ― -b2- Hence, (T,) radaA^ahu bihi He strengthened and supported him, or it, by means of it, (Lth, T, M, * K,) namely, a person by a thing, (Lth, T,) or a thing by a thing, (M,) like as one strengthens and supports a wall by means of a structure which he attaches thereto; (T;) as also ↓ ArAdA^hu. (T, * K.) And radaA^ahu, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. rado'N, (Mgh,) He helped, aided, or assisted, him; (Mgh, TA;) as also ↓ ArdA^hu: (T, S, M, Msb, K:) and radaA^otuhu and ↓ A^arodaA^otuhu, (T,) or binafosiY ↓ A^arodaA^otuhu, (S,) I was, or became, a helper, an aider, or an assistant, to him. (T, S.) ― -b3- Hence also, (i. e., from rdA^ AlHaAy^T,) radaA^a AlA_ibila (tropical:) He took good care of the camels, (A, K, TA,) in tending and pasturing them. (A, TA.) ― -b4- And radaA^ahu biHajarK He cast a stone at him; (M, K;) like [radaAhu, mentioned in art. rdY, and] daraA^ahu. (M.) -A2- raduw^a, aor.
raduAa , inf. n. radaA='apN, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) for which one should not say radaAwapN; (T;) and Th mentions also radaA^a and radiY'a as syn. with raduw^a, but these are strange; and more strange is what is said in the Msb, namely, radaA aor. yaroduw, part. n. radiY~N, [as a dial. var.,] asserted by IDrst, in the Expos. of the Fs, to be erroneous, and peculiar to the vulgar; (MF, TA;) It (a thing, T, S, M, Msb,) [and he, see radiYo'N, its part. n.,] was, or became, bad, corrupt, vitious, depraved, or the like; (S, M, Msb, * K;) or of no rank, or estimation; low, ignoble, vile, or mean; (Msb;) [disapproved, disliked, hated, or abominable: (see radiYo'N:)] and he was, or became, weak, and impotent, so as to be in want or need. (TA from the Expositions of the Fs.)
2 rad~aAa see the next paragraph.

4 ArdA^hu * : see 1, in five places. ― -b2- Also He settled, established, or confirmed, him, or it, (K, TA,) in his, or its, state. (TA.) ― -b3- He stilled, or quieted, him, or it. (K.) ― -b4- And He let it down; namely, a veil, or curtain. (K.) -A2- Also He rendered it bad, corrupt, vitious, depraved, or the like; (S, K;) namely, a thing; said of a man; (S;) [and ↓ rd~A=hu is used in the same sense: (see 1 in art. j$b:)] he made, or asserted, or held,
it (a thing) to be radiY' [or bad, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And ArdA^ signifies He did a thing, or a deed, that was radiYo' [or bad, &c.]: or he met with, or experienced, (A^aSaAba,) a thing that was radiYo'. (M, K.) -A3- ArdA^ EalaY gayorihi It exceeded another thing; as also A^arodaY: (M:) [or the latter only:] accord. to IAar, one says ArdA^ EalaY Als~it~iyna, with ', (M,) and, accord. to Lth, ElY Alxamosiyna, (TA,) and, [accord. to F,] ElY miAy^apK, (K,) meaning He exceeded [the age of sixty, and fifty, and a hundred]: (M, K, TA:) but Az says that ArdA^, with ', [in these phrases,] though authorized by Lth, is wrong; (TA;) and accord. to A' Obeyed, one says A^arodayotu. (M. [It is added, however, in the M, that ArdA^ may perhaps be also used in poetry in the same sense without the prep. ElY.])

5 tarad~aw^uwA *
They helped, aided, or assisted, one another. (Lth, M, TA.)

rido'N *
A buttress, or the like, by means of which a wall is strengthened and supported. (T.) [This is the primary signification. See also rid~N, in art. rd.] ― -b2- [Or] the primary meaning is A thing by means of which one is helped, aided, or assisted; such as the difo' [or thing by which one is rendered warm, or protected from the cold wind]. (Bd in xxviii. 34; where it has the meaning next following, as is said in the T and S.) ― -b3- A helper, an aider, or an assistant. (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, fulaAnN rido'N lifulaAnK Such a one is an aider and a strengthener to such a one. (T.) ― -b4- And i. q. maAd~apN [app. as meaning An accession; or a thing that is added, whatever it be, to another thing]. (M, K.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) i. q. EidolN [i. e. A burden that balances another burden on the other side of a beast]; (T, TA;) so called because one such rd' supports another: (TA:) and a heavy Eidol: (T, K, TA:) pl. A^arodaA='N. (T, TA.)
ridaA='N * : see art. rdY.

radiYo'N * , applied to a thing, (T, S, M, Msb,) and to a man, (M, TA,) Bad, corrupt, vitious, depraved, or the like; (S, M, Msb, * K;) of no rank, or estimation; low, ignoble, vile, or mean; (Msb;) disapproved, disliked, hated, or abominable: and weak, and impotent, so as to be in want or need: and accord to the Msb, one says also radiY~N; [there said to be a dial. var.;] but this is asserted by IDrst, in the Expos. of the Fs, to be erroneous, and peculiar to the vulgar: (TA:) pl. A^arodiy^aA='u, with two hemzehs, (M, K,) applied to a people, or company of men. (M.)

[
A^arodaA^u *
Worse, and worst; more, and most, corrupt &c.]

mirodaA^apN *
A stone which a strong man can hardly lift with both his hands; (TA;) as also mirodaApN. (ISh, TA in art. rdY.)

A_irodab~N *
A well-known mikoyaAl [or measure with which corn is measured], (T,) a large mikoyaAl, (S, M, K,) in Egypt, (K,) [i. e.] of the people of Egypt; (T, S;) or a certain measure of capacity well known in Egypt; (Msb;) not correctly called a mikoyaAl for they do not measure with it, but with the wayobap: (IB, TA:) it comprises, (yaDum~u, [so in the M, but in copies of the K wayuDam~u, which signifies that it is also pronounced with damm,]) as they say, (M,) or it takes, (T,) twenty-four times the measure called SaAE, (T, M, Msb, K,) of wheat, (T,) i. e. sixty-four times the measure called man~, (T, Msb,) the mn~ here meant being the mn~ of our country, (Az, [app. meaning El-'Irák,]) and the SAE being that of the Prophet: (Msb:) or six wayobaAt: (K:) the Ardb~ of Egypt is six wayobaAt; the wayobap being four A^arobaAE; the ruboE, four A^aqodaAH; and the qadaH, two hundred and thirty-two daraAhim: (EsSuyootee in his “ Husn el-Mohádarah:”) the half of the Ardb~ is called qanoqalN: (T:) the word Ardb~ is affirmed by some to be arabicized: (MF:) [it is now vulgarly pronounced A^arodab~:] the pl. is A^araAdibu. (Msb.) El-Akhtal says,
qawomN A_i*aA A@sotanobaHa AlA^aDoyaAfu kalobahumu
qaAluwA liA^um~ihimu buwliY EalaY Aln~aAri
waAlxubozu kaAlEanobari AlhinodiY~i Einodahumu
waAlqamoHu saboEuwna A_irodab~FA bidiynaAri
[Persons who, when the guests induce their dog to bark, (see art. nbH,) say to their mother, “ Make water on the fire: ” and bread is like Indian ambergris in their judgment, while wheat is seventy irdebbs for a deenár]: the former of these two verses [whereof the latter only is cited in the S] is said by As and others to be the most severely-satirical verse uttered by any of the Arabs. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A conduit in which water flows upon the surface of the ground. (M, K.)

A_irodab~apN *
A wide baAluwEap [or sink-hole] made of baked clay: (T, K:) likened to the mikoyaAl above mentioned: pl. as above. (T.) [And Any pipe of baked clay: pl. A_irodab~aAtN: see daAxinapN.] ― -b2- And i. q. qiromiydapN [which may mean A large baked brick, or a thing made of baked clay]: (M, TA:) or large baked bricks; (S, K, TA;) which are called qiromiydN. (S, TA.)

1 radaja * , aor.
radija , inf. n. radojN, He (a mare's foal [or a young ass, or a lamb or kid, or any young solid-hoofed animal only,]) voided the excrement termed radaj.
