(TA.) -A2- radaja, inf. n. radajaAnN, i. q. daraja, inf. n. darajaAnN: (K:) one of these is formed by transposition from the other: or, accord. to IJ, each is an original word. (TA.)

radajN *
What comes forth, (S, K,) or what first comes forth, (TA,) from the belly of a lamb or kid, or of a mare's foal, (S, K, TA,) and of a young mule, and of a young ass, (TA,) or of any young solid-hoofed animal only, (AZ, T, TA,) before it eats: like EiqoYN in relation to a child: (S, K:) pl. A^arodaAjN. (TA.)
A^arodaAjN * pl. of radajN: (TA:) -A2- and used by Ru-beh for A^aranodaj, q. v. (K.)

A^aranodajN * (Lh, S, K) and A_iranodajN (K) and ↓ yaranodajN (Lh, S) Black skin [or leather], (S, K,) of which boots are made: termed by Ru-beh, in the following hemistich, ↓ A^arodaAj:
kaA^an~amaA surowilona fiY AlA^arodaAji
[As though they were clad in trousers of Arndj]: (K:) accord. to A' Obeyd, originally Pers., (S,) arabicized, (K,) from ranodaho: (S, K:) one should not say ranodajN: (ISk, S:) accord. to Lh, i. q. daAri$N: or, he adds, as some say, a skin [or leather] different from that termed dAr$: or i. q. zaAjN, with which one blackens. (TA. [See what follows.]) With respect to these words of a poet, describing a woman as ignorant, or inexperienced,
qabolahaA ↓ lamo tadori maA nasoju Alyaranodaji
[She knew not what is the weaving of yrndj before it], it is said that he imagined yrndj to be woven, or that he meant that this woman, by reason of her ignorance, or inexperience, imagined it to be so. (TA.) ― -b2- [It is said, app. on the ground of an assertion mentioned above, that] ↓ yaranodajN also signifies A certain black dye; (L;) the black [or blacking] with which boots are blacked: or zaAjN [i. e. vitriol]. (K.) ― -b3- Az mentions Arndj and ↓ yrndj as quadriliteral-radical words. (TA.)
yaranodajN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

1 radaHa Albayota * , (S, K,) aor.
radaHa , (K,) inf. n. radoHN, (TA,) He inserted an oblong piece of cloth, (S, K,) such as is termed rudoHap, (TA,) in the hinder part of the tent; as also ↓ ArdHhu: (S, K:) or both signify he widened the tent: (A:) or he lowered, or let down, the curtain (rudoHap, or sutorap,) at the hinder part of the tent. (L, and so in some copies of the K.) ― -b2- Also (thus in the S, but in the K “ or ”) He put a thick coating, or covering, of clay, or mud, upon the house, or structure; and so ↓ ArdHhu. (S, K.) ― -b3- radoHN also signifies The spreading a thing upon the ground, so that it becomes even; and so tarodiyHN [inf. n. of ↓ rd~H]; but it is said that the latter occurs only in poetry: or the former, accord. to Az, the spreading a thing so that its back [or upper surface] becomes even with the ground. (TA.) ― -b4- And radaHahu He threw him down prostrate. (L.) -A2- raduHato, aor.
raduHa , inf. n. radaAHapN, She (a woman) was, or became, such as is termed radaAH, i. e. heavy in the hips, or haunches; or large in the posteriors, heavy in the hips, or haunches, and perfect in make. (TA.)
2 rad~aHa see the preceding paragraph.
4 A^arodaHa see 1, in two places.

rudoHapN *
A curtain (sutorap) in the hinder part, of a bayot [or tent]: (S, K:) or a piece, (S, K,) i. e. an oblong piece of cloth, (TA,) that is added in a tent, (S, K,) [in the hinder part thereof, (see 1,)] or inserted therein. (L.) ― -b2- The rudoHap of the lurking-place, or pit, of a hunter consists of Stones set up around; which are also called HamaAy^iru, pl. of HimaArapN. (TA.) -A2- Also i. q. saEapN; and so ↓ murotadaHN: thus in the saying, laka Eanohu rudoHapN and murotadaHN [meaning Thou hast ample scope, freedom, or liberty, to avoid it; or thou hast that which renders thee in no need of it]; (K;) like laka Eanohu manoduwHapN. (TA.)

radaAHN * A great [bowl such as is termed] jafonap: (S, A, * K:) this is said to be the primary signification: (Har p. 609:) pl. ruduHN. (S, A.) ― -b2- A widened tent; as also ↓ maroduwHN and ↓ murodaHN [of both which see the verbs]. (A.) ― -b3- A woman heavy in the hips, or haunches: (S, K:) or a woman large in the hips, or haunches, and the posteriors: (A:) or a woman large in the posteriors, heavy in the hips, or haunches, and perfect in make; as also ↓ raAdiHapN and ↓ raduwHN. (TA.) And A she-camel, (T, TA,) and a ram, (A, K,) large in the posteriors. (T, A, K, TA.) ― -b4- A camel heavily laden, (K, TA,) that will not be roused, or put in motion or action, and rise. (TA.) ― -b5- An army, or troop, (katiybapN,) marching heavily by reason of numbers, (S, K,) or dragging along the apparatus of war, heavily laden, (K,) great, (TA,) compact, with many horsemen. (A, TA.) ― -b6- A great, wide, spreading tree. (A, K.) ― -b7- [A place, or land,] abounding with herbage, or with the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; fruitful; or plentiful. (K.) ― -b8- EukuwmN radaAHN Loads balancing one another that are heavy, much stuffed with goods or utensils and furniture; as also ↓ ridaAHN: so in the Towsheeh &c. (TA.) ― -b9- fitonapN radaAHN (A, K) (tropical:) Heavy and great [conflict and faction, or sedition, or discord, or the like]: pl. ruduHN: whence, in a saying of 'Alee, A_in~a mino waraAy^ikumo A^umuwrFA mutamaAHilapF ruduHFA, (K,) meaning (tropical:) [Verily behind you are events whereof the exposition would be long,] great conflicts and factions, or seditions, &c.: (TA:) or, accord. to one relation, rud~aHFA, (K, TA,) pl. of ↓ raAdiHapN, and meaning heavy, scarcely departing: and accord. to another, ↓ fitanFA murodiHapF, meaning oppressing by their weight; or covering the hearts; from A^arodaHa Albayota [in the latter of the senses assigned to it above: see 1]. (TA.) ― -b10- radaAHN also means (tropical:) Darkness. (A, TA.)
ridaAHN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
raduwHu * : see the next preceding paragraph.
raAdiHapN * : see radaAHN, in two places. ― -b2- maAy^idapN raAdiHapN A large table abounding with good things. (TA.)

murodaHN * : see radaAHN. ― -b2- Homeyd says, (S, TA,) i. e. Ibn El-Arkat, (TA,)
binaA='a SaxorK murodaHK biAlT~iyni
meaning [A structure of rocks, or large stones,] thickly coated, or covered, with clay, or mud. (S.) ― -b3- Az says that murodaHN sometimes occurs in poetry in the sense of ↓ maroduwHN as meaning Spread so that its back [or upper surface] is even with the ground. (TA.)
murodiHap * : see radaAHN, last sentence but one.
maroduwHN * : see radaAHN: ― -b2- and murodaHN.
murotadaHN * : see rudoHapN.

1 radasa Alqawoma * , (S, K,) aor.
radusa , inf. n. radosN, (S,) He threw a stone at the people, or party; or threw at them and hit them with a stone: (S, K:) or with a great stone: (Ham p. 214:) or radasa, aor.
radisa , inf. n. as above, he threw at, or shot at; or he threw at and hit, or he shot; (ramaY;) with anything. (M.) [See also 3.] ― -b2- radosN also signifies The act of striking, or smiting. (Sh, M.) ― -b3- And radasahu, (M, K,) aor.
radisa and
radusa , inf. n. as above; (M;) or radasahu bimirodaAsK; (A;) He beat it so as to break it, or crush it; (M, A, K;) namely, a thing, (M,) or a wall, and the ground, (K,) and a lump of dry clay; (TA;) with a hard thing, (M,) or with a big stone, (A,) or with a bard and broad thing. (K.) And radasahu, aor.
radisa and
radusa , (IDrd, K,) inf. n. as above, (IDrd, TA,) He broke it; namely, a stone with a stone. (IDrd, K.) ― -b4- radasa biraA^osihi He pushed, or thrust, or repelled, (dafaEa, [not rafaEa, as Freytag seems to have found it written, as on the authority of Meyd,]) with his head. (TA.) ― -b5- And radasahu, inf. n. as above, He broke, or trained, him; like darasahu, inf. n. darosN. (M.) -A2- radasa He went away: you say, maA A^adoriY A^ayona radasa I know not whither he went away, or has gone away. (S, TA.) And radasa biAl$~aYo'i He went away with, or took away, the thing. (K.)

3 rAds Alqawoma *
i. q. radasahumo [explained above, in the first sentence]: (S, TA:) [or He threw stones at the people, or party, they doing so at him; or pelted them with stones, they pelting him: for the inf. n.] muraAdasapN is explained in the O and K as meaning muraAyaApN; but the correct explanation may be muraAmaApN. (TA.)

5 trd~s mino makaAnihi *
He, or it, fell from his, or its, place. (Ibn-'Abbád, Sgh, K.)
qawolN radosN * (assumed tropical:) A saying that is as though it were thrown at one's adversary. (IAar, M.)
raduwsN * : see what next follows.

rid~iysN * A man who throws stones at others, or pelts them with stones, much, or often: (S: [this meaning is there indicated, but not expressed:]) or, as also ↓ raduwsN a man who pushes, thrusts, or repels, much, or vehemently; syn. dafuwEN; (K;) or naTuwHN; and who is strong, as though his enemy were pelted with him. (IAar in explanation of rdws.)

mirodasN *
A hard thing with which a thing is beaten so as to be broken, or crushed, thereby: (M:) and ↓ mirodaAsN signifies [in like manner] a big stone with which a thing is so beaten: (A:) or each, a hard and broad thing with which a wall and the ground (K, TA) and a lump of dry clay (TA) are so beaten: (K, TA:) or the latter word, a mass of stone, or rock, which one throws; and the former has this meaning also, as well as the first meaning: (M:) or the latter word, (S,) or each, (M,) a stone which is thrown into a well in order that one may know whether there be in it water or not. (S, M. [See also mirojaAsN.])

mirodaAsN * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also The head; (AA, K;) because one pushes, or thrusts, or repels, with it. (AA, TA.) ― -b3- And also said to signify A great mountain. (TA in art. rEn.)

1 radaEahu * , aor.
radaEa , inf. n. radoEN, He restrained, withheld, prevented, or hindered, him; made him to restrain himself, withhold himself, refrain, forbear, or abstain; (S, Msb, K;) turned him back, repelled him, or averted him; (K;) Eani Al$~aYo'i from the thing. (S, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] radaEa jayobahu Eanohu (assumed tropical:) He cleared his bosom, or heart, of it; syn. farajahu, or far~ajahu; (accord. to different copies of the K;) [as though he withheld his mind from it;] meaning, grief, and perturbation; jyb being used to signify the “ bosom, ” and the “ heart: ” (TK:) mentioned by Sgh. (TA.)

6 trAdE Alqawomu *
The people, or company of men, restrained, withheld, prevented, or hindered, one another; made one another to restrain himself, withhold himself, refrain, forbear, or abstain; turned back, repelled, or averted, one another. (TA.)

8 ArtdE *
He became restrained, withheld, prevented, or hindered; was made to restrain himself, withhold himself, refrain, forbear, or abstain; or he restrained himself, withheld himself, refrained, forbore, or abstained; (S, Msb, K, TA;) he became turned back, repelled, or averted; or he turned back, or reverted. (K.) You say, ArtdE birawaAdiEi AlquroA=ni [He became restrained by the restrictions of the Kur-án]. (Msb.)

[
raAdiEapN * , app. for A=yapN raAdiEapN A restraining verse of the Kur-án, seems to be the sing. of rawaAdiEu, of which an ex. occurs above: see 8.]

1 radiga * [aor.
radaga ,] inf. n. radagN, It (a place) was, or became, slimy, or miry. (MA.) [See also 4.] -A2- radaga bihi AlA^aroDa He threw him (a man) upon
the ground. (TA.) And rudiga bihi He was thrown down, or prostrated. (TA.)
3 rAdghu * [He strove with him, in wrestling, to throw him down]. (TA in art. rsg: see 3 in that art.)

4 Ardgt AlA^aroDu *
The land, or ground, was, or became, very slimy or miry; [like Arzgt;] or had much stiff slime or mire; (K;) as also ArdEt. (TA.) [See also radiga.] ― -b2- And Ardgt Als~amaA='u and Arzgt The sky gave water such as moistened the earth or ground. (TA.)

8 Artdg *
He fell into a slimy, or miry, place; (A, TA;) or into ridaAg, (JK, K,) or radagap. (TA.)
radogN * and radagN: see radagapN, in four places.
radigN * A slimy, or miry, place; (Mgh, L;) a place in which is radog: (Tekmileh, TA:) or a place in which is much radog. (K.)

radagapN * and radogapN Slime, or mire; i. e. water and clay or mud: and stiff slime or mire: (S, K:) or much slime or mire: (JK:) pl. ridaAgN and [coll. gen. ns.] ↓ radagN (S, K) and ↓ radogN: (K:) or ↓ ridaAgN signifies thin mud: or, as some say, it is pl. of radogapN: (Mgh:) accord. to Kr, ↓ radogN and ↓ ridaAgN signify slime, or mire; and are sings. (TA.) [See also razagapN.] Hence, ↓ yawomN *uw radogK [A day of slime, or mire, &c.]. (TA, from a trad.) And Eani AljumuEapi ↓ manaEanaA h`*aA Alr~idaAgu [This slime, or mire, &c., prevented us from attending the prayer of Friday: AlrdAg being here used as a sing. n.]. (TA, from another trad.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] radogapu AlxabaAli and radagapu AlxbAl The [corrupt] fluid squeezed, or wrung, or flowing, from the inhabitants of Hell. (K, TA.) This, it is said in a trad., will be given to drink to him who drinks wine. (TA.) ― -b3- You say also maA='N radogapN and radagapN [app. Slimy, or miry, water]; both meaning the same. (TA.)
ridaAgN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

radiygN *
Thrown down, or prostrated; (IAar, K;) as also radiyEN. (TA.) -A2- And Foolish, or stupid, (JK, S, K,) and weak: (JK, TA:) this, and radiyEN, the former mentioned on the authority of Sh, and the latter on the authority of AHeyth, are thought by Az to mean foolish, or stupid. (TA.)
marodagN * : see the following paragraph.

marodagapN *
A rawoDap [i. e. meadow, or garden,] that is beautiful, or goodly; or that is beautiful in appearance, exciting admiration, and satisfying the eye: (IAar, K:) and so marogadapN. (TA.) -A2- Also sing. of maraAdigu, which signifies The parts between the neck and the collar-bone: (S, K;) also called the baA=dil. (S.) And The portion of flesh [or muscle] between the waAbilap of the katif [i. e. the extremity in which is the glenoid cavity of the shoulder-blade, or the muscle of the shoulderblade,] and the heads of the ribs of the breast: (IAar, K:) or the maraAdig are [the parts] beneath the two collar-bones, on each side of the breast. (TA.) And you say naAqapN *aAtu maraAdiga (K) and jamalN *uw maraAdiga (TA) meaning A fat she-camel (K) and he-camel: (TA:) ISh says, when the camel is satisfied by abundance of herbage, he has mrAdg in his belly and upon the upper parts of his shoulder-blades, i. e. accumulated fat thereon, like hares lying down; but when he is not fat, there is no ↓ marodag there. (TA.) marodagapu AlEunuqi means A portion of flesh [or a muscle, app. of a camel,] upon the hinder side of the rising part from the middle of the EaDud [or humerus] to the elbow: or, as some say, the flesh of the breast. (TA.) And maraAdigu Als~anaAmi means The fat that adjoins the maA^onap [q. v., of the hump]: (JK, Ibn- 'Abbád, TA:) sing. marodagapN. (JK.)

1 radifahu * , (T, S, O, Msb, K &c.,) aor.
radafa , (K,) inf. n. radofN, (MA, KL,) He rode behind him [on the same beast]; (AZ, Sh, Zj, T, MA, Msb;) [and] so radafahu, [aor.
radufa ;] (M;) and ↓ Ardfhu; (AZ, Sh, T, M;) said by IAar to signify the same as radifahu: (T:) [or, in other words,] radifahu signifies he became to him a ridof [meaning a radiyf]; and so radifa lahu; for the Arabs often add the l with a trans. v. that governs an accus. noun; so that they say, samiEa lahu and $akara lahu and naSaHa lahu, meaning samiEahu and $akarahu and naSaHahu: (Fr, T:) [and also] he, or it, followed, or came after, him, or it; (S, O, K, and Ham p. 148;) and so radifa lahu; (Ham ibid.;) and radafahu, aor.
radufa ; (K;) and ↓ Ardfhu; (S, K, and Ham ubi suprà;) and ↓ Artdfhu also signifies the same as radifahu; (K;) radifahu and ↓ Ardfhu being like tabiEahu and A^atobaEahu in [form and] meaning: (S:) [↓ rad~afahu, likewise, appears to be syn. with radifahu; or, probably, rud~ifahu, which seems to signify lit. he was made to ride behind him; &c.; for it is said that] the inf. n. tarodiyfN signifies the coming, or going, behind; as also tarodaAfN: (KL:) and radifotuhu also signifies I overtook him and outwent him. (Msb: [explained in my copy by lHqth wsbqth: but I think that sbqth is a mistranscription for tabiEotuhu; and that the meaning therefore is, I overtook him and followed him.]) One says, kaAna nazala bihimo A^amorN faradifa lahumo A=xaru A^aEoZamu minohu [An event had befallen them, and another, of greater magnitude than it, happened afterwards to them]. (Lth, * T, * S, O.) And A^amorN ↓ Ardfhu is a dial. var. of radifahu, meaning An event happened to him afterwards: (S, O:) or radifahumu AlA^amoru and ↓ A^arodafahum signify the event came upon them suddenly, or unexpectedly; or came upon them so as to overwhelm them. (M.) It is said in the Kur [xxvii. 74], EasaY A^ano yakuwna radifa lakumo baEoDu A@l~a*iY tasotaEojiluwna, meaning [Perhaps a portion of that which ye desire to hasten] may have drawn near to you; (Yoo, Fr, T, O,) as though the l were introduced because the meaning is danaA lakumo: or it may mean yakuwna radifakumo [may have become close behind you]; (Fr, T, O;) the l being introduced for a reason mentioned above, as in samiEa lahu &c. for samiEahu &c.: (Fr, T:) El-Aaraj read radafa lkm. (O.) And Khuzeymeh Ibn-Málik Ibn-Nahd says,
Alv~uray~aA ↓ A_i*aA AljawozaA='u A^arodafati
Zananotu biA=li faATimapa AlZ~unuwnaA
[When Orion, or Gemini, shall ride behind, or closely follow, the Pleiades, (an event which will never occur,) I will form in my mind, respecting the family (meaning the father) of Fátimeh, opinions]: (S, O:) cited by Fr [and by J] as an ex. of Ardft in the sense of radifat: (T:) he means Fátimeh the daughter of Yedhkur Ibn-'Anazeh, who [i. e. Yedhkur] was one of the qaAriZaAn. (S, O. [Respecting the qArZAn, see art. qarZ.])
2 rad~afa see 1, in the former half of the paragraph.

3 rAdft Ald~aAb~apu *
The beast allowed a radiyf [to ride it], and was strong enough to bear him; as also ↓ Ardft [accord. to some]. (Msb.) You say, ha*ihi daAb~apN laA turaAdifu (T, S, M, O, K) and ↓ laA turodifu, (Lth, M, O, K,) but the latter is rare, (K,) or post-classical, of the language of the people of towns and villages, (T, O,) and not allowable, (T,) This beast will not allow a radiyf (Lth, T, M) to ride it; (Lth, T;) will not bear a rdyf. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- muraAdafapu AljaraAdi signifies The mounting of [locusts one behind, or upon, another;] the male locust upon the female, and the third upon those two. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- And muraAdafapu Almuluwki is [a phrase meaning The acting as a ridof, or as A^arodaAf, to the kings,] from Alr~idaAfapu [q. v.]. (O, K.) Jereer, who was of the Benoo-Yarbooa, to whom pertained the ridaAfap in the Time of Ignorance, says,
rabaEonaA waraAdafonaA Almuluwka faZal~iluwA
wTaAba AlA^aHaAliybi Alv~umaAma Almunaz~aEaA
[We have taken the fourth part of the spoils, and we have acted as A^arodaAf to the kings; therefore shade ye the skins of the camel-loads of milk collected from the camels in the pasture with panic grass plucked up, and so make it cool for us]: (S, * O:) wiTaAb is the pl. of the waTob of milk. (S.) ― -b4- [In the conventional language of lexicology, rAdfhu, inf. n. muraAdafapN, signifies It was synonymous with it; i. e. a word with another word: as though the former supplied the place of the latter, like as the ridof supplied the place of the king. See also 6.]

4 A^arodafotuhu * , (T, S, Msb,) inf. n. A_irodaAfN, (Msb,) I made him to ride (Sh, Zj, T, S, Msb) behind me, (Sh, * Zj, T, Msb,) or with me, (S,) on the back of the [same] beast; and so ↓ Airotadafotuhu: (Msb:) or ↓ Artdfhu signifies he placed him behind him on the beast: (M:) and A^arodafotuhu maEahu I made him to ride with him [or behind him, on the same beast]. (O, K.) ― -b2- And Ardf Al$~aYo'a biAl$~aYo'i and Ardfhu Ealayohi He made the thing to follow the thing. (M.) ― -b3- See also 1, in six places. ― -b4- Ardft Aln~ujuwmu,
[baEoDuhaA baEoDFA being app. understood,] The stars followed one another. (S, O, K.) [See also 6.] ― -b5- See also 3, in two places.

6 taraAdufN * is syn. with tataAbuEN. (T, S, O.) You say, taraAdafaA They followed each other. (K.) And trAdf Alqawomu The people, or party, followed one another: and in like manner one says of anything following another thing. (Msb.) [See also 4.] And trAdf Al$~aYo'u The thing was, or became, consecutive in its parts; one part of the thing followed another. (M.) ― -b2- It is also a word alluding to a certain foul act: (M, O:) from Alr~idofu signifying AlEajuzu. (M.) You say, (of two boys, or young men, TK,) taraAdafaA meaning tanaAkaHaA. (K.) ― -b3- And taraAdafuwA Ealayohi They aided, helped, or assisted, one another against him. (As, S.) And taraAdafaA They aided, helped, or assisted, each other; (O, K;) as also trAfdA. (O.) ― -b4- As a conventional term in lexicology, taraAdufN signifies Synonymousness; or the being synonymous. (Mz, 27th nwE; and Kull p. 130.) [You say, of two words, yataraAdafaAni They are synonymous. See also 3: and see mutaraAdifN.]

8 A_irotadafa see 1, in the former half of the paragraph: ― -b2- and see also 4, in two places. ― -b3- You say also, Artdfhu meaning He came behind him; syn. Aisotadobarahu. (S, O.) And Artdf AlEaduw~a He took the enemy, or seized him, or took him captive, or gained the mastery over him and slew him, coming from behind him; syn. A^axa*ahu mino waraAy^ihi A^axo*FA. (K.) A^atayonaA fulaAnFA faA@rotada fonaAhu is explained by Ks as meaning A^axa*onaAhu &c. as above [i. e. We came to such a one, and took him, &c.]. (T, S, M, * O.)

10 Astrdfhu *
He asked him to make him [or to let him] ride behind him on the back of the beast. (S, * O, Msb, K. *)

ridofN * : see radiyfN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A sequent of a thing; (T, S, M, O, Msb, K;) whatever that sequent be: (S, O, Msb, K:) pl. A^arodaAfN, which is its pl. in all its senses; (M;) and is particularly applied to the [stars that are] followers of [other] stars; (T, M, O;) [and] its pl. is [also] rudaAfaY; (T;) which is particularly applied to drivers of camels; or drivers who urge camels, or excite them, by singing to them: (T, S, K:) and to aids, assistants, or auxiliaries; (S, K;) [as being a man's followers; or] because, when any one of them is fatigued, another takes his place: (S:) or, as some say, rudaAfaY is syn. with radiyfN: (T:) or it is also syn. with radiyfN, and (O, K) some say, (O,) a pl. thereof. (O, K.) ― -b3- The night: and the day: (K:) Alr~idofaAni signifying the night and the day, (T, S, O, K,) because each of them is a ridof to the other: (T:) and the morning, between daybreak and sunrise, and the evening, between sunset and nightfall; as also AlA^aboradaAni and AlbarodaAni. (T in art. brd.) ― -b4- The consequence of an event, or affair; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ radafN. (O, K.) So the former in the saying, h`*aA A^amorN layosa lahu ridofu [This is an event, or affair, that has not, or will not have, any consequence, or result]. (S, O.) [So too ↓ radiyfN; the phrase ↓ Alr~adiyfu waAlmaroduwfu meaning The consequence and that of which it is the consequence.] ― -b5- The hinder part of anything. (M.) ― -b6- The posteriors, or buttocks, (S, M, O, Msb,) or peculiarly, accord. to some, (M,) of a woman: pl. A^arodaAfN; (M, Msb;) with which rawaAdifu is syn., but [ISd says,] I know not whether it be an extr. pl. of ridofN, or pl. of ↓ raAdifapN. (M.) ― -b7- ridofu Almaliki He who, in the Time of Ignorance, supplied the place of the king, (T, M,) in the management of the affairs of the realm, like the waziyr in the time of El-Islám, (T,) or like the SaAHibu Al$~uroTap in this our age: (M:) in the Time of Ignorance, (S,) he who sat on the right hand of the king, and, when the king drank, drank after him, before others, and, when the king went to war, sat in his place, (S, O, K, *) and was his vicegerent over the people until he returned, and, on the return of the king's army, took the fourth of the spoil: (S, O:) he also rode behind the king upon his horse: (Har p. 321:) pl. A^arodaAfN. (T, S, M.) [See also Alr~idaAfapu.] ― -b8- Alr~idofu [is also a name of] The bright star [a] on the tail of the constellation Ald~ajaAjap [i. e. Cygnus; which star is also called Al*~anabu, and *anabu Ald~ajaAjapi]; (Kzw;) a certain star near to Aln~asoru AlwaAqiEu [or a of Lyra]; (Lth, M, O, K;) and (M) so ↓ Alr~adiyfu; (S, M, O;) or this is another star near to Alnsr AlwAqE. (K.) And ridofu Alv~uray~aA i. q. AljawozaA='u [i. e. either Orion or Gemini]. (O.) ― -b9- Lebeed applies the dual ridofaAni to Two sailors in the hinder part of a ship. (O, K.)
radafN * : see ridofN, in the former half of the paragraph.

bahomN radofaY *
Lambs, or kids, brought forth in the xriyf [or autumn], and in the Sayof [meaning spring], in the last part of the period in which sheep, or goats, bring forth. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
ridaAfN * The place upon which the radiyf, or ridof rides. (S, M, O, K.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

radiyfN *
One who rides behind another (S, M, O, Msb, K) on the back of the [same] beast; (Msb;) as also ↓ ridofN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and ↓ murotadifN: (S, K:) the pl. (M, K) of the first (M) is rudaAfaY, (M, K, [in my copy of the Msb rdfY, which is app. a mistranscription, and there said to be irreg.,]) or the pl. of radiyfN is ridaAfN, (S, [so in both of my copies,]) and rudafaA='u: (M:) and ↓ rudaAfaY is used as a sing., syn. with radiyfN, (T, K,) accord. to some, (T,) as well as pl. [thereof]: (K:) or it is pl. of ridofN [q. v.]. (T.) [Hence,] one says, jaAw^uwA rudaAfaY They came following one another. (K.) [Hence,] also, A Haqiybap, and the like, that is [conveyed] behind a man; [i. e. a bag, or receptacle, in which a man puts his travellingprovisions; and any other thing that is conveyed behind a man on his beast;] and so ↓ ridofN. (M.) ― -b2- See also ridofN, in two places. ― -b3- Also A star rising in the east, when its opposite star is setting in the west. (S, O, K.) And (K) A star facing a rising star: (Lth, M, O, * K:) used in this sense by Ru-beh; who terms the rising star raAkibu AlmiqodaAri. (Lth, M.) ― -b4- Also One who brings his arrow after the winning of one of the players at the game called Almayosir, or of two of them, and asks them to insert his arrow among theirs: (O, K:) or ↓ ridaAfN [so in the M accord. to the TT, but app. a mistranscription,] signifies one who brings his arrow after they have divided among themselves the slaughtered camel, and who is not turned back by them disappointed, but is assigned by them a portion of what has become their shares. (M.)

Alr~idaAfapu *
The function of the ridof of a king, (S, O, K,) in the Time of Ignorance: (S: [see ridofN:]) a term similar to AlxilaAfapu: (K:) it pertained to the Benoo-Yarbooa, in that time; because there were not among the Arabs any who waged war more than they did against the kings of El- Heereh, who therefore made peace with them on the condition that the rdAfp should be assigned to them and that they should abstain from waging war against the people of El-'Irák: (S, O:) it was of two kinds; one being the riding behind the king upon his horse; and the other, what has been explained above, as from the S, voce ridofN. (Har p. 321.)
rudaAfaY * : see radiyfN [of which it is said to be a syn. and also a pl., or pl. of ridofN, q. v.].

Alr~aAdifapu * , in the Kur lxxix. 7, means The second blast [of the horn on the day of resurrection]: (S, O, Bd, Jel, and K in art. rjf:) or the heaven, and the stars, which shall be cleft and scattered. (Bd.) [See also Alr~aAjifapu.] ― -b2- See also ridofN. ― -b3- rawaAdifu is pl. of raAdifapN and of ↓ raAduwfN. (K.) It signifies The [shoots that are termed] rawaAkiyb [pl. of raAkuwbN q. v. voce. raAkibN] of the palm-tree. (S, O, K.) And Streaks [or layers] of fat, overlying one another, in the hinder part of a camel's hump: those in the fore part are called rawaAkibu. (O * and K * in the present art., and A and K and TA in art. rkb.)
raAduwfN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

[
Almaroduwfu * as opposed to Alr~adiyfu: see ridofN.]
muraAdifu lafoZK * , in the conventional language of lexicology, A synonym of a word or expression. (Mz, 27th nwE.) [See 3, last signification: and see also mutaraAdifu.]
murotadifN * : see radiyfN, first sentence.

mutaraAdifN * , as a conventional term in lexicology, Synonymous: you say A^alofaAZN mutaraAdifapN synonymous words or expressions. (Mz, 27th nwE.) [Loosely explained in the K by the words A^ano yakuwna A@somFA li$~Yo'K waAHidK, meaning significant of one thing; which is the contr. of mu$otarakN, i. e. “ homonymous: ” and in like manner, AlmutaraAdifapu is expl. in the O, An tkwn A^asomaA='F l$Y'K wAHdK; and is said to be post-classical.] mutaraAdifaAtN [its pl. when used
as a subst.] signifies Synonyms; i. e. single, or simple, words denoting the same thing considered in one and the same respect or light: thus the mutaraAdifaAni differ from the noun and the definition [thereof], because these [generally] are not both single words; and from the mutabaAyinaAni [or “ two disparates ”] such as Als~ayofu and AlS~aArimu, because these denote the same thing considered in two different respects, the one in respect of the substance, and the other in respect of the quality: (Fakhred-Deen [Er-Rázee] in the Mz, 27th nwE:) or they may be two simple words, as All~ayovu and AlA^asadu; and two compound expressions, as, juluwsu All~ayovi and quEuwdu AlA^asadi; and a single word and a compound expression, as Almuz~u and AlHulowu AlHaAmiDu. (Kull p. 130.) [See also muraAdifu lafoZK.] [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 radama * , (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
radima , (S, K,) or
raduma , (M, Msb,) inf. n. radomN, (Lth, T, S, M, Msb,) He stopped up, or closed, syn. sad~a, (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K,) a door, (Lth, T, M, K,) or a place of entrance, (T,) and a gap, or breach, (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K,) and the like, (Lth, T, M, Msb,) wholly: (Lth, T, K:) or to the extent of a third thereof: (K:) or it signifies more than sad~a; (M, K;) [i. e. he stopped up by putting one thing upon another; as in building up a doorway or the like;] for Alr~adomu is “ that of which one part is put upon another. ” (M.) ― -b2- And radama, (S, TA,) inf. n. radomN; (TA;) and ↓ rd~m, inf. n. tarodiymN; (S, TA;) and ↓ trd~m; (S, K, TA;) He patched, or pieced, a garment, or piece of cloth; or patched, or pieced, it in several places. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- And rudima It (anything) was put, and joined, or sewed, one part to another. (TA.) -A2- radama Alqawosa, (M,) inf. n. radomN, He caused the bow to make a sound, [i. e., to twang,] by pulling the string and then letting it go. (M, K. *) And rudimati Alqawosu The bow was so caused to make a sound. (T, M.) -A3- radama, aor. yarodimu, or yarodumu, with damm, (accord. to different copies of the S, [in one copy raduma, with damm, which is a mistake,]) inf. n. rudaAmN; (S, K; *) or radama, said of a camel, and of an ass, aor. yarodimu, (M,) inf. n. radomN, (M, K, *) and rudaAmN is the subst.; or radama bihaA, inf. n. radomN, used in a general manner; (M;) He broke wind, with a sound. (S, M, K. *) -A4- See also 4, in two places.

2 rad~ama see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] rd~m kalaAmahu, and ↓ trd~m [i. e. trd~m klAmh] (tropical:) He considered repeatedly his saying, or speech, so as to rectify it, and repair what was defective thereof. (TA.) -A2- See also 5.

4 A^arodamati AlHum~Y *
The fever continued, or was continuous; (T, S, M, K;) as also ↓ radamat: and in like manner one says of the saHaAb [or clouds]; and of the wirod [or coming to water, or company of men &c. coming to water, &c.]. (K.) You say, A^arodamato Ealayohi AlHum~aY The fever continued upon him: (M:) did not quit him. (T.) And Ardm Ealayohi AlmaraDu The disease clave to him. (M.) ― -b2- A^arodamati Al$~ajarapu The tree became green after it had become dry; as also ↓ radamat. (K.) -A2- Ardm AlbaEiyra He felt the camel, to know if he were fat. (K.)

5 tarad~ama see 1: ― -b2- and 2. ― -b3- Also trd~m fulaAnFA (tropical:) He sought to find in such a one something that he should be ashamed to expose, or some slip or fault, and obtained a knowledge of the state, or case, in which he was; (K, TA;) as though he imputed some error to him. (TA.) ― -b4- And trd~m Alqawomu AlA^aroDa (assumed tropical:) The people, or party, consumed, or ate, the pasture (marotaE) of the land time after time [or part after part, app. so as to make the ground appear as though it were patched]. (M.) -A2- trd~m also signifies It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was, or became, old, and worn out, requiring to be patched: (S, K: [see also 8:]) this verb being intrans. as well as trans. (S.) -A3- trd~mt, [or trd~mt EalaY waladihaA, as seems to be implied in the K,] She (a camel, M) inclined to, or affected, her young one; (M, K;) [perhaps from radama Alqawosa, because of her yearning cry;] as also EalaY waladihaA ↓ rd~mt, inf. n. tarodiymN. (K.) -A4- trd~mt AlxuSuwmapu The contention, or altercation, was, or became, far-extending, and long. (K. [See also 4.])

8 Artdm * , said of a place, [a door, or a place of entrance, a gap, or breach, and the like, (see 1, first sentence,)] It was, or became, stopped up, or closed. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And app., said of a garment, or piece of cloth, It was, or became, old, and worn out, and patched, or pieced; or patched, or pieced, in several places: see its part. n., murotadimN: and see also 5.] ― -b3- [Also He put on, or he was, or became, clad with, old and worn-out garments. (Freytag, from the “ Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen. ”)]

radomN * is an inf. n. and also a subst. [in the proper sense of this term]: (S, M, TA:) as the latter, i. q. sad~N (S, K *) or sud~N (M) [as meaning A thing intervening between two other things, preventing the passage from one to the other; an obstruction; a barrier; any building with which a place is obstructed]; a meaning erroneously assigned in the B to radamN: (TA:) or a thing of which one part is put upon another: (M:) a rampart, or fortified barrier: it is larger than a sd~; and is [said to be] from vawobN murad~amN meaning “ [a garment, or piece of cloth,] having patches upon patches: ” (Bd in xviii. 94:) and signifies also anything having parts put, and joined or sewed, one upon another: (M:) pl. ruduwmN. (M, K.) Alr~adomu also signifies particularly The rampart (Als~ud~u, M, or Als~ad~u, K) that is between us [meaning the people of the territory of the Muslims] and Yájooj and Májooj [or Gog and Magog]: (M, K, * TA:) mentioned in the Kur xviii. 94. (TA.) And What falls, [and lies in a heap, one part upon another,] of a wall in a state of demolition. (M, K.) -A2- Also A sound, (M, K,) in a general sense: (K:) or particularly the sound [or twang] of a bow. (M, K.) ― -b2- And An emission of wind from the anus, with a sound; (M, K;) as also ↓ rudaAmN: (S, K:) or this is a subst. from radama said of a camel, and of an ass, meaning “ he broke wind with a sound. ” (M.) ― -b3- And, applied to a man, (M,) (assumed tropical:) One in whom is no good; and so ↓ rudaAmN, (M, K,) and ↓ mirodaAmN. (K.)
rudaAmN * : see the next preceding paragraph, last two sentences.

[
raduwmN * One who often breaks wind, with a sound: used in this sense by Jereer. (Freytag.)]

radiymN * An old, and worn-out, garment, or piece of cloth: (T, S, K:) and a garment, or piece of cloth, patched, or pieced; or patched, or pieced, in several places; (S;) and so ↓ murad~amN; (Lth, T, S, K;) like mulad~amN: (Lth, T:) or ↓ murad~amN signifies having patches upon patches: (Bd in xviii. 94:) or this last, and ↓ murotadimN and ↓ mutarad~imN, a garment, or piece of cloth, old, and worn-out, and patched, or pieced, or patched or pieced in several places: (M:) or ↓ mutarad~imN, a garment, or piece of cloth, old, and worn out, requiring to be patched: (S:) the pl. of radiymN is rudumN. (Lth, T, K.)

radiymapN * [in some copies of the K radiymaAni, which, as is said in the TA, is a mistranscription,] Two garments, or pieces of cloth, that are sewed together; (M, K;) like what is called lifaAq; (M, TA;) in the copies of the K, erroneously, lifaAf: (TA:) pl. rudumN, (M, K, [in a copy of the M, accord. to the TA, ruduwm,]) as though the p [in the sing.] were imagined to be rejected. (M.) Hum~aY murodimN, (S, M,) and saHaAbN murodimN, (S,) and wirodN murodimN, (TA,) [A fever, and clouds, and a coming to water, or a company of men &c. coming to water, &c.,] continuing, or continuous. (S, M, TA.)
murad~amN * : see radiymN, in two places.
mirodaAmN * : see radomN, last sentence.
murotadimN * : see radiymN.

mutarad~amN *
A place, of a garment, or piece of cloth, that is to be patched, or pieced, (T, S, K,) syn. mutaraq~aEN; and to be repaired, or mended, syn. mutaSal~aHN. (T.) 'Antarah says, [commencing his mo'allakah,]
halo gaAdara Al$~uEaraA='u mino mutarad~ami
A^amo halo Earafota Ald~aAra baEoda tawah~umi
(T, S, M,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Have the poets left any deficiency to be supplied? or,] any discourse to be annexed to other discourse? meaning, they have preceded me in saying, and left no say for a sayer [after them]: (M:) or have the poets left any place to be patched, or pieced, which they have not patched, or pieced, and repaired? meaning, the former has not left for the latter anything respecting which to mould his verses; i. e. poets have preceded me not leaving for me any place that I may patch, or piece, nor any place that I may repair: then he digresses, and says, address-
ing himself, [Nay but I have somewhat to say:] hast thou known the abode of thy beloved, 'Ableh, after thy doubting respecting it? (EM pp. 219 — 220.)
mutarad~imN * : see radiymN, in two places.

1 radVna [radanato, aor. app.
raduna , but accord. to Freytag
radina , inf. n. radonN, She (a woman) spun thread with the mirodan: see radanN:] Alr~adonu and Algazolu are nearly the same [in meaning]. (Ham p. 218. [Hence maroduwnN applied to spun thread.]) ― -b2- [And app. She wove a garment, or piece of cloth, with spun thread such as is termed maroduwnN, or radanN: whence maroduwnN applied to such a garment, or piece of cloth.] ― -b3- The vulgar say of him who is drowsing, drowsy, or heavy with sleep, Eayonuhu trdnu watagozilu [perhaps tarodinu, to assimilate it to tagozilu, app. meaning (assumed tropical:) His eye blinks, twinkles, or moves its lids to and for; like the hand that spins thread in two different directions, or that throws the shuttle to and fro]. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b4- And radanotu AlmataAEa, (S,) aor.
raduna , (JM, PS,) inf. n. radonN, (S, K,) I put the goods, household-goods, or commodities, one upon another; or put them, or set them, together, in regular order, or piled up. (S, K.) -A2- radonN also signifies The making, or causing, to smoke. (K.) You say, radana Aln~aAra, aor.
radina , inf. n. radonN, He made, or caused, the fire to smoke. (TK.) -A3- radina jiloduhu, (S, K, *) aor.
radana , inf. n. radanN, (S,) His skin became contracted, shrunk, or wrinkled. (S, K. *)
2 rad~ana see what next follows.

4 Ardn AlqamiySa *
He put, or made, a rudon [q. v.] to the shirt; as also ↓ rd~nhu, (S, K,) inf. n. tarodiynN: (S:) or he put, or made, A^arodaAn [pl. of rudon] to the shirt. (M.) -A2- Ardnt Ealayohi AlHum~aY i. q. Ardmt [i. e. The fever continued upon him]. (S: in some copies of which, as in the TA, Elyh is omitted.)

8 Artdnt *
She (a woman, TA) took to herself, or made, a mirodan [q. v.], (K, TA,) for spinning. (TA.)
Q. Q. 1 rawodana * , (K,) inf. n. rawodanapN, (TA,) He was, or became, fatigued, tired, weary, or jaded, (K, TA,) and weak, or feeble. (TA.)
radonN * The sound of the falling [or clashing] of weapons, one upon another. (S, K.)

rudonN * The base (A^aSol) of the sleeve: (S, K:) [app. meaning the part thereof that is next to the shoulder: but see what follows:] the fore part of the sleeve of the shirt: (M:) or the lower part thereof: (M, and Har pp. 149 and 390:) or the sleeve altogether: (M:) and it may tropically mean the whole garment: (Har p. 390:) pl. A^arodaAnN. (S, M, K. [In the TA is added, and Ardnp; as though another pl. were A^arodinapN: but I think that this is a mistake, originating in a copy of the M; for, immediately after A^arodaAnN, in the M, is added, waA^arodanahu jaEala lahu A^arodaAnFA; and I suspect that in some copy thereof, wArdnh has been inadvertently written twice.]) You say qamiySN waAsiEu Alr~udoni [A shirt wide in the rdn]. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, huwa danisu AlA^arodaAni (tropical:) [meaning He is foul in character, conduct, or the like; for it is tropical]. (A in art. dns. [See, there, other similar phrases.]) -A2- See also rudayoniY~N. -A3- [Also pl. of A^arodanu, q. v.]

radanu *
Spun thread: (Sh, T, S, K:) or spun thread that is not even: (T:) or thread spun [by moving the hand] forwards [upon the spindle against the thigh]: or spun thread that is manokuws [i. e. twisted in a manner the reverse of that which is usual: see $azorN]: thread spun with the mirodan. (M. [See maroduwnN.]) ― -b2- And [Cloth of the kind termed] xaz~: (AA, T, S, M, K, and Ham p. 218:) or yellow xaz~: (AA, T:) or what is woven from what women spin with the mirodan (mmA trdnh AlnsA'): (Ham ubi suprà: [see, again, maroduwnN:]) or silk; i. q. qaz~N; (M;) or HariyrN. (TA.) ― -b3- And The [membrane called] giros [q. v.] that comes forth with the young (S, K, TA) from the belly of its mother. (TA.) The Arabs say, h`*aA midoraEu Alr~adani [This is the giros]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- See also raAdinN.

rumoHN rudayoniY~N * [meaning A well-straightened spear; lit. a spear of Rudeyneh]: and qanaApN rudayoniy~apN [the same, or a well-straightened spear-shaft]: (S:) and rimaAHN rudayoniy~apN [well-straightened spears]: (M:) accord. to their [the Arabs'] assertion, (S,) so called in relation to a woman named Rudeyneh, (S, M,) wife of Es-Semharee [or Semhar]; both of whom used to straighten spears, or spear-shafts, in Khatt-Hejer: and some say ↓ xaT~iy~apN rudonN [wellstraightened spears of El-Khatt], and rimaAHN rudonN. (S.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. *wq, 6th conj.]

raAdinN *
Saffron; (S, K;) as also ↓ radanN. (Sgh, TA in art. $Er.)

A^aHomaru raAdiniY~N * A camel, (As, T,) or a thing, (S,) of which the redness is mixed with yellowness, (As, T, S, K,) like waros [q. v.]: (As, T:) hence the epithet raAdiniY~N is applied to a he-camel, (S, TA,) and with p to a she-camel: (As, T, S:) or raAdiniY~N is applied to a he-camel as meaning having crisp, or curly, fur, of generous race, (Lth, T, M,) beautiful, (Lth, T,) and inclining a little to blackness: (Lth, T, M:) or intensely red; (TA, and Ham p. 218;) or it has this meaning also: (M:) or between yellow and red: accord. to some, from raAdinN signifying “ saffron; ” (Ham ubi suprà;) but As says, I know not in relation to what thing the camel is called by this epithet. (M.) They said also A^aromaku raAdiniY~N [i. e. Intensely dun or brown or dusky &c.]; to denote intensiveness; like as they said A^aboyaDu naASiEN. (IAar, M.)
A^arodanu * [or xaz~N A^arodanu] A sort of [cloth of the kind termed] xaz~, (S, K,) red: (S:) [pl. rudonN:] and [hence] viyaAbN rudonN Red garments or cloths. (So in one of my copies of the S.)

A^urodunN * , (ISK, T, S, M, and so in some copies of the K,) in some of the copies of the K erroneously said to be with the r musheddedeh, (TA,) [in the CK with the d, which is also a mistake,] A drowsiness, or dozing: (S, K:) or an overpowering drowsiness or dozing: a poet uses the phrase naEosapN A^urodun~N: (ISk, T:) or this means an intense drowsiness or dozing: (M:) Yákoot says that it appears to signify intenseness and an overpowering, because there is no meaning in one's saying naEosapN naEosapN. (TA.) It is a word of which no verb has been heard. (S.) Hence, accord. to ISK, AlA^urodun~u as the name of a certain province; (T;) a province of Syria, (S, K,) and a river thereof [i. e. the Jordan]; (S;) also without teshdeed. (TA.)

murodinN *
Dark; (S, M, K;) applied to night. (M.) ― -b2- Also, applied to sweat, Stinking: (K:) or, thus applied, that wets all the skin: (M:) [or] ↓ maroduwnN has the latter meaning, thus applied. (T.)

mirodanN *
A spindle (S, M, K) with which [the thread termed] radan is spun: (M, TA:) pl. maraAdinu. (TA.)

maroduwnN * is applied as an epithet to gazol [i. e. spun thread, meaning Spun with the mirodan: see also radanN]. (M.) ― -b2- Also to a garment, or piece of cloth, (M,) meaning Woven (Sh, T, M) with spun thread that is maroduwn. (M.) Aboo-Duwád El-Iyádee says,
A^asoA^adato layolapF wayawomFA falam~aA
daxalato fiY musarobaxK maroduwni
[She (app. referring to a camel) hastened in her journey, or journeyed on without stopping to rest, a night and a day; and when she entered a desert, or waterless desert, far-extending, wide, or spacious, woven with the mirage, or overspread by a rippling mirage resembling a web: or they (i. e. camels) hastened &c.]: Sh says that maroduwn signifies woven: and the poet means, by msrbx mrdwn, a tract of land in which was the mirage: (T:) or mrdwn here means woven with the mirage: (TA in art. srbx:) or, as some say, by mrdwn he means maroduwm, [app. as signifying conjoined, so as to be uninterrupted, (see radama,)] and has changed the m into n; and msrbx means wide, or spacious: (T:) or mrdwn signifies mawoSuwl [which has the meaning that I have assigned above to mrdwm]: (T, K:) so some say. (T.) ― -b3- See also murodinN.
1 radaA * aor. yarodiw said of a horse: see 1 in art. rdY. ― -b2- And radaAhu biHajarK, aor. yaroduwhu, inf. n. radowN: see 1 in art. rdY.

3 rAdAhu * , said to be formed by transposition from raAwadahu, [and therefore it should properly be
mentioned in this art.,] is explained in art. rdY.

1 radiYa * aor. yarodaY, inf. n. radFY, He (a man, TA) perished. (S, M, Msb, K.) [See an ex. in the Kur xx. 17.] ― -b2- And radiYa (AZ, T, M, and so in a copy of the S,) aor. yarodaY, (AZ, T,) inf. n. radFY; (M;) or radaY; (K, and so in copies of the S;) or both of these verbs; aor. of the latter yarodiY; (TA;) and ↓ trd~Y; (S, M, K;) He fell into a well: (AZ, * T, * S, K:) or he tumbled down into a deep hollow, or cavity, or pit: (M:) or ↓ the last of these verbs has this meaning: (Lth, T:) or it signifies he fell into a deep hollow, or cavity, or pit: (Msb:) or he tumbled down (S) from a mountain; (AZ, T, S;) and so the first, or second: (S:) and ↓ trd~Y signifies he fell from a mountain and died. (TA.) A_i*aA ↓ tarad~aY, in the Kur [xcii. 11], means When he falls into the abyss of the fire [of Hell]: (T, * TA:) or into the cavity of the grave: or into the lowest depth of Hell: or when he perishes: (Bd:) or when he dies. (T.) ― -b3- And radaY He (a man) went away. (K.) You say, maA A^adoriY A^ayona radaY I know not whither he went away, or has gone away. (S.) -A2- radaAhu, (S, M, K,) aor. yarodiY, (M,) inf. n. radoYN, (TK,) He broke it; (M, K;) namely, a thing with a stone: (M:) or he beat it, [or battered it,] namely, a stone with a piece of rock, or with a pickaxe, in order to break it. (S.) ― -b2- And He dashed himself against him, or knocked against him, (S, K, TA,) like as the pickaxe knocks against the stone. (TA.) ― -b3- And radaAhu biHajarK, (T, K,) or biHijaArapK, (S,) aor. yarodiY, inf. n. radoYN; (T;) and radaAhu biHajarK, (K and TA in art. rdw,) aor. yaroduw, inf. n. radowN, (TA,) with w for the final radical; (K, TA;) [like radaA^ahu, and daraA^ahu;] He threw at him, or threw at him and hit him, with a stone, or stones. (T, S, M.) [It is also said in the T, with reference to mirodaApN, as signifying a large stone with which other stones are beaten, or battered, Alr~adoYu A_in~amaA huwa rafoEN bihaA waramoYN bihaA; but I think that rafoEN is a mistranscription for dafoEN; and that the meaning intended to be expressed by these words is, that radoYN signifies The thrusting with a mirodaAp; and the throwing it, or with it.] ― -b4- [Hence, app.,] radaY said of a horse, (As, ISk, T, S, M, K,) aor. yarodiY, (As, ISk, T, S, K,) inf. n. radoYN and radayaAnN; (ISk, S, M, K;) and radaA, (K and TA in art. rdw, [in the CK, w is omitted before the word lugapN in that art.,]) aor. yaroduw; (TA;) [and, accord. to Freytag, ↓ ArtdY is used in the same sense by Jereer;] He beat, or battered, the ground, (rajama AlA^aroDa, As, ISk, T, S, ISk, T, S, M, K,) with his hoofs, (M, K, TA,) in running, (As, T,) or in going along, and in running, (M,) or in going a pace between running and vehement walking: (ISk, S:) or radayaAnN signifies the same as taqoriybN: (AZ, T, M: [see 2 in art. qrb:]) or it is [a manner of going] between running and walking: (K:) or the running (T, S, M) of the horse (T) or of the ass (S, M) between his A=riY~ [or place of confinement, or the loop to which he is tied,] and his mutamaE~ak [or place of rolling upon the ground]; (T, S, M;) thus explained by El-Munteji' Ibn-Nebhán, (T, S,) to As. (S.) In the K, rajamato is erroneously put for rajama; being app. taken from the M, in which it refers to horses; [not to a single horse;] as does also the pronoun in biHawaAfirihaA, in the same portion of the passage in the K and in the M. (TA.) Accord. to AZ, this is from radayaAnu AljawaAriY, explained in what follows. (Ham p. 221.) ― -b5- You say, radati AljaAriyapu The girl raised one leg and went along upon the other, in play; (K, TA;) and so ↓ Airotadat: (TA:) and AljawaAriY yurodiyna, inf. n. radayaAnN; (M;) or ↓ yarotadiyna; (T;) the girls played, (T, M,) raising one leg, (M,) or one of them raising one leg, (T,) and going along upon the other: (T, M:) or radayaAnu AljawaAriY signifies the girls' playing in which one of them raises one leg and steps with the other two steps, and then puts it down and raises the other, doing thus several times. (AZ, Ham p. 221.) And radaY AlgulaAmu The boy raised one leg and leaped, or jumped, [or hopped,] with the other. (S.) And radaY AlguraAbu, (M, K,) aor. yarodiY, (T,) The crow, or raven, raised one leg and hopped on the other; or leaped along. (T, M, K.) -A3- radato ganamiY My sheep, or goats, increased, or exceeded; as also ↓ A^arodato. (Fr, M, K.) ― -b2- And radayotu EalaY Al$~aYo'i and ↓ Ardyt I exceeded the thing. (M.) And EalaY gayorihi ↓ ArdY It exceeded another thing; as also ArdA^ [q. v.] (M in art. rdA^.) And radayotu EalaY Alxamosiyna, (S, M, *) and Alv~amaAniyna, (M,) and ↓ Ardyt, (S,) I exceeded [the age of fifty, and eighty]. (S, M. *)

2 rd~Ahu * , (Msb, K,) inf. n. tarodiyapN, (Msb,) He made him to fall, or threw him down, (Msb, K,) into a deep hollow, or cavity, or pit, (Msb,) or into a well; as also ↓ ArdAhu. (K.) He (God) overthrew him; as also ↓ ArdAhu. (M.) -A2- rad~ayotuhu, inf. n. as above, I clad him with a ridaA=' [q. v.]. (S.)

3 raAdayotu Ean Alqawom * , (S, K. *) inf. n. muraAdaApN, (S,) I contended in throwing stones in defence of the people, or party. (S, K. *) -A2- rAdAhu, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) is also syn. with raAwadahu [He endeavoured to turn him; or to turn him by blandishment, or by deceitful arts; or to entice him to turn]; (S, M, K;) formed from the latter by transposition; (S;) or daAwarahu [which means the same]; EalaY AlA^amori [to the thing, or affair]: (T as on the authority of A 'Obeyd:) and daAraAhu [which means the same; or he treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him; or he deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; or endeavoured, or desired, to do so]; (S, M, K; the first as on the authority of A 'Obeyd;) or, accord. to AA, i. q. daAjaAhu and daAlaAhu and faAnaAhu [all of which are syn. with daAraAhu]. (T.)

4 ArdAhu *
He (i. e. God, M, or another, S, M *) caused him to perish; or destroyed him. (S, M, K.) Hence, (M,) in the Kur [xxxvii. 54], A_ino kidota laturodiyni Verily thou almost causedst me to perish, or destroyedst me. (T, M. *) ― -b2- See also 2, in two places. ― -b3- Also He made him (i. e. a horse) to go in the manner signified by the verb radaY [q. v., meaning, beating, or battering, the ground, &c.]: so accord. to the M and K, except that, in both, the fem. pronoun is used, in the M referring to horses, and in the K improperly referring to a single horse. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 1, last four sentences.

5 trd~Y * : see 1, second and third sentences, in four places. ― -b2- He was, or became, overthrown. (M.) -A2- Also, and ↓ ArtdY, He put on, or clad himself with, or wore, a ridaA=' [q. v.]: (S, K: but in the latter the verbs are fem. [as said of a woman]:) or so trd~Y biridaA='K and bihi ↓ ArtdY. (M, Msb.) ― -b2- And trd~Y bisayofihi, and ↓ ArtdY, (assumed tropical:) He hung upon himself his sword, putting its suspensory belt or cord upon his neck or shoulder; syn. taqal~adahu. (M.) ― -b3- And trd~t AljaAriyapu (assumed tropical:) The girl, or young woman, put on, or decked herself with, a wi$aAH [q. v.], which is also called ridaA='. (T, K.)

8 ArtdY * : see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in three places. -A2- See also 5, in three places: and see an ex. voce ridaA='N ― -b2- [Hence,] AirotadaAniY He carried me, or bore me, upon his shoulder, in the place of the ridaA='. (Ham p. 471.)

radFY * an inf. n. of radiYa [q. v.]. (S, M, Msb, K.) -A2- Also Excess, redundance, or superfluity; syn. ziyaAdapN: so in the saying, maA balagotu radaY EaTiy~atika, i. e. I have not attained to thy excess, &c., in thy gift: and yuEojibuniY radaY qawolika The excess of thy saying pleases me: and so in the saying of Kutheiyir,
lahu Eahodu wud~K lamo yakad~aro yaziynuhu
radaY qawoli maEoruwfK HadiyvK wamuzomini
meaning [He has a covenant of love, or affection, into which he has entered, which has not been sullied, and] which excess of kind speech, on his part, [recent and of long duration,] adorns: (T:) or, [as ISd cites the verse,] qawoli maEoruwfK ↓ radiY &c.: [and he adds,] it is said, in explanation thereof, that radiY means ziyaAdap; and I think that it is an inf. n., of the measure faEilN, like DaHikN and HabiqN, or a subst. put in the place of an inf. n. (M.) -A3- See also radaApN.
radK * [originally radiYN] Perishing; (IAar, T, S, M, K;) applied to a man: fem. radiyapN. (S, K.) -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

ridoyapN *
A mode, or manner, of wearing the ridaA=': (S, M, * Msb: *) like rikobapN from Alr~ukuwbu, and jilosapN from Aljuluwsu: (S:) you say, huwa Hasanu Alr~idoyapi [He is comely in respect of the manner of wearing the rdA='] (S, M, Msb.)

radaApN *
A rock; or piece of rock; or great mass of
stone, or of hard stone: (Fr, T, S, K:) pl. radayaAtN (Fr, T) and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ radFY. (S, K.)

ridaA='N *
A certain garment; (S, Msb;) a kind of miloHafap [or outer wrapping garment], (M, K,) well known; (K;) one of the garments that are not cut and sewed; (Mgh in art. qTE, and MF voce A_izaArN;) [being of a single piece;] covering the upper half of the body; or lying upon the shoulders and back; (MF voce A_izaArN;) or falling upon the belly and there ending: (TA voce SiforN:) [a rdA' worn by Mohammad, “thrown over the left shoulder and wrapped round the body under the right arm,” is described as “four cubits long and two cubits and a span wide:” (Sprenger's Life of Mohammad, Part I, English ed., pp. 86 and 87:)] it is of the masc. gender, and it is not allowable to make it fem.: (IAmb, Msb:) the dual is ridaAA=ni and ridaAwaAni the latter being allowable, (S, Msb,) but the former being preferable: (S:) and the pl. is A^arodiyapN: (S, M, Msb:) the ridaA=' is also called ↓ ridaA='apN, (M, K, TA, [in the CK ridAp,]) like as the A_izaAr is also called A_izaArapq; (M;) and ↓ mirodaApN, (K, TA, in the CK marodAp,) of which the pl. is ↓ maraAdK, (TA,) occurring in the saying,
maraAdiYa AlHariyri ↓ laA yarotadiY
walaA yuraY bisud~api AlA^amiyri
A_il~aA liHalobi Al$~aAopi waAlbaEiyri
[He will not wear outer wrapping garments of silk, nor will he be seen at the porch of the commander, or prince, unless for the purpose of milking the sheep, or goat, and the camel]; (M, TA;) AlmaraAdiY meaning AlA^arodiyap; (M;) but accord. to Th, it has no sing.: (M, TA:) [or] ↓ maraAdK signifies waist-wrappers; syn. A^uzurN. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, Siforu ridaAy^ihaA, in a description of Umm-Zara, in a trad., meaning (assumed tropical:) Lank in her belly; as though her rdA=' were empty. (TA in art. Sfr.) ― -b3- And gamoru Alr~idaA='i (tropical:) Abounding in beneficence. (T, M, K, TA.) And Eayo$N gamoru Alr~idaA='i (tropical:) A life ample, or plentiful, in its means. (TA.) ― -b4- And ridaA='u Al$~abaAbi (assumed tropical:) The beauty, and softness, tenderness, or delicateness, of youth. (T.) ― -b5- And ridaA='u Al$~amosi (assumed tropical:) The light, (M,) or beauty and light, (T,) of the sun. (T, M.) ― -b6- ridaA='N also signifies (assumed tropical:) A sword; (T, M, K;) [ISd says,] I think, as being likened to the garment thus called; (M;) [i. e.] because it is hung, by its suspensory cords, upon the neck and shoulder [like that garment]. (T.) [See also mirodFY, near the end of the paragraph.] Mutemmem says,
laqado kaf~ana AlminohaAlu taHota ridaAy^ihi
fatFY gayora miboTaAni AlEa$iy~aAti A^arowaEaA
[Verily El-Minhál has shrouded beneath his sword a young man not voracious in the evenings, when the chief meal is eaten, one who excited the admiration of the beholder]: for El-Minhál had slain his [the poet's] brother Málik; and when a man slew another who was a celebrated man, he used to lay his sword upon him, in order that his slayer might be known. (M. [But see, in relation to this verse, a long story in the Ham pp. 370-372.]) And El-Khansà says,
jaEalota ridaA='aka fiyhaA ximaAraA
wadaAhiyapK jar~ahaA jaArimN
[And in many a calamity which a committer of a crime has brought to pass, thou hast made thy sword to be as a covering to the head]; meaning, thou hast smitten, therein, the necks of thine enemies with thy sword like the xmAr [which means a woman's “muffler” and a man's “turban”]. (T.) ― -b7- Also (assumed tropical:) A bow; (AAF, M, IAth;) because it is borne upon the shoulder, which is the place of the rdA' [properly thus called]. (IAth, TA.) ― -b8- And [for the like reason] (assumed tropical:) The [ornament called] wi$aAH [q. v., worn by women]. (T, K.) So in a verse of El-Aashà, cited voce raqoraqa. (T.) ― -b9- And (assumed tropical:) A bier; because it is borne upon the place of the rdA' [properly thus called, i. e., upon the shoulder]. (Ham p. 471.) ― -b10- And (assumed tropical:) Debt; (T, M, K;) because it is [regarded as] a thing that cleaves to the neck of the debtor, like as the rdA' [properly thus called] cleaves to the shoulders of the wearer. (T.) You say, huwa xafiyfu Alr~idaA='i, meaning (tropical:) He is little burdened in respect of debt: and also, in respect of household. (K, * TA.) [See also an ex. voce nasaA='N.] ― -b11- Also (assumed tropical:) Intelligence: ― -b12- and (assumed tropical:) ignorance: (M, K:) both on the authority of IAar: (M:) ― -b13- he says also that it means (assumed tropical:) anything that is the pride, or ornament, of a person; (T, M;) even, (M,) for instance, one's house, and one's father; (T, M;) or one's house and one's beast; (so in the TA;) each of these, he says, is one's rdA' [or (assumed tropical:) pride]: (T:) thus, (M,) it is (assumed tropical:) a thing that graces: and (assumed tropical:) a thing that disgraces: (M, K:) so that it has two contr. meanings: thus in the K, referring to the meanings of “intelligence” and “ignorance:” but this requires consideration. (TA.)
ridaA='apN * : see the next preceding paragraph, first signification.
radiY~N * : see radiYo'N, in art. rdA^

Alr~aAdiY *
The lion; (K;) because he dashes himself (yarodiY i. e. yaSodimu) [against his prey]. (TA.)

mirodFY *
A stone that is thrown; (S, K;) as also ↓ mirodaApN: (T, S:) or a piece of rock with which date-stones are broken: (Ham p. 417:) and accord. to ISk, ↓ the latter signifies a piece of rock with which stones are broken, (S,) or with which one breaks [anything]: (M:) or a stone which the strong man can hardly, or not at all, lift with his hands; [like mirodaA^apN; (TA in art. rdA^;)] with which stones are broken; and with which they beat and soften a rugged place that they hollow out; and with which the hole of the [lizard called] Dab~ is broken, or battered, when it is among large stones (fY qlEp [i. e. fiY qalaEapK]), which qlEp it softens and demolishes: (En-Nadr, T:) the same word (mrdAp) also signifies the stone, (T,) or the piece of rock, (M,) by means of which the Dab~ is guided to its hole: (T, M:) [and accord. to Golius, on the authority of Meyd and the Mirkát el-Loghah, the upper mill-stone:] the pl. of mirodaApN is ↓ maraAdK: (T:) and this pl. is [also] syn. with maraAmK [app. as pl. of miromaApN, and meaning the arrows thus called; or any missiles]. (M.) Hence the prov., ↓ Einoda juHori kul~i Dab~K mirodaAtuhu [Near by the hole of every dabb is its stone that is to be thrown at it, or its stone by means of which it guides itself to that hole]; applied to a thing that is near at hand, having no obstacle in the way to it; for the dabb will not be guided to its hole, when it goes forth from it and returns to it, except by means of a stone which it places as a mark to point out its hole: (T:) or kul~u ↓ Dab~K Einodahu mirodaAtuhu (S, M, Meyd) i. e. Every dabb has near by it its stone that is to be thrown at it; (S, * Meyd;) for the dabb has little knowledge, therefore it prepares not its hole save by a stone that may be a mark thereof, so that he who seeks it finds the stone that is to be thrown at the dabb near to it; therefore the prov. means that thou shouldst not feel secure from accidents, because calamities are prepared with every time, or period; and it is applied to him who exposes himself to destruction. (Meyd.) Hence also, i. e. from mirodFY in the first of the senses assigned to it above, (S,) or in the second of those senses, (Ham p. 417,) said of a courageous man, A_in~ahu lamirodaY HuruwbK (assumed tropical:) [Verily he is like the missile of wars]; (S;) or fulaAnN mirodaY AlHuruwbi (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is like the crushing stone of the wars]; or mirodaY AlxuSuwmi, i. e. (assumed tropical:) he whom they throw against the antagonists and who crushes them: (Ham ubi suprà:) and humo maraAdiY AlHuruwbi: [maraAdK being pl. of mirodFY, as well as of mirodaApN:] (S:) and fulaAnN mirodaY xuSuwmapK waHarobK (assumed tropical:) Such a one is very patient in the endurance of contention and war. (M.) mirodFY is also used as meaning (assumed tropical:) A horse hard like the stone thus called; thus in a verse of 'Antarah: or it there means a horse that runs swiftly; from Alr~adayaAnu [an inf. n. of radaY, q. v.]: or it is from Alr~adaY [inf. n. of radiYa, and syn. therewith], meaning perdition: or it means, in that verse, [like ridaA='N,] a sword, [as being an instrument of perdition,] from Alr~adaY. (Ham p. 207.) ↓ mirodaApN, also, (S,) or naAqapN mirodaApN, (TA,) is used as meaning (assumed tropical:) A she-camel like the stone thus called in hardness. (S, TA.) And ↓ maraAdK [as pl. of mirodFY or of mirodaApN] means also (assumed tropical:) The legs of camels, (Lth, T, M, K,) and of the elephant (Lth, T, K) or of elephants; as being likened to the stones thus called; (M, TA;) or because of their heaviness, and vehemence of tread. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Also mirodFY, (so in the S,) or ↓ murodiY~N, with damm [to the l] and with shedd [to the Y], (K,) A pole with which a ship, or boat, is propelled, (S, K,) being in the hand of the sailor: (S:) pl. [of the former] maraAdK, (S,) or [of the latter] maraAdiY~u: (K:) in the dial. of the vulgar midorY [pronounced by them midoraY, without tenween, or midoraA, for midoraA^N]; pl., with the art., AlmadaAriY [and vulgarly pronounced madaAriY also without the art.]. (TA.)
mirodaApN * , and its pl. maraAdK (which is also pl. of mirodFY): see the next preceding paragraph, in seven places: ― -b2- and see also ridaA='N, in three places.
murodiY~N * : see mirodFY, last sentence.

AimoraA^apN hayofaA='u Almurad~aY *
A woman lank, or slender, in the place of the [ornament called] wi$aAH [q. v.]. (T.)

Almutarad~iyapu * , in the Kur v. 4, means That which falls from a mountain, or into a well, or from an elevated place, and dies. (T.) The sheep or goat thus termed is forbidden [to be eaten] because it has died without having been slaughtered according to the law. (Msb.)
1 ra*V3a see what next follows.

4 Ar*~t Als~amaA='u * , (T, S, M, A, K,) inf. n. A_iro*aAdN; (T, TA;) and ↓ ra*~at, (A, K,) inf. n. ra*aA*N, (TA,) or ru*aA*N; (so in the TT as from the T;) The sky rained, or let fall, such rain as is termed ra*aA* [explained below]. (T, S, M, A, K.) And baAtati Als~amaA='u turi*~unaA The sky during the night rained upon us, or let fall upon us, such rain as is so termed. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Ar*~ Als~iqaA='u, (inf. n. as above, T,) (tropical:) The water-skin, or milk-skin, exuded, or let flow, what was in it. (T, A, L, K.) And Ar*~t Al$~aj~ap (tropical:) The wound in the head flowed with what was in it. (T, A, L, K.) And Ar*~t AlEayonu bimaAy^ihaA (tropical:) The eye flowed with its water. (T, A, L.)
ra*a*N * : see what next follows.

ra*aA*N * , (T, S, M, A, L, K,) and by poetic license ↓ ra*a*N, (M, L,) Weak [or drizzling] rain, (S, M, L, K,) but exceeding what is termed qiToqiT: (S, L:) or fine rain, but exceeding what is termed Tal~: (A:) or the lightest of rain except what is termed Tal~: (As, T:) or, accord. to El-Khattábee, and Suh in the R, rain more than what is termed Ta$~ and bago$, but a little less strong than what is termed Tal~, or like this last: (MF, TA:) or still, continuous rain, consisting of small drops, resembling dust: or such as is after [app. meaning more than] what is termed Tal~: (M, L, K:) n. un. ra*aA*apN. (M.) To such rain, the poet Bakhdaj, using the abbreviated form of the word, likens some of his verses; not as meaning weak, but as meaning continuous, or uninterrupted, and unruffled; while he likens others of his verses to rain such as is termed waAbil. (M.) One says, yawomunaA yawomu ra*aA*K wasuruwrK waA@loti*aA*K [Our day is a day of fine rain, &c., and of happiness, and of delectation]. (A.) ― -b2- Hence, (assumed tropical:) A little wealth or property. (Har p. 57.) One says, naHonu naroDaY bira*aA*i nayolika wara$aA$i sayolika (tropical:) [We are content with a little of what is obtained of thy bounty, and with the sprinkling of thy torrent of munificence]. (A.)

A^aroDN mura*~N EalayohaA * (As, A 'Obeyd, S, M, K) and ArD mura*~apN (Ks, T, S, M) and ↓ maro*uw*apN, (Th, M, K,) or the second and third of these are not allowable, but only the first is, (As, A 'Obeyd, S, M,) Land upon which has fallen rain such as is termed ra*aA*. (As, A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K.)

muri*~N * A sky (samaA='N) raining, or letting fall, such rain as is termed ra*aA*; and so mari*~apN. (A, TA.) One says, Als~amaA='u muri*~N waAls~amaAEu muli*~N fahalo A^anota A_ilayonaA mugi*~N [The sky is raining a fine rain, and what is being heard is delighting: art thou, then, coming to us quickly?]: meaning what is heard of discourse, or narration, and of science; not of singing. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A day in which is rain such as is termed ra*aA*. (Lth, El-Umawee, T, S, A, K.) And (tropical:) A water-skin, or milk-skin, exuding, or letting flow, what is in it. (A, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) Anything flowing. (T.)
A^aroDN maro*uw*apN * : see mura*~N.

1 ra*ula * , (T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
ra*ula , (T, S, K,) inf. n. ra*aAlapN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ru*ulapN; (S, M, Msb, K;) and ra*ila, aor.
ra*ala ; (Sgh, K;) He (a man) was, or became, low, base, vile, mean, or contemptible; (T, S, M, K;) in his aspect, and in his states, or circumstances: (T:) or it (a thing, M, Msb, K, of any kind, M, K) was, or became, bad, corrupt, vile, base, abominable, or disapproved. (M, Msb, K.) -A2- ra*alahu, (S, M, K,) aor.
ra*ula , inf. n. ra*olN; (M, TA;) and ↓ Ar*lhu; (S, K;) He made, or pronounced, him (a man) to be low, base, vile, mean, or contemptible: (S, * M, K, * TA:) or he made, or pronounced, it (a thing of any kind) to be bad, corrupt, vile, base, abominable, or disapproved. (M, K. *) You say, daraAhima ↓ Ar*l, (T,) or mino daraAhimiY ka*aA, (TA,) He (a man, T, or a money-changer, TA) pronounced, or showed, dirhems or pieces of money, or such of my dirhems or pieces of money, to be bad; syn. fas~alahaA. (T, TA.) And ganamiY ↓ Ar*l [He pronounced my sheep, or goats, to be bad; or he disapproved, or refused, them]. (T, TA.) And mino rijaAlihi ka*aA waka*aA rajulFA ↓ Ar*l (T, TA) He disapproved, or refused, [as low, base, &c.,] of his men, such and such men. (TA.)

4 Ar*l *
He had low, base, vile, mean, or contemptible, companions. (K.) -A2- As a trans. v.: see 1, in four places.

10 Astr*lhu * [He reckoned him or esteemed him, or he found him to be, or he desired that he might be, low, base, vile, mean, or contemptible: or he reckoned it or esteemed it, or found it to be, or desired that it might be, bad, corrupt, vile, base, abominable, or disapproved:] contr. of AisotajaAdahu. (O, K.) Hence the trad., maA A@sotaro*ala A@ll~`hu EabodFA A_il~aA HaZara Eanohu AlEiloma waAlA^adaba [God desires not that a servant (meaning a man) may be low, base, vile, mean or contemptible, but He withholds from him knowledge, or science, and discipline of the mind, or good qualities and attributes of the mind or soul, &c.]. (O, TA.)

ra*olN * (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ ru*aAlN (S, K) and ↓ ra*iylN and ↓ A^aro*alu (M, K) applied to a man, Low, base, vile, mean, or contemptible; (T, S, M, K;) in his aspect, and in his states, or circumstances: (T:) or, applied to a thing (M, Msb, K) of any kind, (M, K,) bad, corrupt, vile, base, abominable, or disapproved: (M, Msb, K:) fem. of the first with p: (M, Msb:) pl. [of pauc.], of the first, A^aro*ulN, (Msb,) or [of the same,] A^aro*aAlN, (T, S, M, O, and so in some copies of the K,) [or this is more probably pl. of ↓ ra*iylN, accord. to analogy,] and ru*uwlN (S, M, K) and ru*aAlN, (M, K,) which is of a rare form, (M,) [in the CK ru*~AlN,] and ra*oluwna, (T,) [which is applied only to rational beings,] and (of ↓ ra*iylN, TA) ru*alaA='u, (S, M, K,) and, of the pl. A^aro*ulN, (Msb, [but] said in the O to be of [the pl.] A^aro*aAlN, TA,) A^araA*ilu, (T, Msb, TA, and so in some copies of the K in the place of A^aro*aAlN,) and [of ↓ AlA^aro*alu,] AlA^aro*aluwna, (T, M, K,) [which is applied only to rational beings, and is said in the M and TA to be used only with the article Al prefixed to it, but is written without the Al in the K.] You say rajulN ra*olu Alv~iyaAbi and AlfiEoli [A man mean, or bad, &c., in respect of clothes and of action]. (T, TA.) And vawobN ra*olN A dirty, bad, or vile, garment; (TA;) and so ↓ vwb ra*iylN: (M, TA:) or ↓ vwb ra*ilN [so accord. to a copy of the T, but perhaps a mistranscription for ra*olN,] a dirty garment: and ↓ vwb ra*iylN a bad, or vile, garment. (T.)
ra*ilN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

ru*aAlN * : see ra*olN [of which it is both a syn. and a pl.]. ― -b2- Also, (S,) or ↓ ru*aAlapN, (T,) or both, (M, Msb, K,) The worse or viler, or the worst or vilest, (T,) or the bad, or vile, (S,) of anything: (T, S:) [or the refuse thereof; i. e.] a thing of which the good has been picked out, (M, Msb, K,) and the bad or vile, (M,) or the worse or viler, or worst or vilest, (Msb,) remains. (M, Msb.) You say also, Aln~aAsi ↓ humo ru*aAlapu and ru*aAluhumo [They are the lower or baser &c., or lowest or basest &c., or the refuse, of mankind, or of the people]. (T.)
ra*iylN * : see ra*olN, in five places.
ru*aAlapN * : see ru*aAlN, in two places.

ra*iylapN *
A low, base, vile, mean, contemptible, or bad, quality; contr. of faDiylapN; (M, K:) pl. ra*aAy^ilu. (TA.)
ru*aAlaY * : see the next paragraph.

A^aro*alu * : see ra*olN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The worse, or worst: so in the phrase A^aro*alu AlEumuri [The worse, or worst, part of life]. (O, K.) [In the K, immediately after the words waA^aro*ala SaAra A^aSoHaAbuhu ru*alaA='a, we find, in some copies, waru*aAlaY kaHubaAraY waA^aro*alu AlEumuri A^asowaw^ohu; and in other copies, waru*aAlaY kaHubaAraY A^aro*alu AlEumuri A^asowaw^uhu: accord. to the former reading, the meaning is, that ↓ ru*aAlaY is syn. with ru*alaA='u; and such SM holds to be the case: accord. to the latter reading, that ru*aAlaY is syn. with A^aro*alu AlEumuri. I have no doubt that the latter is the
original reading in the K, and that it is taken from the O, where (with a preceding context different from that in the K) the words are, waru*aAlaY Aar*ali AlEumuri Aasowaw^uhu; thus, with Ar*l in the gen. case: but I believe, as this word thus written suggests, and as some persons, alluded to by MF, have supposed, that kHbArY has been foisted into the text of the K in consequence of a misunderstanding or of a mistranscription of the words in question in some work earlier than the O; that the correct reading is, warud~a A_ilaY A^aro*ali AlEumuri A^asoway^ihi; and that this is taken from what here follows.] It is said in the Kur [xvi. 72 and xxii. 5], waminokumo mano yurad~u A_ilaY A^aro*ali AlEumuri, (T, TA,) i. e. [And of you is he who is brought back to] the worse, or worst, [part] of life, (Ksh and Bd and Jel,) and the more, or most, contemptible thereof; (Ksh in xvi. 72;) a state of decrepitude and dotage; (Ksh and Bd and Jel;) which resembles the state of a young infant: (Ksh and Bd:) meaning he who dotes by reason of old age, so that he has no intellect; as is shown by the words in the same [immediately following], likayolaA yaEolama baEoda EilomK $ayoy^FA or mino baEodi EilomK $ayoy^FA. (T, TA. *)
maro*uwlN * A man made, or pronounced, to be low, base, vile, mean, or contemptible: (S, * TA:) and a thing made, or pronounced, to be bad, corrupt, vile, base, abominable, or disapproved. (TA.)

1 raz~ahu * , [aor.
razu3a , inf. n. raz~N,] He pierced, stuck, or stabbed, him. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- He stuck, or fastened, or fixed, it, (S, A, K,) into the ground, (S,) or into another thing; (K;) as, for instance, a nail (TA) or a knife (A) into a wall, (A, TA,) or a knife into the ground, (TA,) and an arrow into the target. (A.) ― -b3- raz~ati AljaraAdapu, aor.
razu3a (S, K) and
razi3a , (K,) inf. n. raz~N (S, TA) and ruzuwzN, (so in a copy of the S, but wanting in another,) The locust stuck her tail into the ground, (AZ, S, K,) and laid her eggs, (AZ, S,) or to lay her eggs; (K;) as also ↓ Arz~t. (AZ, S, K.) -A2- raz~a AlbaAba, (S, K,) aor.
razu3a , inf. n. raz~N, (TA,) He furnished the door with a raz~ap [or staple to receive the bolt of the lock]. (S. K.) -A3- raz~ati Als~amaA='u, (A, K,) aor.
razi3a , (A, TA,) inf. n. raz~N, (TA,) The sky made a sound by reason of rain. (K.) ― -b2- raz~a is also said of a stallion [i. e. a stallion-camel, meaning He uttered a low braying]: and of thunder [meaning It made a low sound]. (A.) [See riz~N below.] ― -b3- And raz~N signifies also The being instantly silent. (TA.)

2 raz~azotu laka AlA^amora * , (S,) inf. n. taroziyzN, (S, K,) (tropical:) I arranged, or facilitated, for thee the affair. (S, K. *) And zar~azotu A^amoraka Einoda fulaAnK (tropical:) I arranged, or facilitated, thine affair, and put it in a sound, right, or proper, state, (vab~at~uhu, [or, as in one copy of the A, bay~anotuhu, i. e. made it clear, or plain,]) with such a one. (A, TA.) -A2- taroziyzN also signifies The glazing, or polishing, of paper. (S, K.) ― -b2- [See also the pass. part. n., below: whence it appears that it signifies also The dressing, or preparing, &c., with rice.]

R. Q. 1 razorazahu * , (K,) inf. n. razorazapN, (TA,) He put it in motion, or in a state of commotion. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And He equalized it; namely, a load, or burden; (K, TA;) made it to counterbalance. (TA.)
4 Arz~t AljaraAdapu * : see 1.

8 Artz~ *
It stuck, or became fastened or fixed, into a thing; (TA;) as, for instance, an arrow into the target, (S, A, K,) and into the ground. (A.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He (a niggardly man) remained fixed in his place, and was tenacious, (S, * K, * TA,) and was ashamed and confounded, or speechless and motionless through confusion and shame. (TA.)

ruz~N *
i. q. A^aruz~N [i. e. Rice: see the latter word, in art. Arz]. (S, K.)

riz~N *
A piercing [pain] and rumbling in the belly: (A:) or pain in the belly; as also ↓ riz~iyzaY: (S:) or pain, and pressure of the feces: (TA:) or the pressure and motion of the feces in the belly, (Kt, Mgh, TA,) in the effort to pass forth, so that the person who feels it wants to enter the privy; whether it be with a rumbling or without: (Kt, TA:) or a sound of rumbling or the like in the belly. (As, Mgh, * TA.) You say, wajadotu fiY baToniY riz~FA (As, S, A) I felt in my belly a piercing [pain] and rumbling: (A:) or a pain: (As, S: expl. in the KL by the Pers. word darod:) as also ↓ riz~iyzaY: (As, S:) or pain, and pressure of the feces; &c. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A vehement burning in the mouth of a camel, arising from thirst, with pain. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A low sound: (TA:) any sound that is not vehement: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or a sound that one hears from afar; as also ↓ riz~iyzaY: (K:) or a sound that one hears but knows not what it is: (TA:) or a sound in a more common sense; (K, TA;) vehement or slight: (TA:) or a sound; as of thunder &c.: (S:) or the sound of thunder; (K;) as also ↓ raziyzN, [in measure] like A^amiyrN: or the former has a more general application: and ↓ A_iroziyzN [in like manner] signifies a sound: and also thunder: (TA:) and riz~N also signifies the braying of a stallion-camel. (K, * TA.)

raz~apN *
A single piercing; a stick, or stab. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And A pain in the back. (Sgh, TA.) -A2- The iron [meaning the staple] into which [the bolt of] the lock enters: (S, K:) so called because [the bolt of] the lock penetrates it: pl. raz~aAtN. (TA.)

razaAzN *
i. q. raSaASN [generally meaning Lead]: (Sgh, K:) a dial. var. of the latter word. (TA.)
raziyzN * : see riz~N. -A2- Also A certain plant, with which one dyes. (S, K.)

raz~aAzN *
One who sells, and traffics in, ruz~ [or rice]. (TA.)
riz~iyzaY * : see riz~N in three places.

A_iroziyzN *
A piercing, sticking, or stabbing, (K, TA,) such as is firm, or steady. (TA.) -A2- A tremour. (Th, S, K.) ― -b2- See also riz~N, last sentence. -A3- Long-sounding. (K.) -A4- Hail: (Th, TA:) or small hail, like snow. (S, K.)

maraz~apN *
A place in which ruz~ [or rice] is collected together; like the kudos of wheat. (TA.)

muraz~azN * Food dressed, prepared, or mixed up, (muEaAlajN,) with ruz~ [or rice]. (Sgh, K.) And Paper dressed, or prepared, (muEaAlajN,) with ruz~ [or rice]: (A, TA:) or paper glazed, or polished. (S.)

1 razaA^ahu * , aor.
razaAa , inf. n. ruzo'N and maroziy^apN, He got, or obtained, from him good (S, K) of any kind. (S.) And razaA^a fulaAnN fulaAnFA i. q. br~h; [a mistake, through an oversight, for qabila bir~ahu; i. e. Such a one accepted the bounty of such a one;] as also razaAhu, without ': the former said by AM to be the original. (TA.) And razaA^a Al$~aYo'a He took from the thing, diminished it, lessened it, or impaired it; (K;) and ↓ trAzA^hu signifies the same; or he took from it, diminished it, &c., by little and little. (JM.) You say, razaA^ahu maAlahu, and raziy^ahu maAlahu, aor.
razaAa , inf. n. ruzo'N, He got, or obtained, somewhat of his property; as also maAlahu ↓ ArtzA^hu. (K.) And maA razaA^otuhu maAlahu, (S,) and maA raziy^otuhu maAlahu, (S, K, *) I did not take from him of his property; or did not diminish to him his property. (S, K. *) And maA raziy^otuhu $ayoy^FA I did not take from him, or it, aught. (Mgh.) And maA razaA^a fulaAnFA $ayoy^FA He did not get, or obtain, from such a one aught of his property; and did not take from him aught thereof. (TA.) And maA razaA^otuhu zibaAlFA I did not take from him, or it, as much as an ant would carry with its mouth: (Har p. 197:) or thus originally, but meaning, anything. (S in art. zbl.) And maA razaA^onaA mino maAy^ika $ayoy^FA We took not of, or from, thy water, anything: occurring in a trad. (TA.) In another trad., as some relate it, raziynaA occurs for raziy^onaA, which is the original. (IAth.)
