Accord. to AZ, [however,] one says, ruziy^otuhu, meaning [I had it taken, or received, from me; or, virtually,] it was taken, or received, from me; but not ruziytuhu. (TA.) [Hence, when relating to a moral attribute, or the like, it virtually means (assumed tropical:) It was experienced from me: see a verse cited voce mutoladN, in art. tld.] You say also, huwa yurozaA^u, [virtually] meaning He is a bountiful person; one whose gratuitous gifts people obtain. (Ham p. 722.) And A_in~ahu laqalyilu Alr~uzo'i mina AlT~aEaAmi Verily he is one who gets little of the food. (TA.) ― -b2- razaA^otuhu also signifies I afflicted him with an affliction, a misfortune, or a calamity. (Msb.) And razaA^atohu raziyoy^apN An affliction, a misfortune, or a calamity, befell him. (S, Msb.) It is said in a trad., respecting a woman who came asking for her son, A_ino A^urozaA^i A@boniY falamo A^urozaA^o A^aHobaAbiY, meaning If I be afflicted by the loss of my son, I have not been afflicted by the loss of my friends. (TA.)
4 ArzA^ * : see ArzY, in art. rzY.
6 taraAozaAa see 1.

8 A_irotazaAa see 1. -A2- ArtzA^ also signifies It (a thing, S) was, or became, diminished, lessened, or impaired. (S, K.) A poet says, (namely, Ibn Mukbil, describing a stallion, S in art. zbl,)
falamo yarotaziY'o birukuwbK zibaAlaA
(S, TA) And he had not been lessened [by riding, so as to lose] as much as the gnat will carry: (TA:) or as much as the ant will carry with its mouth; meaning, anything: (S in art. zbl:) but some read trtzY'; [and some, yurotazaA^o, as in copies of the S in art. zbl;] and some, birukuwnK. (TA.)

ruzo'N * , (S, Mgh, K,) [originally an inf. n., and] a subst. from razaA^atohu raziyoy^apN, (Msb,) and ↓ raziyoy^apN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) also pronounced raziy~apN, originally with ', (Msb,) and ↓ maroziy^apN, (S, K,) An affliction, a misfortune, or a calamity, (S, Msb, K, TA,) by the loss of things dear to one: (TA:) or a great affliction or calamity or misfortune: (Mgh:) pl. (of the first, S, TA) A^arozaA='N (S, K, TA) and (of the second, S, Msb, TA) razaAyaA. (S, Msb, K, TA.)
raziyoy^apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
maroziy^apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

muraz~aA_N * ; (so in some copies of the S; in others murozaA^N, which is said in the K to be a mistranscription;) pl. muraz~aw^uwna: (K:) A generous man, (S, K, * [in the latter of which only the pl. is explained,] and TA,) whose good things men get, or obtain, (S,) or from whom much is gotten, or obtained. (TA.) One says, in praising, fulaAnN muraz~aA^N fiY maAlihi [Such a one is a person from whom much of his property has been obtained]: and in expressing pity and grief, fulaAnN muraz~aA^N fiY A^aholihi [Such a one is a person who has had some one, or more, of his family taken from him]. (Ham p. 176.) And the pl., mentioned above, also signifies Persons of whom the best have died: (K:) or persons of whom death befalls the best. (L.)

1 razabahu * , (A, K,) aor.
razuba , inf. n. razobN, (TK,) He kept, or clave, to him, or it, (A, K,) not departing. (K.)

A_irozab~N * , (S, K,) quasi-coordinate to jirodaHolN, (S,) applied to a man, (TA,) Short: (S, K:) and great, or old; syn. kabiyrN: and thick and strong: and big, or bulky: (K:) or short and thick and strong: (TA:) or great in body, and stupid, foolish, or deficient in intellect. (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA.) ― -b2- Also The vulva of a woman; (K;) accord. to Kr, a subst. [properly speaking] applied thereto: (TA:) or an epithet, meaning large, or big, (S, K,) applied thereto, (K,) or applied to a rakab [i. e. pubes]. (S.)

A_irozab~apN * and ↓ mirozab~apN, both with teshdeed; (A, K;) or the former only, (S, Msb, K,) of these two, (S, Msb,) and ↓ mirozibapN, without teshdeed; (S, A, Msb;) ↓ the second mentioned by Ks, (Mgh,) but it is vulgar, (Fs, Msb,) and said by ISk to be wrong; (Msb;) A thing with which clods of clay are broken: (S, L:) or a small rod, or batoon, of iron: (A, K:) and the last, ↓ mirozabapN, without teshdeed, a large blacksmith's hammer: (TA:) or a mallet with which wooden pins or pegs or stakes are knocked into the ground or into a wall; syn. miytadapN: (Mgh:) the pl. of the first is A^araAzibu; (Msb;) and of ↓ the last, maraAzibu, (A, Msb,) as also of marozubaAnN [q. v.]. (A.)

marozabapN * [A satrapy; the government of a satrap, or prefect of the Persians;] the headship of the Persians. (K.) You say, fulaAnN EalaY marozabapi ka*aA, and lahu marozabapu ka*aA, [Such a one is over the satrapy of, or has the office of satrap over, such a province,] like as you say, lahu dahoqanapu ka*aA. (S.)
mirozabapN * and mirozab~apN: see A_irozab~apN, in five places.

mirozaAbN *
i. q. miyzaAbN [and mizoraAbN, i. e. A water-spout; &c.; see art. wzb]; (A, K;) a dial. var. thereof; (S, Msb;) but not a chaste word; (S;) and disallowed by A'Obeyd, (TA,) and by ISk and Fr and AHat. (TA voce mizoraAbN.) ― -b2- Also A great ship: (A, K:) or a long ship: (AZ, S, K:) pl. maraAziybu. (AZ, S.)

marozubaAnN * [A satrap; or] a great man, or chief, (A, Mgh, K,) of the Persians: (S, Mgh, K:) or a courageous cavalier who is set over a people, under a king: (TA:) it is said, on the authority of As, that the chief of the Eajam [here meaning Persians] was called marozubaAnN and mazorubaAnN: (IB, TA:) mrzbAn is an arabicized word, (S, Mgh,) [originally Persian,] used anciently: (Shifá el-Ghaleel, TA:) pl. maraAzibapN. (S, A, Mgh, K.) Hence, [and from maraAzibapN as pl. of mirozabapN,] the saying, A^aEuw*u biA@ll~`hi mina AlmaraAzibapi wamaA biA^ayodiyhimo mina AlmaraAzibapi [I seek protection by God from the satraps, and the iron batoons that are in their hands]. (A.) ― -b2- And hence, (S Mgh,) marozubaAnu Alr~aA^orapi, (S, Mgh, K,) [lit. The chief of the forest, or the like,] the latter word meaning AlA^ajamapi, (Mgh, TA,) and also pronounced Alz~aArapi; (Mgh;) an appellation of the lion; (S, Mgh, K;) and so ↓ AlmarozubaAniY~u; for which ElMufaddal said AlmazobaraAniY~u, as referring to the zuborap of the lion; but As disallowed this. (S.)
AlmarozubaAniY~u * : see what next precedes.
ruzotaAqN * : see ruzodaAqN, in art. rzdq.

1 razaHato * , aor.
razaHa , inf. n. ruzuwHN (S, K) and ruzaAHN, (S, L,) or razaAHN, (K,) She (a camel) fell down (S, L, K) by reason of fatigue, emaciated, (S, L, &c.,) or by reason of fatigue or emaciation, (K accord. to the TA,) or by reason of fatigue and emaciation: (CK:) or clave to the ground, and had not power to rise. (TA.) And razaHa, (Mgh, Msb,) aor.
razaHa , (Msb,) inf. n. ruzuwHu and ruzaAHN (Mgh, Msb) and razaAHN, (Msb,) He (a camel, Mgh, Msb) fell down by reason of fatigue: (Mgh:) or became much emaciated. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, or from marozaHN as meaning low, or depressed, ground or land, razaHa said of a man, (tropical:) He became weak, and what was in his hand went from him. (TA.) ― -b3- And razaHato HaAluhu and A^aHowaAluhu ↓ trAzHt (A) (tropical:) His state, or condition, was, and his circumstances, were, or became, weak and evil. (A, * and Har p. 489.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] razaHa AlEinabu The grape vine fell down. (TA.) -A2- razaHa fulaAnFA biAlr~umoHi, inf. n. razoHN, He thrust, or pierced, such a one with the spear, or with the iron at the lower extremity of the spear; syn. zaj~ahu. (K.)
2 rz~H * , inf. n. taroziyHN, (S, K,) He made a she-camel to fall down by reason of fatigue, emaciated: (S:) or he emaciated her. (K.) And raz~aHatohaA AlA^asofaAru Journeys emaciated her. (A, * TA.)

4 ArzH AlEinaba *
He raised [or propped up] the grape-vine [that had fallen down]. (TA.)
6 taraAozaHa see 1.

raAziHN * (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA) and ↓ mirozaAHN (TA) A camel that has fallen down by reason of fatigue: (Mgh:) or much emaciated: (Mgh, Msb:) or much emaciated, that will not move: (TA:) perishing by reason of emaciation: (S, TA:) or that throws himself down by reason of fatigue: or much emaciated, but having power to move: (A, TA:) pl. [of the former] razoHaY (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and ruz~aHN (S, A, Mgh, K) and razaAHaY (S, A, Msb, K) and [of the same or of raAziHapN] rawaAziHu (A, TA) and [of mirozaAHN] ↓ maraAziyHu. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qawomN ruz~aHN and rzAH [app. ruz~aAHN, agreeably with analogy, or perhaps rizAHN,] (assumed tropical:) A people, or party, emaciated, and falling down [or tottering by reason of weakness]. (Ham p. 227.) ― -b3- And lahu HaAlN raAziHapN (tropical:) [He has a weak and an evil state or condition: see 1]. (A.)

marozaHN * [A place where camels fall down by reason of fatigue: and hence,] a far-extending place of crossing or traversing [of a desert &c.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- And A low, or depressed, tract of land. (K.)

mirozaHN * The wood, or pieces of wood, (xa$ab,) with which a grape-vine is raised from the ground (T, S, K) when one part thereof has fallen down upon another: (T, TA:) or a vine-prop; a piece of wood with which a grape-vine is raised from the ground. (TA in art. jz'.) -A2- Also, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, [but why this is said I do not see, unless the primary meaning be that assigned by EshSheybánee to the next following word,] A voice, sound, or noise; (TA;) and so ↓ miroziyHN: (K:) accord. to Esh-Sheybánee, the latter signifies
having a vehement voice or sound or noise; (S;) but this [said to be] is a mistake. (K.)
mirozaAHN * , and its pl. maraAziyHu: see raAziHN.
miroziyHN * : see mirozaHN.

razodaqN *
A row of palm-trees, and of men: (IF, S, Msb, K:) or [simply] a row: (JK, Mgh:) and an extended cord or string or thread: (JK:) an arabicized word, from rasotaho, (S, K,) which is Persian: (S:) Lth says, What the people [now] call rasotaq we call razodaq, meaning a row: it is an adventitious word. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, AijoEali AlA^amora razodaqFA waAHidFA, meaning Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr, TA in art. bA^H.)

ruzodaAqN * (S, Msb, K, &c.) and ruzotaAqN (Lh, L, TA) and rusodaAqN (ISk, K) and rusotaAqN, (Lh, S, Msb, K, &c.,) but this last disallowed by ISk, (TA,) [though allowed by many others, and of frequent occurrence,] and said by some to be post-classical, and to be correctly ruzodaAqN, (Msb,) arabicized, (S, Msb, K,) of Pers. origin, (S,) from ruwsotaA, (K,) [erroneously] said by IF to be from razodaqN signifying as explained above; (Msb;) A rural district; or district consisting of cultivated land with towns or villages; syn. sawaAdN, (S,) or sawaAdN and qurFy: (K:) Yákoot explains rusotaAq as applied, in his time, in the country of the Persians, to any place [or district] in which are sown fields, and towns or villages; not to cities, like El-Basrah and Baghdád; so that it is, with the Persians, like sawaAdN with the people of Baghdád, and is a more special term than kuwrapN [in Arabic] and A_isotaAn [in Persian]: (TA:) or it is used as meaning an outlying district, or a border-district, of a country: (Msb:) [but the correctness of this last explanation is questionable:] the pl. is razaAdiyqu (Msb) [and razaAtiyqu and rasaAdiyqu] and rasaAtiyqu (S, Msb) and ruzodaAqaAtN (Har p. 249) [&c.].

3 raAzagotuhu * , (JK,) inf. n. muraAzagapN, (JK, K,) I practised deceit, delusion, guile, or artifice, with him, or towards him; syn. raAwagotuhu; (JK, K; *) and sought, or endeavoured, to induce him; syn. HaAwalotuhu: said [in speaking] of a wolf &c. (JK, TA. *)

4 Arzgt AlA^aroDu *
The land, or ground, was, or became, very slimy or miry; or had much slime, or mire, and moisture. (K, * TA. [See also 4 in art. rdg.]) ― -b2- Arzg said of a digger, He reached the moist earth or clay. (S, K.) ― -b3- Arzgt Als~amaA='u The sky gave water such as moistened the earth or ground: (TA:) like Ardgt. (TA in art. rdg.) And Arzgt AlriyHu The wind brought nadFy [i. e. moisture, or rain, &c.]. (IF, K.) And Arzg AlmaTaru AlA^aroDu The rain moistened the earth, or ground, (S, K,) and exceeded the ordinary degree, (S,) but did not flow. (S, K.) ― -b4- Arzg AlmaA='u The water was, or became, little in quantity. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

razogN *
A small quantity of water in what are termed vimaAd [q. v.] and HisaA=' [pl. of HisoyN q. v.] and the like. (TA.) ― -b2- See also razagapN.
razagN * : see razagapN. ― -b2- Also Moisture. (TA.)

razigN *
Sticking fast in slime or mire: (JK, T, S, * K:) or so ↓ murozigN and ↓ murozagN. (IB.)

razagapN * (S, K) and razogapN (Lth, Mgh) Thin mud; (TA;) [i. e.] slime, or mire: (S, K:) or much slime or mire: or, accord. to the M, it is less than what is termed radogapN [or radagapN, q. v.]: (TA:) but accord. to Lth (Mgh) and to the T, (TA,) stiffer than what is termed rdgp: (Mgh, TA:) or slime, or mire, little in quantity: (Ham p. 632:) pl. rizaAgN and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ razagN (K) [and ↓ razogN]: or razagN and razogN signify slime, or mire: (Mgh:) and ↓ rizaAgN is also expl. [as a sing., like ridaAgN,] as having this last meaning; and as meaning also moisture of the earth. (TA.)
rizaAgN * : see what next precedes.
marozagN * Rain producing much slime or mire; opposed to masiylN, “ causing much flowing. ” (Ham p. 632.)
murozagN * : see razigN.

murozigN * Rain that moistens the earth, or ground, exceeding the ordinary degree, but not flowing; opposed to musiylN, “ that causes the valleys and water-courses (tilaAE) to flow. ” (S, and Ham * p. 632.) ― -b2- See also razigN.

1 razaqahu A@ll~`hu * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
razuqa , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. rizoqN, (S,) or razoqN, (IB, K,) the latter being the proper inf. n., (K,) and the former a simple subst. but also used as an inf. n., (TA,) God caused what is termed rizoq [q. v.] to come to him: (K:) or God gave him. (S, IB.) [The verb is doubly trans.: when the second objective complement is implied, the phrase generally means God caused the means of subsistence to come to him; i. e., gave him, granted him, or bestowed upon him, the means of subsistence; or supplied, provided, or blessed, him therewith: when the second objective complement is expressed, this word is generally one signifying the means of subsistence or the like, property, or offspring.] One says also, razaqa AlT~aAy^iru faroxahu, aor.
razuqa , inf. n. razoqN, [The bird fed its young one.] (TA.) And razaqa AlA^amiyru Aljunoda The commander gave their subsistence-money, pay, or allowances, to the army: and razaqa Aljunoda razoqapF He gave the army their subsistence-money, &c., once: and ruziquwA razoqatayoni They were given their subsistence-money, &c., twice. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence ruziqa also signifies It (a place) was rained upon.] Lebeed says,
ruziqato maraAbiyEa Aln~ujuwmi waSaAbahaA
wadoqu Alr~awaAEidi jawoduhaA warihaAmuhaA
meaning muTirato; (TA;) i. e. They were rained upon with the rain of the A^anowaA=' [pl. of nawo'N q. v.] of the rabiyE, and the rain of the thundering clouds fell upon them, the copious thereof and the drizzling and lasting thereof. (EM pp. 140 and 141.) ― -b3- And razaqa fulaAnFA He thanked such a one; was thankful, or grateful, to him; or acknowledged his beneficence: of the dial. of Azd, (K,) i. e. Azd-Shanooah. (TA.) One says, faEalotu *`lika lam~aA razaqotaniY i. e. lam~aA $akarotaniY [I did that since, or because, thou thankedst me]. (TA.) And hence, in the Kur [lvi. 81], watajoEaluwna rizoqakumo A^an~akumo taka*~ibuwna [And do ye make your thanking to be that ye disacknowledge the benefit received, as being from God?]; (K;) i. e., accord. to Ibn-'Arafeh, do ye, instead of acknowledging what God has bestowed upon you, and being thankful for it, attribute it to another than Him? or, accord. to Az and others, [as J also says in the S,] the meaning is, tajoEaluwna $akora riziqokumu Alt~ako*iyba [do ye make the thanking for your sustenance to be disacknowledgment?]: (TA:) and some read $akorakumo [for rizoqakumo]. (Bd.)

8 ArtzqwA * , (S, Msb, K,) said of soldiers, (S,) or of people, (Msb,) They took, or received, their A^arozaAq [i. e., when said of soldiers, portions of subsistence-money, pay, or allowances, and when said of others, means of subsistence, &c.]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

10 Astrzqhu *
He asked, or demanded, of him what is termed rizoq [i. e. means of subsistence, &c.; when said of a soldier, subsistence-money, pay, or allowance]; (MA, TA;) as also ↓ Artzqhu. (TA.)

rizoqN *
A thing whereby one profits, or from which one derives advantage; (S, K;) as also ↓ murotazaqN, (K, TA,) in the pass. form: (TA: [in the CK, erroneously, murotaziq:]) and a gift; and especially, of God: (S:) or [especially, and according to general usage,] the means of subsistence, or of the support and growth of the body, which God sends to [mankind and other] animals; [sustenance, victuals, food, or provisions; or a supply thereof from God:] but with the Moatezileh it means a thing possessed and eaten by the deserving; so that it does not apply to what is unlawful: (TA:) pl. A^arozaAqN: (S, Msb, K:) and what are thus termed are of two kinds; apparent, [or material,] which are for the bodies, such as aliments; and unapparent, [or intellectual,] which are for the hearts and minds, such as the several sorts of knowledge and of science: (TA:) or rizoqN properly signifies a portion, share, or lot; or particularly, of something good, or excellent; syn. HaZ~N: and is conventionally made to apply to a thing by which an animal is enabled to profit: (Bd in ii. 2:) and [hence] it signifies also a daily allowance of food or the like; and so ↓ rizoqapN of
which the pl. is rizaqN: (TA:) [the subsistencemoney, pay, or allowance, of a soldier; or] what is given forth to the soldier at the commencement of every month, or day by day: or, accord. to ElKarkhee, AlEaTaA='u is what is assigned to those who fight; and Alr~azoqu, to the poor: (Mgh: [but see EaTaA='N:]) and ↓ razaqaAtN, pl. of ↓ razaqapN, which is the inf. n. of unity of raraqa, signifies the portions of subsistence-money, pay, or allowances, (syn. A^aTomaAE,) of soldiers: (S, K:) one says, kamo rizoquka fiY Al$~ahori How much is thy allowance of food, or the like, [or thy subsistence-money, or pay,] in the month? (TA:) and A^axa*uwA A^arozaAqahumo [They took, or received, their portions of subsistence-money, &c.,] (S, Msb, K) is said of soldiers. (S.) Alr~izoqu AlHasanu means A thing [or provision] that comes to one without toil in the seeking thereof: or, as some say, a thing [or provision] that is found without one's looking, or watching, for it, and without one's reckoning upon it, and without one's earning it, or labouring to earn it. (KT.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Rain (S, K) is sometimes thus called; as in the Kur xlv. 4 and li. 22: this being an amplification in language; as when one says, “ The dates are in the bottom of the well; ” meaning thereby “ the [water for] watering the palm-trees. ” (S.)
razoqapN * , and its pl. razaqaAtN: see the next preceding paragraph.
rizoqapN * : see rizoqN.
Alr~az~aAqu * : see what next follows, in two places.

Alr~aAziqu * and ↓ Alr~az~aAqu, the latter of which has an intensive signification, are epithets applied to God, meaning [The Supplier of the means of subsistence, &c.; or] the Creator of what are termed AlA^arozaAq, and the Giver of their A^arozaAq to his creatures. (TA.) [The former epithet is also applicable to a man; but ↓ the latter is not.] ― -b2- rawaAziqu [as pl. of raAziqN, agreeably with a general rule relating to epithets of the measure faAEilN when not applicable to rational beings, and of raAziqapN,] Dogs, and birds, that prey, or catch game. (TA.)

raAziqiY~N * [erroneously written by Golius and Freytag raAzaqiY~N] Weak: (Moheet, L, K:) applied to anything. (Moheet, L.) -A2- Also The species of grapes called mulaAHiY~ or mul~aAHiY~; (T, K;) a species of grapes of Et-Táïf, with long berries; they are called EinabN raAziqiY~N. (TA.) ― -b2- And Wine (K, TA) made of the grapes so called; (TA;) as also ↓ raAziqiy~apN. (K, TA.) -A3- And ↓ raAziqiy~apN [as a coll. gen. n. of which raAziqiY~N is the n. un.] White flaxen cloths. (S, K.) Lebeed says, describing vessels of wine,
lahaA galalN mino raAziqiY~K wakurosufK
biA^ayomaAni EujomK yanoSufuwna AlmaqaAwilaA
[They have a strainer of white flaxen cloth and of cotton, in the right hands of foreigners that act as servants to the kings]: he means yaxodumuwna AlA^aqoyaAla: (S:) and by galalN he means “ a strainer ” (miSofaAp, or fidaAm,) on the heads of the A^abaAriyk. (S in art. gl.)
raAziqiy~apN * [erroneously written by Golius and Freytag raAzaqiy~apN]: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
marozuwqN * A man possessed of good fortune, or of good worldly fortune. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- A^abuw marozuwqK was the name of A certain he-goat, mentioned in poetry. (IAar.)
murotazaqN * : see rizoqN.

Almurotaziqapu *
Those who receive [subsistence-money, pay, or] settled periodical allowances of food or the like: (Mgh, * Msb, * TA:) and they are thus called though they be not written down in the register [of the army &c.]. (Mgh.)

1 razama * , said of a camel, (Lh, K,) and of a man, &c.; (Lh, TA;) or razamato, said of a she-camel; (S;) aor.
razuma and
razima , inf. n. ruzuwmN and ruzaAmN; (S, K;) He was unable to rise, (Lh, K, TA,) in consequence of his having fallen down by reason of fatigue and emaciation, (Lh, TA,) or in consequence of emaciation (K, TA) arising from hunger or disease: (TA:) or she stood still, or stopped from journeying, in consequence of fatigue and emaciation, and was motionless. (S, TA.) ― -b2- razama, (K, TA,) said of a man, inf. n. razomN, (TA,) He died. (K, TA.) ― -b3- razama EalaY qironihi He overcame his adversary, and kneeled upon him, (K, TA,) and quitted not his place. (TA.) One says of a lion razama EalaY firiysatihi [He lay upon his breast on his prey, not quitting it]. (TA.) ― -b4- Airozimo bihi maA razama Be thou firm, or steadfast, with it as long as it is firm, or steadfast: referring to fortune when it is severe, or rigorous. (Ham p. 362.) ― -b5- And razama biAl$~aYo'i He laid hold upon the thing. (K.) ― -b6- $adiydapF ↓ razama Al$~itaA='u razomapF The winter was, or became, intensely cold. (K, * TA.) Hence ↓ nawo'u Almirozami [q. v. infrà]. (K, TA.) ― -b7- razamati AlA^um~u bihi The mother brought him forth: (K:) and so zaramato bihi. (TA.) -A2- razama Al$~aYo'a, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
razuma (Msb, K) and
razima , (K,) inf. n. razomN, (Msb, TA,) He collected together the thing (S, Msb, K) in a garment, or piece of cloth. (K. [See 2.]) -A3- See also 4.

2 rz~m Alqawomu * , (K,) inf. n. taroziymN, (TA,) The people cast, or laid, themselves down upon the ground, (K, TA,) and remained fixed there, (TA,) not quitting their place. (K, TA.) -A2- rz~m Alv~iyaAba, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He bound the clothes, or tied them up, (S, K,) in rizam [or bundles]: (S:) he made the clothes into rizam. (Msb.)

3 rAzm Ald~aAra *
He remained, stayed, or dwelt, long in the house, or abode. (K, TA.) ― -b2- rAzm bayonahumaA He conjoined them two; (K;) [as, for instance, two kinds of food, by taking them in immediate succession:] he mixed them. (TA.) You say, rAzmt AlA_ibilu The camels mixed two pastures. (S, TA.) And rAzmt AlA_ibilu AlEaAma The camels pastured upon the HamoD [or salt, or sour, plants] one time, and xul~ap [or sweet plants] another time, this year. (TA.) [In the case of a man,] muraAzamapN in eating signifies the making a consecutive, or successive, connexion [between two things]; kamaA yuraAzimu Alr~ajulu bayona AljaraAdi waAlt~amori [like as when the man makes a consecutive, or successive, connexion between the eating of locusts and that of dates; or makes locusts and dates consecutive, or successive]: (S, TA:) or muraAzamapN in relation to food signifies the making an interchange, by eating one day flesh-meat, and one day honey, (K, TA,) and one day dates, (TA,) and one day [drinking] milk, (K, TA,) and one day [eating] bread without any seasoning or condiment, (TA,) and the like; not keeping continually, or constantly, to one thing: (K, TA:) or the intermixing the [acts of] eating with thanks, and the mouthfuls with praise; (IAar, K, TA;) by saying, between the mouthfuls, Praise be to God: (IAar, TA:) or the mentioning God between every two mouthfuls: (Th, TA:) or the eating the soft and the dry or tough [alternately], and the sweet and the sour, and the unseasoned, or disagreeable in taste, and the seasoned: agreeably with all of these interpretations is explained the saying of 'Omar, A_i*aA A^akalotumo faraAzmuwA: (K, TA:) as though he said, [When ye eat,] eat what is easy and agreeable to swallow with what is unseasoned, or disagreeable in taste: (TA:) or mix ye, in your eating, what is soft with what is rough, or harsh, or coarse: (IAth, TA:) or make ye praise to follow [your eating]. (S.) ― -b3- muraAzamapu Als~uwqi means The purchasing in the market less than what will make up the full quantity of the loads. (K.)

4 Arzmt *
She (a camel) uttered a cry such as is termed razamap [q. v.] when loving, or affecting, her young one: (S:) or she (a camel) uttered a cry of yearning towards her young one: (K:) and in like manner, Arzmt EalaY waladihaA is said of a ewe, or she-goat: but sometimes A_irozaAmN means the uttering of a cry, or sound, absolutely: and Arzmt said of a she-camel occurs in a trad. as meaning she uttered a cry. (TA.) One says, laA A^afoEalu *aAka maA A^arozamato A^um~u HaAy^ilK [I will not do that as long as a mother of a female young camel utters her gentle yearning cry]: (S, K: *) a prov. (K.) And hence, i. e. from Arzmt said of a she-camel, (TA,) Arzm is also said of thunder, (S, K,) meaning (tropical:) It made a vehement sound, or noise: (K, TA:) or it made a sound, or noise, (S, K,) not vehement. (K.) [And it seems that ↓ razimato and razima signify the same as Arzmt and Arzm said of a she-camel and of thunder: for] the inf. n. razamN, used in relation to a camel and to thunder, signify The making a sound or noise. (KL.) Arzmt is also said of a cooking-pot, meaning (assumed tropical:) It made a noise by its boiling. (Ham p. 663.) And you say, Arzmt Alr~iyHu fiY Aljawofi (assumed tropical:) The wind made a sound [in the belly]. (K.)
razimN * Rain accompanied by incessant thunder: a possessive epithet. (Lh, TA.)

ruzamN *
Firm, or steadfast, standing upon the ground: (S, K:) and ↓ murozimN and ↓ raAzimN signify [the same; or] firm, or steadfast, upon the ground: and the pl. of the last is ruz~aAmN, occurring in a verse cited voce rizaAmN, q. v. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The lion; and so ↓ murozimN; (K, TA;) because he lies upon his breast on his prey, not quitting it: (TA:) or ruzamN (Ham p. 362) and ↓ razaAmN (TA, and Ham ibid., [but in the latter without any syll. signs,]) like saHaAbN, and ↓ razaAmapN like saHaAbapN, [which is of a form denoting intensiveness of signification,] (TA,) are epithets applied to a lion, meaning that lies upon his breast on his prey, (Ham, TA,) and growls. (Ham.) Accord. to J, it is applied in a verse of Sáïdeh Ibn-Ju-eiyeh to an elephant: but accord. to IB, and the Expos. of Skr, it is there applied to a lion, as meaning That has remained firm, or steadfast, in his place. (TA.)

razomapN * : see 1: ― -b2- and see also the next paragraph, in two places. ― -b3- A^akala Alr~azomapN He ate the wajobap [or meal that sufficed for a day and a night, or for four and twenty hours]. (K.)

rizomapN *
A quantity remaining in a [receptacle of the kind called] jul~ap, [a meaning said in the TA, in art. rdm, to be erroneously assigned in the K, in that art, to ridomapN,] of dates, amounting to half thereof, or a third, or thereabout: (TA:) or, accord. to Sh, the third part, or fourth part, of a [sack such as is called] giraArap, (Mgh, TA,) or thereabout, (Mgh,) of dates or flour: or, accord. to Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh, like qawosN, signifying the quantity of the fourth part of the jul~ap, of dates: (TA:) or, accord. to the Tekmileh, [the pl.] rizamN signifies the [sacks called] garaAy^ir, in which is wheat: and hence the rizam of clothes [explained in what here follows. (Mgh.) ― -b2- A kaArap [or bundle, put in one piece of cloth and tied up,] of clothes; (S, Msb, TA;) what are tied up in one piece of cloth, (K, TA,) of clothes: (TA:) or clothes, and other things, put together [in a bundle]; as also ↓ razomapN: (Mgh:) IAmb explains it as meaning the thing in which are sorts (Durawb) and mixtures of clothes: and hence the author of the K has taken a meaning assigned by him to rizomapN, which, he says, is also written ↓ razomapN, namely, DarobN $adiydN [a vehement beating], altering and substituting: (TA:) the pl. of rizomapN is rizamN. (S, Msb.)

razamapN *
A cry, or sound, (AZ, S, K, TA,) a sort of yearning cry, (TA,) of a she-camel, when loving, or affecting, her young one, uttered from her throat, or fauces, (AZ, S, K, TA,) without opening her mouth, not as loud as that which is termed HaniynN. (AZ, S, TA.) It is said in a prov., razamapN walaA dir~apN [A gentle yearning cry of a she-camel, and no flow of milk]: (S:) or laA xayora fiY razamapK laA dir~apa fiyhaA [There is no good in a gentle yearning cry of a she-camel with which is no flow of milk]: (K:) applied to him who promises and does not fulfil: (S, K:) or to him who causes to wish and does not act: (A, TA:) or to him who makes a show of love, or affection, without proving it to be true or without;t its being accompanied by any gift. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Also The cry of a boy, or child. (K, TA: but not in the CK.) ― -b3- And, accord. to IAar, A vehement cry or sound. (TA.) ― -b4- And The cries of beasts of prey. (S, TA.) A poet says,
lils~ibaAEi Hawolahu razamaho
tarakuwA EamoraAna munojadilAF
[They left 'Amrán prostrate upon the ground; there being cries of the beasts of prey around him]. (IB, TA.)
razaAmN * : see ruzamN.

rizaAmN * A man strong and stubborn. (K.) ruzaAmN, [a mistranscription, app. for ↓ raz~aAmN, for it must be with teshdeed to the z, as is shown by an ex. in a copy of the S, consisting of two verses, of which the former here follows,] as an epithet applied to a man, means Stubborn, behaving with forced hardness or hardiness: it occurs, accord. as some relate it, in the saying of a rájiz, [so in the S and TA, but correctly, a poet using the sixth species of the metre termed Als~ariyE,] which others relate thus:
↓ A^ayaA baniY Eabodi manaAfi Alr~uz~aAmo
A^anotumo HumaApN waA^abuwkumu HaAmN
[O sons of 'Abd-Menáf, the firm, or steadfast, upon the ground, (accord. to this reading; but accord. to the reading that seems to be raz~aAmo, the stubborn, &c., as a sing., referring to 'AbdMenáf himself;) ye are defenders, and your father was a defender, HaAmo being for HaAmK]: ruz~aAm being pl. of raAzimN. (So in one of my two copies of the S: in the other copy omitted.)

raziymN *
A roaring, or growling: a poet says,
liA^usuwidhin~a EalaY AlT~ariyqi raziymu
[There is, or was, a roaring, or growling, of their lions on the road]. (S.)
razaAmapN * : see ruzamN.

Alr~izaAmiy~apu *
A sect who said that the office of Imám, after 'Alee, belonged to Mohammad Ibn-El-Hanafeeyeh, and then to his son 'Abd-Allah, and who accounted lawful those things that are [esteemed by the orthodox] forbidden: (KT:) or a sect of the extravagant zealots of the class of innovators, of the schismatics, or followers of 'Alee, who say that the office of Imám belonged to Aboo-Muslim El-Khurásánee, after El-Man- soor, and some of whom arrogated to themselves divinity, one of them being El-Mukanna', who made the moon to appear to them in Nakhshab, and of whose persuasion there is in this day a party in Má-wará-en-Nahr. (TA.)
raz~aAmN * : see rizaAmN. ― -b2- [Alr~az~aAmu, as an epithet applied to the lion, The roaring. (Freytag, from the “ Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen. ”)]

raAzimN * A camel remaining fixed upon the ground, (S, TA,) unable to rise, (Lh, S, K, TA,) in consequence of his having fallen down by reason of fatigue and emaciation, (Lh, TA,) or in consequence of emaciation (S, K, TA) arising from hunger or disease: (TA:) and in like manner applied to a man, &c.: (Lh, TA:) and also, [without p,] applied to a she-camel, meaning standing still, or stopping from journeying, in consequence of fatigue and emaciation, and motionless: (S:) pl. razomaY and rizaAmN, [accord. to Freytag ruzamN,] applied to camels. (TA.) ― -b2- See also marozimN. ― -b3- Also, applied to winter, Cold. (TA.)

[
murozimN *
A prey. (Freytag, from the “ Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen. ”)]
murozimN * : see ruzamN, in two places.

Almirozamu * is a name of The right star [app. γ, i. e. Bellatrix,] in the left arm of Aljab~aAr [or Orion]. (Kzw. [Golius says, as on the authority of Kzw, that it is “ a star in the right shoulder of Orion: ” but Kzw says that this star (which is a of Orion) is called manokibu AljawozaA='i and yadu AljawozaA='i; and then he mentions that in the left arm, as being called Almrzm: whence it seems that Golius was misled by the omission of some words in a copy of the work of Kzw.]) And AlmirozamaAni, (S, K,) also called mirozamaA Al$~iEorayayoni, (S,) is the name of Two stars [of which one is commonly known as B of Canis Major, and the other is app. B of Canis Minor, though Golius says, on the authority of Ulugh Beg, that the former is in the right hind leg of Canis Major,] with the $iEorayaAni [by which latter appellation are meant Sirius and Procyon], (K,) or one of which is in [or by] Al$~iEoraY [commonly so called, i. e. Sirius,] and the other is in Al*~iraAE [by which is meant Al*~iraAE AlmaqobuwDap, i. e. the asterism consisting of a and B of Canis Minor]; (S;) or one of them is Al*rAE AlmqbwDp [mentioned above and the other is Al$~iEoraY (q. v.) commonly so called]: thus says Ibn-Kunáseh: both are of the stars of rain: and sometimes the sing. appellation (Almirozamu) is used [app. as applied to Sirius, or to Bellatrix, or perhaps to B of Canis Minor]. (TA.) nawo'u Almirozami [means The auroral setting of some one of the stars above mentioned; for it] is so termed because of its intense cold. (TA. See 1.) Als~amaAku Almirozamu is another name for Als~imaAku Alr~aAmiHu [The star Arcturus]. (Az and TA in art. rmH. [This star neither sets nor rises aurorally in the cold season, nor is it one of the Mansions of the Moon; but it rises aurorally during “ the first of the rains, ” the autumnal rain, called AlwasomiY~.]) ― -b2- A^um~u mirozamK (tropical:) The north wind: (S, K, TA:) or the cold north wind: (Skr, on a verse of Sakhr-el-Gheí:) from razaAmapu Aln~aAqapi meaning “ the [gentle] yearning cry of the she-camel: ” (TA:) or it signifies, (ISd, TA,) or signifies also, (K,) the wind: (ISd, K, TA:) thus expl. by ISd without any restriction. (TA.)

muraz~imN *
That has cast, or laid, himself upon the around, and remained fixed, or motionless: or having [or making or uttering] a sound, or cry: and applied to an army, or a military force, agreeably with one or the other of these explanations. (Skr, on a verse of Abu-l-Muthellem.)
tarakotuhu biAlmurotazami * [I left him in the place where one cleaves to the ground; or] I made him to cleave to the ground. (K.)

1 razuna * , (S, K, &c.,) inf. n. razaAnapN (S, * MA, K, * TA) and ruzuwnN, (TA,) [It (a thing) was, or became, heavy, or weighty: this is the primary signification: see razaAnapN below. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; (S, MA, K, TA;) and forbearing: and still, or motionless: (S, * K, * TA:) or firm, or sound, of judgment: (TA:) wise, or sensible. (MA.) -A2- razana biAlmakaAni [thus in the K, with fet-h to the z,] He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (K.) -A3- razanahu, (S, K,) aor.
razuna , inf. n. razonN, (S,) He lifted it (namely, a thing, S) in order that he might see what was its weight. (S, K.) ― -b2- Hence, razana AlHajara He lifted the stone from the ground. (TA.)

2 raz~ana [rz~nhu, inf. n. taroziynN, (assumed tropical:) He pronounced him, or held or reckoned him, to be grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm:] the inf. n. taroziynN is syn. with tawoqiyrN [q. v.]. (S in art. wqr.)

5 trz~n *
i. q. tawaq~ara (assumed tropical:) [He showed, exhibited, or manifested, gravity, staidness, steadiness, sedateness, or calmness; or he endeavoured, or constrained himself, to be grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm]; (M, K;) fiY majolisihi [in his sittingplace], (M,) or fiY Al$~aYo'i [in the thing]. (K.)
6 yataraAzaAnaAni * , said of two mountains, They are opposite, or facing, each other. (K.)

razonN *
A place that is elevated (S, K, TA) and hard, (TA,) having in it a depression that retains the water [of the rain]: pl. ruzuwnN and rizaAnN: (S, K, TA:) the latter of which pls. is also pl. of rizonapN [q. v.]. (K.) It is also sing. of A^arozaAnN signifying [Hollows, or cavities, such as are termed] nuqarN [pl. of nuqorapN] in stone, or in rugged ground, that retain the water [of the rain]; and so is ↓ rizonN; or, accord. to Ibn-Hamzeh, this latter only; and thus says IB, because a noun of the measure faEolN has not a pl. of the measure A^afoEaAlN, except in a few instances. (TA.) [The pl.] ruzawnN also signifies The remains of a torrent in places which it has partially worn away. (TA.)
rizonN * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also i. q. naAHiyapN [A side, region, quarter, or tract, &c.]. (K.)

rizonapN *
A place where water remains and collects; or where it collects and stagnates; or where it remains long, and becomes altered: pl. rizaAnN [mentioned above as a pl. of razonN, q. v.]: (S, K:) so says AO. (S.)
razaAnN * : see the next paragraph.

raziynN *
Heavy, or weighty; (S, K;) applied to a thing (S, TA) of any kind. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) Grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; (S, MA, K, TA;) and forbearing: and still, or motionless: (S, * K, * TA:) or firm, or sound, of judgment: (TA:) wise, or sensible: (MA:) or a man having much gravity, staidness, &c.: (Har p. 227:) and ↓ razaAnN signifies the same, applied to a woman; (MA, K;) or, thus applied, grave, staid, &c., in her sitting-place: (S:) the epithet raziynapN is not applied to her unless she be firm, or constant; and grave, staid, &c.; and continent, chaste, or modest; grave, staid, &c., in her sitting-place. (TA.) ― -b3- A^abuw raziynK is a name given to The [kind of sweet food commonly called] xabiyS [q. v.]; because of its excellence among eatables, and its high estimation, and its surpassing cost, and its being put the last thing to be eaten. (Har p. 227.)

razaAnapN * inf. n. of razuna [q. v.]. (MA, TA.) Heaviness, or weight: this is the primary signification. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) Gravity, staidness, steadiness, sedateness, or calmness; (S, MA, K, TA;) and forbearance: and stillness, or motionlessness: (S, * K, * TA:) or firmness, or soundness, of judgment: (TA:) wisdom, or sensibleness: (MA:) and firmness, or constancy. (Har p. 423.)

rawozanN * , (T, Mgh,) or ↓ rawozanapN, (ISk, S, M, K,) A hole, a perforation, an aperture, or a window, (ISk, T, S, M, Mgh, K,) syn. kuw~apN, (ISk, S, Mgh, K,) or kuw~apN naAfi*apN, (T,) [in a wall, or chamber, i. e. a mural aperture,] or in the upper part of a roof: (M, TA:) an arabicized word [from the Pers. rawozano, or rawozanaho]: (ISk, S:) thought by the author of the T to be arabicized, used by the Arabs: (TA:) pl. rawaAzinu. (T, Mgh.)
rawozunapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A^arozan * [accord. to general opinion, being a subst. only, not originally an epithet, A^arozanN, or, accord. to some, it may be A^arozanu, as being imagined to possess the quality of an epithet,] A kind of hard tree, (Lth, S, K,) of which staves are made. (Lth, S.)

huwa muraAzinuhu *
i. q. muHaAl~uhu [He is his companion in alighting, or descending and stopping or sojourning &c.]: (so in copies of the K:) or muxaAl~uhu [his friendly associate; or true, or sincere, friendly associate]. (So in the K accord. to the TA [which is followed in this instance, as generally, in the TK: but the former I regard as the true reading, from razana biAlmakaAni q. v.].)

1 razaY fulaAnFA * , aor.yaroziY, (K,) inf. n. razoYN, (TA,) He accepted the bounty of such a one. (K.) [See also razaA^ahu: and, under the same head, see raziynaA, and ruziytuhu: and see a verse cited voce mutoladN; in which ruziynaA seems to be used for ruziy^onaA; or the latter may be the correct reading.]

4 ArzY A_ilayohi *
He leaned, or stayed, himself upon, or against, him, or it; and he had recourse, or betook himself, to him, or it, for refuge, protection, covert, or lodging: (K:) or A^arozayotu ZahoriY A_ilaY fulaAnK I had recourse, or betook myself, to such a one for refuge, protection, covert, or lodging: (S:) or, accord. to Lth, the verb is A^arozaA^a, with '. (TA.)
raziy~apN * , for raziyy^apN: see the latter, in art. rzA^.

1 ras~a AlhuwaY fiY qalobihi * , and Als~uqomu fiY jisomihi, [aor., accord. to the general rule,
rasi3a ,] inf. n. ras~N and rasysN, Love entered, and established itself, in his heart, and disease in his body; as also ↓ Ars~. (M.) [It seems also, from explanations of ras~u and rasiysN mentioned below, that one says ras~ati AlHum~aY, meaning The fever commenced, or first touched a person.]
4 A^arosa3a see above.

ras~N * The beginning, or commencement, of a thing. (K.) And hence, (K,) ras~u AlHum~aY, and ↓ rasiysuhaA, The beginning, or commencement, (M, A, K,) or first touch, (S,) of fever, (S, M, A, K,) before it becomes vehement, or severe; (A;) i. e., when the person attacked thereby stretches on account of it, and becomes languid in his body, and relaxed, or heavy, sluggish, or torpid, or confused in his intellect: (M, TA:) or the first that a man feels of the touch of fever, before it takes him forcibly, and becomes apparent. (As, TA.) Accord. to Fr, you say, A^axa*atohu AlHum~aY biras~K, meaning, The fever became settled in his bones. (TA.) [Hence also,] ras~u AlHub~i, and ↓ rasiysuhu, The beginning, or commencement, of love: (K:) or a remain, or relic, or trace, of love: (M:) or AlhawaY ↓ rasiysu signifies the first, or original, feeling (A^aSol) of love. (Aboo-Málik, TA.) [Hence also,] balaganiY ras~N mino xabarK The first of news reached me: (TA:) or somewhat of news reached me: (S, M:) [or news not true reached me: for,] accord. to AZ, you say, A^ataAnaA ras~N mino xabarK, and mano xabarK ↓ rasiysN, meaning, News not true came to us: (TA:) or ↓ rasiysN [alone] signifies news not true. (K.)
rasiysN * : see ras~N, throughout.

1 rasaba * , (S, M, A, &c.,) aor.
rasuba , (M, A, &c.,) inf. n. rusuwbN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and rasobN; (Msb;) and rasuba, aor.
rasuba ; (M, A, K;) It (a thing, S, Msb) sank, or subsided, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) in water [&c.]. (S, M, A, Mgh, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rasabato EayonaAhu (tropical:) His eyes sank [in their sockets]. (S, A.) ― -b3- And Als~ayofu yarosubu fiY AlD~arybapi (tropical:) The sword sinks, or disappears, in the thing struck with it. (TA.)

2 rs~b *
It precipitated a substance, or caused it to sink in a liquid: used in this sense in chymical works; but probably post-classical. See what next follows.]

4 Arsb *
It caused [a thing] to sink: hence, in a trad., describing the people of Hell, A_i*aA Tafato bihimu Aln~aAru A^arosabatohumu AlA^agolaAlu When the fire shall raise them, and make them. to appear [or rather to
swim upon its surface], the collars, by reason of their weight, shall make them to sink to the bottom thereof. (TA.) -A2- And ArsbwA Their eyes sank in their heads by reason of hunger. (K, TA.)

5 trs~b *
It (a substance) became precipitated, or was caused to sink, in a liquid: used in this sense in chymical works; but probably postclassical.]
rasabN * and rusabN: see the next paragraph.

rasuwbN * [What is wont to sink, or subside, in water &c. ― -b2- And hence,] Dregs amid water and blood: in this sense improperly pronounced rusuwbN. (KL. [Golius, as on the same authority, explains it as meaning sedimentum aquæ, urinæ, etc.: hypostasis. See also the next paragraph.]) ― -b3- [Hence also,] (tropical:) A sword (S, M, A, K) that penetrates into, (S,) or that disappears in, (M, A, K,) the thing struck with it; (S, M, A, K;) and so ↓ rasabN (M, K) and ↓ rusabN (K, TA) and ↓ mirosabN. (A, K, TA. [In the CK, by the omission of wa after the last, this and the last but one are made to be appellations of a sword of Mohammad or of Soloman, and of a sword of El-Hárith Ibn-AbeeShemir.]) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The glans of the penis: (M, K:) app. because of its disappearance on the occasion of the act of jimaAEi. (M.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Forbearing, or element; as also ↓ raAsibN. (K.)

rusaAbapu AlmaA='$ * (JK and Mgh and K in art. tqn [in CK erroneously rasaAbap]) [The sediment of water;] the thick matter that is borne by water [and that sinks to the bottom]. (Lth, Mgh in that art.)

[
rasuwbiY~N * and ↓ mutaras~ibN, terms used by Ibn-Seenà, are explained by Golius as meaning Having, or depositing, a sediment: but the former rather means having the nature of dregs, or sediment: and the latter, becoming, or that becomes, precipitated.]
raAsibN * (tropical:) A firm mountain. (M, A, K.) ― -b2- See also rusuwbN.

rawosabN *
A calamity, or misfortune; (K;) as also rawosamN. (TA.)
mirosabN * : see rasuwbN.

maraAsibu *
i. q. A^awaAsK [pl. of A=siyapN, and app. here meaning Columns, or props]. (K.)
mutaras~ibN * : see rasuwbiY~N.
rusotaAqN * : see ruzodaAqN, in art. rzdq.

1 rasHa * , aor.
rasaHa , inf. n. rasaHN, (L, Msb,) He had little flesh, or was scant of flesh, in his posteriors and thighs: or he had small buttocks, sticking together: (L:) or he had little flesh in his thighs. (Msb.)

4 ArsH *
It rendered a person scant of flesh in the posteriors (S, A) and thighs. (S.)

rasaHN *
Paucity of flesh in the posteriors (S, A, L, K) and thighs: (S, L, K:) or smallness of the buttocks, and their sticking together: (L:) or paucity of flesh in the thighs. (Msb.)

rasiHN *
Having little flesh in his thighs. (Msb.) [See also what follows.]

A^arosaHu * A man (S, L) having little flesh in his posteriors (S, A, L) and thighs: (S, L:) or having small buttocks, sticking together: (L:) fem. rasoHaA='u; applied to a woman: (S, A, L:) pl. rusoHN. (S, K.) [See also rasiHN.] AlA^arosaHu means The wolf: (TA:) [for] every wolf is [termed] A^arosaH because of the lightness [of the flesh] of his haunches: (S, A, * K:) and so is the simoE [a mongrel beast, the offspring of a wolf begotten from the hyena]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the fem., A foul, an ugly, or an unseemly, woman: (K, TA:) though disapproved by MF. (TA.)

1 rasaxa * , (S, A, L, &c.,) aor.
rasaxa , (A, Msb, JM, &c.,) inf. n. rusuwxN, It (a thing, S, Msb) was, or became, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) in its place. (L.) [Hence,] rasaxa AlHiboru fiY AlS~aHiyfapi (tropical:) [The ink became fixed upon the piece of paper or the like]. (A, L.) And Alr~aq~u Ald~ahiynu laA yurosaxu fiyhi AlHiboru (tropical:) [Ink will not become fixed upon oiled parchment]: (A:) or Alwaraqu Ald~ahiynu [oiled paper]. (TA.) And rasaxa fiY AlEilomi (tropical:) He became firmly rooted, or grounded, or established, in science, or knowledge. (L.) And AlEilomu yarosaxu fiY qalobi AlA_inosaAni (tropical:) Science, or knowledge, becomes firmly rooted, or grounded, or fixed, in the heart of man. (L, A. *) And rasaxa Hub~uhu fiY qalobihi (tropical:) [The love of him, or it, became fixed in his heart]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] said of a pool of water left by a torrent, (tropical:) It sank into the earth, and disappeared: (JK, A, K:) inf. n. as above. (JK, TA.) And, said of rain, (tropical:) It sank into the earth so that the two moistures [meaning that of the rain and that of the soil beneath] met together. (A, K.) ― -b3- rasoxN [as an inf. n.] signifies (assumed tropical:) The connexion of the soul of a human being, after its departure from the body, with an inanimate, not increasing, body: distinguished from nasoxN, which is with the body of another human being: and from masoxN, which is with the body of a beast: and from fasoxN, which is with a plant. (Marginal note in a copy of the KT.) But see 1 (last sentence) in art. fsx
4 Arsxhu * , (JK, K,) inf. n. A_irosaAxN, (TA,) He made it firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established, (JK, K,) in its place. (JK.)

raAsixN * Anything firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established [in its place (see 1)]. (S, A, Msb.) You say jabalN raAsixN A firm, or steadfast, mountain. (A.) And in like manner dimonapN raAsixapN [A black, or dark, patch of compacted dung and urine of cattle sticking fast upon the ground]. (A.) And [hence,] lahu qadamN raAsixapN fiY AlEilomi (assumed tropical:) [He has a firm footing in science, or knowledge; or] he possesses excellence, and large acquirements, in science, or knowledge. (Msb.) Alr~aAsixuwna fiY AlEilomi [in the Kur iii. 5 and iv. 160] means (tropical:) Those who are firmly rooted, or established, in science, or knowledge: (S, Bd, L, Jel, TA:) or who have made a firm advance therein: (L:) or who are far advanced therein: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh:) or those who study the Book of God: (TA:) or those who have committed [it] to memory, and who call to mind [its doctrines and precepts] one with another. (IAar.)
rusodaAqN * : see ruzodaAqN, in art. rzdq.

1 rasagahu * , aor.
rasaga , inf. n. rasogN, [He tethered him by the fore legs; i. e.] he tied the rusog [or pastern] of each of his (a camel's [or an ass's]) fore legs with a string, or cord, which is called rusogN. (TA.)

2 rs~g * , (S, Msb, &c.,) inf. n. tarosiygN, (IAar, K,) said of rain, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) It rained so that the water reached to the rusog [or pastern, or ankle], (S,) or so that it reached to the place of the A^arosaAg [pl. of rusogN]: (Msb:) or it moistened the earth (IAar, K, TA) so that the hands of him who dug for it reached to his A^arosaAg [or wrists]; (IAar, TA;) or so that the moisture reached to the measure of the rusog [or wrist] of the digger: (TA:) or it was so much that the rusog [or pastern, or ankle,] disappeared in it; as also ↓ Arsg, a dial. var., on the authority of IAar. (TA.) -A2- tarosiygN also signifies The making [the means of subsistence] ample, or abundant. (K.) You say, rs~g AlEayo$a He made the means of subsistence ample, or abundant. (TK.) [Or rs~g Ealayohi fiY AlEayo$i He made ample, or abundant, provision for him in the means of subsistence: see the pass. part. n., below: and see also 8.] -A3- rs~gtu kalaAmFA, (JK,) inf. n. as above, (K,) i. q. laf~aqotu bayonahu [meaning I interlarded, or embellished, speech. or discourse, with falsehood: accord. to the TK, connected it, and arranged it, or put it in order: but see the pass. part. n., below]. (JK, K, * TA.)

3 rAsghu * , (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) inf. n. muraAsagapN and risaAgN, (Lth, Ibn-'Abbád, K,) He took hold of his rusog [meaning ankle] in wrestling with him, the latter doing the like. (Lth, Ibn-'Abbád, K.) One says, raAdagahu vum~a raAsagahu vum~a maAragahu [He strove with him to throw him down: then he took hold of his ankle &c.: then he rolled with him on the ground, or in the dust]. (TA.)
4 A^arosaga see 2.

8 Artsg EalaY EiyaAlihi *
He expended amply, or abundantly, upon his family, or household. (Ibn-Buzurj, K.) [See also 2.]

rusogN * and ↓ rusugN, (S, Msb, K,) of a daAb~ap [or beast
of the equine kind], (S, Msb,) [The pastern; i.e.] the slender place [or part] between the solid hoof and the joint of the waZiyf [or shank] of the fore leg, and of the hind leg; (S, Msb, K;) or, [in other words,] of solid-hoofed animals, the part that joins the wZyf of each of the fore legs, and of the hind legs, to the hoof; and of camels, the part that joins the A^awoZifap [or shanks] to the A^axofaAf [or feet]: (TA:) and (Msb, and so in some copies of the K, but in other copies of the latter “ or, ” [which is more correct, as will be seen from what follows,]) of a human being, [the wrist, and the ankle; i. e.] the joint between the hand and the fore arm, and between the foot and the shank: (Msb, K, TA:) and of any beast (dAb~h,) the like thereof; (K;) [the part between the shank and hoof or foot, in the fore leg and in the hind leg, of any quadruped:] pl. A^arosaAgN [used as a pl. of mult. and of pauc.] (Msb, K) and A^arosugN [which is only a pl. of pauc.]. (K.) ― -b2- See also risaAgN: ― -b3- and see mirosagapN.

rasagN *
A laxness in the legs of a camel. (As, S, K.)
rusugN * : see rusogN

risaAgN *
A cord, or rope, that is tied (JK, S, K) firmly (S) to the rusog [or pastern] of the camel, (JK, S, K,) or, accord. to the T, to each rusog, [the dual form being there used, meaning to the pastern of each fore leg,] of the camel, (TA,) to prevent him from going away; (S, K;) also called ↓ mirosagapN; of which the pl. is maraAsigu: (JK:) or, as some say, rsaAgN is pl. of ↓ rusogN meaning a cord, or rope, with which a camel, and an ass, is [tethered, or] shackled; or a string, or cord, with which the rusog [or pastern] of each of the fore legs of a camel [or an ass] is tied. (TA.) ― -b2- Also an inf. n. of 3.

Eayo$N rasiygN *
Ample, or abundant, means of subsistence: and TaEaAmN rasiygN Much food or wheat. (Aboo-Málik, K.)

mirosagapN * sing. of maraAsiygu [probably a mistranscription for maraAsigu] meaning [Bracelets of tortoiseshell or horn or ivory, such as are termed] masak, that are worn by women on their arms; one of which is also called ↓ rusogN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also risaAgN.

huwa muras~agN Ealayohi fiY AlEayo$i *
He is amply, or abundantly, provided for in respect of the means of subsistence. (JK, * TA.) -A2- raA^oYN muras~agN An unsound opinion or counsel or advice. (JK, Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

1 rasafa * , aor.
rasufa and
rasifa , inf. n. rasofN and rasafaAnN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and rasiyfN, (M, O, Msb, K,) He walked, or went along, in the manner of him who is shackled: (S, M, O, K:) or he walked, or went along, in shackles, gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner: (M:) or you say, rasafa fiY qayodihi he walked, or went along, in his shackles: (MA, Msb:) or he went along [therein] by leaps; or gently. (MA.) rasiyfN also signifies The making short steps. (O.) And rasafa, aor.
rasufa , He (a camel) went with short steps, raising and putting down his feet quickly. (Aboo-Nasr, O.)

4 A^arosafotu AlA_ibila * , (AZ, S,) inf. n. A_irosaAfN, (K,) I drove along the camels, they being shackled. (AZ, S, K. * [In one of my copies of the S, instead of muqay~adapF, I find muqay~adFA, i.e. I being shackled.])

8 Artsf * , inf. n. AirotisaAfN; (K; so in MS. copies, and so in the CK;) or ↓ Airotasaf~a, in measure like Aikofahar~a, inf. n., AirotisofaAfN; (O, and in like manner in the TK;) i. q. AirotafaEa [It became raised; or it rose: &c.]. (O, K.)
R. Q. 4 Airotasaf~a * : see what next precedes. [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 rasila * , aor.
rasala , inf. n. rasalN and rasaAla, He (a camel) was, or became, easy in pace. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also, aor.
rasala , inf. n. rasalN (AZ, Az, Msb, K) and rasaAlapN, as above, (AZ, Az, K,) It (hair) became lank, not crisp; (Msb, K;) and so ↓ Astrsl: (S, K:) or lank and pendent: (Msb:) or long, and lank or pendent. (AZ, Az, Msb.) laA yajibu mina Alb~iHoyapi ↓ gasolu maA A@sotarosala means [The washing] of what hangs down, and descends, [of the beard,] from the chin [is not requisite, or necessary, or incumbent]. (Mgh.) -A2- [Golius says, as on the authority of the KL, that rasala signifies Nuncium misit: but what I find in the KL is, that rasuwlN, as an inf. n., signifies the bringing a message (PygAm brdn) : whence it seems that rasala means he brought a message.]

2 tarosiylN * , in reading, or reciting, (Msb, K,) i. q. tarotiylN; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) Easy [or leisurely] utterance; without haste: (Yz, Msb, TA:) or, as some say, with consecution of the parts, or portions: (TA:) and ↓ taras~ulN therein signifies the same: (Yz, Msb:) or fiY ↓ taras~ala qir~A='atihi signifies he proceeded in a leisurely manner in his reading, or reciting, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and was grave, staid, sedate, or calm, (Mgh,) and endeavoured to understand, without raising his voice much. (TA.) It is said in a trad., kaAna fiY kalaAmihi tarosiylN i. e. tarotiylN [There was in his (Mohammad's) speech an easy, or a leisurely, utterance]. (TA.) And in another trad. it is said, waA_i*aA A^aqamota faA@Ho*imo ↓ A_*aA A^a*~anota fataras~alo [expl. in art. H*m]. (Mgh.) -A2- See also 4, last sentence but one. -A3- ras~alotu fuSolaAniY, inf. n. tarosiylN, I gave to drink [to my young camels, or my young weaned camels,] risol (K, TA,) i. e. milk. (TA.)

3 rAslhu * (S, MA,) inf. n. muraAsalapN, (S,) He sent a message, and a letter, or an epistle, to him, (MA, PS,) the latter doing the like: (PS:) [he interchanged messages, and letters, with him.] You say, rAslhu fiY ka*aA [He interchanged messages, or letters, with him, in relation to such a thing]: and bayonahumaA muraAsalaAtN [Between them two are interchanges of messages, or of letters]. (TA.) And haYa turaAsilu AlxuT~aAba [She interchanges messages, or letters, with those who demand women in marriage]. (M, K.) And turaAsiluhu biAlxuT~aAbi [She interchanges messages, or letters, with him by means of those who demand women in marriage]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rAslhu fiY niDaAlK A^awo gayorihi [He acted interchangeably, or alternated, with him in a competition in shooting, or in some other performance]. (S.) And rAslhu fiY AlginaA='i, and AlEamali, He relieved him, or aided him, in singing, and in work, [by alternating with him, i. e.,] in the former case, by taking up the strain when the latter was unable to continue it [so as to accomplish the cadence (see 6)], and in the latter case by taking up the work when the latter person was unable to continue it; or he so relieved, or aided, him in singing with a high voice: or rAslhu fiY Eamalihi he aided him, [or relieved him, by alternating with him,] or he followed him, or imitated him, in his work: (IAar, Msb:) and rAslhu AlginaA='a he emulated him, or imitated him, [by alternating with him,] in the singing. (TA.) And rAslhu fiY AlqiraA='ap He aided him, or assisted him, [or relieved him, by alternating with him,] in the reading, or reciting, of the Kur-án &c. (MA.)

4 A_irosaAlN * signifies The act of sending. (K, KL, &c.) Thus is explained A_irosaAlu A@ll~`hi A^anobiyaA='ahu [i. e. God's sending his prophets.] (Th, TA.) You say, ↓ A^arosalotu fulaAnFA fiY risaAlapK (S) I sent such a one with a message. (PS.) And ↓ Arsl A_ilayohi rasuwlFA (MA, Msb *) He sent to him a message, or a letter, (MA,) or a messenger. (Msb.) ― -b2- [The act of sending forth, or starting, a horse for a race: the discharging a thing; as, for instance, an arrow from a bow; and water, or the like, from a vessel &c. in which it was confined: the launching forth a ship or boat; letting it go; letting it take its course:] the act of setting loose or free; letting loose; loosing, unbinding, or liberating. (K.) You say Arsl Al$~aYo'a He set loose or free, &c., the thing. (M.) And A^arosalotu AlT~aAy^ira mino yadiY I let go, or let loose, the bird from my hand. (Msb.) And [hence,] Arsl AlHuruwfa [He uttered the letters]. (Mgh in art. rtl.) And Arsl AlginaA='a [He uttered the song; he sang]. (TA.) And Arsl AlA_iqaAmapa [He chanted the AqAmp]. (Msb in art. drj. [See A^adoraja.]) And Arsl Ealayohi lisaAnahu [(assumed tropical:) He let loose his tongue against him]. (A in art. brd.) And Arsl AlkalaAma (assumed tropical:) He made the speech, or language, to be unrestricted. (Msb.) [In like manner,] A_irosaAlN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The making a thing, such as property, and a legacy, absolute, or unrestricted. (Mgh.) ― -b3- [The act of letting down, letting fall, or making to hang down, the hair &c. You say, Arslhu, and Arslhu mino A^aEolaY A_ilaY A^asofala, He let it down, &c., or lowered it.] ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The act of leaving, leaving alone, or neglecting, (M, K,) a thing. (M.) [Hence,] one says, Arslhu Eano yadihi (tropical:) He left, forsook, or deserted, him; or he abstained from,
or neglected, aiding him, or assisting him. (TA.) ― -b5- Also The act of making to have dominion, or authority, and power; making to have, or exercise, absolute dominion or sovereignty or rule, or absolute superiority of power or force; or giving power, or superior power or force. (M, K.) Hence, in the Kur [xix. 86], A^arosalonaA Al$~ayaATiyna EalaY AlkaAfiriyna taw^uz~uhumo A^az~FA, i. e. [We have made the devils to have dominion, &c., over the unbelievers, inciting them strongly to acts of disobedience; or] we have appointed, or prepared, the devils for the unbelievers, because of their unbelief; like as is said in the same [xliii. 35], nuqay~iDo lahu $ayoTaAnFA [“ We will appoint, or prepare, for him a devil ” as an associate]: this is the preferred explanation: [or it may be well rendered we have sent the devils against the unbelievers:] some say that the meaning is, we have left the devils to do as they please with the unbelievers, not withholding them, or preserving them, from acceptance from them. (Zj, M.) -A2- ArslwA [from risolN] They had milk in their cattle: (S:) or their milk became much; as also ↓ rs~lwA, inf. n. tarosiylN: (K:) or the latter signifies their milk and drink became much. (TA.) ― -b2- Also [from rasalN] They became possessors of herds or flocks. (O, K. *)

5 trs~l *
He acted, or behaved, gently, and deliberately, or leisurely, (M, K, TA,) and with gravity, staidness, sedateness, or calmness. (TA.) Alt~aras~ulu fiY AlA^umuwri is The acting, or behaving, [gently, and] deliberately, or leisurely, and with gravity, staidness, sedateness, or calmness, in affairs. (TA.) See also 2, in three places. ― -b2- Alt~aras~ulu in riding is The extending one's legs upon the beast so as to let, or make, his clothes hang down loosely upon his legs: and in sitting, the crossing one's legs, and letting, or making, his clothes hang down loosely upon them and around him. (TA.) -A2- trs~lA bayona Alqawomi [He acted as a rasuwl (or messenger) between the people]. (Msb and TA in art. Alk.)

6 trAslwA *
They sent, one to another, (MA, Msb, TA,) a message [or messages], (MA, Msb,) or a messenger [or messengers]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, trAslwA fiY AlginaA='i [They relieved, or aided, one another alternately in singing;] i. e. they combined in singing, one beginning, and prolonging his voice, but being unable to continue long enough to accomplish the cadence, and therefore pausing, and another then taking up the strain, and then the first returning to the modulation, and so on to the end. (Msb.) laA taraAsula fiY AlA^a*aAni means [in like manner] There shall be no relieving, or aiding, one another [alternately], i. e., no combining [of two or more persons, each performing a part alternately], in the chanting of the call to prayer. (Msb.) [In other cases likewise] Alt~araAsulu signifies The doing the like of that which one's companion, or fellow, [or another,] does, in such a manner as that one follows another [alternately]. (Har p. 268.)

10 Astrsl *
It (a thing) was, or became, loose, or slack; syn. salisa. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Said of hair: see 1, in two places. [In like manner said of a tree, &c., It drooped; or was pendent. Said of a cheek, (to which its part. n. musotarosilN is applied as an epithet in the K voce A^asiylN,) It was, or became, lank.] ― -b3- AlAisotirosaAlu in the pace of a beast is The going gently, deliberately, or leisurely. (TA.) [And you say, Astrslt Ald~aAb~apN The beast went a gentle, deliberate, or leisurely, pace.] ― -b4- Also, [in other cases,] The being still, and steady. (TA.) ― -b5- Hence, (TA,) Astrsl A_ilayohi (tropical:) He acted, or behaved, towards him with freedom, boldness, forwardness, or presumptuousness, and with familiarity; syn. AinobasaTa, and AisotaA^onasa; (S, K, TA;) and was at ease, and confided in him, with respect to that which he told him: (TA:) or he acted forwardly, or impudently, towards him: he acted forwardly, impudently, freely, or familiarly, towards him, in the way of coquetry, or feigned disdain. (MA.) ― -b6- And Astrsl Ald~ahoru fiyhimo faA^afonaAhumo [(assumed tropical:) Fate made free with them, and destroyed them]. (TA in art. bhl) -A2- Also He said, Send thou to me the camels in droves (A^arosaAlFA [in the CK, erroneously, AirosAlFA]); (K, TA;) ArsAlA being with fet-h to the hemzeh; i. e. drove after drove: for the camels, when they come to the water, are numerous; and their tender brings them to the watering-trough thus; not all together, as in this case they would press together upon the watering-trough and not satisfy their thirst. (TA.)

rasolN *
Easy; applied to a pace. (M, K.) ― -b2- Easy in pace; applied to a he-camel: fem. with p: (S, M, K:) or soft, or gentle, in pace; applied to a he-camel and to a she-camel: (Msb:) and ↓ mirosaAlN, also, applied to a she-camel, has the former of these significations; and its pl. is maraAsiylu: (S, K:) or this pl. signifies light, or active, she-camels, that give thee what they have to give spontaneously; and rasolapN is applied to one thereof: a she-camel is termed ↓ mirosaAlN as being likened to the arrow thus called. (TA.) ― -b3- Soft, and lax, or flaccid: [app. applied to a he-camel; for it is added,] one says naAqapN rasolapN AlqawaAy^imi, meaning A she-camel loose, or slack, [in the legs, and] soft in the joints [thereof]. (TA. [See also another meaning assigned to this phrase in what follows.]) ― -b4- Applied to hair, i. q. ↓ musotarosilN; (S, K; in the CK murosal;) which means Lank; not crisp: (Mgh, Msb: [and so accord. to an explanation of Astrsl in the S and K:]) or lank and pendent: (Msb:) or long, and lank or pendent. (AZ, Az, Msb.) ― -b5- And rasolapN, (M,) or rasolapu AlqawAy^imi, [of which see an explanation in what precedes,] (L, TA,) and ↓ mirosaAlN, applied to a she-camel, (M, L, TA,) Having much hair, (M,) or much and long hair, (L, TA,) upon her shanks, or hind legs (fiY saAqiyohaA): (M, L, TA:) but in the K, rasolapN and ↓ muraAsilN [not mirosaAlN] are explained as epithets applied to a woman, meaning having much and long hair upon her shanks. (TA.) ― -b6- Also sing. of ↓ risaAlN, (TA,) which signifies The legs of a camel: (AZ, S, K, TA:) so called because of their length. (AZ, TA.) -A2- See also muraAsilN. -A3- And see the paragraph here next following.

risolN *
Gentleness; and a deliberate, or leisurely, manner of acting or behaving; as also ↓ risolapN; (M, K;) [and perhaps ↓ rasolN and ↓ rasolapN; for] one says AifoEalo ka*aA waka*aA EalaY risolika (S, Mgh, * Msb, * CK * [but not in my MS. copy of the K nor in the copies used by SM]) and rasolika and rasolatika, (CK, [but likewise wanting in MS. copies of the K,]) i. e. [Do thou such and such things] at thine ease; (Msb;) or act thou gently, deliberately, or leisurely, (S, Mgh, K, *) in doing such and such things; like as one says, EalaY hiynatika. (S.) Sakhr-el-Ghei says, when despairing of his companions' overtaking him, his enemies surrounding him, and he feeling sure of slaughter, (M,)
lawo A^an~a HawoliY mino qurayomK rajolaA
biyDa Alwajuwhi yaHomiluwna Aln~abolaA
lamanaEuwniY najodapF A^awo risolaA
(Skr, M, *) i. e. [If there were around me, of the family of Kureym, men on foot, fair in the faces (app. meant tropically), bearing arrows, they would defend me] by violent means or by gentle means: (Skr:) or with fighting or without fighting. (M.) [See also a phrase cited from a trad. in what follows of this paragraph.] One says also, ↓ jaAw^uwA risolapF risolapF They came company by company. (M.) ― -b2- And A soft, gentle, saying or speech. (TA.) -A2- Also Milk, (S, M, K,) of whatever sort it be: (M, K:) or, accord. to the Towsheeh, fresh milk. (TA.) One says, kavura Alr~isolu AlEaAma, meaning Milk has become abundant this year: and the people of the desert assert that, when this is the case, dates are few; and that, when dates are abundant, milk is scarce. (TA.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad. [respecting the giving of the poor-rate], A_il~aA mano A^aEoTaY fiY najodatihaA warisolihaA, (S, TA,) which is explained in two different ways: (TA:) [J says that] it is from risolN in the sense first explained above; meaning straitness and plenty; i. e. Except him who gives when they are fat and goodly, when it is difficult, or hard, to their owner to give them forth, and when they are lean, [or] in a middling condition: (S:) and A'Obeyd says the like; and that it is similar to the saying, qaAla fulaAnN ka*aA Eam~aA risolihi, meaning Such a one said such a thing holding it (the saying) in light estimation: others say that it is from risolN signifying “ milk; ” which A'Obeyd disallows: IAth says that what is meant by njdp is straitness and drought or barrenness or dearth; and by rsl, plenty, and abundance of herbage or the like; because rsl, i. e. milk, is plentiful only in the case of abundance of herbage; so that the meaning is, except him who gives forth the due of God in the case of straitness and in that of plenty. (TA.) -A3- The risolaAni of a horse are The extremities of the EaDudaAni [or two arms]. (M, K. *)

rasalN *
Camels: (M, K:) thus expl. by A'Obeyd, without any epithet: (M:) or a drove, or herd, or a distinct collection or number, of camels, (S, M, * Msb, K,) and of sheep or goats, (S, K,)
accord. to ISk from ten to twenty-five, (TA,) or the rasal of the watering-trough is at least ten, and extending to twenty-five; and the word is masc. and fem.; (M;) and also (assumed tropical:) of horses or horsemen; (S;) applied to (tropical:) a company of men (Mgh, Msb) as being likened to a drove, or herd, of camels: (Msb:) and also a distinct collection or number of any things: (M, K:) pl. A^arosaAlN. (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) A rájiz says,
yaA *aAy^idayohaA xaw~iSaA biA^arosaAlo
walaA ta*uwdaAhaA *iyaAda AlD~ul~aAlo
[O ye two drivers of them, water some before others, by droves, and drive them not with the driving of those who err from the right way]: (S, TA:) i. e. bring near your camels some after some, and do not let them crowd upon the water-ing-trough. (TA.) And one says, jaA='ati AlA_ibilu rasalFA The camels came [in a drove, or] following one another. (IAmb, TA.) And jaA='ati Alxayolu A^arosaAlFA, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The horses, or horsemen, came] in successive distinct companies. (S, TA.) And jaA'uwA A^arosaAlFA (tropical:) They (men) came in successive companies. (Msb. [And the like is said in the Mgh and in the TA.]) waqiyrN kaviyru Alr~asali qaliylu Alr~isoli, occurring in a trad. relating to a drought, is said by IKt to mean [A collection of sheep or goats] of which many were sent to the pasture, i. e. many in number, but having little milk but the more probable explanation of kvyr Alrsl is that of El-'Odhree, who says that it means much dispersed in search of pasture: for the trad. relates that the camels had died, notwithstanding their ability to endure drought: how then should the sheep or goats be safe, and increase so as to become numerous? (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- Also Animals, or beasts, having milk. (M, TA.)
rusulN * A young girl, that has not worn the [muffler, or veil, called] xamaAr. (K.) -A2- Also a pl. of rasuwlN. (S, M, &c.)

rasolapN *
A soft, or delicate condition of life: you say, humo fiY rasolapK mina AlEayo$i They are in a soft, or delicate, condition of life. (M.) ― -b2- And Heaviness, sluggishness, laziness, or indolence: (M, K:) you say rajulN fiyhi rasolapN A man in whom is heaviness, &c. (M.) ― -b3- See also risolN, first sentence.
risolapN * : see risolN, in two places.
risaAlN * : see rasolN (of which it is the pl.), near the end of the paragraph: -A2- and see also muraAsilN.

rasuwlN *
i. q. risaAlapN: (S, M, K:) see the latter, in five places. ― -b2- Hence, as meaning *uw rasuwlK, i. e. *uw risaAlapK [One who has a message; i. e. a messenger]; (TA;) i. q. ↓ murosalN, (S, M, K,) meaning one sent with a message; (S;) of the measure faEuwlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN [or rather mufoEalN]: (Msb:) [and often meaning an apostle of God; and with the article Al especially applied to Mohammad:] accord. to IAmb, its meaning in the proper language of the Arabs is one who carries on by consecutive progressions the relation of the tidings of him who has sent him; taken from the phrase jaA='ati AlA_ibilu rasalFA, meaning “ The camels came following one another: ” and the saying of the Muëdhdhin, A^a$ohadu A^an~a muHam~adFA rasuwlu A@ll~`h means I know [or acknowledge] and declare that Mohammad is the relater by consecutive progressions of the tidings from God: (TA:) [or, as commonly understood, I testify that Mohammad is the apostle of God:] a rasuwl is also called ↓ mirosaAlN, as being likened to the arrow thus termed: (TA:) the pl. of rasuwlN is rusulN (S, M, Msb, K) and rusolN (S, Msb) and rusalaA='N, (M, K,) which last is from IAar, (M,) or Fr, (Sgh,) and A^arosulN, (M, K,) which [is a pl. of pauc., and] occurs in the saying of the Hudhalee,
lawokaAna fiY qalobiY kaqadori qulaAmapK
HubFA ligayoriki qado A^ataAhaA A^arosuliY
[Had there been in my heart as much as a nailparing of love for another than thee, my messengers (or, accord. to the TA, app., my messages) had come to her]: respecting which IJ says that he has given to rasuwlN this form of pl., which is [regularly] proper to feminines [of this class of words, consisting of four letter whereof the third is a letter of prolongation], such as A^ataAnN and EanaAqN and EuqaAbN, because women are meant thereby, as they, generally, are the persons required to serve in cases of this kind: (M:) [for] rasuwlN is applied without variation to a male and a female, and to one [and to two] and to a pl. number; (S, M, Msb, K;) sometimes: (M:) i. e., it is allowable thus to apply it: (Msb:) hence, (S, K,) in the Kur [xxvi. 15], (S,) A_in~aA rasuwlu rab~i AlEaAlamiyna [Verily we are the apostles of the Lord of the beings of the whole world]: (S, K:) MF says, in ch. xx. [verse 49], we find A_in~aA rasuwlaA rab~ika [Verily we are the two apostles of thy Lord]; the dual form being here used: and Z says, in the Ksh, that in this instance it means the messengers, and therefore the dual form is necessarily used; but in ch. xxvi. it means the message, and therefore it is allowable to use it alike, when applying it as an epithet, as sing. and dual and pl.: Aboo-Is-hak the Grammarian says that the meaning here is, A_in~aA risaAlapN rab~i AlEaAlamiyna, i. e. *awuw risAlapi [Verily we are those that have the message &c.]: (TA:) [but] rasuwlN [as meaning a messenger] is like Eaduw~N and SadyqN [&c.] in its being used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. [and dual] and pl.: (Sgh, TA:) Aboo-Dhu-eyb uses it in the sense of rusul in his saying,
A^alikoniY A_ilayohaA waxayoru Alr~asuw
li A^aEolamuhumo binawaAHiY Alxabaro
[Be thou my messenger to her: and the best of messengers is the most knowing of them in respect of the bounds, or limits, of the tidings]. (M.) See 4. The saying in the Kur [xxv. 39], waqawoma nuwHK lam~a ka*~abuwA Alr~usula A^agoraqonaAhumo [lit. And the people of Noah, when they charged with lying the apostles, we drowned them], Zj says, may mean that they charged with lying Noah alone; for he who charges with lying a prophet charges therewith all the prophets, since they believe in God and in all his apostles; or the general term may be here used as meaning one; like as when you say, A^anota mim~ano yunofiqu Ald~araAhima, meaning “ Thou art of those who expend the kind of things termed drAhm. ” (M.) ― -b3- One says also, Als~ihaAmu rusulu AlmanaAyaA (tropical:) [Arrows are the messengers of death, or of the decrees of death]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also the next paragraph.

rasiylN *
Easy: occurring in the saying of Jubeyhà El-Asadee,
waqumotu rasiylFA biAl~a*iY jaA='a yabotagiY
A_ilayohi baliyja Alwajohi lasotu bibaAsiri
[And I undertook, or managed, with ease, that which he came seeking to obtain; bright in countenance to him: I was not frowning]. (TA.) -A2- Also A stallion-camel (K, * TA) of the Arabian race, that is sent among the $awol [or she-camels that have passed seven or eight months since the period of their bringing forth] in order that he may leap them: one says, h`*aA rasiylu baniY fulaAnK This is the stallion of the camels of the sons of such a one: and A^arosala banuw fulaAnK rasiylahumo [The sons of such a one sent the stallion of their camels]: as though it were of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufoEalN, from A^arosala. (TA.) ― -b2- And accord. to some, A horse that is started with another in a race. (Har p. 544.) ― -b3- [In the CK and in a MS. copy of the K, voce EamuwdN, it occurs as though meaning The scout, or emissary, or perhaps the advanced guard, of an army: but in other copies of the K, in this instance, accord. to the TA, and in the L, the word is ray^iys.] ― -b4- I. q. ↓ muraAsilN [as meaning one who interchanges messages or letters with another: see 3]. (S, K.) ― -b5- The person who stands with thee (AlmuwaAqifu laka [in the K (in which this explanation is erroneously assigned to ↓ rasuwlN) AlmuwaAfiqu laka in a competition in shooting and the like: (M:) [i. e.] rasiylu Alr~ajuli signifies he who stands with the man, (yaqifu maEahu, Har p. 544,) or he who acts interchangeably, or alternates, with the man, (yuraAsiluhu, S,) in a competition in shooting, or in some other performance. (S and Har.) And, as also ↓ muraAsilN, One who relieves, or aids, another, in singing and in work, [by alternating with him, i. e.,] in the former case, by taking up the strain when the other is unable to continue it [so as to accomplish the cadence (see 6)], and in the latter case by taking up the work when the other is unable to continue it; or one who so relieves, or aids, another in singing with a high voice; i. q. mutaAlK: or one who aids another, [or relieves him, by alternating with him,] or who follows him, or imitates him, in his work. (IAar, Msb.) One says, huwa rasiyluhu fiY AlginaA='i wanaHowihi [He is the person who relieves him, or aids him, by alternating with him, in singing and the like thereof]. (TA.) ― -b6- See also risaAlapN, in two places. -A3- Also Wide, or ample. (K.) ― -b2- A thing little in quantity, or incomplete: Al$~aYo'u All~aTiyfu in the copies of the K should be
Al$~aYo'u AlT~afiyfu, as in the Moheet (TA.) ― -b3- And Sweet water. (K.)
rasaAlapN * : see the next paragraph.

risaAlapN * (S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ rasaAlapN (M, K) and ↓ rasuwlN (S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ rasiylN (Th, M, K) signify the same, (S, M, Msb, K,) A message; and a letter; (MA in explanation of the first, and KL in explanation of the first and third;) [a communication sent from one person or party to another, oral or written;] substs. from A^arosala A_ilayohi: (M, K: *) the pl. of the first is rasaAy^ilu; (Msb;) and A^arosulN is pl. of ↓ rasuwlN in the sense of risaAlapN, and of the fem. gender. (TA. [See the former of the two verses cited voce rasuwlN.]) You say, A^arosalotu fulaAnFA fiY risaAlapK: (S:) and A^arosala A_ilayohi ↓ rasuwlFA: (MA:) see 4. A poet says, (S,) namely El-Ash'ar El-Joafee, (TA,)
↓ A^alaA A^abolgo A^abaA EamorKw rasuwlFA
biA^an~iY Eano futaAHatikumo ganiY~u
[Now deliver thou to Aboo-' Amr a message, saying that I am in no need of your judging]: (S:) or baniY EamorKw [the sons of ' Amr]: he means, Eano Hukomkumo. (TA.) And hence the saying of Kutheiyir,
laqado ka*aba AlwaA$uwna maA buHotu Einodahumo
↓ bisir~K walaA A^arosalotuhumo birasuwli
[Assuredly the slanderers have lied: I revealed not in their presence a secret, nor did I send them with a message]: (S, TA:) or, as some relate the second hemistich, (TA,)
↓ bilayolaY walaA A^arosalotuhumo birasiyli
[i. e. I revealed not the case of Leyla, nor did I send them with a message]: thus cited by Th. (M, TA.) ― -b2- risaAlapN also signifies [A tract, or small treatise or discourse;] a majal~ap [i. e. book, or writing, relating to science, or on any subject.] comprising a few questions, inquiries, or problems, of one kind: pl. rasaAy^ilu. (TA.) ― -b3- And Apostleship; the apostolic office or function.
