(MA.) ― -b4- A^um~u risaAlapa [in a copy of the K A^um~u risaAlapK] The raxamap [or female of the vultur percnopterus, in the CK raHomap]: (M, K, TA:) a surname thereof. (TA.)

Alr~usayolaY *
A certain small beast or reptile or insect; expl. by the word duwayob~apN: (M, K, TA:) in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, Alr~usayolaA='u. (TA.)

rusayolaAtN * dim. of rslAt [i. e. risalaAtN] pl. of risolN [or rather of its syn. risolapN]: hence the saying, (TA,) A^aloqaY AlkalaAma EalaY rusayolaAtihi, i. e. He held the saying, or speech, in light, or little, or mean, estimation; or in contempt. (M, K, TA.)

Alr~aAsilaAni *
The two shoulder-blades: or two veins therein: (M, K:) he who says that they are two veins in the two hands, (K,) pointing to what is found in the copies of the Mj of IF, [in which fiY Alkaf~ayoni is put in the place of fY Alkatifiyoni,] (TA,) is in error: (K:) or the waAbilataAni [q. v., a word variously explained]: (M, TA:) in the copies of the K, Alr~aAbilataAni is erroneously put for AlwaAbilataAni. (TA.)

murosalN * : see rasuwlN, second sentence. ― -b2- Applied to a tradition (HadiyvN), it means (assumed tropical:) Of which the ascription is not traced up so as to reach to its author: (Msb:) [i.e.] AlA^aHaAdiyvu Almurosalapu means the traditions which one relates as on the authority of a taAbiEiY~, (K TA,) by tracing up the ascription thereof uninterruptedly to him, (TA,) when the tAbEY~ says, “ The Apostle of God (May God bless and save him) said, ” without mentioning a SaHaAbiY~ (K, TA) who heard it from the Apostle of God: (TA: [and the like is said in the Mgh:]) maraAsiylu is the [pl. or] quasi-pl. n. of murosalN thus used, [or rather used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] like as manaAkiyru is of munokarN. (Mgh.) ― -b3- In lexicology, it means, like munoqaTiEN, (assumed tropical:) That of which the series of transmitters is interrupted: as a word &c. handed down by IDrd as on the authority of AZ [with whom he was not contemporary, without his mentioning the intermediate transmitters]: and such is not admitted [as unquestionable]; because exactness is a condition of the admission of what is transmitted, and the exactness of him who is not mentioned is not known. (Mz 4th nwE.) ― -b4- majaAzN murosalN: see art. jwz. ― -b5- [See also the next paragraph.]

murosalapN *
A qilaAdap [or necklace], (M,) or a long qlAdp, (IDrd, O, K,) that falls upon the bosom: (IDrd, M, O, K:) or a qlAdp upon which are beads &c. (Yz, O, K.) ― -b2- As used in the Kur [lxxvii. 1], (M,) AlmurosalaAtu means The winds (S, M, K, TA) that are sent forth, [by EurofFA, which follows it, being meant consecutively,] like [the several portions of] the mane of the horse: (TA:) or the angels [so sent forth]: (Th, S, M, K, TA:) or the horses (M, K, TA) that are started, [one following another,] in the racecourse. (TA.)

mirosaAlN * One who sends the morsel [that he eats] into his fauces: or who throws forth the branch from his hand, (O, K,) when he goes in a place of trees, (O,) in order that he may hurt his companion. (O, K.) ― -b2- A short arrow: (S, O:) or a small arrow. (K.) ― -b3- See also rasolN, in three places. ― -b4- And see rasuwlN.

muraAsilN * : see rasolN. -A2- See also rasiylN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A woman who interchanges messages, or letters, with the men who demand women in marriage: or whose husband has become separated from her (M, K, TA) in any manner, (M, TA,) by his having died or his having divorced her: (TA:) or who has become advanced in age, (M, K, TA,) but has in her some remains of youth: (M, TA:) or whose husband has died, or who has perceived that he desires to divorce her, and who therefore adorns herself for another man, and interchanges messages, or letters, with him (S, K, * TA) by means of the men who demand women in marriage, (TA,) and who has in her some remains (K, TA) of youth; but this addition is more properly mentioned in a former explanation. (TA.) The subst. [app. meaning The state, or condition, of a woman such as is thus termed] is ↓ risaAlN. (M, TA.)

musotarosilN * : see rasolN. -A2- musotarosilN lilomawoti i. q. musotamytN and musotaqoitlN [i. e. Seeking, or courting, death or slaughter; resigning, or subjecting, himself to death, and not caring for death]. (A and TA in art. mwt.)

1 rasama Ald~aAra * , (M,) or Ald~iyaAra, (K,) [aor.
rasuma , accord. to a rule of the K,] inf. n. rasomN, (M,) It (the rain) rased the house or dwelling, or the houses or dwellings, leaving a relic, or relics, thereof cleaving to the ground. (M, K.) In the saying of El-Hotei-ah,
A^amino rasomi daArK murobiEN wamuSiyfu
liEayonayoka mino maA='i Al$~uw^uwni wakiyfu
[Is it in consequence of autumn-rain's and springrain's rasing of a dwelling so as to leave only a relic thereof cleaving to the ground, that there is to thine eyes a distilling of the water of the tearchannels?], mrbE and mSyf are in the nom. case because of the inf. n., i.e. rsm. (M, TA. [But in the latter, maSiyfu: and in a copy of the former, marobaEN and maSiyfu, both of which are evidently wrong.]) ― -b2- [rasama often signifies He marked, or stamped: and he drew, traced, traced out, sketched, sketched out, or planned: and he delineated, or described.] You say, rasama AlT~aEaAma He stamped, or sealed, the corn; (TA in art. r$m;) as also ra$amahu. (S, K, TA, all in that art. [See rawosamN.]) And rasamotu AlbinaA='a, aor. and inf. n. as above, I marked out the building. (Msb.) And rasama kitaAbFA walamo yaHo$uhu [He sketched out a book and did not fill it up]. (Mz 1st nwE.) And rasamotu AlkitaAba I wrote the book, or letter, or writing. (Msb.) And rasama EalaY ka*aA He wrote upon such a thing; (S, K;) and ra$ama is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] rasama lahu ka*aA, (S, K, TA,) or bika*aA, (Msb,) (tropical:) [He prescribed to him the doing of such a thing;] he commanded, ordered, bade, or enjoined, him to do such a thing. (S, * Msb, * K, TA.) [And rasama lahu ka*aA also means (assumed tropical:) he assigned, or appointed, him such a thing, as a stipend, &c.: often used in this sense.] ― -b4- rasamato said of a she-camel, (S, M, K,) aor.
rasuma (S, M, [and so accord. to a rule of the K,]) or
rasima , not
rasuma , (TA,) inf. n. rasiymN, (S, M, K,) She made marks upon the ground (S, M, K) by the vehemence of her tread. (S, M.) ― -b5- And rasama said of a camel, aor.
rasima , inf. n. rasiymN, (S, K,) with which mirosamN is syn., (K,) He went a certain pace, (S, K,) exceeding that which is termed *amiyl [inf. n. of *amala, q. v.]: one should not say of a camel A^arosama, for this latter verb is trans. (S.) ― -b6-
Also rasama naHowahu, inf. n. rasomN, He went, or went away, quickly towards him, or it. (TA.) ― -b7- And rasama fiY AlA^aroDi, (K,) inf. n. rasomN, (TA,) He disappeared in the land, or country: (K:) and [hence], used metonymically, (tropical:) he died; like razama. (TA.)

2 tarosiymN * [inf. n. of ras~ama] The act of marking, or stamping, [and of drawing, tracing, tracing out, sketching, sketching out, or planning, several things, or of doing so much, or] well:: and writing [much, or] well: and making a garment, or piece of cloth, striped. (KL.)

4 Arsm *
He caused a she-camel to make marks upon the ground (M, K) by the vehemence of her tread. (M.) ― -b2- And He made a camel to go the pace termed rasiym (S. [The meaning is there indicated, but not expressed.]) faA^arosamaA ending a verse of Homeyd Ibn-Thowr [which is variously related] refers to two boys, or young men, mentioned therein, and means faA^arosamaA baEiyrayohimaA [And they made their two camels to go the pace termed rasiym]. (AHát, TA.)

5 trs~m * , (K, but omitted in some copies,) or trs~m Alr~asoma, (M,) He looked at the rasomi [or mark, trace, relic, &c.]. (M, K.) And trs~m Ald~aAra He considered, or examined, the rusuwm [or marks, traces, relics, &c.,] of the house, or dwelling; (S, TA; *) or did so repeatedly, in order to obtain a clear knowledge thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- And in like manner trs~m signifies He looked, and considered, or examined, or did so repeatedly, in order to know where he should dig, or build. (S, TA.) Hence, taras~amati AlqanaAfi*u fiY AlA^aroDi (tropical:) The hedge-hogs looked, or considered, or examined, repeatedly, to know where they should make their holes. (TA.) And trs~m Al$~aYo'a (assumed tropical:) He looked, or looked long, at the thing; or considered, or examined, it, or did so repeatedly, in order to obtain a clear knowledge of it. (TA.) And trs~m AlqaSiydapa (tropical:) He considered, or studied, the ode, and retained it in his memory, or sought, or endeavoured, to remember it. (K, * TA.) And A^anaA A^ataras~amu ka*aA (assumed tropical:) I remember, or I seek, or endeavour, to remember, such a thing, but am not sure, or certain, of it. (TA.)

8 AirotisaAmN * [in its primary sense, as quasi-pass. of rasomN, inf. n. of rasama, is app. post-classical, but, as such,] is used by the logicians as meaning The being stamped and depicted [in the mind]: (“ Dict. of the Technical Terms used in the sciences of the Musalmans: ”] an image's being fixed in, or upon, a thing. (KL.) [It is used, in this sense, of an image formed by the fancy, and of any ideal image.] -A2- [Also (tropical:) The obeying a prescript or command &c.] You say, rasamotu lahu ka*aA, (S, K,) or bika*aA, (Msb,) faA@rotasama, (Msb, K,) or faA@rotasamahu, (S,) (tropical:) [I prescribed to him the doing of such a thing; or] I commanded, ordered, bade, or enjoined, him to do such a thing, (K, TA,) and he obeyed (S, Msb, TA) it [i. e. the prescript &c.]. (S, Msb.) And ↓ A^anaA A^arotasimu maraAsimaka (tropical:) [I obey thy prescripts &c.;] I do not transgress thy mrAsm. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) Artsm signifies also (tropical:) He said Aall~`hu A^akobaro [God is great, or most great]: (S, M, K, TA:) and he sought protection or preservation [by God]: (M, K, TA;) and he prayed or supplicated or petitioned [God]: (S, K:) as though [meaning] he took the course prescribed by God, of having recourse to Him for protection or preservation. (TA.) El-Aashà says, [speaking of wine,]
waSal~aY EDlaY dan~ihaA waA@rotasamo
waqaAbalahaA AlriyHa fiY dan~ihaA
(S, M, TA,) or waA^aqobalahaA, (so in some copies of the S in this art. and in art. Slw, and in the Mgh, also, in the latter art.,) i. e. [And he exposed it to the wind, in its jar, and he prayed over its jar,] and petitioned for it (TA in this art. and in art. Slw) that it might not become sour, nor spoil: (TA in the latter art.:) AHn says that Artsm means he stamped its vessel with the rawosam; but this saying is not valid: (M, TA:) [and Mtr, also, says that] Artsm, here, is from Alr~awosamu, and means he stamped it. (Mgh in art. Slw.)

rasomN * inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Msb, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence rasomu AlmuSoHafi The writing of the book of the Kur-án; for which particular rules are prescribed. ― -b3- Hence also rasomN is sometimes used by logicians as meaning A definition, either perfect (taAm~N) or imperfect (naAqiSN); like Had~N.] ― -b4- Also A mark, an impression, a sign, a trace, a vestige, or a relic or remain; syn. A^avarN; (S, Msb, K;) and ra$amN is a dial. var. thereof, accord. to Aboo-Turáb; as is also ↓ rasamN, both syn. with A^avarN, (TA in art. r$m,) and so is ra$omN. (K in that art.:) or a relic, or remain, of what is termed A^avarN [as meaning a mark, an impression, a sign, a trace, or a vestige]: or such, of what are termed A=vaAr [as meaning relics or remains], as has not substance and height: (M, K:) or such as is cleaving to the ground: (M:) rasomu daArK means remains of a house or dwelling, cleaving to the ground: (S, TA:) or rasomN signifies a remain, or remains, of a ruined dwelling or place of alighting and abiding: (Har p. 607:) and ↓ rawosamN is syn. with rasomN: (S, M, K [accord. to the correct copies of this last:]) the pl. [of pauc.] of rasomN is A^arosumN and [the pl. of mult. is] rusuwmN. (M, Msb, K.) ― -b5- [I. q. marosuwmN: see maraAsimu. And hence, as being prescribed,] rusuwmu Ald~iyni means (assumed tropical:) The ways that are followed in respect of the doctrines and practices of religion. (TA.) ― -b6- And A well which one fills up (M, K) in the ground: (K:) pl. risaAmN. (M, K.) ― -b7- [In some copies of the K, two meanings that belong to rawosamN are, by the omission of a w, assigned to rasomN: see rawosamN.]
rasamN * : see the next preceding paragraph. -A2- Also Goodness, or elegance, of gait, pace, or manner of going. (K.)

rasuwmN *
That makes marks upon the ground by the vehemence of her tread: applied to a she-camel. (S TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. jhm.] ― -b2- Also That continues journeying a day and a night: (S, K:) applied to a he-camel. (TK.)

rasiymN *
A certain pace of camels, (S, K,) exceeding that which is termed *amiylN [q. v.]; (S;) [see rasama, of which it is an inf. n.;] and ↓ mirosamN signifies the same. (K.)

ras~aAmN *
One who engraves [or draws inscriptions or other designs] upon tablets or the like. (TA.)
raAsimN * , (S, K,) or maA='N raAsimN, (TK,) Running water. (S, K.) ― -b2- And raAsimapN A she-camel that goes the pace termed rasiym: pl. rawaAsimu. (Har p. 495.)

rawosamN * : see rasomN. ― -b2- Also A sign, a token, a mark, or an indication, (M, K,) of beauty or of ugliness; as in the saying, A_in~a Ealyohi larawosamFA [Verily upon him is a sign, &c.]: so says Khálid Ibn-Jebeleh: (M:) pl. rawaAsimu and rawaAsiymu. (TA.) ― -b3- And as pl. of rawosamu, (TA,) rawaAisymu signifies Certain books, or writings, that were in the Time of Ignorance. (S, K.) ― -b4- Also the sing., A stamp, or seal; i. e. an instrument with which one stamps, or seals; and rawo$amN is a dial. var. thereof: (M:) or, as some say, particularly, (M,) one with which the head [or mouth] of a [large jar such as is called] xaAbiyap is stamped, or sealed; (M, K;) as also ↓ raAsuwmN, (K,) and raA$uwmN. (TA.) And A piece of wood, (S, M, Msb, K,) or a small tablet, (A,) upon which is some inscription (S, M, A, K) engraved, or hollowed out, (A, K,) with which wheat, (S, M, K,) or corn, or grain, (Msb,) [in its repository,] is stamped, or sealed, (S, M, Msb, K,) or with which collections of wheat or corn are stamped, or sealed: (AA, TA:) as also rawo$amN: pl. rawaAsimu. (Msb.) [In some copies of the K, by the omission of a w, this meaning and the next are assigned to rasomN.] ― -b5- And (as some say, S) A certain thing with which deenárs are polished. (S, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Kutheiyir, (TA,)
danaAniyru $iyfato mino hiraqolK birawosami
[Deenárs, of Heraclius, that were polished with rwsm]. (S, TA.) -A2- It occurs in poetry as meaning The face of a horse, in the phrase quroHapN birawosamK [A star, or blaze, in the face of a horse]. (M.) -A3- Also A calamity, or misfortune; (K;) like rawosabN. (TA.)
raAsuwmN * : see the next preceding paragraph. [Accord. to rule, its pl. is rawaAsiymu, mentioned above as a pl. of rawosamN.]

murosimN * [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. In the saying of the Hudhalee,
waA@lomurosimuwna A_ilaY Eabodi AlEaziyzi bihaA
maEFA wa$at~aY wamino $afoEK wafur~aAdi
[And those urging them to make marks upon the ground by the vehemence of their tread in their way to 'Abd-El-'Azeez, together and separately, and two by two and one by one], he means AlmurosimuwhaA, inserting the b redundantly between the verb [or part. n., which is often termed a verb,] and its objective complement. (M.)
mirosamN * : see rasiymN.
muras~amN * A garment, or piece of cloth, striped, (S, M, K,) or marked with faint lines. (TA.)

marosuwmN * [or kitaAbN marosuwmN] A book, or writing, stamped, or sealed: pl. maraAsiymu. (TA.) And TaEaAmN marosuwmN Wheat stamped, or sealed. (TA. [See rawosamN.]) ― -b2- See also the following paragraph.

maraAsimu *
Marks, stamps, impressions, signs, or characters. (KL.) ― -b2- [And (assumed tropical:) Prescripts, commands, orders, biddings, or injunctions: and (assumed tropical:) assignments, or appointments: in both of these senses app. a contraction of maraAsiymu, pl. of ↓ marosuwmN; thus used in the present day; like rusuwmN, pl. of ↓rasomN.] See 8.

1 rasana Alfarasa * (S,) or Ald~aAb~apa, (M, Msb, *) and Aln~aAqaha, (M, K, *) aor.
rasuna and
rasina , (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. rasonN; (M, Msb;) and ↓ Arsn; (S, M, Msb, K;) He tied the horse [or the beast and the she-camel] with the rasan [q: v.]: (S:) or he bound upon the [horse or] beast [or she-camel] its rasan: (Msb:) or he made for, or put to, the [horse or] beast or she-camel a rasan: (M, * K: [in the former it is merely indicated that the two verbs signify the same:]) or the former verb [in the CK the latter verb] has the first signification; (M, K, TA;) and the latter verb has the last signification; (M, TA;) thus resembling Hazama and A^aHozama. (TA.) ― -b2- And rasana Ald~aAb~apa, and ↓ ArsnhA, He left the beast to itself, to pasture as it pleased. (TA.)
4 A^arosana see above, in two places. -A2- Also Arsn Almuhoru The colt was, or became, submissive, manageable, or tractable, and gave its head. (TA.)

rasanN *
A rope, or cord: (S, M, Msb, K:) or [a halter; i. e.] a rope, or cord, with which a camel [or a horse (see 1)] is led: (TA:) and such of the [reins, or leading-ropes, termed] A^azim~ap [pl. of zimaAmN] as is upon the nose; (M;) [in other words,] such a zimaAm as is upon a nose: (K:) pl. A^irosaAnN (S, M, Msb, K) and A^arosunN, (M, Msb, K,) [both properly pls. of pauc.,] and sometimes they said rusunN; (Msb;) or, accord. to Sb, it has no other pl. than A^arosaAnN; (M, Msb;) [but perhaps he meant of pauc., for SM says,] Sb disallowed A^arosunN. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Ibn-Mukbil, (TA,)
hariytN qaSiyru Ei*aAri Alil~jaAmi
A^asiylN Tawiylu Ei*aAri Alr~as~no
[Wide-mouthed, short in the cheek-straps of the bridle (or headstall): smooth and long in the cheek, long in the appertenance of the halter corresponding to the cheek-straps of the bridle or headstall; because this appertenance is longer than are the cheek-straps of the bridle or headstall]. (S, TA.) m~r~a AlS~aEaAliyki biA^arosaAni Alxayoli [As the passing along of the robbers with the halters of the horses] is a prov., applied to an affair, or event, that is quick and uninterrupted. (TA.) And one says, ramaY birasanihi EalaY gaAribihi [He threw his leading-rope upon his withers], meaning (assumed tropical:) he left his way free, or open, to him; so that God did not withhold him from that which he desired to do. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rasanu AlbaAziY [The leash of the hawk]. (A in art. rwd.) -A2- [The pl.] A^arosaAnN also signifies Rugged and hard tracts of ground. (K, * TA.)

raAsanN *
A certain plant, resembling the plant called zanojabiyl [i. e. ginger]; (M;) i. q. qanasN; [both of which names are applied to the inula helenium, common inula, or elecampane; also called in the present day zanojabiylN $aAmiY~N;] a Pers. word [arabicized]. (K.)

marosinN * (S, M, K) and marosanN, (M, K,) or the latter should be mirosanN, [but I think this doubtful,] thus written in some of the copies of the S, and in both ways in the L, (TA,) The part, of the nose of the horse, which is the place of the rasan: (S:) or the nose of a solid-hoofed animal: this is the primary signification: (M:) then, by a secondary application, (S, M,) the nose (S, M, K) in an absolute sense, (M, K,) or, of a human being: (S:) pl. maraAsinu (TA) [which, as stated by Freytag, is used in a sing. sense, in the Deewán of Jereer, as meaning the nose]. salisu Almarosini, a phrase used by the poet El-Jaadee, means (assumed tropical:) Easy to be led, tractable, or compliant. (TA.) And you say, faEalotu *`lika EalaY ragomi marosinihi (assumed tropical:) [I did that against his wish; in spite of him; or notwithstanding his dislike, or disapproval, or hatred; like as you say, EalaY ragomi A^anofihi]. (S.)

marosuwnN * A horse [or the like] tied with the rsn: (S:) [or having a rasan bound upon him or attached to him, or made for him: see 1.] You say, A^ajorarotu Almarosuwna rasanahu I made the haltered beast to drag his halter. (TA.)
Almarosiynu * [The myrtle-tree;] i. q. rayoHaAnu Alqubuwri: of the dial. of Egypt. (TA.) [Also mentioned in art. mrs: for some hold the m to be augmentative; and some, the n.]

1 rasaA * , (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yarosuw, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rusuw~N (M, Msb, K) and rasowN, (K,) It (a thing, S, M, Msb) was, or became, stationary, at rest, fixed, fast, firm, steady, steadfast, or stable; (S, M, Msb, K) as also ↓ ArsY, (M, K,) inf. n. A_irosaA='N; and ↓ trs~Y. (TA.) Alrsw and Alrswx [i. e. Alr~usuw~u and Alr~usuwxu] are nearly the same [in meaning]. (Ham p. 51.) You say, rasaA Aljabalu (assumed tropical:) The mountain was firmly based, or firm in its base, upon the ground. (TA.) And vabiyrN ↓ maA A^arosaY (tropical:) As long as Thebeer [the mountain so called] remains [firm] in its place. (TA.) [Its being said that this is tropical is app. meant to indicate that the verbs above are properly used only in relation to a ship, in senses explained in what follows; which, however, I doubt.] You say also, rasato qadamuhu, meaning His foot stood firm in war: (M:) or rasato A^aqodaAmuhumo fiY AlHarobi Their feet stood firm in war. (S, Msb. *) And rasati Als~afiynapu, (S, M, K,) aor. tarosuw, inf. n. rusuw~N and rasowN (S) [and marosFY, as shown below, see 4], The ship [anchored; cast anchor; lay at anchor; or] rested, or became stationary, upon the anchor: (T, S, K:) in [some of] the copies of the K [and of the S], EalaY AlbaHori is erroneously put for ElY AlA^anojari [or ElY All~anojari]: (TA:) or the meaning is, [in some instances, the ship grounded; i. e.] the lower, or lowest, part of the ship reached the bottom of the water, and she consequently remained stationary. (T, M, TA.) ― -b2- rasaA AlfaHolu bi$awolihi (S, M, K,) (tropical:) The stallion [-camel] leaped, or leaped upon, his $wl [or she-camels that had passed seven or eight months since the period of their bringing forth]: (S, TA:) or brayed to his $wl, and they became motionless, or still: (M:) or brayed to his $wl when they had dispersed themselves from him, and they turned aside to him, and became motionless, or still. (K, TA.) ― -b3- rasawotu bayona Alqawomi, (S, M, * Msb,) inf. n. rasowN, (S, M,) I effected an agreement, a harmony, a reconciliation, an accommodation, or an adjustment, between the people, or party. (S, M, * Msb.) -A2- rasaA lahu rasowFA mino HadiyvK (S, * M, K *) He mentioned to him a part, or portion, of a tradition, or story. (S, M, * K. [See also rasowN below.]) And rasaA Eanohu HadiyvFA, (S, M, K,) inf. n. rasowN, (M,) He related a tradition, or story, as received from him, (S, M, K,) ascribing it to him. (M, K.) And rasaA AlHadiyva fiY nafosihi He related the tradition, or story, to himself. (TA.) ― -b2- rasaA AlS~awoma, (K,) inf. n. rasowN, (TA,) He intended, or purposed, fasting. (K.)
3 rAsAhu * , (T, K,) inf. n. muraAsaApN, (TA,) i. q. saAbaHahu, (T, K,) i. e. He swam with him. (TK.)

4 ArsY * , inf. n. A_irosaA='N: see 1, in two places. -A2- ArsAhu He made it (a thing, M, Msb) to become stationary, at rest, fixed, fast, firm, steady, steadfast, or stable. (M, Msb, K.) And ArsY Als~afiynapa, [inf. n. as above and also (as is shown by what follows) murosFY, He anchored the ship;] he made the ship to rest, or become stationary, upon the anchor: (TA:) or the meaning is, [in some instances, he grounded the ship; i. e.] he made the lower, or lowest, part of the ship to reach the bottom of the water, so that she remained stationary. (M, TA.) You say also of a ship, turosaY baAlA^anojari [She is made fast by means of the anchor]: (M:) and of the anchor, yurosiY Als~afiynapa It makes fast the ship, so that it does not go on. (T, TA.) For the words of the Kur [xi. 43], bisomi A@ll~`hi mujoraAhaA wamurosaAhaA, (S, M, * K, *) meaning A_ijoraAw^uhaA waA_irosaAw^uhaA [i. e. In the name of God be the making it to run and the making it to rest], (Aboo-Is-hák, TA,) from A^ajorayotu and A^arosayotu, (so in one copy of the S,) or [its being made to run and its being made to rest,] from A^ujoriyato and A^urosiyoto, (so in another copy of the S,) some say majoraAhaA wamarosaAhaA, (S, K,) meaning its running and its resting, (Aboo-Is-hák, TA,) from jarato and rasato, (S, K,) [though] Az says that the readers agree in pronouncing the m of mrsAhA with damm, but differ as to the m of mjrAhA, the Koofees pro-
nouncing this with fet-h, (TA,) or the latter reading may have the same meaning as the former, (Aboo-Is-hák, TA,) or the former reading may mean in the time, or the place, of making it to run, and that of making it to rest, and the latter reading may mean in the time, or the place, of its running, and that of its resting, for in each case each noun may be a n. of time or a n. of place or an inf. n.; (Bd, q. v.;) and some read mujoriyhaA ↓ wamurosiyhaA, as epithets applied to God, (M, K,) who maketh it to run and who maketh it to rest. (TA.) Accord. to Zj, (M,) yasoA^aluwnaka Eani A@ls~aAEapi A^ay~aAna murosaAhaA, in the Kur [vii. 186 and lxxix. 42], means [They will ask thee respecting the sAEp,] when will be its taking place? [or when will be the time of its being made to take place?]; (M, K; *) by the sAEp being meant the time in which all created beings shall die. (M.)
5 taras~awa see 1, first sentence.

rasowN *
A part, or portion, of a tradition, or story: (Lth, T, K:) [see an ex. near the end of the first paragraph:] accord. to IAar, i. q. ras~N [app. as meaning the first part or portion]. (T.)

rasowapN *
A [bracelet, or one of a particular kind, called] dasotibnaj; (IAar, T, M, K;) so accord. to Kr: (M, TA: but in a copy of the M written dasotabanoj:) a certain thing of strung beads; (S, TA;) like the dstynj; which is an arabicized word [from the Pers. dasotiynaho]: (TA:) a bracelet of beads: (ISK, TA:) or a bracelet of *abol [i. e. turtle-shell, or tortoise-shell]: pl. rasawaAtN: it has no broken pl. (M, TA. [Golius and Freytag say that its pl. is risFY; but on what authority, I know not: the former mentions no authority beside the S and K; and the latter, none but the K.])

rasiY~N *
Firm, or steadfast, in good and in evil. (Az, Sgh, K.) ― -b2- And The pole that is fixed in the middle of the [tent called] xibaA='. (Az, Sgh, K.)

raAsK *
Stationary, at rest, fixed, fast, firm, steady, steadfast, or stable. (Msb.) You say jibaAlN raAsiyapN (Msb) and raAsiyAatN and rawaAsK (S, Msb) Firm, or steadfast, mountains; (S, Msb;) the sing. of the last said by Akh to be raAsiyapN. (S.) And qidorN raAsiyapN (tropical:) A cooking-pot that will not move from its place, (M, K, TA,) by reason of its greatness, (K, TA,) and that cannot be removed. (M.) quduwr raAsiyaAt in the Kur [xxxiv. 12] means, accord. to Fr, (tropical:) Cooking-pots that would not be lowered from their place, by reason of their greatness. (TA.)

marosFY * may be used as an inf. n., or a n. of time, or a n. of place. (Bd in xi. 43 [cited above: see 4].) [As a n. of place, it commonly means An anchorage, or a place of anchoring; a port; or a station for ships: pl. maraAsK.]
murosFY * may be used as an inf. n., or a n. of time, or a n. of place. (Bd in xi. 43 [cited above: see 4].)
murosK * , as an epithet applied to God: see 4, near the end of the paragraph.

mirosaApN * , The anchor of a ship: (S, M, K:) or a large anchor, which, being tied with ropes and let down into the water, holds fast the ship, so that she does not go on: (T, TA:) pl. maraAsK. (Har p. 111.) [Hence,] one says, A^aloqawoA maraAsiyahumo, meaning (assumed tropical:) They remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode. (TA.) And A^aloqati Als~aHaAbapu maraAsiyahaA (tropical:) The cloud rained continually; syn. daAmat: (S, Msb:) or remained steady, raining: (T, TA:) or remained still, or stationary, and rained. (M, K: * in the latter, Als~aHaAbu is put in the place of AlsHAbp.)

1 ra$~a * , (A, Msb,) aor.
ra$u3a , (MS,) inf. n. ra$~N (S, A, Msb, K) and taro$aA$N, (A, K,) He sprinkled, or scattered in drops, (A, K, TK,) water, (S, A, Msb, K,) and blood, (S, A, K,) and tears, (S, K,) &c. (A.) ― -b2- ra$~a AlmakaAna, (S, TA,) or AlmawoDiEa, (Msb,) and Albayota, (A,) inf. n. ra$~N, (S, TA,) He sprinkled, or wetted by sprinkling, (TA,) the place, (S, Msb, TA,) and the house, or chamber, or tent, (A,) bimaA'K with water. (Msb, TA.) And ra$~a AlHaAy^iku Aln~asiyja biAlomira$~api [The weaver sprinkled the web with the mr$~p]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] ra$~ati Als~amaA='u, and ↓ A^ara$~at, (S, A, Msb, K,) The shy rained: (A, Msb:) or let fall a little rain, such as is termed ra$~N. (S. [After the former of these verbs, AlA^aroDa, or the like, seems to be understood.]) [And hence,] AlT~aEonapu ↓ A^ara$~ati [The spear-wound, or the like, sprinkled forth blood: a signification implied, but not expressed, in the S and A: or] became wide, so that its blood became scattered about: (K:) or passed through, and made the blood to flow, or to appear and flow, or to flow copiously, or with force. (Msb.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] ra$~ahu bivaA=' K HasanK (assumed tropical:) He eulogized him. (TA voce xam~a.) ― -b5- And ra$~ahu He washed him, or it. (MF, from the Expositions of the “ Muwatta. ”)
2 ra$~a3a [r$~$ Alqalamu AlHibora The pen spirtled the ink.]
4 A^aro$a3a see 1, in two places. -A2- Ar$~ Alfarasa, (A, K,) inf. n. A_iro$aA$N, (A,) He made the horse to sweat by urging him with his feet. (A, K.)

5 tr$~$ Ealayohi AlmaA='u * , (S,) and Elyh ↓ tara$ora$a, (A,) [The water became sprinkled, or scattered in drops, upon him or it.] And tr$~$t nuqoTapN mina Alqalami [A drop of ink became spirtled from the pen]. (S and K in art. mj)
R. Q. 2 tara$ora$a * : see 5. ― -b2- Also It (roasted meat) dripped with gravy; or was succulent, and dripping with juice; or was fat. (TA.) ― -b3- And It flowed. (TA.)

ra$~N * , (S, K,) or ra$~N mino maTarK, (A, TA,) A little [sprinkling] rain: (S, K:) [and so ↓ ra$~apN in the present day:] or the first [or lightest and weakest] of rain: (IAar: [see rak~N:] pl. ri$aA$N. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also the former, (assumed tropical:) A painful beating. (Sgh, K.)
ra$~apN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

ra$aA$N *
What is sprinkled, (S, A, * K,) or scattered, (Msb,) of water, (A, Msb,) and the like, (Msb,) or of blood, (S, A, K,) and of tears, (S, K,) and the like, (K,) and of rain; (TA in art. T$;) what is scattered, or flies about, of blood. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] lamo yadoxulo fiY Al$~ar~i waA^aSaAbahu mino ra$aA$ihi (tropical:) [He did not enter into evil, or mischief, and yet somewhat thereof, or of its effects, befell him]. (A, TA.) And A^alaH~a binaA AlEuTaA$u wamaA naAlanaA minoka A_il~aA Alr~a$aA$u [app. meaning Insatiable thirst, or desire, to hear from thee, or the like, remained in us, and there did not reach us from thee aught save a mere sprinkling; or perhaps, what was scattered abroad, of rumours, or the like]. (A, TA. *) [See also an ex. voce ra*aA*N.]
ra$iy$N * : see maro$uw$N.
ra$oraA$N * Roasted meat (Aboo-Sa'eed, A, K) dripping with its gravy; (Aboo-Sa'eed, A, TA;) or succulent, and dripping with its juice; (TA;) or fat: (K:) and ↓ muri$~N signifies the same. (TA.)
muri$~N * : see what next precedes.

mira$~apN *
A thing with which one sprinkles: (Ibn- 'Abbád:) a thing with which the weaver sprinkles the web: (A, TA:) [in the present day, applied to a long-necked bottle, with a stopper pierced with a hole or holes, for sprinkling scented water.]

maro$uw$N * [Sprinkled, or scattered in drops; as also ↓ ra$iy$N, occurring in this sense in a verse in the TA in art. xft]. ― -b2- maHal~N maro$uw$N [A place of alighting sprinkled, or wetted by sprinkling]. (A.) ― -b3- A^aroDN maro$uw$apN Land upon which [rain such as is called] Alr~a$~ has fallen. (TA.)

1 ra$aA^a *
i. q. jaAmaEa [Inivit feminam]. (K.) -A2- ra$aA^ato She (a gazelle) brought forth. (K.)

ra$aA^N *
A young gazelle, (S, Msb, K,) that has become active, or in motion, (S, Msb,) or that has become strong, (K,) and has walked (S, Msb, K) with its mother: (K:) pl. A^aro$aA='N. (Msb, K.) [In the following saying, I find it written as though with medd; app. for the sake of assimilation to Aln~isaA=':] EinodiY jaAriyapN mina Aln~isaA='i A^a$obahu $aYo'K biAlr~a$aA='i, meaning [I have with me a young woman most like to] the [young] gazelle: so in the A. (TA.)

1 ra$aHa * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
ra$aHa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. ra$oHN, (S, Msb,) He, or it, (the forehead, or the side thereof above the temple, A, TA, or the body, Msb,) sweated; exuded sweat; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Ar$H, (K,) or Ar$H EaraqoA, and EaraqFA ↓ tr$~H. (Fr, TA.) And ra$iHa, aor.
ra$aHa , inf. n. ra$aHN and ra$aHaAnN, He, or it, was, or became,
moist with sweat. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ra$aHati Alqirobapu biAlmaA='i (tropical:) [The water-skin sweated with the water]: and ra$aHa bimaA fiyhi (tropical:) [It sweated with what was in it] is said of a [porous] mug, and of any [porous] vessel. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] lamo yaro$aHo lahu bi$aYo'K (assumed tropical:) He gave him not anything. (S, K.) And ra$aHa jalomaduhu, said of one known to be a niggard, (assumed tropical:) He gave something. (Har p. 95.) ― -b4- ra$aHa is also said of a young gazelle, meaning (tropical:) He walked, being trained, or accustomed, to do so by his mother: [because the training him to walk causes him to sweat: see 2: and see also 5.] (A.) Also, said of a gazelle, (assumed tropical:) He leaped, or bounded, and exulted [or was brisk or lively or sprightly]. (K.) Also, inf. n. ru$awHN, said of a young weaned camel, (assumed tropical:) He became strong: [see, again, 5:] and the inf. n. is metaphorically used in relation to small clouds [app. when they collect together to give rain]. (L.) -A2- See also 2, as said of a she-camel.

2 ra$~aHa [r$~H app. He, or it, caused to sweat: this seems to be the primary signification, whence the other significations here following.] ― -b2- ra$~aHato waladahaA, inf. n. taro$iyHN, (tropical:) She (a gazelle) trained, or accustomed, her young one to walk, so that he was caused to sweat (fayura$~aHu [perhaps a mistranscription for fayaro$aHu so that he sweated]): (A, TA:) or she (a wild animal), when her young one became able to walk, walked with him, until, or so that, he was caused to sweat (Hat~aY yura$~aHa EaraqFA), and became strong. (Mtr, on the authority of Kh, in De Sacy's “ Chrest, Ar., ” sec. ed., iii. 231.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) She (a camel) rubbed the root of her young one's tail, and pushed him on with her head; and went before him, and waited for him until he overtook her; and sometimes gently urged him on, and followed him; as also ↓ ra$aHatohu and ↓ Ar$Hthu. (L.) ― -b4- ra$~aHato waladahaA biAll~abani Alqaliyl, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) She (a mother) fed her child with a little milk, putting it into his mouth by little and little, until he became strong enough to such. (S, TA.) ― -b5- taro$yHN also signifies (tropical:) A doegazelle's licking her young one so as to remove the moisture that was upon it at the time of its birth; (K, TA;) and so ↓ tara$~uHN. (TA.) ― -b6- r$~H Aln~baAta, (A, TA,) or Aln~abota, inf. n. as above, (Msb,) (tropical:) It (the moisture, or dew, A, Msb, TA, or the rain, TA) fostered the herbage. (Msb, TA.) ― -b7- r$~H waladahu (assumed tropical:) He fed his child well. (Mtr, on the authority of Kh, in De Sacy's “ Chrest. Ar ” ubi suprà.) ― -b8- And ru$~iHa, (S, A, K,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) (tropical:) He was reared, brought up, or educated, and rendered fit, (S, A, K, TA,) and prepared, (TA,) lil$~aYo'i [for the thing], and liA^amori [for the affair], (TA,) or lilowizArapi [for the office of wezeer], (S,) or lilomuloki [for the office of king], (K,) or liloxilaAfapi [for the office of khaleefeh]; from ra$~aHato waladahaA in the sense expl. in the second sentence of this paragraph; (A;) or ru$~iHa liloxilaAfapi means (tropical:) he was made the appointed successor of the khaleefeh: (TA:) and fulaAnu lika*aA ↓ A^uro$iHa and ↓ tara$~aHa (tropical:) [Such a one was reared, &c., for such a thing]. (A, TA.) ― -b9- And ra$~aHa maAlahu, (A,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) He managed, or tended, or took care of, his property, or cattle, well. (A, K.) It is said in a trad., yura$~iHuwna HaSiydahaA, meaning (tropical:) They tend [the place of seed-produce thereof], and put it into a good, or right, state, or make it to thrive, in order to its becoming productive; like as is done to grape-vines and palm-trees. (TA.)

4 Ar$H * , intrans.: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- A^aro$aHato (assumed tropical:) She (a camel, and a woman,) had a young one that associated, or kept company, with her, walking with her and behind her, and not fatiguing her: or had a young one that had become strong. (L.) -A2- Ar$Ht waladahaA, said of a camel: ― -b2- and A^uro$iHa fulaAnN lika*aA: see 2.

5 tr$~H * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) He (a young weaned camel) was, or became, strong enough to walk, or able to walk with strength: (S, K:) or became strong, and walked with his mother. (As, S.) [See 1.] ― -b3- See also 2, in the middle of the paragraph. ― -b4- tr$~H Aln~abotu [or Aln~abaAtu] (assumed tropical:) The herbage became fostered by moisture or dew. (Msb.) ― -b5- tr$~H fulaAnN lika*aA: see 2, near the end of the paragraph.

10 Astr$H AlbuhomaY * (assumed tropical:) The [barley-grass termed] buhomaY grew tall. (K.) -A2- yasotaro$iHuwna AlbuhomaY, so in most of the copies of the K, (TA,) [and so in the L,] (assumed tropical:) They foster the bhmY, in order that it may grow large: (L, K:) in some of the copies of the K Albahoma [i. e. the lambs, or kids, &c.]: (TA:) the place thereof is termed ↓ musotaro$aHN: (K:) or AlbuhumaY ↓ musotaro$aHu signifies the place, or tract of ground, that fosters the bhmY. (L.) And ystr$Hwn Albaqola, so in all the copies of the K but some in which is found Aln~afala, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) They wait for the herbs, or leguminous plants, (or the plants called nfl,) to grow tall, in order that-they may pasture thereon. (K.)
ra$aHN * The moisture of sweat upon the body. (A, * TA.) [And (assumed tropical:) Fluid, or matter, exuded: see zabaAdN.]

ra$iHN *
That sweats much. (TA.)

ra$oHapN * [as an inf. n. of un., A sweat, or a sweating: a meaning indicated, though not expressed, in the A. ― -b2- Hence, app., (assumed tropical:) A dew, or fall of dew from the sky. ― -b3- And hence, as being likened thereto, (tropical:) A gift]. You say, A^aSaAbaniY bira$oHapK mino samaAy^ihi (tropical:) [He gave me a gift from his store of bounty]. (A.)
biy^orN ra$uwHN * (assumed tropical:) A well containing little water: (TA:) [pl. ru$uHN.]

ra$iyHN *
Sweat. (AA, S, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A certain plant: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) plants, or herbage, upon the surface of the ground. (L.)
niHoYN ra$~aAHN * (assumed tropical:) A butter-skin that sweats much. (A in art. ntH.)

raA$iHN *
Sweating; exuding sweat. (A, * Msb.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A mountain moist in the lower part, (K, TA,) and at the base of which there sometimes collects a little water: when this is much [in comparison with what thus collects, though still little abstractedly], it is termed wa$alN: (TA:) pl. rawaA$Hu. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) What one sees, like sweat, running in the interstices between stones. (K, * TA.) You say, kamo bayona AlfuraAti AlT~aAfiHi waAlwa$ali Alr~aA$iHi (tropical:) [How great a difference is there between the overflowing Euphrates and a little water that distils scantily in interrupted drops from a rock or mountain, appearing, like sweat, running in the interstices between stones!]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- The pl. rawaA$iHu also signifies (assumed tropical:) The vuEol [which means a small teat in excess], (K,) or the A^aTobaA=' [or teats], (TA,) of a ewe or she-goat, particularly. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And the sing., (tropical:) A young gazelle that walks, being trained, or accustomed, to do so by his mother, so that he is caused to sweat. (A.) And (assumed tropical:) A young weaned camel that has become strong enough to walk, or able to walk with strength: (S, K:) or that has become strong, (As, S, L,) and walks with his mother: (As, S:) pl. ru$~aHN. (L.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) What creeps upon the earth, of such as are termed its xi$aA$ and its A^aHonaA$. (K, TA.) ― -b7- See also muro$iHN.

A^aro$aHu * [More, and most, sweating]. ― -b2- [Hence,] huwa A^aro$aHu fuw^aAdFA (tropical:) He is most largely endowed with sharpness, or acuteness, of mind, or with quickness of intelligence, understanding, sagacity, skill, or knowledge: (K, TA:) as though sweating therewith. (TA.)

muro$iHN * , (S, L, K,) or ↓ mura$~iHN, (so in one of my copies of the K,) (assumed tropical:) A she-camel having a young one that has become strong enough to walk, or able to walk with strength: (S, K:) or having a young one that has become strong, and that walks with her: (As, S:) or having a young one that associates, or keeps company, with her, walking with her and behind her, and not fatiguing her: or having a young one that has become strong: and in like manner a woman: or each signifies, as also ↓ raA$iHN, applied to a she-camel, as a possessive epithet, having a young one of which she rubs the root of his tail, pushing him on with her head; and before which she goes, and waits for him to overtake her; and which she sometimes gently urges on, and follows. (L.)

miro$aHN * and ↓ miro$aHapN The inner covering that is beneath the felt cloth of a horse's saddle; so called because it imbibes the sweat: (L:) or the thing that is beneath the miyvarap [q. v. in art. wvr]. (S, L, K.)
miro$aHapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
mura$~iHN * : see muro$iHN.
musotaro$aHN * : see 10, in two places.

1 ra$ada * , aor.
ra$uda ; and ra$ida, aor.
ra$ada ; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) the former of which is the better known and the more chaste; (TA;) inf. n. ru$odN, (S, L, Msb, K,) which is of the former, (S, L,) and ra$adN, (S, L, Msb, K,) which is of the latter, (S, L, Msb,) and ra$aAdN, (L, K,) which is also of the latter verb, (TA,) or this last is a simple subst.; (Msb;) He took, or followed, a right way or course or direction; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) as to a road, and also as to an affair: (L:) [and often relating to religion; meaning he held a right belief; was orthodox:] and ↓ Astr$d signifies the same: (L, K:) you say, Astr$d liA^amorihi, meaning He took, or followed, a right way to conduct his affair: and ra$ada A^amorahu, meaning He took, or followed, a right course in his affair; this latter being a phrase similar to A^alima baTonahu and safiha raA^oyahu &c. (L.) Some say that ra$odN relates to the things of the present life and to those of the life to come; and ra$adN, only to those of the life to come: but this distinction does not accord with what has been heard from the Arabs, nor with readings of the Kur-án, in which some read ru$od and others ra$ad in several verses. (MF.) The former also signifies The continuing in the way of truth, or the right way, with self-constraining firmness in so doing. (K.) One says to the traveller, ra$idota [Mayest thou take, or follow, the right way]. (A.) ― -b2- [See also ru$odN below.]

2 r$~dhu * , inf. n. taro$iydN, said of a kádee, or judge, i. q. jaEalahu ra$iydFA [meaning He pronounced him to be one who took, or followed, a right way or course or direction: or to be one who held a right belief; to be orthodox]. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

4 Ar$dhu * (S, A, L, Msb, K) and ↓ r$~dhu, (L,) said of God, (S, L, K,) and of a governor, or commander, (L,) [or of any man,] He made him, or caused him, to take, or follow, a right way or course or direction; or he directed him aright, or to the right way or course or direction; (S, * A, * L, Msb, * K; *) A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i and Ealayohi and lahu [to the thing]: so says AZ: (Msb:) [often relating to religion; meaning he made him, or caused him, to hold a right belief; to become orthodox.] See also the next paragraph.

10 Astr$d * : see 1. ― -b2- Also He sought, or desired, the taking, or following, a right way or course or direction. (So accord. to some copies of the K.) ― -b3- And Astr$dhu He desired of him the taking, or following, a right way or course or direction: (L, and so accord. to some copies of the K, and the TA:) or he asked, demanded, or desired, of him, direction to the right way. (MA.) You say, ↓ Aisotaro$adotuhu faA^aro$adaniY [I asked, demanded, or desired, of him, direction to the right way, and he directed me to the right way] (A, Msb) A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i and Ealayohi and lahu [to the thing]: so says AZ. (Msb.)

ru$odN * an inf. n. of 1. (S, L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [As a simple subst., Rectitude.] Also Maturity of in- tellect, and rectitude of actions, and good management of affairs. (TA in art. Ans: see 4 in that art.) [Hence, balaga ru$odahu He attained to years of discretion, when he was able of himself to take, or follow, a right way or course: a phrase of frequent occurrence.]
ra$odapN * : see the next paragraph, in four places.

ri$odapN *
A mode, or manner, [and ↓ ra$odapN an act,] of ra$aAd [or right procedure; &c.]. (Ham p. 463.) [Hence,] huwa liri$odapK, (S, A, L, Msb,) and wulida liri$odapK, (L, K,) and ↓ lira$odapK, (L, Msb, K,) the latter accord. to AZ and Fr, and said to be the more chaste, but the former allowable accord. to Ks, and preferred by Th in the Fs, (L, TA,) [and seems to be the more common,] (tropical:) He is, or was, trueborn; (A, Msb;) contr. of lizinoyapK, (S, L, K,) or lizanoyapK, (Fr, TA,) and ligay~apK. (AZ, Fr, TA.) And ↓ wulida ligayori ra$odapK [or ri$odapK i. e. (tropical:) He was not trueborn]. (Fr, TA.) And h`*aA waladu ri$odapK (tropical:) This is an offspring of valid marriage. (TA.) And Aid~aEaY ↓ waladFA ligayori ra$odpK (tropical:) [He claimed, as his, a child not lawfully begotten, or not trueborn]. (TA, from a trad.)
ra$adaY * : see ra$aAdN.
ri$odiynN * : see raA$idN.

ra$aAdN * an inf. n. of 1, (L, K,) or a simple subst., (Msb,) [signifying Right procedure; or the adoption, or pursuit, of a right way or course or direction; as to a road, and also as to an affair: and often meaning right belief, or orthodoxy: in both these senses] contr. of gaY~N, (S, A, Msb,) and of DalaAlN: (Msb:) and ↓ ra$adaY is a subst. syn. with ra$aAdN. (L, K. *) -A2- Hab~u Alr~a$aAdi i. q. AlHurofu, (K,) in the dial. of El-'Irák; (TA;) they gave it this name as one of good omen, because HurofN is syn. with HiromaAnN: (K:) [ra$aAdN and HurofN are names given to several species of Gress; and Hab~u Alr~a$aAdi seems to mean the seed of r$Ad: accord. to Golius, on the authority of Ibn-Beytár, r$Ad is the name of the nasturtium: accord. to Delile, (Flor. AEgypt., nos. 576, 580, 571, 584, and 610,) it is the Arabic name of the lepidium sativum of Linn.; the lepidium hortense of Forsk.: and the cochlearia nilotica: ra$aAdu AlbaHori, i. e., nasturtium maritimum, that of the cakile maritima of Tournef.; Desf., a pinnatifida; the bunias cakile of Linn.; the isatis pinnata of Forsk.: Alr~a$aAdu AljabaliY~u, that of the lunaria parviflora: and ra$aAdu Alb~r~i, i. e., nasturtium deserti, that of the raphanus recurvatus of Persoon; the raphanus lyratus of Forsk.]

ra$iydN * : see raA$idN. ― -b2- Alr~a$iydu, of the measure faEiyl in the sense of the measure mufoEil, (L,) as an epithet applied to God, means The Director to the right way: (L, K:) and He who appoints, or ordains, well that which He appoints, or ordains: (K:) or He whose regulations are conducted to the attainment of their ultimate objects in the right way, without any one's aiding in directing their course aright. (L.)

raA$dN * and ↓ ra$iydN Taking, or following, a right way or course or direction [as to a road, and also as to an affair: and often meaning holding a right belief; or orthodox]. (A, Msb.) One says to a traveller, raA$idFA mahodiy~FA [May God make thee to be a taker, or follower, of a right way; one directed aright]. (A.) And one says, ↓ yaA ri$odiynu, as meaning yaA raA$idu [O thou who takest, or followest, a right way &c.]. (L) AlxulafaA='u Alr~aA$iduwna [The Khaleefehs who took, or followed, a right course, or the orthodox Khaleefehs,] is an appellation specially applied to Aboo-Bekr, 'Omar, 'Othmán, and 'Alee; but applicable also to any others of the Imáms who pursued the same course as those four. (L.) ― -b2- A^um~u raA$idK a surname (S) applied to The female rat or mouse (AlfaA^urapu). (S, K.)
AlT~ariyqu AlA^aro$adu * is like AlA^aqoSadu [i. e. The more, or most, direct road]. (S.)

AlmaraA$idu * , a pl. without a sing., like maHaAsinu and malaAmiHu, (L,) The right places to which roads tend; syn. maqaASidu AlT~uruqi. (S, L, K.) You say, huwa yahodiY A_ilaY AlmaraA$idi [He directs to the right places to which roads tend]. (A.)

1 ra$afahu * , aor.
ra$ufa and
ra$afa , inf. n. ra$ofN, (S, MA, O, Msb, K,) [and app. ra$iyfN also (which see below), and taro$aAfN, which has an intensive signification, mentioned by Freytag as occurring in the “ Mak- soorah ” of Ibn-Dureyd;] and ra$ifahu, aor.
ra$afa , (AA, O, K,) inf. n. ra$ofN; (K;) He sucked it in, (S, MA, O, K,) namely, water, (MA, K,) and the saliva of a girl, (IAar, O,) with the two lips; (MA;) as also ↓ Art$fhu (S, MA, O, * K) and ↓ tr$~fhu (S, * MA, O, * K) and ↓ Ar$fhu and ↓ r$~fhu: (IAar, O, K:) or he took it, namely, water, with the two lips in a manner exceeding that which is termed maS~N: (Msb:) and ra$afa, (Msb,) or ra$afa AlA_inaA='a and ra$ifahu, (K,) inf. n. ra$ofN, (IF, O,) he drank to the uttermost what was in the vessel, not leaving in it anything: (IF, * O, * Msb, K:) or, accord. to some, ra$ofN signifies the sucking in the water of the mouth in kissing: (Har p. 271:) you say, ra$afahaA, meaning he sucked her (a girl's) saliva from her mouth: (IAar, L in art. mSd:) and ↓ Art$fhA he kissed her and sucked in her saliva; from r$f [i. e. ra$afN] meaning “ saliva: ” and ↓ tr$~f signifies he sucked in much: (Har p. 231:) or i. q. tamaS~aSa. (O.) It is said in a prov., Alr~a$ofu A^anoqaEu, i. e. The sucking in (↓ tr$~f) of water by little and little is most effectual to quench thirst. (S, O, K.)
2 ra$~afa see above.
4 A^aro$afa see above.
5 tara$~afa see 1, in three places.
8 A_irota$afa see 1, in two places.

ra$afN *
A small quantity of water remaining in a watering-trough, or tank: the surface of the water, which the camels suck in with their mouths.
(Lth, O, K.) ― -b2- Saliva. (Har p. 231: but there without the vowel-signs.)

ra$uwfN *
Sweet in the mouth; sweet-mouthed; [as though her saliva were sucked in by her lover because of its sweetness;] applied to a woman. (S, O, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also Dry in the faroj; so applied. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b3- And A she-camel that eats with her lip. (As, O, K.)
ra$iyfN * an inf. n., [like ra$ofN,] (Lth, O,) The taking of water with the two lips; (Lth, O, K;) exceeding what is termed maS~N. (Lth, O.)

[
miro$afN *
An instrument with which one sucks in water &c. Its pl. maraA$ifu is used in the present day as meaning The lips: thus in the phrase AimoraA^apN Ea*obapu AlmaraA$ifi A woman sweet in the lips; a sweet-lipped woman.] [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 ra$aqahu * , (S, Msb,) or ra$aqahumo, (M,) biAls~ahomi, (M, Msb,) or biAln~aboli, (S, K,) wagayorihi, (K,) aor.
ra$uqa , (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. ra$oqN; (S, M, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Ar$qhu (Msb) [or Ar$qhm]; He shot, or shot at, him, or them, with the arrow, or with the arrows, and other things. (S, M, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., lahuwa A^a$ad~u Ealayohimo mino ra$oqi Aln~aboli [Verily it is harder upon them, or more severe or distressing to them, than the shooting of arrows at them]. (TA.) ― -b2- And ra$aqahumo binaZarihi (assumed tropical:) He cast his look at them. (M.) ― -b3- See also 4, in two places. -A2- ra$uqa, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. ra$aAqapN, (S, M, Msb,) He (a man) was, or became, goodly, or beautiful, and slender, in stature, or person: (S, K:) or he (a boy) was, or became, just in proportion, (T, A,) and slender; (A;) and in like manner ra$uqato is said of a girl: (T:) or he (a boy, M, or a person, Msb) was, or became, light, or active, (M, Msb,) in his work; (Msb;) and in like manner ra$oqato is said of a girl. (M. [See also 5.])

3 rA$qhu * , (Moheet, K,) inf. n. muraA$aqapN, (Moheet,) (assumed tropical:) He went, or ran, with him; or vied with him in going, or running; syn. saAyarahu. (Moheet, K.) [And] raA$aqaniY maqoSidiY (tropical:) He vied with me (baAraAniY) in going to the place to which I was repairing. (A, TA.)

4 Ar$q *
He shot in one direction; (Zj, K; *) as also ↓ ra$aqa. (Zj, O.) ― -b2- See also 1. ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He looked sharply, or intently, or attentively: (S, K:) [and] A^aro$aqato, inf. n. A_iro$aAqN, she looked sharply, &c.; said of a woman, and of a mahaAp [or wild cow]. (M.) You say, A^aro$aqotu A_ilaY Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) [I looked sharply, &c., or] I raised, or cast, my eyes, and looked, at, or towards, the party, or company of men; (L;) and so Alqawoma ↓ ra$aqotu. (JK.) And A^aro$aqati AlZ~aboyapu A_ilaY maA^orabihaA (assumed tropical:) The she-gazelle looked sharply, or intently, or attentively, at the object of her want. (A, TA.) As some say, (M,) Ar$qt AlZ~aboyapu signifies (tropical:) The she-gazelle extended, or stretched out, her neck. (S, M, K, TA.) -A2- maA A^aro$aqahaA, said of a bow, (tropical:) How light, and swift in the flight of its arrow, is it! The exclamation mark is unclear in the text. (K, TA.)

5 tr$~N fiY AlA^amori *
He was, or became, sharp in the affair. (M. [See also 1, last signification.])
ra$oqN * : see the next paragraph, last sentence.

ri$oqN * a subst. from 1 in the first of the senses explained above: (S, K:) [i. e. as signifying] A bout ($awoTN) of the shooting of arrows; (T, M, TA;) when persons, competing in shooting, shoot all the arrows that they have with them and then return [to the butt]: (T, TA:) and a direction in which arrows are shot, (S, M, Msb, K,) when the people, all of them, shoot all the arrows: (Msb:) pl. A^aro$aAqN. (Msb, TA.) You say, ramayonaA ri$oqFA; (S, K;) or ramawoA ri$oqFA, (Msb,) or rmwA ri$oqFA waAHidFA and EalaY ri$oqK waAHidK, (M,) We shot, all of us, [a bout,] in one direction; (S, K;) or they shot, (M, Msb,) all of them, (Msb,) [a bout,] in one direction, with all their arrows. (M, Msb.) And it is said in a trad. of Fudáleh, kaAna yaxoruju fayaromiY AlA^aro$aAqa [He used to go forth, and shoot bouts]. (TA.) Accord. to IDrd, Alr~i$oqu signifies The arrows themselves that are shot. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also The [stridulous] sound of the pen (Lth, M, Z, K) when one writes with it; (Lth, M;) and so ↓ ra$oqN. (Lth, M, Z, K.)
ra$aqN * : see the next paragraph but one, in two places.
ra$uwqN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

qawosN ra$iyqapN * (tropical:) A swift-shooting bow; (JK, A, K;) as also ↓ ra$uwqN (JK) and ↓ ra$aqN. (O, K.) ― -b2- A^ajalN ra$iyqN and ↓ ra$uwqN (assumed tropical:) [A period] quick [in passing]. (JK.) ― -b3- ra$iyqN applied to a boy, (T, TA,) or to a man, (S, K,) and ↓ muro$iqN, (JK,) and ra$iyqapN applied to a girl, (T, TA,) Just in proportion, (JK, T, A,) and slender: (A, TA:) or goodly, or beautiful, and slender, in stature, or person: (S, K:) or ra$iyqN (M, Msb) and ↓ muro$iqN (M) signify a boy, (M,) or a person, (Msb,) light, or active, (M, Msb,) in his work; (Msb;) and in the same sense are applied to a girl: (M:) the pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] of ra$iyqN is ↓ ra$aqN, (K,) like as A^adamN is of A^adiymN, and A^afaqN of A^afiyqN. (TA.)

raA$iqN *
Shooting. (Har p. 37.) ― -b2- sahomN raA$iqN i. q. *uw ra$oqK, i. e. *uw ramoYK [lit. An arrow having propulsion; meaning shot; the latter word being] of the class of [possessive epithets, such as] laAbinN and taAmirN. (Har p. 82.)

jiydN A^aro$aqN *
An erect neck. (M.)

muro$iqN * , applied to a woman, (JK, M,) and to a she-gazelle, (M,) or to a wild animal [of any kind], (JK,) Having her young one with her; (JK, M;) as though she were always watching it. (JK.) ― -b2- [Also (assumed tropical:) Having a stretched out, or long, neck. Hence,] Almuro$iqaAtu (assumed tropical:) [The long-necked ones] is used as meaning the gazelles: but is not applied to the [wild] oxen or cows, because of the shortness of their necks: these are called by Aboo-Du-ád banaAtu Eam~i Almuro$iqaAti [lit. the sons, or daughters, (for banaAt applied to irrational animals is pl. of AibonN as well as of binot,) of the paternal uncle of the long-necked ones, i. e., of the gazelles]: he says,
walaqado *aEarotu banaAti Eam~i Almuro$iqaAti lahaA baSaAbiSo
meaning [And verily I have frightened] the wild oxen or cows [having waggings of the tail]. (L.) ― -b3- See also the paragraph commencing with qawosN ra$iyqapN, in two places.

[
miro$aqapN * is explained by Golius, on the authority of Meyd, as signifying A ring used in shooting, by means of which the thumb, it being furnished therewith, more easily draws the tighter sort of bow-string.]

1 ra$ama * , (S, K,) aor.
ra$uma , inf. n. ra$omN, (S,) He stamped, or sealed, wheat. (S, K. [See rawo$amN.]) ― -b2- And He wrote; (K, TA;) Ealayohi [upon it], and A_ilayohi [to him]: accord. to the copies of the K, like ↓ r$am; but this is a mistake for rasama, with the unpointed s [and without teshdeed]. (TA.)
2 ra$~ama see above.

4 A^aro$ama see the next paragraph. -A2- Ar$mt It (land) showed its herbage. (TA.) ― -b2- And She (a wild cow) saw and depastured the ra$am, (K, TA,) i. e. the first that appeared of the herbage: the epithet applied to her is ↓ muro$imN [without p]. (TA.)

8 Art$m * , in the copies of the K erroneously written ↓ A^aro$ama, [is expl. as meaning] He stamped, or sealed, his vessel with the rawo$am: thus in the saying of El-Aashà, as some relate it,
waSal~aY EalaY dan~ihaA waA@rota$amo
but accord. to others, waA@rotasamo. (TA. [See art. rsm.])
ra$omN * : see what next follows.

ra$amN *
i. q. A^avarN [A mark, an impression, &c.]; (Aboo-Turáb, K, TA; [in the CK AlmaTaru is erroneously put for AlA^avaru;]) as also ↓ ra$omN; (K, TA;) like rasamN (Aboo-Turáb, TA) and rasomN [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K, all in art. rsm.) ― -b2- And [particularly] The mark, or impression, &c., (A^avar,) of rain, upon the ground. (K.) ― -b3- And The first that appears of herbage; (ISk, S, K;) as also ↓ rawo$amN. (TA.)

rawo$amN *
i. q. rawosamN (S, K, TA) as meaning The [small engraved] tablet, (S, TA,) or the stamp, or seal, (K, TA,) with which collections of wheat or corn [in their repositories] are stamped, or sealed; (S, TA;) as also ↓ raA$uwmN. (AA, K.) And The thing with which [the mouth of] a vessel is stamped, or sealed; (K;) and ↓ raA$uwmN signifies [the same; or] a stamp, or seal, with which the head [or mouth] of a [large jar such as is called] xaAbiyap is stamped, or sealed: (TA in art. rsm:) as also rawosamN (M and K in that art.) and raAsuwmN: (K in that art.:) or a stamp, or seal, in a general
sense; as also rawosamN. (M in that art.) -A2- See also ra$amN.
raA$uwmN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. muro$imN, an epithet applied to a wild cow: see 4.

1 ra$ana * , (S, K, TK,) [in the CK ra$una, there said to be like karuma,] aor, and inf. ns. as in the next sentence, (TK,) He (a man) came to a feast uninvited thereto, and entered without permission. (S, K. * [See raA$inN, below.]) ― -b2- And ra$ana fiY AlA_inaA='i, (S, K,) aor.
ra$una , (S,) inf. n. ra$onN and ru$uwnN, (S, K,) He (a dog) put his head into the vessel, (S, K, TA,) to eat and drink. (TA.)

ra$onN *
A turn, or time, for the taking of water; (K;) so in the M; (TA;) as also ↓ ra$anN. (K.)
ra$anN * : see what next precedes.

ganamN ru$uwnN *
Sheep, or goats, pasturing and drinking at pleasure, amid abundance of herbage, and plenty. (K.)

raA$inN *
i. q. TufayoliY~N; (S, K;) i. e. One who comes to a feast uninvited thereto: he who watches for the time of food, and then goes in to the party when they are eating, is termed waAri$N. (S.) ― -b2- And One who eats all that is upon the table of food; syn. miqam~N: in the K, Almuqiymu is erroneously put for Almiqam~u. (TA.) -A2- Also A small gift to the pupil of the SaAy^ig [or goldsmith]; in Pers, called $AkrdAnh [correctly $aAkirodaAnaho]. (K. [mA yuroDaHu in the CK is a mistake for mA yuroDaxu.])

rawo$anN *
i. q. kuw~apN [i. e. A window; so in the present day; or a mural aperture; an aperture in a wall or chamber]: (S, K:) [arabicized:] in Pers. rawozano. (KL, PS,) ― -b2- Also i. q. raf~N [q. v.; app. here meaning A kind of arched construction, upon which are placed vessels and other utensils &c. of the house]. (TA.)

1 ra$aA * , said of a young bird, It stretched forth its head to its mother in order that she should put food into its beak. (Abu-l-'Abbás [Th], Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, [accord. to Th, but see ri$owNp, below,] ra$aAhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. wyaro$uw, inf. n. ra$owN, (S, Msb,) He gave him a ri$owap [or bribe]. (S, * Mgh, Msb, K.) [See also 3.]

3 rA$Ahu * , (S, ISd, K,) inf. n. muraA$aApN, (TA,) i. q. SaAnaEahu [He bribed him; (see also 1;) or endeavoured to conciliate him; or did to him a thing in order that he (the latter) might do to him (the former) another thing]: (K:) and HaAbaAhu [app. as meaning he treated him, or behaved towards him, with partiality]: (ISd, K:) or ZaAharahu [he aided him, or assisted him]. (S.)

4 Ar$Y Ald~alowa *
He put a ri$aA=' [or rope]. to the bucket. (S, ISd, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Ar$Y said of the colocynth [or any similar plant (see ri$aA='N)] (assumed tropical:) It extended its rope-like branches [or stalks]. (Az, S, K, ↓ TA.) -A2- A^aro$ayotu AlfaSiyla, (S, K,) inf. n. A_iro$aA='N, (S,) I made the young camel to suck, or to be suckled. (S, K.)

5 tr$~Ahu *
He was soft, tender, gentle, bland, or mild, towards him; or he treated him with gentleness, or blandishment. (S, ISd, K.)

8 Art$Y *
He took, or received, a ri$owap [or bribe], (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) minohu from him. (Mgh.)

10 Astr$Y *
He sought, or desired, to be suchled; said of a young camel. (S, K.) ― -b2- And Astr$Y maA fiY AlD~aroEi He drew forth what was in the udder. (Az, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, probably,] Astr$Y fiY Hukomihi He sought, or desired, or demanded, a ri$owap [or bribe] in the case of his deciding judicially, for his doing so [agreeably with the desire of the briber]. (S, K, ↓ TA.)

ri$owapN * and ru$owapN (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and ra$owapN, (Lth, K,) of which the first is that which is the most commonly used, (TA,) i. q. juEolN [as meaning A bribe]; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) a thing that one gives to a judge, or to another person, in order that he may judge in his [the giver's] favour, or to incite him to do what he [the giver] desires; (Msb, TA;) or a means of attaining that which one wants, by bribery; not including what is given as a means of obtaining a right or repelling a wrong; for it is related on the authority of several of the leading doctors of the Tábi'ees that there is no harm in man's bribing for the defence of himself and his property when he fears being wronged; so says IAth: and Lth explains the last of these three words as meaning an act of bribery: (TA:) accord. to Abu-l-'Abbás [i. e. Th], (TA), the former meaning is from ra$aA said of a young bird, explained in the first sentence of this art.: (Msb, TA:) or it is from Alr~i$aA='u, (IAth, Mgh, TA,) signifying “ that by means of which one obtains water, ” (IAth, TA,) or “ the rope of the bucket: ” (Mgh:) or, accord. to ISd, the reverse of this is the case: (TA:) the pl. (of the first, Msb, TA) is ri$FA or ri$FY and (of the second, Msb, TA) ru$FA or ru$FY. (S, Msb, K, TA.)

ri$aA='N *
A rope: (S, Msb, K:) [or a well-rope; i. e.] the rope of the bucket: (Mgh:) and ↓ tiro$aA='N, also, with kesr, has the same meaning as ri$aA='N: (K:) hence it would seem that this is generally the case; but they have expressly declared that the latter word has not been heard except in relation to the like of an enchantment, or a fascination: so says MF, pointing to the saying of Lh, that among the phrases of women who enchant, or fascinate, men is A^ax~a*otuhu bidub~aA=' mumal~aA^K mina AlmaA=' muEal~aqK bitiro$aA=' [I have enchanted him, or fascinated him, with a gourd, filled with water, suspended by a rope, or well-rope]; and that tr$A', meaning a rope, is not thus said except in this enchantment, or fascination: accord. to ISd, the last radical of r$A' is judged to be w because one obtains water by means of the r$A', like as one obtains the thing sought by means of the ri$owap; which is the reverse what has been said above, that Alr$wp is from Alr$A': (TA:) the pl. is A^aro$iyapN. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Alr~a$aA='u is also the name of (assumed tropical:) A Mansion of the Moon; (K, TA;) [the Twenty-eighth, which is the last, of the Mansions of the Moon;] so called as being likened to a rope; (TA;) [the northern fish, of the constel-lation Pisces, together with the star beta of Andromeda; or, more correctly, delta and epsilon, with some neighbouring stars, of Pisces;] a group of many stars, in the form of a fish, with the tail towards the south and the head towards the north; (Kzw;) many small stars, in the form of a fish, called [also] baTonu AlHuwti, in the navel of which is a bright star, which the moon makes one of its mansions; (S, TA;) [or including bTn AlHwt, which is in the navel of Andromeda; for] bTn AlHwt is the name of the bright star [beta] that is above the drapery round the waist of Andromeda: (Kzw, descr. of Andromeda:] Alr$A' is also called qalobu AlHuwti. (TA in art. qlb.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.]

ra$iY~N *
A young camel; syn. faSiylN. (K.) [See 4, last sentence.]

raA$K * The giver of a ri$owap [or bribe]: hence the trad., laEana A@ll~`hu Alr~aA$iYa waAlmurota$iYa waAlr~aAy^i$a, i. e. [May God curse] the giver of a ri$owap, who aids another to do what is wrong, and the receiver thereof, and him who is agent between them two, demanding more for this or less for this. (IAth, TA.)
tiro$aA='N * : see ri$aA='N, first sentence.
murota$K * The receiver of a ri$owap [or bribe]. (IAth, TA.) [See an ex. above, voce raA$K.]

musotaro$K *
A seeker, desirer, or demander, of a ri$owap [or bribe]. (TK.) Hence, (TK,) one says, A_in~aka lamusotaro$K lifulaAnK, [in the TA A_ilaY fulaAnK,] i. e. muTiyEN lahu taAbiEN limasar~atihirS [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily thou art obedient to such a one, subservient to that which gives him happiness]. (K, TK.)

1 raS~ahu * , (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
raSu3a , inf. n. raS~N, (S, M, Msb,) He stuck it (a thing, S, Mgh) together, one part to another, (S, A, Mgh, K,) so that there might be no interstice in it; (Mgh;) joined it together; (Msb, K;) namely, a building; (Msb;) and ↓ rS~Shu, (S, * Mgh, K,) inf. n. taroSiySN, (S,) signifies the same; (S, Mgh, K;) and so ↓ raSoraSahu: (TA:) or these three verbs all signify he made it (a building) firm and compact: (M:) or ↓ rSrSh signifies he made it (a building) firm and strong: (IDrd, K:) and ruS~a, said of anything, it was made firm, and joined together. (M, TA.) And hence, Alqumoqumapa ↓ rSiS He tied ($ad~a [perhaps a mistranscription for sad~a he stopped up]) firmly the mouth of the qmqmp [a kind of vessel]. (Mgh.) And raS~a baAbahu He closed, or locked, his door; as also laS~ahu, q. v. (TA in art. lS.) ― -b2- raS~ato bayoDahaA She (a domestic hen, A, K,
and an ostrich, A) made her eggs even, or level, with her bill (A, K) and her feet, to sit upon them. (A.) ― -b3- See also raSaASpN.

2 raS~a3a see 1, in two places. ― -b2- raS~aSato, (AZ, M,) inf. n. taroSiySN, (AZ, S,) She (a woman) put on, or wore, her niqaAb [a kind of face-veil] in such a manner that nothing was seen but her eyes: (AZ, S, M:) as also waS~aSato, (AZ, TA,) or waSowaSato: (M:) wS~St is of the dial. of Temeem. (AZ, TA.) ― -b3- rS~S (tropical:) He was importunate, or urgent, in asking, or begging. (Fr, TA.)
5 taraS~a3a see 8.

6 trAS~wA *
They placed themselves close together, (Ks, S, M, A, K,) in a rank, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) in prayer, (A, TA,) and in battle, (TA,) so that there was no intervening space among them; (Ks;) as also ↓ ArtS~wA: (A:) they placed themselves in a rank, or in ranks, in battle, and in prayer. (M.)

8 ArtS~t AljanaAdlu *
The stones were stuck, or set close, together; as also ↓ trS~St. (A.) ― -b2- See also 6.
R. Q. 1 raSoraSahu * : see 1, in two places. ― -b2- raSoraSa fiY AlmakaAni He continued, or became fixed or settled, in the place. (IAar, K.)
raSaSN * in the teeth is like laSaSN; (M, TA;) and ↓ raSiySN in the teeth signifies [the same, i. e.,] Nearness together. (A, TA. *) -A2- See also the next paragraph.

raSaASN * (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ riSaASN, (M,) or the latter is vulgar, (S,) and not allowable, (K,) or, accord. to AHát, it is correct, and it is quoted by Ez-Zarkashee, and by certain of the Expositors of the Fs, and is the only form mentioned by AHei, (TA,) and, accord. to some of the moderns, ↓ ruSaASN also, (MF,) and ↓ raSaSN, (M, TA,) which is a contraction of the first, (TA,) [Lead;] a certain mineral, (M,) well known; (S, K;) i. q. EalaAbiY~u; (Mgh;) pure Arabic; (IDrd;) so called because of the compactness of its particles: (IDrd, M:) it is of two kinds; the black, which is [also called] A^usorub~N, and A^ab~aArN or A_ibaArN [accord. to different copies of the K]; and white, which is [also called] qaloEiY~N, and qaSodiyrN [which is applied in the present day to tin, and pewter]: if a little thereof [of the former kind thereof accord. to the TA] be thrown into a cooking-pot, its flesh-meat will never become thoroughly cooked: and if a tree be encompassed by a ring thereof, its fruit will not drop, but will become abundant: (K:) and Abu-l-Hoseyn ElMedáïnee says, it used to be said, the drinking from a vessel thereof is a security against the colic: (TA:) ↓ raSaASapN signifies a piece thereof. (Msb.)
ruSaASN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
riSaASN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
raSuwSN * : see A^araS~u.
raSiySN * : see maroSuwSN, in two places. ― -b2- A woman's [face-veil of the kind called] niqaAb drawn near to her eyes. (AA, K.) -A2- See also raSaSN.

raSaASapN * : see raSaASN. ― -b2- Also, (accord. to a copy of the M,) or ↓ raS~aASapN, with teshdeed, (K,) Stones cleaving to the circuit of a running spring; and so ↓ raSoraASapN: (Lth, M, K:) or rSASp [in my copy of the A written ↓ ruSaASap] signifies a stone: and the pl. is raSaAy^iSu [which is reg. as pl. of either of the above-mentioned forms without tesh-deed but not as pl. of that with teshdeed]. (A.) You say, EalaY Alqabori Alr~aSaAy^iSu ↓ ruS~ato The stones were heaped together upon the grave. (A.) ― -b3- Hence, ↓ ruSaASapN, (as in the A,) or ↓ raS~aASapN, (accord. to the K,) (tropical:) A niggard: (A, K:) likened to a stone. (A.)
ruSaASapN * : see raSaASapN, in two places.
raS~aASN * [app., accord. to the TA, A manufacturer of lead: or] a seller of lead. (Meyd, in Golius.)
raS~aASapN * : see raSaASapN, in two places.
raSoraASapN * : see raSaASapN. ― -b2- Hard ground or land. (K.) This is its meaning accord. to IDrd. (TA.)

A^araS~u * A man whose teeth are near together: (M, A, K:) fem. raS~aA='u. (M, A.) ― -b2- And the fem., applied to a woman, Impervia coëunti; as also ↓ raSuwSN. (M.) ― -b3- raS~aA='u Alfaxi*iyoni A woman whose thighs are close together. (A.) ― -b4- faxi*N raS~aA='u A thigh that cleaves, or sticks, to its fellow. (O, K.)

A^uroSuwSapN *
A [cap of the kind called] qalanosuwap like a melon. (O, K.)
muraS~aSN * : see what follows, in two places.

maroSuwSN * A building having its several parts stuck together, (S, A, Mgh, TA,) so that there is no interstice in it: (Mgh:) or a building made firm and compact: (M:) and ↓ muraS~aSN signifies the same; (A, Mgh, TA;) and so ↓ raSiySN. (M, TA.) You say also, ↓ bayoDN raSiySN Eggs [set] one upon another. (K.) ― -b2- A thing done over, or overlaid, (maToliY~N,) with raSaAS; as also ↓ muraS~aSN. (S, K.) biy^orN maroSuwSapN A well cased with raSaAS. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

1 raSadahu * , (As, S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
raSuda , (As, S, Msb,) inf. n. raSodN (S, Msb, K) and raSadN; (S, K;) and ↓ ArtSdhu, (A,) and ↓ trS~dhu, (S, * K,) or lahu ↓ trS~d, (A,) He sat [or lay in wait] for him in the road, or way: [see raSadN:] (A, Msb:) or he watched, or waited, for him; (As, S, K;) and so ↓ rASdhu, (A,) and lahu ↓ ArSd: (L:) [or] you say, raSadahu biaAlxayori wagayorihi, aor.
raSuda , inf. n. raSodN, he watched, or waited, for him [with that which was good and otherwise]; and in like manner, raSadahu biAlmukaAfaA^api [he watched, or waited, for him with requital]; (M;) and also raSada lahu, and ↓ ArSdhu: (Hudot;am p. 89:) or, accord. to some, you say, lahu biAlxayori waAl$~ar~i ↓ ArSd; only with A; not otherwise: [see this verb below:] and accord. to some, one says, raSadahu, meaning he watched, or waited, for him; and lahu AlA^amora ↓ ArSd, meaning he prepared for him the thing, or affair, or event; and ↓ AirotiSaAdN is syn. with raSodN. (M.) One says of a serpent (Hay~ap), taroSudu AlmaAr~apa EalaY AlT~ariyqi litalosaEa [It watches, or lies in wait, for the passers-by on the road, or way, that it may bite]: (L:) and of a beast of prey, (S, A, K,) or of a wolf, (M,) yaroSudu liyaviba, (S, M, A,) or yaroSudu Alwuvuwba, (K,) i. e. He watches, or waits, to leap, or spring: (TA:) and of a she-camel, taroSudu $uroba AlA_bili vum~a ta$orabu [She watches, or waits, for the drinking of the other camels, and then she drinks]; (S, A;) or taroSudu $uroba gayorihaA lita$oraba hiYa [she watches, or waits, for the drinking of others, that she may drink]. (K.) ― -b2- ruSidati AlA^aroDu The land was rained upon by a rain such as is termed raSodapN, (S,) or by rain such as is termed raSadN. (TA.)
3 raAoSada see above, first sentence.

4 ArSdhu EalaY ka*aA *
He charged him with the watching, or guarding, of such a thing. (L.) ― -b2- See also 1, in four places. ― -b3- ArSd lahu also signifies (tropical:) He prepared, or made ready, [a person, or thing,] for him, or it; (As, S, A, K;) as an army for battle, and a horse for charging, and property, or money, for the payment of what was due. (A, TA.) You say, A^aroSadotu lahu AlEuqowbapa (tropical:) I prepared for him punishment: properly signifying I put punishment in his road, or way. (L.) And A^aroSadotu lahu xayorFA and $ar~FA (tropical:) [I prepared for him good and evil]. (A.) A_il~aA A^ano A^uroSidahu lidayonK EalaY~a occurs in a trad. [as meaning (tropical:) Unless I prepare it for a debt that I owe]. (S.) And [hence, app., as seems to be indicated in the TA,] you say, yuroSidu Alz~akaApa fiY Silapi A_ixowaAnihi (tropical:) He places alms in kind, or good and affectionate and gentle and considerate, treatment of his brethren; [as though meaning he prepares for himself the recompense of alms (vawaAba Alz~akaApi, like as one says yaHotasibu Eamalahu meaning yHtsb vawaAba,) Eamalihi,) in so doing;] reckoning such treatment of them as alms. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (tropical:) He requited him, or recompensed him, with good, (L, K, TA,) accord. to the original application, (L, TA,) or with evil, (L, K, TA,) as some apply it. (L, TA.) ― -b5- And ArSd AlHisaAba (assumed tropical:) He showed, or cast up, or produced, the reckoning. (MF, from the 'Ináyeh.)
5 taraS~ada see 1, first sentence, in two places.
8 A_irotaSada see 1, in two places.
raSodN * : see the next paragraph.

raSadN * : see raASidN, in three places. -A2- Also A road, or way; (Msb;) and so ↓ maroSadN, (TA,) both signify the same, (M,) and ↓ mroSaAdN (S, K, TA) and ↓ murotaSadN: (TA:) and ↓ miroSaAdN, (IAmb, K,) or ↓ maroSadN, (S,) or both, (M, A,) and ↓ murotaSadN and raSadN, (A,) a place where one lies in wait, or
watches, (IAmb, S, M, A, K,) for an enemy: (IAmb, K:) the pl. of raSadN is A^aroSaAdN; (Msb;) and the pl. of ↓ maroSadN is maraASidu, (TA,) which signifies also lurking places of serpents. (M, L.) You say, ↓ qaEada lahu biAlmaroSadi and ↓ biAlmiroSaAdi and ↓ biAlmurotaSadi (A, Msb) and biAlr~aSadi (A) He lay in wait for him in the way. (A, * Msb.) And A^anaA laka biAlr~aSadi and ↓ biAlmiroSaAdi (tropical:) [I am in the place of lying in wait for thee], meaning thou canst not escape me. (A.) And 'Adee says,
↓ waA_in~a AlmanaAyaA lil~rijaAli bimroSadi
(tropical:) [And verily deaths are in a place of lying in wait for men, so that they cannot escape them]. (TA.) ↓ waA@qoEuduwA lahumo kul~a maroSadK, in the Kur [ix. 5], means And lie ye in wait for them in every road, or way; (AM, TA;) accord. to Fr, in their way to the Sacred House. (TA.) And ↓ A_in~a rab~aka labiA@lomiroSaAdi, in the Kur [lxxxix. 13], means Verily thy Lord is in the way; i. e., in the way by which thou goest; (TA;) so that none of thine actions escapeth Him: (Msb:) or it means that He watcheth, or lieth in wait, to punish him who disbelieveth in Him and turneth away from Him: (Zj, TA:) or that He watcheth every man to recompense him for his deeds: (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA:) or, accord. to El-Aamash, AlmrSAd is here a name applied to three bridges behind the SiraAT; on one of which is security; on another, mercy; and on the third, the Lord. (L, TA.) -A3- Also A small quantity of rain: (S, K:) one says, bihaA raSadN mino HayFA [In it, namely, the land (AlA^aroD), is a small quantity of rain]: (S:) and so ↓ raSodN: (TA:) or both signify rain that comes after other rain: or rain that falls first, before other rain coming: or the first of rain: or, accord. to IAar, the former word signifies rain such as is termed EihaAd, after which other rain is looked for; and if other rain follow it, herbage is produced: one shower thereof is termed ↓ raSadapN and ↓ raSodapN; the latter mentioned by Th: (M:) or ↓ raSodapN signifies a shower, or what falls at once, of rain [app. in any case]: (S, K:) the pl. of raSadN is A^aroSaAdN (S, M, K) and riSaAdN, (M,) the latter mentioned on the authority of A'Obeyd: (TA:) [or] the latter is pl. of ↓ raSodapN. (S.) ― -b2- Also A small quantity of herbage, (S, M, K,) in land upon which one hopes for the fall of the rain of the season called Alr~abiyE. (M.)

raSodapN * an inf. n. of un. of 1: pl. raSadaAtN, whence the saying, laA yuxoTiy^uka min~iY raSadaAtu xayorK, or $ar~K, (tropical:) [My watchings of good conduct, or of evil, will not miss thee], meaning I will requite thee for thy deeds. (A, TA.) -A2- See also the latter part of the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

ruSodapN *
A pitfall for a lion; syn. zuboyapN. (S, K.) ― -b2- And A ring of brass, or of silver, in the thongs [or cords] by means of which the sword is suspended. (K.)
raSadapN * : see raSadN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

raSadiY~N *
One who lies in wait for men in the way, to take their property unjustly; (Msb;) syn. with the Pers. raAhodaAro; and so ↓ raS~aAdN. (Meyd, accord. to Golius [who, however, explains the Pers. word as meaning viæ custos, et vectigalium pro transitu exactor; which I do not think to be here intended thereby].)
raSuwdN * A she-camel that watches, or waits, for the drinking of others, (S, A, K,) and then herself drinks, (S, A,) or that she may drink. (K.)

raSiydN * A beast of prey, (S, A, K,) or a wolf, (M,) that watches, or waits, to leap, or spring. (S, M, A, K.) And A serpent (Hay~pN) that watches, or lies in wait, to bite persons passing along the road, or way. (L.)

raSaAy^idu *
Snares, or traps, prepared for catching beasts of prey; as also waSaAy^idu. ('Arrám, L.)
raS~aAdN * : see raSadiY~N.

raASidN *
