Sitting [or lying in wait] for one in the road, or way: (Msb:) or watching, or waiting; li$aYo'K for a thing: (S:) or one lying in wait, or in a place of watching, or in a road or way, for the purpose of guarding: (Mgh:) pl. raASiduwna, (K,) and ↓ raSadN, like as xadamN is pl. of xaAdimN, (Mgh, Msb,) and HarasN of HaArisN; (Mgh;) or [rather] raSadN is syn. with raASiduwna, (S, * A, * K,) or with murotaSiduwna, [which has the same meaning,] and is a quasi-pl. n., (M,) a word like HarasN (S, A) and xadamN, (A,) and used alike as sing. and pl. [and masc.] and fem.; and sometimes they said A^aroSaAdN; (S;) and raSadapN also is used as a pl. of raASiadN, agreeably with analogy; (Mgh;) and ruS~adN likewise appears to be a pl. of the same. (Ham p. 415.) One says, ↓ fulaAnN yaxaAfu raSadFA mino qud~aAmihi waTalabFA mino waraAy^ihi i. e. [Such a one fears] an enemy lying in wait [before him, and pursuers behind him]. (A.) By ↓ raSadFA in the Kur lxxii. last verse but one, are meant watchers over an angel sent down with a revelation, lest one of the jinn, or genii, should overhear the revelation and acquaint therewith the diviners, who would acquaint other men therewith, and thus become equal to the prophets. (M, L.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) Alr~aASidu is an appellation of The Lion. (K, TA.)
muroSadN * : see raSadN, in six places.

muroSidN * [i. q. raASidN]. One says, A^anaA laka muroSidN biA_iHosaAnika Hat~aY A^ukaAfiy^aka bihi (tropical:) [I am watching, or waiting, for thee, on account of they beneficence, that I may requite thee for it]. (Lth, A.) ― -b2- A^aroDN muroSidapN Land in which is a small quantity (raSadN, M) of herbage: (M, K:) or land which has been rained upon, and which it is hoped will produce herbage: (AHn, M, K:) and land upon which has fallen a rain such as is termed raSodap; (M;) and so ↓ maroSuwdapN: (S, M:) or, accord. to some, one should not say maroSuwdapN nor muroSdapN; but A^aSaAbahaA raSodN and raSadN. (M.)
miroSaAdN * : see raSadN, in five places.
A^aroDN maroSuwdapN * : see muroSidN.
murotaSadN * : see raSadN, in three places.

1 raSiEa bihi * , aor.
raSaEa , (S, K,) inf. n. raSaEN, (S,) or, as in the L, ruSuwEN, (TA,) It stuck, adhered, or clave, to it; (S, K;) as also ↓ ArtSE. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) You say, A^asonaAnuhu ↓ AirotaSaEato His teeth were near together, (K, TA,) and stuck, adhered, or clave, together. (TA.) [See also the part. n. of the latter verb, below.] ― -b2- raSiEa biAlT~iybi i. q. Eabiqa bihi [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) He kept, or became addicted to, the use of perfume; syn. A^uwliEa bihi: but accord. to the TK, he rubbed, or anointed, himself with perfume]. (IF, K.) ― -b3- raSaEa biAlmakaAni, aor.
raSaEa , inf. n. raSoEN, He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (K, * TA.) -A2- raSaEa Al$~aYp'a He tied the thing in a complicated treble knot, such as the knots of the tamiymap and the like: [or perhaps this is a mistranscription, for ↓ raS~aEa; for it is added,] when you take a thong, and tie in it treble knots, this [action] is [termed] taroSiyEN. (TA.)

2 taroSiyEN * [inf. n. of rS~E] The act of setting, fixing, or putting together, [jewels, precious stones, gems, pearls, &c.;] syn. tarokiybN. (S, K.) [See the pass. part. n., below.] ― -b2- The act of making [a thing] according to a measure; syn. taqodiyrN. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- The act of weaving [a thing]; or forming [it] by the inserting of one part within another; like as a bird weaves its nest. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) You say, rS~E AlT~aAy^iru Eu$~ahu biquDobaAnK wariy$K The bird put twigs and feathers near together, and wove with them its nest. (A, TA.) ― -b4- rS~E AlEiqoda biAljawohari, inf. n. as above, He furnished the necklace with jewels, precious stones, or gems, connected, or drawn, together, in a series. (TA.) ― -b5- [Hence,] in rhetoric, Alt~aroSiyEu signifies (assumed tropical:) A kind of jinaAs; (TA;) the making the words of a clause of rhyming prose, or at least two of them, conformable in their measures, and agreeing in their latter parts, with the corresponding words of the corresponding clause; as in the saying in the Kur [end of ch. lxxxviii.], A_in~a A_ilayonaA A_iyaAbahumo vum~a A_in~a EalayonaA HisaAbahumo: and the like in verse; as in the saying of Aboo-Firás [El-Farezdak],
waA^amowaAluhu lilT~aAlibiyna nihaAbu
waA^afoEaAluhu lil~aAgibiyna kariymapN
(Har p. 9.) ― -b6- See also 1; last sentence.
8 A_irotaSaEa see 1, first and second sentences.
raSiyEN * The button of the loop of a copy of the Kurán. (AA, Z, Sgh, K.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

raSiyEapN * The knot that is in the bridle (All~ijaAm), by the cheek (AlmuEa*~ar), resembling a [small piece of money such as is called] falos. (K.) ― -b2- A ring, of those with which a sword is ornamented: (S:)
or the round ornament of a sword: (IDrd, K:) or any round ring in the ornamental part of a sword or saddle or other thing: (IDrd, K: *) or a plaited thong between the suspensory thong, or shoulder-belt, and the scabbard, of the sword; as also ↓ raSiyEN: or [the pl. signifies] plaited thongs in the lower parts of the suspensory thongs of the sword; and a dial. var. is with s; (TA;) i. e. rasaAy^iEu, (K and TA in art. rsE,) on the authority of ISh. (TA in that art.) The pl. of raSiyEapN (S, K) in all the senses explained above (K, TA) is raSaAy^iEu. (S, K.)

raASiEN *
Sticking, adhering, or cleaving. (AZ, L.)

muraS~aEN *
Adorned with jewels, precious stones, or gems; applied to a crown, and sword: (K:) or you say, taAjN muraS~aEN biAljawaAhiri meaning a crown set with jewels, precious stones, or gems: and sayofN muraS~aEN a sword ornamented with the rings called raSaAy^iE, pl. of raSiyEapN. (S.) ― -b2- farasN muraS~aEu Alv~unani A horse having the hairs of the fetlock baEoDuhaA fiY baEaDK [meaning compacted together, as though woven]: (AO, and so in some copies of the K:) in [some of the copies of] the K baEoDuhaA fawoqa baEoDK. (TA.)

A^asonaAnuhu murotaSiEapN *
His teeth are set close together. (A, TA.)

1 raSafahu * , aor.
raSifa , [or
raSufa , as appears from what follows,] inf. n. raSofN, He put, or joined, together, or together and in regular order, its several parts. (M.) [Hence,] raSafa AlHijaArapa, (S, O, Msb, in the M AlHajara,) aor.
raSufa , inf. n. as above, (S, M, Msb,) He put, or joined, together the stones (S, O, Msb) in building, or in the building or structure: (S, O:) or he built, or constructed, and joined together, the stones. (M.) And ruSifato A^asonaAnuhu His teeth were disposed in a regular and an even row in their manner of growth; as also raSifato, [aor.
raSafa ,] inf. n. raSafN. (M.) And raSafa qadamayohi He (a man praying, O, K) put his feet together: (S, O, K:) or raSafa maAbayona rijolayohi he put his legs near together. (M.) ― -b2- Also He bound it round with a thing. (Har p. 376.) You say, raSafa Als~ahoma, inf. n. raSofN, He bound, (S, O, K,) or wound, (M,) a sinew (Eaqabap) upon the socket of the head of the arrow, (S, M, O, K,) when it had broken. (M.) -A2- raSifato A^asonaAnuhu: see above. ― -b2- raSifato also signifies She [a woman] was small, or narrow, in the faroj [or vulva]. (M.) -A3- raSufa, aor.
raSufa , inf. n. raSaAfapN, said of a deed, or an action, (assumed tropical:) It was firm, or sound; or firmly, or soundly, or well, executed, or performed. (O, K.) ― -b2- [See also raSaAfapN below.] ― -b3- One says also, h`daA A^amorN laA yuroSufu bika (assumed tropical:) This is a thing, or an affair, that will not become thee, or be suitable to thee. (S, O, K.)

2 taroSiyfN * [inf. n. of rS~f] The putting, or placing, together, or constructing, well stones or bricks in a building. (KL.) ― -b2- The connecting well words with words. (KL.) ― -b3- And The binding round an arrow well [at the part in which the head is inserted] with a sinew. (KL.)

4 ArSf *
He mixed his wine ($araAbahu) with what is termed maA='u Alr~aSafi, i. e. water descending from the mountains, upon the rocks. (O, K.)
5 taraS~afa see 8.
6 taraAoSafa see 8. ― -b2- taraASafuwA fiY AlS~af~i They stood close together, side by side, in the rank. (S, O, K.) taraASufN is syn. with talaASuqN. (O.)

8 ArtSf *
It had its several parts put, or joined, together, or together and in regular order; as also ↓ trS~f, [or this means it had its several parts well put, or joined, together, &c., (see 2, of which it is the quasi-pass.,)] and ↓ trASf. (M.)

raSafN *
Stones put, or joined, together, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) [whether artificially or naturally, and particularly] in a channel of water: (O, K:) n. un. ↓ raSafapN. (S, M, O, Msb, K.) A dam constructed for [the purpose of obstructing or retaining] water: [such is now termed ↓ raSiyfN; which is originally an epithet, but thus used as a subst., and commonly applied to a quay; and a bank, generally of masonry or bricks, raised along the side of a river or of a lake &c.; and any similar mass of masonry:] also (i. e. raSafN) the channel of a [reservoir such as is termed] maSonaEap. (M.) [Hence,] maA='u Alr~aSafi The water descending from the mountains, upon the rocks. (K.) El-'Ajjáj says,
mino raSafK naAzaEa sayolFA raSafaA
meaning that the wine of which he is speaking was mixed with water of a raSaf [or ledge of rocks or stones] that had contended, in flowing, with another raSaf, because of its thereby becoming more clear and more delicate: he suppresses the word signifying water, meaning it to be understood, (saying mino raSafK for mino maA='i raSafK, [but in both of my copies of the S, maA='K is erroneously put for maA='i,]) and he calls its passing (masiyrahu [in the O and in one of my copies of the S masylahu]) from rSf to rSf its contending therewith [i. e. with the latter rSf]. (S, O.) ― -b2- See also raSafapN.
raSofapN * : see the next paragraph. ― -b2- The raSofataAni are Two sinews, or ligaments, (EaSabataAni,) in, or between, the [two bones called] raDofataAni of the two knees. (M.)

raSafapN * n. un. of raSafN, q. v. ― -b2- Also A sinew (EaqabapN) that is wound upon the socket of the head of an arrow, (S, M, O, K,) when it has broken; (M;) as also ↓ ruSaAfapN (Lth, O, K) and ↓ ruSuwfapN, each with damm; (K;) or as also ↓ riSaAfapN, [thus written with kesr,] of which the pl. is raSaAy^ifu (M) and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ riSaAfN; (M, O;) but [ISd says,] I think that AHn has made this last to be a sing.: and ↓ raSafN is the pl. of raSafapN, [or rather it is a coll. gen. n.,] and A^aroSaAfN I hold to be pl. of raSafN: (M:) or riSaAfN is the pl. of raSafapN. (S, K.) ― -b3- Also, and ↓ raSofapN, A sinew (EaqabapN) that is bound upon another sinew, and is then bound upon the suspensory (HimaAlap) of the bow. (M.) ― -b4- And raSafataAni [if not a mistake for raDafataAni] Two round bones in the knee of a horse, separate from the other bones. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.
raSofaA='u * : see raSuwfN.
raSaAfN * : see raSafapN. ― -b2- Also A part like stairs, in the side of a mountain; pl. ruSufN. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O.)

raSuwfN * A woman narrow in the faroj [or vulva]: (S, M, O:) or small therein: (M:) or small in the vulva, and narrow therein, and, consequently, impervia viro; as also ↓ raSofaA='u (IAar, * O, * K) and ↓ maroSuwfapN: (O, * K:) or this last, [syn with marofuwgapN,] a woman whose place of circumcision has cohered [after the operation, when she was young], and, consequently, impervia [viro]. (M.)

raSiyfN * [Put, or joined, together, or together and in regular order, in its several parts; like ↓ maroSuwfN]. You say, A^asonaAnuhu raSiyfapN and ↓ murotaSifapN His teeth are disposed in a regular and an even row in their manner of growth. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) An imitator, or emulator, of another in actions; and an inseparable associate. (O. K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A deed, or an action, that is firm, or sound; or firmly, or soundly, or well, executed or performed: (S, O, Msb, K:) and in like manner, an answer, or a reply: (S, O:) or an answer, or a reply, that is strong, or valid; not to be rebutted. (Msb.) ― -b4- Also An arrow having a sinew (Eaqabap) wound upon the socket of its head, when it has broken; and so ↓ maroSuwfN. (M.) ― -b5- See also raSafN. -A2- Also sing. of riSaAfN, which signifies The sinews, or ligaments, (EaSab,) of the horse: or this signifies the bones of the side: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) and has for its pl. ruSufN, like kutubN [as pl. of kitaAbN]. (K.)

raSaAfapN * inf. n. of raSufa. [q. v]. (K.) ― -b2- Alr~aSaAfapu bAli$~aYo'i signifies The being gentle (Alr~ifoqu) with the thing: and [hence] it is said in a trad., walamo yakuno binaA minohaA ↓ lanaA EimaAdN A^aroSafa [And no stay, or support, to us was more gentle, or convenient, (A^arofaqa,) to us than she, or it]: no verb thereof [in this sense] has been transmitted. (M.)
ruSaAfapN * : see raSafapN.
riSaAfapN * : see raSafapN.
ruSuwfapN * : see raSafapN.
A^aroSafu * [i. q. A^arofaqu]: see raSaAfapN.
maroSuwfN * : see raSiyfN, in two places. ― -b2- maroSuwfapN, applied to a woman: see raSuwfN.

miroSaAfapN *
i. q. miToraqapN [q. v.]: (O, K:) because the thing hammered, or beaten, is joined, and made to cohere, therewith. (O.)

murotaSifu AlA^asonaAni * A man having the teeth near
together. (O, K.) See also raSiyfN. ― -b2- AlmurotaSifu The lion. (IKh, O, K.) [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 raSuna * , (S, M, K,) inf. n. raSaAnapN, (S, M,) It (a thing, M, or a building, TA) was, or became, firm, stable, strong, solid, compact, or sound. (S, M, * K. *) ― -b2- Also, said of a man, i. q. razuna (assumed tropical:) [He was, or became, grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; and forbearing: still, or motionless: or firm, or sound, of judgment: wise, or sensible]. (M.) -A2- raSanahu, (As, S, M, K,) aor.
raSuna , inf. n. raSanN, (As, S,) He made it complete, entire, or perfect; (As, S, M, K;) namely, a thing. (As, S.) ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- And see 2, in two places. ― -b4- raSanahu bilisaAnihi, (S, K,) inf. n. raSonN, (S,) He reviled him, or vilified him. (S, K.)

2 rS~n Al$~aYo'a maEorifapF * , (K,) thus accord. to some copies of the S, (TA,) inf. n. taroSiynN; (K;) accord. to other copies of the S, ↓ raSana; (TA; [and accord. to the KL, the inf. n. of the verb in this sense, expl. by gAlb $dn, is raSonN;]) (assumed tropical:) He overcame the thing by knowledge: (S, K:) so says AZ: (S:) [accord. to the JM, ↓ raSanahu signifies He knew it: but] the reading in the K, with teshdeed, is confirmed by the saying of Z, in the A, that raS~ino liY h`*aA Alxabara means (tropical:) Verify thou for me, or to me, this information; syn. Haq~iqohu; a tropical phrase. (TA.)

4 ArSnhu *
He made it, or rendered it, firm, stable, strong, solid, compact, or sound; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ raSanahu; namely, a thing. (TA.) You say, A^uroSina AlbinaA='u The building was made, or rendered, firm, stable, &c. (TA.) And A_i*aA Eamilota EamalFA faA^aroSinohu (tropical:) When thou doest a deed, do it soundly, thoroughly, skilfully, judiciously, or well. (TA.)

raSiynN *
Firm, stable, strong, solid, compact, or sound; (S, M, K;) applied to a thing: (M:) and ↓ muroSanN and ↓ maroSuwnN, made, or rendered, firm, stable, strong, &c. (TA.) You say diroEN raSiynN A coat of mail firmly, strongly, or compactly, made. (TA.) And ↓ binaA='N muroSanN A building made, or rendered, firm, stable, strong, &c. (TA.) And rajulN lahu raA^oYN raSiynN (assumed tropical:) [A man having firm, or sound, judgment]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a man, i. q. raziynN (assumed tropical:) [Grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; and forbearing: still, or motionless: or firm, or sound, of judgment: wise, or sensible]. (M.) ― -b3- fulAnN raSiynN biHaAjatika (assumed tropical:) Such a one is gracious, or knowing and gracious, with respect to thy want; or mindful, regardful, or considerate, thereof; syn. HafiY~N bihaA. (S, K. *) ― -b4- raSiynN also signifies Pained, or suffering pain: (S, K:) so in the saying of a poet,
yaquwlu A_in~iY raSiynu Aljuwofi faA@soquwniY
[He says, or he saying, Verily I am suffering pain of the belly, or chest, therefore give ye me to drink]. (S.) -A2- What are termed Alr~aSiynaAni, (S,) or raSiynaA Alfarasi, (K,) are The [two] extremities of the qaSab [or round and hollow bones, meaning here of the arms, (in one of my copies of the S, erroneously, of the EaSab, or sinews,)] that are set in, or upon, the raDofap [n. un. of raDofN, which is evidently the correct reading, meaning the bones that are between the arm and the shank], in the knee. (S, K.)
muroSanN * : see the paragraph next preceding, in two places.

miroSanN *
An iron instrument with which beasts (dawaAb~) are cauterized. (K.)

maroSuwnu * : see raSiynN. ― -b2- saAEidN maroSuwnN [A fore arm, or an upper arm, of a man, or a fore shank, or an arm, of a beast, (for sAEd has all these meanings,)] marked with a hot iron; syn. mawosuwmN. (K.)

1 raD~ahu * , (S, A, Msb,) aor.
raDu3a , (Msb,) inf. n. raD~N, (S, A, Msb, K,) He bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed, it: (IF, A, Msb, K:) or it signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (K,) he bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed, it coarsely, not finely; (S, K;) as also ↓ raDoraDahu: (TA:) or he broke it; (Msb, TA;) and so ↓ the latter verb. (S, K, TA.) You say, Darabahu faraD~a EiZaAmahu He beat him, and crushed his bones. (A.) And samiEotu bimaA nazala bika fafat~a kabidiY waraD~a EiZaAmiY (tropical:) [I heard of what befell thee, and it crumbled my liver and crushed my bones]. (A, TA.)

4 ArD~ * , (S, K,) inf. n. A_iroDaADN, (TA,) He (a man, S) was, or became, heavy and slow. (S, K.) And He ran vehemently. (ISk, K.) Thus it has two contr. significations. (K.) And ArD~ fiY AlA^aroDi He went away into the country, or in the land; syn. *ahaba [q. v.]. (ISk, TA.) ― -b2- ArD~t Alr~aviyoy^apu, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) The [milk termed] rvyy^p became thick. (S, K.) -A2- ArD~ AlEaraqa It (fatigue, TA, or food or drink, AZ, K) made the sweat to flow. (AZ, * K, * TA.)
5 taraD~a3a see the next paragraph.

8 ArtD~ *
It (a thing) broke, or became broken, in pieces; (TA;) and ↓ trD~D signifies [the same; or] it became broken, bruised, or brayed; (KL;) [and so, accord. to some, ↓ taraDoraDa: for you say,] HijaArapN tataraDoraDu EalaY wajohi AlA^aroDi, meaning Stones that break in pieces upon the surface of the earth; (S, K; *) as some say: but others say that this means stones that move about, without stopping, upon the surface of the earth. (TA.)

R. Q. 1
see 1, above, in two places.

R. Q. 2
see 8.

raD~N *
Dates bruised, or brayed, (S,) or freed from the stones, (K,) or bruised, or brayed, and freed from the stones, (TA,) and steeped in unmixed milk; (S, K, TA;) as also ↓ muriD~apN and ↓ miraD~apN: (K:) or dry dates bruised, or brayed, and thrown into fresh milk; as also ↓ raDiyDN (A.)

ruDaADN *
Fragments, or broken particles, (S, IF, Msb,) of a thing: (S:) what is bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed; or bruised, &c., coarsely; of a thing. (IDrd, K.)

raDiyDN *
Bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed: (K:) bruised, &c., coarsely: as also ↓ muroDuwDN. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also raD~N.
raDoraDN * : see what next follows.

raDoraADN *
Pebbles: (IDrd, A, K:) or small pebbles: (A, K:) as also ↓ raDoraDN, (K,) which is a contraction of the former: (TA:) or bruised, or crushed, pebbles. (S.) Hence the saying nahorN *uw siholapK wa*uw raDoraADK A river, or channel, having a bed of sand upon which the water runs, and having bruised, or crushed, pebbles. (S.) Or raDoraADN signifies Hard, smooth stones. (Kr, L.) And with p, Stones that break in pieces, or that move about without stopping, upon the surface of the earth. (TA.) ― -b2- Land broken up (↓ maroDuwDapN) with stones. (IAar, S, K.) -A2- Small drops of rain. (AA, K.) -A3- Fleshy; having much flesh; applied to a man; (S, K;) and to a camel: (S:) fem. with p; applied to a woman. (S, K.) ― -b2- kafalN raDoraADN Buttocks that quiver (K, TA) in walking. (TA.)
raDaAriDu * Pasturing beasts that crush the herbage in eating: (TA:) or camels pasturing at pleasure; as though they crushed the herbage. (S, TA.)

A^araD~u *
Always sitting still, not quitting his place. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

muriD~apN * : see raD~N. ― -b2- Also Thick [milk such as is termed] raviyoy^ap; i. e. fresh milk upon which sour milk is poured, and which is then left awhile, whereupon there comes forth from it a thin yellow fluid, which is poured from it, and the thick is drunk: (S:) or fresh milk drawn from the udder upon sour milk; or before it has become mature: (TA:) or fresh milk poured upon milk that has been collected in a skin: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or, as described to ISk by one of the Benoo-'Ámir, very sour milk, that causes the man who has drunk it to arise in the morning languid, or loose in the joints. (TA.) ― -b3- And A food, or a drink, that causes the sweat of him who has eaten it, or drunk it, to flow. (AZ, K, TA.) In this explanation, raD~ato is put in [some copies of] the K instead of A^araD~ato in the explanation given by AZ. (TA.) -A2- Also A mare that runs vehemently. (AO, TA.)

miraD~apN *
A thing with which one bruises, brays, pounds, or crushes; or with which one bruises, &c., coarsely. (TA.) [And particularly what is termed in Latin Tribulum; (Golius, on the authority of Meyd;) i. e. a kind of drag used for the purpose of separating the grain of wheat and barley &c. and of cutting the straw; more commonly called nawrajN (q. v.) and midorasN and jarojarN.] -A2- See also raD~N.
maroDuwDN * : see raDiyDN; and raDoraADN.

1 raDaba riyqahaA * , (A, K,) aor.
raDuba , (A, TA,) inf. n. raDobN, (TA,) He sucked in, or gently sucked or drew in with his lips, her (a girl's, or young woman's, TA) saliva; (A, K, TA;) as also ↓ trD~bihA, (A,) or riyqahaA ↓ trD~b. (K.) ― -b2- And raDaba AlmaTaru The rain poured vehemently, or abundantly and extensively; (K, TA;) as also ↓ ArDb, inf. n. A_iroDaAbN. (TA.) And raDabati Als~amaA='u The sky poured incessantly with rain in large drops. (AA, TA.) ― -b3- raDubN is also used as a verb, [meaning an inf n. of raDaba signifying It (dew) fell, or formed, in distinct particles upon the trees,] from ruDaAbN applied to dew. (TA.) -A2- raDabati Al$~aApu i. q. rabaDat, [q. v., app. formed from the latter by transposition,] (K,) but seldom used. (TA.)
4 A^aroDaba see the preceding paragraph.
5 taraD~aba see 1, in two places.
raDabapN * : see raADabN.

ruDaAbN *
Saliva; syn. riyqN: (S:) or saliva (ryq) that is sucked in, or gently sucked or drawn in with the lips; (L, K;) as when a man kisses a girl: (L:) or what one so sucks or draws in, of his own saliva: (L:) or what forms into little bubbles, of saliva, and spreads, or becomes scattered, or sprinkled; what flows being termed buzaAq: (TA:) or particles of saliva in the mouth: (K:) or, as some say, the separation of saliva into distinct particles, and abundance of the water of the teeth: but of each of the last two explanations, AM [or, I believe, ISd] says, "I know not how this is." (TA.) ― -b2- Sweet water. (TA.) ― -b3- Froth of honey. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Particles of dew upon trees. (K) ― -b5- Particles of snow, of hail, and of sugar. (K.) ― -b6- Particles of musk: (K:) or so ruDaAbu misokK. (TA.)

raADibN *
Vehement, or abundant and extensive, rain: (S, K:) or rain pouring incessantly, in large drops. (AA, TA.) -A2- Also A species of the [lote-tree called] sidor: (S, K:) one of which is called raADibapN, [with respect to which it is a coll. gen. n.,] and ↓ raDabapN, (K,) with respect to which latter, if this be correct, it is a quasi-pl. n. (TA.)
maraADibu * [in the TK maraADiybu] Sweet salivæ. (K, TA.)

1 raDaHa * , aor.
raDaHa , (L, Msb, K,) inf. n. raDoHN, (S, L, Msb,) He broke, (S, L, Msb, K,) and bruised, brayed, or crushed, (Msb, TA,) pebbles, (S, K,) or date-stones, (S, L, Msb, K,) &c., (Msb,) with a stone [&c.]; (L;) like raDaxa, (S, Msb,) which is a dial. var. (Msb.) And He broke, (Msb, TA,) or bruised, (TA,) a person's head (Msb, TA) with a stone; (TA;) as also raDaxa. (Msb, TA.)

5 trD~H * (S, K) and ↓ ArtDH (L) It (a pebble, S, K, and a date-stone, L, K) became broken, (S, L, K,) [or bruised, brayed, or crushed,] with a stone [&c.]. (L.) Jirán-el-' Owd says,
yakaAdu AlHaSaY mino waToy^ihaA yataraD~aHu
[The pebbles almost became broken by her tread]. (S.)

8 A_irotaDaHa see the next preceding paragraph. -A2- ArtDH mino ka*aA He excused himself, or he urged, or showed, or manifested, an excuse, for such a thing; or he asserted himself to be clear thereof. (K.)

raDoHN * inf. n. of 1. (S, L, Msb.) [Hence,] nawaY Alr~aDoHi Date-stones that fall out from others [in the operation of breaking or bruising]. (S, K.) And ↓ raDoHapN A date-stone that flies from beneath the stone [called miroDaAH]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, [or perhaps more properly with x,] A small gift. (TA.) ― -b3- And A little of news or tidings. (TA.)

ruDoHN * is a subst. from raDaHa; and [as such, as is implied, or rather indicated, in the S,] signifies Broken [or bruised, brayed, or crushed,] datestones; i. q. ↓ nawFY maroDuwHN; (S, K;) as also ↓ raDiyHN [i. e. nawFY raDiyHN]. (K.) [See also raDiyxN, with x.]
raDoHapN * : see raDoHN.
raDiyHN * : see ruDoHN.

raD~aAHN * [That breaks, or bruises, pebbles &c. much or vehemently]. Abu-n-Nejm says,
bikul~i waA^obK liloHaSaY raD~aAHi
layosa bimuSoTar~K walaA firo$aAHi
[With every strong hoof, that breaks the pebbles much or vehemently, that is not contracted, or immoderately narrow, nor spreading]. (S.)
miroDaHapN * The thing with which date-stones are broken, or bruised, brayed, or crushed, to serve as provender [for camels]. (R, TA.) [See also what next follows.]

miroDaAHN * The stone with which date-stones are broken [or bruised or brayed or crushed, to serve as food for camels]: (S, K:) miroDaAxN [q. v.] is a dial. var. of weak authority. (TA.) [See also what next precedes.]
maroDuwHN * : see ruDoHN.
See what is said at the end of the next art.

1 raDaxa * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
raDaxa (A, Msb, K) and
raDixa , (K,) inf. n. raDoxN, (JK, S, Msb,) He broke, (JK, S, Msb, K,) and bruised, brayed, or crushed, (Msb, TA,) pebbles, (S, K,) and date-stones, (S, Msb, TA,) and a bone, (TA,) and other things, (Msb, TA,) of such as were dry, (TA,) or datestones and the like; (JK;) like raDaHa; (S Msb;) as also ↓ rD~x [app. in an intensive sense]. (A.) He broke (S A, Mgh, Msb) another's head, (Mgh, Msb,) or the head of a serpent, (S, TA,) &c., (TA,) with stones; (S, TA;) as also ↓ rD~x [app. in an intensive sense]. (A.) And raDaxati Alt~uyuwsu The he-goats betook themselves to striking one another with their horns, (JK, K, TA,) so that some of them broke the heads of others. (TA.) And raA^ayotuhumo yaroDaxuwna Alxuboza and ↓ yuraD~ixuwnahu I saw them breaking in pieces the bread and eating it: (A:) and ↓ Zal~uwA yataraD~axuwna [i. e. They passed the time, or the day-time,] breaking in pieces bread and eating it and taking it with their hands: (TA:) and ↓ kun~aA nataraD~axu We were eating. (JK.) ― -b2- raDaxa bihi AlA^aroDa means jaladahu bihaA [app. for jalada bihi AlA^aroDa, i. e. He threw him, or it, down upon the ground]. (JK, K.) ― -b3- raDaxa lahu, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and raDaxahu, (S, Msb,) aor.
raDaxa , (Msb,) inf. n. raDoxN, (S, Msb,) He gave him what was not much; (S, Msb, K;) he gave him little; (A, Mgh, TA;) mino maAlihi of his property: (TA:) and raDaxotu lahumo mino maAliY raDoxapF [I gave them, of my property, a small gift]: (A:) and lilr~ajuli ↓ A^aroDaxotu [if not a mistranscription for raDaxotu] I gave the man a little out of much. (TA.) A^amarotu lahu biraDoxK waraDaxotuhu [I ordered the giving of a small gift to him, or I ordered a small gift to him, and I gave him a small gift] occurs in a tradition. (S.)
2 raD~axa see above, in three places.

3 rADxhu * , (S, L, K,) inf. n. muraADaxapN, (L,) He engaged with him in throwing stones, each at the other; (AAF, S, L, K;) so that each broke the other's head: (AAF, L:) or, accord. to ElKhattábee and IAth and others, he engaged with him in the shooting of arrows, each at the other: but AAF questions the correctness of this latter explanation, preferring the former. (L.) [See, however, 6.] ― -b2- And rADx $ayoy^FA, (JK, L, K,) inf. n. as above, (L,) He gave a thing unwillingly. (JK, L, K.) ― -b3- And raADaxonaA minohu $ayoy^FA We obtained of him, or it, something. (JK, L.)
4 A^aroDaxa see 1, last sentence but one.

5 taraD~axa see 1, in two places. ― -b2- You say also, humo yataraD~axuwna Alxabara [They hear the news, but are not sure of it, or are not acquainted with it clearly, or plainly]: from raDoxN in the last of the senses explained below. (K, * TA.)

6 trADxnA *
We cast, or shot, one at another; syn. taraAmayonaA: (S, K:) or taraADuxN signifies a people's shooting arrows, one at another: (JK, TA:) and trADxnA biAls~ihaAmi We shot, one at another, with arrows: (TA:) and humo yataraADaxuwna biAln~u$~aAbi They shoot, one at another, with arrows. (A.)

8 huwa yarotaDixu lukonapF Eajamiy~apF * [He has a foreign vitiousness of speech; or] he, having grown up among foreigners, (K, TA,) a little while, (TA,)
and then become a dweller among the Arabs, inclines to, or resembles, foreigners, in certain words, or expressions, though he strive [to do otherwise, or to speak correctly]. (K, TA.)

raDoxN * , (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) originally an inf. n., used as a subst. [properly so termed]; or of the measure faEolN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, like Darobu AlA^amiyri [applied to a dirhem]; (Msb;) [app., in its primary acceptation when thus used, A fragment: for] you say, Einodahu raDoxN mino xubozK [He has a fragment of bread]: (A: [so in a copy of that work; and this is agreeable with significations of raDaxa: or the right reading may be xabarK: (see the last sentence in this paragraph:) or it may be that which here next follows:]) Einodahu raDoxu xayorK He has somewhat of good, or of good things. (Msb.) Also A small gift; (S, * L, Msb, TA;) and so ↓ raDoxapN (JK, A, [in my copy of the Mgh, erroneously, raDixapN,]) and ↓ raDiyxapN (Mgh, L) and ↓ ruDaAxapN: (L:) or a moderate gift, neither good nor bad; and so ↓ raDiyxapN: (L:) and a small gift, less than one's share, of booty. (Mgh, * MF.) ― -b2- Also, [or raDoxN mino xabarK,] News, or tidings, (K,) or a little thereof, (TA,) which one hears, but of which one is not sure, or with which one is not clearly, or plainly, acquainted: (K, accord. to different copies, and TA:) in some copies of the K, in the place of tasotayoqinuhu, we find tasotabiynuhu. (TA.)
raDoxapN * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- One says also, waqaEato raDoxapN mino maTarK (JK, A) A small quantity of rain fell: (JK:) pl. riDaAxN. (JK, A. *)
raDiyxN * [or nawFY raDiyxN] and ↓ maroDuwxN Bruised, or crushed, date-stones, [with which camels are fed, and] which are first moistened with water. (L in art. Hfd.) [See also ruDoHN, with H.]
ruDaAxapN * : see raDoxN.
raDiyxapN * : see raDoxN, in two places.
miroDaxapN * : see what next follows.

miroDaAxN *
A stone with which, (K, and Ham p. 615,) or upon which, (Ham,) date-stones are broken [or bruised or crushed; to serve as food for camels]; (K, Ham;) as also ↓ miroDaxapN: pl. maraADaxu: (TA:) but miroDaAxN is [said to be] a dial. var. of weak authority, of miroDaAHN. (TA in art. rDH.)
maroDuwxN * : see raDiyxN. It is allowable to substitute H for x in the words of this art., except in those relating to eating and giving. (L.)

1 raDiEa A^um~ahu * , aor.
raDaEa ; and raDaEa, aor.
raDiEa ; (S, Msb, * K;) the former of the dial. of Tihámeh; (O, L;) the latter of the dial. of Nejd; (S, O, L;) or the former of the dial. of Nejd; and the latter of the dial. of Tihámeh, and used by the people of Mekkeh; (Msb;) and raDaEa, (Msb,) i. e. raDaEa vadoYa A^um~ihi, (IKtt, TA,) aor.
raDaEa ; (IKtt, Msb;) inf. n. raDaAEN, (S, Msb, K,) of the first, (S, TA,) or of the third, (Msb,) and riDaAEN, (K,) [which is also an inf. n. of 3,] and raDaEN, (Msb, K,) of the first, (Msb, TA,) and raDoEN, (S, Msb, K,) of the second, (S, Msb,) and raDiEN, (Msb, K,) said by some to be the original form of the inf. n. of the second, (Msb,) and raDaAEapN, (Msb, K,) of the third, (Msb,) and riDaAEapN; (K;) or the last two are simple substs. form raDaAEN; (IAth;) said of a child; (S, Msb;) He sucked the breast of his mother; (K;) and ↓ ArtDE signifies the same. (Msb, TA.) You say, h`*aA A^axiY mina Alr~aDaAEapi [This is my foster-brother]; and h`*aA raDiyEiY. (S, K. *) The saying, in a trad., Alr~aDaAEapu mina AlmajaAEapi, and Alr~iDaAEapu, means The sucking which occasions interdiction of marriage [with the woman whose milk is sucked and certain of her relations] is that of an infant when hungry; not of a child that is grown up: (IAth:) or that consequent upon hunger which is stopped by the milk in the time of infancy of the child; not when the child's hunger is only to be stopped by solid food. (Mgh in art. jwE.) You also say, of a man, yaroDaEu A_ibilahu (S, K) and ganamahu (S) [He sucks the teats of his camels and of his ewes or she-goats, by reason of his sordidness: see raADiEN]. ― -b2- raDiEa All~uw^oma mino vadoYi A^um~ihi (tropical:) [He sucked meanness, sordidness, or ignobleness, from the breast of his mother]; (K;) i. e. he was born in meanness, sordidness, or ignobleness. (TA.) ― -b3- yaroDaEu Aln~aAsa (assumed tropical:) He begs of men; (K, TA;) asks gifts of them. (TA.) So, accord. to IAar, in the saying of Jereer,
wayaroDaEu mano laA qaY waA_ino yara muqoEadFA
yaquwdu biA^aEomaY faA@lofarazodaqu saAy^luho
[And he begs of him whom he meets; and if he see a cripple leading a blind person, El-Farezdak asks of him]: but [properly speaking] the muqEad is one who cannot stand, so as to lead the blind. (TA.) ― -b4- huwa yaroDaEu Ald~unoyaA waya*um~uhaA (tropical:) [He sucks the sweets of the present world, and dispraises it]. (TA.) -A2- raDuEa, (S, Z, K,) with damm, as though what the verb denotes were natural to the person of whom it is said, (S, TA,) or the verb has this form because it is changed in meaning so as to be intensive, (Z, TA,) aor.
raDuEa ; and raDaEa, aor.
raDiEa ; (Ibn- 'Abbád, K;) inf. n., (Z, K,) of the former verb, (Z, TA,) raDaAEapF, (Z, K,) with fet- h only; (IAth, TA;) (tropical:) He (a man, S) was, or became, mean, sordid, or ignoble: (S, * K, TA:) or he was, or became, very mean, &c.: (Z, TA:) [see raADaEN:] or one says, law^uma waraDuEa, for the sake of mutual resemblance; and the meaning is, [he was, or became, mean, sordid, or ignoble, and] he sucked from the teat of the she-camel, fearing lest, if he milked, any one should know of his doing so, and demand of him somewhat. (Msb.) -A3- raDaEato A^alobaAnuhaA (tropical:) Their milk became little in quantity; said in reference to milch-camels abounding with milk. (TA. [But the context in the TA suggests that this is a mistake; that the phrase is said of the wind called raDaAEapN; and that the right reading is raDaEato A^alobaAnahaA; and the meaning, (assumed tropical:) It rendered their milk little in quantity.])

3 rADEhu * , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. muraADaEapN and riDaAEN (Msb, K, TA) and also riDaAEapN, (Msb,) [but this last is anomalous, and, if correct, is probably a simple subst.,] He sucked with him; or had him sucking with him; (Msb, * K, * TA;) he had him as his raDiyE [or foster-brother]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] bayonahumaA riDaAEu AlkaA^osi (tropical:) [Between them two is the sipping of the wine-cup, or cup of wine]. (TA.) ― -b3- muraADaEapN also signifies An infant's sucking the breast of his mother while she has a child in her belly. (K.) -A2- rADE A@bonahu He gave, or delivered, his son to the woman who should suckle him. (S, K.) [See also 4.]

4 A^aroDaEato *
She (a woman) had a child which she suckled. (K.) ― -b2- *aAtu A_iroDaAEK, also, signifies (assumed tropical:) Having milk, though not having a child that is suckled. (IB.) -A2- A^aroDoEatohu A^um~uhu His mother suckled him. (S, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- You say also, A^aroDaEa Alwalada [app. meaning He caused the child to be suckled: or, perhaps, he suckled the child, by means of his wife or a female slave; because his semen genitale is considered as the source of the milk of a woman who has borne him a child; accord. to a saying of Lth, cited in an explanation of a usage of the word laqaAHN or liqaAHN]. (K voce malaHa, q. v.) [See also 3.]

6 trADEA *
They both sucked the breast of a woman together; each with the other. (TA.)

8 ArtDE * : see 1; first sentence. ― -b2- ArtDEt AlEanozu The she-goat drank [or sucked] her own milk [from her udder]. (S, K.) ― -b3- Hence AirotiDaAEu AlkaA^osi (assumed tropical:) The drinking [of the cup] of wine. (Har p. 284: [See also 3.])

10 AstrDE *
He sought, or demanded, a wetnurse. (K.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 233], waA_ino A^aradotumo A^ano tasotaroDiEuwA A^awolaAdakumo And if ye desire to seek, or demand, wet-nurses for your children; i. e., An tstrDEwA AwlAdkm maraADiEa; the second objective complement [accord. to this order of the words], but the first in reality because the wetnurse is the agent with respect to the child, being suppressed; for you say, AisotaroDaEotu AlmaroA^apa waladiY, meaning I sought, or demanded, of the woman that she should suckle my child: (IB:) accord. to some, the verb is doubly trans.: accord. to others, the prep. li is suppressed in the Kur; the meaning being liA^awolaAdikumo. (El-Howfee, in the “ Burhán fee tefseer-el-Kur-án. ”)

riDoEN *
A kind of trees upon which camels feed. (O, K.)

raDaEN * The young ones [or suckers] of palmtrees; (IAar, K;) as also raSaEN, (K,) accord. to Lth and IDrd and the S; (TA in art. rSE;) or the latter, accord. to Az, is a mistranscription: (K * and TA in that art.:) n. un. with p. (TA.) -A2- (tropical:) Meanness, sordidness, or ignobleness; a subst. from raDuEa; as also ↓ raDiEN. (K.)
raDiEN * : see raADiEN, in two places: -A2- : and see raDaEN.

raDiyEN *
A foster-brother; syn. ↓ muraADaEN: pl. ruDaEaA='u (TA.) You say, h`*aA raDiyEiY, (S, Msb, * K, *) i. e. h`*aA A^axiY mina Alr~aDaAEapi [This is my foster-brother]. (S, K. *) ― -b2- [A child while it is a suckling;] a child before it is termed faTiymN [i. e. weaned]. (IAar, TA in art. Tbx. [See also raADaEN.]) [In explanations of the words waTobN and $akowapN in the S, it is applied as an epithet to a kid, evidently as meaning Sucking; or a suckling; like raADiEN, q. v., and raDiEN.] ― -b3- See two other significations, voce raADagN, in two places.

raDaAEapN * , said in the K to be an inf. n. of 1 in the first of the senses explained in this art., is, accord. to IAth, a simple subst. (TA.) ― -b2- [It is a regular inf. n. of raDuEa, q. v.] -A2- Alr~aDaAEapu also signifies (tropical:) The [west wind, or westerly wind, called] dabuwr: or a wind between that and the [south wind, or southerly wind, called] januwb: (IDrd, K, TA:) because, when it blows upon the milch-camels abounding with milk, their milk becomes little in quantity. (IDrd, TA.)

riDaAEapN * , said in the K to be an inf. n. of 1 in the first of the senses expl. in this art., is, accord. to IAth, a simple subst. (TA.) ― -b2- [It is also said, in the Msb, to be an inf. n. of raADaEahu, q. v.]
raDuwEapN * A female that suckles her young: (TA:) or a ewe or she-goat that suckles, or that has a young one which she suckles. (AO, S, K.)
raD~aAEN * : see the next paragraph.

raADaEN *
Sucking the breast of his mother; a suckling; as also ↓ raDiEN: pl. of the former ruD~aEN; and of the latter; ruDuEN. (K. [See also raDiyEN, which signifies the same; as is shown below, voce muroDiEN; and by Bd in xxii. 2; &c.]) ― -b2- One who sucks from the teat of the she-camel, fearing lest, if he milked, any one should know of his doing so, and demand of him somewhat: (Msb:) or a pastor who does not take with him a milkingvessel, and, when he is asked for milk, excuses himself on that ground, (K, TA,) and, when he desires to drink, sucks the teat of his milchbeast: (TA:) pl. ruD~aEN. (Msb.) The phrase lay^iymN raADiEN [i. e. Mean, sordid, or ignoble; who sucks the teats of his she-camels, &c.,] originated, (S, K,) as they assert, (S,) from a certain man's sucking the teats of his she-camels (S, K) or ewes or she-goats, and not milking them, (S,) lest the sound of his milking should be heard and somewhat should be demanded of him: (S, K:) or the origin was the coming of a guest by night to a certain man of the Amalekites, whereupon the latter sucked the udder of his ewe, lest the guest should hear the sound of the streaming of the milk from the teat. (IDrd.) But when a single epithet is used, one says ↓ raDiyEN. (Msb. [See, however, what follows.]) ― -b3- [Hence,] (tropical:) Mean, sordid, or ignoble; (K, TA;) as also ↓ raDiyEN and ↓ raD~aAEN: pl. ruD~aEN and ruD~aAEN: (K:) and raDiEuwna, as a pl., [i. e. pl. of ↓ raDiEN,] has the same signification, of mean, &c. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Selemeh Ibn-El-Akwa', Alyuwoma yuwomu Alr~uD~aEi, meaning (tropical:) To-day is the day of the destruction of the mean, &c. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (tropical:) Mean, sordid, or ignoble, who has sucked meanness, sordidness, or ignobleness, from the breast of his mother; (ElYemámee, K, TA;) i. e. born in meanness, sordidness, or ignobleness. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A beggar: (TA:) one who begs of men: (K:) thus Ibn-'Abbád explains lay^iymN raADiEN. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) One who eats the particles of food remaining between his teeth, lest anything [thereof] should escape him: (K:) or such is termed lay^iymN raADiEN. (TA.) -A2- A possessor of milk: after the usual manner of a possessive epithet [like laAbinN]. (TA.)

raADiEapN *
A central incisor when it falls out: (Msb:) or the raADiEataAni are the two central incisors (S, Msb, K, TA) of a child, (S K, TA,) over which the milk is drunk [or sucked]: (Msb, TA:) pl. rawaADaEu: (S, Msb, K:) or the rawaADiE are the teeth of a child that grow and then fall out in the period of sucking; (Msb, * TA;) and they are said to be six in the upper part of the mouth and six in its lower part: (TA:) [the pl. is applied to all the milk-teeth of a child, and of a horse &c.; it applies to the teeth called rabaAEiyaAt that fall out, as well as to the vanaAyaA, or central incisors, accord. to AO, in a passage relating to a colt, in his ktAb Alxyl quoted in the TA in art. Hfr; and to the teeth called qawaAriH that fall out, accord. to a passage in the S, voce A^aHofara, q. v., as well as the extract from the work of AO mentioned above, and in this case likewise relating to a colt.]
maroDaEN * The breast, as being the place of sucking: pl. maraADiEu. (Ksh and Bd in xxviii. 11.) ― -b2- And [as an inf. n.] The act of sucking the breast: pi. as above. (Ksh and Bd ibid.)

muroDaEN *
Suckled: pl. maraADaEu; which is opposed to fuTumN, pl. of faTiymN. (Mgh.)

muroDiEN * and muroDaEapN A mother [or other woman] suckling: (Msb:) or one having with her a child which she suckles: the former epithet may with reason be applied to the mother because suckling is performed only by females, like as the epithets HaAy^iDN and TaAmivN are applied to a woman; and if muroDaEapN were applied to her who has with her a child, it would be correct: (Fr, TA:) [but see another saying ascribed to Fr in what follows:] or the former, a woman having a child which she suckles; (Kh, S, IB, K;) after the manner of a possessive epithet; (IB;) i. e. having a raDiyE; (Kh, IB;) like AimoraA^apN muTofilN “ a woman having a Tifol; ” (Kh;) or ZaboyapN mu$odinN “ a doe-gazelle having a $aAdin; ” though muroDiEN has a verb bearing a signification agreeing with this; and it sometimes occurs as meaning having milk, though not having a child that is suckled: (IB:) but the latter is used in describing a woman as performing an action; (Kh;) signifying suckling a child: (S, K:) the former is used when the [abstract] quality is meant: the latter, when the action is meant: but God knows: (Akh:) or the former signifies one who is near to suckling, but has not yet suckled: and one having with her the child that is suckled [by her] (AlS~abiY~u Alr~aDiyEu): and the latter, [in the TA the former, but this is a mistranscription, as is shown by what follows,] one who is suckling, her teat being in the mouth of her child; and in this sense it is used in the Kur, in a passage which see below: (AZ in the TA:) Th says, the latter signifies one who suckles, though she have not a child, or if she have a child: and the former, one who has not a child with her, and sometimes having with her a child: and in one place he says, when the action is meant, the latter is used, and it is made an epithet: and when the p is not added, it is meant as a subst: (TA:) Fr and some others say that it is without p when the proper signification of suckling is meant: and with p when the tropical signification of a subject of the attribute of suckling in time past or future is meant: (Msb:) the pl. [of both, though said in the Mgh and TA to be that of the former,] is maraADiEu (Mgh, Msb, TA) and maraADiyEu. (Msb, TA.) The saying in the Kur [xxii. 2], yawoma tarawonahaA ta*ohalu kul~u muroDiEapK Eam~aA A^aroDaEato means [On the day when ye shall see it,] every woman that is suckling;, (AZ, Kh,) in the act of doing so, (Kh,) with her teat in the mouth of her child; (AZ,) [shall neglect, or become heedless of or diverted from, that which she shall have been suckling:] or mrDEp here has the last signification explained in the preceding sentence [so that the meaning is every woman who shall have been suckling or shall be going to suckle]. (Msb.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., niEomati AlmuroDiEapu wabiy^osati AlfaATimapu, meaning (assumed tropical:) Excellent in the office of commander, or governor, and the profit, or advantage, which it brings to its possessor; and very evil is death, which destroys his delights, or pleasures, and stops the profits, or advantages, of that office. (TA.) ― -b3- The pl. maraADiyEu is metaphorically applied as an epithet to bees (jawaAris, i. e. naHol). (TA.)
muraADaEN * : see raDiyEN. ― -b2- Also An unborn child of a woman who is suckling another child: such a child proves to be meagre in body, slender in the bones, and ill nourished. (En-Nadr, Sgh.)

musotaroDaEN * [for musotaroDaEN lahu, agreeably with an opinion mentioned by El-Howfee, (see 10,) One for whom a wet-nurse has been sought, or demanded]. You say, fulaAnN AlmusotaroDaEu fiY baniY tamiymK [Such a one is he for whom a wet-nurse has been sought, or demanded, among the Benoo-Temeem]. (TA.)

1 raDafahu * , aor.
raDifa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. raDofN, (Msb,) He cauterized him, or it, (namely, a thing, Msb,) with a heated stone. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And He roasted it (namely, flesh-meat,) upon heated stones. (Msb.) And Az says, rub~amaA raDafati AlEarabu AlmaA='i biAlr~aDofi liloxayoli [Sometimes, or often, the Arabs heated, or warmed, water with heated stones for the horses]. (O.) -A2- raDafa bisaloHihi He ejected his excrement, or thin excrement. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.) -A3- raDafa AlwisaAdapa He folded the pillow. (IDrd, O, K.)

raDofN *
Heated stones (S, O, Mgh, Msb, K) with which milk is made hot, or is made to boil; (S, O, K;) [and with which one cauterizes; and upon which flesh-meat is roasted; as shown above;] as also ↓ miroDaAfapN: (O, K:) n. un. with p. (S, O, Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a prov., xu*o mina Alr~aDofipi maA EalayohaA [Take thou from the heated stone what is upon it]: (S, O:) i. e. take thou what adheres, of the milk, to the heated stone when it is thrown, with others, therein, to make it hot, or to make it to boil: it is applied to the case of one's taking as spoil a thing from a niggard, though it be little, or paltry. (Meyd, O.) [Hence,] muTofiy^apu Alr~aDofi A piece of fat which, when it falls upon the heated stones, melts, and extinguishes their heat: and a serpent of which the poison, when it passes by the heated stones, extinguished their fire: (O, K:) and a lean sheep or goat, that puts out the fire and does not become thoroughly cooked: (M, L, K, all in art. Hds:) or a fat sheep or goat, that slakes the heated stones by its fat: (T and TA in that art.:) and (assumed tropical:) a calamity that makes one to forget that which was before it: (AO, O, K:) or simply (assumed tropical:) a calamity. (K in art. TfA^ [q. v.].) ― -b2- Also Certain bones in the knee, like fingers put together, holding together one another; (O, K;) above which is the daAgiSap [or patella]: (TA in art. dgS:) in a horse, what are between the shank and the arm: (En-Nadr, O, K:) they are certain small bones, places together, at the head of the upper part of the *rAE [app. a mistranscription for kuraAE, i. e. shank]: (En-Nadr, O:) one thereof is termed raDofapN and ↓ raDafapN. (O, K.)
raDofapN * n. un. of raDofN [q. v.]. (S, O, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] raDafaAtu AlEarabi an appellation of four [tribes of the Arabs], Sheybán and Teghlib and Bahrà and Iyád. (O, K.)

raDafapN *
A certain brand, or mark, made by burning the skin with [heated] stones. (Lth, O, K.) ― -b2- See also raDofN, last sentence.

raDiyfN *
Milk that is boiled by means of the heated stone [or stones]. (S, O, K.)
maroDuwfN * Roast meat roasted by means of heated stones: (S, O, K: *) and thoroughly cooked thereby. (K.)
mroDaAfapN * : see raDofN, first sentence.

maroDuwfapN *
A cooking-pot [in which the food is] thoroughly cooked by means of heated stones: (S:) or the stomach, or maw, of a ruminant animal, which is washed and cleansed, and carried in a journey; and when the people desire to cook, and there is no cooking-pot, they cut up the flesh-meat, and put it into the stomach, or maw, then they betake themselves to some stones, and kindle a fire upon them so that they become heated, whereupon they put them into the stomach, or maw. (O, K.) It occurs in the saying of ElKumeyt,
wamorDuwfapK lamo tuw^oni fiY AlT~aboxi TaAhiyFA
Eajilotu A_ilaY muHowar~ihaA Hiyna garogaraA
(S, O, K,) i. e. [Many a cooking-pot &c, or many a stomach, or maw, &c., has there been,] that did not impede nor delay [in the cooking the cook, to the whiteness of the froth whereof I have hastened when it made a sound in boiling, or broiling]. (S.) [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 raDiYa * is originally raDiwa; the w being changed into Y because of the kesreh: (S:) the tribe of Teiyi said raDaA for raDiYa. (IDrd in his lex., cited by Freytag; and Mughnee voce A_ilaY there said to be a dial. var. of raDiYa.) You say, raDiYa Eanohu, (S, M, Msb, K,) and Ealayohi, (M, Msb, K,) which is of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, (Msb,) the verb being thus made trans. by means of ElY, accord. to Ks, agreeably with the opinion of Sb respecting instances of this kind, for the purpose of making it to accord with its contr., saxiTa, (M, TA,) aor. yaroDaY, (K,) inf. n. riDFY (S, M, Msb, K) and ruDFY (M, K) and riDowaAnN and ruDowaAnN, (S, * M, Msb, * K,) the last of the dial. of Keys and Temeem, (Msb, TA,) and mentioned by Sb, (M, TA,) but all the readers of the Kur read rDwAn with kesr, except 'Ásim, who is related to have read it with damm, (T, TA,) and maroDaApN, (S, * M, K,) originally maroDawapN, (TA,) He was pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied, with him; regarded him with good will, or favour; or liked, or approved, him; (MA;) [i. e., as said above,] contr. of saxiTa; (M, Msb, K;) the object being a person: (Msb:) and Sb states that they also said raDoyuwA, with the medial radical quiescent, for raDuwA; but it is extr. (M, TA.) The saying in the Kur [v. last verse but one, and ix. 101, &c.] raDiYa A@ll~`hu Eanohumo waraDuwA Eanohu [God is well pleased with them and they are well pleased with Him] means God is well pleased with their deeds and they are well pleased with the recompense that He has bestowed upon them: (M, TA:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, riDaY AlEabodi Eani A@ll~`hi means The servant's, or man's, being not displeased with that which God's decree has made to happen to him; and riDaY A@ll~`hi Eini AlEabodi, God's seeing the servant, or man, to be obedient to that which He has commanded, and refraining from that which He has forbidden. (TA.) You say also, raDiytuhu, (S, Msb, K,) and raDiytu bihi, (M, Msb,) inf. n. riDFY (Msb, TA) [and ruDFY and riDowaAnN &c., as above]; and ↓ AirotaDayotuhu; (S, Msb;) I was pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied, with it; regarded it with good will, or favour; or liked, or approved, it: (MA: [for the verb is there said to have the same signification in the phrases raDiyahu and raDiYa bihi as it has in raDiYa Eanohu and Ealayohi; and ArtDAh is there similarly explained: and the like is implied in the S and K; and is evidently agreeable with general usage:]) or he chose it, or preferred it: (Msb, TA:) the object being a thing: (S, Msb, TA:) or (accord. to explanations of taroDaAhaA in the Kur ii. 139) I loved it, or liked it; (Ksh, Bd, Jel;) inclined to it; (Ksh;) had a desire for it. (Bd.) The saying of the lawyers, [respecting a woman whose consent to her marriage has been asked,] ya$ohadu EalaY riDaAhaA means It [i. e. her silence] testifies, or declares, her permission [or consent]; because permission indicates riDFY. (Msb.) You say also, raDiytu bihi SaAHibFA [I was pleased with him, or I liked him, or approved him, or chose him, or preferred him, as a companion]. (S.) And raDiyahu li*`lika AlA^amori, and ↓ ArtDAhu, [which may be well rendered He approved him for that thing, or affair,] meaning he saw him, or judged him, to be fit for that thing, or affair. (M.) And liSuHobatihi waxidomatihi ↓ ArtDAhu (K, TA) He [approved him, or] chose him, or preferred him; and saw him, or judged him, to be fit; for his companionship, and his service. (TA.) And ruDiyato maEy$atuhu [His living, or sustenance, was found pleasing, well pleasing, contenting, or satisfying; or was liked, or approved]: one should not say raDiyatp [in this case]. (S, K.) ― -b2- raDawotuhu, (S, M, K,) aor. A^aroDuwhu, (S, K,) signifies I surpassed him in riDFY [i. e. in being pleased, well pleased, content, &c.: see above, second sentence]: (S, * M, K *:) so in the saying, faraDawotuhu ↓ raADaAniY [He vied, or contended, with me in being pleased, well pleased, content, &c., and I surpassed him therein]: (S, M, K:) the inf. n. of rADAnY thus used is muraADaApN and riDaA='N; (M;) both these signify the same (K, TA) as inf. ns. of this verb. (TA.)
2 raD~awa see 4.
3 raAoDawa see 1, last sentence. ― -b2- rADayotuhu, inf. n. muraADaApN and riDaA='N, signifies [also] I agreed, consented, accorded, or was of one mind or opinion, with him. (Msb.)

4 ArDAhu * , (M, MA, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iroDaA='N, (Msb,) He, or it, made him to be pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied; (MA;) [he, or it, pleased, contented, or satisfied, him:] or he gave him that with which he would be pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied. (M, K: * in the former, A^aEoTaAhu maA yaroDaY bihi: in the latter, A^aEoTaAhu maA yuroDiyhi.) Hence, in the Kur [ix. 8], yuroDuwnakumo biA^afowaAhihimo wataA^obaY quluwbuhumo [They will please you, or content you, with their mouths, but their hearts will be incompliant]. (TA.) And A^aroDayotuhu Ean~iY, and ↓ raD~ayotuhu with teshdeed, [I made
him to be pleased, well pleased, content, &c., with me,] faraDiYa [and he was pleased, &c.]. (S.)

5 trD~Ahu *
He sought to please, content, or satisfy, him; (M, K;) as also ↓ AstrDAhu. (K.) A poet says,
A_i*aA AlEajuwzu gaDibato faTal~iqo
walaA taraD~aAhaA walaA tamal~aqo
[When the old woman is angry, then divorce thou; and seek not to please, or content, her, nor behave in a loving, or blandishing, or coaxing, manner]: he says taraD~aAhaA instead of taraD~ahaA to avoid what is termed xabonN; but some relate it in the manner better known, saying walaA taraD~ahaA. (M.) ― -b2- [Also] taraD~ayotuhu I pleased, contented, or satisfied, him (A^aroDayotuhu) after striving, labouring, or toiling. (S.)

6 taraADayaAhu * [They two agreed, consented, accorded, or were of one mind or opinion, respecting it; or were pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied, with it; they both liked it, or approved it]: (A, K:) and taraADayaA bihi [signifies the same]. (Bd in iv. 28.) And taraADawohu bayonahumo They agreed among themselves in being pleased, contented, or satisfied, with it; or in liking, or approving, it. (MA.) A_i*aA taraADawoA bayonahumo, in the Kur [ii. 232], means [When they agree, or consent, among themselves; or] when they are pleased, well pleased, content, &c., [among themselves,] every one of them with his [or her] companion. (TA.) Hence the trad., A_in~amaA AlbayoEu Eano taraADF [Sel-ling, or buying, is only resultant from mutual agreement, consent, or content, or approval]. (TA.) And you say, waqaEa bihi Alt~araADiY [Mutual agreement, or consent, to it, or mutual content with it, or mutual approval of it, happened, or took place]. (A, K. [In some copies of the K, by the omission of wa, this phrase is made to be as though it were meant as an explanation of taraADayaAhu.])
8 A_irotaDawa see 1, in three places.

10 AstrDAhu *
He asked, begged, or petitioned, of him that he would please, content, or satisfy, him, or that he would give him that with which he would be pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied. (Z, K.) You say, AisotaroDayotuhu faA^aroDaAniY [I asked, begged, or petitioned, of him that he would please me, &c., and he pleased me, &c.]. (S.) ― -b2- See also 5.

ruDFY *
A certain idol-temple, belonging to [the tribe of] Rabee'ah: (K:) whence they gave the name of Eabodu ruDFY [Servant of Rudà]. (TA.)

riDFY * is merely an inf. n., (S,) [as such] syn. with maroDaApN, (K,) meaning The being pleased, well pleased, content, &c.; [see 1;] contr. of saxaTN: (M:) and the simple subst. is ↓ riDaA='N, with medd.; [signifying a state of being pleased, &c.;] (Akh, S;) or the latter is only an inf. n. of 3, (M,) syn. with muraADaApN: (M, K:) [but] the former [is also used as a subst., signifying content, or approval: and permission, or consent: and] is dualized, app. as meaning the kind [or mode or manner, of being pleased, &c.]: (M:) the dual is riDawaAnK and riDayaAni: (S, M, K:) Ks heard riDawaAni and HamawaAni as duals of riDFY and HimFY; and says that the proper way is to say riDayaAni and HimayaAni, [which in the case of the former is strange, as its final radical is w,] but that the pronunciation with w is the more common: (S:) and accord. to some, maraADK is an irreg. pl. of riDFY; but others say that it is pl. of maroDaApN. (TA.) You say, maA faEalotuhu Eino riDaAhu and riDowatihi: see the latter, below. (Z, K.) ― -b2- See also raADK, latter sentence. -A2- And rajulN riDFY, (M, K,) and qawomN riDFY, (M,) A man, (M, K,) and a people, or party, (M,) with whom one is pleased, well pleased, contented, or satisfied; regarded with good will, or favour; liked, or approved; syn. maroDiY~N (M, K) and qunoEaAnN: riDFY being, thus used, an inf. n. in the sense of a pass. part. n., like as the inf. n. is used in the sense of an act. part. n. in the instance of EadolN, and xaSomN. (M.) ― -b2- [See also raDiY~N; for which riDFY or riDFA seems to be erroneously substituted, in two senses, in some copies of the K.]
raDK * : see raADK.
maA faEalotuhu Eano riDowatihi * means ↓ Eano riDaAhu [i. e. I did it not of, or with, his pleasure, good pleasure, content, or approval]. (Z, K.)
riDowaAnN * an inf. n. of raDiYa; like ruDowaAnN. (M, K, &c.) -A2- Also The treasurer, keeper, or guardian, of Paradise. (MA, K.)
riDaA='N * : see riDFY, first sentence.

raDiY~N * : see raADK. ― -b2- Also, (K, TA,) i. e. like ganiY~N, (TA,) [in the CK Alr~iDaY, and in my MS. copy of the K Alr~iDaA, are put in the place of Alr~aDiY~u,] One who is responsible, accountable, or answerable; syn. DaAminN: so in the copies of the K, and in like manner in the Tekmileh: accord. to the copies of the T, DaAmirN [lean, or light of flesh, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And Loving; a lover; or a friend. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b4- And Obeying, or obedient. (IAar, TA.)

raADK * , of which the pl. is ruDaApN; and ↓ raDiY~N, of which the pl. is A^aroDiyaA='u and ruDaApN, (M, K,) the latter pl. on the authority of Lh, but extr. as pl. of raDiY~N, and in my opinion, [says ISd,] it is pl. of raADK only; (M;) and ↓ raDK, of which the pl. is raDuwna; (Lh, M, K;) Pleased, well pleased, content, contented, or satisfied; regarding with good will, or favour; liking, or approving. (M, K.) ― -b2- Eiy$apN raADiyapN means maroDiy~apN [i. e. A state, or sort, of life that is found pleasing, well pleasing, contenting, or satisfying; or with which one is pleased, &c.; or that is liked, or approved]: (S, K:) or, accord. to Sb, raADiyapN is, in this case, a possessive epithet, meaning ↓ *aAtu riDFY [i. e. having approvedness; riDFY being here an inf. n. of ruDiyato]. (M, TA.)

maroDaA=pN * , originally maroDawapN, (TA,) an inf. n. of raDiYa. (S, * M, K.) ― -b2- [Also A cause, or means, or an occasion, of riDFY, i. e., of being pleased, well pleased, conten, &c.: a word of the same class as maboxalapN and majobanapN. Hence the saying,] Albir~u maroDaApN lilr~ab~i masoxaTapN lil$~ayoTaAni [Piety is a cause of approbation to the Lord, a cause of disapprobation, or anger, to the devil]. (TA in art. sxT.) The pl. of maroDaApN is maraADK [accord. to rule]: or this is an irreg. pl. of riDFY. (TA.)
maroDuw~N * : see what follows.

maroDiY~N * and ↓ maroDuw~N, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) the former the more common, (S, Msb,) the latter erroneously written in [some of] the copies of the K maroDuY~N, (TA,) applied to a thing, (S, Msb,) or a person, (M,) Found pleasing, well pleasing, contenting, or satisfying; or with which, or with whom, one is pleased, &c.; or liked, or approved: (K: [the meaning being there indicated to be the contr. of masoxuwTN; and being well known to be commonly as above:]) or chosen, or preferred: (Msb:) or seen, or judged, to be fit for a thing or an affair: (M:) [see also riDFY, last sentence but one; and raADK, latter sentence.]

div2.head: Quasi rDY
div2.entryFree: riDayaAni * a dual of riDFY, which see in art. rDw.

1 raTuba * , (S, A, MA, Msb, K,) aor.
raTuba ; (K;) and raTiba, aor.
raTaba ; (K;) inf. n. ruTuwbapN (S, A, MA, Msb, K) of the former verb (S, A, Msb) and raTaAbapN [also of the former verb]; (MA, K;) It (a thing, S, Msb) was, or became, the contr. of what is termed yaA bis (S, Msb, K) and jaAf~; i. e., (Msb,) it was, or became, moist, humid, succulent, sappy, or juicy: (A, MA, Msb:) or soft, or tender, to chew: (A:) [and fresh, or green; agreeably with the Pers. explanation, taro$udo, in the MA: and supple, pliant, or flexible: all meanings well known, of frequent occurrence, and implied in the first of the explanations above, and in explanations of raTobN and raTiybN:] and soft, or tender, said of a branch, or twig, and of plumage, &c.: (K:) [and ↓ trT~b, as used in the L in art. Eqd, &c., signifies the same.] ruTuwbapN [used as a simple subst.] signifies A quality necessarily involving facility of assuming shape and of separation and of conjunction. (KT.) ― -b2- [Hence, raTubato said of a girl, (assumed tropical:) She was, or became, sappy, or supple; and soft, or tender: and raTuba said of a boy, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, sappy, or soft, or supple; and femininely soft or supple: see raTobN, below. ― -b3- Hence also,] raTuba lisaAniY bi*ikorika and ↓ trT~b (tropical:) [My tongue has become supple by mentioning thee; i. e., has been much occupied by mentioning thee: a well-known phrase: (see also 2:) it may also be used as meaning my tongue has become refreshed (lit. moistened) by mentioning thee]. (A.) And xu*o maA raTubato bihi yadaAka (tropical:) [Take that by means of the
frequent handling of which thy hands have become supple]; meaning, what thou hast found to be profitable, or useful. (A.) ― -b4- See also 4, in two places. -A2- raTiba, aor.
raTaba , He spoke what he had in his mind, right and wrong, or correct and erroneous. (K, TA.) -A3- raTaba, (aor.
raTuba , A,) inf. n. raTobN, (A'Obeyd, S, A, K) and ruTuwbN, (A'Obeyd, S, K,) He fed a horse (or similar beast, K) with [the trefoil called] raTobap [q. v.]. (A'Obeyd, S, A, K.) ― -b2- See also 2.

2 rT~b * , inf. n. taroTiybN, He [or it] made, or rendered, a thing such as is termed raTobN and raTiybN; i. e. [moist, humid, succulent, sappy, or juicy: or soft, or tender, to chew: and fresh, new, or green: and supple, pliant, or flexible: and soft, or tender, as applied to a branch, or twig, and to plumage, &c.:] contr. of yaA bis: (S:) he moistened a garment, or piece of cloth, (A, K, TA,) &c.; (TA;) as also ↓ ArTb. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, lisaAniY bi*ikorika ↓ maA zilotu A^uroTibu (tropical:) [I have not ceased to make my tongue supple by mentioning thee; meaning I have not ceased to employ my tongue frequently in mentioning thee: or mA zlt A^uraT~ibu Alx: for] one says also maA raT~aba lisaAniY bi*ikorika A_il~aA maA balalotaniY bihi mino bir~ika (tropical:) [Nothing has made my tongue to become supple by mentioning thee save what thou hast bestowed upon me of thy bounty]. (A. [See also 1.]) -A2- Also rT~b, (S, A, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He fed people with ruTab [or fresh ripe dates]; (S, A, K;) and so ↓ raTaba. (K.) You say, ↓ mano A^aroTaba naxoluhu walamo yuraT~ibo xabuva fiEoluhu walamo yaTibo [He whose palm-trees have fresh ripe dates and he does not feed people with such dates, his conduct is bad, and is not good]. (A.) -A3- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

4 ArTb * as a trans. v.: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. -A2- ArTb Albusoru The fullgrown unripe dates became ruTab [i. e. freshly ripe dates]: (S, A:) or so ↓ raTaba, and ↓ raTuba, and ↓ rT~b, (K,) of which last the inf. n. is taroTiybN: or all signify, attained to the time of ripening: (TA:) or ArTbt Albusorapu signifies the full-grown unripe date had ripening (↓ taroTiyb) beginning in it. (Msb.) ― -b2- And ArTb Aln~axolu The palm-trees had upon them, (S,) or produced, (A,) or attained to the time of having, (K,) dates such as are termed ruTab. (S, A, K.) See an ex. in the next preceding paragraph. ― -b3- And ArTb Alqawomu The people had palm-trees that had attained to the time of having such dates: (K:) or ArTb signifies he had abundance of such dates. (A.) ― -b4- [Also] The people became amid fresh green herbage. (Msb.) ― -b5- And ArTbt AlA^aroDu, inf. n. A_iroTaAbN, The land had such herbage: (Msb:) or abounded therewith. (A.)
5 taraT~aba see 1, in two places.

raTobN * and ↓ raTiybN Contr. of yaAbisN (S, Msb, K) and jaAf~N; i. e. (Msb) moist, humid, succulent, sappy, or juicy: (A, MA, Msb:) or soft, or tender, to chew: (A:) and [fresh, (agreeably with the Pers. explanation, taro, in the MA,) or] green; applied to herbage: (TA:) or they signify, (Msb,) or signify also, (S, K,) soft, or tender; (S, Msb, K;) applied to a branch, or twig, and to plumage, (S, K,) &c.: (K:) [and] supple, pliant, or flexible. (Msb.) [All these meanings are well known, of frequent occurrence, and implied in the first of the explanations above.] The former occurs in a trad. as an epithet particularly applied to Any article of property [or of provisions] that is not stored up, and will not keep; such as [most kinds of] fruits, and herbs, or leguminous plants: such, IAth says, fathers and mothers and children may eat and give away agreeably with approved usage, without asking permission; but not husbands nor wives [when it belongs to one of them exclusively], without the permission of the owner. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jaAriyapN raTobapN (tropical:) A soft, or tender, [or a sappy, or supple,] girl, or young woman. (A, K, * TA.) And gulaAmN raTobN (tropical:) A boy, or young man, [sappy, or soft, or supple, or] femininely soft or supple. (A, K.) And rajulN raTobN (tropical:) A soft, or supple, man. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] bi*ikorika ↓ lisaAniY raTiybN (tropical:) [My tongue is become supple by mentioning thee: and it may also be used as meaning my tongue is become refreshed (lit. moistened) by mentioning thee]. (A. [See also 1 and 2.]) ― -b4- And AimoraA^apN raTobapN (tropical:) [A pliant, or] a vitious, or an unchaste, woman; a fornicatress, or an adulteress. (A.) One says, in reviling, yaA A@bona Alr~aTobapi (tropical:) [O son of the fornicatress or adulteress]. (A.) And ↓ yaA raTaAbi, like qaTaAmi, (tropical:) [meaning O fornicatress or adulteress, raTaAbi, being indecl., as a proper name in this sense,] is said in reviling a woman or girl. (A, K.) ― -b5- [And yaHomilu AlHaTaba Alr~aToba (tropical:) : see 1 in art. Hml.] ― -b6- And Eayo$N raTobN (tropical:) A soft, a delicate, or an easy, life. (A.) ― -b7- And qaraA^a AlquroA=na raTobFA (assumed tropical:) He read, or recited, the Kur-án softly, or gently; not with a loud voice. (TA from a trad) ― -b8- luw^oluw^N raTobN is a metonymical expression, meaning (tropical:) Brilliant pearls, beautiful, smooth in the exterior, and perfect in clearness: it does not denote the ruTuwabp that is the contr. of yubuwsap: and similar to this is the expression Almanodalu Alr~aTobu [app. meaning (tropical:) Fresh and fragrant, or fine, aloes-wood]. (TA.)

ruTobN * (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ ruTubN (S, K) Herbage, or pasture, (S, A, Mgh,) such as is juicy, fresh, or green: (A, Mgh:) or green pasture, consisting of herbs, or leguminous plants, (T, Msb, K, TA,) of the [season called] rabiyE, (Msb, TA,) and of trees [or shrubs]: (T, K, TA:) [each] a coll. gen. n.: (TA:) or green herbage in general: (K, TA:) accord. to the Kifáyet el-Mutahaffidh, ruTobN signifies fresh, or juicy, herbage or pasture; (TA;) or, as some say, ↓ ruTobapN, like gurofapN, [though this seems to be the n. un. of ruTobN,] has this last meaning; (Msb;) what is dry being called Ha$iy$. (TA.)

ruTabN * [Fresh ripe dates; i. e.] ripe dates (A, Mgh, Msb, K) before they become dry; (Msb, TA;) also called ↓ tamorN raTiybN and ↓ muroTibN (K, TA) and ↓ muraT~ibN: (TA:) the dates so called are well known: (S:) [it is a coll. gen, n.:] n. un. with p: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) it is not a broken pl. of ruTabapN, being masc. [as well as fem.] like tamorN: you say, h`*aA ruTabN [These are fresh ripe dates]; whereas, if it were a broken pl., you would make it [only] fem.: (Sb, TA:) its pl. [of pauc.] is A^aroTaAbN (S, Msb) and [of mult.] riTaAbN; and the pl. of the n. un. is ruTabaAtN. (S.) There are two sorts of ruTab: one sort cannot be dried, and spoils if not soon eaten: the other sort dries, and is made into Eajowap [q. v.]. (Msb.) [See also busorN.]
ruTubN * : see ruTobN.

raTobapN *
i. q. qaDobN, (S, [in my copy of the Msb qaDobap, but this is the n. un. of qaDobN,]) or qat~N, (A,) or A_isofisotN [in Pers. A_isofisot or A_isoPisot], (Mgh,) or fiSofiSapN, (K,) [all which signify A species of trefoil, or clover,] specially (S) while juicy, or fresh, or green, (S, A, Mgh, TA,) before it is dried: (Msb:) or, as some say, a meadow of fSfSp, while continuing green: and ↓ ruTobapN signifies the same: (TA:) pl. riTaAbN: (S, Mgh, Msb:) which is also said to be applied to the cucumber and melon and bA*njAn [q. v.] and the like: but [Mtr says] the first is the meaning mentioned in the Lexicons in my hands, and is a sufficient explanation. (Mgh.)
ruTobapN * : see ruTobN: ― -b2- and raTobapN.
ruTabiY~N * [A seller of ruTab, or fresh ripe dates: mentioned in the K only as a surname].
raTaAbi * : see raTobN.
raTiybN * : see raTobN, in two places: and ruTabN.
muroTibN * : see ruTabN. ― -b2- A^aroDN muroTibapN Land abounding with ruTob [q. v.]. (S, * A, K.)

rakiy~apN maroTabapN *
A well of sweet water among wells of salt water. (K.)
muraT~ibN * : see ruTabN.

maroTuwbN * A horse fed with [the trefoil called] raTobap. (A.) ― -b2- [And A man fed with ruTab (or fresh ripe dates).] -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) A man in whom is softness, or suppleness; mano bihi ruTuwbapN; (K;) or SaAHibu ruTuwbapK. (S.)

1 raTala * , (O, Msb, K,) aor.
raTula , inf. n. raTolN, (Msb, TA,) He weighed a thing: (O, TA:) or he put in motion a thing with his hand, (IDrd, O,) or weighed with his hand a thing, (Msb,) or tried a thing, (K,) in order that he might know its weight (IDrd, O, Msb, K) nearly. (Msb.) [See also 2.] But IF says, of this combination of letters and the like, that they are not of the genuine language [of the Arabs]. (O.) -A2- He ran; syn. EadaA. (O, K.)

2 taroTiylN * The act of weighing by, or with, A^aroTaAl [or pound-weights]. (K.) [See also 1.] -A2- Also The anointing of the hair, (S, O,) or making it soft, or smooth, (K,) with oil, or ointment, and
the crimping (takosiyr) thereof: (S, O, K:) and the making it to be loose, and to hang down: (IAar, IAmb, K:) accord. to IAmb, rT~l $aEarahu means he made his hair to be loose, and to hang down: (O:) but accord. to the T, the saying of the vulgar, raT~alotu $aEariY, as meaning raj~alotuhu, [i. e. I made my hair to be wavy, or somewhat curly; or combed it; or combed it down; &c.;] is a mistake: for trTyl signifies the act of making the hair soft, or smooth, with oil, or ointment; and wiping it so that it becomes soft, or smooth, and glossy. (TA.)

3 rATl *ahabFA bi*ahabK * , inf. n. muraATalapN, He sold by counterpoising gold for gold, and wariqFA biwariqK coined dirhems for coined dirhems: but [Mtr says] I have not found this except in the “ Muwatta. ” (Mgh.) You say also, baAEa muraATalapF [He sold by counterpoising]. (TA.)

4 ArTl *
He had a child such as is termed raTol [q. v.]: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) or his ears became flabby. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

raTolN * (S, O, K) and ↓ riTolN (K) A man soft, lax, or uncompact; (S, O, K, * TA;) as also ↓ muroTilN: (K, TA:) and old and weak: or inclining to softness, and laxness, or uncompactness, and old age: (K:) and a boy slender, slim, or lean, (K, TA,) or, as some say, (TA,) near to attaining puberty, or virility: (K, TA:) or whose bones have not become strong: (K:) or the former, applied to a boy, whose strength has not become fully established; as also ↓ muroTalN [thus written with fet-h to the T]: (O:) pl. riTalapN: (O, TA:) and the first, i. e. raTolN, a man who is foolish; stupid; unsound, or deficient, in intellect or understanding; (K;) fem. with p: (TA:) one who has not, or possesses not, what suffices; or who is not profitable to any one: and also having flaccid ears: (O:) and, applied to a horse, (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K,) as also ↓ riTolN, (K,) or, as some say, the latter only, (TA,) light, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA,) and weak: (TA:) fem. with p, (O, K, TA,) in all the senses. (TA.) -A2- [Alr~aTolu is also explained in the K as syn. with AlEadolu: but perhaps this is a mistranscription for AlEadowu, inf. n. of EadaA: see 1, last sentence.] -A3- See also the next paragraph.

riTolN * and ↓ raTolN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the former of which is the better known, (Msb, TA,) or the more chaste, (O, TA,) [but the latter is that which is now in common use,] A certain thing with which one weighs, (Mgh, O, Msb,) or which one uses as a measure of capacity: (Mgh, Msb:) [or rather both: a pound-weight: and a pint-measure: and also a pound of anything: and a pint of anything:] the half of what is termed manFA: (S:) accord. to the standard of Baghdád, twelve ounces; the ounce (A^uwqiy~ap) being an A_isotaAr and two thirds of an AstAr; and the AstAr being four mavaAqiyl and half of a mivoqaAl; and the mvqAl being a diroham and three sevenths of a drhm; and the drhm being six dawaAniq; and the daAniq being eight Hab~aAt and two fifths of a Hab~ap; so that the rTl is ninety mvAqyl; i. e. a hundred and twenty-eight daraAhim and four sevenths of a drhm (Msb:) or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, a hundred and twenty-eight drAhm of the weight of seven (wazona saboEapK [explained voce dirohamN]): (Mgh:) or twelve ounces; the ounce (A^uwqiy~ap, i. e. the ounce of the Arabs, TA,) being forty drAhm; (Mgh, K, TA;) so that the whole is four hundred and eighty drAhm: (Mgh, TA:) this is the Syrian rTl: (TA:) and thus it is, accord. to El-Harbee, in the saying, Als~un~apu fiY Aln~ikaAHi riTolN [meaning The usage of the Prophet in the case of marriage was to give a rTl of silver]: (Mgh, TA:) so says Az in the T: (Mgh:) or, as is [also] said by Az, it is in this instance twelve ounces and a na$~; the n$~ being twenty [drAhm] so that the whole is five hundred drAhm; as is related on the authority of 'Áïsheh: but in a trad. 'Omar, twelve ounces, without the mention of the n$~: accord. to the lawyers, [however,] when the rTl is mentioned without restriction, what is meant thereby is the rTl of Baghdád: (TA:) [as a measure of capacity, i. e. a pint,] it is said in the A [&c.] to be the eighth part of the SaAE; the half of the mud~; (TA;) [i. e.] the half of the man~: and hence applied to one of the vessels of the vintner [app. because it contains a pint]: (Har p. 650:) pl. A^aroTaAlN. (Msb.) -A2- See also raTolN, in two places.
muroTalN * : see raTolN: ― -b2- and see also what here follows.
muroTilN * , like muHosinN [in measure], (K,) written by Sgh with fet-h, (TA,) i. e. ↓ muroTalN, (so in the O,) A tall man. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also raTolN.

1 raTamahu * , (S, K, TA,) aor.
raTuma , (TA,) inf. n. raTomN, (S, TA,) He made him to stich fast fiY AlwaHoli [in the mire]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) [or raTamahu fiY A^amorK,] (tropical:) He caused him to be involved in an affair, or a case, from which he could not extricate himself. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence, app.,] ruTima, said of a camel, (assumed tropical:) He had, or was affected with, a suppression of his excrement: (K, TA:) and so, accord. to the K, ↓ A^uroTima; but this is a mistake for ATm [i. e. A^uTima or A^aTima]. (TA.) ― -b4- raTama bisaloHihi, expl. in the K as meaning He ejected his excrement, is a mistake for A^aTama. (TA.) ― -b5- raTama, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) also signifies Inivit; (S, TA;) said of a man: (S:) or, [said of a man, and of an ass,] inivit toto veretro immisso, (K, TA,) mulierem, et asinam. (TA.)
4 ArTm * (assumed tropical:) He was silent; (Sh, K;) said of a man. (Sh, TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.
5 taraT~ama see 8, last sentence.
6 taraAoTama see the next paragraph.

8 ArtTm *
He stuck fast fiY AlwaHoli [in the mire]. (TA.) You say, ArtTmt Ald~aAb~apu fiY AlwaHoli [The beast stuck fast in the mire], and fY AlxabaAri [in the soft ground], (TA in art. tE,) and fY Alr~amoli [in the sand]. (S and K in that art.) And ArtTmt bihi farasuhu His mare's feet sank [in the mire, or soft ground, or sand,] with him. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) ArtTm fiY A^amorK (tropical:) He became involved in an affair, or a case, from which he could not extricate himself (K, * TA) unless with confusion, or perplexity, cleaving to him. (TA.) ― -b3- And ArtTm Ealayohi A^amorN, (S,) or AlA^amoru, (K,) (tropical:) An affair, or a case, or the affair, or case, was such that he could not extricate himself from it; (S, K;) it wearied him, and the ways thereof were obstructed against him, so that he could not extricate himself from it. (TA.) ― -b4- And ArtTm It (a thing) was, or became, pressed together, or compressed: and it was, or became, heaped up, piled up, or accumulated, one part upon another; (K;) as also ↓ trATm. (TA.) -A2- ArtTm Als~aloHa He suppressed, or retained, the excrement; as also ↓trT~mhu. (K.)

ruTomapN * (assumed tropical:) An affair of which one knows not the end, or result, to which it leads, or tends; (K, TA;) an affair in which one struggles, or is agitated, or disturbed; and so ↓ rTwmp [app. ruTuwmapN]; as in the saying, waqaEa fiY ruTomapK and rTwmpK [He fell into an affair in which one struggles, &c.]. (TA.)
ruTaAmN * (assumed tropical:) Suppression of the excrement, in a camel. (K.)

raTuwmN * A woman wide in the vulva; (S, TA;) as in the saying of a rájiz,
yaAA@bona raTuwmK *aAti farojK Eafolaqi
