for he means [O son of] a woman wide in the vulva, having [a vulva with] much moisture; though F says, (TA,) it does not signify thus, but narrow in the vulva: (K, TA:) and applied to a she-camel, it has this latter meaning: (AA, K, TA:) and also, applied to a woman, impervia coëunti; syn. ratoqaA='u [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b2- Also Foolish; stupid; or unsound, or deficient, in intellect. (TA.) ― -b3- And White; applied to a domestic hen. (AA, TA.)
rTwmp * [app. ruTuwmapN]: see ruTomapN.

raATimN *
Keeping, cleaving, or adhering, to a thing. (S, K.)

maroTuwmapN *
Inita; applied to a young woman: or so applied, and also to a she-ass, inita toto veretro immisso. (TA.) -A2- Also, applied to a woman, Accused, or suspected, of evil. (K, * TA.)

1 raTana lahu * , (S, K,) aor.
raTuna , (MS, JM,) inf. n. raTaAnapN and riTaAnapN; (S, * K, * MA, MS, JM, TA;) and ↓ rATnhu, (S, K,) inf. n. muraATanapN; (TK;) He spoke to him biAlA^aEojmiy~api [i. e. with a barbarous, or vitious, speech]; (S, K;) or, correctly, accord. to Aboo-Zekereeyà, biAlEajamiy~api [i. e. in a language foreign to the Arabs]: (TA: [and in like manner expl. in the MA and PS and TK:]) or, [as sometimes used,] in a language not generally understood, conventionally formed between two, or several, persons: (JM, TA:) [or he gibbered,
or uttered gibberish or jargon, to him: (see R. Q. 1 in art zm:)] and ↓ taraATanuwA (S, K) fiymaA bayonahumo (S) They so spoke (&c.] (S, K) among themselves. (S.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Tarafeh, (TA,)
Alfurosi ↓ A^aSowaAtuhumo kataraATuni
[Their voices were like the barbarous, or vitious, or rather the foreign, speech, among themselves, of the Persians]. (S.) ― -b2- You say also, raTana bi$aYo'K, meaning He alluded to a thing, not mentioning its name explicitly, or unequivocally. (JM.)
3 raAoTana see above, first sentence.
6 taraAoTana see 1, in two places.
raTuwnN * : see the next paragraph.

raTaAnapN * , (so in my copies of the S, [like the former of the two inf. ns. of raTana,] and so in copies of the K,) or raT~aAnapN, (so accord. to the TA, as from the K,) and ↓ raTuwnN, (S, K,) accord. to As, Camels when they are many, (TA,) or, accord. to Fr, camels when they are such as are termed rifaAq [pl. of rufoqapN], and have their owners with them: (S, TA:) or camels when they are many, and are such as are termed rifaAq, and have their owners with them: (K:) and accord. to As, they are also termed TaH~aAnapN and TaHuwnN: by rifaAq being meant those upon which people have gone forth to purvey for themselves wheat, or corn, or other provisions from the towns or villages; each, or every, company being a rufoqap. (TA.)

maA ruTayonaAka * and ruT~ayonaAka means maA Al*~aY taroTunu bihi [i. e. What is that to which thou alludest, not mentioning it explicitly?]: (JM:) or maA ruT~ayonaAka h`*ihi, and sometimes without teshdeed, means What is [this] thy speech? (K.)

4 A^aroTati AlA^aroDu *
The land produced the kind of trees called A^aroTFY [or A^aroTaY; as also A=raTat, belonging to art. ArT, q. v.]. (S.)
rawaATK * Sands producing the trees called A^aroTaY or A^aroT~Y. (M.)

A^aroTFY * [or, as some say, A^aroTaY]: see art. ArT: (K:) it is of the measure A^afoEalN [or A^afoEalu] for one reason, and faEolFY [or faEolaY] for another reason: for they say A^adiymN maA^oruwTN as well as ↓ maroTiY~N, meaning A hide tanned with the leaves of the tree called ArTY.
maroTiY~N * : see A^aroTFY, above.

1 raE~N * The being still, syn. sukuwnN, [a signification contr. to one borne by two other words in this art.,] (IAar, K,) is the inf. n. of raE~ati Alr~iyHu, aor.
raEu3a , [probably a mistake for
raEi3a , which is the regular form of an intrans. verb of this class, notwithstanding the guttural letter,] The wind was, or became, still. (TK.)

R. Q. 1 raEoraEahu *
He (God) caused him [a child, or boy, as is implied in the S,] to grow. (S, Z, K.) ― -b2- raEoraEa daAb~atahu He (a horseman) rode his beast to train it when it was in the first stage of training and as yet refractory. (O, TS, K.) In IN the L we find A_i*aA lamo takuno ray~iDFA, [meaning when it was not trained, ray~iDFA being here used in the sense of maruwDapF,] in the place of A_i*aA kaAnato ray~iDFA, which is the reading in the O and TS and K. (TA.) ― -b3- [See also raEoraEapN, below.]

R. Q. 2 taraEoraEa *
He (a child, or boy,) became active (taHar~aka), and grew, grew up, or became a young man, (S, K,) and some add, wakabira [and became big, or attained to full growth]. (TA.) [See its part. n., below.] ― -b2- taraEoraEati Als~in~u The tooth became loose, and wabbled, or moved about. (K.) ― -b3- AlmaA='u yataraEoraEu fiY wajohi AlA^aroDi, [or rather, EalaY wjh AlArD,] The water is in a state of commotion, or agitation, upon the surface of the ground. (TK.) And taraEoraEa Als~araAbu (assumed tropical:) The mirage was in a state of commotion, or agitation: being likened to water. (TA.)

raEaAEN *
Young men of the lowest, or basest, or meanest, sort, or of the refuse of mankind; or low, ignoble, mean, or sordid, young men, such as serve for the food of their bellies: (S, K:) or the lowest, basest, or meanest, sort, or refuse, of mankind, or people: or a medley, or mixed or promiscuous multitude or collection, of men, or people; or of the lowest or basest or meanest sort, or refuse, thereof: (Msb:) and raEaAEu Aln~aAsi the lowest, basest, or meanest, sort, or refuse, of mankind, or of the people; the medley of men, or of such men: (TA:) n. un. with p: (Msb, TA:) Az mentions his having read in the handwriting of Sh AlrEAE mn AlnAs, like AlzjAj [in form, app. meaning ↓ Alr~uEaAEu, like Alz~ujaAju, for this is the most chaste form of the latter word, and the most usual with classical writers], as meaning the refuse, and weak, of mankind, or of the people, who, when frightened, fly. (TA.) ― -b2- [The n. un.] raEaAEapN signifies [also] One without heart and without intellect or intelligence. (AA, K.) ― -b3- And An ostrich; (Abu-l-'Omeythil, K;) because always as though frightened. (Abu-l-'Omeythil.)
ruEaAEN * : see raEaAEN.
raEaAEapN * n. un. of raEaAEN [q. v.].
raEoraEN * : see raEoraAEN; each in three places.
ruEoruEN * : see raEoraAEN; each in three places.

raEoraEapN * [originally an inf. n. of R. Q. 1] A state of beautiful youthfulness, and activity, of a boy. (TA.) ― -b2- A state of commotion, or agitation, (IDrd, K,) of clear water, (K,) or of clear shallow water, (IDrd,) upon the surface of the ground. (IDrd, K.)
ruEoruEapN * : see the next paragraph.

raEoraAEN * The tall reed or cane, or tall reeds or canes, (K, TA,) in the place of growth thereof, while fresh: so accord. to Az, as heard by him from the Arabs. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, as some say, or, accord. to others, from raEoraEapN in the latter of the two senses assigned to it above, A boy who has attained to youthful vigour, and justness of stature; as also ↓ raEoraEN: (TA:) or a youth, or young man, of goodly proportions, (S, K,) with beauty of youthfulness; (K;) as also ↓ raEoraEN (S, K) and ↓ ruEoruEN: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) or arriving at the age of puberty; (TA;) as also ↓ ruEoruEN and ↓ ruEoruEapN: (Kr:) or who has become active, (taHar~aka,) and big, or of full growth: (TA:) [see also mutaraEoriEN:] the pl., (S, TA,) i. e. of ↓ raEoraEN [and ↓ ruEoruEN] and raEoraAEN, (TA,) is raEaAriEu. (S, TA.) ― -b3- A coward. (El-Muärrij, K.) ― -b4- A certain plant: [perhaps the inula Arabica; now called raEoraAE A^ay~uwb; or, as Forskål (in his Flora Aegypt. Arab., pp. lxxiii. and 150,) designates the plant now thus called, inula dysenterica:] some say that this word is formed by transposition from EaroEaArN. (TA.)
mutaraEoriEN * applied to a boy, (Mgh, TA,) Almost, or quite, past the age of ten years: (Mgh:) or active; syn. mutaHar~ikN. (TA.) [See its verb, R. Q. 2; and see also raEoraAEN.]

1 raEaba * , aor.
raEaba , (Msb, K,) inf. n. ruEobN (K, TA) and ruEubN, or the latter of these is a simple subst., (TA,) or each of them is a simple subst., (Msb, TA,) and the inf. n. is raEobN; (Msb;) and raEuba; and ruEiba, like EuniYa; both mentioned by 'Iyád and Ibn-Kurkool, and the last by ISk also; (TA;) and ↓ ArtEb; (K;) He feared; he was afraid or frightened or terrified: (Msb, K, TA:) or his bosom and heart were filled with fear: or he feared in the utmost degree; was in a state of the utmost terror. (TA.) ― -b2- raEaba said of a valley, [like zaEaba,] aor.
raEaba , (assumed tropical:) It became filled with water. (L.) ― -b3- raEabati AlHamaAmapN, aor.
raEaba ; and ↓ rE~bt, (K,) inf. n. taroEiybN; (A, TA;) (tropical:) The pigeon raised, and poured forth loudly, or vehemently, its cooing cry. (A, * K, TA.) You say ↓ HamaAmN lahu taroEiybN (tropical:) Pigeons, or a pigeon, having a loud, or vehement, cooing. (A.) ― -b4- And raEaba, aor.
raEaba , [inf. n. raEobN,] (assumed tropical:) He composed, or uttered, rhyming prose. (K.) -A2- raEabahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. ruEobN, (A, K,) inf. n. raEobN (A, MA) and rE~yhu, (MA,) He caused him, or made him, to fear, or be afraid; frightened, or terrified, him: (S, A, Msb, K:) or he filled his bosom and heart with fear: or he put him in the utmost fear, or terror: (TA:) and ↓ taroEiybN signifies the same, (Lb, K,) inf. n. taroEaAbN and ArEbhu; (K;) and so does ↓ raEaba, accord. to Ibn-Talhah El-Ishbeelee, and Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee, and Fei in the Msb; but this is disallowed by IAar and Th and J. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raEobN, aor.
raEaba , [inf. n. raEobN,] signifies also He threatened. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- Also, aor.
raEaba , (K,) inf. n. raEobN, (TA,) He charmed, or fascinated, by magical enchantment [or by the eye] or otherwise. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- Also, [like zaEaba,] (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
raEaba , (K,)
inf. n. raEobN, (TA,) (tropical:) He filled (S, A, Msb, K) a watering-trough, or tank, (S, A,) or a vessel: (Msb:) and it (a torrent) filled a valley. (L, TA.) -A3- raEabahu, (K,) aor.
raEaba , (TA,) also signifies He cut it [into pieces, or long pieces, or slices, (see tiroEiybapN, below,)], namely, a camel's hump, or other thing; and so ↓ rE~bhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. taroEiybN. (TA.) ― -b2- And He broke its (an arrow's) ruEob [q. v.]. (K.)

2 raE~aba as an intrans. v.: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- The inf. n., taroEiybN, as relating to a camel's hump, accord. to Sh, signifies Its shaking, or quivering, and being fat and thick; as though it shook, or quivered, by reason of its fatness: but it is otherwise explained [as a subst. properly speaking] below. (TA.) -A2- raE~abahu, inf. n. as above, and, in one sense, taroEaAbN also: see 1, in two places. -A3- Also, inf. n. taroEiybN, He repaired its (an arrow's) ruEob [q. v.]. (K.)
4 A^aroEaba see 1.
8 A_irotaEaba see 1, first sentence.

raEobN * an inf. n. of 1, in senses pointed out above. (M, A, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- A threat, or threatening. (K.) ― -b3- A charm or charming, or a fascination or fascinating, by magical enchantment [or by the eye] or otherwise. (K.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A rhyming prose of the Arabs. (K.)

ruEobN * (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ ruEubN, (A, Msb, K,) both said to be inf. ns., (TA,) or the former is an inf. n. of raEaba as intrans. (K, TA) or as trans., (A, MA,) and the latter is a simple subst., (TA,) or each of them is a simple subst., (Msb, TA,) Fear, fright, or terror: (S, A, Msb, K:) or fear that fills the bosom and heart; as Er-Rághib and Z have indicated, following Aboo-'Alee and IJ: or the utmost fear or terror. (TA.) One says, faEala *`lika ruEobFA laA rugobFA He did that from fear, not from desire. (A.) -A2- Also the former, The socket of the head of an arrow; the part into which the head enters, over which are the twists of sinew; syn. ruEoZN: pl. riEabapN. (K.)
ruEubN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
ruEobabN * : see ruEobuwbapN, last sentence.
ruEobubN * : see tiroEiybapN.
ruEobwbN * : see raEiybN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also ruEobuwbapN.
riEobiybN * : see what next follows.

ruEobuwbapN * (S, A, K) and ↓ ruEobuwbN (K) and ↓ riEobiybN (Seer, K) A woman, (S, A,) or a girl, or young woman, (K,) Tall, and well-formed; soft, thinskinned, and plump; (S, * A, K;) or (A, K) white, or fair; (S, A, K;) goodly, or beautiful; sweet; and tender: (A, K:) or only white, or fair: (TA:) or soft, or tender: (IAar, Lh, K:) and the first, tall: (TA:) pl. raEaAbiybN. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or the first and second, (TA,) applied to a she-camel, Restless, or unsteady; (K, TA;) light, or active, brisk, lively, or sprightly. (TA.) ― -b3- For another meaning of the first, see tiroEiybapN. ― -b4- Also the first, The base, or lower part, (A^aSol,) of the TaloEap [i. e. either the spathe, or the spadix, of a palm-tree]; and so ↓ ruEobabN. (K.)

raEiybN *
Afraid, or frightened, or terrified: (K:) [or filled with fear: or in a state of the utmost fear or terror: (see 1:)] and so ↓ maroEuwbN, (S, K,) and ↓ muraE~abN, and ↓ murotaEibN: (TA:) and ↓ ruEobuwbN signifies [the same; or] weak and cowardly. (S, K.) [Hence,] rajulN raEiybu AlEayoni and ↓ maroEuwbuhaA and ↓ ruEobuwbuhaA (tropical:) A cowardly man, who sees nothing without being frightened. (A.) [ragiybu AlEayoni has a different meaning: see art rgb.] ― -b2- Also Fat, as an epithet; (K;) dripping with grease: (S, K:) and so ↓ muraEobibN. (K.) And applied to a camel's hump as meaning Full and fat. (S.) ― -b3- And Short; as also ↓ A^aroEabu: pl. [of the former] ruEubN and [of the latter] ruEobN. (TA.)
raE~aAbN * : see what next follows.

raAEibN * and ↓ raE~aAbN, [but the latter is an intensive epithet, or denotes habit, or frequency,] One who threatens; a threatener. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- One who charms, or fascinates, by magical enchantment [or by the eye] or otherwise. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- One who composes, or utters, the rhyming prose termed raEobN. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Also the former (rAEb), A torrent that fills the valley: (S:) or (tropical:) that frightens by its abundance and its width and its filling the valley. (A.) It is applied also to rain. (TA.) And A valley filled with water. (L.)

HamaAmN raAEibiY~N * , (S, A,) or raAEibiy~apN, (K,) [or] the latter is the fem. form of the epithet, (S,) A certain kind of pigeons; (S;) accord. to the K, from a land called raAEibN [in the CK raEibN]; but this land is unknown, and is not mentioned by El-Bekree nor by the author of the Marásid; and in the Mj and other old works, AlHamaAmapu Alr~aAEibiy~apu is expl. as meaning (assumed tropical:) the pigeon that is loud, or strong, in its cry, or voice: so says MF; and this is the truth: in the L it is said, Alr~aAEibiY~u, meaning a kind of wild pigeons, or doves, has the form of a rel. n., but is not such; or, as some one says, is a rel. n. from a place of the name whereof I know not the form: in the A it is said that HamaAmN raAEibiY~N means a pigeon that cooes loudly, or vehemently, exciting admiration by its voice, or filling with it the passages thereof. (TA.)
A^aroEabu * : see raEiybN.
tiroEaAbN * : see tiroEaAbapN.
tiroEiybN * and taroEiybN: see tiroEiybapN.

tiroEaAbapN * , (S, A, K,) in the Mj, and in [some of] the copies of the S, ↓ tiroEaAbN, without p, (TA,) Very fearful: (S:) or most exceedingly fearful (A, K, TA) of everything. (TA.) You say, huwa fiY Als~ilomi taloEaAbapN wafiY AlHarobi tiroEaAbapN [He is in peace most exceedingly playful, and in war most exceedingly fearful]. (A.)

tiroEiybapN *
A piece of a camel's hump; (S, K;) as also ↓ ruEobuwbapN (K) and ↓ ruEobubN: (TA:) pl. ↓ tiroEiybN; (K;) or rather, accord. to AHei, this is a coll. gen. n.: (MF, TA:) it is also pronounced ↓ taroEiybN; (Sb, AHei;) and is said to signify a camel's hump cut into long pieces, or slices: it is a subst. [properly so termed], not an inf. n.: (TA:) and its t is shown to be augmentative by the fact that there is no [undisputed] word of the measure faEoliylN, with fet-h [to the f]. (MF, TA.)

maroEabapN *
A frightful qaforap [or desert destitute of herbage and of water]. (K. [In the CK and TA, qafozap is erroneously put for qaforap.]) ― -b2- Also A person's springing, or leaping, [towards another,] and seating himself by the other's side, so as to cause the latter, not being aware, to be frightened. (K. [From its measure, it seems to be a simple subst., not an inf. n., signifying this action as being A cause of fear.])
muraE~abN * : see raEiybN. -A2- Also A camel's hump cut into pieces, (S, TA,) or into long pieces, or slices. (TA.)
muraEobibN * : see raEiybN.
maroEuwbN * : see raEiybN, in two places.
murotaEibN * : see raEiybN.

1 raEivato * , aor.
raEava , inf. n. raEavN; and raEavato, aor.
raEava , inf. n. raEovN; (tropical:) She (a goat, K, TA, and a sheep, $aAp, TA) had white extremities to her zanamataAni [or two wattles] (K, TA) beneath the two ears. (TA.)

5 trE~vt *
She (a woman) adorned herself with the [kind of ear-ring, or ear-drop, called] quroT (S, K, TA) and riEaAvN; (TA;) as also ↓ ArtEvt. (IJ, K, TA.)
8 A_irotaEava see what next precedes.
raEovN * : see what next follows, in two places.

raEavN * and ↓ raEavapN and ↓ ruEovapN are said to be applied to Anything suspended: or, accord. to some, only to the [kind of ear-ring, or ear-drop, called] quroT, and the [necklace called] qilaAdap, and the like: or, accord. to Az, ↓ riEaAvN signifies anything suspended, such as the quroT, and the like, suspended from the ear; or the [necklace called] qilaAdap: and the pl. is ↓ raEovN [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.] and ↓ riEaAvN [like the sing.] and ruEovN, which last is a pl. pl.: (TA:) or ↓ raEovapN and ↓ raEavapN signify the [kind of ear-ring, or ear-drop, called] quroT; (S, A, K, TA;) and any similar pendant to the ear: (TA:) or the rEvp is in the lower part of the ear; and the $anof, in the upper part thereof; and the rEvp is a pearl, or large pearl, (dur~apN,) attacked to the quroT: (IAar, TA:) and the pl. of raEovapN and raEavapN is riEaAvN (S, K, TA) and riEavapN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raEavN signifies [also] (tropical:) Wool, or wool died of various colours, (EihonN,) in a general sense: [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. raEavapN: (TA:) or, (S, A, K,) as also ↓ raEovN and ↓ ruEovapN, (K,) such wool (EihonN) suspended to the [kind of
women's camel-vehicle called] hawodaj, (A'Obeyd, S, K, TA,) and the like, for ornament; like what are termed *abaA*ib: (TA:) or [pendant] ornaments of the hawodaj, of the kind called *abaA*ib, consisting of such wool. (A.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The blossoms of the pomegranate-tree. (A.)

raEovapN * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) The Euvonuwn [or wattle] of the cock, (S, K, TA,) that grows forth beneath the bill; i. e. its beard, or barb; (TA;) as also ↓ raEavapN: (K:) each of the two things that grow forth beneath the bill of the cock. (A.) You say, SaAHa *uwAlr~aEovataAni (tropical:) [The owner of the two wattles cried]; meaning the cock. (A.) And a poet says, (S,) namely, El-Akhtal, (TA,)
maA *aA yuw^ar~quniY waAln~awomu yuEojibuniY
mino Sawoti *iYraEavaAtK saAkini Ald~aAri
[What is this that renders me wakeful, when sleep pleases me, of the voice of an owner of wattles, an inhabitant of the mansion?]. (S, TA. [Another reading, as well as the foregoing, of this verse is given in the Ham, p. 823.]) ― -b3- Also, (Ham ubi suprà,) or ↓ raEavapN, (L,) (assumed tropical:) The zanamap [or wattle], (Ham,) [i. e.] each of the zanamataAni [or two wattles], (L,) of a sheep or goat ($aAp) [or, accord. to some, of a goat only (see ranamapN)]. (Ham, L.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A drinking-vessel, such as is called talotalapN, made of the spathe of a palm-tree; (T, M, L, K, TA;) as also ↓ raEavapN. (K.)
ruEovapN * : see raEavN, in two places.
raEavapN * : see raEavN, in two places: ― -b2- and raEovapN, in three places.

$aApN raEovaA='u * (tropical:) A sheep, or goat, [or, accord. to some, a goat only (see zanamapN),] having two wattles (zanamataAni), beneath her two ears. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- And Alr~aEovaA='u (tropical:) A species of grape, having long berries; (K, TA;) likened to the zanamataAni [or two wattles of a sheep or goat]. (TA.)
riEaAvN * : see raEavN, in two places.
muraE~avN * A boy adorned with the [kind of earring, or ear-drop, called] raEovapN (S) or quroTN. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (tropical:) A cock having a raEovap [or wattle]. (S, TA.)

1 raEadati Als~amaA='u * , (As, Fr, S, L, Msb,) aor.
raEuda (L, Msb) and
raEada , (L,) inf. n. raEodN and ruEuwdN; (Fr, L, Msb;) and ↓ A^aroEadat, (AO, AA, S, L,) but the latter is disallowed by As; (S, TA;) The shy thundered: (S, Msb:) or made a sound [to be heard from the clouds] previously to rain: (L:) and [in like manner] raEada, aor.
raEada and
raEuda , is said of the clouds (Als~aHaAb), or of the angel that drives the clouds. (K.) You say, raEadati Als~amaA='u wabaraqato, and, accord. to AO and AA, waA^aboraqat ↓ A^aroEadat, (S, TA,) which latter As disallows in this case as well as in another mentioned below, (S, * TA,) meaning The sky [thundered and lightened: or] thundered and lightened much before rain. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raEada, inf. n. raEodN, (tropical:) He threatened, or menaced, with evil; as also ↓ ArEd, inf. n. A_iroEaAdN: (Msb:) or the latter signifies he threatened, or menaced; or he frightened, or terrified: (K:) and raEada wabaraqa he frightened, or terrified, (S, K,) and threatened, or menaced; (S;) as also ↓ A^arEada waA^aboraqa: (AO, AA, S:) and raEadalahu and baraqa lahu he threatened him, or menaced him: (As, TA:) and raEada liY biAlqawoli, aor.
raEuda , inf. n. raEodN; and ↓ ArEd; he threatened me, or he frightened me with speech: (TA:) or, accord. to As, ↓ ArEd and Abrq are not allowable: when one cited against him the verse of El-Kumeyt,
A^aroEido waA^aboriqo yaA yaziydu famaA waEiyduka liY biDaAy^iro
(tropical:) [Threaten and menace, O Yezeed, but thy threatening is not harming to me], he denied ElKumeyt to be an authority. (S, TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce jal~a.] Hiyna raEada AlA_isolaAmu wabaraqa, occurring in a trad., means When El-Islám came with its threatening and its terrifying. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] raEadato wabaraqato (tropical:) She (a woman) beautified and adorned herself, (S, A, * K,) and showed, or presented, herself, liY to me: (A:) or she exhibited her beauty intentionally: (TA in art. brq:) and [some hold that] ↓ A^aroEadato [or A^aroEadato waA^aboraqato] signifies the same. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 8, in two places. ― -b5- And see 4.

4 ArEd *
He, or it, (a company of men, S, Msb,) was assailed, or affected, by thunder; (Lh, S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ ruEida: and the former, he heard thunder. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in seven places. -A2- ArEdhu He, or it, (fear, [or cold, see riEodapN,] &c., L,) caused him to tremble, quiver, quake, shiver, or be in a state of commotion. (S, * L.) ― -b2- See also 8, in two places. ― -b3- Also A^uroEida (tropical:) It (a hill, or heap, of sand) poured down; or became [shaken, and consequently] poured down. (IAar, K, TA.)
5 taraE~ada see the next paragraph, in two places.

8 ArtEd *
He trembled, quivered, quaked, shivered, or became in a state of commotion, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) by reason of fear, (A, L,) or cold, (A,) &c.; (L;) as also rEd, aor. yrEd: (Msb: [written in my copy without any syll. signs; but it seems to be indicated that it is ↓ raEada aor. yaroEudu: I believe, however, that ↓ ruEida is also used in this sense, and in the sense here following:]) he was affected with a tremour, quivering, quaking, shivering, or commotion; (A, L;) as also ↓ A^uroEida, (S, A, L, K,) and ↓ taraEodada, (L,) and ↓ trE~d; (TA;) by fear, (A, L,) or cold, (A,) &c. (L.) You say, faraAy^iSuhu Einoda ↓ A^uroEidato AlfazaEi (tropical:) [His muscles called the frAy^Sa (pl. of fariySapN q. v.) quivered on the occasion of fright]. (S, A, * L.) And AlA^aloyapu ↓ taraE~adati, (K,) or, as in some of the Lexicons, ↓ taraEodadat, (TA,) (tropical:) The Alyp [or buttock, or buttocks, &c.,] quivered, or moved to and fro: (K, TA:) and in like manner one says of anything subject to such motion; as [the kinds of food called] qariys and faAluw*, and a hill or heap of sand, and the like. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 raEodada *
He was importunate in asking, or begging. (S.)
R. Q. 2 taraEodada * : see 8, in two places.

raEodN *
Thunder; i. e. the sound that is heard from the clouds, (S, K, *) or from the sky: (A:) so say the people of the desert: (Akh, TA:) [thus termed as being supposed to be a trembling, or state of agitation, of the clouds, as is implied in the Ksh and the Expos. of Bd in ii. 18, where it is said to be from AlAirotiEaAd, or as being a cause of trembling:] originally an inf. n., and therefore [it is said that] it has no pl.: (Bd ubi suprà:) [but see what follows, in which ruEuwdN occurs, perhaps as its pl.:] or Alr~aEodu is the name of an angel who drives the clouds [with his voice] like as a man drives camels with singing. (I'Ab, Z, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jaA='a bi*aAti Alr~aEodi waAlS~aliyli i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He brought, or brought to pass, that which had thunder and noise; meaning,] (tropical:) war: (S, K, TA:) or calamity: (A, TA:) and bi*awaAti ↓ Alr~awaAEidi (tropical:) calamities: (A:) [for] ↓ *aAtu Alr~awaAEidi [in the CK *awAtu] signifies calamity. (S, K, TA.) And fiY kitaAbihi ruEuwdN waburuwqN [which may be rendered In his letter are thunders and lightnings;] meaning, (tropical:) words of threatening. (A.)
raEodapN * : see what next follows.

riEodapN *
A tremour, quivering, quaking, shivering, or commotion, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) occasioned by fear, (A, L,) or cold, (A,) &c; (L;) and ↓ raEodapN signifies the same. (K.)

riEodiydN *
Cowardly; (S, A, L, K;) that trembles, or quakes, (A, L,) from fear, (A,) or at fighting, by reason of cowardice; (L;) and in like manner riEodiydapN applied to a woman: (A:) or this has the former signification, [but in an intensive sense,] as also ↓ tiroEiydN: pl. [of the first or second] raEaAdiydu. (L.) ― -b2- Also the first, (S, K,) or second, (A, L,) applied to a woman, (S, L, K,) or a girl, (A,) (tropical:) Soft, or tender; (S, A, L, K;) whose flesh quivers by reason of its softness: (L:) pl. as above. (A.) ― -b3- And the first, (assumed tropical:) A soft, or tender, plant. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- And [(tropical:) Anything quivering or quaking: hence, as a subst., particularly applied to The kind of sweet food called] faAluw*aj, (A,) or faAluw*. (K.) It was said to an Arab of the desert, “ Dost thou know what is called fAlw* ? ” and he answered, naEamo A^aSofaru riEodiydN [Yes: it is yellow, quivering]. (S.) ― -b5- Also, (A,) and ↓ muroEadN, (IAar, A, K,) (tropical:) A hill, or heap, of sand [shaking, or shaken, and consequently] pouring down. (IAar, A, K.)

ruEayodaA='u *
What is thrown away from wheat when it is picked, or cleansed, (L, K,) as the zuwaAn [or zuw^aAn, q. v.,] and the like: by some written rgydA='; but the former is more correct. (L.)

raE~aAdN * [That thunders much]. saHaAbapN raE~aAdapN signifies A cloud that thunders much: (TA:) but Ks says, “ We have not heard them say thus. ” (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] applied to a man, (S,) (assumed tropical:) Loquacious; (S, K;) and so raE~aAdapN [but in an intensive sense]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, [as a coll. gen. n., n. un.
with p, The torpedo: and the silurus electricus, found in the Nile: generally meaning the latter:] a certain fish; when a man touches it, a numbness affects his hand and arm to the shoulders, and a tremour, as long as the fish remains alive: (S, K: *) so called because he who lays hold upon it, when it is alive, trembles with a kind of trembling wherewith he cannot restrain himself; it is a kind of trembling with a coldness, or chilness, and intense numbness, and formication in the limbs, and heaviness, so that he possesses no power over himself, and cannot lay hold of anything at all with his hand; the numbness rising by degrees to his upper arm and his shoulderblade and the whole of his side, when he touches the fish with the slightest touch in the shortest time. (So says 'Abd-El-Lateef. [See “ Abdollatiphi Hist. Aeg. Comp. ” p. 82; and De Sacy's Translation and Notes.])

saHaAbN raAEidN * [Thundering clouds]: and saHaAbapN raAEidapN [a thundering cloud]: (A:) pl. of the fem. rawaAEidu. (Ham p. 440.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce A_im~aA.] SalafN taHota Alr~aAEidapi [A lack, or paucity, of rain beneath the thundering cloud], (S, K,) or rub~a SalifK taHota Alr~aAEidapi, (S and K &c. in art. Slf,) or rub~a SalafK (A, and S and K &c. in art. Slf,) [i. e., accord. as we read SalifK or SalafK, Many a cloud lacking, or having little, rain, or oftentimes a lack, or paucity, of rain, is there beneath the thundering cloud,] is a prov., (A,) applied to a loquacious man destitute of good: (S, A, K:) or to a loquacious man who speaks much of that which he has not done: (Nh, TA:) or to one who threatens and does not perform: (S and O and K in art. Slf:) or to the wealthy niggard: (A'Obeyd, K in that art.:) or to him who praises himself much and is destitute of good. (IDrd, K in that art.) ― -b2- See also raEodN, in two places.
tiroEiydN * : see riEodiydN.
muroEadN * : see riEodiydN.

muraEodidN *
Importunate in asking, or begging. (K.)
maroEazN * and maroEiz~N: see what here follows.

miroEiz~aY * (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and maroEiz~aY (S, K) and ↓ miroEizaA='u and maroEizaA='u (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ miroEiz~N (S, Msb, K) and maroEiz~N (S, K) and ↓ maroEazN, the last like jaEofarN, but not miroEizN, (Msb,) The down, (S, Msb, K,) or what resembles wool, (Az, Mgh,) that is beneath, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or amid, (Az,) the hair of the she-goat: (Az, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) Sb makes miroEiz~aY an epithet; meaning soft, applied to wool: and Kr says that this and miroEizaA='u are the only words of these two measures in the language: (TA:) [he seems to have held the m to be a radical letter: but accord. to J,] mrEz~Y is of the measure mafoEil~aY, because faEolil~aY does not occur [except in the instance of $ifoSil~aY, the name of a certain plant]. (S.)
maroEizaA='u * : see what immediately precedes.

vawobN mumaroEazN *
A garment, or piece of cloth, made of maroEiz~aY. (K.)

1 raEi$a * , (S, A, K,) aor.
raEa$a ; and raEa$a, aor.
raEa$a ; (A, K;) inf. n. (of the former, S) raEa$N; (S, K;) and [of the latter,] raEo$N; (K;) He trembled, quivered, quaked, or shivered; (S;) as also ↓ ArtE$: (S, A, * K:) or he was taken with a tremour, quivering, quaking, or shivering: (A, K:) [or he was made to tremble, &c.; for] raEi$ato yaduhu is like ↓ A^uroEi$ato [His hand, or arm, was made to tremble, &c.]. (Zj.) And raEo$N, like manoEN [in form], signifies The shaking of the head in going along, and in sleep. (TA.) You say also, ↓ ArtE$ raA^osuhu His head shook by reason of old age. (A, TA.) And yaduhu ↓ ArtE$t, (TA,) and A^anaAmiluhu, (A, TA,) and mafaASiluhu, (TA,) His hand, or arm, and the ends, or end-joints, of his fingers, and his joints, trembled, or quivered. (TA.)
2 raE~a$a see what next follows.

4 ArE$h *
He, (God, S, K,) or it, (old age, A,) made him to tremble, quiver, quake, or shiver; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ rE~$hu. (A.) You say also, A^uroEi$ato yadaAhu [His hands, or arms, were made to tremble]. (A.) See also 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] A^aroEa$atohu AlHarobu (tropical:) War, or the war, made him to hasten, or be quick. (A, TA. *)
8 A_irotaEa$a see 1, in three places.

raEi$N * , applied to a man, (TA,) or to an old man, (A,) Trembling, quivering, quaking, or shivering; (A, TA;) as also ↓ raEiy$N and ↓ murotaEi$N (TA) and ↓ muroEa$N; (A;) and so ↓ raEo$anN, applied to a man; (S;) in which last, the n is augmentative. (S, K.) And in like manner, ↓ raEo$anN, applied to a hecamel; (S, TA;) and raEi$apN (A) and ↓ raEo$anapN (TA) and ↓ raEo$aA='u, (A, K, TA,) applied to a she-camel; (K, TA;) or to a beast (daAb~apN), (A,) and the last of these epithets applied to a she-ostrich; (S;) (tropical:) That shakes himself, or herself, (S, A, K,) in going along, (S, K,) by reason of speed, (K,) or from sharpness of spirit, and briskness: (A:) or ↓ rE$A', applied to a she-camel, signifies longnecked. (TA.) And ↓ raEuw$N, applied to a she-camel, Whose head shakes by reason of old age; (S, K;) as also raEuwsN; (S, TA;) or, as the latter is expl. in the K, by reason of briskness, or sprightliness. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Cowardly; or a coward; (S, K;) as also ↓ riEo$iy$N (K) and ↓ raEo$anN, (K in art. rE$n,) and raEi$u Alyadayoni; (A, TA;) one who trembles in war by reason of cowardice. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Quick; swift; applied to a male ostrich; (Kh;) as also ↓ raEo$anN, applied to the same, and to a camel; fem. with p; (K in art. rE$n;) and ↓ raEo$aA='u, applied to a female ostrich: (Kh, K:) or the last, thus applied, signifies tall. (TA.) ― -b4- fulaAnN raEi$N A_ilaY AlqitaAli, and A_ilaY AlmaEoruwfi; (En-Nadr, A, K, TA;) and ↓ riEo$iy$N; (K;) (tropical:) Such a one is quick to fight, and to do good, or confer a favour or benefit. (En-Nadr, A, K.) In the K it is added that it thus has two contr. significations; but this requires consideration. (TA.)

riEo$apN * : see ruEaA$N, in two places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Haste, or quickness. (A, TA.) You say, bihi riEo$apN A_ilaY liqaA='i Eaduw~ihi (tropical:) In him is haste, or quickness, to meet his enemy. (A.)
raEo$aA='u * : see raEi$N, throughout.
raEo$anN * : see raEi$N, throughout.
riEo$iy$N * : see raEi$N, throughout.

ruEaA$N * [and ↓ riEo$apN] A tremour, quivering, quaking, or shivering, that befalls a man in consequence of a disease that attacks him, not quitting him. (TA.) You say, ↓ bihi riEo$apN and ruEaA$N [In him is a tremour, &c.]. (A.)
raEuw$N * : see raEi$N.
raEiy$N * : see raEi$N.

maroEa$N *
A kind of pigeons that soar in their flight and circle in the air; as also ↓ muroEa$N: (S, K:) the latter form being sometimes used: (S:) or this signifies the white pigeon: or, accord. to Abu-l-'Alà, the vulture (nasor) that has become extremely aged, or old and weak. (Ham p. 823.)
muroEa$N * : see raEi$N: -A2- and maroEa$N.
murotaEi$N * : see raEi$N.

div2.head: Quasi rE$n
div2.entryFree: raEo$anN * ; fem. with p: see raEi$N, in art. rE$.

1 raEaZahu * , aor.
raEaZa , (K,) inf. n. raEoZN, (TA,) He made a ruEoZ [q. v.] to it, namely, an arrow; as also ↓ ArEZhu: (K:) or you say, raEaZahu biAlEaqabi, meaning he wound and bound the sinew upon it, namely, an arrow; as also ↓ ArEZhu. (TA.) ― -b2- And He broke its ruEoZ; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) as also ↓ ArEZhu. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) -A2- raEiZa, aor.
raEaZa , inf. n. raEaZN, It (an arrow) had its ruEoZ broken; its ruEoZ broke. (S.)
4 A^aroEaZa see 1, in three places.

ruEoZN * The socket of the head of an arrow, or place into which the head enters, over which are the twists of sinew: pl. A^aroEaAZN. (Lth, S, K.) It is said in a prov., A_in~a fulaAnFA layakosiru Ealayoka A^aroEaAZa Aln~aboli [Verily such a one breaks against thee the sockets of the heads of the arrows]: applied to him whose anger is vehement: as though one said, when he takes the arrow, (K, TA,) being vehemently angry, (TA,) he strikes the ground with its point, in his silent wrath, with such vehemence as to break the socket of its head: or it means (tropical:) he grates the teeth at thee, (K, TA,) by reason of the vehemence of his anger, so that their sockets break; (TA;) the sockets of the dog-teeth being
thus likened to the sockets of arrow-heads: (K, TA:) so in the O and L. (TA.) And it is said in another prov., maA qadarotu EalaY ka*aA Hat~aY taEaT~afato EalaY~a A^aroEaAZu Aln~aboli [I was not able to do such a thing until the sockets of the heads of the arrows became much bent against me]. (O, K.)

raEiZN * An arrow having its ruEoZ broken: (S:) and [in like manner,] ↓ marEuwZN an arrow having its ruEoZ broken, and being therefore bound with sinew: (IB:) or the latter signifies a weak arrow. (Aboo-Kheyreh El-'Adawee, Ibn-' Abbád.)
raEiyZN * and ↓ maroEuwZN An arrow [having a ruEoZ made to it: (see 1:) or] having the sinew wound and bound upon it. (TA.)
maroEuwZN * : see raEiZN: ― -b2- and raEiyZN.

1 raEafa * , aor.
raEafa and
raEufa , (S, K,) inf. n. raEofN, (TK,) He (a horse) preceded; went, or got, before; outwent, outran, or outstripped; as also ↓ AstrEf, (S, K,) and ↓ ArtEf. (K.) [This is held by some, and is said in the O, to be the primary signification: see ruEaAfN.] ― -b2- raEifa Ald~amu, aor.
raEafa , The blood flowed. (K.) And raEafa A^anofuhu His nose bled; blood flowed from his nose: this is the chaste form of the verb: ruEifa, from which is formed the part. n. maroEuwfN, is incorrect; (Mgh;) unknown to As: (O:) [or] raEafa alone, aor.
raEufa and
raEafa , has this last signification; as also raEufa, (S, O, * Msb, K,) but this is a dial. var. of weak authority, (S, O,) or is rare; (Msb;) and raEifa, aor.
raEafa ; and ruEifa [mentioned above as incorrect]; (K;) and the inf. n. is raEofN (Msb, K) and ruEaAfN, (K,) or the latter is a simple subst. (Msb.) [And hence raEafa signifies also (assumed tropical:) It (a vessel, such as a skin,) overflowed:] see 4, in two places. ― -b3- raEafa bihi AlbaAba He entered with him the door. (O, K.)
2 raE~afa see the next paragraph, in two places.

4 ArEfhu *
He incited him, or urged him, to hasten, or be quick: (S, O, K:) but this is said to be not of established authority. (O.) ― -b2- [And He, or it, made his nose to bleed, or flow with blood: often used in this sense; as in the S and A and K voce A^anovara, and in the L and K voce laboxapN: and so ↓ rE~fh: accord. to Ibn-Maaroof,] the inf. ns. A_iroEaAfN and ↓ taroEiyfN signify the bringing blood from the nose. (KL.) ― -b3- And ArEf Alqirobapa He filled the skin (S, O, K) so that it overflowed (↓ Hat~aY taroEufa): (S, O:) whence the saying of a rájiz, ['Amr Ibn-Leja, so in a copy of the S,]
A^aEolaAhaA mini A@motilaAy^ihaA ↓ yaroEufu
[Its upper part overflows, or overflowing, by reason of its fulness]. (S.)
8 A_irotaEafa see 1, first sentence.

10 A_isotaroEafa see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- AisotiroEaAfN also signifies The drawing forth blood from the nose. (KL. [Golius, as on this authority, explains the verb as signifying “ Nasum prehendit: ” but the inf. n. is explained in the KL by the words xwn brA=wrdn Az bynY; which I have rendered above.]) ― -b3- [Hence,] AstrEf AlHaSaY manosima AlbaEiyri (assumed tropical:) The pebbles made the toe, or sole, or foot, of the camel to bleed. (S.) ― -b4- And AstrEf [or AstrEf Al$~aHomapa] (assumed tropical:) He endeavoured to make the piece of fat to drip, and took what became melted thereof. (Th, O, K.)

ruEaAfN * an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]: (K:) or a simple subst., of which the primary meaning is The act of preceding; going, or getting, before; outgoing, outrunning, or outstripping. (Msb.) ― -b2- And hence, The issuing of blood from the nose: (O, * Msb:) or, accord. to some, (Msb,) blood itself, issuing, or that issues, from the nose: (S, O, * Msb, K:) because it issues before one knows it. (Msb.)
ruEuwfN * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] (assumed tropical:) Light rains. (IAar, O, K.)

raEiyfN *
Clouds (saHaAbN) preceding another cloud. (AA, O, K.)
ruEaAfiY~N * One who gives many gifts. (Fr, O, K.)

[
raE~aAfN *
Emitting much blood: mentioned by Freytag, but without any indication of the authority.]

raAEifN * A horse that precedes other horses; that goes, or gets, before them; that outgoes, outruns, or outstrips, them; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ musotaroEifN. (O, K.) ― -b2- Having blood flowing from his nose: (Msb:) or having a continual bleeding of the nose. (PS and TK voce mudiymN, in art. dwm.) And A^unuwfN rawaAEifu [Noses bleeding]. (O.) ― -b3- The extremity of the A^aronabap [or lower portion, or lobule, of the nose]; (S, O, K;) [because the blood drops from it when the nose bleeds.] (S, K.) ― -b4- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) A prominence, or projecting part, of a mountain. (S, O, K.) ― -b5- rimaAHN rawaAEifu Spears that are the first to thrust, or pierce: or from which blood is dropping: (S:) or spears are termed rawaAEifu because thrust forward to pierce, or because blood drops from them. (IDrd, O.)

raAEuwfapu biy^orK * and ↓ A^uroEuwfatuhaA, (S, O, K,) both mentioned by A'Obeyd, (S, O,) A piece of rock that is left in the bottom of a well, being there when it is dug, in order that the cleanser of the well may sit upon it in cleansing it: or a stone that is at the head of the well, upon which the drawer of water stands. (S, O, K.) It is said in a trad., “ When he (Mohammad) was enchanted, his charm was put into the spathe (juf~) of a palm-tree, and buried beneath the rAEwfp of the well. ” (S, O.)
A^uroEuwfapu Albiy^ori * : see the next preceding paragraph.
AlmuroEifu * : see AlmuzoEifu.
maroEuwfN * , as part. n. of ruEifa, is [said to be] incorrect. (Mgh.)

maraAEifu * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] The nose and the parts around it. (O, K.) One says, faEalotu *aAka EalaY Alr~agomi mino maraAEifihi, like maraAgimihi. (S, O. * [See art. rgm.])
musotaroEifN * : see raAEifN. [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 raEuna * , (S, K,) and raEina, and raEana, (K,) [aor. of the first
raEuna , and of the second and third
raEana ,] inf. n. [of the first] ruEuwnapN, and [of the second, or second and third,] raEanN, (S, * K,) He was, or became, foolish, stupid, unsound in intellect or understanding, or deficient therein, and lax, flaccid, slack, or languid: (S, K:) or ruEuwnapN and raEanN signify the being foolish, or stupid: and also the being soft, weak, relaxed, or languid. (KL.) ― -b2- And raEanN also signifies [simply] The being slack, or loose; or slackness, or looseness; as in the saying of a rájiz, (S, TA,) namely, Khitám El-Mujáshi'ee, (TA,) describing a she-camel,
waraHaluwhaA riHolapF fiyhaA raEano
[And they saddled her in a manner of saddling in which was a slackness, or looseness]; i. e. they did not bind her saddle firmly, by reason of fear and haste. (S, TA.) Also The being unsteady, or in a state of commotion or agitation: and quickly changing or altering. (Meyd, in explanation of a prov. cited below, voce A^aroEanu.) [And accord. to Freytag, as on the authority of Meyd, Haste of pace.] ― -b3- And ruEuwnapN signifies also The being beautified, and adorned: and raEanN, the displaying oneself adorned. (KL.) -A2- raEanatohu Al$~amosu, (S, K,) inf. n. raEonN, (KL,) The sun rendered him relaxed, (S, KL,) or weak, or languid: (KL:) or pained his brain, so that he became relaxed thereby, and swooned. (K.) And ruEina He (a man) became thus affected by the sun. (TA.) Pass. part. n. ↓ maroEuwnN, signifying Thus affected by the sun; (S, TA;) applied to a man. (TA.)

4 maA A^aroEanahu *
How foolish, stupid, unsound in intellect or understanding, or deficient therein, and lax, flaccid, slack, or languid, [or how foolish, or stupid, and how soft, weak, relaxed, or languid, (see 1,)] is he! (S, K.)

raEonN *
A prominence, or projecting part, (S, K,) or such as is large, (TA,) of a mountain: (S, K:) pl. ruEuwnN and riEaAnN. (S, K.) And A long mountain: (K:) or, accord. to Lth, a mountain that is not long: pl. ruEuwnN. (TA.)
raEan~aka * a dial. var. of laEal~aka. (Lh, K.)

raEuwnN *
Having much motion; or moving itself much. (K.) ― -b2- And Hard, or strong. (K.) -A2- And (as some say, TA) The darkness of night: (K, TA:) or [simply] darkness. (TA.)

raAEinaA * in the phrase laA taquwluwA raAEinaA, in the Kur [ii. 98, and occurring again in iv. 48], is said to be a word meant to convey a reviling of the Prophet, derived from [the inf. n.] Alr~uEuwnapu: El-Hasan read raAEinFA, with tenween: and Th says that the phrase means Say not ye a lie, and mockery, and foolishness. (TA.) [See also 4 in art. rEY.]

A^aroEanu * , (S, K,) applied to a man, (S,) Foolish, stupid, unsound in intellect or understanding, or deficient therein, and lax, flaccid, slack, or languid: (S, K:) or, so applied, foolish, or stupid: (KL:) [and also soft, weak, relaxed, or languid: (see 1:)] and foolish, or stupid, and hasty, in speech: (K:) fem., applied to a woman, raEonaA='u: (S:) [pl. ruEonN.] ― -b2- [Its primary application, though I do not find it mentioned, is probably to a mountain, as meaning Having a raEon, or prominence, or projecting part: accord. to Freytag, “ is qui habet rEn: ” and then poetically used, in the Deewán of Jereer, as signifying a mountain. ― -b3- And hence,] also, applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Having a long nose [likened to a raEon]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) An army having redundant parts, or portions, (K, TA,) like the riEaAn of mountains: (TA:) or an army has this epithet applied to it as being likened to the raEon of a mountain: or, as some say, the epithet thus applied means in a state of commotion by reason of its numerousness. (S.) ― -b5- El-Basrah is termed Alr~aEonaA='u, as being likened to the raEon of a mountain; (IDrd, S, K;) i. e., because of a bend in it: (TA:) or because of the abundant flow of the river there, and its sultry heat: (Az, MF:) or because of the ease and plenty that are in it, and as being likened to the woman to whom this epithet is applied; or because of the languidness and changeableness of its air. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b6- And Alr~aEonaA='u is also a name of A sort of grapes, of Et-Táïf, (K, TA,) white, and long in the berries. (TA.) -A2- A^aroEanu mino hawaA='i AlbaSorapi is a prov., meaning More unsteady and changeable than the air of El-Basrah. (Meyd.)
maroEuwnN * : see 1, last sentence.

1 raEaA * , aor. yaroEuw, (S, TA,) [He refrained, forbore, or abstained: or, used elliptically,] he refrained, forbore, or abstained, (S, TA,) from things, or affairs, (S,) or from ignorance, and reverted therefrom in a good manner; (TA;) [as also ↓ AiroEawaY; (K;) [for] raEowN and riEowN and ruEuwN (K) and raEowapN and riEowapN (S, K) and ruEowapN (K) are syn. with ↓ AiroEiwaA='N (S, K) meaning the refraining, forbearing, or abstaining, from ignorance, and reverting therefrom in a good manner, (K, TA,) [all app. as inf. ns.,] and so are ↓ raEuwaY (S, K) and ↓ ruEowaY (K) and ↓ ruEoyaA, (S, K,) [in the last of which the radical w is changed into Y as it is in dunoyaA and EuloyaA and quSoyaA,] but these three, as some say, (TA,) or the first and last of these three, (S,) are simple substs.: (S, TA:) you say, fulaAnN Hasanu Alr~aEowapi and Alr~iEowapi and ↓ Alr~aEowaY [&c., meaning Such a one is good in respect of refraining, &c.]. (S.) ↓ AiroEawaY is of the measure AifoEalala [for AifoEal~a]; the two infirm letters not being incorporated, one into the other, because the Y is quiescent: (S: [see also Ham p. 220:]) you say, Eani AlqabiyHi ↓ ArEwY, (S, Msb,) or En Aljaholi, (Ham ubi suprà,) He refrained, forbore, or abstained, from bad, or foul, conduct, (S, Msb,) or from ignorance, and reverted therefrom: (Ham:) and ↓ ArEwY [alone] signifies He refrained, forbore, or abstained; and he repented: (Har p. 240:) [see also an ex. in a verse cited voce A^alaA:] accord. to AHei, it is quasi-pass. of raEawotuhu. (TA.) -A2- [Hence, raEawotuhu app. signifies I caused him to refrain, forbear, or abstain, &c.]
9 AiroEawaY * , inf. n. AiroEiwaA='N: see the preceding paragraph, in five places.
raEowaY * and ruEowaY: see 1, in three places: ― -b2- and see also art. rEY.
ruEoyaA * : see 1: ― -b2- and see also art. rEY.
raEaAwaY * and ruEaAwaY: see art. rEY.
raEaAwiy~apN * (in some copies of the K raEaAwiyap, without teshdeed); and ruEaAwiy~apN: see art. rEY.
A^aroEuw~apN * : see art. rEY.
A^aroEaAwiy~apN * : see art. rEY.

1 raEati AlmaA$iyapu * , aor. taroEaY, (Msb, K,) inf. n. raEoYN (S, * Msb, K) and riEaAyapN (K) and maroEFY; (S, * K, * JM;) and ↓ ArtEt, and ↓ trE~t; (K;) The cattle [pastured, or] pastured by themselves. (Msb.) And raEati AlmaA$iyapu AlkalaA^a, inf. n. raEoYN (Mgh, TA) and riEaAyapN [and maroEFY]; and ↓ ArtEt, and ↓ trE~t; [The cattle pastured upon, or depastured, the herbage;] all signifying the same: (TA:) and of a camel you say, raEaY AlkalaA^a binafosihi, inf. n. raEoYN [&c., He pastured upon, or depastured, the herbage by himself]; and in like manner ↓ ArtEY. (S.) ― -b2- The saying of 'Áïsheh faA_ino kaAnato taroEaY maA hunaAlika is an allusion to the feeling, or touching, of the faroj itself. (Mgh.) -A2- raEoYN also signifies The keeping, or tending, animals; pasturing, or feeding, them; and defending them from the enemy. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say, raEayotu AlA_ibila, (S,) or AlmaA$iyapa, (Msb, K,) or Alganama, (MA,) aor. A^aroEaAhaA, (S, Msb,) inf. n. raEoYN (S, MA) [and riEaAyapN, as appears from a phrase mentioned below,] and riEoyapN, (MA,) or this last is a simple subst. from this verb, (K,) I [kept, or tended, or] pastured, (MA, Msb,) or lead to pasture, (MA,) the camels, (S,) or the cattle, (Msb, K,) or the sheep or goats; (MA;) and ↓ ArEAhA signifies the same as raEaAhaA. (K.) And SinaAEatuhu riEaAyapu AlA_ibili [His habitual work, or occupation, is the tending, or pasturing, of camels]. (ISd, K.) And fulaAnN yaroEaY A^abiyhi [Such a one tends, or pastures, for his father;] i. e. yaroEaY ganamahu [tends, or pastures, his father's sheep or goats]. (S.) ― -b2- And hence, as also riEaAyapN, The keeping or guarding [a person or thing]; being mindful or regardful [of him or it]; and managing or ruling or governing [him or it]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say, raEayotuhu I kept, or guarded, him, as a ruler or governor, or a prince or commander, who manages, conducts, orders, or regulates, the affairs of the people: (Msb:) and raEaY AlA^amiyru raEiy~atahu [The prince ruled, or governed, his subjects], inf. n. riEaAyapN. (S.) And raEoyFA laka [I beg God's keeping, or guarding, for thee]; meaning raEaAka A@ll~`hu May God keep thee, or guard thee. (Har p. 617.) And raEaY A^amorahu, (K,) inf. n. raEoYN (TA) [and riEaAyapN], He was mindful, or regardful, of his affair, or case; as also Amrh ↓ rAEY, (K, TA,) inf. n. muraAEaApN. (TA.) And riEaA='N [app. as an inf. n. of ↓ rAEY] signifies The guarding of palm-trees. (TA.) famaA raEawohaA Haq~a riEaAyatihaA, in the Kur [lvii. 27], means But they did not observe it with its right, or due, observance; were not mindful, watchful, observant, or regardful, of it, in the right, or due, manner of being so. (TA.) You say also, raEayotu Ealayohi Huromatahu, inf. n. riEaAyapN, (ISk, S,) i. e. 1 was mindful, regardful, or observant, of his Hrmp [meaning of what was entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence, in his character and appertenances]: and in like manner, ↓ muraAEaApN AlHuquwqi, mentioned in the S, means The being mindful, regardful, or observant, of rights, or dues. (PS.) This last phrase is from ↓ raAEayotuhu, inf. n. muraAEaApN, (TA,) which means I regarded him; had regard, or an eye, to him; or paid regard, or consideration, to him; (S, Msb, K, TA;) acting, or behaving, well to him; doing good to him; or conferring a benefit, or benefits, upon him. (K, TA.) [Hence also, fiyhi ka*aA ↓ ruwEiYa Regard is had, in it, (the meaning of a word or phrase,) to such a thing, as alluded to therein.] And AlA^amora ↓ raAEayotu, (S, K,) inf. n. muraAEaApN, (TA,) signifies also I looked to see what would be the issue, or result, of the affair, or case. (S, Msb, K.) Hence, accord. to Er-Rághib, Aln~ujuwmi ↓ muraAEaApu: (TA:) you say, raEaY Aln~ujuwma; (S, K;) and ↓ raAEaAhaA, (K,) inf. n. muraAEaApN; (TA;) He watched the stars, (S, K, TA,) waiting for the time when they would disappear. (K, TA.) El-Khansà says,
↓ A^aroEaY Aln~ujwma wamaA kul~ifotu riEoyatahaA
wataArapF A^ataga$~aY faDola A^aTomaAriY
[I watch, or I watching, the stars, waiting for the time when they will, or would, disappear, though I am not, or I was not, tasked with the watching of them; and at one time I cover myself, or covering myself, with the redundant parts of my old and worn-out garments]. (S.) ― -b3- riEaAyapN also signifies The being faithful to an engagement, or promise; syn. wafaA='N. (Mgh. [See raAEK, below; last sentence.])
2 rE~Ahu * , inf. n. taroEiyapN, He said [of him], raEaAhu A@ll~`hu [May God keep him, or guard him: or he said to him, raEaAka A@ll~`hu May God keep thee, or guard thee]. (TA.)

3 rAEY AlHimaAru AlHumura *
The ass pastured with the [other] asses: (S, K:) and in like manner one says of camels with wild animals. (TA.) ― -b2- rAEt AlA^aroDu, a reading required by the context in the K, is wrong; the correct phrase being ArEt AlA^aroDu [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in eight places. ― -b4- AlmuraAEaApu is also syn. with AlmunaAZarapu [app. as meaning The looking towards, or facing, a person or thing: a signification nearly like the last referred to in the
sentence here immediately preceding]. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 4, in three places. ― -b6- war~iEi All~iS~a walaA turaAEihi, in a trad. of 'Omar, means Restrain thou the thief, or make him to refrain, from taking thy goods, but bear not witness against him: so says Lth: or the meaning is, and do not wait for him. (TA.)

4 ArEY AlmaA$iyapa *
i. q. raEaAhaA: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph. Said of God, it means He caused to grow, for the cattle, that upon which they might pasture. (S.) One says also ArEt AlA^aroDu, [as though AlmaA$iyapa or the like were understood] The land abounded [as though it fed abundantly] with herbage: (Zj, K:) rAEt AlA^aroDu, in this sense [as stated above, see 3,] is wrong. (TA.) And ArEAhu AlmakaAna He made the place to be a pasturage for him. (ISd, K.) ― -b2- A^arEayotuhu samoEiY means I made my ear, or ears, to be mindful of his speech: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or I gave ear, hearkened, or listened, to him. (S, Msb.) You say, A^aroEiniY samoEaka, (Msb, K,) and ↓ raAEiniY, i. e. Hearken thou, or listen thou, to my speech. (K.) Hence ↓ raAEinaA in the Kur [ii. 98 and iv. 48]: Akh says that it is of the form faAEilonaA from AlmuraAEaApu, and means A^aroEinaA samoEaka; the Y having gone away because it is an imperative: he says also that it is read raAEinFA, as an objective complement, from Alr~uEuwnapu: (S: [see art. rEn:]) the reading in Ibn-Mes'ood's copy of the Kur-án is raAEuwnaA. (TA.) You say also, huwa laA yuroEiY A_ilaY qawoli A^aHadK He will not pay any regard, or attention, to the saying of any one. (TA.) ― -b3- And A^aroEayotu Ealayohi I showed mercy to him [by sparing him, or letting him live, or by pardoning him, or otherwise]; had mercy on him; pitied, or compassionated, him; syn. A^aboqayotu Ealayohi and taraH~amotuhu. (S, K.) Aboo-Dahbal says,
A_ino kaAna h`*aA Als~iHoru minoki falaA
turoEiY EalaY~a wajad~idiY siHoraA
[app. meaning If this enchantment be from thee, then spare me not, but renew enchantment]. (TA. [It seems to be there cited as an instance of the verb's having a second objective complement; (for which I see no reason;) following the assertion that one says, A^aroEaY Ealayohi ka*aA, signifying AbqY; and that the verb is made trans. by means of ElY as properly meaning ArEAh mtTlEA Elyh: but I doubt not that the correct reading is A^aroEaAhu muT~aliEFA Ealayohi, i. e. He showed mercy to him, coming to him, or getting sight and knowledge of him.]) ↓ AlmuraAEaA=pu, also, [or AlmuraAEaApu EalaY Al$~aYo'i,] signifies AlA_iboqaA='u EalaY Al$~aYo'i. (TA.)
5 taraE~aYa see 1, first and second sentences.
8 A_irotaEaYa see 1, in three places, first two sentences.

10 AstrEY * [app. signifies He desired cattle to pasture: and hence, he left them to pasture alone]. You say, AisotaroEayotu maAliYa Alqamara, meaning I left my cattle to pasture without a pastor to take care of them in the night: and [in like manner,] AstrEythu Al$~amosa, in the day. (TA in art. qmr.) ― -b2- AisotaroEayotuhu Al$~aYo'a (S, K *) I asked him, or desired him, to keep or guard, or be mindful of or regardful of, the thing. (K, * TA.) Hence the prov., mani A@sotaroEaY Al*~iy^oba faqado Zalama [He who asks, or desires, the wolf to keep guard does wrong]; (S, TA;) i. e. he who trusts in one who is treacherous puts trust in a wrong place. (TA.) [And hence also,] AisotaroEaY AlA^asomaAEa lixuTobatihi He asked, or desired, the ears [meaning the hearers] to mind his discourse, or oration. (Har p. 361.)

riEoYN * and ↓ maroEFY Pasture, or herbage; (S, Mgh, K;) the food of beasts: (Msb:) pl. of the former A^aroEaA='N [meaning kinds, or sorts, of pasture or herbage]: (K:) and of ↓ the latter maraAEK. (Msb.) It is said in a prov., walaA kaAls~aEodaAni ↓ maroEFY [Pasture, but not like the sEdAn: see art. sEd]. (S.) ― -b2- riEoYu AlHamaAmi waAlA_ibili A certain herb, having berries like myrtle-berries, in which is the least degree of sweetness; not injurious to the camels that feed upon it, but poison to [venomous or noxious reptiles or the like, such as are termed] hawaAm~: the decoction thereof blackens the hair. (Ibn-Seenà, book ii. p. 252.)

riEoyapN * a subst. from 1 in the first of the senses mentioned in this art.; i. e. [The act of cattle's pasturing, or their pasturing alone,] from raEati AlmaA$iyapu. (K.) ― -b2- [Also The act, or occupation, of keeping or tending, or of pasturing or feeding, animals.] You say [of a man], yujiydu riEoyapa AlA_ibili [He performs well the act of keeping or tending, or of pasturing or feeding, camels]. (S, K.) ― -b3- [And The act of watching, and waiting for the time of the disappearance, of the stars.] See a verse cited near the end of the first paragraph. -A2- Also Land in which are projecting stones that impede the plough. (K, TA.)

raEowaY * and ruEowaY: see the next paragraph. ― -b2- [Both seem to be also substs. from A^aroEayotu Ealayohi; and thus to be syn. with baqowaY and buqowaY; and in like manner, ↓ ruEoyaA is probably syn. with buqoyaA: the radical Y being changed into w as it is in bqwY.] You say, maA liY Ealayohi raEowaY walaA baqowaY [I have no mercy nor pity to bestow upon him]. (JK in art. bqY. [See buqoyaA.]) See also 1 in art. rEw [from which raEowaY in this phrase may also with reason be regarded as derivable].

ruEoyaA * a subst. from raEaY as used in the phrase raEaY A^amorahu [expl. in the first paragraph; thus signifying Mindfulness, regardfulness, or observance, of an affair, or a case]; as also ↓ raEowaY and ↓ ruEowaY. (K.) ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph. And see art. rEw.

[
raEiY~N *
Pastured: ruled, or governed: and kept, or guarded: so accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the KL; but not in my copy of that work. It is agreeable with analogy as syn. with maroEiY~N: and from it is formed the subst. next following.]

raEiy~apN * [with p affixed liln~aqoli, i. e., to transfer the word from the category of epithets to that of substantives,] Cattle pasturing, or pasturing by themselves: and cattle kept, tended, or pastured: (K, TA:) pl. raEaAyaA: (TA:) this latter (the pl.) signifies cattle kept, tended, or pastured, for any one; (K, TA;) for the subjects and for the Sultán; (TA;) as also ↓ raEaAwiy~apN: (K, TA: in some copies of the K raEaAwiyap, without teshdeed:) and ↓ A^aroEaAwiy~apN signifies cattle kept, tended, or pastured, for the Sultán, (K, TA,) especially, and upon which are his brands and marks. (TA.) Hence the trad., kul~u raAEK masow^uwlN Eino raEiy~atihi [Every pastor shall be questioned respecting his pastured cattle: or every ruler shall be questioned respecting his subjects; agreeably with what follows]. (TA.) ― -b2- The people ruled or governed; the subjects of a ruler or governor: (Msb, K:) the community; the people in common or in general; or the common people: (S:) [any persons or person, and things or thing, in the keeping, or under the guardianship or rule or government, of a man or woman:] see raAEK, in the latter half of the paragraph: pl. as above. (TA.)
rEA'p Alxayoli * : see raAEiyapN.

raEaAwaY * and ruEaAwaY Camels that pasture around the people and their dwellings (S, K) because they are those upon which they work [or perform their business]: (S:) but in the Tekmileh it is written ↓ ruEaAwiy~apN, as meaning cattle that pasture around the dwellings of the people. (TA.)
raEaAwiy~apN * : see raEiy~apN.
ruEaAwiy~apN * : see raEaAwaY.

raAEK * [act. part. n. of 1]. You say maA$iyapN raAEiyapN Cattle [pasturing, or] pasturing by themselves: (Msb:) pl. rawaAEiY [a mistranscription for rawaAEK]. (TA.) ― -b2- raAEiY AlbusotaAni and AlA^utuni ↓ raAEiyapu are names of Two species of janaAdib [or locusts]; (K;) the latter mentioned by ISd: Sgh says that the former is a large junodab: and the latter is another species, that does not fly. (TA.) ― -b3- raAEK also signifies A keeper, or guarder, (TA,) or pastor, (Msb,) of cattle: (Msb, TA:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: (TA:) pl. ruEaApN, (S, Msb, TA,) but this is said to be mostly used as pl. of raAEK in another sense as will be shown below, (TA,) and riEaA='N [and app. ruEaA='N (mentioned below)] and ruEoyaAnN; (S, Msb, TA;) and ruEaApN has a pl., namely, ruEFY. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] Alr~aAEiY is the name of The star [a] that is upon the head of AlHaw~aA=' [i. e. Ophiuchus]: that which is upon the head of AlHAwY [a mistranscription in my MS. for AljaAviY, i. e. Hercules, the star a,] being called kalobu Alr~aAEiY. (Kzw.) Also The star [ γ] that is upon the left leg of Cepheus: between whose legs is a star [app. K] that is called kalobu Alr~aAEiY: (Kzw:) [from their longitudes it seems that these two stars are the same as are meant by what here follows:] Alkalobu [or kalobu Alr~aAEiY] is a certain star over against Ald~alow [or Aquarius, which latter is] below; in the path of which is a
red [or perhaps another (A=xar instead of A^aHomar)] star, called Alr~aAEiY. (TA in art. klb.) [And accord. to Freytag, raAEiY AljawozaA='i is the name of A star otherwise called the Foot of Orion: and raAEiY Aln~aEaAy^imi, the name of The star λ in Sagittarius: see Ideler's “ Untersuch. über den Ursprung etc. der Sternnamen, ” to which he refers, pp. 213, 226, for the former; and p. 187 for the latter.] ― -b5- [And hence,] raAEK signifies also A ruler, or governor, (S, K,) or prince, or commander, (Msb,) who manages, conducts, orders, or regulates, the affairs of a people: (Msb, K:) and a ruler, or governor, of himself: (TA:) pl. ruEaApN and ruEoyaAnN, (K,) but it is said that the former is mostly used as meaning rulers, or governors, and the latter as pl. of raAEK in relation to sheep or goats [or the like], (TA,) and riEaA='N and ruEaA='N. (K.) It is said in a trad., kul~ukumo raAEK wakul~ukumo masow^uwlN Eino ↓ raEiy~atihi [Every one of you is a ruler, or governor, and every one of you shall be questioned respecting those, or that, of which he is ruler or governor]: such is the man in respect of his family, and in respect of the property of his father; and the servant in respect of the property of his master; and the wife is a raAEiyap in respect of the house, or tent, of her husband: and every one of these shall be questioned respecting his, or her, raEiy~ap. (ElJámi' es-Sagheer of Es-Suyootee.) And one says, kaAlr~aAEiY ↓ layosa AlmaroEiY~u [The ruled, or governed, is not like the ruler, or governor]. (S.) ― -b6- In the saying of El-Karkhee, baAEa TayorFA EalaY A^an~ahu raAEK, relating to [carrier-] pigeons, it is from Alr~iEaAyapu signifying AlwafaA='u; [the saying meaning He sold birds on the condition of their being such as would be faithful to their charge;] for pigeons in El- 'Irák and Syria are bought for high prices, and sent from distant points with letters of informations, and convey them, and bring back replies to them. (Mgh, JM.)

raAEiyapN * [fem. of raAEK. ― -b2- Also a subst. formed from the latter word by the affix p; like raEiy~apN from raEiY~N]: see rAEK, third sentence. ― -b3- Alr~aAEiyapu is the name of A certain bird: (TA:) [and] so is raAEiyapu Alxayoli; (TA, and thus in some copies of the K;) thus correctly written, as in the Tekmileh; in [some of] the copies of the K, rAEyp Aljbl; [perhaps the same as the former bird;] a yellow bird, that is found beneath the bellies of horses or similar beasts; thus in the Tekmileh; said by ISh to be a small bird like the sparrow, that alights beneath the bellies of the horses and other beasts, yellow, as though its neck and wings were tinged with saffron, its back having upon it a dinginess, or duskiness, and blackness, its head being yellow, and its zimik~aY [or tail] being neither long nor short; accord. to Sgh, also called Alxyl ↓ rEA'p. (TA [thus written without any syll. signs: if applying to the species in the manner of a coll. gen. n., perhaps a mistranscription for ruEaApu Alxayoli].) ― -b4- raAEiyapu Al$~ayobi, and rawaAEiY Al$~ayobi, (tropical:) The commencement of hoariness, (K, TA,) and the first marks thereof. (TA.)

A^aroEaY * [app. More, and most, merciful or compassionate; from A^aroEayotu Ealayohi, though by rule it should be formed from an unaugmented verb accord. to many of the grammarians: ― -b2- and hence, being nearly syn. with A^arofaqu in the primary sense, syn. with this latter, or nearly so, in a secondary sense]. You say, A^amoru ka*aA A^arofaqu biY waA^aroEaY EalaY~a [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) This affair is more, or most, easy and convenient to me]. (TA.)
A^uroEuw~apN * The yoke that is placed upon the necks of the two bulls employed in ploughing; (AA, Sgh, K, TA;) of the dial. of Azd-Shanoo-ah. (TA.)
A^aroEaAwiy~apN * : see raEiy~apN.
tiroEiY~N * : see what next follows.

tiroEiy~apN * and turoEiy~apN (Fr, S, ISd, K) and taroEiy~apN, (ISd, K,) and sometimes without teshdeed, (K,) the first without teshdeed mentioned by Sgh on the authority of Fr, (TA,) and ↓ tiroEaAyapN (S, K) and ↓ turoEaAyapN (Sgh as from Fr) and ↓ turaAEiyapN (Sgh, K) and ↓ tiraAEiyapN and ↓ tiroEiY~N (K) A man who performs well the act of keeping or tending, or of pasturing or feeding, camels: (S, K:) or whose habitual work, or occupation, or the habitual work, or occupation, of whose fathers, is, or has been, the tending, or pasturing, of camels: (ISd, K:) or who is a good seeker after herbage for the cattle. (ISd, TA.)
turoEaAyapN * : see what next precedes.
turaAEiyapN * : see what next precedes.

maroEFY * an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- And A pasturage, or place of pasture; (S, K;) as also ↓ maroEaApN: (Sgh, K:) pl. maraAEK. (TA.) [Hence,] faA_in~a likul~K bugaApN ↓ laA tadaEan~a fataApF walaA maroEaApF [Do not thou leave uncared for a young woman nor a pasturage, for there are persons that seek, or endeavour, to find and get each]: a prov. enjoining the availing oneself of an opportunity, and the setting about an affair with prudence, discretion, precaution, or sound judgment. (Meyd.) ― -b3- See also riEoYN, in three places.
maroEaApN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
maroEiY~N * [Kept, or tended; pastured, or fed: kept, guarded, or minded: and] ruled, or governed; as in an ex. above, voce raAEK, last sentence but one. (TA.)

1 ragiba * , aor.
ragaba , inf. n. ragobapN (JK, TA) and ragobaY (JK) [and app. ragabN &c. as in the next sentence but one], He desired a thing [app. in an absolute sense, agreeably with what follows in the next sentence but one: and also,] vehemently, eagerly, greedily, very greedily, with avidity, excessively, or culpably; he coveted a thing, longed for it, or lusted after it. (TA.) ragabu Aln~afosi means The [soul's] hoping largely, and desiring much. (TA.) ― -b2- ragiba fiyhi, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) and ragibahu, (Msb, TA,) aor.
ragaba , (K, TA,) inf. n. ragobapN (S, A, * Mgh, K) and ragabN (S, Msb) and ragobN (Mgh, Msb, K) and rugobN (K) and rugobaY (A, * Msb) and ragobaY (Msb) and ragobaA='u, (A, * Msb,) He desired it, or wished for it; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also fyh ↓ Artgb. (S, K.) You say, maA liY fiyhi ragobapN and rugobaY and ragobaA='u [I have not any desire, or wish, for it]. (A.) And ruhobaAka xayorN mino rugobaAka, i. e. The fearing thee is better than the loving thee; rhbAk being an inf. n. prefixed to an objective complement; and so rgbAk: and said to mean, thy being given a thing through fear of thee is better than through desire: a prov., similar to rahabuwtN xayorN mino raHamuwtK. (Meyd. [Freytag explains it otherwise: see his Arab. Prov. i. 542.]) ― -b3- ragiba Eanohu He did not desire it, or wish for it; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) he shunned, or avoided, it; abstained from it; (S, TA;) or left it, relinquished it, or forsook it, (JK, S, TA,) intentionally. (JK, TA.) ― -b4- ragiba A_ilayohi, inf. n. ragabN (K) and ragobN and rugobN (TA) and rugobaY (Mgh, * K) and ragobaY (K) and ragobaA='u (A, * K) and ragobapN (Mgh, * TA) and rugobapN and ragabapN and ragabuwtN, and ragabuwtaY and ragabaAnN, (K,) He made petition to him, addressed a petition to him, asked him, petitioned him, sought of him, or demanded of him: (TA:) or he prayed to him, or supplicated him, with humility or abasement, or with sincerity or earnestness or energy: or he humbled, or abased, himself, and made petition to him. (K, A, TA.) You say, ragiba A_ilaY fulaAnK fiY ka*aA He made petition to such a one, petitioned him, or asked him, for such a thing. (TA.) And A_ilaY A@ll~`hi A^arogabu To God I humble, or abase, myself, and make petition; syn. A^aDoraEu: and A_ilayoh$ A^arofaEu ragobatiY [To Him I raise my humble petition]. (A.) And Alr~uhobaY mina A@ll~`hi waAlr~ugobaY A_ilayohi [Fear should be of God; (not of a creature;) and petition, &c., should be to Him]. (Lth, TA in art. rhb.) See also another ex. in a verse cited voce ragiybapN. ― -b5- ragiba binafosihi Eanohu [lit. He made himself to be not desirous of, or to shun, or abstain from, or leave, him, or it; the b having the same effect as in *ahaba bihi &c.; and hence,] he held himself above, or superior to, him, or it. (K.) And ragibotu bifulaAnK Eano h`*aA I made such a one to shun, abstain from, or leave, this, disliking it for him. (MF.) -A2- raguba (assumed tropical:) It (anything) was, or became, wide, or ample. (TA. [See also 6.]) You say, raguba AlwaAdiY, aor.
raguba , inf. n. rugobN and rugubN (K) and ragaAbapN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The valley was large and wide, taking, or receiving, much water. (K, * TA.) And ragubati AlA^aroDu, inf. n. rugobN [&c.], (assumed tropical:) The land was soft (S, TA) and wide, with even, or sandy, soil: (TA:) or (S, TA) took much water; (TA;) was such as would not flow unless in consequence of much rain. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] raguba, inf. n. rugobN (S, K *) and rugubN, (K, * TA,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, voracious, a great eater; (K, TA;) very greedy, or gluttonous; (S, K, TA;) vehemently, excessively, or culpably, desirous of worldly goods, and one who made himself to be large, or abundant, therein: or as some say, large in his hopes,
and desirous of much. (TA.) Accord. to the T, rugobu AlbaToni signifies (assumed tropical:) Voracity: and rugobN, alone, as occurring in a trad., is explained as meaning capaciousness of the belly, and voracity. (TA.) And raguba raA^oyuhu, inf. n. rugobN, (tropical:) He was, or became, liberal, or bountiful, and large in opinion or judgment. (A.)

2 rg~bhu fiY $aYo'K * , [inf. n. tarogiybN,] He made him to desire, or wish for, a thing; (S, * MA, K; *) as also fyh ↓ Argbhu. (S, * K: *) both signify the same. (S.) You say, rag~abotuhu fiY SuHobatihi [I made him to desire, or wish for, his companionship]. (A.) ― -b2- And rg~bhu, inf. n. tarogiybN; (IAar, TA;) and rg~b A_ilayohi; (TA;) He gave him what he desired, or wished for. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- [rg~b is also said by Golius to signify Cupivit avide et expetivit; as on the authority of the KL: but this signification is not in my copy of that work, nor do I find it in any other lexicon.]

3 rAgb * is said by Golius, as on the authority of the KL, and by Freytag after him, to signify Cupiditatem monstravit: but it is not mentioned in any sense in my copy of the KL, nor have I found it in any other lexicon.]

4 A^arogaba see 2. ― -b2- [Argbhu app. signifies also He made it wide, or ample. ― -b3- And hence,] A^arogaba A@ll~`hu qadoraka means (tropical:) May God enlarge thy power, and make its steps to extend far. (A, TA.)

6 trAgbwA fiyih *
They vied, one with another, in desiring it; or they desired it with emulation; syn. tnAfswA fyh. (A and TA in art. nfs.) ― -b2- trAgb AlmakaAnu (assumed tropical:) The place was, or became, wide, or ample. (TA. [See also raguba.])
8 A_irotagaba see 1, third sentence.
ragibN * : see ragiybN, second sentence.
rugubN * : see ragaAbN, and raEiybN; with both of which it is synonymous. ― -b2- It is also a pl. of the latter, (L in art. A^sd,) and of ragibN. (TA.)

ragobapN *
A desire, or wish: pl. ragabaAtN. (Mgh, Msb.) Hence, qal~ato ragabaAtu Aln~aAsi [The desires, or wishes, of the people, or of mankind, became few]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also ragiybapN.
ragobaY * : see ragiybapN.

ragabuwtN * , an epithet applied to a man, [signifying One who makes petition; who asks, petitions, seeks, or demands: or who prays, or supplicates, with humility or abasement, or with sincerity or earnestness or energy: or who humbles, or abases, himself, and makes petition: originally an inf. n. of ragiba A_ilayohi; or] from Alr~agobapu. (S, TA. [In one copy of the former erroneously written ragabuwbN; in another, ragobuwbN; and in another, omitted.])

rugobaAnapN * The [knot called] saEodaAnap of a sandal; (K;) i. e. the knot beneath the [appertenance called] $isoE [which passes through the sole and between two of the toes, and to which the $iraAka, also called zimaAm, is attached]. (TA.)

A^aroDN ragaAbN * (A'Obeyd, ISk, S, K) and ↓ rugubN (K) (assumed tropical:) Land that is soft, (A'Obeyd, S, K, TA,) and wide, with even, or sandy, soil: (K, TA:) or (S, K, TA) that takes much water; (TA;) that will not flow unless in consequence of much rain. (ISk, S, K, TA.)

ragiybN * (assumed tropical:) Wide, or ample; applied in this sense to a watering-trough or tank, and to a skin for water or milk, (S, TA,) &c.: pl. rigaAbN (TA) and rugubN. (L in art. A^sd.) You say also ↓ TariyqN ragibN (assumed tropical:) A wide road: pl. rugubN. (TA.) And makaAnN ↓ muraAgibN (assumed tropical:) A wide, or an ample, place. (TA.) And ↓ waAdK rugubN (assumed tropical:) A wide valley; (TA;) [and] so waAdK ragiybN: (JK:) or (tropical:) a wide valley, that takes much water; as also ragiybN; (AHn, K;) contr. of waAdK zhiydN. (TA.) And TaEonapN ragiybapN (assumed tropical:) A wide wound inflicted with a spear or the like. (TA.) And sayofN ragiybN (assumed tropical:) A wide sword, that inflicts a large wound. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A man, or other animal, (K,) having a capacious inside, or belly: (S, K:) pl. rigaAbN. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Voracious; a great eater: (A, K: [but accord. to the former, not tropical in this sense:]) desirous of much eating: (Msb:) very greedy, or gluttonous: (S, K: [see also rig~iybN:]) vehemently, excessively, or culpably, desirous of worldly goods; and one who makes himself to be large, or abundant, therein: or large in his hopes, and desirous of much: (TA:) and ragiybu Aljawofi a man who is a great eater; (TA;) or capacious in the inside, or belly, and a great eater: (JK:) and baTonN ragiybN a belly that devours much. (Ham p. 418.) ― -b4- huwa ragiybu AlEayoni, (T and A and TA in art. zhd,) and lahu EayonN ragiybapN, (A in that art.,) (assumed tropical:) He is not content but with much; contr. of hw zahiydu AlEayoni, (T and A in that art.,) and of lahu EayonN zahiydapN. (A in that art.) [raEiybu AlEayoni has a different meaning: see art. rEb.] ― -b5- farasN ragiybu Al$~aHowapK (S, in a copy of the A and in the TA Al$Hw,) (tropical:) A horse of wide step, that takes a large space of ground (A, TA) with his legs: pl. rigaAbN. (TA.) ― -b6- A_ibilN rigaAbN, the latter word being the pl. form, (assumed tropical:) Camels yielding a copious supply of milk, and very profitable. (IAth, TA) And (assumed tropical:) Many camels. (TA.) ― -b7- HimolN ragiybN and ↓ murotagibN (assumed tropical:) A heavy load. (TA.)

ragiybapN *
A thing desired, or wished for; (K;) as also ↓ ragobapN: (Ham p. 501:) a thing of high account or estimation; that is desired, or wished for: pl. ragaAy^ibu. (A, Mgh.) You say, A_in~ahu lawahuwbN, likul~i ragiybapK, i. e. [Verily he is a liberal giver] of everything that is desired. (TA.) [And ↓ ragobaY has a similar meaning; for] you say also, A^aSabotu minohu Alr~agobaY, i. e. I obtained from him abundance of what I desired. (TA.) ― -b2- A large gift: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. as above. (S, Mgh, Msb.) A poet (En-Nemir Ibn-Towlab, TA) says,
wamataY tuSiboka xaSaASapN faA@roju AlginaY
waA_ilaY Al~a*iY yuEoTiY Alr~agaAy^iba faA@rogabi
[And when poverty befalls thee, then hope thou for competence, and to Him who gives large gifts humble thyself, and make petition]. (S, * TA.) ― -b3- And A large recompense that one desires to obtain [in the world to come] by prayer: (El-Kilábee, TA:) or that which is wished for by one who has large hope and who desires much: whence the prayer called SalaApu Alr~agaAy^ibi [generally said to be a supererogatory prayer]. (TA.)
Alr~ugaAbaY * , like Alr~ugaAmaY (JK, K) and Alr~uEaAmaY, (TA,) What is called the ziyaAdap of the liver. (JK, K.)

rig~iybN *
Very, or intensely, or exceedingly, desirous of much eating. (Msb.) [See also ragiybN.]

raAgibN *
Desiring, or wishing; (K;) [as in the phrase raAgibN fiY ka*aA desiring, or wishing for, such a thing;] and so ↓ murotagibN. (TA.)

marogabN * [A place, or time, of desire or wish: and hence, an object thereof]. You say, xaTaba faA^aSaAba Almarogaba [app. meaning He demanded a woman in marriage, and attained the object of desire]. (A.)
murogibN * (tropical:) Possessing competence or sufficiency; rich, or wealthy; (K, TA;) possessing much property. (JK, TA.)
marogabapN * : see maraAgibu.

[
maroguwbN fiyhi *
Desired, or wished for. ― -b2- maroguwbN Eanohu Not desired, &c. ― -b3- maroguwbN A_ilayohi Petitioned, &c.: see an ex. voce marohuwbN.]

huwa murag~abN lahu ka*aA waka*aA *
To him are allowed, or permitted, such and such things; like musaE~abN and musag~abN. (TA in art. sEb.)

maraAgibu * [lit. Causes of desire; sing., if used, ↓ marogabapN, a word of the same class as maboxalapN and majobanapN &c.: and hence,] things that are eagerly desired, or coveted; syn. A^aTomaAEN [which also signifies soldiers' stipends, or allowances]: (TA:) and (TA) things that are desired to be gained for subsistence, or sustenance; i. q. mDTrbAt lilomaEaA$i. (K, TA. [In the CK, the former of the two nouns in this explanation is muDoTaribAt: in two MS. copies of the K, it is without the syll. signs: the right reading is evidently muDoTarabaAt, syn. with mukotasabaAt: Freytag renders the explanation personæ quæ in rebus quæ spectant ad victum perturbatæ et anxiæ sunt; deriving this meaning from the rendering in the TK: Golius, with a near approach to correctness, renders it res ad sustentandam vitam necessariæ; but he has given this explanation as on the authority of J, by whom it is not mentioned; and has put maraAgibN for maraAgibu.])
muraAgibN * : see ragiybN.
murotagibN * : see raAgibN. ― -b2- See also ragiybN, last sentence. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A large, big, bulky, or corpulent, man. (JK.)

1 ragavahaA * , (S, A, K,) aor.
ragava , (K,) inf. n. ragavN; (TK;) and ↓ ArtgvhA; (K;) said of a kid, (S, A,) [and app. of a lamb, (see 4,) or of any young animal,] He sucked her; (S, A, K;) namely, his mother. (S, A.) ― -b2- Hence, in a trad., *ahaba rasuwlu A@ll~`hi Sal~aY A@ll~`hu Ealayohi wasal~ama waA^anotumo tarogavuwnahaA (assumed tropical:) [The Apostle of God (may God bless and save him) has departed from the world, and ye suck the sweets of it]; meaning the world; i. e. taroDaEuwnahaA. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] ragavahu Aln~aAsu (assumed tropical:) The people, or men, asked, or begged, of him so much that all that he had passed away. (TA.) And rugiva, (ElAhmar, JK, S, K,) inf. n. rigaAvN, (JK,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was asked of, or begged of, so much that all that he had became exhausted. (El-Ahmar, JK, S, K.) -A2- rugiva, (K,) or rugivato said of a woman, (TA,) He, (K,) or she, (TA,) had a complaint of, or a pain in, the rugavaA='.
