(K, TA.) ― -b2- ragavahu He thrust, pierced, stuck, or stabbed, him time after time; and so ↓ Argvhu. (K. [See also the latter below.])

4 Argvthu * , said of a ewe, (S,) [and app. of a she-goat also, (see 1,) or of any female,] She suckled him; (S, K;) namely, her young one. (S.) See also raguwvN. -A2- Argvhu He thrust, pierced, stuck, or stabbed, him in his rugavaA='. (K.) ― -b2- See also 1, last signification.
8 A_irotagava see 1, first signification.
ragovaA='u * : see what next follows.

rugavaA='u *
A certain duct (EiroqN) in the breast, or mamma, (S, K,) that emits the milk: (S:) or a certain sinew, or tendon, (EaSabapN,) beneath the breast, or mamma: (ISk, T, S, K:) sometimes written ↓ ragovaA='u: (Fr, T, TA:) or the rugavaAwaAni [dual of rugavaA='u] are the two sinews, or tendons, that are beneath the two breasts, or mammæ: or what are between the two shoulder-joints and the two breasts, next the arm-pit: (TA:) or two portions of flesh, (JK,) or two small portions of flesh, (TA,) between the vunoduw^ap [q. v.], and the shoulderjoint, (JK, TA,) on either side of the chest: (TA:) or the blackness [app. meaning the areola] of each of the two breasts. (TA.)

A^aroDN rugaAvN *
Land that does not flow with water except (A_il~aA [but this word is omitted in the TA]) from much rain: (JK, K:) [i. e., that sucks in the rain-water, and does not cause it to flow upon its surface, except when it is copious.]

raguwvN * Any female suckling; (JK, S, K;) as also ↓ murogivN: (K:) or one says $aApN raguwvN and raguwvapN, meaning particularly a ewe suckling: but [the inf. n.] ↓ A_irogaAvN has been used in relation to the she-camel: or raguwvN applied to a $Ap means only that has brought forth: (TA:) and one says biro*awonapN raguwvN meaning [a hackney-mare] that is sucked, i. q. ↓ maroguwvapN; (S, TA;) and that scarcely ever raises her head from the manger: [whence] it is said in a prov., A=kl Ald~awaAb~i biro*awonapN raguwvN [The most voracious of beasts is a hackneymare that is sucked]: or, as J gives it [in the S, and Z in the A], thus, as verse:
A=klu mino biro*awonapK raguwvi
[More voracious than a hackney-mare that is sucked]: and ↓ murogivN is applied to a woman as meaning suckling: the pl. of raguwvN is rigaAvN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A child, or young one, that is suckled; a suckling. (TA.)
murogivN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Possessing much property. (JK.)
murag~avN * [written in the JK marogav, but said in the K to be like muHam~adN,] The part, of the finger, which is the place of the signet-ring. (K.)

maroguwvN * : see its fem. above, voce raguwvN. ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A man asked of, or begged of, so much that all that he had is exhausted. (El-Ahmar, JK, S, A, K.) And (assumed tropical:) Possessing little property. (JK.) And A^amowaAluhu maroguwvapu (tropical:) [His possessions are exhausted. (A.)

1 ragida * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ragada , (Msb, K,) inf. n. ragadN (Msb) [and ragodN, as seems to be indicated in the K by its being said that the verb is like samiEa]; and raguda, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
raguda , (Msb, K,) inf. n. ragaAdapN; (Msb;) It (one's life) was, or became, ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, (S, Msb, K,) and easy, (Msb,) and pleasant. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] fulaAnN daAy^ibN fiY A^amorihi laA yarogudu [Such a one is striving, labouring, or toiling, in his affair:] he will not flag, or be remiss. (JK.) -A2- [In the JK, ragadonaA, aor. narogadu, is mentioned immediately after an explanation of ragiydapN, app. to indicate that it signifies We prepared, or we ate, rgydp.]

4 ArgdwA *
They became in a state of life ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful; (S, A;) they had abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (S, K.) -A2- Argd A@ll~`hu Eayo$ahumo God made their life to be ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, [and easy,] and pleasant. (A.) ― -b2- And ArgdwA mawaA$iyahumo They left their cattle to pasture by themselves, where they pleased. (S, K.)

10 Astrgd AlEayo$a *
He found life to be ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, [and easy,] and pleasant. (Har p. 657.) One says, Ainozlo Hayovu yusotarogadu AlEayo$u [Alight thou where life is found to be ample in its means &c.]. (A.)

11 ArgAd~ * , (S, TA,) inf. n. AirogiydaAdN, (S, K, TA,) It (milk) became commingled, one part with another, but not yet completely thickened. (S, TA.) And in like manner, It (anything) became commingled, or confused, one part with another. (S, K, * TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He became [confused, or] in doubt, in his opinion, or judgment, not knowing how to utter it. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He slept without fully satisfying his drowsiness, (K, TA,) so that he awoke heavy. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He was angry, and changed in colour by reason of anger: (TA:) or he was angry, and would not answer. (K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He was sick, not severely affected (lamo yujohado [in the CK lm yajohado]), (L, K,) but suffering depression: (K:) or he showed himself to be depressed, (JK, L,) without emaciation, (JK,) or by emaciation: (L:) and he was oppressed by sickness beyond his power of endurance: (L:) or he began to suffer pain, and exhibited an extenuated state of the belly, and dryness, and languor. (En-Nadr.) ― -b6- ArgydAd also signifies (assumed tropical:) Languidness, or weakness, in the eye, and the ear, and the sight. (JK.)

Q. Q. 3 Airogal~ada * [a verb app. syn. with ragida in an intensive sense;] of the measure AifoEal~ala from Alr~agadu [inf. n. of ragida]. (K.) Its l is augmentative; and therefore it should not be mentioned independently as it is in the K. (TA.)

ragodN * , applied to property, or water, or life, or herbage, Plentiful; that does not cause one fatigue. (L.) [Being originally an inf. n., it is used without variation as a masc. and fem. and sing. and pl. epithet; as also ↓ ragadN.] You say Eayo$N ragodN and ↓ ragadN and ↓ raAgidN and ↓ ragiydN (A, Msb) and ↓ A^arogadu, (Lh, TA,) and ↓ maEiy$apN ragiydapN, (A,) Life that is ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, (Lh, A, Msb,) and easy, (Lh, * Msb,) and pleasant. (A, Msb.) And giy$apN ragodN and ↓ ragadN A mode of life ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, [and easy,] and pleasant. (S, A, K.) And ↓ qawomN ragadN, (A, L, K,) or ragodN, (JK,) and ↓ nisowapN ragadN, (A, L, K,) or nisaA='N ragodN, (JK,) People, and women, in a state of life ample in its means or circumstances, &c.; (JK, A, K;) or having abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life, and having camels abounding with milk. (L.)

ragadN * an inf. n. of ragida. (Msb.) You say, huwa fiY ragadK mina AlEayo$i He is in a state of life ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, (A, Msb,) [and easy,] and pleasant. (A.) ― -b2- See also ragodN, in five places.
ragiydN * , and its fem., with p: see ragodN.

ragiydapN *
Fresh milk, which is boiled, and upon which some flour is sprinkled, (JK, S, K,) then dates are mixed therewith, (JK,) or then it is mixed and stirred about, (S,) and it is licked up: (S, K:) and also remains of milk: (JK:) or fresh butter: (Msb:) or a piece, or portion, of fresh butter: (A:) pl. ragaAy^idu. (JK, A.) You say, AlA^amonu fiY AlmaEiy$api Alr~agiydapi A^aToyabu mina AlbaroniY~a biAlr~agiydapi, meaning [Security in the state of life that is ample in its means or circumstances, &c., is sweeter than the dates called baroniY~] with some fresh butter. (A.)

rugayodaA='u *
i. q. ruEayodaA='u [q. v.]; (K;) [i. e.] What is taken forth from wheat, and thrown away. (JK.)
raAgidN * : see ragodN.
A^arogadu * : see ragodN.
marogadapo * [A place abounding with herbage;] a meadow, or a garden; syn. rawoDapN. (L.) See also marodagapN.

murogaAd~N * part. n. of 11. (L, K.) Milk [that has become commingled, one part with another, but] not yet completely thickened. (L.) [And in like manner, Anything that has become commingled, or confused, one part with another.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) One who is [confused, or] in doubt, in his opinion, or judgment, (JK, S, K,) not knowing how to utter it. (S, K.) ― -b3- [For its other meanings, see the verb.]

1 ragasahu A@ll~`hu * , aor.
ragasa , inf. n. ragosN, God blessed, or prospered, him, and made him to increase and multiply: God made his property to increase and multiply. (TA.) You say, kaAnuwA qaliylFA faragasahumu A@ll~`hu They were few, and God multiplied and increased them: and in like manner one says of Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect], &c. (S, TA.) And ragasahu A@ll~`hu maAlFA, (El-Umawee, S, K,) and waladFA, (TA,) aor. as above, (K,) God multiplied to him his property, (El-Umawee, S, K,) and his offspring, (TA,) and blessed him therein; (ElUmawee, S, K; *) as also maAlFA ↓ Argshu, (K,) and waladFA. (TA.)
4 A^arogasa see the last sentence above.

ragosN *
Increase: (S, K:) abundance: (TA:) wealth, or property; or much wealth or property; or good fortune, prosperity, welfare, wellbeing, or weal; syn. xayorN. (S, K.) El-'Ajjáj says,
xaliyfapN saAsa bigayori taEosi
A_imaAmu ragosK fiY niSaAbi ragosi
[app. meaning, A khaleefeh who ruled without evil, a prosperous prince, of prosperous origin]: niSaAb is syn. with A^aSol. (S.) ― -b2- Also A benefit, favour, boon, or blessing; syn. naEomapN: (K:) or ampleness, or largeness, therein: (TA:) pl. A^arogaAsN, (K.)
murogasN * : see the next paragraph.

murogisN * One who makes himself to have a plentiful and pleasant and easy life; (Ibn-'Abbád, Sgh, K;) as also with $. (TA.) ― -b2- A plentiful state of life; as also ↓ murogasN, (K,) in the saying hamo fiY murogisK mino Eayo$ihimo [They are in a plentiful state of life]. (TA.)

maroguwsN *
Blessed; prospered; fortunate: (K, * TA:) applied to a man, blessed, or prospered; (TA;) abounding in wealth or property; (K, TA;) fortunate, or possessed of good fortune: (TA:) and, applied to a face, blessed and fortunate; (S;) or cheerful and fortunate. (TA.) You say also, huwa maroguwsu Aln~aASiyapi (assumed tropical:) He has a blessed, or fortunate, forelock. (TA.) ― -b2- And with p, applied to a woman, (Lth, K,) and to a ewe, or she-goat, (TA,) Prolific; having numerous offspring. (Lth, K, TA.)

1 ragafa * , (JK, O, Msb,) aor.
ragafa , (O, Msb,) inf. n. ragofN, (JK, O, Msb, K,) He collected together (JK, O, Msb, K) clay, (JK, O, K,) or dough, (Msb, O, K,) making it into a compact mass, (JK, O, K,) or making it round (Msb) [and flat, but not thin, or not very thin], with his hand. (Msb, O, K.) ― -b2- ragafa AlbaEiyrN, (JK, O, K,) aor. as above, (O, K,) and so the inf. n., (JK, O,) He put into the camel's mouth, by mouthfuls, seeds (bazor), and flour, (JK, O, K,) and the like. (O, K.)

4 Argf *
He looked sharply, or intently, or attentively; (JK, O, K;) A_ilayohi [at him, or it]; (TK;) said of a man and of a lion. (O.) ― -b2- And He hastened, made haste, or sped, in going, journeying, or pace. (K.)

ragiyfN *
A round cake (MA, KL) of bread, (S, MA, Mgh, KL,) such as is thick, or not thin, (MA,) the contr. of such as is termed raqiyq; (Mgh;) [generally about a span, or less, in width, and from half an inch to an inch in thickness;] of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Msb,) from ragafa as expl. in the first sentence above: (JK, O, Msb, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^arogifapN (S, O, Msb, K) and [of mult.] rugofaAnN (JK, S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K) and rugufN (JK, S, O, Msb) and rugofN and ↓ taraAgiyfu; (JK, O, K;) the last anomalous, (TK,) mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád. (O.)
taraAgiyfu * : see what next precedes. [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

div2.head: Quasi rgld
div2.entryFree: Airogal~ada * : see Q. Q. 3 in art. rgd.

1 ragima AlA^anofu * , [and, as will be seen from what follows, ragama, and raguma, inf. n. ragomN and rugomN and rigomN,] His nose clave to the ragaAm [i. e. earth, or dust]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ragama A^anofuhu, aor.
raguma , inf. n. ragomN [&c. as above]; and ragima, aor.
ragama ; [and raguma, aor.
raguma ;] (tropical:) He was, or became, abased, or humble, or submissive; as though his nose clave to the ragaAm by reason of abasement &c. (Msb.) And ragima A^anofiY lil~`hi, and ragama, (S, K,) and raguma, (El-Hejeree, K,) inf. n. ragomN and rugomN and rigomN, (S,) [and app. marogamapN also, as seems to be indicated in the S and TA,] (tropical:) My nose [meaning my pride] was, or became, abased, or humbled, to God, against my will; (K, TA;) i. e. liA^amorihi [to his command]. (TA.) And fulaAnN rugima A^anofFA and gurima A^anofFA (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is, or has been, abased, or humbled]. (TA.) ― -b3- And ragama fulaAnN, (S, TA,) or ragima, aor.
ragama , inf. n. ragomN [&c. as above], (JK,) (tropical:) Such a one was unable to obtain his right, or due; (JK, S, TA;) as also ragama A^anofuhu: the part. n. is ↓ raAgimN. (Har p. 369.) -A2- ragama as a trans v.: see 4, [with which it is app. syn. properly as well as tropically,] in three places. ― -b2- [Hence,] ragamotuhu, (K,) inf. n. ragomN; (JK, TA;) and ↓ tarag~amotuhu; (so in the JK; [perhaps a mistranscription for ragamotuhu;]) (assumed tropical:) I did a thing against his will: (JK, K, TA:) or, so as to anger him; and vexed him. (TA.) ― -b3- [And (assumed tropical:) I made him to do a thing against his will; forced him to do a thing: for] Alr~agomu is also syn. with Alqasoru; (IAar, K, TA;) in some copies of the K erroneously written Alqa$oru. (TA.) ― -b4- And ragimahu and ragamahu, aor.
ragama , (K,) inf. n. ragomN (TA) [and app. rugomN and rigomN and marogamapN, as seems to be indicated in the K] (tropical:) He disliked it, disapproved it, or hated it. (K, TA.) You say, maA A^arogamu minohu $ayoy^FA (tropical:) I dislike not, &c., of it, anything. (JK, TA.) And ragamati Als~aAy^imapu AlmaroEaY (tropical:) The pasturing beasts disliked, &c., the pasture. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 2. ― -b6- [And see ragomN, below.]

2 rag~ama see 4, in three places. ― -b2- rg~mhu, (JK, M, K,) inf. n. tarogiymN, (K,) also signifies He said to him ragomFA; (JK; [see ragomN, below;]) or ragomFA ragomFA; so in the K; but in the M, ragomFA wadagomFA: (TA:) and ↓ ragamahu inf. n. ragomN, [in like manner,] he said to him ragomFA: or he did with him that which made his nose to cleave to the earth, or dust, (maA yurogimu A^anofahu,) and that which abased him. (Ham p. 97.)

3 muraAgamapN * signifies (tropical:) The breaking off from, or quitting, another in anger: (S, K, TA:) and the cutting off another from friendly, or loving, communion; cutting one, or ceasing to speak to him; or forsaking, abandoning, deserting, or shunning or avoiding, one: and the becoming alienated, or estranged; or the going, removing, retiring, or withdrawing, to a distance, far away, or far off, one from another: (K, TA:) [or] rAgmhu signifies (assumed tropical:) He left, forsook, abandoned, or relinquished, him, or separated himself from him, against his [the latter's] wish: (Mgh:) or he broke off from him, or quitted him, in anger: (Msb:) and A^aholahu ↓ Argm (tropical:) He cut off his family from loving communion, or forsook them, or deserted them, against their wish. (TA.) It is said in a trad., liyuraAgimu rab~ahu A_ino A^adoxala A^abawayohi Aln~aAra, i. e. (tropical:) He will assuredly break off in anger from his Lord [if he cause his two parents to enter the fire of Hell]. (TA.) And you say, raAgama fulaAnN qawomahu (tropical:) Such a one retired apart from his people, or party; or disagreed with them; or opposed them; (S, K, * TA;) and went forth from them; (S, TA;) and cut them off from friendly, or loving, communion; or forsook them; and treated them, or regarded them, with enmity, or hostility. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And fulaAnN laA yuraAgimu $ayoy^FA (assumed tropical:) Such a one does not want, need, or require, and is not unable to attain, anything. (JK, TA.)

4 Argmhu * [He cast it upon the ragaAm, i. e. earth, or dust: and he made it to cleave to the earth, or dust]. You say, Argm All~uqomapa mino fiyhi He cast the morsel from his mouth upon the earth, or dust. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, respecting the material for dyeing the hair, and the hands of women, Ausolutiyhi waA^arogimiyhi [Wipe thou it off
from thy hand, or hands, and cast it upon the earth, or dust]. (S. [There said to be from the phrase here next following.]) You say also, Argm A^anofahu He, (i. e. God, JK, S,) or it, (i. e. abasement, or humility, or submissiveness, K, * TA, *) made his nose to cleave to the ragaAm, i. e. earth, or dust; (JK, * S, TA;) [or may He (i. e. God) make his nose to cleave to the earth, or dust;] and ↓ ragama A^anofahu signifies the same [app. in this (the proper) sense, as well as in that next following]. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] the former of these two phrases means (tropical:) He (i. e. God, Msb) abased him, humbled him, or rendered him submissive, (Msb, TA,) against his will; (TA;) [or may He abase him, &c.;] and so ↓ the latter of the same two phrases: and the former, (assumed tropical:) He angered him; likewise said of God; (Ham p. 551;) and so Argmhu alone; (K, TA;) like Adgmhu; (TA;) or both signify (tropical:) he did evil to him, and angered him: (TA in art. dgm:) and A^urogima (assumed tropical:) He was abased, or humbled, or rendered submissive: (Ham p. 617:) and A@ll~`hu bihi AlA^unuwfa ↓ ragama, inf. n. ragomN, (assumed tropical:) God abased, or may God abase, the noses by means of him, or it. (Har p. 369.) [↓ rg~mhu, also, signifies (assumed tropical:) He abased him, humbled him, or rendered him submissive: you say,] lahu ↓ h`*aA tarogiymN (assumed tropical:) This is an abasing, or a humbling, to him: (Msb:) and lil$~ayoTaAni ↓ tarogiymFA (occurring in a trad., TA) means (assumed tropical:) For the abasing, or humbling, of the devil. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And Argmhu (assumed tropical:) He urged him, or made him, to do that from which he was not able to hold back, or that which he could not refuse to do, or that which he could not resist doing. (JK, TA, and Ham p. 97, from Kh.) ― -b4- See also 3.

5 trg~m * (assumed tropical:) He became angered, or angry, (S, K, TA,) with speech, and otherwise: (TA:) and sometimes it occurs with z [i. e. tzg~m]. (S, TA.) Hence the saying of El-Hotei-ah, [app. describing a she-camel,]
taraY bayona laHoyayohaA A_i*aA maA tarag~amato
lugaAmFA kabayoti AlEanokabuwti Alumad~adi
[Thou seest between her two jaws, when she is angered, foam like the web of the spider stretched out]. (TA.) -A2- See also 1.

ragomN * and ↓ rugomN and ↓ rigomN are inf. ns. of ragima and ragama said of the nose; and ↓ marogamapN is syn. therewith; (S;) as is also ↓ marogamN. (TA.) One says to another, [by way of imprecation,] ragomFA [for ragima A^anofuka ragamFA May thy nose cleave fast to the earth, or dust; meant to be understood in the proper sense, or in a tropical sense explained by what follows]; (JK, M, K;) and [sometimes] dagomFA is added, (M,) which is an imitative sequent to ragomFA. (K in art. dgm.) And liA^anofihi Alr~agomu and ↓ Almarogamapu [May cleaving to the earth, or dust, befall his nose; which may likewise be meant to be understood properly, or tropically]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] the first also signifies, (IAar, K, TA,) and so ↓ marogamapN also, (TA,) (tropical:) Abasement. (IAar, Mgh, K, TA.) The Prophet said, ↓ buEivotu marogamapF, (S,) i. e. (tropical:) I was sent for abasement to the believers in a plurality of gods, [or] by reason of dislike or disapproval [of their state; agreeably with the explanation next following]. (TA.) ― -b3- ragomN and ↓ rugomN (Msb, K, TA) and ↓ rigomN and ↓ marogamapN (K, TA) also signify (tropical:) Dislike, disapproval, or hatred. (Msb, K, TA.) You say, faEalahu ragomFA or ↓ rugomFA or ↓ rigomFA, (TA,) and EalaY ragomK, (ISh, TA,) and ElY ragomihi, and ElY Alr~agomi minohu, (TA,) and ElY ragomi A^anofihi and A^anofihi ↓ rugomi, (Msb,) and ElY Alr~agomi mino A^anofihi, (S,) i. e. (tropical:) [He did it against his wish; in spite of him; or] notwithstanding his dislike, or disapproval, or hatred. (Msb, TA.) ― -b4- Hat~aY yaxoruja ↓ manohu Alr~ugomu, [or Alr~agomu, in the TA without the vowel-sign,] occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) In order that he may become humble and abased, and the pride of the Devil may go forth from him. (Mgh, TA.) -A2- See also ragaAmN.
rugomN * : see the next paragraph above, in six places.
rigomN * : see ragomN, in three places.

$aApN ragomaA='u *
A sheep, or goat, having upon the extremity of its nose a whiteness, (JK, K,) or a colour different from that of the rest of its body. (K.)
ragomaAnu * : see the next following paragraph.

ragaAmN *
Earth, or dust; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ ragomN: (IAar, K:) [or] soft earth or dust, (K, TA,) but not fine: (TA:) or fine earth or dust: (AA, TA:) or sand mixed with earth or dust: (K:) or sand such as does not flow from the hand: (As, TA:) or, as IB says on the authority of AA, sand that dazzles the sight; as also ↓ ragomaAnu; which latter, accord. to the K, is the name of a certain tract of sands. (TA.)

rugaAmapN *
A thing that one desires, or seeks; (JK, K;) as also ↓ marogamapN: (TA:) so in the saying, liY Einodahu rugaAmapN (JK, TA) and marogamapN (TA) [I have a thing that I desire, or seek, to obtain from such a one].

rugaAmaY * The nose; as also ↓ marogamN and ↓ marogimN, (K,) of which the pl. is maraAgimu: (TA:) or rugaAmaY signifies the nose with what is around it: (IKoot, TA:) and in this sense also the pl. above mentioned is used; as in the saying, laA^aTaA^an~a maraAgimaka [I will assuredly trample upon thy nose with the parts around it]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The [appertenance called the] ziyaAdap [q. v.] of the liver; as also ruEaAmaY; (S, K;) but the former is the more approved. (TA.) ― -b3- And, (K,) some say, (S, TA,) [The bronchi, or the windpipe; i. e.] the tubes, (qaSab, S,) or the tube, (qaSabap, K,) of the lungs. (S, K.) -A2- Also A certain plant: a dial. var. of ruxaAmaY [q. v.]. (K.)

raAgimN * : see 1. You say, huwa raAgimN and raAgimu AlA^anofi [He has the nose cleaving to the dust: and hence,] (assumed tropical:) he is abased, or humble, or submissive: and (assumed tropical:) he is unable to obtain his right, or due: and [rugomN is its pl.:] you say, humo rugomu AlA^unuwfi. (Har p. 369.) And daAgmN is used as an imitative sequent thereto. (K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Angry. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Disliking, disapproving, or hating. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Fleeing. (TA.)
marogamN * : see ragomN, first sentence: -A2- and see also rugaAmaY: -A3- and muraAgamN.
marogimN * : see rugaAmaY, first sentence.
marogamapN * : see ragomN, in five places: -A2- and see also rugaAmapN. -A3- Also A certain game of the Arabs. (K.)
murag~amN * : see the next paragraph but one.
mirogaAmapN * (tropical:) A woman who angers her husband. (K, TA.)

muraAgamN * (S, Mgh, K, TA) and ↓ mutarag~amN (JK, TA) and ↓ marogamN, (JK,) thus accord. to one reading in the Kur iv. 101, (Ksh,) or ↓ murag~amN, (TA, [perhaps a mistranscription,]) (assumed tropical:) A road by the travelling of which one leaves, or separates himself from, his people, against their wish, or so as to displease them: (Ksh and Bd in iv. 101:) and a place to which one emigrates: (Zj and Ksh and Jel ibid.:) or a place to which one shifts, removes, or becomes transferred: (Bd ibid.:) or a way by which one goes or goes away: (Fr, JK, S, K:) and a place to which one flees; a place of refuge: (Fr, S, Mgh, K:) and i. q. muDoTarabN [meaning a place in which one goes to and fro seeking the means of subsistence: see art. Drb]: (Fr, JK, S, K:) and a fortress, or fortified place; syn. HiSonN. (IAar, K.) It is said in the Kur, [iv. 101, of him who emigrates for the cause of God's religion], yajidN fiY AlA^aroDi muraAgamFA kaviyrFA [He shall find in the earth many a road &c.]. (S, TA.) And a poet says,
A_ilaY baladK gayori daAniY AlmaHal~i
baEiydi AlmuraAgami waAlmuDoTarabo
[To a country not near in respect of the place of alighting, remote in respect of the road &c. and of the region in which people go to and fro seeking the means of subsistence]. (Zj, TA.)
mutarag~amN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 ragaA * , (S, Mgh, K,) aor. yaroguw, (S,) said of a camel, (S, Mgh, K,) and of a hyena, and of an ostrich; (K;) or ragato, aor. taroguw, said of a she-camel; (JK, Msb;) inf. n. rugaA='N, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, * K,) with which ↓ raAgiyapN is syn. [either as an inf. n. or as a simple subst.]; (JK;) He grumbled, or uttered a grumbling cry; syn. Daj~a; (S;) or uttered a cry, (Mgh, K,) and grumbled; syn. Saw~ata faDaj~a: (K:) or she uttered a cry [&c.]: (Msb:) so camels are wont to do when the loads are lifted upon them; and youthful camels do so much: (TA:) rugaA='N signifies the cry or crying [or grumbling, which is a kind of gurgling growl,] (S, Msb) of the camel [when he is being laden, and on some other occasions of discontent], (Msb,)
or of animals having the kind of foot called xuf~: (S:) also of the bird called rag~aA='N [&c.]. (TA.) It is said in a prov., kafaY birugaAy^ihaA munaAdiyFA [Her grumbling cry suffices as a caller] i. e., the rugaA=' of his camel serves instead of his calling in presenting himself for entertainment as a guest: (S:) A'Obeyd says that it is well known to the Arabs as relating to the accomplishment of an object of want before the asking for it: and it is applied also to the case of a man whose aid is wanted and who does not come to thee; excusing himself by saying that he did not know: and to the case of one who stands at a man's door, and to whom it is said, “ Send him who shall ask permission for thee [to go in]; ” whereupon he replies, “ His knowledge of my standing at his door suffices for asking permission for me: if he pleased, he would grant me permission. ” (Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 328—9.]) And in another prov., Albakori ↓ kaAnato Ealayohimo karaAgiyapi, (JK, Meyd,) or Als~aqobi, [i. e. There befell them the like of the grumbling cry of the young camel,] meaning, the rugaA=' of the young camel of Thamood [which preceded the destruction of those who heard it]: the prov. relates to the auguring evil from a thing. (Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 327.]) ― -b2- ragaA said of a boy, or child, means (tropical:) He wept most violently. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [It is also, app., said of a man, as meaning (assumed tropical:) He shouted: and (assumed tropical:) he spoke with a loud voice. (See 6, and rag~aA='N.)] -A2- See also 2.)

2 rg~Y * , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tarogiyapN, (S,) said of milk, (S, Msb, K,) It frothed; (S;) it had ragowap [or froth]; as also ↓ ArgY, (K,) inf. n. A_irogaA='N; (TA;) and ↓ ragaA, (K,) aor. yaroguw, inf. n. ragowN: (TA:) or it had much froth; as also ↓ ArgY: (TA:) or its froth estuated. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^amosato A_ibiluhumo turag~iY watuna$~ifu, i. e. [Their camels became, or became in the evening, so as that they yielded frothy milk; or so as that] they had ragowap and nu$aAfap. (Yaakoob, S.) -A2- tarogiyapN also signifies (tropical:) The act of angering [another]. (IAar, K, TA.)

4 ArgY *
He made his she-camel to utter the grumbling cry termed rugaA=': (S, K:) [and] he made his camel to do so in order that he might be entertained as a guest. (M, TA. [See a prov. cited in the first paragraph.]) Sebrah Ibn-'Amr El-Fak'asee says,
wamaA yurogaY li$ad~aAdK faSiylu
[And a young camel belonging to the family of Sheddád is not made to utter its grumbling cry for the want of its mother]; meaning that they are niggardly; that they will not separate the young camel from its mother by slaughter nor by gift. (S.) And it is said in a prov.,
A^aroguwA lahaA HuwaArahaA taqir~u
[Make ye her (the camel's) young one to utter its grumbling cry, then she will be quiet]: for the she-camel when she hears the rugaA=' of her young one becomes still: (Meyd:) the prov. means, give him that which he wants, [then] he will be quiet. (JK, Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 532.]) A^arogawoA lilr~aHiyli means They made their saddle-camels to utter the grumbling cry [for removal, or departure, or journeying]; camels being wont to do so when the loads are lifted upon them. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, ArgAhu (assumed tropical:) He subdued, subjected, or oppressed, him; and abased him: because the camel [generally] does not utter the cry termed rugaA=' except in consequence of abasement, or humiliation. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] hiYa maliykapu AlA_irogaA='i (assumed tropical:) She is the slave (maliykap meaning mamoluwkap) of noise and loquacity, so that she distresses the hearers: or it may mean [she is subject to] the frothing of her lips, by reason of her loquacity; from ragowapN meaning “ froth. ” (TA. [See rag~aA='N.]) ― -b4- You say also, maA A^avogaY walaA A^arogaY He gave not a sheep or goat, nor a she-camel; (S, K;) like as you say, maA A^aHo$aY walaA A^ajal~a. (S. [See 4 in art. vgw.]) -A2- See also 2, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] ArgY said of him who is discharging his urine, (tropical:) He had much froth to his urine. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] turogiynaA suqaATa HadiyvihaA, a phrase used by a poet, means (assumed tropical:) She feeds us with [or gives us] little discourse, [or the refuse of her discourse,] like froth. (TA.)

6 taraAgawoA *
They uttered the cry termed rugaA=', [or rather (assumed tropical:) a cry, or cries, similar thereto,] one here and one here. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., taraAgawoA Ealayohi faqataluwhu (S, IAth, TA) (assumed tropical:) They shouted, one to another, and called one another, against him, to slay him, and slew him. (IAth, TA.)

8 ArtgY *
He drank ragowap, i. e. froth: (S, Msb:) or ArtgY ragowapF he took, and sipped, or supped, froth. (K.) It is said in a prov., yusir~u HasowFA fiY A@rotigaA='K [He conceals a sipping, or supping, in drinking froth]: applied to him who pretends one thing when he means, or desires, another: (S:) accord. to AZ and As, it originated from a man's having some milk brought to him, and his pretending that he desired the froth, and, while drinking this, taking of the milk; and is applied to a man who pretends to aid thee, and benefits himself: (Meyd:) Esh-Shaabee, to one who asked him respecting a man who kissed his wife's mother, replied in these words; and added, “ His wife has become unlawful to him. ” (S.)

ragowapN *
A single uttering of the grumbling cry termed rugaA='. (TA.) -A2- Also, and ↓ rugowapN and ↓ rigowapN, (JK, S, Msb, K,) the last mentioned by Lh and others, (S,) and ↓ rugaAyapu (JK, S, Msb, K) and ↓ rigaAyapN, (S, Msb, K,) the latter as heard by Abu-l-Mahdee, (S,) and ↓ rigaAwapN (JK, S, Msb, K) and ↓ rugaAwapN, (S, K,) the latter as heard by Abu-lMahdee, (S,) and ↓ rugaAwaY, (AZ, TA,) The froth of milk [&c.]; (JK, S, K;) or the first three signify the froth that comes upon a thing when it estuates; and the next three, the froth of milk: (Msb:) pl. of the first ragawaAtN, (Msb, TA,) and of the second rugFY, (S, * Msb, TA,) and of the last ragaAwaY. (TA.) -A3- Also the first (ragowapN), A rock, or a piece of rock. (IAar, K.)
rugowapN * [The grumbling cry termed raAgiyapN;] a subst. from zugaA='N [inf. n. of ragaA]. (TA.) -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph.
rigowapN * : see ragowapN.
ragowaAnu * : see rag~aA='N.
rugaA='N * inf. n. of 1 as explained in the first sentence. (S, K, &c.) [It is often used as a simple subst. like its syn. raAgiyapN.] ― -b2- See also rag~aA='N.
raguw~N * A she-camel that utters much, or often, the grumbling cry termed rugaA='. (S, K.)
rugaAwapN * : see ragowapN.
ruigaAyapN * : see ragowapN.
rugaAwaY * : see ragowapN.

rag~aA='N * (assumed tropical:) Loquacious: or loud in voice: (TA:) and ↓ ragowaAnu is [syn. therewith, or nearly so, being] a surname of Mujáshi' (K, TA) the son of Dárim, (TA,) because of his eloquence, (K, TA,) and the loudness of his voice. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A certain bird, (K, TA,) that cries much and uninterruptedly; (TA;) of the kind called dux~al; dust-coloured: its crying is termed ↓ rugaA='N: and the pl. is rag~aAA=tN. (En-Nadr, TA.)

raAgK * [part. n. of ragaA]. You say naAqapN raAgiyapN A she-camel that utters the cry termed rugaA='. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] maA lahu vaAgK walaA raAgK [He has not a sheep or goat, nor a camel]: (TA in art. vgw:) and maA lahu vaAgiyapN walaA raAgiyapN He has not a sheep or goat, nor a she-camel: (S:) and maA biAld~aAri vaAgK walaA raAgK (assumed tropical:) There is not in the house any one. (S and TA in art. vgw.) ― -b3- Also, raAgK, A certain bird, begotten between the wara$aAn [q. v.] and the HamaAm [or common pigeon]; an admirable variety: so says Kzw, but he has written the word with the unpointed E: Es-Suyootee says that in the “ Tibyán ” it is with the pointed g: and El-Jáhidh mentions its being prolific, long-lived, and having in its cooing a quality which its parents have not. (TA.) -A2- Also Milk having froth. (JK.)

raAgiyapN * fem. of raAgK [q. v.] ― -b2- Also syn. with rugaA='N [as an inf. n. or a simple subst.]: (JK:) see 1, in two places: [as a simple subst., like rugowapN, it has for its pl. rawaAgK:] you say, samiEotu rawaAgiYa AlA^ibili I heard the [grumbling] cries of the camels. (TA.)

murogK * [act. part. n. of 4]. ― -b2- [Its fem.] murogiyapN is app. the sing. of maraAgiY [probably a mistranscription for maraAgK, the reg. pl.], (TA,) which is an epithet applied to camels, meaning Whose milk has much froth. (K, TA.)

mirogaApN *
A skimmer; i. e. a thing with which (or in which, as in one copy of the K,) froth is taken: (S, K:) or a wooden thing with which one takes off the froth of milk: pl. maraAgK. (JK.)
kalaAmN murag~K * (tropical:) Speech, or language, that does not clearly express its meaning. (S, K, TA.)

1 raf~a * , (T,) or raf~a lawonuhu, (S, M, O, K,) aor.
rafi3a , inf. n. raf~N and rafiyfN, Its colour shone, or glistened; (T, S, M, O, K;) said of a thing; (T;) as also
↓ Artf~. (K.) Thus raf~ato A^asonaAnuhu, His teeth shone, or glistened. (M.) El-Aashà says, describing the front teeth of a woman,
ya$ofiY Almutay~ama *aA AlHaraAraho
wamahFA tarif~u guruwbuhu
[And clean, white, lustrous front teeth, the abundance of their saliva shining, or glistening; that would cure of his malady the enslaved by love who has burning in his heart]. (T, O, S.) And one says also, raf~a Albaroqu, aor.
rafi3a and
rafu3a , (M,) inf. n. raf~N, (M, K,) The lightning gleamed, or shone; or flashed faintly, and then disappeared, and then flashed again. (M, K. *) ― -b2- raf~a Aln~abaAtu, aor.
rafi3a , inf. n. rafiyfN, The plant, or herbage, quivered, or became tall, (Aihotaz~a,) being green and glistening; and wariyfN is a dial. var. of the inf. n. ra*iyfN in this sense: (Lth, T:) or quivered, or became tall, (Ahtz~,) and was luxuriant, or flourishing, and fresh, or succulent: or, as AHn says, became glistening, or bright, in its sap: (M:) and raf~a Al$~ajaru, aor. and inf. n. as above, The trees appeared beautiful and bright in their greenness by reason of their succulence and luxuriance; as also warifa, aor. yarifu, inf. n. wariyfN. (T in art. wrf.) ― -b3- raf~ato Eayonuhu, aor.
rafi3a and
rafu3a , inf. n. raf~N, His eye quivered, or throbbed: (M, K:) and in like manner one says of any other member, or part of the person, (M,) or of other things; (IAar, T, K;) as, for instance, of the eyebrow. (IAar, T, M.) ― -b4- raf~a said of a bird: see R. Q. 1, in two places. ― -b5- raf~a, aor.
rafi3a , [said of a man,] He exulted; rejoiced overmuch, or above measure; or exulted greatly, or excessively; and was exceedingly brisk, lively, or sprightly: and behaved proudly, or haughtily; was proud, haughty, or self-conceited; or walked with a proud, or haughty, and selfconceited, gait. (M.) ― -b6- raf~a A_ilaY ka*aA He was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly, at, or to do, such a thing; syn. AirotaAHa: (K:) and so said of the heart. (O.) ― -b7- raf~a lahu, (O, K,) aor.
rafu3a and
rafi3a , inf. n. rufuwfN and rafiyfN, (O,) He laboured for him with service, both honourable and mean. (O, K.) ― -b8- raf~a bifulaAnK He treated such a one with honour: (O, K:) [and so, accord. to the TA, raf~a fulaAnFA, as is shown in the first paragraph of art. Hf.] ― -b9- raf~a Alqawomu bihi The people, or party, surrounded, encompassed, or encircled, him; or went round him, or round about him. (O, K.) ― -b10- raf~ato Ealayohi Aln~iEomapu Wealth became abundantly bestowed upon him; syn. Dafato. (M.) -A2- raf~a, aor.
rafu3a (IAar, T, K) and
rafi3a , (K,) [probably trans., or so with the former aor. and intrans. with the latter,] inf. n. raf~N, (O,) He ate (IAar, T, K) soundly, (IAar, T, [see raf~apN, the inf. n. of unity,]) or much, or largely. (O, K.) ― -b2- raf~ati AlA_ibilu, (AHn, M, K,) and Alganamu, (K,) or rf~t Albaqola, (TK,) aor.
rafu3a and
rafi3a , inf. n. raf~N, The camels, (M, K,) and the sheep or goats, (K,) ate, (AHn, M, K,) or ate herbs, or leguminous plants, (TK,) in a certain manner, (K,) without filling the mouth therewith. (TK.) ― -b3- raf~a All~abana, (TK,) inf. n. raf~N, (K,) He drank milk every day. (K, TK.) ― -b4- [Hence, perhaps,] A^axa*atohu AlHum~aY raf~FA The fever attacked him every day. (O, K.) ― -b5- raf~a, aor.
rafu3a , (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M,) inf. n. raf~N (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) and rafiyfN, (M,) also signifies He sucked (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) a thing: (M:) and he sucked in [saliva &c.] with his lips. (A 'Obeyd, T, S.) You say, raf~a A^um~ahu He (a young camel) sucked his mother. (K.) And r~f~a AlmaroA^apa, (M, O,) or AljaAriyapa, (IAar, L in art. mSd,) aor.
rafu3a , (M, O,) inf. n. raf~N, (O,) He sucked in the woman's, or the girl's, saliva from her mouth: (IAar, M, and L ubi suprà:) or he kissed her with the extremities of his lips. (M, O, K.) And hence, (M,) A_in~iY laA^aruf~u $afatayohaA waA^anaA SaAy^imN, in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh, (T, M, O, Msb,) means Verily I suck in her saliva [from her lips while I am fasting]: (A 'Obeyd, T, M, O:) or I kiss [her lips], and suck [them], and suck in [her saliva from them]. (Msb.) -A3- raf~ahu, (M, O, K,) aor.
rafu3a , (M,) inf. n. raf~N, (M, O, K, *) He did good to him; conferred a benefit, or benefits, upon him. (M, O, K. *) [And He gave to him.] You say, fulaAnN yaHuf~unaA wayarof~unaA, meaning Such a one gives to us, and brings us corn or food. (M. [See also other explanations in art. Hf.]) And fulaAnN yaruf~unaA Such a one guards us, defends us, or takes care of us. (S.) [Hence,] it is said in a prov., mano Haf~anaA A^awo raf~anaA faloyaqotaSido [explained in art. Hf]: and one says, ↓ maA lahu HaAf~N walaA raAf~N [also explained in art. Hf]. (S.) -A4- raf~a Albayota He made to the byt [which here seems from the context to mean tent] what is termed a raf~ [q. v.]. (M.) [And hence, app.,] raf~a vawobahu, aor.
rafu3a , inf. n. raf~u, He added to his garment, or piece of cloth, another piece, to enlarge it, at its lower part. (K.) -A5- raf~ahu He fed him [i. e. a beast] with ruf~ap, i. e. straw, or straw that had been trodden, or thrashed, and cut, and what had been broken in pieces thereof. (M.) -A6- raf~a Alv~awobu, (M,) inf. n. rafafN, (M, O, K,) The garment, or piece of cloth, became thin: (M, O, K: *) but this is not of established authority. (M.)

4 Arf~t EalaY bayoDatihaA *
She (a hen) spread, or expanded, the wing over her egg. (O, K.)
8 A_irotafa3a see 1, first sentence.

R. Q. 1 raforafa * , (T, S, M, K,) inf.n. raforafapN, (T, K,) He (a bird) moved, or agitated, his wings, in the air, [or fluttered in the air,] without moving from his place; (T, M;) as also ↓ raf~a: (M:) or he (a bird, S, or an ostrich, K) did thus around a thing, desiring to alight, or fall, upon it: (S, O, K:) or he (a bird) expanded and flapped his wings without alighting: (TA in art. fr$:) and he (a bird) expanded his wings; as also ↓ raf~a; but this latter is not used. (O, K.) One says also, of an ostrich, yuraforifu bijanaAHayohi vum~a yaEoduw [He flaps his wings, then runs]. (T, S, O.) ― -b2- [See also R. Q. 1 in art. zf, last sentence.] ― -b3- rfrf EalaY Alqawomi He was, or became, affectionate, favourable, or kind, to the people, or party; syn. taHad~aba. (M.) ― -b4- raforafapN also signifies The making a sound: (K:) its verb, raforafa, meaning It (a thing) made a sound. (TK.)

raf~N *
A thing resembling a TaAq, [i. e. a kind of arched construction, app. like the Suf~ap described and figured in the Introduction to my work on the Modern Egyptians,] (El-Fárábee, S, Msb, K,) upon which are placed the TaraAy^if [or choice articles, such as vessels and other utensils &c.,] of the house; as also ↓ raforafN: (IAar, T, K:) the raf~ that is [commonly] used in houses is well known [as being a wooden shelf, generally extending along one or more of the sides of a room]: IDrd says that the word is Arabic: (Msb:) the pl. is rufuwfN (T, S, O, Mgh, Msb, K) and rifaAfN. (O, Mgh, Msb.) The latter pl. occurs in the saying of Kaab Ibn-El-Ashraf, A^amaA A_in~a rifaAfiY taqaS~afu tamorFA Verily my shelves are breaking with dates, by reason of the large quantity thereof. (Mgh.) rufuwfu Alxa$abi, also, means The planks of the laHod [or lateral hollow of a grave]. (Mgh.) [And accord. to Golius, on the authority of a gloss. in the KL, raf~N also signifies A small arched window in a wall.] -A2- [When the raf~ of a bayot is mentioned, by byt may sometimes be meant a tent:] see raforafN. -A3- Also A flock of sheep, (Fr, T, S, M, O, K,) or of sheep or goats. (Lh, M, K.) ― -b2- A herd of oxen or cows. (Lh, O, K.) ― -b3- A row of birds. (IAar, T and TA in art. Abl.) ― -b4- A company of men. (Fr, T.) ― -b5- Large camels; (O, K;) as also ↓ rif~N: (K:) [or] a large herd of camels. (M.) -A4- An enclosure (HaZiyrap) for sheep or goats. (M, O, K.) -A5- Any tract of sand elevated above what is adjacent to it or around it. (K.) -A6- Wheat, corn, or other provision, which one brings for himself or his family or for sale; syn. miyrapN. (M, K.) -A7- A soft garment or piece of cloth. (K.) -A8- And, as some say, (M,) Saliva (M, K) itself [as well as the “ sucking in of saliva: ” see 1]. (M.)
ruf~N * : see ruf~apN.

rif~N *
A daily $irob [i. e. drinking, or share of water]. -A2- See also raf~N.

raf~apN * [inf. n. of unity of raf~a,] i. q. baroqapN [app. as meaning A flash of lightning]: (IAar, T:) or a shining, or glistening. (O.) ― -b2- And A quivering, or throbbing. (IAar, T.) -A2- Also A sound act of eating; syn. A^akolapN muHokamapN. (IAar, T, O, K. [In the CK, in this sense, erroneously written ruf~ap.]) ― -b2- And A suck. (IAar, T.)

ruf~apN *
i. q. tibonN [i. e. Straw; or straw that has been trodden or thrashed, and cut]; and what has been broken in pieces thereof; [also written rufapN and rufatN and rufapN;] (M, O, K;) as also. ↓ ruf~N. (K.) [See also rufapN.]

rufaAfu *
What has fallen about of straw, and of dried leaves or branches of the samur [or gumacacia-tree]. (IAar, M.)

rafiyfN *
Shining, or glistening. (KL. [The meaning of “ dispersed ” assigned to it by Golius as on the authority of the KL is not in my copy of that work, nor is any other meaning than that which I have given above; in which sense it is
app. an inf. n. used as an epithet: it is expl. in the KL by the Pers. word drx$ndh.]) One says also vagorN rafaAfN [app. ↓ raf~aAfN] Front teeth shining or glistening. (Har p. 314.) ― -b2- Applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, O,) and to trees ($ajar), (S, O, * K,) and other things, (K,) Moistened [app. by dew or the like, so as to be rendered glossy]. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, Thin. (O.) -A2- Abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (O, K.) -A3- The lily. (O, K.) -A4- The roof (Sh, M, O, K) of a [tent such as is called] fusoTaAT. (Sh, O, M.) ― -b2- See also raforafN. -A5- *aAtu Alr~afiyf Boats upon which a river was crossed, consisting of two or three joined together, for the use of the king. (O, K.)
rifaAfapN * , The thing that is put in the lower part of the helmet. (AA, O. [See also raforafN.])
raf~aAfN * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also A plant, or herbage, intensely green. (TA in art. wrf.)

raforafN * : see raf~N, first sentence. ― -b2- Also A window; or an aperture for the admission of light; syn. rawo$anN; (IAar, T, K;) and so ↓ rafiyfN. (AA, T, O, K.) -A2- Also Coverlets (HaAbis, Katádeh, T) for beds: (T:) or beds [themselves]: (AO, T, O, K:) or carpets: (AO, T, K:) or green pieces of cloth, or pieces of cloth of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, (viyaAbN xuDorN, [which may have either of these two meanings,] S, M, O, K,) that are spread, (M,) or of which maHaAbis [see above] are made, (S, O, K,) and which are spread; (K;) n. un. with p; (S, O, M;) but some make the former a sing.: (O:) pl. rafaArifu: (M:) or it signifies, (T, O,) or signifies also, (K,) the redundant parts of maHaAbis, (T, O, K,) and of beds; (K;) and anything that is redundant and that is folded: (O, K:) or pieces of thin diybaAj [or silk brocade]: (M, K:) it occurs in the Kur lv. 76: and some say that it there means the meadows, or gardens, (riyaAD,) of Paradise: (Fr, T:) or, as some say, pillows: (T:) or it signifies also a pillow: and meadows, or gardens; syn. riyaADN: (K:) also a carpet: (T:) and sometimes it is applied to any wide garment or piece of cloth. (Bd in lv. 76.) ― -b2- Also The kisor [app. as meaning the lowest piece of cloth, or the part of that piece that is folded upon the ground,] of a [tent of the kind called] xibaA=': (Lth, T, S, M, O, K:) and a piece of cloth (xiroqapN) that is sewed upon the lower part of a [tent of the kind called] fusoTaAT, (Lth, T, M, K,) and of a suraAdiq, (M, K,) and the like; as also ↓ raf~N, of which the pl. is rufuwfN: (M: [in the CK, AlfusoTATu is erroneously put for AlfusoTaATi:]) or the skirt of a tent: (Bd in lv. 76:) and, accord. to IAar, the extremity, edge, or border, of a fusoTaAT. (T.) ― -b3- Also The redundant portion of the skirt of a coat of mail: (A 'Obeyd, T, O:) or the sides of a coat of mail, (S, K,) and the pendent portions thereof: (S, O, K:) n. un. with p. (S.) And the raforaf of a coat of mail is [The tasobigap, q. v. : or] a piece of mail (zaradN) which is fastened to the helmet, and which the man makes to fall down upon his back. (M, K.) ― -b4- The pendent branches of the [tree called] A^ayokap. (T, O, K.) ― -b5- Soft, or tender, and drooping trees. (M, K.) And Certain trees, (K,) certain drooping trees, (As, T, O,) growing in El-Yemen. (As, T, O, K.) ― -b6- Also, [because pendent,] The [caruncle, in the vulva of a girl or woman, called] baZor [q. v.]. (Lh, M, K.) -A3- And A species of fish (Lth, T, M, O, K) of the sea. (M, K.)

Alr~aforaAfu *
The bird called xaATifu Zil~ihi. (Ibn-Selemeh, S, O, K. [See art. xTafa.]) And sometimes, (S,) The male ostrich: (T, S, M, O, K:) because (S) he flaps his wings (yuraforifu bijanaAHayohi) and then runs. (T, S, O.) ― -b2- Also The wing of an ostrich and of any bird. (M.)

rufaArifN *
Quick, or swift. (O.)
raAf~N * : see 1, [of which it is the act. part. n.,] in the last quarter of the paragraph.

maraf~N *
i. q. maA^okalN [A place, or time, of eating]. (O.) [This art. is wanting in the copies of the L and TA to which I have had access.]

1 rafaA^a Als~afiynapa * , (M, Mgh, K,) aor.
rafaAa , inf. n. rafo'N, (M,) He brought the ship near to the bank of a river; (M, K;) as also ↓ A^arofaA^ahaA: (S, TA:) or both signify he brought the ship near to the bank of a river and made her still, or motionless: (Mgh:) or the latter, he brought her near to the land; or to the part of the land that was near; or so the former accord. to AZ; (T;) and so the latter: but in the K, ArfA^ is expl. as signifying simply he made, or drew, or brought, near. (TA.) ↓ A^arofaw^uwA A_ilaY jaziyrapK occurs in a trad. [as meaning They brought the ship near to an island]: and some say A^arofayotu for A^arofaA^otu; which latter is the original. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, accord. to ISd in the M, but this I think doubtful,] rafaA^a Alv~awoba, (AZ, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (AZ, T, S, Mgh, Msb,) and so the inf. n., (AZ, T, S, Mgh,) He repaired, or mended, [or darned,] the garment, (S, Msb,) where it was rent; (S;) or he closed up what was rent in the garment, drawing the parts together, (M, Mgh, K,) by texture [with the needle, i. e. darning]: (Mgh:) and sometimes it is pronounced without '; (S;) [i. e.,] one says also [rafaA Alv~awoba, and] rafawotuhu, aor.
rafuAa , (Msb,) inf. n. rafowN; (IAar, T, Msb;) and rafayotuhu, aor.
rafiAa , inf. n. rafoYN, which is of the dial. of Benoo-Kaab; (Msb;) but this last is strange. (TA.) [See 1 in art. rfw.] One says, mani A=gotaAba xaraqa wamani A@sotagofara rafaA^a (tropical:) [He who traduces another, behind his back or otherwise, though with truth, rends, and he who begs forgiveness repairs]: (S, M:) i. e., by AlAigotiyaAb he rends his religion, and by AlAisotigofaAr he repairs it. (M.) ― -b3- And [hence,] rafaA^a bayonahumo He effected a reconciliation, or made peace, between them; (M, K;) like raqaA^a. (TA.) ― -b4- And rafaA^a Alr~ajula, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He appeased quieted, or calmed, the man, (M, K, TA, [like rafaAhu, without ', see art. rfw,]) stilling his fear, or terror, and treated him with gentleness. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 3. ― -b6- rafaA^a is also said to signify tazaw~aja [He married; or took a wife]; (TA;) or so rafA [without ']. (T.)

2 rf~A=hu * , (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. tarofiy^apN and tarofiYo'N, (T, S, K,) He said to him, (namely, a man who had had a wife given to him, T, S, M,) biAlr~ifaA='i waAlbaniyna; (T, S, M, K; [see rifaA='N, below;]) as also rf~Ahu, without '. (TA.)

3 rAfA^hu * , (AZ, T, S, M,) inf. n. muraAfaA^apN; (AZ, T;) and ↓ ArfA^hu, (K, but there without any objective complement,) and ↓ rafaA^ahu; (TA;) He treated him in an easy and a gentle manner; or abated to him the price, or payment; syn. HaAbaAhu; (AZ, T, S, M, K; *) fiY AlbayoEi [in selling]: (AZ, T, S:) or ↓ ArfA^hu signifies daAraAhu [he treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him; &c.]: (IAar, M:) or ArfA^ is also syn. with daAraY; and so is rAfA^. (K.)

4 ArfA^ *
He, or it, drew near, or approached. (K.) You say, ArfA^ti Als~afiynapu The ship drew near, or approached, (T, TA,) to the land, (T,) or to the part of the land that was near, or to the bank of a river. (TA.) ― -b2- ArfA^ A_ilayohi He inclined to, or towards, him, or it; (Fr, T, K; *) as also ArfY. (Fr, T.) And (K) He had recourse, or he betook himself, or repaired, to him, or it, for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging; (S, M, K;) as also ArfY. (TA in art. rfw.) ― -b3- He combed, or combed and dressed, his hair. (K, * TA.) -A2- As a trans. v. : see 1, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 3, in two places.

6 taraAfaw^uwA *
They agreed together; or were of one mind or opinion: (S, K:) and they aided, or assisted, one another; or leagued together, and aided one another. (S.) And trAfw^wA EalaY AlA^amori They agreed together to do the thing: (M:) they agreed together, or conspired, to do the thing, their stratagem and their affair being one. (T, TA.)

rifaA='N *
Close union; coalescence; (ISk, T, S, M, K;) consociation; these being the meanings if the root be with ': (ISk, T:) good consociation: (T:) and composure of disunited circumstances or affairs: (K:) or reparation: (Msb:) and concord, or agreement; (T, S, M;) like muraAfaAtN; [if the root be] without ': (T:) or, if the root be without ', the meaning is tranquillity; or freedom from disturbance, or agitation. (ISk, T, S.) Such are said to be the meanings in the saying, biAlr~ifaA='i waAlbaniyna; (ISk, T, S, M, Msb, K; [see 2;]) i. e. [May it (the marriage) be] with close union, &c., (K, TA,) and increase (TA) [or rather the begetting of sons, not daughters]: or with reparation [of circumstances or condition, and the begetting of sons]. (Msb.) It is said, in a trad., that the Prophet forbade the use of this phrase, disliking it because it was a customary form of congratulation in the Time of Ignorance: (T, * TA:) and some relate that he used to say, in its stead, baAraka A@ll~`hu Ealayoka and baAraka fiyka [May God
bless thee], and jamaEa bayonakumaA fiY xayorK [may He unite you two in prosperity]. (T, TA.) Some of them used to congratulate him who had taken a wife by saying, biAlr~ifaA='i waAlv~abaAti waAlbaniyna laA AlbanaAti [May it be with close union, &c., and constancy, and the begetting of sons, not daughters]. (Har p. 364.) And one says also, bayona Alqawomi rifaA='N, meaning Between the people is close union, and concord, or agreement. (Msb.)
raf~aA='N * [A darner;] one who closes up what is rent in garments, drawing the parts together, (M, Mgh, K,) by texture [with the needle, i. e. darning]; in Pers. rafuwGaro. (Mgh.)
marofaA^N * : see the next paragraph. ― -b2- Also A place where garments are darned. (KL.)

murofaA^N * , (S, Mgh, Sgh, K,) and ↓ marofaA^N, (M, K,) [A station of ships;] a place where ships are brought near to the bank of a river [or to the land; see 1, first sentence]; (S, M, K;) i. q. furoDapN. (Mgh.)

yarofay^iY~N *
Heartless, or deprived of his heart, by reason of fright. (M, K.) ― -b2- A male ostrich: (M:) or a male ostrich taking fright, and fleeing, or running away at random. (K.) ― -b3- A gazelle; because of its briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, and its uninterrupted running: (M:) or a gazelle that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, much, or often, (qafuwzN,) and goes back, or retreats, (M, * K, TA,) fleeing. (TA.) ― -b4- And A pastor of sheep or goats: (M, K:) it is said to have this meaning: (T:) or by this is meant a certain black slave so called. (TA.)

1 rafatahu * , (T, M, A, K,) aor.
rafita and
rafuta , (M, K,) inf. n. rafotN, (M,) He broke it; (T, M, K;) or broke it in pieces: (T:) he crushed, bruised, brayed, or pounded, it: (M, K:) he crumbled it, or broke it into small pieces, with his hand, like as is done with lumps of dry clay, and old and decayed bones. (A.) And rufita It was broken; or broken in pieces; [&c.] (Akh, S.) You say, rafata Eunuqahu, aor.
rafita , inf. n. as above, He broke, or crushed, his neck. (Lh, M.) And rafata EiZaAma Aljazuwri He broke the bones of the slaughtered camel, in order to cook them and to extract their grease. (T.) And one says of him who does that from which he finds it difficult to liberate himself, AlD~abuEu taroqutu AlEiZaAma walaA taEorifu qadora A@sotihaA taA^okuluhaA vum~a yaEosuru EalayohaA xuruwjuhaA [The hyena breaks in pieces the bones, but knows not the size of its anus: it eats them; then their exit becomes difficult to it]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rafata AlEaTa$a (assumed tropical:) It (water) broke the vehemence of thirst. (Z, TA in art. frt.) -A2- (See also 9.)

2 rf~thu * , inf. n. tarofiytN, He broke it [app. much, or into many pieces]: ― -b2- and hence, (assumed tropical:) He dishonoured, despised, or condemned, him; tarofiytN being syn. with taHoqiyrN, and contr. of tarofiylN and taEoZiymN. (Er-Rághib, TA. *)

9 Arft~ * , as also ↓ rafata, (M, K,) the latter being intrans. as well as trans., (K, * TA,) It was, or became, broken, broken in pieces, crushed, bruised, brayed, or pounded: (M, K:) said of a bone; i. e., it became what is termed rufaAtN. (M.) And It became cut or broken, cut off or broken off; it broke, or broke off: (K, TA:) the former is said, in this sense, of a rope. (A, TA.)

rufatN *
i. q. tibonN [i. e. Straw; or straw that has been trodden, or thrashed, and cut: also written ruf~apN, and rufapN, and rufapN]. (IAar, T, K.) It is said in a prov., A^anaA A^agonaY Eanoka mina Alt~ufahi Eani Alr~ufati, (TA,) or A_ilaY Alr~ufati (T,) [I am more free from the want of thee than the badger is from the want of straw, or cut straw]: the tfh is what is called EanaAqu AlA^aroDi, which has a canine tooth, and does not procure for itself straw nor herbage; and the word is written with h; but Alrft is with t: (T:) or, accord. to ISk, the two words are correctly without teshdeed, and with the radical h. (TA in art. tfh.) [See also rufahN.] -A2- Also One who breaks, breaks in pieces, crushes, bruises, brays, pounds, or crumbles, anything, or everything. (K, * TA.)

rifotapN *
A mode, or manner, of breaking, breaking in pieces, crushing, &c. (Lh, M.)

rufaAtN * A thing, (M,) an old and decayed bone, (A, TA,) or anything, (L, TA,) broken, broken in pieces, crushed, bruised, brayed, or pounded; (M, L, TA;) or crumbled, or broken into small pieces with the hand; (A, TA;) or a thing that has become old and worn out, and crumbled, or broken into small pieces: ('Ináyeh, TA: [see marofuwtN:]) or broken, or crumbled, particles; fragments, or crumbs; of a thing that is dry, (T, S, A, K, TA,) of any kind; (T;) [as, for instance,] of musk. (A, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xvii. 52 and 100], A^ay^i*aA kun~aA EiZaAmFA warufaAtFA When we shall have become bones and broken particles? (S, M, TA.) [Hence also the phrase] laA birofaAtika, meaning No, by thy ancestors who have become broken and crumbled bones in the dust. (Har p. 634.) And [hence one says,] huwa Al~a*iY A^aEaAda AlmakaArima waA^aHoyaA rufaAtahaA waA^ano$ara A^amowaAtahaA (tropical:) [He is the person who has restored generous qualities or actions, and revived such of them as had decayed, and brought to life again such of them as had become dead]. (A, TA.)

marofuwtN *
Broken, broken in pieces, &c. (Akh, S. [See rufaAtN.])

1 rafava * (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) fiY kalaAmihi (M, A, Mgh) or fiY manoTiqihi (Msb,) aor.
rafuva , (K, and so in a copy of the S,) or
rafiva , (T, and so in another copy of the S,) or both, (Msb, TA,) the latter mentioned by 'Iyád in the “ Meshárik; ” (TA;) and rafiva, (M, K,) aor.
rafava ; (K;) and rafuva, aor.
rafuva ; (Lh, M, K;) inf. n. rafovN, which is of rafava, (M, TA,) and rafavN, (T, * S, * M, A, * Mgh, * Msb, K, *) which is of rafiva, (M, TA,) or of rafava, (Msb,) or, accord. to some, this is a simple subst., (TA,) and rufuwvN; (K;) and ↓ Arfv; (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) and ↓ trf~v; (A;) He uttered foul, unseemly, immodest, lewd, or obscene, speech, (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) in relation to women: (T:) and talked to a woman, in, or respecting, coition; (S, K, TA;) and (as in the A and Mgh, but in the Msb “ or ”) spoke plainly of what should be indicated allusively, relating to coition. (A, Mgh, Msb.) And rafava biA@moraA^atihi, and maEahaA, He compressed his wife: and he kissed her; and held amatory and enticing talk, or conversation, with her; and did any other similar act, of such acts as occur in the case of coition. (M.) And rafava A_ilaY A@moraA^atihi He went in to his wife; i. e. he compressed her; or was with her alone in private, whether he compressed her or not; syn. A^afoDaY A_ilayohaA. (A.) [See also rafavN below.]

3 rAfv SaAHibahu * , inf. n. muraAfavapN, [He joined with his companion, or vied with him, in foul, unseemly, immodest, lewd, or obscene, conversation, in relation to women: and in talking plainly of what should be indicated allusively, relating to coition.] (A.)
4 A^arofava see 1, first sentence.
5 taraf~ava see 1, first sentence.

6 trAfvA * [They two joined mutually, or vied with each other, in foul, unseemly, immodest, lewd, or obscene, conversation, in relation to women: and in talking plainly of what should be indicated allusively, relating to coition]; said of two men. (A.)

rafavN * , said by some to be a simple subst., but by others to be an inf. n., (TA,) Foul, unseemly, immodest, lewd, or obscene, speech, (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) in relation to women; (T;) this being the primary signification: (Lth, T:) and talk to women in, or respecting, coition: (S, K, TA:) and the speaking plainly of what should be indicated allusively, relating to coition: (Mgh:) or allusion to coition: (M:) or foul, unseemly, immodest, lewd, or obscene, speech addressed to women; (T, S, Mgh, K;) so accord. to I'Ab: (T, S, Mgh:) and coition: (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) and kissing; and amatory and enticing talk, or conversation; and any other similar act, of such acts as occur in the case of coition: (M:) or with the pudendum, (A, Mgh,) or with respect to the pudendum, (Msb,) it is coition: (A, Mgh, Msb:) and with the tongue, (A, Mgh,) or with respect to the tongue, (Msb,) the making an appointment for coition: (A, Mgh, Msb:) and with the eye, (A, Mgh,) or with respect to the eye, (Msb,) the making a signal of a desire for coition: (A, Mgh, Msb:) or it is a word comprehending everything that a man desires of his wife. (Zj, T.) In the Kur ii. 193, where it is forbidden during pilgrimage, it means Coition: (Zj, T, Mgh, Msb:) and speech that may be a means of inducing coition: (Zj, T:) or foul, unseemly, immodest, lewd, or obscene, speech: (M, Mgh, Msb:) or, accord. to Th, the removal of external impurities of the body, by such actions as the paring of the nails, and plucking out the hair of the armpit, and shaving the pubes, and the like. (M. [In the L and TA, the explanation
of Th is so given as to relate, not to rafavN, but, to laA rafava.]) And in the same, ii. 183, where it is allowed in the night of fasting, it means Coition: (Msb:) or the going in to one's wife; syn. A_ifoDaA='; wherefore it is made trans. by means of A_ilaY, like as is A_ifoDaA='. (M, Mgh.)

1 rafadahu * , aor.
rafida , inf. n. rafodN, He gave him, or gave him a gift: (T, S, M, A, * Msb, K:) or it signifies, (Msb,) or signifies also, (S, M, A,) he aided, helped, or assisted, him: (T, S, M, A, Msb:) and ↓ Arfdhu, (M, A, Msb,) inf. n. A_irofaAdN, (S, K,) signifies the same (S, M, A, Msb, K) in the latter sense, (S, M, A, K,) and in the former sense also: (S, K:) or both signify he aided, helped, or assisted, him, by a gift or by a saying or by some other thing: (Mgh:) [it is said in the Ham p. 128, that the latter verb has been transmitted, but is not the choice one; but in p. 276, that both are chaste:] and you say also ↓ rAfdhu; (A;) [meaning he aided him; or he aided with him; or he aided him, being aided by him; for] muraAfadapN is syn. with muEaAwanapN. (S, L.) One says, laA A^aquwmu A_il~aA rafodFA I will not stand unless I be helped to do so. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] He propped it up; namely, a wall: (Zj, T, A:) and rafadotuhu bihi I propped it up, or supported it, namely, a thing, with it, meaning any other thing used for such a purpose. (Zj, T.) ― -b3- And [hence,] rafadahu, (M, L,) or rafada Ealayohi, aor.
rafida , inf. n. rafodN, (AZ, T, S, M,) He made for him, (AZ, S, M, *) or put upon him, (T, M, *) namely, a camel, (AZ, S,) an appertenance of the saddle, called a rifaAdap: (AZ, T, S, M:) [and ↓ Arfdhu, or Arfd Ealayohi, signifies the same; for] A_irofaAdN is syn. with rafodN as meaning the putting to a beast, or furnishing him with, a rifaAdap. (K.) [Hence,] yurofadu bixiroqapK [meaning It is furnished with a piece of rag, as a compress,] is said of a wound (S, K) &c. (S.) ― -b4- And rafadahu signifies also It held it fast; namely, any one thing, another thing. (M.)

2 raf~aduwA fulaAnFA * , (M, A,) inf. n. tarofiydN, (S, K,) (tropical:) They made such a one a lord, or chief; (S, M, A, K;) made him great, or magnified him, or honoured him; (K; *) and set him over their affairs; (M;) [lit. made him to give gifts;] as also raf~aluwhu: because a man when he becomes a lord, or chief, gives gifts, and drags his skirt upon the ground (A_i*aA saAda rafada warafala). (A.) And ruf~ida fulaAnN (tropical:) Such a one was made a lord, or chief; and was made great, or magnified, or honoured. (S, TA.) -A2- rf~d, (T, L,) inf. n. as above, (T, L, K,) also signifies He went a pace like that called hmolajapN, (T, L,) or like that called harowalapN. (K.) [See 2 in art. rqd.]
3 raAofada see 1.
4 A^arofada see 1, in two places.

6 trAfdwA *
They aided, helped, or assisted, one another [by gifts or otherwise]. (S, * M, A, Msb, K. *)

8 Artfd *
He gained, acquired, or earned, (T, S, M, A, K,) property. (T, M, A.) And Artfdtu minohu I obtained a gift, or aid, from him. (A.)

10 Astrfdhu *
He sought, desired, demanded, or asked, aid, help, or assistance, from him [by a gift or otherwise]. (S, * A, Msb, K. *)
rafodN * : see the next paragraph.

rifodN *
A gift; (S, A, Msb, * K;) [and so, app., ↓ mirofadN or ↓ marofadN;] a gratuity: (T, S, A, K:) pl. A^arofaAdN (Ham p. 128) [and maraAfidu is pl. of mirofadN or marofadN]. You say, huwa kaviyru AlA^arofaAdi and ↓ AlmaraAfidi [He is a person of many gifts]. (A.) It is said in a trad., mini A@qotiraAba Als~aAEapi A^ano yakuwna AlfaYo'u rifodFA [One of the signs] of the approach of the hour of resurrection shall be, that the tribute shall be a gratuity bestowed according to men's natural desires, and not according to right, or desert. (T, L.) ― -b2- Aid, help, or assistance; (T, M, L, Msb;) as also mirofdN and marofdN [app. ↓ mirofadN and ↓ marofadN]; (M;) by a gift, and by giving milk to drink, and by a saying, and by anything. (T.) ― -b3- A lot, share, or portion. (M, L.) ― -b4- Also, (IAar, Ibn-El-Mubárak, T, S, M, A, L, K,) and ↓ rafodN, (El-Muärrij, T, S, M, L, K,) and ↓ mirofadN, (S, M, L, K,) and ↓ marofadN, (M, L,) A large [drinking-cup, or bowl, of the kind called] qadaH, (T, S, A, L, K,) in which a guest is given to drink: (S, L:) this is the meaning most known; and this meaning is assigned by Zj to the third of the words above, i. e. mirofadN: (T:) or a large Eus~, (M, L,) larger than the common Eus~, which latter is a large qadaH that holds enough to satisfy the thirst of three men, or four, or more; larger than the gamar: (L:) or a qadaH, (Ibn-El-Mubárak, T, M, L,) of whatever size it be; accord. to some: (M, L:) in a qadaH a she-camel is milked: (T:) or a vessel in which one milks. (El-Muärrij, T.) One says, huriyqa rifoduhu [His drinking-cup, or bowl, was emptied], meaning (tropical:) he was slain; a phrase similar to Safirato wiTaAbuhu, and kufiy^ato jafonatuhu: (A:) or he died. (K.) And mad~a fulaAnN biA^arofaAdiY [app. Such a one drew water with my bowls], meaning (tropical:) such a one aided me, or assisted me. (A, TA. [In my copy of the former, biA'irofaAdiY; which I think a mistranscription: in the latter, biArofaAdiY])

rifodapN *
A company such as is termed EuSobap, of men, (M, L,) [aiding one another: pl. rifadN: see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., ii. 461.]

rafuwdN * A she-camel that fills the [vessel called] rifod or rafod at one milking: (S, A, K:) or that is constantly over her milking-vessel: or that yields an uninterrupted supply of milk: (IAar, L:) or that aids her owners by the abundance of her milk: (TA in art. rkd:) pl. rufudN. (L.)

rifaAdapN * [A kind of pad, or stuffed thing, beneath a saddle;] a thing like the jadoyap of a horse's saddle, (S, Mgh, K,) for a beast: (K:) a support for the saddle of a horse or camel &c.: (M, L:) it is put beneath a horse's saddle in order that it may become raised thereby. (Lth, T.) ― -b2- A piece of rag with which a wound, (S, K,) &c., (S,) is furnished as a compress (yurofadu bihaA). (S, K.) ― -b3- A contribution which the tribe of Kureysh made among themselves in the Time of Ignorance, for the purpose of purchasing for the pilgrims wheat, and raisins (S, M, K) for [the beverage called] nabiy*: (S, M:) each gave according to his ability, and thus they collected a great sum, in the days of the assembling of the pilgrims; and they continued to feed the people until the end of those days: (M:) the rifaAdap and siqaAyap [i. e. the supplying these provisions and this beverage] pertained to the Benoo-Háshim; and the sidaAnap [or service of the Kaabeh], and the liwaA=' [or banner], to the Benoo-'Abd-ed-Dár: (S:) the term rifaAdapN used in relation to the feeding of the pilgrims is from rafadahu signifying “ he aided him by a gift ” &c.: (Mgh:) the first who performed this custom was Háshim Ibn-'Abd-Menáf. (T.) ― -b4- One says also, huwa rifaAdapu SidoqK liY and SidoqK ↓ rafiydapu, meaning (tropical:) [He is an excellent] aider, or helper, or assistant, to me. (A.)
rafiydapN * : see what next precedes.

raAfidN * [act. part. n. of rafada; Giving, or giving a gift: and aiding, &c.]: pl. [raAfiduwna and] ruf~adN. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN niEoma Alr~aAfidu A_i*aA Hal~a bihi AlwaAfidu [Such a one is an excellent, or a most excellent, giver, or aider, when the comer alights at his abode]. (A, TA.) And A^aEoTaY zakaApa maAlihi Tay~ibapF bihaA nafosuhu raAfidapF Ealayohi He gave the portion of his property that was due as the poor-rate, his soul being well pleased, or content, therewith, aiding him to do so. (L.) ― -b2- One who is next in station to a king, [who aids him,] and who, when the latter is absent, occupies his place. (IB.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A river that flows into, and augments, another river: you say nahorN lahu raAfidaAni (tropical:) A river that has two rivers flowing into it, and augmenting it. (A.) Hence, (A,) Alr~aAfidaAni is an appellation applied to (tropical:) The Tigris and Euphrates. (S, M, A, K.) ― -b4- [Hence,] one says also, fulaAnN yamod~u Albariy~apa raAfidaAhu (tropical:) Such a one's two hands or arms [afford aid, or succour, to mankind]. (A.)

raAfidapN * a word of the measure faAEilapN [app. as meaning A thing that aids, helps, or assists,] from Alr~afodu signifying “ the act of aiding, helping, or assisting. ” (TA.) rawaAfidu [is its pl., and] signifies The rafters, or beams, or timbers, (xa$ab, S, Mgh, K, or xu$ub, M,) of a roof, (IAar, S, M, Mgh, K,) over which are laid [planks, or only] the bundles of reeds, or canes, called HaraAdiY~; (IAar, L in art. Hrd;) as also raAfidaAtN. (S, M.) A poet says, (describing a house, S in art. bx,)
rawaAfiduhu A^akoramu Alr~aAfidaAti
[Its rafters are the most excellent of rafters]. (S, M.)

banuw A^arofadapa * , (S, K,) or A^arofidap, which latter is the more common and more approved, (TA,) mentioned in a trad., (S,) A class of the Abyssinians, (S, K,) who danced: (S:) or a surname of them: or they were so called from the name of their chief ancestor, (TA.)
tarofiydN * , a subst., like tamotiynN, and tanobiytN, The posteriors of a woman. (IAar, M.)
marofadN * , and its pl. maraAfidu: see rifodN, in four places.

mirofadN * , and its pl. maraAfidu: see rifodN, in four places. ― -b2- Also A piece of stuff, or a thing like a pillow, with which a woman small in the posteriors makes those parts to appear large. (S, K. *)
maraAfiydu * [a pl. of which the sing. (probably mirofaAdN, like migozaArN and midoraArN &c.,) is not mentioned,] Ewes, or she-goats, whose milk does not cease (S, K) in summer nor in winter. (S.)

1 rafashu * , (S, M, Msb, K, *) or rafasahu birijolihi, (M,) aor.
rafisa (S, M, Msb, K) and
rafusa , (M, K,) inf. n. rafosN (S, M, &c.) and rifaAsN, (Jm, K,) or this is a simple subst., (M,) and rufaAsN, (Jm,) [or this also is a simple subst.,] He kicked him, or struck him with his foot or leg, (S, M, Msb, K, *) in an absolute sense, (M, Msb,) or in, or upon, the breast. (Kh, M, Msb.) ― -b2- rafasahu, inf. n. rafosN, He pounded it, or brayed it; namely, flesh-meat, or other food; or anything; but originally, food. (M, TA.) -A2- rafasa AlbaEiyra, (K,) aor.
rafusa , inf. n. rafosN, (TA,) He bound the camel with the rifaAs [q. v.]. (K.)

rafosapN *
A kick, or blow with the foot or leg, [in an absolute sense, or] in, or upon, the breast. (Lth, K.)

rifaAsN * The act, or habit, of kicking, or striking with the foot or leg, in an absolute sense, or in, or upon, the breast; as also ↓ rafiysN and ↓ rufuwsN. (M, TA.) -A2- Also The [cord, or rope, called] A_ibaAD [q. v.]: (K:) or the bond with which the hind legs of the camel, when lying down, are bound to his thighs. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

daAb~apN rafuwsN *
A beast that has a habit of kicking, or striking with the foot or leg, in an absolute sense, or in, or upon, the breast. (M, TA.)
rufuwsN * : see rifaAsN.
rafiysN * : see rifaAsN.

mirofasN *
An instrument with which flesh-meat is pounded. (M, TA.)

1 rafaDahu * , aor.
rafiDa and
rafuDa , inf. n. rafoDN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and rafaDN, (S, K,) He left, forsook, relinquished, abandoned, or deserted, him, or it. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- He separated, dispersed, or scattered, it. (L.) ― -b3- rafoDN also signifies The act of breaking [a thing]. (TA.) ― -b4- And The act of driving away. (TA.) ― -b5- And rafaDa He threw, cast, or shot: (K:) whence raAfiDN as explained below. (TA.) ― -b6- And rafaDa A_ibilahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
rafiDa (S) and
rafuDa also, (O,) inf. n. rafoDN and rafaDN, (as in one copy of the S, but the former only in another copy,) He left his camels to separate, or disperse themselves, in their place of pasture, (S, A, Msb, K,) wherever they pleased, not turning them away from what they desired; (S;) as also ↓ ArfDhA, (Msb, K,) inf. n. A_irofaADN: (TA:) or, as the latter is explained by Fr, he sent them away without a pastor. (TA.) -A2- rafaDati AlA_ibilu, (Fr, S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
rafiDa , (Fr, S,) inf. n. rufuwDN, (S,) or rafoDN, (Fr,) The camels separated, or dispersed themselves, (Fr, A, Msb,) in the place of pasture: (Msb:) or pastured by themselves, (Fr, S, K,) the pastor seeing them, (S,) or looking at them, (K,) near or far off, (S,) not fatiguing them, nor collecting them together. (L.) Thus this verb is intrans. as well as trans. (TA.) [See also 9.] ― -b2- rafaDa Aln~axolu The palm-tree expanded its raceme, and the qiyqaA=' [or envelope] thereof fell off. (S, Sgh, K) ― -b3- rafaDa AlwaAdiY The valley widened; became wide; as also ↓ ArfD, (O, K,) and ↓ AstrfD. (Ibn- 'Abbád and K.) ― -b4- rafaDa fuwhu He shed his vagor [or front teeth]. (AA, TA.)

2 rf~D fiY Alqirobapi * , inf. n. tarofiyDN, He left a small quantity of water remaining in the skin. (AZ, S, K.) [See rafoDN.] ― -b2- rf~D said of a horse, He put forth his veretrum without being vigorously lustful. (K.)
4 ArfD A_ibilahu * : see 1. -A2- ArfD AlwaAdiY: see 1, last sentence but one.

5 trf~D *
It (a thing, TA) broke, or became broken, in pieces. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also 9, in three places.

9 ArfD~ *
It (a thing) became dispersed, (S, A, K,) and departed, or went away; (S, K, TA;) as also ↓ trf~D. (A, K, TA.) It (a company of men) separated, or became dispersed; or dispersed themselves; as also ↓ the latter verb. (Lth.) ― -b2- ArfD~ Ald~amoEu, (S, TA,) or Ald~umuwEu, (K,) The tears became scattered in drops: (S, K: [in one copy of the S, AirofiDaADu Ald~amoEi is explained by taro$iy$uhu; but the right reading is tara$~u$uhu, which I find in two copies; as in the K:]) or flowed and became scattered; and flowed and dropped continuously: or flowed in a scattered manner: (L:) and ↓ trf~D signifies the same. (TA.) You say also, ArfD~ Als~ayolu [The torrent dispersed itself]. (S, K.) And ArfD~ juroHuhu The thick purulent matter of his wound flowed, and became dispersed. (TA.) And ArfD~ EaraqFA His sweat ran; and flowed. (TA.) ― -b3- ArfD~ AlwajaEu (assumed tropical:) The pain ceased, or went away. (TA.) And ArfD~ minohu SaboriY (tropical:) [My patience departed in consequence of it]. (A, TA.)
10 A_isotarofaDa see 1, last sentence but one.

rafoDN * Camels in a state of separation, or dispersion; and in like manner, men, and goods, and plants or herbage: (A:) or camels pasturing by themselves, (S, K,) the pastor seeing them, (S,) or looking at them, (K,) near or far off: (S:) you say, A_ibilN rafoDN (S, K,) and ↓ rafaDN also, and ↓ raAfiDapN: (S, A, K:) and the pl. of rafaDN is A^arofaADN: (S, K:) [and ↓ rufuwDN seems to be a pl. of rafoDN.] Also A herd of gazelles in a state of separation, or dispersion: pl. rifaADN. (TA.) You say also ↓ naEaAmN rafaDN Ostriches in separate flocks. (S.) And fiY Als~afari ↓ Aln~aAsu A^arofaADN The men are in a state of separation, or dispersion, in journeying. (TA.) And Aln~aAsi ↓ rufuwDu The different parties of men. (S, K.) And mino kalaA^K ↓ rufuwDN Scattered pieces of herbage or pasturage, (Jm, S, K,) distant one from another. (Jm, S, O.) And AlA^aroDi ↓ rufuwDu Land which is deserted after having been prohibited to the public: (S:) or which has no possessor: (O, L, K:) so says IDrd; but he adds, or, accord. to some, deserted land (L, TA) between two cultivated pieces of land, (L,) or between two pieces of land belonging to two tribes. (TA.) ↓ rafaDN also signifies What is large, and in a state of separation or dispersion, of a thing: pl. A^arofaADN. (TA.) ― -b2- And rafoDN, A side, or a part, or portion, (syn. jaAnibN,) of a thing. (TA.) ― -b3- Also rafoDN, (IAar, ISk, Az, Z,) or ↓ rafaDN, (AZ, Fr, A'Obeyd, S,) the latter said, in a marginal note in the S, to be the correct form heard from the Arabs, (TA,) or both, (Sgh, K,) A small quantity of water; (S, A, K;) and of milk; (A, TA;) remaining in the bottom of a skin or of a mazaAdap; like a juroEap: (TA:) or a little less than is sufficient to fill a skin: (IAar:) pl. ↓ A^arofaADN. (Lh.) ― -b4- And hence, the former, (tropical:) Food that is sufficient to sustain life; syn. quwtN. (TA.)

rifoDN * The persuasion, or creed, or a tenet, of the raAfiDap; as in the saying attributed to the Imám Esh-Sháfi'ee,
A_ino kaAna rifoDFA Hub~u A=li muHam~adK
faloya$ohadi Alv~aqalaAni A^an~iY raAfiDaY
[If the love of the family of Mohammad be a tenet of the Ráfidees, let men and genii bear witness that I am a Ráfidee]. (TA.)
rafaDN * : and its pl. A^arofaADN: see rafoDN, in six places.

rajulN rufaDapN * , (A, L,) or rajulN qubaDapN rufaDapN, (S, K,) A man who lays hold upon a thing, and then leaves it (S, A, L, K) without delay. (S, A, L.) And raAEK qubaDapN rufaDapN A pastor who collects together the camels, and, when they come to a place which they like, leaves them to pasture where they will. (ISk, S, A. *) [See also art. qbD.]

rafaDaAtN * , in the following saying, is from rafaDati AlA_ibilu, explained above: li$awoqiY A_ilayoka fiY qalobiY rakaDaAtN waliHub~ika fiY mafaASiliY rafaDaAtN (tropical:) [app. meaning By reason of my yearning for thee, in my heart are impulses; and by reason of the love of thee, in my joints are loosenesses]. (A, TA.)

Alqawomu rafoDaY fiY buyuwtihimo *
The people, or company of men, are in a state of separation, or dispersion, in their tents, or houses: heard by Az from an Arab of the desert. (TA.) [rafoDaY seems to be a pl. of ↓ raAfiDN; like as halokaY is of haAlikN. See also rafoDN.]

rufaADN *
What is broken in pieces, and scattered, or dispersed, of a thing. (IDrd, S, K.)

$arakN rifaADN *
Tracks in a road differing one from another: (S:) or furrows in the middle, or main part, of a road, separating, one from another; or separating to the right and left. (TA.)
rufuwDN * : see rafoDN, in four places.

rafiyDN * i. q. ↓ marofuwDN, applied to a thing; (S, K;) i. e. Left; forsaken; relinquished; abandoned; deserted: (S, TA:) cast away: separated; dispersed; scattered: (TA:) and, applied to a spear, broken in pieces. (K.) -A2- Sweat; (O, K;) because of its flowing. (TA.)

raf~aADapN *
Men who pasture their beasts upon land such as is termed rufuwD: (S, K:) or, as in the O, who sow such land. (TA.)

raAfiDN * in the following saying of 'Amr Ibn-Ahmar El-Báhilee means A thrower: he says,
A_i*aA maA AlHijaAziy~aAtu A^aEolaqona Tan~abato
bimayovaA='a laA yaA^oluwka raAfiDuhaA SaxoraA
meaning, When the women of El-Hijáz hang their goods and utensils upon the trees, they stretch their tent-ropes and pitch their tent in a soft tract of land, the thrower wherein will not be able to throw a large piece of stone at thee, because of the not finding it. (O, L, K, * TA.) -A2- See also rafoDaY.

raAfiDapN *
A party of rawaAfiD: (K:) whence the rel. n. ↓ raAfiDaY~N [signifying of, or belonging to, rawaAfiD]. (TA.) rawaAfiDu [is pl. of raAfiDapN, and] signifies An army, or a military force, (S, O,) or any army or military force, (K,) which has deserted its leader: (S, O, K:) or armies which have deserted their leader.
