(L.) ― -b2- Also Alr~aAfiDapN, A certain sect of the $iyEap (S, Msb, K) of ElKoofeh; (Msb;) so called because they deserted Zeyd the son of 'Alee, (As, S, Mgh, Msb,) when he forbade them to speak against the Companions of the Prophet; (Mgh, Msb;) for they had promised allegiance to Zeyd the son of 'Alee (As, O, L, K) the son of El-Hoseyn the son of 'Alee the son of Aboo-Tálib, (As, O, L,) and then desired him to renounce the two elders, [Aboo-Bekr and 'Omar, (TK,)] and on his refusing to do so they deserted him: (As, O, L, K:) AlA^arofaADu is also applied to this sect, as though it were pl. of raAfiDN, like as A^aSoHaAbN is of SaAHbN; (TA;) and Alr~awaAfiDu also; but not Alr~uf~aADu: (TA:) and the rel. n. [which serves as a n. un.] is ↓ raAfiDaY~N [as above]. (K.) Afterwards, this appellation became applied to All persons transgressing in this way, [i. e. all apostates, or schismatics,] speaking against the Companions of the Prophet. (Msb.) ― -b3- A_ibilN raAfiDpN: see rafoDN.
raAfiDaY~N * : see raAfiDapN, in two places.

marofaDN * and ↓ marofaDapN sings. of maraAfiDu: the former is explained as A place in which water flows, and where it remains: (TA:) or maraAfiDu waAdK signifies the parts of a valley into which the torrent disperses itself. (S, A, * K. *) ― -b2- maraAfiDu AlA^~roDi The tracts of land where the main quantity of sand ends, becoming thin, at the sides of mountains and the like. (So in some copies of the S and in the TA.)
marofaDapN * : see marofaDN.
murofaD~N * Anything becoming dispersed, and departing, or going away. (S.)
marofuwDN * : see rafiyDN.

1 rafaEahu * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
rafaEa , (K, TA,) inf. n. rafoEN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He raised it: [this is generally the best rendering, as it serves to indicate several particular significations which will be found explained in what follows:] he elevated it; upraised it; uplifted it: he took it up: contr. of xafaDahu: (Msb:) or of waDaEahu: (S, Mgh, K:) as also ↓ rf~Ehu, (K,) inf. n. tarofiyEN; (TA;) and ↓ ArtfEhu; (K;) for accord. to the “ Nawádir, ” you say, ArtfEhu biyadihi and rafaEahu [he raised it, lifted it, heaved it, or took it up, with his hand]; but Az says that ArtfE is intrans., and that he has heard no authority for its being trans., in the sense of rafaEa, except that which he had read in the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb:” (TA:) rafoEN is sometimes applied to corporeal things, meaning the raising, or elevating, a thing from the resting-place thereof: sometimes to a building, meaning the rearing it, uprearing it, or making it high or lofty: (Er-Rághib:) or in relation to corporeal things, it is used properly to denote motion, and removal: (Msb:) it signifies the putting away or removing or turning back a thing after the coming or arriving thereof; like as dafoEN signifies the putting away or removing or turning back a thing before the coming or arriving [thereof]: (Kull p. 185:) but in relation to ideal things, it is [tropically used, as it is also in many other cases, and] accorded in meaning to what the case requires. (Msb.) [In its principal senses, proper and tropical, rafoEN agrees with the Latin Tollere..] It is said in the Kur [ii. 60 and 87], rafaEonaA fawoqakumu A@lT~uwra We raised above you from its resting-place the mountain: and in the same [xii. 2], Aall~`hu A@l~a*iY rafaEa Als~am`waAti bigayori EamadK tarawonahaA [God is He who raised the heavens without pillars that ye see; or, as ye see them]: and in the same [ii. 121], waA_i*o yarofaEu A_ibor`hiymu AlqawaAEida mina Albayoti [And when Abraham] was rearing or uprearing or making high or lofty [the foundations of the House of God, at Mekkeh]. (Er-Rághib.) And you say, AirofaEo h`*aA Take thou this: (Mgh:) or take it and carry it [away; or take it up and remove it]. (TA.) And rafaEa Alz~arEa, (Lh, K,) or rafaEahu A_ilaY Albayodari, (Msb,) aor.
rafaEa , (Lh,) inf. n. rafoEN (Lh, S) and rifaAEapN and rifaAEN [perhaps a mistranscription for rafaAEu, which see below], (Lh, TA,) He removed, or transported, the seed-produce from the place in which he had reaped it, (Lh,) or carried it after the reaping, (S, K,) to the place in which the grain was to be trodden out. (Lh, S, K.) [This last signification is said in the TA to be tropical; but according to a passage of the Msb quoted in the first sentence of this art., it is proper. In most of the phrases here following, the verb is undoubtedly used tropically.] ― -b2- rafaEuwA A_ilaY~a Euyuwnahumo (tropical:) [They raised towards me their eyes]. (TA.) ― -b3- daxalotu EalaY fulaAnK falamo yarofaEo biY raA^osFA (Mgh, TA *) (tropical:) I went in to such a one, and he did not look towards me, nor pay any regard, or attention, to me. (Mgh.) [biY is not here a mistake for liY, for the phrase is often found thus written.] ― -b4- rufiEa liYa Al$~aYo'u (assumed tropical:) [The thing was, as it were, raised into view, i. e. it rose into view, to me;] I saw the thing from afar. (TA.) ― -b5- rafaEa Als~araAbu Al$~axoSa, aor.
rafaEa , inf. n. rafoEN, (tropical:) The mirage raised, or elevated [to the eye, (see an ex. near the end of the first paragraph of art. zwl)] the figure of a man or some other thing seen from a distance; [or it may be allowable to render it, made it to appear tall, and as though quivering, vibrating, or playing up and down;] syn. zahaAhu [of which, when it relates to the mirage, the meaning is best expressed by the latter of the two explanations here given]. (TA.) ― -b6- warafaEonaA baEoDahumo fawoqa baEoDK darajaAtK, in the Kur [xliii. 31], means (assumed tropical:) And we have exalted some of them above others in degrees of rank, or station: and narofaEu darajaAtK mano na$aA='u, in the same, [vi. 83, and xii. 76,] (assumed tropical:) We exalt in degrees of rank, or station, whom We please: (Er-Rághib:) and waA@ll~`hu yarofaEu mano ya$aA='u wayaxofiDu (assumed tropical:) And God exalteth whom He pleaseth, and abaseth: (S and TA:) and [in like manner,] rafoEu Al*~ikori means the exalting of one's fame; as in the Kur xciv. 4. (Er-Rághib.) But the words, waA_ilaY Als~amaA='i kayofa rufiEato, in the Kur [lxxxviii. 18], indicate two meanings; And to the heaven, how it is elevated in respect of its place; and (assumed tropical:) how it is exalted in respect of excellence, and exaltation of rank. (Er-Rághib.) [In like manner also,] fiY buyuwtK A^a*ina A@ll~`hu A^ano turofaEa, in the Kur [xxiv. 36], means In houses which God hath permitted to be built; (Bd, TA;) accord. to some: (TA:) or, (assumed tropical:) to be honoured; (Zj, Bd;) so says El-Hasan; (Zj;) or, (assumed tropical:) to be exalted in estimation. (Er-Rághib.) It is said in a trad., A_in~a A@ll~`ha yarofaEu AlEadola wayaxofiDuhu (assumed tropical:) Verily God exalteth the just, and maketh him to have the ascendency over the unjust, and at one time abaseth him, so that He maketh the unjust to overcome him, in order to try his creatures, in the present world. (Az, TA.) [See also art. xfD.] And you say, rafaEahu EalaY SaAHibihi fiY Almajolisi (assumed tropical:) He advanced him above his companion [in the sitting-place, or sitting-room, or assembly]. (TA.) And rafaEotuka Eano ka*aA (assumed tropical:) [I exalted thee, or held thee, above such a thing]: (M voce rabaA^a:) and A_in~iY laA^arofaEoka Eano h`*aA AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) [Verily I exalt thee, or hold thee, above this thing]. (S voce rabaA^a, q. v.) ― -b7- rafaEa A@ll~`hu Eamalahu (assumed tropical:) [God honoured his work by acceptance; or] God accepted his work. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [xxxv. 11], waA@loEamalu AlS~aAliHu yarofaEuhu (assumed tropical:) And righteous
work He will accept: (Jel:) or the meaning is yarofaEu AlEamalu AlS~aAliHu Alkalima AlT~ay~aba (assumed tropical:) [righteous work will cause praise, or the like, (mentioned immediately before the above-cited words of the Kur,) to ascend, and obtain acceptance]: (Mujáhid, TA:) Katádeh says, [that the meaning is,] speech will not be accepted without work. (TA.) ― -b8- rafoEN Also signifies (assumed tropical:) The bringing a thing near; or presenting, or offering, it; syn. taqoriybN. (S.) And hence, rafaEotuhu A_ilaY Als~uloTaAni, (S, Mgh, K,) and A_ilaY AlHakami, (TA,) inf. n. rafoEN (S, * TA) and rufoEaAnN (S, K) and rifoEaAnN, (TA,) (tropical:) I presented him to, or brought him before, or brought him forward to, the Sultán, (S, * Mgh, * K, * TA,) and the judge, to arraign him and contest with him: (TA:) and A_ilaY AlHaAkimi ↓ raAfaEahu, (S K,) inf. n. muraAfaEapN, (TA,) [in like manner] signifies (tropical:) he preferred a complaint against him to the governor, or judge: (K:) or (tropical:) he presented him to, or brought him before, or brought him forward to, the governor, or judge, to arraign him and contest with him, and preferred a complaint against him: (TA:) [or it denotes the doing so mutually; for, accord. to Mtr,] xaSomahu A_ilaY Als~uloTaAni ↓ raAfaEa signifies (tropical:) he brought his adversary before the Sultán (qar~abahu A_ilayohi), the latter doing the same with him. (Mgh.) [See also 2.] ― -b9- rafaEa AlquroA=na EalaY Als~uloTaAni (tropical:) [He adduced, or brought forward, the Kur-án against the Sultán;] he interpreted the Kur-án against the Sultán, and judged thereby that he should rebel against him. (TA.) ― -b10- rafoEotu Alr~ajula also signifies (tropical:) I traced up the man's lineage to his greatest ancestor; or I mentioned his lineage, saying, He is such a one the son of such a one, or He is of such a tribe, or city, &c.; syn. namayotuhu, and nasabotuhu. (TA.) ― -b11- And hence, rafaEa AlHadiyva A_ilaY Aln~abiY~i (tropical:) [He traced up, or ascribed, or attributed, the tradition to the Prophet, mentioning, in ascending order, the persons by whom it had been handed down, up to the Prophet; in the manner more fully explained in the sentence here next following]. (TA.) You say also, rafaEa AlHadiyva A_ilaY qaAy^ilihi, meaning A^asonadahu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He traced up, or ascribed, or attributed, the tradition to the author thereof, by mentioning him, or by mentioning, uninterruptedly, in ascending order, the persons by whom it had been transmitted, up to the Prophet; or by mentioning the person who had related it to him from the Prophet if only one person intervened, saying, “ Such a one told me, from such a one, ” (and so on if more than one intervened between him and the Prophet,) “ from the Apostle of God; ” or with an interruption in the mention of the persons by whom it had been transmitted]. (S * and Msb in art. snd.) [And hence what next follows.] It is said in a trad., rafaEato A_ilayonaA mina AlbalaAgi ↓ kul~u raAfiEapK faqado Har~amotuhaA A^ano tuEoDada A^awotuxobaTa, (S, * TA, [in a very old and excellent copy of the former of which I find, as above, A_ilayonaA, and so in some copies of the K and in the O and TA in art. blg; but in one copy of the S and in the TA in the present art., I find in its place EalayonaA, and so in the CK in art. blg, where the verb preceding it is erroneously written rufiEato; and in the L, in the place of AlynA is put Ean~aA; of all which three readings I prefer the first; though the last is agreeable with an explanation of rafaEotuhu given in the Msb and in the sentence next following;]) i. e. (assumed tropical:) Every company of men (jamaAEap, S, TA), or person (nafos, TA), that communicates, or announces, from us, (S, TA,) and makes known, [lit. traces up to us,] what we say, (TA,) [or rather, aught of what is communicated, or announced,] or [aught] of what is communicated, or announced, of the Kur-án and of the [statutes, or ordinances, &c., termed] sunan, (K in art. blg,) or the meaning is mino *awiY AlbalaAgi, i. e., Alt~aboliygi, [of those who have the office of communicating, or announcing,] the simple subst. being put in the place of the inf. n., (T, O, K, TA, all in art. blg,) let that company, or person, communicate, or announce, and relate, that I have forbidden [its trees' being lopped, or being beaten with a stick in order that their leaves may fall off,] referring to El-Medeeneh: (S, * TA:) but some relate it differently, saying, mina Albul~aAgi [of the communicaters, or announcers,] like Hud~aAv in the sense of muHad~ivuwn: (TA:) and some say, mina AlbilaAgi, meaning mn AlmubaAligiyna fiY Alt~aboliygi, i. e. of those who do their utmost in communicating, or announcing. (Hr, and K in art. blg.) ― -b12- [Hence,] rafaEotuhu [alone] signifies (tropical:) I made it known. (Msb.) You say, rafaEa Ealayohi kalaAmFA (assumed tropical:) [He told, or related, a saying against him; informed against him]. (S and K voce raq~aY, q. v.) And rafaEa EalaY AlEaAmili rafiyEapF (tropical:) He communicated, (S,) or made known, (Msb,) [or submitted, or referred,] a case [to the administrator of the law]; (S;) and A_ilaY AlHaAkimi [to the governor, or judge]. (TA.) And rafaEotu AlA^amora A_ilaY Als~uloTiAni, inf. n. rufoEaAnN, (tropical:) I made known [or submitted, or referred, by way of appeal,] the affair, or matter, to the Sultán. (Msb.) [See also 2.] ― -b13- [And hence, app.,] rufiEato lahu gaAyapN fasamaA lahaA (tropical:) [An object to be reached, or accomplished, was proposed to him, and he aspired to it]. (TA.) ― -b14- rafaEa AlbaEiyra, (Sb, K,) and Aln~aAqapa, (TA,) or rafaEa Aln~aAqapa fiY Als~ayori, and Ald~aAb~apa, (M in art. nS,) inf. n. rafoEN, (TA in that art.,) (tropical:) He made the camel, (S, Msb, K,) and the she-camel, (TA,) and the beast, (M ubi suprà,) to exert himself, or herself, to the full, or to the utmost, or beyond measure, in going, or pace; (S, K, TA;) or to go quickly; (Msb;) or to go with the utmost celerity: (TA in art. nS:) or constrained him, or her, to go the pace termed marofuwE [q. v. infrà], (TA,) which is an inf. n. of the intrans. verb rafaEa [q. v. infrà] said of a camel (S, TA) and of a beast: (TA:) and ↓ rf~Ehu, (S, TA,) [and rf~EhA,] and rf~E minohu, (TA,) [and minohaA,] inf. n. tarofiyEN, signify the same: (S, TA:) or the phrase used by the Arabs is AirofaEo mino daAb~atika (tropical:) [Make thou thy beast to exert itself, &c.]. (L, TA.) [You say also, app. in like manner, rafaEatoniY A^aroDN: or in this case the verb may have a different meaning: see an ex. in the first paragraph of art. xfD.] ― -b15- [Hence,] rafaEotuhu A_ilaY Had~i maA Einodahu mina AlEilomi (assumed tropical:) [I urged him to tell the utmost of what he knew;] (A in art. nS;) i. e. I went to the utmost point [with him] in questioning him, or asking him. (TA in that art.) ― -b16- [rafaEa Aln~aAra (assumed tropical:) He stirred up the fire; made it to burn up.] ― -b17- rafaEati Aln~aAqapu labanahaA (tropical:) The she-camel [drew up, or withdrew, or withheld, her milk; i. e.,] did not yield her milk: (A, TA:) and rafaEati All~ibaA^a fiY DaroEihaA (tropical:) [She (a camel) drew up, & c., or refused to yield, the biestings in her udder]. (As, S, K.) ― -b18- rafaEahu fiY xizaAnatihi, and Sunoduwqihi, (tropical:) He kept it, preserved it, laid it up, stowed it, or reposited it, in his repository, store-room, or closet, and his chest. (TA.) ― -b19- huwa laA yarofaEu AlEaSaA Eano EaAtiqihi, (Msb, TA,) or EaSaAhu En EAtqh, or Eano A^aholihi, (Mgh,) (tropical:) [lit. He does not put away the staff, or stick, or his staff, or stick, from his shoulder, or from his wife,] is an allusion to discipline, chastisement, or punishment, (Mgh, TA,) or to severity thereof, (Msb,) and to beating (Mgh, TA) of women; (Mgh;) not meaning that the staff, or stick, is on the shoulder: (Msb:) or the first is an allusion to many journeyings. (TA.) ― -b20- rufiEa Alqalamu Eano valaAvK; (Mgh, Msb;) so in the “ Firdows, ” on the authority of 'Alee and I' Ab and 'Áïsheh, meaning valaAvi A^anofusK; (assumed tropical:) [The pen of the recording angel is withheld from three persons;] a saying of Mohammad, which means that nothing is recorded either for or against three persons; (Mgh, Msb; *) these three being the sleeper until he awakes, the afflicted with disease or the like, or the demented, until he recovers, and the child until he becomes big, or attains to puberty. (El-Jámi' -es-Sagheer of Es-Suyootee; in which we find valaAvapK in the place of valaAvK.) This is like the saying next before mentioned; the pen having never been put [to the tablet to record aught] against the child. (Msb.) ― -b21- [rafaEa often signifies (assumed tropical:) He withdrew, put away, removed, did away or did away with, annulled, revoked, or remitted.] You say, Aall~`hum~a A@rofaEo Ean~aA h`*ihi AlD~ugoTapa (assumed tropical:) [O God, withdraw, put away, or remove, from us this straitness, difficulty, distress, or affliction]. (S in art. DgT.) [And in like manner also you say, rafaEa Eanohu AlEa*aAba (assumed tropical:) He withdrew, or put away, from him the punishment; he annulled, revoked, or remitted, his punishment.] rafaEuwA AlHaroba [may also be rendered in a similar manner; (assumed tropical:) They gave over, or relinquished, war; as though they put it away; like waDaEuwhaA: but] is used by Moosà Ibn-Jábir [in the contr. sense, (assumed tropical:) they raised, or made, war;] in opposition to wDEwhA. (Ham p. 180.) ― -b22- AixotalafuwA faqaAla baEoDuhumo narofaEu TariyqFA waqaAla baEoDuhumo laA narofaEu means (assumed tropical:) [They disagreed; and some of them said,] We will exclude a way, or passage, from among the portions, or shares, (qisomp, [q. v.,]) of the land, or the house; and [some of them said,] We will not exclude it. (Mgh.) ― -b23- In the conventional language of the grammarians, rafoEN, in the inflection of words, is like Dam~N in the non-inflection. (S) [You say, rafaEa AlHarofa, aor.
rafaEa , inf. n. rafoEN, (assumed tropical:) He made the final letter to have rafNEa or
rafuEa
in
its inflection.] -A2- rafaEa Alqawomu (tropical:) The people, or company of men, went up, or upwards, through the countries, or lands. (As, K, TA.) ― -b2- rafaEa AlbaEiyru, (S, Msb, K,) fiY Als~ayori, (S,) or fiY sayorihi, (Msb, K,) inf. n. marofuwEN (Sb, S, TA) and rafoEN, (S, A, K, all in art. xfD,) the former an inf. n. (Sb, S, TA) of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Sb, TA,) like [its contr. maxofuwDN, and] majoluwdN, and maEoquwlN, (S, TA,) and mawoDuwEN, (Sb, TA,) (tropical:) The camel exerted himself to the full, or to the utmost, or beyond measure, in going, or pace, or in his going, or his pace: (S, K, TA:) or was quick therein: (Msb:) or went the pace termed marofuwE, [q. v. infrà,] which is a running below that termed HuDor: (S, TA:) as though he had that [manner of going] which raised him, as well as that which lowered him. (Sb and TA with reference to the inf. n. mrfwE and mwDwE.) And rafaEuwA fiY masiyrihimo (assumed tropical:) They [namely men] rose above the [easy and quick pace termed] hamolajap in their going, or journeying. (ISk.) -A3- rafuEa, inf. n. rifoEapN; (S, K;) or, accord. to Aboo-Bekr Mohammad Ibn-Es-Sereé, [so in two copies of the S, but in others, accord. to the TA, Ibn-EsSarráj,] they did not say rafuEa from rafiyEN in the sense of $ariyfN; (S, O;) so says Sb; and he adds, but [they said] ↓ ArtfE; (TA;) (tropical:) He (a man, S) was, or became, high, elevated, exalted, lofty, or eminent, in rank, condition, or state; (S, K, TA;) noble, honourable, glorious, or illustrious. (TA.) And rafuEa fiY Hasabihi wanasabihi (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, of high or exalted rank, or noble, or honourable, in his grounds of pretension to respect, and his relationship, or race, or lineage. (Msb.) ― -b2- rafuEa Alv~awobu (assumed tropical:) The garment, or piece of cloth, was fine, fine in texture, delicate, or thin. (Msb.) ― -b3- rafuEa, (S, K,) inf. n. rafaAEapN, (K,) (tropical:) He (a man, S) was, or became, high, or loud, (rafiyE,) in voice. (S, K.) [See rafaAEapN below.]

2 rf~Ehu * , inf. n. tarofiyEN: see 1, in the first sentence. ― -b2- He took it, namely, a thing, and raised it, (rafaEahu,) the first [part thereof] and then the first [or next in succession]: En-Nábighah EdhDhubyánee says,
xal~ato sabiyla A^atiY~K kaAna yHobisuhu
waraf~aEatohu A_ilaY Als~ijofayoni faAln~aDadi
[She had cleared the way of a torrent coming from another quarter, which it (meaning the barrier raised around the tent to keep away the torrent, which barrier is mentioned two verses before,) confined, and raised it by degrees, the first part and then the next, to the two curtains meeting together at the entrance of the tent, and then to the goods piled up therein: or the meaning here intended is, brought it forward, or advanced it; syn. qad~amatohu; agreeably with the next explanation of raf~aEa here following: see some observations on the above-cited verse in De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd. ed., vol. ii. pp. 430 and 431]. (Lth, TA.) ― -b3- raf~aEahumo He put them, brought them, or sent them, forward; or advanced them; liloHarobi to the war, or fight: or, accord. to Ibn-'Abbád and the K, he put them, sent them, or removed them, far away; [app. meaning, far in advance;] fiY AlHarobi in the war, or fight. (TA.) You say also, raf~aEotu h`*aA AlA^amora A_ilaY AlA^amiyri (assumed tropical:) I brought forward this affair, or matter, to the commander, governor, or prince. (From an Arabic note on the above-cited verse of En-Nábighah, cited by De Sacy, ubi suprà.) [See also 1, in two places in which reference is made to this paragraph.] ― -b4- rf~E AlbaEiyra, and Aln~aAqapa, and rf~E minohu, and minohaA: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. -A2- rf~E AlHimaAru, (Lth, K,) inf. n. as above, (Lth,) (assumed tropical:) The ass ran with a running of which one part was quicker (A^arofaE) than another. (Lth, K.)

3 rAfEhu A_ilaY AlHaAkimi * , inf. n. muraAfaEapN: and rAfE xaSomahu A_ilaY Als~uloTaAni: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- raAfaEaniY fulaAnN waxaAfaDaniY falamo A^afoEalo (tropical:) Such a one endeavoured in every way to induce me to turn or incline, or endeavoured in every way to turn me by deceit or guile, but I did not [that which he desired]. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- rAfE bihimo (assumed tropical:) He spared them; or pardoned them, and forbore to slay them. (K.) And raAfaEotuhu (assumed tropical:) I left him; or left him unmolested; or left him, being left by him; or made peace, or reconciled myself, with him; syn. taArakotuhu. (TA.)

5 trf~E * (tropical:) He exalted himself; he was, or became, haughty, proud, or disdainful; syn. tajaAl~a; (S in art. jl;) [and so fiY nafosihi ↓ ArtfE, occurring in the S in art. dkl, on the authority of AZ.] You say, fulaAnN yataraf~aEu Eano *`lika (S ubi suprà, TA *) (tropical:) Such a one exalts himself above that; holds himself above it; disdains it; or is disdainful of it; syn. yatajaAl~u. (S ubi suprà.) And taraf~aEato biY him~atiY Eano ka*aA (tropical:) [My ambition raised me above such a thing; made me to hold myself above it, or to disdain it]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 8.

6 taraAfaEonaA A_ilaY AlHaAkimi * (tropical:) [Each of us preferred a complaint against the other to the governor, or judge: or each of us presented the other to, or brought him before, or brought him forward to, the governor, or judge, to arraign him and contest with him, and preferred a complaint against him: agreeably with explanations of the phrase raAfaEahu A_ilaY AlHaAkimi]: (S:) or each of us communicated, or made known, his case [against the other] to the governor, or judge. (TA.)

8 ArtfE *
It became raised; or it rose: it rose high, or became high or elevated or lofty: [it became raised, upraised, uplifted, or elevated, or it rose, from its resting-place: and, said of a building, it became reared, upreared, or made high or lofty:] it became taken up: [it became taken away, put away, or removed; or it went away; after its coming or arriving: thus when said of corporeal things: but when said of ideal things, it is tropically used, as it is also in many other cases, and accorded in meaning to what the case requires:] quasi-pass. of rafaEahu as signifying the contr. of waDaEahu. (S, K.) [See 1; first sentence.] ― -b2- It (the water of a well) rose, by its becoming copious: and also it went away: (A in art. qlS:) [in which latter sense, likewise, it is said of milk in the udder; or as meaning it became drawn up, or withdrawn, or withheld: see 1. See also a usage of this verb voce raqaA^a.] ― -b3- (tropical:) Said of a man: see 1, voce rafuEa, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b4- ArtfE qadoruhu (tropical:) [His rank became high, elevated, exalted, lofty, or eminent]. (S, TA.) ― -b5- AirotafiEo, said to a man entering a sittingplace, sitting-room, or assembly, means (tropical:) Advance thou: it is not from AirotifaAEN denoting height. (TA.) ― -b6- See also 5. ― -b7- ArtfEt AlD~uHaY (tropical:) [The morning became advanced; meaning] the sun became high: AlD~uHaY being originally a pl., namely, of AlD~aHowapu; [wherefore the verb is fem.;] but afterwards used as a sing. [as in the next ex. here following]. (Msb.) You say also, AlD~uHaY ↓ taraf~aEa (tropical:) [meaning the same]. (TA.) And ArtfE Aln~ahaAru (assumed tropical:) [The day became advanced, the sun being somewhat high: a phrase said by the doctors of the law in the present day to be employed when the sun has risen the measure of a rumoH or more]. (S and K in art. mtE; &c.) ― -b8- ArtfE Als~iEoru waA@noHaT~a (tropical:) [The price rose, or advanced, and became low, or abated]. (TA.) ― -b9- [ArtfEwA (assumed tropical:) They removed from, or to, a place. ― -b10- ArtfE Eanohu, said of a disease, pain, an affliction, and the like, (assumed tropical:) It quitted him; became withdrawn from him.] ― -b11- Aln~aqiyDaAni laA yajotamiEaAni walaA yarotafiEaAni (assumed tropical:) [What are termed nqyDAn cannot be coexistent in the same thing, nor simul taneously nonexistent in the same thing]; as existence itself and nonexistence, and motion and rest. (Kull pp. 231 and 232.) -A2- ArtfEhu: see 1; first sentence.

10 AstrfEhu *
He desired, required, demanded, or asked, that it should be raised, elevated, taken up, or removed. (K.) You say, AstrfE AlwaAEiZu AlA^ayodiYa lild~uEaA='i The preacher asked that the hands of the people should be raised for supplication. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, as though meaning AstrfE nafosahu i. e. It required that itself should be re moved,] AstrfE AlxuwaAnu (assumed tropical:) What was on the table became consumed, and it was time for it to be taken up, or removed. (K.)
rafoEN * [see rafaEa, (of which it is the inf. n.,) throughout].

rifoEapN * [see rafuEa, near the end of the first para graph: used as a simple subst., which it seems properly to be accord. to some of the lexicologists,] (tropical:) High, elevated, exalted, lofty, or eminent, rank or condition or state; nobility, honourableness, gloriousness, or illustriousness; (TA;) as also ↓ rifaAEapN, a subst. from rafuEa. (Msb.)

h`*ihi A^ay~aAmu rafaAEK * , and ↓ rifaAEK; (AA, ISk, Az, S, Mgh, * Msb, * K;) but As disallows the latter; (TA;) and Ks says, I have heard AljiraAm and AljaraAm, and their coordinates, [such as AlS~iraAm and AlS~araAm, &c.,] but AlrfAE with kesr I have not heard; (S, TA;) These are days of removal, or transport, of seed-produce from the place in
which it has been reaped, (TA,) or of carriage thereof after reaping, (S, Mgh, K,) to the place in which the grain is trodden out. (S, Mgh, K, TA.) [See 1, near the beginning.] ― -b2- rafaAEN, or ↓ rifaAEN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) or each, (TA,) also signifies The storing-up of seed produce. (K.)
rifaAEN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

rafiyEN * (tropical:) High, elevated, exalted, lofty, or eminent, in rank, condition, or state; noble, honourable, or glorious; (S, Msb, K, TA;) applied to a man: (S, Msb, TA:) fem. with p. (TA.) You say, huwa rafiyEu AlHasabi waAlqadori (tropical:) [He is high, &c., in respect of grounds of pretension to honour, and of rank]. (TA.) And hence the phrase used by letter-writers, AljanaAbu Alr~afiyEu (tropical:) [The exalted object of recourse]. (TA.) Hence also the phrase in the Kur [xl. 15], rafiyEu Ald~arajaAti (assumed tropical:) The Exalted in respect of degrees of dignity: (Er-Rághib:) or this means (assumed tropical:) Great in respect of attributes: or the Exalter of the degrees of dignity of the believers in Paradise. (Jel.) ― -b2- Applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (assumed tropical:) Fine, fine in texture, delicate, or thin. (Msb.) ― -b3- rafiyEu AlS~awoti (tropical:) [High, or loud, in voice]; (K, TA;) applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b4- sayorN rafiyEN (tropical:) [A pace in which a beast is made to exert itself to the full, or to the utmost, or beyond measure; or in which the utmost pos sible celerity is elicited: see rafaEa AlbaEiyra, in the latter half of the first paragraph: and see also marofuwEN]. (K in art. nS.)

rafaAEapN * [an inf. n., (see 1, last sentence,)] and ↓ rufaAEapN, (ISk, S, K,) and ↓ rifaAEapN, (Sgh, K,) (tropical:) [Highness, or loudness, or] vehemence, (K, TA,) in the voice, (ISk, S,) or of the voice. (K.)

rufaAEapN *
A string (xayoT) whereby he who is shackled (muqay~ad) raises his shackles (qayod), (Yoo, S, K,) to which that string is fastened; (TA;) as also ↓ rifaAEapN. (K.) ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) and ↓ rifaAEapN, (Az, K,) A thing by means of which a woman having little flesh in the posteriors makes herself to appear large [in that part]; (S;) i. q. EuZ~aAmapN: (K:) pl. rafaAy^iEu. (TA.) -A2- See also rafaAEapN.
rifaAEapN * : see rifoEapN: ― -b2- and rafaAEapN: -A2- and see also rufaAEapN, in two places.

rafiyEapN * (tropical:) A case which one communicates, or makes known, to the administrator of the law: (S, TA:) pl. rafaAy^iEu. (TA.) You say, liY Ealayohi rafiyEapN (tropical:) [I have, against him, a case to communicate, or make known, &c., or which I have communicated, or made known, &c.]. (TA.)
raf~aAEN * (tropical:) One who traces up traditions to the Prophet, or to his Companions; or who communicates them, or makes them known. (TA.) [See rafaEa AlHadiyva &c.]

raAfiEN * act. part. n. of rafaEahu; Raising; &c. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Alr~aAfiEu, one of the names of God, meaning (tropical:) The Exalter of the believer by prospering [him], and of his saints by teaching [them]. (TA.) xaAfiDapN raAfiEapN, in the Kur lvi. 3, is explained in art. xfD. ― -b3- raAfiEapN, for jamaAEapN raAfiEapN, (S, TA,) or nafosN raAfiEapN: (TA:) see a trad. (commencing with the words kul~u raAfiEapi) in the first paragraph of this art. ― -b4- naAqapN raAfiEN (tropical:) A she-camel [drawing up, or withdrawing, or withholding, her milk; i. e.,] not yielding her milk: (A, TA:) or when she draws up, &c., or refuses to yield, (A_i*aA rafaEato,) the biestings in her udder. (As, S, K.) [See also daAfiEN, to which it is opposed.] -A2- (tropical:) A man going up, or upwards, through the countries, or lands: pl. with wn. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Lightning rising. (Lth, K, TA.) ― -b3- rawaAfiEu [pl. of raAfiEpN for jamaAEapN raAfiEapN] (assumed tropical:) People going the pace termed marofwE [on their camels or beasts]. (ISk.) ― -b4- A^aroDN raAfiEapu Als~uqoyaA (assumed tropical:) Land difficult of irrigation; contr. of xaAfiDapN AlsqyA. (TA in art. xfD.)
raAfiEapN * [as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] A hard and elevated tract of land. (ISh, TA voce xaAfiDapN [which signifies the contr.]) [See also raAfiEN.]

A^arofaEu * [Higher, or more elevated &c.: and highest, or most elevated &c.]. ― -b2- A^arofaEu liloHadiyvi (tropical:) More skilled in tracing up, or ascribing, or attributing, a tradition to its author; i. q. A^anaS~u, q. v. (TA in art. nS.) ― -b3- EadaA EadowFA baEoDuhu A^arofaEu mino baEaDK (assumed tropical:) [He ran with a running of which one part was quicker than another]; said of an ass. (Lth, K.)
marofaEN * [A place of elevation: and hence, ― -b2- ] A chair, or throne; syn. kurosiY~N: of the dial. of El Yemen. (TA.)

mirofaEN *
A thing with which one raises, elevates, or takes up. (TA.)

marofuwEN * pass. part. n. of rafaEahu. ― -b2- wafuru$K marofuwEapK, (S, K, *) in the Kur [lvi. 32], (S,) means [And beds raised] one upon another: (Fr, S, Bd, K:) or (assumed tropical:) of high estimation: (Bd:) or (tropical:) brought near to them: (S, K:) or wives elevated upon couches: (Bd:) or (assumed tropical:) honoured wives. (S, K.) ― -b3- HadiyvN marofuwEN (tropical:) A tradition related by a Companion of the Prophet, and ascribed, or attributed, to the Prophet himself, by the mention of him as its author, or of the person, or persons, up to the Prophet, by whom it has been handed down. (Kull p. 152.) -A2- It is also an inf. n.: [see rafaEa AlbaEiyru, in the latter half of the first paragraph:] and signifies (tropical:) A certain pace of a beast, (S, TA,) of a horse and of a camel; (L;) contr. of mawoDuwEN; (S, TA;) and of maxofuwDN; (A in art. xfD;) it is a run below that termed HuDor: (S, TA:) or above that which is termed mawoDuwE, and below that which is termed Eadow: (TA: [but probably Edw is here a mistake for HuDor:]) or a pace of a camel rising above the [easy and quick rate of going termed] hamolajap. (ISk.) You say, layosa lahu marofuwEN (tropical:) He (a beast) has not the pace termed mrfwE. (S.)

jabalN murotafiEN *
A high mountain. (TA.)

1 rafoga Eayo$uhu * , [aor.
rafuga ,] inf. n. rafaAgapN, His means of subsistence became ample, or abundant. (S.) [See also rafogN, below.] -A2- [rafaga, aor.
rafaga , He made the means of subsistence ample, or abundant. You say,] A^arofagu lakumu AlmaEaA$a I will make ample, or abundant, to you the means of subsistence. (TA.) -A3- rafaga AlmaroA^apa i. q. trf~ghA, q. v. (TA.)

5 trf~g *
He (a man) became, or made himself, ample, or abundant, in his means of subsistence; syn. tawas~aEa: (S:) or he exhibited ampleness, or abundance, in his means of subsistence. (PS.) -A2- trf~g fawoqa AlbaEiyri He (a man), feared that the camel [upon which he was riding] would throw him, and therefore wound his legs next the sheath of his [the camel's] penis: [i. e., pressed his heels against the camel's A^arofaAg (or groins):] in the K, as also in the O and Tekmileh, xalofa rijolayohi is erroneously put for falaf~a rijolayohi, the reading in the L. (TA.) ― -b2- trf~ghA, He sat between her thighs, for the purpose of compressing her; (K;) from the Nawádir el-Aaráb; as also ↓ rafagahaA, i.e. rafaga AlmaroA^apa. (TA.)

rafogN *
Softness, tenderness, or smoothness: (O, L, K: *) this is the primary signification, accord. to the O and L: accord. to MF, softness, tenderness, or smoothness, and uncleanness, or dirtiness; but this addition is wrong; and he has wrongly ascribed this explanation to Er-Rághib, who mentions in his book only the words of the Kur-án. (TA.) ― -b2- Ampleness, or abundance, of the means of subsistence; and abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life: (S, K, * TA:) and so ↓ rafaAgapN, (JK, * S, * TA,) an inf. n., (S,) and ↓ rafaAgiyapN, [also, app., an inf. n., like rafaAhiyapN;] (JK, * S, * TA;) and ↓ rufagoniyapN, like bulahoniyapN (K, TA) and rufahoniyapN, (TA,) [in which the last three letters, following the g, are all augmentative,] signifies [the same, or] ampleness, or abundance, of the means of subsistence. (K, TA.) -A2- Also, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) and ↓ rufogN, (S, Msb, TA,) the former of the dial. of Temeem, and the latter of the dial. of the people of El- 'Áliyeh and of El-Hijáz, (Aboo-Kheyreh, Msb, TA,) [The groin;] the root of the thigh; (ISk, Jm, Msb, K; and Mgh in art. whm;) and any of the other magaAbin [or places of flexure or creasing]; (ISk, Msb;) and any place of the body in which dirt collects, (ISk, Jm, L, Msb, K,) such as the armpit and the crease of the belly and the like: (L:) or the inner side of the thigh, at the root: (JK:) or the inner side of the root of each thigh, next the upper parts of the sides of the pubes, where the upper parts of the inner sides of the thighs and the upper part of the belly [app. a
mistake for the lower part of the belly] meet: (TA:) [or each of the two inguinal creases; for] the rufogaAni are between the pubes and the thigh, [one on each side,] and are also called the magaAbin: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) the latter (rufogN) also particularly signifies the armpit: (Fr, Mgh, K:) or, as some say, the root [or innermost part] of the armpit: (TA:) and the same, (ISh, K,) or each, (Msb,) the parts around the faroj [or vulva, or external portion of the organs of generation,] (ISh, Msb, K) of a woman: (ISh, K:) and sometimes the faroj itself: (Msb:) the pl. is A^arofaAgN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and rufuwgN (Msb, K) and rifaAgN and [of pauc.] A^arofugN, the first of which four is pl. of rufogN, [and is properly a pl. of pauc.,] the rest being pls. of rafogN: (Msb:) [accord. to J,] A^arofaAgN signifies the magaAbin [or places of flexure, or creasing,] of the armpits, and of the roots of the thighs: (S:) accord. to As, the armpits, and the [other] magaAbin of the body: (Mgh in art. whm:) IAar says that ↓ maraAfigu signifies the roots of the arms and of the thighs, and has no proper sing.: and AlArfAg is the sing. of Alr~ufagu (wAHd Alr~ufagi [but this is app. a mistranscription for wuAHiduhu Alr~ufogu meaning that A^arofaAgN has for its sing: rufogN]): and ↓ rufagN signifies the magaAbin and maHaAlib [by which latter are app. meant the places that sweat] of the body: accord. to As, what is thus termed is in camels and in human beings. (TA. [But the sing. verb in this last clause suggests that there is another mistranscription here, and a looseness of explanation; and that we should read thus: “ and rufogN (not rufagN) signifies any of the magaAbin and of the maHaAlib of the body. ”]) ― -b2- Also, both words, The dirt of the nail: (K:) or the dirt that is between the end of the finger and the nail, when the nail is not pared, after scratching the A^arofaAg [or groins and armpits and the like]: (TA:) or the former [or each] signifies the dirt of the magaAbin [or places of flexure, or creasing, of the body]; (K;) or the dirt and sweat that collect in the mgAbn of the armpits, and of the roots of the thighs, and other places of folding of the limbs. (TA.) ― -b3- Also the former word, (rafogN,) (assumed tropical:) A soft, or plain, tract, or piece, of land: (JK, K: *) pl. rifaAgN. (K.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Land having much soil or dust. (L, K.) [Hence,] one says, jaA='a fulaAnN bimaAlK karafogi Alt~uraAbi (assumed tropical:) Such a one came with, or brought, wealth, or cattle, abundant as the soil, or dust, thus termed. (L.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A place affected with drought, or barrenness, (L, K,) thin, or shallow, [in its soil,] of middling quality. (L.) ― -b6- (tropical:) The vilest place in a valley, and the worst in re spect of soil: (Aboo-Málik, K, * TA:) the lowest part of a valley and of a desert: (TA:) or A^arofaAgu AlwaAdiY signifies the sides of the valley. (AHn, JK, TA.) ― -b7- (tropical:) A side, or lateral part or region: (Akh, IAar, K:) pl. A^arofugN. (K.) You say, huwa fiY rafogK mino qawomihi, and mina Alqaroyapi, (tropical:) He is in a side, or lateral part, not in the middle, of his people, or party, and of the town, or village. (IAar, TA.) ― -b8- Also sing. of A^arofaAgN meaning (tropical:) The lower, or lowest, baser or basest, meaner or mean est, sort, or the rabble, or refuse, of mankind; (JK, K, TA;) likened to the A^arofaAg of a valley: or the sing. of ArfAg in this sense is ↓ rufogN. (TA.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) A skin for water, or for milk, that is thin, or rendered thin, (accord. to different copies of the K,) and of little worth. (K, TA.) ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) The straw of [the species of millet called] *urap: so accord. to the author of the L; but accord. to others, it is dafogN, with dAl, if this be not a mis transcription. (TA.) -A3- As an epithet, rafogN sig nifies Soft; applied to dust, or earth, and to food, or wheat, (TaEaAm,) and to kilos [or quicklime, &c.]. (K, * TA.)
rufogN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
rufagN * : see rafogN in the middle of the paragraph.
rafigapN * A she-camel having purulent pustules, ulcers, or sores, in the rufogaAni [meaning groins or armpits]. (A, TA.)

rafogaA='u * [fem. of A^arofagu], applied to a woman, (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, L, K,) Small in the mataAE [or vulva]: (L:) or thin in the thighs, small in the han [or vulva], deep in the rufogaAni [or groins]: (JK, Ibn 'Abbád, K:) or a woman narrow in the A^arofaAg [or groins, or inguinal creases, or the like]: (TA in art. rbl, from the 'Eyn:) or, applied to a woman, (A,) or to a she-camel, (JK, L,) wide in the rufog [app. meaning the vulva or the parts around the vulva]. (JK, A, L.)
Eayo$N rafiygN * (JK, S, TA) and ↓ raAfigN (S, TA) and ↓ A^arofagu (TA) Ample, or abundant, (JK, S, TA,) and pleasant, or good, (S, TA,) means of subsist ence. (JK, S, TA.)
rafaAgapN * : see rafogN, second sentence.
rafaAgiyapN * : see rafogN, second sentence.
rufagoniyapN * : see rafogN, second sentence.
raAfigN * : see rafiygN.
raAfigapN * , i. q. niEomapN [app. as meaning A benefit, benefaction, favour, boon, or blessing]: pl. rawaAfigu. (TA.)
A^arofagu * : see rafiygN. ― -b2- Its fem., rafogaA='u, is mentioned above, by itself.

marofuwgapN * [syn. with maroSuwfapN] A woman small in the han [or vulva], (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K,) or whose place of circumcision has cohered [after the operation] when she was young, and, conse quently, (L,) impervia viro. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, L, K.)
maraAfigu * : see rafogN, in the middle of the paragraph.

1 rafaqa * , (S, O, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
rafuqa , (S, Msb,) inf. n. rifoqN (S, * O, Mgh, * Msb, * K) and marofiqN and mirofaqN (AZ, O, K,) and marofaqN; (O, K;) and rafiqa, (JK, O, K,) [aor.
rafaqa ,] inf. n. rafaqN; (JK;) and rafuqa; (JK, O, K;) He was, or became, gentle, soft, tender, gracious, courteous, or civil; or he be haved, or acted, gently, softly, &c. (JK, S, O, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, rafaqa bihi, (AZ, S, O, Mgh, Msb, K,) and Ealayohi, (AZ, O, K,) inf. ns. as above; (O, K;) and rafiqa, and rafuqa; (K;) He was, or became, gentle, &c., or he behaved, or acted, gently, &c., with him, (AZ, S, O, Mgh, Msb, K,) and to him; (AZ, O, K;) and in like manner, bihi ↓ trf~q, (S, O, Mgh, K,) and ↓ Arfqhu. (AZ, O, K.) Hence the saying of the Prophet, mano rafaqa biA^um~atiY rafaqa A@ll~`hu bihi [He who is gentle, &c., with my people, God will be gentle, &c., with him]. (O.) [Hence, also,] one says, ↓ trf~q fiY A^amorihi [and rafaqa fiyhi as is indicated in the O] He used gentleness, or acted gently, in his affair; syn. taA^at~aY. (Msb in art. AtY.) And liHaAjatihi ↓ trf~q He applied himself with gentleness to his needful affair or business; syn. taA^at~aY. (T in art. AtY.) And liloA^amori ↓ trf~q He applied himself with gentle ness to the affair; syn. talaT~afa. (S in art. lTf.) ― -b2- Hence, rafuqa, in form like faruba, He was, or became, gentle, delicate, nice, neat, or skilful, in work or operation; the contr. of such as is termed A^axoraq. (Msb.) ― -b3- And rafaqotu AlEamala, with fet-h to the f, aor.
rafuqa , I did, or made, the deed, or work, soundly, thoroughly, skilfully, judiciously, or well. (Msb.) ― -b4- And rafaqotu fiY Als~ayori I pro ceeded in a right, or a moderate, manner in journeying, or in pace. (Msb.) -A2- See also 4. -A3- rafaAqapN is an inf. n. signifying The being a rafayq. (O, K.) Fr says, I heard a man at 'Arafát saying [to the pilgrims there assembled], jaEalakumu A@ll~`hN fiY rafaAqapi muHam~adK Sal~aY A@ll~`hu Ealayohi wasal~ama [May God make you to be in the companionship of Mohammad: may God bless and save him]. (O.) [And accord. to the TK, one says, rafuqa bihi, inf. n. rafaAqapN, meaning He became a rafiyq with him: but what is commonly said in this sense is raAfqahu, q. v.] -A4- rafaqa fulaAnFA, He struck the mirofaq [or elbow] of such a one. (K.) ― -b2- And rafaqa Aln~aAqapa, (S, O, K,) aor.
rafuqa , inf. n. rafoqN, (S, O,) He bound the she-camel's arm [app. together with the shank (for such is the common practice)], (S, O, K,) to prevent her going quickly, (S, O,) when fearing her yearning towards, or longing for, her home, or accustomed place: (S, O, K:) [or] rafaqa AlbaEiyra, aor.
rafiqa , inf. n. rafoqN, he bound the camel's neck (Eunuq [probably, I think, a mistranscription for EaDud i. e. arm,]) to his pastern, because of a slight lameness therein. (JK.) -A5- rafiqa said of a camel, aor.
rafaqa , inf. n. rafaqN, He had his elbow dis torted from his side. (TA and TK. [See rafaqN below, and A^arofaqu: and see also dafiqa.]) ― -b2- [And rafiqato, inf. n.rafaqN, is probably said of a she-camel, as meaning She had, in her teat, or teats, what is termed rafaqN: see, again, this word below.]

2 tarofiyqN * [as the inf. n. of the verb in the phrase
ruf~iqati Al$~aApu, if this verb have been used, means A sheep's, or goat's having the fore legs white to the elbows; for it] is from $aApN muraf~aqapN, explained below. (O.)

3 rAfqhu *
He was, or became, his rafiyq, or travelling-companion; he accompanied him in a journey; (S, O, Msb, K;) inf. n. muraAfaqapN (TK) and rifaAqN. (TA.) ― -b2- And this latter inf. n. also signifies The being hypocritical, or acting hypocritically. (TA. [See also 3 in art. rmq.])

4 Arfqhu * : see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- Also He profited him, or was useful to him; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ rafaqahu. (K.) ― -b3- [And in the present day, it means He associated him bigayorihi with another or others.]
5 taraf~aqa see 1, in four places.

6 trAfqwA *
They were, or became, travellingcompanions; they travelled, or journeyed, together; as also ↓ ArtfqwA: (JK:) and trAfqA they two were, or became, travelling-companions; &c.: (K:) and trAfqnA fiY Als~afari we were, or became, companions in travelling, or journeying. (S, O.)

8 Artfq *
i. q. Tlb rfqA [i. e. Talaba rifoqFA] and AstEAn [both meaning He sought, or demanded, aid, or help]. (Har p. 395. [See also 10.]) ― -b2- And hence, (Har ibid.,) Artfq bihi He profited, or gained advantage or benefit, by him, or it, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) namely, a thing. (Msb.) [This phrase is also often used as meaning He made use of it; namely, a garment, and an implement, &c.] ― -b3- See also 6. -A2- Also He leaned upon the mirofaq of his arm [i. e. upon his elbow]: (O, Msb, * K:) or upon the pillow [called mirofaqap]. (K.) -A3- And It was, or became, full, or filled. (K.)

10 Astrfqhu *
He sought, or demanded, his profiting him, or being useful to him. (TA.)

Q. Q. 2 tamarofaqa *
He took a mirofaqap, i. e. pillow [upon which to lean with his elbow]. (S.)

rifoqN * an inf. n. of rafaqa; (O, K;) Gentleness, softness, tenderness, graciousness, courteousness, or civility; contr. of EunofN; (S, O, Mgh, Msb;) i. q. luTofN, and Husonu SaniyEK, (IDrd, O, K,) or liynu jaAnibK and laTaAfapu fiEolK; and so ↓ rafaqN; (JK;) and ↓ raAfiqapN likewise; whence the phrase A^awolaY fulaAnFA raAfiqapF [He treated such a one with gentleness, &c.]. (JK, IDrd, O.) It is also explained as meaning Good submission to that which conduces to what is comely, or pleasing. (TA.) ― -b2- And Gentleness, delicacy, nicety, neatness, or skilfulness, in work or operation; contr. of xuroqN. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also A thing by means of which one seeks help or assistance. (K.) See also mirofaqN.

rafaqN * inf. n. of rafiqa: see the next preceding paragraph. -A2- [Also Easy of attainment.] You say marotaEN rafaqN [A place of pasturing, or of unrestrained and plentiful pasturing,] easy to be sought [and attained]. (S, O.) And maA='N rafaqN Water that is easy (JK, S, O, K) to be sought (JK, S, O) and taken: (JK:) or of which the well-rope is short. (K.) And HaAjapN rafaqu Albigoyapi An object of want that is easy [to be sought and attained]. (O, K.) -A3- Also A distortion of the elbow of a camel from the side. (Lth, S, O, K. [Said to be the inf. n. of rafiqa, q. v.]) ― -b2- And A stoppage of the orifice of the teat, (K,) or of the orifices of the teats, (O,) of a she-camel: (O, K:) so says Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh: (O:) or a disorder in the orifice of the teat, in consequence of being badly milked, or of the milker's not shaking the teat to remove what remained in it, so that the milk reverts into the udder, and turns to blood, or becomes coagulated and mixed with yellow water. (K. [Perhaps in this sense, also, an inf. n.: see 1, last sentence.]) -A4- See also rufoqapN.
rafoqapN * : see what next follows.

rufoqapN * , (JK, S, O, Mgh, Msb, K,) in the dial. of Temeem, (Msb,) and ↓ rifoqapN, (S, O, Msb, K,) in the dial. of Keys, (Msb,) and ↓ rafoqapN, and on the authority of Ibn-Tal-hah ↓ rufaAqapN, (K, [in which this last is said to be like vumaAmapu, to indicate that it is with damm to the r, but not (as will be shown below, voce rafiyqN,) that it is without tenween, imperfectly decl., and determinate like Alr~ufoqapu,]) Persons travelling, or journeying, together; (Mgh;) a company of persons [travelling, or journeying, or] with whom one is travelling, or journeying; but not when they have separated: (S, O, Msb, K:) or persons with whom one travels, or journeys, as long as they are congregated in one place of assembly, and in one journey; but not when they have separated: (JK:) pl. [of mult.] rifaAqN, (S, O, Mgh, Msb, K,) which is pl. of rufoqapN, (Mgh, Msb,) and rufaqN, [which is also pl. of rufoqapN,] and [of pauc.] A^arofaAqN; (O, K;) and the pl. of rifoqapN is rifaqN: (Msb:) or rufoqapN is a quasi-pl. n. of ↓ rafiyqN, or syn. with this last used in a pl. sense; and its pl. is rifaqN and rufaqN and [quasi-pl. n.] ↓ rafaqN. (K.) [Golius explains the first and second and third, as on the authority of the KL, by the words “ consortium, societas: ” but in my copy of the KL, I find only the first and second; and these are explained only by the words Grwh hmrAhAn, agreeably with the renderings which I have given above.] ― -b2- The pl. rifaAqN also signifies Camels upon which people have gone forth to purvey for themselves wheat, or corn, or other provisions from the towns or villages; each, or every, company being termed a rufoqap. (TA voce raTaAnapN.)
rifoqapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
rafiqapN * as an epithet applied to a she-camel: see A^arofaqu.

rifaAqN * The cord that is used for the purpose described in the explanation of rafaqa Aln~aAqapa, (S, O, K,) or in the explanation of rafaqa AlbaEiyra. (JK.) [See 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.] So in the saying of Bishr, (S,) i. e. of Bishr Ibn-Abee- Házim, (O,)
faA_in~iY waAl$~akaApa mina Ali laA^oYK
ka*aAti AlDigoni tamo$iY fiY Alr~ifaAqi
(O,) or waA=la laAmK, (S, O,) accord. to different readings: (O:) [i. e. And verily I, with respect to the fault, or the complaint, of the family of Läy, or and the family of Lám, am like her that yearns towards, or longs for, her home, or accustomed place, going along with her arm and shank in the rfAq]: he says, I am withheld from satirizing them, like as this she-camel that yearns towards, or longs for, her home, or accustomed place, is bound and withheld; but if they do not what I approve, I will let loose my tongue with satirizing them. (O.) ― -b2- Also A thing in form like a finger, made for the teat of a she-camel when she is affected with the [disorder termed] rafaq: it is stuffed with dates, and then the SiraAr [q. v.] is bound over it, in order that it [the teat] may be cured. (JK.)

rafiyqN *
Gentle, soft, tender, gracious, courteous, or civil; (JK, Msb;) as also ↓ raAfiqN. (JK.) ― -b2- And hence, (Msb,) Gentle, delicate, nice, neat, or skilful, in work or operation; contr. of A^axoraqu. (S, O, Msb, K.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] h`*aA AlA^amoru rafiyqN bika and bika ↓ raAfiqN and raAfiqN Ealayoka (assumed tropical:) [This affair, or thing, is easy, or convenient, to thee: see A^arofaqu]. (O.) -A2- Also A companion (JK, S, O, Msb, K) and companions (JK, S, O, K) in travel-ling, or journeying, and afterwards: (Kh, S, O, Msb, K:) used as sing. and pl., (JK, S, O, K,) like SadiyqN (S, O) and xaliyTN: (O:) pl. rufaqaA='u; (JK, S, O, K;) with which ↓ rufaAqapN is syn., as in the phrase fitoyapN rufaAqapN [Young men companions &c.]. (JK.) See also rufoqapN. It is said in the Kur [iv. 71], waHasuna A^uwlaAy^ika rafiyqFA, (JK, S, O,) meaning rufaqaA='a [i. e. And good, or very good, will be those as companions after the journey of life] in Paradise! (JK.) And Mohammad is related by 'Áïsheh to have said, [just before his death,] when he had been given his choice between continuance in the present world and what was with God, and had chosen the latter, bali Alr~afiyqa AlA^aEolaY mina Aljan~api [Nay, rather, the highest companions of Paradise]; meaning, I desire the company, or congregation, of the prophets. (O.)
rufaAqapN * : see rufoqapN and rafiyqN.
raAfiqN * : see rafiyqN, in two places.
raAfiqapN * : see rifoqN.

A^arofaqu * [compar. and superl. of rafiyqN; meaning More, and most, gentle, &c.] ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, h`*aA AlA^amoru A^arofaqu bika [and Ealayoka] (assumed tropical:) This affair, or thing, is more, or most, easy, or convenient, to thee. (TA in art. Ewd.) [See also an instance voce maHoniyapN (in art. Hnw), last sentence.] -A2- Also, applied to a camel, Having the elbow (Almirofaq) distorted from the side: (JK, S, O, K:) so says Lth: (O:) and so the fem. rafoqaA='u, applied to a she-camel: (JK, S:) but Az says that the epithet preserved by him in his memory as heard from
the Arabs applied to a camel is A^adofaqu, with dAl. (O.) ― -b2- Accord. to As, (O,) rafoqaA='u applied to a she-camel signifies Having the orifice of her teat stopped up; (O, K;) and so ↓ rafiqapN: (K:) the latter is said by Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh to signify, so applied, having the orifices of her teats stopped up. (O.)
marofaqN * : see mirofaqN, in two places.
marofiqN * : see what next follows, in three places.

mirofaqN * and ↓ marofiqN inf. ns. of rafaqa, (AZ, O, K,) of which ↓ marofaqN also is an inf. n. (O, K.) ― -b2- Also A thing by which one profits, or gains advantage or benefit. (S, O, Msb, K.) It is said in the Kur [xviii. 15], wayuhay~iy^u lakumo mino A^amorikumo mirofaqFA or ↓ marofiqFA, accord. to different readers, [i. e. And He will prepare for you a condition of your case by which ye shall profit], but no one reads ↓ marofaqFA, (S, O,) which, however, is allowable, meaning ↓ rifoqFA. (S. [See rifoqN, last sentence.]) The pl. is maraAfiqu. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence,] maraAfiqu Ald~aAri Such appertenances [or conveniences] of the house as the privy and the kitchen and the like: (Mgh, Msb:) or the sinks, and the like, of the house: (S, O, K:) and particularly privies: (O:) when used in these senses, the sing. is mirofaqN only, with kesr to the m and fet-h to the f, (Mgh, Msb,) likened to the noun signifying an instrument. (Msb.) [See also Hay~izN, in art. Hwz.] ― -b4- And from the same words in the sense expl. in the second sentence above, (Msb,) mirofaqN and ↓ marofiqN signify also The elbow, or elbow-joint; the place where the *iraAE joins upon the EaDud; (S, O, K;) [in other words,] the place where the EaDud is connected with the saAEid; (Mgh;) the mrfq of a man: (Msb:) [and in like manner in a beast, the elbow, or elbowjoint, as in the JK, S, O, and K, voce A^arofaqu; and in countless other instances: but in the K voce rukobapN (q. v.), it seems to be applied to the knee of a beast:] pl. as above. (Msb.)

mirofaqapN *
A pillow (S, O, Mgh, K) upon which one leans [with the elbow]: from mirofaqN in the sense explained in the last sentence of the next preceding paragraph. (Mgh.)
$aApN muraf~aqapN * A sheep, or goat, having the fore legs white to the elbows. (O, K.)

mirofaAqN * A camel whose elbow hurts (yuSiybu) his side. (O, K.) ― -b2- And A she-camel that is hurt by the SiraAr [q. v.] when her udder is bound therewith, and from whom blood issues (JK, O, K) when she is loosed [therefrom] (A_i*aA Hul~ato), (JK,) or when she is milked (A*A Hulibato). (O, K.)
marofuwqN * A camel having a complaint of his mirofaq [or elbow]. (IDrd, O, K.)

murotafaqN *
A place, or thing, upon which one leans [properly with the mirofaq, or elbow]. (Bd in xviii. 28 and 30.)

murotafiqN *
Leaning upon his elbow. (S, O.) -A2- Also Full, standing, and continuing, or remaining: (O, K:) or nearly full: so explained by IAar as occurring in the following verse of 'Obeyd Ibn-El-Abras, (O,) describing rain that had filled the low tracts of ground: (TA in art. SwH:)
faA^aSobaHa Alr~awoDu waAlqiyEaAnu mumoriEapF
mino bayoni murotafiqK minohaA wamunoSaAHi
[And the meadows, and the plain, or soft, low tracts, became abundant with herbage, partly by what was full, &c., in consequence thereof, and partly by what was flowing, running upon the surface of the ground]: (O:) or, as some relate it, mutoraEapF [i. e. “ filled ”]; and murotatiqK, which means herbage “ of which the blossoms have not yet come forth from their calyxes; ” and munoSaAH [accord. to this reading] meaning herbage “ of which the blossoms have appeared: ” (TA in art. SwH:) [or, accord. to the reading murotatiqK, the meaning may be, “ partly such as were compact thereof, ” i. e. of the meadows &c., “ and partly such as were cracked ” by the heat and drought:] another reading is
mino bayoni murotafiqK minohaA wamino TaAHiY
mn TAHY meaning “ of what was flowing and going away. ” (TA ubi suprà.) [Nearly the whole of this art. is wanting in the copies of the TA to which I have had access.]

1 rafila * , (S, M, K,) aor.
rafala , (K,) inf. n. rafalN; (S, M;) and rafala, aor.
rafula , (M, K,) inf. n. rafolN; (M;) He was awkward (S, M, K,) in his manner of wearing his clothes, (S,) or with his clothes [when walking &c. (see rafilN)], and in every work. (M, K.) ― -b2- And rafala, (M, K,) or rafala fiY viyaAbihi, (S, TA,) aor.
rafula , (S, M,) inf. n. rafolN (Lth, T, M, K) and rufuwlN (T, TA) and rafalaAnN; (M, K;) and ↓ Arfl; (S, M, K;) He dragged his skirt, and kicked it with his foot: (Lth, T:) or he made his clothes long, and dragged them, walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side: (S:) or he dragged his skirt, and walked in the manner described above: or he moved his arm up and down [in walking]: (M, K:) and fiY viyaAbihi ↓ trf~l signifies the same as rafala and Arfl: (TA:) or ↓ A_irofaAlN [inf. n. of 4] signifies a man's having a long garment, such as a skirt and a jub~ap: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, T in art. *yl:) and one says, fiY mi$oyatihaA xroqFA ↓ tataraf~alu [She drags her skirt, &c., in her gait, by reason of awkwardness]. (S.) tarofulu AlmaraAfilaA, a phrase used by Ru-beh, [↓ maraAfilu being app. pl. of marofalN, a regular inf. n. of rafala,] means She walks with every sort of rafol or rufuwl [i. e. dragging of the skirt, &c.]. (Lth, T accord. to different copies.) And ↓ tarofala, inf. n. tarofalapN, He walked with an inclining of his body from side to side (tabaxotara) by reason of pride (kiborFA), or by reason of old age (kibarFA): (K, accord. to different copies:) the t is augmentative. (TA.) -A2- See also the next paragraph, last sentence, in two places.

2 tarofiylN * The making a garment ample, or long towards the ground: the letting it down, or making it to hang down: (TA:) [and so ↓ A_irofaAlN:] you say, viyaAbahu ↓ Arfl, (Sh, T,) or vawobahu, (M,) or rifolahu, (K, TA, in the CK rafilahu,) He let down, or made to hang down, his garments, or his garment, or his skirt. (Sh, T, M, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) rf~lhu, (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M,) inf. n. as above, (Sh, T, S, M, K,) (tropical:) He magnified him, or honoured him: (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K:) he made him a king, (A 'Obeyd, T, M, K,) and a lord, or chief, (Sh, T, M, K,) and a commander, and a judge: (TA:) [like raf~adahu:] and he rendered him submissive; made him to submit; or brought him under, or into, subjection: (M, K:) thus it has two contr. meanings; (K;) [like tar~afahu;] for when a man is made judge in an affair, it is as though he were subjected to service therein. (TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
A_i*aA naHonu raf~alonaA A@moraA^F saAda qawomahu
waA_ino lamo yakuno mino qaboli *`lika yu*okaru
(assumed tropical:) [When we magnify a man, or make a man a king, &c., he becomes lord, or chief, of his people, though he have been before that not mentioned]. (T, S, M.) And you say, ruf~ila fulaAnN (assumed tropical:) Such a one was made a lord, or chief, over his people. (Sh, T.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) He increased, or exceeded, to him that over which he had authority to judge, or to decide. (TA.) ― -b4- And tarofiylN also signifies (tropical:) The leaving a well for its water to collect in it; (S, O, K;) and so ↓ rafolN: (O, K:) you say, rf~l Alr~aky~ap (tropical:) He left the well for its water to collect in it; (Ks, T, M;) as also ↓ rafalahaA, aor.
rafula , inf. n. rafolN. (O.)
4 Arfl * , and its inf. n. A_irofaAlN: see 1, in two places: -A2- and see also 2, in two places.

5 taraf~ala see 1, in two places. ― -b2- trf~l also signifies (tropical:) He was, or became, or was made, a lord, or chief. (Sh, T, TA.) Hence, in a trad. of Wáïl Ibn-Hojr, yataraf~alu EalaY AlA^aqowaAli Hayovu kaAnuwA mino A^aholi HaDoramawota (tropical:) [He is, or will be, &c., a lord, or chief, over the subordinate kings, wherever they are, of the people of Hadramowt]. (T, * TA.)
Q. Q. 1 tarofala * , inf. n. tarofalapN: see 1.

rifolN * , (IDrd, O, K, TA,) or, as in some copies of the Jm, ↓ rifal~N, (O, TA,) or ↓ rafalN, (accord. to a copy of the M,) or ↓ rafilN, (accord. to the CK,) [in the K said to be with kesr, which, accord. to a rule observed in that work, indicates that it is rifolN,] The skirt, or lower extremity, of a garment. (M, O, K.) You say, A^arofala rifolahu [explained above: see 2]. (K.) And qamiySN saAbigu Alr~ifoli, i. e. [A shirt ample, or long,] in the skirt. (TA.)

rafalN * (tropical:) The water that collects after drawing, (jam~ap, thus accord. to the T and O and some copies of the K, [and this is said in the TA to be the right explanation,]) or the black mud, or black fetid mud, (HamoA^ap, thus accord. to other copies of the K, or mukolap [which has the same or
a similar meaning], thus accord. to the M and A and L,) of a well. (T, M, O, A, L, K.) -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph. -A3- rafalo rafalo A call to the ewe, to be milked. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

rafilN *
Awkward (S, M, K) in his manner of wearing his clothes, (S,) or with his clothes [when walking &c.], and in every work; as also ↓ A^arofalu; fem. [of the latter] ↓ rafolaA='u. (M, K.) And rafilapN (Lth, T, M, K, TA) and ↓ raAfilapN (Lth, T, TA) A woman who drags her skirt (Lth, T, M, K, TA) well, or beautifully, (M, K, TA,) when she walks, and who walks with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: (Lth, T, TA:) or the former signifies a woman who drags her skirt (tataraf~alu), in her gait, by reason of awkwardness: (S, TA:) and ↓ rafolA='u, a woman who does not walk well (ADk, T, S, M, K) in her clothes, (ADk, T, S, M,) dragging her garment, (M,) or dragging her skirt: (K:) and ↓ raAfilN, a man making his clothes long, and dragging them, walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side; (S;) in which sense rafilapN may be well used as an epithet applied to a woman: (Lth, T:) or ↓ raAfilN (TA) and ↓ tarofiylN, (Seer, M, K, TA,) in which latter the t is augmentative, (TA,) signify a man who drags his skirt, and walks in the manner last described above; or who moves his arm up and down in walking. (Seer, M, K, TA.) ― -b2- Also, i. e. rafilN, Foolish; stupid; or unsound, or deficient, in intellect, or understanding. (S.) ― -b3- And rafilapN, A foul, or an unseemly, or ugly, woman; (M, K;) as also ↓ rifal~apN, (M,) or ↓ rifilapN, with two kesrehs: (K:) and the same epithets are applied likewise in this sense to a man. (M.) -A2- See also rifolN.
rifilapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, near the end.

rifal~N *
Long in the tail; (Lth, T, S, M, K;) applied to a garment: (S:) or, thus applied, wide, or ample: (M, K:) in the former sense, applied to a horse, (Lth, As, T, M,) and to a bull, (Lth, T,) and to a camel, (Lth, T, S, M,) and to a mountaingoat; (M;) and rafan~N signifies the same: (Lth, As, M:) and applied to a horse as meaning also (M) having much flesh; (M, K;) and so rifan~N: (M:) and to a camel as meaning also wide in the skin: (Lth, T, S, M, K:) and, applied to hair, long; (M;) [or] so ↓ rafaAlN, like saHaAbN; (K;) or ↓ rufaAlN, or ↓ rifaAlN; (so accord. to different copies of the T;) and so ↓ rafaAlN applied to a garment. (TA.) Also A man having a long skirt. (Ham p. 386.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Eayo$N rifal~N, (TA,) or maEiy$apN rifal~apN, (S, M, in one copy of the S rafilapN,) (tropical:) Ample means of subsistence. (S, M, TA.) -A2- See also rifolN. -A3- And see rafilN.
rafaAlN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
rufaAlN * : see rifalN.
rifaAlN * : see rifal~N. -A2- rifaAlu Alt~ayosi A thing that is put before the penis of the goat, in order that he may not copulate. (IDrd, M, K.)
raAfilN * ; and its fem., with p: see rafilN, in three places.
A^arofalu * ; and its fem., rafolaA='u: see rafilN, in three places.
tarofiylN * : see rafilN.
A_izaArN murofalN * [A waist-wrapper] made to hang down. (Sh, T.) [Hence, perhaps, what next follows.]

mrflp * [written without any syll. signs, app. either murofalapN or muraf~alapN, an epithet used as a subst., or converted into a subst. by the addition of p,] A long [dress or garment such as is called] Hul~ap, in which one drags his skirt, and walks with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait (yurofalu fiyhaA). (TA.)
muraf~alapN * A she-camel having her udder bound with a piece of rag, which is made to hang down over her teats so as to cover them. (M, O, L, K.) ― -b2- [See also the next preceding paragraph.]

mirofaAlN * , applied to a woman, means kaviyrapu Alr~ufuwli fiY vawobihaA [i. e. Who drags her skirt, &c., much]: (Lth, T:) [and in like manner,] applied to a man, (TA,) kavyru Alr~afalaAni [which means the same: see 1]. (M, K, TA.)
maraAfilu * [app. pl. of marofalN, an inf. n. of rafala]: see 1.

1 rafuha Eayo$uhu * , (JK, K,) or AlEayo$u, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. rafaAhapN and rafaAhiyapN (JK, Mgh, Msb, K *) and rufohapN, (JK,) His life, or the life, was, or became, ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, (JK, Mgh, Msb, K,) and easy, pleasant, soft, or delicate. (JK, * Msb, K.) [See also rafaAhapN, below.] -A2- rafaha, aor.
rafaha , inf. n. rufuwhN (JK, Msb, K) and rafohN (Msb, K) and rifohN, (K,) [or this last is perhaps a simple subst.,] said of a man, He led [a plentiful, and] an easy, a pleasant, a soft, or a delicate, life; (K;) he found, or experienced, [or enjoyed, (see the part. n. raAfihN, below,)] an easy, a pleasant, a soft, or a delicate, life, with ampleness of the means of subsistence; and ↓ trf~h is [syn. therewith, its part. n. mutaraf~ihN being syn. with raAfihN, and the verb itself being] quasipass. of raf~aha: (Msb:) or he found, or experienced, rest, or ease, after fatigue. (JK.) [See also 4.] ― -b2- rafahati AlA_ibilu, (S, Mgh, K,) aor.
rafaha , (S, Mgh,) inf. n. rafohN and rufuwhN, (S, [and it is implied in the K that rifohN also is an inf. n. of the verb thus used, but it is a simple subst. accord. to the S,]) The camels came to the water to drink (S, Mgh, K) every day, (S,) when they would. (S, Mgh, K.) [See rifohN, below.] -A3- A^amaA tarofahu fulaAnFA Hast thou not, or wherefore wilt thou not have, mercy, or pity, or compassion, on such a one? (TA. [The meaning is there only indicated by the context.])

2 rf~h * , inf. n. tarofiyhN: see 4, in five places. ― -b2- rf~h nafosahu, inf. n. as above, He rested himself; made himself to be at rest or at ease; or gave himself rest. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b3- rf~h Eanohu, (JK, S, Mgh, K,) or Ealayohi, (so accord. to one copy of the S, [both correct, but the former the more common,]) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He made his circumstances ample and easy; eased him, or relieved him; and granted him a delay; (JK, * S, * Mgh, K; *) namely, his debtor; (S, Mgh;) or one who was in straitness, or distress: (TA:) and he behaved, or acted, gently, softly, tenderly, graciously, or courteously, with him: (JK, TA: *) and raf~iho EalaY~a Grant thou to me a delay: it is from rifohN as used in relation to camels. (Mgh.) And ruf~iha Eanohu Alt~aEabu Fatigue was removed from him, or made to quit him. (TA.)

4 Arfh *
He found, or experienced, rest, or ease, (K,) or he remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, and found, or experienced, rest, or ease, (IAar, TA,) EinodinaA at our abode; as also ↓ rf~h, inf. n. tarofiyhN; (IAar, TA;) and ↓ Astrfh. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- He kept continually, or constantly, to the eating of dainty food, (K, TA,) and indulged himself largely in eating and drinking: and this is said to be meant in a trad. in which AlA_irofaAh is forbidden; because it is one of the practices of the foreigners and of worldly people. (TA.) ― -b3- He anointed himself, (JK, S, K,) and combed, or anointed and combed, his hair, (S,) every day: (JK, S, K:) and this also is said to be meant in the trad. above mentioned: (JK, S, TA:) or by AlArfAh in that trad. is meant [the indulging in] ease and plenty. (JK.) ― -b4- Arfhu AlmaAlu The cattle remained near to the water (K, TA) in the water-ing-trough or tank, pasturing there upon the plants, or trees, called HamoD. (TA.) ― -b5- And ArfhwA Their camels, (JK,) or their cattle, (K,) came to the water to drink (JK, K) every day, (JK,) or when they would. (K.) -A2- A^arofahahumo He (God) made them to have an easy, a pleasant, a soft, or a delicate, and a plentiful, life; as also ↓ raf~ahahumo, inf. n. tarofiyhN: (K, TA:) and A^arofahotuhu and ↓ raf~ahotuhu I made him to find, or experience, [or enjoy, (see 1,)] an easy, a pleasant, a soft, or a delicate, life, with ampleness of the means of subsistence. (Msb.) ― -b2- And Arfh AlA_ibila; (S, K;) and ↓ rf~hhA, (K,) and EanohaA ↓ rf~h, inf. n. as above; (TA;) He made the camels to come to the water to drink (S, K, TA) every day, (S, TA,) when they would. (S, K, TA.)
5 taraf~aha see 1.
10 A_isotarofaha see 4.

rifohN * [said in the K to be an inf. n. of rafaha said of a man, and app. of rafahat said of camels: or it is] a subst. from rafahat said of camels; (S;) and [thus] signifies The coming of camels to the water to drink (JK, S, * Mgh) every day, (JK, S, *) when they will: (S, * Mgh:) or the shortest and quickest of the times of coming to water. (TA.) [See also vilovN, and EurayojaA='u.] Lebeed uses it metaphorically in relation to palm-trees growing over water, saying,
ya$orabona rifohFA EiraAkFA gayora SaAdiyapK
fakul~uhaA kaAriEN fiY AlmaA='i mugotamiru
[(tropical:) They drink every day, together, not thirsting; and every one of them is sipping the water, dipping therein]. (TA.) -A2- Also Small, or young, palm-trees. (JK, K, TA. [By Golius and Freytag written, in this sense, rifahN.])

rufahN *
i. q. tibonN [i. e. Straw; or straw that has been trodden, or thrashed, and cut: by some written ruf~apN; and by some, rufatN]: (Kr, S, K:) whence the prov., A^agonaY mina Alt~ufahi Eani Alr~ufahi [More free from want than the badger is from the want of straw]; Alt~ufahu meaning the beast of prey called EanaAqu AlA^aroDi; because it does not feed upon straw: (S:) [by some written Alt~uf~ahu; and by some, Alt~ufapu; and by some, Alt~uf~apu:] accord. to some, the former word is with p; and Alr~ufarufatN occurs as its pl. in a verse cited by IF: accord to ISk, the two words are correctly without teshdeed, and with the radical h. (TA in art. tfh.) [See also rufatN, in art. rft.]

rafohapN *
Pity, compassion, or mercy. (AHeyth, K.) Thus expl. as used in the saying, A_i*aA saqaTati AlT~arofaho qal~ato fiY AlA^aroDi Alr~afohah. (TA. [But AlT~arofah is here an evident mistranscription for AlS~arofah, the name of the Twelfth Mansion of the Moon: the meaning is, When AlSrfh sets aurorally, pity becomes little in the earth; because then the cold ends: see art. Srf.])
rafohaAnu * : see raAfihN, in two places.
rufahoniyapN * : see rafaAhapN.
rafiyhN * : see raAfihN, in two places.

rafaAhapN * and ↓ rafaAhiyapN, (S, Msb, K, [both expressly shown in the JK and Mgh and Msb to be inf. ns.,]) like rafaAgapN and rafaAgiyapN, (TA,) and ↓ rufahoniyapN, (S, K,) like rufagoniyapN, (TA,) the last rendered quasi-coordinate to the quinqueliteral-radical class [partly] by means of A in its latter part, changed into Y because of the kesreh before it, (S, [but mentioned also in a separate art., as well as here, in the S and K,]) A state of life ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, (S, Msb, K,) and easy, pleasant, soft, or delicate: (Msb, K:) so in the saying, huwa fiY rafaAhapK mina AlEayo$i (S) and rafaAhiyapK (S, Msb) and rufahoniyapK (S) He is in a state of life ample in its means &c. (S, Msb.)
rafaAhiyapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

raAfihN * , applied to life, as meaning Ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, (Mgh,) [and easy, pleasant, soft, or delicate; like ↓ rafiyhN: ― -b2- and] applied to a man, (JK, S, Msb,) In a state of ease, and ampleness of the means or circumstances of life; (JK, S;) in a state of rest, or ease; (Mgh, Msb, K;) enjoying an easy, a pleasant, a soft, or a delicate, life; (Msb, K;) as also ↓ rafiyhN (K [though this seems to be applied more properly to life itself, being from rafuha,]) and ↓ rafohaAnu (K) and ↓ mutaraf~ihN: (Mgh, Msb, K:) or ↓ rafohaAnu signifies in a state of rest, or ease, after fatigue; and its pl. is rifaAhN and rafaAhaY. (JK.) ― -b3- A_ibilN rawaAfihu, [the latter word being pl. of raAfihapN,] Camels coming to the water to drink (JK, K) every day, (JK,) when they will. (K.) ― -b4- bayoniY wabayonaka layolapN raAfihapN, (S, Msb, K,) and valaAvu layaAlK rawaAfihu, (JK, S, K, *) [Between me and thee is a night, and are three nights,] of gentle, or easy, journeying. (JK, S, Msb, K.) ― -b5- huwa raAfihN bihi He is affected with mercy, pity, or compassion, for him. (Aboo-Leylà, K.)
huwa A^arofahu minohu * means A^akovaru rafohFA [i. e. He is one who leads, or enjoys, a more easy, pleasant, soft, or delicate, and plentiful, life than he]. (TA.)
mutaraf~ihN * : see raAfihN.

1 rafawotu Alv~awoba * , (S, M, Msb,) third pers. rafaA, (K,) aor. A^arofuwhu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rafowN; (S, M, Msb;) and, in the dial. of Benoo-Kaab, rafayotuhu, aor. A^arofiyhi, inf. n. rafoYN; (Msb;) but this latter is strange; (TA in art. rfA^;) I repaired, or mended, the garment, (Msb, K, TA,) [where it was rent,] drawing parts thereof together; (TA;) [or rather, as is well known, I darned it; for] rafowN is the finest, or most delicate, kind of sewing; the weaving [over] a rent, or hole, in a garment, so that it appears as though there were in it no rent, or hole: (Har p. 91:) and rafaA^utuhu signifies the same: (S, M, Msb:) IAar and AZ say that it is with '; but the latter says that the ' is [sometimes] changed into w, so that one says rafawotu: accord. to ISk, [but this is at variance with what follows,] the verbs with and without ' have different meanings; for one says, rafaA^a Alv~awoba, and rafawotu Alr~ajula. (TA.) ― -b2- rafawotu Alr~ajula, (ISk, S, M,) third pers. rafaA, (K,) [aor. and inf. n. as above,] (tropical:) I appeased, or quieted, or calmed, the man; (ISk, M, TA;) as also rafaA^otuhu; (M and K in art. rfA^;) [i. e.] I quieted the man's fear; (S, K, TA;) did away with his fear, like as one does away with a rent, or hole, by Alr~afow [i. e. darning]. (TA.) ― -b3- And rafaA, aor. yarofuw, (tropical:) He married, or took a wife; (TA;) and rafaA^a is said to signify the same. (TA in art. rfA^.)

2 raf~ayotuhu * , inf. n. tarofiyapN, I said to him (i. e. to a man taking to himself a wife, S) biAlr~ifaA='i waAlbaniyna [expl. below, see 3]: (S, K:) and so raf~aA^otuhu. (T, S, M, K; all in art. rfA^.)

3 yuraAfiyniY * means He agrees, or is of one mind or opinion, with me; [the inf. n.] muraAfaApN being syn. with Ait~ifaAqN, (S, TA,) or muwaAfaqapN, (AZ, M, TA,) as also rifaA='N, (AZ, TA,) this latter being thus made by AZ an inf. n. [like the former]: (TA:) [or] ↓ rifaA='N [is a simple subst., or is generally used as such, and] signifies close union, or coalescence; and concord, or agreement; (S, K, TA;) and good consociation: (TA:) and hence the saying, to one taking to himself a wife, (S, in the TA llmlk [to the king],) biAlr~ifaA='i waAlbaniyna [May it (the marriage) be with close union, &c., further expl. in art. rfA^]: (S, TA:) ISk says that it is originally with '; (TA;) but if you will, he says, the meaning may be, with tranquillity, or freedom from disturbance or agitation; from rafawotu Alr~ajula “ I appeased, or quieted, or calmed, the man. ” (S, TA.) ― -b2- muraAfaApN is also syn. with mudaAraApN: and with muHaAbaApN: as a dial. var. of muraAfaA^apN: [i. e., raAfaAhu signifies, like daAraAhu, He treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him; &c.: and he treated him in an easy and a gentle manner in selling; or abated to him the price, or payment:] and accord. to IAar, ↓ ArfAhu [also, like ArfA^hu,] is syn. with daAraAhu. (TA.)

4 A^arofayotu A_ilayohi *
I had recourse, or I betook myself, or repaired, to him, or it, for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging: (TA:) and I inclined to, or towards, him, or it: a dial. var. of A^arofaA^otu. (Fr, TA.) -A2- A^arofayotu Als~afiynapa I brought the ship near to the land; a dial. var. of A^arofaA^otu. (ISh, TA.) ― -b2- See also 3, last sentence.

6 taraAfawoA EalaY AlA^amori *
They agreed together to do the thing; a dial. var. of taraAfaw^uwA. (TA.)
rufapN * : pl. rufaAtN: see rufahN, in art. rfh.
rifaA='N * : see 3; and see also art. rfA^.

A^arofaY *
Having large and flabby ears: fem. rafowaA='u; (K, TA;) meaning, whose ears approach each other so that their extremities almost touch one another. (TA.)
A^urofiY~N * : see art. rfY.
1 rafabotu Alv~awoba * : see 1 in art. rfw.

A^urofiY~N *
Pure milk: (IAar, TA:) or milk of a gazelle: or pure and good milk: (M, K:) ISd says, it may be of the measure A^ufoEuwlN, or fuEoliY~N; or it may belong to art. rfw, because one says rafawotu, but not [to his knowledge] rafayotu. (TA.)

1 raq~a * , aor.
raqi3a , (S, Mgh, * Msb, K,) inf. n. riq~apN, (JK, S, Mgh, K, * TA,) It (a thing, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, TA) had the quality termed diq~apN; (K, TA; [in the CK, Alr~aq~apu is erroneously put for Ald~iq~apu;]) [i. e.] it was, or became, the contr. of galiyZN, (S, Msb, TA,) and of vaxiynN: (S, TA:) [or rather, properly, it is the contr. of vaxuna; i. e. it was, or became, thin as meaning of little thickness in comparison with its breadth and length together; little in extent, or depth, between its two opposite surfaces: thin, fine, delicate, flimsy, unsubstantial, or uncompact, in texture &c.; said of a garment and the like: shallow, or of little depth; said of water, and of sand, &c.: thin as meaning wanting in spissitude; said of mud &c.: attenuated: see riq~apN, below; and raqiyqN:] and ↓ Astrq [in like manner] signifies the contr. of AstglZ [and therefore contr. of galuZu; for these last two
verbs are syn.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raq~ato EiZaAmuhu, [inf. n. riq~apN, or raqaqN, or both, (and if so, the second pers. may be raqaqota and raqiqota, and the aor. yariq~u and yaraq~u,) (assumed tropical:) His bones became weak; or became thin, and consequently (assumed tropical:) weak; meaning] (assumed tropical:) he became aged: (JK:) or it is said of one who has become aged. (TA. [See riq~apN and raqaqN below; and see also raqiyqN.]) ― -b3- And raq~a, [inf. n. riq~apN, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, weak: and abject, mean, paltry, or contemptible: see raqiyqN: and see also 4:] his patience, or endurance, became weak, or weakened: (TA:) he was, or became, weak-hearted, and fearful; as also raq~a qalobuhu: (Mgh:) and affected with shame, shyness, or bashfulness.
