(K, TA.) ― -b4- And raq~a lahu, (Mgh, K, *) first pers. raqaqotu, aor.
raqi3a , inf. n. riq~apN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, [tender-hearted, (see raqiyqN and A^araq~u,)] merciful, compassionate, or pitiful, to him; (Mgh, K;) as also raq~a lahu qalobuhu: (TA:) and lahu ↓ trq~q signifies the same as raq~ lahu qalobuhu. (S, K.) ― -b5- [And raq~a kalaAmuhu (assumed tropical:) His speech was, or became, soft or tender, or easy and sweet, or elegant, graceful, or ornate: see raqiyqN, and see also 2. ― -b6- And raq~ Sawotuhu (assumed tropical:) His voice was, or became, slender, or soft, or gentle. ― -b7- And raq~ato HaAluhu (assumed tropical:) His state, or condition, was, or became, narrow in its circumstances, or evil: see riq~apN, below, and 4; and see also 4 in art. xf. ― -b8- And raq~a Eayo$uhu (assumed tropical:) His living, or sustenance, was, or became, scanty.] ― -b9- And raq~a Eadaduhu (tropical:) His years that he numbered were for the most part passed, so that the remainder was little (raqiyq) in his estimation. (IAar, TA.) -A2- raq~a, (Mgh, Msb,) aor.
raqi3a , (Msb,) inf. n. riq~N, (S, * Mgh, Msb, K,) He was, or became, a slave; (S, * Mgh, Msb, K; *) or he remained a slave. (Mgh.) -A3- raq~ahu and ↓ Arq~hu He made him a slave: (Msb:) or ↓ the latter signifies he kept him as a slave; (Mgh;) contr. of A^aEotaqapu; (S, Mgh;) as also ↓ Astrq~hu: (S:) or ↓ the second and ↓ third, he possessed him as a slave; (K;) and so raq~ahu; accord. to ISk and Az and others: (TA:) or ↓ Astrq~hu signifies he made him, or took him as, a slave; (Mgh;) or he brought him into a state of slavery. (TA.)

2 rq~qhu * , (S, K,) inf. n. taroqiyqN; (TA;) and ↓ Arq~hu, (S, K,) inf. n. A_iroqaAqN; (TA;) contr. of gal~aZahu; (K;) or He made it, or rendered it, raqiyq [i. e. thin, as meaning of little thickness in comparison with its breadth and length together; &c.: see 1, first sentence; and raqiyqN, below]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] taroqiyqu AlkalaAmi (assumed tropical:) The making speech to be [soft or tender, or easy and sweet, or] elegant, graceful, or ornate; the beautifying, or embellishing, and adorning, of speech. (S, TA.) And hence, (TA,) it is said in a prov., (S,) A^aEano SabuwHK turaq~iqu (S, K, TA) (tropical:) Dost thou allude (K, TA) gracefully, courteously, politely, or delicately, (TA,) to a morning-draught? (K, TA:) [the origin of which prov. was this:] a certain man named Jábán alighted by night at the abode of a people, and they entertained him, and gave him an evening-draught; and when he had finished it, he said, “ When ye shall have given me a morning draught, how shall I enter upon my way and prosecute the object of my want? ” whereupon the saying above was addressed to him: (K, * TA:) it is applied to him who makes an allusion to a thing, like this guest, who desired to oblige the people to give him the morning draught: and was said by Esh-Shaabee to one who spoke of kissing a woman when meaning thereby jimaAE. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] rq~q Sawotahu (K in art. Hzn) or ↓ Arqhu (S in that art.) (assumed tropical:) [He made his voice slender, or soft, or gentle]. ― -b4- taroqiyqN also signifies (assumed tropical:) [The pronouncing a word with the slender sound of the lengthened fet-h (like the sound of “ a” in our word “father ”), and with the ordinary sound of the letter l; both as in biAll~`hi and ll~`hi;] the contr. of tafoxiymN. (Kull p. 127.) ― -b5- rq~q Alma$oYa, said of a camel, (K, TA,) (tropical:) He went an easy pace: and ↓ trq~q, alone, signifies the same. (TA.) [See also R. Q. 2.] ― -b6- rq~q bayona Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) He created, or excited, disorder, disturbance, disagreement, or dissension, or he made, or did, mischief, between, or among, the people. (TA.)

4 Arq~ * , said of the white grape, (AHn, O, K,) It was, or became, thin in its skin and abundant in its juice: (AHn, TA:) or completely ripe. (O, K.) ― -b2- Said of a man, (tropical:) He was, or became, in a state, or condition, narrow in its circumstances, or evil; i. q. SaAra raqiyqa AlHaAli, (JK,) or saA='ato HaAluhu. (K, TA.) ― -b3- A^araq~ato bihimo A^axolaAquhumo (tropical:) Their natural dispositions were, or became, niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious. (TA.) -A2- Arqhu: see 2, in two places. ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence, in three places.
5 taraq~a3a see 1: ― -b2- and see also 2. -A2- taraq~aqatohu She (a girl) captivated his heart so that his patience, or endurance, became weak, or weakened. (TA.)

entryFree.key: laA tadoriY EalaY maA yataraAq~u harimuka

div2.entryFree: 6 laA tadoriY EalaY maA yataraAq~u harimuka * (assumed tropical:) Thou knowest not what thing thou wilt choose: (JK:) or to what state, or condition, thy mind will come at the last. (TA.) The origin of the word (ytrAq~) is unknown. (JK.) [See also art. hrm.]

10 A_isotaroqa3a see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] Astrq~ AlmaA='u The water [became shallow: and hence,] (tropical:) sank into, or disappeared in, the earth, except a little. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And Astrq~ All~ayolu (assumed tropical:) The night for the most part passed. (TA.) -A2- Astrq~hu: see 1, last sentence, in three places.

R. Q. 1 raqoraqahu * , (S, K,) inf. n. raqoraqapN, (TK,) He poured it forth in small quantity; namely, water &c.: (K:) or he made it to come and go; namely, water. (S.) ― -b2- rqrq Alv~ariyda biAls~amoni He poured a little clarified butter upon the broken bread; (K, TA;) i. e. made it savoury therewith: or, as some say, poured much thereof upon it. (TA.) ― -b3- rqrq Alv~awoba biAlT~iybi He made the perfume to run [to and fro (as is implied in the S)] upon the garment: (TA:) [or he poured and rubbed the perfume upon the garment.] El-Aashà says,
wataborudu baroda ridaA='i AlEaruwsi fiY AlS~ayofi raqoraqota fiyhi AlEabiyraA
[And she is cool, with the coolness of the wi$aAH (see ridaA=') of the bride, in summer, upon which thou hast poured and rubbed perfume mixed with saffron &c.]. (S, TA: in the latter, biAlS~ayofi.) ― -b4- rqrq Alxamora He mixed the wine. (TA.) ― -b5- rqrq Eayonahu He made his eye to shed tears. (TA.) ― -b6- It is said in a trad., tajiYo'u fitonapN faturaqoriqu baEoDuhaA baEoDFA, meaning [Sedition, or the like, will come, and] one act thereof will cause desire for another by its embellishment thereof, or investing it with charms. (TA.) ― -b7- [See also raqoraqapN, below.]

R. Q. 2 taraqoraqa *
It (water, &c.,) poured forth in small quantity. (TA.) ― -b2- He, or it, ran in an easy manner. (TA.) [See also 2, last sentence but one.] ― -b3- It (water, S, TA) was, or became, in a state of motion, or commotion; (K, TA;) in which sense, [meaning it flickered,] it is [also] said of the saraAb [or mirage]; (O, K; [see also another explanation below;]) [it went to and fro;] it came and went. (S, K, TA.) And in like manner, (S,) trqrq Ald~amoEu The tears went round about at the inner edge of the eyelid- (S, K.) And trqrqt Al$~amosu The sun appeared as though it were turning round (A'Obeyd, K, TA) and coming and going, by reason of its nearness to the horizon, and of vapours intervening between it and the eyes; which it does not when it is high. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b4- It (a thing) shone, or glistened; (JK, S, K;) as does the saraAb [or mirage]. (JK.) ― -b5- trqrqt Eayonuhu His eye shed tears. (TA.)

raq~N * : see raqiyqN; and ruq~N. -A2- Also, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ riq~N, (Msb, K,) but the latter is a rare dial. var. though some read thus in the Kur lii. 3, (Msb,) [Parchment; and vellum; so in the present day; or] skin, (Mgh, Msb,) or thin skin, (S, K,) upon which one writes: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or (so accord. to the Mgh, but in the K “ and ”) a white [i. e. blank] SaHiyfap [which means a paper and a piece of skin, but generally such as is written upon]: (JK, Mgh, K:) or metaphorically applied to (tropical:) a skin written upon: properly one upon which one writes: (Bd in lii. 3:) accord. to Fr, (assumed tropical:) the SaHaAy^if [i. e. papers, or pieces of skin, meaning records,] that will be produced to the sons of Adam on the day of resurrection; which indicates that such as is written is also thus termed: (Az, TA:) in the Kur lii. 3, [accord. to some,] applied to (assumed tropical:) the Book of the Law revealed to Moses: or the Kur-án. (Jel.) -A3- Also, (K,) or the former word [only], (JK, S, Msb,) The tortoise: (JK:) or a great tortoise: (S, K:) or the male tortoise: (Msb:) and the crocodile: (JK:) or, (K,) accord. to Ibráheem El-Harbee, (TA,) a certain aquatic reptile, (K, TA,) [app. the turtle, or sea-tortoise,] having four legs, and claws, or nails, and teeth in a head which it exposes and conceals, and which is killed for food: (TA:) pl. ruquwqN. (A'Obeyd, JK, S, Msb, K.)

riq~N * : see raq~N. [It is indicated in the K that it is syn. with the latter word in all of its (the latter's) senses: but I do not find it to be so in any other lexicon.] ― -b2- A thin thing. (S. [There expl. as signifying $aYo'N raqiyqN; but perhaps by this may be meant that it is an epithet syn. with raqiyqN, as it is said to be in the K.]) See raqiyqN. ― -b3- The leaves of trees: or the branches that are easy for the cattle [to eat]. (K.) ― -b4- And A certain thorny plant. (K.) ― -b5- See also raqaAqN. -A2- Also The state, or condition, of a slave; slavery; servitude; (JK, S, Msb, K;) and so ↓ riq~iy~apN. (KL.)

raq~apN *
Any land by the side of a valley, over which the water spreads in the days of the increase, and into which it then sinks, or disappears, (S, K,) and which therefore produces good herbage: (S:) pl. riqaAqN. (K.) ― -b2- See also raqaAqN.

riq~apN * [an inf. n. of raq~a in several senses, as shown above, in the first paragraph of this art.]: it is explained in the K as syn. with diq~apN: [see 1, first sentence:] but El-Munáwee says, in the “ Tow- keef, ” that the former is like the latter [as meaning Thinness], but that the latter is said with regard to the lateral parts of a thing, and the former with regard to the depth of a thing [or the extent between the two opposite surfaces thereof]: thus, in a material substance, such, for instance, as a garment, or piece of cloth, [&c.,] it is [thinness as meaning little thickness in comparison with the breadth and length together; littleness in extent, or depth, between the two opposite surfaces: fineness, delicateness, flimsiness, unsubstantialness, or uncompactness, in texture &c.:] the contr. of [vaxaAnapN and] SafaAqapN: (TA:) [in water, and sand, &c., shallowness, or littleness of depth: (see ruq~N:) in mud, and anything imperfectly liquid, thinness as meaning want of spissitude: an attenuated state or condition of anything.] ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Weakness; (Mgh;) as in the phrase riq~apu jaAnibK [weakness of resistance; similar to liynu jaAnibK; contr. of gilaZu jaAnibK]; (Ham p. 631;) [and in the phrase riq~apu diynK weakness of religion: (see raqiyqN:) also abjectness, meanness, paltriness, or contemptibleness: and weak-heartedness, and fearfulness: (see 1:)] and shame, shyness, or bashfulness. (K.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) [Tender-heartedness, (see raqiyqN and A^araq~u,)] mercy, compassion, or pity; (K;) and so riq~apu qalobK: (TA in art. Hn:) in the soul, it is the contr. of jafowapN and qasowapN. (ElMunáwee, TA.) ― -b4- [And (assumed tropical:) Softness or tenderness, or easiness and sweetness, or elegance, gracefulness, or ornateness, of speech: see raqiyqN, and see also 2. ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Slenderness, softness, or gentleness, of voice.] ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) Evilness [or narrowness of the circumstances] of state or condition: so in the saying, Eajibotu mino qil~api maAlihi wariq~api HaAlihi (assumed tropical:) [I wondered at the paucity of his property, and the evilness, or the narrowness of the circumstances, of his state or condition]. (TA.) ― -b7- [And (assumed tropical:) Scantiness of living or sustenance &c.] ― -b8- And riq~apu baTonK (assumed tropical:) [A looseness, or diarrhœa]. (TA in art. xlf.)

raqaqN * , an inf. n., (KL, [see 1,]) [Thinness, and consequently] (tropical:) weakness (JK, S, K, KL, TA) of the bones, (JK,) or in the bones, (TA,) or of the bone, (KL,) or as in the bone, (S,) and in a camel's foot: (TA:) [and] lightness in a horse's hoof. (AO, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Paucity: thus in the saying, fiY maAlihi raqaqN (tropical:) [In his property is paucity]: (JK, S, K, TA:) mentioned by Fr, (S,) or by A'Obeyd thus, but the saying mentioned by Fr is maA fiY maAlihi raq~qN (tropical:) There is not in his property paucity. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Scantiness (riq~ap) of food. (TA.) -A2- See also the next paragraph.

raqaAqN *
A [desert tract such as is called] SaHoraA=': (K:) or a wide, or spacious, SHrA=', of soft soil, beneath which is hardness: (TA:) or a level, (S, K, TA,) expanded, (TA,) tract of land, of soft soil, beneath which is hardness: (S, K, TA:) or a tract from which the water has sunk into the ground; as also ↓ ruqaAqN and ↓ raq~apN [q. v.]: or a soft and wide tract of land; (K, TA;) accord. to As, without sand; (TA;) as also ↓ riq~N and ↓ ruq~N and ↓ raqaqN; (K;) the last of which is a contraction of raqaAqN, used by Ru-beh, (S, TA,) by poetic license. (TA.) -A2- yawomN raqaAqN A hot day. (Fr, K.) [See also raqoraAqN.]

ruqaAqN * : see raqiyqN. ― -b2- Also, (JK, S, K,) as a subst., (Th, S,) or xubozN ruqaAqN, (Mgh, Msb,) Thin bread, (↓ xubozN raqiyqN, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) such as is [flat, or flattened, or] expanded: (TA:) n. un. ruqaAqapN, (Mgh, * Msb, K,) meaning a single thin, round cake of bread: (Mgh:) one should not say riqaAqapN, with kesr: (K:) the pl. of ruqaAqN accord. to the K is riqaAqN; but this is pl. of raqiyqN, like as kiraAmN is pl. of kariymN. (TA.) [See also muraq~aqN.] ― -b3- ma$aY ma$oyFA ruqaAqFA, said of a camel, means raq~aqa Alma$oYa, (K, TA,) i. e. (tropical:) He went an easy pace. (TA.) ― -b4- See also raqaAqN.

raqiyqN * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) fem. with p, (TA,) Having the quality termed diq~apN; (K, TA; [see 1, first sentence, respecting a mistranscription in the CK;]) as also ↓ ruqaAqN, (K,) of which the fem. is likewise with p; (TA;) and ↓ ruq~aAqN, (K,) like rum~aAnN; (TA;) [i. e.] contr. of galiyZN; (S, Msb, K, TA;) as also ↓ raq~N (K, TA) and ↓ riq~N: (K:) and contr. of vaxiynN: (S, TA:) [or rather this last is the proper explanation of raqiyqN, as well as of all the other epithets above mentioned; (see riq~apN;) i. e. thin as meaning having little thickness in comparison with its breadth and length together; having little extent, or depth, between its two opposite surfaces:] applied to bread that is [flat, flattened, or] expanded; such as is termed ruqaAqN, q. v.: (TA:) and to a garment, or piece of cloth, (Mgh, El-Munáwee, TA,) and the like, as meaning thin, fine, delicate, flimsy, unsubstantial, or uncompact, in texture &c.; contr. of SafiyqN; (El-Munáwee, TA;) as also ↓ ruqaAriqN: (TA:) and to water [as meaning shallow, or of little depth; and in like manner to sand]: see ruq~N: (IDrd, K, TA:) [thin as meaning wanting in spissitude; applied to mud &c.: attenuated:] pl. riqaAqN (TA) and A^ariq~apN. (JK.) [Hence,] Alr~aqiyqaAni The part between the xaASirap [or flank] and the rufog [or groin, on either side]: (AA, K:) and the pl. AlA^arq~apu the thin parts at the flanks of she-camels. (JK.) Also, the dual, AlrqyqAn, The HiDonaAni [or part between the armpit and the flank, on either side]. (K, TA. [In the CK AlxuSoyAni, q. v.]) And [The two veins called] the A^axodaEaAni [q. v.]. (K.) And, of the nose, The two sides: (K:) so says As: or the raqiyq of the nose is the thin and soft part of the side. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also Thin, or attenuated, and consequently (assumed tropical:) weak, in the bones: see raqaqN.] You say naAqapN raqiyqapN meaning (assumed tropical:) A she-camel whose marrow-bones have become weak and thin (DaEufato waraq~ato), and whose medullary canal is wide: pl. riqaAqN and raqaAy^iqu. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Weak: and abject, mean, paltry, or contemptible: applied to a man [&c.]. (TA.) And goats are called maAlN raqiyqN [Weak cattle] because they have not the endurance of sheep. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Weak-hearted. (Mgh.) And raqiyqu Alqalobi (assumed tropical:) Soft, or tender, of heart; contr. of qaAsiY Alqalobi. (El-Munáwee, TA.) ― -b5- [(assumed tropical:) Soft or tender, or easy and sweet, or elegant, graceful, or ornate, speech or language.] raqiyqu All~afoZi means [(assumed tropical:) Soft or tender, &c., of expression; applied to a man: and also soft or tender or] easy and sweet expression. (Har p. 8.) ― -b6- [(assumed tropical:) Slender, or soft, or gentle, applied to the voice.] ― -b7- rajulN raqiyqu AlHawaA$iY (assumed tropical:) A man gentle, gracious, or courteous, to his associates. (TA in art. H$Y.) And Eayo$N raqiyqu AlHawaA$iY (tropical:) A soft or delicate, pleasant, or plentiful and easy, life. (TA.) ― -b8- [Eayo$N raqiyqN may sometimes mean the same: but it commonly means (assumed tropical:) Scanty living or sustenance.] ― -b9- And fulaAnN raqiyqu Ald~iyni waAlHaAli (tropical:) [Such a one is weak in respect of religion, and narrow in the circumstances of, or evil in, his state or condition: see riq~apN]. (TA.) -A2- Also A slave, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) male and female; (Msb;) [but] the latter is [also] called raqiyqapN: (Lh, JK, TA:) and slaves; for it is used as sing. and pl.; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) like rafiyqN and xaliyTN: (TA:) accord. to Abu-l-'Abbás, so called because they are abject and submissive to their owner: (TA:) the pl. of raqiyqN is A^ariq~aA='u, (Msb, TA,) erroneously said in the K to be riqaAqN; (TA;) and that of raqiyqapN is raqaAy^iqu. (Lh, TA.) Using it as pl., you say, h`w^ulaA='i raqiyqiY [These are my slaves]. (Mgh.) And layosa fiY Alr~aqiyqi SadaqapN, i. e. [There is no poorrate] in the case of slaves used for service [as distinguished from those that are for sale]. (Msb.) [See also muraq~N.]
ruq~aY * [fem. of A^araq~u, q. v.].
ruq~aAqN * : see raqiyqN, first sentence.
riq~iy~apN * : see riq~N last sentence.
raqoraqapN * inf. n. of R. Q. 1. (TK.) ― -b2- Quickness in going and coming. (JK. [If an inf. n. in this sense, its verb is perhaps ruqoriqa.])

raqoraAqN * : see ruqaAriqN. ― -b2- Also, applied to a collection of clouds (saHaAbN), Going and coming. (TA.) See also the next paragraph. ― -b3- Applied to tears (damoEN), Going round about at the inner edge of the eyelid. (TA.) ― -b4- Anything shining, or glistening. (S, TA.) [Hence,] raqoraAqapN A woman (As, TA) as though water were running upon her face: (As, K, TA:) or raqoraAqapu Alba$arapi a girl whose external skin shines, or glistens, (Ham p. 622, and TA,) with whiteness: (TA:) pl. raqaAriqu, applied to soft, or tender, young women. (Ham ubi suprà.) [Hence also,] Alr~aqoraAqu is The name of a sword of Saad Ibn-'Obádeh El-Ansáree. (K.) ― -b5- Applied to a day, i. q. SaAr~N [app. a mistranscription for HaAr~N, i. e. Hot; like raqaAqN; as though shining, or glistening, with the sunlight]. (Fr, TA.) -A2- The taraqoruq [or commotion, or moving to and fro, or coming and going, whether real or apparent,] of the saraAb [or mirage], and of anything that shines, or glistens. (JK.)

ruqoruqaAnu Als~araAbi *
What is in a state of commotion, of the srAb [or mirage]: (IDrd, O, K:) and Als~araAbi ↓ raqoraAqu means [the same, or] what [moves to and fro, or undulates, or] comes and goes, of the srAb. (S.) And saraAbN ruqoruqaAnN [Mirage] that shines, or glistens. (TA.)

ruqaAriqN * : see raqiyqN, first sentence: and ruq~N. Also, applied to the saraAb [or mirage], (so in the CK,) or $araAb [i. e. wine or beverage], (so in copies of the K and in the O and TA,) [the former of which readings I think the more probably that which is correct, supposing the mirage to be likened to shallow water, which is thus termed, but Freytag prefers the latter reading,] i. q. raqiqu [app. as meaning Shallow, or perhaps thin]; (IDrd, O, K;) and so ↓ raqoraAqN. (IDrd, O.) ― -b2- And A sword having much maA=' [q. v.; i. e. much diversified with wavy marks, streaks, or grain; or having much lustre]: (IDrd, K, TA:) or shining, or glistening, much. (TA.)

A^araq~u * [compar. and superl. of raqiyqN; i. e. More, and most, thin, &c.]. ruq~aY, [its fem.,] applied to a piece of fat ($aHomapN), means mino A^araq~i Al$~aHomi; [i. e. Of the finest, or most delicate, sort of fat; (in the CK, erroneously, mino A^araq~a Al$~aHomu;)] (JK, K, TA;) such that no one comes upon it without his eating it. (JK, TA.) Hence the prov., wajadotaniY Al$~aHomapa Alr~uq~aY EalayohaA AlmaA^otaY [Thou hast found me to be the finest, or most delicate, piece of fat, to which there is a way of access]: said by a man to his companion when he esteems him weak. (JK, Sgh, K.) [See also $aHomuhu Alr~uk~aY, or $aHomapu Alr~uk~aY, in art. rk.] ― -b2- humo A^araq~u quluwbFA (assumed tropical:) They are more, or most, tender-hearted; and more, or most, inclined to accept admonition. (TA.)

maraq~N * sing. of maraAq~u, (Hr, K,) which signifies The thin, or delicate, and soft, or tender, parts of the belly: (S, K:) or the lower part thereof with what surrounds it, that is thin or delicate [in the skin]: (TA as from the S [but not in my copies of the latter]:) or the lower part of the belly, in the region of the SifaAq [q. v.], beneath the navel: (T, TA:) and metonymically applied in a trad. respecting ablution to the lower part of the belly of a man, together with the rufogaAni [or groins] and the genitals and the [other] places of which the skin is thin or delicate: and, of a camel, the A^arofaAg [or groins, and similar places of flexure or creasing]: (TA:) or (K) maraAq~u [thus applied] has no sing. (S, K.) Also The soft part of the nose, (JK, TA,) in the side thereof; [i. e. each of the alæ thereof;] as also ↓ musotaraq~N: (TA:) pl. as above. (JK.)

muraq~N * and ↓ maroquwqN, mentioned by ISk, (Msb, TA,) and by Az, and in the 'Ináyeh, therefore the disallowing of the latter by some is not to be regarded, (TA,) or the latter is for maroquwqN lahu meaning “ compassionated, ” (Mgh,) Made a slave: (Msb:) or possessed as a slave: (TA:) [or kept as a slave: (see 1, last sentence:)] fem. of the former with p, (Msb, TA,) and so of the latter. (Msb.) [See also raqiyqN, last signification.]
muriq~N * A horse thin in the hoof: (K:) or light therein. (AO, TA.)
muraq~aqN * A cake of bread [made thin and] wide, or broad. (TA.) [See also ruqaAqN.]

miroqaAqN *
A baker's rolling-pin; (MA;) the thing with which bread is made thin [and flat]; (K;) i. q. miHowarN [q. v.] and SawobajN. (TA, in art. lT.)
maroquwqN * : see muraq~N.
maAlN mutaraqorqN lils~imani * , or lilohuzaAli, (K, TA,) and liA^ano yaromida, (TA,) Cattle disposed, (K, TA,) and seen to be near, (TA,) to fatness, or to leanness, (K, TA,) and to perishing. (TA.)
musotaraq~N * : see maraq~N.

1 raqaA^a Ald~amoEu * , aor.
raqaAa , inf. n. raqo'N and ruquwo'N, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) The tears stopped, or ceased to flow; (Fs, JK, S, Mgh, Msb;) or dried up, (IDrst, Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee, K,) and stopped, or ceased: (K:) and in like manner, Ald~amu the blood: (JK, S, Mgh, Msb:) whence the phrase juroHaAni laA yaroqaA=ni Two wounds not ceasing to bleed. (Mgh.) And in like manner also, (JK,) raqaA^a AlEiroqu, (Fs, JK, K, TA, [not AlEaraqu, as supposed by Golius and Freytag,]) inf. ns. as above, (K,) The vein stopped or ceased [bleeding]; syn. AinoqaTaEa, (Fs, JK, TA,) and sakana, (TA,) or AirotafaEa; (K;) [in all of which explanations, damuhu is understood.] -A2- raqaA^a bayonahumo, (K, TA,) aor.
raqaAa , inf. n. raqo'N, (TA,) He effected a reconciliation, or made peace, between them; (K, TA;) like rafaA^a: (TA:) and [in like manner,] raqaA^a maA bayonahumo He arranged, or rightly disposed, or rectified, the matter, or affair, between them. (TA.) And the former phrase (rqA^bynhm) also signifies He created disorder or discord, or made mischief, between them: thus having two contr. meanings. (K.) -A3- raqaA^a fiY Ald~arajapi, (K,) and raqiy^a, also, mentioned by Ibn-Málik in the “ Káfiyeh, ” as a dial. var. of raqiYa, and both mentioned by IKtt, aor. of each
raqaAa , (TA,) He ascended the series of stairs, or the ladder: (K:) on the authority of Kr; but extr. [with respect to usage]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AiroqaA^o EalaY ZaloEika (a dial. var. of Airoqa TA) (assumed tropical:) Be gentle with thyself, and impose not upon thyself more than thou art able to perform: (JK, S, TA:) or abstain thou, for I know thine evil qualities or actions: (JK:) or, as some say, rectify thou, or rightly dispose, first thy case, or thine affair. (TA.)

4 ArqA^ damoEahu * , (S,) or Ald~amoEa, (K,) said of God, (S, K,) He caused his, or the, tears to stop, or cease, flowing; (S, TA;) or caused them to dry up, and to stop, or cease. (K.) The saying laA A^aroqaA^a A@ll~`hu damoEatahu is expl. by El-Mundhiree as meaning May God not remove, or do away with, (laA rafaEa,) his tear. (TA.) You say also, A^aroqaA^otu AlEiroqa [meaning I caused the vein to stop or cease bleeding: see 1]. (K, TA.)

raquwo'N *
A styptic; or a thing that is put upon blood for the purpose of stanching it, or stopping its flowing: (S, K:) a subst. from raqaA^a. (Msb.) Hence the saying, (Msb,) accord. to J, in a trad., but this is a mistake, for it is a saying of Aktham, (K,) or, accord. to the Expositions of the Fs, it was said by Keys Ibn-'Ásim El-Minkaree, (TA,) laA tasub~uwA AlA_ibila faA_in~a fiyhaA raquwo'a Ald~ami [Revile not ye camels, or it may perhaps mean hock not ye camels, but the former, I am told, is here meant, for in them is a preventive of the flowing of blood]; alluding to their being given in compensation for homicide, and thus preventing the shedding of blood. (S, Msb, K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rajulN raquwo'N bayona Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) A man who is a reconciler of the people; or a peacemaker between them: and [so] raquwo'N limaA bayonahumo, a phrase used by a poet. (TA.)
maroqaA^apN * and miroqaA^apN, (K,) the former a n. of place, the latter an instrumental n., and both correct, dial. vars. of maroqaApN and miroqaApN, (TA,) A series of stairs; or a ladder. (K, TA.)

1 raqabahu * , (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
raquba , (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. ↓ rqobapN, (JK, S, Mgh, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and [the inf. n. is] riqobaAnN (JK, S, K) and ruquwbN (S, K) and raquwbN and raqobapN and raqaAbapN, (K,) He looked, watched, or waited, for him, or it; he awaited, or expected, him, or it; (JK, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely, a man, (JK, A,) or a thing; (S;) as also ↓ trqbhu; (JK, * S, * A, Msb, K;) and ↓ Artqbhu; (S, * A, Msb, K;) and ↓ rAqbhu, (Mgh,) inf. n. muraAqabapN. (JK, S, A, Mgh, Msb.) You say, qaEada yaroqubu SaAHibahu He sat looking, watching, or waiting, for his com-
panion; as also ↓ yarotaqibuhu. (A.) And ka*aA ↓ A^ataraq~abu I look, &c., or am looking, &c., for such a thing. (A.) And yaroqubu mawota SaAHibihi [He looks, &c., for the death of his companion], (JK, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) and A^abiyhi liyarivahu [of his father, in order that he may inherit his property]: (A:) and ↓ turaAqibu mawota baEolihaA [She looks, &c., for the death of her husband], (K, TA,) liyamuwta fatarivahu [that he may die and she may inherit his property]. (TA.) And lamo taroqubo qawoliY, in the Kur [xx. 95], means And thou didst not wait, or hast not waited, for my saying [or what I should say]. (JK, TA.) ― -b2- And raqabahu, (Msb, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. ruquwbN, (Msb,) He guarded, kept, preserved, or took care of, it; was mindful, or regardful, of it; (Msb, K;) namely, a thing; (TA;) as also ↓ rAqbhu, inf. n. muraAqabapN and riqaAbN; (K;) [and ↓ trq~bhu.] You say also A^anaA A^aroqubu lakumu A@ll~ayolapa I will guard, or keep watch, for you to-night. (A.) ― -b3- And He regarded it; paid regard, or consideration, to it. (Bd and Jel in ix. 8.) You say, maA laka laA taroqubu *im~apa fulaAnK [What aileth thee that thou wilt not regard the inviolable right or due, &c., of such a one?]. (A. [This phrase is there mentioned as proper, not tropical.]) ― -b4- And (tropical:) He feared him; (A;) and so ↓ rAqbhu; (S, A, Mgh;) namely, God; (S, Mgh;) fiY A^amorihi [in his affair]; (S;) because he who fears looks for, or expects, punishment (yaroqubu AlEiqaAba): (A, Mgh:) or A@ll~`ha ↓ raAqabotu signifies (assumed tropical:) I feared the punishment of God. (Msb.) ↓ riqobapN [as inf. n. of raqaba app. used intransitively, or perhaps as a simple subst.,] signifies (assumed tropical:) The fearing, or being afraid [of a person or thing]: or fear: and also (assumed tropical:) the guarding oneself; being watchful, vigilant, or heedful: or self-guardance; &c. (K, TA. [See this word below.]) ― -b5- And you say, baAta yaroqubu Aln~ujuwma and ↓ yuraAqibuhaA, like yaroEaAhaA and yuraAEiyhaA (tropical:) [i. e. He passed the night watching the stars and waiting for the time when they would disappear]. (A, TA.) IAar cites the following saying of one describing a travelling-companion of his:
Aln~ajoma riqaAba AlHuwti ↓ yuraAqibu
meaning (tropical:) He watches (↓ yarotaqibu) the star, or asterism, with vehement desire for departure, like the [watching with] vehement desire of the fish for water. (TA.) [See also raqiybN.] -A2- raqaba fulaAnFA He put the rope [or a rope] upon the raqabap [i. e. neck, or base of the hinder part of the neck, &c.,] of such a one. (K.) -A3- raqiba, [aor.
raqaba ,] inf. n. raqabN, (TA,) or this is a simple subst., (K,) He was, or became, thick in the raqabap [or neck, &c.]. (TA.)
2 raq~abuwA liln~amiri * [They made a ruqobap (q. v.) for the leopard]. (JK.)
3 rAqb * , inf. n. muraAqabapN and riqaAbN: see 1, in seven places.

4 Arqbhu Ald~aAra * , (JK, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iroqaAbN, (Msb,) He assigned the house to him as a ↓ ruqobaY [q. v.], (JK, A, * Mgh, K, TA,) and to his offspring after him, in the manner of a waqof [so as to be unalienable]: (TA:) and ↓ Arqbhu Alr~uqobaY [he assigned to him the ruqobaY]: (Lh, K:) or Arqbhu daArFA, or A^aroDFA, means he gave to him a house, or land, on the condition that it should be the property of the survivor of them two; saying, If I die before thee, it shall be thine; and if thou die before me, it shall be mine: (S:) it is from AlmuraAqabapu; because each of the two persons looks for (yaroqubu) the death of the other; (S, Mgh, Msb;) in order that the property may be his: (Msb:) the subst. is ↓ ruqobaY [signifying, as a quasi-inf. n., the act explained above; and, as a subst. properly so termed, the thing given in the manner explained above: the verb being similar to A^aEomara; and the subst., in both of its applications, to EumoraY: see these two words]. (S, Msb.)
5 taraq~aba see 1, in three places.
8 A_irotaqaba see 1, in three places. ― -b2- You say also, Artqb AlmakaAna He ascended upon the place. (K, * TA.)

raqabN *
Thickness of the raqabap [or neck, &c.]: (S, K:) a subst. [as distinguished from an inf. n.: but see 1, last signification]. (K.) -A2- See also raqabapN.
ruqobapN * [A pit made for the purpose of catching the leopard]: it is, for the namir, like the zuboyap for the lion. (JK, K.)

riqobapN * : see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and again, in the latter half of the paragraph. [Hence,] wariva fulaAnN maAlFA Eano riqobapK (tropical:) Such a one inherited property from distant relations; not from his fathers. (K, TA.) And wariva Almajoda Eano riqobapK (tropical:) He inherited glory, or nobility, from distant relations: [it is said of a man] because it is feared that it will not be conceded to him on account of the obscurity of his lineage. (A.) El-Kumeyt says,
kaAna Als~adaY waAln~adaY majodFA wamakorumapF
tiloka AlmakaArimu lamo yuwravona Eino riqabi
(tropical:) [The night-dew and the day-dew that nourished his mental growth were nobility and generous disposition: those generous qualities were not inherited from distant relations: riqabN being pl. of riqobapN]: i. e., he inherited them from near ancestors. (TA.)

raqabapN * The neck: or the base of the hinder part thereof: (A, K:) or the hinder part of the base of the neck: (JK, S:) or the upper part of the neck: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] riqaAbN (JK, S, Msb, K) and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ raqabN (JK, S, K) and [pl. of pauc.] A^aroqubN (IAar, K) and raqabaAtN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- By a synecdoche, it is applied to (tropical:) The whole person of a human being: as in the saying, *anobuhu fiY raqabatihi (tropical:) [His sin, or crime, &c., be on his own neck; meaning, on himself]. (IAth, TA.) [Hence also] one says, h`*aA AlA^amoru fiY riqaAbikumo (tropical:) [This affair is upon your own selves], and fiY raqabatika (tropical:) [upon thine own self]. (A.) And A^aEotaqa A@ll~`hu raqabatahu (tropical:) [May God emancipate him]. (A.) And laka riqaAbuhun~a wamaA Ealayohin~a, in a trad., relating to camels, (tropical:) They themselves, and the burdens that are upon them, are thine. (TA.) And [hence], in another trad., lanaA riqaAbu AlA^aroDi (tropical:) To us belongs the land itself. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, i. e. by a synecdoche, (IAth, Mgh, TA,) (tropical:) A slave, (S, IAth, Mgh, K, TA,) male and female: (IAth, TA:) and a captive: (TA:) pl. riqaAbN. (Mgh.) You say, A^aEotaqa raqabapF (tropical:) He emancipated a slave, male or female. (IAth, TA.) And fak~a raqabapF (tropical:) He released a slave, or a captive. (TA.) Alr~iqaAb in the Kur ix. 60 means (tropical:) Those slaves who have contracted with their owners for their freedom. (T, Mgh, Msb, TA.) ― -b4- riqaAbu AlmazaAwidi (tropical:) [lit. The necks of provision-bags] is a nickname which was applied to the Eajam [or Persians, or foreigners in general]; because they were red; (S, A;) or because of the length of their necks; (El-Karáfee, TA in art. zwd;) or rather because of the thickness thereof, as though they were full. (MF in that art.)

ruqobaY * One's giving to another person a possession, (K,) such as a house, and land, and the like, (TA,) on the condition that, whichever of them shall die, the property shall revert to his [the giver's] heirs: (K:) so called because each of them looks for (yaroqubu) the death of the other: (TA:) or one's assigning it, (K,) namely, a dwelling, (TA,) to another person to inhabit, and, when he shall die, to another: (K:) or one's saying to a man, If thou die before me, my dwelling [or my land, which I give to thee,] shall revert to me; and if I die before thee, it shall be thine: so called for the reason above mentioned. (JK, KT. *) [It also signifies The property so given.] See 4, in three places. The act thus termed is forbidden in a trad., which pronounces that the property so given belongs to the giver's heirs. (JK.) Accord. to the Imám Aboo-Haneefeh, and [the Imám] Mohammad, it is not a hibap: accord. to Aboo-Yoosuf, it is a hibap like the EumoraY; but none of the lawyers of El- 'Irák says so: the Málikees absolutely forbid it. (TA.) You say, daAriY laka ruqobaY [My house is thine as a rqbY]: from AlmuraAqabapu; because each of the two persons looks for the death of the other. (A.)
raqabaAnN * : see A^aroqabu.
raqabaAniY~N * : see A^aroqabu.

raquwbN * (tropical:) A woman (S, A) of whom no offspring lives, or remains, (S, A, K,) and who looks for the death of her offspring, or of her husband [app. that she may have offspring by another]: (A:) and in like manner applied to a man: (S:) because he, or she, looks for the death of the child, in fear for it: (IAth, TA:) in like manner also a she-camel of which no offspring lives: (TA:) or he who has no offspring: (Msb:) or he who has not sent before him [to Paradise, by its dying in infancy,] any of his children: this, says A'Obeyd, is the meaning in the [classical] language of the Arabs; relating only to the loss of children: (TA:) he who has had no child die in infancy: or he who has had children and has died without sending before him any of them [to
Paradise, by its dying in infancy]. (So in the explanations of two trads., each commencing with Alr~aquwbu, in the “ Jámi' es-Sagheer ” of EsSuyootee.)
warivotuhu Eano Eam~apK raquwbi
is a prov., expl. by Meyd as meaning [I inherited it from a paternal aunt] of whom no offspring was living: such, he says, is most compassionate to the son of her brother. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A woman who looks for the death of her husband, (S, K,) in order that she may inherit his property. (S.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) An old and a poor man who is unable to earn for himself, and has none to earn for him: so called because he looks for a benefaction or gratuity. (Msb.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that does not draw near to the wateringtrough, or tank, on account of the pressing, or crowding [of the other camels to it], (S, K,) by reason of her generous disposition: (S:) so called because she waits for the others to drink, and drinks when they have done. (TA.) ― -b5- A^um~u Alr~aquwbi (assumed tropical:) Calamity, or misfortune. (K.)

raqiybN * , of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN, (TA,) A looker, watcher, or waiter, in expectation [of a person or thing]: (S, Msb, K:) pl. ruqabaA='u. (Msb.) ― -b2- A guarder, guardian, keeper, or preserver: (JK, S, A, Msb, K:) a guard of a people; one stationed on an elevated place to keep watch: (TA:) a spy, or scout, of an army: (A, TA:) a watcher, or an observer. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] Alr~qiybu is an appel-lation applied to God; (A, K, TA;) meaning The Guardian, Keeper, Watcher, or Observer, from whom nothing is hidden. (TA.) ― -b4- Also The A^amiyn of the players at the game called Almayosir; (JK, K;) or (K) he who is intrusted with the supervision of the Dariyb [or shuffler of the arrows]: (JK, S, K:) or the man who stands behind the HuroDap [q. v.] in the game above mentioned: the meanings of all these explanations are [said to be] the same: pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) The third of the arrows used in the game above mentioned: (T, S, K:) it is one of the seven arrows to which lots, or portions, appertain: (TA:) by some it is called AlD~ariybu: (Lh, L in art. Drb:) the arrows are ten in number: the first is Alfa*~u, which has one notch and one portion; the second, Alt~awo'amu, which has two notches and two portions; the third, Alr~aqiybu, which has three notches and three portions; the fourth, AlHilosu or AlHalisu, which has four notches [and four portions]; the fifth, Aln~aAfisu, which has five notches [and five portions]; the sixth, Almusobilu, which has six notches [and six portions]; and the seventh, AlmuEal~aY, the highest of all, which has seven notches and seven portions: those to which no portions appertain are Als~afiyHu and AlmaniyHu and Alwagodu. (TA.) A poet says,
A_i*aA qasama AlhawaY A^aEo$aAra qalobiY
fasahomaAki AlmuEal~aY waAlr~aqiybu
[When love divides the tenths of my heart, thy two arrows will be the mo'allà and the rakeeb]: by the sahomaAni, [which properly signifies two arrows, and hence (assumed tropical:) two portions gained by two gaming-arrows, and then (assumed tropical:) any two portions,] he means her eyes: and as the mEl~Y has seven portions and the rqyb has three, the shmAn would gain the whole of his heart. (TA. [See also a verse cited voce Eu$orN.]) ― -b6- raqiybu Aln~ajomi signifies (tropical:) The star, or asterism, that sets with the rising of that [other] star, or asterism: for example, the rqyb of Alv~uray~aA is AlA_ikoliylu: [and the former is the rqyb of the latter:] when the latter rises at nightfall, the former sets: (S, TA:) or raqiybN signifies the star, or asterism, which [as it were] watches, (yuraAqibu,) in the east, the star, or asterism, setting in the west: or any one of the Mansions of the Moon is the rqyb of another: (K, TA:) whenever any one of them rises, another [of them] sets: (TA: [see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl; and see also nawo'N:]) and Alr~aqiybu is (assumed tropical:) a [certain] star, or asterism, of the stars, or asterisms, [that were believed to be the givers] of rain, that [as it were] watches another star, or asterism: (K:) [it was app. applied to AlA_ikoliylu, as being the rqyb of the most noted and most welcome of all the Mansions of the Moon, namely, Alv~uray~aA: see nawo'N.] The raqiyb of Alv~uray~aA is [also] an appellation applied to Ald~abaraAnu (assumed tropical:) [i. e. The Hyades; or the five chief stars of the Hyades; or the brightest star among them, α of Taurus]; because a follower thereof: (A:) [and] AlEay~uwqu (assumed tropical:) [i. e. Capella] is so called as being likened to the rqyb of the game called Almayosir. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, laAA=tiyka A^awo yaloqaY Alv~uray~aA raqiybuhaA (tropical:) [I will not come to thee unless their rqyb meet the Pleiades]. (A.) ― -b7- raqiybN also signifies (tropical:) A man's successor, (A, K,) of his offspring, and of his Ea$iyrap [i. e. kinsfolk, or nearer or nearest relations by descent from the same ancestor, &c.]. (K.) So in the saying, niEoma Alr~aqiybu A^anota liA^abiyka wasalafika (tropical:) [Excellent, or most excellent, is the successor; such art thou to thy father and thine ancestors]: because the successor is like Ald~abaraAn to Alv~uray~aA. (A.) ― -b8- And (assumed tropical:) The son of a paternal uncle. (K.) [App. because two male cousins by the father's side are often rivals, and watchers of each other; the son of a girl's paternal uncle being commonly preferred as her husband.] ― -b9- Also (assumed tropical:) A species of serpent: as though it watched by reason of hatred: (TA:) or a certain malignant serpent: pl. raqiybaAtN and ruqubN. (T, K.)

raq~aAbapN *
A low, or an ignoble, man, a servant, or a slave, syn. rajulN wagodN, (S, K,) who keeps, guards, or watches, the [utensils and furniture called] raHol of a people when they are absent. (S.)

A^aroqabu * and ↓ raqabaAniY~N, (JK, S, A, K,) the latter irregular (Sb, S, K) as a rel. n., (Sb,) and ↓ raqabaAnN, (IDrd, K,) applied to a man, (S, IDrd, A,) Thick, (JK, S, K,) or large, (A, Mgh, in which latter only the second epithet is mentioned,) in the raqabap [or neck, &c.]: (JK, S, A, K:) the fem. [of the first] is raqobaA='u, (JK, IDrd,) applied to a female slave, (JK,) not applied to a free woman, nor does one say raqabaAniy~apN. (IDrd.) ― -b2- AlA^aroqabu is also [an epithet] applied to The lion; (K;) because of the thickness of his raqabp. (TA.)

maroqabN * and ↓ maroqabapN An elevated place upon which a spy, or watchman, ascends, or stations himself: (S, A, * Msb, K: *) [a structure such as is termed] an Ealam, or a hill, upon which one ascends to look from afar: or, accord. to Sh, the latter signifies a place of observation on the top of a mountain or of a fortress: accord. to AA, the pl., maraAqibu, signifies elevated pieces of ground. (TA.)
maroqabapN * : see what next precedes.
muraq~abN * A skin, or hide, that is drawn off from the part next to the head (S, K) and the raqabap [or neck, &c.]. (S.)

2 rq~H * , (S, A,) inf. n. taroqiyHN, (S, K,) He ordered, or put into a good or right or proper state, managed well, tended, or took care of, property, or cattle: (S, A, K:) and in like manner, he ordered, put into a good or right or proper state, or managed well, the means of subsistence; (S, * A, TA;) as also ↓ trq~H [app. with the objective complement (AlEayo$a or AlmaEiy$apa) understood]. (TA.) ― -b2- And He gained, acquired, or earned, property. (TA in art. rqE.) ― -b3- It occurs in a trad., in the phrase raq~aHa A_inosaAnFA, as meaning raf~aA^a [q. v.]. (TA.)

5 taraq~aHa see above. ― -b2- trq~H liEiyaAlihi He gained, acquired, or earned, or he sought, or laboured, to gain or acquire or earn, sustenance for his family, or household; syn. Aikotasaba, (S, [see also 1,]) or takas~aba; (A, K;) on the authority of Lh. (TA.)
raqoHaA='u * A woman who gains her subsistence by prostitution. (MF.)

raqaAHapN *
Good management of property. (TA.) ― -b2- Gain, acquisition, or earning: and merchandise, commerce, or traffic. (S, K.) Hence, (TA,) the Pagan Arabs, (S, A,) or some of them, (TA,) used to say in the talobiyap, [i. e. in uttering the ejaculation lab~ayoka, during the performance of the rites of the pilgrimage,] jiy^onaAka liln~aSaAHapi lamo naA^oti lilr~aqaAHapi [meaning We have come to Thee for the purpose of sincere worship: we have not come for gain, or traffic]. (S, A, TA.)

raqaAHiY~N *
A merchant, trafficker, or trader, (A, TA,) who manages well his property. (TA.) You say, huwa raqaAHiY~N maAlK He is one who orders, or puts into a good or right or proper state, manages well, tends, or takes care of, property, or cattle: (S, K: *) or who gains, acquires, or earns, property, and orders it, puts it into a good or right or proper state, or manages it well. (A, TA.)

huwa raAqiHapu A^aholihi *
He is the gainer, or earner, of sustenance for his family. (A, L.)

1 raqada * , (S, Msb,) aor.
raquda , inf.n. ruqaAdN and ruquwdN (JK, S, A, Msb, K) and raqodN (S, Msb, K) and perhaps also maroqadN [q. v.], (TA,) He slept, (JK, S, A, Msb, K,) accord. to some, specially, (Msb, K,) by night; (JK, Msb, K) but it correctly means, whether by night or by day; as is shown by verse 17 of ch. xviii. of the Kur-án: (Msb:) the assertion that it means, specially, by night, is weak: (TA:) accord. to Lth, ruquwdN is by night; and ruqaAdN, by day: but the Arabs used both of these words as meaning the sleeping by night and by day. (T, TA.) You say, maAbiY ruquwdN and ruqAdN [There is not in me any sleep]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raqada Eani AlA^amori (tropical:) He abstained, or held back, from the affair. (Msb, TA.) And raqada Eano Dayofihi (tropical:) [He neglected his guest;] he did not pay attention, or frequent attention, to his guest. (A, TA.) And raqada Alv~awobu, inf. n. raqodN and ruqaAdN, (TA,) (tropical:) The garment became old and worn out, and no longer of use; (A, * TA;) like naAma. (A.) And raqadati Als~uwqu (tropical:) The market became stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic; like naAmat. (Th, TA.) And raqada AlHar~u (tropical:) The heat remitted, or subsided. (TA. [See also rakada.])

2 taroqiydN *
A certain manner of going on foot, (JK, K,) with quickness: (JK:) perhaps a mistranscription for tarofiydN. (TA.)

4 Arqdhu *
He, or it, caused him to sleep; put him to sleep. (S, K.) It is said of a medicine. (S, A, K.) And you say, Arqdt AlmaroA^apu waladahaA The woman put her child to sleep. (A.) -A2- Arqd AlmakaAna, (K,) or biAlmakaAni, (S,) or biAlbaladi, (A,) or biA^aroDi ka*aA, (IAar, JK, TA,) (tropical:) He resided, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place, or town or country, or in such a land. (IAar, JK, S, A, K.)

6 trAqd *
He feigned himself asleep. (A.)

9 Arqd~ * , (JK, S, A,) inf. n. AiroqidaAdN, (JK, S, K,) He hastened; or was quick, or swift; (JK, S, M, A, K;) in his pace, or going: (M, A:) or he ran vehemently; as also Armd~; said of a camel: (AA, T in art. rmd:) or he ran with leaps, or bounds, as though leaping, or bounding, from a thing: (As, L in art. rmd:) or he went at random, heedlessly, headlong, or in a headlong course; and quickly; (As, JK, L in art. rmd;) as also Armd~. (As, T in that art.)

10 Astrqd *
He became overpowered by sleep [or drowsiness; and therefore desired to sleep]. (A, TA.)

A^aroHaA='u raqodK *
Mill-stones of Rakd; (S) which is the name of a mountain whence mill-stones are hewn; (S, A, K;) or, as some say, a valley in the district of Keys. (TA.) You say also raHFY ↓ raqodiy~apN A mill-stone of the mountain [or valley] called raqod. (A.)

raqodapN *
A sleep. (S.) One says, maA A^aToyaba raqodapa Als~aHari [How sweet is the sleep of the time a little before daybreak!]. (A.) ― -b2- A state of extinction of vitality (hamodapN) between the present life and the life to come. (JK, A. *) ― -b3- A^aSaAbatonaA raqodapN mana AlHar~i (JK, A, K) (tropical:) A period of heat befell us lasting half a month, or less, (A,) or ten days: (JK, K:) or raqodapN signifies a heat that befalls one after days of wind and an abatement of violent heat. (L.)
ruqadapN * : see raquwdN.
raqadaAnN * [an inf. n. of which the verb is not mentioned,] The act of leaping, or leaping up, by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, (S, K,) like the lamb and the kid. (S.)
raHFY raqodiy~apN * : see A^aroHaA='u raqodK, above.

raquwdN * and ↓ raq~aAdN (A) and ↓ yaroquwdN (K) [all signify the same; i. e. A man who sleeps much; as the last is expl. in the K and so ↓ ruqadapN; as Golius says on the authority of a gloss. in the KL: or] raquwdN signifies a man always sleeping; as also ↓ miroqid~aY. (TA.) [Hence,] AimoraA^apN raquwdu AlD~uHaY [A woman who sleeps much in the morning after sunrise; meaning] (tropical:) a woman that leads an easy, and a soft, or delicate, life; and so naw^uwmu AlD~uHaY. (A.)
raq~aAdN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

[
raAqidN * act. part. n. of 1:] ruq~adN [is its pl., and] signifies Persons sleeping; as also ruquwdN; (S, K;) the last occurring in the Kur xviii. 17. (Msb.)

raAquwdN *
A large vessel of the kind called dan~: (K:) or a vessel of the kind so called, (S, K,) or a vessel in form like the dan~, (JK,) resembling an A_irodab~ap, (S, A.) long in the lower part, (JK, S, K,) smeared inside with pitch: (S, A, K:) or an oblong earthen jar, smeared with pitch: (TA:) an arabicized word: (S:) pl. rawaAqiydu. (JK, S.) ― -b2- And A certain fish, (JK, K,) small, (K,) of the size of the finger, and round; (JK;) found in the sea. (TA.)

maroqadN *
A sleeping-place: (S, A, K:) pl. maraAqidu. (A.) You say, baEavahu mino maroqadihi [He roused him from his sleeping-place]. (A.) And A^axa*uwA maraAqidahumo [They took their sleeping-places]. (A.) ― -b2- It seems, from the manner in which it is used in the Kur xxxvi. 52, [like the former of the two exs. mentioned above,] that it may perhaps also be an inf. n. (TA.)

muroqidN * A medicine that causes him who drinks it to sleep (S, K. [In a copy of the A ↓ muraq~idN; and thus pronounced in the present day.]) ― -b2- Also A conspicuous road: (JK, K;) thus on the authority of As; but ISd says, “ I know not how it is: ” and others say that it is ↓ muraq~idN. (TA.)
muraq~idN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
miroqid~aY * : see raquwdN. ― -b2- Also A man quick in his affairs. (S, K.)
yaroquwdN * : see raquwdN.

1 raqa$a * , (A,) aor.
raqusa , (TK,) inf. n. raqo$N, (S, M, A, K,) He variegated; coloured with two or more colours; decorated; embellished; syn. naqa$a; (S, * A, K; *) and zay~ana; as also ↓ rq~$; (Har p. 57;) and ↓ taraq~a$a. (So in a copy of the A: [but I think that this is a mistranscription, for raq~a$a.]) ― -b2- He wrote: (M, TA:) and he pointed, or dotted, (As, M, TA,) characters, and writing: (As, TA:) as also ↓ rq~a$, inf. n. taroqiy$N; in both senses: and ↓ the latter, he wrote upon, or in, papers or the like, or books. (M, TA.)

2 rq~$ * , inf. n. taroqiy$N: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- He embellished his speech: or embellished it with lies: syn. Has~ana, and zaw~aqa: (TA:) or zay~ana, (A,) and zaw~ara, (S, K,) and zaxorafa. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- Hence, (A, TA,) (tropical:) He made known, divulged, or told, discourse, or conversation, in a malicious or mischievous manner, so as to occasion discord, dissension, or the like; (S, A, TA;) because he who does so embellishes his speech, or embel-lishes it with lies: (A, TA:) he told a calumny to the object thereof. (M.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He excited discord, dissension, or animosity. (M.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He blamed, reproved, or chid; syn. EaAtaba. (M, TA.)

5 trq~$ *
He adorned himself: (A, K:) he displayed his beauty, or goodliness. (A, TA.) -A2- See also 1.
8 Artq$wA * (assumed tropical:) They became mixed together in fight. (AA, K.)

raqa$N *
A good, or beautiful, xaT~ [i. e. character, or handwriting]. (TA.) [See also ruqayo$N: and see 1.] -A2- Also Food. (M.)
raqa$N * and ↓ ruqo$apN A colour in which are [intermixed] duskiness, or dinginess, and blackness; and the like of those two hues. (M.) [See A^aroqa$u.]
ruqo$apN * : see what next precedes.
raqaA$N * The serpent: (A, Sgh, K:) app. because of the ruqo$ap [see raqa$N] upon his back: (TA:) or a serpent speckled with black and white [like Hay~apN raqo$aA='u]. (A.)

ruqayo$N * dim. of raqo$N, signifying The pointing, or dotting, of characters and writing: (As, TA:) or of A^aroqa$u; as also ↓ A^urayoqi$u [so in the TA, but in some copies of the K, A^urayoqi$N]: (AHát, K:) the latter is allowable. (A Hát.)

A^aroqa$u * ; fem. raqo$aA='u; (S, M, &c.;) pl. ruqo$N; (A;) Variegated with duskiness, or dinginess, and blackness; or the like of those two hues; applied to the [species of locust called] junodab: (M, TA:) and the fem., applied to a serpent (Hay~ap), (S, M, IAth, K,) signifies the same: (M:) or speckled with black and white; (S, K;) and so when applied to a she-goat: (IAar, M:) or, applied to a serpent, it signifies one of the viper-species (A^afoEFY); because of the lines and specks upon its back: (IAth:) and A^aroqa$u AlA^u*unayoni having his ears variegated with black and white, and the rest of his hair black; applied to a kid. (S.) ― -b2- Also the fem., A small creeping thing (M, K) that is found in herbs, a variegated and beautiful worm, (M,) resembling [another small creeping thing called] the HumoTuwT, (M, K,) speckled with red and yellow.
(IDrd, TA.) Sgh., or his copyist, has corrupted HmTwT into xuTuwT. (TA.) ― -b3- Also the fem., The $iqo$iqap [i. e. the bursa faucium, or faucial bag,] of the camel: (S, A, K:) or the $q$qp of the camel is sometimes rq$A=', having in it a mixture of colours. (IDrd.)
A^urayoqi$u * : see ruqayo$N.

1 raqaSa * , (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
raquSa , (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. raqoSN, (S, M, Msb, CK,) or raqaSN, of the measure faEalN, like TaradN and HalabN, inf. ns. of Tarada and Halaba, (IDrd, IB, TA,) [He danced; this is what is meant by the explanation] he played, or sported; syn. laEiba: (A, K:) said of a raq~aAS [or dancer], (A, K,) or of a laE~aAb [or player or sporter], (M,) and of a muxan~av [or effeminate man, or one who affects the manners &c. of women], and of a SuwfiY~ [or mystic, in a choral celebration of the praises of God, which is termed a *ikor, performed by certain orders of darweeshes, all of whom, more or less, pretend to be mystics]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also raqaSa, (Lth, A,) aor.
raquSa , (Lth,) inf. n. raqoSN (Lth, M, A, K) and raqaSN, (Lth, M, K,) or the latter only, (IDrd, Ibn-Málik, TA,) and raqaSaAnN, (Lth, M, A, K,) (tropical:) He (a camel, A, TA) went the pace, or in the manner, termed xababN; [i. e. ambled;] (Lth, M, A, K, TA;) or went in a manner which was a kind of xabab: or went quickly. (TA.) One does not say yaroquSu [in speaking of any animate being] except of a player or sporter and of a camel (Lth, K, * TA) and the like: (Lth, TA:) in relation to others, one uses the terms qaqozN and naqozN: (Lth, K, TA:) or sometimes, (Lth, TA,) ― -b3- it is also said of an ass, meaning (tropical:) He played with his she-ass. (Lth, A, TA.) ― -b4- You say also, raqaSa fuw^aAduhu bayona janaAHayohi mina AlfazaEi (tropical:) [His heart throbbed, or leapt, between his two sides, by reason of fright]. (A.) ― -b5- raqaSa also signifies (tropical:) It (wine, S, K, and the beverage called nabiy*, A) estuated: (A, K:) or began to do so. (S, A.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) It (the mirage) was, or became, in a state of commotion; [it danced;] (S, M, A, K;) and so it signifies when said of bubbles (HabaAb). (M.) You say, A^anayotuhu Hiyna raqaSa Als~araAbu (A) or AlA=lu (TA) (tropical:) [I came to him when the mirage danced; in the heat of the day]. ― -b7- And (tropical:) He hasted, or was quick, fiY kalaAmihi in his speech. (A, TA.) You say also, lahu raqoSN fiY Alqawoli (tropical:) He has a haste in speech. (A, TA.) ― -b8- [And (tropical:) He spoke evil against another.] You say, samiEotu raqoSa Aln~aAsi EalayonaA (tropical:) I heard the evil speaking of the people against us. (A, TA.)
2 raq~aSa see 4, in two places.

4 ArqShu * [He made him to dance; or to play, or sport;] trans. of 1. (Msb.) You say, A^aroqaSato waladahaA, (S, A,) or Sabiy~ahaA, (M,) She (a woman, S, M) [danced, or dandled, her child; or] made her child to leap or spring or bound [in her arms or on her knee]; (S, M;) as also ↓ rq~Sthu, (S, M, A,) inf. n. taroqiySN: (S, A:) or the latter verb has an intensive signification. (Msb.) ― -b2- ArqS baEiyrahu (tropical:) He made his camel to go in the [ambling] manner termed xababN: (S, M, A, K:) and the same, (TA,) or ↓ rq~Shu, (M,) he made him (i. e. his camel) to leap, spring, or bound. (M, TA.) -A2- See also 5.

5 trq~S * [lit., He, or it, became danced or dandled. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) He, or it, became raised and lowered; or rose and sank; or went up and down. (K, TA.) You say, trq~SwA fiY masiyrihimo (tropical:) They went up and down in their journeying; (A;) as also ↓ ArqSwA. (A, TA.) And Er-Rá'ee uses the phrase taraq~aSati AlmafaAzapu, meaning, (tropical:) The desert [in appearance] went up and down; the mirage, only, making it [seem] to rise and sink. (TA.)

[
raqoSapN *
A dance, or a dancing: pl. raqaSaAtN. See an ex. voce qaroSapN.]
raq~aASN * [A dancer; a player, or sporter: one who dances, or plays, or sports, much, or often]: (S, A, Msb, K:) an intensive epithet. (Msb.)
raq~aASapN * [A female dancer]. ― -b2- A certain game of the Arabs. (IF, K.) -A2- A^aroDN raq~aASapN (assumed tropical:) Land that does not give growth to anything, though rained upon. (K.)
raAqiSN * [A man dancing; playing, or sporting]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Alr~aAqiSu The star [ μ] on the tongue of Alt~in~iyn [or Draco]. (Kzw.)

kalaAmN muroqiSN * (tropical:) Speech, or language, that makes one to be affected with a lively emotion of joy, or of grief. (TA.) You say also, h`*ihi muroqiSapu AlS~uwfiy~api [app. meaning, (assumed tropical:) This is that poem, or ode, which makes the mystics to dance; or to be affected with a lively emotion of joy: for darweeshes are often seen to be excited to frantic ecstasy, or ecstatic catalepsy, by certain love-songs designed to have a mystic religious sense]. (TA.) ― -b2- falaApN muroqiSapN (tropical:) A desert that makes the traverser thereof to hasten, or go quickly. (A, TA.)
miroqaSN * (tropical:) A camel that goes much, or often, in the [ambling] manner termed xababN (M, TA.)
2 raq~aTotu EalaY vawobiY * (tropical:) I made specks, or small spots, [with ink or the like, (see 5,)] upon my garment; syn. naq~aTotu. (A, TA.)
5 trq~T vawobuhu * (tropical:) His garment became sprinkled with specks, or small spots, of ink or the like. (K, TA.)

9 ArqT~ * , (S, K,) inf. n. AiroqiTaATN, (S,) He, or it, was, or became, of a black colour speckled with white: or the reverse: (K:) [or speckled with white, and black, and red, and yellow: (see ruqoTapN:)] as also ↓ ArqAT~, (K,) inf. n. AiroqiyTaATN: (TA:) or the former, he (a sheep, or goat,) was, or became, such as is termed A^abogav. (S.) ― -b2- It (the stalk, or twig, of the Earofaj) put forth its leaves, and what resembled nails (A^aZaAfiyr) were seen in the place of separation (mutafar~aq) of its stalks, or twigs, and internodal portions; as also ↓ the latter verb: (K, * TA:) this is said to be after what is termed tavoqiybN and qamalN, and before what is termed A_idobaA='N and A_ixowaASN: (TA:) or ↓ the latter verb, said of the Erfj, signifies it put forth its leaves; and this it does before its A_idobaA=': (S:) [see EarofajN:] in a trad. occurs the expression ArqAT~ EawosajuhaA; but El-Kutabee thinks that it should be EarofajuhaA. (TA.)
11 A_iroqaAoT~a see 9, in three places.

raqoTN *
A dotting, or speckling: pl. A^aroqaATN. (O.)

ruqoTapN *
Blackness mixed with speckles of white: (S, K:) or the reverse: (M, K:) or speckles of white, and of black, and of red, and of yellow, in an animal: (A, TA:) and the state, or quality, denoted by the epithet A^aroqaTu. (TA.)

A^aroqaTu *
Black speckled with white: or the reverse: fem. raqoTaA='u. (K.) Applied to a sheep or goat, Like, (S,) or syn. with, (K,) A^abogavu: (S, K:) or speckled with black and white. (Har p. 303.) And the fem., applied to a domestic fowl or hen (dajaAjap), Black speckled with white: (S:) or party-coloured: (K:) or having patches of white and black: much sought after, and used, by enchanters; and rarely found. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b3- And the fem. is applied to a tract (risaAlapN), and to an ode (qaSiydapN), as meaning Having one of the letters of a word thereof dotted, and another not dotted: from the same epithet applied to a sheep or goat. (Har p. 303.) ― -b4- Als~ilosilapu Alr~aqoTaA='u A certain reptile; the most malignant of the [kind of lizards called] EiZaA=': when it crawls upon food, it poisons it. (TA.) ― -b5- variydapN raqoTaA='u (tropical:) [A mess of crumbled or broken bread] having much oil (Sgh, K *) or clarified butter. (TA.) ― -b6- AlA^aroqaTu The leopard: (K:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.) ― -b7- Alr~aqoTaA='u (tropical:) Civil war; conflict and faction; sedition; or the like; syn. Alfitonapu: (K:) because of its variableness: or such as is not universal; likened to a speckled serpent: occurring in a trad. (TA.)

1 raqaEahu * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
raqaEa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. raqoEN, (Msb, TA,) He patched it; pieced it; put a piece of cloth in the place thereof that was cut or rent; (Msb;) repaired it, (K,) and closed up the hole or holes thereof, (TA,) with [a patch or] patches; (S, K;) namely, a garment, or piece of cloth; (S, Msb, K;) and in like manner, a skin, or hide; (TA;) as also ↓ rq~Ehu, (K,) inf. n. taroqiyEN: (TA:) or trqyE signifies the patching a garment, or piece of cloth, in several places. (S, TA.) ― -b2- He stopped it up, or closed it up; namely, any hole, or aperture; and so ↓ rq~Ehu; as in the saying of 'Omar Ibn-Abee-Rabee'ah,
wakun~a A_i*aA A^aboSaronaniY A^awosamiEonaniY
xarajona faraq~aEona AlkuwaY biAlmaHaAjiri
[And they (referring to women) used, when they
saw me, or heard me, to come forth, (xarajona being used for yaxorujona,) and close up the apertures in the walls with the eyes and the parts immediately around them]. (L.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) [He repaired it in a figurative sense; as also ↓ rq~Ehu.] You say, yaroqaEu diynahu bitawobatihi (assumed tropical:) [He repairs his religion by his repentance]. (TA.) And ↓ rq~E dunoyaAhu baA=xiratihi (assumed tropical:) [He repaired his state, or condition, in the present word by sacrificing his blessings in the world to come]: whence the saying of 'AbdAllah Ibn-El-Mubárak,
nuraq~iEu dunoyaAnaA bitamoziyqi diyninaA
falaAd diynunaA yaboqaY walaA maA nuraq~iEu
(assumed tropical:) [We repair our state, or condition, in the present world by the rending, or marring, of our religion, so that neither our religion remains nor what we repair]. (TA.) And HaAlahu wamaEiy$atahu ↓ rq~E (tropical:) He repaired, amended, or put to rights, his state, or condition, and his means of subsistence; syn. A^aSolaHa, (TA,) and raq~aHa: (K, * TA:) with which latter ↓ rq~E is also syn. as signifying (tropical:) he gained, acquired, or earned, property; accord. to an explanation of its inf. n., trqyE. (TA.) And yaSilu AlkalaAma fayaroqaEu baEoDahu bibaEoDK (tropical:) [He connects the language, and repairs one part thereof by inserting another]: said of a poet. (TA.) And ↓ taroqiyEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) [The act of interpolating: or] the adding to a tradition, or story, or narrative. (TA.) ― -b4- ↓ maA raqaEa maroqaEFA [lit. He did not patch a place of patching, or place to be patched;] means (tropical:) he did not, or made not, or wrought not, anything. (TA.) ― -b5- kaAna muEaAwiyapu yaloqamu biyadK wayaroqaEu biA^uxoraY (assumed tropical:) [Mo'áwiyeh used to put morsels into his mouth with one hand,] and spread another hand in order that the portions of his morsels that fell might become scattered upon it. (IAth, Sgh, K.) ― -b6- raqaEa Alr~akiy~apa, (Ibn-' Abbád, K,) and raqaEahaA biAlr~iqaAEi, inf. n. raqoEN, (TA,) (tropical:) He lined, or cased, the interior of the well for the space of the stature of a man, or twice that measure, fearing its becoming demolished, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) in its upper part. (TA.) ― -b7- raqaEa xal~apa AlfaArisi [lit. He closed up the interval between him and the horseman;] means (tropical:) he reached, or overtook, the horseman, and pierced him, or thrust him; Alxal~apu signifying the interval, or intervening space, between the piercer, or thruster, and the pierced, or thrust. (O, K, TA.) ― -b8- raqaEa AlgaraDa bisahomK, [and Alr~aqoEapa,] (tropical:) He hit, or struck, the butt, or target, with an arrow. (K, TA.) raqoEu ruqoEapK also signifies (assumed tropical:) Any hitting, or striking. (TA.) And raqaEa (assumed tropical:) He struck, or beat, in any manner; with a whip; and otherwise; as in the phrases raqaEahu kaf~FA (assumed tropical:) [He struck him a slap with the hand]; and huwa yaroqaEu AlA^aroDa birijolihi (assumed tropical:) [He beats the ground with his foot]. (TA.) And raqaEa Al$~ayoxu (tropical:) The old man supported himself, or bore, upon his two palms, [as though meaning he struck the ground with the palms of his hands,] in order to rise. (TA.) ― -b9- [And hence,] raqaEahu, (S, K,) or raqaEahu bqawolihi, (TA,) (tropical:) He censured him, reviled him, or satirized him. (S, K, TA.) -A2- raquEa, (S, TA,) inf. n. raqaAEapN, (S, K,) (tropical:) He was, or became, stupid, foolish, deficient in sense; (S, K, TA;) shattered, or marred, in his intellect; (TA;) such as is termed raqiyE. (S.)

2 raq~aEa see 1, in seven places. ― -b2- rq~E Aln~aAqapa biAlhinaA='i, inf. n. taroqiyEN, (tropical:) He smeared the traces of mange, or scab, upon the she-camel, one after another, with tar, or liquid pitch. (TA.)
4 ArqE * : see 10. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) He (a man, S) acted, or spoke, stupidly, or foolishly. (S, K, TA.)
5 trq~o * (tropical:) He sought, sought after, or sought to gain, sustenance, or the like; or he applied himself, as to a task, to do so. (K, TA.)

10 AstrqE Alv~awobu *
The garment, or piece of cloth, required to be patched; (A, TA;) it was time for it to be patched; (S, K;) as also ↓ A^aroqaEa. (K.)

raqoEN * (TA) and Alr~aqoEu (K, TA) The seventh heaven. (K, TA.) So, accord. to some, in a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abi-s-Salt, [where others read biroqiEa instead of raqoEFA,] cited voce sadirN. (TA.) [See also Alr~aqiyEu,]
raqoEapN * (assumed tropical:) The sound of the arrow in, or upon, the butt, or target. (IAar, K, TA.)

ruqoEapN *
A patch; i. e. a piece of cloth, or rag, with which a garment, or the like, is patched, or pieced, or repaired: (S, Msb, K:) pl. riqaAEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ruqaEN. (TA.) Hence the saying, AlS~aAHibu kaAlr~uqoEapi fiY Alv~awobi faA@Tolubohu mu$aAkilFA [The companion is like the patch in the garment; therefore seek thou the one that is suitable]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A [patch, or] trace, or mark, of mange, or scab: (TA:) the commencement of the mange, or scab: (K, TA: [in some copies of the K, AlHarob is erroneously put for Aljarab:]) pl. riqaAEN. (TA.) ― -b3- ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A piece of land, or ground, adjoining another piece [which is in some manner distinguished therefrom; i. e. a patch of land, or ground: and in like manner, of herbage]: pl. riqaAEN. (TA.) You say, riqaAEu AlA^aroDi muxotalifapN (assumed tropical:) [The patches of the land, or ground, are various, or diverse]. (TA.) And h`*ihi ruqoEapN mina AlkalaA^i (assumed tropical:) [This is a patch of herbage]: and maA wajadonaA gayora riqaAEK mino Eu$obK (assumed tropical:) [We found not aught save patches of green herbage]. (TA.) ― -b5- [A note, billet, or short letter: and particularly a short written petition or memorial, addressed to a prince or governor: a ticket: a label:] a certain thing that is written: pl. riqaAEN (S, K) [and accord. to modern usage ruqaEN also]. Hence the saying in a trad., yajiYo'u A^aHadukumo yawoma AlqiyaAmapi EalaY raqabatihi riqaAEN taxofiqu [One of you will come, on the day of resurrection, having, suspended upon his neck, billets fluttering]; meaning, by the rqAE, the claims to be made upon him, or the dues incumbent on him, written on the rqAE. (TA.) ― -b6- A butt, or target, at which to shoot; also termed ruqoEapu garaDK. (TA.) ― -b7- A chess-table; also termed ruqoEapu Al$~iToranoji: so called because it is patched [with squares]. (T A.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) The original matter; the substance; (S, TA;) of a garment, or piece of cloth; (S, TA;) or of a thing: (TA:) or (tropical:) the thickness of a garment, or piece of cloth. (Mgh.) You say, ruqoEapu h`*aA Alv~awobi jay~idapN (tropical:) The [substance or] thickness of this garment, or piece of cloth, is good. (Mgh.) ― -b9- [The pl.] riqaAEN also signifies (tropical:) The lining, or casing, which is constructed in the upper part of the interior of a well when one fears its becoming demolished. (TA.) [See raqaEa Alr~ikiy~apa.]

raqiyEN *
Patched; a garment, or the like, having a piece of cloth put in a place thereof that is cut or rent; (Msb;) as also ↓ maroquwEN. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (O, Msb,) (tropical:) Stupid, foolish, deficient in sense; (S, O, K;) in whose intellect is something needing repair; [so I render fiY Eaqolihi maram~apN;] (S, TA;) shattered, or marred, in his intellect; (TA;) as also ↓ A^aroqaEu, (TA,) and ↓ maroqaEaAnN; (S, K;) or unsound in intellect; likened to a ragged, or old and worn-out, garment; as though patched: (Msb:) or a man whose judgment, and state of affairs or circumstances, have become shattered, disorganized, dissipated, marred, or impaired: (A, TA:) fem. [of ↓ A^aroqaEu] raqoEaA='u, (K,) but this is post-classical; (L, TA;) and [of maroqaEaAnN] ↓ maroqaEaAnapN. (K.) ― -b3- Hence also, (TA,) Alr~aqiyEu (tropical:) The first heaven; (K;) i. e. (TA) the heaven of the lower world; (S, TA;) [agreeing with the Hebrew term; an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates; for Als~amaA='u Alr~aqiyEu; and therefore, properly, fem.; though an instance occurs of its being used as a masc. noun, as will be seen below;] so called because it is [as though it were] patched with the stars, or with the lights which are therein; as also ↓ AlA^aroqaEu: (TA:) or the heaven, or sky: (Msb, K:) and also each one of the seven heavens; (S;) each of them being a cover to that which is next to it [beneath, so that each, except the highest, is as though it were patched over by the next above it, the highest being in like manner covered over by the kurosiY~,] like as the garment is patched with the ruqoEap: (TA:) pl. A^aroqiEapN. (S, Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a trad., laqado Hakamotu biHukomi A@ll~`hi mino fawoqi saboEapi A^aroqiEapK (S, * Mgh) (tropical:) Verily I have decreed by the decree of God written upon the preserved tablet above seven heavens: (Mgh:) the speaker thus making rqyE masc., as though he regarded it as meaning saqofN. (S, TA.) [See also raqoEN.]

huwa raqaAEiY~u maAlK *
i. q. raqaAHiY~u (tropical:) [He is a good, or right, orderer, or manager, of property, or of camels, &c.]: because he amends the condition thereof. (TA.)

raAqiEN * [act. part. n. of raqaEa: see an ex. voce xaroqN]. ― -b2- It is said in a trad., Almuw^ominu waAhK raAqiEN fiAls~aEiydN mano halaka EalaY raqoEihi (tropical:) The believer is one who becomes unsound in his religion by his disobe-
dience, and who repairs it by his repentance: [therefore the happy is he who dies while he is repairing:] (TA in the present art.:) i. e., one who offends [and] who repents. (TA in art. whY.)

A^aroqaEu * : fem. raqoEaA='u: see raqiyEN, in three places. ― -b2- Also, the fem., applied to a ewe, or she-goat, (tropical:) Having a whiteness in her side. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And, applied to a woman, (assumed tropical:) Having no buttocks: (ISk, K:) or slender in the shanks. (TA.) -A2- [Also (assumed tropical:) More, and most, stupid, foolish, or deficient in sense.] You say, maA taHota Alr~aqiyEi A^aroqaEu minohu (assumed tropical:) [There is not beneath the sky a person more stupid, &c., than he]. (TA.)

maroqaEN * [A place of patching; or a place to be patched; as also ↓ mutaraq~aEN]. ― -b2- [Hence,] maA raqaEa maroqaEFA: see 1. ― -b3- And laA A^ajidu fiyka maroqaEFA lilokalaAmi (tropical:) [I do not, or shall not, find in thee anything requiring amendment, to speak of]. (TA.) ― -b4- And fiyhi limano yuSoliHuhu ↓ mutaraq~aEN (assumed tropical:) (assumed tropical:) In it, or him, is a place, or subject, for patching, or amendment, for him who will rectify it, or him: like as one says, fiyhi mutanaS~aHN, meaning a place for sewing. (TA.) ― -b5- And ↓ A^araY fiyhi mutaraq~aEFA (tropical:) I see in him, or it, a subject, or place, for censure, reviling, or satire. (S, TA.)
$AEirN miroqaEN * (tropical:) A poet who connects language [skilfully], and repairs (yaroqaEu) one part thereof by [inserting] another. (TA.)
maroqaEaAnN * : fem. with p: see raqiyEN, in two places.

muraq~aEN * A garment, or piece of cloth, much patched, or having many patches. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [And hence, as being likened to a garment much used,] (tropical:) A man tried, or proved, by use, practice, or experience; expert, or experienced. (TA.)

muraq~aEapN *
A certain garment worn by the devout Soofees;; so called because of the [many] patches that are in it. (TA.) [A garment of this kind, a gown, or long coat or cloak, is worn in the present day by many devotees, reputed saints, and darweeshes; and passing from one to another at the death of the former, at length consists almost entirely of patches; and therefore, the more it is patched, the more is it esteemed: it is also called xiroqapN; and dalaqN, or daliqN, or daloqN, or (now generally by the vulgar) diloq, from the Persian dalaho.] ― -b2- Also thought by A'Obeyd to mean A quiver, or a pouch, much patched: whence the prov., zanodaAni fiY muraq~aEapK [Two pieces of stick for producing fire, in a quiver, or pouch, much patched:] an allusion to a poor and unprofitable man. (Meyd.)
maroquwEN * : see raqiyEN. ― -b2- (tropical:) A camel having [patches,] traces, marks, or commencements, of mange, or scab. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A man censured, reviled, or satirized. (TA.)
mutaraq~aEN * : [so in three copies of the S, and in the TA: in Freytag's Lex., murotaqaEN:] see maroqaEN, in three places: i. q. mutarad~amN. (T in art. rdm.)
1 raqVla see the next paragraph.

4 Arqlt * , said of a palm-tree (naxolap), inf. n. A_iroqaAlN, It became such as is termed raqolap [q. v.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Arql, (S, K,) said of a he-camel, (S,) or Arqlt, said of a she-camel, (JK, Msb, TA,) inf. n. as above, (JK, S, Msb,) He, or she, went quickly; (JK, K;) went a sort of quick pace; (Msb;) went a sort of pace of the kind termed xabab [q. v.]: (S, TA:) or went a sort of run exceeding that termed xabab: (TA:) and ↓ raqalato signifies the same as Arqlt. (JK.) Arql is also said of a man, (S, K,) meaning (assumed tropical:) He went quickly. (TA.) And you say, ArqlwA fiY AlHarobi, (TA,) or A_ilaY AlHarobi, (JK,) (tropical:) They went quickly in, or to, war, or battle. (JK, TA.) And fulaAnN yuroqilu fiY AlA^umuwri (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is quick in affairs]. (TA.) And A^aroqalato A_ilayohi is metaphorically said, by Aboo-Heiyeh En-Numeyree, of spears [as meaning (tropical:) They had been quickly directed towards him]. (TA.) -A2- Accord. to Lth and the K, Arql also signifies He traversed, or crossed, a desert: and Lth cites the following verse of El-'Ajjáj [as his authority for this explanation]:
laAhum~a rab~i Albayoti waAlmu$ar~aqi
waAlmuroqilaAti kul~a suhobK samolaqi
but Az says that this is a mistake of Lth; that kul~a is here an adv. n.; and that the meaning is, [O God, by the Lord of the House (of Mekkeh) and of the Musharrak (the mosque of El-Kheyf) and] by the Lord of the swift she-camels in every even plain: and ISd also has notified the same. (TA.)
raqolN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

raqolapN *
A tall palm-tree: (S, Msb:) or a palmtree exceeding the reach of the hand; (K, * TA;) above such as is termed jab~aArap: or this latter word, accord. to As, has this meaning; and the former word, a palm-tree higher than such as [just] exceeds the reach of the hand: (TA:) or a palmtree of which the trunk has become such as that one may reach [the fruit] from [the top of] it: (JK:) pl. riqaAlN (JK, S, Msb, K) and raqalaAtN (Msb) and ↓ raqolN, (K,) or [rather] of this last it is a n. un. (Msb.) Hence the prov.,
wamaA yudoriyka biAld~axoli
↓taraY AlfitoyaAna kaAlr~aqoli
[Thou seest the youths, or young men, like tall palm-trees, &c.; but what will acquaint thee with the vice, &c., that is, or may be, in them?]. (TA. [See also another reading of this verse voce daxolN.]) [And rawaAqilu, pl. of ↓ raAqilN, as used by a Hudhalee poet, applied to the trunks of palmtrees, signifies Tall. (“ Abulfedæ Annales, ” vol. i. page 494.)]
raAqilN * ; pl. rawaAqilu: see what next precedes.

raAquwlN *
A rope by means of which palm-trees are ascended; (S, TA;) so in one of the dials.; (TA;) i. q. HaAbuwlN [q. v.] (S, K) and kar~N. (S.)

muroqilN * (S, K) and muroqilapN (ISd, K) and ↓ miroqaAlN (S, K) applied to a she-camel, (S, ISd, K,) That goes quickly: (K:) or that goes in the manner termed A_iroqaAl much, or often: (S, TA:) and maraAqiylu [as pl. of the last] is applied [in like manner] to she-camels. (TA.) [Hence,] fiY AlA^umuwri ↓ fulaAnN miroqaAlN [Such a one is quick in affairs]. (TA.)
miroqaAlN * ; pl. maraAqiylu: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

1 raqama * , (Msb, K,) aor.
raquma , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. raqomN, (S, Msb, TA,) He wrote (S, Msb, K) a writing, book, or letter. (Msb.) And He sealed, stamped, imprinted, or impressed. (S, TA.) And raqama AliktaAba, (K,) inf. n. as above, (JK,) He marked the writing with the dots, or points, (JK, K, TA,) and made its letters distinct, or plain. (K, * TA.) One says, huwa yaroqumu AlmaA='a, (S,) or huwa yaroqumu fiY AlmaA='i, (JK, TA,) [He writes, &c., upon the water,] a prov., applied to the skilful and intelligent, (JK, * TA,) meaning he is so skilful that he writes, &c., (yaroqumu) where the writing, &c., (Alr~aqomu,) will not remain fixed. (JK, S, TA.) And one says of a skilful workwoman, clever in sewing skins and the like, hiYa taroqumu AlmaA='a and taroqumu fiY AlmaA='i. (TA.) ― -b2- And raqama Alv~awoba, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (JK, Msb,) and so the inf. n.; (Msb, TA;) and ↓ rq~mhu, (S, K,) inf. n. taroqiymN; (S, TA;) He figured, variegated, or decorated, the garment, or piece of cloth; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) and (TA) made it striped, or marked it with stripes: (K, TA:) or, accord. to IF, he figured it, variegated it, or decorated it, with a certain, or known, figuring or variegation or decoration, such as became a mark [thereof]. (Msb.) Also the former phrase, (JK, Mgh, TA,) and ↓ the latter likewise, (TA,) said of a trader, or dealer, (JK, Mgh,) He marked, or put a mark on, the garment, or piece of cloth, (JK, Mgh, TA,) specifying its price; he put a price-mark upon it: (Mgh:) whence, laA yajuwzu bayoEu Al$~aYo'i biraqomihi [The sale of the thing by the putting a price-mark upon it shall not be allowable, because the express consent of the seller as well as that of the purchaser is necessary to the ratification of the sale]: (Mgh:) [or] raqamotu Al$~aYo'a signifies I marked the thing so as to distinguish it from other things, as, for instance, by writing and the like: and hence, laA yubaAEu Alv~awobu biraqomihi walaA bilamosihi [The garment, or piece of cloth, shall not be sold by the putting a price-mark upon it, for the reason explained above, nor by the feeling it, or touching it: see 3 in art. lms]. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence,] huwa yaziydu fiY Alr~aqomi is a phrase used by the relaters of traditions as meaning (assumed tropical:) He adds to his tradition, and lies: from Alr~aqomu signifying the writing upon a garment, or piece of cloth. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, raqama AlbaEiyra (assumed tropical:) He cauterized the camel. (TA.)
