[And raqama Alfarasa (assumed tropical:) He (a farrier) marked the horse, making lines upon him, with a hot iron: see maroquwmN, and see also jaAEirapN.]
2 raq~ama see above, in two places. taroqiymN signifies [also] The drawing, and the writing, of a line [or lines]. (KL.)

raqomN * is originally an inf. n. [of 1, q. v.]: and hence raqomu Alv~awobi The writing [or price-mark, &c.,] upon the garment, or piece of cloth. (S.) [Hence also Alr~aqomu AlhinodiY~u The Indian notation of numerals; adopted by the Arabs; whence is formed the notation which we term “ the Arabic. ”] ― -b2- Also A sort of [the kind of garments called] buruwd: (S:) or a striped sort of [the kind of garments, or cloth, termed] wa$oY; or of [the kind of cloth termed] xaz~; or of [the kind of garments called] buruwd: (K:) or a garment, or piece of cloth, figured with round forms: (Har p. 416:) or buruwdu Alr~aqomi signifies a sort of figured, or variegated, or decorated, [garments of the kind called] brwd: (Mgh:) or raqomN signifies [cloth of the kind termed] xaz~ figured, variegated, or decorated; (JK, Msb;) so accord. to El-Fárábee: (Mgh:) but accord. to IF, ↓ raqiymN signifies any garment, or piece of cloth, figured, variegated, or decorated, with a certain, or known, figuring or variegation or decoration, such as is a mark [thereof]; and you say burodN raqomN and buruwdN raqomN [a garment of the kind called brd, and garments of the kind called brwd, thus figured, &c.; using the latter word as sing. and pl. because it is originally an inf. n.]: (Msb:) and ↓ maroquwmN (Msb, TA) and ↓ muraq~amN (TA) signify a garment, or piece of cloth, figured, variegated, or decorated: (Msb, TA:) and striped, or marked with stripes: and marked, or having a mark [specifying its price] put upon it. (TA.) -A2- See also raqimN, in two places.
raqamN * : see ruqomapN: -A2- and see also the paragraph here next following. -A3- yawomu Alr~aqami The day of Er-Rakam was one of the days [of conflict] of the Arabs, (S,) well known. (K.)

raqimN *
A calamity, or misfortune; (JK, S, K;) as also ↓ raqamN and ↓ raqomN; (K;) all mean thus, and a thing that one cannot accomplish, or manage; (TA;) and ↓ ruqomapN signifies the same as raqimN. (JK.) One says, waqaEa fiY Alr~aqimi, (TA,) and waqaEa fiY Alr~aqimi ↓ Alr~aqomaA='i, (S,) meaning He fell [into calamity or misfortune, and he fell into great calamity or misfortune, or] into that which he could not accomplish, or manage. (S, TA.) And jaA='a fulaAnN ↓ biAlr~aqimi Alr~aqomaA='i Such a one brought to pass that which was a great calamity or misfortune. (As, TA.) And bnotu Alr~aqimi signifies the same as Alr~aqimu, That which is a calamity or misfortune. (S, TA.) ― -b2- One says also, jaA='a biAlr~aqimi and ↓ biAlr~aqomi meaning [He brought, or did,] much. (K.)

raqomapN * (assumed tropical:) Any one of several small marks of cauterization upon the shanks of a beast. (JK, T, TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) One of what are termed Alr~aqomataAni: (TA:) this signifies two [horny] things resembling two nails (JK, S, K, TA) in the legs of a beast (JK, K, TA) or in the legs of a sheep or goat, (S,) opposite each other: (JK, S, TA:) and of the ass and horse, two marks in the inner sides of the two arms: (S:) or the jaAEirataAni; (K, TA;) which are two black spots [or marks made by cauterization] upon the rump of the ass: (TA:) or what borders upon the jaAEirataAni of the ass, of the mark made by cauterization: or two portions of [callous] flesh next to the inner side of each of the arms of the horse, having no hair upon them. (K, TA.) Agreeably with all of these renderings has been explained the trad., maA A^anotumo mina AlA^umami A_il~aA kaAlr~aqomapi mino *iraAEi Ald~aAb~api (assumed tropical:) [Ye are no more, of the nations in general, than such as is the rqmp of the arm of the beast]. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A small quantity of herbage; as in the saying, maA wajadotu A_il~aA raqomapF mino kalaA^K (assumed tropical:) [I found not save a small quantity of herbage]. (TA.) ― -b4- A herb, or leguminous plant, of those termed A^aHoraAr [pl. of Hur~N, q. v.]: (S:) a certain plant; said to be a herb, or leguminous plant, inclining to bitterness, and having a small red flower; (JK;) as some say, (JK, TA,) the xub~aAzaY [or mallow]. (JK, K, TA.) ― -b5- A meadow (rawoDapN, S, K) is sometimes thus termed. (S.) ― -b6- Also The side of a valley: (S, K:) or the place where its water collects; (K;) the part, of a valley, in which is the water. (Fr, JK, TA.)
ruqomapN * The colour of the serpent termed A^aroqam; (JK, TA;) as also ↓ raqamN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also raqimN.

raqamapN *
A certain plant, (K, TA,) resembling the kr$ [i. e. kari$ or kiro$, a plant little known, said to be so called because its leaves resemble the villous coat of the stomach of a ruminant animal]: so says Az: and in one place he says, it is a herb that grows m$HTA [app. a mistranscription for musaT~aHFA, a term often used in descriptions of plants, meaning expanded], juicy, or sappy, and scarcely ever, or never, eaten by the camels, or cattle, except from want: AHn describes the rqmp [perhaps meaning the raqomap, q. v.,] only as a herb, or leguminous plant, of those termed A^aHoraAr, of which the particular characteristics were not known to him. (TA.) [Forskål, in his Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. cviii., mentions a plant seen by him in El-Yemen, previously unknown to him, which he calls “ rokama prostrata, ” of the class pentandria; writing its Arabic name rqmh, and the pronunciation “ Rókama. ”]

raqamiy~aAtN *
Certain arrows, so called in relation to a place in El-Medeeneh, (S, K,) named Alr~aqamu; (K;) or in relation to a place thus named in the way to El-Medeeneh; (JK;) or, accord. to Nasr, in relation to a water thus named, where they were made, by certain mountains of the same name. (TA.)
raquwmN * , used as a fem. epithet, Remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding; and remaining fixed. (JK.)

raqiymN * : see maroquwmN: and raqomN. It occurs in a trad. of 'Alee, describing the sky, as meaning Figured, or decorated, with the stars. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A book, or writing. (S.) As used in the Kur xviii. 8, Alr~aqiymu is said to mean A tablet (JK, S, K *) of lead, (K,) whereon were inscribed, (JK, * S,) or engraved, (K,) the names of the People of the Cave [commonly called the Seven Sleepers], (JK, S, K,) and their ancestry, (JK, K,) and their story, (S,) and their religion, and what it was from which they fled: (K:) so says Suh, on the authority of Fr: (TA:) or a mass of stone; (Suh, JK, K;) [i. e.] a stone tablet on which were inscribed their names, and which was put upon the entrance of the cave: (Bd:) or the town, or village, from which they came forth: (JK, K:) or their mountain (Zj, K) in which was the cave: (Zj:) or the valley (AO, JK, K) in which was the cave: (AO, JK:) or their dog: (El-Hasán, R, K:) or [in the JK and CK “ and ”] the receptacle for ink: (JK, K, TA:) mentioned by IDrd, but with the expression of uncertainty as to its correctness; (TA;) and said to be of the language of the Greeks: (JK, * TA:) and the tablet: (K:) thus, also, explained as used in the verse of the Kur-án: (TA:) but I'Ab is related by 'Ikrimeh to have said, I know not what is Alr~aqiymu; whether a book or writing, or a building: (S, TA:) it is [said to be] of the measure faEiyl in the sense of the measure mafoEuwl. (TA.) ― -b3- raqiymapN, applied to a woman, (tropical:) Intelligent; such as is termed barozapN [fem. of barozN q. v.]. (Fr, K, TA.) ― -b4- daAhiyapN raqiymN (assumed tropical:) A great calamity or misfortune. (JK.)

A^aroqamu * (assumed tropical:) A certain serpent: (JK:) a serpent in which are blackness and whiteness: (S, M, K:) or a serpent [begotten] between two serpents [app. of different varieties], marked with redness and blackness and duskiness and [the colour termed] bugovap [q. v.]: (ISh:) or a serpent upon which are white specks: (Ham p. 784:) or the most malignant of serpents, and the most wont to pursue mankind: (Ibn-Habeeb, K:) or a serpent like the jaAn~ in respect of the fear that men have of killing it, though it is one of the weakest and the least irascible of serpents; for one fears, in killing the Arqm and the jAn~, the punishment of the jin~ to them who kill them: (Sh:) or, applied to a serpent, i. q. A^aroqa$u [q. v.] : (Mgh:) or the male serpent: (K:) the female is not so called, nor is she called raqomaA='u; (TA;) but she is called raqo$aA='u: (K, TA:) when you use the epithet, you say A^aroqa$u; but A^aroqamu is [used as] a subst: (Ibn- Habeeb:) the pl. is A^araAqimu, (JK, ISd,) a pl. proper to substs., because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- See also miroqamN. ― -b3- For the fem., raqomaA='u, see raqimN, in two places.

taroqiymN * inf. n. of 2 [q. v.]. ― -b2- Also, [as a subst.,] A certain sign, or mark, of the keepers of the register of the [tax, or tribute, termed] xaraAj, (K, TA,) conventionally used by them, (TA,) put upon [the notes, or billets, or petitions, termed] riqaAE [pl. of ruqoEapN, q. v.], and upon [the writings termed] tawoqiyEaAt [pl. of tawoqiyEN, q. v.], and upon accounts, or reckonings, lest it should be imagined that a blank has been left [to be afterwards filled up], in order that no account be put down therein; as also taroqiynN. (K.)

miroqamN *
A writing-reed; (K) because it is an instrument for Alr~aqom, i. e. writing: (TA:) also
called ↓ A^aroqamu [app. because partly blackened with ink]. (Z, TA.) One says to him who is vehemently angry, (K, TA,) extravagantly, or immoderately, so, (TA,) TagaA miroqamuka, (assumed tropical:) [signifying Thy pen has exceeded its due limit], (K, TA,) in some of the lexicons TamaA, (TA,) and jaA$a mrqmk, (K,) and EalaA, or galaA, accord. to different copies of the K, and faADa, (TA,) and TafaHa, and AirotafaEa, and qa*afa mrqmk: (K, TA:) all [virtually] meaning the same. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A thing with which bread is marked (yunoqa$u); (TA;) like minosagapN; in Pers. called Pari naAno [i. e. a feather, or bundle of feathers, with which bread is pricked by the maker]: pl. maraAqimu. (MA.)
muraq~amN * : see maroquwmN: ― -b2- and raqomN.

muraq~imN *
A writer; as also muraq~inN.

maroquwmN *
Written; (S, Msb, TA;) as also ↓ raqiymN: (Msb:) and sealed, stamped, imprinted, or impressed: (S:) and a writing marked with the dots, or points, (JK, TA,) and having its letters made distinct, or plain: [i. e. distinctly written:] and ↓ muraq~amN signifies the same: (TA:) the first occurs in the Kur [lxxxiii. 9 and 20], in the phrase kitaAbN maroquwmN, (S, TA,) meaning, in both instances, [as some say, a writing] sealed, or stamped. (Jel.) ― -b2- See also raqomN. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A beast having small marks of cauterization upon his shanks; every one of which is termed raqomapN: (JK, T, TA:) or daAb~apN maroquwmapN means (assumed tropical:) a beast having lines of cauterization upon its legs. (K.) It is also applied as an epithet to a wild ass, because of a blackness upon his legs: (TA:) or maroquwmu AlqawaAy^imi, so applied, and applied to a [wild] bull, means (tropical:) Having lines of black upon his legs. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And maroquwmapN (tropical:) Land (A^aroDN) in which is little herbage: (Fr, S, K, TA:) or in which is the plant called raqomap. (JK.)
1 raqaA * , aor. yaroquw, inf. n. raqowN, said of a bird, It rose, or rose high, in its flight. (Msb, TA.)
taroquwapN A^rq rqY rqy trqY trqwh trqwp , mentioned in this art. in the K, as well as in art. trq: see the latter art.

1 raqiYa * , aor. yaroqaY, inf. n. ruqiY~N (JK, K, TA, [but this inf. n. is omitted in the CK,]) and raqoYN, (K, TA, [but this is omitted in my MS. copy of the K,]) He ascended, A_ilayohi [to him, or it]; as also ↓ ArtqY, and ↓ trq~Y: (K:) or he ascended a ladder, or a stair: (JK:) or raqiytu fiyhi, (S, Msb, in the Mgh raqiYa fyh,) inf. n. ruqiY~N (S, Mgh, Msb) and raqoYN; (S, Msb;) and ↓ Artqyt, (S, Mgh, * Msb,) and ↓ trq~yt; (Mgh, * Msb;) I ascended it; (S;) namely, a ladder, or a stair, (S, Mgh, Msb,) &c.: (Msb:) and raqiytu Aljabala (Msb,) and Als~aToHa, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) the verb being thus trans. by itself, (Msb, TA,) without fiY (Mgh,) and likewise with fY, (TA,) I ascended, or mounted, upon the mountain, and upon the house-top: (Msb:) and ↓ ArtqY is in like manner trans. without fY; whence the saying, laqadi SaEobFA ↓ A@rotaqayota murotaqFY [Thou hast indeed ascended a difficult place of ascent]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Airoqa EalaY ZaloEika Ascend thou, and go, [according to thy limping, or halting, i. e.] as far as thou art able to do so, and impose not upon thyself that which thou art not able to perform. (S, TA. [Some, instead of Airoqa, say AiroqaA^o; and some, Airoqi, from the verb mentioned in the next sentence; and some, q: see 1 in art. rqA^; and see also art. ZlE.]) -A2- raqaAhu, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yaroqiY, (JK, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. ruqoyapN (JK, S, Mgh, K) and raqoY (JK, Mgh, Msb, * K) and ruqiY~N (K,) He charmed him, syn. Eaw~a*ahu, (JK, Mgh, Msb,) by [invoking] God: (Msb:) and (Mgh) he puffed, or sputtered, upon his charm; syn. nafava fiY Euw*atihi: (Mgh, K:) [it signifies he charmed him from, or against, such a thing; (mino ka*aA;) and also he enchanted him, or fascinated him; by uttering a spell; or by tying knots in a thread, or string, and puffing, or sputtering, upon them; or by both these actions combined: see the last chap. but one of the Kur-án:] the epithet applied to the performer is ↓ raAqK [meaning Charming; &c.]; (S, Mgh, TA;) and ↓ raq~aA='N [A charmer; &c.; or one who habitually practises charming; &c.]: (JK, K, TA:) and the epithet applied to the person who is the object of the performance is ↓ maroqiY~N [meaning Charmed; &c.]. (JK, TA.) In the saying Airoqi EalaY raA^osiY mina AlS~udaAEi, meaning Charm thou me (Eaw~i*oniY [or rather charm thou my head against the headache]), the verb is made trans. by means of ElY because it is as though it implied the meaning of Aiqor~A^o [i. e. “ recite thou ” a spell] and Aunofuvo [i. e. “ puff, ” or “ sputter, ” upon knots]. (Mgh.)

2 riq~Ahu * , inf. n. taroqiyapN, He made him to ascend; syn. SaE~adahu. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse of ElAashà cited in art. vmn, voce vamaAnuwna.] ― -b2- [And hence, He elevated, or exalted, him.] ― -b3- [Hence also,] raq~aY Ealayohi kalaAmFA, inf. n. as above, i. q. rafaEa [meaning He told, or related, a saying against him; he informed against him; as is indicated by what next follows, and by a meaning of trq~Y as quasi-pass. of rq~Y thus used]. (S, K.) You say also, rq~Y EalaY AlbaATila, inf. n. as above, He brought a false accusation against me; said, against me, what was not the case; and exaggerated [in what he said against me]. (JM, TA.)

5 taraq~aYa see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] trq~Y fiYi AlEilomi He rose by degrees, or step by step, in knowledge, or science. (S, TA.) And hence, maA zaAla yataraq~aY bihi AlHaAlu Hat~aY balaga gaAyatahu The state, or condition, ceased not to rise with him until he reached the utmost point thereof. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also, the verb being quasi-pass. of 2,] trq~Y A_ilayohi AlxabarN The news, or information, came to him, or reached him. (MA.)
6 trAqY * [meaning He exalted himself] is from Alr~uqiY~u signifying AlS~uEuwdu and AlAirotifaAEu. (Har p. 128.)
8 A_irotaqaYa see 1, first sentence, in three places. ― -b2- [Hence,] ArtqY baTonuhu His belly became [drawn up, i. e.] lean, or lank; syn. AinoTawaY: said of a camel, and of a sheep or goat. (JK.)

10 AstrqAhu *
He asked him, or desired him, to charm him. (S, * TA.)

ruqoyapN *
i. q. Euw*apN [as meaning A charm, or spell, either uttered or written], (K, TA,) by which a person having an evil affection, such as fever and epilepsy &c., is charmed: (TA:) when it is in any other language than that of the Arabs, and one knows not what is in it, it is disapproved, lest it should involve enchantment (siHor) and infidelity; but in such as is from the Kur-án or any of the forms of prayer, there is no harm: (Mgh in art. tm: [see tamiymapN:]) [but Euw*apN generally signifies “ an amulet to charm the wearer against the evil eye &c. ”:] 'Orweh says,
famaA tarakaA mino Euw*apK yaEorifaAnihaA
walaA ruqoyapK A_il~aA bihaA raqayaAniY
[And they two left not any amulet that they knew, nor any charm, or spell, but with it they charmed me]: (TA:) [sometimes, also, it signifies anything by which one enchants, or fascinates: and hence it is said,] AlmaroA^apu ruqoyapN [Woman is a thing by which one is enchanted, or fascinated]: (Msb:) pl. ruqFY. (S, Msb, K.)

ruqoyaA * [The act, or practice, or art, of charming: and also, of enchanting, or fascinating; i. e. enchantment, or fascination:] the subst., (Msb,) of the measure fuEolaY, from raqaAhu, aor. yaroqiyhi. (Msb, TA.)
ruqiy~apN * [Ascent; or the act of ascending;] the subst. from raqiYa aor. yaroqaY. (TA.)

raq~aA='N *
One who ascends mountains much or often. (TA.) -A2- See also 1, last sentence but one.

raAqK * : see 1, last sentence but one. The saying in the Kur [lxxv. 27], mano raAqK [Who is one that charms?] means that there is no charmer that shall charm him and protect him: or, accord. to I'Ab, the meaning is, who is he that ascendeth with his soul? shall the angels of mercy [ascend with it] or the angels of punishment? (TA.) In the saying of a rájiz,
laqado Ealimota waAlA^ajal~i AlbaAqiY
A^ano lano yarud~a Alqadara Alr~awaAqiY
[the meaning may be, Assuredly thou knowest, by the Most Majestic, the Everlasting, that the female charmers will not repel, or avert, that which is decreed; or, that the potent charmers will not &c.: for] the pl. may be that of ↓ raAqiyapN as an epithet applied to a woman, or of this
same word as an intensive epithet applied to a man. (S.)
raAqiyapN * ; pl. rawaAqK (with the article Alr~awaAqiY): see what next precedes.

maroqFY *
A place of ascent; as also ↓ murotaqFY; (Msb, TA;) and so ↓ maroqaApN and ↓ miroqaApN: (Msb:) or ↓ these last two signify a series of steps or stairs; or a ladder; syn. darajapN; (S, K;) and sul~amN; (M and K in art. slm;) the former of them as being a place of ascent, and the latter of them as being likened to an instrument; (S, Msb;) and both of them are authorized by the M; (TA;) but the latter of them is disallowed by A'Obeyd, and said by him to be not of the language of the Arabs: (Msb, TA:) the pl. of ↓ miraqaApN [and of maroqFY] is maraAqK. (TA.) You say jabalN laA maroqaY fiyhi and ↓ lA murotaqaY (JK, TA) A mountain in which is no place of ascent. (TA.)

maroqiyaA AlA^anofi * [in my MS. copy of the K muroqiyaA] The two edges [or alœ] of the nose: (K, TA:) so says Th; but the expression commonly known is maraq~aA AlA^anofi, mentioned before [in art. rq]. (TA.)
maroqaApN * and miroqaApN: see maroqFY, in four places.
maroqiY~N * : see 1, last sentence but one.
murotaqFY * : see maroqFY, in two places; and see an ex. in the first sentence of this article.

1 rak~a * , (S, K,) aor. yarik~u, (K, JM, TA, in the CK yarak~u,) inf. n. rakaAkapN (K, JM) [and app. rukuwkapN, q. v. infrà,] and rak~N, (CK, [but not in the TA nor in my MS. copy of the K,]) or rk~p [i. e. rik~apN, like riq~apN and diq~apN, with both of which it is syn.], (JM,) It (a thing, S) was, or became, weak, or feeble; syn. DaEufa: and thin, or of little thickness or depth; syn. raq~a: (S, K:) [and little, or small, in quantity; and slender: and (assumed tropical:) feeble, or weak, and incorrect; said of a word or an expression: (see the part. n. rakiykN:) and (assumed tropical:) unsound, invalid, or incorrect; said of information, an announcement, &c.; as is shown by what follows.] Hence the saying, AiqoTaEohu mino Hayovu rak~a [Cut thou it off from where it is weak, or thin]: for which the vulgar say, mn Hyv raq~a. (S.) [And hence also the saying,] fiY h`*aA Alxabari rakaAkapN (assumed tropical:) In this information, announcement, piece of news, or narration, is unsoundness, invalidity, or incorrectness; and so, fiyhi ravaAvapN. (A and TA in art. rv.) -A2- rak~a Al$~aYo'a baEoDahu EalaY baEoDK, (S,) or simply rak~ahu, aor.
raku3a , (K,) inf. n. rak~N, (TA,) He threw one part of the thing upon another. (S, K.) ― -b2- rakakotu Algul~a fiY Eunuqihi, aor.
raku3a , inf. n. rak~N, [I put the gul~ (or iron collar) upon his neck, and inserted his hand in it; or] I confined his hand to his neck by means of the gul~. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence,] rakakotu Al*~anoba fiY Eunuqihi i. q. A^alozamotuhu A_iy~aAhu (assumed tropical:) [I attached to him responsibility for the sin, crime, or misdeed]. (S, K. *) And rakakotu h`*aA AlHaq~a fiY Eunuqihi [in like manner] means A^alozamotuhu A_iy~aAhu (assumed tropical:) [I attached to him responsibility for the rendering of this right, or due]. (Lth, TA.) ― -b4- And rak~a AlA^amora, aor.
raku3a , inf. n. rak~N, i. q. rad~a baEoDahu EalaY baEoDK (assumed tropical:) [He reversed the order of parts, or of the parts, of the affair, or case]. (TA.) -A3- rak~a Al$~aYo'a biyadihi, (IDrd, K,) [aor.
raku3a ,] inf. n. rak~N, (IDrd, TA,) He felt the thing, or pressed it lightly, with his hand, in order that he might know its bulk. (IDrd, K, * TA.) ― -b2- And rak~a AlmaroA^apa, (IDrd, K,) inf. n. as above, (IDrd, TA,) He compressed the woman, and distressed her, or fatigued her, in so doing; (IDrd, K, * TA:) and so bak~ahaA, inf. n. bak~N; and dak~ahaA, inf. n. dak~N. (IDrd, TA.) -A4- rak~a A@ll~`hu namaA='ahu God lessened, or diminished, or may God lessen, or diminish, his, or its, increase. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)
2 rak~a3a see 4, in two places.

4 A^arak~ati Als~amaA='u *
The sky rained such rain as is termed rik~; (S, K;) as also ↓ rak~akat. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- And A^urik~ati AlA^aroDu The land was rained upon with such rain as is termed rik~, (S,) or with such rains as are termed rikaAk; as also ↓ ruk~ikat. (TA.)

8 Artk~ * , (K,) inf. n. AirotikaAkN, (TA,) [He was indistinct in his speech; said of a drunken man: (see its part. n., murotak~N, below:) or,] though seen to be eloquent [when alone (see again the part. n.)], he was impotent in speech in a case of altercation: (K:) or he was, or became, weak, or feeble; (TA;) [like rak~a.] ― -b2- Artka fiY A^amorihi He doubted in, or respecting, his affair, or case. (Yaakoob, K.) ― -b3- Artka is also syn. with Airotaj~a [He, or it, was, or became, in a state of commotion or agitation; or of convulsion, or violent motion; or shook, quaked, or quivered]: (K:) accord. to Yaakoob, it is an instance of substitution [of k for j]. (TA.) One says, mar~a yarotak~u [He passed by in a state of commotion &c.]. (TA.)

10 Astrk~hu *
He esteemed him weak, or feeble. (S, K.)

R. Q. 1 rakoraka *
He was, or became, cowardly, or weak-hearted. (IAar, TA.) [See also rakorakapN, its inf. n., below.]

R. Q. 2 tarakorukuhu * , (K,) relating to a skin [of milk], (TA,) means tamax~uDuhu [i. e. Its being agitated] with the butter. (K, TA. [In the CK, tarakorakahu and tamax~aDahu are put for tarakorukuhu and tamax~uDuhu.])
rak~N * : see the next paragraph.

rik~N * , with kesr, Lean, or emaciated: mentioned by J [and in the K] in art. zk, [and there written zak~,] but Sgh says that this is a mistranscription, and that it is correctly with r [and with kesr]; (TA in the present art.;) and Az says that zk~ is a mistake, and is correctly with r. (TA in art. zk.) -A2- Also, (S, K,) and ↓ rak~N and ↓ rakiykapN, (K,) Weak rain: (T, S:) or rain little in quantity: [and ↓ rak~apN is expl. in like manner by Freytag, as meaning pluvia tennis, pauca; but it seems to be a n. un. of rak~N, and so ↓ rik~apN of rik~N:] or exceeding what is termed dav~N [q. v.]: (K:) accord. to IAar, the first [or lightest and weakest] of rain is that called ra$~N; then, the Ta$~; then, the bago$; and then, the rik~: (TA:) or the Ta$~ exceeds the rik~: (TA in art. T$:) the pl. [of pauc. of rk~] is A^arokaAkN (K) and rikaAkN (S, K) and rik~aAnN; (Sgh, TA;) and the pl. of ↓ rakiykapN is rakaAy^iku. (TA.) ― -b2- rik~N applied to a land, or a place: see murak~N.
rak~apN * and rik~apN: see rik~N.
rukaAkN * : see the next paragraph.

rakiykN *
Weak, or feeble: (S, JM, KL:) so as applied to a man: (TA:) and thin, or of little thickness or depth: (JM:) anything little, or small, in quantity; and slender: applied to water [that is little in quantity, and shallow], and to herbage, and to science: (Sh, TA:) feeble, or weak, and incorrect; applied to a word or an expression; (PS in art. jzl;) contr. of jazolN: (S and K in that art.:) [and unsound, invalid, or incorrect; applied to information, an announcement, &c.: see 1.] You say vawobN rakiyku Aln~asoji A garment, or piece of cloth, weak in respect of texture. (S, * TA.) And A_in~ahu yubogiDu AlwulaApa Alr~akakapa [Verily he hates weak rulers, or magistrates]: occurring in a trad.: rakakapN being pl. of rakiykN, like as [its syn.] DaEafapN is pl. of DaEiyfN. (TA. [See also a similar saying in what follows.]) And rajulN rakiyku AlEilomi, (K,) and AlEaqoli, (TA,) A man having little knowledge, (K,) and intelligence. (TA.) And rakiykN and ↓ rukaAkN, (K,) the latter of which has a stronger signification than the former, like TuwaAlN in relation to TawiylN, (TA,) and ↓ rukaAkapN, (K,) which has a still stronger signification, (TA,) and ↓ A^arak~u, (K,) all applied to a man, (TA,) signify Low, ignoble, vile, mean, sordid, or possessing no manly qualities; weak in his intellect, and in his judgment or opinion: or one who is not jealous (K, TA) of his wife; i. q. day~uwvN: (TA:) or one who is not revered, respected, or feared, by his wife, or his family: (K:) accord. to AZ, rakiykN and ↓ rukaAkapN signify one esteemed weak by the women, not revered or respected or feared by them, and not jealous of them: (TA:) the epithet similarly applied to a woman is rakiykN likewise, and ↓ rukaAkapN: and the pl. is rikaAkN. (K.) It is said in a trad., ↓ A_in~ahu laEana Alr~ukaAkapa, (S, * TA, [in one of my copies of the S written Alr~akaAkapa, and in the other copy without the vowel-signs,]) meaning Verily he cursed him who is not jealous of his wife. (S.) And in another trad., A_in~a A@ll~`ha yubogiDu ↓ Als~uloTaAna Alr~ukaAkapa, i. e. [Verily God hateth the sovereign, or ruling, power] that is weak. (TA.) ― -b2- rakiykapN, [fem. of rakiykN,] as an epithet applied to land: see murak~N. -A2- Also Felt, or pressed [lightly with the hand; see 1]; and so ↓ marokwkN. (TA.)
rukaAkapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in five places.
rukuwkapN * [app. an inf. n., see 1, first sentence,] Weakness, or feebleness. (TA. [See also rakorakapN.])
rakiykapN * , as a subst., see rik~N, in two places.

$aHomuhu Alr~uk~aY * , (so in one of my copies of the S, and in the O, and in my MS. copy of the K,) or $aHomapu Alr~uk~aY, (so in one of my copies of the S, and in the TA and CK,) meaning [His fat is, or a piece of fat of,] such as melts quickly, is a prov., (S, O, K,) applied to him who does not fatigue, or weary, thee, (laA yuEan~iyka, so in my copies of the S, or laA yuEoniyka, so in the O,) or to him who does not aid thee, (laAyuEiynuka, so in the TA and CK, [in my MS. copy of the K it reads either lA yuEnyk or lA yuEynk,]) in needful affairs, (S, O, K,) nor avail thee, or profit thee, or stand thee in any stead. (O, TA.) [See also ruq~aY, voce A^araq~u.] ― -b2- Accord. to AA, ruk~aY signifies A wide Eafolaq [or vulva, or flabby vulva]. (O, TA.)
rak~aA='u * The sound of the echo, (K, TA,) which it returns to one from the mountain, imitating what one utters. (TA.)
rakorakapN * [inf. n. of R. Q. 1,] Weakness, or feebleness, in anything. (K. [See also rukuwkapN.])
rakoraAkapN * A woman large in the posteriors and thighs. (S, K.)
A^arak~u * : see rakiykN.

murak~N EalayohaA * , applied to land (A^aroDN), Rained upon with such rain as is termed rik~; (K;) as also murak~apN, alone, and ↓ murak~akapN (TA) and ↓ rakiykapN, (K,) the last two meaning also rained upon by such rain as is termed rik~ and containing but little pasturage, (TA,) and ↓ rik~N, (K,) which last is mentioned by ISh, and explained as meaning a place upon which has fallen only a little, or weak, rain. (O.)
murak~akapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
marokuwkN * A siqaA=' [or skin for milk or water] dressed, or prepared, (Euwlija,) and put into a good, or proper, state. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also rakiykN, last sentence.

murotak~N * A soft, or flabby, camel, having diluted marrow (mamo*uwqu Aln~iqoYi). (O, K. [In the CK, Aln~aqiY~u is erroneously put for Aln~iqoYi; and in my MS. copy of the K, AlnqY~.]) ― -b2- And A drunken man indistinct in his speech: (S:) or a man seen to be eloquent (K, TA) when alone, (TA,) but impotent in speech when he engages in altercation. (K, * TA.)

1 rakibahu * , (S, * A, K,) and rakiba Ealayohi, (A,) aor.
rakaba , (A, K,) inf. n. rukuwbN (S, A, K) and marokabN; (A, K;) and ↓ Artkbhu; (K;) I. q. EalaAhu (A, K, TA) and EalaA Ealayohi [explained by what follows]. (TA.) You say, rakibotu Ald~aAb~apa, (Msb,) or Alfarasa, (Mgh,) and rakibotu EalayohaA, [or Ealayohi,] inf. n. rukuwbN and marokabN [as above, meaning I rode, or rode upon, and I mounted, or mounted upon, the beast, or the horse]. (TA. [See also raAkibN.]) [And rakibotu Als~afiynapa, or fiY Als~afiynapi (agreeably with the Kur xi. 43 and xviii. 70 and xxix. 65), I embarked in the ship; went on board the ship.] And one says, of anything, rakibahu [and ↓ Artkbh] as meaning EalaAhu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, upon, or over, it; got upon it; came, or arose, upon it; overlay it; was, or became, superincumbent, or supernatant, upon it; overspread it]; namely, another thing. (TA.) [In like manner,] one says also, of anything, rukiba and ↓ Aurotukiba as meaning EuliYa [i. e., when said of a horse or the like, He was ridden, or ridden upon, and was mounted, or mounted upon: whence other significations in other cases, indicated above]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rakiba baEoDuhu baEoDFA i. q. ↓ trAkb (tropical:) [It lay one part upon another; it was, or became, heaped, or piled, up, or together, one part upon, or overlying, another:] said of fat [as meaning it was, or became, disposed in layers, one above another: see raAkibapN]. (A, TA.) [And hence, rakiba Aln~aAsu baEoDuhumo baEoDFA (assumed tropical:) The people bore, or pressed, or crowded, (as though mounting,) one upon another; a phrase well known, and of frequent occurrence: or meaning (assumed tropical:) the people followed one another closely; from what next follows.] ― -b3- rakibahu also means [(assumed tropical:) He came upon him, or overtook him; or] he followed closely, or immediately, after him: and rakibotu A^avarahu and Tariyqahu (assumed tropical:) I followed close after him. (L.) ― -b4- [rakiba AlT~ariyqa, and Alr~amola, and AlmafaAzapa, (assumed tropical:) He went upon, or trod, or travelled, the road, and the sand or sands, and the desert: and rakiba AlbaHora (assumed tropical:) He embarked, or voyaged, upon the sea. Hence,] rakiba All~ayola, and Alhawola, (tropical:) [He ventured upon, encountered, or braved, the night, and that which was terrible or fearful,] and the like thereof. (TA.) [And rakiba A^amorFA and ↓ Artkbhu (assumed tropical:) He ventured upon, embarked in, or undertook, an affair: and (assumed tropical:) he surmounted it, or mastered it: the former meaning is well known: the latter is indicated by an explanation of the phrase rak~aAbN liloA^umuwri, which see below.] And rakiba *anobFA (A, K) and ↓ Artkbhu (S, A, MA, K) (tropical:) He committed a sin, or crime, or the like. (S, MA, TA.) And rakiba fulaAnN fulaAnFA biA^amorK (assumed tropical:) [Such a one did to such a one a thing]. (TA.) And rakibahu bimakoruwhK and ↓ Artkbhu (tropical:) [He did to him an evil, or abominable, or odious, deed]. (A.) And rakibotu Ald~ayona and ↓ Artkbthu (tropical:) I became much in debt: and rakibaniY Ald~ayonu and ↓ ArtkbnY (tropical:) [Debt burdened me]. (Msb.) ― -b5- rakiba raA^osahu (tropical:) He went at random, heedlessly, or in a headlong manner, (maDaY EalaY wajohihi, A, Msb,) [i. e.,] without consideration, (A,) or without any certain aim, or object, (Msb,) not obeying a guide to the right course. (A.) You say, yurokabu raA^osahu laA yadoriY A^ayona yatawaj~ahu (assumed tropical:) [He goes at random, &c., not knowing whither to direct himself]. (S and K in art. kmh.) [See also rakobapN. In like manner also, you say, rakiba raA^oyahu (K voce Aisotahaj~a &c.) (assumed tropical:) He followed his own opinion. And rakiba hawaAhu (S in art. jmH) (assumed tropical:) He followed his own natural desire, without consideration, and not obeying a guide to the right course of conduct.] ― -b6- rakibotu dub~atahu and dub~ahu (assumed tropical:) I kept to his state, or condition, and his way, mode, or manner, of acting &c.; and did as he did. (M in art. db.) And rakibatohu AlHum~aY (assumed tropical:) [The fever continued upon him] is a phrase similar to A^agobaTatohu AlHum~aY and AimotaTatohu and AirotaHalatohu. (A and TA in art. gbT) -A2- rakabahu, aor.
rakuba , (S, A, K,) inf. n. rakobN, (TA,) [from rukobapN,] He struck, or smote, his knee: (S, A, K:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (S, A,) he struck him, or smote him, with his knee: (S, A, K:) or he took him by his hair, (K,) or by the hair of each side of his head, (TA,) and struck his forehead with his knee. (K, TA.) Hence, in a trad., rakabotu A^anofahu birukobatiY I struck his nose with my knee. (TA.) And in another trad., A^amaA taEorifu AlA^azoda warakobahaA Ait~aqi AlA^azoda laA yaA^oxu*uwka fayarokubuwka [Knowest thou not El-Azd, (the tribe so called,) and their striking with the knee? Beware thou of El-Azd, lest they take thee, and strike thee with their knees]: for this practice was notorious among El-Azd; in the dial. of whom, A^um~u kayosaAna was a metonymical appellation of the knee. (TA.) -A3- rukiba, like EuniYa, [pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] He (a man) had a complaint of his knee. (TA.) -A4- rakiba, aor.
rakaba , (K,) inf. n. rakabN, (TA,) He was large in the knee. (K.)

2 rk~bhu Alfarasa * , [inf. n. as below,] He lent him the horse, [or mounted him on the horse,] to go forth on a warring and plundering expedition, on the condition of receiving from him one half of the spoil: (K, * TA:) or for a portion of the spoil that he should obtain. (TA.) [See also 4.] ― -b2- And rk~bhu, inf. n. tarokiybN, He put, or set, one part of it upon another: (K:) [he set it, or fixed it, in another thing: he composed it; constituted it; or put it together.] tarokiybN signifies The putting together, or combining, things, whether suitable or not, or placed in order or not: it is a more general term than taA^oliyfN, which is the collecting together, or putting together, suitable things. (Kull p. 118.) You say, rak~aba AlfaS~a fiY AlxaAtami (S, A) He set the stone in the signet-ring: and rk~b Als~inaAna fiY AlqanaApi He fixed the spearhead in the shaft; (A;) and Aln~aSola fiY Als~ahomi [the arrow-head in the shaft]. (S.) And $aYo'N Hasanu Alt~arokiybi [A thing good, or beautiful, in respect of composition or constitution; well, or beautifully, composed or constituted or put together]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also He removed it from one place to another in which to plant it; namely, a shoot of a palm-tree. (Mgh.)

4 Arkb *
He (a colt) became fit for being ridden; attained to the fit time for being ridden. (S, Msb, K.) [See also murokibN.] -A2- Arkbhu He gave him, appointed him, or assigned him, an
animal on which to ride. (S.) [See also 2.] ― -b2- A^arokabaniY xalofahu [He mounted me, or made me to ride, behind him]. (A.) And A^arokabaniY marokabFA faArihFA [He mounted me on a quick, brisk, sharp, or strong, beast]. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence, Arkbhu A^amorFA (assumed tropical:) He made him to venture upon, embark in, or undertake, an affair. And Arkbhu *anobFA (assumed tropical:) He made him to commit a sin, or crime, or the like.]

5 trk~b *
It had one part of it put, or set, upon another; as also ↓ trAkb: (K:) [it was, or became, composed, constituted, or put together: see 2.] You say, trk~b AlfaS~u fiY AlxaAtami [The stone was set in the signet-ring]: and trk~b Aln~aSolu fiY Als~ahomi [The arrow-head was fixed in the shaft]. (S.)
6 trAkb * : see 1: and 5. You say, trAkb Als~aHaAbu The clouds were, or became, [heaped, or piled, up,] one above, or upon, [or overlying,] another; as also trAkm. (TA.)
8 A_irotakaba see 1, in eight places.
10 Astrkbhu faA^arokabahu * [He asked him to give him, appoint him, or assign him, an animal on which to ride, and he gave him, appointed him, or assigned him, one]. (A.)
rakobN * : see raAkibN, in three places.

rakabN * The EaAnap: (ISk, Msb, K:) or the place of growth of the EaAnap, (S, K,) or of the hair of the EaAnap: (Mgh:) [i. e. it signifies the pubes; either as meaning the hair of the mons Veneris, or the mons Veneris itself: generally the latter; and this is often meant by the term EAnp alone:] or the part that slopes down from the belly, and is beneath the vun~ap [q. v.] and above the pudendum: in all these senses said by Lh to be masc.: (TA:) or the pudendum (Az, Msb, K) itself: (TA:) or the external portion thereof: (K:) or the rakabaAni are the roots of the two thighs, upon which is the flesh of the pudendum, (K, TA,) or upon which are the two portions of flesh of the pudendum: (TA:) the rkb is masc.: (Msb:) it is common to the man and the woman, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) accord. to Fr: (S, Msb:) or peculiar to the woman, (S, Mgh, K,) accord. to Kh: (S:) ElFarezdak makes it plainly common to both, saying,
Hiyna A@ltaqaY Alr~akabu AlmaHoluwqu biAlr~akabi
[When the shaven pubes met the pubes]: (TA: [and a similar ex. is given in the S and Msb, as cited by Fr:]) the pl. is A^arokaAbN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and A^araAkiybu; (K;) the latter being pl. of the former; but in some copies of the K A^araAkibu, like masaAjidu. (TA.) -A2- Also Whiteness in the rukobap [or knee]. (TA.)

rakobapN *
A single ride, or act of riding: pl. rakabaAtN. (IAth, L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, huwa yamo$iY Alr~akobapa (tropical:) [i. e. yarokabu raA^osahu He goes at random, heedlessly, or in a headlong manner, &c., (see 1,)] and humo yamo$uwna Alr~akabaAti (tropical:) [They go at random, &c.]. (A. [The meaning is there indicated by the context, and is shown by what here follows.]) Respecting the phrase tmo$uwna Alr~akabaAti, occurring in a trad., meaning tarokabuwna ruw^uwsakumo (assumed tropical:) [Ye go at random, &c.], in that which is false, wrong, or vain, and in factions, or seditions, or the like, following one another without consideration, IAth says that rakobapN [properly] signifies as explained above in the first sentence of this paragraph, and that the pl. AlrkbAt is here governed in the accus. case by a verb understood, and [with that verb] is a denotative of state relating to the agent in tm$wn: it supplies the place of that verb, which it does not require to be expressed; and the implied meaning is tamo$uwna tarokabuwna Alr~akabaAti. (L.)

rukobapN * a word of well-known meaning, (S, Msb,) [The knee; i. e., in a man,] the joint between the lower parts of the thigh and the upper parts of the shank: (A, K:) or [in a quadruped,] the joint between the metacarpus and the radius (mawoSilu AlwaZiyfi waAl*~iraAEi): this is the right explanation: in the K, mawoDiE is erroneously put for mawoSil: [this explanation is evidently given accord. to the terms employed in the anatomy of quadrupeds as compared to human beings: in that which next follows, there is certainly an omission, which I have endeavoured to supply:] or the rukobataAni of the fore legs of the camel are the two joints that [project forwards, in like manner as do, in the hind legs, those that] are next the belly [meaning the stifle-joints] when he lies down upon his breast with folded legs: the two joints that project behind [in the hind legs, namely, the hocks,] are called the EuroquwbaAni: in every quadruped, the rkbtAn are in the fore legs, and the ErqwbAn are in the hind legs: and the Erqwb is what is called mawoSilu AlwaZiyfi [i. e. the upper joint of the metatarsus]: (TA:) or the rkbp is the mirofaq [which in a man is the elbow, but here seems to mean the lower joint] of the *iraAE [or radius] of anything [i. e. of any beast]: (K:) [from its being said in the S and Msb that the rukobap is “ well known, ” I conclude that there is no real discrepancy in the foregoing explanations: it is perhaps needless to add that the term rukobap is now universally applied to the knee of a man and to what we commonly call the knee of a horse and the like:] the pl. is rukabN, (S, Msb, K,) i. e. the pl. of mult., and the pl. of pauc. is rukobaAtN and rukabaAtN and rukubaAtN. (S.) Lh mentions the phrase baEiyrN musotawoqiHu Alr~ukabi [meaning A hardkneed camel]; as though the term rukobapN were applied to each part, and the pl. used accord. to this application. (TA.) ― -b2- One says [of an agitating affair or event], A^amorN A@SoTak~ato fiyhi Alr~ukabu waHak~ato fiyhi Alr~ukobapu Alr~ukabapa (tropical:) [An affair, or event, in which the knees knocked together, and in which the knee rubbed the knee]. (A.) ― -b3- And of one who has the mark of prostration in prayer on his forehead, between his eyes, (L,) bayona Eayonayohi mivolu rukobapi AlEanozi [Between his eyes is the like of the knee of the she-goat]. (A, * L.) And of any two things that are alike, or correspondent, humaA karukobataY AlEanozi [They are like the two knees of the she-goat]; because her two knees fall together upon the ground when she lies down. (L.) ― -b4- And it is said in a prov., $ar~u Aln~aAsi mano miloHuhu EalaY rukEbatihi [The worst of men is he whose fat is upon his knee]: applied to him who is quickly angered; and to the perfidious: (Meyd, TA:) the phrase miloHuhu EalaY rukobatihi is also used as meaning The smallest thing makes him angry: (TA:) and a poet says,
laA talumohaA A_in~ahaA mino EuSobapK
miloHuhaA mawoDuwEapN fawoqa Alr~ukabo
[Blame her not; for she is of a set of people whose fat is placed above the knees: perhaps meaning, for she is but a woman; as women are generally fat in the part above the knee]: (TA:) or mino nisowapK [in the place of mino EuSobapK], meaning of women whose object of anxiety, or care, is fatness and fat: (Meyd, TA:) so that the prov. seems to mean that the worst of men is he who has not such intelligence as bids him to do that which is praiseworthy, but only bids him to do that in which is inconstancy and levity, and an inclining to the dispositions of women, to the love of fatness and fat. (Meyd.) [See other explanations in art. mlH.] -A2- Also The lower part (A^aSol) of the plant Sil~iyaAnap, when it has been cut. (K.)

rikobapN *
A mode, or manner, of riding. (S.) You say, huwa Hasanu Alr~ikobapi He has a good mode, or manner, of riding. (A, * TA.) ― -b2- [It is said in the K to be a subst. from rakibahu; as though signifying A riding.]

rakabapN *
A company of riders upon camels, (K,) or of owners of camels on a journey, or travellers upon camels, exclusively of other beasts, (S,) but less in number than the company called rakobN: (S, K:) [and probably also a company of riders upon any beasts, but less than what is called rakobN:] accord. to MF, it is a pl. of raAkibN. (TA.) [See also A^urokuwbN.]
rakobaY * and rakobaApN: see rakuwbN.
rakabuwtN * and rakabuwtaY: see rakuwbN.
rakobaAnapN * : see rakuwbN, in two places.

rikaAbN * [Travelling-camels, used for riding; i. e.] camels (S, K, TA) upon which people journey; (S, TA;) i. q. maTiY~N: (Msb:) or camels fit for carrying: (Har p. 22:) it has no proper sing.: (S:) the word used for the sing. is raAHilapN: (S, Msb, K:) or, as ISh says, in the “ Book of Camels, ” rikaAbN and EiyrN are applied to camels that go forth for corn (TaEaAm) to be brought back upon them, both when they go forth and after they have come back: and the former term is applied also to camels upon which people journey to Mekkeh, on which maHaAmil are borne: and hired [or other] camels that carry the goods and corn of merchants: but camels are not called Eyr, though bearing corn, [unless] if hired: [I insert
the words “ or other ” and “ unless ” because it is further said,] Eyr are not those that bring corn for their owners; but these are called rikaAbN: (L, TA:) the pl. is rukubN, (S, K,) accord. to A'Obeyd, (TA,) and rikaAbaAtN and rakaAy^ibu; (K;) or, accord. to IAar, rukubN is not pl. of rikaAbN; and others say that it is pl. of ↓ rakuwbN, signifying any beast on which one rides, [an epithet] of the measure faEuwlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; (TA;) but called by ISd a subst.; (TA voce jazuwzN;) and ↓ rakuwbapN is a more special term than rakuwbN. (TA in the present art.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rikaAbu Als~aHaAbi (tropical:) [The bearers of the clouds; i. e.] the winds. (A, K.) Umeiyeh says,
tarad~adu waAlr~iyaAHu lahaA rikaAbu
[It (referring to a cloud) goes to and fro (tarad~ad being for tatarad~adu), the winds being its bearers]. (TA.) -A2- Also [The stirrup of a horse's saddle;] a well-known appertenance of a horse's saddle; (S;) the same with respect to a horse's saddle as the garoz with respect to a camel's: pl. rukubN. (K.)

rakuwbN * and ↓ rakuwbapN: see rikaAbN: both signify A beast that is ridden: (S:) or a she-camel that is ridden: (K:) or the latter has this meaning: and is metaphorically applied to anything ridden: (Msb:) or the former signifies any beast that is ridden: and the latter is a name for everything that is ridden; applied to one, and to a pl. number: (TA:) or the former signifies ridden, as a fem. epithet: and the latter, one specially appointed for riding; and that is constantly kept to work; of beasts (K, TA) of any kind: (TA:) and the latter and ↓ rakobaAnapN and ↓ rakobaApN and ↓ rakabuwtN (K) and ↓ rakobaY and ↓ rakabuwtaY, (K * and TA in art. Hlb, [see HaluwbN in several places,]) a she-camel that is ridden; or that is broken, trained, or rendered submissive or manageable: (K:) or rakuwbN has this last signification, accord. to AZ: and its pl. is rukubN: (TA:) the pl. of rakuwbapN being rakaAy^ibu: (TA voce jazuwzN:) and ↓ rakobaAnapN signifies [also] a she-camel fit to be ridden; (S, TA;) like as HalobaAnapN signifies fit to be milked: the A and n are [said to be] added in order to give intensiveness to the signification: (TA:) [and all the other epithets mentioned above seem also, accord. to some, to have an intensive sense: see HaluwbN.] You say, maA lahu rakuwbapN walaA HamuwlapN walaA HaluwbapN He has not a she-camel to ride, nor one to carry burdens, nor one to be milked. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also baEiyrN rakuwbN A camel having marks of galls, or sores, on his back, produced by the saddle. (TA.) ― -b3- And TariyqN rakuwbN A road ridden upon, (S, TA,) and trodden so as to be rendered even, or easy to be travelled. (TA.) -A2- See also rak~aAbN.

rakiybN * One who rides with another; a fellowrider. (K.) rakiybu Als~uEaApi, mentioned in a trad., and there promised a place in Hell, means He who accompanies tyrannical Eum~aAl [or collectors of the poor-rates]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also marak~abN. ― -b3- naxolN rakiybN (K) and rakiybN mino naxolK (TA) Palmtrees planted in a row by a rivulet, or not by a rivulet. (K, TA.) -A2- Also A ma$aArap, (K,) i. e. saAqiyap [or channel of water for irrigation]: (TA:) or a rivulet between [two pieces of sown ground such as are termed] daborataAni: (K:) or between two gardens of palm-trees and grape-vines: (so accord. to the text of the K in the TA:) or what is between two gardens of palm-trees and grape-vines: (so accord. to the CK and my MS. copy of the K:) or grape-vines between two rivers or rivulets: (TA:) or a place of seed-produce: (K:) or a clear, or cleared, piece of land, in which one sows: (T:) pl. rukubN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^aholu Alr~akiybi The people who stay, or dwell, by water; syn. AlHuD~aAru. (TA.)
rukayobN * dim. of rakobN. (TA.) See raAkibN.
rakuwbapN * : see rakuwbN.
zayotN rikaAbiY~N * [Olive-oil:] so called because brought on camels from Syria. (S, A, * K.)

rak~aAbN * and ↓ rakuwbN, applied to a man, (K, TA,) the latter on the authority of Th, (TA,) signify the same, (K, TA,) Who rides much; a great rider: and so rak~aAbapN applied to a woman. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rak~aAbN liloA^umuwri (assumed tropical:) A man who surmounts, or masters, affairs; [or who often does so; or accustomed to embark in, or undertake, or to surmount, or master, them; or who often embarks in, or undertakes, them, and therefore surmounts, or masters, them;] by his knowledge, and repeated experience, and good judgment. (K and TA in art. TlE.)
EalAhu Alr~uk~aAbu * (tropical:) The nightmare, or incubus, came upon him. (A.)
rak~aAbapN * : see the latter part of the next paragraph.

raAkibN *
Riding; or a rider: (Mgh, Msb, K:) or properly only a rider upon a camel: (ISk, S, K:) or the latter is its meaning when it is not used as a prefixed noun, as explained below; and is said to be the original signification: IB says that it may signify a rider upon a camel, ass, horse, or mule, when used as a prefixed noun; as when you say riAkibu jamalK and raAkibu HimaArK &c.: (L:) accord. to ISk, you term a rider upon an ass faArisN EalaY HimaArK, (S, TA,) and a rider upon a mule faArisN EalaY bagolK; (TA;) but 'Omarah says, I do not call the owner or rider of the ass fArs, but Ham~aArN; and the reason of his saying so is manifest, for fArs is an epithet of the measure faAEilN from Alfarasu “ the horse, ” meaning “ an owner, or a rider, of the horse: ” (S, TA:) the pl. is ruk~aAbN (S, K) and rukobaAnN (S, * Mgh, Msb, K) and rukuwbN (Mgh, K) and rikabapN, (K,) or this last is a mistake for rakabapN [q. v.], (MF, TA,) and ↓ rakobN, (Akh, Msb, K, TA,) as some say; (TA;) or this last is a quasi-pl. n., (K, TA,) not a broken pl. of raAkibN; (TA;) and signifies riders upon camels; (K;) or owners of camels on a journey, or travellers upon camels; (S;) consisting of ten or more: (S, K:) and sometimes it signifies riders upon horses: (IB, K:) or riders upon horses and camels: (IB, L, TA:) or a company of riders upon horses; or upon horses and camels: (TA:) [or, accord. to Kh, riders upon any beasts: (De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Ar. p. 54 of the Arabic text:)] in the Kur viii. 43, Alr~akobu may signify the riders upon horses, or the riders upon camels, or the army composed of both these: (TA:) the pl. of rakobN is A^arokubN, (S, K,) [a pl. of pauc.,] and rukuwbN. (K.) Accord. to IB, you do not say A_ibilK ↓ rakobu nor rukobaAnu A_ibilK: but it is said that ruk~aAbu A_ibilK and ruk~aAbu xayolK &c. are allowable. (L.) An instance of rukobaAn as distinguished from furosaAn occurs in a verse cited as one of the exs. of the preposition bi. (TA.) ↓ rukayobN [properly signifying A small company of riders upon camels, &c.,] occurs as meaning collectors of the poorrates: it is the dim. of ↓ rakobN; and shows that this latter is not a pl. [properly speaking] of raAkibN; for, were it so, the word used as its dim. would be ruwayokibuwna. (TA.) [See also rakabapN, and A^urokuwbN.] ― -b2- [Also A person on board of a ship or boat: pl. ruk~aAbN.] You say ruk~aAbu Als~afiynapi (S, TA) The persons on board of the ship, or boat: and ruk~aAbu AlmaA='i the voyagers upon the water: and Ibn-Ahmar has used in this sense the pl. rukobaAnN; but it is said that this is not allowable; nor is A^urokuwbN; nor rakobN. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, and ↓ raAkuwbN, (assumed tropical:) A shoot germinating upon the trunk of a palm-tree, not having any root in the ground: (S:) or a shoot on the upper part of a palm-tree, hanging down, but not reaching the ground; and so ↓ raAkibapN and ↓ raAkuwbapN and ↓ rak~aAbapN: (K:) or, as some say, the last of these words is not thus applied, but means a woman “ who rides much: ” AHn, however, says that it signifies a palm-shoot, or the like thereof, growing forth at the top of the trunk of a palm-tree, and, in some instances, bearing with its mother; but when it is cut off, it is better for the mother: and raAkibN is also explained in the L as meaning small palm-trees that grow forth at the lower parts of large palmtrees: (TA:) or it means a shoot of a palm-tree not cut off from its mother: (Ham p. 66:) accord. to As, when a palm-shoot grows from the trunk, and does not adhere to the ground, it forms a vile kind of palm-tree; and the Arabs call it raAkibN and ↓ raAkuwbN: the pl. of this last [and of ↓ raAkuwbapN] is rawaAkiybu. (TA.) ― -b4- rukobaAnu Als~unobuli means (tropical:) What first appear, or grow forth, from the qunobuE, (A, K, TA,) i. e. the envelope of the grain, (TA,) of the ear of wheat. (K, TA.) ― -b5- raAkibN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The head [or summit] of a mountain (jabal), as in [most of] the copies of the K; in some of which is found Habol [or rope]. (TA.)

raAkibapN * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also sing. of rawaAkibu (TA) which signifies (tropical:) Streaks [or layers] of fat, (A, K, TA,) overlying one another, (K, TA,) in the fore part of a
camel's hump: those in the hinder part are called rawaAdifu, (A, K, TA,) of which the sing. is raAdifapN. (TA.)
raAkuwbN * and raAkuwbapN: see raAkibN, latter part, in four places.

A^arokabu *
Large in the rukobap [or knee]. (S, K.) ― -b2- A camel having one of his knees larger than the other. (S, K.)

A^urokuwbN *
A company of riders upon camels, (K,) or of owners of camels on a journey, or of travellers upon camels, exclusively of other beasts, (S,) but more in number than the company called rakobN: (S, K:) pl. A^araAkiybu. (TA.) [See also rakabapN.]

marokabN * an inf. n. of rakiba. (A, K, TA.) ― -b2- And also a noun of place [properly signifying A place of riding, &c.]. (TA.) [Hence, Anything upon which one rides; and upon, or in, which one is borne or carried:] one of the maraAkib of the land; and [more commonly] of the sea: (S, K:) [i. e.] a beast [on which one rides]; (A, TA;) and a vessel, i. e. a ship or boat: (A, Mgh, Msb, TA:) a saddle; and any kind of vehicle borne by a camel or other beast: (the lexicons passim:) maraAkibu is the pl. (Mgh, Msb.) You say, niEoma Almarokabu Ald~aAb~apu [Excellent, or most excellent, is the thing upon which one rides, the beast]. (A.) And jaA='ato maraAkibu Alyamani The vessels, or the ships or boats, of El-Yemen came. (A.) ― -b3- [And hence Almarokabu as the name of (assumed tropical:) The principal star (a) of Pegasus; because in the place of the saddle.]
murokibN * A colt that has become fit for being ridden. (TA.) And daAb~apN murokibapN A beast that has attained the age at which one may ride him during a warring and plundering expedition. (TA.)

murak~abN * A man to whom a horse is lent for a portion of the spoil that he may obtain: (IAar, TA:) or a man who borrows a horse upon which to go forth on a warring and plundering expedition, and who receives one half of the spoil, the other half being for the lender: (K:) or one to whom a horse has been given for him to ride, and who has put his foot into the stirrup. (A.) [Also] Weak in the art of horsemanship, or the management of horses, and the riding of them. (Ham p. 441.) ― -b2- [Also Put, or set, one part upon another: set, or fixed, in another thing: composed; constituted; or put together: see its verb, 2.] The stone [set] in the signet-ring is termed murak~abN and ↓ rakiybN; and so the arrowhead [fixed] in the shaft: (S:) or rakiybN signifies, (K, TA,) as a subst., (TA,) a thing set (murak~abN) in a thing, such as a ring-stone in the bezel, or collet, of the signet-ring. (K, * TA.) -A2- Also (tropical:) Origin: and place of growth or germination or vegetation. (S, K, TA.) You say, fulaAnN kariymu Almurak~abi (tropical:) Such a one is generous, or noble, in respect of the origin of his rank among his people. (S, A. *)

1 rakada * , (S, A, Msb,) aor.
rakuda , (Msb,) inf. n. rukuwdN, (S Msb, K,) It was, or became, still, or motionless; (S, A, Msb, K;) said of water: (S, A, Msb:) and fixed, or stationary. (K.) And in like manner, using the verb in the former sense, one says of the wind: (S, A:) [whence] one says also, rakudato riyHuhumo [lit. Their wind became still, or calm] meaning (tropical:) their good fortune ceased, and their affairs, or circumstances, began to retrograde by degrees: and [in like manner,] ↓ Tafiqato riyHuhumo tataraAkadu (tropical:) [their good fortune began to cease by degrees]. (A.) So too one says of the expressed juice of grapes, meaning It ceased to estuate. (L.) And of the heat, i. e. It remitted, or subsided. (L. [See also raqada.]) And rakadati Als~afiynapu The ship became still, or motionless, (S, * A, * Msb, TA,) or aground. (TA.) And rakada AlmiyzaAnu The balance was, or became, in a state of equilibrium. (S, A, K.) And rakadati Albakorapu The sheave of the pulley was, or became, fixed: and also the sheave of the pulley turned, or revolved: thus bearing two contr. significations. (L.) And rakadati Al$~amosu The sun was, or became, at its midday-height: (S:) or continued overhead; as though not quitting its place. (A.) And rakada Alqawomu The people were, or became, still, motionless, or silent. (S, A.)

4 Arkdhu *
He rendered it still, or motionless; namely, water [&c.]. (Msb.)
6 trAkd * [app., in its proper sense, It became still, or motionless, by degrees]. See 1.

jafonapN rakuwdN * (tropical:) A bowl that is full, (K,) or filled; (S;) or heavy; (A;) or filled and heavy. (L.) And naAqapN rakuwdN (tropical:) A she-camel whose supply of milk is constant, (A, K,) unceasing. (K.)

raAkidN * [Still, or motionless: and] anything remaining fixed in its place; stationary. (S.) You say maA='N raAkidN Water that is not running: and riyHN raAkidapN a wind becoming still, or calm; pl. riyaAHN rawaAkidu. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Alr~awaAkidu [and also, accord. to Reiske, as mentioned in Freytag's Lex., Alr~uk~adu,] The three pieces of stone upon which a cooking-pot is set: so called because they remain in their places. (L.)

maraAkidu * [pl. of marokadN, like marokazN,] Places in which a man, or some other thing, remains still, or motionless. (S, A, * L.) And Much depressed parts of the earth. (L.) Usámeh Ibn-Habeeb El-Hudhalee says, describing an ass [i. e. a wild ass] that had been chased by horses, or horsemen, and had fied for refuge to the mountains, whence, from their ravines, he saw the sky like streaks,
A^arotohu mina AljarobaA='i fiY kul~i mawoTinK
TibaAbFA famavowaAhu Aln~ahaAra AlmaraAkidu
[They (the ravines) showed him, in every spot where he stopped, streaks of the shy, and the much-depressed parts of the earth were his places of abode all the day]. (S, * L.) [J quotes this verse, in the S, but with manozilK in the place of mwTn, and maroEaAhu in the place of mvwAh, as an ex. of mrAkd in the former of the senses explained above.]

1 rakaza * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
rakuza (S, Msb, K) and
rakiza , (K,) inf. n. rakozN, (S, A, Msb,) He stuck, or fixed, a spear, (S, A, Msb, K,) and a stick, (A,) or some other thing, (TA,) into the ground, (S, A, Msb, K,) upright; (TA;) as also ↓ rk~z, (K,) inf. n. tarokiyzN. (TA.) You say also, rakaza AlHar~u Als~afaY, aor.
rakuza , inf. n. rakozN, The heat made the thornbushes fast in the ground [by hardening the soil]. (TA.) And rakaza A@ll~`hu AlmEaAdina fiY AljibaAli God fixed the metals, or minerals, in the mountains: (A, TA:) or caused them to exist therein. (K, * TA.) And rakaza AlmaAla, inf. n. as above, He buried the property. (TA.)
2 rak~aza see the preceding paragraph.

4 Arkz *
He (a man) found what is termed rikaAz: (S, A, * K:) or his mine yielded him abundance of silver &c.: (TA:) or he found a [quantity of gold or silver equal to a sum of money such as is termed] badorap, collected together, in the mine. (Es-Sháfi'ee, TA.) ― -b2- It (a mine) had in it what is termed rikaAz: (K:) or what is so termed was found in it. (IAar, TA.)

8 Artkz *
It (a spear) became stuck, or fixed, in the ground. (Msb.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He became fixed (K, * TA) in his place of abode. (TA.) You say, daxala fulaAnN faA@rotakaza fiY maHal~ihi laA yaboraHu (tropical:) [Such a one entered, and remained fixed in his place of abode, not quitting it]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Artkz EalaY Alqawosi (tropical:) He put the extremity of the bow upon the ground and leaned upon it. (S, A, * TA.) And Artkz ElY rumoHihi (assumed tropical:) He bore (taHaAmala) upon the head of his spear, leaning upon it, in order that he might die. (Mgh, from a trad.)

rikozN *
A sound: (Fr, TA:) or a low sound; (S, A, K;) i. q. His~N: (K:) or a sound that is not vehement: or the sound, or voice, of a man, which one hears from afar; such as that of the hunter talking to his dogs. (TA.) So in the Kur [xix. last verse], A^awotasomaEu lahumo rikozFA [Or dost thou hear a sound of them? &c.]. (S, TA.) [See fahara.] ― -b2- [Golius assigns to it also the signification of Beauty (pulchritudo); app. from his having found, in a copy of the K, waAlHusonu in the place of wAlHis~u.] -A2- Also An intelligent, forbearing, liberal or munificent, man: (AA:) or a learned, intelligent, liberal or munificent, generous, man. (K.)

rikozapN * : see riakaAzN. ― -b2- (tropical:) Firmness of understanding; (Fr, K;) strength thereof. (A, TA.) Fr says, I heard one of the Benoo-Asad say, kal~amotu fulaAnFA famaA raA^ayotu lahu rikozapF(tropical:) I spoke to such a one, and I found him not to have firmness of understanding. (TA.)

rikaAzN *
Metal, or other mineral; (A, Mgh, TA;) what God has caused to exist (rakazahu, i. e. A^aHodavahu,)
in the mines; (K;) meaning tibor that is created in the earth; (TA;) as also ↓ rakiyzapN: (K:) the former is pl. of ↓ rikozapN: (K:) or it is pl. of ↓ rakiyzapN: (Ahmad Ibn-Khálid, TA:) and pieces (K, TA) of large size, like [stones such as are called] jalaAmiyd, (TA,) of silver and of gold, (K, TA,) that are extracted from the earth, (TA,) or from the mine: (K, TA:) accord. to the people of El- 'Irák, any metals or other minerals: (TA:) or [so in the A and Mgh, and accord. to the TA, but in the K “ and, ”] buried treasure (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) of the people of the Time of Ignorance: (S, Msb, K:) the first of the significations given above is the primary one: and ancient wealth [buried in the earth] is likened to metals or minerals: or, accord. to certain of the people of El- Hijáz, it signifies specially property buried by men before the period of El-Islám; and not metals or other minerals. (TA.) It is said in a trad., that the fifth part of what is termed rikaAzN is for the government-treasury: (S, * TA:) or, accord. to another relation, of what is termed ↓ rakiyzN: as though it [the latter] were pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of ↓ rakiyzapN, or [the former] of ↓ rikaAzapN. (TA.)
rakiyzN * : see rikaAzN, last sentence.
rikaAzapN * : see rikaAzN, last sentence.
rakiyzapN * : see rikaAzN, in three places: -A2- see also marokazN.
raAkizN * A thing that is firm, or fixed. (Mgh.) [Hence,] one says, Eiz~uhumo raAkizN (tropical:) Their might, or glory, is firmly established. (A, TA.)

marokazN *
A place where a spear or other thing is stuck, or fixed, into the ground, upright: (TA:) a place of firmness, or fixedness. (Msb.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The place of a man; his place of alighting or abiding. (S, K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) The station of an army, or of a body of troops or soldiers, to which its occupants are commanded to keep. (K, TA.) You say, h`*aA marokazu Alxayoli (tropical:) [This is the fixed station of the cavalry]. (A.) Pl. maraAkizu. (A.) ― -b4- The centre of a circle. (S, K.) ― -b5- ↓ rakiyzapN signifies the same as marokazN [but in what sense I do not find pointed out]. (TA.)
A_in~ahu marokuwzN fiY AlEuquwli * (tropical:) [Verily it is firmly fixed in the minds, or understandings]. (A, TA.)

1 rakasahu * , (S, Msb,) aor.
rakusa , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. rakosN, (S, A, Msb, K,) He turned it over, or upside down; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A^arokasahu: (S:) or the former, (TA,) or ↓ latter, (Msb,) he turned it over upon its head: (Msb, TA:) and the former, he reversed it; made the first part of it to be last; or turned it fore part behind. (Lth, A, Msb, K.) It is said in the Kur [iv. 90], bimaA kasabuwA ↓ waA@ll~`hu A^arokasahumo Since God hath subverted them [for what they have done, or committed]; syn. tak~asahumo: (IAar, K:) or hath made them return to their unbelief; (Fr, S, K;) and rakasahumo signifies the same: (Fr, TA:) or hath separated, or dispersed, them, for what they have done of their disbelief, and acts of disobedience: (Jel:) rakasotu Al$~aYo'a and ↓ A^arokasotuhu both signify I separated the thing; or set it apart. (TA.) You say also, A@ll~`hu Eaduw~aka ↓ A^arokasa May God overturn thine enemy upon his head: or change, or reverse, the state, or condition, of thine enemy. (A.) And fiY Al$~ar~i ↓ A^arokasahu He turned him back, or caused him to return, to evil. (A.) And ↓ A^arokisi Alv~awoba fiY AlS~ibogi Return thou the garment, or piece of cloth, to the dyeing-liquor. (A.)
4 A^arokasa see 1, throughout.

8 Artks *
He, or it, became turned over, upside down, or upon his, or its, head; became inverted, subverted, or reversed; became turned fore part behind: (K, TA:) he returned, reverted, or went back, from one thing or state to another: (TA:) he fell. (K.) You say, Artks fulaAnN fiY A^amorK kaAna qado najaA minohu (S, A, TA) Such a one fell [again] into a case from which he had escaped. (TA.)

rikosN *
i. q. rijosN [Uncleanness, dirt, or filth; or an unclean, a dirty, or a filthy, thing]: (S, A, Msb, K:) and anything that is disliked, or hated, for its uncleanness, dirtiness, or filthiness; (Msb;) as also ↓ rakiysN: (TA:) the former is similar in meaning to rajiyEN [dung of a man, or of a horse and the like, or of a wild beast]; (A 'Obeyd, TA;) and ↓ rakiysN [also] is syn. with rajiyEN. (TA.)
rakiysN * : see marokuwsN, throughout: -A2- see also rikosN, in two places.

marokuwsN * A thing turned over, or upside down; turned over upon its head; turned fore part behind; as also ↓ rakiysN. (TA.) ― -b2- Turned, or sent, back, or away; as also ↓ the latter epithet. (TA.) ― -b3- One who goes back, or reverts, from his state or condition; like manokuwsN: (IAar, TA:) and ↓ the latter epithet (rkys), a weak person, who returns, or reverts, from one thing or state to another; syn. DaEiyfN murotakisN. (TA.)

1 rakaDa * , aor.
rakuDa , inf. n. rakoDN, He moved, (S, A, K,) or struck with, (Msb,) his leg, or foot: (S, A, Msb, K:) or he struck and hit therewith, like as one strikes and hits therewith a beast. (IAth.) Hence, (S, A, K,) the phrase in the Kur [xxxviii. 41], (S,) AurokuDo birijolika [Strike thou the ground with thy foot]: (S, A, K:) or strike thou, and tread, the ground with thy foot. (Sgh.) You say also, rakaDa Alr~ajulu (tropical:) The man struck the ground with his foot: and rakaDati Alxayolu (tropical:) The horses struck the ground with their hoofs: and jaA='ati Alxayolu rakoDFA (tropical:) [The horses came striking the ground with their hoofs]: and rakaDati Aljunodabu Alr~amoDaA='a bikuraAEayohaA (tropical:) [The locusts termed jndb struck the vehemently-hot ground with their two legs]: and tarakotuhu yarokuDu birijolihi lilomawoti (tropical:) [I left him striking the ground with his foot previously to death: see also 8]. (A.) [The above-mentioned phrases marked as tropical are so marked on the authority of the A: but the reason of their being so I do not see.] ― -b2- They also said, sometimes, rakaDa AlT~aAy^iru, meaning (assumed tropical:) The bird moved his wings in flying: (S:) the inf. n., rakoDN, signifying (tropical:) the act of moving the wing: (K, TA:) and AlT~aAy^ru yarokuDu bijanaAHayohi (tropical:) The bird moves his wings, and puts them back against his body: (A, TA:) or the former of these two phrases means (assumed tropical:) the bird was quick, or swift, in his flying. (TA.) ― -b3- rakoDN also signifies The act of impelling; syn. dafoEN: and the urging a horse to run, (A, K, TA,) [by striking] with his foot or leg: (TA:) the striking a beast with one's feet or legs, to urge him: (Mgh:) or putting him in motion, whether he go on or not. (As.) You say, rakaDotu Alfarasa birijoliY I urged the horse to run, with my foot or leg. (S, O, Msb. *) And rakaDa Ald~aAb~apa, aor.
rakuDa , inf. n. rakoDN, He struck the sides of the beast with his foot or leg. (TA.) And rakaDa Ald~aAb~apa birijolK, and birijolayoni, He struck the beast to urge it with a foot or leg, and with two feet or legs. (A.) ― -b4- And from frequency of usage of the phrase rakaDotu Alfarasa, originated the saying rakaDa Alfarasu, (AZ, * S, Mgh, Msb,) meaning (tropical:) The horse ran: (S, Mgh: *) which some disallow; but without reason, since it has been transmitted by a good authority: (Msb:) it is disallowed by As: (TA:) [and J says,] the correct phrase is rukiDa Alfarasu: (S:) or you say, rukiDa Alfarasu farakaDa huwa, meaning [The horse was urged to run,] (assumed tropical:) and he ran: (K:) and rakoDN signifies (assumed tropical:) the act of running: (K, in another place in this art.:) and (assumed tropical:) the act of fleeing: whence, [in the Kur xxi. 12], A_i*aA humo minohaA yarokuDuwna (K) (assumed tropical:) lo, they fled from it, from punishment: (Zj:) or (assumed tropical:) were routed, and fled from it: (Fr:) or they ran from it: (Mgh:) [for] rakaDa Alr~ajulu signifies (assumed tropical:) The man fled, and (assumed tropical:) ran. (ISh.) [Hence,] rakaDati Aln~ujuwmu fiY Als~amaA='i (tropical:) The stars moved along in the sky. (A, TA.) [And hence,] rakoDN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A man's going along by both his legs together. (TA.) ― -b5- You also say, rakaDahu AlbaEiyru (S, A, Msb) (tropical:) The camel struck him with his kind leg: (S, Msb:) like as you say, ramaHahu Alfarasu: (A, Msb: *) but you should not say, [when a camel is the agent,] ramaHahu. (Yaakoob, S.) And rakaDa AlA^aroDa, and Alv~awoba, (assumed tropical:) He struck the ground, and the garment, or piece of cloth, with his foot or leg. (TA.) And AlmaroA^apu tarokuDu *uyuwlahaA waxaloxaAlahaA birijolayohaA A_i*aA ma$ato (tropical:) [The woman kicks her skirts and her anklets with her feet when she walks]. (A, TA.) ― -b6- And rakaDati Alqawosu Als~ahoma (tropical:) The bow propelled the arrow. (A, TA.) ― -b7- And rakaDotu Alqawosa (tropical:) I shot with the bow. (A, TA.) ― -b8- And huwa laA yarokuDu AlmiHojana (assumed tropical:) He does not defend himself: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) he is not angry and vexed at a thing, nor does he defend himself. (IAar, L.) ― -b9- And rakaDa Aln~aAra baAlmirokaDi (tropical:) [He stirred the fire with the markaD]. (A.)

3 rAkDhu * , (S, K,) or rAkDhu Alxayola, (A,) He
contended with him in a race, each making his horse to run. (S, K.)

4 ArkDt * , said of a woman, (K,) or of a mare, (A 'Obeyd, S, O, L,) (tropical:) Her fœtus became large in her belly, and moved about: (S, O, L, K:) or her fœtus moved about in her belly: (A 'Obeyd;) and so ↓ ArtkDt, said of a she-camel. (A, TA.)

6 xarajuwA yataraAkaDuwna * [They went forth contending together in urging their horses]. (A.) And trAkDwA A_ilayohimo xayolahumo [They contended together in urging towards them their horses] (S, A) Hat~aY A^adorakuwhumo [until they overtook them, or came up to them]. (A.) And fiY AlHalobapi ↓ ArtkDwA [app. signifies They urged their horses in the raceground]. (A, TA.)

8 A_irotakaDa see 6. ― -b2- tarakotuhu yarotakiDu lilomawoti (tropical:) [I left him struggling with, or convulsed in, his legs, previously to death: see also 1, near the beginning]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- ArtkD also signifies (tropical:) It was, or became, in a state of commotion or agitation: (S, A, K:) said of a fœtus in the belly (S, A) of a mare: (S:) and of water in a well. (A, TA.) ― -b4- ArtkD fulaAnN fiY A^amorihi (tropical:) Such a one was, or became, agitated, or disturbed, or disquieted, in his affair: (S, TA:) and, which implies the same, (TA,) he exercised art, or cunning, (taqal~aba,) in his affair, and strove thereby to accomplish or effect it. (A, TA.) ― -b5- Hence AirotikaADN signifying (assumed tropical:) The travel-ling through, or traversing, countries, or regions. (Har p. 660.) ― -b6- See also 4.

rakoDapF *
An impulse: a motion: (K:) [pl. rakaDaAtN: see an ex. voce rafaDaAtN.] Hence, (TA,) it is said in a trad. of I'Ab, that the blood which continues to flow after menstruation is rakoDapN mina Al$~ayoTaAni, (S, * TA,) i. e. An impulse from the devil; (S;) whereby he finds a way of putting the woman in doubt respecting the affairs of her religion, and her state of pureness, and her prayer. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] one of the names of [the well of] Zemzem is rakoDapu jiboriyla [The impulse of Gabriel; because it is fabled to have gushed forth on the ground's being struck by Gabriel's wings]. (TA.)

rakuwDN * , applied to a bow (qawos), (tropical:) That sends the arrow swiftly: (S, TA:) or that impels it vehemently: and ↓ murokiDapN [or perhaps ↓ mirokaDapN] signifies the same. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- See also raAkiDN.
rak~aADapN * : see the next paragraph.

raAkiDN * , applied to a horse, (tropical:) Running; as also ↓ rakuwDN: (K:) or the correct epithet is ↓ marokuwDN: (S:) and ↓ rak~aADapN signifies the same, applied to a mare. (TA.) [Hence,] bit~u A^aroEaY Aln~ujuwma wahoYa rawaAkiDu (tropical:) I passed the night observing the stars while they moved along in the sky. (A, TA.)

tarokaDaY * and tirokiDaA='u, the former incorrectly written in the K tarokaDaA='u, [or, in some copies, tarokuDaA='u, and the latter in one copy written tarokiDaA='u,] are there said to be used as examples by the grammarians, but not explained; and the author offers his opinion that they are syn. with rakoDN: (TA:) but this is a strange defect: for AHei explains them as signifying A certain gait, in which is a proud and self-conceited air, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: and he asserts the t to be augmentative: (MF, TA:) and in the L they are expl. as signifying a particular kind of gait: or meaning as above. (TA.)

marokaDN * The part of the flank of a horse which the rider strikes with his heel or foot, (A, TA, the latter in this art. and also voce yaEosuwbN,) on either side: (TA:) pl. maraAkiDu. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] maraAkiDu HawoDK (tropical:) The sides of a watering-trough, (A, K,) against which the water strikes. (A, TA.)

murokiDN * , applied to a mare, (A 'Obeyd,) or a she-camel, (A,) (tropical:) Whose fœtus moves about in her belly; (A 'Obeyd, A;) [or whose fœtus is large, and moves about in her belly; (see 4;)] as also murokiDapN; (A 'Obeyd;) or ↓ murotakiDapN. (A.) ― -b2- See also rakuwDN.
mirokaDN * : see mirokaDapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) An instrument for stirring a fire. (A, K.)

mirokaDapN * (tropical:) A mare that beats the ground with her legs (K, TA) when she runs. (TA.) ― -b2- See also rakuwDN. ― -b3- Also (tropical:) A certain part of a bow; well known; one of [the two parts called] its mirokaDataAni; (S;) or ↓ mirokaDaAni: (IB:) each of the two curved extremities thereof; as also ↓ mirokaDN: (A:) or the side thereof: (K:) pl. maraAkiDu. (TA.)
marokuwDN * : see raAkiDN.
murotakaDu AlmaA='i * (tropical:) The place in which water collects. (S, A, K.)
murotakiDapN * : see murokiDN.

1 rakaEa * , (Th, S, &c.,) aor.
rakaEa , (Th, TA,) inf. n. rukuwEN (Th, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and rakoEN, (Th, TA,) He bowed, or bent, himself; or became bowed or bent: (Th, S, Mgh, Msb:) so says Er-Rághib, adding that it is sometimes used to denote a particular manner of doing so in prayer, and sometimes to denote humility and self-abasement either in worship or in other cases: (TA:) he lowered his head: (Th:) and he (an old man) bowed himself, or bent himself, or became bowed or bent, by reason of age: (S, Msb, K:) this is [said to be] the primary signification: (TA:) or he fell upon his face; (IDrd, IB, K;) and stumbled. (IB.) ― -b2- And hence, from rakaEa as used in the first of the senses explained above, (S, Mgh,) or as used in the first of the senses assigned to it above when said of an old man, (TA,) or as used in the last sense explained above, (IB,) rukuwEu AlS~alaApi, (S, IB, Mgh, TA,) or Alr~ukuwEu fiY AlS~alaAp, The lowering of the head, (K, TA,) by a person praying, (TA,) [or in prayer,] after the act of standing in which the recitation [of portions of the Kur-án] is performed, so that the palms of the hands reach the knees; or, so that the back becomes depressed; (K, TA;) accord. to the doctors of practical law, so that if a cup full of water be placed upon the back, it will not be spilled. (TA.) ― -b3- rakaEa A_ilaY A@ll~`hi He lowered his head, or he humbled himself, to God; syn. AiTomaA^an~a. (Z, TA.) ― -b4- rakaEa, also signifies He prayed; (Mgh;) and so ↓ trk~E. (TA.) Thus in the Kur [ii. 40], waA@rokaEuwA maEa Alr~aAkiEiyna, And pray ye with those who pray. (Mgh.) You say also, rakaEa rakoEapF, and rakoEatayoni, and valaAva rakaEaAtK, He prayed a rek'ah, and two rek'ahs, and three rek'ahs. (K.) [See rakoEapN, below.] ― -b5- Also, accord. to IKoot and several others, He stood to prayer. (Msb) ― -b6- lagibati AlA_ibilu Hat~aY rakaEato (tropical:) The camels became fatigued, or fatigued in the utmost degree, or languid in consequence of fatigue, so that they lowered their heads, and fell upon their faces. (TA.) ― -b7- rakaEati Aln~axolapu (assumed tropical:) The palm-tree inclined: a phrase which may be of classical authority, but [Mtr says,] I have not found it. (Mgh.) ― -b8- Said of a man, (TA,) rakaEa, also signifies (tropical:) He became poor after richness, or competence, or sufficiency; and his state, or condition, became lowered, or abased. (K, TA.)
5 tarak~aEa see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

rakoEapN * , [inf. n. of un. of 1: and particularly signifying] A single act of standing in prayer: and in its legal acceptation, used in a more particular sense; (Msb;) meaning a single act of standing in prayer, followed by the rukuwE [or lowering of the head in the manner described above (see Alr~ukuwEu fiY AlS~alaApi in the first paragraph)] and two prostrations: (TA:) [and hence, by a further extension of the meaning, for SalaApu rakoEapK, the prayer of one bowing of the head and body; the previous act of standing, and the two subsequent prostrations, being understood as included in this expression:] pl. rakaEaAtN. (Msb, K.) [Using it in the last of these senses,] you say, Sal~aY rakoEapF [He performed the prayer of one bowing of the head and body]: (K:) and Sal~aY rakoEatayoni [he performed the prayers of two bowings of the head and body]. (Msb, K.) [A full description of the act of prayer thus termed may be seen in my work on the Modern Egyptians.]

rukoEapN *
A deep hollow (huw~apN) in the ground: (IDrd, K:) asserted to be of the dial. of ElYemen. (IDrd, TA.)

raAkiEN * part. n. of 1, Bowing, or bending himself; or becoming bowed or bent: [&c.:] (Mgh:) anything, or anybody or any person, (accord. to different copies of the K,) lowering its, or his, head: (K:) or falling upon its, or his, face, so that the knees touch the ground, or do not touch it, after lowering the head: (TA:) ― -b2- prostrating himself in thanksgiving; used in this sense in the Kur xxxviii. 23: (Mgh:) ― -b3- praying: (Mgh:) ― -b4- and applied by the Arabs in the Time of Igno-
rance to a follower of the true religion, not worshipping idols: (TA:) ― -b5- pl. raAkaEuwna (Mgh) and ruk~aEN and rukuwEN. (TA.) ― -b6- A_ibilN rawaAkiEu, [pl. of raAkiEapN,] (tropical:) Camels lowering their heads, and falling upon their faces, in consequence of fatigue, or the utmost fatigue, or languor arising from fatigue. (TA.)
marokaEN * [A place in which one bows, or bends himself: and particularly, in prayer: pl. as below]. ― -b2- A hard and long stone upon which one grinds wheat or the like: pl. maraAkiEu. (TA.)

1 rakalahu * , aor.
