rakula , (S, TA,) inf. n. rakolN, (S, K, TA,) He kicked him; i. e., struck him with his foot, or leg; namely, a horse; in order that he should run: (K, TA:) and (K) he struck him with one foot, or leg: (S, K, TA:) and some say, he struck him with the feet, or legs. (TA.) One says, laA taA^okulu baEodahaA baEodahaA A^akolapF ↓ laA^arokulan~aka rakolapF [I will assuredly kick thee with one kick after which thou shalt not eat one meal]. (TA.) And AlfaArisu yarokulu Ald~aAb~apa birijolihi The horseman puts the beast in motion with his foot, or leg, for the purpose of [his] running. (S.) And tarokiylN, also, [inf. n. of ↓ rk~l, in like manner] signifies The striking a thing with the foot or hoof. (KL.)
2 rak~ala see what next precedes.
3 raAokala see 6, in two places.

5 trk~l bimisoHaAtihi *
He struck his msHAp [or spade] with his foot, (S, K, TA,) and pressed upon it with his haunch, (TA,) in order that it might enter into the earth. (S, K, TA.)

6 trAklwA *
They kicked one another: (S, * K, * TA:) said of boys, meaning they struck (rakaluwA) one another with their feet, or legs: and ↓ muraAkalapN signifies the same as taraAkulN: you say, ↓ rAkl AlS~abiY~u SaAHibahu [The boy kicked his companion, or fellow, being kicked by him]. (TA.)
rakolapN * : see 1 [of which it is the inf. n. of un].

marokalN * The part, of a beast, where one strikes him with the foot, or leg, (K, TA,) when putting him in motion for the purpose of [his] running: (TA:) the two such parts are termed the marokalaAni: and the pl. is maraAkilu. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And A road: (S, K:) because it is beaten with the foot. (TA.)

mirokalN * The foot, or leg, [as being the instrument with which the action termed rakolN is performed:] in the copies of the K, Alr~ajulu is erroneously put for Alr~ijolu: or, accord. to the L, the foot, or leg, of the rider. (TA.)

A^aroDN murak~alapN *
Ground trodden by the hoofs of horses or similar beasts. (S, K.)

1 rakama Al$~aYo'a * , aor.
rakuma , (S, M,) inf. n. rakomN (M, K,) He heaped up, piled up, or accumulated, the thing; i. e. he collected together the thing, and put, or threw, one part of it upon another; (S, K; *) or he put, or threw, one part of the thing upon another. (M, TA.)

6 trAkm * and ↓ Artkm It (a thing) was, or became heaped, or piled, up, or together, or accumulated; i. e., collected together, (S, K, TA,) one part upon [or overlying] another. (TA.) You say, trAkm Als~aHaAbu The clouds were, or became, [heaped, or piled, up,] one above, or upon, [or overlying,] another; as also trAkb. (TA in art. rkb.) And trAkm laHomu Aln~aAqapi [lit. The flesh of the she-camel became accumulated]; meaning the she-camel became fat. (TA.) [And trAkmt AlZ~alomapu (assumed tropical:) The darkness became condensed, or dense: for the Arabs describe thick darkness as “ darknesses one above another: ” see Kur xxiv. 40.] And trAkmt AlA^a$ogaAlu and ↓ Artkmt (tropical:) [Occupations, or the occupations, became accumulated]. (TA.)
8 A_irotakama see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
rakamN * : see rukaAmN.

rukomapN * , (S, K, [so in my copies of the S,]) with damm, (K,) in [some of] the copies of the S rakamapN, (TA,) Clay, or mud, (S, K, TA,) and earth, or dust, (TA,) collected together [and app. heaped up]. (S, K, TA.)

rukaAmN * (S, K) and ↓ rakamN (IAar, K) and ↓ mutaraAkimN (S, K) and ↓ murotakimN and ↓ marokuwmN (TA) Clouds (saHaAbN) collected together, and heaped, or piled, up; (IAar, S, K, TA;) and so sand; (S, TA;) and the like: (S:) [or, as the explanations seem to indicate, the first and second are used as substs., implying what is collected together &c; and the rest only as epithets:] and you say also rukaAmu saHaAbi (TA) and rukaAmu ramolK: (K, TA:) and $aYo'N rukaAmN means a thing accumulated, one part upon another. (TA.) ― -b2- And qaTiyEN rukaAmN (tropical:) A large herd or flock or the like; (K, TA;) likened to the rkAm of clouds or of sand. (TA.)

marokuwmN * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence,] naAqapN marokuwmapN (tropical:) A fat she-camel. (TA. [See 6.]) ― -b3- marokuwmN is applied by Dhu-r-Rummeh as an epithet to midnight (jawozu All~ayoli) [meaning marokuwmN ZulumaAtuhu, i. e. Densely dark, as though its darknesses were heaped one upon another: see 6]. (TA in art. xfq.)
murotakamN * (tropical:) The main part, or middle, of a road. (S, K, TA.)
murotakimN * : see rukaAmN.
mutaraAkimN * : see rukaAmN.

1 rakana A_ilayohi * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
rakuna ; (S, Msb, K;) of the dial. of the lower (sufolaY) [app. in territory] of Mudar, and said by Az to be not chaste [thought it, or the third, seems to be the most common of the dial. vars. here mentioned]; (Msb;) and rakina aor.
rakana ; (S, Msb, K;) mentioned by AZ; (S;) and rakana, aor.
rakana ; (S, Msb, K;) which is a combination of two dial. vars., [namely, the first and second of those above mentioned,] (S, Msb,) because neither the medial nor the final radical letter is faucial; (Msb;) said to be the only instance of its kind except A^abaY aor. yaA^abaY; (T in art. AbY;) and rakina, aor.
rakuna ; which is likewise an instance of the commixture of two dial. vars., like faDila and HaDira and naEima, aor. yafoDulu and yaHoDuru and yanoEumu; (TA;) inf. n. rukuwnN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and rakaAnapN and rakaAniyapN; (TA;) He inclined to him, or it; syn. maAla: and he trusted to, or relied upon, him, or it, so as to be, or become, easy, or quiet, in mind; syn. sakana: (S, Mgh, K:) or he leaned, rested, or relied, upon him; syn. AiEotamada Ealayohi: (Msb:) or he inclined to him in the least degree; (Bd in xi. 115;) rukuwnN signifying slight inclining. (Ksh and Bd ibid.) It is said in the Kur [xi. 115], walaA tarokanuwA A_ilaY A@l~a*iyna ZalamuwA [And incline ye not, &c., to those who have acted wrongfully]: (S, Msb:) or, incline ye not in the least degree [&c.]: (Bd:) thus generally read; and also tirokanuwA, (Ksh, Bd, TA,) accord. to the dial. of Temeem; and ↓ turokanuwA, in the pass. form, from A^arokanahu. (Ksh, Bd.) ― -b2- rakina fiY Almanozili, aor.
rakana , inf. n. rakonN, He kept tenaciously to the place of alighting, or abode, (Dan~a bihi,) and did not relinquish it. (TA.) -A2- rakuna, inf. n. rakaAnapN (S, K) and rukuwnapN (K) and rakaAniyapN, (TK,) [primarily, it seems, said of a mountain, meaning It was inaccessible, or difficult of access, having high, or strong A^arokaAn i. e. sides or angles: see Har p. 561; and see rakiynN, below; and 5. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, firm, (Har p. 561,) still, or motionless, (TA,) grave, staid, steady, sedate; or calm. (S, K, TA.)

2 rk~n * is said by Golius, as on the authority of the KL, to signify He made like, “ similem fecit: ” and hence Freytag also thus explains it: but it is zk~n that has this signification. In my copy of the KL, tazokiynN (not tarokiynN) is expl. by mAnnd krdn.]

4 Arknhu *
He made him to incline [A_ilaY gayorihi to another]; syn. A^amaAlahu: [and to trust to, or rely upon, another, so as to be, or become, easy, or quiet, in mind: or to lean, rest, or rely, upon another: see 1:] whence a reading in the Kur xi. 115. (Ksh, Bd. *) See 1.

5 trk~n * said of a man, (TA,) [or primarily and properly, of a thing, like rakuna,] He, [or it] was, or became, firm, or strong, (K, TA,) and inaccessible, or difficult of access. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) He endeavoured, or constrained himself, to be grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; syn. tawaq~ara, (K,) and taraz~ana. (TA.)
rakonN * The jura* [or large field-rat]: and the faA^or [or common rat or mouse]; as also ↓ rukayonN. (K.)

rukonN * The jaAnib [meaning side, or outward part,] of a thing: (Msb:) or the strongest jaAnib
[i. e. side, or outward part,] (S, K, TA) of a thing (S, TA) of any kind: (TA:) the corner, or angle, (zaAwiyap,) of a house or room or the like: (K in art. zwY:) [and this is perhaps what is meant by the “ strongest jAnb; ” for the strongest outward part of the house is unquestionably the corner, or angle: thus the angle in which is the Black Stone, of the Kaabeh, is specially called rukonu Albayoti, i. e. rukonu bayoti A@ll~`hi:] the rukon of a qaSor [or palace, or pavilion, &c.,] is its jaAnib [or its strongest jAnb], and so of a mountain: (TA: [see rakuna, and rakiynN:]) the pl. is A^arokaAnN and A^arokunN [each properly a pl. of pauc., but the former is used as a pl. of mult.]: (Msb, TA:) the A^arokaAn of anything are is jawaAnib [or sides, or outward parts, or its corners, or angles,] upon which it rests, and by which it is supported: (TA:) and the A^arokaAn of a land are its extremities [or sides or corners]. (Ham p. 478.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) A stay, or support, of any kind: see an ex. voce mirojamN: whence, perhaps,] one says, tamas~aHotu biA^arokaAnihi, meaning tabar~akotu bihi (tropical:) [i. e. I looked for a blessing by means of him, or it]. (TA.) (assumed tropical:) A thing whereby one is strengthened (maA yuqaw~aY bihi [in the CK mA taqaw~aYbh]), such as dominion (mulok [in the CK malik]), and an army, or a military force, &c.: (K:) and thus it has been explained as occurring in the Kur [li. 39], where it is said, fatawal~aY birukonihi, (TA,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) And he turned away from belief with his forces; because they were to him like the rukon [properly so termed]. (Jel.) (assumed tropical:) A man's kinsfolk; or nearer, or nearest, relations; or clan; or tribe; syn. Ea$iyrapN: (AHeyth, TA:) (assumed tropical:) a man's people, or party; and the higher among them; and the persons by whom he is aided and strengthened: thought by ISd to be thus called by way of comparison [to a rukon properly so termed]: and thus it has been explained as used in the Kur [xi. 82], where it is said, A^awo A=wiYa rukonK $adiydK (assumed tropical:) [Or that I might have recourse to a strong people, or party, &c.]: (TA:) or it here means Ea$iyrap [explained above]. (Jel.) And (assumed tropical:) A noble, or high, person; as in the saying, huwa rukonN mino A^arokaAni qawomihi (assumed tropical:) [He is a noble, of the nobles of his people]. (TA.) And A^arokaAnu AlA_inosaAni means (assumed tropical:) The members, or limbs, of the man, with which things are gained or earned, or with which he works; as the hands or arms, and the feet or legs. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Might, and resistance: (S, K:) so in the saying, huwa yaA^owiY A_ilaY rukonK $adiydK (assumed tropical:) [He has recourse to strong, or vehement, might and resistance]: (S:) and so it has been explained as used in the words of the Kur last cited above. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A thing, an affair, a case, an event, or an action, of great magnitude or moment, momentous, formidable, or terrible. (AHeyth, K.) Thus AHeyth explains it as used in the saying of En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee],
laA taqo*ifan~iY birukonK laA kifaA='a lahu
[By no means reproach thou me with a momentous, or a formidable, thing or action, or an enormity, that has not its equal; though (he proceeds to say) the enemies incite thee, with companies of men aiding one another]. (TA.) ― -b5- In the conventional language [of the schools], rukonu Al$~aYo'i means (assumed tropical:) [The essence of the thing; or] that whereby the thing subsists: from Alt~aqaw~umu; because the qiwaAm [or subsistence] of the thing is by its rukon: not from AlqiyaAm: else it would necessarily be the case that the agent would be a rukon to the action; and the substance, to the accident; and the thing to which a quality is attributed, to the quality: (KT:) it is (assumed tropical:) that without which the thing has no subsistence: (Kull:) and is [also] applied to (assumed tropical:) [an essential, or essential part, of the thing; i. e.,] a part of the maAhiy~ap [or essence] of the thing, (Kull, [and in like manner A^arokaAnu Al$~aYo'i is explained in the Msb as meaning the parts of the mAhy~p of the thing,]) as when we say that AlqiyaAm is a rukon of AlS~alaAop; as well as to (assumed tropical:) the whole maAhy~p [of the thing]: (Kull:) [thus] A^arokaAnu AlEibaAdaAti means (assumed tropical:) the fundamentals [or essentials] of the services of religion, by the neglect, or non-observance, of which they are ineffectual, or null, or void: (TA:) or, as some say, rukonu Al$~aYo'i means that whereby the thing is complete; and this is intrinsic therein; differing from the $aroT [or condition] thereof, which is extrinsic thereto. (KT.)

rakiynN * A mountain having high A^arokaAn [i. e. sides, or angles]: (S, K:) or having strong ArkAn: (TA:) or inaccessible, or difficult of access, having ArkAn. (Har p. 561.) ― -b2- And hence, (Har ibid.,) (tropical:) A man (S, K, &c.) firm, (Har,) still, or motionless, (TA,) grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm. (S, K, Har, TA.)
rukayonN * : see rakonN.

A^arokuwnN *
A great dihoqaAn, (K, TA,) i. e. headman, or chief, of a village or town: [app. from the Greek ἄρχω ν; though it is said that] he is thus called because the people of the village or town trust to him and incline to him. (TA.)

mirokanN *
A kind of vessel, well known, (K, TA,) like a tawor [q. v.], of leather, used for water: (TA:) or i. q. A_ij~aAnapN [q.v.], (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) in which clothes and the like are washed; (TA;) called in Pers. tagaAro: (Mgh:) pl. maraAkinu and maraAkiynu. (TA.) One says, zaraEuwA Alr~ayaA Hiyna fiY AlmaraAkiyni [They sowed the sweet-smelling plants in the mrAkyn]. (TA.)

murak~anN * A thing having A^arokaAn [here meaning corners, or angles]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] DaroEN murak~anN A great udder; as though having ArkAn: (S, TA:) and an udder that has opened [or expanded] in its place so as to fill the A^arofaAg [or groins], and is not very long. (TA.) Tarafeh says,
waDar~atuhaA murak~anapN daruwru
[And her udder is great, having much milk: or,] accord. to AA, mrk~np [here] signifies mjm~Ep [app. meaning collecting much]. (TA.) And you say also naAqapN murak~anapu AlD~aroEi (S, TA) [A she-camel great in the udder; or] whose udder has A^arokaAn by reason of its greatness. (TA.)

1 rakaA * (ISd, K,) [aor. yarokuw,] inf. n. rakowN, (ISd, TA,) He dug, or excavated, (ISd, K, TA,) the ground, forming an oblong hollow. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- He made, formed, or fashioned, in a suitable manner, a small watering-trough such as is termed marokuw~, (AZ, TA,) or a watering-trough [in an absolute sense]; as also ↓ ArkY. (TA.)
4 A^arokawa see what next precedes.

rakowapN * (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and rikowapN and rukowapN, (K,) all well known, but the first is the most chaste, (MF,) A certain thing for water: (S:) it is [a small drinking-vessel] like a tawor, of leather; (ISd, TA;) a small drinking-vessel of skin: (Nh, TA:) or a small dalow [or bucket, generally of leather], (Mgh, Msb,) well known: (Msb:) all of these explanations have been strangely neglected by the author of the K: (TA:) pl. rikaA='N (S, Mgh, Msb) and rakawaAtN; (S,) Msb;) the latter allowable. (Msb.) The prov. (S) SaArati Alqawosu rakowapF [lit. The bow became a rkwp, app. meaning the bow became exchanged for a vessel such as is called rkwp, but see what follows,] is applied in relation to the retiring of good fortune, and reverse in the state of affairs. (S, K.) ― -b2- A small zaworaq [or skiff]. (ISd, K.) ― -b3- A ruqoEap [or piece of cloth, or rag,] beneath the EawaASir, (K,) which means three stones [with which grapes are pressed so as to force out the juice,] placed one above another: so in the M. (TA.) [Hence, accord. to the TK, the prov. above mentioned: but I see not why.] ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The faloham of a woman; i. e. her faroj [or vulva]: so in the copies of the K: but in the T, her qulofap [i. e. the prepuce of the clitoris], on the authority of IAar; as being likened to the rkwp of water: (TA:) the pl. [app. in all its senses] is rikaA='N and rakawaAtN [as above], (K,) or in the last sense rukFY. (TA.)
rakiY~N * : see what next follows, in two places.

rakiy~apN *
A well: (S, Msb, K:) or a well containing water; (MA;) otherwise a well is not thus called: (Durrat el-Ghowwás, in De Sacy's Chrest. Ar. ii. 332:) or a well not made neat; or not constructed [or cased] with bricks [&c.]: (MA:) pl. rakaAyaA (S, Msb, K) and ↓ rakiY~N, (S, and so in some copies of the K,) or the former is the pl. and ↓ the latter is [properly speaking] a gen. n., [i. e. a coll. gen. n.,] and often occurs as a sing. and as a pl., (Nh, TA,) or the pl. is also rukiY~N: (so in some copies of the K and in the TA:) accord. to ISd, it is from rakaA in the first of the senses assigned to this verb above. (TA.)

marokuw~N * [pass. part. n. of 1: ― -b2- and hence, as a subst.,] A large watering-trough or tank: (AA, T, S, K:) [in the S and K is added, waAljuromuwzu AlS~agiyru, which may mean either that the small watering-
trough is called jrmwz, and such is the case, or that marokuw~N also signifies a small jrmwz, agreeably with what here follows, and with an explanation of this word in the TA voce HawiY~N:] Az, after mentioning AA's explanation given above, says, but what I have heard from the Arabs is, that the mrkw~ is a small watering-trough or tank, which a man makes, or forms, or fashions, in a suitable manner, with his hands, at the head of the well, when he has not, and cannot procure, a vessel in which to give water to a camel or to two camels: and that which is large is not thus called. (TA.) [But see an ex. voce salosN.]

1 ram~ahu * , (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yarum~u (T, S, M, Msb, K) and yarim~u (S, Msb, K,) the latter [irreg. as aor. of a trans. v. of this class, and] said by MF to be unknown, but there are other instances of the same kind, as har~ahu, aor. yahur~u and yahir~u and Eal~ahu, aor. yaEul~u and yaEil~u, (TA,) inf. n. ram~N (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and maram~apN, (Lth, T, S, Mgh, K,) He repaired it; or put it into a good, sound, right, or proper, state; (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) after a part thereof had become in a bad state; (Lth, T;) namely, a thing, (Lth, T, S,) as, for instance, a rope becoming old and worn-out, or a house, (Lth, T,) or a building, (Mgh,) or a wall, &c.; (Msb;) as also ram~a $aA^onahu, (S,) or $aA^onahaA referring to a house (daAr): (Lth, T:) and in like manner, he rectified it, namely, an affair, after it had become disorganized, or disordered: (Lth, T:) and ↓ rm~m signifies the same in an intensive sense; [i. e. he repaired it, &c., much, or well:] (Msb:) and ↓ ramorama he repaired, or rectified, his affair, case, state, or condition. (TA.) The saying, kun~aA A^ahola vam~ihi waram~ihi, (T, S,) occurring in a trad., (S,) accord. to the relaters thereof ↓ vum~ihi warum~ihi, but A'Obeyd holds the former reading to be the right, (T, S,) means, accord. to AA, We were the fit persons to put it into a good, sound, right, or proper, state: (T:) or, accord. to A'Obeyd, to put it into such a state, and to eat it. (T, S. [See another explanation of the verb in what follows.]) ― -b2- You say also, ram~a sahomahu, meaning (tropical:) [He made his arrow even, or straight, by means of his eye; or] he looked at his arrow until he made it even, or straight. (TA.) -A2- ram~N also signifies The act of eating; and so ↓ AirotimaAmN. (ISh, T.) You say, ram~ahu, (T, S, K,) aor. yarum~u (T, S,) inf. n. ram~N, (TA,) He ate it. (T, S, K.) And it is said in a trad., Ealayokumo biA^alobaAni Albaqari faA_in~ahaA tarum~u mino kul~i Al$~ajari [Keep ye to the milk of cows, for they eat of all the tress]; (T, S, * TA;) i. e. taA^okulu: or, accord. to one reading, it is ↓ tarotam~u. (TA.) ram~ati Al$~aApu AlHa$iy$a aor. tarum~u, inf. n. ram~N, means The sheep, or goat, took the dry herbage, or fodder, with its lips. (M.) And ram~ati Al$~aApu mina AlA^aroDi, and ↓ Artm~t, The sheep, or goat, ate from the land. (S.) And ram~ati Albahomapu, (M,) or Albahiymapu, (K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and ↓ Artm~t; i. e. [The lamb, or kid, or the beast, or quadruped,] reached and took the branches (M, K) with its mouth. (K.) And kul~a rumaAmK ↓ huwa yataram~amu He eats every [kind of] rumaAm [q. v.]. (T.) And AlEaZoma ↓ trm~m He ate off the flesh from the bone; syn. taEar~aqahu: or he left the bone like the rim~ap [q. v.]: in [some of] the copies of the K, taram~ama is erroneously explained by taEaz~aqa; [in my MS. copy, by taEar~afa; and in the CK, by tafar~aqa;] the right reading being taEar~aqa, as in the A. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., respecting the she-cat, walaA mino xa$aA$i AlA^aroDi ↓ A^arosalotuhaA turamorimu, meaning [And I did not send her] for her to eat [of the creeping things of the earth]. (TA.) -A3- ram~a AlEaZomu, aor. yarim~u (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. ram~N (T, M,) or rim~apN, (S,) or both, (K, TA, [the former written in the CK rim~]) and ramiymN; (M, K;) and ↓ Arm~; (M, K; [but see what follows;]) The bone became such as is termed rm~ap; (M, TA;) [i. e.,] became old and decayed; (MA, KL;) syn. baliYa. (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K.) Accord. to IAar, one says, ram~ato EiZaAmuhu, and ↓ A^aram~ato, meaning His bones became old and decayed; syn. baliyato: but others explain AlEaZomu ↓ Arm~ differently, as below: see 4. (T.) In the saying, mentioned in a trad., yaA ↓ rasuwla A@ll~`hi kayofa tuEoroDu SalaAtunaA Ealayoka waqado A^aramota, meaning baliyta [i. e. O Apostle of God, how shall our blessing be offered, or addressed, to thee when thou shalt have become decayed in the grave?], the last word is originally A^aromamota; one of the two m s being rejected; like as is done in A^aHasota, for A^aHosasota: (IAth, K, * TA: [in the CK, taEoraDu is put in the place of tuEoraDu:]) accord. to one relation, it is A^aram~ata; accord. to another, ramamota; and accord. to another, A^urimota: but the first is the proper manner of relation. (TA.) And ram~a AlHabolu The rope became [old and worn out or rotten, (see rum~apN,) or] ragged, or dissundered. (M.)
2 ram~a3a see 1, first sentence.

4 Arm~ * , said of a bone, It had in it, or contained, rim~, i. e. marrow, (T, S, K,) running therein. (S.) One says of a sheep or goat (S, M) that is lean, or emaciated, (S,) and of a she-camel, (M,) maA yurim~u minohaA maDoribN, (S, M,) meaning Not a bone of her that is broken and from which the marrow is [sought to be] extracted [contains any marrow]: (M:) i. e., if any of her bones be broken, no marrow will be found in it. (S.) And Arm~t is said of a she-camel in the first stage of fatness when becoming in good condition of body, and in the last stage thereof when becoming lean; (M, TA;) meaning She had in her somewhat of marrow. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in the latter part of the paragraph, in four places. -A2- Also, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. A_iromaAmN, (T,) He (a man, T) was, or became, silent; (T, M, K;) in a general sense; or, as some say, from fear, or fright: (M:) [and in like manner a bird: see its part. n. murim~N:] or they (a company of men) were, or became, silent. (S.) [See also R. Q. 2.] -A3- Arm~ A_ilaY All~ahow He inclined to diversion, sport, or play. (IAar, M, K.) ― -b2- And Arm~ lika*aA He was cheered, or delighted, and pleased, or was diverted, by reason of such a thing; like A^aran~a lahu. (T in art. rn.)

5 trm~mhu *
He proceeded gradually, by degrees, step by step, or time after time, with the repairing of it; or with the putting it into a good, sound, right, or proper, state. (TA.) -A2- See also 1, near the middle of the paragraph, in two places.
8 A_irotama3a see 1, in the middle portion of the paragraph, in four places. ― -b2- Artm~ is also said of a young camel as meaning He began to be in that state in which one could feel his hump. (K.)

10 Astrm~ *
It (a wall, S, MA, Mgh, K, or a building, KL) needed, or required, its being repaired; (M, MA, K, KL; expl. in the M and K by daEaA A_ilaY A_iSolaAHihi;) having become old: (MA:) or attained to the time in which it should be repaired; (S, Mgh;) a long period having elapsed since it was plastered with mud. (S.)
R. Q. 1 ramorama * : see 1, in two places.

R. Q. 2 taramorama *
He moved his lips, (T,) or his mouth, (S,) to speak: (T, S:) or taramoramuwA they put themselves in motion to speak, but spake not: (M, K:) but it is said to be mostly used in negative phrases. (TA.) One says, maA taramorama fulaAnN biHarofK Such a one uttered not [a letter, or a word]: (T, TA:) or put not himself in motion [therewith]. (IDrd, TA.) And kal~amahu famaA taramorama [He spoke to him and] he returned not a reply. (M, TA.)

ram~N * an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Lth, T, S, &c.) ― -b2- One says, maAliY minohu Ham~N walaA ram~N There is not for me any avoiding it, or escaping it: (S:) or maA lahu Eano *`lika AlA^amori Ham~N walaA ram~N (T, TA) There is not for him any avoiding, or escaping, that thing, or affair: (TA:) and some say ↓ Hum~N walaA rum~N: (S:) so says Lth: (T:) [accord. to ISd,] in the saying ↓ maA Eano *`lika Hum~N walaA rum~N, meaning There is no avoiding, or escaping, that, rum~N is an imitative sequent; (M;) and so says Lth. (T. [But see the next paragraph.]) ― -b3- See also another signification assigned to ram~N in the last sentence but one of the next paragraph. ― -b4- [And see the last sentence also of that paragraph.]

rum~N * : see 1, second sentence: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph next preceding this, in two places. ― -b3- Also i. q. bayotK ↓ maram~apu, (ISk, T, S, M,) i. e. Household-goods; or the utensils and furniture of a house or tent. (M. [This explanation, from the M, I have found, in the TT, since I composed art. vm; in which I have said that, accord. to analogy, maram~apu Albayoti app. signifies the means by which a house, or tent, is put into a good state; and therefore good furniture and utensils.]) So in the saying, maA lahu vum~N walaA rum~N, (ISk, T, S, M,) and maA yamoliku vum~FA walaA rum~FA, (ISk, T, S,) i. e. He has not,
and he possesses not, such household-goods as water-skins, or milk-skins, and vessels, (ISk, T, M,) nor any of the utensils and furniture of the house or tent. (ISk, * T, * M.) This explanation is better than the saying of Lth [that rum~N is an imitative sequent: see the next preceding paragraph]. (T.) One says also, maA lahu Hum~N walaA rum~N, meaning He has not anything: (S:) or he has neither little nor much. (TA voce Ham~N [q. v.]) [See also vum~N.] ― -b4- Also i. q. ham~N [as meaning An object, or a thing intended or meant or determined upon or desired, in the mind: and perhaps also anxiety; or disquietude, or trouble, of mind]. (M, K. [This signification, ham~N, Freytag has assigned to ram~N, not to rum~N; rendering it “ cura, sollicitudo; ” as from the K; in which the word bearing it is expressly said to be “ with damm. ”]) So in the saying, maA lahu rum~N gayoru ka*aA [He has not any object in his mind except such a thing]. (M.) And so in the saying, maA lahu Hum~N walaA rum~N gayoruka and ↓ Ham~N walaA ram~N [He has not any object in his mind except thee]. (TA in art. Hm.) -A2- Also A company of men: occurring in a trad. applied to a company of [the people called] A^akoraAd, abiding [in a place] like a HaY [or tribe] of the Arabs of the desert: [perhaps correctly ram~N, from the Pers. ramo:] said by Aboo-Moosà to be app. a Pers. word. (TA.)

rim~N * The herbage and other things that are upon the land: whence the current saying, jaA='a fulaAnN biAlT~im~i waAlr~im~i, meaning Such a one brought everything of what is on the land and in the sea: [or, of what is in the sea and on the land; for] AlT~im~u means “ the sea; ” and is originally AlT~m~u, but is pronounced [in this case] AlT~im~ to assimilate it to Alr~im~. (T.) [Or] i. q. varFY [app. as meaning Good of any kind; and particularly wealth; as appears from what immediately follows]: one says, jaA='ahu biAlT~im~i waAlr~im~, meaning He brought him much wealth. (S.) [Or] jaA='a biAlT~im~i waAlr~im~i means He brought what was of the sea and what was of the land: (biAlbaHoriY~i waAlbar~iY~, K: [so in MS. copies and in the CK: in the copy of the K followed in the TA, and in like manner in the M, bAlbHr wAlvrY, which, I think, is evidently a false reading:]) or moist and dry: or earth and water: (M, K:) or much wealth; (K;) as in the S: (TA:) and it is said in the copies of the K, [and in the M,] that Alr~im~u signifies what is borne [on its surface] by the water; but this is a signification of AlT~im~u; and Alr~im~u signifies what is borne by the wind: (TA:) or what is upon the ground, of fragments of dry herbage. (M, K.) [See also art. Tm.] ― -b2- Also Marrow. (T, S, M, K.)

rum~apN * The remains of a rope after it has become ragged, or dissundered: (T:) or a piece of a rope (S, M, Msb, K) that is old and worn out or rotten; (S;) as also ↓ rim~apN: (M, K:) pl. [of mult.] rumamN (T, S,) or rimamN (M, K,) and rimaAmN (S, M, K) and [of pauc.] A^aromaAmN: (M, K:) and they said also HabolN A^aromaAmN and rimamN [or rumamN] and rimaAmN; (M, K;) [like HabolN A^aromaAvN and vawobN A^axolaAqN &c.;] thus using the pl. as though every part [of the rope] were termed a single thing. (M.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, A^aEoTayotuhu Al$~aYo'a birum~atihi (assumed tropical:) I gave him the thing altogether: (T:) or dafaEa A_ilayohi Al$~aYo'a birum~atihi (assumed tropical:) He gave him the thing altogether: (S:) or A^axa*ahu birum~atihi (assumed tropical:) He took it altogether: (M; and the like is said in the Msb:) and A^atayotuka biAl$~aYo'i birum~tihi (assumed tropical:) I brought thee, or have brought thee, the thing altogether: (M:) or A^aEoTaAhu birum~atihi (assumed tropical:) He gave it altogether: (K:) originally meaning the rope that is put upon the neck of the camel: (T:) [i. e.] originating from the fact that a man gave to another a camel with a rope upon his neck: (S, K:) or from the fact that a man sold a camel with a rope upon his neck; and it was said, Give him with his rum~ap: (Msb:) or, as some say, from the bringing a captive bound with his rum~ap; but this is not a valid assertion. (M.) In all the copies of the K, Alr~um~apu is also expl. as syn. with Aljabohapu; but [SM says,] I have not found it in the originals from which it is derived; and may-be the right reading is Aljumolapu. (TA.) 'Alee said, dispraising the present world, A^asobaAbuhaA rimaAmN, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Its ties (lit. ropes) are] old and worn out or rotten. (TA.) ― -b3- ↓ A^aromaAmN [perhaps as pl. of rum~apN] also signifies (assumed tropical:) The last remains of herbage. (M, TA.)

rim~apN *
Old and decayed bones: (AA, T, S, M, Msb, K:) or the old and decayed, of bones: (Mgh:) pl. rimamN and rimaAmN. (S, Msb.) The performance of the act termed AlAisotinojaA=' therewith is forbidden. (Mgh, TA.) [See also ramiymN.] ― -b2- [And A bone in which is marrow. (Freytag, from the “ Kitáb el-Addád. ”)] ― -b3- See also rum~apN, first sentence. -A2- Also A two-winged ant: (M, K:) so accord. to Aboo-Hátim; but disallowed by ElBekree. (TA.) ― -b2- And The A^araDap [or woodfretter], (M, K,) in some one or more of the dialects. (M, TA.)

rumumN *
Clever, ingenious, skilful, or intelligent, girls, or young women: (IAar, K:) app. pl. of ↓ raAm~apN, [as it is said to be in the TK, whence Freytag (who has mentioned it as from the K, explaining it as an epithet applied to a girl meaning “ ingeniosa, prudens, ”) appears to have taken it,] which signifies a female skilful in repairing. (TA.)

rumaAmN * : see ramiymN. ― -b2- It is applied as an epithet to vumaAm, in a saying of 'Omar, explained in art. vm: accord. to some, it means that whereof the heads are grown, so that they are eaten (turam~u, i. e. tuw^okalu): it is also applied to a herb, or leguminous plant, such that the cattle pluck it with their mouths, obtaining but little thereof: and to herbage that had dried up when becoming green. (T.)
$iAopN ramuwmN * A sheep, or goat, that eats that by which it passes. (M, TA.)

ramiymN * A bone old and decayed: (S, M, Msb, K:) and ↓ rumaAmN signifies the same (K, TA) in an intensive sense: (TA:) or the former is like rim~apN; (A 'Obeyd, T, and Ksh in xxxvi. 78;) i. e. it is a subst., signifying the old and decayed, of bones; (Ksh and Bd ibid.;) not of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN or mafoEuwlN: (Ksh ibid.:) or it is used in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, [meaning eroded,] from ramamotuhu [“ I ate it ”]: (Bd ibid.:) its pl. is in most instances A^arim~aA='u [when it is used as a subst. or as an epithet], like A^adil~aA='u pl. of daliylN [or A^aqoribaA=' pl. of qariybN]; and rimaAmN also occurs [when it is used as a subst., for rim~apN, of which rimaAmN is a pl., or when it is used as an epithet], like kiraAmN pl. of kariymN: (Msb:) or you say A^aEoZumN ramaAy^imu, and ramiymN also; or ramiymN may have the meaning of a gen. n., and therefore be used in the place of a pl. (M.) It is said in the Kur ubi suprà, mano yuHoyiY A@loEiZaAma wahiYa ramiymN [Who will quicken the bones when they are old and decayed &c.?]; the last word being without p because it is a subst., as expl. above, (Ksh, Bd, Jel,) not an epithet; (Ksh, Jel;) or because it is used in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, as stated above; (Bd;) or because words of the measures faEiylN and faEuwlN are sometimes used alike as masc. and fem. [and sing.] and pl., like SadiyqN and rasuwlN and Eaduw~N. (S.) And Hátim, or some other, says,
A^amaA waAl~a*iY laA yaEolamu Als~ir~a gayoruhu
wayuHoyiY AlEiZaAma AlbiyDa wahoYa ramiymu
[Verily, or now surely, by Him beside whom none knoweth the secret, and who quickeneth the white bones when they are old and decayed &c.]; in which rmym may have the meaning of a gen. n., as observed above. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Anything old and decayed or worn out. (M.) One says, A^aHoyaY ramiyma AlmakaArimi (tropical:) [He revived what had become decayed of generous qualities or actions or practices]. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) The remains of the herbage of the next preceding year: (Lh, M:) from the same word in the sense first expl. above. (M.) -A2- ramiymu is one of the names of The east, or easterly, wind; AlS~abaA: and is also a proper name for a woman. (M.)

rumaAmapN *
A sufficiency of the means of subsistence, (K, TA,) whereby life becomes, or is held to be, in a good, or thriving, state. (TA.)
ram~aA='u * , applied to a ewe, White, (S, M,) without any colour upon her. (M.)
ram~aAmN qa$~aA$N * One who collects what has fallen of food, and the worst thereof, to eat it, not preserving himself from its uncleanness. (T, as heard by its author from the Arabs.)

rum~aAnN * is of the measure fuEolaAnN accord. to Sb: accord. to Abu-l-Hasan [i. e. Akh], of the measure fuE~aAlN, (M, TA,) and is [therefore] mentioned in the S and K in art. rmn [q. v.]: (TA:) the n. un. is with p. (M.)

ramoraAmN * The Ha$iy$ [or herbs, or dry herbage,] of the [season called] rabiyE: and also a certain species of trees, (S, M,) of sweet scent: n. un. with p: (M:) or ramoraAmapN signifies a certain well-known
sort of Ha$iy$ in the desert; and ramoraAmN, much thereof: (T:) or this latter signifies a certain herb having prickly branches and leaves, that forbid the touch, rising to the height of a cubit; long in the leaves, broad, and intensely green, having a yellow flower, and eagerly desired by the cattle: (AHn, M:) or a certain dust-coloured plant, (Aboo-Ziyád, M, K,) which people use as a remedy for the sting of the scorpion. (Aboo-Ziyád, M.)
riAm~apN * : see rumumN, of which it is thought to be the singular.
A^aromaAmN * a pl. of rum~apN as signifying “ a piece of a rope: ” (M, K:) ― -b2- and perhaps also in another sense: see the latter word, last sentence.

murim~N *
Containing rim~, i. e. marrow; applied to a bone. (T.) And, [in like manner without p,] applied to a she-camel, (S, M, K,) in the first stage of fatness when becoming in good condition of body, and in the last stage thereof when becoming lean, (M,) meaning Having in her somewhat of marrow. (S, M, * K. *) -A2- Also Silent; (A 'Obeyd, T, S;) in a general sense; or, as some say, from fear, or fright; (TA;) applied to a man, (A 'Obeyd, T,) and to a bird, as in the saying of a rájiz, (S,) namely, Homeyd El-Arkat, (TA,).
muroxFY riwaAqaAhu hujuwdN saAmiruho
yaridona waAll~ayolu murm~N TaAy^iruhu
[They come to the water when the bird of night is silent, when its curtains (lit. its two curtains) of darkness are let down, when the holders of discourse therein are sleeping]. (S, * TA.) -A3- [The pl.] murim~aAtN signifies Calamities, or misfortunes: (T, K:) so accord. to AZ in the saying, ramaAhu biAlmurim~aAti [He smote him, or afflicted him, with calamiites, or misfortunes]: or, accord. to Aboo-Málik, it signifies AlmusokitaAt [i. e. silencing words or acts]. (T.)

maram~apN * [originally maromamapN, a noun of the same class as majonbanapN and maboxalapN &c., meaning A cause of repair: and hence, a thing needing repair; as in a phrase mentioned voce raqiyEN]. ― -b2- See also maram~apu bayoti, voce rum~N. ― -b3- And see what here follows.

miram~apN * , (Th, T, S, M, TA,) accord. to the K, marim~apN, but this is a mistake, (TA,) The lip of any cloven-hoofed animal, (Th, T, S, M, K, TA,) such as the cow &c.; because it eats therewith; (S;) like miqam~apN; (Th, T;) as also ↓ maram~apN [like maqam~apN]. (S, M, K.)

maromuwmN * sing. of maraAmiymN, (TA,) which is [an epithet] applied to arrows, meaning Having the feathers repaired, or put into a good state. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) An arrow [made even, or straight, by means of the eye; or] looked at until made even, or straight. (TA.) ― -b3- You say also, A^amoru fulaAnK maromuwmN [i. e. The affair, or case, of such a one is rectified, or repaired]. (TA.)

1 ramava * , (S, TA,) aor.
ramuva , (TK,) inf. n. ramovN, (K,) He put a thing into a right, or proper, state, or adjusted it; and wiped it with his hand. (S, K, * TA.) He collected together a thing, and put it into a right, or proper, state, or adjusted it. (As, TA.) -A2- ramivati AlA_ibilu, (T in art. TlH, S, M,) aor.
ramava , (TA,) inf. n. ramavN, (S, M, K,) The camels ate rimov alone, without any change of food: (T in art. TlH:) or had a complaint from eating rimov: (S, M, K:) AHn says that the complaint thus caused is a looseness, or flux of thin excrement from the bowels, consequent upon eating rmv when hungry; and that one fears for the camels in this case. (M.) ― -b2- ramiva A^amoruhumo, aor.
ramava , (K,) inf. n. ramavN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) Their affair, or case, or state of things, became confused. (K.) -A3- ramiva, aor.
ramava ; and ramava, aor.
ramuva ; inf. n. of each ramavN; He stole. (T.)

2 rm~v *
He mixed, or confounded, a thing with another thing. (IAth, TA.) -A2- rm~v naAqatahu He left some milk remaining in his she-camel's udder after milking; (M;) as also ↓ A^aromavahaA. (T, * M.) ― -b2- And rm~v fiY AlD~aroEi, inf. n. taromiyvN, He left somewhat [of milk] remaining in the udder; as also ↓ Armv. (S, K.) And in like manner one says, (TA,) fulaAnN fiY maAlihi ↓ Armv (K, TA, in the CK and in a MS. copy of the K fulaAnFA,) Such a one left a residue, or remainder, in his property, or among his cattle; as also ↓ Astrmv. (K, TA. [Had fulaAnFA been the right reading, the author of the K would, or should, have said “ as also Astrmvhu. ”]) ― -b3- rm~v Ealayohi He, or it, exceeded him, or it; (IAth, TA;) as also ↓ Armv. (IAth, K, * TA.) You say, rm~v EalaY Alxamosiyna He exceeded the [age of] fifty [years]: (M, K:) and in like manner one says of other numbers, relating to age. (M.) And ram~avato ganamuhu EalaY AlmiAy^api His sheep, or goats, exceeded the [number of a] hundred. (M.) And in like manner, rm~vt Aln~aAqapu EalaY miHolabihaA [The she-camel yielded more than the contents of her milking-vessel]. (M.) And Ealayohi fiY AlmanoTiqi ↓ Armv He exceeded him, or surpassed him, in speech. (TK.)
4 Armv * : see 2, in five places. -A2- Also i. q. lay~ana [He, or it, rendered soft, &c.]. (K.)
10 A_isotaromava see 2.

rimovN * [A certain shrub, resembling a dwarftamarisk;] a certain pasture of camels; (S, A, Msb, K;) a species of tree [or shrub], (T,) of the kind termed HamoD, (T, S, A, Msb, K,) growing in plain, or soft, ground, (Msb,) the leaves of which fall, [or droop], like the A^u$onaAn [i. e. kali, or glasswort]; eagerly desired by the camels when they are satiated with, and tired of, the [sweet pasture termed] xul~ap: (T:) it is a species of tree [or shrub] resembling that called gaDFA, (M, K,) which does not grow tall, but the leaves of which spread, [app. meaning that its sprigs spread out flat, and (as described above) droop, like those of the common tamarisk,] and it resembles the A^u$onaAn: (M:) like the gDA and A$nAn, it is burned for making qiloY [or potash]: (TA &c. in art. qlY:) AHn says that it has long and slender hadab [generally, and app. here, meaning sprigs garnished with minute leaves overlying one another like the scales of a fish], and is a pasture upon which camels and sheep or goats will live when they have nothing else with it; sometimes there comes forth upon it a white honey, [a species of manna,] resembling jumaAn [i. e. pearls, or silver beads like pearls], very sweet; it affords firewood, and wood for other uses; its kindled firewood is hot; and its smoke is beneficial as a remedy for the rheum: AHn also says in one place, that, accord. to certain of the Basrees, the rmv occupies the space of a man sitting, and grows in the manner of the $iyH [a species of wormwood]: also that he had been told by certain of [the tribe of] Benoo-Asad that it rises not so high as the stature of a man, and is used as firewood: (M, TA:) [a coll. gen. n.:] the n. un. is with p. (T, M.) [See a prov. cited voce *uw^onuwnN, in art. *A^n.] ― -b2- Also A man whose clothes are old and worn out: (A, K:) said by MF to be tropical, but not said to be so in the A. (TA.) ― -b3- And Weak in the maton [i. e. the back, or the flesh on either side of the back-bone]. (K.)

ramavN *
A raft, constructed of pieces of wood or timber (As, T, S, M, Msb, K) put together (T, S, M, Msb, K) and bound, (T,) upon which one embarks (T, S, M, Msb, K,) on the sea or a great river: (S, M, Msb, K:) of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, from ramava “ he collected together ” a thing, “ and put ” it “ into a right, or proper, state, ” or “ adjusted ” it: (As, TA:) pl. A^aromaAvN. (T, S, M, Msb.) -A2- An old, wornout, rope; pl. A^aromaAvN. and rimaAvN: (M:) and one says HabolN A^aromaAvu, (S, M, A, K,) meaning as above, (A,) i. e. A^aromaAmN; (S, K;) like as one says vawobN A^axolaAqN: (M:) or ramavN signifies a rope undone, or untwisted. (IAar, T.) ― -b2- And The thong, or the like, by which is suspended the skin of churned milk. (K.) -A3- Also Remains, of milk, in the udder, (T, S, M, K,) after milking; and so ↓ rumovapN: pl. of the former A^aromaAvN. (M.) ― -b2- And i. q. HalabN [app. as meaning Milk, or fresh milk, drawn from the udder]. (T.) -A4- An An excel-lence, or excellent quality. (T, K.) So in the saying, in the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb, ” lifulaAnK EalaY fulaAnK ramavN [To such a one belongs an excellence over such a one]. (T.)

ramivN * [part. n. of ramiva]. You say A_ibilN ramivapN, (S, M, K,) and ramaAvaY (S, K) and ramovaY, (M, K,) [which are pls.,] Camels having a complaint from eating rimov. (S, M, K. [See 1, third sentence.])
rumovapN * : see ramavN.
A^aroDN ramovaA='u * : see maromavapN.
ram~aAvN * [from ramavN] The maker of a raft or rafts: and one who draws, or tows, [or propels,] a raft. (MA.)
A^aroDN maromavapN * [in the CK muromivapN] Land producing [the shrubs called] rimov; (M, K;) and ↓ ArD ramovaA='u [signifies the same, or] land in which are rimov. (Ham p. 99.)

humo fiY maromuwvaA='a *
They are in a state of confusion. (K.)

1 ramaHahu * , (S, A, L, K,) aor.
ramaHa , (L, K,) inf. n. ramoHN, (L,) He thrust him, or pierced him, with a rumoHN [i. e. spear, or lance]. (S, A, L, K.) ― -b2- And ramaHa, aor. and inf. n. as above, He (a solid-hoofed animal) struck with his hind leg. (Msb.) You say, of a horse, (S, A, K,) and of an ass, and of a mule, (S, A, *) or any solid-hoofed animal, (TA,) ramaHahu, (S, A, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He kicked him; (K;) or struck him with his hind leg, (S, A, TA,) or with both his hind legs: (TA:) and accord. to Az, it is sometimes metaphorically said of a camel, (Msb, TA,) and ramaHato is sometimes said of a she-camel. (TA.) ― -b3- [In the vulgar modern language, it means He (a horse or the like) galloped.] ― -b4- [Hence,] said of the [locust termed] junodab, (tropical:) It struck the pebbles: (so in three copies of the S:) or it struck the pebbles with its hind leg, (L and A, and so, accord. to the TA, in the S,) or with its two hind legs. (K.) ― -b5- And, said of lightning, (tropical:) It gleamed (A, K) with gleams slight and near together. (A.)
3 rAmHhu * , inf. n. muraAmaHapN, He contended with him in thrusting, or piercing, with the spear, or lance. (A, TA. [The meaning is indicated in both, but not expressed.])

6 trAmHwA *
They contended, one with another, in thrusting, or piercing, with the spear, or lance. (A, TA. [The meaning is indicated in both, but not expressed.])

rumoHN *
A certain weapon, (L, TA,) well known; (L, Msb, K;) [i. e. a spear, or lance; one with which one thrusts, not which one casts; accord. to El-Hareeree, (cited by De Sacy in his “ Chrest. Ar, ” sec. ed., ii. 332,) not so called unless having its iron head mounted upon it:] pl. rimaAHN and A^aromaAHN, (S, L, Msb, K,) the former of mult. and the latter of pauc. (L.) [Hence the saying,] kasaruwA bayonahumo rumoHFA [lit. They broke a spear between them, or among them; meaning] (tropical:) evil, or mischief, [or enmity, or contention,] happened between them, or among them. (A, TA.) And muniynaA biyawomK kaZil~i Alr~umoHi (tropical:) We were tried with a long and distressing day. (A, TA.) And humo EalaY baniY fulaAnK rumoHN waAHidN (tropical:) [They are in league against the sons of such a one as one man]. (A, TA.) And kaA^an~a Eayonayohi fiY rumoHayoni [As though his two eyes were upon two spears] is said of one in fear and fright, and looking hardly, or intently; and sometimes of one in anger. (TA.) [The dim. is ↓ rumayoHN. And hence the saying,] A^axa*a rumayoHa A^abiY saEodK (assumed tropical:) He (a man, K, TA, or an old man, TA) stayed himself upon a staff by reason of extreme old age, or decrepitude: by AbwsEd is meant Lukmán the Sage, (K, TA,) who is mentioned in the Kur-án: (TA:) or Marthad Ibn-Saad: or it is a surname applied to old age, and decrepitude. (K, TA.) ― -b2- See also raAmiHN. ― -b3- [As a measure in astronomy, accord. to modern Arabian astronomers, it is Four degrees and a half; the eightieth part of a great circle; and accord. to various works on practical law, it consists of twelve A^a$obaAr (or spans): but there is reason to believe that ancient usage differed from the modern, with respect to both these measures, and was not precise nor uniform: in an instance mentioned voce zubaAnaY, it appears to be about twice the measure stated above; i. e., about nine degrees; and to consist of five cubits, a measure perhaps equal to twelve spans.] ― -b4- A^axa*ato rimaAHahaA, said of the [species of barley-grass called] buhomaY, (T, S, A, TA,) and of any similar pasture, (T, TA,) (tropical:) It assumed, or put forth, its prickles, (A, * TA,) or became dry in its prickles, (T, TA,) and thus (T, A, TA) resisted the attempts of animals to pasture upon it. (T, S, A, L, TA.) Also, said of camels, (tropical:) They became fat, (S, K, TA,) or yielded milk plentifully; (S, TA;) as though they prevented one's slaughtering them; (K;) or because their owner is prevented from slaughtering them: (S:) or they became goodly in the eye of their owner so that he was prevented from slaughtering them; (A, * TA;) and so A^axa*ato A^asoliHatahaA. (TA.) One says also naAqapN *aAtu rumoHK (tropical:) A fat she-camel; and A_ibilN *awaAtu rimaAHK (tropical:) fat camels; because their owner, when desiring to slaughter them, looks at their fatness and their goodly appearance, and is prevented from slaughtering them. (A, * TA.) ― -b5- rimaAHu Aljin~i (tropical:) [The pestilence termed] AlT~aAEuwnu. (A, K.) [See the following verses.] ― -b6- rimaAHu AlEaqorabi i. q. $awolaAhaA [evidently a mistranscription for $awolaAtuhaA, i. e. (assumed tropical:) The stings of scorpions, with which they strike; AlEqrb being here used, as it seems to be in some other instances, as a coll. gen. n.: that such is the case is shown by the verses here following, quoted in the TA as an ex. of rimaAHu Aljin~i]. (K.) A poet, cited by Th, says,
laEamoruka maA xa$iytu EalaY A^ubaY~K
rimaAHa baniY muqay~idapi AlHimaAri
wal`kin~iY xa$iytu EalaY A^ubaY~K
rimaAHa Aljin~i A^awo A_iy~aAka HaAri
[By thy life, or by thy religion, I feared not, for Ubeí, the stings of the scorpions; but I feared, for Ubeí, the pestilence, or thee, O Harith; HaAri being for HaArivu]; by bnY mqy~dp AlHmAr he means the scorpions. (TA.) ― -b7- [The dim.] ↓ rumayoHN is a proper name of (assumed tropical:) The penis; (K, * TA;) like as $urayoHN is a proper name for “ the vulva of a woman. ” (TA.) ― -b8- ↓ *uw Alr~umayoHi means (assumed tropical:) A species of jerboa, (K, TA,) long in the hind legs, in the middle [?] of each waZiyf [here meaning metacarpus] having a nail in excess [of those of the hind feet; for the fore feet have each five toes of which one only has no nail, and the hind feet have each but three toes, all of which have nails]: or it means any jerboa: and its rmH [evidently a mistranscription for rumayoH] is its tail. (TA. [It is there added, wrmAHh $wlAthA; another mistranscription, and an obvious solecism; or probably some words which should have preceded these have been omitted by the copyist.])
ramoHapN * : see ram~aAHN: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph here following.

rimaAHN * a pl. of rumoHN. (S &c.) -A2- Also [The vice of kicking, or striking with the hind leg or with both the hind legs;] a subst. from ramaHa said of any solid-hoofed animal: (Msb, TA:) it is a vice for which an animal that has been sold may be returned. (TA.) One says, huwa *uw rimaAHK [He has a vice of kicking]. (A.) And A^aboraA^u A_ilayoka mina AljimaAHi waAlr~amaAHi [I am irresponsible to thee for the vice of overcoming the rider and running away with him, and the vice of kicking]. (TA.) [And ↓ ramoHapN, in like manner, signifies A trick of kicking: see an ex. voce jamoHapN.]

ramuwHN * and ↓ ram~aAHN [A horse, or the like, that has a habit of kicking]. You say daAb~apN ramuwHN EaDuwDN and EaD~aADapN ↓ ram~aAHapN, [A kicking, biting, beast]. (A.) And naAqapN ramuwHN (tropical:) A kicking she-camel. (TA.)
rumayoHN * : see rumoHN, [of which it is the dim.], in three places.
rimaAHapN * , The art of making rimaAH [spears, or lances]. (S, A, * K.) See the next paragraph.

ram~aAHN *
A maker of rimaAH [spears, or lances]. (S, A, * Msb, K.) You say, huwa ram~aAHN HaA*iqN fiY ↓ Alr~imaAHapi [He is a maker of spears or lances, skilful in the art of making them]. (A.) ― -b2- See also raAmiHN. -A2- See also ramuwHN, in two places. ― -b2- qawosN ram~aAHapN A bow that propels [the arrow] vehemently. (K.) The word rm~AHp used [app. in this sense, without a subst.,] by Tufeyl El-Ghanawee is expl. by some as meaning A thrust, or piercing, with the rumoH; but no way of resolving this is known, unless it be used in the place of ↓ ramoHapN, as the inf. n. of un. of ramaHa. (L.) -A3- Also (tropical:) Poverty, need, or want. (K, TA. [This meaning is erroneously assigned in Freytag's Lex. to rumoHN.])

raAmiHN *
Thrusting, or piercing, another with a rumoH [i. e. spear, or lance]. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Also (S [in the Msb “ or ”]) A man having a rumoH [spear, or lance]; (S, Msb, K;) and so ↓ ram~aAHN: (L:) the former an epithet [of the possessive kind,] similar to laAbinN and taAmirN, having no verb. (S.) ― -b3- Als~imaAku Alr~aAmiHu is the name of (tropical:) [The star Arcturus;] a certain star, before, or preceding, Alfak~ap [or Corona Borealis], preceded by another star, [the star η in the left leg of Bootes,] which is called its ↓ rumoH [or spear, i. e. rumoHu Als~imaAki and simply Alr~umoHu], (S, K,) whence its name: it is one of two stars which are together called Als~imaAkaAni; and is not one of the Mansions of the Moon: (S:) it is also called Als~imaAku Almirozamu: (Az, TA:) the other smAk [is Spica Virginis, the Fourteenth Mansion of the Moon, and] is called AlA^aEozalu, because it has no star [near] before
it: AlrAmH is more red. (TA.) ― -b4- raAmiHN also signifies (tropical:) A bull; so called because of his pair of horns: (A:) [i. e.] a wild bull; thought by ISd to be so called because of his horn: (TA:) or vaworN raAmiHN signifies a [wild] bull having a pair of horns. (S, K.)

1 ramaduwA * , (Sh, T, M, A, L,) [aor., app.,
ramida ,] inf. n. ramodN; (M, L;) and ↓ ArmdwA; (Sh, T, M, L;) for which A 'Obeyd erroneously says ramiduwA, with kesr to the m; and ↓ ArmduwA, with teshdeed to the d; (T, L;) They (a people, or party,) perished: (Sh, T, M, A, L:) or became like ramaAd [or ashes]: (A:) and ramada Eayo$uhumo, (L,) or ↓ Armd Ey$hm, (TA,) has the former meaning. (L, TA.) And ramada [so in the T and L and TA, not ramuda,] aor.
ramuda , inf. n. rumuwdapN, It (a garment, En-Nadr, T, or a thing, TA) perished by becoming old and wornout, and had no goodness and lastingness. (En-Nadr, T, L, TA.) ― -b2- ramadati Alganamu, (S, M, K,) aor.
ramida , (S, K,) inf. n. ramodN, (S,) The sheep, or goats, perished by reason of cold, or of hoar-frost or rime. (S, M, K.) -A2- ramada, (AZ, ISk, T, S, Nh, Msb,) aor.
ramuda , (AZ, T,) or
ramida , (Msb,) or both, (ISk, S,) inf. n. ramodN; (AZ, ISk, T, S, Msb;) or ↓ rm~d; (M, TT;) and ↓ Armd; (M, Nh, L;) He, (God, M, TA, or a man, Msb,) or it, (a company of men, ISk, S,) destroyed (AZ, ISk, T, S, Msb) a person or thing, (L, Msb,) or people: (AZ, ISk, T, S, M:) or destroyed, and rendered like ashes. (Nh.) -A3- ramida, (S, M, L, K) aor.
ramada , (S, L,) inf. n. ramadN; (S, M, L;) and ↓ A^uromida, or ↓ Airomad~a; (accord. to different copies of the K;) He (a man, S) was, or became, affected with pain and swelling of the eye; (M;) with inflammation thereof; or with ophthalmia; syn. haAjato Eayonuhu. (S, L, K. *) And ramidato Eayonuhu, (T, A, L, Msb,) aor.
ramada , (L, Msb,) inf. n. ramadN; (T, A, L, Msb, K;) and ↓ A^aromidato; (T, Msb;) or ↓ Airomad~ato, (TA,) inf. n. AiromidaAdN; (K, TA;) His eye was, or became, painful and swollen, inflamed, or affected with ophthalmia; syn. haAjato. (L, K, * TA.)

2 rm~dhu * , (M, A,) inf. n. taromiydN, (S,) He put ashes into it, (M, * A,) or upon it; (M;) namely, roast meat: (M, A:) or he put it (a thing) into ashes. (S.) It is said in a prov., $awaY A^axuwka Hat~aY A_i*aA A^anoDaja ram~ada [Thy brother roasted, until, when he had thoroughly cooked the meat, he put ashes into it, or put it into the ashes]: (T, S, M, A:) meaning (tropical:) Thy brother did a good deed and then marred it: (A:) [i. e.] it is applied to him who mars, or corrupts, that which he has put into a good, or right, state: (T:) or to him who does a kind act, and then mars it by reproach, or cuts it short. (IAth.) ― -b2- Also He put it (namely, flesh-meat to be roasted,) into live coals. (M.) ― -b3- See also 1. -A2- ram~adato, (AZ, T, S, M, K,) inf. n. taromiydN; (S) and ↓ Armdt; (S, K;) said of a ewe, or she-goat, (AZ, T, S, M,) and of a she-camel, (S, M, K,) and of a cow, (S,) She secreted milk in her udder a little before her bringing forth; syn. A^aDoraEato: (S, K:) or she showed herself to be pregnant, and became large in her udder; as also A^aDoraEato: (AZ, T:) or she secreted a little milk at the time of bringing forth: (T:) or she showed herself to be pregnant, and became large in her belly and swollen in her udder and her vulva: or she secreted somewhat [of milk] at the time of bringing forth, or a little before it: the epithet applied to her in this case is ↓ muram~idN [without p]. (M.) [See also rab~adato.] One says, ram~adati AlD~aA^onu farab~iqo rab~iqo [The ewes have secreted milk in their udders, &c.]: (I Aar, T, S:) therefore prepare thou the A^arobaAq: prepare thou the ArbAq: [i. e., the loops into which their heads are to be inserted:] for the ewes secrete milk in their udders only EalaY raA^osi Alwaladi [i. e. at the time of bringing forth, or when about to produce the young]. (S.) And [in like manner,] ram~adati AlmiEozaY faran~iqo ran~iq. (IAar, T. [See also arts. rmq and rnq.])

4 Armd * , as an intrans. v.: see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) inf. n. A_iromaAdN, said of a man, (S,) He was, or became, poor, needy, or indigent. (S, K.) And Armd Alqawomu The people were, or became, afflicted with drought, barrenness, or dearth, (A, K, TA,) and their cattle perished (K, TA) in consequence thereof. (TA.) -A2- See also 1, last two sentences. -A3- And see 2. -A4- As a trans. v.: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph. -A5- Armd Eayonahu He, (God, S, M, L, K,) and it, (weeping, A, TA,) caused his eye to become painful and swollen, inflamed, or affected with ophthalmia. (S, M, L, K, TA.)

9 Armd~wA * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Armd~, said of a man's face, i. q. Arbd~ [as meaning It became like the colour of ramaAd or ashes; or it became altered by reason of anger]. (A, TA.) -A2- See also 1, last two sentences. -A3- Also, inf. n. AiromidaAdN, said of a camel, accord. to AA, He ran vehemently; and so Arqd~: or, accord. to As, both signify he went at random, heedlessly, headlong, or in a headlong course; and quickly: (T:) or he went quickly, or a quick pace; accord. to some, specially said of the ostrich: (M, L:) or he ran in the manner of the rumod [meaning ostriches]. (A.
Q. Q. 4 Airomiy^odaAdN * [inf. n. of AiromaA^ad~a] The going, or acting, vigorously, or with energy. (M, TA.)
ramodN * : see ramaAdapN.

ramidN * , applied to water, Turbid: (T:) or altered for the worse in taste and colour, though still drinkable; (Es-Sijistánee, S, A, K;) as also ↓ muromidN. (Lh, L.) ― -b2- And, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, Faded; syn. faAsxN; as also ↓ A^aromadu [q. v.]. (A, TA.) -A2- Also, (S, L. Msb, K,) and ↓ A^aromadu, (S, M, A, L, Msb, K,) and ↓ muromadN, or ↓ muromad~N, (accord. to different copies of the K,) A man affected with pain and swelling of the eye; with inflammation thereof; or with ophthalmia: (S, M, A, * L, Msb, * K:) fem. of the first ramdapN, (Msb,) and of the second ↓ ramodaA='u, (M, Msb,) [and pl. of the second ↓ rumodN.] And EayonN ramidapN (S, M, L) and ↓ ramodaA='u (M, A, L) An eye painful and swollen, inflamed, or affected with ophthalmia: (S, M, A, * L:) pl. of the latter ↓ EuyuwnN rumodN. (A.)

rumodapN *
Ash-colour; the colour of ramaAd; as also rubodapN: (A in art. rbd:) a colour like wuroqapN, inclining to blackness; and so rubodapN: (T in that art.:) a colour inclining to that of dust. (M.)
maA tarakuwA A_il~aA rimodapa Hat~aAna mA trkwA AlA rmdp HtAn , or Hat~aAnK, (as in different copies of the K,) a phrase expl. in art. Ht.

ramaAdN rimodidN * (S, M, K) and rimodadN, (K,) which latter is abnormal, (TA,) or ramodadN, (so accord. to a copy of the T,) and ↓ rimodiydN and ↓ A^aromadu, (M, K,) Ashes perishing, or coming to nought: (S, K:) or much in quantity, and very fine or minute: (M, K:) or reduced to the finest, or most minute, state: (T, TA:) or rimodidN signifies burnt to the utmost degree, and reduced to the finest, or most minute, state. (IAth, TA.)
rimodidaA='u * : see ramaAdN.
rimodiydN * : see rimodidN.

ramaAdN *
Ashes; i. e. charcoal reduced to particles T, M) by being burnt; (T;) burnt coals that have become mixed with dust, and extinguished, and reduced to particles: (M:) and ↓ rimodidaA='u signifies the same; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ A^aromidaA='u, like A^arobiEaA='u, (so in some copies of the K, and in a copy of the S,) or ↓ A^aromadaA='u, like A^arobaEaA='u, (so in other copies of the K,) or ↓ A_iromidA='u; (so in two copies of the S, there said to be like A_irobiEaA='u, and so in the M;) as some say; or ↓ A^aromidaA='u is a pl. of ramaAdN, as is also A^aromdapN; and ↓ A_iromidaA='u, which is mentioned on the authority of Kr, and which is [said to be] the only word of its measure, [though A_irobiEaA='u also is mentioned by IHsh,] is a quasi-pl. n.: (M:) [ramaAdN is a coll. gen. n.;] and ↓ ramaAdapN [is its n. un., and as such] signifies a portion thereof. (M.) [Hence] one says, fulaAnN kaviyru ramaAdu Alqidori [lit. Such a one has many ashes of the cooking-pot]; meaning (assumed tropical:) such a one is very hospitable; has many guests: (Mgh in art. ErD:) [and so huwa kaviyru Alr~amaAdi:] and huwa EaZiymu Alr~amaAdi (assumed tropical:) he has many guests: because the ashes become much in quantity in consequence of cooking. (L, from a trad.) And sufiYa Alr~amaAdu fiY wajohihi [lit. Ashes were blown and scattered in his face]; meaning (tropical:) his face became altered. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [maA='u Alr~amaAdi is a term applied in the present day to Lixivium, or lye; i. e. water infused with wood-ashes.]

ramaAdapN *
Perdition, destruction, or a state of destruction; (S, Msb;) as also ↓ ramodN (T, S.) Hence, (S Msb,) EaAmu Alr~amaAdapi The year of perdition or destruction, (S, Msb. K,) or of drought, (A,) in the days of 'Omar, (S, Msb, K,) the seventeenth or eighteenth year of the Flight, (TA,) in which men perished (S, M, Msb, K) in great numbers, (M,) and cattle also, (S, K,) in consequence of drought (S, Msb) long con-
tinuing, (S,) wherefore it was thus called, (S, M,) because the earth became like ashes by reason of the drought; (Msb;) or, as some say, because the drought continued so as to render the earth and the trees like the colour of ashes: but the first reason assigned above, for its being thus called, is preferable. (M.) ― -b2- See also ramaAdN.

ramaAdiY~N *
A sort of grapes, of Et-Táif, of a dusty black colour. (M.)
raAmidN * [Perishing: or becoming like ramaAd, or ashes: or] perishing by becoming old and wornout, and having no goodness and lastingness. (En-Nadr, T, L, TA.)

A^aromadu *
Of the colour of ramaAd [or ashes]; (S, M, K;) [ash-coloured; ashy;] of a dusty colour in which is a duskiness, or dinginess: (S:) [fem. ramodaA='u: and pl. rumodN.] Hence ramodaA='u applied to A female ostrich: (S, K:) [and rumodN applied to ostriches: (see 9, last sentence:)] and hence also rumodN applied to gnats (T, S, A, L, K) of a certain species: (T:) and you say naEaAmapN ramodaA='u (M, A) i. e. [an ostrich or a female ostrich,] of an obscure black hue, like the colour of ashes: (M:) and ZaliymN A^aromadu [a male ostrich of such a colour]: (M:) and naEaAmN rumodN [ostriches of such a colour]: (A:) and viyaAbN rumodN garments, or pieces of cloth, of a dusty colour in which is a duskiness, or dinginess; from ramaAdN. (T.) Lh asserts that the m in this word is a substitute for b. (M, L. [See A^arobadu.]) ― -b2- See also ramidN, in six places. ― -b3- And see rimodidN.
A^aromadaA='u * and A^aromidaA='u and A_iromidaA='u: see ramaAdN, in five places.
muromadN * : see ramidN.

muromidN * A she-camel, (Ks, T, TA,) and a cow, and a ewe, or she-goat, (TA,) secreting milk in her udder a little before her bringing forth; (Ks, T, TA;) as also murid~N: (Ks, T:) or both signify a she-camel having her udder shining, and infused with milk. (Ks, L in art. rd.) [See also muram~idN, in the second paragraph of this art.] ― -b2- See also ramidN.
muromad~N * : see ramidN.
muram~adN * Flesh-meat roasted in live coals. (T, S. *)
muram~idN * : see 2.

muromay^id~N *
Going, or acting, vigorously, or with energy: (K, * TA:) AljaAriY, in the explanation given in the K, is a mistake for AljaAd~u. (TA. [See Q. Q. 4.])

1 ramaza * , (S, A, &c.,) aor.
ramuza , and
ramiza , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. ramozN (S, A, Msb, K) and rumozN and ramazN, (K,) He made a sign, (S, A, Msb, K, TA,) in indication of a thing that might be shown or pointed out by utterance, with anything: (L, TA:) or with the lips; (S, A, K, TA;) as also ↓ trm~z; (TA in art. nfS;) putting them in motion by speech not understood by means of utterance; not vocally manifested: (TA:) or with the lip: (Msb:) or with the eyebrow: (S, A, Msb:) or with the eyebrows: (K:) or with the eye: (Msb:) or with the eyes; (K;) as also ↓ trm~z: (TA in art. nfS:) or with the mouth: or with the hand or arm: (K:) or with the tongue, (K, TA,) by uttering a low voice: (K, B, TA:) but also applied to signify he made any sign or indication. (B, TA.) You say, ramaza A_ilayohi He made a sign to him with the lips, or eyebrow. (A.) And ramazatohu AlmaroA^apu biEayonihaA The woman made a sign to him with her eye. (TA.) And kal~amahu ramozFA [He talked to him by making signs &c.]. (A.)
5 taram~aza see 1, in two places.

6 trAmzwA * [They made signs, or indications, in one or other of the manners described above, one to another]. You say, daxalotu Ealayohimo fatagaAmazuwA wataraAmazuwA [I went in to them, and they made signs and indications, &c., one to another]. (A, TA.)
ramazN * : see raAmizN.
ramuwzN * : see raAmizN.

ram~aAzN * [Making frequent signs, in one or other of the manners described above; like ramuwzN]. You say, AimoraA^apN ram~aAzapN A woman who makes frequent signs. &c.; who has a habit of doing so; syn. gam~aAzapN. (TA.) And jaAriyapN gam~aAzapN biyadihaA ham~aAzapN biEayonihaA lam~aAzapN bifamihaA ram~aAzapN biHaAjibihaA [A girl who makes frequent signs with her hand or arm, who does the like with her eye, who does the like with her mouth, who does the like with her eyebrow]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S, TA,) ram~aAzapN signifies [also] An adulteress, or a fornicatress: (Sh, S, K:) a prostitute: (A:) because she makes signs with her eye. (S, TA.) [See also zam~aArapN.]

raAmizN *
Making a sign, as [with the lips, &c., as described above, or] with the hand, or arm, or with the head: pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] ↓ ramazN. In the Kur iii. 36, instead of ramozFA, some read ramazFA; meaning as here explained: and some read rumuzFA, meaning doing so mutually; pl. of ↓ ramuwzN [which is an intensive form, meaning, making frequent signs &c.; like ram~aAzN]. (Bd.)

1 ramasahu * , (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
ramusa (M, Mgh, Msb) and
ramisa , (M, Msb,) inf. n. ramosN, (A, Msb, K,) He buried him, or it; (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely, a dead person; a corpse: (S, Mgh, Msb:) this is [said to be] the primary signification: (A:) as also ↓ Armshu: (S, Msb:) or he buried him, and made the earth even over him. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Zeyd Ibn-Soohán, vum~a A@romusuwniY Then do ye bury me: or it may mean, conceal my grave, and make it even with the ground. (Mgh.) ― -b2- He poured, (M,) or scattered, (A,) dust, or earth, upon it; (M, A;) namely, anything. (M.) You say also, ramasahu biAlt~uraAbi [in this sense]. (A.) And ramasonaAhu biAlt~urobi We filled it up with dust, or earth. (M.) And it is said in a trad. of Ibn-Maakil, AuromusuwA qaboriY, meaning Make ye my grave even with the ground; not gibbous, or elevated. (TA.) ― -b3- He concealed, and covered, him, or it: this is [also said to be] the primary signification. (TA.) You say, ramasa Al$~aYo'a, aor.
ramusa , inf. n. ramosN, He, or it, effaced, or obliterated, the traces, or remains, of the thing. (M.) And Alr~iyHu taromusu AlA=vaAra bimaA tuviyruhu [The wind effaces the traces, or remains, by what it raises, of dust or sand &c.]. (A.) And ramasuwA qabora fulaAnK They concealed the grave of such a one, and made it even with the ground. (S.) And ramasotu Alxabara, (K, * Msb,) and AlHadiyva, (TA,) I concealed the news, or information, (K, * Msb,) and the story. (TA.) And ramasotu Ealayohi Alxabara, (S, M,) and AlA^amora, (As A,) I concealed from him the news, or information, (S, M,) and the affair. (As, A.) ― -b4- rumisa Hub~uka fiY qalobiY The love of thee hath become vehement, and firmly settled, [as though buried,] in my heart. (A, TA.) -A2- ramasotuhu biHajarK, (S,) inf. n. ramosN, (K,) I cast a stone at him. (Ibn- 'Abbád, S, K. *)
4 A^aromasa see 1, first signification.

8 Artms fiY AlmaA='i *
i. q. Ainogamasa (Mgh, Msb) or Aigotamasa (K) [He immersed himself in the water]; or so that his head and whole person became concealed therein; the doing of which by one fasting is forbidden in a trad.: (Sh, Sgh;) or not remaining long in the water; (Mgh, TA;) whereas Angms and Agtms denote [the doing so and] remaining long in the water; and agreeably with this explanation of the difference, the two verbs are used in another trad., where it is said, AlS~aAy^imu yarotamisu walaA yanogamisu The faster may immerse himself not remaining long in the water, but not immerse himself and remain long therein. (TA.)

ramosN *
Dust, or earth: (Msb:) or dust with which the wind effaces traces or remains: (M:) or dust, or earth, that is scattered upon a corpse: (A:) or dust, or earth, of a grave: (S, Mgh, K:) an inf. n. used as a subst. (S, * Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) A grave; (M, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ raAmuwsN and ↓ maromasN: (K:) or a grave that is made even with the surface of the ground; not elevated: (TA:) and ↓ maromasN signifies the place of a grave; (S;) or of a ramos: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] of ramosN is A^aromaAsN (M, K) and [of mult.] rumuwsN. (M, Msb, K.) -A2- A low, gentle, or soft, sound or voice. (M, TA.)
ramiysN * : see maromuwsN, in two places.

Alr~aAmisaAtu * (AHn, M, A, K) and Alr~awaAmisu, (AHn, S, M, &c.,) [each pl. of Alr~aAmisapu,] The winds that bury traces or remains; (K;) the winds that raise the dust, and [spread it so as to] bury traces or remains: (S:) or the winds that transport the dust from one district to another which is some days distant from the former, and sometimes cover the whole face of a land with the dust of another land. (AHn, M.) ― -b2- rawaAmisu also signifies Flying things (TayorN) that fly by night: or any creeping thing (daAb~ap) that comes forth by night (ISh, K)
is called raAmisN. (ISh.) ― -b3- It also occurs as a possessive epithet, or as an act. part. n. in the place of a pass. part. n. (M.)
raAmuwsN * : see ramosN; for the latter, in two places.
maromasN * : see ramosN; for the latter, in two places.

maromuwsN *
Buried; as also ↓ ramiysN: (M, TA:) having dust, or earth, poured upon it; as also ↓ the latter epithet. (TA.) ― -b2- xabarN maromuwsN Concealed news or information. (TA.)

waqaEuwA fiY maromuwsapK mino A^amorihimo *
They fell into a state of confusion in respect of their affair, or case. (IAar, M.)

1 ramiSato Eayonuhu * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ramaSa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. ramaSN, (Msb,) His eye had in it what is termed ramaSN [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) And ramiSa, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, He had what is termed ramaSN. (M.) -A2- ramaSotu A_ilayohi, aor.
ramuSa , inf. n. ramoSN, I looked towards him, or at him, with the most secret look. (O, TA.)

4 ArmShu *
It (disease) caused him to have what is termed ramaSN. (M.)

ramaSN *
Filth, [or foul matter,] (S, Mgh,) or white filth, (K,) or tough, or dry, white filth, (A,) that collects, (S, A, K,) or concretes, (Mgh,) in the inner corner of the eye: (S, A, Mgh, K:) if fluid, it is called gamaSN: (S:) or it is in the side of the eyelashes: (ISh, TA in art. gmS:) or what is fluid; what is concrete being termed gamaSN: or i. q. gamaSN, i. e. dirt which the eye emits: or smallness and sticking of the eye. (M.) You say, mano A^asaA='ahu Alr~amaSu sar~ahu AlgamaSu [Him whom tough, or dry, white filth collecting in the inner corner of the eye vexes, fluid matter therein rejoices]: for gamaS is a fresh fluid; and that is better than the tough, or dry. (A, TA.)

rumayoSaA='u * [dim. of ramoSaA='u, fem. of A^aromaSu]. ― -b2- Al$~iEoraY Alr~umayoSaA='u [i. q. Al$~iEoraY AlgumayoSaA='u, i. e., Procyon; (see Al$~aEoraY;)] one of the two stars of the *iraAE: so called because of its smallness and its littleness of light [in comparison with the other $iEoraY, which is Syrius]. (M.)
A^aromaSu * A man (S, Mgh, Msb) having, in his eye, what is termed ramaSN: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) fem. ramoSaA='u: (Msb, K:) and pl. rumoSN. (TA.)

1 ramDat AlA^aroDu * , (Mgh,) and AlHijaArapu, (A, Mgh,) [aor.
ramaDa ,] inf. n. ramaDN, (A,) The earth, or ground, (Mgh,) and the stones, (A, Mgh,) became vehemently heated by the sun. (A, Mgh.) ― -b2- ramiDa yawomunaA, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S, Msb,) and so the inf. n., (S, A, Msb,) Our day became intensely hot. (S, A, Msb, K.) ― -b3- ramiDa said of a man, (A, Mgh, TA,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Mgh, TA,) He had his fast burnt (A, Mgh, TA) by the ground, or stones, vehemently heated by the sun, (A,) or by the vehemence of the heat: (Mgh, TA:) or he was smitten, or affected, by the heat of the sun: (Ham p. 173:) and ramiDato qadamuhu his foot was burnt by the ground, or stones, vehemently heated by the sun. (S, Msb, K.) In like manner you say, ramiDati AlfiSaAlu The young camels, or young weaned camels, felt the heat of the sun from the ground, or stones, vehemently heated thereby: then is the prayer of the period called AlD~uHaY: (S:) or had their feet burned by the ground, or stones, thus heated: (Mgh, Msb:) or lay down in consequence of the intense heat of the sand, and the burning of their feet. (IAth.) And ramiDati Alganamu The sheep, or goats, from pasturing in intense heat, had their livers ulcerated, (S, K,) and their lungs affected with dropsy: (S:) or had their lungs and livers affected with dropsy, and ulcerated. (L.) And ramiDato Eayonuhu His eye became hot, so that it almost burned: the verb occurs in this sense in a trad., as some relate it, with D [instead of S]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, said of a man fasting, His inside became vehemently hot (Fr, K) by reason of intense thirst. (Fr, TA.) ― -b5- And, said of a man, He went upon ground, or stones, vehemently heated by the sun. (TA.) ― -b6- And He returned from the desert to the region of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land. (L, TA.) ― -b7- You say also, ramiDotu mina AlA^amori and ramiDotu lahu and ↓ AirotamaDotu (tropical:) [meaning I was distressed and disquieted by reason of the thing, or affair: or I grieved for it]: (A:) [for] mino ka*aA ↓ ArtmD signifies (tropical:) he was distressed and disquieted by reason of such a thing: (S, K, TA:) and ↓ ArtmD lifulaAnK (tropical:) he grieved for such a one; i. q. Hazina lahu, accord. to the [S and] L [and CK]: or i. q. Hadiba lahu, [but this I think a mistranscription, for you say Hadiba Ealayohi, not Hadiba lahu,] accord. to the O and [some copies of the] K. (TA.) -A2- ramaDahu AlHar~u: see 4. ― -b2- s ramaDa Alganama, (K,) aor.
ramiDa , inf. n. ramoDN, (TA,) He pastured the sheep, or goats, upon ground vehemently heated by the sun, (K, TA,) and made them to lie down upon it; (TA;) as also ↓ ArmDhA; and ↓ rm~DhA, (K, TA,) inf. n. taromiyDN. (TA.) ― -b3- ramaDa Al$~aApa, aor.
ramiDa , (S, M, K,) inf. n. ramoDN, (S, M,) He clave the sheep, or goat, leaving its skin upon it, and threw it upon heated stones, and put hot ashes upon it, in order that it might become thoroughly cooked: (S, K:) or he kindled a fire upon stones, then clave the sheep, or goat, with its skin upon it, then broke its ribs from within, in order that it might lie steadily upon the ground, with the heated stones beneath it, and hot ashes above it, a fire being kindled over it: when it is thoroughly cooked, they skin it and eat it: (M, TA:) you say also ↓ ArmD Al$~aApa: ― -b4- and rumiDa All~aHomu [The flesh was dressed in the manner above described]. (TA.) -A3- ramuDa, if used, is the verb whereof ↓ ramaADapN, which is mentioned by Sh and in the K, is the inf. n.; and accord. to the explanation of the latter in the K, signifies It (a large or broad knife or blade) was, or became, sharp. (TA.) -A4- ramaDa Aln~aSola, (S, K,) or AlmuwsaY, (A,) aor.
ramiDa , and
ramuDa , (S, K,) He put the blade between two smooth stones, and then beat it, to make it thin: (ISk, S, K: [but in the text of the K, as given in the TA, the word rendered “ stones ” is omitted:]) or he beat the razor between two stones, in order that it might become thin; as also ↓ ArmD. (A.)

2 rm~Dhu * , inf. n. taromiyDN, (S, A, K,) originally signifies He attributed to him A_iromaAD [meaning the causing one to be burnt by the heat of the sun, or by the vehemently-heated ground: or (assumed tropical:) the giving pain:] and hence, as this results from tardiness, (A, TA,) ― -b2- (tropical:) He waited expecting him a while: (Ks, Jm, S, A, O:) or a little while, and then went away. (Sh, * K.) IF says that the m may be original, or it may be a substitute for b. (TA.) ― -b3- rm~D Alganama: see ramaDa. -A2- ram~aDotu AlS~awoma I purposed fasting or the fast [app. during the month of ramaDaAn]. (Sgh, K.)

4 A^aromaDatoniY Alr~amoDaA='u *
The ground, or stones, vehemently heated by the sun, burned me. (S.) And ArmDhu AlHar~u The heat burned him; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ ramaDahu, aor.
ramiDa . (TA.) And ArmD AlHar~u Alqawoma (Jm, A, K) The heat distressed the people, or company of men; (Jm, K;) so that it hurt them. (K.) You say also, gaw~iruwA binaA faqado A^aromaDotumuwnaA (Jm, A) Make ye the camels to lie down with us during the vehement midday-heat [for ye have caused us to be burnt by the heat of the sun, or by the vehemently-heated ground]. (Jm, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ArmDhu (tropical:) It (anything, AA) pained him. (AA, K.) And ArmDhu AlA^amoru (tropical:) [The thing, or affair, pained him] is a phrase which has originated from the first of the phrases mentioned in this paragraph. (S, TA.) ― -b3- ArmD Alganama: see 1. ― -b4- ArmD Al$~aApa: see 1. -A2- ArmD AlmuwsaY: see 1, last signification.

5 trm~D AlZ~ibaA='a *
He drove the gazelles upon the ground, or stones, vehemently heated by the sun, until their hoofs became dissundered, or dislocated, and so they were taken: (A:) or he hunted them during the vehement midday-heat, (S, K,) pursuing them until, their legs being dislocated by the vehemently-heated ground, he took them. (S, TA.) -A2- Alt~aram~uDu also signifies The heaving of the soul [or stomach]; or its being agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. gavayaAnu Aln~afosi. (IAar, K.)

8 ArtmD *
He burned by reason of vehement heat, or (assumed tropical:) of grief. (Har p. 442.) ― -b2- ArtmDt kabiduhu His liver became in a corrupt, or disordered, state. (S, O, K.) And ArtmD Alr~ajulu The man became in a corrupt, or disordered, state, in his belly and his stomach. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- See also ramiDotu mina AlA^amori, in three places. -A2- ArtmDt Alfarasu bihi The horse, or mare, leaped with him: (K:) so said Mudrik El-Kilábee: as also Artmzt. (A boo-Turáb, TA.)

ramaDN * The vehemence of the action (lit. of the falling) of the sun upon the sand &c.: (S, A, K:) or vehemence of heat; (Mgh, Msb;) as also ↓ ramoDaA='u: (Mgh, TA:) or the heat of the stones, arising from the intense heat of the sun: or the burning of the intense heat of summer: or heat. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] tadaAxalaniY mino ha*aA AlA^amori ramDN (tropical:) [Distress and disquietude, or grief,
crept into me from, or in consequence of, this thing: see ramiDotu mina AlA^amori.] (A, TA.)

HaSFY ramiDN * , (TA,) and A^aroDN ramiDapN, (A, TA,) [Pebbles, and ground or land,] vehemently heated by the sun; or intensely heated by the vehement action of the sun thereupon. (A.) And A^aroDN ramiDapu AlHajaArapK Land of which the stones are vehemently heated by the sun. (S.) [See also ↓ ramoDaA='u.] ― -b2- ramiDapN (assumed tropical:) A woman whose thighs rub each other. (Ibn-' Abbád, Sgh, K.)
wajadotu fiY jasadiY ramaDapN * (assumed tropical:) I felt in my body what resembled maliylap [or fever in the bones]. (TA.)

ramoDaA='u * , a subst., (TA,) [or rather an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] Ground or land, (S, K,) or stones, (A, Mgh, Msb,) or sand, (IAth,) vehemently hot: (K:) or vehemently heated by the sun: (S, A, Mgh, Msb:) or vehemently hot and burning. (IAth.) [See also ramiDN.] ― -b2- It is also syn. with ramaDN as expl. above: see the latter word. (Mgh, TA.)
