saHaAbN ramaDiY~N * , and maTarN ramaDiY~N, Clouds, and rain, in the end of summer and the beginning of autumn: (K, TA:) because arriving at the period when the sun is [intensely] hot. (TA.) ― -b2- Almiyrapu Alr~amaDy~apu The wheat, or corn, that is brought, or purveyed, when the earth becomes burnt [by the sun, about July]. (M in art. dfA^.) [See art. myr.]

$ahoru ramaDaAna * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ramaDaAnu, alone, for the latter, though disapproved by some of the learned, occurs in a trad., (Mgh, Msb, TA,) and in poetry, (TA,) but not Alr~amaDaAnu, for this is incorrect, (Mgh,) The ninth of the Arabian months: (TA:) so called because, when they changed the names of the months from the ancient language, they named them according to the seasons in which they fell, (Jm, S, K,) and this month, (Jm, S,) or naAtiqN, (K,) for this was its ancient name, (TA,) agreed with the days of vehement heat: (Jm, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) [see zamanN:] or from ramiDN said of a man fasting, expl. above: (Fr, K:) or because [its effect is as though] it burned [and annulled] sins; (K;) from ramaDahu AlHar~u, expl. above; but [SM says,] I know not how that is; for I have not seen any one [except F] mention it: (TA:) the pl. is ramaDaAnaAtN (S, Msb, K) and A^aromiDaA='u (S, Msb) and A^aromiDapN (L, K) and ramaDaAnuwna (K) and ramaADiynu, (Yoo, Sgh, L, Msb,) like $aEaAbiynu, (Msb,) and A^aromuDN, which is anomalous, (IDrd, K,) is asserted by some of the lexicologists to be another pl., but this is not well established nor received. (IDrd.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad. that ramaDaAnu is One of the names of God; but this trad. is pronounced by El-Beyhakee to be of weak authority; and that it is so is evident; as no learned man has transmitted this word as such; (Msb;) [except Mujáhid; for] it is related that Mujáhid disapproved of forming a pl. from it, saying, It has been told me that it is one of the names of God: (TA:) if it be so, it is not derived (K, TA) from what has been here mentioned; (TA;) or it refers to the meaning of (assumed tropical:) The Forgiving; or He who obliterates sins. (K.)

ramiyDN * : see maromuwDN. -A2- Also Made thin by being beaten between two stones: (A:) sharpened: (S, K:) sharp: (K, TA:) applied to a knife; (Sh;) and to such as is termed $aforap; (S, K;) and to a naSol [or blade]; (S;) and to a razor (muwsaY), as also ramiyDapN; (A, TA;) and in the last of the above-mentioned senses, to anything: (S:) it is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (TA:) or it may be in the sense of the measure faAEilN, from ramuDa, though this verb may not have been heard. (Sgh, TA.)
ramaADapN * : see ramuDa.
A^aromuDN * said to be an anomalous pl. of ramaDaAnu, q. v. (IDrd, K.)
maromiDN * The place in which a sheep, or goat, is dressed in the manner described above in the explanation of ramaDa Al$~aApa. (S, TA.)

maromuwDN * Flesh-meat dressed in the manner described above in the explanation of ramaDa Al$~aApa: (S:) or roasted flesh-meat, such as is termed kaniys, [a word with which I have not met except in this place,] which is nearly the same as Haniy*, save that what is called by this last epithet is divided into fragments, and then a fire is kindled over it; as also ↓ ramiyDN. (TA.)

1 ramaqahu * , (S, Mgh, K,) aor.
ramuqa , (S, Mgh,) inf. n. ramoqN, (S,) He looked at him, or it; (S, TA;) as also ↓raAmqhu: (TA:) or he glanced lightly at him, or it; looked at him, or it, lightly, from the outer angle of the eye: (IDrd, K, TA:) or he looked long at him, or it; (Mgh;) or so ramaqahu biEayonihi, aor. and inf. n. as above: (Msb:) whence, in a trad., faramaqahu Aln~aAsu biA^aboSaArhimo [And the people looked long at him]: (Mgh:) or ramaqotuhu bibaSariY and ↓ raAmaqotuhu signify I followed him with my eye, paying attention to him, and watching him: (TA:) and ↓ rAmqhu, (TA,) inf. n. rimaAqN, (K, * TA,) he looked at him from the outer angle of the eye with a look of enmity: (K, * TA:) and ↓ rm~qhu, inf. n. taromyqN, he looked at him long from the outer angle of the eye with anger or aversion: (TA:) and ↓ rm~q, inf. n. as above, he continued looking; like rn~q. (S, TA.)

2 rm~qhu *
He, or it, stayed, or arrested, what remained in him of life. (TA.) [Hence,] humo yuram~iquwnahu bi$aYo'K They give him something sufficient to stay, or arrest, what remains in him of life. (O, TA.) ― -b2- [The inf. n.] taromiyqN also signifies The scanting of fodder and drink. (JK.) ― -b3- [And The drinking little by little.] One says, ram~adati AlmiEozaY faram~iqo ram~iqo, meaning [The she-goats have secreted milk in their udders: therefore] drink thou their milk little by little; drink thou &c.: (IF, K, TA:) because they secrete milk some days before their bringing forth: (IF, TA:) or because they will bring forth after a while. (K, TA. [See also arts. rmd and rbq and rnq : and see 5 in the present art.]) ― -b4- Also The doing a work not well, yet so as to satisfy oneself, or to attain one's desire, thereby. (K, TA. [See also 3.]) You say, huwayuram~iqu fiY Al$~aYo'i He does not exert himself, or take pains, or exceed the usual bounds, in doing the thing. (TA.) And ram~iqo EalaY mazaAdatayoka Repair thou thy pair of leathern water-bags sufficiently to satisfy thyself. (O, TA.) ― -b5- And The interlarding, or embellishing, of speech, or discourse, with falsehood; taromiyqu AlkalaAmi signifying taloqiyquhu; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) as also tarobiyquhu. (Ibn-'Abbád and K in art. rbq.) You say, rm~q AlkalaAma He interlarded, or embellished, the speech, or discourse, with falsehood, (laf~aqahu, Z, or laf~aqa bayonahu, JK,) [adding] thing after thing, or thing by thing. (Z, TA.) -A2- See also 1, in two places.

3 raAomaqa [rAmq seems to signify He strove, or contended, to retain what remained in him of life. And hence, as implying this meaning, He was at the last gasp: see muraAmiq, below. Whence, app.,] the inf. n. muraAmaqapN signifies (assumed tropical:) The having little friendship [remaining in the heart]. (KL. [See, again, muraAmiqN.]) One says, h`*ihi Aln~axolapu turaAmiqu biEiroqK laA taHoyaA walaA tamuwtu; or laA yaHoyaA walaA yamuwtu; [as though meaning, accord. to the former reading, This palm-tree strives to retain life with a root, being neither alive nor dead; or, accord. to the latter reading, with a root that is neither alive nor dead;] (S; [in one of my copies of which I find only the former reading; and in the other, both readings;]) or h`*ihi Aln~axolapu turaAmiqu biEiroqK means this palm-tree is neither alive nor dead. (K.) And fulaAnN yuraAmiqu Eayo$ahu i. e. yudaAriyhi [app. meaning Such a one strives by artful means to preserve his life]. (TA.) ― -b2- [The inf. n.] rimaAqN also signifies The being hypocritical, or acting hypocritically; (K, TA;) [like rifaAqN; see 3 in art. rfq;] which is nearly the same in meaning as mudaAraApN; because the hypocrite strives to deceive by lying: mentioned by Hr in the “ Ghareebeyn. ” (TA.) ― -b3- rAmq AlA^amora, (S, K,) inf. n. muraAmaqapN, (TA,) He did, or performed, the thing, or affair, unfirmly, or unsoundly. (S, K, TA. [See also 2.]) -A2- See also 1, in three places.
4 A^aromaqa [Armq is said by Golius, on the authority of a gloss in the KL, to signify He rendered water turbid; for Arnq.]

5 trm~q *
He drank milk little by little. (K. [See also 2.]) And He supped, or sipped, water, (S, K,) &c., sup after sup, or sip after sip. (K.)

9 Armq~ *
It (a skin, or hide, A_ihaAbN,) was, or became, thin. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, said of life or the means of subsistence (AlEayo$u) [as meaning (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, narrow in its circumstances, or scanty; like raq~a]. (TA.) ― -b3- It (an affair, S, or a thing, IDrd, K,) was, or became, weak; (IDrd, S, K;) and so ↓ ArmAq~ said of a rope: (S, K:) or the former verb, said of a rope, it was, or became, weak in its strands. (IDrd, TA.) ― -b4- Armq~t Alganamu The sheep, or goats, died: (IDrd, K:) and ↓ ArmAq~t they (sheep, or goats,) perished, or died,
by reason of leanness, or emaciation: (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA:) or ArmAq~ signifies he perished, or died, by reason thereof. (K.) ― -b5- Armq~ AlT~ariyqu The road was, or became, long. (TA: but the verb is there written without the sheddeh.)
11 A_iromaAoq~a see 9, in two places.

ramaqN * The remains of life, (Lth, K,) or of the spirit, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or of the soul; (IDrd, TA;) or the last breath: (TA:) and applied also to strength: (Msb:) pl. A^aromaAqN. (K.) It is said that a man in a case of necessity may eat of that which has died a natural death maAyasud~u Alr~amaqa, i. e. [What will stay, or arrest, the remains of life; or] what will maintain, and preserve, the strength. (Msb.) [In like manner, also,] one says, of sustenance, yumosiku Alr~amaqa [It stays, or arrests, the remains of life; or maintains the strength]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- See also rumoqapN. -A2- Also A flock of sheep, or herd of goats: (S, K:) a Pers. word, (S,) arabicized, (S, K,) from ramaho. (K.)

Eayo$F ramiqN *
Sustenance that stays, or arrests, the remains of life; or that maintains the strength; expl. by yumosiku Alr~amaqa. (IF, Msb, K.) -A2- [And accord. to Golius, on the authority of a gloss in the KL, ramiqN is used for rawonaqN, as signifying Fairness, beauty, or brightness: and also as meaning Bright, and clear.]

rumuqN * , a pl., signifying Poor men, who are satisfied with little sustenance, such as suffices to stay, or arrest, the remains of life, or to maintain the strength: ― -b2- and envying persons: sing. ↓ raAmiqN and ↓ ramuwqN: (IAar, K, TA:) which signifies one. who looks at men from the outer angle of the eye and with envy. (IAar, TA.)

maA fiY Eayo$ihi A_il~aA rumoqapN * , (JK, K,) with damm, (K,) or ↓ ramaqapN, (S, [so in both of my copies,]) and ↓ rimaAqN, (S,) or ↓ ramaAqN, (JK,) or both, and ↓ ramaqN, (K,) There is not in his means of subsistence save what is but just sufficient: (S, K:) or a small supply, that may stay, or arrest, the remains of life, or that may maintain the strength. (K.) The Arabs said, mawotN laA yajur~u A_ilaY EaArK xayorN ↓ mino Eayo$K fiY ramaAqK [Death that does not lead to disgrace is better than life with a bare sufficiency of sustenance]. (Yaakoob, TA.)
ramaqapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
ramaAqN * : see rumoqapN, in two places.

rimaAqN * , Straitness, or narrowness, of the means of subsistence. (K. [In the CK, for AlD~iyqu is put AlD~ay~iqu, which makes the meaning to be “ strait, ” or “ narrow, ” as applied to the means of subsistence.]) ― -b2- See also rumoqapN.
ramuwqN * : see rumuqN.

rum~aqN *
Weak; (K;) applied to a man. (TA.)

raAmiqN * , applied to a man, i. q. *uw ramaqK [i. e. Having, or retaining, remains of life: a possessive epithet, of the class of laAbinN and taAmirN & c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also rumuqN. [And see muraAmiqN.] -A2- Also The bird that the sportsman sets up in order that the falcon, or hawk, may alight upon it and so he may capture it; (K;) also called raAmijN and milowaAHN: he takes an owl, and ties something black to its leg, and sews up its eyes, and ties to its shanks a long string; and when the falcon, or hawk, alights upon it, he captures it from his lurking-place: mentioned by Lth and by IDrd; and thought by the latter to be not a genuine Arabic word. (TA.)
HabolN A^aromaAqN * [in which the latter word is a pl., like A^aromaAvN in the phrase HabolN A^aromaAvN,] A rope that is weak, (S, K, TA,) old and worn out. (TA.)

Eayo$N muromaq~N * and ↓ muram~aqN Mean, paltry, or scanty, means of subsistence. (S, O.) And huwa muromaq~u AlEayo$i, (A 'Obeyd, K,) and ↓ muram~aquhu, (IDrd, K,) He is one who has mean, paltry, or scanty, means of subsistence: (A 'Obeyd, K:) or he is straitened in the means of subsistence. (IDrd, K.) ― -b2- muromaq~N also signifies Anything bad, or corrupt. (TA.)
muram~aqN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
muraAmiqN * One who is at the last gasp. (TA.) [See also raAmiqN.] ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) One who has but little love, or affection, for thee remaining in his heart. (S, K.)
yaromuwqN * A weak-sighted man. (IDrd, K.)

1 ramaka biAlmakaAni * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ramuka , (S,) inf. n. rumuwkN, (S, K,) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place, (S, Msb, K,) not quitting it: or he did so being fatigued, or wearied, or distressed: (K:) or ramaka signifies he (a man) made his home, or constant residence, in a country, or town. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- ramakati AlmaA$iyapu, (O,) or AlA_ibilu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (O,) The cattle were confined, (O,) or the camels kept constantly, (K,) at the water, (O, K,) and were fed with fodder. (O.) ― -b3- ramaka fiY AlT~aEaAmi, aor. and inf. n. as above, [app. He kept constantly to the food;] he loathed nothing of the food: and so rajana, aor.
ramuka , inf. n. rujuwnN: (L, TA:) both mentioned by Lh. (TA in art. rjn.) -A2- ramaka, said of a man, also signifies He was, or became, lean, or emaciated, and what was in his hands went away. (O, TA. [See also 9: and see ramakapN, as applied to a man.]) ― -b2- [It seems also that this verb is used in a similar sense in relation to a beast; like Armk~ said of a camel: for it is immediately added in the O and TA without any explanation, that one also says, ↓ h`*ihi daAb~apN raAmikapN, as though meaning This is a lean beast: and ramakato, inf. n. rumuwkN, as though meaning It was, or became, lean.]

4 A^aromakotuhu *
I made him to remain, stay, dwell, or abide, in a place, (S, K,) not quitting it. (K.) ― -b2- And Armk AlA_ibila He (a pastor) kept the camels constantly at the water, and fed them with fodder. (TA.)

9 Armk~ *
He was, or became, of the colour termed rumokapN: said of a camel in this sense [and in another expl. in what follows]. (S, K.) -A2- It (a thing, Ibn-'Abbád, O) was, or became, thin, or slender. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) And He (a camel) was, or became, lean, lank, light of flesh; slender; or lean, and lank in the belly; and emaciated. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K. [In the CK, nahika is erroneously put for nuhika.])
10 Aisotaromaka Alqawomu * (tropical:) The people were deemed ignoble; (K, TA;) as being likened to the ramakap. (TA.)

ramakN * : see ramakapN. ― -b2- In the saying of Ru-beh,
yarobiDu fiY Alr~awovi kabiro*awoni Alr~amako
[That lies down upon his breast in the dung of horses, or similar beasts, like the jade, or hack, of the ramak], AA says, Alrmk, here, is from the Pers. ramaho [which means a “ herd," ” “ flock, ” “ troop, ” or the like]; and he adds that the people's saying that it means Alr~amakap is a mistake. (O, TA. [Perhaps, however, AA knew not ramakN as a coll. gen. n. of which ramakapN is the n. un.; for as such it seems to me more reasonable to regard it in this instance.])

rumokapN *
A certain colour of camels; accord. to A 'Obeyd, a dun colour; i. e. a kNmotap [or brown hue] so intense as to have in it a blackness: (S:) thus explained by As: (TA:) or, in the colours of camels, brownness; i. e. redness intermixed with blackness: (Kr, TA:) or a colour more dusky, or dingy, than that which is termed zuroqap [q. v.]: (Msb:) or the colour of ashes: (K:) or wuroqapN [which is a colour like that of ashes] inclining to blackness: or, as some say, duwna Alwuroqapi [less intense than what is termed warqp]: (TA:) it sometimes has for its pl. rumukN, with two dammehs. (ISd, TA.)

ramakapN *
A mare: and [particularly] a biro*awonap [or mare of mean breed], (Lth, Mgh, K,) the female of the baraA*iyn, (S, Msb,) that is taken for breeding: (Lth, Mgh, K:) pl. rimaAkN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) accord. to rule, (Mgh,) and, ramakaAtN, (S,) and A^aromaAkN, (Fr, S, Mgh,) formed on the supposition of the elision of the p, (Mgh,) or this is a pl. pl., and the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] is ↓ ramakN. (K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A weak man. (K.)
raAmakN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

raAmikN *
Remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding, in a place, (Msb, K,) not quitting: or especially, when fatigued, or wearied, or distressed. (K.) -A2- See also 1, last sentence. -A3- Also, and ↓ raAmakN, (S, Msb, K,) the former of which is the more usual, or more approved, (TA,) A certain thing, black, (S, Msb, K,) like pitch, (Msb,) that is mixed with musk, (S, Msb, K,) and is then called (yujoEalu) musk. (Msb.) [Freytag, as on the authority of the K, in which nothing more is said respecting it than what I have given above, describes it thus: “ Res ex aliis rebus composita, nempe atramento sutorio, mali Punici cortice, gummi Arabico aliisque rebus, quibus admisceri solet muscus. ”] A poet says, (S,) namely, Khalaf Ibn-Khaleef El-Akta', (O, TA,)
A_in~a laka AlfaDola EalaY SuHobatiY
waAlmisoku qado yasotaSoHibu Alr~aAmakaA
[Verily thou hast such excellence as renders thee above my companionship; but musk sometimes unites with rAmk]. (S, O.) ― -b2- [↓ raAmakN, from the Pers. raAmako, is also the name of A certain astringent medicine, used as a remedy for dysentery &c. In the printed edition of the “ Kánoon ” of Ibn-Seenà (Avicenna), book ii. p. 253, it is erroneously written rmk.]

A^aromaku *
Of the colour termed rumokapN: (S, Msb, K:) applied to a camel: fem. ramokaA='u. (S, Msb.) The rmkA=' is said by Honeyf-el-Hanátim, who was one of the most skilled of the Arabs respecting camels, to be the most beautiful of she-camels. (TA.) The fem. is also applied, tropically, to a woman. (Th, TA.) ― -b2- A poet says, [applying it to dust,]
waAlxayolu tajotaAbu AlgubaAra AlA^aromakaA
[And the horses, or horsemen, cleave the dark brown, or ash-coloured, &c., dust]. (TA.) ― -b3- And it is said in a trad., [but to what it relates I know not,] The name of the higher, or highest, land is Alr~amokaA='u; said by IAth to be fem. of AlA^aromaku. (TA.)

1 ramala * as syn. with ram~ala: see the latter in two places. -A2- ramala AlHaSiyra, [aor. app.
ramula , and inf. n. ramolN;] and ↓ Armlhu; He wove (nasaja, A 'Obeyd, T, or saf~a, A 'Obeyd, S) the mat [of palm-leaves or the like]. (T, S.) [Or] ramala Als~ariyra, and [so in the M, but in the K “ or ”] AlHaSiyra, aor.
ramula , inf. n. ramolN, He ornamented the couch, and the mat, with jawohar [i. e. jewels, precious stones, gems, &c.], and the like. (M, K.) [Or] AlHaSiyra ↓ Arml, and ramalahu, He made the weaving of the mat thin (Har p. 55.) And ramala Aln~asoja, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (TA;) and ↓ Armlhu, and ↓ rm~lhu; (M, K; the last omitted in the TA;) He made the woven thing, or the weaving, thin. (M, K.) And ramala Als~ariyra, (S, K,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above; (TA;) and ↓ Armlhu; He wove (ramala) $ariyT [or palm leaves split and then plaited together], (S, O, K,) or some other thing, (S, O,) and made the same a back (jaEalahu ZahorFA) to the couch. (S, O, K. [What is here called the “ back ” of the couch is app. so called as being likened to the back of a beast on which one rides: see rumaAlN.]) Accord. to IKt, ramalotu Alsyr [app. a mistranscription for Als~ariyra] and ↓ A^aromalotuhu signify I wove the syr [or the sryr] with a $ariyT of leaves, or fibres, of the palm-tree. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ramalotu Alqawola and AlwaSofa [(assumed tropical:) I wove, i. e. composed, the saying and the description]. (Phrases cited in the TA from two modern poets.) -A3- ramala, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
ramula , (T, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. ramalaAnN (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and ramalN (S, M, &c.) and maromalN, (K,) said of a man, i. q. harowala [i. e. He went a kind of trotting pace, between a walk and a run]; (S, Mgh, Msb, K; [in the M said to be “ less than Alma$oYu and above AlEadowu; ” app., as is remarked in the TT, through inadvertence of a writer;]) i. e. (TA) he was quick in his manner of walking, (T, TA,) and shook his shoulder-joints, (TA,) leaping, (so in the T accord. to the TT,) or not leaping, (so in the TA,) in doing so; (T, TA;) while performing the circuitings round the Kaabeh, (T, Mgh, TA,) but only in some of those circuitings, exclusively of others, (TA,) which one does in imitation of the Prophet and his Companions, who did thus in order that the people of Mekkeh might know that there was in them strength; (T, TA;) and in going between Es-Safà and El-Marweh. (S, TA.) [It is also said of a camel: see rataka.] -A4- ramalN as an inf. n. [app. of ramila AlEaAmu or ramilati Als~anapu] signifies The year's having little rain. (KL.) ― -b2- ramilato mino zawojihaA: see 4.

2 rm~lhu * , (M, TA,) inf. n. taromiylN, (TA,) He put ramol [i. e. sand] into it; namely, food; (M, TA;) and (TA) so ↓ ramalahu, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) aor.
ramula , inf. n. ramolN; but the former verb is the more chaste. (TA.) Hence, in a trad. respecting [the eating of the flesh of] domestic asses, A^amara A^ano tukofaA^a Alquduwru waA^ano yuram~ala All~aHomu biAlt~uraAbi, meaning [He ordered that the cooking-pots should be turned upside-down, and] that the flesh should be stirred about and mixed with dust, in order that no use might be made of it. (TA.) ― -b2- And He defiled, or smeared, him, or it, with blood; (S, M, TA;) namely, a man, (S,) or a garment, and the like; (M, TA;) and (TA) so ↓ ramalahu; (K TA;) but in this sense also the former verb is the more chaste. (TA.) And rum~ila fulaAnN biAld~ami Such a one was defiled, or smeared, with blood. (T, TA. [See also 4 and 5.]) ― -b3- In relation to speech, or language, (TA,) Alt~aromiylu signifies (tropical:) i. q. Alt~azoyiyfu; (K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, Alt~aroniyfu;]) i. e., [as inf. n. of ram~ala, The adulterating it, corrupting it, or rendering it unsound, or untrue; and as inf. n. of rum~ila,] its being [adulterated, corrupted, or] unsound, or untrue. (TA. [See the pass. part. n., below.]) ― -b4- See also 1. -A2- And see 4.

4 Arml *
It (a place) became sandy; had ramol in it or upon it. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And He clave to the sand.] ― -b3- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) He became poor: (Mgh:) or (assumed tropical:) his provisions, or travelling-provisions, became difficult to obtain, and he became poor: (Msb:) or his travelling-provisions went: (Mgh:) and A^aromaluwA (tropical:) their provisions, or travel-ling-provisions, became exhausted, or consumed: (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K, TA:) from Alr~amolu; (Mgh, TA;) as though [he or] they clave to the sand; (TA;) like A^adoqaEa, (Mgh,) or A^adoqaEuwA, (TA,) from Ald~aqoEaA='u: (Mgh, TA:) or from ramalN meaning “ little rain: ” or from A^aromala AlHaSiyra and ramalahu meaning “ he made the weaving of the mat thin: ” (Har p. 55:) and ArmlwA zaAdahumo (tropical:) They exhausted, or consumed, their provisions, or travelling-provisions. (K, * TA. [In the TT, as from the M, Atx*wh is erroneously put for A^anofaduwhu, the explanation in the TA.]) ― -b4- And [hence,] Armlt, (Yz, T, S, Msb,) or, accord. to Sh, Armlt mino zawojihaA, or mn zwjhA ↓ ramilatN; (T, accord. to different copies;) and ↓ ram~alato [alone], (K, TA, [said in the latter to be on the authority of Sh, and therefore it may perhaps be taken from a copy of the T,]) inf. n. taromiylN; (TA;) (tropical:) She (a woman) became such as is termed A^aromalapN, (T, Msb, K, TA,) i. e. without a husband; (T, Msb;) because of her being in need of one to expend upon her; [for] Az says that she is not thus called unless she be also poor: (Msb:) or [she became a widow;] she lost her husband by his death. (S.) ― -b5- And Arml said of an arrow, It became defiled, or smeared, with blood, (Ibn- 'Abbád, K, TA,) and had the mark thereof remaining upon it; (Ibn-'Abbád, TA;) and so ↓ Artml. (TA. [See also 2 and 5.]) -A2- Said of a poet, it is from Alr~amalu, like A^arojaza from Alr~ajazu; (TA;) i. e. He versified, or composed verses, in the metre termed Alr~amalu. (Ibn-Buzurj, L in art. qSd.) -A3- As a trans. v.: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- Also He lengthened, or made long, a rope, or cord: (K:) and in like manner, he lengthened, and widened; or made long, and wide; a shackle, or shackles: you say, Arml lahu fiY qayodihi He lengthened, and widened, or made long, and made wide, for him his shackle, or shackles. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

5 trm~l *
He became defiled, or smeared, (T, S,) with his blood, (T,) or with blood; as also ↓ Artml. (S. [See also 2 and 4.])

8 A_irotamala see 4 and 5. -A2- You say also, Artmlt fulaAnapu fiY baniyhaA (assumed tropical:) Such a woman maintained, or undertook the maintenance of, her children, her husband having died. (O, TA. [But in both I find fY bythA, an obvious mistranscription, for which I read fY baniyhaA; and in the explanation, in both, AqAmt Elyhm, for which I read qaAmato Ealayohimo.])

ramolN * [Sand;] a kind of dust or earth, (M,) well known: (Lth, T, M, Msb, K:) ↓ ramolapN is its n. un.; (M, K;) a more special term than the former; (S;) signifying a piece, or portion, [or tract, or collection,] thereof: (Lth, T, TA:) [and the former word is also sometimes used as meaning a tract, or collection, of sand:] the pl. [of mult.] is ramaAlN (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] A^aromulN; (M, K;) [and A^aramilu is used as a pl. pl., i. e. pl. of A^aromulN; occurring in a verse cited in the TA, art. hj.] ― -b2- [Hence,] A^um~u rimaAlK a name of The hyena. (ISk, S.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] Alr~amolu, (TA in this art., [in the Lexicons of Golius and Freytag, erroneously, ramalN,]) or Eilomu Alr~amoli, i. q. Eilomu AlxaT~i, (IAar, TA in art. xT,) [Geomancy,] a certain well-known science. (TA in the present art. [See a description of it voce xaT~a.])

ramalN *
Weak rain: (IAar, T:) or little rain: (Har p. 55:) or a small quantity of rain: (ElUmawee, T, S, M, K:) one says, A^aSaAbahumo ramalN mino maTarK A small quantity of rain fell upon them: (El-Umawee, T, M:) but Sh says, “ I have not heard ramalN in this sense except on the authority of El-Umawee: ” (TA:) the pl. is A^aromaAlN. (T, S, M.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] A^aromaAlN mino A_ibilK A number of camels in a state of dispersion. (TA.) ― -b3-
Also, the sing., [as a coll. gen. n.,] Lines, or streaks, upon the legs of the wild cow, (S, M, K,) upon her fore legs and kind legs, (M,) differing from the rest of her colour: (S, M, K:) n. un. ↓ ramalapN. (TA. [See also rumolapN.]) ― -b4- And A redundance, or an excess, (ziyaAdapN,) in a thing. (K.) -A2- Alr~amalu is also the name of A certain kind of metre of verse; (T, S, M, K;) [the eighth kind;] the measure of which is [originally] composed of faAEilaAtuno (T, TA) six times; (TA;) so called from Alr~amalu signifying “ a certain kind of walk or pace, ” inf. n. of ramala [q. v.]: (M, K: *) and Kh says that it is also applied to any meagre verse or poetry, incongruous in structure; such being so named by the Arabs without their defining anything respecting it; as, for instance, the saying [of 'Abeed Ibn-El-Abras (TA in arts. *nb and qTb)],
faAlquTabiy~aAtu faAl*~anuwbu
A^aqofara mino A^aholihi maloHwbu
[Melhoob (the name of a place, K in art. lHb) has become destitute of its inhabitants, and El- Kutabeeyát, (by which is meant a certain water, called AlquTabiy~apu, with its environs, K* and TA in art. qTb,) and Edh-Dhanoob (the name of a place, TA in art. *nb)]: he says also that, generally, the majozuwo' [i. e. what is curtailed of two of the original feet, or what consists of two feet only,] is thus called by them: accord. to IJ, it is applied by them to verse, or poetry, that is incongruous, unsound, or faulty, in structure, and such as falls short of the original [standard so as not to answer completely to any regular kind or species]: (M, TA:) thus it signifies as first explained above, and also any verse, or poetry, that is not such as is termed qaSiyd [as meaning that of which the hemistichs are complete] nor such as is termed rajaz [which some hold to be not verse, or poetry, but a kind of rhyming prose]. (IJ, M, K. *) [See also zamalN.]
ramolapN * : see ramolN, of which it is the n. un.

rumolapN * sing. of rumalN, which signifies The diversity of colours (wa$oYN) upon the legs of the wild bull: (T: [see also ramalN:]) or rumolapN signifies a black line or streak, (IKh, M, IB, K,) as some say, (M,) such as is upon the back and thighs of the gazelle: (IKh, IB:) pl. [of mult.] rumalN and [of pauc.] A^aromaAlN. (K.)
ramalapN * : see ramalN.

[
ramoliY~N *
Of, or relating to, ramol (or sand): sandy.]

rumaAlN * The woven work of a mat. (K, TA.) It is said in a trad., of the Prophet, that he was lying upon his side on the rmAl of a mat, which had made an impression upon his side: (T, TA: *) or, as some relate it, of a couch; meaning, in this case, that its face was woven of palm-leaves, and that it had nothing spread upon it to lie upon, but the mat only. (TA. [See ramala Als~ariyra.])
ramiylapN * Land (A^aroD) rained upon with Alr~amal, i. e. little rain. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

ram~aAlN *
A practiser of the science called Alr~amolu [i. e. geomancy]. (TA.)
raAmilapN * sing. of rawaAmilu, (TA,) which signifies Female weavers of mats. (T, TA.)

A^aromalu *
i. q. ↓ muromilN, meaning (assumed tropical:) A man whose provisions, or travelling-provisions, have become difficult to obtain, [or exhausted, or consumed, (see 4,)] and who has become poor: [as though he were cleaving to the sand: (see again 4:)] pl. A^araAmilu: (Msb:) or A^aromalu is applied to a man, and ↓ A^aromalapN to a woman, (M, K,) and the latter also to a pl. number, (M,) as meaning needy, needing, or in want: (M, K:) or as meaning [misokiynN and] misokiynapN [and masaAkiynu, i. e. destitute, or indigent, &c.]: (K:) and the pl. is A^araAmilu and A^araAmilapN; (M, K;) after the manner of substs., because the quality of a subst. is predominant therein: (M:) ↓ A^aromalapN is applied to any collective number of men and women, or men without women, or women without men, after they have become in need or want: (M:) [and] it is applied [also] to a man and to a woman as meaning poor so as to be unable to obtain anything: (T, and Mgh as from the T:) accord. to ISk, A^araAmilu is applied to a number of men and women, as meaning masaAkiynu [expl. above]; (T, S, Mgh;) or so to a number of persons whether men or women; (Msb;) and to men though there be not among them women; (T, S, Mgh;) and so ↓ A^aromalapN: (T, Mgh:) or this last, to a number of men and women needy, needing, or in want; (S;) and to men needy, needing, or in want, and weak, (S, K,) though there be not among them women. (S.) Ibn-Buzurj mentions the saying, A_in~ bayota fulaAnK laDaxomN maA yuHom~iluwnahu A_il~aA maA A@sotafoqaruwA lahu ↓ waA_in~ahumo laA^aromalapu, meaning [Verily the household of such a one is large, and verily they are destitute of what camels they may load therewith except] what they borrow [for that purpose]; (T, * TA;) i. e., they are a party not possessing camels, and unable to make a journey except upon camels that they borrow; [AstfqrwA being] from A^ufoqira Zahora baEiyriY signifying “ he was lent the back of my camel. ” (TA.) See also A^uromuwlapN. ― -b2- ↓ A^aromalapN is also applied to a woman as meaning Having no husband: (T, S, M, Msb, K:) or a widow; one whose husband has died: (IAmb, Mgh:) or not if she possesses competence, or wealth: (Ibn-Buzurj, T, Mgh, Msb, K:) it is applied to her who has no husband because she is in need of him who would expend upon her; (Msb;) or to her whose husband has died because her provision has gone and she has lost him who earned for her (IAmb, Mgh) and by means of whom her state of life had been good: (IAmb:) in like manner, also, A^aromalu is applied to a man as meaning having no wife, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) accord. to Kt (T, Mgh) and Sh; (Mgh;) like as A^ay~imN is applied to a man [as well as to a woman], and A^ay~imapN to a woman: (T:) or a widower; one whose wife has died: (TA:) or A^aromalu is not applied in this sense except in cases of deviation from the usual course of speech, (IAmb, Mgh, Msb, [and the like is said in the Mgh also as on the authority of Lth, and in the M as on the authority of IJ,]) because the man's provision does not go in consequence of the death of his wife, since she is not his maintainer, (IAmb, Mgh, Msb,) whereas he is her maintainer: (IAmb:) Jereer says,
kul~u AlA^araAmili qado qaDayota HaAjatahaA
famano liHaAjapi h`*aA AlA^aramali Al*~akari
(M, TA,) or h`*iY AlA^araAmilu Alx; (S, Mgh; [in the former ascribed in one of my copies to an unnamed poet, and in the other, to El-Hotei-ah; but in the Mgh, to Jereer, as in the M;]) [i. e. All the widows, or these widows, thou hast accomplished their want; but who is there for the want of this male widowed person]; meaning thereby himself. (M, TA.) It is said that, if one bequeath his property to the A^araAmil, some of it is to the men whose wives have died: (Mgh:) IB says, on the authority of IKt, that when a man says, “ This property is for the A^araAmil, ” it is for the men and the women, because AlA^araAmilu applies to the males and the women; but he adds, IAmb says that it is to be given to the women exclusively of the men, because AlArAml generally applied to the women. (TA. [This is cited in the TA as though relating to ArAml as meaning masaAkiyn: but IAmb evidently uses it here as applying to women whose husbands have died; and this is its predominant meaning.]) ― -b3- It is also applied to a [lizard of the kind called] Dab~, in the following saying of a rájiz,
A^uHb~u A^ano A^aSoTaAda Dab~FA saHobalaA
raEaY Alr~abiyEa waAl$~itaA='a A^aromalaA
(T, TA,) meaning [I love to hunt out, or catch, a large Db~, that has pastured during the autumn and the winter,] having no female, so that he may be fat. (TA.) ― -b4- And one says also EaAmN A^aromalu (ISk, T, S, M, K) and sanapN ramolaA='u (ISk, T, S, M) meaning (tropical:) A year of little rain (ISk, T, S, M, K, TA) and of little good or benefit. (T, M, K, TA.) -A2- Also i. q. A^abolaqu [i. e. Black and white: or white in the kind legs as high as the thighs]: (AA, T:) or a sheep or goat of which all the legs are black: fem. ramolaA='u: (A 'Obeyd, S:) or the latter is applied to a ewe as meaning of which the legs are black, the rest of her being white. (AZ, T, M, K.)
A^aromalapN * as fem. of A^aromalu, and as an epithet applied to a pl. number of persons: see the next preceding paragraph in five places.

A^uromuwlapN * , as an epithet applied to a boy, or young man, (gulaAmN, Lth, T, Ibn-'Abbád, K,) i. q. ↓ A^aromalu [as meaning Poor, needy, or the like]; (Ibn- 'Abbád, K;) accord. to Lth, (T, TA,) i. q. zaAraho [i. e. abject] in Persian: (T, M, TA: [but in two copies of the T zaA*aho; and in the TT, as from the M, zaAzaho:]) but Az says, I know not AlA^uromuwlapu, nor the Persian rendering thereof. (T.) -A2- Also The stump (ju*omuwr) of the [plant, or tree, called] Earofaj: pl. A^araAmilu and A^araAmiylu: (K:) or A^araAmilu AlEarfaji signifies the stocks, or stems, (A^uSuwl, [but
this sometimes means stumps, as well as roots, &c.,]) of the Erfj. (M.)
muromalN * : see maromuwlN.
muromilN * A man whose provisions, or travellingprovisions, are exhausted, or consumed. (A'Obeyd, T.) See also A^aromalu, first sentence. -A2- See also Almuram~ilu.

miromalN *
A small qayod [i. e. shackle or pair of shackles]. (IAar, T, K.)

TaEaAmN muram~alN * [Food, or wheat,] into which sand (Alr~amol) has been thrown. (TT, as from the T.) And xabiySN muram~alN [A mess of dates and clarified butter mixed together] into which dust, or earth, and sand, have been put: (so in a copy of the T: [but this seems to be a mistake, occasioned by the omission of what here follows:]) [or] such as has been much stirred about and turned over (K, TA, and so in the TT, as from the T) [app. with coarse flour (see jariy$N)] so that it has complicated streaks. (TA, and so in the TT, as from the T.) ― -b2- And kalaAmN muram~alN (tropical:) [Speech, or language, adulterated, corrupted, or] rendered unsound, or untrue: like TaEaAmN muram~alN. (TA.)

Almuram~ilu *
The lion; [app. because he smears his prey with blood;] as also ↓ Almuromilu. (O, K.)
maromuwlN * A mat woven [of palm-leaves or the like (see 1)]; as also ↓ muromalN. (A 'Obeyd, T, TA.)

yaromuwlN *
Palm-leaves (xuwSN) woven together. (K, * TA.)

rum~aAnN * [The pomegranate;] a certain fruit, (T,) the produce of a certain tree, (M,) well known: (T, S, M, K:) n. un. with p: (S, M, Msb, K:) the sweet sort thereof relaxes the state of the bowels, and cough; the sour sort has the contrary effect; and that which is between sweet and sour is good for inflammation of the stomach, and pain of the heart: the rm~An has six flavours, like the apple; and is commended for its delicacy, its quick dissolving, and its niceness, or its elegance: (K:) rum~aAnN is of the measure fuEolaAnN accord. to Sb: (M in art. rm:) Kh, being asked by Sb respecting Alr~um~aAn, (S,) or [rather] respecting rum~aAn, (M in art. rm,) when used as a proper name, (S,) said that he declined it imperfectly (S, M) when [thus made] determinate; (S;) and that he made it to accord to the majority, because its derivation is unknown, (S, M, *) i. e., that he regarded its A and n as augmentative: (S:) but accord. to Akh, the n is radical, (S,) [i. e.] he held it to be of the measure fuE~aAlN, making it to accord to many similar names of plants, (M,) like Hum~aADN &c., (S, M,) fuE~aAlN being more common than fuEolaAn; (S;) he meant, as applied to plants; for otherwise the contr. is the case: (TA:) [Fei says,] the measure is fuE~aAlN, the n being radical, and therefore the word is perfectly decl., unless when used as a proper name, in which case it is imperfectly decl., being made to accord to the majority [of proper names ending with A and n, as EuvomaAnu &c.]. (Msb.) [Freytag mentions several varieties of rm~An, as follows: but the names, as given by him and here transcribed, require verification or correction: “ rmAn AlqsTysY, rmAn AlmrsY, rmAn AlEdsY, rmAn AlxzAynY, rmAn AltrHyn, rmAn AlmrwnY, qui ad speciem dulcium pertinent: tum rmAn $ErY dulce et corticem tenuissimum habens: rmAn AmlysY Malum Punicum maximum, esu gratissimum et acinorum expers: rmAn AlsHY, rmAn AldlwY, rmAn AldwArY, sunt minoris magnitudinis, formæ rotundæ: rmAn AlsfryA Malum Punicum magnitudine et sapore præstantissimum, a viro Sefri dicto ita appellatum, quod a Syria Cordubam regnante Abd-Alrahmano hanc speciem transtulerat: ” and he refers to “ Casiri, Bibl. Ar. Hisp. T. i. p. 329; and Avicenn. L. ii. p. 254; ” the latter of which authors only mentions the properties of the rm~An.] ― -b2- rum~aAnu Als~aEaAliY [in the CK Als~uEAlaY] The white xa$oxaA$ [or poppy]: or a species thereof. (K. [The heads of the poppy are called rum~aAnu Alxa$oxaA$i because of their resemblance to pomegranates.]) ― -b3- rum~aAnu AlA^anohaAri [Androsæmum; or hypericum majus;] the large species of hayuwfaAriyquwn. (K.) ― -b4- [In the present day, rum~aAnN and more properly rum~aAnataAni are used as meaning (assumed tropical:) A young woman's breasts, when small and round; they being likened to pomegranates. In a saying of Umm-Zara, (mentioned in the M in art. rm,) rum~aAnataAni seems to be used in this sense, or as meaning a woman's posteriors.] ― -b5- The n. un., rum~aAnapN, is also used, vulgarly, as meaning (assumed tropical:) The qaTinap [or third stomach, commonly called the manyplies, and by some the millet, of a ruminant animal]: (K in art. qTn:) or it signifies (assumed tropical:) the thing [or part] in which is the fodder, of the horse. (M and TA in art. rm and in the present art.) One says, malaA^ati Ald~aAb~apu rum~aAnatahaA (assumed tropical:) [The beast filled its rm~Anp]. (TA.) And A^akala Hat~aY nataA^ato rum~aAnatahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He ate until his navel with the parts around it projected. (TA.) ― -b6- [(assumed tropical:) A knob of metal, of wood, and of silk, &c.: so called as resembling in shape a pomegranate.] ― -b7- And [for the same reason] (assumed tropical:) The weight of a steelyard, or Roman balance. (MA.) [Also applied in the present day to (assumed tropical:) The steelyard itself; and so ruwmaAnap.]
rum~aAnapN * n. un. of rum~aAnN [in the proper sense of this word, and also in several tropical senses expl. in the latter part of the next preceding paragraph]. (S, M, Msb, K.)

rum~aAniY~N * [Of, or relating to, the pomegranate. ― -b2- ] A seller of rum~aAn [or pomegranates]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Of the colour of the pomegranate. ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Rubycoloured. ― -b5- And, accord. to Golius, on the authority of a gloss in a copy of the KL, (assumed tropical:) The ruby itself.]

rum~aAniy~apN *
A kind of food prepared with pomegranates. (KL.)
rumayomiynapN * dim. of rum~aAnN [or rather of rum~aAnapN, the n. un.]. (TA.)

maromanapN *
A place of growth of rum~aAn [or pomegranates], (T, K,) when they, (K,) or their stems, (T,) are numerous therein. (T, K.)
rimFA * , mentioned under this head in the M, see the art. here following.

1 ramaY Al$~aYo'a * , (T, * S, M, K,) aor. yaromiY, (T,) inf. n. ramoYN; (T, M;) and ramaY bihi; (M, K;) He threw, cast, or flung, the thing, (S, K,) mino yadihi from his hand; (S, TA;) as also ↓ ArmY; (M, K;) i. e. ArmY Al$~aYo'a mino yadihi: (M: [in the K it is implied that one says also bahi ↓ ArmY; agreeably with a phrase mentioned in what follows:]) you say, AlHajara mino yadiY ↓ A^aromayotu I threw the stone from my hand: (S:) and Alfarasu biraAkibihi ↓ ArmY The horse threw, or threw down, [i. e. threw off,] his rider: (T:) ramayotu Alr~ajula is said A_i*aA ramayotahu biyadika; [i. e., as meaning ramayotuhu biyadiY; which may be rendered I threw him (the man) with my hand; and also I threw, or shot, at him (the man) with my hand;] but when you remove him from his place, you say, Eani Alfarasi wagayorihi ↓ A^aromayotuhu [I threw him, or threw him down or off, from the horse &c.]: (Msb:) and Eano farasihi ↓ TaEanahu faA^aromaAhu, meaning [He thrust him, or pierced him, with his spear,] and threw him, or threw him down [or off], from his horse: (El-Fárábee, S, Msb:) and AlHimola Eano Zahori AlbaEiyri ↓ A^aromayotu I threw down the load from the back of the camel. (T.) wamaA ramayota A_i*o ramayota wal`kin~a A@ll~`ha ramaY, in the Kur [viii. 17], is said by Aboo-Is-hák to be tropical, and to mean (tropical:) And thou didst not cast [in effect, or] so as to attain the point that was attained, [when thou didst cast,] but God [cast in effect, i. e.,] overruled the casting: or, accord. to Abu-l-' Abbás, the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) thou didst not cast fear, or terror, into their hearts, when thou didst cast the pebbles, [but God cast the fear, or terror:] or, accord. to Mbr, (assumed tropical:) thou didst not cast with thy strength, when thou didst cast, but with the strength of God thou didst cast [so that in effect God cast]. (T. [See also another explanation in what follows.]) ― -b2- [ramaY bisaloHihi He cast forth his excrement, or ordure, or properly, in a thin state, is a phrase of frequent occurrence.] ― -b3- You say also, ramayotu biAls~ahomi [I shot the arrow], inf. n. ramoYN and rimaAyapN. (S.) And ramaY Eani Alqawosi, (S, M, Msb,) or ramaY Als~ahoma Ean Alqawosi, (Mgh, * K,) and EalayohaA, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. ramoYN (Mgh, Msb, K) and rimaAyapN, (Mgh, K,) [He shot, or shot the arrow, from, and upon, meaning with, the bow;] and accord. to El-Ghooree, bihaA also; (Mgh;) but one should not say ramaY bihaA, (S, M, Msb, K,) unless meaning “ he threw it from his hand; ” though some make it to mean [ramaY EanohaA or] ramaY EalayohaA, making the b to be instead of En or ElY. (Msb.) ― -b4- And ramaY AlqanaSa, (S, M,) or AlS~ayoda, [He shot, or shot at, the animal, or animals, of the chase,] inf. n. ramoYN and rimaAyapN, (Msb,) or ramoYN, and none other. (M.) [And ramaAhu bika*aA He threw at him, cast at him, or shot at him, with such a
thing; i. e. he threw it, cast it, or shot it, at him: and, more commonly, he threw at him, or cast at him, and hit him, or he shot him, with such a thing: namely, with a stone, an arrow, &c. And ramaAhu biHijaArapF He threw at him with stones, threw stones at him: and he pelted him with stones, i. e. threw at him and hit him with stones.] And ramaY fiY AlA^agoraADi [He shot, or cast, at the butts]. (ISk, T, S, M.) ― -b5- [Hence,] one says, in cursing a person, ramaY A@ll~`hu fiY yadihi, and A^anofihi, (assumed tropical:) [May God aim at, and smite, with some bane, or malady, his hand, or arm, and his nose,] and in like manner in relation to other members. (M, K. *) [And ramaAhu A@ll~`hu bika*aA, sometimes meaning (assumed tropical:) God smote him, or afflicted him, with such a thing: but generally, may God smite him, or afflict him, with such a thing; as in the saying,] ramaAhu A@ll~`hu bidaA='i Al*~iy^obi (assumed tropical:) [May God smite him, or afflict him, with the disease of the wolf]; a prov., meaning may God destroy him, or cause him to perish; because [it is said that] the wolf has no disease but death: or, as some say, the meaning is, ramaAhu A@ll~`hu biAljuwEi [may God afflict him with hunger]; because the wolf is always hungry. (Meyd.) And ramaAhu bidaAhiyapK (assumed tropical:) [He (God) sent upon him, or against him,. or smote him with, a calamity: and also] (assumed tropical:) he (a man) made a very sagacious and crafty and politic man to be his assailant. (L in art. Hjr. [See also, in that art., rumiYa fulaAnN biHajiri AlA^aroDi, and biHajarihi.]) [And ramaAhu bika*aA (assumed tropical:) He assailed him with such a thing; as, for instance, reproach, and an argument, &c. Hence,] ramaAhu biqabiyHK, (TA,) or biA^amorK qabiyHK, (IAar, T,) or biAlqabiyHi, (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) He reproached him, or upbraided him, with a thing, or with that, which was bad, evil, abominable, or foul: (IAar, T, Msb, TA:) whence the usage of the verb alone [in this sense, adultery being understood,] in the Kur xxiv. 4 and 6. (T, TA.) [And ramaAhu bisuwo'K (assumed tropical:) He cast an evil imputation upon him; accused him, or suspected him, of evil: see maromiY~N. And ramaAhu alone (assumed tropical:) He accused him, or suspected him.] And ramaAhu biAlHaq~i (assumed tropical:) [He accused him with truth]. (L in art. qrH, in explanation of qaraHahu biAlHaq~i.) [And ramaAhu bilisaAnihi (assumed tropical:) He spoke against him.] ― -b6- ramaY A@ll~`hu laka means (tropical:) May God aid thee, or aid thee against thine enemy, and work [good] for thee: (AO, S, TA: *) and ramaY A@ll~`hu lahu (tropical:) God aided him, or aided him against his enemy, (AAF, M, K, TA,) and wrought [good] for him: (AAF, M, TA:) and [it is said that] the verb has this meaning in the words of the Kur, wamaA ramayota A_i*o ramayota wal`kin~a A@ll~`ha ramaY [of which other explanations have been given above]; because, when God aids a person against his enemy, He aims at, and smites, (yaromiY,) that enemy. (M, TA.) [In like manner, also, fulaAnN yaromiY mino waraA='i fulaAnK means (assumed tropical:) Such a one defends such a one.] ― -b7- rumiytu bika*aA (tropical:) I had such a thing offered, or presented, to me, the meeting with it being appointed, or prepared; [I had it as it were thrown to me, or thrown in my way; as though I were thrown at therewith;] like nubi*otu bihi. (A in art. nb*.) ― -b8- ramaAniY Alqawomu biA^aboSaArihimo (assumed tropical:) The people, or party, [cast their eyes, on me: or] looked at me sideways, or did so with anger, or aversion: or looked at me hardly, or intently. (Mgh.) [And ramaY bibaSarihi AlA^aroDa (assumed tropical:) He cast his eyes on the ground.] ― -b9- ramaY biAlqawomi (assumed tropical:) He, or it, caused, or made, the people, or party, to go forth; expelled them; [or cast them forth;] from one country, or the like, to another. (M, TA.) [See also 6.]) [And ramaY binaAqatihi AlfalaApa (assumed tropical:) He urged forth his she-camel, or went forth with her, or journeyed with her, or directed his course with her, into the desert; agreeably with what precedes or with what follows.] ramoYN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The going forth from one country, or the like, to another. (Th, M, TA.) And ramaY Alr~ajulu (assumed tropical:) The man journeyed. (IAar, T, TA.) And Az says, (TA,) I heard an Arab of the desert say to another, A^ayona taromiY, meaning (assumed tropical:) Whither dost thou direct thy course. (T, TA.) One says, raA^ayotu naAsFA yaromuwna AlT~aAy^ifa (assumed tropical:) I saw men directing their course to, or towards, Et-Táïf. (Har p. 54.) [See also an ex. in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh cited in p. 78.] ― -b10- ramawohaA biA^avowaAbK xifaAfK, in a verse cited voce vawobN, [They cast upon them light, or agile, bodies,] means they mounted them with their [light, or agile,] bodies; referring to camels. (T and TA in art. vwb.) ― -b11- rumiYa fiY jinaAzatihi He has been carried, or lifted, and put, into, or upon, his bier, means (assumed tropical:) he died, or has died: (TA:) it is said in giving information of a man's death. (TA in art. jnz.) ― -b12- [ramaY also app. means (assumed tropical:) He (a governor) imposed an impost upon his subjects: see ramiy~apN.] ― -b13- And ramaY, aor. yaromiY, means also (assumed tropical:) He misconjectured; thought wrongly; or formed a wrong opinion: (IAar, T:) [and app. he threw out a conjecture: or he spoke conjecturally; for Az adds,] it is like the phrase rajomFA biAlgayobi [or rajama biAlgayobi or qaAla rajomFA biAlgayobi]. (T.) ― -b14- ramaY Als~aHaAbu: see 6. ― -b15- ramaY EalaY Alxamosiyna: see 4. -A2- ramuwa is a verb of the same kind as qaDuwa and hayuw^a, [invariable as to person, time, and mood,] and means Excel-lent [or how excellent] is he in his throwing, or shooting! (IJ, TA voce hayuw^a, q. v. [See also baTuw^a, voce buToA=na.])

3 raAmayotuhu * , (S, K,) and raAmayotuhu biAls~ihaAmi, (TA,) inf. n. muraAmaApN and rimaA='N (T, S, K) and ↓ taromaA='N, (K,) or this last is like the two preceding ns. [in meaning, but is a quasi-inf. n.], (T,) [I threw, or shot, (generally the latter,) and I shot arrows, with him, or at him; (see 6;) mostly meaning in competition, or contention; i. e. I competed, or contended, with him, in throwing, or shooting, and in shooting arrows: and raAmayotuhu alone often means raAmayotuhu biAlHijaArapi, or biAls~ihaAmi; whence it is said that] muraAmaApN signifies the shooting arrows, and throwing stones, with any one. (KL.) It is said in a prove., respecting an affair in which one is forward before doing it,
qabola Alr~imaA='i tumolaA^u AlkanaAy^inu
[Before shooting arrows with another, or doing so in competition or contention, the quivers are to be filled]. (A 'Obeyd, T.)

4 A^aromaYa see 1, first sentence, in seven places: ― -b2- and see also 6. -A2- ArmY, (M, Mgh,) inf. n. A_iromaA='N, (Mgh,) also signifies It (a thing, Mgh) exceeded. (M, Mgh.) You say, ArmY Ealayohi It (anything) exceeded it, namely, another thing. (M.) Hátim- Teiyi says,
waA^asomara xaT~iy~FA kaA^an~a kuEuwbahu
nawaY Alqasobi qado A^aromaY *iraAEFA EalaY AlEa$ori
[And a tawny spear of El-Khatt, as though its knots, or joints, were hard date-stones; one that exceeded a cubit over the ten]: (T, S:) i. e., qado zaAda EalayohaA. (T.) And hence, (T,) you say, ArmY EalaY Alxamosiyna, i. e. He exceeded [the age of fifty]; (AZ, A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K;) [like ArbY;] as also ↓ ramaY; (AZ, T, S, M, K;) [for] ramoYN signifies the exceeding in age: and one says also A^aromaA^a and ramaA^a in the same sense. (IAar, T.) And ArmY fulaAnN signifies the same as A^arobaY [meaning Such a one took usury or the like]. (S.) See also ramaA='N, below. You say also, saAb~ahu faA^aromaY Ealayohi, i. e. [He reciprocated reviling, or vilifying, with him, and] he exceeded him. (S.)

5 trm~Y *
He shot, or cast, at the butts, and at the trunks of trees. (ISk, T, S, M.)

6 taraAmayonaA * and ↓ AirotamayonaA [We cast, or shot, (generally the latter,) one with another, or one at another; mostly meaning in competition, or contention; i. e. we competed, or contended, together in throwing, or shooting]: (S, K:) and trAmY Alqawomu biAls~ihaAmi and ↓ ArtmwA The people, or party, shot arrows, [one with another, or] one at another. (T.) ― -b2- [Hence,] trAmt bihi AlbilaAdu (tropical:) The countries cast him forth, or expelled him; (M, K, TA;) [as though they bandied him, one to another;] as also ↓ Artmt, (so in a copy of the M, [which I think correct,]) or ↓ Armt. (K.) ― -b3- And trAmY Als~aHaAbu (assumed tropical:) The clouds became drawn, or joined, together, (M, K, TA,) [as though thrown, one at another,] and heaped, or piled, up; (TA;) as also ↓ ramaY. (M, TA.) ― -b4- And trAmY A^amoruhu A_ilaY AlZ~afari; or A_ilaY Alxi*olaAni; i. e. (assumed tropical:) [His affair, or case,] came eventually [to the attainment of what was desired, or sought; or to abandonment by God]. (T, K, TA.) Hence, (TA,) it is said in a trad., of Zeyd Ibn-Háritheh, subiYa fiY AljaAhiliy~api fataraAmaY AlA^amoru A^ano SaAralixadiyjapa, (T, TA,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He was made a captive in the Time of Ignorance, and the case] came eventually, and led, [to his becoming the property of Khadeejeh, (A_ilaY being understood before A^ano SaAra,)] as though the decrees [of God] cast him thereto. (IAth, TA.) One says also, trAmY AlA^amoru, meaning taraAxaY [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The affair was sluggish, or backward]: (K:) [or] one says of a [purulent swelling such as is termed] Hiyon, (T,) or of a wound, (S,) trAmY A_ilaY fasaAdK, (T,) or AlY AlfasaAdi, (S,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) It was in a sluggish, or backward, state, (taraAxaY,) and became putrid and corrupt. (T.) And trAmY A_ilayohi Alxabaru (assumed tropical:) The
news, or information, came to him; or came to him by degrees. (MA.) ― -b5- trAmt saforatuhu (assumed tropical:) His journey was, or became, distant, or far-extending. (Har p. 34.) ― -b6- trAmAhu Al$~abaAbu Youthfulness, or youthful vigour, attained its full term [in him]. (Skr, M.)

8 ArtmY *
It was, or became, thrown, cast, or flung. (S, K, TA.) It fell to the ground: so in the saying, ArtmY AlHimolu Eano Zahori AlbaEiyri [The load fell to the ground, or it may mean was thrown down, from the back of the camel]. (T.) ― -b2- Also He shot, or shot at, an animal, or animals, of the chase. (T, S, M.) ― -b3- See also 6, in three places.
ramoYN * [originally an inf. n.]: see ramiY~N.
rimFY * The sound of a stone (T, K) thrown at a boy (so accord. to a copy of the T) or thrown by a boy; (K;) on the authority of IAar. (T.) -A2- rimFA [thus written in the M]: see ramaA='N.

ramoyapN *
A single throw, or cast, or fling: and a single shot: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) pl. ramayaAtN. (Msb, TA.) rub~a ramoyapK mino gayori raAmK [Many a hitting shot, or scarce any hitting shot, is there without a skilled shooter] is a prov. [applied to the case of an unexpected success obtained by an inexperienced person;] meaning many a [hitting] shot, or scarce any [hitting] shot, originates from a shooter that [usually] misses. (Meyd)

ramaA='N * , (S, IAth, K, in a copy of the T and in a copy of the S without any vowel-sign,) with fet-h and medd, (IAth, and so in a copy of the S, in which it is added that it is said by Ks to be with medd,) like samaA='N; (K;) or ↓ rimaA='N; (Mgh, and so in a copy of the T;) or ↓ rimFA, said by Lh to be formed by substitution [of m for b, as is shown by what follows]; (M;) An excess, or an addition; i. e., (A 'Obeyd, T, Mgh,) i. q. ribFA, (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K,) or ribFwA, (Mgh, and thus written in some copies of the S and K, or in most of the copies of the K, [meaning usury, and the like,]) or an excess, or addition, over what is lawful. (T, IAth.) Hence the trad. of 'Omar, laA tabiyEuwA, (A 'Obeyd, T,) or he said laA ta$otaruwA, (S,) Al*~ahaba biAlfiD~api A_il~aA yadFA biyadK haA wahaA, [or haA^o wahaA^o, (see art. hwA^,)] or haA=' wahaA=', [i. e. haA='a wahaA='a,] (accord. to different copies of the T and S,) adding, (T, S,) A_in~iY A^axaAfu Ealayokumu AlrmA='a; (T, S, Mgh;) [i. e. Exchange not ye gold for silver, except it be done hand with hand, meaning, except there be no delay between the giving and receiving, take and take: verily I fear for you the practice of usury;] or he said, A_il~aA haA='a wahaA='i, meaning, except [by saying] take and give: (Az, TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np:) and, as some relate it, he said, An~Y AxAf Elykm ↓ AlA_romaA='a; [which means the same;] using the inf. n. (T, Mgh.)
rimaA='N * : see the next preceding paragraph.

ramiY~N * , applied to the male of the goat-kind, or mountain-goat, or of the gazelle, [and any male animal of the chase,] and likewise, without p, to the female, i. q. ↓ maromiY~N [i. e. Thrown at, or cast at, or shot at, or shot]: but when they do not distinguish a male from a female, the word applied to the male and to the female is [↓ ramiy~apN,] with p [added liln~aqoli, i. e. to transfer it from the category of epithets to that of substantives]: or, accord. to Lh, ramiY~N and ↓ ramiy~apN are both applied, as epithets, to the female; but the former is the more approved: the pl. of the former [and of the latter also] is ramaAyaA. (M, TA.) -A2- Also, (M,) accord. to As, i. q. saqiY~N, i. e., (T, S,) A cloud of which the rain-drops are large, and vehement in their fall, (T, S, M, K, *) of the clouds of the hot season and of the autumn: (S:) or, (M, K,) accord. to Lth, (T,) small portions of clouds, (T, M, K,) of the [apparent] size of the hand, or somewhat larger; but the approved explanation is that given by As: (T:) and ↓ ramoYN is a dial. var. thereof: (TA:) the pl. is A^aromiyapN, (T, S, M, K,) like as that of saqiY~N is A^asoqiyapN, (S,) and A^aromA='N, (Lth, T, M, K,) [each, properly, a pl. of pauc.,] and ramaAyaA. (M, K.)

ramiy~apN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. [As a subst.,] it signifies A thing, (S, M,) meaning (S) an animal (As, T, S, M, * Mgh, Msb) of the chase, (As, T, S,) that is thrown at, or cast at, or shot at, or shot, (As, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb,) by its pursuer; and any beast thrown at, cast at, shot at, or shot; (As, T;) applied to the male and the female: (As, T, Mgh, Msb:) it is originally a word of the measure faEilaypN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: (Msb:) [or rather] it is made fem., (As, T,) [i. e.] it has p, (S,) because it is made a subst., (As, T, S,) not an epithet: (As, T:) it is not maromiy~apN converted into ramiy~apN: (S:) or, accord. to Sb, the p, in general, is affixed to show that the act has not yet been executed upon the object thereof; [so that the meaning is, an animal to be thrown at, cast at, shot at, or shot;] and thus *abiyHapN is applied to “ a sheep, or goat, [to be slaughtered or sacrificed,] not yet slaughtered [or sacrificed]; ” but when the act has been executed upon it, it is [said to be] *abiyHN: (M:) the pl. is ramiy~aAtN and ramaAyaA. (Msb.) One says, biy^osa Alr~amiy~apu AlA^aronabu, meaning Very bad is the thing of those that are [or are to be] thrown at, or cast at, or shot at, or shot, the hare. (S, M.) ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) An impost which the governor imposes [so I render maA yaromiyhi AlEaAmilu] upon his subjects. (TA.)

rim~iy~aA * , (S, TA,) thus correctly written, like Eim~iy~aA; in the copies of the K like Eimiy~aA, (TA,) [and in two copies of the T written rimiy~aA; in a copy of the M, rim~iyaA;] i. q. taraAmK: (T, S: *) or muraAmaApN: (K:) or ramoYN: (M:) or it is an intensive inf. n. from Alr~amoYu, of the measure fiE~iylaY, like hij~iyarY and xiS~iySaY: (Nh, TA:) one says, kaAnato bayonahumo rim~iy~aA (T, * S, M, * TA) vum~a Hajazato bayonahumo Hij~iyzaY, (T,) or vum~a SaAruwA A_ilaY Hij~iyzaY, (S, TA,) i. e. There was between them a reciprocal throwing of stones, (T, TA,) [or shooting of arrows or the like, or a great, or vehement, throwing, &c.,] then there intervened between them [an intervention, or a vehement intervention, or] a person, or persons, who withheld them, one from another, (T,) or then they withheld themselves, [or withheld themselves much,] one from another. (TA.)

raAmK * act. part. n. of 1; (Lth, T, TA;) Throwing, &c.: (TA:) [pl. rumaApN.] ― -b2- [Hence, Alr~aAmiY a name of The constellation Sagittarius; the ninth of the signs of the zodiac: thus called in the present day; but more commonly, Alqawosu.] ― -b3- [Hence likewise,] raAmK also signifies (assumed tropical:) [One who assails with reproach, &c.:] (assumed tropical:) one who reproaches, or upbraids; or who gives an ill name: (KL:) [(assumed tropical:) one who accuses, or suspects, another: see maromiY~N.]
A^aromaY * [More, and most, skilled in throwing, or casting, or shooting]: see an ex. voce tiqonN.
taromaA='N * : see 3 [of which it is a quasi-inf. n.].

maromFY *
A place [of throwing, or casting, or] of shooting arrows; (KL;) the place of the butt at which arrows are shot: (TA:) [pl. maraAmK.] ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) i. q. maqoSidN [meaning A place, and an object, to, or towards, which one directs his aim or course]: (TA, and Har p. 54:) pl. maraAmK: (Har ibid.:) whence the trad., layosa waraA='a A@ll~`hi maromFY, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [There is not, beyond God,] any object (maqoSid) towards which to direct hopes. (TA.)

miromFY *
An instrument for throwing, or casting, or shooting: pl. maraAmK. (Har p. 54.) [Hence,] maraAmiY niyraAnK [Engines for throwing fire upon the enemy]. (S and K voce Har~aAqapN.) [See also miromaApN.]

maromaApN *
i. q. galowapN [as meaning The limit of a shot or throw]. (K in art. glw.) -A2- See also the next paragraph.

miromaApN *
An arrow with which one shoots (As, IAar, T) at a butt: (As, T, Mgh:) an arrow with which one learns to shoot; (M, K, TA;) which is the worst kind of arrows: (TA:) or a small, weak arrow: (AHn, M, K:) or an arrow with its [head of] iron: (Th, TA in art. Hsb:) or, like sirowapN, a round arrow-head: (AA, [so in the S, but in the TA it is IAar,] S, TA:) [and app. a missile of any kind: (see mirodFY:)] pl. maraAmK. (M.) When they see many maraAmK in the quiver of a man, they say,
wanabolu AlEabodi A^akovaruhaA AlmaraAmiY
[And the arrows of the slave, most of them are those that are small and weak]: a prov., said to mean that the free man purchases arrows at a high price, buying the broad and long iron head, because he is a man of war and of the chase; but the slave is only a pastor, and therefore is content with what are termed maraAmK, because they are cheaper if he buy them; and if he ask for them as a gift, no one gives him aught but a miromaAp. (M.) [See also the last sentence of this paragraph.] ― -b2- It is also used, tropically, as meaning (tropical:) A manojaniyq [or kind of engine for casting stones
at the enemy; app. such as was called by the Romans “ onager, ” or the like thereof]: because, like the miromaAop before mentioned, it is an instrument for casting, or shooting. (Mgh.) [See also miromFY.] And [the pl.] maraAmK also signifies (assumed tropical:) Thunderbolts; syn. SawaAEiqu. (Bd in xviii. 38.) ― -b3- Also A cloven hoof (S, Mgh, K) of a sheep or goat; because it is of the things that are thrown away: (Mgh:) [or,] accord. to A 'Obeyd, (T, S,) a thing that is between the two hoofs of a sheep or goat; (T, S, M, K;) as also ↓ maromaApN: (A 'Obeyd, T, M, K:) thus, he says, it is explained; but I know not what is its meaning: (T, S:) its dual occurs in the following trad.: lawo A^an~a A^aHadahumo duEiYa A_ilaY miromaAtayoni laA^ajaAba wahuwa laA yujiybu A_ilaY AlS~alaApi; (T, S; related also, with some variations, in the M and Mgh;) in which it is said to be the dual of miromaApN in the former of these two senses; [i. e. If any one of you were invited to partake of two hoofs of a sheep or goat, he would obey the invitation, but he will not obey the invitation to prayer;] (S, Mgh;) or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, it is here the dual of this word in the latter of the same two senses: (T, S:) accord. to IAar, (T, TA,) or Aboo-Sa'eed, it here means the kind of arrow called miromaApN: (T, Mgh, TA:) but in another, and similar, trad., mrmAtyn is followed by A^awoEaroqK [i. e. “ or a bone with some meat remaining upon it ”]. (T, Z, TA.)

maromiY~N * pass. part. n. of 1; Thrown, &c.: (TA:) [thrown at, or cast at, or shot at, or shot:] see ramiY~N. ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) Smitten, or afflicted, with some bane, or malady, &c.: (assumed tropical:) assailed with reproach, &c.: (assumed tropical:) reproached, or upbraided, or stigmatized with an ill name: (assumed tropical:) accused, or suspected.] You say AimoraA^apN maromiy~apN bisuwo'K (assumed tropical:) A woman accused, or suspected, of evil. (TA in art. rTm.)

murotamK *
A scout (T, K) liqawomK [to a people or party]: (T, K: *) and so murotabiy^N. (T.)

1 ran~a * , aor. yarin~u, inf. n. raniynN; and ↓ Arn~; (Msb, K;) It (a thing) emitted a sound: (Msb:) or he cried aloud; (K;) or ran~ato, aor. and inf. n. as above; and ↓ Arn~t; she cried aloud, said of a woman: (S:) or ran~a and ↓ Arn~ signify he raised his voice in weeping: (Ham p. 11:) or raniynN signifies the crying aloud in weeping; (Lth, T;) or the uttering a plaintive, or mournful, voice or sound or cry: (M:) and ↓ A_ironaAnN, [inf. n. of Arn~,] the uttering a loud, or vehement, sound or cry; (Lth, T, M;) or the uttering of the sound of reiterating the breath with weeping: (IAar, T:) or raniynN and ↓ A_ironaAnN signify the crying out loudly, or vehemently; and the uttering a plaintive, or mournful, voice or sound or cry, in singing, or in weeping: (M:) you say of a woman, ran~ato, inf. n. as above; and ↓ Arn~t; (T, M;) and ↓ rn~nt, inf. n. taroniynN and taroniyapN [which is properly inf. n. of ran~ato as belonging to art. rnw]; all meaning she cried out loudly, or vehemently; and she uttered a plaintive, or mournful, voice or sound or cry, in singing or in weeping: (M:) and Aln~isaA='u ↓ A^aran~ati fiY niyaA Hatihin~a [the women cried loudly, or vehemently, in their wailing]. (T.) See also 4. -A2- ran~a A_ilayohi, and ↓ Arn~, He gave ear, hearkened, or listened, to him, or it. (K.)
2 ran~anotu Alqawosa * , inf. n. taroniynN, [I twanged the bow;] I made the bow to produce a sound [by pulling the string and letting it go suddenly]. (S.) -A2- See also 1.

4 Arn~ * , inf. n. A_ironaAnN: see 1, in seven places. A^aran~ato is said of a woman in her wailing [as expl. above]; and of a pigeon (HamaAmap) in its cooing [app. as meaning It uttered plaintive sounds]; (M;) and of a bow (qawos), (T, S, M, Msb, TA,) on the occasion of its string's being pulled and let go, (T,) accord. to the K ↓ ran~ato, but this is a mistake, (TA,) meaning it [twanged, or] produced a sound, (S, M, Msb,) accord. to AHn, above what is termed HaniynN; (M;) and of a cloud (saHaAbap) in its thundering [app. as meaning it resounded]. (M.) And Arn~ is also said of an ass in his braying; (T, M;) and of water in its murmuring, or gurgling, or running vehemently. (M.) -A2- Arn~ fulaAnN lika*aA Such a one was cheered, or delighted, and pleased, or was diverted, by reason of such a thing; as also A^aram~a lahu, and ranaA lh, and AstrnY. (T.) -A3- Arn~ A_ilayohi: see 1, last sentence.

ran~ahN *
A sound, voice, or cry, (IAar, T, S, K,) [in an absolute sense, or] in joy or sorrow: (IAar, T:) or a plaintive, or mournful, cry; whence one says EuwdN *uw ran~apK [a lute having a plaintive sound]: (Lth, T:) [or a moaning:] or a cry; (Msb;) or a loud cry: (M, Msb: *) and also a plaintive, or mournful, voice or sound or cry, in singing, or in weeping: (M:) pl. ran~aAtN. (IAar, T.)

rananN *
A certain thing that utters a cry [or sound] yaSiyHu [in one of my copies of the S yaTiyHu]) in the water, (S, K,) or in still water, (so in one copy of the S,) in the Sayof [i. e. spring or summer], (S,) or in winter. (K.) A poet says,
walamo yaSodaHo lahu Alr~ananu
[And the rnn did not raise its voice at him, or it]. (S.) ― -b2- Also A small quantity of water. (TA.)

raniynN * inf. n. of 1. (T, S, M, &c.) ― -b2- [Accord. to Golius, El-Meydánee explains it also as meaning A woman afflicted and oppressed by misfortune; and Golius adds, as though moaning, or lamenting.]

Alr~un~aY *
Mankind, or all created beings. (AA, T, K.) One says, maA fiY Alr~un~aY mivoluhu [There is not among mankind, or all created beings, the like of him]. (AA, T.) -A2- Also, (AA, T,) or run~aY, without Al, (K,) The month Jumádà: (AA, T:) or a name of Jumádà-l-Ákhireh; (K;) and so runapu, [said to be from ruwnapN, (see art. rwn,) though app. belonging to art. rnw, being] without teshdeed: pl. runanN: Aboo-' Amr Ez-Záhid disallowed rub~aY, and pronounced it to be a mistranscription: but accord. to Ktr and IAmb and Abu-t-Teiyib 'AbdEl-Wáhid and Abu-l-Kásim Ez-Zejjájee, it is rub~aY only; because in it were known the results of their wars; from rub~aY applied to a ewe or she-goat: and AlHaniynu was a name of Jumádà-l-Oolà: see also art. rb, in which is said what somewhat differs from the statement here. (TA.)

run~aA='N * , like rum~aAnN, with teshdeed, accord. to Th, i. q. TarabN: (TA:) or so runaA='N, without teshdeed, (M, TA,) accord. to A 'Obeyd: the latter is mentioned in its proper place [in art. rnw, q. v.]. (TA.)

A^arowanaAnN * , an epithet applied to a day, meaning Vehement in respect of anything, is of the measure A^afowaEaAlN, from Alr~aniynu, accord. to IAar; but accord. to Sb, of the measure A^afoEalaAlN, from ruwnapN, meaning “ hardness, ” and “ grievousness, ” of a thing, or an affair, or event: it is mentioned in art. rwn. (M.)

murin~apN * is applied as an epithet to birds [app. as meaning Uttering plaintive sounds]: (S:) and, as also ↓ mironaAnN, as an epithet to a bow [as meaning twanging], and so to a cloud (saHaAbap) [app. as meaning resounding with thunder]: (M:) and each is applied to a bow [itself]; (S, K;) and the latter, to a cloud [itself]; as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant [so as to imply, app., the meaning of resounding with thunder, or because it is hoped that it will resound with thunder, or because it often does so]. (M.)
mironaAnN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A^aronabN * [The hare; and now applied to the rabbit also;] a certain animal, (TA,) well known, (M, A, K, TA,) like the EnAq [?], having short fore legs and long hind legs, that treads the ground with the hinder parts of its [hind] legs: (TA:) a certain very prolific animal, called in Pers. xrkw$ [or xaroGuw$o]: it is said that it is one year a male and another year a female, and menstruates like women; and its fore legs are shorter than its hind legs: when it sleeps, it keeps its eyes open; and when it is sick, it eats green canes (qaSab), and its sickness ceases: (Kzw:) the word is a gen. n., (TA,) of the fem. gender, (Msb, TA,) accord. to El-Jáhidh; (TA;) but (Msb) applied to the male and the female; (M, A, K, TA;) as is also ↓ A^aronabapN, (Msb,) which is a dial. var.: (Mgh, Msb:) or to the female [only]; the male being called xuzazN; (T, M, K, TA;) accord. to Lth; but others allow its application to the male: (T:) the female is also called Eikori$apN: and the young, xironiqN: (TA:) the pl. is A^araAnibu (T, S, M, Msb, K) and A^araAnK, (Lh, S, M, K,) the latter, like vaEaAlK for vaEaAlibu, occurring in poetry, (S, M, *) and not allowed by Sb except in poetry. (M.) The A in A^aronabN is augmentative, accord. to Lth: accord. to most of the grammarians it is disjunctive, (so in a copy of the T and in the TA,) or radical: (so in another copy of the T:) Lth says that no word commences with a radical A but such as
is triliteral; as A^aroDN and A^aro$N. (T, TA.) [Hence,] one says of the low, abject, or ignominious, and weak, A_in~amaA huwa A^aronabN [He is only a hare]; because that animal cannot defend itself, and even the lark will endeavour to make it its prey. (A, TA.) See another ex. below, voce A^aronabapN. [Hence, also,] AlA^aronabu is the name of (assumed tropical:) A certain constellation, [Lepus,] comprising twelve stars in its figure, having no observed stars around it, situate beneath the feet of Aljab~aAr [i. e. Orion], and facing the west. (Kzw.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or ↓ maronabN accord. to the L, (TA,) or both, (M,) and ↓ yaronabN, A jura* [or large field-rat], (M, L, K,) like the jerboa, (M, L,) having a short tail. (M, L, K.) ― -b3- AlA^aronabu AlbaHoriY~u, accord. to Kzw, A certain marine animal, the head of which is like that of the A^aronab [or hare], and the body like that of a fish: or, accord. to Ibn-Seenà, a small testaceous animal, which is of a poisonous quality when drunk [app. meaning in water]: so that, accord. to this explanation, the resemblance [to the Arnb commonly so called] is in the name, not the form. (TA.) -A2- Also A sort of ornament worn by women. (M, K.)

A^aronabapN * The end, or tip, [i. e. the lower portion, or lobule,] of the nose: (T, S, A, K:) this is [also] called A^aronabapu AlA^anofi: (Mgh, Msb:) it is one of the parts that touch the ground in prostration [in prayer]: (TA:) pl. A^araAnibu. (T, A, TA.) You say, jadaEa A^aronabatahu [lit. He cut off the end of his nose;] meaning (assumed tropical:) he held him in mean estimation, or in contempt. (A, TA.) And wajadotuhumo mujad~aEiY ↓ AlA^araAnibi A^a$ad~a fazaEFA mina AlA^araAnibi (assumed tropical:) [I found them to be held in contempt, (lit. having the ends of their noses cut off,) more fearful than hares]. (A, TA.) -A2- See also A^aronabN.
A^aronabaAniY~N * [Cloth of the kind called] xaz~ of a blackish colour (A^adokanu). (K.) ― -b2- See also maronabaAniY~N.

maronabN *
A large faA^orap [or rat]: (K:) omitted in some copies of the K. (TA.) See A^aronabN. ― -b2- See also muw^aronabN.
muronabN * : see muw^aronabN.

maronabapN *
A villous [garment of the kind called] qaTiyfap. (T, K.) -A2- See also A^aroDN muw^aronibapN.

kisaA='N maronabaAniY~N *
A [garment of the kind called] ksA' that is of the colour of the A^aronab [or hare]; (T, M, A, K;) as also ↓ A^azonabaAniY~N. (A.) See also the next paragraph.

kisaA='N muw^aronabN *
A [garment of the kind called] ksA' of which the thread is intermixed with the soft hair of the A^aronab [or hare]; (T, S, M, K;) as also ↓ muronabN, (so in a copy of the M,) or ↓ maronabN, like maqoEadN: (A, K:) or, as some say, i. q. ↓ maronabaAniY~N. (T.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

A^aroDN muw^aronibapN *
A land in which are A^araAnib [or hares]: (S:) or abounding therewith; (T, Kr, M, and so in some copies of the K;) as also ↓ muw^aronabapN, (M, and so in some copies of the K, and in a copy of the A,) and ↓ maronabapN. (T, M, A.)
yaronabN * : see A^aronabN.

raAnijN * , (El-Fárábee, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) or raAnajN, (Msb,) The Indian nut, or cocoa-nut: (AHn, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA:) thought by AHn to be an arabicized word: (TA:) [J says,] “ I do not think it to be Arabic: ” (S:) pl. rawaAniju. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A kind of smooth date, (Msb, K,) so some say, (Mgh,) like that called taEoDuwD: [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (K.) ― -b3- waladu Alr~aAniji is a name given by the children of Mekkeh to The muqol [or fruit of the dawom, i. e. cucifera Thebaïca, or Theban palm]. (A.)

2 rn~Hhu * , [inf. n. as below,] said of wine ($araAb), It made him to incline from side to side. (A, TA.) [Also, as appears from what follows, It made him to incline and go round. It made him giddy in the head, and confused: it affected him with giddiness in the head like one in a swoon.] It deprived him of his strength by reason of its potency. (Ham p. 562.) [And, said of a beating, and app. of intoxication &c., It made him to swoon, or faint: for,] when you have beaten a person so that he swoons, or faints, you say, Darabotuhu Hat~aY ran~aHotuhu. (Ham ibid.) [Hence, run~iHa He was made to incline from side to side: ran~aHa is expl. in the TA in a similar sense, as said of a man &c.; but it is app. a mistranscription for run~iHa]: see 5. He was made to incline and go round. (L.) It is said, by Imra-el-Keys, of a dog gored by a wild bull. (S, * L.) He was giddy in the head, and confused: and run~iHa bihi he was affected with giddiness in the head like one in a swoon. (L.) Also, (L,) and run~iHa Ealayohi inf. n. taroniyHN, (S, L, K,) He swooned, or fainted; or was affected by a weakness of the bones, (S, L, K,) and of the body; by reason of beating or fright or intoxication, and sometimes by reason of anxiety, and grief, or sorrow; (L;) and inclined from side to side. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- ran~aHati Alr~iyHu AlguSona (tropical:) The wind made the branch to incline from side to side. (A.)

5 trn~H *
He inclined from side to side, by reason of intoxication &c; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ ArtnH, (K,) and ↓ ran~aHa [app. a mistranscription for run~iHa]. (TA.) He inclined, and went round. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (a branch) inclined from side to side, being blown by the wind. (A.) ― -b3- trn~H bayona A^amorayoni (tropical:) He wavered between two things. (A.) ― -b4- trn~H EalaY fulaAnK (tropical:) He was, or became, inimical to such a one, domineering, and exalting himself. (A.) ― -b5- And trn~H He sipped wine ($araAb) by little and little. (AHn, K.)
8 A_irotanaHa see 5, first signification.

ranoHN *
Vertigo, or giddiness in the head; (K;) and confusion. (TA.) -A2- Also A certain appertenance of the brain, separate, or distinct, therefrom, like, or of the size of, the EuSofuwr [q. v.]. (K.)
maronaHapN * The prow, or fore part, of a ship. (Az, K.)
muronaHN * : see what follows.

muran~aHN *
Swooning, or fainting; or affected by a weakness of the bones, (S, L, K,) and of the body; by reason of beating or fright or intoxication, and sometimes by reason of anxiety, and grief, or sorrow; (L;) and inclining from side to side. (S, L, K.) -A2- Also, (A, K,) or ↓ muronaHN, (so in the L,) (tropical:) Aloes-wood, (A, L, K,) of the best kind, (L, K,) used for fumigation. (A, L, K.)

ranodN * [a coll. gen. n.] A kind of tree of sweet odour, (AO, T, S, A, Msb, K,) which distils much (say~aAlN); (A;) of the trees of the desert; (AO, T, S, A, Msb;) a kind of tree of the desert, of sweet odour, with the wood of which the teeth are cleaned; not large; and having a berry; (Hab~ap); called [i. e., the tree is called, and not the berry, for the verb is masculine,] gAr [a name commonly and properly applied to the laurus nobilis, or sweet bay]: n. un. ranodapN: (M:) or the myrtle (A=s); (M, A;) this is also called rnd, (Kh, Msb, K,) on account of its sweet odour; (Kh, Msb;) and Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà says that the rnd is the A=s accord. to all the lexicologists except Aboo- 'Amr Esh-Sheybánee and IAar, who assert that the rnd is the plant called Hanowap, and is of sweet odour; but AO also denies it to be the A=s; (T;) and so does As: (S:) or aloes-wood, (Euwd,) with which one fumigates; (M;) Ewd (or Euwdu AlT~iybi, with which one fumigates, AO, and T,) is also thus called, (AO, As, T, S, K,) sometimes: (AO, As, T, S:) [and accord. to Forskål, (Flor. Aeg. Ar., cxix.,) the artemisia pontica bears this name.]

runozN *
i. q. A^aruz~N [and ruz~N, i. e. Rice]; (S, K; [incorrectly said in the TA to be omitted by J;]) in the dial. of 'Abd-el-Keys: (ISd, TA:) as though the first z were changed into n, (S, TA,) as j in A_inojaASN for A_ij~aASN. (TA.) [See HaZ~N.]

1 raniqa * , (S, Sgh, K,) aor.
raniqa ; (K;) and ranaqa, aor.
ranuqa ; (ISd, K;) inf. n. (of the former, S) ranaqN (S, K) and [of the latter] ranoqN and runuwqN; (K;) It (water) was, or became, turbid, thick, or muddy; (S, K;) as also ↓ trn~q. (K.) -A2- See also 4, in two places.

2 rn~q * , (S, K,) inf. n. taroniyqN, (IAar, S,) He rendered water turbid, thick, or muddy; (IAar, S, K;) as also ↓ Arnq. (S, K.) ― -b2- And the former, He cleared it; rendered it clear: thus it bears two contr. significations. (IAar, K.) [Hence,] one says, rn~q A@ll~`hu qa*aAtaka May God
clear away thy q*Ap [or mote in the eye; probably meaning (assumed tropical:) that which annoys thee]. (IAar, K) -A2- Also, as an intrans. verb, He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (TA.) And taroniyqN signifies A man's standing, not knowing whether to go or come. (TA.) And The being weak, or infirm, [and, app., disordered, or perturbed,] in sight, and in body, and in an affair or case. (S, K.) Hence, (TA,) rn~qwA fiY AlA^amori They confused the judgment, or opinion, [that they formed, or they were confused in judgment or opinion,] in, or respecting, the affair, or case.
