(S, K.) ― -b2- Also He paused and waited. (TA.) [Hence the saying,] ram~adati AlmiEozaY faran~iqo ran~iqo, (JK, S, K,) i. e. The she-goats have secreted milk in their udders; (JK;) but wait thou, wait thou, (JK, S, TA,) for their bringing forth, (S, TA,) for they show signs, but do not bring forth until after some time: (S:) thou wilt have to wait long for them: (TA:) sometimes it is said with m [in the place of n], and also with d [in the place of r]: (S, TA:) it is mentioned in art. rbq [q. v.]. (K. [See also art. rmq.]) ― -b3- Also He continued looking; (S, K, TA, in this art. and in art. rmq;) like rm~q. (S and TA in the same two arts.) And you say also, rn~q A_ilayohi Aln~aZura and dn~q [meaning He continued looking at it]. (S in art. dnq.) And rn~q Aln~aZara meaning [He looked covertly, or clandestinely; or] he concealed the looking. (TA.) ― -b4- Said of a company of men, They remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in a place (bimakaAnK), (S, K,) and confined themselves therein. (S.) ― -b5- Said of a bird, He flapped his wings in the air, (S, K,) and remained steady, (S,) not flying: (S, K:) or flapped his wings in the air without alighting and without quitting his place: or it has two meanings: i. e. he expanded his wings in the air without moving them: and he flapped his wings. (TA.) Hence, said of a captive, He stretched out his neck on the occasion of slaughter, like the bird expanding his wings. (TA.) [Hence also,] rn~qt Als~afiynapu (JK, TA) fiY makaAnihaA (JK) The ship turned round in its place without proceeding in its course. (JK, TA.) ― -b6- rn~qt Al$~amosu The sun became near to setting. (TA. [See also dn~qt.]) And rn~qt minohu Almaniy~apu (tropical:) Death was near to befalling him: a metaphorical phrase from rn~q said of a bird. (TA.) ― -b7- rn~N Aln~awomu (S, K) fiY Eayonayohi (K) (tropical:) Sleep pervaded (xaAlaTa) his eyes, (S, Z, Sgh, K,) without his sleeping. (Z, TA.) -A3- taroniyqN also signifies The breaking of the wing of a bird by a shot or throw, or by disease, so that he, or it, falls. (Lth, K.) [You say of the bird run~iqa or run~iqa janaAHuhu His wing was broken &c. See the pass. part. n., below.]

4 Arnq * : see 2. -A2- Also He moved about, or agitated, [or waved,] his banner, previously to a charge, or an assault, in war or battle; (IAar, K;) and [in like manner,] ↓ ranaqa, inf. n. ranoqN, he moved about, &c., the banner. (TA.) -A3- And It (a banner) was moved about or agitated [or waved]; (IAar, K;) and [in like manner,] ↓ ranaqa it (a banner) was moved about &c. over the heads. (TA.)
5 taran~aqa see 1.

ranoqN *
Turbid, thick, or muddy, water; (S, K;) as also ↓ raniqN and ↓ ranaqN. (K.) ― -b2- Also (TA) Dust in water, consisting of motes, or particles of rubbish, and the like, that fall into it [and render it turbid]; (JK, TA;) and so ↓ ranaqN. (JK.) Accord. to IB, ranoqN has for pl. ranaAy^iqu; as though this were pl. of raniyqapN: (TA:) or Alr~ayaAniqu is pl. of AlmaA='i ↓ ranoqapu, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) or of ranoqapN, (JK,) and is formed by transposition, (JK, Ibn- 'Abbád, K, TA,) being originally Alr~anaAy^iqu. (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA.) One says, ↓ maA fiY Eayo$ihi ranaqN (assumed tropical:) [There is not in his life anything that renders it turbid]. (JK.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Lying, or falsehood, or a lie; syn. ka*ibN. (TA.)
ranaqN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
raniqN * : see ranoqN. ― -b2- [Hence,] Eayo$N raniqN (assumed tropical:) Turbid life. (S.)

ranoqapN *
A small quantity of turbid water remaining in a watering-trough or tank. (TA.) [And accord. to Freytag, ↓ ranoqaA='u occurs in the Deewán El-Hudhaleeyeen as meaning A small quantity of turbid water.] Accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, (TA,) one says, SaAra AlmaA='u ranoqapF, (K, TA,) or ↓ ruwonaqapF, (JK, and so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K,) meaning The water became such that mud predominated in it: (JK, K, TA:) but the correct phrase, as given in the “Nawádir” by Lh, is, SaAra AlmaA='u ranoqapF waAHidapF [The water became one puddle in which mud predominated]. (TA.) See also ranoqN.

ranoqaA='u * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also Land (A^aroDN) that does not give growth (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K) to anything: (JK, Ibn- 'Abbád:) pl. ranoqaAwaAtN. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- And A female bird sitting on eggs. (K.)

rawonaqN * The maA=' [or water] of a sword; (S, K, TA;) i. e. its firinod [or diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain]; (TA;) and its beauty; (S, K;) or the semblance of water that is seen upon a sword. (JK.) ― -b2- And (hence, S) of the DuHaY [or early part of the forenoon], (S, K,) &c.; (S;) meaning (tropical:) The first, or beginning, thereof; (JK, * TA;) and its clearness. (TA.) One says, A^atayotuhu fiY rawonaqi AlD~uHaY I came to him in the first, or beginning, of the DHY; like as one says fiY wajohi AlD~uHaY. (TA.) And rawonaqu Al$~abaAbi means (tropical:) The prime of youth; and its freshness, or brightness, and beauty. (TA.)
rawonaqapN * : see ranoqapN.

turonuwqN * (JK, S, K) and taronuwqN and turonuwqaA='u (K) The mud that is in rivers, and in a channel of water, (S, K,) when the water has sunk therefrom into the earth: (K:) or the thin, and viscous, cohesive, or slimy, mud remaining in a pool of water left by a torrent: (JK:) or the slime of a well, and of the channel of a torrent, mixed with black, or black and fetid, mud. (Mgh voce tiqonN, from the “Jámi'” of El-Ghooree.)
muran~aqu AljanaAHi * A bird having the wing broken by a shot or throw, or by disease, so that he, or it, falls. (K.)

laqiytu fulaAnFAmuran~iqapF EayonaAhu * (so in one of my copies of the S, and in the PS and JM; in the other of my copies of the S muran~aqapF;) (assumed tropical:) I met such a one having his eyes languid by reason of hunger or from some other cause. (S.)
1 ranima * : see 5, with which it is syn., in two places.
2 ran~ama see the next paragraph, in four places.

5 trn~m * ; and ↓ ranima, (S, Msb,) aor.
ranama , (Msb,) inf. n. [ranamN and] raniymN; (TK;) i. q. raj~aEa Sawotahu (S, Msb) i. e. [He trilled, or quavered; or] he reiterated his voice in his throat, or fauces, (S and K and TA in art. rjE,) like [as is done in] chanting, (S in that art.,) or in reading or reciting, or singing, or piping, or other performances, of such as are accompanied with quavering, or trilling: (TA in that art.:) both said of a singer: (Msb:) and the former said of a bird, in its hadiyr [or cooing]; (S, Msb;) and of a bow, when it is twanged: (S:) and taroniymN [inf. n. of ↓ rn~m] signifies the like: (S:) or Alt~aroniymu signifies taToriybu AlS~awoti [i. e. the trilling, or quavering, and prolonging the voice; or prolonging the voice, and modulating it sweetly, or warbling]; (T, * M, K;) and so raniymN [mentioned above as inf. n. of ↓ ranima]; (Lth, T, M, K;) whence Alt~aran~umu [which signifies the same, as is shown by what follows]: (Lth, T:) ↓ rn~m is said of the pigeon, (M, K,) and of the [bird called] muk~aA', (M,) and of the [locust, or species of locust, called] junodab [meaning it chirped], and of the bow [meaning it emitted a musical ringing sound, or a plaintive sound (see taronamuwtN, below,) when twanged], (M, K,) and [in like manner] of the lute, (M,) and of a thing (M, K:) of any kind (M) of which the sound is esteemed pleasant, or delightful; and taran~ama likewise: (M, K:) or you say, AlHamaAmapu tataran~amu [The pigeon trills, or quavers, or cooes]: and of the muk~aA=' you say, ↓ fiY Sawotihi taroniymN [In its voice, or cry, is a trilling, or quavering]: and of the bow, and the lute, and a thing [of any kind] of which the sound is esteemed pleasant, or delightful, ↓ lahu taroniymN [It has a musical ringing sound, or a plaintive sound]. (Lth, T.) It is said in a trad., maA A^a*ina A@ll~`hu li$aYo'K A^a*anahu linabiY~K Hasani Alt~aran~umi biAlquroA=ni [God has not listened to anything as He listens to a prophet having a good manner of trilling, or quavering, or prolonging and modulating sweetly his voice, in reciting the Kur-án]: or, as some relate it, Hasani AlS~awoti yataran~amu biAlquroA=ni [good in respect of the voice, trilling, &c., in reciting the Kur-án]. (TA.)

ranamN *
i. q. SawotN [as meaning A voice, or sound; or, more probably, the uttering thereof: see ranima, of which it is an inf. n., in the next preceding paragraph]. (S, K.)
runumN * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned; app. pl. of ↓ raAnimapN; like as rumumN is supposed to be of raAm~apN, originally raAmimapN;] Good, or excellent, female singers. (IAar, T, K.)

ranomapN * , (M, and so in copies of the K.) thus it seems to be accord. to [a rule observed in] the K, but accord. to Z it seems to be ↓ ranamapN, (TA, and thus it is written in the CK,) and ↓ taronamuwtapN, (M, and so in the K accord. to the TA,) or ↓ taronamuwtN, (S, [and so in my MS. copy of the K,]) or this last also, (M,) or ↓ taronuwmapN or turonuwmapN, (accord. to other copies of the K,) i. q. taran~umN [i. e. A trilling, or quavering, &c.: see 5]. (S, M, K.) Thus in the phrases, samiEa ranomapF HasanapF and ↓ taronamuwtapF [He heard a good, or pleasing, trilling, &c.]: (M:) and lahu ranomapN HasanapN or ↓ ranamapN and ↓ taronamuwtapN &c. (accord. to different copies of the K) [i. e. He, or it, has a good, or pleasing, trilling, &c.]. ↓ taronamuwtN is formed by the addition of w and t, like as is malakuwtN: (S:) it is said to be the only instance in which t is added at the beginning and end of a word: (MF:) and it is used in relation to a bow [as meaning A musical ringing sound on the occasion of twanging]. (S, M.) [↓ raniymN, also, said in the TK to be an inf. n. of ranima, and in the M and K to be syn. with taroniymN, is used in a similar manner:] you say, samiEotu lahu raniymFA [I heard him to have a trilling, or quavering, sound proceeding from him; or I heard it to have a musical ringing sound proceeding from it]; taken from the taran~um of the bird in its cooing. (Msb.)

ranamapN *
A certain slender plant, (T, K,) well known; (T;) said by As to be one of the plants growing in plain, or soft, ground: (A'Obeyd, T:) IAar is related to have said that the ranamap, with n, is a certain species of tree: Sh knew not this word, and supposed it to be a mistranscription for ratamap; but the ratam are [comparatively] large trees, [or rather shrubs, of the broom-kind,] having trunks; whereas the rnmp is of the slender kind of plants [as is said above]. (T.) -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
raniymN * : see ranomapN.
raAnimapN * : see runumN.

taronamuwtN * : see ranomapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also an epithet applied to a bow, meaning Having a plaintive sound (His~N, so in a copy of the M, or HaniynN, K, TA) on the occasion of shooting. (M, K.)
taronamuwtapN * : see ranomapN, in three places.
taronuwmapN * or turonuwmapN: see ranomapN.

1 ranaA A_ilayohaA * , (Lth, T,) or A_ilayohi, (S, M,) and [ranaAhaA, or] ranaAhu, (M, TA,) aor. yaronuw, (Lth, T, S, Msb,) inf. n. runuw~N (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K) and ranFA, (Lth, T, M, K,) He gazed, i. e., looked continually, (Lth, T, S, M, K,) without any motion of the eyes, (M, K,) at her, (Lth, T,) or at him, or it: (S, M:) or ranaA A_ilayohi signifies [simply] he looked at him, or it; as also ranaA^a; but the former is said to be the original word. (TA in art. rnA^.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- runuw~N also signifies The being cheered, or delighted, and pleased, or being diverted, together with occupation of the heart and eyes, and with predominance of love and desire. (M, K.) You say, yaronuw A_ilaY HadiyvihaA [He is cheered, or delighted, &c., with her discourse]. (M, K.) And ranawotu A_ilaY Hadiyvihi I was cheered, or delighted, and pleased, or was diverted, with his discourse. (T.) And ranaA lika*aA and lahu ↓ AstrnY He was cheered, &c., as above, by reason of such a thing: and so A^aran~a lh. (T in art. rn.) And ranaA, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) is syn. with Tariba [app. as meaning He was, or became, affected with a lively emotion of joy, moved with delight, mirthful, joyful, glad, or delighted]. (K.) [See runaA='N, below, which is perhaps an inf. n.]

2 rn~Ahu * : see 4. ― -b2- Also, (TA,) inf. n. taroniyapN, (K,) i. q. Tar~abahu [app. as meaning He, or it, affected him with a lively emotion of joy; moved him with delight; rendered him mirthful, joyful, glad, or delighted: see also 4]. (K, * TA.) -A2- taroniyapN signifies also The act of singing. (K.) And i. q. HaniynN [app. as meaning The uttering a plaintive sound, or plaintive sounds]. (K.) A woman's crying out loudly, or vehemently; and uttering a plaintive, or mournful, voice or sound or cry, in singing or in weeping; like taroniynN. (M in art. rn.)
3 rAnAhu * , (K,) inf. n. muraAnaApN, (TA,) He treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him: (K, TA:) he treated him in an easy and a gentle manner. (TA.)

4 ArnAhu * ; (S, M, Msb, K;) and ↓ rn~Ahu, (M, K,) inf. n. of the latter taroniyapN; (TA;) It (beauty, K, or beauty of aspect, M, or the beauty of a thing that he saw, S, Msb) made him to gaze, i. e., to look continually, (S, M, K,) without any motion of the eyes: (M, K:) or pleased him: (Msb:) or pleased him, and made him to gaze, &c. (TA.) And the former, It (a thing) cheered, or delighted, him, and pleased him; or diverted him. (T in art. rn.) [See also 2.] ― -b2- ArnAhu A_ilaY AlT~aAEapi He (God, T) reduced him to obedience, so that he became still, and continued obedient: (T, TA:) from a trad. (T.)

5 trn~Y *
He continued looking at the thing that he loved. (IAar, T, K.) [See also 1.]

6 taraAnawotu Eanohu *
I feigned myself unmindful of, or inadvertent to, him, or it. (A, TA.) [The primary meaning seems to be, I feigned myself looking steadily away from him, or it.]
10 A_isotaronawa see 1.

ranFA *
A thing at which one looks (S, M, K) continually, [or gazes,] without any motion of the eyes, by reason of its beauty: (M, K:) an inf. n. used as a subst. properly so termed. (M.)
runapN * , or Ar~unapu, a name of The month Jumádà-'l- Ákhireh: see Alr~un~aY in art. rn, and ruwnapN in art. rwn.

ranowapN *
A piece of flesh or flesh-meat: pl. ranawaAtN, (IAar, T, K, TA,) like as $ahawaAtN is pl. of $ahowapN. (TA. [In the CK, the pl. is erroneously written ranowAtN.])
ranaA='N * , with fet-h, (T,) like saHaAbN, (TA,) i. q. jamaAlN [Beauty, goodliness, comeliness, &c.]: (T, K:) so says AZ. (T.)

runaA='N * , with damm, i. q. TarabN [app. as meaning A lively emotion of joy; mirth, joy, gladness, or delight]. (K. [See also run~aA'N, in art. rn: and see the last signification of 1 in the present art.]) ― -b2- Also A sound, voice, or cry: (El-Umawee, T, K:) [like ran~apN as expl. in the S and K:) pl. A^aroniyapN. (T.)

ranuw~N * in the following phrase is like Eaduw~N: (K:) you say, huwa ranuw~u fulaAnapa He is one who gazes, or looks continually, at such a woman or girl: (Lth, T, S: [see also ran~aA='N:]) or he is one who is cheered, or delighted, or diverted, and pleased, with the discourse of such a woman or girl. (M, K. *) And fulaAnN ranuw~u AlA^amaAniY Such a one is a person who expects things for which he wishes. (Lth, T, M. *)

rajulN ran~aA='N *
A man who gazes, or looks continually, at women. (S. [See also ranuw~N.])

kaA^osN ranawonaApN * [A cup of wine] lasting, or continuing, syn. daAy^imapN, (IAar, T, S, M, Msb, K,) to the drinkers; (EalaY Al$~arobi; IAar, T, K; Al$rb being with fet-h to the $, pl. [or rather quasipl. n.] of $aAribN; TA; [in the CK, and in one copy of the T, erroneously, ElyY Al$~urobi;]) still, or motionless; syn. saAkinapN: (S, Msb:) [were it not for this addition, the meaning might be thought to be, a cup of wine circling to the drinkers:] or pleasing: (Msb:) pl. ranawonayaAtN: (IAar, T, K:) the word rnwnAp is of the measure faEaloEalapN; (S;) [originally ranawonawapN;] and it occurs in the poetry of Ibn-Ahmar, (T, S, M,) but (as some say, S) has not been heard except in that poetry. (S, M.)

turonaY A^rnY rA^Y rn rnA rnY trnY trny wrY
A fornicatress, or an adulteress: (M, K:) [accord. to ISd,] of the measure tufoEalu, from Alr~unuw~u; i. e., that is gazed at, or looked at continually; because she is made an object of suspicion, or evil opinion: (M:) [whence,] Aibonu turonaY One that is base-born. (S.) [See more in art. trn.]

muran~K *
A singer. (AA, K.)

1 rahiba * , aor.
rahaba , inf. n. rahabN (S, A, * Msb, K) and ruhobN (S, K) and ruhubN (Ksh and Bd in xxviii. 32) and rahobN (K) and rahobapN, (S, A, * K,) or this is a simple subst, (Msb,) and ruhobaAnN and rahabaAnN, (K,) He feared: (S, A, Msb, K:) or he
feared with caution. (TA.) You say, fiY qalobiY minohu rahobapN and rahabN [In my heart is fear, or cautious fear, of him, or it]. (A.) ― -b2- And rahibahu, inf. n. rahobapN (JK, Mgh) and ruhobapN and ruhobN and rahabN; (JK;) [and app. rahiba minohu, as seems to be indicated above;] He feared him, or it; (JK, Mgh;) [or feared him, or it, with caution;] namely, a thing. (JK.) -A2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

2 rah~aba see 4. ― -b2- [Hence, rh~bhu Eano ka*aA, inf. n. tarohiybN, He made him to have no desire for such a thing; to relinquish it, or abstain from it; contr. of rag~abahu fiyhi: used in this sense by postclassical writers, and perhaps by classical authors also. ― -b3- And rh~bhu He made him a raAhibi, or monk: in this sense likewise used by post-classical writers; and mentioned by Golius as so used in El-Mekeen's History.] -A2- rah~aba, said of a man, He was, or became, fatigued, tired, weary, or jaded. (JK.) And rhb, [so in the TA, app. rah~aba, but perhaps ↓ rahaba, without teshdeed,] said of a camel, He rose, and then lay down upon his breast, by reason of weakness in his back-bone. (TA.) You say also, rah~abati Aln~aAqapu faqaEada yuHaAyiyhaA, (K, TA,) [or, accord. to some copies of the K, yuHaAbiyhaA,] inf. n. tarohiybN, (K,) but in some copies the verb is an unaugmented triliteral, [app. ↓ rahabat,] (TA,) The she-camel was fatigued, or jaded, by travel, so he sat feeding her and treating her well until her spirit returned to her. (K, * TA.) -A3- ruh~iba It (an iron head or blade of an arrow &c.) was rubbed [app. so as to be made thin: see rahobN]. (JK.)

4 Arhbhu * (JK, S, A, K) and ↓ Astrhbhu (S, A, K) He, or it, frightened him, or caused him to fear; (S, K;) as also ↓ rh~bhu: (MA:) or disquieted him, or agitated him, by frightening. (A.) You say, yaqo$aEir~u AlA_ihaAbu A_i*aA waqaEa minohu AlA_irohaAbu [The skin quivers when frightening befalls from him]. (A, TA.) And A^arohaba Aln~aAsa Eanohu baA^osuhu wanajodatuhu (tropical:) [His valour and courage frightened men away from him]. (A.) And lamo A^urohabo bika [lit. I was not frightened by thee]; meaning (tropical:) I did not see in thee what induced in me doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion. (A, TA.) And Arhb AlA_ibila, (JK, A,) inf. n. A_irohaAbN, (JK, K,) (tropical:) He drove away, (A,) or repelled, (JK,) or withheld, (K,) the camels, (JK, A, K,) Eani AlHawaDi [from the watering-trough or tank]. (A, K.) -A2- Arhb (said of a man, TA) also signifies He rode a camel such as is termed rahob. (K.) -A3- Also He was, or became, long in the rahab, i. e. sleeve. (IAar, K. *)

5 trh~b *
He (a man) became a raAhib [or monk], fearing God, or fearing God with reverence or awe: (TA:) or he devoted himself to religious services or exercises (JK, S, A, K) in his SawomaEap [or cell]: (A:) or he (a monk) detached himself [from the world. or became a recluse,] for the purpose of devoting himself to religious services or exercises. (Msb.) -A2- trh~bhu He threatened him. (K.)

10 Astrhbhu *
He called forth fear of him, so that men feared him. (TA.) waA@sotarohabuwhumo, in the Kur [vii. 113], has been expl. as meaning And they called forth fear of them, [i. e. of themselves,] so that men feared them. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 4.

rahobN * An emaciated she-camel; (As, S, K;) or so [the fem.] rahobapN: (JK:) or the former, a she-camel much emaciated; as also ↓ rahobaY; or, as some say, this last, occurring in a verse, is the name of a particular she-camel: and the first also signifies a she-camel lean, and lank in the belly: (TA:) or tall; applied to a he-camel; (K;) fem. with p: (TA:) or one that has been used in journeying, and has become fatigued, or jaded; (JK, TA;) fem. with p: and ↓ rahobaA='u signifies a she-camel fatigued, or jaded: and the first, a he-camel large, wide in the belly-girth, broad in make between the shoulder-joints: (JK:) or wide in the bones, broad in make between the shoulder-joints. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A slender arrow: or a great arrow: (TA:) and a thin iron head or blade (S, K, TA) of an arrow: (S, TA:) pl. rihaAbN. (S, K.)
ruhobN * : see what next follows, in two places.

rahabN * (Zj, K, TA) and ↓ ruhobN (Zj, TA) A sleeve: (T, K:) accord. to Z, (TA,) of the dial. of Himyer; but one of the innovations of the expositions [of the Kur-án]: (Ksh in xxviii. 32, and TA: [not, as Golius says, referring to the Ksh as his authority, of the dial. of the Arabs of El- Heereh:]) said in the Jm to be not of established authority: but signifying thus accord. to AA: and so accord. to Zj, (L, TA,) and Mukátil, (T, L, TA,) in the Kur xxviii. 32; [though generally held to be there, accord. to all the various readings, (which are Alr~ahab and Alr~uhob and Alr~uhub and Alr~ahob,) an inf. n. of rahiba;] and Az says that this is a correct meaning in Arabic, and the most agreeable with the context. (L, TA.) One says, ↓ waDaEotu Al$~aYo'a fiY ruhobiY, meaning I put the thing in my sleeve [to carry it therein, as is often done] (TA.)
rahobapN * : see what next follows: ― -b2- and see also rahobaAniy~apN.

rahobaY * and ↓ ruhobaY and ↓ rahobaA='u and ↓ ruhobaA='N [which last I write with tenween accord. to a general rule applying to words of the measure fuEolaA='] and ↓ rahabuwtN and ↓ rahabuwtaY, each a simple subst., (K,) as also ↓ rahobapN, (Msb, [but accord. to the S and K, this last is an inf. n. of rahiba,]) signifying Fear: (Msb, K:) or fear with caution. (TA.) One says, xayorN mino raHamowtK ↓ rahabuwtN, (S, Meyd, K,) or, accord. to Mbr, xayorN mino raHamuwtaY ↓ rahabuwtY, (Meyd,) [Fear is better than pity, or compassion,] meaning thy being feared is better than thy being pitied, or compassionated: (S, Meyd, K:) a proverb. (Meyd. [See 1 in art. rgb.]) And ↓ ruhobaAka xayorN mino rugobaAka, a similar prov. [expl. voce ragiba]. (Meyd.) And mina A@ll~`hi wAlr~ugobaY A_ilayohi ↓ Alr~uhobaY [also expl. voce ragiba]. (Lth, TA.) -A2- For the first word, see also rahobN.
ruhobaY * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
rahobaA='u * : see rahobaY: -A2- and see also rahobN.
ruhobaA='N * : see rahobaY.

rahobaAnu *
Excessively fearful. (Bd in lvii. 27.)
rahobanapN * : see rahobaAniy~apN.
rahabuwtN * : see rahobaY, in two places. -A2- Also Fearful; applied to a man. (S.)
rahabuwtaY * : see rahobaY, in two places.

rahobaAniy~apN * , (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) written in an exposition of the Makámát [of El-Hareeree] without teshdeed, (Mgh,) [Monkery; asceticism; the life, or state, of a monk or an ascetic;] the state of a raAhib, (A, Msb,) or Christian devotee; (Mgh;) the masdar of raAhibN, (JK, S, K,) as also ↓ rahobapN: (S, K:) or it is originally from Alr~ahobapu; and by a secondary application is used as a noun signifying excess, or extravagance: (AAF, TA:) or it is from ↓ rahobanapN, [which has the same signification, of the measure faEolanapN from rahobapN, or faEolalapN on the supposition that the n is a radical letter: (IAth, TA:) or it signifies excess in religious services or exercises, and discipline, and the detaching oneself from mankind; and is from rahobaAnu, signifying “excessively fearful:” so in the Kur lvii. 27; where it is said, warahobaAniy~apF A@botadaEuwhaA, (Bd,) meaning waA@botadaEuwA rahobaAniy~apF A@botadaEuwhaA [And they innovated excess &c.: they innovated it]: (AAF, Bd, TA:) and some read with damm, [ruhobaAniy~apF,] as though from ruhobaAnN, pl. of raAhibN. (Bd.) It is said in a trad., (TA,) laA rahobaAniy~apa fiY AlA_isolaAmi [There is no monkery in El-Islám]; i. e., no such thing as the making oneself a eunuch, and putting chains upon one's neck, and wearing garments of hair-cloth, and abstaining from flesh-meat, and the like. (K.) And in another trad., Ealayokumo biA@lojihaAdi faA_in~ahu ruhobaAniy~apu A^um~atiY [Keep ye to the waging of war against the unbelievers, for it is the asceticism of my people]. (TA.)
rahaAbN * and ruhaAbN: see what next follows.

rahaAbapN * (S, K) and ruhaAbapN and ↓ rah~aAbapN and ruh~aAbapN accord. to El-Hirmázee, (K, TA,) [The ensiform cartilage, or lower extremity of the sternum;] a certain bone, (S, K,) or small bone, (TA,) in the breast, impending over the belly, (S, K, TA,) resembling the tongue, (S,) or like the extremity of the tongue of the dog: (TA:) or a certain cartilage, resembling the tongue, suspended in the lower part of the breast, impending over the belly: (TA:) the tongue of the sternum, at the lower part: (ISh, TA:) or, accord. to IAar, the extremity of the stomach: (TA:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] ↓ rahaAbN [and ruhaAbN]. (K.)
rah~aAbapN * and ruh~aAbapN: see what next precedes.

raAhibN *
Fearing; [or a fearer; or fearing with caution; or a cautious fearer;] as in the phrase huwa raAhibN mina A@ll~`hi [He is one who fears God; or a fearer of God; &c.]: whence the signification
next following. (Msb.) ― -b2- A Christian [monk, ascetic, religious recluse, or] devotee; (Mgh, Msb;) one who devotes himself to religious services or exercises, in a SawomaEap [or cell]; (TA;) one of the ruhobaAn of the Christians: (S, K:) [i. e.] the pl. is ruhobaAnN (A, Mgh, Msb) and rahabapN; (A;) or, sometimes, ruhobaAnN is a sing.; (K;) as in the following ex., cited by IAar:
lawo kal~amato ruhobaAna dayorK fiY Alqulalo
laA@noHadara Alr~uhobaAnu yasoEaY fanazalo
[If she spoke to a Christian monk in a monastery among the summits of a mountain, the Christian monk would come down running, and so descend]: but he says that the approved way is to use it as a pl.: (TA:) and rahaAbiynu is a pl. (A, Msb, K) of ruhobaAnN, (K,) and rahaAbinapN is another pl. (A, K) of the same, and so is ruhobaAnuwna. (K.) -A2- See also marohuwbN.

raAhibapN *
A state, or condition, that frightens. (TA.)

A^arohaAbN *
Birds that are not rapacious; that do not prey. (K.) [App. so called because timid; as Golius supposes.]
murah~ibN * , applied to a she-camel, [though of a masc. form,] Fatigued in her back. (TA. [See its verb, 2.])

marohuwbN *
Feared: (Mgh, Msb:) [or feared with caution:] applied to God. (Msb.) In the phrase lab~ayoka marohuwbN wamaroguwbN A_ilayoka [At thy service time after time: Thou art feared, and petitioned, or supplicated with humility, &c.], it is in the nom. case as the enunciative of an inchoative [A^anota] suppressed. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Almarohuwbu, as also ↓ Alr~aAhibu, [the latter in this case being like raADK in the sense of maroDiY~N,] The lion. (K.)

4 Arhj * , (K,) or Arhj AlgubaAra, (S, Mgh,) He, or it, raised the dust. (S, Mgh, K.) You say, A^arohajato HawaAfiru Alxayoli The hoofs of the horses raised the dust. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence, because a heavy rain raises the dust,] Arhjt Als~amaA='u (tropical:) The sky poured, or flowed, with rain. (A, K.) ― -b3- And Arhj bayonahumo (tropical:) He raised, or excited, conflict and faction, or sedition, or discord or dissension, between them, or among them. (A.) ― -b4- And ArhjwA fiY AlkalaAmi waAlS~axabi (tropical:) [They raised a tumult in talking and clamouring]. (A.) ― -b5- And Arhj He had in his house, or chamber, much baxuwr [or incense]. (IAar, K.)
rahojN * : see what next follows.

rahajN * (S, A, Mgh, K) and ↓ rahojN (K) Dust, syn. gubaArN, (S, A, Mgh, K,) raised. (Mgh.) In the phrase Ealayohi rahaju AlgubaAri [Upon him, or it, is raised dust], AlgbAr is subjoined by way of explanation. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., mano daxala jawofahu Alr~ahaju lamo yadoxulohu Har~u Aln~aAri [He into whose inside the dust raised in fighting in the cause of God has entered, the heat of the fire of Hell will not enter it]. (TA. [The meaning is shown by another trad. there cited.]) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or the former word, (TA,) Clouds, (K,) or thin clouds, (TA:) without water, (K,) resembling dust: (TA:) n. un. with p. (K.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or the former word, (TA,) (tropical:) Excitement of evil or mischief, of conflict and faction, of sedition, or of discord or dissension. (IAar, L, K, TA.)
ruhojuwjN * : see what next follows.

rihojiyjN *
Weak; (K;) applied to a young weaned camel; (TA;) or to a man and an animal [of any kind]: (TK:) and soft; as also ↓ ruhojuwjN, (K,) with damm; (TA; in the CK [erroneously] rahojuwj;) applied to a man. (TK.)
ma$oYN rahowajN * (S) An easy, gentle, pace: (TA:) the latter app. a Pers. word, arabicized; (S;) [from rahowaA or rahowaAro, or] its Pers. original is rahowaho. (L.)

rahowajapN *
A certain [easy] kind of pace. (S, K.)
nawo'N murohijN * (tropical:) [A star, or an asterism, of the Mansions of the Moon, or of any that were believed to bring rain,] attended by much rain [as though it raised the dust]. (A, K.)

Q. 1 rahodana * , (TA,) inf. n. rahodanapN, (K, TA,) He circled in walking [like the bird called rahodanN]: (K, TA:) or he was as though he circled in his gait. (Az, TA.) See rahodanN. ― -b2- He was, or became, slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward. (K, TA.) And He was, or became, restricted, or limited. (K, TA.) A poet, cited by IAar to Th, says,
fajiy^otu biAln~aqodi walamo A^urahodino
i. e. [And I brought the cash, or ready money, and] was not slow, or tardy, &c., and was not restricted, or limited, with it. (TA.)

rahodanN * (S, K) and ↓ ruhodanN and ↓ rihodanN (K) A certain bird, in Mekkeh, like the EuSofuwr [or sparrow]; (S, K;) as also ↓ rahodanapN, and ↓ ruhodun~apN and ↓ ruhoduwnN: (K:) and a certain bird resembling the jum~ar, [which is said by Es-Sakháwee, cited in the Msb in art. Hmr, to be the qub~ar, i. e. lark,] except that it is A^adobas [i. e. brown, or of a colour between black and red, or of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, in which are redness and blackness], and is larger than the Hum~ar; as also ↓ rahodanapN: (S, TA:) pl. rahaAdinu: (S, K:) and rahodalN, pl. rahaAdilu, signifies the same: (TA:) or the ↓ ruhodun~ap is a bird resembling the qunoburap [or lark], that moves as though circling (kaA^an~ahaA tasotadiyru ↓ turahodinu) in her gait: (JK:) and accord. to the L, in art. HDb, the rahodan is the qunobur [or lark]. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A coward: (K, TA:) as being likened to the bird so called. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Foolish; stupid; or unsound, or deficient, in intellect or under- standing: (K:) or so the first word (rahodanN): or a weak man: (JK:) pl. rahaAdinapN. (TA.)
ruhodanN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
ruhodunN * , without teshdeed, (assumed tropical:) A heavy [or slow] man. (JK.)
rihodanN * : see rahodanN.
rahodanapN * and ruhodun~apN: see rahodanN; for each in two places.
ruhoduwnN * : see rahodanN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A liar. (K.)
1 rahVTa see what next follows.

8 naHonu *awuw A@rotihaATK *
We are collected together, or congregated; as also ↓ naHonu *awuw rahoTK: (K, TA:) [the last word in each of these phrases being an inf. n.; unless that in the latter be a mistake for A^arohuTK, (a pl. of rahoTN,) which I find put in the place of rahoTK in a MS. copy of the K:] from Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.) ― -b2- In a trad. occurs the phrase, faA^ayoqaZanaA wanaHonu A@rotihaATN [And he waked us,] we being parties collected together, or congregated: the last word being an inf. n. put in the place of the verb [or rather of the part. n., or for *awuw A@ratihaATK]. (TA.)

rahoTN * (Lth, S, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ rahaTN, (Lth, Msb, K,) but the former is the more chaste, (Lth, Msb,) A man's people, and tribe, (S, Msb, K,) consisting of his nearer relations: (Msb:) [i. e. his near kinsfolk:] and a number of men less than ten, among whom is no woman; (AZ, S, Msb, K;) as also nafarN: (AZ, Msb:) or from seven to ten; (IDrd, Msb, K;) and sometimes a little more; (IDrd;) less than seven, to three, being called nafarN: (Msb:) or from three to ten: (K:) or i. q. Ea$iyrapN: (ISk, Msb:) or more than ten, to forty: (As, IF, Msb:) a pl., (S, Msb,) or a word having a pl. meaning, (Th, Az, Msb,) without any proper sing.; (Th, Az, S, Msb, K;) like nafarN and qawomN and maEo$arN and Ea$iyrapN; all applied to men, exclusive of women: (Th, Msb:) and ↓ A^urohuwTN signifies the same: (ISh, TA:) the pl. of rhT is A^arohuTN (Lth, S, K) and A^arohiTapN (Lth) and A^arohaATN, (S, K,) [all pls. of pauc.,] the last of these being pl. either of rahaTN or of rahoTN, (TA,) and A^araAhiTu, (S, ISd, K,) as though pl. of A^arohuTN, (S, ISd,) though Sb makes it pl. of rahoTN, because of the rareness of the pl. pl., (ISd,) and A^araAhiyTu [which is app. pl. of A^arohaATN]. (S, K.) You say, humo rahoTuhu dinoyapF They are his people, and his tribe, closely related. (S, TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xxvii. 49], wakaAna qiY Almadiynapi tisoEapu rahoTK, (S,) but this means, [And there were in the city] nine persons, (Bd,) or nine men. (Jel.) ― -b2- You also say rahoTN mino Eu$arK [A collection of plants of the kind called E$r]. (IAar, Sh, TA in art. Ayk.) -A2- An enemy; syn. Eaduw~N; (K, TA; [in the CK Eadow;]) mentioned by Sgh, on the authority of Ibn- 'Abbád. (TA.) -A3- A skin, (K,) or a waistwrapper (A_izaAr) made of leather, (Jm,) the sides
of which are slit in several places in their lower parts, so that one may walk in it; (Jm, K;) or made of skin, and also of wool; (Aboo-Tálib the Grammarian;) or a skin of Et-Táïf, slit in several places; (M, TA;) or a skin of a size equal to the space between the navel and the knee; (S;) or a skin slit into a number of thongs or strips; (ISh, S, K;) or a skin cut into a number of thongs or strips, these being one above another; (AHeyth;) or a waist-wrapper (miy^ozar) made of skin, or leather, slit in several places, except in the place of the pudendum; (TA;) or a skin slit into strips, each strip being of the breadth of four fingers; (IAar;) worn by children, (M, K,) or by a young girl before she has arrived at puberty, (IAar,) and by a woman in menstruis: (IAar, S, M, K, &c.:) [in Nubia, the rahoT, still called by that name, is very neatly made, consisting of a great number of slender thongs: it is worn there by young girls, and is generally their only covering, completely surrounding and concealing the pelvic portion of the body, and the whole or part of the thighs:] in the Time of Ignorance, the men used to perform their circuitings [around the Kaabeh] naked, and the women wearing [only] the rhT: (S:) [see also HawofN, in two places:] the pl. is A^arohaATN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, TA) and rihaATN: (ISh, S, K:) or this last is a sing. also, (K,) signifying a piece of leather of a size equal to the space between the place of the waist-band and the knee, slit in several places like the [thongs called] $uruk [of the sandal, pl. of $iraAk]; worn by a girl of seven years: or a garment worn by the boys of the Arabs of the desert, consisting of overlapping folds or plies, one above another, like fans: (TA:) pl. A^arohiTapN [a pl. of pauc.]. (K.)
rahaTN * : see rahoTN.

rahoTiY~N *
Of, or relating to, or belonging to, a rahoT, meaning a man's people, and tribe, &c. (L.)
ruhaTapN * : see what next follows.
ruhaTaA='u * : see what next follows.

raAhiTaA='u * and ↓ ruhaTapN (S, K) and ↓ ruhaTaA='u, (K,) like daAm~aA='u, (S,) One of the holes of the jerboa, from which it takes forth the earth or dust, (S, K,) and collects it; (S;) it is the first hole that it excavates; (TA:) and is between the qaASiEaA=' and the naAfiqaA='; and therein it hides its young: (Az, TA:) or, as AHeyth explains the first of these words, what the jerboa makes, or puts, at the mouth of the qASEA', and what is behind that, covering its hole except enough to admit the light from it. (TA.)
A^urohuwTN * : see rahoTN.

1 rahufa * , aor.
rahufa , inf. n. rahaAfapN (JK, MA, K) and rahafN (JK, K) and rahofN, (TA,) It (a sword, K, or a thing [of any kind], JK, TA) was, or became, thin, and slender; (JK, K, TA;) it (a sword) was, or became, thin in the edge or point; (Ham p. 349;) it was, or became, sharp, or keen; contr. of kal~a. (MA.) -A2- rahafahu: see what next follows.

4 Arhfhu * , (JK, S, K, &c.,) inf. n. A_irohaAfN; (Ham p. 93;) and ↓ rahafahu, aor.
rahafa , (K,) inf. n. rahofN; (TA;) He made it (a sword, S, K, &c., or a thing [of any kind], JK) thin, (S, MA, K,) or sharp or pointed; (JK, MA;) he made it (a sword) thin in the edge or point; (Ham p. 93;) he made it sharp, or keen. (MA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^arohafota EalayonaA lisaAnaka (tropical:) [Thou hast sharpened against us thy tongue]. (A, TA.) And A^arohifo garoba *ihonika limaA A^aqwlu (tropical:) [Sharpen the edge of thine intellect for what I say]. (A, TA.)

rahiyfN *
Thin; slender; (JK, TA;) applied in this sense to a sword; (TA;) and also to a neck: (ISh, TA in art. btE:) or thin in the edge or point; applied to a sword: (Ham p. 349:) or sharp, or keen; thus applied: (JK, * MA:) but Az says that it is seldom used; ↓ murohafN being used in its stead. (TA.)

murohafN * (JK, S, TA) and ↓ marohuwfN (JK, TA) Made thin; (JK, S, TA;) applied to a sword, (S, TA,) or to an arrow: (JK:) and the former, [or each,] made sharp or pointed: (JK:) [or made thin in the edge or pointed: or made sharp or keen: see 4:] and see also rahiyfN. ― -b2- A^u*unN murohafapN (assumed tropical:) A slender ear. (TA.) And xaSorN murohafN (assumed tropical:) A slender waist. (Ham p. 93.) And rajulN murohafu Aljisomi (JK, TA) and ↓ Albadani ↓ marohuwfu, but the former is the more common, (tropical:) A man slender in the body. (TA.) ― -b3- farasN murohafN (assumed tropical:) A horse lank in the belly, having the ribs near together: which is a fault. (IDrd, K, TA.)

murohafapN * [as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] Swords; (Ham p. 93;) and so murohafaAtN: (S and TA in art. brd:) or swords made thin in the edge or point. (Ham p. 349.) One says murohafaAtN bawaAridu Sharp, or cutting, swords: (TA in art. brd:) or slaying swords. (S in that art.)
marohuwfN * : see murohafN, in two places.

1 rahiqahu * , (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
rahaqa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. rahaqN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He, or it, came upon, properly as a thing that covered, him, or it; or came to him, or it; syn. ga$iyahu: (S, K:) and (K) reached, or overtook, him, or it: (ElFárábee, Msb, K:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (S,) he drew near to, or approached, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) whether he took, or did not take, (S, K,) him, or it: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or he followed him, and was near to reaching, or overtaking, him. (JK.) It is said in the Kur [x. 27], walaA yarohaqu wajuwhahumo qatarN walaA *il~apN, meaning (assumed tropical:) And there shall not come upon, or overspread, their faces [blackness, or darkness, nor abjectness, or ignominy]. (S, TA.) And you say, rahiqahu Ald~ayonu, (Msb, TA,) or dayonN, (Mgh,) Debt, or a debt, came upon him. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) And rahiqatonaA AlS~alaApu, (inf. n. ruhuwqN, Msb, or rahaqN, TA,) (tropical:) The time of prayer came upon us. (Mgh, * Msb, TA.) And it is said in a trad., A_i*aA Sal~aY A^aHadukumo A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i faloyarohaqohu, i. e. [When any one of you prays towards the thing,] let him come near to it. (JK, S. [In the Mgh, A_ilaY sutorapK faloyarohaqohaA, i. e. towards a thing that he has set up for that purpose, &c.]) One says also, Talabotu fulaAnFA Hat~aY rahiqotuhu, inf. n. rahaqN, I sought such a one until I drew near to him, and, as it sometimes means, took him, or, as it sometimes means, did not take him. (S.) And Talabotu Al$~aYo'a Hat~aY rahiqotuhu wakidotu A=xu*uhu A^awo A^axa*otuhu [I sought the thing until I came near to it, and I almost took it, or I took it]. (Az, Msb.) And rahaqa $uxuwSu fulaAnK, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Such a one's going, or going forth or away,] drew near. (S.) ↓ A^arohaqotuhu also signifies I drew near to it; syn. daAnayotuhu. (Msb.) And one says, All~ayolu ↓ A^arohaqakumu faA^asoriEuwA, i. e. (tropical:) The night has drawn near [to you, therefore hasten ye]; syn. danaA. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, rahiqahu bimaA yakorahu, inf. n. rahaqN, He did to him that which he disliked, or hated. (JK.) ― -b3- And rahiqotu A_ivomFA: see 4. -A2- rahiqa as an intrans. v.: see rahaqN, which is its inf. n., below.

2 ruh~iqa *
He was one to whom rahaqN [q. v.] was attributed. (Mgh.) [He was one to whom ignorance was attributed; an object of suspicion in respect of his religion: (see the part. n., below:) or he was suspected of evil conduct.] It is said in a trad., Sal~aY EalaY A@moraA^apK turah~aqu, (S, Mgh,) meaning [He prayed over a woman] suspected of evil conduct. (S.)

3 rAhq * , (S, Msb, K,) and rAhq AlHuluma, (JK, Az, K, all in art. xlf,) inf. n. muraAhaqapN, (Msb,) He (a boy) was, or became, near to attaining puberty, or virility; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ Arhq, inf. n. A_irohaAqN. (Msb.) And rAhqt AlEi$oriyna [She nearly attained the age of twenty]. (K in art. ESr.)

4 Arhqhu TugoyaAnFA *
i. q. A^ago$aAhu A_iy~aAhu [i. e. He made excessive disobedience to come upon him, properly as a thing that covered him]; (S, K;) and A^aloHaqahu bihi [i. e. made it to reach him, or overtake him, or befall him]. (K.) It is said in the Kur xviii. 79, faxa$iynaA A^ano yurohiqahumaA TugoyaAnFA wakuforFA, meaning [And we disapproved] that he should make excessive disobedience, and ingratitude, to come upon them twain, by his undutiful conduct, so bringing evil upon them: or that he should couple with the faith of them twain his excessive disobedience and his ingratitude, so that there would be in one house two believers and one who was excessively disobedient and ungrateful: or that he should communicate to them twain his excessive disobedience and his ingratitude. (Ksh, Bd. [See also xa$iYa.]) And one says, A^arohaqaniY fulaAnN A_ivomFA ↓ Hat~aY rahiqotuhu, meaning Such a one made me to hear the burden of a sin, [as though he made the sin to come upon me as a burden,] so that I bore it. (S.) And A^arohaqotu Alr~ajula A^amorFA I made, required, or constrained, the man to bear, or endure, a thing, or an event. (Msb.) And rAhqhu EusorFA He made, required, or constrained, him to do a difficult thing: (AZ, S, Mgh, K:) or he made a difficulty to come upon him, properly as a thing
that covered him; syn. A^ago$aAhu A_iy~aAhu. (Ksh and Bd in xviii. 72.) And Arhqhu, alone, He demanded of him a difficult thing. (S, Msb, K.) You say, laA turohiqoniY laA A^arohaqaka A@ll~`hu Demand not thou of me a difficult thing: may God not demand of thee a difficult thing. (AZ, S, K.) And A_irohaAqN signifies also The inciting, or urging, a man to do a thing that he is not able to do. (Az, K, TA.) ― -b2- You say also, A^arohaqonaAhumu Alx~ayola We made the horsemen to overtake them, or come up with them: (TA:) or to be near doing so. (JK.) ― -b3- And Arhq AlS~alaApa (tropical:) He delayed the prayer (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) until it approached the other [next after it], (JK,) or until it almost approached the other, (Mgh, K, TA,) or until the time of the other approached. (S, Msb.) ― -b4- And A^arohaqotuhu A^ano yuSal~iYa i. q. A^aEojalotuhu EanohaA [i. e. I hurried him so as to prevent him from praying: see similar phrases in art. Ejl]. (K.) ― -b5- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two places: ― -b6- and see 3. -A2- Arhqt Ald~aAb~apu Als~aroja: see 4 in art. zhq.

rahaqN * The doing of forbidden things: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) wrongdoing; wrongful, unjust, in jurious, or tyrannical, conduct: (Fr, S, K:) it has this meaning in the Kur lxxii. 13, (S, TA,) accord. to Fr; or, as some say, the former mean ing: (TA:) the doing evil: (AA, K:) and a subst. from A_irohaAqN signifying the inciting, or urging, a man to do a thing that he is not able to do: (Az, K:) lightwittedness; or lightness and hastiness of disposition or deportment; (S, K;) and excessive disobedience: so in the Kur lxxii. 6, (S, TA,) accord. to some: (TA:) foolishness, or stupidity: lightness, or levity: (K:) or ignorance, and lightness of intellect: (JK:) and illnature, or evil disposition: (TA:) and haste: (K:) and lying: (Mgh, K:) in all these senses, [i. e. in all that have been mentioned above as from the K, and app. in others also, above and below,] its verb is ↓ rahiqa, aor.
rahaqa , [meaning He did forbidden things: acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: &c.:] (K, TA:) of which it is the inf. n.: (TA:) and the following meanings also are assigned to it [app. by interpreters of the passages in which it occurs in the Kur]: sus picion, or evil opinion: and sin: accord. to Katádeh: lowness, vileness, or meanness; and weakness; accord. to Zj: error; accord. to Ibn El-Kelbee: and bad, or corrupt, conduct: and pride: and so ↓ rahoqapN, in these two senses: and the commission of a sin or crime or fault; syn. EanatN: and the act of reaching, or overtaking [app. of some evil accident]: and perdition. (TA.)

rahiqN * A man in whose conduct, or character, is rahaqN [expl. above: i. e. one who does forbidden things: &c.]: (O:) hasty: quick to do evil: and self-conceited; proud, or haughty. (TA.) And rahiqapN A vitious woman; or an adulteress, or a fornicatress. (TA.)
rahoqapN * : see rahaqN.

yaEoduw Alr~ahaqaY *
He runs quickly, so as to require his pursuer to do what is difficult or what is beyond his power (Hat~aY yurohiqa TaAlibahu, or, as in the CK, Ht~Y yurohaqa TaAlibuhu [which is virtually the same]): (M, K, TA:) or he runs quickly, so that he almost reaches, or overtakes, (Ht~Y yakaAda yarohaqu,) the object of his pursuit. (JK.)
ruhoqaAnu miAy^apK * : see what next follows.

ruhaAqu miAy^apK * and rihaAqu miAy^ipK As many as a hundred; (AZ, ISk, JK, S, K;) as also mAy^p ↓ ruhoqaAnu: (so in one of my copies of the S:) such are said to be a man's camels, (JK,) or such is said to be a company of men. (AZ, ISk, S.)
rahuwqN * A wide-stepping, and quick, or excellent, she-camel, that comes upon him who leads her so as almost to tread upon him with her feet. (En Nadr, K.)

rahiyqN *
Wine: (K:) a dial. var. of raHiyqN, like as madohN is of madoHN. (TA.)
raAhiqN * applied to a boy, and raAhiqapN applied to a girl, From ten to eleven years old. (TA.) [See also muraAhiqN.]

rayohuqaAnN *
Saffron. (JK, IDrd, S, K.)

murohaqN *
Reached, or overtaken, (JK, S, O, K,) to be slain. (S, O.) ― -b2- Straitened. (Ham p. 682.)

A^atayonaA fiY AlEuSayori Almurohiqapi * (tropical:) [app. We came when the time of the afternoon-prayer was drawing near; AlEuSayor being the dim. of AlEaSoru: see the phrase A^arohaqakumu All~ayolu faA^asoriEuwA, near the end of the first paragraph]. (TA.)

murah~aqN * One to whom men come (S, K, TA) often, (TA,) and at whose abode guests alight. (JK, S, K, * TA.) ― -b2- Also One to whom rahaqN [q. v.] is attributed: (JK, K:) [said in the TA to have no verb; but this is not the case: see 2:] one of whom evil is thought: (JK, S, K:) or who is suspected of evil, or of lightwittedness: (TA:) one to whom ignorance is attributed: (Mgh;) an object of suspicion in respect of his religion: (Mgh, TA:) corrupt [in conduct]: one in whom is sharpness [of temper] and lightwittedness. (TA.)

muraAhiqN *
Near to attaining puberty; applied to a boy: (JK, Mgh, TA:) and with p applied to a girl. (TA.) [See also raAhiqN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] daxala mak~apa muraAhiqFA (tropical:) He entered Mekkeh nearly at the end of the [proper] time [to do so as a pilgrim], so that he almost missed the halt at 'Arafát. (Nh, O, K, TA.) And Sal~aY AlZ~uhora muraAhiqFA (tropical:) He performed the noon-prayer nearly missing the time. (TA.)

1 rahila laHomuhu * , (S, K,) [aor.
rahala ,] inf. n. rahalN, (JK, TA,) His flesh was, or became, quivering, and flaccid, or flabby: (S, K:) and (some say, TA) his flesh was, or became, inflated, or puffy, or swollen, (K, TA,) in any part: (TA:) or it was, or became, swollen without disease; (JK, K, TA;) he being flaccid by reason of fatness, (JK, TA,) and inclining to weakness. (TA.) [See also 5.]

2 rh~lhu * , inf. n. tarohiylN, It (flesh-meat) rendered it (i. e. his flesh) quivering, and flaccid, or flabby: (S, K:) or inflated, or swollen: or swollen without disease: (K: [see 1:]) or it (much sleep) rendered his face swollen, and the parts below, or around, his eyes puffy. (TA.)

5 trh~l *
He was, or became, soft in the flesh: and it (the flesh of a limb or member) was, or became, soft. (KL.) [See also 1.]
riholN * [in the Lexicons of Golius and Freytag rihalN] Thin clouds, resembling [falling] dew, (K, TA,) in the sky. (TA.)

rahalN *
Yellow water [or fluid] in the suxod [app. here meaning the membrane that encloses the fœtus of a beast]. (IDrd, K.)

rahilN *
Quivering, and flaccid, or flabby, flesh. (TA.) And rahilN AlS~adori A horse quivering, and flaccid, or flabby, in the breast. (S, TA.)

A^aSobaHa murah~alFA *
He was, or became, in the morning, swollen (K, TA) in his face, by reason of much sleep. (TA. [See 2. In some copies of the K, tahay~aja is erroneously put, in this explanation, for tahab~aja.])

1 ruhimati AlA^aroDu *
The land was rained upon [with such rain as is termed rihomap]. (Z, TA.)
4 Arhmt Als~amaA='u * , (JK, K,) or Als~aHaAbapu, (S,) The sky, or the cloud, shed the sort of rain, or rains, termed rihomp, or rihaAm. (JK, S, K.)

rihomapN *
A drizzling and lasting rain; i. e. a lasting, or continuous, rain, consisting of small drops: (JK:) or weak and lasting rain, (S, K,) said by AZ to be such as falls with more force, and passes away more quickly, than that which is termed diymapN: (S:) pl. rihamN and rihaAmN: (JK, S, K:) El-Ámidee seems to have held that rihaAmN is pl. of rahamapN; for he likens these two words to A_ikaAmN and A^akamapN; but this is at variance with what is held by the leading lexicologists. (TA.) [See an ex. of the pl. rihaAmN in a verse of Lebeed cited in the first paragraph of art. rzq.]

A^aroDN rahomaA='u *
Land upon which rains such as are termed rihaAm have fallen: (Ham p. 99:) and ↓ rawoDapN marohuwmapN, [from ruhimat, Meadows] watered by the rain termed rihomapN: (JK, S, K:) one should not say murohamapN. (K.)
rahomaAnu * : see rahuwmN.

rahamaAnN * , in the going of camels, A bearing, and leaning, on one side, or sideways. (JK, * K. [In the former, it is implied that the word is rahomaAn, which is at variance with an express statement in the K.])

rahaAmN * (assumed tropical:) A sheep, or goat, [$aApN,] lean, or ema ciated; (JK, K; [in the former written ruhaAm, but said in the latter to be like saHaAbN;]) and so
↓ rahuwmN: (TA:) [i. e.] you say also $aApN rahuwmN, (JK, K, TA,) meaning (assumed tropical:) a sheep, or goat, lean, or emaciated: (TA:) from [rahuwmN, or perhaps rahaAmN, or both, as meaning] clouds (saHaAbN) that have discharged their water. (JK.)
ruhaAmN * , applied to a bird, That does not prey: (K:) or the bird called guronuwq. (JK.) -A2- Also A large number. (JK, K.)
rahuwmN * : see rahaAmN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A man weak in seek ing, or searching, [to find what is best to be done;] who follows mere opinion; as also ↓ rahomaAnu. (JK, K.)

A^arohamu *
More [and most] fruitful, or plentiful, or abundant in herbage or in the goods or conveniences or comforts of life: [as though meaning more, and most, watered by rain such as is termed rihomap:] so in the saying, nazalonaA bifulaAnK fakun~aA fiY A^arohami jaAnibayohi [We alighted at the dwelling of such a one, and we were in the more fruitful, &c., of the two sides of his place of abode; meaning, and we were entertained by him in the best, or most bountiful, manner]. (S.)

marohamN * [A place upon which has fallen rain such as is termed rihomapN: pl. maraAhimu: see an ex. in what follows. ― -b2- Also] A certain application for wounds; (S;) a soft plaster or dressing, (K, TA,) the softest of medicaments, (TA,) [i. e. an unguent, or the like,] with which a wound is plastered, dressed, overspread, or anointed: (K, TA:) [pl. as above:] it is an arabicized word [from the Pers. marohamo]: (S:) or derived from Alr~ihomapu, [as some say,] because of its softness. (K.) You say, maraAhimu AlgawaAdiY maraAhimu AlbawaAdiY [The places watered by the drizzling and lasting rains of the early morning-clouds are the soft plasters, or unguents, of the deserts]. (A, TA.)
rawoDapN marohuwmapN * : see A^aroDN rahomaA='u, above.

1 rahana * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
rahana , (Msb,) inf. n. rahonN, (S, TA,) or ruhuwnN, (Msb,) It (a thing, S, Msb, TA) continued, subsisted, lasted, endured, remained, or remained fixed or stationary; it was, or became, permanent, constant, firm, steady, stead fast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established. (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA.) This is the primary signification. (Mgh, TA. *) ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh,) rahana biAlmakaAni (tropical:) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (A, Mgh, TA.) ― -b3- And rahana, (JK, S, K,) aor.
rahana , (K, TA,) or
rahuna , (JK, [but this I think to be a mis take,]) inf. n. ruhuwnN, (K,) said of a man, and of a camel, (JK, S, * TA,) and of any beast (TA,) He was, or became, lean, or emaciated; (JK, S, K, TA;) and fatigued, tired, weary, or jaded. (JK, TA.) You say, rakiba Hat~aY rahana He rode until he became lean, or emaciated. (ISh, TA. [See raAhinN.]) -A2- As trans., see 4, first signification. ― -b2- [Hence,] as a law term, rahonN signifies The putting, or placing, an article of real property [to remain] as a pledge, or security, or making it to be such, for a debt that is obligatory or that will become obligatory. (TA.) You say, rahanahu Al$~aYo'a, and rahanahu Einodahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
rahana , (K,) inf. n. rahonN (Msb, TA) [and rahiynapN, q. v. voce rahonN]; and ↓ Arhnhu Al$~aYo'a; (S, K;) all signify the same; (S;) i. e. He deposited the thing with him (Msb, K) [as a pledge] to be in lieu of that which he had taken, or received, from him: (K:) [i. e. he pledged the thing to him, or with him:] and rahanotu AlmataAEa biAld~ayoni, inf. n. rahonN, I restricted the commodity or placed it in custody, for, or by reason of, the debt; and bAldyn ↓ Arhnthu is a dial. var. thereof, but of rare occurrence, and disallowed by those who are held in esteem: (Msb:) for, properly, they say, (Msb,) zayodFA Alv~awoba ↓ A^arohanotu signifies I gave to Zeyd the garment, or piece of cloth, in order that he should deposit it as a pledge (Msb, K *) with some one. (Msb.) 'Abd-Allah Ibn Hemmám Es-Saloolee says, (S,) or Hemmám Ibn-Murrah, (TA,)
maAlikaA ↓ najawotu wa A^arohanotuhumo
falam~aA xa$iytu A^aZaAfiyrahumo
[And when I dreaded their nails, I escaped, and gave them, or left with them, as a pledge, Málik]: thus, says Th, all relate the verse, except As, who says wa A^arohanuhumo mAlkA [i. e. leaving with them, as a pledge, Málik]: he likens this phrase to the say ing qumotu wa A^aSuk~u wajohahu; and this is a good way of explaining it; for the w is that which is a deno tative of state; the meaning being SaAk~FA wajohahu: [accord. to the former reading, in the opinion of Th,] the poet means I left Málik remaining with them; not as a pledge; because [when the leaving a thing as a pledge is meant, in his opinion,] one does not say, Al$~aYo'a ↓ A^arohanotu, but only rahanotuhu. (S, TA.) [See, however, 4.] You say also, rahanahu Eanohu, inf. n. rahonN, meaning He made him, or it, to be a pledge in lieu of him, or it: a poet, asserted by IJ to be a pagan, says,
Airohano baniyka Eanohumu A^arohano baniYo
[Make thou thy sons to be pledges in lieu of them: in that case I will make my sons to be pledges: baniY being for baniY~a]. (TA.) And rahanotuhu lisaAniY (assumed tropical:) [I made my tongue to be as though it were a pledge to him, to be restrained, or to be used, for his sake or benefit]: in this case one should not say ↓ A^arohanotuhu; (IAar, K;) though one says thus of a garment, or piece of cloth, [&c.,] as well as rahanotuhu. (TA.)

3 raAhunotu fulaAnFA EalaY ka*aA * , (S, Msb,) inf. n. muraAhanapN, (S,) or rihaAnN, (Msb,) or both, (K, and so in a copy of the S,) I laid a bet, or wager, or stake, with such a one, for such a thing, (S, Msb, K, *) mostly (TA) said in relation to horses running a race, (JK, TA, *) to be taken by him who should outstrip, or overcome. (Msb.) ― -b2- The inf. ns. also signify (tropical:) The contending [of two persons] to outstrip [in a race] upon horses, (K, TA,) and otherwise. (TA.) Hence the prov., humaA kafarasaYo rihaAnK [explained in art. frs]. (JK.)

4 Arhn *
He made (a thing, Msb,) to continue, subsist, last, endure, remain, or remain fixed or stationary; to be, or become, permanent, can stant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established; (S, * Mgh, * Msb, K; *) and so ↓ rahana; (K;) but the former is the more ap proved: (TA:) and also he found it to be so. (Msb.) You say, Arhn lahumu AlT~aEaAma, (T, S, K, TA,) and Al$~araAba, (T, S, TA,) and AlmaAla, (TA,) (tropical:) He continued, or made permanent, to them the food, (T, S, K, TA,) and the beverage, (T, S, TA,) and the property. (TA.) [And accord. to an expla nation of A^urohinato (referring to dates), by 'Alee Ibn Hamzeh, cited in a marginal note in a copy of the S, in art. A^arohana, whb signifies He prepared food, and continued it, or made it permanent.] ― -b2- [Hence Arhnhu as used by some in another sense of rahanahu:] see 1, in six places. [That it is allowable to use it thus may be inferred from phrases here following.] ― -b3- You say, A^arohanotu maAliY I staked my property. (JK.) And A^arohanuwA bayonahumo xaTarFA They gave, of their own free will, what the party approved, whatever were its amount, to be to them a stake at a race. (TA.) And A^arohanotu bihi waladiY (S, K, *) inf. n. A_irohaAnN, (S,) (assumed tropical:) I made my children to be as a stake for him, or it. (S, K. *) And Arhnhu lilomawoti (assumed tropical:) He resigned him to death. (IAar, TA.) And Arhn Almay~ita Alqabora (tropical:) He deposited the dead body in the grave [as a pledge to be rendered up on the day of resurrection]. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Accord. to AZ, (S, TA, in one copy of the S it is A'Obeyd,) A^arohanotu fiY Als~iloEapi signifies I bought the commodity for a dear, or an excessive, price; (S, K, TA;) gave largely for it until I obtained it: (TA:) accord. to ISk, I paid in advance for the commodity; syn. A^asolafotu; (S, TA;) and in the T it is said, [and in like manner in the JK,] that Arhn fiY ka*aA wa ka*aA signifies Aslf fiyhi: (TA:) [in the K it is said that A^arohanahu signifies A^asolafahu, as though it meant he lent him a sum of money &c.:] accord. to Er-Rághib, the proper meaning [of A_irohaAnN] is one's giving a com modity before [the full payment of] the price, and so making it to be pledged for the completion of its price. (TA.) -A2- Arhnhu also signifies He, or it, weakened him: (K:) [like A^awohanahu:] and rendered him lean, or emaciated. (TA.) And Arhn A@ll~`hu quw~atahu God weakened him; syn. A^awohanahu. (JK.)

6 trAhnA *
They two laid bets, wagers, or stakes, each with the other; syn. tawaADaEaA Alr~uhuwna. (TA.) And trAhn Alqawomu The party contended together, every one of them laying a bet, wager, or stake, in order that the person outstripping should take the whole when he overcame. (Msb.)

8 Arthn minohu *
He took, or received, from him a pledge. (K.) [Or] Arthnhu He took, or received, it as a pledge: (JK, Mgh:) or Arthnhu minohu he took, or received, it from him; namely, a pledge. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Accord. to Freytag, Arthnhu bihi signifies He had him, or held him, as a pledge to him for it. And Aurotuhina He, or it, was given as a pledge. But for neither of these has he mentioned any authority.]

10 A_isotarohana [Astrhnhu He asked him, or desired him, to pledge a thing with him: and, to give a pledge.] You say, AisotarohananiY ka*aA farahanotuhu Einodahu [He asked me, or desired me, to pledge such a thing, or to
deposit such a thing as a pledge, and I pledged it with him, or deposited it with him as a pledge]. (Mgh.)

rahonN * , originally an inf. n., (Msb,) is syn. with ↓ marohuwnN; (Mgh, Msb;) i. e. (Msb) it signifies [A pledge;] a thing deposited with a person (Msb, * K) to be in lieu of a thing that has been taken, or received, from him; (K;) or a thing that is deposited as a security for a debt: and ↓ rihaAnN has a similar meaning, but is specially applied to a thing that is deposited as a bet, or wager, or stake; and is likewise originally an inf. n.: (Er-Rághib, TA:) ↓ rahiynapN, also, is syn. with rahonN [as meaning the act of giving as a pledge], like as $atiymapN is syn. with $atomN; the p being added to give intensiveness to the significa tion: then, like rahonN, it is used as syn. with marohuwnN [in the sense explained above, as will be seen in what follows in this paragraph]; (IAth, TA;) [i. e.] rahiynapN is an inf. n. like $atiymapN, applied to denote the pass. part. n. [used as a subst. pro perly so termed] like rahonN, not as an epithet; (Bd in lxxiv. 41;) [or, in other words,] rahiynapN signifies anything by reason of which a thing [such as a debt or the like] is restricted, or appro priated, to oneself; as also ↓ murotahanapN: (K: [I here follow two copies of the K, in which it is said, kul~u maA A@Hotubisa bihi $aYo'N farahiynapN wa murotahanapN: in the CK, and in the copy of the K followed in the TA, farahiynuhu wa murotahanuhu, which perverts the meaning, though ↓ rahiynN and ↓ murotahanN may be used in the same sense as rahiynapN and muzotahanapN, as will be seen in the course of this paragraph: and in the TA, in the place of A@Hotubisa, is put yHbs, meaning yuHobasu: there is, however, this difference between ↓ rahiynapN and ↓ murotahanapN; that the former properly signifies a thing deposited as a pledge; and the latter, a thing taken, or received, as a pledge:]) the pl. of rahonN is rihaAnN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ruhuwnN (Mgh, Msb, K) and ruhunN, (Mgh, K,) this last said to be a pl. of rahonN by Aboo-' Amr Ibn-El-' Alà, but disap proved by Akh, because a word of the measure faEolN has not a pl. of the measure fuEulN except in rare and anomalous instances, though he says that it may be [as it is said to be in the Msb] pl. of rihaAnN, which is pl. of rahonN, (S,) and Fr says that ruhunN is pl. of rihaAnN, but this is denied in the M, because any pl. may not be pluralized except when there is express authority for it and when the case does not admit of any other decision; (TA;) and ruhonN, also, is another pl. of rahonN, (TA,) [or rather it is a contraction of ruhunN;] and another pl. of rahonN [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] is ↓ rahiynN, (IJ, K,) like as EabiydN is of EabodN: (TA:) the pl. of ↓ rahiynapN is rahaAy^inu. (S, K.) galiqa Alr~ahonu bimaA fiyhi. [The pledge became, or has become, per manent as a possession, with what was, or is, comprised in it,] is a prov., applied to him who has fallen into a case from which he cannot hope to escape: it is said in a trad., laA yagolaqui Alr~ahonu, (Meyd,) [i. e. The pledge shall not remain, or let not the pledge remain, in the hand of its receiver when its depositer is able to release it; for] lA is here either negative or prohibitive: you say, galiqa Alr~ahonu, aor. yagolaqu, inf. n. guluwqN [or galaqN], meaning The pledge remained in the hand of the receiver when the depositor was able to release it: (Nh, cited in a copy of the “ Jámi' es-Sagheer: ”) the trad. means that the receiver of the pledge shall not have a right to it when the depositer has not released it within a certain time: for it was a custom in the Time of Ignorance for the receiver to keep possession of the pledge in this case; but El-Islám abolished it. (Meyd, * Nh.) You say also, huwa rahonN bika*aA and bk*A ↓ rahiynapN He, or it, is [a person, or thing,] pledged for such a thing: (IAth, TA:) or taken [as a pledge] for such a thing; as also ↓ rahiynN and ↓ murotahanN. (TA.) And A^anaA rahonN bika*aA and ↓ rahiynN and ↓ rahiynapN I am taken [as a pledge] for such a thing. (Mgh.) And [hence,] A^anaA laka rahonN bika*aA (JK, TA) and ↓ rahiynapN (TA) I am responsible, or a surety, to thee for such a thing. (JK, TA.) And biqayodihi ↓ rijoluhu rahiynapN [His leg, or foot, is a pledge for the safe-keeping of his shackle: for if the meaning were marohuwnapN it would be rahiynN, without p]. (TA.) And Alxaloqu Almawoti ↓ rahaAy^inu [Mankind, or all created beings, are the pledges of death]. (TA.) And huwa rahonu yadi Almaniy~api [He is the pledge of the hand of death, or of fate, or destiny]; said of one when he has sought, or courted, death. (TA.) And yadiY laka rahonN [My hand is a pledge to thee]; by which is meant responsibility, or suretiship. (TA.) And qaborK ↓ A_in~ahu larahiynu [Verily he is the pledge of a grave, which will render him up on the day of resurrection]. (TA.) It is said in the Kur lxxiv. 41, ↓ kul~u nafosK bimaA kasabato rahiynapN, meaning [Every soul is a thing] pledged with God [for what it shall have wrought; its works being regarded as a debt, for which it will be either released or held in custody to be punished everlastingly]: rhynp being an inf. n. like $atiymapN applied to denote the pass. part. n. [in a manner before mentioned] like rahonN; for if it were an epithet [i. e. used in the proper sense of a pass. part. n.] the word would be rahiynN. (Bd.) And in lii. 21 of the same, kul~u ↓ A@moriy^K bimaA kasaba rahiynN, i. e. [Every man is] pledged (marohuwnN, Bd, Jel) with God (Einoda A@ll~`hi) for what he shall have wrought; so that if he have done good, He will release him; but other wise, He will destroy [or hold in confinement and punish] him; (Bd;) or to be punished for evil, and recompensed for good. (Jel.) And it is said in a trad., biEaqiyqatihi ↓ kul~u gulaAmK rahiynapN [Every boy that is born is a pledge for his Eqyqp, i. e. for the victim that is to be sacrificed for him when his head is shaven the first time; which is com monly regarded as his ransom from the fire of Hell]: i. e., the Eqyqp is absolutely necessary for him; wherefore he is likened, when not released from it, to a pledge in the hand of the receiver: El-Khattábee says that the best explanation of it is that of Ahmad Ibn-Hambal; that if the Eqyqp be not sacrificed for the boy and he die an infant, he will not intercede for his parents. (TA.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.
huwa rihonu maAlK * , (JK, K, TA,) with kesr, (K,) and ↓ rahonuhu, (JK,) He is a manager, tender, or superintendent, of cattle, or camels &c.; or a good pastor thereof. (K, * TA.)
rihaAnN * , as a sing: see rahonN. ― -b2- It is also a pl. of the latter word. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.)
rahiynN * : see marohuwnN: and see also rahonN in six places.
rahiynapN * , and its pl. rahaAy^inu: see rahonN, in ten places.

raAhinN *
Continuing, subsisting, lasting, enduring, remaining, or remaining fixed or stationary, permanent, constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established. (S, * Mgh, Msb.) You say TaEaAmN raAhinN (S, Mgh) Food that continues, or is permanent, &c. (Mgh.) And xamorN raAhinapN Wine of which there is a con tinual, or constant, supply; uninterrupted, or unfailing. (TA.) And niEomapu A@ll~`hi raAhinapN, i. e. [The bounty of God is] continual, permanent, or constant. (TA.) And HaAlapN raAhinapN A state, or condition, continuing; remaining to the present time. (Es-Semeen, TA.) And h`*aA raAhinN laka meaning This is continual, or permanent, to thee; beloved by thee; and also as explained below. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Remaining, staying, dwelling, or abid ing, in a place. (JK.) ― -b3- Prepared. (K.) One says, h`*aA raAhinN laka meaning as explained above, and also This is prepared for thee. (TA.) ― -b4- As an epithet applied to a man, and a camel, (JK, S, TA,) and any beast, (TA,) Lean, or emaciated; (JK, S, K, TA;) accord. to ISh, in consequence of riding, or disease, or some [other] accident: (TA:) and fatigued, tired, weary, or jaded. (JK, TA.) ― -b5- And A_ibilN raAhinapN Camels that will not, or do not, pasture upon the [plants, or tress, termed] HamoD. (JK.)
raAhinapN * The navel, with what surrounds it, (JK, Az, K,) in the outer part of the belly (JK) of the horse. (JK, Az, K.)

A_irohaAnN *
A thong, or strap, that is bound upon the middle of the niyr [or yoke] that is upon the two bulls [drawing a plough]. (JK.)
A^urohuwnN * A girl, or young woman menstruating: (K:) seen by Az in the handwriting of Aboo Bekr El-Iyádee, but not seen by him on any other authority. (TA.)

marohuwnN * [Pledged; deposited as a pledge; or] restricted, or placed in custody, for, or by reason of, a debt; (S, * Msb;) originally marohuwnN biAld~ayoni [or bidayonK]; (Msb;) and ↓ rahiynN signifies the same; (S, Msb;) and the fem. of this [or rather the subst. formed from it, for when it is used as a fem. epithet, having the sense of a pass. part. n., it is without p, as remarked above, voce rahonN,] is rahiynapN. (S.) AlA^umuwru marohuwnapN biA^awoqaAtihaA is expl. by makofuwlapN [app. meaning Events are guaranteed, or pledged, for their times, to which they are limited by the decrees of God]. (TA.) See also rahonN.
murotahanN * : see rahonN, in two places.
murotahinN * One who takes, or receives, a rahon [or pledge]. (S.)
murotahanapN * : see rahonN, in two places.

1 rahaA bayona rijolayohi * , aor. yarohuw, (AO, JK, S,) inf. n. rahowN, (AO, S, K,) He parted, or made an opening between, his legs: (AO, S, K:) or he parted widely, or made a wide opening between, his legs. (JK.) Hence the saying in the Kur [xliv. 23], wa A@toruki AlbaHora rahowFA [expl. in art. trk, and below]. (S.) ― -b2- rahowN also signifies The going easily: (S, K:) one says, jaA='ati Alxayolu rahowFA [The horses, or horsemen, came pacing along easily]: and accord. to IAar, rahaA fiY Als~ayori, aor. as above, mean He was gentle in going, or pace: (S:) or, as some say, rahowN in going, or pace, is the being soft, or gentle, with continuance: (TA:) or the going along quietly: (JK:) and one says, jaA='ati AlA_ibilu rahowFA, meaning The camels came following one another. (TA.) Also The going lightly: (JK:) you say, rahato, aor. and inf. n. as above, They, [i. e. camels or the like,] or she, went lightly. (TA.) And The going vehemently. (TA.) [Thus it has two contr. significations.] ― -b3- Also The being still, quiet, motionless, calm, allayed, or assuaged. (K, TA.) You say, rahaA AlbaHoru The sea became still, or calm. (S.) And rahaA AlHar~u The heat became allayed, or assuaged. (TA.) Hence some explain wa A@toruki AlbaHora rahowFA [mentioned above] as meaning And leave thou the sea motionless, or calm: some, as meaning dry. (TA.) And you say, AifoEalo *`lika rahowFA Do thou that quietly, or calmly. (S.) And faEala *`lika sahowFA rahowFA He did that quietly, or calmly, without being hard, or difficult: (TA:) or voluntarily; without its being asked, or demanded; (K and TA in art. shw;) and without constraint. (TA in that art.) And A^aEoTayotuhu rahowFA I gave to him voluntarily; without being asked; or without con straint. (JK.) ― -b4- rahaA, (JK, TA) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. rahowN, (JK, K,) said of a bird, He spread his wings, (JK, K, TA,) without flapping them. (JK.)

3 rAhAhu * , (K,) inf. n. muraAhaApN, (TA,) He ap proached it, or drew near to it. (K, TA.) [App. a dial. var. of raAhaqahu, which is better known.] You say, raAhayotu AlAiHotilaAma I approached, or drew near to, puberty, or virility. (JK.) -A2- Also He aided him in his foolishness, or stupidity; syn. HaAmaqahu. (K, TA: in the CK jaAmaEahu.)

4 ArhY *
He found, or met with, a wide, or an ample, place. (M, K.) ― -b2- He took to wife a woman wide in the vulva. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- He continued the food to his guests by reason of liberality. (TA.) And A^arohayotu lahumu AlT~aEaAma wa Al$~araAba I continued to them the food and the beverage; (Yaakoob, S, K;) like A^arohanotu. (S.) ― -b4- He did well: they say to the shooter, or thrower, when he does ill, A^arohiho, i. e. Do thou well. (TA.) ― -b5- A^arohi EalaY nafosika Be gentle with, or to, thyself: (S, K, TA;) [in the CK Arohu; and (hence, perhaps,) thus in the printed edition of Har, p. 498; where it is said to be from rhA fY Alsyr, meaning rfq: but the right reading is A^arohi, for] one says also maA A^arohayota A_il~aA EalaY nafosika Thou wast not, or hast not been, gentle, save with, or to, thyself: (TA:) or thou didst not show, or hast not shown, mercy, save to thyself. (JK.) ― -b6- ArhY laka Al$~aYo'u The thing became, or has become, within thy power, or reach; or possible, or practicable, to thee. (TA.) ― -b7- And A^arohayotuhu laka I made it, or have made it, to be within thy power, or reach; or possible, or practicable, to thee. (TA.) ― -b8- maA A^arohayotuhu I did not leave it still, or motionless: and A^arohi *aAka Leave thou that until it become still, or motionless. (TA.) -A2- He kept continually, or constantly, to the eating of the [rahow, or species of crane called] kurukiY~. (K.)
6 taraAhayaA * , (JK, K,) inf. n. taraAhK, (JK,) They two made peace, or became reconciled, each with the other; syn. tawaAdaEaA. (JK, K, TA: in the CK twArEA.)

9 AirotahawoA *
They became commingled, confounded, or confused. (K.) -A2- Also, (K,) or ArthwA rahiy~apF, (TA,) They made rahiy~ap; i. e. they took ears of corn, and rubbed them with their hands, then bruised, or pounded, them, and poured milk thereon, and then cooked this mixture. (K, TA.)

rahowN * inf. n. of 1. (S, K, &c.) ― -b2- Also An intervening space (JK, TA) between two things, (JK,) as, for instance, between the two humps of a camel of the species termed faAlij. (TA.) ― -b3- A place where water remains and collects or stagnates: (JK, TA:) a jawobap [i. e. a depressed place, or a hollow, or an excavation, or such as is round and wide,] in the place of abode of a people, into which flows the rain-water or other fluid: (A 'Obeyd, S:) or, as also ↓ rahowapN, a depressed place (S, K) in which water collects: (S:) and, both words, an elevated place: thus they have two contr. significations: (S, K:) or ↓ rahowapN signifies an elevation like a hillock, upon a hard and elevated, or an elevated and plain, tract of ground, or upon a mountain, (JK, TA,) where hawks and eagles alight: (TA:) or a hillock inclining to softness, two or three cubits in height, but only in a soft tract of ground, and in hard, or hard and level, ground consisting of earth, mould, or clay; not upon a mountain: (TA:) [and accord. to some, it signifies a mountain itself; for] Ghatafán are called in a trad. tanobaEu maA='F ↓ rahowapN, meaning a mountain welling forth water: or it means that in them were roughness and hardness: (TA:) the pl. [accord. to the S app. of rahowN, and accord. to the TA app. of ↓ rahowapN, in each case agreeable with analogy,] is rihaA='N. * (S, TA.) ― -b4- [Also, accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the KL, A way through a market-place, at the sides of which sit the sellers: but not in my copy of the KL.] -A2- Also Wide, ample, or spacious. (TA.) ― -b2- A well (biy^orN) wide in the mouth. (TA.) ― -b3- A woman (S) wide in the vulva; (Lth, ISh, S, K;) as also ↓ rahowaY (Lth, K) and ↓ rahaA='N: (IAar, K:) [or] a woman who will not refrain from vitious conduct, or adultery, or fornication; as also ↓ rahowaY: (JK, TA:) or (TA) a woman that is not approved on the occasion of jimaAE, (JK, TA,) because of her being wide [in the vulva]. (JK.) ― -b4- A thing dispersed, or scattered. (TA.) ― -b5- And sometimes, Quick, or swift. (TA.) ― -b6- And Still, quiet, or motionless. (TA.) ― -b7- And [hence, or maTarN rahowN,] A still rain. (TA.) -A3- Also A company of men (JK, K, TA) following one another. (TA.) And gaArapN rahowN [A company of horsemen making a raid, or an inroad, or incursion,] following one another. (TA.) And one says, Aln~aAsu rahowN waAHidN maA bayona ka*aA wa ka*aA i. e. mutanaAZiruwna [app. meaning The people are disposed consecutively in one double rank, partly such and partly such, facing one another]. (TA.) -A4- Also A certain species of bird; as some say, (S,) the [species of crane called] kurokiY~: (JK, S, K, TA:) or a certain aquatic bird resembling the krkY~: (TA:) pl. rihaA='N. (JK.) -A5- And A headcovering which is next to the head, and which very soon becomes dirty. (TA.)

rahowapN *
A state of elevation: and a state of depression: thus having two contr. significations. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph, in four places.
rahowaY * : see rahowN, as applied to a woman, in two places: ― -b2- and see also mirohaApN.

rahowaAnN *
A depressed piece of land or ground. (TA.) ― -b2- And applied to A biro*awn [or horse for ordinary use and for journeying] that has an easy back in going along: a genuine Arabic word: (TA:) or rahawaAnN [thus I find it written, but it is commonly pronounced rahowaAn, or raHowaAn with H,] is a vulgar term applied to a pacing horse. (MF voce himolaAjN.)

rahaA='N * A wide place. (K.) ― -b2- A wide tract of land: (S, TA:) or what is wide of land: (M, TA:) [or] an even tract of land, seldom free from the saraAb [or mirage]: (JK, TA:) and what is even of anything. (TA.) ― -b3- See also rahowN, as applied to a woman. -A2- It is also [app. A hue, or a haze,] like dust-colour and smoke. (TA.)

rahiy~apN *
Wheat which is ground between two stones, and upon which milk is poured: (M, TA:) or ears of corn rubbed with the hands, then bruised, or pounded, and then milk is poured thereon, and it is cooked. (K.)

raAhK * A life (Eayo$N) ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, easy, pleasant, soft, or delicate; (S, K;) and quiet, or calm. (S.) Easy; as an epithet applied to a [journey such as is termed] ximos. (S.) And Anything still, or motionless; as also raA='K. (TA.) ― -b2- TaEaAmN raAhK Food that continues, or is permanent; like raAhinN: (AA, S:) and [in like manner (see raAhinN)] the fem. of each, with p, is applied to wine. (S.) [Freytag adds, “ Inde dicitur rAhY AlAbAjl Celer de equo: ” but rAhY is here a mistranscription for waAhiY: see A^abojalu.]
raAhiyapN * [the epithet raAhK converted by the affix p into a subst.,] A bee; because of its quiet manner of flying. (JK, K.)

farasN mirohaApN * , with kesr, (K, TA,) like misoHaApN [in form], (TA,) or mirohaA='N, (JK, and so in the CK, [like miroxaA='N in form, and, as most explain the latter, similar also in meaning, whence it seems that mirohaA='N is the more probably correct,]) A quick, swift, or fleet, mare: (JK, * K, TA:) pl. maraAhiY, (JK, K,) [or rather maraAhK if the sing. be mirohaApN, and maraAhiY~o if the sing. be mirohaA='N,] like masaAHiY [or rather masaAHK], (TA,) or like maraAxiY [or rather maraAxiY~o, pl. of miroxaA='N]: (JK:) but in the M, it is ↓ rahowaY, [app. meaning that the sing. is thus,] like sakoraY; and in like manner in the Tekmileh and the Jm. (TA.)

2 rw~A^ fiY AlA^amori * , (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. tarowiy^apN, (S, Mgh, K,) or tarowiyapN, (so in one of my copies of the S,) after the manner of a verb with an infirm final radical, like tazokiyapN, inf. n. of zak~aY, (TA,) and tarowiYo'N, (S, K,) agreeably with analogy; (TA;) and, accord. to IDrst, in his Expos. of the Fs, raw~aY also is allowable; but the former is the original; or, accord. to the L, the former is anomalous, like Hal~aA^otu in the phrase Hal~aA^otu Als~awiyqa; (TA;) He looked into the thing, or affair, or case; inspected it; examined it; considered it; or thought upon it; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) and thought upon it repeatedly; syn. taEaq~abahu; (M, L, K, TA;) i. e. rad~ada fiyhi fikorahu; (TA;) not hastening to reply: (S, K:) and ray~aA^a signifies the same; (K in art. ryA^;) i. q. fak~ara; (T;) or, accord. to some, it is a mispronunciation. (MF.) ― -b2- Hence, yawomu Alt~arowiyapi The eighth day of [the month] Dhu-l-Hijjeh; originally with ': its derivation from Alr~uw^oyapu is a mistake; and its derivation from Alr~iY~u requires consideration.
