(Mgh.) [See 2 in art. rwY.]

4 A^arowaA^a *
It (a place) abounded with the [kind of plant, or tree, called] raA=': (AZ, AAF, K:) or so A^arowaA^ato, said of land (A^aroD). (M.)

raA='N *
A kind of [plant, or] tree, (T, * S, M, K, &c.,) that grows in plain, or soft, land, (T, M, TA,) having a white fruit: or, as some say, a kind of dust-coloured tree, having a red fruit: (M, TA:) n. un. raA='apN: (T, S, M, K:) and dim. ↓ ruwayoy^apN: (M, TA:) AHn says that the rA='p is not taller nor broader than a sitting man: and accord. to one of the Arabs of the desert of 'Omán, it is a tree that rises on a stem, and then there branch forth [so in the M, but accord. to the TA, rise,] from it round, rough leaves: others, he adds, say that it is a small tree of the mountains, resembling an EZlmp [q. v.], having a soft white flower like cotton: (M, TA: [but in the latter, the word rendered “ soft ” is omitted:]) some say that it is a species of the kind of tree called TaloH [acacia, or mimosa, gummifera], and is the tree that grew at the cave in which were the Prophet and Aboo-Bekr: so say Suh and others: it is, they say, of the height of a man, and has white flowers, resembling cotton, with which cushions are stuffed, like feathers in lightness and softness: it is said by IHsh to be the same [tree] that is called A^um~u gayolaAn [see art. gyl]; but they have found fault with him. [for so saying]: it is not the Eu$ar [asclepias gigantea], as one author has supposed; but a tree resembling this: (MF, TA:) such is the truth: the rA=' is not the E$r: I have seen them both [says SM] in El-Yemen; and with the fruit of each of them cushions and pillows are stuffed: but the fruit of the E$r commences small; then increases to the size of the bA*njAnp [or fruit of the egg-plant, and much larger, like a bladder]; and then breaks open, disclosing what is like cotton: and the fruit of the rA=' is not thus: the E$r [he adds] is not found in Egypt; but it and the rA=' are peculiar to El- Hijáz and the neighbouring parts; [in saying this, however, he errs; for I have seen the E$r in abundance in the deserts of the upper part of the Sa'eed;] and the saddles of camels &c. are stuffed with the fruit of the rA=' in El-Hijáz. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The foam of the sea. (AHeyth, K.) -A2- And One of the letters of the alphabet. (TA.) [See the letter r.] -A3- See also art. ryA^.
raA='apN * n. un. of raA='N. (T, S, M, K.) -A2- See also raAyapN, in art. rY.

rawiyoy^apN * , or, as some say, only rawiy~apN, without '; (M;) the latter was the usual form, without '; (S, Msb;) or each; (K;) a subst. from raw~aA^a fiY; AlA^amori; (S, K;) meaning Inspection, examination, consideration, or thought; (S, * M, Msb, K; *) and repeated inspection or examination or consideration; (M, * Msb, K, * TA;) or consideration of the issues, or results, of an affair; (Msb;) without haste to reply. (S, * K, * TA.) You say, fulaAnN layosa lahu rawiy~apN [Such a one has no inspection, &c.]. (T.) It precedes what is termed EaziymapN [i. e. resolution, or determination, &c.], and follows what is termed badiyhapN [i. e. intuitive knowledge, &c.]: one has well said,
badiyhatuhu taHul~u EuraY AlmaEaAniY
A_i*aA A@nogalaqato fatakofiyhi Alr~awiy~aho
[His intuitive knowledge undoes the loops of meanings when they are fast closed, and inspection suffices him]. (Har p. 8.) [See also rawiy~apN in art. rwY.]
ruwayoy^apN * dim. of raA='N, q. v. (M, TA.)
qaSydapN raAy^y~apN * and raAwiy~apN and ray~iy~apN A qSydp of which the rawiY~a is r. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np.)

1 raAba * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yaruwbu, (T, S, &c.,) inf. n. rawobN, (Lth, T, Msb,) or ruw^uwbN, (S,) or both, (T, M, Mgh, K,) said of milk, (T, S, M, &c.,) It was, or became, thick, or coagulated: (M, A, Msb, K:) or was churned, and deprived of its butter: (M, * A, K: *) or it was, or became, fit to be churned: (T:) or thick, (S,) or having a compact pellicle upon its surface, and thick, or resembling liver so that it quivered, (Lth, T,) and fit to be churned: (Lth, T, S:) or such as had become thick; (Fr, A'Obeyd, T, S, * Mgh;) until its butter was taken forth; (Fr, A'Obeyd, T, S; *) or before and after it had been deprived of its butter. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] raAba damuhu, (T, M, A, K,) aor. as above, (T,) inf. n. rawobN, (M,) (tropical:) [His blood is about to be shed;] his death, or destruction, is at hand: (M, K:) said of one who has exposed himself to that which will cause his blood to be shed; (T;) of one who has exposed himself to slaughter: (A:) like the phrase yafuwru damuhu; (T;) or like yagoliY damuhu: his blood being likened to milk that has become thick, and fit to be churned. (A.) ― -b3- And raAba Alr~ajulu, (As, T, S, &c.,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. rawobN (S, M, K) and ruw^uwbN, (M, K,) (tropical:) The man was, or became, confused, or disturbed, (As, T, S, K,) in his affair, or case, (As, T,) or in his reason, or intellect, (S, K,) and his opinion: (As, T, S:) or confounded, or perplexed; unable to see his right course: (M, K:) and languid in spirit, by reason of satiety, or drowsiness, (M, A,) or intoxication; as also raAbato nafosuhu: (A:) or he arose (M, K, TA) from sleep (M, TA) disordered in body and mind: (M, K, TA:) or he was intoxicated with sleep: (M, K:) or he was lazy, sluggish, or slothful. (Aboo-Sa'eed, T.) ― -b4- And raAba, (Th, M, K,) inf. n. rawobN; (TA;) and ↓ rw~b, (Th, M,) inf. n. tarowiybN; (K;) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, Th, M) was, or became, fatigued, or jaded. (Th, M, K.) And maTiy~apu fulaAnK ↓ raw~abato (assumed tropical:) The riding-camel of such a one was, or became, fatigued, or jaded. (T.) ― -b5- And raAba (assumed tropical:) He, or it, was, or became, quiet, still, or motionless. (IAar, T.) ― -b6- It is said in a prov., of him who does wrong and does right, [or of him who does right and does wrong,] huwa ya$uwbu wa yaruwbu, meaning, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, (assumed tropical:) He defends his companion [at one time], and is lazy or sluggish or slothful [at another time]: or it means he defends without energy at one time, and at another time is lazy or sluggish or slothful, so that he defends not at all: or, as some say, he mixes water with the milk, and so spoils it, and he makes it good; from the saying of IAar that raAba signifies A^aSolaHa; but if it have this meaning, it is originally raA^aba, with hemz. (T. [See more in art. $wb.]) -A2- Accord. to IAar, raAba also signifies He suspected. (T. [But in this sense it seems to belong to art. ryb.]) -A3- Also He lied. (K. [But in the T, this signification is assigned to $aAba, not to raAba; app. in relation to the prov. above cited.])

2 rw~b All~abana * , (S, M, A, K,) inf. n. tarowiybN, (AZ, M,) He made the milk to be such as is termed raAy^ib; (S, M, A, K;) as also ↓ ArAbhu: (M, A, K:) or he put the milk into the skin, and turned it over, in order that it might become fit for churning, and then churned it, when it had not thickened well. (AZ, M.) -A2- See also 1, in two places.

4 ArAb All~abana * : see 2. -A2- [ArAb as an intrans.
verb app. signifies He had much milk such as is termed raAy^ib: see its part. n. muriybN, below.]
raAbN * The equal in quantity or measure or the like: so in the saying, ha*aA raAbu ka*aA [This is the equal in quantity &c. of such a thing. (K, * TA.)

rawobN * : see raAy^ibN, in two places. ― -b2- Hence, (M,) laA $awoba wa laA rawoba, (IAar, T, M,) occurring in a trad., meaning (assumed tropical:) There is, or shall be, no dishonesty, nor any mixing: (TA:) it is a saying of the Arabs, in a case of selling and buying, respecting the commodity which one sells, and means I am irresponsible to thee for its faults, or defects. (IAar, T, M.)
rawobapN * : see what next follows, in three places.

ruwbapN * The ferment of milk, (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) consisting of a sour portion, (S, TA,) which is put into milk in order that it may become such as is termed raAy^ib; (T, S, Mgh, Msb, TA;) and ↓ rawobapN signifies the same as ruwbapN in this sense, (Kr, M, A, K,) and in the other senses which follow: (M:) this is the primary signification: (TA:) or ferment of milk which contains its butter, and when its butter has been taken forth; as also ↓ raAy^ibN in both of these two senses; (T;) or in the latter state it is termed ↓ raAy^ibN: (TA:) or (so in the A and K, but in the M “ and, ”) remains of milk (M, A, K, in the second of which, as in the last, this applies also to ↓ rawobapN,) that has become such as is termed raAy^ib: (M:) or remains of milk left in the [skin or vessel called] mirowab in order that fresh milk, when poured upon it, may quickly become raAy^ib: (T:) and milk containing its butter: and also milk from which its butter has been taken forth: (Aboo-' Amr ElMutarriz, MF, TA.) It is said in a prov., $ubo $awobFA laka ruwbatuhu [Mix thou a mixture, app. of thick and fresh milk: thine shall be what will remain of it]: (S:) or laka baEoDuhu [thine shall be some of it]: (so Meyd:) it is like the saying AuHolubo HalabFA laka $aToruhu [expl. in art. $Tr]: (S, Meyd:) and is applied in inciting to aid him in whom one will find profit, or advantage. (Meyd.) ― -b2- I. q. durodiY~N [as meaning A ferment] such as is put into [the beverage called] nabiy* [to make it ferment]. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) What has collected of the seminal fluid (T, S, M, A, K) of a horse, (S, A,) or of a stallion, (M, K,) after resting from covering; (T, S, M, K;) and ↓ rawobapN in this sense is mentioned by Lh: (M:) you say, A^aEironiY ruwabapa faHolika, (T,) or farasika, (S, A,) when you ask a person to lend you a stallion, or a horse, to cover: (T, S, A:) or the collecting thereof: or the seminal fluid of the stallion in the womb of the camel: (M, K:) it is thicker than that which is termed muhaAp, and more remote in respect of the place into which it is injected. (M.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Strength of a horse to run: so in the phrase farasN baAqiY Alr~uwbapi (tropical:) [A horse whose strength to run remains]. (A.) ― -b5- (tropical:) Intellect (IAar, S, A) of a man (IAar, S) when it has attained to full vigour: (A:) [app. as being likened to the rwbp of the stallion:] so in the saying, huwa yuHad~ivuniY wa A^anaA A_i*o *aAka gulaAmN layosa liY ruwbapN (tropical:) [He would talk to me, I being then a boy, not having full intellect]. (IAar, S, A: in one of my copies of the S, and in the TA, layosato.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) The main, or most essential, part, syn. jum~aAE, of an affair: (M, K:) so in the saying, maA yaquwmu biruwbapi A^amorihi (assumed tropical:) [He does not undertake, or superintend, or attend to, the main, or most essential, part of his affair]: app. from the rwbp of the stallion. (M.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) Means of subsistence: (M, K:) (assumed tropical:) food, or sustenance: (TA:) (assumed tropical:) anything that puts a thing into a good, right, or proper state; from the same word as signifying “ a sour ferment that is put into milk to make it ferment: ” (JM:) (tropical:) a want, or thing that is needed [to put one into a good, or right, state]: (S, M, A, K:) and want as meaning poverty. (Ibn-Es-Seed, K, TA.) You say, laA yaquwmu biruwbapi A^aholihi, (S, A,) or maA yaquwmu Alx, (M, TA,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He will not, or does not, undertake, or take upon himself, or attend to,] the food, or sustenance, of his family: or (assumed tropical:) their case, and the putting them into a good, right, or proper, state: (TA:) or (tropical:) [the supplying of] what they require of him. (S, M, A, TA.) ― -b8- (tropical:) A part, or portion, or small portion, (TaAy^ifapN, S, M, or qiToEapN, K, or saAEapN, T, M, A,) of the night: (T, S, M, A, K:) [app. from the same word signifying “ remains of milk; ” as seems to be implied in the A:] so in the saying, maDato ruwbapN mina All~ayoli (tropical:) A period, or short portion, (sAEp,) of the night passed: (T, M, TA:) and baqiyato ruwbapN mina All~ayoli (tropical:) A period, or short portion, (sAEp,) of the night remained: (M, A, TA:) and hariqo Ean~aA mino ruwbapi All~ayoli, (S, A,) i. e. Aikosiro Ean~aA saAEapF minohu [app. for Aikosiro jahodanaA or the like, i. e. (tropical:) Abate thou, or allay thou, our fatigue, or the like, or relieve thou us, for a period, or short portion, of the night; mn before rwbp being redundant]. (A.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) A piece of flesh-meat: (M, K:) so in the saying, qaTaEa All~aHoma ruwbapF ruwbapF (assumed tropical:) [He cut the flesh-meat into pieces; or cut it piece by piece]. (M.) -A2- (assumed tropical:) Heaviness, sluggishness, or torpidness, (T, K,) or laxness, or confusedness of the intellect, (T,) and languor, feebleness, or faintness, (K,) from drinking much milk. (T.) -A3- Good and fertile land, abounding with plants, or herbage, (T, M, K,) and with trees: (T, M:) that kind of land in which the herbage, or pasturage, remains longest. (T.) ― -b2- Accord. to Aboo-' Amr Esh-Sheybánee, i. q. ma$aArapN, which means A saAqiyap [or channel of water for irrigation: but it has also other meanings, which see in art. $wr]. (TA.) ― -b3- The tree called nulok; (T, K, TA;) expl. by Ibn-Es-Seed as meaning the tree called zuEoruwr [q. v.]. (TA.) -A4- A kind of hooked instrument (kal~uwb) by means of which an animal that is hunted is drawn forth from its hole: (M, K:) accord. to Abu-l-'Omeythil, the miHora$ [app. meaning the same, or an instrument used for drawing forth the lizard called Dab~ from its hole]. (M.) -A5- It is also mentioned by IAar as [syn. with rubapN and A^urobapN,] meaning A knot. (T.) -A6- A piece of wood with which a wooden bowl, or other vessel, is repaired, or mended; or with which a breach, or broken place, therein is stopped up: (T, TA:) and, accord. to AZ, a patch, or piece, with which a camel's saddle (raHol) is patched, or pieced, when it is broken: (TA:) pl. ruwabN: but this is [properly, or originally, ruw^obapN,] with ': (T, TA:) so says ISk. (T.) [See art. rA^b.]
rawobaAnu * : see the next paragraph.

raAy^ibN * , applied to milk, (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) and ↓ rawobN, so applied, (Lth, T, M, K,) Thick, or coagulated: (M, Msb, K:) or churned, and deprived of its butter: (As, T, M, K:) see also ruwbapN, in two places: or thick, (S,) or having a compact pellicle upon its surface, and thick, or resembling liver so that it quivers, (Lth, T,) and fit to be churned: (Lth, T, S:) or such as has been churned, and such as has not been churned: (S:) or such as has become thick; (Fr, A 'Obeyd, T, S, Mgh;) until its butter is taken forth; (Fr, A 'Obeyd, T, S;) or before and after its butter has been taken forth; (Mgh;) like as the epithet Eu$araA='u is applied to a she-camel when pregnant and when she has brought forth. (A 'Obeyd, T, S.) A poet, cited by As, says,
wa mano laka biAlr~aAy^ibi AlxaAviri
saqaAka A^abuw maA EizK raAy^ibFA
(T, S Mgh) meaning Aboo-Má'iz gave thee to drink churned [milk], (T, S,) but how wilt thou obtain, (T,) or [rather] but who will be answerable to thee for, (S,) the unchurned (T, S) [that is thick, or] that has not had its butter taken forth from it? (S. [Or raAy^ib in the former instance may be from raAba of which the aor. is yariybu; so that it may there mean what occasioned doubt, or evil opinion: see raAy^ibN in art. ryb: and if so, this word as belonging to the present art., and applied to milk, may signify only thick, or unchurned.]) And one says, maA Einodahu $awobN wa laA ↓ rawobN, (T,) or maA EinodiY Alx, (M,) i. e. He has not, or I have not, mixed honey, nor milk such as is termed raAy^ib: (T, M:) or, as some say, honey nor milk; thus explaining the two words $wb and rwb without restriction. (M. [See also art. $wb.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] raAy^ibN applied to a man, (T, S, M, A, K,) as also ↓ rawobaAnu, (T, M, K,) and ↓ A^arowabu, (M, K,) (tropical:) Confused, disturbed, or disordered, (T, S, A,) in mind, by reason of drowsiness, or satiety, or intoxication: (A:) or confounded, or perplexed; unable to see his right course: (M, K:) and languid in spirit, by reason of satiety, or drowsiness: (M:) or who has arisen (M, K) from sleep (M) disordered in body and mind: or intoxicated with sleep: (M, K:) or raAy^ibN signifies (assumed tropical:) confused in his intellect and his opinion and his affair: (TA:) and a man (tropical:) fatigued, wearied, distressed, embarrassed, or troubled: (A:) fem. [of the first] raAy^ibapN: (Lh, M:) pl. of the first, (S, M, A, * Mgh,) accord. to As, (S,) or of the second, rawobaY: (S, A, Mgh:) you say qawomN rawobaY (tropical:) a people, or company of men, confused, disturbed, or disordered, in minds, (T, S, Mgh,) by reason of drowsiness: (Mgh:) accord. to Sb, (M,) rendered heavy, or weak, or languid, by journeying, (S, M,) and by pain, (M,) and heavy with sleep: (S:) or intoxicated by drinking [milk such as is termed] raAy^ib. (S, Mgh.) ― -b3- And raAy^ibN
also signifies (tropical:) A thing, or an affair, that is clear, or free from dubiousness or confusedness; (Th, T and TA in art. ryb;) like the milk so termed. (TA in art. ryb. See an ex. in that art.)
A^arowabu * : see the next preceding paragraph.

mirowabN *
A vessel, (T, S,) or receptacle, (A,) or skin, (M, K,) in which milk is made to be such as is termed raAy^ib. (T, S, M, A, K.) [See also muraw~abN.]

muriybN *
Having much milk such as is termed raAy^ib. (Har p. 416.)

muraw~abN * Milk that has not as yet been churned, and that is in the skin, not having had its butter taken from it. (As, T.) ― -b2- And siqaA='N muraw~abN A skin in which milk has been made such as is termed raAy^ib: (M, K:) or a skin that is wrapped up [in order that its milk may thicken more quickly by its being kept warm] until it attains the fit time for the churning. (S.) It is said in a prov., A^ahowanu maZoluwmK siqaA='N muraw~abN, (T, S, M, A,) meaning [The lightest in estimation] of what is drunk, or given to be drunk, [of milk,] before its butter comes forth from it (As, T) [is that in] a skin that is wrapped up &c., as expl. above: (S:) [or (assumed tropical:) the least to be esteemed of the wronged is he who remains quiet, or inert, like milk not yet in a state of fermentation:] AZ mentions it as applied to him who is low, abject, or contemptible; who is held to be weak: and he says that Zalamotu Als~iqaA='a means “ I gave [the milk of] the skin to be drunk before it had attained to maturity [so as to be fit for the process of churning]: ” (T:) or muraw~abN signifies not churned, but having in it its ferment; and the prov. is applied to him who is constrained to do something that is difficult, and to become in a state of abasement, or ignominy, and does not manifest any disapproval. (Meyd.)

1 raAva * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yaruwvu, (T, A, Msb,) inf. n. rawovN, (T, M, A, Msb,) said of a horse (S, Msb, K) and the like, (Msb,) [i. e.] of a solid-hoofed animal (T, M, A) of any kind, (T,) He dunged. (M, Msb. *) It is said in a prov., A^aHu$~uka wa taruwvuniY, (S,) or A^aHu$~uki wa taruwviynaniY. (TA in art. H$, in which it is explained.)

rawovN * , (T, S, M, &c.,) originally an inf. n., (Msb,) The dung (M, Msb *) of the horse (S, Msb, K) and the like, (Msb,) [i. e.] of a solidhoofed animal (T, M, A, Mgh) of any kind: (T, Mgh:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. ↓ rawovapN: (S, Msb, K:) and pl. A^arowaAvN. (S, M, A, Mgh, K.)

rawovapN * : see what next precedes. -A2- Also The end, or tip, (S, M, A, K,) of the nose, (M,) [i. e.,] of the A^aronabap [or lower portion, i. e. lobule, of the nose], (S, A, K,) where the blood that flows from the nostrils drops, or drips: (M, A:) or the fore part of the nose altogether: (M:) or the end, or tip, of the nose, in the fore part thereof. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN yaDoribu bilisaAnihi rawovapa A^anofihi, (S, TA,) meaning [Such a one strikes with his tongue] the tip of his nose, or the tip of his nose in the fore part thereof. (TA.) It is said in a trad. that the mulet for mutilating a person by depriving him of this part is a third of the whole price of blood. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The bill of the eagle: Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhalee terms the eagle's bill rawovapu A^anofihaA. (M.) ― -b3- And rawovapu Als~ayofi, occurring in a trad., is expl. as meaning (assumed tropical:) The upper part [of the kilt] of the sword, that is next to the little finger of the person grasping it. (TA.) -A3- Also The remains of the culms of wheat in the sieve, when it is sifted. (K. [Not found by SM in any other lexicon.])
maraAvN * and ↓ marowavN (M, K) The part whence the rawov (or dung) issues; (M;) the xaworaAn [i. e. the rectum, or the tuel,] of a horse. (K.)
marowavN * : see what next precedes.
muraw~avN * A man having a large nose. (A, TA.)

1 raAja * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yaruwju, (S, A, Msb,) inf. n. rawaAjN, (S, A, K,) or this is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is rawojN, (Msb,) It (a thing, S, or a commodity, Msb) had an easy, or a ready, sale; was, or became, saleable; easy, or ready, of sale; or in much demand. (S, * A, * Msb, K. *) ― -b2- And raAjati Ald~araAhimu, inf. n. rawojN, The dirhems, or money, passed, or had currency, among men, in buying and selling. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And rAj AlA^amoru, inf. n. rawojN and rawaAjN, accord. to IKoot, The thing, or affair, was, or became, quick, speedy, or expeditious: (L, Msb:) or came quickly. (MF.) ― -b4- And rAj It was, or became, present, or ready, and prepared: so in the saying, xu*o maA raAja [Take thou what is present, or ready, and prepared]. (Har p. 116.) ― -b5- See also 2. ― -b6- rAjt Alr~iyHu, (K,) or ↓ rw~jt, (Msb, [app. a mistranscription, unless ruw~ijat be meant,]) The wind was, or became, confused, (Msb, K,) not continuing from one direction, (Msb,) so that one knew not whence it came. (K.)

2 rw~j * , (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. tarowiyjN, (A, Msb, K,) He made a commodity to have an easy, or a ready, sale; to be saleable; easy, or ready, of sale; or in much demand. (S, A, K. *) ― -b2- He made money to pass, or be current. (S, * A, * Msb.) ― -b3- rw~j Al$~aYo'a, and rw~j bihi, He made the thing to be quick, speedy, or expeditious; or was quick with it. (L.) ― -b4- raw~ajotu is also syn. with A^ar~ajotu: so in the saying, ↓ raw~ajotu AlA^amora faraAja, aor. of the latter yaruwju, and inf. n. rawojN, [app. meaning I excited the affair, or event, and it became excited.] (TA.) ― -b5- rw~j kalaAmahu He embellished his speech, or language, and made it vague, so that one knew not its true meaning: (Msb, TA:) from raAjati Alr~iyHu, (TA,) or from rw~jt Alr~iyHu. (Msb.) ― -b6- For rw~jt AlryH see 1, last sentence. ― -b7- rw~j AlgubaAru EalaY raA^osi AlbaEiyri [perhaps ruw~ija] The dust continued, or went round, upon, or over, the head of the camel; syn. daAma. (TA.)

5 trw~j *
He [app. a camel] went round about the watering-trough, or tank, thirsting, and not getting to it. (K.)

rawojapN *
Haste, quickness, speed, or expedition. (IAar.)
rawaAjN * [an inf. n., (see 1,) or] a subst., meaning The state, or quality, of having an easy, or a ready, sale; of being saleable; or in much demand. (Msb.)
raw~aAjN * [app. applied to a camel] Going round about the watering-trough, or tank, thirsting, and not getting to it. (K.)

A^amorN muraw~ajN *
A confused thing or affair. (TA.)

fulaAnN muraw~ijN *
Such a one is a person who makes commodities to have an easy, or a ready, sale; to be saleable; easy, or ready, of sale; or in much demand: or who makes money to pass, or be current. (S.)

1 raAHa * , (S, Msb, K,) sec. pers. riHota, (Msb,) aor. yaraAHu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. riyHN; (K;) and aor. yaruwHu, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. rawoHN, (Msb,) or ruw^uwHN; (TA;) It (a day) was violently windy. (S, Msb, K.) And rAH, aor. yaruwHu, inf. n. ruw^uwHN, It (a day) was one of good, or pleasant, wind. (TA.) ― -b2- rAH, aor. yaraAHu, inf. n. rawoHN, It was, or became, cool and pleasant [by means of the wind]. (L.) It (a house, or tent, the door being opened,) [was, or became, aired by the wind; or] was entered by the wind. (L.) ― -b3- rAH Al$~ajaru The trees felt the wind. (AHn, K.) [See also another meaning below.] ― -b4- [Hence, perhaps,] rAH, aor. yaraAHu, inf. n. raAHN, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, or quick; [as though he felt the wind and was refreshed by it;] (L;) as also ↓ ArtAH: (S, A, L, K:) raAHN and ↓ AirotiyaAHN signify the same: (S, L, K: [in the CK, AlAirotiyAHi is erroneously put for AlAirotiyaAHu:]) and ↓ AisotarowaHa (assumed tropical:) he (a man) became light, or active, and quick; syn. $am~ara. (Msb.) You say, rAH lil$~aYo'i [and A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i] and ↓ ArtAH [and ArtAH bihi] (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, brisk, lively, &c, as above, at the thing, [or betook himself with briskness, liveliness, &c., to the thing,] and was rejoiced by it. (Lth, TA.) A poet says,
wa zaEamota A^an~aka laA taraAHu A_ilaY Aln~isaA
[(assumed tropical:) And thou assertedst that thou dost not, or wilt not, betake thyself with briskness, &c., to women, nor be rejoiced by them]. (Lth, TA.) And rAH liloA^amori i. q. ↓ ArtAH [He betook himself with briskness, &c., to the thing, or affair; or was brisk, &c., to do it]. (TA.) And rAH li*`lika AlA^amori, (L,
K,) and A_ilayohi, (L,) aor. yaraAHN, inf. n. rawaAHN and ruw^uwHN and raAHN and riyaAHapN (L, K) and raAHapN and A^aroyaHiy~apN, (L,) (assumed tropical:) He brightened in countenance at that thing, (L, [there explained by A^a$oraqa lahu, and this I regard as the right reading, rather than that which I find in the copies of the K, which is A^a$orafa lahu, perhaps meaning the same as A^a$orafa Ealayohi, i. e. he became acquainted with that thing, or knew it, syn. AiT~alaEa Ealayohi,]) and rejoiced in it, or at it, (L, K,) and was thereby affected with alacrity, cheerfulness, briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, disposing him to promptness in acts of kindness or beneficence: said of a generous man when he is asked to confer a gift; and sometimes, metaphorically, of dogs when called by their owner, and of other animals. (L.) [It is also said that] rawaAHN and rawaAHapN and raAHapN and rawoHapN and rawiyHapN [all app. inf. ns. of raAHa, or some of them may be simple substs.,] and muraAyaHapN [as though inf. n. of ↓ raAyaHa] (L, K) signify (assumed tropical:) The experiencing relief from grief or sorrow, after suffering therefrom: (L:) or the experiencing the joy, or happiness, arising from certainty. (K. [See also rawoHN, below.]) You say also, A_ilaY Hadiyvihi ↓ AisotarowaHotu [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) I was affected with cheerfulness, liveliness, or the like, at his discourse, or narration; as seems to be indicated by the context in the place where it is mentioned: or perhaps, he trusted to his discourse, and became quiet, or easy, in mind; agreeably with an explanation of the verb which see below]: (A:) or AlY Hdyvh ↓ AstrAH (assumed tropical:) he inclined to his discourse. (MA.) And rAH lilomaEoruwfi, (S, A, L, K,) sec. pers. riHota, (L,) aor. yaraAHu, inf. n. raAHapN (S, L, K) and riyHN; (L;) and lh ↓ ArtAH; (A, L;) (tropical:) He was affected with alacrity, cheerfulness, briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, disposing him to promptness to do what was kind or beneficent: (As, S, L, K:) he inclined to, and loved, kindness or beneficence. (L.) And liln~adaY ↓ ArtAH (assumed tropical:) [He was affected with alacrity, &c., and so disposed to bounty or liberality]. (S, K.) And nazalato A@ll~`hu biraHomatihi faA^anoqa*ahu minohaA ↓ bihi baliy~apN faA@rotaAHa (tropical:) [A trial, or an affliction, befell him, and God was active and prompt with his mercy, and delivered him from it]: (T:) but ISd disapproves of thus speaking of God; and El-Fárisee says that it is an instance of the rudeness of speech characteristic of Arabs of the desert. (TA.) [Hence seems to have originated, as is app. implied in the TA, the assertion that] ↓ AlAirotiyaAHu signifies (assumed tropical:) The being merciful: and A@ll~`hu lahu biraHomatihi ↓ ArtAH, (assumed tropical:) God delivered him from trial, or affliction: (K:) or A@ll~`hu lifulaAnK ↓ ArtAH (assumed tropical:) God was merciful to such a one. (S.) One also says, rAHt yaduhu lika*aA, (K,) or bika*aA, (S L,) (tropical:) His hand was active, prompt, or quick, (S, L, K, TA,) to do such a thing, (K, TA,) or with such a thing; (S, L, TA;) as, for instance, with a sword, to strike with it. (L.) Hence the saying of the Prophet, mano raAHa A_ilaY AljumuEapi fiY Als~aAEapi AlA^uwlaY fakaA^an~amaA qad~ama badanapF (tropical:) [Whosoever is brisk, or prompt, or quick, in repairing to the Friday-prayers in the first hour, he is as though he offered a camel, or a cow or bull, for sacrifice at Mekkeh]: (K, * TA:) the meaning is, xaf~a A_ilayohaA, (K, TA,) and maDaY; (TA;) not the going in the latter part of the day. (K, * TA.) [See also what follows.] ― -b5- raAHa, aor. yaruwHu, inf. n. rawaAHN; and ↓ trw~H; both signify the same; (S, Msb, K, &c.;) contr. of gadaA; (S;) said of a man, (TA,) and of a company of men, (K, TA,) He, and they, went, or journeyed, or worked, or did a thing, in the evening, (K, TA,) or in the afternoon, i. e., from the declining of the sun from the meridian until night: (IF, Msb, K, TA:) this is said to be the primary meaning: (TA:) but they also mean he, or they, returned: (Msb:) and went, or journeyed, at any time: (Msb, * TA:) [for] Alr~awaAHu is not, as some imagine it to be, only [the going, or journeying,] in the last, or latter, part of the day; but is used by the Arabs as meaning the going, or journeying, at any time of the night or day; as also Alguduw~u: so say Az and others: (Msb:) or rAH, inf. n. rawaAHN, signifies he came, or went, after the declining of the sun from the meridian: but is sometimes used as meaning he went in an absolute sense: (Mgh:) and thus it means in the trad. commencing mano raAHa A_ilaY AljumuEapi [mentioned above, where a different explanation of the verb is given]: (Mgh, * Msb:) and [in like manner] one says to his companion or companions, ↓ taraw~aHo or taraw~aHuwA as meaning Go, or journey: (TA:) but raAHati AlA_ibilu, (S, L, K,) aor. taruwHu and taraAHu, inf. n. rawaAHN (L) and raAy^iHapN, (AZ, L, K,) signifies only The camels returned in the evening, or afternoon, (S, * Msb,) when their pastors drove or brought them back to their owners: so says Az. (Msb.) You say, ruHotu A_ilayohimo and Einodahumo, inf. n. rawoHN and rawaAHN, I went, (K, TA,) and I came, (TA,) to them in the evening, or afternoon; [or at any time, as appears from what has been said above;] and so ruHotuhumo, (K, TA,) inf. n. rawoHN; (TA;) and ↓ raw~aHotuhumo, (K, TA,) inf. n. tarowiyHN; (TA;) and ↓ taraw~aHotuhumo: (K, TA:) and ↓ A^anaA A^ugaAdiyhi wa A^uraAwiHuhu [I go, or come, to him early in the morning, in the first part of the day, or between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise, and I go, or come, to him in the evening, or afternoon, app. he doing the like to me]. (A. [See also 6.]) And raAHato Ealayohi A_ibiluhu, and ganamuhu, and maAluhu, His camels, and his sheep or goats, and his cattle, returned to him after the declining of the sun from the meridian; only at that time: and ↓ ArAHt may perhaps be a dial. var. thereof: (L, TA:) or rAHt biAlEa$iY~i EalaY A^aholihaA they (i. e. camels) returned from the place of pasture in the evening, or afternoon, to their owners. (S, * Msb.) ― -b6- rAH Al$~ajaru, (S, A, K,) aor. yazaAHu; (S, A;) and ↓ trw~H; (S, A;) [said in the TA to be tropical, but not so in the A;] The trees broke forth with leaves: (S, A, K:) or the former, the trees broke forth with leaves before the winter, when the night became cold, without rain; (As, TA;) and so the latter: (L:) or the latter, the trees broke forth with leaves after the close of the Sayof [or summer]: (S, TA:) and AlguSonu ↓ trw~H The branch put forth leaves after other leaves had fallen from it. (R, TA.) [See another meaning of rAH Al$jr near the beginning of this art.] ― -b7- rAH, (S, K,) aor. yaraAHu, inf. n. raAHapN, (S,) said of a horse, [perhaps from the same verb as signifying “ he was, or became, brisk, lively, ” &c.,] He became a stallion, or fit to cover. (S, K.) -A2- raAHatohu Alr~iyHu, aor. taraAHu, The wind smote it; namely, a thing; (L, K;) as, for instance, a tree, and said of a tempestuous wind. (L.) And riyHa, said of a pool of water left by a torrent, It was smitten [or blown upon] by the wind. (S, A, K.) In like manner also it is said of other things. (TA.) One says, riyHati Al$~ajarapu The tree was blown upon by the wind: or was blown about, or shaken, by the wind, so that its leaves were made to fall: or had the dust scattered upon it by the wind. (L.) And riyHuwA They (a people, or party,) were smitten and destroyed by the wind: (K, TA:) or they entered upon [a time of] wind; (K;) as also, in this latter sense, ↓ A^araAHuwA, (S, K,) or ↓ A^arowaHuwA. (A.) ― -b2- rAH Al$~aYo'a, (A 'Obeyd, S, K,) first pers. riHotu, (A 'Obeyd, S,) aor. yaraAHu (A 'Obeyd, S, K,) and yariyHu, (AA, S, K,) [inf. n., app., of the former rawoHN and of the latter riyHN as in the phrase of similar meaning following;] and ↓ A^araAHahu, (Ks, S, K,) and ↓ A^arowaHahu; (AZ, K;) He smelt the thing; perceived its smell, or odour; (S, K, &c.;) as also ↓ AstrAHhu and ↓ AisotarowaHahu: (Ham p. 228:) and rAH Alr~iyHa, aor. yaraAHu, inf. n. rawoHN; and aor. yariyHu, inf. n. riyHN; and ↓ A^araAHahaA; He smelt the odour. (Msb.) You say of an object of the chase, ↓ A^araAHaniY, (S,) and ↓ A^arowaHaniY, (AZ, S, A,) inf. n. of the latter A_irowaAHN, (AZ, TA,) He smelt me; perceived my smell, or odour: (AZ, S, A, TA:) and of the same, ↓ ArAH, (K,) and ↓ A^arowaHa, (T, S, K,) and ↓ AisotarowaHa, and ↓ AstrAH, (T, S,) He smelt a human being; perceived his smell, or odour: (T, S, K:) and the second of these four, (K, TA,) and the third and fourth, (TA,) he smelt gently, that he might perceive the odour of a thing: (K, TA:) or the third and fourth of the same, he smelt, or perceived, odour: (A:) and these two, said of a stallion, he perceived the smell of the female: and of a beast of prey you say, Alr~iyHa ↓ A^arowaHa, and ↓ A^araAHahaA, and ↓ AstrAHhA, and ↓ AisotarowaHahaA, meaning he smelt, or perceived, the odour; and accord. to Lh, some say, raAHahaA; but this is seldom used. (TA) [It is asserted (in Har p. 324) that ↓ AstrAH is only from Alr~aAHapu; but this assertion is of no weight against the authorities cited above.] It is said in a trad., mano qatala nafosFA muEaAhidapF lamo yaraHN raAy^iHapa Aljan~api, (A 'Obeyd, S, Mgh, * Msb, *) or lm yariHo, (AA, S, Msb,) or ↓ lm yuriHo, (Ks, S, Mgh, Msb,) i. e. [He who slays a person with whom he is on terms of
peace, (or, as in' the TA, muw^ominFA, i. e. a believer,)] he will not perceive the odour of Paradise: (S, Mgh, Msb:) As says, I know not whether it be from riHotu or from A^araHotu. (S.) You say also, minohu TiybFA ↓ A^arowaHotu I perceived from him (a man, S) a sweet odour. (S, A.) ― -b3- [And hence, app.,] rAH minoka maEoruwfFA, and ↓ ArAHhu, (assumed tropical:) He obtained from thee a favour, or benefit. (K.) -A3- rawiHa, aor. yarowaHu, inf. n. rawaHN, He (a man) had the quality termed rawaHN, [explained below, i. e. width in the space between the thighs or legs; &c.; or] a spreading in the fore part of each foot. (Lth, TA.) And rawiHato qadamuhu His foot had the quality so termed. (TA.)

2 rw~H * [He fanned]. You say, rw~H Ealayohi biAlmirowaHapi [He fanned him with the fan]. (A, TA.) And AiHotaAjuwA A_ilaY Alt~arowiyHi mina AlHar~i biAlmirowaHapi [They required to be fanned, by reason of the heat, with the fan]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (A, Msb,) inf. n. tarowiyHN, (Msb,) He perfumed oil; rendered it sweet in odour, (A, Msb,) by putting perfume in it. (Msb.) ― -b3- rw~H Eanohu; and raw~iHuwA binaA: see 4. ― -b4- rw~H bihimo, (A, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (A, Msb,) He performed with them the prayers termed Alt~araAwiyH. (A, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b5- rw~H having for its objects camels, and sheeep or goats: see 4. ― -b6- raw~aHotuhumo: see ruHotu A_ilayohimo, in the latter half of the first paragraph.

3 A^anaA A^ugaAdiyhi wa A^uraAwiHuhu * : see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- AlmuraAwaHapu fiY AlEamalayoni, (S,) or bayona AlEamalayoni, (Mgh, K,) signifies The doing the two deeds, or works, alternately; this one time, and that one time: (S, Mgh, K:) as, for instance, reading, or reciting, at one time, and writing at another time: (Mgh:) and AlmrAwHp byn Alr~ijolayoni the standing upon the two legs alternately; upon each in turn: and AlmrAwHp byn Aljanobayoni the turning over [upon the two sides alternately, or] from side to side. (K.) You say, rAwH bayona Eamalayoni [He did two deeds, or works, alternately; he alternated them]. (A.) And rAwH bayona rijolayohi He stood upon one of his legs one time and upon the other another time: (S, Mgh:) it is said also of one walking [as meaning he moved his legs alternately]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., kaAna yuraAwiHu bayona qadamayohi mino Tuwli AlqiyaAmi He used to rest upon one of his feet one time and upon the other another time to give relief to each of them [in consequence of long standing]. (TA.) One says also, rAwHhu He did a thing with him by turns, each of them taking his turn [and so relieving the other: for AlmuraAwaHapu signifies the giving mutual relief, or rest]. (TA in art. Eqb.) [See also 6.] -A2- raAyaHa, inf. n. muraAyaHapN: see 1, in the former part of the paragraph.

4 ArAH *
He breathed: (S, A, K:) said of a man, (A,) and of a horse. (S.) ― -b2- [It emitted an odour:] it (a thing, Msb) stank; (S, Msb, K;) as also A^arowaHa: (Msb, TA:) the former said of flesh-meat, (S, K,) and of water; (K;) and so the latter: (TA:) or the latter, it became altered [for the worse] in odour; (Lh, S, M, A, Msb;) said of flesh-meat, (Lh, M, A, * Msb,) and of water, (Lh, S, M, A, Msb,) &c.; (S;) and so the former, said of water: (L, TA:) ISd makes a distinction between ArwH and ↓ trw~H [q. v., as does also J,] said of water. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (inf. n. A_iraAHapN, L,) He (a man, S, and a beast, Lh) revived, or his spirit returned to him, after fatigue; (Lh, S, K;) like ↓ AstrAH, q. v.: (TA:) and he had rest. (K.) ― -b4- And [hence], (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iraAHapN, (TA,) or A_irowaAHN, (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) died; (S, Msb, K;) as though he found rest: and he (a camel) died, or perished. (TA.) You say, A^araAHa faA^araAHa [He rested, i. e. had rest, and so rested others], meaning (assumed tropical:) he died, and so people became at rest from him. (A.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] A^araHonaA biAlS~alaApi We performed the act of prayer: because its performance is [a cause of] rest to the soul; the waiting for the time thereof being troublesome. (Msb.) ― -b6- A^araAHato said of camels &c. [as though meaning They returned in the evening, or afternoon, to rest]: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b7- ArAH, inf. n. A_iraAHapN and A_iraAHN, said of a man, His camels, and sheep or goats, and cattle, returned to him in the evening, or afternoon, from pasture. (L.) ― -b8- And ArAH, [app. for ArAH baEiyrahu,] like wise said of a man, He alighted from his camel to rest him and to alleviate him. (L.) ― -b9- A^araAHuwA, or A^arowaHuwA: see 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph. -A2- A^araAHahu and A^arowaHahu, and ArAH Alr~iyHa, &c.: see 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph, in twelve places. ― -b2- ArAHhu, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iraAHapN, (Msb, TA,) and ↓ raAHapN is a subst. used as an inf. n., [i. e. a quasi-inf. n.,] like TaAEapN and EaArapN used as inf. ns. of A^aTaAEahu and A^aEaArahu, (TA,) said of God, (S, K,) or of a man, (A, Msb,) He rested him, made him to be at rest or at ease, or gave him rest; (S, * A, * Msb;) namely, a hired man, (Msb,) or any man; as also Eanohu ↓ rw~H: (TA:) and the former, He (God) caused him to enter into a state of rest, (K, TA,) or of mercy. (TA.) And binaA ↓ raw~iHuwA (K in art. lv) Give ye us rest. (TK in that art.) And ArAH baEiyrahu He revived, or recovered, his camel. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] ArAH Aln~aAsa biAlS~alaApi He chanted the call to prayer, and so made the people to ease their hearts by performing the act of prayer. (L.) ― -b4- And ArAH, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iraAHapN; (M, Mgh;) accord. to one dial., haraAHa, aor. yuhariyHu; (TA;) and ↓ rw~H, (S, * A, TA,) inf. n. tarowiyHN; (S;) He (the pastor, Msb) drove back, or brought back, (S, M, Msb, K,) camels, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and sheep or goats, (M, A, * Mgh,) and cows or bulls, (A, * Mgh,) in the evening, or afternoon, (M, Msb,) after the declining of the sun from the meridian, (S,) [from their place of pasture,] to their nightly resting-place, (S, M, K,) or A_ilaY A^aholihaA [and EalaY A^aholihaA (for you say raAHato EalaY A^aholihaA) i. e. to their owners]. (Msb.) ― -b5- [Hence,] ArAH Ealayohi Haq~ahu (assumed tropical:) He restored to him his right, or due; (S, K;) as also A^arowaHa. (K.) And the saying, in a trad., of Umm-Zara, ArAH EalaY~a naEamFA variy~FA (assumed tropical:) He gave me much cattle: because she was [as though she were] a muraAH for his bounty. (L.)

5 trw~H * [He fanned himself]. (A, TA.) And trw~H bimirowaHapK [He fanned himself with a fan]. (S, Msb, K.) raA^ayotuhumo yataraw~aHuwna fiY AlD~uHaY, occurring in a trad., means I saw them requiring the being fanned with the fan (Alt~arowiyH biAlmirowaHap) by reason of the heat [in the morning after sunrise]: or it may mean returning to their tents or houses: or seeking rest. (TA.) ― -b2- trw~Ht Alr~aAy^iHapu The odour exhaled, or diffused itself. (Msb.) ― -b3- trw~H said of water, It acquired the odour of another thing by reason of its nearness thereto. (S, A, Msb, K.) See also 4. ― -b4- See also 10: ― -b5- and see 1, in five places. ― -b6- trw~H said of herbage, It became tall: (S, K:) and in like manner said of trees; as well as in well as in another sense explained in the first paragraph. (TA.) ― -b7- taray~uHN, thought by ISd to be an inf. n., of which the verb is taray~aHa: see A^aroyaHiy~apN.

6 taraAwaHaA EamalFA * (TA) and ↓ AirotawaHaAhu, (K, TA,) [like taEaAwaraAhu and AiEotawaraAhu,] They two did a deed, or work, by turns, [resting by turns,] or alternately; syn. taEaAqabaAhu. (K, TA.) And trAwHwA A^amorFA They did a thing by turns; syn. tEAwrwhu. (TA.) [Hence,] A_in~a yadayohi latataraAwaHaAni biAlmaEoruwfi (S, A *) [in the S, the context implies that the meaning is, Verily his two hands are occupied alternately in doing that which is kind, or beneficent: in the A, it is said to be tropical, and the context seems to indicate that the meaning is, (tropical:) his two hands vie, one with the other, in promptness to do that which is kind, or beneficent]. ― -b2- trAwHwA libuyuwtihimo and trAwHwA buyuwtahumo [They went in the evening, or afternoon, to their tents, or houses, app. meaning one to another's tent, or house, by turns]. (A.) [See also 3.]
8 ArtAH * , and its inf. n. AirotiyaAHN: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in ten places: ― -b2- and see also 10. -A2- AirotawaHaA EamalFA: see 6.

10 AisotarowaHa * , said of a branch, (Msb, TA,) It became shaken by the wind: (TA:) or it inclined from side to side. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 1, near the beginning of the paragraph; and see AisotarowaHotu A_ilaY Hadiyvihi, and AstrAH AlY Hdyvh, in the former part of the same paragraph. ― -b3- Also, (K,) and AstrAH, (S, A, Msb, K,) [which latter is the more common in this sense,] and ↓ ArtAH, (TA,) and sometimes ↓ ArAH, q. v., (Msb,) [and ↓ trw~H, as quasi-pass. of raw~aHa Eanohu or bihi,] said of a hired man, (Msb,) [and of any man,] He found, or experienced, rest, or ease; [was, or became, at rest, or at ease; rested;] (S, * A, * Msb, * K;) minohu [from him, or it], (A,) and bihi [by means of it]; (Msb;) from Alr~aAHapu; (S;) quasi-pass. of A^araHotuhu,
(A, Msb,) and of A^araAHahu A@ll~`hu. (S.) ― -b4- AstrwH A_ilayohi (accord. to the S and K, but in other lexicons AstrAH, TA) He trusted to, or relied upon, him, or it, and became quiet, or easy, in mind. (S, K, TA.) ― -b5- See also 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph, in seven places. -A2- AstrwH AlmaTaru Al$~ajara The rain revived the trees. (L.)

raAHN *
Windy; applied to a day: (TA:) or, so applied, violently-windy; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ raAy^iHN, which is the original form, (Msb,) or may be so: (TA:) fem. of the former with p, applied to a night (layolapN). (A, TA.) [See also ray~iHN.] One says, h`*ihi layolapN raAHapN lilomakoruwbi fiyhaA raAHapN [This is a windy night: the oppressed in mind has rest therein]. (A.) -A2- It is also syn. with AirotiyaAHN. (S, L, K. [See 1, near the beginning of the paragraph.]) ― -b2- And [hence,] Wine; (S, A, * K;) as also ↓ rayaAHN: (S, K:) so called because the drinker thereof becomes brisk, lively, or sprightly; or, accord. to IHsh, because he becomes affected with briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, disposing him to generous actions: in the L, [which mentions these two words in art. ryH,] the A in the former word is said to be substituted for Y [and hence the Y in the latter if such be the case]. (TA.) -A3- See also raAHapN, in four places.

rawoHN * , as an epithet; fem. with p: see ray~iHN, in two places. -A2- Also A gentle wind; a gentle gale; a breeze; the commencement of a wind before it becomes strong; or the breath of the wind when weak: (S, K, TA:) or the cold, or coolness, of such gentle wind. (A, TA.) ― -b2- I. q. nfs [app. nafasN i. e. Breath; like ruwHN]: said to be the primary signification: (MF:) or spirit; [like ruwHN;] syn. nafosN; as in the saying, A^aHoyaA Aln~aAsa birawoHihi [He (meaning God) hath quickened, or vivified, mankind with his spirit: or perhaps the right reading is biruwHihi]. (A.) ― -b3- See also raAHapN, with which it is syn. (S, K.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) Joy, happiness, or gladness; (AA, MF, TA;) said to be a metaphorical meaning, from the same word as syn. with nfs; (MF;) and ↓ ruwHN likewise has this meaning: (IAar, TA:) or the former, rest, or ease, from grief, or sorrow, of heart. (As, TA.) In the saying of 'Alee, fabaA$aruwA rawoHa Alyaqiyni or Alyqyn ↓ ruwHa, the phrase rwH Alyqyn is thought by ISd to mean (assumed tropical:) The joy and happiness that arise from certainty. (TA. [See art. b$r.]) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) Mercy (S, K, TA) of God; thus called as being a cause of rest, or ease; (TA;) and so ↓ riyHN; (K;) and ↓ rayoHaAnN; (L;) and ↓ ruwHN is said by Az to have this meaning in the Kur iv. 169: the pl. of the first of these three words [and of the last, and accord. to some a pl. of the second also,] is A^arowaAHN. (TA.)

ruwHN * The soul, spirit, or vital principle; syn. nafosN; (IAar, IAmb, L, Msb, TA, and S and K &c. in art. nfs; [but there is a difference between these two words, for they are not always interchangeable, as I have shown in art. nfs;]) [i. e.] maA bihi HayaApu AlA^anofusi; (K; [see also rawoHN, third sentence;]) often occurring in the Kur and the Traditions in different senses, but generally signifying [as explained above, i. e.] the vital principle; (IAth, TA;) [or the nervous fluid; or animal spirit;] a subtile vaporous substance, which is the principle of vitality and of sensation and of voluntary motion; also called the ruwH HayawaAniY~; (KT in explanation of the term nafosN;) or a subtile body, the source of which is the hollow of the corporeal heart, and which diffuses itself into all the other parts of the body by means of the pulsing veins, or arteries: (KT in explanation of the term Alr~uwHu AlHayawaAniY~u: [so too nafosN; q. v.: see also Gen. ix. 4: many of the ancients believed the soul to reside in the blood: see Aristotle, De Anim. i. 2, and Virgil's Æn. ix. 349:]) or the vital principle in man: (Fr, TA:) or the breath which a man breathes, and which pervades the whole body: [and this seems to be the original idea expressed by the word:] after its exit, he ceases to breathe; and when it has completely gone forth, his eyes remain gazing towards it until they close; called in Pers. jaAno: (AHeyth, TA:) accord. to the Sunnees, the rational soul, (Aln~afosu Aln~aATiqapu, [also termed Alr~uwHu AlA_inosaAniY~u,]) which is adapted to the faculty of making known its ideas by means of speech, and of understanding speech, and which perishes not with the perishing of the body, being a substance, not an accident; as is shown by the words in the Kur iii. 163, which refer to the rwH: (Msb:) most of the doctors of the fundamentals of religion forbid the diving into this matter, because God has abstained from making it known: (TA:) the philosophers say that it is the blood, by the exhausting of which the life ceases: (Msb:) the word is masc., (IAar, IAmb, Az, S, M, A, Msb, K, *) thus, with the Arabs, differing from nafosN, for this they make fem., (IAar, IAmb, Msb,) but the former is also fem., (S, M, A, Msb, K,) app. as meaning nafosN, (Msb,) as is said in the R; (TA;) and most hold it to be as often fem. as it is masc.: (MF:) one says xaraja ruwHuhu (IAar, Az, TA) [and also xarajato ruwHuhu, meaning His soul departed, or went forth]: the pl. is A^arowaAHN. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Also i. q. nafoxN (K) [properly A blowing with the mouth; but here] meaning wind that issues from the ruwH; (TA;) wind, or breath. (ADk, TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, respecting fire that he had struck, and upon which he bade his companion to blow, A^aHoyihaA biruwHika Give life to it, or enliven it, with thy wind [or breath]. (TA.) And one says, malaA^a Alqirobapa mino ruwHihi He filled the skin with his wind; with his breath. (ADk, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] Alr~uwHu also signifies (assumed tropical:) Inspiration, or divine revelation; (Zj, Th, K;) such as is imparted by means of an angel: thus in the Kur xvi. 2 and xl. 15: so called because it quickens from the death of infidelity, and thus is, to a man, like the ruwH which is the vital principle of his body: (T:) or (so says Zj accord. to the L, but in the K “ and ” ) the prophetic commission. (Zj, K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The Kur-án; (IAar, Zj, S, * A, * K;) whereby God's creatures are [spiritually] quickened, and guided to the right way. (TA.) So in the trad., taHaAyawoA bi*ikori A@ll~`hi wa ruwHihi (tropical:) [Revive yourselves with God's book of religion and religious laws, (or *ikor may here have some other meaning,) and his Kur-án]. (TA. [Mentioned also in the A; in a copy of which, in the place of taHaAyawoA, I find taHaAbuwA, an evident mistranscription.]) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) What God ordains and commands (K, TA) by means of his assistants and angels. (TA.) ― -b6- Also Jibreel [i. e. Gabriel]; (S, * A, * K;) called in the Kur [xxvi. 193] Alr~uwHu AlA^amiynu, and [in ii. 81] ruwHu Alqudusi or Alqudosi, as related by Az on the authority of Th. (TA.) [The last of these appellations, or generally, but incorrectly, Alr~uwHu Alqudusu, is applied by the Eastern Christians among the Arabs to The Holy Spirit; the Third Person of the Trinity.] ― -b7- And [sometimes Our Lord] Jesus. (S, * A, * K.) ― -b8- And A certain angel, (I'Ab, K,) in the Seventh Heaven, (I'Ab, TA,) whose face is like that of a man, and his body like that of the [other] angels: (I'Ab, K:) or certain creatures resembling mankind, but not men: so in the Kur lxxviii. 38: (Zj:) or the watchers over the angels who are watchers over the sons of Adam, whose faces are said to be like the faces of men, and whom the other angels see not, like as we see not the watchers nor the [other] angels. (Th.) ― -b9- See also rawoHN, in three places. -A2- Also pl. of raw^uwHN: (L:) ― -b2- and of A^arowaHu. (S &c.)

rawaHN * : see raAy^iHN, of which it is said to be a quasi-pl. n., in three places. -A2- Also Width, wideness, or ampleness. (S, K.) El-Mutanakhkhil [in the TA El-Muntakhal] El-Hudhalee says,
l`kino kabiyru bonu hinodK yawoma *`likumu
futoxu Al$~amaAy^ili fiY A^ayomaAnihimo rawaHu
(S, TA,) meaning But Kebeer Ibn-Hind, a tribe of Hudheyl, on that day, were lax in the joints of the left hands by reason of vehement pulling [of the bows], having wideness in their right hands by reason of vehement striking with the sword. (TA.) ― -b2- And [particularly] Width, or wideness, in the space between the thighs: (TA:) or width, or wideness, (S, Mgh, K,) in, (S, K,) or of, (Mgh,) [or between,] the two legs, (S, Mgh, K,) less than what is termed faHajN, (S, K,) or less than fajajN, (A, Mgh,) with wideness between the fore parts of the feet, and nearness of the heels, each to the other: (S:) or [simply] wideness between the fore parts of the feet, and nearness of the heels, each to the other: (Msb:) or a spreading in the fore part of each foot: (Lth, Mgh, Msb:) or a turning over of the foot upon its outer side: IAar says that rawaHN in the legs is less than fadaEN, and this is less than EaqalN. (TA.) -A3- h`*aA AlA^amoru bayonanaA rawaHN means This is a thing, or an affair, which we do by turns; as also EawarN. (TA.)

riyHN * originally riwoHN, the w being changed into Y because of the preceding kesreh, (T, S, Msb,) as is shown by its dim. mentioned below; (T, Msb;) Sb held it to be of the measure fiEolN; and
Abu-l-Hasan, fiEolN and fuEolN; [if the latter, originally ruyoHN;] (TA;) [Wind; i. e.] the air that is made to obey [the will of God] and to run its course between heaven and earth: (Msb, TA:) or the breath (nasiym) of the air; and in like manner, of anything: (L, TA:) said to be thus called because it generally brings rawoH and raAHap [i. e. rest, or ease]: (IAmb, MF:) one says riyHN and ↓ riyHapN, like daArN and daArapN; (S;) [using the latter as a more special term; for] riyHapN signifies a portion of wind (TaAy^ifapN mino riyHK) [meaning a wind of short duration; or a breath, puff, blast, or gust, of wind]; (Sb, M;) but riyHN and ↓ riyHapN may be used in the same sense; i. e. the latter may be used as syn. with the former, and they are mentioned by some [as analogous] with kawokabN and kawokabapN: (Sb, L:) riyoH is of the fem. gender (IAmb, L, Msb) in most cases; (Msb;) and all the other names for wind are fem. except A_iEoSaArN, which is masc.; (IAmb, Msb;) but ryH is sometimes made masc. as meaning hawaA='N: (AZ, Msb:) [it is used by physicians as signifying flatus, flatuosity, or flatulence; as in the phrase riyHN galiyZapN a gross flatus:] the pl. [of pauc.] is A^arowaAHN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and A^aroyaAHN, (S, Msb, K,) the latter used by some, but disallowed by AHát because there is in it no kesreh to cause the w to be changed into Y, (L, Msb,) and [the pl. of mult. is] riyaAHN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) with Y because of the kesreh, (Msb,) and riyaHN; (K, but not found by SM in any other lexicon;) and the pl. pl. is A^araAwiyHu [pl. of A^arowaAHN] and A^araAyiyHu [pl. of A^aroyaAHN]: (K:) the dim. of riyHN is ↓ ruwayoHapN. (T, Msb.) riyaAHN, or another form of pl., is often used in a good sense; and the sing., in an evil sense; because the Arabs say that the clouds are not made to give rain save by diverse winds blowing together; and this distinction is observed in the Kur-án. (L.) Hence, it is related in a trad., that he [Mohammad] used to say, when wind rose, Aall~`hum~a A@joEalohaA riyaAHFA wa laA tajoEalohaA riyHFA [O God, make it to be winds, and made it not to be a wind]. (TA.) [But this distinction is not always observed.] One says, fulaAnN yamiylu maEa kul~i riyHK (tropical:) [Such a one inclines, or turns, with every wind]. (TA.) And fulaAnN kaAlr~iyHi Almurosalapi [Such a one is like the wind that is sent forth to drive the clouds, and produce rain; (see the Kur xxv. 50;)] meaning, (tropical:) quick, or prompt, to do acts of kindness, or beneficence. (A.) And rajulN saAkinu Alr~iyHi (tropical:) A man who is calm, sedate, staid, or grave. (A.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Predominance, or prevalence; and power, or force. (S, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Suleyk Ibn-Es-Sulakeh, or Taäbbata-Sharrà, or Aashà of the tribe of Fahm, (TA, and so in one of my copies of the S,)
A^atanoZuraAni qaliylFA rayova gafolatihimo
A^awo taEoduwaAni faA_in~a Alr~iyHa liloEaAdiY
(assumed tropical:) [Will ye two await, a little, the time of their inadvertence, or will ye act aggressively? for prevalence is for the aggressor]. (S.) And hence the phrase in the Kur [viii. 48], wa ta*ohaba riyHukumo (assumed tropical:) [And your predominance, or power, depart]: (S:) [or in this latter instance it has the meaning next following.] ― -b3- (tropical:) Aid against an enemy; or victory, or conquest: (K, TA:) and (tropical:) a turn of good fortune. (A, K, TA.) One says, *ahabato riyHuhumo (tropical:) Their turn of good fortune departed. (A.) And A_i*aA hab~ato riyaAHuka faA@gotanimohaA (tropical:) [When thy turns of good fortune come, avail thyself of them]. (A.) And Alr~iyHu liA=li fulaAnK (tropical:) Aid against the enemy, or victory or conquest, or the turn of good fortune, is to the family of such a one. (TA.) ― -b4- See also rawoHN. ― -b5- And see raAy^iHapN (with which it is syn.), in four places. ― -b6- Also (assumed tropical:) A good, sweet, or pleasant, thing. (K.) ― -b7- The pl. A^arowaAHN occurs in a trad. as meaning (tropical:) The jinn, or genii; because they are [supposed to be often] invisible, like the wind. (TA.)

raAHapN *
Rest, repose, or ease; contr. of taEabN; (TA;) cessation of trouble, or inconvenience, and of toil, or fatigue; (Msb;) [or freedom therefrom;] and ↓ rawoHN signifies the same as raAHapN, (S, A, K,) from AlAisotiraAHapu; (S, A;) like ↓ rawaAHN [mentioned in the first paragraph as an inf. n. in a similar sense, as are also raAHapN and ↓ rawoHapN and ↓ rawaAHapN and ↓ rawiyHapN, i. e., as meaning the experiencing relief from grief &c.]. (TA.) You say, ↓ maA lifulaAnK fiY h`*aA AlA^amori mino rawaAHK i. e. raAHapK [There is not, for such a one, in this affair, or case, or event, any rest, &c.]. (TA.) And AifoEalo ↓ *`lika fiY saraAHK wa rawaAHK (tropical:) Do thou that in a state of ease (S, A, K) and rest. (A.) ― -b2- See also 4, near the middle of the paragraph. -A2- (assumed tropical:) A wife; syn. EirosN: (K:) because one trusts to her, or relies upon her, and becomes quiet, or easy, in mind. (TA.) -A3- The hand; syn. kaf~N: (S, K:) or [rather] the palm of the hand; (Msb, MF;) for the term kaf~ includes the rAHp with the fingers: (MF:) pl. ↓ raAHN, (S, A, * Msb, K, *) [or rather this, said in the K to be syn. with raAHaAtN, is a coll. gen. n., of which raAHapN is the n. un.,] and [the pl. is] raAHaAtN. (Msb, K.) You say, dafaEuwhu ↓ biAlr~aAHi [They pushed him with the palms of the hands]. (A.) The saying of a poet,
↓ A_i*aA dalakato $amosu Aln~ahaAri biraAHi
is explained as meaning When the sun of day has set, and men, looking towards it, shield themselves from its rays with the palms of their hands: or, accord. to IAar, when the [sun of] day has become dark, by reason of the dust of battle, and it is as though it were setting, and people have found rest from its heat. (L. [See also baraAHN, in art. brH; where other readings are mentioned.]) ― -b2- [Hence, app., as seems to be indicated in the TA,] raAHapu Alkalobi (tropical:) A certain plant. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And *uw Alr~aAHapi (assumed tropical:) A sword of El-Mukhtár Ibn-Abee-' Obeyd (K, TA) Eth-Thakafee. (TA.) ― -b4- raAHapN also signifies A court, an open area, or a yard, (K, TA,) of a house. (TA.) One says, tarakotuhu A^anoqaY mina Alr~aAHapi (K, TA) i. e. I left him, or it, more clear than the court, open area, or yard, [of a house,] or than the palm of the hand; (TA;) meaning, (assumed tropical:) without anything. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And ↓ raAHN signifies also Plain and open tracts of land, producing much herbage, (ISh, K,) hard, but comprising soft places and [what are termed] jaraAviym [pl. of jurovuwmapN, q. v.], not forming any part of [the bed of] a torrent nor of a valley; (ISh;) one whereof is termed raAHapN. (ISh, K.) ― -b6- Also The plicature of a garment, or piece of cloth: (K, TA:) or the original plicature thereof: so in the saying, in a trad., respecting a new garment, or piece of cloth, AiTowihi EalaY raAHatihi [Fold thou it in the manner of its original plicature]. (TA.)

rawoHapN * : see raAHapN. ― -b2- Also A journey in the evening, or afternoon: an inf. n. of un. of raAHa: (L:) pl. rawoHaAtN. (Ham p. 521.) And The space of a journey in the afternoon, or evening. (L.) -A2- [Also, as seems to be indicated in the TA, The outer side of each of the legs of a man when bowed: see rawaHN.]
riyHapN * : see riyHN, in two places: -A2- and see also ray~iHapN.

[
riyHiY~N *
Of, or relating to, wind: flatulent; as in the phrase qawolanojN riyHiY~N flatulent colic.]

rayoHaAnN * a word respecting the formation of which there are different opinions; many saying that its medial radical letter is w, and its original form rayowaHaAnN, as may be argued from the form of its dim., mentioned below; (Msb;) others, that its original form is rawoyaHaAnN; (MF;) and others, that its medial radical letter is Y, and that it is of the same measure as $ayoTaAnN, as may be argued from the form of its pl., mentioned below; (Msb;) A certain plant, (S, K,) well known, (S,) of sweet odour; (K;) the $aAhasofaram [or $aAhisofaram, i. e. basil-royal, or common sweet basil, ocimum basilicum, the seed of which (called bizoru Alr~ayoHaAni) is used in medicine]: (Mgh: [see also HabaqN:]) or any sweet-smelling plant; (T, Mgh, Msb, K;) but when used absolutely by the vulgar, a particular plant [that mentioned above] is meant thereby: (Msb:) or the extremities thereof; (K;) i. e. the extremities of any sweet-smelling herb, when the first of its blossoms come forth upon it: (TA:) or the leaves thereof: (K:) or the leaves of seed-produce: so, accord. to Fr, in the Kur lv. 11: (S, TA:) [it is a coll. gen. n.:] the n. un. is with p; (TA;) and is applied to a bunch (TaAqapN) of rayoHaAn; and, with the article Al, (as a proper name, TA,) the Hanowap [a certain plant respecting which authors differ]: (K:) the dim. of rayoHaAnN is ruwayoHiynN: (Msb:) and the pl. is rayaAHiynu. (Mgh, Msb) rayoHaAnu AlHabaAHimi: and rayoHaAnu Al$~uyuwxi: see HabaqN. rayoHaAnu Alqubuwri is a name of The mirosiyn [or myrtle-tree]. (TA in art. mrs.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Offspring; (L, K, TA;) from the same word as signifying “ any sweet-smelling
plant; (Ham p. 713;) or from the same word in the sense next following: (L:) [a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p; whence,] riyoHaAnanaY~a [meaning (tropical:) My two descendants] occurs in a saying of Mohammad as applied to El-Hasan and El-Hoseyn. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A bounty, or gift, of God; such as the means of subsistence, &c.; syn. rizoqN: (S, L, K, TA:) said to be of the dial. of Himyer. (MF.) So in the saying, xarajotu A^abotagiY rayoHaAna A@ll~`hi (tropical:) [I went forth seeking, or seeking diligently, the bounty, &c., of God]. (AO, S, TA.) And in a verse of En-Nemir Ibn-Towlab cited voce dir~apN. (S, TA.) And in the saying, in a trad., Alwaladu mino rayoHaAni A@ll~`hi (tropical:) [Offspring are of the bounty of God]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- It is also used (S, K) in the accus. case as an inf. n. [forming an absolute complement of a verb understood], (S,) in the sense of AisotirozaAq: so in the saying, suboHaAna A@ll~`hi wa rayoHaAnahu (assumed tropical:) [I extol, or celebrate, or declare, the absolute perfection, or glory, or purity, of God, and beg his bounty, or his supply of the means of subsistence]. (S, K.) ― -b5- See also rawoHN.
rawoHaAniY~N * , with fet-h to the r, applied to a place, Good, or pleasant [app., like ray~iHN, in respect of wind or air]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

ruwHaAniY~N * , with damm to the r, (S, A, K, &c.,) and ↓ rawoHaAniY~N, with fet-h, but this latter is deemed strange by the lexicologists [as syn. with the former], (MF,) app. rel. ns., from rawHN [in the former instance], or from rawoHN meaning the “ breath of the wind when weak ” [in the latter instance], extraordinary in form, with A and n added to the usual form of the rel. n.: (TA:) Of, or relating to, the angels and the jinn or genii: (S, A, * K:) in this sense Abu-l-Khattáb asserts himself to have heard the former used: (S:) accord. to AO, it is applied by the Arabs to anything having in it a soul, or spirit, (Sb, S,) whether a human being or a beast: (Sb:) or it has this signification also: (K:) accord. to Wardán Aboo-Khálid, as related by ISh, among the angles are those who are termed ruwHaAniy~uwna, and those who are created of light; and of the former are Jibreel and Meekáeel and Isráfeel: and ISh adds that the rwHAny~wn are souls, or spirits, which have not bodies; [spiritual beings;] and that the term rwHAnY~ is not applied to anything save what is of this description, such as the angles and the jinn and the like: and this is the correct explanation; not that of Ibn-El-Mudhaffar, that it signifies that into which, a soul, or spirit, has been blown. (T, TA.)
AlHabaqu Alr~ayoHaAniY~u * : see HabaqN.

rawaAHN * : see raAHapN, in three places. ― -b2- It is also an inf. n. of raAHa, [q. v.,] signifying the contr. of guduwN. (S.) ― -b3- And it signifies also The evening; (K;) or the afternoon, from the declining of the sun from the meridian until night. (S, K.) One says, saAruwA rawaAHFA [They journeyed in the evening, or afternoon]. (TA.) And ↓ laqiytuhu raAy^iHapF I met him in the evening, or afternoon. (A.) And xarajowA birawaAHK mina AlEa$iY~i, (S, K,) and mn AlE$Y~ ↓ biriyaAHK, (so in the T, A, L, and K,) or ↓ birayaAHK, (so in the S,) and mn AlE$Y~ ↓ biA^arowaAHK, (A, K,) using a pl. form, (TA,) meaning the same, (S,) or They went forth in the beginning of the evening, (K,) or (tropical:) when there were yet some remains of the evening. (A.) And A^ataY fulaAnN wa Ealayohi mina Aln~ahaAri ↓ riyaAHN, and ↓ A^arowanHN (tropical:) [Such a one came when there were yet some remains for him of day]. (A.)
rayaAHN * : see raAHN: -A2- and see also rawaAHN.
riyaAHN * : see rawaAHN, in two places.
raw^uwHN * : see raAy^iHN.
rayuwHN * : see ray~iHN, below.
rawaAHapN * : see raAHapN.
rawiyHapN * : see raAHapN.
ruwayoHapN * dim. of riyHN, q. v. (T, Msb.)

yawomN ray~iHN *
A day of good, or pleasant, wind; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ yawomN rawoHN and ↓ rayuwHN; (TA;) or these two signify a good, or pleasant, day: (S:) and ↓ layolapN rawoHapN a good, or pleasant, night; (K;) or a night of good, or pleasant, wind; as also ray~iHapN and ↓ raAy^iHapN: (TA:) and makaAnN ray~iHN a place of good, or pleasant, wind: (S: [see also rawoHaAniY~N:]) or, accord. to Lth, (TA,) and the Kifáyet el-Mutahaffidh, (Msb,) yawomN ray~iHN signifies a violently-windy day; like yawomN raAHN [before mentioned]. (Mgh, Msb, TA.)

ray~iHapN * and ↓ riyHapN A certain plant that appears at the roots, or lower parts, of the EiDaAh, remaining from the preceding year: or what grows when affected by the cold, without rain: (K:) in the T, the former is expl. as signifying a plant that becomes green after its leaves and the upper parts of its branches have dried: (TA: [see also rabolN:]) this term is applied to the Hul~ab, the naSiY~, the ruxaAmaY, and the makonaAn. (TA in art. Hlb.)
raw~aAHN * [(assumed tropical:) Very brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, or quick]. ― -b2- See also raAy^iHN.

raw~aAHapN *
A flock of sheep or goats. (L.)

raAy^iHN * , applied to a day; and raAy^iHapN, applied to a night (layolapN): see raAHN; and ray~iHN. [In each case it probably has both of the meanings assigned under these two heads.] ― -b2- Also Going, or returning, [or journeying, or working, or doing a thing, (see its verb, 1,)] in the evening, or in the afternoon: (L:) [and going, or journeying, at any time of the night or day: (see, again, its verb:)] and in like manner, [but in an intensive sense,] ↓ raw^uwHN, of which the pl. is ruwHN; and ↓ raw~aAHN, of which the pl. is raw~aAHuwna, it having no broken pl.: (L:) ↓ rawaHN is pl., (S, K,) or [rather] a quasi-pl. n., (L,) of raAy^iHN, (S, L, K,) like as xadamN is of xaAdimN. (S, L.) qawomuka raAy^iHN [Thy people, or party, are, or is, going, &c.] is a phrase of the Arabs mentioned by Lh on the authority of Ks; but he says that it is only used thus, with a determinate noun; i. e., that one does not say qawomN raAy^iHN [though this is agreeable with analogy, as well as qawomN raAy^iHapN and qawomN raAy^iHuwna]: one says also ↓ qawomN rawaHN and ruwHN. (L, TA.) And one says A_ibilN raAy^iHapN Camels returning in the evening, or afternoon, from pasture. (Msb.) [Hence,] maA lahu saAriHapN wa laA raAy^iHapN [lit. He has not any camels, &c., that go away to pasture, nor any that return from pasture], meaning (assumed tropical:) he has not anything: (S:) and sometimes it means (assumed tropical:) he has not any people, or party. (Lh, TA in art. srH.) A^aEoTaAniY raAy^iHapK zawojFA occurs in a trad. as meaning He gave me, of every kind of cattle that returned to him from pasture, a portion, or sort: and in another, maAlN raAy^iHN, as meaning (assumed tropical:) [Property, or cattle,] of which the profit and recompense return to one: or in each, as some relate it, the word is with b [i. e. raAbiHap and raAbiH]. (TA.) ↓ TayorN rawaHN means Birds in a state of dispersion: or returning in the evening, or afternoon, (S, K,) to their places, (S,) or to their nests: (K:) or, accord. to the T, rawaHN in this case is for rawaHapN, [a pl. of raAy^iHN,] like kafarapN and fajarapN, [pls. of kaAfirN and faAjirN,] and means, in this instance, in a state of dispersion. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, [used as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] A wild bull: so in the saying of El-' Ajjáj,
EaAlayotu A^anosaAEiY wa juiloba Alkuwri
EalaY saraApi raAy^iHK mamoTuwri
i. e. [I put my plaited thongs, and the curved pieces of wood, or the cover, of the camel's saddle, upon the back of (a camel like)] a wild bull rained upon; for when he is rained upon, he runs vehemently: (S, TA:) but the reading commonly known is,
balo xilotu A^aEolaAqiY wa juiloba kuwri
[Nay, or nay rather, I fancied my bags for travelling-provisions &c. that were hung upon my camel, and the curved pieces of wood of my camel's saddle]. (IB, TA in art. jlb. [AElAqY is there explained as meaning “ my things that I held in high estimation: ” but the rendering that I have given I consider preferable.])

raAy^iHapN * [fem. of raAy^iHN, used as a subst.,] and ↓ riyHN both signify the same; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) i. e. An accidental property or quality that is perceived by the sense of smelling; [or rather an exhalation that is so perceived; meaning odour, scent, or smell;] (Mgh, Msb;) syn. nasiymN; whether sweet or stinking: (K:) and the former, a sweet odour which one perceives in the nasiym [or breath of the wind]: (L:) ↓ the latter is fem. [like the former]: (Msb:) the pl. of the former is rawaAy^iHu; and El-Hulwánee mentions A^araAyiyHu as pl. of A^aroyaAHN [which is pl. of ↓ riyHN, under which see its other
pls.]. (Mgh.) You say, Al$~aYo'i ↓ wajadotu riyHa and raAy^iHatahu in the same sense [i. e. I perceived the odour of the thing]. (S.) And lih`*ihi Albaqolapi raAy^iHapN Tay~ibapN [This herb, or leguminous plant, has a sweet odour]. (L.) ― -b2- It is said in the K, that maA fiY wajohihi raAy^iHapN means (tropical:) There is not in his face any blood: but [SM says that] this requires consideration; for, accord. to A'Obeyd, one says, A^ataAnaA fulaAnN wa maA fiY wajohihi raAy^iHapu damK mino Alfaraqi (tropical:) [Such a one came to us not having in his face any tinge of blood by reason of fright, or fear]: and accord. to the A [and the Mgh], one says of a person who has come in fright, or fear, A^ataAnaA wa maA fiY rajohihi raAy^iHapu damK: (TA:) [accord. to Mtr, however,] one sometimes says, wa maA fiY wajohihi raAy^iHapN, without adding dm; and an instance of this occurs in a trad. of Aboo-Jahl. (Mgh.) ― -b3- raAy^iHapN also signifies A rain of the evening or afternoon: (Lh, K:) or, as Lh says on one occasion, [simply] rain: (TA:) pl. rawaAy^iHu. (Lh, K.) ― -b4- [And] A cloud (saHaAbapN) that comes in the evening or afternoon. (Har p. 667.) ― -b5- See also rawaAHN.

A^arowaAHu * [More, and most, conducive to rest or ease]. (K in art. mxr.) -A2- Also Having the quality termed rawaHN [q. v.] (Lth, A, Mgh, Msb, K) in the thighs, (TA,) or in the legs, (S, A, * Mgh, * K,) and feet, (S,) or in the feet: (Lth, Mgh, Msb:) fem. rawoHaA='u: (S, Msb:) and pl. ruwHN. (S.) Such was 'Omar; (K, TA;) appearing as though he were riding when others were walking: (TA:) and such is every ostrich. (S, TA.) You say also qadamN rawoHaA='u, meaning A foot spreading in its fore part: (Lth, Mgh, TA:) or turning over upon its outer side. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ A^aroyaHu, (K,) or the latter only is correct in this case, (TA,) Wide; applied to a maHomil [q. v.]: (K, TA:) and so the latter applied to anything: (Lth, TA:) so too the former applied to a [bowl such as is termed] qadaH: and the same also signifies shallow; applied to a vessel: (TA:) and so rawoHaA='u; applied to a [bowl such as is termed] qaSoEap. (S, A, K.)
A^aroyaHu * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A^aroyaHiY~N * (tropical:) Large, or liberal, in disposition; (S, K, TA;) characterized by alacrity, cheerfulness, briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, disposing him to promptness in acts of liberality, kindness, or beneficence: (S, * A, L, K: *) the former Y is said by AAF to be substituted for w: (TA. Mentioned in the L in the present art. and in art. ryH.) The Arabs have many epithets like this, [as A^ajowaliY~N and A^aHowa*iY~N and A^aHowaziY~N and A^alomaEiY~N,] of the meansure A^afoEaliY~N, as though they were rel. ns. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also an epithet applied to a sword, meaning (assumed tropical:) That shakes, (TA, and Ham p. 358,) as though brisk, or prompt, to strike: (Ham:) or meaning of Aryah, a town of Syria, (TA and Ham, [in the latter of which the phrase suyuwfa A^aroyaHa is cited in confirmation from a poem of Sakhr el-Ghei,]) or a tribe of El-Yemen. (TA.)

A^aroyaHiy~apN * (tropical:) Largeness, or liberality, of disposition; (S, K, TA;) alacrity, cheerfulness, briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, disposing one to promptness in acts of liberality, kindness, or beneficence: (S, * A, L, K: *) the former Y is said by AAF to be substituted for w: (TA:) ↓ taray~uHN, accord. to Lh, signifies the same, and ISd thinks it to be an inf. n., of which the verb is taray~aHa. (L: in which these two ns. are mentioned in the present art. and in art. ryH. [See also raAHN: and see 1.]) You say, A^axa*atohu AlA^aroyaHiy~apu, (S, L, K,) or A^aroyaHiy~apN A_ilaY Aln~adaY, (A,) i. e. (tropical:) Alacrity, cheerfulness, &c., disposing him to promptness in acts of liberality, affected him. (S, A, L, K.) [See also 1, near the begin ning, where it is mentioned as an inf. n.]
A^arowaAHN * [pl. of rawoHN, and of ruwHN, and of riyHN]. ― -b2-
xarajuwA biA^arowaAHK mina AlEa$iY~i * : and A^ataY fulaAnN wa Ealayohi mino Aln~ahaAri A^arowaAHN: see rawaAHN.

tarowiyHapN *
A single rest: pl. taraAwiyHu. (Mgh, * Msb, * TA.) ― -b2- Hence, the tarowiyHap of the month of Ramadán, (K, TA,) or SalaApu Alt~araAwiyHi [A form of prayer performed at some period of the night in the month of Ramadán, after the ordinary prayer of nightfall, consisting of twenty, or more, rek'ahs, according to different persuasions]; (Mgh, * Msb, TA;) so called because the per former rests after each trwyHp, which consists of four rek'ahs; (Mgh, * Msb, K, * TA;) or because they used to rest between every two [pairs of] salutations. (TA.) [See De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., i. 167-8.] You say, Sal~ayotu bihimu Alt~araAwiyHa [I performed with them the prayer of the trAwyH]. (A, * Mgh, Msb.)

maraAHN * a n. of place from 1: (Msb:) A place from which people go, or to which they return, in the evening or afternoon [or at any time: see 1]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] maA taraka fulaAnN mino A^abiyhi magodFY wa laA maraAHFA, (S, and K in art. g*w,) and ↓ magodaApF wa laA maraAHpF, (K in that art.,) (assumed tropical:) Such a one resembled his father [without exception,] in all his states, conditions, or circumstances. (S, K. *) See also what next follows.

muraAHN * a n. of place from 4; (Msb;) meaning The place to which camels, and sheep or goats, and cows or bulls, are driven, or brought, back [from their place of pasture] in the evening, or afternoon; (Mgh;) the nightly resting-place or resort (S, Msb, K) of cattle, (Msb,) or of camels, (S, K,) and sheep or goats [&c.]. (S.) ↓ maraAHN, with fet-h, in this sense, is wrong. (Mgh, Msb.)

maruwHN * and ↓ mariyHN, applied to a pool of water left by a torrent, (S,) and to a place, &c., (TA,) and the former, (A,) or the latter, (S,) to a branch, (S, A,) Smitten [or blown upon] by the wind: (S:) and maruwHapN and ↓ mariyHapN, the latter originally maroyuwHapN, applied to a tree ($ajarapN), blown upon by the wind: or blown about, or shaken, by the wind, so that its leaves have been made to fall: or having the dust scattered upon it by the wind. (L.)
mirowaHN * : see mirowaHapN.
mariyHN * , and its fem., with p: see maruwHu.
maraAHapN * : see maraAHN.

marowaHapN *
A place in which, or through which, the winds blow, (S, *, K, TA,) and in which they efface the traces of dwellings: (TA:) and [hence,] a desert, or waterless desert: (S, K:) pl. maraAwiyHu [for maraAwiHu]. (S.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce tadal~aY, in art. dlw.]
mirowaHapN * (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ mirowaHN (Lh, K) A fan; a thing, or an instrument, with which one fans himself (yutaraw~aHu): (S, A, Msb, K:) pl. maraAwiHu. (S.)

muraw~aHN *
Perfumed; applied to oil; (S, A;) and to A_ivomid [q. v.], (A'Obeyd, S,) which latter is per fumed with musk. (A'Obeyd.)

naAqapN muraAwiHN *
A she-camel that lies down behind the other camels. (IAar, Az.)

AlmurotaAHu *
The fifth of the horses that run in a race; (K, TA;) the number of which is ten. (TA.)
miroyaAHN * , applied to food, That occasions much flatulence in the belly. (A, TA.)

musotaraAHN * a n. of place: and as such meaning (assumed tropical:) The grave [as being a place of rest or ease]. (Ham p. 228.) [And as such] (assumed tropical:) A privy; syn. maxorajN. (S.) ― -b2- Also, accord. to rule, a n. of time [i. e. A time of rest or ease]. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b3- And a pass. part. n. of 10. (Id. ibid.) [As such] meaning (assumed tropical:) Dead [for musotaraAHN minohu]; as also ↓ musotaryiHN [lit. at rest or ease]. (Id. p. 251.) ― -b4- And it may also be used as an inf. n. of 10. (Ham p. 228.)
musotariyHN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 raAda * , aor. yaruwdu, (T, S, A,) inf. n. rawadaAnN (A, TA) and rawodN, (K, TA,) He, or it, (a thing, S,) came and went; (T, S, A, K;) [went to and fro;] was restless, or unsettled. (T, TA.) One says, maA liY A^araAka taruwdu muno*u Alyawomi [What aileth me that I see thee coming and going, or going to and fro, during this day?]. (A, TA.) And raAdato, (S, M, A, K,) aor. taruwdu, (S, A,) inf. n. rawadaAnN (S, M, K) and rawodN and ruw^uwdN, (M,) She (a woman) went about to and from the tents, or houses, of her female neighbours. (S, M, A, K.) And rAdt AlA_ibilu, aor. taruwdu, (AHn, M,) inf. n. riyaAdN (AHn, S, M, K) [and app. rawadaAnN &c. as above], The camels went to and fro in the place of pasture. (AHn, S, M, K.) And rAd Aln~aEamu fiY AlmaroEiY, inf. n. ryaAdN, The cattle went to and fro in the place of pasture. (A.) And rAdt Ald~awaAb~u, inf. n. rawodN and rawadaAnN [and app. riyaAdN also]; and ↓ AstrAdt; The beasts pastured [going to and fro]. (M.) And rAdt Alr~KyHu, (T, M,) aor. taruwdu, (TA,) inf. n.
rawadaAnN (T, TA) and rawodN and ruw^uwd, (TA,) The wind became in motion, or in a state of commotion: (T, TA:) or veered about. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rAd wisaAduhu [lit.
