His pillow moved to and fro; meaning] (tropical:) he was, or became, restless, (S, A,) by reason of disease or anxiety: (A:) [or he was, or became, sleepless: for] a poet uses the phrase raA*a wisaAduhaA as expressive of an imprecation, mean ing (assumed tropical:) May she be sleepless, so that her pillow may not remain still. (TA.) [And rAd xurotu Alqawomi and rAdt A^axoraAtuhumo: see xurotN.] -A2- rAd, aor. yaruwdu, (Msb,) inf. n. riyaAdN (Msb, K) and rawodN; (K;) and ↓ ArtAd, (Msb,) inf. n. AirotiyaAdN; (K;) and ↓ AstrAd; (TA;) He sought, sought after, or desired; or he sought, or desired, to find and take, or to get; (Msb, K;) a thing. (Msb.) [It seems to imply the going to and fro in seeking.] You say, rAd AlkalaA^a, (S, A, Mgh, L,) and AlmaA='a, (Mgh,) aor. yaruwdu, (S, A, Mgh, L,) inf. n. riyaAdN and rawodN: (S, L;) and ↓ ArtAdhu; (S, A, Mgh, L;) [and ↓ Astrdhu, as appears from what follows;] and simply rAd; (L;) He sought after herbage, (S, Mgh, L,) and water. (Mgh.) And rAd A^aholahu kalaA^F, and manozilFA, (M, L,) and rAd lahumo kalaA^F, and manozilFA, inf. n. rawodN (T, M, L) and riyaAdN; (M;) and ↓ ArdtAd; (T, M, L;) and ↓ AstrAd; (M, L;) He looked for, (T,) and sought after, herbage, and a place in which to alight, (T, M, L,) and chose the best [that he could find], (T,) for his family. (T, M, L.) And AlT~ayoru ↓ tasotariydu The birds seek after their sustenance, going to and fro in search of it. (A.) [Hence,] libawolihi ↓ ArtAd He sought a soft place, (S, Mgh, L,) or a sloping place, (S, L,) for his urine. when he desired to void it, (S, Mgh, L,) lest it should return towards him, or sprinkle back upon him: (L:) from a trad. (S, L.) ― -b2- rAd Ald~aAra, aor. as above, He questioned, or interrogated, [respecting a person beloved,] the house, or abode. (M.) ― -b3- rudotu Ald~awaAb~a I pastured the beasts; as also ↓ A^aradotuhaA. (M.)

3 rAwdhu *
He endeavoured to turn him [to, or from, a thing]; as in the phrase rAwdhu EalaY AlA_isolaAmi He endeavoured to turn him, or convert him, to El-Islám; occurring in a trad., in which the agent of the verb is Mohammad, and the object is his uncle Aboo-Tálib;. syn. raAjaEahu and raAd~ahu: (L:) or raAwadotuhu EalaY ka*aA, (S,) or EalaY AlA^amori, (Msb,) inf. n. muraAwadapN and riwaAdN, (S, Msb, K,) [primarily] signifies I desired, (S, Msb, K, *) or sought, (Msb,) of him that he should do such a thing, or the thing; (S, * Msb;) AlmuraAwadapu implying contention (AlmuxaASamap), because he who desires, or seeks, affects gentle, or bland, behaviour, like him who deceives, or beguiles, and, like him, strives, or labours, to attain his object: (Msb:) and [hence,] rAwdhu Eani AlA^amori, and Ealayohi, He endeavoured to turn him by blandishment, or by deceitful arts, or to entice him to turn, from the thing, and to it; syn. daAraAhu, (M, L,) or raAdaAhu. (TT, as from the M.) sanuraAwidu Eanohu A^abaAhu, in the Kur xii. 61, means [We will endeavour to turn his father from him, by blandishment, or artifice, and to make him yield him to us: or] we will strive, or labour, to obtain him of his father. (Bd, Jel.) And raAwadatohu Eano nafosihi [in the Kur xii. 23] (assumed tropical:) She desired, or sought, of him, copulation, or his lying with her, using blandishment, or artifice, for that purpose; she tempted him to lie with her: (T, and Bd in xii. 23:) [more literally, she endeavoured to turn him, or entice him, by blandishment, or deceitful arts, from his disdain, or disdainful incompliance, and to make him yield himself to her:] and raAwadahaA Eano nafosihaA (assumed tropical:) he desired, or sought, of her, copulation, &c. (T.) And raAwadahu Eano nafosihi (tropical:) He endeavoured to deceive him, or beguile him, and to turn him [from his disdain, or purpose, or will,] by blandishment, or artifice. (A.)

4 A^arowada * , (S, A, K,) inf. n. A_irowaAdN and murowadN and [quasi-inf. n.] ↓ marowadN (S, K) and ↓ ruwayodN (TA as from the K [but omitted in my MS. copy of the K and in the CK]) and ↓ ruwayodaA='u and ↓ ruwayodiyapN or ↓ ruwayodiy~apN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) He acted, or proceeded, gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner, (S, A, K, TA,) in going, or pace. (S, A, TA.) -A2- A^arowadahu, (S,) inf. n. A_irowaAdN, (M,) He acted gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner, towards, or with, him; or granted him a delay, or respite; let him alone, or left him, for a while; syn. A^amohalahu. (S, M. *) ― -b2- A^aradotu Ald~awaAb~a: see 1, last sentence. -A3- A^araAdahu, (M, L, Msb,) inf. n. A_iraAdapN, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) originally with w, [i. e. A^arowadahu,] because you say raAwadahu (S, L) in a similar sense, (L,) He willed, wished, or desired, it: (S, * M, L, K: *) he loved, or liked, it; and cared for, or minded, it; or was rendered thoughtful, careful, or anxious, by it: (M, L:) or he desired it; sought it, or sought after it; (Talabahu;) and chose it: (Msb:) [or] it differs from Talabahu, inasmuch as A_iraAdapN is sometimes merely conceived in the mind, not apparent; whereas TalabN is never other wise than apparent, either by act or by word: (Aboo-'Obeyd El-Bekree, TA:) Th says that it sometimes denotes loving, or liking, and some times it does not [as will be shown by what follows]: and Lh mentions the saying harodtu Al$~aYo'a, aor. A^uhariyduhu, inf. n. hiraAdapN, with h substi tuted for ' [as in haraqotu for A^araqotu, &c.]. (M.) You say, A^aradotu minohu ka*aA [I desired, of him, such a thing]. (A.) And maA A^aradotu A_il~aA maA faEalota [I desired not aught save what thou didst, or hast done]. (A.) [And ArAd bihi ka*aA He desired to do to him, or he intended him, such a thing; whether good or evil: see Kur xxxiii. 17, &c.] And Kutheiyir says,
A^uriydu liA^anosaY *ikorahaA fakaA^an~amaA
tumav~alu liY layolaY bikul~i sabiyli
[I desire to forget the remembrance of her, or the mention of her; but it seems as though Leylà were imaged to me in every road]; meaning A^uriydu A^ano A^anosaY. (M.) [And ISd says,] I think that Sb has mentioned the phrase A^araAdaniY bih`*aAlika, i. e. He intended, or meant, me by that. (M.) [ArAd often signifies He intended, or meant, such a thing by a saying or an action.] fawajadaA fiyhaA jidaArFA yuriydu A^ano yanoqaD~a, in the Kur xviii. 78, means (tropical:) [And they found therein a wall] that was near, or about, to fall down, (Bd, Jel,) or that was ready to fall down; though AlA_iraAdap is only from an animate being, and not properly predicable of a wall: and there are many similar instances; as the saying of a poet,
yuriydu Alr~umoHu Sadora A^abiY baraA='K
wa yaEodilu Eano rimaA='i baniY Euqayoli
[The spear is ready to pierce the breast of Aboo Barà, but it turns away from the bloods of the sons of 'Okeyl]. (M.) [In like manner also] one says, ArAd AlbukaA='a (assumed tropical:) [He was about, or ready, to weep: a phrase of frequent occurrence; like tahay~aA^a lilobukaA='i, and ham~a biAlobukaA='i]. (TA in art. jh$, &c.) ― -b2- You say also, ArAdhu EalaY Al$~aYo'i, (M,) or ElY AlA^amori, (A, Mgh,) He endeavoured to induce him, (M,) or he incited him, or made him, (A, Mgh,) to do the thing. (M, A, Mgh.) And ArAdhu EalaY A^ano yakotuba He incited him, or made him, to write. (Mgh.) And ArAdhu A_ilaY AlkalaAmi He constrained, or necessitated, him to speak. (M, * TA.)

5 trw~d *
He trembled, or quaked, by reason of extreme softness, or tenderness, and fatness. (KL.)
8 A_irotawada see 1, in four places.
10 A_isotarowada see 1, in five places. ― -b2- AstrAd liA^amori A@ll~`hi occurs in a trad. as meaning He returned, and became gentle and submissive to the command of God. (TA.)

raAdN * : see raAy^idN, with which it is syn. (S, M, K.) raAdapN [is its fem.: and] is a pl. of raAy^idN. (L.) ― -b2- AimoraA^apN raAdapN A woman who goes about to and from the tents, or houses, of her female neighbours; (AZ, As, S, M, A, K;) as also raAdN (TA) and ↓ rawaAdN (S M) and ↓ raw^uwdN (Aboo-' Alee, M) and ↓ ruwaAdapN, like vumaAmap, and ↓ raAy^idapN. (K.) You say AimoraA^opN raA^odapN gayoru raAdapK A soft, or tender, woman; not one that roves about: in which the former rAdp may be without ', and the latter must be so. (A and TA in art. rA^d.) [See ruw^odN; where it is stated that raAdN and raAdapN and ↓ ruwdapN, as epithets applied to a girl or woman, are syn., one with another, meaning Soft, or tender, &c., like raA^odN and raA^odapN and ruw^odapN.] ― -b3- riyHN raAdapN A wind blowing violently to and fro: (TA:) [and ↓ riyHN raAy^idapN signifies the same; or wind in motion, or in a state of commotion.; or veering about: see 1.] [And] A wind blowing gently; (A;) and so ↓ rawodN and ↓ raAy^idapN (K) and ↓ rawaAdN. (TA. [See also art. ryd.])
rawodN * : see what next precedes.

ruwdN *
Gentleness; or a leisurely manner of acting or proceeding. (S, M, A, K.) [And accord. to the TT, as from the M, so ruw^odN; but this is a mistranscription, for ruw^odN: see this last, in art. rA^d.] You say, yamo$iY EalaY ruwdK He walks, or goes, gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner. (S, A,
K.) And its dim. is ↓ ruwayodN. (S, A, K. [But see what follows.]) They said ↓ ruwayodFA, meaning Gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner; (T, S, M, A, K;) with tenween: (T:) and ↓ Aimo$i ruwayodFA Walk thou, or go thou, gently, &c.: (T, A:) so accord. to the lexicologists [in general]: but accord. to Sb, it is a verbal n.: [for] they said, zayodFA ↓ ruwayoda, meaning Act thou gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner, towards, or with, Zeyd; or grant him a delay, or respite; let him alone, or leave him, for a while; syn. A^amohilohu: hence it has no dual nor pl. nor fem. form: and hence they say that it is for A_irowaAdFA, in the sense of A^arowido; as though it were an abbreviated dim., formed by the rejection of the augmentative letters: this is the opinion of Sb; for he holds it to be a substitute for A^arowido; though it has a nearer resemblance to A_irowaAdN because it is a noun: others hold it to be the dim. of ruwdN, and cite the saying [of a poet],
kaA^an~ahu mivolu mano yamo$iY EalaY ruwdi
[As though he were like him who walks, or goes, gently, &c.]: but this is a mistake; for ruwdN is not put in the place of a verb, as A_irowaAdN is. (M.) Accord. to Ibn-Keysán, ↓ ruwayod seems to have two contr. significations; for they said, ruwayoda zayodFA, meaning Leave thou Zeyd, or let him alone; and also meaning act thou gently towards, or with, Zeyd, and retain him, or withhold him. (TA.) One says also, EamorFA ↓ ruwayodaka, meaning Act thou gently, &c., towards, or with, 'Amr; syn. A^amohilohu: (T, * S, M, * K:) the k in this case being a denotative of allocution, (T, S, M,) and having no place in the desinential syntax: (S, M: *) it is added only when rwyd is used in the sense of an imperative; (T, S, K;) and to prevent confusion of him who is meant to be addressed with him who is not meant, because rwyd applies to one and to more than one and to the male and to the female; though sometimes one says rwydk to a person when one does not fear his being confounded with another, using the k as a corroborative. (T.) In this case, ↓ rwyd is an abbreviated dim. of A_irowaAd, the inf. n. of A^arowada. (S.) In like manner also one says, (K, TA,) to a male, (TA,) ↓ ruwayodakaniY [Act thou gently, &c., towards, or with, me]; and to a female, ↓ ruwayodakiniY; and ↓ ruwayodakumaAniY (K, TA) to two persons; (TA;) and ↓ ruwayodakumuwniY (K, TA) to males more than two; (TA;) and ↓ ruwayodakun~aniY (K, TA) to females more than two. (TA.) ↓ ruwayod is used in four different manners: first, as a verbal n.; as in EamorFA ↓ ruwayoda, (S, K, *) i. e. A^arowido EamorFA, (S,) meaning A^amohilohu [expl. above]: (S, K:) secondly, as an inf. n.; as in EamorKw ↓ ruwayoda [virtually meaning the same]; the former word being prefixed to the latter, governing it in the gen. case; (S, M, * K; *) like faDaroba Alr~iqaAbi, in the Kur [xlvii. 4], (S, M, *) in which the inf. n. is put for its verb; (Jel;) and like Ea*iyra AlHaY~i [expl. in art. E*r]: (M:) thirdly, as an epithet; as in ↓ saAruwA sayorFA ruwayodFA [They went, or journeyed, at a gentle, or leisurely, rate of going, or journeying]; (Sb, S, K;) and saAruwA ↓ ruwayodFA, in which sayorFA is suppressed: (T:) fourthly, as a denotative of state; as in ↓ saAra Alqawomu ruwayodFA [The people, or party, went, or journeyed, going, or journeying, gently, or leisurely]; it being here in connection with a determinate noun, and therefore a denotative of its state. (S, K.) When it is used as a threat, it is with nasb, without tenween; (Lth, T, M; *) as in the saying of a poet,
taSaAhalo biA@loEiraAqi jiyaAdunaA ↓ ruwayoda
kaA^an~aka biAlD~aH~aAki qado qaAma naAdibuho
[Act thou, or proceed thou, gently, lest our coursers neigh, one to another, in El-'Irák: it is as though thou wert with Ed-Dahhák, his summoner to battle having already risen]. (Lth, T.) Sb mentions his having heard the saying, waA@ll~`hi maA Al$~iEora ↓ lawo A^aradota Ald~araAhima laA^aEoTayotuka ruwayoda [By God, hadst thou desired the money, I had given thee: let alone the poetry: mA being here redundant]: (T, M:) like the phrase, fadaEi Al$~iEora: (M:) and similar to this is the saying, Al$~iEora yagib~a ↓ ruwayoda [explained in art. gb]. (T.)

riydN * [originally riwodN] Will, wish, or desire; (K;) and so ↓ riydapN [originally riwodapN]: (M, L:) or the former signifies a thing that one wishes, or desires, and strives to obtain: (T in art. ryd:) and the latter, love, or liking, for a thing; and solicitude respecting it: (M, L:) or the latter signifies a kind, or manner, of wishing or desiring; as in the saying, A^aradotuhu bikul~i riydapi [I wished it, or desired it, with every kind, or manner, of wishing or desiring]. (M.)
ruwdapN * : see raAdN.
riydapN * : see riydN.
rawaAdN * : see raAdN, in two places.

Alr~iyaAdu * , originally an inf. n., and *ab~u Alr~iyaAdi, The wild bull; [a species of bovine antelope;] (M;) called *b~ AlryAd because he goes to and fro, not remaining in one place; (M in art. *b;) or because he pastures going to and fro; (T and S * and M in that art.;) or because his females pasture with him, going to and fro. (T in that art.) Also, the latter, (tropical:) A man who comes and goes. (Kr, M and TA in art. *b.) And (tropical:) A man who is in the habit of visiting women. (AA, T and K in that art.)
raw^uwdN * : see raAdN.

Alr~iwanodu AlS~iyniY~u * , (K,) or Alr~iywanodu AlS~iyniY~u, (L,) [mentioned in this art. though the n should be regarded as radical, for] it is not genuine Arabic, (L,) [China-rhubarb;] a well-known medicine; (K;) a certain cool medicine, good for the liver: (L:) the physicians add an A to it, (K,) saying raAwanod: (TA:) there are four kinds thereof; the best of which is the SiyniY~; and inferior to this is the xuraAsaAniY~, which is [commonly] known by the appellation of raAwanodu Ald~awaAb~i, used by the veterinarians: it is a black [app. a mistake for red, or yellow,] wood, of compound powers, but its predominant qualities are heat and dryness. (TA.)
ruwayodN * : see 4, first sentence: and see also ruwdN throughout.
ruwaAdapN * : see raAdN.
ruwayodaA='u * and ruwayodiyapN or ruwayodiy~apN: see 4, first sentence.

raAy^idN * [act. part. n. of 1, Coming and going; moving to and fro; &c.]. [Hence,] AimoraA^apN raAy^idapN: see raAdN. And dawaAb~u rawaAy^idu [pl. of daAb~apN raAy^idapN] Beasts pasturing at pleasure: (T:) or going to and for [in the place of pasture]: or pasturing together while the rest are debarred from the pasture, or tied. (M.) And riyHN raAy^idapN: see raAdN, last two sentences. And raAy^idu AlwisaAdi [lit. Whose pillow moves to and fro; meaning] (tropical:) a man restless by reason of disease or anxiety; (A;) or uneasy on his pillow by reason of anxiety that disquiets him: (TA:) [or sleepless: see 1.] And raAy^idu AlEayoni The Euw~aAr of the eye, [i. e. the mote, or the like, that has fallen into it, or the foul, thick, white matter that collects in its inner corner, and] that moves to and fro (yaruwdu) therein. (S.) ― -b2- The handle of the hand-mill, (S, M, A, K,) which the grinder grasps (S, M, A) when he turns round the mill-stone (S, A) therewith. (A.) ― -b3- See also mirowadN. ― -b4- One who is sent (S, M, A, Mgh, L, K) before a people or party (Mgh) to seek for herbage (S, M, A, Mgh, L, K) and water (Mgh) and the places where rain has fallen; (L;) or one who looks for, and seeks, herbage, and a place in which to alight, and chooses the best thereof; (T;) and ↓ raAdN signifies the same; (S, M, K;) the latter occurring in the poetry of Hudheyl; (M;) [originally rawadN,] of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure faAEilN, (S, K,) like faraTN in the sense of faAriTN, (S,) or of the measure faAEilN deprived of its medial radical letter, or of the measure faEilN, [originally rawidN,] but if so, it is a kind of rel. n., not an act. part. n.: (M:) the pl. of the former is ruw~aAdN (M, A, L) and raAdapN. (L.) One says, Alr~aAy^idu laA yako*ibu A^aholahu, (T, Mgh,) or laA yako*ibu Alr~aAy^idu A^aholahu, (S,) [The seeker of herbage, &c., will not lie to his family,] for if he lie to them he perishes with them: (Ham p. 547:) a prov. applied to him who will not lie when he relates a thing. (M.) And hence the saying, AlHum~aY raAy^idu Almawoti (tropical:) Fever is the messenger that precedes death; like the messenger that goes before a people, or party, to seek for herbage and water. (Mgh, TA.) Hence, likewise, raAy^idN is also applied to (tropical:) One who goes before with some abominable deed or design. (TA.) And to (assumed tropical:) A seeker of science or knowledge. (L, from a trad.) [Hence also,] A^anaA raAy^idu HaAjapK and ↓ murotaAduhaA (tropical:) [I am the seeker of an object of want]: and A^unaAsN ruw~aAdu AlHaAjaAti (tropical:) [Men who are the seekers of the objects of want]. (A.) ― -b5- Also One who has no place in which to alight or abide. (T in art. ryd and TA.) -A2- [See also art. rA^d.]
raAy^idapN * a subst. that is put in the place of AirotiyaAdN [inf. n. of 8], and of A_iraAdapN [inf. n. of 4]. (T in art. ryd.)

A^arowadu *
Gentle, or quiet, and unnoticed in operation: so in the saying, Ald~ahoru A^arowadu giyarK [Time, or fortune, is gentle, or quiet, and unnoticed in operation; characterized by changing accidents]. (S, TA.) -A2- ↓ A^uroyadu [More, and most, desirous], occurring in the prov., A_ino kunoti turiydiyna faA^anaA laki A^aroyadu [If thou desire me, I am more desirous of thee], is said by Akh to be altered from A^arowadu; and thus to be like A^aHoyalu, in the phrase huwa A^aHoyalu Aln~aAsi, originally A^aHowalu. (MF.)
A^aroyadu * : see what next precedes.

maraAdN *
A place where camels go to and fro in pasturing; (S, K;) as also ↓ musotaraAdN. (K.) And maraAdu Alr~iyHi The place where the wind [blows to and fro, or] goes and comes. (S, TA.)
muraAdN * [What is willed, or wished;] desired; sought, or sought after; and chosen: (Msb:) loved, or liked. (L.) [Intended, or meant, by a saying or an action.]
marowadN * : see 4, first sentence.

mirowadN *
A certain well-known instrument, (Msb,) [resembling a bodkin, or small probe, tapering towards the end, but blunt, generally of wood or bone or ivory or silver,] with which the [black powder called] kuHol is applied to the eyes; (TA;) syn. miylN, (S, M, A, K,) and mikoHaAlN: so called [because it is passed to and fro along the edges of the eyelids,] from raAda signifying “he, or it, came and went:” (Mgh:) pl. maraAwidu. (Msb.) ― -b2- The pivot of the sheave of a pulley, if of iron. (S, K. *) ― -b3- A wooden pin, peg, or stake; syn. watidN. (M, K.) ― -b4- An iron [swivel] that turns round in the lijaAm [i. e. bit, or bit and bridle]: (S, K:) or an iron [swivel] which is attached to the rasan of the colt [or horse] and of the hawk, [i. e., to the halter, or leading-cord, of the colt or horse, and the leash of the hawk,] and which, when he turns round, turns round with him: (A:) or the mirowadaAni, also called the ↓ raAy^idaAni, are the two rings in [either of] which is the extremity of the Ei*aAr [or side-piece of the headstall of the horse]. (IDrd, in his “Book on the Saddle and Bridle.”) You say, daAra Almuhoru wa AlbaAziY fiY Almirowadi [The colt, and the hawk, went round, attached to the mrwd]. (A.) ― -b5- A joint; syn. mafoSilN. (M.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A limit, or an extent, to which one runs: so in a trad. of 'Alee, in which it is said, A_in~a libaniY A^umay~apa mirowadFA yajoruwna A_ilayohi [Verily there is a limit, or an extent, for the sons of Umeiyeh, to which they run]: from A_irowaAdN as signifying A_imohaAlN. (TA.)

[
muriydN * as meaning A candidate for admission into a religious order, during his state of probation, is a conventional post-classical term. So too as meaning A devotee, whose sole endeavour is to comply with the will of God.]
murotAdu HaAjapK * : see raAy^idN.

musotaraAdN * : see maraAdN. -A2- [Also pass. part. n. of 10.] The sayings fulaAnN musotaraAdN limivolihi and fulaAnapu musotaraAdapN limivolihaA are expl. as meaning (tropical:) The like of such a man, and the like of such a woman, is sought after, and coveted, by reason of the high estimation in which he, and she, is held: and it is said that the meaning is, mstrAd mvlh and mvlhA; the l being redundant. (M, TA. [The latter clause seems to indicate a different meaning from that before expressed: but for this I see no reason.])
2 raw~asa * : see raA^~asa.
8 yarotaAsu * : see yarotay^isu.
raw~aAsN * and raw~aAsiY~N: for both, see raA^~=sN: and for the latter, see also A^aroA^asu.

1 raADa * , (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor. yaruwDu, (S,) inf. n. riyaADapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and riyaADN, (S, M, K,) or the latter is used poetically for the former, and rawoDN, (M,) He broke, or trained, (M, K, Msb,) a colt, (S, K,) or beast, (M, A, Msb,) and made it easy to ride upon: (M:) or he taught it to go: (TA:) and ↓ rw~D, inf. n. tarowiyDN, he did so well, or vigorously. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, raADa SaAHibahu (assumed tropical:) [He made his companion easy and tractable]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] raADa nafosahu (assumed tropical:) [He trained, disciplined, or subdued, himself: or] he became clement, or forbearing. (Msb.) And nafosaka biAlt~aqowaY ↓ raw~iDo (tropical:) [Train, discipline, or subdue, thyself well by piety]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] raADa Al$~aAEiru AlqawaAfiYa (tropical:) [The poet rendered rhymes, or verses, easy to him by practice]. (A, TA.) And lahu A^amorFA ↓ rw~D (assumed tropical:) He made an affair easy to him; syn. saw~asahu, q. v. (TA in art. sws.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] ruDotu Ald~ur~a, inf. n. riyaADapN, (tropical:) I bored the pearls: and huwa SaEobu Alr~iyaADapi, and saholu AlryADp, (tropical:) It is difficult to bore, and easy to bore. (A, TA.)

2 raw~aDa see 1, in three places. -A2- rw~D, (K,) inf. n. tarowiyDN, (TA,) He kept to the riyaAD [pl. of rawoDap, q. v.]. (K.) -A3- rw~D AlqaraAHa, (S, K,) or AlA^aroDa, (M, A,) He, or it, (a man, S, or a torrent, M, or the rain, A,) made the clear or bare land, (S, K,) or the land, (M, A,) a rawoDap. (S, M, K.) And A@ll~`hu AlA^aroDa ↓ ArAD God made the land riyaAD. (M.)

3 rAwDhu * , (S, A, K,) EalaY A^amori ka*aA, (S,) or EalaY ka*aA, (A,) inf. n. muraAwaDapN, (Mgh,) (tropical:) He coaxed, wheedled, beguiled, or deluded, him; (S, A, Mgh, K;) and he endeavoured to deceive or beguile him; like as he does who is training a beast not yet rendered perfectly tractable; (Mgh;) in order to make him enter into such a thing or affair; (S;) or until he entered into such a thing. (A.) ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh,) bayoEu AlmuraAwaDapi (tropical:) That mode of selling which is termed bayoEu AlmuwaASafapi; (Mgh, K; *) which is when one describes to a man an article of merchandise not present with him: (Sh, K:) this is said in a trad. to be an action that is disapproved: (K:) but some of the professors of practical law allow it when the article of merchandise agrees with the description. (L.)

4 ArAD * (Yaakoob, S, A) and A^arowaDa (Yaakoob, S) It (a place) became abundant in its riyaAD [pl. of rawoDapN, q. v.]; (Yaakoob, S, A;) as also ↓ AstrAD. (A.) And A^arowaDati AlA^aroDu and A^araADat The land became clad with plants, or herbage (M.) ― -b2- [And hence,] ArAD (tropical:) It (a valley) had water stagnating, or remaining, or collecting, in it; (S, A, Msb, K;) concealing its bottom; (A;) as also ↓ AstrAD: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) and so the former verb, (S,) or ↓ both, (A,) said of a watering-trough: (S, A:) or, when said of a watering-trough, the former verb signifies (assumed tropical:) it had its bottom, or lower part, covered with water: (M:) and ↓ the latter, (assumed tropical:) the water spread widely upon the surface thereof; (M;) and so the former too: (TA:) or ↓ the latter, (tropical:) it had a sufficient quantity of water poured into it to conceal its bottom; (O, K;) or to cover its bottom, or lower part. (L, TA.) ― -b3- And from ArAD, said of a watering-trough, has originated the saying, (S,) $aribuwA Hat~aY A^araADuwA (assumed tropical:) (assumed tropical:) They drank until they thoroughly satisfied their thirst. (S, K. *) And ArAD also signifies (assumed tropical:) He drank a second draught after a first. (K.) -A2- ArAD A@ll~`hu AlA^aroDa: see 2. ― -b2- [Hence,] ArAD AlHawoDa (assumed tropical:) He poured into the watering-trough a sufficient quantity of water to conceal its bottom. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) A^araADahumo, said of a vessel, (tropical:) It satisfied their thirst: (S, * K:) or it satisfied their thirst in some degree. (M, TA.) Hence the saying, fadaEaA biA_inaA='K yuriyDu Alr~ahoTa (tropical:) And he called for a vessel which would satisfy (K, TA) in some degree (TA) the [number of men termed a] rahoT; (K, TA;) occurring in a trad., (TA,) accord. to one relation, but the more common is yurobiDu, (K, TA,) with the singlepointed b. (TA.) ― -b4- ArAD also signifies (assumed tropical:) He poured milk upon milk; (K;) accord. to A 'Obeyd; but he deems it strange. (TA.)

6 Alt~araAwuDu * in selling and buying is syn. with Alt~aHaA*iY; i. e. (tropical:) The increasing [of the sum offered] and diminishing [of the sum demanded] which take place between the two parties bargaining; as though each of them were making his companion easy and tractable; from Alr~iyaADapu as inf. n. of raADa in the first of the senses expl. above. (TA.) In the phrase taraAwaDaA Als~iloEapa, meaning (assumed tropical:) They coaxed, wheedled, beguiled, or deluded, each other, with respect to the article of merchandise, [in the manner explained above, or otherwise,] the omission of the prep. [fiY] requires consideration. (Mgh.) You say also, taraAwaDaA fiY AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) They practised dissimulation, or showed feigned affection, each to the other, in, or respecting, the thing, or affair; as also tanaAZaraA: (TK in art. nZr:) Alt~araAwuDu fiY AlA^amori is syn. with Alt~anaAZuru. (M and K in art. nZr.)

8 ArtAD * , said of a colt, (K,) and ArtADt, (S, A,) said of a she-camel, (S,) or of a beast
(daAb~ap), (A,) It became broken, or trained. (S, A, * K, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] ArtADt AlqawaAfiY lil$~aAEiri (tropical:) [The rhymes, or verses, became rendered easy by practice to the poet]. (A, TA.)

10 AstrAD * : see 4, in five places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) It (water) stagnated, or remained, or collected, in a place. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) It (a place, S, M, K) was, or became, wide, ample, or spacious. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b4- And [hence (see its part. n. below)] AstrADt Aln~afosu (tropical:) The mind was, or became, dilated, free from straitness, cheerful, or happy. (K, TA.)
rawoDN * : see the paragraph next following, near the middle, in three places; and again, in the last sentence of the same.

rawoDapN * (S, M, A, Msb, K) and ↓ riyDapN (AA, A, K) and ↓ riy~iDapN (TA) [seem to be best rendered, in general, A meadow; meaning, a verdant tract of land, somewhat watery; or (as in Johnson's dictionary) ground somewhat watery, not ploughed, but covered with grass and flowers: and sometimes, a garden: accord. to the following explanations:] verdant land: a place where water collects, and the herbage becomes abundant, without trees: or fresh green herbage, with water, or having water by its side; not otherwise: or, accord. to Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilábee, a tract of plain land, producing [lote-trees of the kind called] sidor; which may be of the extent of Baghdád: and also, of herbs, or leguminous plants, and fresh green herbage: (M:) or this last [only]: (S:) or a tract of plain land, in which are jaraAviym [perhaps here meaning ants' nests, as these are generally found in soft soil,] and soft hillocks, in the low, or best and most productive, parts of a country, where water stagnates, or remains, or collects, at least a hundred cubits in extent: (M:) or a tract of sand, and of fresh green herbage, where water stagnates, or remains, or collects; so called because of the stagnation, or remaining, or collecting, of the water therein: (A, K, TA:) it is said that rawoDapN is mostly applied to a place where beasts pasture at pleasure: some say that it signifies a land having waters and trees, and sweet, or pleasant, flowers: (TA:) or a place that is pleasant with flowers; said to be so called because the waters that flow thither rest there: (Msb:) it is said in the 'Ináyeh, that ↓ rawoDN [perhaps a mistake for rawoDapN] signifies a garden; and in common conventional language, one having rivers, or rivulets: MF says that rivers, or rivulets, do not necessarily belong to the signification; but that having water does; though not in common conventional language: (TA:) accord. to Th, rawoDapN signifies a beautiful garden: (M:) the pl. of rawoDapN is ↓ rawoDN, (S, M, K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and riyaADN, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) originally riwaADN, (S,) and riyDaAnN, (Lth, M, K,) originally riwoDaAnN, (TA,) or rather riyDaAnN is pl. of ↓ rawoDN, (M,) and rawoDaAtN, (M, Msb,) in the dial. of Hudheyl rawaDaAtN: (Msb:) Az says that the ryAD of the hard and stony and rugged tracts in the desert are low level places, in which the rainwater stagnates, or remains, or collects, and which consequently produce various kinds of herbage, that do not quickly dry up and wither: that sometimes a rawoDap contains thickets of wild sidor: and sometimes it is a mile in length and breadth: but such as are very wide are termed qiyEaAn. (TA.) It is said in a prov., A^aHosanu mino bayoDapK fiY rawoDapK [More beautiful than an egg in a meadow, or garden]. (A, TA.) And one says, A^anaA Einodaka fiY rawoDapK (tropical:) [I, in thy presence, am as though I were in a meadow, or garden]: and majolisuka rawoDapN mino riyaADi Aljan~api (tropical:) [Thy sittingplace is like a meadow, or garden, of the meadows, or gardens, of Paradise]. (A, TA.) Mohammad is related to have said, “Between my grave, or between my house, and my pulpit is a rawoDap of the riyaAD of Paradise:” meaning, accord. to Th, that he who abides in this place is as though he abode in a rwDp of the ryAD of Paradise. (M.) [See another tropical meaning of riyaADu Aljan~api voce rataEa, last sentence.] ― -b2- rawoDapN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Any water that collects in pools left by torrents, or the like, and in places in land or in the ground to which the rain-water flows and which retain it. (K, * TA. [In the CK, AlAax~A*At and Almus~AkAt are erroneously put for AlA_ixaA*aAt and Almas~aAkaAt.]) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or ↓ rawoDN, (S, M,) (assumed tropical:) About the half of a firobap [or water-skin] (S, M, K) of water: (S:) and the former, (tropical:) as much of water as covers the bottom of a watering-trough. (S, M, A.)
riyDapN * : see rawoDapN. [It is implied in the K that the former is syn. with the latter in all its senses: but accord. to the TA, this is not the case.]

raAy^iDN *
A breaker, or trainer, (M, Msb, K,) of colts, (K,) or of beasts (dawaAb~): (M, Msb:) pl. raADapN and ruw~aADN (S M, K) and ruw~aDN. (M.)

ray~iDN * , originally rayowiDN, (S,) [in its primary sense seems to be syn. with ↓ maruwDN. ― -b2- And hence it signifies] (assumed tropical:) Clement, or forbearing. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Also, and more commonly,] applied to a she-camel, (S, K,) and to a he-camel, (S,) In the first stage of training, as yet refractory: (S, K:) and in like manner applied to a boy: (S:) or a colt, (A,) or beast, (L,) that has not received training, nor become skilled in going, or pace, (A, L,) nor become submissive to its rider: (L:) and a she-camel not trained: (A:) or, applied to a horse or the like, and to a camel, to a male and to a female, refractory; contr. of *aluwlN; app. designed as an epithet of good omen, because the beast is so called only before being skilfully trained. (M.) ― -b4- [Hence,] qaSiydapN ray~iDapu AlqawaAfiY (tropical:) An ode of difficult rhymes; such rhymes as the poets have not extemporaneously composed: (TA:) or qaSiydapN ray~iDapN means (tropical:) an ode not well, or not skilfully, composed. (A.) And A^amorN ray~iDN (tropical:) An affair not well, not skilfully, or not soundly, managed, conducted, ordered, or regulated. (A, TA.)
ray~iDapN * as a subst.: see rawoDapN

maraADN *
Hard ground in the lower, or lowest, part of a plain, or of soft ground, which retains water: pl. maraAy^iDu and maraADaAtN. (Az, K.)
maruwDN * , (S, K,) and its fem., with p, (S, Msb,) A colt, (S, K,) and she-camel, (S,) or beast (daAb~ap), (Msb,) broken, or trained. (S * Msb, K.) See also ray~iDN.

A^aroDN musotarowiDapN *
Land which has produced good herbage or plants, and of which the herbs, or leguminous plants, have become erect, or strong and erect: and nabaAtN musotarowiDN plants which have attained their utmost size and height. (M.) ― -b2- AifoEalo *aAka maA daAmati Aln~afosu musotariyDapF (tropical:) Do thou that while the mind is free from straitness, cheerful, or happy, (S, M, * Msb, TA, [in the second of which, however, Alnfs is strangely made masc.,]) is from AstrAD said of a place, as explained above. (S.) ― -b3- musotariyDN is also applied, by a poet, (S, M,) El-Aghlab El-'Ijlee, (S,) or Homeyd ElArkat, (AHn, M, IB,) to poetry, and to the metre termed rajaz; (S, M;) as meaning (assumed tropical:) Easy; practicable. (M, TA.)

1 raAEahu * , (IAar, Az, S, Msb, K, *) aor. yaruwEu (Mgh,) inf. n. rawoEN (Msb, TA) and ruwEN and ruwuwEN and ruw^uwEN, (IAar, TA,) [He, or it, affected his ruwE, i. e. heart, or mind, with fright, or fear;] fear of it (namely an affair or event) reached his ruwE; (Az, TA;) he, or it, (a man, S, or an affair or event, IAar, TA, or a thing, Msb,) frightened him; put him in fear; made him afraid; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ rw~Ehu, (S, Msb, K, *) inf. n. tarowiyEN: (TA:) or its beauty and abundance or multitude frightened him: (Lth, TA:) and ↓ the latter also, it frightened him by its abundance or multitude, or its beauty. (TA.) Hence the saying, in a trad., A_i*aA $amiTa lA_inosaAnu fiY EaAriDayohi fa*`lika Alr~awoEu, as though meaning [When the man becomes grizzled in the hair of the two sides of his face, that is] the warning of death. (TA.) You say also, [using the pass. form,] riyEa, aor. yuraAEu, (TA,) inf. n. rawoEN, (S, K,) He was, or became, frightened, or afraid; or he feared; (S, * K, * TA;) as also ↓ ArtAE, and ↓ trw~E. (S, K, TA.) And raAEa minohu, aor. yaruwEu, inf. n. rawoEN, He was, or became, frightened at it, or afraid of it; or he feared it. (TK. [But I know of no authority on which this is founded, except a prov. (cited in art. jEr) , in which some read ruwEiY jaEaAri instead of ruwgiY.]) To a man, you say, laA turaEo [Be not thou frightened;] fear not thou; let not fear overtake thee: and to a woman, laA turaAEiY. (S, TA.) And hence the saying, in a trad., lano turaAEawoA maA raA^ayonaA mino $aYo'K [Ye shall not be frightened, or afraid: we saw not, or have not seen, anything]. (TA.) You also say, minohu ↓ ArtAE and lahu He was, or became, frightened at, or afraid of, him, or it; or he feared him, or it. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) [It affected his ruwE, i. e. heart, or
mind, with a sudden surprise; it took him by surprise.] One says, maA raAEaniY A_il~aA majiyw^uka meaning (tropical:) [Nothing took me by surprise but thy coming; i. e. I was surprised by thy coming; or] I knew not save thy coming; as though he said, nothing struck my ruwE but thy coming. (TA.) And xarajotu wa maA raAEaniY A_il~aA fulaAnN liAlbaAbi (assumed tropical:) [I went forth, and nothing took me by surprise but such a one at the door]; which is equivalent to saying, and lo, such a one was at the door. (Har p. 207.) And it is said in a trad. of I'Ab, falamo yaruEoniY A_il~aA rajulN A=xi*N bimanokibiY, i. e. I knew not [save a man taking hold of, or seizing, my shoulder-joint]; as though he came upon him suddenly, or unexpectedly, without any previous appointment, and without knowledge, and so that event frightened him. (TA.) ― -b3- [It affected his ruwE, i. e. heart, or mind, with admiration, or pleasure;] it excited his admiration and approval; it pleased him, or rejoiced him; (S, Msb, K;) said of beauty [&c.]. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., describing the people of Paradise, fayaruwEuhu maA Ealayohi mina All~ibaAsi And what is upon him, of apparel, excites his admiration &c., by its beauty. (TA.) ― -b4- [It (drink) cooled it, (namely, the heart,) or allayed its thirst.] A poet says,
saqatoniY $arobapF raAEato fuw^aAdiY
saqaAhaA A@ll~`hu mino HawoDi Alr~asuwli
[She gave me to drink a draught that cooled, or allayed the thirst of, my heart: may God give her to drink from the pool of the Apostle in Paradise]. (TA.) You say also, h`*ihi $arobapN raAEa bihaA fuw^aAdiY [which may be rendered This is a draught by which he has cooled, or allayed the thirst of, my heart; and it is implied in the TA that this is the right meaning: or it means] this is a draught by which the thirst, or vehement thirst, of my heart has been allayed: (so accord. to the pointing in the copies of the K:) mentioned by Az. (TA.) -A2- The verb from rawaEN [q. v. infrà] is one and the same [whether trans. or intrans.; i. e., you say raAEahu, aor. yaruwEu, inf. n. rawoEN, meaning “He,” or “it, excited his admiration and approval,” &c., as expl. above; and raAEa, app. with the same aor. and inf. n., meaning He possessed the quality of exciting admiration and approval by his beauty and the pleasingness of his aspect, or by his courage, &c.; and in like manner, raAEato, said of a woman]; the trans. verb [in this case] being like the trans. [in other cases], and the intrans. [in this case] like the intrans. [in other cases]: but the regular form, accord. to Az, of the [intrans.] verb hence derived is rawiEa, aor. yarowaEu, inf. n. rawaEN. (TA.) -A3- raAEa fiY yadiY ka*aA: see art. ryE. ― -b2- And raAEa, aor. yaruwEu, and yariyEu, inf. n. of the former ruwaAEN, and of the latter rayoEN: see art. ryE.
2 raw~aEa see 1, first sentence, in two places.
5 taraw~aEa see 1, in the former half of the paragraph.

8 A_irotawaEa see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- ArtAE liloxayori i. q. ArtAH lahu [He was affected by alacrity, cheerfulness, briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, disposing him to promptness to do good; he inclined to, and loved, doing good]. (AZ.)

rawoEN * [see 1, of which it is an inf. n. ― -b2- ] Fright, or fear; (S, K;) as also ↓ rawEN [accord. to some, but this seems to be little known]. (TA.) Hence the saying, A^aforaxa rawoEuhu His fright, or fear, departed. (S.) Az says, All the lexicologists whom I have met say A^aforaxa rawoEuhu, with fet-h to the r [in rwEh], except El-Mundhiree, who informs me that AHeyth used to say, It is only ↓ Afrx rawoEuka, with damm. (TA.) Accord. to different relations of a trad., you say, ↓ A^aforaxa ruwEuka, meaning Fright, or fear, hath departed from thy heart; or may fright, or fear, depart from thy heart; (K, TA;) thus expl. by AHeyth; (TA;) and Afrx rawoEuka, with fet-h; or this latter, only, is the right, and means what thou fearest hath quitted thee, and departed from thee, and become removed; or may what thou fearest quit thee, &c.; as though it were taken from the young bird's going forth from the egg, (K, TA,) and the darkness' becoming removed from it; thus expl. by Aboo-Ahmad El-Hasan Ibn-' Abd-Allah Ibn-Sa'eed El-' Askeree; and AO says that Afrx rwEk [thus in the TA, without any syll. signs,] means let thy fright, or fear, depart, for the case is not as thou fearest it to be. (TA.) It is also said, in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh, that he wrote in a letter to Ziyád, ↓ liyuforixo ruwEuka, with damm; (K, TA;) but the opinion commonly obtaining with the leading lexicologists is, that it is with fet-h; except AHeyth, who relates it thus, with damm; (TA;) meaning Dismiss thou the rawoE from thy ruwE; (K, TA;) i. e., the fright, or fear, from thy heart: (TA:) for you say A^aforaxati AlbayoDapu when the young bird quits the egg; and rawoE is fright, or fear, which does not depart from itself, but from its place, which is the ruwE, with damm; (AHeyth, K;) the rawoE in the ruwE being like the young bird in the egg: in like manner also one says A^aforaxa fuw^aAdu Alr~ajuli when a man's fright, or fear, departs: but Dhu-r-Rummeh, though knowing the meaning, has made an inversion, saying,
qado A^aforaxato Eano ruwEihi Alkurabu
[for qado A^aforaxa Eani Alkurabi ruwEuhu His heart had freed itself from griefs]. (AHeyth, TA.) AHeyth adds, (TA,) one also says, Eani AlA^amori ↓ A^aforixa ruwEaka, or EalaY AlA^amori, [accord. to different copies of the K, the latter being the reading in the TA, but the former probably the right,] meaning [Free thy heart from the affair; i. e.] be thou tranquil, and without fear. (K, TA.) Az observes, What AHeyth says is clear; but I am averse from it because of his being alone in his saying; though sometimes later authorities correct things in which the earlier have erred; therefore the correctness of AHeyth may not be [absolutely] denied in this matter, seeing that he had an ample share of knowledge. (TA.) [See also art. frx, in several places.] ― -b3- Also (tropical:) War, or battle; as in the phrase, $ahida Alr~awoEa (tropical:) [He witnessed, or was present at or in, war, or battle]. (TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce saEafN.]

ruwEN * The heart: (S, Msb, K:) or the part thereof which is the place of rawoE, i. e. fear: (K, * TA:) or the sawaAd [or core, &c.,] thereof: (K:) and the mind: (S, Msb, K, * TA:) and the understanding; or intellect. (S, K.) See rawoEN, in five places. You say, waqaEa *`lika fiY ruwEiY That came into my mind. (S, Msb, * TA.) And it is said in a trad., A_in~a Alr~uwHa nafava fiY ruwEiY [Verily the Trusted, or Trusty, Spirit (meaning Gabriel) inspired into my mind, or heart]. (S.) You say also, vaAbi ruwEuhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He went to [app. a mistake for from] a thing, and then returned to it. (TA.)

rawaEN * The quality of exciting admiration and approval by beauty (S, K) and pleasingness of aspect, or by courage; (K;) the quality denoted by the epithet A^arowaEu, applied to a man, (S, K, *) and rawoEaA='u, applied to a woman. (S.) [See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.]
rawiEN * : see raAy^iEN; last sentence.

rawoEapN *
A fit of fright or fear: (S, K, TA:) pl. rawaEaAtN; (TA;) which is applied by Tarafeh to the frights occasioned by a stallion-camel to a she-camel when he desires to cover her. (EM, p. 66.) It is said in a trad., faA^aEoTaAhumo birawoEapi Alxayoli, meaning And he gave them something for the fright occasioned to their women and their children by the horsemen. (TA.) ― -b2- A trait, or sign, or mark, of beauty [that affects the ruwE, or heart]: (IAar, K:) beauty that excites admiration and approval, or pleases, or rejoices. (TA.)

ruwaAEu Alfuw^aAdi * and ruwaAEapu Alfuw^aAdi, applied to a she-camel, Quick, spirited, vigorous; sharp in spirit; syn. $ahomapN *akiy~apN: (K:) and [in like manner] ↓ rawoEaA='u, applied to a she-camel and a mare, (S, K,) but not to a male [in this sense, i. e. its masc. form, A^arowaEu, is not thus used], (S,) sharp in spirit; syn. Hadiydapu Alfuw^aAdi: (S, K:) in the T, ruwaAEN, without p, is applied as an epithet to a mare: and IAar says that ↓ rawoEaA='u, thus applied, is not from raAy^iEapN, but means one that is as though she were fearful, by reason of her sharpness, and briskness, or lightness, of spirit: he says also, that ↓ A^arowaEu, applied to a horse, is like this epithet applied to a man; and IB says, in art. Ejs, that, applied to a man, it signifies quickly frightened or afraid: it is also applied to a heart, meaning that is frightened, [or startled,] by reason of its sharpness, at everything that is heard or seen; and so ruwaAEN. (TA.) [See also raAy^iEN, and A^arowaEu mentioned and expl. therewith.]

raAy^iEN * [act. part. n. of raAEahu, q. v.,] Frightening; putting in fear; making afraid; [and particu-
larly] by its beauty and abundance or multitude. (Lth, TA.) ― -b2- Applied to beauty, That excites admiration and approval in the ruwE [i. e. heart, or mind,] of him who beholds it, and pleases him, or rejoices him. (TA.) Applied to a man, (K, * TA,) as also ↓ A^arowaEu (S, K, TA) so applied, (S, TA,) Who excites admiration and approval by his beauty (S, K, TA) and pleasingness of aspect, (K, TA,) with generousness, or nobleness, and excellence, and lordly condition; (TA;) or by his courage: (K, TA:) or the former, beautiful in countenance, who excites admiration and approval by his pleasingness of aspect and by the goodliness of his form or figure or state of apparel and the like: or, as some say, who frightens men by his aspect, inspiring reverence or awe: but the former explanation is the more reasonable: and ↓ the latter epithet, a beautiful man, who excites admiration and approval in him who beholds him: or, as some say, sharp; lively in spirit, and sharp in intellect: (TA:) [see also the next preceding paragraph:] the fem. of the former is with p: (TA:) that of the latter, ↓ rawoEaA='u: (S:) the pl. of raAy^iEN is A^arowaAEN, (K, * TA,) applied to men, like as rawaAy^iEu [the pl. of raAy^iEapN] is to women: (TA:) and the pl. of A^arowaEu and rawoEaA='u is ↓ ruwEN, (K, TA,) applied to men and to women. (TA.) You say also, farasN raAy^iEN A beautiful horse, that frightens (yuruwEu, i. e. yuxaw~ifu, [or rather startles, but better rendered excites admiration and approval in, or pleases, or rejoices,]) the beholder by his beauty: (Mgh:) and farasN raAy^iEapN, and ↓ rawoEaA='u, [but see, respecting the latter, a remark of IAar in the next preceding paragraph,] a mare that excites admiration and approval, or pleases, or rejoices, (taruwEu,) by her generousness, or excellence, or high blood, and her description. (TA.) [See also art. ryE, to which, as well as to the present art., raAy^iEN, applied to a horse, is said, in the TA, to belong.] And ziynapN raAy^iEapN Beautiful ornament. (TA.) And kalaAmN raAy^iEN (tropical:) Surpassing, or excelling, speech, or language. (TA.) -A2- Also Frightened, or afraid; and so ↓ rawiEN, with the w unaltered, as though it were of the measure faEiylN: [or both signify having fright or fear: for] each is a possessive epithet: or the former may be of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN [and therefore have the signification first given]. (TA.)
A^arowaEu * : fem. rawoEaA='u: pl. ruwEN: see the two paragraphs next preceding; the former in three places; the latter, in five.

1 raAga * , (S, Msb, K,) aor. yaruwgu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rawogN (S, Msb, K) and rawagaAnN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) said of a fox, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and of a man, (K,) He turned aside or away from a thing: (K:) or went this way and that, (Mgh,) or to the right and left, quickly, (Msb,) and deceitfully, or guilefully: (Mgh, Msb:) [or turned aside to deceive him who was behind him: for] the primary signification of rawogN is the turning aside to deceive him who is behind one. (Er-Rághib, TA.) It is said in a prov.,
ruwgiY jaEaAri wa A@noZuriY A^ayona Almafiro
[for Almafir~u, i. e. Turn aside or away, or go this way and that, &c., O she-hyena, and look where is the place to which to flee: or, as some relate it, the first word is ruwEiY: see art. jEr]. (S, TA. [Freytag seems to have found AlmEz for Almfr; and has explained ruwgiY jaEaAri as meaning “ Vide ubi capræ sint, hyæna! ”]) And you say, rAg AlS~ayodu The game, or object of the chase, went away this way and that, or hither and thither. (TA. [There said to be tropical; but I see not wherefore.]) And one says, rAg Eano fulaAnK He turned aside, or away, from such a one [and particularly with deceit or guile; eluded him; dodged him]. (JK.) And huwa yaruwgu Eani AlHaq~i [He deviates from the truth, or from that which is right or just]. (TA.) And rAg AlT~ariyqu The road turned aside or away, or deviated. (Msb.) And rAg mino ka*aA He turned away from such a thing, and returned, concealing his return: (Har p. 21:) [for,] accord. to Fr, rAg is not said of one who has returned unless he concealed his return. (Har ibid., and TA.) And rAg A_ilaY ka*aA, (S, Msb,) or AlY fulaAnK, (TA,) He turned aside (S, Msb, TA) to such a thing, (S, Msb,) or to such a one, (TA,) secretly. (S, Msb, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [li. 26], farAga A_ilaY A^aholihi fajaA='a biEijolK samiynK And he turned aside, (Jel, TA,) or went away, (Bd,) to his family secretly [and brought a fat calf]: (Bd, Jel, TA:) or he returned to his family concealing his return. (Fr, TA.) And in the Kur [xxxvii. 91], faraAga Ealayohimo DarobFA biA@loyamiyni And he turned against them (Fr, S, Bd, TA) secretly, (Bd, TA,) smiting them with the right hand, or because of the oath that he had sworn; (Bd;) as though the rawog in this case consisted in his employing a pretext against them in order that he might do to their gods what he did: (S, L:) or the meaning is, he advanced against them. (S, TA.) ― -b2- rAg HaAjapF A_ilaY fulaAnK, aor. as above, He sought to obtain quickly an object of want of such a one. (JK, TA. [See also 4.]

2 rw~g * , (IAar, K,) inf. n. tarowiygN, (TA,) (tropical:) He smeared, seasoned, imbued, or soaked, a mess of variyd [i. e. broken, or crumbled, bread], (IAar, K, TA,) or a morsel, or mouthful, (TA,) with grease, or gravy, or dripping; (IAar, K, TA;) as also mar~aga, and sagobala, and raw~ala: (TA:) or you say, raw~agotu All~uqomapa biAls~amoni, inf. n. as above, I smeared, seasoned, imbued, or soaked, the morsel, or mouthful, with clarified butter; as also ray~agotu: (Msb:) or raw~agotu Alxuboza fiY Alwadaki I soaked the bread in grease, or gravy, or dripping; syn. raw~alotuhu fiyhi. (JK.)

3 rAwghu * , (MA, TA,) inf. n. muraAwagapN (KL, TA) and riwaAgN, (TA,) He practised deceit, delusion, guile, or artifice, (MA, KL, TA,) with him, or towards him; (MA, TA;) or strove, endeavoured, or desired, to deceive, delude, beguile, circumvent, or outwit, him; syn. xaAdaEahu; as also ↓ ArAghu, inf. n. A_iraAgapN: and both signify he endeavoured to turn him; or endeavoured to turn him by blandishment, or by deceitful arts, or to entice him to turn; syn. raAwadahu. (TA.) It is said when its object is a person who has turned away from, or shunned, or avoided, that which one has devised, planned, or plotted, against him. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN yuraAwigu fiY AlA^amori [Such a one practises deceit, &c., in the affair], inf. n. muraAwagapN. (S.) And maA zilotu A^uraAwiguhu Eano ka*aA I ceased not to endeavour to turn him, or to entice him to turn, from such a thing, syn. A^uraAwiduhu; (TA in this art;) and Ealayohi to it: (TA in art. mnE:) and [in like manner] you say, EalaY A^amorK ↓ fulaAnN yuriyguniY Such a one endeavours to turn me, or to entice me to turn, to a thing; and Eano A^amorK from a thing; syn. yuraAwiduniY; and seeks, or demands, my doing so. (TA.) ― -b2- muraAwagapN also signifies The act of wrestling together; (S, K;) like ↓ taraAwugN. (K.) You say, raAwghu He wrestled with him: (TK:) or rwAg baEoDuhumo baEoDFA One of them wrestled with another; [or they wrestled, one with another; or they wrestled together;] as also ↓ trAwgwA. (S, TA.)

4 A^arowaga see 3, in two places. ― -b2- ArAg, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iraAgapN, (Msb, TA,) also signifies He sought, sought for or after, sought to find and take or get, or pursued after, and desired, (S, Msb, K,) a thing; (Msb;) or a thing that was difficult to take; as though it turned aside or away, or went this way and that, &c., (kaA^an~ahu yaruwgu,) before him; (Har p. 21;) and ↓ ArtAg, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. AirotiyaAgN, (Msb,) signifies the same. (S, Msb, K.) [A^ariyguwniY A_iraAgatakumo is expl. in one of my two copies of the S by the words AuTolubuwniY Talibatakumo: in the other of those copies, the latter of these words is written Tlibtakm: I think that the right reading is Tilobatakumo; and the meaning, Seek ye me with, or in, your mode, or manner, of seeking: the proper meaning is seek ye me with your seeking.] Khálid Ibn-Jaafar Ibn-Kiláb says, speaking of his mare Hi*oqap,
A^ariyguwniY A_iraAgatakumo faA_in~iY
wa Hi*oqapa kaAl$~ajaA taHota Alwariydi
[Seek ye me with your seeking; but ye will not be able to take me; for I, with Hidhkah, am like the bone sticking fast in the throat beneath the carotid artery]. (TA.) And you say, A^aragotu AlS~ayoda [I sought, or pursued, the game, or object of the chase]. (S.) And ArAgt AlEuqaAbu AlS~ayoda The eagle pursued the game this way and that, as the latter went. (Mgh and TA in art. hwY.) And xarajotu A^uriygu baEiyrFA $arada min~iY I went forth seeking in every road, or way, a camel that had run away from me. (TA, from a trad.) And maA *aA turiygu What is this that thou seekest and desirest? or that which thou seekest and desirest? (S, TA.) And fulaAnN yuriygu ka*aA wa ka*aA Such a one
eeks, and devises or plans or plots, such and such things. (T, TA.)

5 trw~g *
He (a beast) rolled, or turned himself over. (JK, IDrd, K.) And trw~g fiY AlT~iyni He became befouled, or bedaubed, in the mud. (JK.)
6 taraAowaga see 3, last two sentences.
8 A_irotawaga see 4, second sentence.
raAgapN * : see riyaAgapN.

rawaAgN * [The act, or quality, of turning aside or away from a thing: or of going this way and that, or to the right and left, quickly, and deceitfully, or guilefully: or of turning aside to deceive him who is behind one: or of eluding, or dodging:] a subst. from raAga. (S, Msb, K.) -A2- xayorN rwAgN, (so in the TA, the vowel of the r in rwAg not indicated,) or ↓ xayorN lahu rawaAgaA='u and ↓ ruwaAgaA='u, (so in the JK,) Abundant [wealth, or good of any kind]. (JK, TA.)

riyaAgN * [originally riwaAgN] A state of plenty; or of abundance of herbage, or of the goods or conveniences or comforts of life. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K.) You say, fulaAnN fiY Alr~iyaAgi Such a one is in a state of plenty, &c. (JK.) -A2- See also art. ryg.
riwaAgapN * : see what next follows.

riyaAgapN * The wrestling-place of a people; (Yz, JK, S, K;) as also ↓ riwaAgapN, (K,) which is the original form, the w being afterwards changed into Y because of the kesreh before it, though this, as Sgh says, is not a necessary sort of conversion; (TA;) or ↓ raAgapN. (So in the JK.)

ruwayogapN *
i. q. HiylapN [meaning An evasion or elusion, a shift, a wile, an artifice, an artful contrivance or device, a plot, or a stratagem]: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) from Alr~awogu [inf. n. of raAga]: so in the saying, A^axa*otaniY biAlr~uwayogapi [Thou tookest me by an artifice, &c.]. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, K.) [It has a similar meaning also in a saying cited voce HawojaA='u, q. v.]
rawaAgaA='u * and ruwaAgaA='u: see rawaAgN.

raw~aAgN * [Wont to turn aside or away from a thing: or to go this way and that, or to the right and left, quickly, and deceitfully, or guilefully: or to turn aside for the purpose of deceiving him who is behind: or to elude, or dodge]. Mo'áwiyeh said to 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, A_in~amaA A^anota vaEolabN raw~aAgN kul~amaA xarajota mino juHorK A@nojaHarota fiY juHorK [Thou art only a fox wont to elude: whenever thou comest forth from a burrow, thou enterest into a burrow]. (TA.) [Hence,] Alr~aw~aAgu is an appellation of The fox. (JK, K.)

TariyqN raAy^igN *
A deviating road. (S, TA.) Hence ↓ raAy^igapN [as a subst.] A road deviating from the main road: pl. rawaAy^igu. (TA, from a trad.)
raAy^gap * : see what next precedes.

A^arowagu * [More, and most, wont to turn aside or away from a thing: to go this way and that, or to the right and left, quickly, and deceitfully, or guilefully: to turn aside for the purpose of deceiving him who is behind: or to elude, or dodge]. Tarafeh Ibn-El-'Abd said to 'Amr Ibn-Hind, censuring his companions,
kul~uhumu A^arowagu mino vaEolabK
maA A^a$obaha All~ayolapa biAlbaAriHaho
[Every one of them is more wont to elude than a fox: how like is this night to yesternight! meaning, how like are they, one to another! see art. brH]: A^arowagu mino vaEolabK is a prov. (TA.)

1 raAfa * , (IDrd, K,) aor. yaraAfu, (K,) or yaruwfu, inf. n. rawofN, (IDrd,) is a dial. var. of raA^afa, (IDrd, K,) aor. yaroA^afu: (K:) or, as some say, (IDrd,) rawofN signifies The being still; and is not from Alr~aA^ofapu: (IDrd, K:) [ISd says,] raAfa, inf. n. rawofN, signifies sakana [he, or it, was, or became, still, &c.] and raA^afa [q. v.] is a dial. var. thereof [signifying thus]; and is not from raw^uwfN syn. with raHiymN. (M.)
3 rAwf * : see raA^afa.

raAfN *
Wine; a dial. var. of raA^ofN. (TA.)

rawofapN *
Mercy, or compassion: (O, K:) so accord. to IAar. (O.)

1 raAqa * , (S, Msb, TA,) aor. yaruwqu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rawoqN, (S,) It (wine, or beverage, S, or water, Msb, TA, and a thing, TA) was, or became, clear. (S, Msb, TA.) -A2- rAq Ealayohi, (JK, K,) aor. as above, (JK,) and so the inf. n., (K,) He, or it, exceeded him, or it: (JK:) [and] he, or it, exceeded him, or it, in excellence. (K.) You say, rAq fiY yadiY ka*aA Such a thing was redundant, or remained over and above, in my hand; like raAEa; syn. zaAda. (L in art. ryE.) And rAq fulaAnN EalaY A^aholihi Such a one was, or became, above, or superior to, his family; surpassed, or excelled, his family. (JK.) -A3- raAqaniY, (JK, S, MA,) or rAq liY, (so in my copy of the Msb, [perhaps a mistranscription, for only the former is commonly known,]) and rAqahu, (K,) aor. as above, (JK, S,) and so the inf. n., (JK, K,) It (a thing) induced in me, and him, wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy; excited my, and his, admiration and approval; pleased, or rejoiced, me, and him. (JK, S, MA, Msb, K.) -A4- rawiqa, [aor. yarowaqu,] inf. n. rawaqN, He was, or became, long-toothed: (MA:) [or he had long teeth, the upper of which projected over the lower: or his upper central incisors were longer than the lower, and projecting over them: see rawaqN, below.]

2 rw~q * , (JK, S, Msb,) inf.n. tarowiyqN, (S, K,) He cleared, or clarified, (S, Msb, K,) wine, or beverage, (S,) or water; (Msb;) he cleared, or clarified, wine, or beverage, with the raAwuwq. (JK, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He (a drunken man) made water in his clothes. (AHn, K, TA.) -A2- rw~q Albayota, (JK, TA,) inf. n. as above, (JK,) He made, or put, to the tent, a riwaAq, (JK, TA,) meaning a curtain extended below the roof. (TA. [See riwaAqN.]) ― -b2- Hence, (Har p. 50,) rw~q All~ayolu (assumed tropical:) The night extended the riwaAq [or curtain] of its darkness; (S, Msb, Har ubi suprà, TA;) became dark; (Har, TA;) as also ↓ A^arowaqa. (TA.) -A3- tarowiyqN also signifies The selling a commodity and buying one better than it, (IAar, K, TA,) or longer than it, and better: (TA:) or the selling an old and wornout thing and buying a new one: (Th, TA:) or the selling one's garment, and adding something to it, and buying [with that garment and the thing added to it] another garment better than it: (JK:) [or the buying, with a thing and something added thereto, a better thing: for] one says, baAEa siloEatahu faraw~aqa [He sold his commodity, and bought with it and something added thereto a better commodity]. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also, raw~aqa lifulaAnK fiY siloEatihi He named a high price to such a one for his commodity, not desiring it [himself, but app. desiring to induce another to give a high price for it]. (JK, K: expl. in the former by rafaEa lahu fiY sawomihaA wa laA yuriyduhaA; and in the latter by rafaEa lahu fiY vamanihaA wa huwa laA yuriyduhaA.)

4 A^arowaqa * : see 2. -A2- ArAqhu, (Msb in art. ryq, and K in that and the present art.,) inf. n. A_iraAqapN, (S in the present art., and so in the K accord. to the TA,) He poured it out, or forth; (S, Msb, K;) namely, water and the like, (S,) or water and blood: (Msb:) and one says also haraAqahu, (Msb, TA,) changing the A^ into h, originally haroyaqahu, like daHorajahu, in measure, (Msb,) said by Lh to be of the dial. of El-Yemen, and afterwards to have spread among Mudar, (TA in art. ryq,) aor. yuhariyquhu, (Msb, TA,) with fet-h to the h, imperative hariqo, originally haroyiqo, like daHorijo, (Msb,) inf. n. hiraAqapN; (S and K in art. hrq;) and A^ahoraAqahu, aor. yuhoriyquhu, (Msb, TA,) with the h quiescent, like yusoTiyEu aor. of A_isoTaAEa; or, accord. to the T, A^ahoraqotu is wrong as being anomalous; and some say, haraqotuhu, aor.
rawaqa , inf. n. haroqN, as though the h were radical. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., A_in~a A@moraA^apF kaAnato tuharaAqu Ald~imaA='a or tuhoraAqu, the verb being in the pass. form, and the h either meftoohah or quiescent, and AldmA' being in the accus. case as a specificative; [so that the meaning is, Verily a woman used to pour forth with blood; for thrAq is equivalent to tariyqu; but by rule the specificative should be without the article Al;] or AldmA' may be in the nom. case, Ald~imaA='u being for dimaAw^uhaA [i. e. her blood used to pour forth]. (Msb.) ISd says that A^araAqa is judged to be originally A^arowaqa because the medial radical letter of a verb is more commonly w than Y; and because, when water is poured forth, its clearness appears, and it excites the admiration and approval of its beholder; [to which may be
added, also because one says, humA yataraAwaqaAni AlmaA='a;] though Ks states that raAqa AlmaA='u, aor. yariyqu, signifies The water poured out, or forth: IB says that A^araqotu AlmaA='a is from rAq AlmaA='u, aor. yariyqu, inf. n. rayoqN, signifying the water went to and fro upon the surface of the earth. (TA.) One says also, of a man, ArAq maA='a Zahorihi and haraAqahu and A^ahoraAqahu [meaning He poured forth his seminal fluid]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A^ariqo Eanoka mina AlZ~ahiyrapi and hariqo meaning (assumed tropical:) Stay thou until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool; syn. A^aborido. (IAar, TA in art. fyH.) ― -b3- [See more in art. hrq.]

5 trw~q *
It (wine, or beverage, [&c.,]) became clear [or rather cleared] without pressing, or expressing. (TA.)

6 humaA yataraAwaqaAni AlmaA='a *
They two pour the water out, or forth, by turns. (TA.)

rawoqN * [an inf. n. of raAqa, used as an epithet,] Clear; applied to water &c. (IAar, K. [See also raAy^iqN.] ― -b2- [Hence, app., as a subst.,] Pure, or sincere, love. (K.) -A2- [Also, as an epithet originally an inf. n.,] Inducing wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy; exciting admiration and approval; pleasing, or rejoicing; (IAar, K;) as also ↓ raAy^iqN (JK) and ↓ ray~iqN. (IAar, TA.) And, applied to a horse, Beautiful in make, that induces wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy, in his beholder; excites his admiration and approval; or pleases, or rejoices, him; as also ↓ ray~iqN. (K.) -A3- A horn (JK, S, K, TA) of any horned animal: (TA:) pl. A^arowaAqN. (S, TA.) [Hence,] rawoqu Alfarasi (assumed tropical:) The spear which the horseman extends between the horse's ears: (K:) [for] spears are regarded as the horses' horns. (Ham p. 90.) And daAhiyapN *aAtu rawoqayoni (tropical:) A great calamity or misfortune; (K, TA;) lit. twohorned. (TA.) And HarobN *aAtu rawoqayoni (tropical:) A vehement war. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) [A] courageous [man], with whom one cannot cope. (K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A chief (IAar, JK, K) of men. (JK.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A company, or collective body, (As, O, K,) of people: so in the saying, jaA='anaA rawoqN mino baniY fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) [A company of the sons of such a one came to us: or, app., a numerous and strong company; for it is added that this is] like the saying raA^osu jamaAEapi Alqawomi [which means “ the numerous and strong company of the collective body of the people ”]. (As, O.) ― -b5- Also syn. with riwaAqN in several senses, as pointed out below: see the latter word in six places. ― -b6- Also (assumed tropical:) The foremost part or portion of rain, and of an army, and of a number of horses or horsemen. (TA.) And (tropical:) The first part of youth; as also ↓ ray~iqN, (S, O, K,) originally rayowiqN, (O, K,) and ↓ rayoqN, (S, O, K,) which is a contraction of ray~iqN: (O:) you say, faEalahu fiY rawoqi $abaAbihi and $bAbh ↓ ray~iqi and $bAbh ↓ rayoqi (tropical:) He did it in the first part of his youth: (S, TA: *) and maDaY mina Al$~abaAbi rawoquhu (tropical:) The first part of youth passed. (TA.) ― -b7- Also (assumed tropical:) The youth [itself] of a man. (TA.) ― -b8- And (assumed tropical:) Life; i. e. the period of. life: whence the saying, A^akala rawoqahu (assumed tropical:) [He consumed his life; or] he became aged: (K:) or this saying means (assumed tropical:) his life became prolonged so that, or until, his teeth fell out, one after another. (S, O.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) A part, or portion, of the night: (S, K:) pl., accord. to IB, A^arowuqN: but accord. to Aboo- 'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, this is pl. of riwaAqN: (TA:) [or the pl. of rawoqN in this sense is A^arowaAqN.] You say, maDaY rawoqN mina All~ayoli (assumed tropical:) A part, or portion, of the night passed. (TA.) And A^arowaAqu All~ayoli means (tropical:) The folds (A^avonaA=') of the darkness of night. (K, TA.) And A^arowaAqu AlEayoni (tropical:) The sides of the eye: so in the saying, A^asobalato A^arowaAqu AlEayoni (tropical:) The sides of the eye shed tears. (O, K, * TA.) ― -b10- Also (assumed tropical:) The body: (K, TA:) and [in like manner the pl.] A^arowaAqN signifies the (assumed tropical:) extremities and body, of a man: (TA:) and his self; (JK, * TA;) as also the singular. (JK, TA.) You say, ramawonaA biA^arowaAqihimo (assumed tropical:) They threw themselves upon us. (TA.) And A^aloqaY EalayonaA A^arowaAqahu (assumed tropical:) He covered us with himself [by throwing himself upon us]. (TA.) And ramaAhu biA^arowaAqihi (assumed tropical:) He threw his weight upon him. (TA.) And ramaY biA^arowaAqihi Eani Ald~aAb~api (assumed tropical:) He mounted the beast: and ramaY biA^arowaAqihi Eani Ald~aAb~api (assumed tropical:) He alighted from the beast. (O, K.) And A^aloqaY A^arowaAqahu (assumed tropical:) He remained at rest in a place; (S, O, K;) like as one says, A^aloqaY EaSaAhu: (S, O:) a meaning said in the K to be app. the contr. of what here next follows: but this requires consideration. (TA.) Also (assumed tropical:) He ran vehemently: (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K:) not known, however, to Sh, in this sense; but known to him as meaning (assumed tropical:) he strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, in a thing. (TA.) [Agreeably with this last explanation, it is said that] rawoqN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A man's determination, or resolution; his action; and his purpose, or intention. (K, TA.) And hence the saying, A^aloqaY Ealayohi A^arowaAqahu [meaning (assumed tropical:) He devoted his mind and energy to it, or him]: (TA:) [or] you say thus, and A^aloqaY Ealayohi $araA$irahu, meaning his loving it, or him, (A^ano yuHib~ahu,) vehemently [i. e. (assumed tropical:) he loved it, or him, vehemently; agreeably with explanations of the saying AlqY Elyh $rA$rh in art. $r, q. v.]. (Thus in the JM. [In my two copies of the S, and in the O and K, and hence in the TA, in the places of Ealayohi and yuHib~ahu we find Ealayoka and tuHib~ahu; evidently mistranscriptions which have been copied by one lexicographer after another without due consideration: or, if we read Ealayoka, we should read yuHib~aka; for in this case the meaning of the saying would certainly be he loved thee vehemently. Freytag, misled by the reading tuHib~ahu in the S and K, renders AlqY Elyk ArwAqh as meaning Magno amore erga ipsum te accendit. Golius gives, in its place, Drb AwrAqh Elyh (for ArwAqh), as meaning Valde amavit eum.]) ― -b11- You say also, A^aloqati Als~aHaAbapu A^arowaAqahaA, (JK, S, O, K,) or Alqt AlsHAbp EalaY AlA^aroDi ArwAqhA, (TA,) (tropical:) The cloud cast down its rain, and its vehement rain consisting of large drops, (S, O, K, TA,) upon the earth: (TA:) or persevered with rain, and remained stationary upon the land: (JK, TA:) or A^aloqati Als~amaA='u biA^arowaAqihaA The sky cast down all the water that was in it: (IAmb, O, TA:) or this saying, (O, TA,) or the former, (K,) means cast down its clear waters; (O, K, TA;) from raAqa AlmaA='u signifying “ the water was, or became, clear: ” but IAmb deems this improbable, because the Arabs did not say maA='N rawoqN and maAA=ni rawoqaAni and A^amowaAhN A^arowaAqN: (O, TA:) [i. e. they said rawoqN only, in all cases when they used it as an epithet meaning “ clear, ” because it is originally an inf. n., like EadolN &c.:] or, as some say, by bArwAqhA is meant its waters rendered heavy by the clouds: and one says, A^aroxati Als~amaA='u A^arowaAqahaA and EazaAliyhaA (assumed tropical:) [The sky loosed, or let down, its spouts; the clouds being likened to leathern water-bags]: (TA:) [for] rawoqu Als~aHaAbi means (assumed tropical:) The masiyl [or channel by which flows the water] of the clouds. (TA in another part of the art. [See also riwaAqN, as used in relation to clouds.]) -A4- rawoqN also signifies A substitute for a thing, (O, K,) accord. to [the JK and] Ibn-'Abbád. (O.) -A5- And Alr~awoqu means The breathing of [i. e. in] the agony of death (nafosu Aln~azoEi). (O, K, TA. [In the CK and in my MS. copy of the K, nafosu Aln~azoEi, which means the agony of death itself.])
ruwqN * is said to be pl. of ruwqapN, and of raAy^iqN, and of A^arowaqu. (TA.) [See these three words.]

rawaqN *
Length of the teeth, with a projecting of the upper over the lower: (JK:) or length of the upper incisors exceeding that of the lower, (S, O, K, TA,) with projection of the former over the latter. (TA.) [See also 1, last sentence.]
rayoqN * : see rawoqN, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph: ― -b2- and see also riy~iqN.

rawoqapN *
i. q. jamaAlN raAy^iqN [i. e. Beauty, comeliness, or elegance, &c., that induces wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy; or surpassing beauty, &c.]. (K.)

ruwqapN *
Choice, or excellent: (Fr, O:) or goodly, or beautiful: (K:) applied to a boy and to a girl, (Fr, O, K,) and to a he-camel and to a she-camel: (Fr, O:) and very beautiful or comely or elegant; (K;) applied to one and more of human beings: (TA:) used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl. (O, TA) and dual: (TA:) [and also said to be pl. of raAy^iqN, q. v.:] and it has a pl., [or coll. gen. n.,] namely, ruwoqN; (IDrd, O, TA;) applied to she-camels; (IDrd, O;) or sometimes applied to horses and camels, absolutely accord. to IAar, or particularly when on a journey. (TA.) -A2- Also A little, or paltry, thing: (JK, IDrd, O, K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (IDrd, O.) You say, maA A^aEoTaAhu A_il~aA ruwqapF He gave him not save a little, or paltry, thing. (IDrd, O.)
rawaAqN * : see what next follows.
ruwaAqN * : see what next follows.

riwaAqN * (Lth, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ ruwaAqN (MA, K) and ↓ rawaAqN (MA) A bayot [or tent] like the fusoTaAT [q. v.], (Lth, JK, O, Msb, K,) supported upon one pole in the middle thereof; (Lth, O, Msb;) as also ↓ rawoqN; (K, * TA; expl. in the
former as signifying a fusoTaAT; and its pl. A^arowaAqN is expl. in the S as signifying fasaATiyTu;) accord. to Lth: (TA:) or a roof in the front, or fore part, of a bayot [or tent]; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ rawoqN: (S:) or a curtain that is extended below the roof; as also ↓ rawoqN; which latter is expl. in the K as signifying simply a curtain: (TA:) or the riwaAq of a bayot [or tent] is the curtain of the front, or fore part, thereof, extending from the top thereof to the ground: (AZ, TA:) a [piece of cloth such as is called] kisaA=' let down upon the front, or fore part, of a bayot, from the top thereof to the ground: (Mgh:) ↓ rawoqN signifies the same as riwaAqN: (K:) and each signifies the $uq~ap [or oblong piece of cloth] that is beneath the upper, or uppermost, $uq~ap of a bayot [or tent]: (Az, O, K:) or sometimes the rwAq is one such piece of cloth, and sometimes of two such pieces, and sometimes of three: (TA:) and, (Msb,) or as some say, (Mgh, TA,) riwaAqN signifies (assumed tropical:) the front, or fore part, of a bayot [or tent]; (Z, Mgh, Msb, TA;) as also ↓ rawoqN; (JK, Z, K;) its hinder part being called its kifaA=', and its two sides being called its xaAlifataAni; (TA;) whence the saying, bayotihi ↓ qaEaduwA fiY rawoqi and riwaAqi bayotihi, i. e. (tropical:) [They sat in] the front or fore part [of his tent]: (Z, TA:) and ↓ rawoqN also signifies a tent; as in the saying, Daraba rawoqahu [He pitched his tent]: (S:) and [hence] the place of the huntsman [in which he conceals himself to lie in wait]; (K;) as being likened to the rwAq: (TA:) and rwAq signifies also a place that affords shelter in rain: (MA:) [and a portico; and particularly such as surrounds the court of a mosque; (see sud~apN;) in some of the large collegiate mosques, as, for instance, in the mosque El-Azhar, in Cairo, divided into a number of distinct apartments for students of different provinces or countries, each of which apartments by itself is termed a riwaAq:] the pl. of rwAq is A^arowiqapN and ruwqN; (S, O, Msb, K;) the former a pl. of pauc. and the latter of mult. (S, O.) ― -b2- [Hence, Alr~iwaAqu mina Als~aHaAbi, expl. in the TA as meaning mA dAr minohu kariwaAqi Albayoti: but dAr is here evidently a mistranscription for kaAna; and the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) The part, of the clouds, that resembles the rwAq of the tent. See also rawoqu Als~aHaAbi, near the end of the paragraph commencing with rawoqN.] ― -b3- [Hence also,] riwaAqu All~ayoli (assumed tropical:) [The curtain of night: and] the first part of night; and the greater, or main, part thereof. (ISd, K. [It is implied in the latter that one says also in this instance and in the next ruwaAq.]) You say, of night, mad~a riwaAqa Zulomatihi (assumed tropical:) [It extended the curtain of its darkness]: (S, Msb:) and A^aloqaY A^arowiqatahu (assumed tropical:) [It let fall its curtains]. (S.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce murim~N, in art. rm.] ― -b4- And riwaAqu AlEayoni (assumed tropical:) The eyebrow. (JK, K.) -A2- riwaAqu [imperfectly decl. as being a proper name and of the fem. gender, though it is implied in the K that it is Alr~iwaAqu and Alr~uwaAqu,] is a name for The ewe, (O, K,) by which she is called to be milked, by the cry riwaAq riwaAq; (O;) but not unless she be ↓ rawoqaA=' [app., if not a mistranscription for waroqaA=', formed from this latter by transposition, and thus meaning dusky: see A^arowaqu]. (O, K.)

raAy^iqN *
Cleared, or clarified, [or rather ↓ muraw~aqN has this meaning, and raAy^iqN signifies clear,] wine, or beverage. (TA.) And Pure musk. (TA.) [See also the same word in art. ryq: and see rawoqN.] -A2- [Also Exceeding, surpassing, or superlative: see 1, second and next two following sentences.] ― -b2- See also rawoqN, third sentence. [Hence,] Goodly, or beautiful: (S, K, TA:) from raAqaniY signifying as expl. in the first paragraph of this art.; (S;) or from raAqa signifying “ it was, or became, clear: ” (TA:) pl. ruwqapN, (S, K,) like as furohapN and SuHobapN are pls. of faArihN and SaAHibN, (S,) [or rather quasi-pl.,] applied to boys, (S, K,) and to girls; (S;) [and also (as expl. above) an epithet used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl. and dual;] and ruwqN is another pl. of raAy^iqN, like as buzolN is of baAzilN. (S.) ruwqapu Almuw^ominiyna, in which rwqp is [quasi-] pl. of rAy^q, means the best, and the manly and noble or generous, of the believers. (TA.)

ray~iqN * : see rawoqN, in four places, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also The most excellent of anything; (JK, S;) as, for instance, of wine, or beverage, and of rain. (JK.) ― -b3- And it is said to signify also, (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, O,) or so ↓ rayoqN, (accord. to the copies of the K,) A scanty fall of rain: thus bearing two contr. meanings. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

raAwuwqN *
A clarifier, or strainer, (S, Msb, K,) syn. miSofaApN, (S, K,) for wine or beverage: (S:) the naAjuwd [q. v.] with which wine, or beverage, is cleared, (Lth, JK, K, TA,) without pressing, or expressing: (TA:) and (sometimes, S) the [kind of wine-vessel called] baATiyap. (S, K.) Accord. to IAar, (O, TA,) who is said by Sh to differ herein from all others, (TA,) Alr~aAwuwqu signifies also The kaA^os [or drinking-cup, or cup of wine,] itself. (O, K, TA.) And Dukeyn uses it metaphorically in relation to youth; saying,
A^asoqaY biraAwuwqi Al$~abaAbi AlxaADibi
[app. meaning (assumed tropical:) He gave to drink of the cup of ruddy youth: see xaADibN as an epithet applied to an ostrich]. (TA.)

A^arowaqu * [app. originally signifying Horned: ― -b2- and hence,] (assumed tropical:) A horse between whose ears the rider extends his spear: when the rider does not thus, he [the horse] is said to be A^ajam~u. (K.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a man, (S, Mgh, K,) Having long teeth, with a projecting of the upper over the lower: (JK:) or having long incisors: (Mgh:) or whose upper incisors are longer than the lower, (S, K, TA,) and project over the latter: (TA:) fem. rawoqaA='u: (JK, TA:) and pl. ruwqN; (K, TA;) which is also said to be pl. of ruwqapN, and of raAy^iqN. (TA.) [In the K is added, after the mention of the pl., wa ka*`lika qawomN ruwqN wa rajulN A^arowaqu: an addition altogether redundant.] -A2- [It seems that it is also syn. with A^aworaqu, as being formed from the latter by transposition; and that hence] one says sanapN rawoqaA='u and sinuwna ruwqN [meaning (assumed tropical:) A rainless year and rainless years], and EaAva fiyhimo EaAmN A^arowaqu kaA^an~ahu *iy^obN A^aworaqu [meaning (assumed tropical:) A rainless year made mischief, or havock, among them, as though it were a dusky wolf]. (TA.) See also riwaAq, last sentence.
A_iraAqapN * inf. n. of 4. (S.) ― -b2- And [hence,] The maA=' [meaning seminal fluid] of a man; as also hiraAqapN and A_ihoraAqapN. (TA.) [See A^araAqa maA='a Zahorihi.]
maraAqN * : see art. ryq.
maA='N muraAqN * [Water, and hence, seminal fluid, poured forth]. (TA. [There immediately followed by A^araAqa maA='a Zahorihi, q. v.])
rajulN muriyqN * [A man pouring forth water, and hence, his seminal fluid]. (TA. [There immediately followed by maA='N muraAqN, q. v.])

muraw~aqN * : see raAy^iqN: -A2- and see muray~aqN, in art. ryq. -A3- Also A tent (bayotN, S, K, and xibaA='N, S) having a riwaAq [q. v.]. (S, K. [Said in the TA to be tropical; but why, I do not see.])

huwa muraAwiqiY *
He has the riwaAq of his tent fronting, or facing, that of mine; (JK, A, O, K; *) and so huwa jaAriY muraAwiqiY. (A, TA.)

2 rw~l * , (Lth, T, S,) inf. n. tarowiylN, (S,) He (a horse) slavered in his mixolaAp [or nose-bag]. (Lth, T, S.) [See also raAla in art. ryl.] ― -b2- He discharged his urine interruptedly and convulsively. (Sh, T.) ― -b3- He (a horse) put forth his yard for the purpose of staling. (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K.) And (M, in the K “ or, ”) He extended his penis feebly: (M, K: *) or he emitted his semen before access to the woman.
