(K.) -A2- Also, (inf. n. as above, T, S, K,) He seasoned a cake of bread with grease or fat, or melted grease or fat, or the like, (M, K,) and with clarified butter: (M:) or he rubbed it with clarified butter, (As, T, M, K,) and with grease, or gravy, or dripping: (As, T, M:) or he rubbed it hard, or much, with clarified butter: (S:) or he soaked bread in clarified butter; and the like: (Ham p. 114:) or he made his food, (M,) or a cake of bread, (K,) very greasy: (M, K:) i. q. raw~aga [q. v.]. (JK and TA in art. rwg.)

ruwaAlN * and ↓ raAwuwlN, (As, T, S, M, K,) the former also with ', [ruw^aAlN,] as mentioned in art. rAlN, (TA,) but not the latter, for the Arabs do not pronounce a word of this [class and] measure with ', (S, TA,) and A'Obeyd says that it is without ', or, accord. to ISk, it is [also] with ', (M and TA in art. rA^l,) Slaver: (IAar and T in explanation of the former, and S in explanation of both:) [like riyaAlN, mentioned in art. ryl:] one says rajulN kaviyru Alr~uwaAli A man having much slaver: (IAar, T: in one copy of the T Alr~uw^aAl:) and
fulaAnN yasiylu ruwaAluhu Such a one, his slaver flows: (S:) or both signify the slaver of horses and similar beasts, (As, T, M, K,) and of children: (As, T:) or the former signifies peculiarly the froth, or foam, of the horse: (M, K: *) accord. to Lth, the saliva of the horse or similar beast. (T.) [See ruw^aAlN, in art. rA^l.] -A2- See also the next paragraph.

raAy^ilN *
Falling in drops. (AA, T, K.) ruwaAlN raAy^ilN means Slaver falling in drops. (AA, T.) And (K) it has an intensive signification, [app. meaning Much slaver,] (M, K,) like $iEorN $aAEirN. (M.) -A2- Also, (M, K,) and ↓ raAwuwlN, (S, TA,) but disallowed in this sense by As, (T, S,) in the K, erroneously, ↓ ruwaAlN, (TA, [see also ruw^aAlN, in art. rA^l,]) A redundant tooth, (S, M, K,) in a man and a horse, (S,) not growing in the manner of the A^aDoraAs [or other teeth]: (M, K:) or raAy^ilN and ↓ raAy^ilapN signify a tooth that grows to a horse or similar beast, preventing him from drinking [with ease] and from [eating in the manner termed] qaDomN: (Lth, T:) accord. to ISh, rawaAy^ilu [pl. of ↓ raAy^ilapN] signifies small teeth that grow at the roots of the large teeth, and excavate the roots of the latter so that these fall out: (T:) [and] so rawaAwiylu: (TA:) or this last, which is pl. of ↓ raAwuwlN, signifies redundant teeth that are behind the [other] teeth; as also rawaAwilu, with the Y elided. (Ham p. 818.)
raAy^ilapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
raAwuwlN * : see ruwaAlN: -A2- and see also raAy^ilN, in two places.

mirowalN * , (IAar, T, K, in one copy of the T muraw~ilN,) like minobarN, (K,) A man having much slaver. (IAar, T, K.) ― -b2- And [Bread, or food,] soft with seasoning. (IAar, T, TA.) ― -b3- And A horse much affecting to act as a stallion. (IAar, T, TA.) -A2- Also A piece of a weak rope: (AHn, M, K:) and a piece of a rope of which no use is made. (AHn, M.)
muraw~ilN * [see 2, of which it is a part. n.:] One whose penis is, or becomes, flaccid: so accord. to IAar. (T.)

1 raAma * , (T, S, M, Msb,) aor. yaruwmu, (T, S, Msb,) inf. n. rawomN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and maraAmN, (Msb, K, TA,) He sought, sought for or after, or desired, syn. Talaba, (T, * M, Msb, K, *) a thing. (S, M, Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence, He attempted another person in fight &c., and a thing.] ― -b3- And [hence also] Alr~awomu, (K,) or rawomu AlHarakapi, mentioned by Sb, (S,) [as though signifying The desiring to pronounce the vowel-sound without fully accomplishing that desire,] means [the pronouncing] a vowel-sound (Harakap) slurred (muxotalasap) and rendered obscure, (S, K,) for, or by, [accord. to different copies of the S,] a sort of alleviation [of the utterance]; (S;) it is more [in effect] than what is termed AlA_i$omaAm, because it is heard; (S, K;) and it is of the same measure [in prosody] as the vowel-sound [fully pronounced]; as [in the case of what is termed] hamozapN bayona bayona, such as in the saying of the poet,
A^aAano zum~a A^ajomaAlN wafaAraqa jiyrapN
wa SaAHa guraAbu Albayoni A^anota Haziynu
[Is it because that camels have had the nose-reins attached to them, and neighbours have separated, one from another, and the raven of disunion has uttered its cry, thou art mourning?]; A^aAano zumo being scanned as faEuwluno; and it not being allowable to make the E [in fEwln] quiescent: it is such also as in the phrase in the Kur [ii. 181] $ahoru ramaDaAna with him who makes [the dammeh] obscure; it being only with a slurred vowel-sound (Harakap muxotalasap); and it not being allowable for the former r [i. e. the r of $hr] to be quiescent, because the h before it is quiescent, for this would lead to the combination of two quiescent letters in a case of continuity, [i. e. when there is no pause after them,] without there being before them a soft letter [i. e. A or w or Y, as in dawaAb~ &c.], which is not found in any of the dialects of the Arabs: and it is such also as in the instances in the Kur [xv. 9 and x. 36 and xxxvi. 49] A_in~aA naHonu naz~alonaA A@l*~ikora and A^am~ano laA yahid~iY and yaxiS~imuwna [for yahotadiY and yaxotaSimuwna], and the like thereof: no regard should be paid to the saying of Fr, that in this [last] and the like instances a letter [which in this instance and in the next preceding it is t] is incorporated into another [following it]; for they [i. e. the Arabs] do not realize this mode [of incorporation]; and he who combines two quiescent letters in an instance in which the slurring of the vowel-sound (AixotilaAsu AlHarakapi) is not proper errs; as in the reading of Hamzeh, in the Kur [xviii. 96], famaA A@sT~aAEuwA; for the s of AlAisotifoEaAlu may not be made movent in any manner [and therefore it may not be incorporated into the following letter]. (S, TA.) Alr~awomu is [also] in a case of pausing after a word ending with any letter except the fem. p, [in like manner] meaning The indicating the vowel with an obscure sound: (I' Ak p. 351:) rawomu AlHarakapi in pausing after a word that is marofuwE or majoruwr is from raAma Al$~aYo'a signifying Talabahu: Sb says that those of whom one says raAmuwA AlHarakapa [They slurred the vowel-sound] are induced to do what this signifies [instead of suppressing the vowel-sound entirely] by eagerness to exclude it from the case of that which is necessarily made quiescent in every instance, and to show that its case is, in their opinion, not like the case of that which is made quiescent in every instance. (M.) [See also 4 in art. $wr.]

2 rw~m fulaAnFA * (Msb, K) followed by Al$~aYo'a, (Msb,) and (K) rw~m bifulaAnK, (IAar, S, K,) He made such a one to seek, seek for or after, or desire, the thing. (IAar, S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And rw~m raA^oyahu He meditated, intended, purposed, desired, or endeavoured, to do one thing after another. (K.) -A2- And rw~m He tarried; paused; tarried and waited or expected; or was patient, and tarried and waited or expected. (K.) Quasi 4. A^aramota, for A^aromamota: see the latter, near the end of the first paragraph of art. rm.
5 trw~m bihi * , or bihaA, accord. to different copies of the K, (TA,) He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, him, or her. (K, TA.)

raAmN *
A certain species of trees. (S, K. *)
rawomN * inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (T, S, M, &c.) -A2- See also what next follows.

ruwmN * The lobe, or lobule, of the ear; (M, K;) as also ↓ ruwmN. (K.) -A2- Alr~uwmu A certain nation, (M, K,) well known; (M;) [said by the Arabs to be] descendants of Er-Room, the son of Esau (EySuw [so called by the Arabs]), (T, * S, K,) the son of Isaac the Prophet; (TA;) [i. e. the Greeks; generally meaning, of the Lower Empire; but sometimes, only those of Asia; and sometimes those of the Lower Empire together with all the nations of Europe beside: the ancient Greeks are more properly called by the Arabs AlyuwnaAnu:] one says ↓ ruwmiY~N and ruwmN; (S, K;) the former of these two appellations being applied to a single person, (M, K,) and the latter being the pl., (S, K,) [or rather a coll. gen. n.,] like zinojiY~N and zinojN; (AAF, S, M;) the former being distinguished from the latter only by the doubled Y, like as tamorapN is distinguished from tamorN its pl. [or coll. gen. n.] only by the p: (S:) and ruwmiY~N has for [its proper] pl. ↓ A^arowaAmN. (TA.) [It is also applied to The country of the nation, or people, so called, both in Europe and Asia, and sometimes only in Asia. Hence, baHoru Alr~uwmi The Sea of the Greeks; meaning the Mediterranean Sea.]

ruwmapN *
Glue, with which the feathers of an arrow are stuck: (M, K:) said by A'Obeyd to be [thus] without '; but mentioned by Th with '. (M, TA. [See art. rA^m.])
ruwmiY~N * The sail of an empty ship: (AA, T, K:) that of a full ship is called murobiEN. (AA, T.) -A2- See also ruwmN.

ruwaAmN *
i. q. lugaAmN [The foam of the mouth of a camel]: (K:) mentioned also in art. ruw^aAmN [as written ruw^aAmN, and signifying slaver]. (TA.)
ruw~aAmN * [pl. of ↓ raAy^imN, which signifies Seeking, &c.; act. part. n. of 1:] i. q. Tul~aAbN [pl. of TaAlibN]. (TA.)
raAy^imN * : see what next precedes.
A^arowaAmN * pl. of ruwmiY~N. (TA.) See ruwmN.

maraAmN *
i. q. maTolabo (S, M, K) [accord. to the PS A place of seeking or searching: but it should be observed that maTolabN is an inf. n., and also a n. of place and of time: also that maraAmN is expressly said in the Msb and TA to be an inf. n. of raAma, though not in the S nor in the M: and that it is mentioned in the K in the beginning of this art. as syn. with rawomN in the sense of TalabN, and at the end of the art. as signifying the same as maTolabN]. One says, huwa vabotu AlmaqaAmi baEiydu AlmaraAmi [which may mean
He is firm, or steady, in respect of the place of standing; far-aiming in respect of the place of seeking: or, agreeably with an explanation voce vabotN, he is one who does not quit his station, or abode, without necessity, though far-aiming &c.: but it is obvious that both AlmqAm and AlmrAm may here be inf. ns.]. (TA.)

maruwmN *
Sought, sought for or after, or desired. (Msb.)

1 raAna * , [aor. yaruwnu,] inf. n. rawonN It (an affair, or event,) was, or became, hard, difficult, or severe. (TA.) ― -b2- And raAnato layolatunaA Our night was, or became, very cloudy and hot. (Th, M, TA.) -A2- See also raAna in art. ryn.

rawonN * , (so accord. to a copy of the T, [if correct, an inf. n. used as a simple subst., see above, first sentence,]) or ↓ ruwnN, (so in another copy of the T, and accord. to the K,) with damm, (K,) Hardness, difficulty, severity, vehemence, or intenseness: (T, K:) pl. ruw^uwnN, (T, and so in a copy of the K,) or ruw^uwnN. (CK.) [See also ruwnapN.] -A2- rawonN signifies [or signifies also] The furthest part of a ma$aArap [q. v.]. (Yoo, K.)
ruwnN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

ruwnapN * The greater, main, principal, or chief, part of a thing. (M, K.) ― -b2- And Hardness, difficulty, or severity, of a thing, or an affair, or event; and grievousness thereof: so in the saying, ka$afa A@ll~`hu Eanoka ruwnapa h`*aA AlA^amori [May God remove from thee the hardness, &c., and the grievousness, of this thing, or affair, or event]. (M.) [See also rawonN.] ― -b3- And The utmost limit, reach, or degree, of a thing, in respect of heat, or cold, or in other respects, as when said of grief, or of war, or the like: and hence is said to be taken the name Alr~unapu [or runapu, without Al, (see Alr~un~aY, in art. rn,) as though it were a contraction of ruwnap,] given to [the month] Jumádà-l-Ákhireh, because of its intense cold [when it was so named]. (TA.)

A^arowanaAnN * : see the opinions of IAar and Sb respecting its derivation in art. rn. [It is said in the S and K in art. nbj, that there is no word like it except A^anobajaAnN.] You say yawomN A^arowanaAnN (T, S, M, K) and ↓ A^arowunaAniY~N, (S, M,) and layolapN A^arowanaAnapN (T, S, M, K) and ↓ A^arowanaAniy~apN, (M,) A day, and a night, hard, difficult, severe, distressing, or grievous: (S, K, * TA:) or vehemently hot and grievous: (T, TA:) or that has reached the utmost point, or degree, in respect of joy, or grief, or heat: or hard, difficult, or severe, in respect of everything; in respect of heat, or cold, or clamour, cries, shouts, or noises [&c.]. (M, TA.) You say also yawomu A^arowanaAnK, [virtually] meaning the same: (K:) [or this may mean A day of clamour, &c.; as will be seen from what follows.] ↓ yawomu A^arowanaAniY occurs at the end of a verse of a rájiz: this may be [by poetic license] for yawomu A^arowanaAnK, or for yawomu A^arowaAnaAniY~K: and ↓ yawomN A^arowanaAniY occurs at the end of a verse of En-Nábighah El-Jaadee, for yawomN A^arowanaAniY~N. (S.) Accord. to Sh, as is said in the T, (TA,) yawomN A^arowanaAnN, (K, TA,) as also yawomu A^arowanaAnK, (K,) signifies A day that is easy, (K, TA,) or pleasant: (TA:) thus having two contr. meanings: (K:) and Sh cited a verse of En-Nábighah ElJaadee as an ex.: but AHeyth disallowed ArwnAn as having any other meaning than grief, and difficulty or the like; and he disallowed also the verse cited by Sh [as being an ex. of the meaning that he assigned to it]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A voice, or sound: (S, K:) and cries, shouts, or noises, and clamour. (TA. [In one place, in the TA, rwn, thus written, without any vowel-sign, has also this latter meaning assigned to it: but the context seems to show that this is a mistranscription.])
A^arowanaAniY~N * ; and its fem., with p; and A^arowanaAniY: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

huwa maruwnN bihi *
He is overcome, subdued, or subjected. (K.) [maruwnN here is a contraction of marowuwnN, from raAna having for its aor. yaruwnu as a dial. var. of raAna having for its aor. yariynu: see art. ryn.]
Alr~iwanodu * , or Alr~iywanodu, and raAwanod: see art. rwd.

1 rawiYa mina AlmaA='i * , (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and All~abani, (M, K,) aor. yarowaY, (T, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. riY~N (T, S, M, Mgh, * K) and raY~N, (S, K,) or the former is a simple subst. and the latter is the inf. n., (Msb,) or the latter is an inf. n. and also a simple subst., (M, K,) and riwFY, (S, M, K,) the last erroneously written, in [some of] the copies of the K, rawaY, as though it were a pret. verb [like rawiYa]; (TA;) and ↓ ArtwY and ↓ trw~Y; (S, M, Msb, K;) all signify the same; (T, S, M, * Msb, K;) [or the last probably has an intensive meaning;] He was satisfied, or he satisfied himself, with drinking of water [and of milk]; he drank thereof enough to quench, or satisfy, his thirst; contr. of EaTi$a. (Mgh in explanation of the first.) ― -b2- And rawiYa Aln~abaAtu, (M,) or Al$~ajaru, (K,) mina AlmaA='i; (TA;) and ↓ trw~Y; (M, K;) [The plant, or herbage, or the trees, had plentiful irrigation: or] i. q. tanaE~ama [i. e., became flourishing and fresh, luxuriant, juicy, succulent, or sappy]; (M, K;) or became bright and fresh, by reason of plentiful irrigation. (TK.) ― -b3- rawiYa and ↓ ArtwY and ↓ trw~Y are also used metaphorically, as meaning (tropical:) He was, or became, in a good state or condition; and in the enjoyment of much ease, pleasantness, softness, or delicacy, of life. (Har p. 100.) ― -b4- $abiEotu mino h`*aA AlA^amori wa rawiytu is likewise metaphorical, meaning (tropical:) I have become, or I became, disgusted [or satiated to loathing] with this thing, or affair. (S * and TA in art. $bE.) ― -b5- See also a verse cited voce A_ilaY, (p. 85,) in which yarowaY is made trans. by means of that particle in the place of mino. -A2- rawaY EalaY A^aholihi, (T, S, M, K,) and liA^aholihi, (S, M, K,) aor. yarowiY, inf. n. ray~apN, or riy~apN, (accord. to different copies of the T, [the former app. indicated to be the right by what is said in the next sentence,]) or raY~N, (M, [probably also correct,]) He brought water to his family: (S, M, K:) [but in the T it is implied that the meaning is like that of the phrase here following:] rawaY Alqawoma, (ISk, T, S, K,) aor. as above, (ISk, T, S,) inf. n. ry~p, (so in the TA,) He drew water for the people, or party. (ISk, T, S, K.) You say, mino A^ayona ray~atukumo, with fet-h to the r, (S,) or riy~atukumo, (so in the T,) meaning Whence is your providing of yourselves with water? (AlmaA='a ↓ mino A^ayona tarotawuwna: T, immediately after the latter of the foregoing phrases; and S, immediately after the former of them:) so says ISk. (T.) And rawaY EalaY AlyaEiyri He drew water upon the camel. (M. [See saAniyapN.]) ― -b2- And rawaY AlmaA='a, aor. yarowiY, [inf. n., app., riwaAyapN,] He (a camel) bore, carried, or conveyed, water. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (Msb, TA,) rawaY AlHadiyva, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and Al$~iEora, (T, S, M, Mgh,) Eanohu, (MA,) aor. yarowiY, (T,) inf. n. riwaAyapN; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) and ↓ trw~Ahu; (M, K;) both signify the same; (K;) He bore in his memory, knowing by heart, (Hamala,) and transmitted [orally], related, recited, or rehearsed, the tradition, narrative, or story, (Msb, TA,) and the poetry, (TA,) [as learned, or heard, or received,] from him; (MA;) [he related, recited, or rehearsed, the tradition, &c., and the poetry, by heart from him:] you say to a man, A^ano$idi AlqaSiydapa [ “ Recite thou the ode ”]; but you do not say, AirowihaA unless you mean thereby Relate thou it by heart. (S, TA.) [One says also, ruwiYa Eanohu, meaning It has been related as heard, or received, from him. And ruwiYa ka*aA, and yurowaY ka*aA, meaning It has been related, and it is related, (otherwise, i. e.) thus; with the substitution of such a word &c.: and often meaning it has been read, and it is read, &c. And fiY riwaAyapK ka*aA, meaning According to one relation, or way of relation or relating, thus: and often meaning according to one reading, thus.] -A3- rawaY AlHabola, (M, K,) [aor. yarowiY,] inf. n. raY~N, (M,) He twisted the rope: (M, K:) or he twisted the rope well, or thoroughly, or soundly. (M.) ― -b2- rawaY EalaY Alr~ajuli, (S, M, TA,) in the copies of the K, erroneously, Alr~aHoli, (TA,) He bound the man (S, M, K, * TA) with the rope called riwaA=' (M, TA) upon the back of the camel, (S, K, *) lest he should fall (S, M, K, * TA) from the camel (M) in consequence of his being overcome by sleep. (S, M, * TA.) And rawayotu EalaY Alr~aAwiyapi, aor. A^arowiY, inf. n. raY~N, I bound the riwaA=' upon the leathern water-bag, or pair of leathern water-bags, called rAwyp. (T.) You say, rawaY Ealayohi, inf. n. raY~N; and ↓ ArwY; He bound him, or it, with the rope [called riwaA=', as is implied in the M]. (M, * TA.) And Alr~iwaA='a EalaY AlbaEiyri ↓ ArwY [He bound the rwA' upon the camel]; like rawaAhu. (TA.) And ↓ rwAY He bound a load with the riwaA='. (TA.)

2 rw~Y * , inf. n. tarowiyapN: see 4, in two places: ― -b2- and 5. [Hence,] yawomu Alt~arowiyapi [The day of providing oneself with water;] the eighth day of Dhu-l-Hijjeh; (T, Msb;) the day before that of 'Arafeh: (M:) so called because they (the pilgrims, T) used to provide themselves (yatazaw~aduwna, T, M, or ↓ yataraw~awona, Msb, and so in a copy of the T, or ↓ yarotawuwna, S, K) on that day with water (T, S, M, * Msb, K) for the aftertime, (S, Msb, K,) and to rise and go, or when rising to go, to Minè, where is no water, [or, accord. to the Msb, where was little water,] therefore they provided themselves fully with water, or therefore they provided themselves with water from Mekkeh for the alighting and abiding at Minè: (T, accord. to two different copies:) or [it means the day of consideration, or thought; (from another signification of the verb, as will be seen from what follows;) and is so called] because Abraham was considering, or thinking upon, his dream (wa yatafak~aru fiY ruw^oyaAhu ↓ kaAna yataraw~aY) [on that day], and on the ninth he knew [that his dream was from God], and on the tenth he desired to act [according to his dream] (AisotaEomala). (K. [And in a similar manner it is explained in the Ksh and by Bd in xxxvii. 101. See also 2 in art. rwA^]) ― -b3- rw~Y raA^osahu biAld~uhoni, and Alv~ariyda biAld~asami, (T, TA,) He moistened [his head, app. much, or saturated it, i. e. its hair, with oil, or grease, and the broken, or crumbled, bread with grease, or gravy]. (TA.) -A2- rw~Ahu Al$~iEora, (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) and AlHadiyva, (M, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. as above; (S;) and A_iy~aAhu ↓ ArwAhu; (S, K;) He made him to relate by heart the poetry, (S, M, * Mgh, * K, * TA,) and the tradition, narrative, or story; (M, Mgh, TA;) he made him to bear in his memory, knowing by heart, and to transmit, relate, recite, or rehearse, (Msb, TA,) the poetry, (TA,) and the tradition, narrative, or story; (Msb, TA;) [or he taught him to do so; i. e.] he related to him by heart (rawaY lahu) the poetry, (T, TA,) and the tradition, narrative, or story, (TA,) until he retained it in his memory, for the purpose of relating it by heart [as learned, or heard, or received,] from him. (T, TA. *) And ruw~iynaA AlHadiyva [We had the tradition, narrative, or story, related to us by heart; and in like manner, Al$~iEora the poetry]. (Msb, TA.) -A3- raw~ayotu fiY AlA^amori, (S, K, [though Freytag represents the verb as being in the K without teshdeed, and Golius explains the verb nearly in the same manner with and without teshdeed,]) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He looked into the thing, or affair, or case; inspected it; examined it; considered it; or thought upon it; (S, M, K, TA;) deliberately, or leisurely; without haste; a dial. var. of raw~aA^otu [q. v.]: (M, TA:) [and fiyhi ↓ taraw~ayotu app. signifies the same:] see yataraw~aY in the former half of this paragraph, in an explanation of yawomu Alt~arowiyapi.

4 ArwAhu * (M, MA, Msb, K) mina AlmaA='i (MA) [and mn All~abani], inf. n. A_irowaA='N; (KL, and Har p. 67;) and ↓ rw~Ahu (MA, Msb) minohu, (MA,) inf. n. tarowiyapN; (KL;) He satisfied him, or made him to be satisfied, with drinking of water [and of milk]; he satisfied, or quenched, his (another's) thirst, by a drink, or draught, of water [and of milk]; (M, * MA, Msb, * K, * KL; *) he did away with his thirst [thereby]. (Har ubi suprà.) One says of a she-camel abounding in milk, hiYa turowiY AlS~abiY~a [She satisfies the thirst of the young child]: because he sleeps in the beginning of the night, and they desire that her flow of milk may be early, before his sleeping. (M, TA.) [And in like manner, ArwAhu is said of water, and of milk, &c., meaning It satisfied his thirst.] ― -b2- [Hence, ArwY and ↓ rw~Y signify also He watered, or irrigated, plentifully a plant, or herbage, or a tree; or rendered it flourishing and fresh, luxuriant, succulent, or sappy, by plentiful irrigation: see 1, second sentence.] -A2- See also 2, in the middle of the paragraph. -A3- And see 1, last three sentences.

5 trw~Y * : see 1, first three sentences. ― -b2- You say also, taraw~awoA and ↓ raw~awoA, meaning They provided themselves with water. (M.) And kaAnuw yataraw~awona mina AlmaA='i; (Msb, and so in a copy of the T; see 2, second sentence;) or mn AlmA=' ↓ yarotawuwna; (S and K; see again 2, second sentence;) [They used to provide themselves with water:] and AlmaA=' ↓ mino A^ayona tarotawuwna [Whence do ye provide for yourselves water?]. (T and S; see 1, in the middle of the paragraph.) ― -b3- And taraw~ati All~uqomapu biAls~amoni [The morsel was imbued, or soaked, with clarified butter]. (En-Nadr, TA in art. ryg.) -A2- trw~Y AlHadiyva, and Al$~iEora: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. -A3- taraw~ato mafaASiluhu: see 8. -A4- trw~Y fiyhi: see 2, in two places.

8 ArtwY * : see 1, first and third sentences: ― -b2- and see also 5, in two places. ― -b3- Artwt Aln~axolapu The palm-tree, having been planted in a hollow dug for the purpose, was watered at its root. (Lth, T.) -A2- It (a rope) was twisted: (M, K:) or was twisted well, or thoroughly, or soundly: (M:) or was thick in its strands: (S:) or was composed of many strands, and thick, and very compact. (Lth, T.) ― -b2- And Artwt mafaASiluhu His joints (those of a beast, T, or those of a man, S) were, or became, well-proportioned and thick; (T, S, K;) and so ↓ trw~t. (M, K.)
raw~N * : see rawaA='N.
ruY~N * : see what next follows: -A2- and see also art. rY.

riY~N * , said by Esh-Shámee, in his “Seereh [of the Prophet],” to be also with damm [i. e. ↓ ruY~N, which is anomalous, like ruy~aA, for ruw^oyaA], (MF, TA,) is an inf. n. of rawiYa: (T, S, M, Mgh, * K:) and also (M, K) a simple subst. from that verb [meaning The state of being satisfied with drinking of water and of milk; the state in which one is satisfied with drinking or drink; the state of having drunk enough to quench, or satisfy, the thirst]. (M, Msb, K.) One says, fulaAnN fiY riY~K wa ma$obaEK [Such a one is in a state in which he is satisfied with drink and food]. (T, A, TA, all in art. nZr.) ― -b2- [Also, as is indicated in the K &c., in relation to plants or herbage, or to trees, The state of having plentiful irrigation; or of being flourishing and fresh, luxuriant, juicy, succulent, or sappy, by reason of plentiful irrigation.] -A2- EayonN rib~apN A source abounding with water. (S.) -A3- See also art. rY.
riwFY * : see rawaA='N. ― -b2- ruTabN riwFY Dates when they ripen [after they have been cut off,] not upon their palm-trees; as also ↓ murowK. (TA.)
ruwyaA * : see ruw^oyaA, in art. rA^Y.

rawaA='N * and ↓ riwFY (T, S, M, K [in this last improperly said to be like A_ilaY, which is without tenween,]) and ↓ rawiY~N (M, K) Sweet water: (S:) or water that causes him who comes to it to return with his thirst satisfied; (T, S; *) applied only to water that has a continual increase, and does not become exhausted, nor cease: (T:) or abundant water, that satisfies the thirst. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Alr~awaA='u is a name of The well of Zemzem. (K, TA.) -A2- And rwA', (so in the TA, as from the K, and as mentioned by Az on the authority of IAar, [but I have looked for it in vain in two copies of the T, app. rawaA='N, or perhaps ↓ riwaA='N, like the Pers. riwaA, for one of these two may be from the other,] or ↓ raw~N, (so accord. to my MS. copy of the K and accord. to the TK, [but this I think very dubious, and still more strange is the reading in the CK, which is riw,]) Abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (K.)

ruwaA='N * [for ruw^aA='N, (see riy^oYN, in art. rA^Y,) or of the measure fuEaAlN from Alr~iY~u, (see Har p. 24,)] i. q. manoZarN [as meaning A pleasing, or goodly, aspect; or beauty of aspect]: so in the phrase rajulN lahu ruwaA='N [A man having a pleasing, or goodly, aspect]. (S.)

riwaA='N *
A rope with which the two leathern water-bags are bound upon the camel: (T:) or a rope with which goods, or furniture, or utensils, &c., are bound upon the camel; (S, K;) and with which a man is bound upon a camel, lest he should fall in consequence of his being overcome by sleep: (M, and Ham p. 321:) or one of the ropes of the [tent called] xibaA=': and sometimes the load is bound therewith upon the camel: accord. to AHn, it is thicker than well-ropes: (M:) and ↓ mirowFY signifies the same: (T, K:) pl. of the former A^arowiyapN; (T, S, K;) and of ↓ the latter mrAwY, (T, K,) i. e. maraAwaY, and maraAwK. (TA.) -A2- See also rawaA='N.

rawiY~N * : see rawaA='N. ― -b2- Also A full, or complete, drink. (K, TA.) You say, $aribotu $urobFA rawiy~FA (S, TA) I drank a full, or complete, drink. (TA.) ― -b3- And A cloud of which the rain-drops are large, (S, K,) and vehement in their fall; like saqiY~N: (S:) pl. A^arowiyapN. (TA.) ― -b4- And, accord. to IAar, One who gives to drink; or a waterer; syn. saAqK: [in one copy of the T, in the place of Als~aAqiY as explanatory of Alr~awiY~u, I find Alt~aA^an~iY, which I think an evident mistranscription:] ― -b5- and Weak: ― -b6- and Sound in body and intellect. (All three from the T.) -A2- Also The [funda-
mental] rhyme-letter; (S, M, K;) the letter upon which the ode is founded, and which is indispensable in every verse thereof, in one place; as, for instance, the [final] E in the verse here following:
A_i*aA qal~a maAlu Almaro'i qal~a Sadiyquhu
wa A^awomato A_ilayohi biAlEuyuwni AlA^aSaAbiEu
[When the wealth of the man becomes little, his friends become few, and, together with the eyes, the fingers make signs to him]: (Akh, M:) [when two or more letters are indispensable to the rhyme, only one of them is thus termed, according to rules fully explained in the M and in the treatises on versification:] IJ mentions rawiy~aAtN as its pl.; but [ISd says,] I think him to have stated this carelessly, and not to have heard it from the Arabs. (M.) One says qaSiydataAni EalaY rawiY~K waAHidK [Two odes constructed upon one rhymeletter; or having one fundamental rhyme-letter]. (S.)
riwaAyapN * [an inf. n. of rawaY, q. v., when used as a subst., meaning A relation, or recital, &c.,] has for its pl. rawaAyaA. (JM.) See raAwiyapN, last sentence but one.

rawiy~apN *
A want, or thing wanted: (A 'Obeyd, T, S:) so in the saying, lanaA Einoda fulaAnK rawiy~apN [We have a want to be supplied to us on the part of such a one; meaning we want a thing of such a one]: (A 'Obeyd, T:) and lanaA qibalaka rawiy~apN [We have a want to be supplied to us on thy part; we want a thing of thee]. (S.) ― -b2- And The remainder of a debt and the like. (S.) -A2- Also, (S,) or rawiy~apN fiY A^amorK, (M, K, *) thus usually pronounced without ', (S,) [originally rawiyoy^apN,] Inspection, examination, consideration, or thought, of an affair; (S, M, K;) without haste: (M:) pl. rawaAyaA. (JM, TA.) You say, maDaY EalaY wajohihi bigayori rawiy~apK [He went at random, heedlessly, or in a headlong manner, without consideration]. (A in art. rkb.) See raAwiyapN, near the end. [See also rawiyoy^apN in art. rwA^.)

rajulN raw~aA='N *
A man whose habitual work, or occupation, is the drawing of water by means of the raAwiyap [q. v.]: you say, jaA='a raw~aA='u Alqawomi [The people's habitual drawer of water by means of the rAwyp came]. (T.)

ray~aA * [originally rawoyaA] A sweet odour (T, M, K) of anything. (T.) One says of a woman, A_in~ahaA laTay~ibapu Alr~ay~aA, meaning Verily she is sweet in the odour of her body: and hence the saying of Imrael-Keys,
A_i*aA qaAmataA taDaw~aEa Almisoku minohumaA
nasiyma AlS~abaA jaA='ato biray~aA Alqaranofuli
[When they stand, the fragrance of musk is diffused from them, like the breath of the east wind that has brought the sweet odour of the clove]. (T.) -A2- It is also fem. of ray~aAnu. (T, S, M, &c.)

ray~aAnu * [originally rawoyaAnu] an epithet from rawiYa; (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) Satisfied with drinking [of water and of milk &c.]; having drunk [thereof] enough to quench, or satisfy, his thirst; contr. of EaTo$aAnu: (S, Mgh: *) fem. ray~aA, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) in which the Y is not changed into w because the word is an epithet; for it is changed into w only in a subst., of the measure faEolaY, of which Y is the final radical, as in taqowaY; so that if it were a subst., it would be raw~aY; (S, M;) originally rawoyaA: (M:) as to ray~aA that is thought to be used as the proper name of a woman, it is, thus used, an epithet, like AlHaArivu and AlEab~aAsu, though without the article Al: (S, * M:) the pl. is rwaA='N, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) with kesr and medd., (S,) in measure like kitaAbN, (Msb,) masc. and fem. (Mgh, Msb.) You say qawomN riwaA='N mina AlmaA='i [A people, or party, satisfied with drinking of water]. (S.) ― -b2- And nabotN ray~aAnu and $ajarN riwaA='N [A plant, or herbage, and trees, having plentiful irrigation: or flourishing and fresh, luxuriant, juicy, succulent, or sappy, by reason of plentiful irrigation: see the verb]. (M.) ― -b3- [Hence,] ray~aAnu signifies also (assumed tropical:) Full of fat and flesh. (JM.) And you say wajohN ray~aAnu (tropical:) [A plump face]; an expression of dispraise [app. when relating to a man, but not otherwise; for ray~aAnu, or ray~aA, applied to a youth, or to a woman, or a limb of a woman, meaning plump and juicy, is used by way of praise]: opposed to wajohN ZamoA=nu. (A and TA in art. ZmA^.) And AimoraA^apN ray~aA Almuxaloxali (assumed tropical:) [A woman full, or plump, in the place of the anklet]. (JM.) And farasN ray~aAnu AlZ~ahori (assumed tropical:) A horse fat in the portion of flesh and sinew next the back-bone on each side. (T.)

raAwK * [as the act. part. n. of rawaY] is used in relation to water [as meaning Bringing, or one who brings, water to his family: and drawing, or one who draws, water for others: and a camel carrying, or that carries, water; whence the subst. raAwiyapN, q. v.]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] it is used also in relation to poetry (T, S, M) and to traditions or narratives or stories (T, M, Mgh, K) [as meaning A relater, reciter, or rehearser, by heart, of poetry, and of traditions, or narratives or stories, learned, or heard, or received, from another]: and in like manner ↓ raAwiyapN, but in an intensive sense [as meaning a large, or copious, relater or reciter or rehearser, &c.]; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) i. e. kaviyru Alr~iwaAyapi; (T, * TA;) as in the phrase rajulN raAwiyapN lil$~iEori [a man who is a large, or copious, relater &c. of poetry]: (S:) the pl. of raAwK is ruwaApN. (S, TA.) -A2- Also One who has the superintendence, management, or care, of horses (mano yaquwmu EalaY Alxayoli [strangely rendered by Freytag, who seems to have read EalaY Aljamali, “ constrictus fune et stans super cameli dorso ”]). (M, K.)

raAwiyapN *
A camel, (A 'Obeyd, T, S, K,) or a mule, or an ass, (S, and so in the K with the exception of “ and ” for “ or, ”) upon which water is drawn: (A 'Obeyd, T, S, K: [see saAniyapN:]) or a camel that carries water; (M, * Mgh, Msb;) and then applied to any beast upon which water is drawn: (Msb:) [but it is disputed whether this be the primary or proper signification, or whether it be secondary or tropical, as will be shown by what follows:] and also a man who draws water (A 'Obeyd, T, TA) for his family: (TA:) the p is affixed [liln~aqoli, i. e. for the purpose of transferring the word from the category of epithets to that of substantives; or] to give intensiveness to the signification: (Msb:) pl. rawaAyaA [by rule rawaA='K, being originally of the measure fawaAEilu, not faEaAy^ilu]. (S, M, TA.) Also A mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag] (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, Mgh) composed of three skins, (Mgh,) containing water; (M, K;) so called as being the receptacle in which is the water borne by the camel [thus called]; (A 'Obeyd, T;) or the mzAdp is thus termed by the vulgar, but this application of the word is allowable as metaphorical: (S:) or it signifies a pair of such water-bags (mazaAdataAni [see mazaAdapN in art. zyd]): (T:) [accord. to ISd,] it is applied to the mzAdp, and then to the camel, because of the nearness of the latter to the former: (M:) or its primary application is to the camel: (S, Mgh:) accord. to some, its application to the camel is proper; and to the mzAdp, tropical: accord. to others, the reverse is the case: (MF, TA:) the pl. is rawaAyaA, as above. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- One says of a weak person who is in easy circumstances, maA yarud~u Alr~aAwiyapa, meaning He is unable to turn back the rAwyp [or camel bearing a water-bag or pair of water-bags,] notwithstanding its being heavily burdened by the water that is upon it. (M.) ― -b3- And the Prophet applied the appellation rawaAyaA AlbilaAdi [The camels bearing water for the irrigation of the countries, or the water-bags borne by camels for the irrigation of the countries,] to (assumed tropical:) the clouds, by way of comparison. (TA.) ― -b4- rawaAyaA is also applied as an appellation to (assumed tropical:) The chiefs of a people; (IAar, Th, T;) as pl. of raAwiyapN; the chief who bears the burden of the bloodwits owed by the tribe being likened to the camel thus termed. (T, M. *) A Temeemee, mentioning a party that had attacked his tribe, said, laqiynaAhumo faqatalonaA Alr~awaAyaA wa A^abaHonaA Alz~awaAyaA meaning [We encountered them, and] we slew the chiefs, and gave permission to occupy, or to plunder, the houses, or tents. (T.) ― -b5- rawaAyaA also occurs in a trad., in which it is said, $ar~u Alr~awaAyaA rawaAyaA Alka*ibi, and accord. to some, it is, in this instance, pl. of raAwiyapN (JM, TA) in the first of the senses explained above; so that the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) The worst of those who carry tidings are those who carry false tidings; such persons being likened to the beasts so called, in respect of the fatigue that they undergo: (JM:) or it is pl. of ↓ rawiy~apN; (JM, TA;) and the meaning is, the worst of thoughts are those that are untrue, not right, nor tending to good: or it is pl. of ↓ riwaAyapN; and the meaning is, the worst of relations, or recitals, are those that are untrue. (JM.) ― -b6- See also raAwK.
A^arowaY * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

A^urowiy~apN * , (T, S, M, Msb, K,) originally [A^urowuwyapN,] of the measure A^ufoEuwilapN, (S, M, Msb,) and A_irowiy~apN, (Lh, M, K,) The female of the wuEuwl, (El-Ahmar,
A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, Msb, K,) which means mountain-goats: (TA:) or the female and the male; the former of which is also called EanozN, and the latter waEilN; (AZ, T, Msb;) and which are of the [kind called] $aA='N; not of the [kind called] baqarN: (AZ, T:) pl. A^araAwiY~N, (El-Ahmar, A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, Msb, K,) of the measure A^afaAEiylu, (S,) a pl. of pauc., Msb,) applied to three (El-Ahmar, A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) and more, to ten [inclusive], (El-Ahmar, A 'Obeyd, T, M, K,) and ↓ A^arowaY, applied to many, (El-Ahmar, A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, Msb, K,) of the measure A^afoEalu, (S, M, Msb,) erroneously held by Abu-l-'Abbás to be of the measure faEolaY; (M;) an irregular pl.; (Msb, K;) or [rather] it is a quasi-pl. n.; (M, K;) and A^arawiY~u is a broken pl. (M.) It is also a proper name of a woman: and so is ↓ A^arowaY. (S.)
murowK * : see riwFY
mirowFY * : see riwaA='N, in two places.

1 rayayotu * and ↓ ray~ayotu, inf. n. of the former raY~N and of the latter taroyiyapN, are both of them verbs relating to Alr~aAyapu: (T:) you say, Alr~aAyapa ↓ ray~ayotu [and rayayotuhaA] I made the raAyap [q. v.]: (M, TA:) the imperative of rayayotu is Airoyaho, and that of ↓ ray~ayotu is ray~iho: and the pass. part. ns. are ↓ maroyiY~N and ↓ muraY~N, each applied to a banner. (T.)
2 raY~a3a see 1, in three places. -A2- You say also, ray~ayotu raA='F I made a r; (M;) or I wrote a r. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np.)

4 A^aroyayotu Alr~aAyapa * ; accord. to Lh, A^aroA^ayotuhaA, [and so in the K, (see 1 in art. rA^Y, near the end of the paragraph,]) but [ISd says,] I hold that this is anomalous, and that it is properly only A^aroyayotuhaA; I stuck, or fixed, [into the ground,] the banner, or standard. (M, TA.)
8 Airotayotuhu * , [as though a contraction of Airotayayotuhu,] for AirotaA^ayotuhu: see raA^aY, first signification.
10 Aisotarayotuhu * , [as though a contraction of Aisotaroyayotuhu, like as AisotaHayotu is a contraction of AisotaHoyayotu,] for AisotaroA^ayotuhu: see raA^aY, first signification.
raY~N * , said in the CK, in art. rA^Y, to be a pl. of raA^oYN: see this latter word.
ruY~N * : see art. rwY. -A2- It is also said in the K, in art. rA^Y, to be pl. of raA^oYN: see this latter word.

riY~N * : see art. rwY -A2- It is also said in the K, in art. rA^Y, to be a pl. of raA^oYN: see this latter word. ― -b2- Also Beauty of aspect; (K; and M in art. rwY;) accord. to him who holds it to be without '; said by AAF to mean beauty as implying namoEapN [and therefore belonging to art. rwY]. (M in art. rwY. [See also riy^oYN, in art. rA^Y.])
riyapN * : see riy^apN, in art. rA^Y.
riyFA * : see riy^oYN, in art. rA^Y.
riy~apN * an inf. n. of raA^aY [q. v.]. (T, M, K; all in art. rA^Y.)
ray~aA * : see art. rwY.
ruy~aA * : see ruw^oyaA, in art. rA^Y.
riy~aA * : see ruw^oyaA, in art. rA^Y.
riy~FA * : see riy^oYN, in art. rA^Y.
ray~aAnu * : see art. rwY.
raAYN * : see what next follows.

raAyapN * , (T, S, M, Msb, K,) and raA='apN, mentioned by Sb on the authority of Abu-l-Khattáb, the A of raAyapN, though a substitute for the medial radical, [i. e. Y,] being likened by him to the augmentative A, and therefore the final radical is made ', like as is done in the case of siqaA='N &c., (M,) A banner, or standard, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) of an army: (Msb:) accord. to some, (Msb,) originally with ', [see raA^oyapN, in art. rA^Y,] though pronounced by the Arabs without '; (T, Msb;) but others deny this, and say that it has not been heard with ': (Msb:) pl. raAyaAtN (M, Msb, K) and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ raAYN. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also A qilaAadp [app. here meaning collar]: (K:) or a thing that is put upon the neck (Lth, T, M, K) of a runaway male slave, (M, K.) to show that he is a runaway: it is an iron ring, of the size of the neck. (TA.) -A2- It is also said to be an inf. n. of raA^aY: see this latter word.
ruyay~apN * dim. of raAyapN. (Lth, T.)

qaSiydapN ray~iy~apN *
An ode of which the rawiY~ [or fundamental rhyme-letter] is r. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np.)
tariy~apN * and tiriy~apN: see taroy^iyapN, in art. rA^Y.
muraY~N * : see the first paragraph.
maroyiY~N * : see the first paragraph.
1 raA='a * (like xaAfa, TA, [app. indicating that its aor. is yaraA='u, like yaxaAfu,]) a dial. var. of raA^aY [He saw; &c.]. (M, K.)

2 ry~A^ fiY AlA^amori *
i. q. raw~aA^a [q. v.]. (T, * K.) -A2- ry~A^hu, inf. n. taroyiy^apN, i. q. fasaHa Eanohu mino xinaAqihi [app. meaning He relaxed the compression of his throat: or he relaxed the cord by which he was being throttled]: (M:) or fasaHa Eano xunaAqihi [which app. has the former meaning: or perhaps means he, or it, relieved his quinsy, so that he had room, or freedom, to breathe]. (K.) -A3- ry~A^ raA='FA He wrote a r. (TA.)

3 rAyA^ fulaAnFA * , (M, K, *) said to be formed by transposition, [i. e. from raA='aY,] inf. n. muraAyaA^apN, (TA,) He feared, or was on his guard against, such a one. (M, K. *) ― -b2- See also 3 in art. rA^Y.

riYo'N * a subst. from raA='a mentioned above: (M, K:) [i. e., it signifies Sight; &c.; like ruw^oyapN:] and raA='N is said by MF to be like it; but this is a mistake, occasioned by his finding Alr~aA=', in a verse, miswritten for Ald~aA='. (TA.) ― -b2- [See also riy^oY.]
qaSiydapN raAy^iy~apN * : see art. rwA^.

1 raAbaniY * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yariybu, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. rayobN (T, M, Mgh, Msb, &c.) and riybapN, (M, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (S, Msb,) It (a thing) occasioned in me disquiet, disturbance, or agitation, of mind: (Ksh and Bd in ii. 1:) [this is the primary signification; (see riybapN;) a signification also borne by ↓ A^araAbaniY; (see the verses of Khálid cited in this paragraph;) whence the other significations here expl. in what follows:] it (a thing) made me to doubt: (Msb: and in like manner raAbahu is expl. in the Mgh:) or it (a thing, M) caused me to have what is termed riybap [i. e. doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion, or doubt combined with suspicion or evil opinion]; as also ↓ A^araAbaniY: (M, K: in both of which this meaning is indicated, but not expressed:) but the latter is said by Lth to be bad: (T:) or, (T, M, Msb,) accord. to AZ, (T, Msb,) the former signifies he, (T, M, *) or it, i. e. his case, (M, * Msb,) made me to know that there was on his part what is termed riybap [i. e. something occasioning doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion, or doubt combined with suspicion or evil opinion]; (T, M, Msb;) made me to be certain, or sure, of it: (Msb:) and ↓ the latter signifies made me to think that there was in him what is so termed; (Sb, T, M, Msb, K;) without my being certain, or sure, of it: (Msb:) [Az says that] these are the right explanations of the two phrases: (T:) [or] the latter signifies also jaEala fiY~a Alr~iyabapa [he put into me, i. e. into my mind, doubt, or suspicion &c.]; (Sb, M, K; and in a similar manner A^arabotuhu is expl. in the latter;) or A^awohamaniY Alr~iybapa [he made me to think that which occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c.]: (K: and in like manner ArAbhu is expl. in the Ham p. 363:) and ribotuhu signifies A^awoSalotu A_ilayohi Alr~iybapa [I made doubt, or suspicion &c., or that which occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c., to come to him, or to reach him]; (K;) [app. by some act; for it is said that] raAbahu signifies A^ataAhu biriybapK [he did to him a thing that occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c.]: (Ham ubi suprà:) or, (K,) accord. to Lh, the Arabs say, (M,) raAbaniY A^amoruhu, aor. yariybuniY, inf. n. rayobN and riybapN: when they speak allusively [with respect to the cause of doubt &c., not expressing it,] (A_i*aA kanawoA [misinterpreted in the TA as meaning “ when they affix a pronoun to the verb, ” for the meaning here intended is clearly shown by what follows,]) they prefix A [to the verb, saying ↓ A^araAba, and A^arabotu, &c., expl. in the latter part of
this paragraph]; and when they do not speak allusively [with respect to the cause of doubt &c., but express it,] (A_i*aA lamo yakonuwA) they reject that letter; but [so accord. to the M, but in the K “ or, ”] it is allowable to say, AlA^amoru ↓ A^araAbaniY; (M, K;) i. e., to prefix the A when the verb is made trans.: (M:) accord. to As, (T,) raAbaniY [signifies he did what made me to doubt, or to have doubt, or suspicion &c, and what I disliked, or hated; for it] is said of a man when thou seest, on his part, what makes thee to doubt, &c., (maA yuriybuka, [or maA yariybuka,]) and what thou dislikest, or hatest: (T, S:) and Hudheyl say, ↓ A^araAbaniY, (T, S, Msb,) or ArAbnY A^amoruhu, as As says on the authority of 'Eesà Ibn-'Omar; (M;) and ribotu and ↓ Airotabotu, meaning I doubted: (Msb:) accord. to IAth, raAbaniY Al$~ak~u [an evident mistranscription for rAbnY Al$~aYo'u] and ↓ ArAbnY both mean $ak~akaniY wa A^awohamaniY Alr~iybapa bihi [i. e. the thing made me to doubt, and caused me to think that there was that which occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c., in it]; but when you are certain, or sure, of it, you say [only] raAbaniY, without [an incipient] A: (TA:) accord. to Lth, raAbaniY AlA^amoru, inf. n. rayobN, signifies the thing, or event, [app. said only of that which is evil,] betided me, or befell me: and raAbaniY A^amoruhu, his affair, or case, brought upon me doubt ($ak~FA [in the TA $ar~FA i. e. evil]) and fear. (T.) It is said in a trad., of Fátimeh, yariybuniY maA yariybuhaA, meaning That displeases and disquiets me which displeases and disquiets her. (TA.) And in another, respecting a gazelle lying curled in sleep, laA yariybuhu A^aHadN bi$aYo'K, meaning No one shall oppose himself to it and disquiet it, or disturb it. (TA.) And in another, maA raAbaka A_ilaY qaToEihaA, i. e. What disquieted thee and constrained thee to cut it off? as Aboo-Moosà thinks the phrase may be read: but see another reading voce raAbN. (TA.) And in another, daEo maA wa A_in~a ↓ yariybuka A_ilaY maA laA yarybuka faA_in~a Alka*iba riybapN AlS~idoqa TumaA^oniynapN, (Mgh, TA, *) or, as some relate it, ↓ yuriybuka, (TA,) i. e. Leave thou that which causeth thee to doubt, (Mgh, TA, *) and occasioneth in thee Alr~iybap, which originally signifies disquiet, or disturbance, or agitation, of mind, [and hence suspicion &c., and betake thyself to that which will not cause thee to doubt, &c., for verily lying is a thing that occasions disquiet of mind, or doubt, or suspicion &c., and verily veracity is a thing that occasions tranquillity;] because the mind is not at rest when it doubts, but becomes tranquil when it is certain, or sure. (Mgh.) And the Hudhalee, (S, TA,) Khálid Ibn-Zuheyr, (TA,) says,
yaA qawomi maA liY wa A^abaA *uw^ayobi
kunotu A_i*aA A^atawotuhu mino gayobi
ya$um~u EiTofiY wa yajur~u vawobiY
birayobi ↓ kaA^an~aniY A^arabotuhu
[O my people, what aileth me with Aboo-Dhueyb? I was (such that) when I came to him after absence, or from being absent, he would smell my side, or my armpit, and pull my garment, as though I disquieted his mind with doubt, or suspicion &c.]: (S and TA, in this art. and in art. bz; but in the latter with yabuz~u in the place of its syn. yajur~u:) it is said in the L that ArAb is trans. and intrans.; and that he who makes it trans. makes it syn. with raAba; and thus it is in the saying of Khálid cited above; the last hemistich of which is also related thus:
kaA^an~aniY qado ribotuhu birayobi
but ↓ ArAb when intrans. signifies A^ataY biriybapK [meaning he did an act that occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c.]; like as A^alaAma signifies A^ataY bimaA yulaAmu Ealayohi [he did an act for which he was to be blamed]: and agreeably with this signification is expl. the verse ascribed to El-Mutalemmis, or to Beshshár Ibn-Burdeh,
A^axuwka Al~a*iY A_ino ribotahu qaAla A_in~amaA
wa A_ino laAyanotahu laAna jaAnibuho ↓ A^arabotu
[Thy brother is he who, if thou make him to doubt, &c., (or if thou do to him an act occasioning doubt, or suspicion &c., as expl. in the Ham p. 363, where EaAtabotahu is put in the place of laAyanotahu,) says, Only I have done what occasions doubt, &c.; and if thou act gently with him, becomes gentle]: thus the verse is correctly related: he who relates it differently, saying A^arabota, [and thus I find it in two copies of the T,] asserts that A_ino ribotahu means if thou make him of necessity to have doubt, or suspicion &c.; and ↓ Arbt [here said in the TA to be “ with damm, ” but this is evidently a mistranscription for “ with fet-h, ” for it cannot mean with damm to the A, as A^uribota does not bear an appropriate signification, nor can it mean with damm to the t, as the explanation relates to the reading of Arbt with fet-h to the t,] means thou hast caused [me] to think that there was that which occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c., when it was not decidedly necessary. (TA.)

4 ArAb * , as a trans. verb: see 1, in eight places. -A2- As intrans., it signifies He (a man) was, or became, one in whom was something occasioning doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion, or doubt combined with suspicion or evil opinion; i. e. SaAra *aA riybapi: (Sb, T, S, M:) and he did a thing that occasioned doubt, or suspicion &c.: (As, T:) it is said when one is told something of a person, or thinks it, or imagines it: (Msb:) see 1, in the former half of the paragraph; and also, in three places, in the latter part of the same paragraph. Also It (a thing, or an affair, or a case,) was, or became, one in which was something occasioning doubt, or suspicion &c.; i. e. SaAra *aA rayobK (T, K) or *A riybapK. (M.)
5 taray~aba see the next paragraph.

8 ArtAb *
He doubted, (S, Msb, K,) fiyhi [respecting him, or it]. (S.) See 1, in the former half of the paragraph. And ArtAb bihi He suspected him, or thought evil of him: (T, M, K:) or he saw on his part [or in him] what caused him to have doubt, or suspicion &c.; as also bh ↓ try~b; (Har p. 257;) and bh ↓ AstrAb; i. e. raA^aY minohu maA yariybuhu: (S, K, and Har ubi suprà:) the last used by [the tribe of] Hudheyl. (TA.) ― -b2- [It often means particularly He was sceptical in matters of religion.]

10 AstrAb *
He fell into that which occasioned doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion; meaning he feared so that he doubted of safety or security: (Har pp. 256 and 257:) [he conceived doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion:] he doubted: and became infected with suspicion or evil opinion. (Idem p. 309.) See also 8.

raAbN *
Want, or need. (TA.) Hence, in a trad., maA rabukumo A_ilayohi What is [the reason of] your want of him? or your wanting to ask him? (TA.) And, in another trad., maA raAbuka A_ilaY qaToEihaA What is [the reason of] thy wanting to cut it off? thus, says El-Khattábee, they relate it, with damm to the b: but IAth says that it is properly maA A^arabuka, meaning the same: or, accord. to Aboo-Moosà, the right reading may be mA raAbaka, expl. in the preceding paragraph. (TA.)

rayobN * is an inf. n. of 1, (T, M, Mgh, Msb, &c.,) as also ↓ riybapN, (M, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.: (S, Msb:) the primary signification of the latter [and of the former also when it is used as a simple subst.] is Disquiet, disturbance, or agitation, of mind: (Ksh and Bd in ii. 1:) [and hence] the former signifies doubt; (T, S, Msb;) as also ↓ the latter; (S, Mgh;) because doubt disquiets, or disturbs, the mind: (Ksh and Bd ubi suprà, and Mgh:) and opinion; syn. Zan~N: (Msb:) and ↓ the latter, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) and the former also, (M, A, K,) doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion; syn. tuhamapN (S, M, A, Mgh, K) and Zin~apN: (M, A, K:) or the former, [and ↓ the latter also,] doubt combined with suspicion or evil opinion: (IAth, TA:) and a thing, or an event, or a case, that occasions one doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion, or doubt combined with suspicion or evil opinion; i. e. maA raAbaka mino A^amorK: (S, TA:) [in this last sense, the latter is the more common: hence,] lying is termed riybapN in a trad. cited above: see 1: (Mgh:) the ↓ pl. of the latter is riyabN. (Msb.) A man, and a thing or an event or a case, is said to be ↓ *uw riybapK [as meaning Having in him, or it, something occasioning doubt, or suspicion &c.]. (A.) [laA rayoba often occurs as meaning There is no doubt; without doubt; undoubtedly.] ― -b2- Hence, rayobu Alz~amaAni The accidents, or evil accidents, of time, (Ksh and Bd ubi suprà, [in Fleischer's ed. of the latter riyab AlzmAn, which is more agreeable with the explanation, but rayob AlzmAn is more usual,]) that disquiet, or disturb, the minds and hearts: (Ksh:) and rayobu Almanuwni (S, A) [which likewise signifies] the accidents, or evil accidents, of time: (S:) and rayobu Ald~ahori signifies the same; i. e. Sarofuhu, (M, K,) or Suruwfuhu, (T, Msb,) and HawaAdivuhu. (T. [This is said in the TA to be tropical; but I do not find
it so characterized in the A.]) ― -b3- [Hence, likewise,] rayobN also signifies A want; a needful, or requisite, thing, affair, or business; syn. HaAjapN. (S, A, Msb, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Kaab Ibn-Málik El-Ansáree, (TA,)
qaDayonaA mino tihaAmapa kul~a rayobK
wa xayobara vum~a A^ajoyayonaA Als~uyuwfaA
[We accomplished, from Tihámeh, every want, and from Kheyber: then we gave rest to our swords]. (S.) -A2- [ryb mentioned by Freytag as applied in art. dls of the S to a certain plant, and written rayob in both of my copies of the S in that art., is a mistake for rabab, which is the reading in the TA, pl. of rib~apN.]
riybapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in six places. ― -b2- [It often means particularly Scepticism in matters of religion.]

A^amorN ray~aAbN *
A thing, or an event, or a case, that frightens, or terrifies. (M, K.)

raAy^ibN * [act. part. n. of 1; Causing, or occasioning, doubt, or suspicion or evil opinion, &c.] IAar says that Aboo-Bekr is related to have said, in his charge to 'Omar, Ealayoka biAlr~aAy^ibi mina AlA^umuwri wa A_iy~aAk wa Alr~aAy^iba minohaA, which Th explains as meaning Keep thou to what is clear, free from dubiousness or confusedness, of affairs, and beware thou of, or avoid thou, what has in it dubiousness, or confusedness, thereof: (T, TA:) the first is from raAba of which the aor. is yaruwbu, said of milk; and the second is from raAba of which the aor. is yariybu. (TA.) [See also a verse cited voce raAy^ibN in art. rwb, and my remark thereon.]

muriybN * , applied to a man, (T, S, A,) and to a thing or an event, (M, A,) i. q. *uw riybapK [expl. above, voce rayobN]. (T, S, M, A.) A_in~ahumo kaAnuwA fiY $ak~K muriybK, in the Kur xxxiv. last verse, means Verily they were in doubt causing to fall into suspicion or evil opinion: or it means *iY riybapK [having in it something occasioning suspicion &c.]: (Ksh and Bd:) or *iY rayobK [which means the same: or attended with disquiet, or disturbance, or agitation, of mind]: (M, TA:) [see its verb, 4:] it may be from the trans. or from the intrans. verb. (Ksh.)

murotaAbN *
Doubting [or suspecting]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [It often means particularly Sceptical, or a sceptic, in matters of religion. -A2- And murotaAbN fiyhi, or bihi, Doubted of, or suspected.]

1 raAva * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yariyvu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. rayovN, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) He, or it, was, or became, slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward; (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ try~v. (T, K.) You say, raAva EalaY~a xabaruka, (S, A,) or rAv EalayonaA xabaruhu, (T,) Thy news or the news of thee, or his news or the news of him, was slow, &c., in coming to me, or to us. (T, S, A.) And EalayonaA fulaAnN ↓ try~v Such a one was slow, &c., in coming to us. (T.) And rub~a EajalapK wa habato rayovFA, or, accord. to one relation of the saying, tahabu rayovFA, the meaning in both cases being the same, from Alhibapu; [i. e. Many an act of haste causes (lit. gives) slowness, &c.;] (S;) or tuEoqibu rayovFA [occasions, as its result, slowness, &c.]: (A:) a proverb. (S, A.) And it appears from the following saying of Maakil Ibn-Khuweylid,
laEamoruka laloyaA^osu gayoru Almuriyvi xayorN mina AlT~amaEi AlkaA*ibi
[By thy life, or by thy religion, assuredly despair that is not slow in its issue is better than hope that gives a false promise, if this be his meaning,] that ↓ ArAv may be a dial. var. of raAva: but the poet may mean [that does not make a man slow, i. e.] gayoru Almuriyvi Almaro'a. (M.)

2 ray~ava see 4. ― -b2- [Hence,] yuray~ivu Aln~aZara, or, accord. to one relation, yuray~ivu A_ilaY~a Aln~aZara, [meaning He is long in looking or he prolongs the looking, and he is long in looking &c. at me,] is mentioned as a phrase used by one of the companions of Ks. (M.) ― -b3- One says also, ray~ava Eam~aA kaAna Ealayohi He fell short, or failed, of doing, or accomplishing, what was incumbent on him: and in like manner, ray~ava A^amorahu [He fell short, or failed, of accomplishing his affair]. (M.) ― -b4- And taroyiyvN signifies The being fatigued, tired, weary, or jaded: (K:) its verb, ry~v, is said of a man or of a horse. (TK.) -A2- taroyiyvN is also syn. with taloyiynN [The rendering a thing soft, &c.]. (K.)

4 A^aroyava see 1, last sentence. -A2- [It is generally transitive.] You say, maA A^araAvaka (K) and ↓ mA ray~avaka (A) What made thee, or hath made thee, slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward? retarded, or delayed, thee? or kept, or held, thee back? (A, K.) And maA A^araAvaka EalayonaA What retarded, or delayed, thee, or what kept, or held, thee back, from us? or what hath retarded, &c.? (S.)
5 taray~ava see 1, in two places.

10 AstrAvhu *
He deemed, or reckoned, him, or it, (namely, a person, A, TA, or information, news, or tidings, TA,) slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward. (S, * M, A, K, * TA.) You say, Aisotagavotuhu famaA A@sotaravotuhu [I sought, or desired, aid, or succour, of him, and I did not deem him slow, &c.]. (A, TA.)

rayovN *
A space, or measure, [of time,] syn. qadorN, (T, Msb,) or miqodaArN; (A, K;) or a time, a while, syn. saAEapN. (Mgh.) You say, A^amohalotuhu rayovamaA faEala ka*aA, i. e. qadora maA faEalahu (Msb) or saAEapa fiEolihi (Mgh) [I granted him a delay during the space of his doing such a thing]. And lamo yalobavo A_il~aA rayovamaA qulotu, i. e. qadora *`lika [He tarried not save during the space that, or as long as, or while, I said such a thing]. (TA, from a trad.) And so in the saying, maA qaEada EinodanaA fulaAnN A_il~aA rayova A^ano Had~avanaA biHadiyvK tum~a mar~a [Such a one sat not with us, or at our abode, save during the space that, or as long as, or while, he related to us a story, or tradition; then he went away]. (T, TA.) And it is used without mA and without An: (TA:) Aashà Báhileh says,
laA yuSoEibu AlA^amora A_il~aA rayova yarokabuhu
wa kul~a A^amorK siwaY AlfaHo$aA='i yaA^otamiru
[He finds not the affair difficult save while he is embarking in it; and every command but that which exceeds the bounds of rectitude he obeys]: (M, TA:) this mode of expression is common in the dial. of El-Hijáz; accord. to which one says, yuriydu yafoEalu, i. e. A^ano yafoEala. (TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce raAjilapN, and another in a verse cited voce riyHN.]

rayovapN *
Slowness, tardiness, dilatoriness, lateness, or backwardness; contr. of EajalapN; like [the inf. n.] rayovN; (Ham p. 503;) i. q. A_iboTaA='N. (Idem p. 640.)
raAy^ivN * : see what next follows.

ray~ivN * , applied to a man, (IAar, S, M,) and, as some say, to anything, (M,) Slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward; (IAar, T, S, M, A, K;) as also ↓ raAy^ivN; (A, TA;) the latter occurring in a trad. (TA.)
muray~avu AlEayonayoni * , (Fr, S, K,) or AlEayoni, (A,) A man (Fr, S, A) slow of sight. (Fr, S, A, K.)
maA fulaAnN bimusotaraAvi Aln~uSorapi * [Such a one is not a person whose aid is deemed slow, tardy, &c.]. (A, TA.)

div1.div2: ryH For several words mentioned under this head in some of the Lexicons, see art. rwH.

div2.entryFree: 2 taroyiydN * , in agriculture, The raising, with the [implement called] mijonab, the ridges that form the borders of streamlets for irrigation. (M.)

rayodN *
A ledge of a mountain, (T, S, M, * A, K,) in [any of] the sides thereof, (A,) resembling a wall; (M;) i. q. HayodN: (S, M, A:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aroyaAdN (M) and (of mult., M) ruyuwdN. (T, S, M, A, K.) tahowiydN EalaY ruyuwdK, (Meyd, TA,) meaning A resting, or sleeping, upon ledges of mountains, (Meyd,) is a prov., applied to him who enters upon an affair [dangerous or] insalutary in its result. (Meyd, TA.)
riydN * : see art. rwd. -A2- Also An equal in age; syn. tirobN; for riy^odN: so in a verse of Kutheiyir cited voce A^uSodapN. (TA.)
riyHN raAdapN * : see what next follows: and see raAdN in art. rwd.

riyHN rayodapN *
A wind blowing gently; as also ↓ rayodaAnapN (T, S, M, A, K) and ↓ raAdapN: (S, M, A, K:) or the first, as some say, that blows much. (M.) [See also raAdN in art. rwd.]
riydapN * : see riydN, in art. rwd.
riyHN rayodaAnapN * : see rayodapN.
Alr~iyaAdu * : see art. rwd.
A^aroyadu * : see art. rwd.

1 raAra *
His (a man's) marrow became thin. (TA.)

4 ArAr mux~ahu *
He, (God, S, K,) and it, (emaciation, TA,) made his marrow to become thin. (S, K, TA.)
raArN * : see what next follows.

rayorN * and ↓ raArN (Fr, S, K) and riyrN (AA, K) Marrow in a melting or fluid state, (K,) and corrupt, by reason of emaciation: (TA:) or thin: (AA:) or corrupt, and in a melting or fluid state, by reason of emaciation: (Fr, S:) or in a melting or fluid and thin state, by reason of emaciation and severe dearth or drought: (TA:) or what was fat, in the bones, and has become black and thin water. (Lh, K.)
wa Als~aAqu min~iY baAdiyaAtu Alr~ayori
[And my shanks (lit. shank) are such that the melting marrow, &c., in them is manifest] means my emaciation is manifest: the poet says bAdyAt because by Als~Aq he means Als~aAqaAni; and it is allowable to make the enunciative of a dual like that of a pl.: accord. to one relation, it is baAridaAtu. (S.) ― -b2- rayorN also signifies The water that comes forth from the mouth of a child. (K.)

div2.head: Quasi rys
div2.entryFree: riyaAsN * : see riy^aAsN, voce raA^osN.
ray~isN * : see ray^iysN, in two places.

1 raA$ahu * , aor. yariy$u, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. rayo$N, (S, Mgh, TA,) He feathered it, namely, an arrow; stuck the feathers upon it: (S, A, * K:) or he repaired it, or put it into a right state, by putting the feathers upon it: (Mgh:) or he repaired, or put into a right state, its feathers: (Msb:) and ↓ ry~$hu, (K,) inf. n. taroyiy$N, (TA,) signifies the same; (K;) and so ↓ ArtA$hu. (TA.) It is said in a prov., fulaAnN laA yariy$u wa laA yaboriY [lit., Such a one neither feathers nor pares arrows]; meaning, (assumed tropical:) Such a one neither profits nor injures. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He fed him, and gave him drink, and clad him; namely, a friend: (K:) (assumed tropical:) he clad him, and aided him; namely, a poor man; because such is like a bird with a clipped wing: (TA:) (assumed tropical:) He (God) restored him, from a state of poverty, to wealth, or competence: (TA:) (tropical:) he strengthened his wing, [or power,] by beneficence to him: (A:) (tropical:) he rectified, or made good, or amended, his state, or condition, (S, K,) and profited him: (K:) (assumed tropical:) he did that which was a means of good to him: or he caused him to attain good: (Msb:) (assumed tropical:) he did good to him: (assumed tropical:) he strengthened him, and aided him to obtain his subsistence. (TA.) In the saying of Dhu-r-Rummeh,
raA$a AlguSuwna $akiyruhaA
(assumed tropical:) [Their shoots clad the branches: or surpassed in length the branches:] it is said to mean kasaA: or, accord. to AA, TaAla: but the former meaning is the better known. (TA.) [It is also doubly trans.:] you say, raA$ahu A@ll~`hu maAlFA (assumed tropical:) God gave him property. (TA, from a trad.) -A2- raA$a, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) [seems to have originally signified, when used intransitively, He became feathered. ― -b2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) He collected ry$, meaning, property, and A^avaAv [or household goods, or furniture and utensils, &c.]. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- And He (a man) became rich, or in a state of competence: (Fr:) and ↓ try~$ (assumed tropical:) he became wealthy, or abundant in wealth. (Bd in vii. 25.) [See also 8]. -A3- He (a bird) shed many feathers. (TA.)
2 ray~a$a see 1, first sentence.
5 taray~a$a see 8, in two places: and see 1, last sentence but two.

8 ArtA$ * (tropical:) He became strengthened in his wing, [or power,] by being an object of beneficence; as also ↓ try~$: (A:) he became in a good state, or condition: (S:) he attained good: (Msb:) he obtained good, and the effect thereof was seen upon him; as also ↓ the latter verb. (TA.) [See also 1, last sentence but two.] -A2- ArtA$hu: see 1, first sentence.
raA$N * A bird whose feathers have grown. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) A man possessing property and clothing; as also ↓ A^aroya$u. (TA.) -A2- See also the next paragraph.

riy$N * [Feathers; plumage;] a certain appertenance of birds, (S, A, Msb, K,) well known, (A, Msb,) constituting their clothing and ornament; (A, TA;) as also ↓ raA$N: (Kt, K:) n. un. of the former with p: (S, Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aroyaA$N (S, K) and [of mult.] riyaA$N. (IJ, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (B,) (tropical:) Clothing: (ISk, B:) or superb, or excellent, clothing; as also ↓ riyaA$N: (S, K:) or both signify what appears of clothing: (Kt:) the former occurs in the Kur vii. 25, accord. to one reading; (S;) and ↓ the latter accord. to another reading: (TA:) and hence also, the former signifies (tropical:) ornament; and beauty: (A, TA: *) or ↓ both signify (assumed tropical:) property; and plenty, or abundance of the produce of the earth and of the goods or conveniences and comforts of life: (S:) or the former signifies (assumed tropical:) good; or prosperity; or wealth: (Msb:) and (assumed tropical:) state; or condition: (TA:) and ↓ the latter, (assumed tropical:) property: (Msb:) and (tropical:) goodness of state or condition; (A, TA;) or a goodly state or condition: (Msb:) or the former signifies, (K,) and ↓ the latter also, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) plenty, or abundance of the produce of the earth and of the goods or conveniences and comforts of life; and the means of subsistence: (K, TA:) and (assumed tropical:) property which one has acquired for himself: and A^avaAv [or (assumed tropical:) household-goods, or furniture and utensils, &c.]: (TA:) the Benoo-Kiláb say that ↓ the latter word means (assumed tropical:) household-goods of whatever kind, consisting of clothes, or stuffing for mattresses or the like, or outer garments: and sometimes it means (tropical:) clothes, exclusively of other articles or kinds of property. (ISk, TA.) You say, A_in~ahu laHasanu Alr~iy$i (tropical:) Verily he is goodly in clothing, or apparel. (TA.) Respecting the saying, A^aEoTaAhu miAy^ipF biriy$ihaA, it is said, (S, A, * K,) by AO, (S,) that kings, when they gave a gift, put upon the humps of the camels [that bore it] ostrich-feathers, (S, K,) or [other] feathers, (A, TA,) in order that it might be known to be the king's gift; (S, A, K;) and the meaning is, accord. to As, [He gave him a hundred camels] with their saddles (S, A *) and their coverings: (S:) or with their coverings and their cloths beneath the saddles. (K.)
riyaA$N * : see riy$N, (of which it is a syn. as well as a pl.,) in several places.

raAy^i$N * : see mariy$N. -A2- Also (tropical:) An agent between two persons, (A, Mgh, K,) namely, the briber and the accepter of a bribe, (Mgh, K,) who composes their affair, (Mgh,) or who gives (yariy$u) this one of the property of that. (A.) Such Mohammad cursed. (Mgh, TA.) [See raA$K, in art. r$w.)
A^aroya$u * : see raA$N.

mariy$N * , applied to an arrow, Feathered; or having the feathers stuck upon it; (S, A, * K;) as also ↓ muray~a$N: (A, K:) or having its feathers repaired, or put into a right state: (Msb:) and ↓ raAy^i$N signifies [the same: (see raA$a:) or] having feathers; (K;) being like daAfiqN applied to water [in the sense of *uw dafoq]. (TA.) Hence the saying, maA lahu A^aqa*~u wa laA mariy$N [lit., He has not a featherless arrow nor a feathered one]; meaning, (assumed tropical:) he has not anything. (S.)

muray~a$N * : see mariy$N. ― -b2- Also, applied to the kind of garment called burod, (A, K,) an epithet similar to musah~amN: (A:) signifying (tropical:) Figured (Lh, K) with marks in the forms of feathers. (Lh.)
rayoTN * : see what follows.

rayoTapN *
Any [covering for the body such as is called] mulaA='ap not of two pieces (S, Mgh, Msb, K) joined together (Mgh, TA) by sewing or the like, (TA,) but a single piece, (S, K,) all one web: (K:) it is said by Az to be, without exception, white: (TA:) or it signifies, (Mgh, K,) or signifies also, sometimes, (Msb,) any garment, or piece of cloth, that is thin (Mgh, Msb, K) and soft; (Mgh, K;) so says ISk, on the authority of certain of the Arabs of the desert; (TA;) as also ↓ raAy^iTapN: (K:) and a napkin with which the hands are wiped after food: (TA, from a trad., expl. by Sufyán:) [in Har p. 294, q. v., it seems to be applied to a kind of woollen cloth used as a turban:] pl. ↓ rayoTN [or this is rather a coll. gen. n. of which rayoTapN is the n. un.] and riyaATN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- You say, xaraja mu$otamilFA birayoTapi AlZ~alomaA='i (tropical:) [He went forth enveloped with the mantle of darkness]. (TA.) And huwa yajur~u riyaATa AlHamodi (tropical:) [app. meaning He is prolix in praise]. (TA.) ― -b3- The pl. riyaATN
also signifies (assumed tropical:) Something resembling the saraAb [or mirage] in the desert. (TA.)
raAy^iTapN * : see above.

1 raAEa * , aor. yariyEu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. rayoEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ruyuwEN (TA) and riyaAEN (Lh, TA) and rayaEaAnN, (TA,) It increased, or augmented; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) said of wheat and other things: or, as some say, it denotes ziyaAdap [i. e. it signifies it became redundant, or it exceeded, as will be seen in what follows; but the truth is, that it has both of these significations; the latter] in relation to flour, and to bread. (TA.) You say, raAEati AlHinoTapu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. tariyEu, inf. n. rayoEN [&c.]; (Msb;) and ↓ A^araAEat, (S, K,) which latter is said by Az to be more commonly used than the former; (TA;) and AlT~aEaAmu ↓ ray~aEa [which is the same as ray~aEati AlHinoTapu]; (TA;) The wheat increased, or augmented; or received increase and blessing from God; or throve by the blessing of God: (S, Msb, K, TA:) and in like manner one says of other things. (Msb.) And raAEati Al$~ajarapu, and ↓ ArAEt, but the former is rare, The tree became abundant in its produce, or fruit. (AHn.) And sometimes they said, (S,) AlA_ibilu ↓ ArAEt (S, IF, K) (tropical:) The camels had many young ones; (S;) they increased, and had many young ones. (IF, K.) One says also, raAEa AlT~aEaAmu, and ↓ ArAE, The wheat became redundant; or had a part, or portion, redundant; [app. meaning, over and above the original measure;] in the kneading and the making of bread; syn. SaAra lahu ziyaAdapN. (S.) [See the first sentence above; and see rayoEN, below.] And raAEa fiY yadiY ka*aA Such a thing was redundant, or remained over and above, in my hand; as also raAqa; syn. zaAda: (L in this art., and TA in art. rwE:) Sgh has mistranscribed the explanation, zAd, in his two books, [the TS and the O,] writing faAda; and the author of the K has imitated him in mentioning this in art. rwE, instead of the present art., which is its proper place, but has written for the explanation A^afaAda. (TA.) -A2- raAEa, aor. yariyEu, (IDrd, S, K,) inf. n. rayoEN, (S, TA,) He, or it, returned; went, or came, back; reverted: (IDrd, S, K:) and raAEa, aor. yaruwEu, (IDrd, and K in art. rwE,) inf. n. ruwaAEN, (K in that art.,) signifies the same; (IDrd, and K in art. rwE;) or it returned to its place: (TA in that art.:) but the former verb is the more common. (TA in the present art.) One says, of camels that have run away, SaAHa EalayohaA Alr~aAEiY faraAEato A_ilayohi [The pastor cried out at them, and] they returned to him. (TA.) And waEaZotuhu faA^abiY A^ano yariyEa [I exhorted him, but he refused] to return, or revert. (TA.) And fulaAnN maA yariyEu bikalaAmika walA biSawotika Such a one does not return, or revert, by reason of thy speech nor by reason of thy voice. (TA.) And you say of vomit, raAEa minohu $aYo'N Somewhat of it returned: (S:) and raAEa Ealayohi it returned to his inside. (TA.) And in like manner one says of anything that returns to him, raAEa, aor. yariyEu. (TA.) ― -b2- raAEuwA, They drew, gathered, or collected, themselves together; (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA;) as also ↓ try~EwA; and ↓ ry~EwA, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) inf. n. taroyiyEN. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 5. -A3- It became rent: so in the saying of El-Kumeyt,
A_i*aA HiySa minohu jaAnibN raAEa jaAnibN
[When a side thereof is sewed up, a side becomes rent]. (S.) -A4- [It is also said that] raAEa, aor. yariyEu, is like rad~a [app. as signifying He returned a reply, or an answer, to a person; for it is mentioned immediately after rayoEN as syn. with marojuwEN]. (TA.)

2 ry~E AlT~aEaAmu * : see 1; second sentence. ― -b2- ry~EwA They ascended, or ascended upon, the riyEap [n. un. of riyEN, q. v.]. (Ibn- 'Abbád.) ― -b3- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph. -A2- ry~Ehu: see 4. -A3- [See also ruy~iha (in art. ryh), with which ruy~iEa seems to be syn.]

4 ArAEvi AlHinoTapu * ; &c.: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in four places. ― -b2- ArAEwA Their wheat increased, or augmented; or received increase and blessing from God; or throve by the blessing of God: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) and in like manner, their seed-produce [in general]. (TA.) -A2- ArAE Al$~aYo'a He increased, or augmented, the thing; or made it to increase, or augment; as also ↓ ry~Ehu. (TA.)

5 try~EwA * : see 1, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- try~E said of grease, or gravy, (TA,) or oil, (S,) and of clarified butter, when much thereof has been put into food; (S, TA;) or of melted grease in a bowl; (A, TA;) or of clarified butter upon a cake of bread; (ISh, TA;) It flowed, or ran, hither and thither, having no direct course; (S, TA;) or went to and fro; (A, TA;) or portions thereof followed a little after other portions: (ISh, TA:) and, said of water, it ran, or flowed. (TA.) ― -b3- In like manner, (S,) said of the mirage (saraAb), [It quivered, vibrated, or moved to and fro;] it came and went; (S, K;) as also taray~aha: (TA:) and ↓ raAEa, aor. yariyEu, (TA,) inf. n. rayoEN (K, TA) and rayaEaAnN, (TA,) said of the same, it was, or became, in a state of commotion or agitation; it quivered, vibrated, or moved to and fro. (K, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He became confounded, or perplexed, [as though vacillating, or wavering,] and unable to see his right course; as also ↓ AstrAE. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He paused; or waited: (O, L, K:) or (so in the L, but in the O and K “ and ”) he paused; or hesitated; or held, refrained, or abstained. (O, L, K.) [See the part. n., below.] ― -b6- taray~aEato yadaAhu biAljuwdi (tropical:) His two hands overflowed with bounty, [as though they went hither and thither,] for one cause after another. (TA.)
10 A_isotaroyaEa see 5.

rayoEN * [see 1, of which it is an inf. n.] Increase; syn. ziyaAdapN [which may be meant to include the third of the significations here following]; as in the saying, h`*aA TaEaAmN kaviyru Alr~ayoEi [This is wheat of much increase]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Revenue arising from the increase of land: because it is an augmentation. (Mgh.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Milk; as in the phrase, naAqapN kaviyrapN rayoEuhaA (tropical:) [A she-camel whose milk is abundant]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- Redundance; a part, or portion, redundant; a surplus; or a residue; syn. faDolN; of anything; as of flour, or meal, (Msb, K,) over and above the measure of the wheat; (Msb;) and of dough [when it has risen]; and of seed for sowing [when it has been sown]; and the like. (K.) Hence it is said, in a trad. of I'Ab, respecting the expiation of an oath, likul~i misokiynK mud~N mino HinoTapK rayoEuhu A_idaAmuhu [To every poor man, a mudd of wheat: the redundance, or redundant part or portion, thereof shall be for its seasoning]: i. e., it is not necessary for the person to give, with the mudd, seasoning; but the redundance that shall arise, of the flour, or meal, of the mudd [of wheat], when he shall have ground it, therewith shall the seasoning be bought. (TA.) Hence also, the trad. of 'Omar, AimolikuwA AlEajiyna faA_in~ahu A^aHadu Alr~ayoEayoni (assumed tropical:) Knead ye well, or thoroughly, or soundly, the dough; for this action is one of the rayoEaAni [here meaning the two causes of redundance; the other cause being the grinding]. (TA.) [Hence also,] rayoEu Ald~iroEi The redundant parts of the two sleeves of the coat of mail, (S, A, K, TA,) over [and beyond] the ends of the fingers; (TA;) and of the skirt thereof. (A, TA.) ― -b5- See also riyEN. ― -b6- Also, (K,) and ↓ rayoEaAnN, [which latter is the more common in this sense,] (S, K,) (tropical:) The first (S, K) and most excel-lent (K) part of anything: (S, K:) said in the B to be a metaphorical application from rayoEN as signifying a high, or an elevated, place. (TA.) Hence, (S, TA,) rayoEu Al$~abaAbi, by poetic license written ↓ rayaE, (TA,) or Al$~abaAbi ↓ rayoEaAnu, (S, A, L, TA,) (tropical:) The first, or prime, (S, A, TA,) and most excellent, (A, TA,) part, or period, of youth or youthfulness or youthful vigour: (S, A, TA:) or this is from rayoEN in relation to wheat: (A, TA:) or from AlmaTari ↓ rayoEaAnu (assumed tropical:) the first of rain. (L, TA.) Hence also, (S,) Als~araAbi ↓ rayoEaAnu (S, Sgh, L) (assumed tropical:) The first of the mirage; (S, Sgh;) what comes and goes thereof; (Sgh;) or such as is in a state of commotion or agitation, quivering, vibrating, or moving to and fro. (L.) [Hence also,] rayoEu AlD~uHaY (tropical:) The whiteness, and beautiful splendour, of the first part of the day after sunrise. (K, TA.) ― -b7- naAqapN lahaA rayoEN (tropical:) A she-camel having one pace, or rate of going, [app. a quicker pace,] after another. (TA.) ― -b8- fulaAnN layosa lahu rayoEN i. e. marojuwEN [app. meaning Such a one has no reply, or answer, to give: or, perhaps, to such a one there is no reply, or answer, to be given]. (K, * TA.) -A2- Also Fright, or fear; (K;) like rawoEN. (TA.)

riyEN * (Fr, S, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ rayoEN, (Fr, K,) the former occurring, (S,) or the latter accord. to one reading, (TA,) in the Kur [xxvi. 128], (S, TA,) High, or elevated, land or ground: (S, K:) or a high, or an elevated, place; (so in some copies of the S and in the Msb;) which latter
signification is also assigned to ↓ riyEapN; (TA;) and whence the phrase, kamo riyEu A^aroDika, meaning what is the elevation of thy land?
