[a phrase not to be mistaken for kamo rayoEu A^aroDika, in which the meaning is “ increase: ”] (Az, TA:) or any [road such as is termed] faj~: (K:) or (so accord. to the Msb and K, but in the S “ and ”) a road (S, Msb, K) of any kind, (K, TA,) to which some add, whether travelled or not: (TA: [see an ex. in the first paragraph of art. smt:]) or a road opening so as to form a gap in a mountain; (Zj, K;) or, as in some copies of the K, from a mountain; but the former is what is termed faj~N, before mentioned: (TA:) or a mountain; (S, Msb;) so accord. to 'Omárah: (S:) or, as in some copies of the S, a small mountain: (TA:) or signifying also a high mountain: (O, K:) n. of un. with p [i. e. ↓ riyEapN, as it is written in the S; and ↓ rayoEapN also, as implied in the K]: (S, K: [in the former immediately following the signification of “ mountain; ” and in the latter, so following that of “ high mountain; ” whence it seems that riyEN and rayoEN are sometimes used, at least in one sense, as coll. gen. ns.:]) pl. [of mult.] riyaAEN, (S, TA,) which is extr., (TA,) and ruyuwEN, and [of pauc.] A^aroyaAEN: (TA:) but AO says, contr. to J, that ↓ riyEapN is pl. of riyEN: (IB, TA:) or riyEN and rayoEN signify the channel of the torrent of a valley from any, or every, high, or elevated, place. (K.) Also the former, A high mound, or heap of sand, or hill: and a Christian's cloister or cell; syn. SawomaEapN: and a pigeon-turret. (IAar, K.)
rayaEu Al$~abaAbi * : see rayoEN.
rayoEapN * : see riyEN.
riyEapN * : see riyEN, in three places. -A2- Also A number of men who have drawn, gathered, or collected, themselves together: (Ibn-'Abbád, K: *) otherwise, they are not so called. (Ibn-'Abbád.)
rayoEaAnN * : see rayoEN, in four places.
rayoEaAnapN * (tropical:) A she-camel abounding with milk. (A, K, TA.)

farasN raAy^iEN *
A fleet, or swift, and excellent, horse. (S, TA.) [See also art. rwE, to which, as well as to the present art., it is said in the TA to belong.]

tariyEN A^rAE rAE ryE tryE
A register in which is written the rayoE [i. e. increase, or revenue arising from the increase, of the lands] of districts: the t being augmentative: but it is a post-classical word. (TA.)
A^aroDN mariyEapN * , with fet-h to the m, A land [of much rayoE, or increase;] abounding with herbage; fruitful; or plentiful. (S, Msb, TA.)
muray~aEN * , as an epithet applied to the saraAb [or mirage]: see muray~ahN, in art. ryh.

miroyaAEN * A she-camel that goes away in the place of pasturing and returns by herself; (K;) or such is termed misoyaAEN miroyaAEN: (S, TA:) or upon which one repeatedly journeys: or upon which one journeys and returns: (Az, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) that quickly yields an abundant flow of milk: or (assumed tropical:) that quickly becomes fat: (K:) sometimes used in this sense. (Jm, TA.)

mutaray~iEN * (tropical:) A slippery man, who anoints himself with oils. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- A^anaA mutaray~iEN Eano h`*aA AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) I am holding, refraining, or abstaining, from this affair. (TA.)

2 ry~g * (assumed tropical:) He smeared, seasoned, imbued, or soaked, a mess of variyd [i. e. broken, or crumbled, bread, biAld~asami] with grease, or gravy, or dripping; i. q. raw~agahaA (En-Nadr, K, TA) biAld~asami (En-Nadr, TA.)

5 try~gt All~uqomapu biAls~amoni * (assumed tropical:) The morsel, or mouthful, was [smeared, seasoned,] imbued, or soaked, (taraw~at,) with clarified butter. (En-Nadr, TA.) [In the CK, and in some MS. copies of the K, this verb is mentioned as quasi-pass. of 2.]
riygN * : see what next follows.

riyaAgN * , as in the [T and] O and Tekmileh and L; in the K, erroneously, ↓ riygN; (TA;) Dust, or dust raised: (Sh, K:) or, as some say, (TA,) dust, or earth, (K, TA,) in a general sense: or such as is comminuted. (TA.) Ru-beh says, describing an ass [i. e. a wild ass] and his females,
waA_ino A^avaArato mino riyaAgK samolaqaA
tahowiY HawaAmiyhaA bihi mudaq~aqaA
using an inversion, for he means A^avaArato riyaAgFA mino samolaqK [i. e. And if they raise earth from a level plain, the sides of their hoofs make it to fall down reduced to powder]. (TA.) -A2- And i. q. nifaArN [The act of fleeing, going away or aside or apart or to a distance, retiring to a distance, shrinking, &c.; inf. n. of nafara, q. v.]: (K:) so some say. (TA.) -A3- Sgh says that this word may belong to the present art. and to art. rwg, q. v. (TA.)
maraAgN * , signifying The place in which beasts roll, or turn themselves over, is thought by Az to be so called from riyaAgN in the first of the senses assigned to it above. (TA.)
muray~agN * A thing defiled with dust or earth, or much sprinkled with dust. (El-'Azeezee, K.)

1 raAfa * , aor. yariyfu, He (a man of the desert) came to the riyf; (T, O, K;) as also ↓ A^aroyafa and ↓ try~f: (K:) or he entered the region, district, or tract, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land: or raAfuwA signifies they approached the riyf; and so ↓ try~fwA: (Ham p. 676:) or this last, they journeyed to the riyf; (M;) and so ↓ A^aroyafuwA: (S, * M:) or ↓ try~fnA, we abode, or stayed, in [a region of] cities, towns, or villages, and where water was reached by digging, or where it was apparent, running upon the surface of the earth. (T.) ― -b2- And raAfati AlmaA$iyapu The cattle pastured in the riyf. (S, K.)

3 rAyf lilZ~in~api *
He was, or became, near to [having, or incurring] AlZ~in~ap [i. e. suspicion, or evil opinion]; syn. qaArafahaA, and Tan~afa lahaA. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.) [Freytag, app. misled by the TK, renders rAyf, followed by l, as meaning “ Falsa protulit, calumniis accusavit. ” He also assigns to rAyf the signification of “ Adpropinquavit regioni ryf, ” as on the authority of the Ham; in which I do not find it.]

4 A^aroyafa see 1, in two places. ― -b2- ArAft AlA^aroDu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. A_iraAfapN and [accord. to some] ↓ riyfN; like AxSbt, inf. n. A_ixoSaAbN and xiSobN; but, [ISd says,] in my opinion, A_iraAfapN is the inf. n., and riyfN is the subst.; and in like manner one should say of A_ixoSaAbN and xiSobN; (M, TA;) The land abounded, or became abundant, with herbage, and with the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; (S, M, * K;) as also A^aroyafat. (K.)
5 taray~afa see 1, in three places.

raAfN *
Wine: (T, K:) more properly mentioned in art. rwf. (TA.)

riyfN *
Land in which are sown fields, or seedproduce, and abundance of herbage and of the goods or conveniences or comforts of life: (S, O, K:) and (K) the part that is near to water, of the land of the Arabs, (M, O, L, K,) and of other lands: (M, L:) or the part that is near to the Sawád (Als~awaAd), of the land of the Arabs: (IDrd, Ham p. 676:) or a tract in which are green herbs, and waters, (T, O, K,) and level lands of seed-produce, (T,) or sown fields, or varieties of seed-produce: (O, K:) [generally,] a region, district, or tract, [of cultivated fields; or] of towns, or villages, and of cultivated land: (Ham p. 676:) pl. A^aroyaAfN (T, S, M, TA) and ruyuwfN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Also (M, K) Abundance (Lth, T, M, O, K) of herbage, and of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life, and (Lth, T, M) in respect of food (Lth, T, M, O, K) and drink: (O, K:) pl. [in this sense] A^aroyaAfN (M, K) only. (M.) See also 4.

riyfiY~N * [Of, or belonging to, the riyf, or region of cultivated land; opposed to bar~iY~N;] applied to a plant [&c.]. (M, voce EuSofurN.) And A^aroDN riyfiy~apN Cultivated land; contr. of bar~iy~apN. (IAar, and M and K * and TA in art. br.)

A^aroDN ray~ifapN *
Land abounding with herbage, and with the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (S, O, K.)

1 raAqa * , (JK, S, K,) aor. yariyqu, inf. n. rayoqN, (JK, S,) said of the saraAb [or mirage], It was agitated, and moved to and fro, (JK, K,) or it shone, or glistened, (S,) above the ground; (JK, S, K;) and ↓ try~q signifies the same. (S, O, K.) [And in the former sense, rAq may be said of water; for the inf. n.] rayoqN signifies also The going to and fro (Lth, JK, K) of water, (JK,) or of
shallow water and the like, (Lth, K,) upon the surface of the earth. (Lth, JK, K.) ― -b2- Also, (Ks, JK, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ks, Msb,) said of water, (Ks, JK, Msb, K,) and of blood, (Msb,) It poured out, or forth. (Ks, Msb, K.) ― -b3- huwa yariyqu binafosihi, (JK, S, K,) inf. n. ruyuwqN (S, K) and rayoqN, (TA,) (tropical:) He gives up his spirit; or gives away his life; syn. yajuwdu bihaA; (JK, S, K;) at death: (S, K:) mentioned by Ks. (TA.)

2 ray~aqotuhu Al$~araAba *
I gave him to drink the wine, or beverage, fasting; when he had not yet eaten. (TA.)

4 ArAqhu *
He poured it out, or forth. (Msb, K.) See art. rwq.
5 taray~aqa see 1, first sentence.
6 humaA yataraAyaqaAni AlmaA='a * and yataraAwaqaAnihi (JK) They two pour the water out, or forth, by turns. (TA in explanation of the latter in art. rwq.)

rayoqN *
A shining, or glistening, (K, TA,) of a sword [&c.]. (TA.) Hence, in a trad. respecting [the battle of] Bedr, faA_i*aA birayoqi sayofK mino waraAy^iY [And lo, the shining, or glistening, of a sword behind me]: thus written by El-Wákidee: if the reading bariyqu [from baraqa] had been transmitted, it would be evidently reasonable. (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. baATilN [as meaning False, or vain, speech or conduct]. (K.) One says, A^aqoSiro Eano rayoqika [Desist thou from thy false, or vain, speech or conduct]. (TA.) ― -b3- rayoqu All~ayoli, with fet-h [to the r], The saraAb [or mirage]. (TA.) ― -b4- rayoqN also signifies Water: (K:) or water that is drunk in the state of fasting, in the early morning, or first part of the day; (TA;) [and] so ↓ raAy^iqN, which is [said to be] not applied [in this sense] to anything but water: you say maA='N raAy^iqN. (S.) [But see raAy^iqN.] ― -b5- And xubozN rayoqN (IDrd, K) and ↓ raAy^iqN (As, JK, K) Dry bread; i. e. bread without seasoning, or condiment, to render it pleasant, or savoury. (As, JK, IDrd, K.) ― -b6- See also ray~iqN: both are also mentioned in art. rwq q. v.

riyqN *
Saliva; syn. ruDaAbN; (S, K, TA;) i. e. (TA) the water of the mouth; (JK, Msb, K, TA;) its luEaAb: (TA:) or the water of the mouth in the early morning, or first part of the day; (Lth, TA: [but this rendering is often inapplicable:]) or the water of the mouth while it is therein; for when it has gone forth from the mouth it is termed buSaAqN and buzaAqN and busaAqN: (K in art. bSq:) and ↓ riyqapN signifies the same, in poetry: (Msb, TA:) or this has a more particular meaning; (S, Msb, * K;) [i. e. it means somewhat of saliva; or a little saliva:] the pl. is A^aroyaAqN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, K, TA) and riyaAqN [a pl. of mult.]. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, A^aboliEoniY riyqiY [Suffer thou me to swallow my saliva;] give thou me time to swallow my saliva: (K and TA in art. blE:) or (assumed tropical:) grant thou me some delay, or let me alone for a while, that I may say, or do, such a thing. (Har p. 164.) [And AibotalaEa riyqah He swallowed his saliva: meaning (assumed tropical:) he restrained his anger: see 1 in art. blE.] And $uriba EalaY Alr~iyqi [It was drunk in the state of fasting; before breakfast]: (S, K:) and in like manner A^ukila [It was so eaten]. (K.) And huwa EalaY Alr~iyqi, (AO, S, K,) or EalaY riyqihi, (TA,) and ↓ huwa ray~iqN, (AO, S, K,) of the measure fayoEilN, (S,) and ↓ raAy^iqN, (K,) i. e. [He is fasting;] he has not breakfasted. (TA.) And A^atayotuhu EalaY riyqK (ISk, S) and EalaY riyqi nafosiY, (S, TA,) and ↓ A^atayotuhu ray~iqFA and ↓ raAy^iqFA, I came to him [fasting,] not having eaten anything. (ISk, S, TA.) [Hence also riyqu Al$~amosi, likewise called luEaAbu Al$~amosi and muxaATu Al$~amosi and riyqu Al$~ayaATiyni and muxaATu Al$~ayoTaAni, (tropical:) The fine filmy cobwebs termed gossamer: see arts. lEb and mxT.] ― -b2- Also Strength: and the remains of life, or of the spirit, or of the soul: syns. quw~apN and ramaqN [which latter, it should be observed, has both of these meanings, so that possibly only the former meaning may be here intended]. (K.) You say, kaAna h`*aA AlA^amoru wabinaA riyqN This event happened when there was in us strength. (TA.)

[
rayoqapN * , accord. to Freytag, as occurring in the Deewán El-Hudhaleeyeen, signifies The beginning of youth: but perhaps this may be a mistake, occasioned by some one's saying that the beginning of youth is termed ryqh, meaning rayoquhu.]
riyqapN * : see riyqN. ― -b2- *w Alryqp is said by Z to be the name of a sword of Murrah Ibn-Rabee'ah. (TA: but the vowel-signs are not there written.)

raAy^iqN * Anything eaten, or drunk, EalaY Alr~iyqi [i. e. in the state of fasting; before breakfast]. (K.) See also rayoqN, in two places. ― -b2- And see riyqN, likewise in two places. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Empty-handed. (K.) You say, jaA='a raAy^iqFA (assumed tropical:) He came empty [-handed]. (JK.) -A2- Also Pure; (As, K;) applied to musk, and to anything. (As, TA.) [Mentioned also in art. rwq.] -A3- Also said to signify vwb Ejn bAlmsk [i. e. Eujina biAlmisoki, app. meaning that it is an epithet applied to a garment as signifying Sprinkled with musk and then pressed, or kneaded]. (TA.)

ray~iqN * : see riyqN, in two places. -A2- Also, (S,) and ↓ rayoqN, (S, K,) which is a contraction of the former, sometimes used, (S,) and ↓ ray~uwqN, (AO, K,) The first part, (S, K,) and the most excellent, of anything, as, for instance, of youth, and of rain. (S.) [The first and second are also mentioned in art. rwq, q. v. J cites here, and ascribes to Lebeed, as an ex. of the second of these words, a verse which I have cited in the third paragraph of art. ErD, but with rawoqa in the place of rayoqa, from the TA, in which it is ascribed to ElBa'eeth.]
ray~uwqN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
tiroyaAqN tryAq , said in the T to be so called because containing the saliva of serpents, is explained in art. trq. (TA.)

maraAqN * [app. a n. of place from raAqa having for its aor. yariyqu said of water; though anomalous; for by rule it should be mariyqN;] The part, of the throat, which is the place of passage of the water. (T and TA in art. drA^: see the last sentence of the first paragraph of that art.)

muray~aqN * One in whom a thing ceases not to induce wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy; or whom a thing ceases not to please, or rejoice: (K:) occurring in a verse of Ru-beh: but Sgh says that it should by rule be muraw~aqN. (TA.)
1 raAla * , aor. yariylu, He (a child) slavered. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.) [See also art. rwl.]

riyaAlN *
Slaver; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) [like ruwaAlN;] without '. (TA.)

1 rayomN * is syn. with baraAHN; (Lth, T, M, K;) and the verb is raAma, aor. yariymu, [He went away, or departed; and he quitted a place: and he ceased doing a thing:] (Lth, T, TA:) rayomN being the inf. n. (TA.) IAar used to say, in relation [or reply] to the saying maA rimotu [I did not go away, &c., or I have not gone away, &c.], balaY qado rimotu [Nay, I did go away, &c., or I have gone away, &c.]: but others use the verb only with a negative particle: (T:) or it is mostly used in negative phrases. (TA.) You say, raAmahu, aor. yariymuhu, (S, Mgh,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He went away from it, departed from it, or quitted it; syn. bariHahu; (S;) or zaAla minohu, and faAraqahu; namely, his place. (Mgh.) And rimotu fulaAnFA and ramotu mino Einodi fulaAnK [I went away from such a one]: both meaning the same. (S.) And laA tarimohu Go not thou away from him, or it; syn. laAtaboraHohu. (S.) And maA rimotu AlmakaAna and maA rimotu minohu (M, K) I went not from the place; syn. maA bariHotu. (K.) And maA rimotu A^afoEalu *`lika (M, * K, * TA) I ceased not doing that; syn. maA bariHotu. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. tabaAEudN [The being, or becoming, distant, remote, far off, or aloof; &c.]: (T, K:) [you say,] maA yariymN [He does not become distant, &c.]. (T.) [Accord. to the TK, it is, in this sense, inf. n. of raAmahu, aor. as above, meaning He was, or became, distant, &c., from it.] ― -b3- And An inclining, or a leaning, in the load of a camel, (K, TA,) by reason of excess and heaviness thereof. (TA.) One says, lih`*aA AlEidoli rayomN EalaY h`*aA [There is to this side-burden an inclining, or a leaning, by reason of an excess of weight over this: or,] a heaviness [exceeding that of this], by reason of which it inclines, or leans. (TA.) [And accord. to the TK, you say of the load of a camel, raAma, meaning It inclined, or leaned.] ― -b4- And The becoming drawn together, of the mouth of a wound, in order to heal; as also rayamaAnN. (K.) [Both are said in the TK to be inf. ns. of raAma, aor. as above, said of a wound, meaning Its mouth became drawn together, in order to heal.] -A2- riyma bihi i. q. quTiEa bihi [He was
or became, disabled from prosecuting, or unable to prosecute, his journey]. (S, K.) A rájiz says,
wariyma biAls~aAEiY Al~a*iY kaAna maEiY
[And the messenger that was with me became disabled from prosecuting his journey]. (S, TA.)

2 ry~m Ealayohi * , (T, K,) inf. n. taroyiymN, (TA,) He exceeded him; (T, K, TA;) i. e., one man, another; (T;) in journeying, or pace, and the like: from rayomN as signifying ziyaAdapN and faDolN [i. e. “ excess, ” &c.], or as signifying baraAHN [expl. above]. (TA.) ― -b2- ry~m biAlmakaAni, (ISk, S, M,) inf. n. as above, (ISk, S,) He (a man, ISk, S) remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (ISk, S. M.) And ray~amati Als~aHaAbapu faA^agoDanato The cloud remained without clearing away [and rained continually]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And ry~m, inf. n. as above, He journeyed all the day. (TA.)

rayomN *
Excess, redundance, or superiority; syn. faDolN, (ISk, T, S, M, K,) and ziyaAdapN, (S, K,) which is like faDolN. (TA.) One says, lih`*aA rayomN EalaY h`*aA This has excess, or superiority, (faDolN, ISk, T,) over this. (ISk, T, S. *) Alr~ayomu EalaYAlmazojuwri, a phrase used by El-'Ajjáj, means mano zujira faEalayohi AlfaDolu [which may be rendered He who is chidden, it is incumbent on him to exceed; or he who is chidden is exceeded]: (T, S:) such being always the case; for one is chidden only on account of an affair in which he has fallen short of doing what was requisite. (S.) ― -b2- A thing such as is termed EilaAwap [q. v.] between the two side-loads of a camel. (IAar, T, K.) Hence the saying, Alr~ayomu A^avoqalu EalaY Ald~awaAb~i mina AlHimoli [The additional burden that is put between the two side-loads is more onerous to the beasts than the (usual) load]. (TK) after the flesh of the slaughtered camel has been distributed (T, S) in the game called Almayosir, (T,) and which is given to the slaughterer: (M, K:) accord. to Lh, the camel for slaughter is brought, and its owner slaughters it, then puts it upon something laid upon the ground to preserve it from pollution, having divided it into ten portion, namely, the two haunches, and the two thighs, and the rump, and the withers, and the breast, and [the part of the back called] the maloHaA=' [q. v.], and the two shoulders together with the two arms; then he betakes himself to the TafaATif [or soft parts, such as the flanks, or the soft parts of the belly], and the vertebræ of the neck, and distributes them upon those portions equally; and if there remain a bone, or a small piece of flesh, that is the rayom: then the slaughterer waits with it for him who desires it, and he whose arrow wins, his it is; otherwise, it is for the slaughterer. (M, TA.) ― -b3- The last portion of the day-time, extending to the confusedness (AixotilaAT, for which AixotilaAf is erroneously put in the copies of the K, TA) of the darkness. (M, K, TA.) A long [indefinite period such as is termed] saAEap: (S, K:) so in the saying, qado baqiYa rayomN mina Aln~ahaAri [A long period of the day-time had remained; or, emphatically, remains]. (S.) And nahaArN rayomN means A long day or day-time: so in the saying, Ealayoka nahaArN rayomN [app. meaning A long day is appointed thee for the performance of a work or task]. (AZ, T.) -A2- Also i. q. darajapN [as meaning A series of stairs:] (IAar, Jm, T, S, M, K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (S.) Aboo-'Amr Ibn-'Alà says, as related by As, I was in El-Yemen, and I came to the house of a man, inquiring for him, and a man of the house said to me, Ausomuko fiY Alr~ayomi, meaning AiSoEadi Ald~arajapi [Ascend thou the stairs]. (JM, cited in the PS.) ― -b2- And i. q. duk~aAnN [meaning A kind of wide bench, of stone or brick; and also a shop]: (M, TA:) likewise of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.) ― -b3- And Small mountains. (IAar, T, K.) ― -b4- And A grave: (IAar, T, S, M, K:) or the middle thereof. (M, K.) -A3- See also what next follows.

riymN * , (Jm, T, PS,) with kesr, (Jm, PS,) [accord. to the K, erroneously, ↓ rayomN, The antilope leucoryx;] a white antelope; (Jm, PS;) an antelope (ZaboYN) that is purely white: (IAar, T, K:) written with and without ': [see riy^omN, in art. rA^m:] pl. A^aroA=mN (Jm, PS) [and A=raAmN].

maroyamN * A woman who loves the discourse of men, but does not act vitiously or immorally, or commit adultery or fornication. (K.) Also a [female] proper name. (K.) It is said by AA to be of the measure mafoEalN from raAma, aor. yariymu: (S, Sgh, Msb, TA:) but some say that, as a proper name, it is arabicized, from maAriyap. (TA.)

1 raAna * , [aor. yariynu,] inf. n. rayonN, [in its primary acceptation, app. signifies It was, or became, rusty, or covered with rust. And hence,] It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was, or became, dirty, or filthy; syn. taTab~aEa. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] rAnt nafosahu, (S, M, K, *) aor. tariynu, inf. n. as above, (S,) His soul [or stomach] became heavy; or heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. gavato, (S, M, K,) and xabuvato. (S, K.) ― -b3- And rAn Ealayohi, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb,) It (anything) covered it; namely, a thing: (M:) or it (anything) overcame him; (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, * Mgh, Msb, K;) as also rAn bihi; (A'Obeyd, T, S, Mgh, K;) and raAnahu. (A'Obeyd, S, Mgh, K.) [And raAna with yaruwnu for its aor. signifies the same; as will be seen from a verse cited below.] You say of a sin, misdeed, or transgression, (*anob,) rAn EalaY qalobihi, (Zj, T, S, Mgh, K,) aor. as above, (Zj, T, S,) inf. n. rayonN (Zj, T, S, M, K) and ruyuwnN, (S, M, K,) It covered his heart: (Zj, T, M:) or it overcame his heart. (S, Mgh, K.) raAna EalaY quluwbihimo maA kaAnuwA yakosibwuna, in the Kur [lxxxiii. 14], means [What they used to do] hath become like rust upon the clearness of their hearts, so as to make the knowledge of good from evil to be obscured to them: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or hath covered their hearts: (Zj, T:) or hath overcome their hearts: [or hath spread a blackness upon their hearts; for,] accord. to El-Hasan, it means that sin has followed upon sin so that the heart has become black: (S:) and accord. to Aboo-Mo'adh the Grammarian, and a saying of the Prophet, Alr~ayonu means the heart's becoming black in consequence of sins. (T.) You say also, riyna EalY qalobihi His heart became covered [&c.]. (M.) And riyna bihi He was overcome: (T, Mgh:) or his property was beset by debt: (T:) or he fell into grief, by reason of debt: (M:) or he fell into that from which he could not escape, (AZ, T, S, Mgh, K,) and with which he had not power to cope: (AZ, T, S:) or i. q. AunoquTiEa bihi [i. e. he became disabled from prosecuting his journey, his means having failed him, or his beast breaking down with him or perishing]; (T, S, M;) so says El-Kanánee El-Aarábee: (T, S:) and he died. (M.) And raAnato bihi Alxamoru, (T,) or rAnt Ealayohi Alxamoru, (S, M, [in one copy of the S AlHum~aY,]) The wine overcame him; (S, M;) and overwhelmed him: (M:) or overcame his heart and his reason: (T:) and in like manner one says of drowsiness, and of anxiety; by way of comparison. (M.) And rAn Aln~uEaAsu fiY AlEayoni Drowsiness overcame the eye: (S, TA: *) or infected, or pervaded, the eye. (Msb.) Et-Tirimmáh says,
maxaAfapa A^ano yaruwna Aln~awomu fiyhimo
bisukori sinaAtihimo kul~a Alr~uyuwni
[In fear that sleep might overcome them, by reason of the intoxication of their sensations of drowsiness, with every degree of overcoming]. (TA. [This, together with a signification assigned to maruwna in art. rwn in the K, shows that raAna signifying “ he, or it, overcame, ” &c., has yaruwna as well as yariynu for its aor.]) And you say also, rAn Ealayohi Almawotu, and rAn bihi, Death took him away. (M.)

4 ArAnwA *
Their cattle perished, or died: (ElUmawee, T, S, M, K:) and (so in the T, but in the M “ or ”) their cattle became lean, or emaciated. (El-Umawee, T, M.) This also, says A'Obeyd, is from an event that has happened to them and overcome them, and which they have not been able to bear. (T.)

raAnN * : see the next paragraph. -A2- Also [A kind of legging;] a thing like a xuf~ [or boot], but longer, and without a foot: (K:) described by the author of the Msb, in his handwriting upon the margin, as a piece of cloth made like the xuf~, stuffed with cotton, worn beneath it on account of the cold: not a genuine Arabic word: (MF:) it is a Persian word, arabicized. (TA.)

rayonN * , originally an inf. n.: (Msb:) Rust that overspreads the sword and the mirror; (M;) rust that overspreads a polished thing: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or much dirtiness from rust: or simply dirt, filth, soil, or pollution: syn. TabaEN and *anasN: (S, K: [in a copy of the S, and in the CK, AlT~aboEu is erroneously put for AlT~abaEu:]) or a cover, or covering. (Msb.) [And hence,] The like of rust, covering the heart: (Zj, T:) black-
ness of the heart: pl. riyaAnN. (T.) And ↓ raAnN signifies the same as rayonN. (TA.)

rayonapN *
i. q. xamorapN [i. e. Wine, or some wine, or a kind of wine]: pl. rayonaAtN: (IAar, Th, T, K:) so called because it overcomes the reason. (TA.)

rajulN mariynN Ealayohi *
A man beset, or encompassed. (TA.)
muriynuwna * Persons whose cattle have perished, or died: (El-Umawee, T, S, K:) and whose cattle have become lean, or emaciated. (El-Umawee, T.)

1 raAha * , aor. yariyhu, (K,) inf. n. rayohN, said of the saraAb [or mirage], (TA,) It came and went; (K, TA;) [or went to and fro; or appeared to do so;] or ran upon the surface of the earth: (TA:) and ↓ try~h, likewise said of the srAb, [signifies the same,] i. q. taray~aEa: (S, K, TA:) or try~h signifies it was made to run hither and thither, in no uniform manner: (IAar, TA:) or it glistened uninterruptedly. (TA in art. rh.) ― -b2- And He, or it, returned; like raAEa, aor. yariyEu. (TA in art. ryE.)
2 ruy~aha * , said of the saraAb [or mirage]; and ray~ahatohu AlhaAjirapu: see muray~ahN, below.
5 taray~aha see 1.

muray~ahN * , (S, K,) as an epithet applied to the saraAb [or mirage], (TA,) i. q. muray~aEN, (S, K, TA,) [meaning] kaA^an~ahu ruy~iha A^awo ray~ahatohu AlhiAjirapu [As though it were made to come and go, or go to and fro, or run upon the surface of the earth; or as though the vehement midday-heat made it to come and go, &c.]. (TA.)
